MY mother spent the summer of 1971 testing every variation on Bohemians, pastrylike cookies that she made with walnuts or pecans or no nuts at all. My twin brother, Bill, and I were the lucky tasters. We decided which batches were the lightest, chewiest, best. It was as if we had formed a small, secret club that met from June to September whenever my father was at work. Ma was trying to win the grand prize ($25,000 at the time) in the Pillsbury Bake-Off. And we believed she would. On summer weekdays, to free up time for baking, she established a solid routine. Bill and I watched an ''I Love Lucy'' rerun, ate breakfast and went outside, the screen door locked behind us. We had the run of a patio, an above-ground swimming pool and a clubhouse fashioned from an old pup tent. We could return for a bathroom break, if absolutely necessary, but my mother didn't discourage going in the bushes. We ate our lunch al fresco and Ma always served homemade lemonade.

A credit with an article on Feb. 25 about Francesca von Habsburg, the Austrian society and art figure, omitted the name of one of the designers of the clothes she was wearing. While the boots were indeed by Rick Owens, the dress was by Jean Paul Gaultier.
There are blogs out there for every political persuasion. The question is, who's reading them?
My Tuesday column looks at what we can do about Darfur -- and at your suggestions for the next steps we should take. Please offer your comments below, by hitting the comment tab.
It's not quite a link-up between the Montagues and the Capulets, but in this super-heated political environment it comes close.
Representative Ron Paul, a nine-term Republican from Texas, formally announced his presidential candidacy today.
Thousands mourned 10 victims of a Bronx house fire, members of an extended family of immigrants from Mali.

In my column on laughter, I mention that female speakers are more likely to laugh than male speakers are. That's one aspect of a large gender gap that Robert Provine, a neuroscientist at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, discovered when he left the lab and went out into the wild -- well, sidewalks and shopping malls -- to observe "laugh episodes."

Here we are in Fort Myers for the spring revival of baseball's best rivalry, the Yankees and the Red Sox. The Yanks scored three in the first off Tim Wakefield, with Carl Pavano now taking the mound for the Yankees. (Really, he is.)

A new poll by The Times and CBS News finds that Republicans are disillusioned with their party's direction, dissatisfied with the current field of 2008 candidates and believe that contenders who oppose the Bush administration's Iraq war policies will have an advantage in the election.
Republicans and Al Sharpton, in league against Eliot Spitzer, a libertarian site says. [Reason's Hit and Run]
CNN has just released a nationwide poll that shows Rudolph Giuliani leading Senator John McCain among registered Republicans.
Middle school is a netherworld between elementary school and high school, and teachers can be the key.
I was in Spokane yesterday to work on a story about the Gonzaga basketball team and I am convinced that the Bulldogs are going to win at least one game in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton lashed out at Halliburton today for its announcement that it would open a corporate headquarters in Dubai and move its chief executive officer there. The action has raised a lot of questions, and Senator Clinton was quick to link the company to its multi-billion defense and war contracts as well as its ties to Vice President Dick Cheney.

The most famous surviving words from the ancient Greek Battle of Thermopylae have been "molon labe," the defiant taunt by 300 Spartans to their numerically superior Persian adversaries. Translated, it means roughly "Come and take them," referring to their weapons. This past weekend, it could also have referred to seats at movie theaters, as viewers swarmed cinemas to help Warner Brothers' "300" shatter box-office records.

A city health inspector has shut down The Coffee Shop, the well-known Union Square bistro, for what the owner says are picayune violations. It appears to be part of a general crackdown after the recent unpleasantness at a KFC/Taco Bell in Greenwich Village.

British pharmacy chain Alliance Boots rejected a 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) buyout offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its own executive deputy chairman, saying the bid tabled only a few hours before was too low. Shares in Alliance Boots, formed last year from the merger of retailer Boots and drugs wholesaler Alliance Unichem, were up 7 percent at 997 pence.
Should the proposed merger of satellite radio operators XM and Sirius come to pass, who should get the credit? According to the New Yorker's James Surowiecki, that would be Milton Friedman.

Much is being made of venture capitalist John Doerr breaking down into tears as he talked about global warming on Thursday during the TED conference in Monterey, Calif. But what may be more disturbing is what he actually said: "I'm scared. I don't think we're going to make it."

Up here on the Space Coast today, where I had a chance to chat for a few minutes this morning with Nationals Manager Manny Acta, the Mets' former third-base coach. He asked why I didn't come to Viera when the Mets played here Saturday."Are you underestimating my Nationals?" Acta asked. "Don't go underestimating my Nationals."I told him I wasn't (although I don't know that I ever estimated them in the first place.)

As a video circulated around the Internet featuring a 1989 speech in which Rudolph W. Giuiani promoted public financing for abortions, the former New York Mayor was in Washington today touting his ties to some prominent conservatives.

It is shaping up to be a busy month for Michael Eisner, the former head of Disney. Less than a week after announcing it would help take baseball-card maker Topps private, Mr. Eisner's investment firm, Tornante, said it was launching Vuguru, an independent studio to produce and distribute original programming on the Web. Mr. Eisner has shown an interest in Web-based video with his previous investment in Veoh Networks, a video-sharing site that competes with the much more widely visited YouTube.

The battle for Caremark Rx seemed all but over Monday after Express Scripts said that under current conditions it could not raise its $26.3 billion offer for the rival drug benefits manager. Many analysts concluded that CVS's $26 billion bid would win support of Caremark's shareholders, with Wachovia analyst Matt Perry declaring: "If the two offers are within approximately 5 percent of each other, Caremark shareholders are likely to approve the CVS offer."
In the upcoming presidential campaign, there will be no more need for those cumbersome old spoken gotchas. The ones that never play very well at the debates:
Links to real estate news:

Shareholders of Calpine, the bankrupt energy giant, are lining up some high-powered advisers as they try to influence the company's Chapter 11 case. Shareholders are typically relegated to the sidelines in bankruptcy, under the theory that there will be nothing left for them after creditors get paid. But members of Calpine's official committee of equity holders think there will be something left in the till -- and so, apparently, does their financial adviser, Perella Weinberg Partners.

This afternoon, a City Council committee approved a ban on the use of metal bats in high school baseball games, deeming them unsafe. If the ban passes the full Council by a large majority on Wednesday, as seems likely, the city could become the first jurisdiction in the United States to prohibit the use of the bats.

Wachovia Securities, Wachovia's investment banking arm, said Monday that it hired two managing directors to cover the media and communications industries. William Bundy, who had been at J.P. Morgan Chase, will work in Wachovia's media and communications investment banking group, and John Schwarz, previously of Lazard, will be in the mergers and acquisitions group.

Six weeks ago I asked readers to send in their suggestions for ending the conflict in Darfur. There were about 300 responses, and here's a sampling. Please add your comments at the bottom to identify which you agree with or think are awful.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer lit into Senate Republicans at a press conference this afternoon, calling their proposed budget "profligate and their behavior pandering."

The Bracket is delighted to have another entry from our favorite guest blogger and Rhodes Scholarship finalist, Penn forward Stephen Danley. His first post on The Bracket caused quite a stir over on the Penn campus, as evidenced by some of the comments left on the blog. Danley recognized the controversy as a good thing, which shows he's got good journalist instincts.

Since leaving Miramax to cofound The Weinstein Company, Harvey Weinstein has invested in an assortment of niche media plays, some of which are firmly outside the movie industry in which he made his name. His firm, which describes itself as a "multimedia company," bought cable arts channel Ovation and invested in aSmallWorld.net, an invitation-only social-networking Web site for adults. The movie mogul's latest potential target -- a fashion company -- is even farther afield.
In Cairo, where citizens often fix water and electricity lines on their own, many people are resigned not to expect anything from politics or government.
David Pogue takes another look at the Blackberry Pearl.
Robin Toner reports on a New York Times/CBS News Poll showing support for guaranteeing health insurance for every American.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Black Snake Moan,' starring Christina Ricci and Samuel Jackson.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Black Snake Moan,' starring Christina Ricci and Samuel Jackson.

A senior Taliban commander told an Afghan news agency on Saturday that the Italian reporter Daniele Mastrogiacomo would be killed at the end of this week, unless Italy agreed to withdraw its 1,900 troops from the NATO force in Afghanistan before then. As Reuters reports:
Very strange site here at Legends Field right now: the simulated game.
An ad for Avon.
An ad for Avon.

When John Farrell, the pitching coach for the Boston Red Sox, said that he had learned about 20 to 25 Japanese phrases to better communicate with pitchers Daisuke Matsuzaka and Hideki Ojakima, he made me think: Shouldn't I at least know a few Japanese phrases? So I enlisted the help of Roger Kahlon, Hideki Matsui's interpreter, to teach me how to say, "How does your arm feel?" in Japanese. Kahlon gave me the translation and it took me about three tries before he approved my pronunciation. But, because of Kahlon's assistance, I now had a question to ask - and probably shock - any Japanese pitcher. While waiting to interview Sammy Sosa of the Texas Rangers on Sunday, I spotted Akinori Otsuka, a Japanese reliever. Finally, I had the chance to test my Japanese. I dug through my notebook, found the translation, repeated it to myself and then approached Otsuka. As soon as Otsuka heard the words, he smiled and said in English, "My arm feels good." He seemed pleased or amused or both that I had asked him a question in Japanese. I told Otsuka the background to my story and he nodded. We talked for a few more minutes and one thing was obvious: Otsuka's English was much better than my Japanese.
Although no one seems certain that the date is correct, The Associated Press reported on Sunday that people are marking it anyway:

The latest enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to "intruded" brokerage accounts has a nice switch: In addition to having the defrauded investors buy shares of thinly traded companies you never heard of, this group, of three traders from India, also made good money trading in worthless options of a company almost everyone knows: Google.

Morgan Stanley shows no sign of a waning interest in hedge funds. The investment bank said Monday that it has bought a minority stake in Abax Global Capital, a startup cofounded by Citadel Investment Group veterans that will focus on Asian investments. Morgan Stanley did not disclose the size of the stake or the value of the deal.

They seem to have automated everything else, so why not insider trading? BusinessWeek reported Monday that the Securities and Exchange Commission, the nation's top markets regulator, is planning to take a close look at automated trading plans, which are often set up for executives as a way to buy and sell stock of their own companies. The S.E.C. is said to be looking for evidence that these automated programs are being used (or abused) to facilitate stock sales based on inside information -- which is just what they are supposed to prevent.

Budget negotiations kick into high gear this week as the Senate and Assembly begin their joint public negotiations. The chambers introduced their budget bills on Friday and over the weekend.The Assembly's budget, which came in late Friday, would increase the governor's $120.6 billion proposal to nearly $121.3 billion, in large measure because of restoring several hundred million dollars worth of health care cuts by the governor.

Like the editorial page of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal editorial page thinks Alberto Gonzales has made a mess of things at the Department of Justice. The Journal's reasoning, however, is a bit different: "The incompetence at Justice is getting to be expensive for Presidential power." The lead editorial in The New York Times on Sunday chastised Gonzales for "being consigliere to Mr. Bush's imperial presidency."

Acknowledging its weakened position, Express Scripts said Monday that it woud not raise its offer for rival Caremark Rx without the chance to conduct due diligence, which Caremark has refused to allow. The announcement appears to put CVS in a position to win the bitter takeover feud for Caremark, a bitter fight that has played out in public and in the courts since December. In a press release, Express Scripts criticized Caremark's merger process as "flawed" and continued to urge Caremark's shareholders to vote against the merger with CVS, the nation's largest drugstore chain.

There was nothing top secret about this deal: Confirming several previous reports, Ford Motor said Monday that it would sell its Aston Martin, known as the sports car of choice for James Bond, to a group including racing mogul David Richards and two Kuwaiti investment firms. The transaction values Aston Martin at $925 million, but Ford will keep a stake in the unit vauled at $77 million, the company said.

In the Empire Zone column this morning, acting insurance superintendent Eric Dinallo says the Spitzer administration is seeking to reclaim prior approval before increases of health insurance rates. Right now, insurers can raise rates on their own, and the Insurance Department is limited in what it can do retroactively. Hence, double digit increases have become a common practice.
Armed police officers descended on an area of rural Hunan on Monday to restore order after thousands clashed with police in a protest over rising transportation costs.
I have a confession to make: I always knew we needed an architect. (To our readers who suggested that this was the case, thanks. You were right.)
Both the House and Senate head toward clashes over Iraq policy this week though the main events loom in the future.

With state after state moving toward an earlier primary schedule, as they covet the early-bird prominence of Iowa and New Hampshire (as well as South Carolina and Nevada), Adam Nagourney examines how a squished primary season would affect the presidential political cycle:

Like many Manhattan chefs, Shea Gallante has cycled through more than a few popular and celebrated restaurants. He put in time at Coco Pazzo Teatro, at Felidia and at Bouley, where he rose to the rank of chef de cuisine and lapped up knowledge and ideas from David Bouley. In 2004, he got a kitchen of his own, snagging the top job at Cru, in Greenwich Village, which opened that year. Reviews of his work at Cru have been hugely admiring. Mr. Gallante is 33.

UnitedHealth Group, the health-insurance giant, said on Monday it would acquire Sierra Health Services for $2.6 billion, or $43.50 in cash per share, to help it expand in the fast-growing Southwest. Sierra provides health benefits and services to 310,000 members in Nevada and 320,000 customers throughout the United States.

There's still some interesting fallout from the dissolution between Nevada Democrats and Fox News, after senior party officials decided to cancel an August debate amid an uproar among liberal bloggers and activists over the choice of networks.
Hundreds of people packed into the Islamic Cultural Center to say goodbye to the 10 victims.

Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's largest consumer electronics maker, said Friday it plans to sell its 16.2 percent stake in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing over the next few years. The stake is valued at around $8.5 billion. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing is the world's biggest contract chip maker by revenue.

Dollar General, a discount retailer with more than 8,000 stores in the United States, said Monday it agreed to be acquired by private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for $7.3 billion, including about $380 million in assumed debt. Kohlberg Kravis will pay $22 in cash for each Dollar General share, or about 31 percent more than the shares' closing price on Friday, Dollar General said. The company's board has unanimously approved the transaction and is urging shareholders to vote in favor of it.

Donald Trump's Trump Entertainment Resorts has hired Merrill Lynch to help the company evaluate its options, which might include selling a single casino or even the entire company, according to The New Jersey Star-Ledger. Other possibilities for the Atlantic City casino operator include an equity offering to raise cash or even taking the company private, the report said.

You would think that Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who is Jewish, would be exempt from reminders about attending church on Sunday, but that is what happened - indirectly - during a visit to Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem on Sunday morning.

Akzo Nobel said Monday it would sell its pharmaceuticals unit Organon BioSciences to Schering-Plough for 11 billion euros ($14.5 billion), dropping its previously announced plans to hold an initial public offering for the business. The deal bulks up United States-based Schering-Plough, whose chief executive has made no secret of his desire to find acquisitions.

A public relations company hired who says it was hired to buff up the sullied reputation of Maurice "Hank" Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, is suing Mr. Greenberg's company, C.V. Starr, for allegedly refusing to pay a $2 million bill.

The upcoming criminal fraud trial in Chicago of Conrad M. Black, the former head of Hollinger International who faces more than 90 years in jail if convicted, has all the makings of good theater. First there is Mr. Black himself, a larger-than-life figure whose baroque vocabulary and towering demeanor can seem straight out of Dickens. Unlike most defendants in corporate malfeasance trials facing the rest of their years behind bars, Mr. Black has gone very public - giving interviews and speeches, writing articles chastising his accusers and vowing not only exoneration but a comeback.

Analysts are betting that Goldman Sachs, which has reported record earnings and revenue for the past three years, may see a slow-down in the first quarter. The investment bank, whose stock has surged 36 percent in the last 12 months, far outpacing its rivals, is expected to post solid, if not stellar results, when it announces its results this week.

A federal judge gave final approval Friday to a $72.5 million settlement between Arthur Andersen and investors who sued the accounting firm over its role in the 2001 collapse of Enron. U.S. District Judge Melinda Harmon signed the final order at a brief hearing held in Houston, effectively ending the now defunct accounting firm's involvement in the $40 billion class-action lawsuit.

As the markets dropped sharply last week, sending volume soaring and backing up trades handled by the New York Stock Exchange, at least one stock market player was resting easy. Bats Trading, an upstart electronic trading system based in Kansas City, Mo., said it handled the volatility with none of the glitches that others did.
New York will be the host of the inaugural National Asian American Theater Festival, scheduled to run June 11-24 at several locations in the city.

Arguing that the competitiveness of the United States' capital markets is "under strain," a committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce on Monday proposed a series of steps to ease the regulatory burdens for U.S. companies. The report, which noted a "substantial decrease" in the number of initial public offerings in the U.S., called for the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 to be folded into the 1934 law that created the Securities and Exchange Commission and urged companies to stop giving quarterly earnings guidance.

CVC Capital, a European private equity firm with $24 billion in assets under management, said Monday that it hired Robert L. Berner III as a partner to help expand its business in the United States. Mr. Berner, formerly a managing director at Ripplewood Holdings, will be a partner in CVC's recently opened New York office, CVC said.

Ford Motor is expected to sell Aston Martin, maker of the upscale British sports cars favored by James Bond, to a group of investors that includes the racing mogul David Richards and a pair of Kuwaiti companies in a deal that will be announced Monday, according to The New York Times. The Times said that Ford, which put Aston Martin up for sale last August, will retain a 15 percent stake in the marque.

Goldman Sachs is relocating investment banker John Waldron from New York to London, where he will be co-head of the group that advises private equity firms. Reuters said the move is "another signal of the sector's growing significance in Europe."

Safestore, Britain's largest self-storage operator, has raised more than 150 million pounds ($291 million) for its private-equity owners in an initial public offering that comes a year after debt refinancing gave shareholders a 100 million pounds payout. The company said on Friday that it raised 209 million pounds from floating almost half of the firm on the London market, putting a value on the business of 449 million pounds.
Most voters have no opinion of Senator Chuck Hagel, who is expected to announce today if he plans to seek the Republican nomination for President.

A 76-year-old Montreal lawyer with a penchant for preserving Scottish culture has emerged as an alleged culprit in the collapse of Canadian hedge-fund Portus Alternative Asset Management. KPMG, the court-appointed receiver overseeing Portus, has filed a lawsuit against the lawyer, Anthony Malcolm, alleging that he set up a series of offshore accounts that Portus co-founder Boaz Manor used to siphon off $17.6 million of client money.

Strategic Hotels & Resorts, a chain of luxury accommodations, may be the latest real estate investment trust to be the target of a buyout bid. Those who are reportedly mulling a move on the Chicago-based REIT include the Blackstone Group, the Carlyle Group and Walton Street Capital.

Warren E. Buffett, dubbed the Oracle of Omaha for his savvy investments in publicly-traded companies, may be facing some competition from buyout shops. BusinessWeek notes that private equity firms, with their coffers bulging with unprecedented amounts of cash, are taking minority stakes in public companies. And, the magazine says, their involvement is causing the halo effect usually reserved for the likes of Mr. Buffett, signaling that there may be a new player to mimic in the market.

China will create an agency to invest its immense reserves of foreign currency, now totaling more than $1 trillion, the country's finance minister announced on Friday. The minister, Jin Renqing, offered no specifics about how much of China's currency reserves would be under the agency's control. But whatever the precise figure, analysts say that the agency is certain to begin life as one of the world's biggest investment funds.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Friday that it was teaming up with the Italian billionaire Stefano Pessina to make a takeover bid for Alliance Boots, Britain's largest drugstore chain. The move comes amid a flurry of buyout interest in European retailers. K.K.R., based in New York, and Mr. Pessina, who is the deputy chairman of Alliance Boots and its largest shareholder, made a friendly approach worth 1,000 pence in cash for each Alliance share, or about 9.7 billion pounds ($19 billion).

Russian prosecutors and Interior Ministry officers searched the Moscow office of the auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers Friday in connection with its work with Yukos, the bankrupt oil company, and with PricewaterhouseCoopers's own tax filings. Russian officials have compared the Yukos affair to the Enron scandal in the United States, with ominous implications for the firm.

Amid the increasingly heated debate over executive pay, The New York Times' Gretchen Morgenson takes a look at how illuminating the new details that the Securities and Exchange Commission requires in companies' pay filings really are. Calling the filings an exercise in exhaustion, Ms. Morgenson suggests that the additional data now required by the S.E.C. -- with a view to helping shareholders better understand the details of executive compensation -- has produced opaque results.

Brocade Communications Systems' former human resources director, accused of conspiring with the company's former chief executive to manipulate stock option grants, asked a judge for a separate trial. Stephanie Jensen, charged in August with conspiracy, fraud and false securities filing, seeks to sever her case from that of Brocade's former C.E.O., Greg Reyes, so he can provide exculpatory testimony at her trial, according to a filing in San Francisco federal court Friday.

Shareholders of Hutchison Telecommunications International have approved the $11.1 billion sale of its Indian unit to Vodafone Group, a transaction that will finance a special dividend and expansion in Southeast Asia. Stockholders representing a majority of Hutchison Telecom's shares approved the sale at an extraordinary general meeting in Hong Kong, Tim Pennington, chief financial officer of Hutchison, said Friday. The plan got "overwhelming support," he said.

Adaptive Planning, a provider of collaborative business performance management (BPM) software, announced Friday that it had completed a $7.5 million round of financing. Cardinal Venture Capital led the round, which also included participation from previous investors ONSET Ventures and Monitor Ventures.

And then there were four. Citigroup's $10.8 billion takeover offer for Nikko Cordial, a Japanese brokerage firm, has been rejected by yet another shareholder, bringing the total number of those opposed to the much-ballyhooed deal to four.

Get ready: The chill that private equity funds have been feeling in Europe may be about to cross the pond. Lawmakers in the United States are considering taxing the rich fees that private equity bigwigs earn as income, rather than the capital gains that they are currently considered to be. Such a move would take a big chunk out of the 20 percent performance fees that private equity firms charge and will no doubt be fought tooth and nail by the industry.
“The Riches” is so compelling it deserves to be a hit, generating as much media attention and Internet chatter as “Deadwood,” “Nip/Tuck” or “24.”
China’s central bank said it would gradually promote reforms of the yuan’s exchange rate regime and improve its foreign exchange management this year.

The Bracket and The New York Times have hatched a way for you to experience all the excitement of the N.C.A.A. tournament online -- the upsets, the buzzer beaters, the thrill of picking that sleeper Final Four team none of your friends picked.
MIDWEST
With many adults having trouble sleeping at night, orders for separate bedrooms, or even his-and-her wings, are gaining popularity.

An article on Saturday about the troubled state of many of Britain’s youth reversed the rankings for Britain and the United States in a Unicef study that measured children’s well-being in 21 industrialized countries. It was Britain that scored the lowest; the United States was the second-lowest.
Corrections: For the Record

A sports article in some copies on Friday, about the hockey game in which Chris Simon of the Islanders struck the Rangers’ Ryan Hollweg in the chin with his stick, rendered incorrectly a postgame quotation from Simon. He said, “I’ve always been known as a team guy, and I feel real bad about letting the team down.” He did not say, “I’ve always been known as a clean guy,” nor did he say, “I just feel bad for letting my team down.” A version of the quotation printed in larger type above the article and pictures repeated the errors.

An article on Saturday about fund-raising efforts in New York by Senator Barack Obama misspelled the surname of one of President John F. Kennedy’s closest advisers, who introduced Mr. Obama at a fund-raiser. He is Theodore C. Sorensen, not Sorenson. The error also appeared in an article in The Arts on Feb. 22 about books written by candidates, including “Profiles in Courage,” which then-Senator Kennedy wrote with guidance from Mr. Sorensen. (The Times has misspelled Mr. Sorensen’s surname more than 135 times in headlines and articles during the 50-plus years he has been a Democratic adviser and well-known author.).

An article on Thursday about a court ruling terminating a lease on the site of the planned Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn misstated the composition of a group that filed another case challenging the state’s right to condemn their properties under eminent domain law. The 13 plaintiffs in that suit include owners and tenants, not just owners. The article also misstated the reaction of Forest City Ratner, the developer of Atlantic Yards, to the ruling on the lease. Forest City said in a statement that it did not believe the ruling would have an impact on the project; it did not decline to comment.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about a report by the Justice Department’s inspector general critical of the F.B.I.’s use of administrative subpoenas misspelled the surname of the Justice Department’s spokesman, who defended the removal of eight United States attorneys, another problem for the department. He is Brian Roehrkasse, not Roehrkass.

A picture caption with an article on Saturday about violence in Iraq misstated the sequence of events surrounding a military operation south of Baghdad on Friday involving soldiers from the First Battalion, 23rd Infantry Regiment. The soldiers were shown detaining Iraqi men at the start of the military action. It was not until later that the soldiers took fire from the area.

A Political Memo article on Thursday about the challenges Rudolph W. Giuliani faces in running for president as a former New York City mayor referred incorrectly to the presidency of Theodore Roosevelt, also a New York City mayor. He served more than 100 years ago, from 1901 to 1909; his presidency was not “almost 100 years ago.” And although he was indeed the last president born in New York City, he was not the last “born-and-bred New Yorker” to make it to the White House. His distant relative, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was born and raised in Hyde Park, N.Y.

An article on Feb. 27 about a Discovery Channel documentary that said a crypt in Jerusalem contained the bones of Jesus of Nazareth referred imprecisely to the Aramaic language. While Aramaic and Hebrew are closely related and Hebrew is written using the Aramaic script, they are distinct languages; Aramaic is not an ancient dialect of Hebrew.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on March 4 about the reflections of Mets’ left fielder Moises Alou on the shooting deaths of two relatives in Brooklyn in 1995 omitted a credit. Michael S. Schmidt interviewed Brooklyn authorities and neighbors for the article, which was written from Port St. Lucie, Fla., site of the Mets’ spring training.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the first solar observatory in the Americas misstated the title of Ivan Ghezzi, a doctoral student at Yale University who helped investigate the site, in Peru. Mr. Ghezzi is the archaeological director — not the overall director — of the National Institute of Culture, in Peru. (Cecilia Bákula Budge is the director.).

An article on Friday about a lawsuit filed in Massachusetts by advocates for inmates and the mentally ill misstated the number of prison suicides in 2005 in California, which has been ordered to spend $600 million to improve mental health services in prisons. There were 36, not 44.
The boxes bore nine children and one adult who perished in an unforgiving fire in their Bronx home.

The medical examiner concluded yesterday that a woman who was found dead in her home on Saturday night had been strangled. Police officers responded to a report of an unconscious woman at 125-60 Sutphin Boulevard, near Rockaway Boulevard, about 6:35 p.m. on Saturday and found the woman, Raychelle Shelby, 48, who was pronounced dead by emergency medical workers, the authorities said. Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner, said yesterday that an autopsy showed Ms. Shelby had died of ligature strangulation.

The city’s Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday warned debt collectors that they must be licensed if they wish to collect from New York City residents. In the past two months, the department has secured agreements and fines totaling more than $65,000 from six unlicensed collection agencies, while it continues to investigate several others. Jonathan B. Mintz, the commissioner of consumer affairs, said that abusive collection tactics “can significantly harm a consumer’s credit history and impact the financial resources of those who need it most.”.

A 47-year-old man was struck and killed by a black Lincoln Town Car that fled the scene shortly before 2 a.m. yesterday in Coney Island, the police said. The victim, whose name was not released, was crossing Surf Avenue when he was struck by the sedan, which was heading west, the police said. The driver then drove north on West 31st Street, the police said. The victim was taken to Lutheran Medical Center and pronounced dead a short time later. There were no suspects and no arrests yesterday.

A former worker at an assisted-living home was indicted on Friday on charges of stealing more than $300,000 from older and frail residents, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday. The worker, Frances Landrini, 36, of the Bronx, faces four counts of grand larceny and one count of scheming to defraud. She pleaded not guilty; her lawyer, Louis J. Reda, did not immediately respond to a request for comment last night. Ms. Landrini was a contract worker at the New Fordham Arms Home for Adults, a 35-bed home at 2915 Williamsbridge Road, where she helped residents pay their bills and conduct financial transactions. Over two years, Mr. Cuomo said, Ms. Landrini persuaded residents to sign blank checks, claiming that she would fill in the rest to pay the residents’ bills but instead cashed the checks or deposited them into her own bank account. Mr. Cuomo said Ms. Landrini fraudulently obtained and negotiated more than 150 checks from 12 residents.

The New York City Department of Education hopes to improve the high school graduation rate, but has not planned for enough seats to meet that goal, according to a report released yesterday by the city’s public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum. The report said the department has set a goal of having 70 percent of high school students graduate in four years, but its five-year, $13.1 billion school construction plan, which calls for the creation of 26,000 high school seats, assumes a graduation rate of only 46 percent. Andrew Jacob, a Department of Education spokesman, rejected the report’s findings. “The report is absurd,” he said in a statement. “Our construction plan is adjusted annually to reflect projected changes in the graduation rate and demographic trends. We will create seats for all our high school students in whatever numbers they are graduating — the more the better.”.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to release a series of health proposals today as part of an effort to increase emphasis on preventive health care. Among the proposals are new antismoking measures, expanded access to the vaccine that can prevent cervical cancer, a measure to eliminate trans fat products in state food contracts, and an effort to reduce the use of toxic chemicals in public buildings and schools. The governor has proposed about $200 million to support the programs in his 2007-8 budget proposal.

A City Council committee was expected to approve a bill today that would ban the use of nonwood bats in high school baseball games, according to Council officials. The measure, introduced by Councilmen James S. Oddo, Republican of Staten Island, and Lewis A. Fidler, Democrat of Brooklyn, is to be voted on by the full Council on Wednesday. The sponsors cited cases in which metal bats have been linked to serious injuries and, as evidence, research by the Nicholas Institute of Sports Medicine and Athletic Trauma. But at an Oct. 23 hearing, the city’s Department of Education opposed the proposal and the director of the National Center for Catastrophic Sports Injury Research said there was “no evidence that batted-ball injuries are a greater problem from aluminum bats as compared to wooden bats.” A second hearing was scheduled for this morning, before the committee vote.

DRUG WARS The battle for control of Caremark Rx, the prescription drug benefits manager, could be resolved Friday, when the company’s shareholders are scheduled to vote on a takeover offer by CVS, the big pharmacy chain. Express Scripts, another leading pharmacy benefits manager, has tried to counter the CVS bid and may try once again to break up the deal. But CVS, which has raised its bid to $26 billion, seems to hold the advantage.

A full year and a half ahead of the presidential election, the Fox News Channel has suddenly become an issue in the campaign, even as the network tries to cover that campaign. A Democratic candidates' debate sponsored by Fox News set for August from Reno, Nev., was abruptly canceled Friday night with a statement from the Nevada Democratic Party and Harry Reid, the majority leader in the Senate.

COHEN--Shirley on March 10, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Harry B., Jr. Loving mother of Jill and Robert. Services Monday, 10 am, at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Greenwich Hospital.
To the Editor: Re ''Federal-Local Clash in War Over Teaching Reading'' (news article, March 9):

Best Buy in Minneapolis has asked four agencies to take part in a review for advertising assignments with spending estimated at $200 million. The assignments include brand advertising, television commercials and media planning. The agencies are Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, part of MDC Partners, which creates campaigns for the Best Buy ''Geek Squad'' service; Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe; GSD&M in Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group, which has worked for a Best Buy rival, Wal-Mart; and the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom.

To the Editor: ''Casualties of the Budget Wars,'' by Paul D. Eaton (Op-Ed, March 6):
KAUFMAN LANG--Mildred. The family of Mildred Kaufman Lang sadly mourn her passing. She streaks through life like a comet in passionate pursuit to fill her canvas.

There are two ways of looking at how this year's seedings for the N.C.A.A. tournament were determined by the selection committee. It could be argued that the selection committee deserves a lot of credit. More than in many recent seasons, and considerably more than last year, the teams' seedings dovetailed with some of the more advanced statistical methods. The top seeds, for the most part, have the top offenses and defenses in Division I.

The attribution on Tuesday for the Quotation of the Day, taken from a front-page article about conditions at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, referred incorrectly in some copies to the acting secretary of the Army, who said, ''We have let some soldiers down.'' He goes by Pete Geren, not Peter. (His birth name is Preston.)

Amy Winehouse ''Back to Black'' (Republic) At first the songs on Amy Winehouse's second album, ''Back to Black,'' could almost be unknown soul oldies from the 1950s and 1960s. The drums, strings and horns have a vintage production style, and Ms. Winehouse's tart voice and sly, sultry phrasing sound largely unprocessed. Then the anachronisms kick in, from current slang and beats that hint at hip-hop to four-letter words and blunt references to sex and drugs. A 23-year-old English songwriter, Ms. Winehouse is decades too young for '60s nostalgia, but she has come up with a wonderfully time-twisted batch of songs.

An article on Thursday about a court ruling terminating a lease on the site of the planned Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn misstated the composition of a group that filed another case challenging the state's right to condemn their properties under eminent domain law. The 13 plaintiffs in that suit include owners and tenants, not just owners. The article also misstated the reaction of Forest City Ratner, the developer of Atlantic Yards, to the ruling on the lease. Forest City said in a statement that it did not believe the ruling would have an impact on the project; it did not decline to comment.

8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO -- Chris Rock (right) will be James Lipton's guest tonight. Expect Mr. Lipton's usual attempts to get the nitty gritty details of his guest's childhood and influences. The two should have plenty to chat about: ''Saturday Night Live,'' Mr. Rock's experience as the host of the Academy Awards, his sitcom ''Everybody Hates Chris'' and his work in films including ''New Jack City'' and his latest project, ''I Think I Love My Wife.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE -- Julia Louis-Dreyfus settles into her new 8:30 p.m. timeslot with back-to-back episodes. In ''Sleepless in Mar Vista'' at 8:00, she takes some sleeping pills, starts acting even more wacky than usual and later discovers that she made a few embarrassing phone calls while she was incoherent. That is followed at 8:30 by another new episode, ''Undercover Brother.'' Christine learns a big secret from Richard's brother Joe (Charles Esten), but is she likely to keep her mouth shut? 9 P.M. (Fox) 24 -- Another well-known actor joins the cast: Rick Schroder steps in as Mike Doyle, a new Counter Terrorism Unit agent who will head up Field Ops. He comes on board just in time to oversee a crucial mission. 9 P.M. (A&E) KINGS OF SOUTH BEACH -- (2007) A television movie based on the true story of Chris Troiano, a nightclub impresario who opens one of the most sizzling hotspots ever to hit the scene in Miami's South Beach and the troubles that follow. Jason Gedrick(above) is Troiano, and Donnie Wahlberg plays his best friend, Andy Burnett. With a screenplay by Nicholas Pileggi, who wrote ''Goodfellas'' and ''Casino,'' expect a whirlwind tale of models, mobsters, money and murder. 9 P.M. (ABC) SUPERNANNY -- In this season finale, ''Walker Family,'' our new millennium Mary Poppins, Jo, helps a couple who have three children, a live-in nephew and an in- home daycare business that interferes with child rearing. 9 P.M. (Discovery) FUTUREWEAPONS -- Viewers get a glimpse into the secretive, technologically advanced and rather creepy world of military weapons development. On this new episode, ''Smart Destroyers,'' the host (and ex-Navy SEAL) Richard (Mack) Machowicz introduces super-intelligent weapons including the Protector Unmanned Surface Vehicle, a waterborne weapons system that thinks for itself, and the Squad Mission Support System robotic vehicle. Don't mess with this guy. 10 P.M. (FX) THE RICHES -- Eddie Izzard and Minnie Driver star in this new series about a larcenous family of Gypsies that strikes it rich by assuming the identities of a couple they accidentally killed and taking up residence in a posh suburban development. 10 P.M. (NBC) THE BLACK DONNELLYS -- Tommy (Jonathan Tucker, right) is plagued with guilt when Kate(Molly Schaffer), the widow of the Irish mob kingpin Huey, asks him to be host of her murdered husband's wake. When Jimmy (Thomas Guiry) appears to pay his respects, Huey's brother Dokey (Peter Greene) suspects that Jimmy may be the killer. STEVEN MCELROY

DOYLE--Rita A. (nee: McNamara) of Rockville Centre, NY on March 10, 2007. Beloved wife of Robert E. Loving and devoted mother of Clare Verhey, Noni (Michael) Connor and Robert Doyle. Adored grandmother of Christopher. Reposing Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Avenue today and Tuesday 24, 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral Wednesday 10 am. Interment Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven, Valhalla, NY.

The Internet offers some nontraditional fund-raising and educational models. For Idealist.org, the goal is to inspire people to organize on a local level. The site offers how-to information about starting a group, like the one in Lagos, Nigeria, above, an online network and a resource directory. At the Hunger Site, the user clicks on a link to raise money for food from advertising sponsors, and Product RED promotes the power of consumer purchases to generate corporate contributions to buy AIDS medicine in Africa. SHELLY FREIERMAN

RICHARD--Jane S., 87, of Vero Beach, FL and York Harbor, ME, formerly of Brookville, NY died on Friday, March 9th, 2007 at Indian River Medical Center in Vero Beach. A loving wife, mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother, she is survived by her beloved husband of 65 years, H. Van B. Richard, her daughter Phyllis Fritts, sonin-law Guy A. Fritts, daughter-in-law Virginia R. Richard, five grandchildren: James and Garret Fritts; Zachary, Travis and Cecily Richard and one great-grandson, Kai Fritts. She was predeceased by her son Peter L. Richard. A graduate of The Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, CT she was a talented interior decorator, passionate gardener and loyal friend. A Memorial Service is planned in the Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church, 2365 Pine Avenue, Vero Beach, FL 32960 on Saturday, March 17th at 3:30 pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Alzheimer/Parkinson Association of Indian River County, 2501 27th Avenue, Vero Beach, FL 32960.
WALENSKY--Ruth. March 12th, 2006. One year. Your girls miss you. Ellen, Janie and Marilyn

MIDWEST Probably the second-weakest region, with a strong No. 1 seed saving it from being the worst. This is the kind of region most likely to produce an unexpected Final Four team. No. 5 Butler, No. 6 Notre Dame and No. 10 Georgia Tech are all playing well. But look for Florida, which eased through the SEC tournament, to make it to Atlanta. GATORS FOR THE DEFENSE No. 1 Florida vs. No. 16 Jackson State Florida could probably scrape together five football players to advance in this one. * No. 8 Arizona vs. No. 9 Purdue Two completely different styles should make for a telling game. Go with Purdue. No. 5 Butler vs. No. 12 Old Dominion Butler, with wins over Notre Dame, Tennessee, Indiana and Gonzaga, will advance. * No. 4 Maryland vs. No. 13 Davidson Bob McKillop is a top coach, and he will get that elusive N.C.A.A. tournament victory. No. 6 Notre Dame vs. No. 11 Winthrop Winthrop Coach Gregg Marshall is 0 for 6. Look for that skid to continue. No. 3 Oregon vs. No. 14 Miami of Ohio Miami runs out of miracles after a miraculous 3-point shot won the MAC tournament. * No. 7 U.N.L.V. vs. No. 10 Georgia Tech Tech has better players and has quietly come on despite its A.C.C. tournament loss. No. 2 Wisconsin vs. No. 15 Texas A&M-Corpus Christi Behind the crowd in Chicago, the Badgers will roll to the Round of 16. UPSET SPECIAL Before losing to Wake Forest in the A.C.C. tournament, Thaddeus Young, left, and No. 10 Georgia Tech had consecutive victories over Boston College and North Carolina. A victory over No. 7 U.N.L.V. may be an upset in terms of seeding, but it really isn't one for those who follow the game. WHO'S HOT No. 6 Notre Dame played well in New York, despite losing to Georgetown in the semifinals. With Russell Carter, left, the Irish are a good-shooting team. No. 11 Winthrop will be a trendy upset pick, but not a wise one. This Notre Dame team has the personnel to make a Round of 16 run. WEST This is the strongest region, with perhaps the country's best team, U.C.L.A., lurking as a No. 2. Pittsburgh stumbles in after being blown out in the Big East tournament final. Don't be tempted by Duke's brand name; the Blue Devils are primed for an early exit. U.C.L.A., which doesn't have to leave the state, should reach the Final Four. CALIFORNIA HIGHWAY No. 1 Kansas VS. No. 16 Niagara Expect Kansas to break its two-year first-round skid against Niagara, the play-in winner. No. 8 Kentucky vs. No. 9 Villanova Kentucky should be able to handle a Villanova team that has been erratic all season. * No. 5 Virginia Tech VS. No. 12 Illinois Illinois, along with Stanford, may be the most controversial team in the bracket. No. 4 Southern Illinois vs. No. 13 Holy Cross This is a decent matchup for Holy Cross, but S.I.U. is much more athletic. * No. 6 Duke vs. No. 11 Virginia Commonwealth Duke's seed will be questioned even more when the Blue Devils lose. No. 3 Pittsburgh vs. No. 14 Wright State Pittsburgh has the firepower to avert an upset against a good Wright State team. * No. 7 Indiana vs. No. 10 Gonzaga Gonzaga, which has come together since the suspension of Josh Heytvelt, will win. No. 2 U.C.L.A. vs. No. 15 Weber State U.C.L.A. Coach Ben Howland will send home his alma mater without too much strain. UPSET SPECIAL It is remarkable that No. 12 Illinois has played so well considering its injuries. But Warren Carter, left, and the Illini have managed to come together at the end of the season. A second-round matchup of Illini Coach Bruce Weber against his old team, Southern Illinois, would be interesting. WHO'S HOT For No. 11 Virginia Commonwealth, the first-year coach Anthony Grant has taken off where Jeff Capel left off. With Wil Fameni, left, the Rams are an athletic and experienced team that made a stirring run to the Colonial Athletic Association title. Look for V.C.U. to topple No. 6 Duke. EAST Probably the second-strongest region behind the West; no team is hotter than Georgetown. North Carolina would have a potentially difficult team waiting in Round 2: Marquette or Michigan State. A North Carolina-Texas game in the Round of 16 would be a delight. Still, look for Georgetown to take advantage of its favorable draw. HOYAS PUT THE HEAT ON No. 1 North Carolina vs. No. 16 E. Kentucky With a West Virginia-style offense, Eastern will give U.N.C. fits before losing. No. 8 Marquette vs. No. 9 Michigan State Wait for updates on the thumb of Marquette's ace defender, Jerel McNeal. No. 5 Southern California and No. 12 Arkansas The Trojans' Tim Floyd should outcoach Stan Heath. No. 4 Texas vs. No. 13 New Mexico State Texas will win, but the Longhorns still have the toughest draw of any No. 4 seed. No. 6 Vanderbilt vs. No. 11 George Washington G.W. is a tempting upset pick here, but Vandy has played well lately. * No. 3 Washington State vs. No. 14 Oral Roberts The best bet for a long-shot upset, Oral Roberts can really score. No. 7 Boston College vs. No. 10 Texas Tech Should be one of the top first-round games. Jared Dudley should carry B.C. No. 2 Georgetown vs. No. 15 Belmont The Hoyas are so strong, it is hard to fathom them losing this game. UPSET SPECIAL No. 3 Washington State's methodical style meshes perfectly with Kelvin Sango, left, and Oral Roberts, which has the veteran personnel to play with the Cougars. No. 14 Oral Roberts has two veteran scorers -- Caleb Green and Ken Tutt -- and has finally received a decent seed. WHO'S HOT No. 2 Georgetown has won 16 of 17 games and routed Pittsburgh in the Big East tournament final. The Hoyas are a difficult matchup because of their Princeton-style offense, forward Jeff Green, left, and the 7-foot-2 center Roy Hibbert. Look for the Hoyas to make a deep run. SOUTH With a No. 1 seed that looks a bit dysfunctional on the court (Ohio State) and a mysterious No. 2 seed (Memphis), this region breaks well for Texas A&M. Numerous coaches say they haven't seen any teams playing better defense. The Aggies are experienced and have a go-to scorer in Acie Law. Expect them to reach Atlanta. SMOOTH ROAD FOR TEXAS A&M No. 1 Ohio State vs. No. 11 Central Connecticut Central will need to shoot from 20 feet out with Greg Oden in the middle. * No. 8 Brigham Young vs. No. 9 Xavier The Musketeers advance in this mini-upset because they are tournament-tested. No. 5 Tennessee vs. No. 12 Long Beach State The Volunteers have a pretty good draw to make a deep run. No. 4 Virginia vs. No. 13 Albany A surprisingly high seed for Albany, but Virginia will hold it off. No. 6 Louisville vs. No. 11 Stanford Stanford's inclusion in the bracket is almost stunning, and it won't last long. No. 3 Texas A&M vs. No. 14 Penn The Aggies guard teams so well that they'll be able to neutralize Penn's Ibrahim Jaaber. No. 7 Nevada vs. No. 10 Creighton This is the best game on paper in the first round; the Wolf Pack gets the edge. No. 2 Memphis vs. No. 15 North Texas No chance for North Texas; Memphis's up-tempo style should make this a blowout. UPSET SPECIAL No. 9 Xavier won nine in a row before losing to Rhode Island in the semifinals of the Atlantic 10 tournament. Look for Stanley Burrell, left, and the Musketeers to beat No. 8 B.Y.U. and create a compelling matchup with their former coach Thad Matta and Ohio State in the second round. WHO'S HOT Memphis is the country's hottest team, on paper, with 22 straight wins. And while its competition has been questionable, the results have been consistent. The key for Chris Douglas-Roberts, left, and his teammates will be poise in close games because they have played so few of them. ATLANTA NATIONAL SEMIFINALS Georgetown will continue its hot play and come out of the East to face defensive-minded Texas A&M, which will have home-court advantage in San Antonio. U.C.L.A. from the West will face Florida, which has put its uninspired play in the past. NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP GAME Look for U.C.L.A. and Georgetown to play for the national title, with the Bruins overcoming last year's national title loss and bringing glory back to Westwood. * Upset chance

KASINITZ--Julius On March 10, 2007 at age 79. Husband of Margaret Kasinitz of 50 years, father of Philip and Barry Kasinitz. Born in Brooklyn, he was the former CEO of Time Square stores and former president of Almay stores and Two Guys. Prior to that he was for many years Vice President of Caldor and had worked for S.Kliens. Private service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 1pm, Monday March 12th. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Heart Association.

Everything changed on Day 1, according to the governor's favorite slogan. But Mr. Spitzer had a ''Back to the Future'' moment recently when he appointed John C. Egan to head the state's Office of General Services, which procures supplies and office space for government agencies, among other tasks. Mr. Egan led the agency during the 1980s under two Democratic governors, But not all was smooth sailing. In 1984, the Temporary State Commission of Investigation mounted a two-year inquiry into the agency's relocation of state offices from the World Trade Center to other buildings, including one in SoHo. The investigation found that agency employees had accepted gifts from representatives of the owner of the SoHo building, and that one went to work for the landlord after arranging the lease.

ROBBINS--Barbara H. on March 10, 2007, at the age of 70. Loving wife of Alfred T. Devoted mother of Celine Robbins, Deirdre McGovern, Terence and Courtney Robbins. Adored grandmother of Conor, Trevor, Logan, Nicholas and Andrew. Dear sister of Ronnie, Colleen, and Valerie. Reposing Monday 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 9:30am at St. Maraget of Cortona Church. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation would be greatly appreciated.

TEXAS RESISTS ACCOUNTING RULE -- America's 50 states, and its largest cities, will soon be required to disclose the size of their health care obligations to retirees. But Texas officials argue that the rule does not apply to their state. [Page C1.] CONRAD BLACK, PRETRIAL -- The case of the United States of America v. Conrad M. Black, which begins this Wednesday in Federal Court in Chicago is unlikely to resemble recent corporate malfeasance trials. For one thing, Mr. Black has gone very public -- giving interviews and speeches and writing articles chastising his accusers and vowing not only exoneration but a comeback. [C1.] A PRELUDE TO THE NEWS -- While most of the attention in the heated network news competition focuses on the anchors, their performance is greatly complicated by ''lead-ins,'' the programs that precede the national newscasts, and by how much the network newscasts squander or build on the audiences delivered to them by local stations. [C1.] GOLD IN THE ARCHIVES -- The archives of radio and television shows like ''King Biscuit,'' ''Don Kirshner's Rock Concert'' and ''Later with Jools Holland'' have become valuable properties in the desperate search for new content for Web sites, DVDs, and video-on-demand services. [C1.] THE PERFECT FIT ONLINE -- Louise J. Wannier, below, is the chief executive of my-Shape.com, a new Internet company that records the measurements of women, who can then shop from clothing collections matched to their style, fit preferences and body dimensions. [C10.] A DEAL FOR 007's CAR -- The Ford Motor Company is expected to sell Aston Martin, maker of the high-priced British sports cars favored by James Bond, to a group of investors that includes the racing mogul David Richards and a pair of Kuwaiti companies [C10.] OUT, AND INTO ENDORSEMENTS -- HeadBlade, a company that sells men's grooming products, is adding to its roster of endorsers John Amaechi, the former professional basketball player who said last month that he was gay. [C6.] NO SWIMSUITS IN THE LIBRARY -- Sports Illustrated withheld its Feb. 14 swimsuit issue from about 21,000 subscribers identified as ''libraries or classrooms.'' None of the affected subscribers had been informed of the decision to withhold the issue, but all who request copies will get them. [C8.] REMAKE AT TIME -- At the age of 84, Time magazine is coming out with a new look and editorial approach. [C11.] THE MEDIA AS POLITICAL NEWS -- The idea of a candidate running against the news media is hardly novel. But the cancellation of a Democratic candidates' debate on Fox News appears to be part of unusually direct sparring between a political party and a news outlet. [C4.] MANY CELLPHONES, MANY SYSTEMS -- New programs that cellphone carriers are counting on to increase revenue and profit may make it to only a limited number of phones, because the world's 2.5 billion cellphones have dozens of operating systems. [C10.] NEW VOICE IN GLOBAL NEWS -- France 24, a 24-hour international television news channel that is subsidized by the government is moving to establish itself as a third international news network, behind CNN and BBC, in some parts of the world. [C2.] VERIFYING DEGREES AT WIKIPEDIA -- Jimmy Wales, co-founder of Wikipedia, has called for a voluntary system for accrediting contributors who claim to have advanced degrees, like a Ph.D or M.D. [C8.]

As soon as the 65 teams were announced for this year's tournament, the completion of online brackets began. According to ESPN.com's Men's Tournament Challenge Web site at about 9 p.m. last night, Ohio State was the most popular selection to win it all. The East Region had three of the six most popular selections, while Florida was the clear favorite from the Midwest Region. The size of the names of the teams, grouped below by their bracket region, is based on the number of times the team was picked to win the tournament. The small, shaded teams were not selected by anyone.

The Capitol was focused last week on the battle over the governor's budget and the passage of major legislation on workers' compensation and the civil confinement of sex offenders; Gov. Eliot Spitzer has scheduled signing ceremonies for both bills this week. But the Senate also quietly released its latest list of what are known as member items -- legislative pet projects decided largely in secret. After a court battle, lawmakers last year started fully disclosing the items, which ran to $200 million in the most recent budget.

Eric R. Dinallo, the governor's acting insurance superintendent, wants to reclaim state control over health insurance rates. Currently, most health insurers do not have to seek government approval before raising their rates, a result of a series of concessions made to insurers over the last couple of decades. Instead, they can raise their rates as long as they later demonstrate that a certain amount of the increase has been used to pay off claims. The Insurance Department can review the change only retroactively, a practice that has allowed for double-digit annual increases.

The medical examiner concluded yesterday that a woman who was found dead in her home on Saturday night had been strangled. Police officers responded to a report of an unconscious woman at 125-60 Sutphin Boulevard, near Rockaway Boulevard, about 6:35 p.m. on Saturday and found the woman, Raychelle Shelby, 48, who was pronounced dead by emergency medical workers, the authorities said. Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner, said yesterday that an autopsy showed Ms. Shelby had died of ligature strangulation.

An article on Saturday about fund-raising efforts in New York by Senator Barack Obama misspelled the surname of one of President John F. Kennedy's closest advisers, who introduced Mr. Obama at a fund-raiser. He is Theodore C. Sorensen, not Sorenson. The error also appeared in an article in The Arts on Feb. 22 about books written by candidates, including ''Profiles in Courage,'' which then-Senator Kennedy wrote with guidance from Mr. Sorensen. (The Times has misspelled Mr. Sorensen's surname more than 135 times in headlines and articles during the 50-plus years he has been a Democratic adviser and well-known author.)

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has set in motion a review of the Pentagon's dealings with the nation's spy agencies to improve cooperation and heal working relationships bruised by his predecessor, Donald H. Rumsfeld, just one way Mr. Gates has forcefully if quietly pushed back on Mr. Rumsfeld's initiatives. On issues that include shifting priorities on spending, demanding accountability of senior leaders for improper care of wounded troops and encouraging a more consultative dialogue with the military brass and overseas allies, Mr. Gates has already adopted policies and a style in sharp contrast with Mr. Rumsfeld's.

SIMON--Henry, 80, of Bronx, NY, died March 9. Beloved husband of Edith (nee Schwitzman). Loving father of Diane (Jeffrey Levin) and Marcia (Steven Shore) and devoted brother of Irene Hack. Adored grandfather and best friend of Michael, Allison, Jessica, and Jason. Veteran WWII USN.

A former worker at an assisted-living home was indicted on Friday on charges of stealing more than $300,000 from older and frail residents, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday. The worker, Frances Landrini, 36, of the Bronx, faces four counts of grand larceny and one count of scheming to defraud. She pleaded not guilty; her lawyer, Louis J. Reda, did not immediately respond to a request for comment last night. Ms. Landrini was a contract worker at the New Fordham Arms Home for Adults, a 35-bed home at 2915 Williamsbridge Road, where she helped residents pay their bills and conduct financial transactions. Over two years, Mr. Cuomo said, Ms. Landrini persuaded residents to sign blank checks, claiming that she would fill in the rest to pay the residents' bills but instead cashed the checks or deposited them into her own bank account. Mr. Cuomo said Ms. Landrini fraudulently obtained and negotiated more than 150 checks from 12 residents. SEWELL CHAN

The New York City Department of Education hopes to improve the high school graduation rate, but has not planned for enough seats to meet that goal, according to a report released yesterday by the city's public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum. The report said the department has set a goal of having 70 percent of high school students graduate in four years, but its five-year, $13.1 billion school construction plan, which calls for the creation of 26,000 high school seats, assumes a graduation rate of only 46 percent. Andrew Jacob, a Department of Education spokesman, rejected the report's findings. ''The report is absurd,'' he said in a statement. ''Our construction plan is adjusted annually to reflect projected changes in the graduation rate and demographic trends. We will create seats for all our high school students in whatever numbers they are graduating -- the more the better.'' SEWELL CHAN

A woman was struck and killed by a passing car yesterday -- the same day she turned 72 -- as she crossed Third Avenue on the Upper East Side, the police said. The woman, Ariela Koenigsberg, was walking west across 84th Street about 1 p.m. when a sedan headed north on Third Avenue accelerated through the intersection and struck her after the driver honked the horn, according to a witness. The police said Ms. Koenigsberg was taken to Metropolitan Hospital Center, where she was pronounced dead on arrival. Ms. Koenigsberg was apparently inching across the avenue trying to peer around two parked buses for oncoming cars when she was struck, said a woman walking behind her who gave her name only as L. Pierre. Ms. Pierre said that Ms. Koenigsberg was thrown about 20 feet into the middle of the avenue and that the driver brought his silver Ford Focus to a stop but did not get out. The police said that no criminal charges had been filed.

A must-read for anyone who favors an expansion of guest worker programs in the U.S. is a stunning new report from the Southern Poverty Law Center that details the widespread abuse of highly vulnerable, poverty-stricken workers in programs that already exist. The report is titled ''Close to Slavery: Guestworker Programs in the United States.'' It will be formally released today at a press conference in Washington.

An article on Feb. 27 about a Discovery Channel documentary that said a crypt in Jerusalem contained the bones of Jesus of Nazareth referred imprecisely to the Aramaic language. While Aramaic and Hebrew are closely related and Hebrew is written using the Aramaic script, they are distinct languages; Aramaic is not an ancient dialect of Hebrew.
To the Editor: Re '' 'Monologues' Spurs Dialogue on Taste and Speech'' (news article, March 8):

A leading Senate Democrat demanded on Sunday that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales step down, saying he had politicized his office at the expense of the nation's laws. The call by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, came as the Justice Department faced growing criticism over the ouster of eight United States attorneys and the Federal Bureau of Investigation's use of expanded surveillance powers to improperly obtain personal records of citizens.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about a report by the Justice Department's inspector general critical of the F.B.I.'s use of administrative subpoenas misspelled the surname of the Justice Department's spokesman, who defended the removal of eight United States attorneys, another problem for the department. He is Brian Roehrkasse, not Roehrkass.

Been there, almost done that: One distinction John Edwards holds in the crowded presidential field is being the only candidate in either party to have been on a November presidential ballot, having served as Senator John Kerry's running mate in 2004. At that time, he was Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, the youthful, handsome and eloquent (Bill Clinton said he could "talk an owl out of a tree") millionaire former trial lawyer whose own presidential hopes had faded in New Hampshire after a strong second-place showing in the Iowa caucuses. Having declined to seek re-election to the Senate while running in 2004, he left office early the next year.

Work starts early for the people of the Guatemalan countryside, sometimes as early as 5 or 6. Not the time, the age. Guatemalan children shine shoes and make bricks. They cut cane and mop floors. At some factories exporting to the United States, they sew and sort and chop, often in conditions so onerous they violate even Guatemala's very loose labor laws.

KELTNER--Margot A. 76. Of Chappaqua, NY. Passed away peacefully March 10, 2007. Margot was a department head for Letters to the Editor of Fortune Magazine, until her retirement in 1996. Service private. The Dorsey Funeral Home Inc., 14 Emwilton Place, Ossining, NY 10562. 914-941-0167. www.dorseyfuneral.com

To the Editor: Sarah Hamersma is right that tax subsidies do a poor job in prompting employers to hire the disadvantaged (''The Bare Minimum,'' Op-Ed, March 8). But boosting salaries directly through the Earned Income Tax Credit is equally inefficient.

Apostle of Hustle ''National Anthem of Nowhere'' (Arts & Crafts) Andrew Whiteman, a guitarist for the Toronto indie band Broken Social Scene, formed Apostle of Hustle in 2001, after returning from a two-month sojourn in Havana. Among other things the group is his attempt to fold that experience into an honest tapestry, one that's faithful not only to his influences but also his identity: as an indie-rocker with a Canadian address.

Robert Comer says that his death sentence is just and that the state of Arizona should go ahead and kill him. ''I stuck a gun in the guy's ear, pulled the trigger,'' Mr. Comer told a federal judge who was considering whether to let him withdraw his appeals. ''I've already been lawfully convicted.''

An article on Friday about a lawsuit filed in Massachusetts by advocates for inmates and the mentally ill misstated the number of prison suicides in 2005 in California, which has been ordered to spend $600 million to improve mental health services in prisons. There were 36, not 44.
MINDLIN--Michael. 3/11/23 -3/7/04 Lovingly remembered and greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Freda

A Midmajor Decline The emerging trend of fewer midmajor teams receiving at-large bids to the N.C.A.A. tournament continued yesterday. Six midmajor teams claimed at-large invitations: Butler, Old Dominion, Southern Illinois, Xavier, Nevada and Brigham Young. Old Dominion and Butler will face each other in the first round.

A City Council committee was expected to approve a bill today that would ban the use of nonwood bats in high school baseball games, according to Council officials. The measure, introduced by Councilmen James S. Oddo, Republican of Staten Island, and Lewis A. Fidler, Democrat of Brooklyn, is to be voted on by the full Council on Wednesday. The sponsors cited cases in which metal bats have been linked to serious injuries and, as evidence, research by the Nicholas Institute of Sports Medicine and Athletic Trauma. But at an Oct. 23 hearing, the city's Department of Education opposed the proposal and the director of the National Center for Catastrophic Sports Injury Research said there was ''no evidence that batted-ball injuries are a greater problem from aluminum bats as compared to wooden bats.'' A second hearing was scheduled for this morning, before the committee vote. SEWELL CHAN

American Legacy Foundation, Washington, which sponsors the ''Truth'' anti- smoking campaign, chose PHD, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle media planning and buying on its account, with spending estimated at $35 million. The decision came after a required review that also included the incumbent agency, Media Head, New York. Porsche Cars North America, Atlanta, part of Porsche, placed in review its creative and media accounts, with spending estimated at $25 million. The creative account is at Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and the media account is at Kastner & Partners, Los Angeles.

I was standing outside our locker room, talking to a reporter from The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. He was writing the familiar story: at Penn, we're student-athletes who are students first, we do things the right way, etc. I am asked to do these interviews because on a team of smart kids, I'm supposedly the smart kid. Having a chance to work as a summer intern at the White House and being lucky enough to reach the finals of the Rhodes Scholarship have residual effects. All of which means I have my answers canned: No, the Ivy League doesn't offer athletic scholarships, and yes, we play on Fridays and Saturdays so we won't miss class. I throw in a token story, this time about how a teammate wrote a paper on the seven-hour bus ride back from Dartmouth. I've seen enough of these articles to know what reporters are looking for. These stories almost write themselves.

A sports article in some copies on Friday, about the hockey game in which Chris Simon of the Islanders struck the Rangers' Ryan Hollweg in the chin with his stick, rendered incorrectly a postgame quotation from Simon. He said, ''I've always been known as a team guy, and I feel real bad about letting the team down.'' He did not say, ''I've always been known as a clean guy,'' nor did he say, ''I just feel bad for letting my team down.'' A version of the quotation printed in larger type above the article and pictures repeated the errors.

The League of American Theaters and Producers will work with three creative agencies to develop a campaign to promote Broadway as a brand, nationally and abroad, as well as to promote shows whether they are running on Broadway or on tour. The agencies are the Buddy Group in Lake Forest, Calif., for digital work; LaPlaca Cohen in New York, for strategy and media services; and Trailer Park in West Hollywood, Calif., for creative services. The budget for the campaign, planned to begin late this year, is being determined.

Lloyd ''Street Love'' (The Inc./Universal) Having been acquitted of money-laundering, the hip-hop mogul Irving Lorenzo, known as Irv Gotti, comes roaring -- or, more accurately, purring -- back. His label, The Inc. (formerly Murder Inc.), is releasing ''Street Love,'' the second album from the 21-year-old crooner Lloyd; Irv Gotti is listed as one of four executive producers. And Lloyd has a big hit with ''You,'' a PG seduction song, which sits atop Billboard's Hot 100 Airplay chart.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the first solar observatory in the Americas misstated the title of Ivan Ghezzi, a doctoral student at Yale University who helped investigate the site, in Peru. Mr. Ghezzi is the archaeological director -- not the overall director -- of the National Institute of Culture, in Peru. (Cecilia Bákula Budge is the director.)

8Ball & MJG ''Ridin High'' (Bad Boy/Atlantic) Plenty of high-minded hip-hop acts have come and gone since 1993, the year 8Ball & MJG released ''Comin' Out Hard.'' And perhaps it's no coincidence that these two Memphis rappers, with their greasy pimp tales and grim crime narratives, have outlasted the competition. Their rhymes continue a centuries-old tradition of African-American boasting and toasting. Maybe this stuff never sounded new, but it also never gets old.

A picture caption with an article on Saturday about violence in Iraq misstated the sequence of events surrounding a military operation south of Baghdad on Friday involving soldiers from the First Battalion, 23rd Infantry Regiment. The soldiers were shown detaining Iraqi men at the start of the military action. It was not until later that the soldiers took fire from the area.

Metheny Mehldau ''Quartet'' (Nonesuch) On much of the second collaboration between the guitarist Pat Metheny and the pianist Brad Mehldau, time decelerates; music seems to hang in the air by an invisible string. This streamlined, weightless feeling has been rigorously worked out for more than a decade by Mr. Mehldau's trio, and here it's his gift to Mr. Metheny. Conversely Mr. Metheny's work -- especially the 20 or so years of it predating Mr. Mehldau's emergence in jazz -- gave this pianist an open, pastoral-sounding harmonic vocabulary to build on in his formation as a composer and improviser.
To the Editor: Re ''Historians Fight Bush on Access to Papers'' (Arts pages, March 8):

MIDWEST PLAYER TO WATCH BRYCE TAYLOR, a 6-foot-5 sophomore guard from Oregon, averaged 14.8 points a game and made every shot he took en route to scoring a careerhigh 32 points in the Pacific-10 title game. WEST PLAYER TO WATCH SCOTTIE REYNOLDS, a freshman guard for Villanova, is an explosive scorer. He had 40 points against Connecticut at the end of the regular season and scored 29 against DePaul in the Big East tournament. EAST PLAYER TO WATCH ROY HIBBERT, Georgetown's 278-pound center, is big (7 feet 2 inches) and skilled, with the ability to dominate defensively and on the boards. His size could pose a major problem for the Hoyas' opponents. SOUTH PLAYER TO WATCH MARCELUS KEMP, at 6 feet 5 inches and 210 pounds, combines with Nick Fazekas to form a formidable one-two punch for Nevada. Kemp averages 18.3 points a game.

MIDWEST FLORIDA (29-5) The Gators seem to be regaining last year's national championship form just in time for the tournament. They stormed to the Southeastern Conference tournament title, routing opponents by nearly 20 points a game. Joakim Noah's scoring average is down by about 2 points this season, but the junior forward Al Horford, left, remains steady inside. Florida is shooting a nation-best 52.7 percent from the field and looked like college basketball's top team for most of this season. WEST KANSAS (30-4) The fast-breaking Jayhawks have a dependable scorer in the sophomore Brandon Rush, and the versatile 6-foot-8 forward Julian Wright poses a serious matchup problem for opponents. Prone to turnovers in big games last season, the sophomore point guard Mario Chalmers, left, has reduced his miscues this season and has been solid of late. Unable to advance beyond the tournament's first round the past two years, the Jayhawks rank among the nation's best in field-goal shooting and rebounding, key ingredients to success. A potential second-round game against Kentucky looms.
