EAST NORTH CAROLINA (28-6) The success of the Tar Heels will hinge on the play of the freshman starters Ty Lawson, Brandan Wright and Wayne Ellington, who average a combined 37 points a game. But the sophomore forward Tyler Hansbrough, left, anchors this team, which is defined by deft shooting and strong rebounding. The Tar Heels are 21-0 when they shoot 50 percent from the field and 26-2 when they outrebound their opponent. A marquee matchup pitting Hansbrough against Texas' star freshman, Kevin Durant, is possible in the Round of 16. SOUTH Ohio State (30-3) The Buckeyes will rely on their dynamic backcourt, featuring the freshman point guard Mike Conley Jr., left, and the senior Ron Lewis. They also will count on the freshman center Greg Oden, who averaged 17 points in the Big Ten tournament after averaging 15.3 points in the regular season. Winners of 17 consecutive games, the Buckeyes could face their first challenge in the tournament in the Round of 16 against Tennessee, which they beat by 2 points in January.

The attribution on Tuesday for the Quotation of the Day, taken from a front-page article about conditions at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, referred incorrectly in some copies to the acting secretary of the Army, who said, ''We have let some soldiers down.'' He goes by Pete Geren, not Peter. (His birth name is Preston.)

Mets single-game tickets for the 2007 season went on sale yesterday. The defending National League East champion Mets open their 81-date home schedule April 9 against the divisional rival Philadelphia Phillies. A limited number of tickets for opening day and the series against the Yankees at Shea Stadium (May 18-20) are available in selected ticket plans. Single-game tickets for these four games sold out through an online random drawing in February that generated in excess of 400,000 registrations.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 In New Tactic, Militants Burn Houses in Iraq Sunni militants burned homes in a mixed city northeast of Baghdad, forcing dozens of families to flee and raising the specter of a new intimidation tactic in Iraq's evolving civil war, Iraqi officials and witnesses said. Militants also continued their campaign against Shiite pilgrims; the worst attack, a car bombing, killed at least 19 people. A1 President Bush called on Congress to provide financing for the Iraq war ''with no strings attached.'' And he defended his decision to send nearly 9,000 more troops to Iraq and Afghanistan by saying they would be dedicated to training and support missions. A8 Little Progress in Mideast Talks Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel held their second meeting in a month, but aides said that there was little concrete progress to report. A13 Police Quell Zimbabwe Protest Hundreds of Zimbabwe's riot police officers violently crushed an attempt by protesters to hold what they called a prayer meeting in one of the capital's largest slums to express opposition to the rule of President Robert G. Mugabe. A10 NATIONAL A14-20 Military Struggles to Treat Soldiers With Brain Injuries The military health care system has been scrambling to deal with an unanticipated volume of traumatic brain injury cases, largely caused by of improvised explosive devices used by Iraqi insurgents. Caregivers say that wounded soldiers were either written off prematurely or not given aggressive rehabilitation. A1 Citizens Cut From Medicaid A new federal rule intended to keep illegal immigrants from receiving Medicaid has instead shut out tens of thousands of United States citizens who have had difficulty complying with requirements to show birth certificates and other documents proving their citizenship. A1 Dealing With Earlier Primaries The trickle of states moving their 2008 presidential primaries to Feb. 5 has forced all the presidential campaigns to reconsider every aspect of their nominating strategy as they gird for the prospect of a 20-state national primary day. A1 Smoke-Free Tennessee Tennessee will probably become the first major tobacco-growing state to pass a comprehensive smoke-free-workplace law. The ban was proposed in January by Gov. Phil Bredesen, a Democrat, who wants to triple taxes on cigarette sales and to use some of the money for smoking prevention. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 The Roxy Closes Its Doors With Final Gay Dance Party The Roxy, the West Side discothèque famed for its gay-themed Saturday night parties, has closed its doors after 16 years. B1 The Case of Steven Chait The disappearance of Steven Chait, who has been missing for 35 years, is one of the New York Police Department's oldest open missing persons cases, and seems to have been forgotten by history. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Preludes to the News While most of the attention in the heated network news competition focuses on the anchors, the programs that precede the national newscasts -- called lead-ins -- play a large role in determining their audience. C1 Accounting Rule Resisted America's 50 states and its largest cities will soon be required to disclose the value of the health care they have promised their retired workers. But Texas is trying to avoid compliance with the new accounting rule. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: The next big health care battle; a bill Democrats should like; the perfect lawn, mowed and muted; sunshine on history. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E6 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E8 Weather B6

The city's Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday warned debt collectors that they must be licensed if they wish to collect from New York City residents. In the past two months, the department has secured agreements and fines totaling more than $65,000 from six unlicensed collection agencies, while it continues to investigate several others. Jonathan B. Mintz, the commissioner of consumer affairs, said that abusive collection tactics ''can significantly harm a consumer's credit history and impact the financial resources of those who need it most.'' SEWELL CHAN

SPICEHANDLER--Ruth. Loving daughter, wife, mother, sister and grandmother. She lived her life with special generosity of kindness and love. Her insights and compassion will be missed by many. Services Monday 10 am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY.

A 47-year-old man was struck and killed by a black Lincoln Town Car that fled the scene shortly before 2 a.m. yesterday in Coney Island, the police said. The victim, whose name was not released, was crossing Surf Avenue when he was struck by the sedan, which was heading west, the police said. The driver then drove north on West 31st Street, the police said. The victim was taken to Lutheran Medical Center and pronounced dead a short time later. There were no suspects and no arrests yesterday. MICHAEL WILSON

Halliburton Chief to Open a Headquarters in Dubai Halliburton, the big energy services company, said its top executive, David J. Lesar, would establish a headquarters in Dubai in recognition that its business in the region is growing. It plans to maintain offices in Houston. PAGE A16 Bush Visits Colombia, Briefly President Bush traveled to Colombia, a focal point of the war on drugs, to support his closest South American ally, President Álvaro Uribe, as leftist leaders in the region seek to counter the influence of the United States. He also noted signs of progress in the Colombian capital, where no American president had visited in more than two decades. But he stayed only seven hours. PAGE A10 French President to Retire After more than four decades as a politician and a dozen years as president, Jacques Chirac announced his retirement from politics, but he did not endorse Nicolas Sarkozy, the candidate and leader of his own party. Mr. Chirac will probably be best remembered by historians as the European leader who led the opposition to the war in Iraq in 2003. PAGE A3 Breakdown Amid Babel Liev Schreiber, below, plays an abrasive radio talk-show host in a revival of Eric Bogosian's ''Talk Radio,'' an incisive study of the pathology of fame and what happens to a man who sees himself reflected and distorted in the eyes of multitudes. Reviewed by Ben Brantley. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 N.C.A.A. Brackets Are Set Florida, the defending champion, Ohio State, Kansas and North Carolina were chosen as the top seeds for the 65-team N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament, which begins tomorrow with a game between Florida A&M and Niagara. A full schedule of games will begin Thursday. SPORTSMONDAY Conrad Black's Day in Court His former media empire, Hollinger, has been renamed and partly dismantled. His defense lawyer does not know American law. But Canadians, among others, will be riveted to the fraud trial of Conrad M. Black, which starts in Chicago on Wednesday. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 A Mother's 35-Year Vigil Mysterious phone calls have kept a woman hoping that her son, missing since 1972, will return. The case is one of the New York Police Department's oldest open missing persons investigations. PAGE B1

Two Salt Lake City agencies, Struck Design and W Communications, are merging to form Struck. Steve Driggs joins Struck as partner and executive creative director; he had been group creative director at Fallon Worldwide, Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe.

Two operating systems run more than 95 percent of the world's computers, but dozens of systems are behind the 2.5 billion mobile phones in circulation, a situation that has hampered the growth of new services, industry executives and independent specialists say. ''There are too many operating systems already and more are coming on stream, making things complicated for smaller software companies,'' said Tony Cripps, a senior analyst with the telecommunications consulting firm Ovum in London.

CADMAN--Larry. The One Club mourns the passing of Larry Cadman, esteemed copywriter and former member of the Board of Directors of The One Club for Art and Copy. Larry died in New York on February 19, 2007 after a brave battle with lung cancer. Born in 1942 in Coldwater, Michigan, Larry graduated from the University of Michigan. He moved to New York and enjoyed a career here as an award winning copywriter. An avid golfer and published playwright, he leaves a host of loyal friends who will dearly miss his integrity, friendship and tremendous talent. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Caren and sister Kandy Aker. Donations may be made to the American Lung Association.

To the Editor: Thanks to Bob Herbert for ''Lift the Curtain,'' his March 8 column about the failure of the American government to protect, support and care for our soldiers. This extends not just to the current administration, which certainly bears the brunt of the responsibility, but also to our Congress, whose failure to fill its oversight role implicates it as well.

An article on Saturday about the troubled state of many of Britain's youth reversed the rankings for Britain and the United States in a Unicef study that measured children's well-being in 21 industrialized countries. It was Britain that scored the lowest; the United States was the second-lowest.

Isiah Thomas has survived his one-season ultimatum, with a month to spare. Thomas, the Knicks' president and coach, will be given a multiyear extension today, according to a person briefed on the matter. The extension means that James L. Dolan, the Madison Square Garden chairman, has seen the ''evident progress'' that he demanded of Thomas last June. Dolan ordered Thomas to coach the team after firing Larry Brown and told Thomas he had one year to show progress or be fired as both coach and president.
To the Editor: Re ''Makers of Sodas Try a New Pitch: They're Healthy'' (front page, March 7):

As genetic testing for ethnicity and ancestry has become more available to the public, more Americans are seeking information on their lineage. And many are confronting surprises in family background, racial makeup and newfound relatives.
As that wise sage Homer Simpson said, when he took over as pee-wee football coach, "Now it's time for the easiest part of any coach's job: the cuts."

Last spring in Lakeland, Fla., Mike Mussina pitched a game so bad it was funny. He gave up 10 runs on 12 hits in four innings. One of the four homers the Tigers hit was smashed so far, Mussina worried it would crack his windshield in the players' parking lot.
Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below. - The Editors

The most entertaining player in this year's N.C.A.A. tournament is not Kevin Durant or Greg Oden. It'sTravon Free, a center at Long Beach State, who can be spotted performing at the Laugh Factory in Hollywood and the Ice House Comedy Club in Pasadena.
Nick was on the Colbert Report Monday night to share the news about the "Win a Trip" contest. The best moment was when Colbert asked Nick:

Recently, Nick touted Ethiopia as a great destination for student travellers. He wrote that it was cheap and safe. Ten days later a group from the British embassy in Ethiopia was kidnapped. It was announced that today the non-Ethiopians in the group had been released.
New York Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares a stir-fried squid in no time flat.

In an apparent effort to avoid defeat, Clear Channel Communications on Wednesday pushed back both the record date and the voting date for a proposed $18.7 billion management-led buyout. Now, the record date -- which determines the shareholders eligible to vote on the deal -- has been delayed to March 23, and the vote itself moved to April 19 from March 21.

When the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the United States gives an interview in the middle of a controversial war, bloggers pay attention. When the chairman offers his opinions about the "immorality" of homosexuality, the bloggers respond from far and wide.

As The Guardian reports, a second junior member of Prime Minister Tony Blair's government resigned today over Mr. Blair's plans to commit Britain to restocking its nuclear arsenal in the future when the current Trident nuclear missile system warheads start to deteriorate.
In news that might make John Kerry feel more comfortable in his retirement from presidential politics, but could be disturbing to Rudolph W. Giuliani, The Associated Press reports today that:
Voting in Brooklyn's 40th Council District, again and again. [The Politicker]

After the rush of deadline stories on Sunday, The Bracket picked up his phone to chat about this year's field with Friend of The Bracket and Orlando Sentinel scribe Dave Curtis. When DC asked The Bracket's Final Four - Florida, U.C.L.A., Georgetown and Texas A&M - he responded, "I have the exact same one." Weird, but not stunning.
Quite an odd scene around 9:20 this morning inside Tradition Field: on the mound, Orlando Hernandez. Catching, Mike DiFelice. In the stands, yours truly and a few other reporters, and that's it.
A few more interesting tidbits out of the New York Times/CBS News poll that we wrote about in today's newspaper.
The Yankees play the first of three consecutive home night games at Legends Field tonight against the Cincinnati Reds. Good pitching matchup as Mike Mussina takes on Aaron Harang.

Sourcefire's successful initial offering last week may have represented a turning point in the buyout trend among makers of security software. The 451 Group, which researches the enterprise technology sector, expects a "steady flow" of computer security companies to go public over the next few quarters. Among them: Postini, Barracuda Networks, AcrSight and Fortinet.

The political prospects of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came up again today when he was in Washington to speak at a Treasury Department conference on keeping United States capital markets competitive.Mr. Bloomberg sat on a panel with some heavyweights: Alan Greenspan and Paul A. Volcker, former chairmen of the Federal Reserve; Arthur Levitt Jr., former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission; and Robert E. Rubin, former Treasury secretary. The current secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., and the current S.E.C. chairman, Christopher Cox, moderated the panel. Mr. Cox, a Republican former congressman from California, noted that Mr. Bloomberg had won re-election by a greater margin than any other Republican in New York City history.

In the latest Times/CBS News poll, an oversampling of Republicans was gathered to help measure their views. The nationwide poll, conducted from March 7-11 with 1,362 adults, found Republicans who were dispirited and dissatisfied with the slate of their party's candidates as well with the overall direction of the party. (Full story by Adam Nagourney here.)

Last night, an interesting piece of political theater played out on the Senate floor as the Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, brought up the governor's controversial health care budget plan for a vote -- several weeks before the budget deadline.

Well, okay, no need to enter immediately. But my win-a-trip contest is now officially open, and applications are being accepted. I'll choose one university student and one school teacher from the applications, and my plan is to travel together in the latter half of June to Rwanda, Burundi and eastern Congo.
An ad from General Motors.
Chesterton has an amazing new house on the market -- a six-bedroom family home with 5,048 square feet of space at 53 Tregunter Road in London's posh Chelsea neighborhood.
Time for the Empire Zone to delve for a moment into the budget numbers game.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be meeting shortly with community leaders in southeast Queens, as speculation grows that a grand jury will wrap up its inquiry into the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell and release its findings as early as tomorrow.

A "new generation of private equity entrepreneurs" is making its mark on the industry, according to a report in BusinessWeek. Some of these entrepreneurs' firms, like New Mountain Capital, are run by relative unknowns. Others are run by private-equity veterans like Silver Lake Partners, headed by Glenn Hutchins, a co-founder of the Blackstone Group.

"It's a really good time to be an M.B.A.,'' Andy Chan, assistant dean and director of the M.B.A. Career Management Center at Stanford University, tells Bloomberg News. How good? Last year, graduates of Harvard Business School averaged a record $186,174 in starting pay, while new M.B.A.'s from Stanford's business school earned an average of $183,000. Starting pay for graduates from the top business schools may rise further, thanks to intense competition for them among big Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

Spirit Finance, a real estate investment trust based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said on Tuesday it would be acquired by a consortium led by Australia's Macquarie Bank for about $1.6 billion. The group offered $14.50 per share in cash, a premium of about 11 percent over Spirit Finance's closing price of $13.05 on Monday. The deal is expected to close by the end of the third quarter, Spirit Finance said, though a provision lets it solicit other bids through April 9.

Clear Channel Communications has been quiet about its fallback options in the event that shareholders shoot down its $18.7 billion proposal to go private. But with investor opposition building, such a scenario seems increasingly likely. And Victor Miller, an analyst at Bear Stearns, sees plenty of possibilities for what the nation's largest radio broadcaster could do next.

It's been way too long, I know. All I can say is I had a few tasks to do for the newspaper, as well as jury duty, and then there was the little matter of losing my car keys, at which point I had a bit of a snap attack. Oh, and the $65 parking ticket I got before I could find a spare key. Manhattan is not a place that takes kindly to life's little adventures. Let's just say I've been in a solitary, brooding mood.

As reported this morning, parts of West Street will be closed for about a month as part of an expanded search for human remains from ground zero. Here is the memorandum [pdf] from Deputy Mayor Edward Skyler to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
If you thought that private equity funds would slow down after last year's rapid-fire dealmaking, think again.

The University of Louisville's Web site notes that 19 of Rick Pitino's former players and assistant coaches have gone on to head coaching jobs. Several -- including Florida's Billy Donovan, Kentucky's Tubby Smith and Holy Cross's Ralph Willard -- join him in this year's N.C.A.A. tournament field. And several of those coaches' former assistants have taken the link one generation further, including the likes of Virginia Commonwealth's Anthony Grant, who worked for Donovan, and Xavier's Sean Miller, who worked for both Willard at Pittsburgh and for another Pitino disciple, Herb Sendek, at Miami of Ohio and N.C. State.
Worried that your bum really does look big in those new jeans and your partner's just too nice to say anything?

Is Nelson Peltz trying to satisfy his sweet tooth? Responding to rumors Tuesday, Cadbury Schweppes said that Mr. Peltz has amassed a stake of nearly 3 percent in Cadbury, the world's largest candy and soft drink maker. Shares in the company on the London Stock Exchange were up 10.6 percent, at 602.50 pence each, valuing the company at about 12.6 billion pounds ($24.3 billion).

The New York League of Conservation voters has released a scorecard [link fixed] that rates the 51 City Council members on the league's favored issues.A caveat: Despite the purported mathematical precision that typically accompanies these types of scorecards from various lobbying groups, the percentages and rankings are apples-to-oranges comparisons with no statistical validity. But they are a general guide to what a lobbying group thinks of the council's performance. In this case, it applauds the quick approval of a solid waste plan but is unhappy with slow movement on several other bills on global warming, energy efficiency, transportation alternatives, and watershed protection.

Though some reports have said that Samuel Zell's bid for Tribune is a solid hit, it may be a fielders choice of sorts; but in any case, the ball is still in play. Mr. Zell, who completed the record-breaking sale of his Equity Office Properties Trust last month, has said that he intends on keeping the media conglomerate together, including its newspaper and television properties and the Chicago Cubs.

The diagnosis for Express Scripts' $26.3 billion bid for Caremark Rx is getting even grimmer. On Tuesday, a proxy advisory firm came out in favor of the proposed merger of Caremark, a drug-benefits manager, with drugstore chain CVS, reversing its previous position that shareholders should reject the deal.

The Midwest region, top left in your 64 team bracket, will be known as the region with the reigning national champion Florida Gators. Let's take a look at how Florida and the other 15 teams in the Midwest match up.
A 22-year-old Egyptian blogger's appeal was denied, and he will have to remain in jail, The Associated Press reports today.

How would Barry Bonds's massive personality and desire for preferential treatment have fit into the team-oriented world of Japanese baseball? While it seems far-fetched to envision Bonds taking his booming swing to Japan, he said it is a country where he believes he could have played.
Tour three grand estates in Naples, Fla., Jackson, Wyo., and Malibu, Calif.

Moving deeper into the alternative-asset management business, Lehman Brothers said Tuesday it had bought a 20 percent stake in D.E. Shaw, one of the largest hedge funds in the United States. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but it follows similar transactions at Lehman and other Wall Street firms that want to be able to offer their clients greater access to these private pools of capital. Morgan Stanley has been especially active: It announced Monday that it had bought a piece of Abax Global Capital, its fifth hedge-fund investment in the past few months.

While hedge funds confidently flex their muscles in the markets and in boardrooms, in Washington they are experiencing the awkward growing pains of a relatively new industry coming to grips with its own power. Some hedge funds like D. E. Shaw and Cerberus Capital Management have spent time and money in the capital, but most funds have been content to hope Washington will not rear its regulatory head.

Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told The Chicago Tribune yesterday that he opposes any change to the "don't ask, don't tell" policy, which bars service by openly gay soldiers. General Pace, a Marine officer, explained why he supported the current policy:

Scooter Libby is unlikely to become the next Leonard Peltier or Mumia Abu-Jamal, but Michael Kinsley says it's time to Free Scooter! Kinsley uses his column in Time to make a liberal's case for pardoning Scooter Libby. He writes:

Jessica Leighton, the city's deputy commissioner for environmental health, denies that the city has started a crackdown involving restaurant inspections, in the wake of the KFC/Taco Bell rat episode."In the old days, you got a slap on the wrist and they tell you to move the jar of olives onto the shelf, and that was it," said the owner, Charles Milite.

Senator John McCain's name has been synonymous with campaign finance laws for a long time. And it's well known that the bulk of conservatives dislike the McCain-Feingold law. (In fact, the audience at the Conservative Political Action Conference booed and hissed at mentions of the law just a little more than a week ago. And it clapped and cheered when Mitt Romney vowed to fight the law in his speech.)
The suit seeks $1 billion in damages and an injunction against further violations.

Carl C. Icahn is getting tough with WCI Communities. The billionaire financier said Tuesday he would offer to buy the residential homebuilder for $22 share and if the company were to resist, he made it clear that he would try to throw out the board and get the deal done regardless. WCI is just one of several companies that Mr. Icahn has been prodding in recent months in what has been an especially active period for the activist investor.
The board of directors of the 35-year-old Bush Theater in London announced the appointment of Josie Rourke as artistic director.

It is not exactly The Congressional Register, but YouTube is being employed by growing numbers of politicians to put video of floor speeches and other statements online. And the trend is likely to accelerate as C-Span makes more video of Congress available.
Goldman Sachs reported a 29 percent increase in profit for its first quarter despite growing concern on Wall Street over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market.

After Nikko Cordial's four biggest shareholders dismissed its first bid as too low, Citigroup on Tuesday raised its offer for the Japanese brokerage by 26 percent to $13.4 billion. Citigroup's new bid now values Nikko, one of Japan's largest brokerage firms, at 1,700 yen ($14.48) a share, up from 1,350 yen.

The 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.6 billion) takeover bid for Australia's Qantas Airways hit a rough patch on Tuesday as some large shareholders remained cool on the deal. The Australian Financial Review reported that UBS and Balanced Equity Management, who together have enough clout to kill a deal, have pressed the airline's management to release a report explaining why the bid led by Macquarie Bank and the Texas Pacific Group does not undervalue the company.

Jerry Salzman, the longtime outside counsel for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, joined Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom on Monday, as the law firm he cofounded is closing down after 40 years. Mr. Salzman is leaving Freeman, Freeman & Salzman months after the exchange agreed to acquire CBOT Holdings, the parent company of the Chicago Board of Trade, in an $8 billion deal that could create the world's largest futures exchange. Skadden represented the Merc in that deal.

The Children's Investment Fund is turning up the heat on Electric Power Development to triple its dividend, marking the first time the British activist hedge fund has targeted a Japanesey company. Known as TCI, the fund has urged the country's largest electricity wholesaler, often called J-Power, to increase its year-end dividend to 100 yen from its current plans for 30 yen. With a 9.9 percent stake, TCI is J-Power's largest shareholder.
the film producer Harvey Weinstein is casting himself in the role of fashion industry magnate.

The Wall Street banks and brokerage firms that just a few months ago welcomed New Century Financial with open arms and gave it credit lines worth billions of dollars have quickly shut off the spigot, forcing it ever closer to bankruptcy. New Century, one of the biggest mortgage lenders to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit, said in a securities filing Monday that all its lenders had frozen their credit lines and were demanding that it buy back $8.4 billion in loans that it issued using the money it borrowed from the banks - money New Century says it does not have.

Senior Bush administration officials began a series of high-level discussions on Monday with top executives from Wall Street, corporations and the major accounting firms. Many of the executives have urged the rollback of laws passed in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals as well as limits to liability from government and shareholder lawsuits.
Former players who have dementia do not qualify for the N.F.L.'s disability insurance program, because neither the league nor the union consider their conditions football-related.

In yet another bump in the road for the proposed buyout of TXU, a report has found that the company manipulated the Texas electric market in 2005, costing consumers $70 million and giving the utility $20 million in extra profits. TXU, the largest power generator in Texas, sold power to the market at inflated prices and caused electricity prices to rise 15.5 percent during a four-month summer stretch, according to an outside expert whose report was released by state regulators on Monday.

Initial public offerings from tech maker BigBand Networks, commodities risk management firm FCStone and medicine maker Tongjitang Chinese Medicines face a choppy new issues market this week. Roiled by the big sell-off two weeks ago, the I.P.O. market is attempting to find its footing after a couple of big stumbles by recent deals.

More than $30 billion in just four deals announced Monday may represent a big payday for investment-banking advisers, potentially shaking up the industry's league tables as the industry enters the home stretch, MarketWatch notes. The Web site estimated that the total fees could ring in between $30 million and $100 million. Check out the breakdown after the jump.

Merrill Lynch was looking at a possible bid for CanWest Global's stake in the Australian broadcaster Ten Network, Reuters reported. Canada's CanWest has a 56.4 percent stake in Ten and had initially hoped to get up to 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.6 billion) for the holding, but the sale has apparently made slow progress. Ten has a market value of about 3 billion Australian dollars, including the CanWest stake, based on the latest share price.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts's $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

Procter & Gamble said on Monday it had agreed to sell its European tissue operations to a Swedish hygiene and paper product maker SCA for 512 million euros ($672 million). SCA said the acquisition would give it a batch of new brands, including Tempo, the market leader in paper handkerchiefs in western Europe and Hong Kong.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged three men Monday with hacking into online brokerage accounts based in the United States, primarily from Thailand and India, and manipulating stock prices to turn a profit for themselves. The civil charges, brought in a Nebraska federal court, claim the men allegedly used stolen identity information to pose as online buyers, inflate the value of the stock, and then sell their own shares at a higher price.

Anadarko Petroleum agreed to sell part of its stake in the K2 oil and natural gas field in the Gulf of Mexico to two undisclosed buyers for $1.2 billion. The sale, which is expected to close in the second quarter, would reduce Anadarko's stake in the project to 41.8 percent from 65 percent, the company said.

British private equity leaders, determined to change the perception of themselves as vultures and locusts, stayed on point Monday. Speaking at the annual dinner of the British Private Equity and Venture Capital Association, Rod Selkirk, the association's chairman, said private equity takeovers were responsible for strong growth in British jobs and exports over the past five years. He said the industry had also benefited workers' pension funds, because their investments in private equity funds had made double-digit gains.
Akzo Nobel's $14.4 billion deal to sell its Organon BioSciences unit to Schering-Plough has stoked further takeover speculation in the industry.

Linde, the world's biggest producer of industrial gases, said Monday it sold part of its BOC Edwards subsidiary to private equity firm CCMP Capital for 685 million euros ($901.12 million). The deal to sell the unit of BOC Edwards, which was part of Britain's BOC Group that Linde paid 12.4 billion euros for last year, is subject to regulatory approval.

Microsoft is close to acquiring Tellme Networks, a privately held maker of products that bridge the worlds of speech recognition and the Internet, in a deal that could come as early as this week, according to CNet News.com.

Acer is going to try to make a major purchase in the PC world this year and says it will pass Lenovo to become the third largest computer maker in the world. In an interview with The Wall Street Journal, Acer's chief executive J.T. Wang said the Taiwan-based company wants to make a meaningful acquisition of another PC maker this year. "We are looking at some candidates which we want to pick up," he said.

Oracle's $3.3 billion acquisition of Hyperion Solutions, announced March 1, is turning out to be a very sweet deal for some company insiders. The announcement that Oracle would pay $52 dollar a share for the Santa Clara-based maker of business intelligence software, a big premium over the $42.84 the stock had closed at the previous day, caused Hyperion's stock to jump 20.4 percent to $51.57 by the close of the market.

You win some, you lose some; that may be what the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges is thinking right now. Just as the firm welcomes back legendary bankruptcy partner Harvey Miller, it is losing four other restructuring stars to a rival firm.

Swisscom bid 3.74 billion euros ($4.93 billion) on Monday to acquire FastWeb, one of the largest fixed-line phone companies in Italy, in what analysts suggested could signal the start of a consolidation wave in the telecommunications industry. The deal, worth $4.93 billion, would give Swisscom, a phone operator, the chance to counter slowing growth in its home market while giving FastWeb financing to continue its expansion in the underdeveloped broadband Internet market in Italy.

Stock market regulators in the United States and Canada filed civil charges on Monday against former executives of Nortel Networks, a large maker of telecommunications equipment. The former chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, and others were accused of committing accounting fraud to meet earnings forecasts and investor expectations.

In what will no doubt be unwelcome news for Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, Apax Partners Worldwide has announced that it will stop investing in start-up companies to focus solely on leveraged buyouts after it raised a record 10 billion euro ($13 billion) takeover fund. "Our next fund will be 100 percent buyouts," Martin Halusa, chief executive of Apax, said last week after giving a presentation to the Washington State Investment Board in Olympia. "Our venture results have been very volatile, and our focus is on the more stable end of the business."

Responding to a drumbeat for better corporate governance, Bristol-Myers Squibb said Monday that it had agreed to a new guideline for establishing pay for its chief executive. Under the guideline, chief executive compensation at the company will require approval by a three-quarters vote of the independent directors, rather than just a majority.

On July 16, 1983, a day before Terence Tao’s eighth birthday, Ken Clements, an
expert on the education of mathematically gifted children, visited the boy’s home to
evaluate his abilities. As part of the evaluation, he gave Terry the following set of written questions. Terry answered orally, without writing anything down. All his answers were correct.

Aquiline Capital Partners, a private equity firm founded by former executives of Marsh & McLennan, said it closed its first fund at $1.1 billion. Aquiline will use the fund to make in investments in financial-services companies.

There is more to Boston Scientific than the troubled heart stent and defibrillator businesses for which it is best known - enough that the company predicts it could raise at least $1 billion by spinning off a portion to the public. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., said yesterday that it was considering a public stock offering for 18 percent to 25 percent of those other businesses, which are grouped under its Endosurgery division.

Bear Stearns was among the Wall Street firms that helped fuel the meltdown in the subprime mortgage sector by failing to adequately monitor the quality of the loans they were buying, a credit-research firm, CreditSights, concluded in a study. An unidentified Bear Stearns executive told The New York Post that the research firm "got it wrong, period."
Jotting on an elegant feat of hillside engineering.
The author announced that he planned to give away a film option to his latest novel, “You Don’t Love Me Yet.”
Spike’s reality show, which follows a a 4,000-mile road race, caters to the automobile aficionado who will understand and love all the unenlightening car talk and swearing.
Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five joined Patti Smith, the Ronettes, Van Halen and R.E.M. as inductees in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
At age 7, Terence Tao was taking high school math classes. At 31, he is one of the world’s top mathematicians, tackling an unusually broad range of problems.
Officials said the visit was an opportunity for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to exchange ideas on how to quell the violence and improve the quality of life.
Pope Benedict XVI strongly reasserted Tuesday the church’s opposition to abortion, euthanasia and gay marriage.
Betty Hutton was a singer and actress celebrated as a “blonde bombshell” of Hollywood musicals and comedies in the 1940s and 50s.
A Queens grand jury decision could come as early as this week on whether to indict any police officers in the shooting of an unarmed black man killed last fall hours before his wedding.
Sumner Redstone’s compensation for his role as chairman of CBS will be reduced after a shareholder lawsuit.
The Schoenfeld Theater played host to a celebration of the memory of Vincent Sardi Jr., the owner and manager of a landmark Broadway restaurant.
Gen. Peter Pace said that he should not have expressed his personal view that homosexual conduct was immoral.
If approved, the draft Climate Change Bill would require a 60 percent cut in carbon dioxide emissions by 2050.
President Felipe Calderón also urged President Bush, who is visiting Mexico, to create a temporary-worker program.

With a 25 year-old point guard, two juniors who are six years removed from high school and five players who are married, Brigham Young seems to have the maturity to manage the pressure of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
The Veterans Administration and its benefits programs need to be streamlined, a Congressional panel was told.
Morgan Tsvangirai was jailed and beaten for his role in a banned anti-government meeting.
The spectacular demolition ended a yearlong farewell to a classic 48-year-old resort that was, in its heyday, considered the ultimate in luxury and style.

An article on March 2 about the slaying of Ken Gorman, a supplier of medical marijuana in Denver, included an erroneous estimate from Allen St. Pierre, the executive director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, on the number of legal marijuana providers who have been killed nationally. Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

An article on March 2 about the slaying of Ken Gorman, a supplier of medical marijuana in Denver, included an erroneous estimate from Allen St. Pierre, the executive director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, on the number of legal marijuana providers who have been killed nationally. Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

An article on March 2 about the slaying of Ken Gorman, a supplier of medical marijuana in Denver, included an erroneous estimate from Allen St. Pierre, the executive director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, on the number of legal marijuana providers who have been killed nationally. Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about a campaign by Patrick M. Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, against a type of short selling, referred incorrectly to David Rocker, a short seller and former head of Rocker Partners. Mr. Rocker and his firm were not the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into possible manipulation of Overstock.com shares. (Mr. Rocker did testify in the course of an S.E.C. investigation of similar accusations against Gradient Analytics, a research firm. The S.E.C. recently sent a letter to Gradient saying that it would not pursue any action against the firm.).
The utility manipulated the Texas electric market in 2005, costing consumers $70 million and giving it $20 million in extra profits.
Until he justifies his four-year, $39.95 million contract, Carl Pavano may remain a human punch line.
The Nets could not have asked for a better time to play the Memphis Grizzlies.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to cut health care spending is running into staunch resistance from the upstate and suburban Republicans who lead the State Senate.
The New York Islanders were determined to save the season, despite the suspension of the bruising left wing Chris Simon

A wildfire burning among houses in the hills southeast of Los Angeles was ignited by flames from a stolen car that had been intentionally set ablaze during strong Santa Ana winds, a fire official said. Chief Ed Fleming of the Orange County Fire Authority Battalion stopped short of calling it arson, however, because it was not clear if the intent had been to start a wildfire or simply cover up criminal evidence. The three-square-mile fire had damaged one home but was 80 percent contained yesterday.

The commissioner of state social services called for the release of 21 factory workers arrested in an immigration raid last week, saying many had children with no one else to care for them. They were among 361 people taken in to custody after a raid at a factory that makes equipment and apparel for the military. Many of the suspected illegal immigrants were shipped to detention centers in Texas. Advocates had said the raid created a “humanitarian crisis.” The commissioner, Harry Spence, said the detainees he wanted released had children ages 2 to 16, all of whom were believed to have been born in the United States. Immigration officials in Texas were releasing 9 of the 21, said Russ Knocke, spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security.

Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles announced the retirement of the city zoo’s oldest elephant. The 46-year-old elephant, known as Ruby, will move to an animal sanctuary in Central California. Animal rights advocates had said elephants do not have enough space at the Los Angeles Zoo. Zookeepers have said Ruby is in good health, and the zoo director, John Lewis, has insisted that space alone is not the issue in caring for captive elephants. Ruby’s departure will leave the zoo with one elephant: Billy, age 22.

Gov. Bill Richardson signed a bill outlawing cockfighting, leaving Louisiana as the last state where the sport is legal. Supporters argue that cockfighting is a Hispanic tradition and that a ban would push it underground. Opponents say that it is animal cruelty and that it encourages illegal gambling.

Flooding caused by torrential rainstorms swept cars off roads in Central Texas, killing two people, the authorities said. One woman drowned after the car she was in was washed off a road north of Seguin, about 35 miles east of San Antonio; a second woman was found a quarter-mile downstream from her car in Rebecca Creek in Comal County, northeast of San Antonio. Much of the Hill Country outside San Antonio received at least three inches of rain in nine hours overnight.
Former President George Bush was treated at a hospital for dehydration after collapsing Sunday on a golf outing in Palm Springs.
Police hope to catch a man who punched and robbed two elderly women before he strikes again.
Prosecutors revealed they had offered help to a key witness who was in jail for violating probation on a drug conviction.
Conservationists fear a herd of rare white deer may be imperiled because of plans to build a $115 million ethanol and biofuel electricity production center.
White House officials consulted with the Justice Department in preparing a list of U.S. attorneys who would be removed.

Prime Minister Girija Prasad Koirala called for King Gyanendra to abdicate now instead of waiting for a vote on his future. Mr. Koirala’s interim government is organizing elections for an assembly that will determine whether Nepal will remain a kingdom. With demands growing to declare Nepal a republic, he said abdication would ease the transition to a permanent political setup in Nepal. “The king and crown prince are persons of ill repute,” he told reporters in Biratnagar, 125 miles southeast of Katmandu. In nearby Inurwa, officials imposed a curfew after five people were injured in clashes between Madhesis, the main ethnic group in region, and Maoists. The Madhesis seek a greater stake in government jobs and in Parliament.

The dean of the Seton Hall University School of Law said on Monday that Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s $1 million donation to the university played no role in the school’s decision to give a scholarship to Mr. Corzine’s former companion Carla Katz.

A soldier was charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of a fellow soldier in Afghanistan. Master Cpl. Jeffrey Walsh was killed Aug. 9 when a gun discharged during a patrol outside Kandahar in southern Afghanistan. Master Cpl. Robbie Fraser was charged with one count of manslaughter in the case and one count of negligent performance of duty. Master Corporal Fraser has returned to his base in Shilo, Manitoba. Both were in Afghanistan as members of the Princess Patricia’s Canadian Light Infantry.

The scores of all 900 students who took the SAT exam in South Korea in January will be canceled, the Educational Testing Service announced in South Korea on Friday. Tom Ewing, a spokesman for the testing service, which is responsible for security issues involving the College Board’s college admissions exam, said an investigation had shown that an unknown number of students had seen at least a portion of the test before the exam was given on Jan. 27. Because the number could not be determined, he said, all the scores were being canceled. Students will be able to retake the test or accept a refund. In the early 1990s, thousands of Graduate Record Exam scores were canceled across most of India, Mr. Ewing said, and in 1992 about 10,000 scores on the TOEFL, a test measuring fluency in English, were canceled in China.
Reuben Droughns and Brandon Jacobs will compete to become the Giants’ new starting running back.

A 13-year-old boy and a woman were killed Sunday night by stray bullets and five others were wounded as Ethiopian troops protecting government installations in Mogadishu battled with insurgents, witnesses said. About 20 heavily armed men engaged in a 15-minute gunbattle with Ethiopian troops at the Defense Ministry and then vanished, said a witness, Khalif Dahir. The boy was sitting in front of his house when he was hit in the head by a bullet, and the woman was fatally shot while traveling in a truck, the witnesses said. Sunday night’s gunbattle came hours after Somalia’s deputy defense minister said his troops were ready to fill a “power vacuum” in the restive capital, Mogadishu, with the help of African Union peacekeepers from Uganda.

An appeals court in Alexandria upheld the four-year prison sentence given to a blogger who had criticized conservative Muslims and was convicted of insulting Islam and Egypt’s president, court officials said. The blogger, Abdel Kareem Nabil, left, who is 22 and a former student at Al Azhar University, was sentenced last month to three years in prison on charges of insulting Islam and the Prophet Muhammad and inciting sectarian strife, and another year for insults to President Hosni Mubarak. Mr. Nabil, who wrote as Kareem Amer, was a scathing critic of conservative Muslims. His attacks on Al Azhar led the university to expel him in March 2006 and led to the trial. In his blog, he called Muhammad and his seventh-century followers “spillers of blood” for their teachings on warfare, a comment that was cited by the judge.

Four Seasons Hotels, the world’s largest operator of luxury hotels, reported a fourth-quarter profit on higher room revenue. Four Seasons, based in Toronto, said profit was $16.9 million, or 44 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $37.8 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. The company said it had higher costs in the year-earlier period related to retirement benefits and lower revenue after ending its lease for the Pierre in New York. Revenue rose 19 percent, to $69.8 million, from $58.5 million, because of an increase in hotel management and ownership fees. Revenue for each available room worldwide rose 14 percent, to $258.13; at properties in the United States, it was up 8.4 percent, to $297.83. Four Seasons agreed last month to be sold to a group of private investors.

Oxbow Carbon and Minerals Holdings raised its offer for the Great Lakes Carbon Income Fund to about 657 million Canadian dollars ($562 million), topping a higher bid from Rain Commodities and extending a bidding war for Great Lakes, a producer of carbon used to make aluminum. Oxbow raised its bid to 13.50 Canadian dollars a share for Great Lakes Carbon, which was above Rain’s bid of 13.25 Canadian dollars a share, Oxbow said. Oxbow, a unit of the privately held energy company Oxbow Group, bid 13 Canadian dollars a share on Wednesday. Oxbow is based in West Palm Beach, Fla., and Rain Commodities is based in India. Shares in Great Lakes Carbon trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

Alliance Boots, the British pharmacy chain, rejected a £9.7 billion ($18.7 billion) takeover proposal from the private equity group Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. Alliance Boots said that the 1,000 pence ($19.32) a share offer from Kohlberg Kravis and its largest shareholder, the Italian billionaire Stefano Pessina, undervalued the business and its prospects. The company’s board held an emergency meeting to discuss the friendly bid, made after the London Stock Exchange closed on Friday. Alliance Boots, formed after Alliance UniChem and the Boots Group merged last year, said the board did not believe that the offer “reflects the fundamental value of the company or the attractive prospects, opportunities and synergies available to Alliance Boots following the very recent completion of its merger.” Alliance Boots has retail operations in six European countries and in Thailand. It is also a pharmaceutical wholesaler in Europe for more than 125,000 pharmacies, hospitals and health centers.

The Blackstone Group sold the majority of its property holdings in Germany to institutional investors for about 1.6 billion euros ($2.1 billion), the company said yesterday. Blackstone said it had sold a majority stake in its Vitus subsidiary to a consortium including Round Hill Capital and Morley Fund Management, the wealth-management unit of the British insurer Aviva. Blackstone bought Vitus, which has more than 31,000 apartments, from a German holding company, WCM, at the end of 2004.

WASHINGTON, March 12 — D. Kyle Sampson has never worked full time as a federal prosecutor. But for much of the Bush administration he played a considerable role in vetting who served in the Justice Department. And last year he used his post as chief of staff to the attorney general to make a bid for a job as a United States attorney in Utah.
Strictly forbidden by the U.S. military in Iraq and Afghanistan, alcohol is a factor in a growing number of crimes by troops.
Families whose babies suffer from fatal conditions are turning to specialized hospice programs for help.
Wall Street lenders cut their credit lines to New Century Financial, forcing it ever closer to bankruptcy.
The resignation last week of Coach Pokey Chatman has fueled speculation and rumors in the absence of a specific explanation.
Vice President Dick Cheney said those seeking to limit President Bush’s authority to spend money on the war were “telling the enemy simply to watch the clock and wait us out.”
A report has accused the government of organizing killings and rapes against its own population and has criticized the international response as inadequate.
Hinting that he would play in 2008 if he remains healthy, Barry Bonds also seemed to christen Alex Rodriguez as the next challenger to home run records.
Many top executives have urged the rollback of laws passed in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals.
Elite athletes in many sports use the “rest high, train low” strategy to improve endurance. Can it help sled dogs?

Meaghan Francella made a 4-foot birdie putt and beat Annika Sorenstam on the fourth hole of a playoff yesterday to win the rain-delayed MasterCard Classic in Huixquilucan, Mexico, for her first L.P.G.A. victory. Francella, 24, making only her sixth start on the Tour, closed with a three-under 69 for an 11-under 205. Sorenstam, making her first start of the season, had four birdies on the front nine and three more on the back before taking a bogey-5 at the 16th. She finished with a 66.
The F.D.A. is suggesting that the fresh-cut produce industry constantly monitor and control vulnerable places in the production cycle where the bacteria are likely to form.

Abby Wambach scored two goals and Carli Lloyd also scored, leading the United States past Sweden, 3-2, last night in Vila Real De Santo Antonio, Portugal, for a place in the Algarve Cup final. Lloyd has four goals in the tournament. The United States, which won the tournament in 2000 and from 2003 to 2005, will play Denmark in tomorrow’s final. Denmark advanced despite a 3-0 loss to Germany.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer has made New York the latest state to travel down a murky legal road when it comes to the civil commitment of sex offenders.

The track coach Remi Korchemny agreed yesterday to permanently stay out of elite-level coaching, marking the first time a United States Anti-Doping Agency case has led to a coach being banished for doping violations. The case is significant because it shows that the doping agency will pursue coaches, in addition to athletes.The doping agency brought charges against Korchemny, 74, last November. He is best known as the coach for the sprinters Kelli White and Dwain Chambers, both of whom tested positive for banned substances and were suspended.Korchemny, who was sentenced to probation in the Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative case for supplying the banned stimulant modafinil, was essentially retired before agreeing that he will not participate with any organization that recognizes the World Anti-Doping Code.

The United States 8-kilometer running championship, to be held Saturday in Central Park, lost a star yesterday when Dathan Ritzenhein withdrew because of an injured left foot. His coach, Brad Hudson, said that Ritzenhein, the 24-year-old Olympian, sustained a minor injury while running last week on grass in Tallahassee, Fla. If Ritzenhein’s recovery stays on schedule, he will run in the Cardinal Invitational next month in Palo Alto, Calif., and probably the Healthy Kidney 10 kilometers in May in Central Park.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about a campaign by Patrick M. Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, against a type of short selling, referred incorrectly to David Rocker, a short seller and former head of Rocker Partners. Mr. Rocker and his firm were not the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into possible manipulation of Overstock.com shares. (Mr. Rocker did testify in the course of an S.E.C. investigation of similar accusations against Gradient Analytics, a research firm. The S.E.C. recently sent a letter to Gradient saying that it would not pursue any action against the firm.).
To the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball committee, it was not what have you done lately, but what have you done all season.
President Bush faces difficulties as he tries to revive what many Mexicans see as a moribund partnership.
The stent maker said it was considering a public stock offering for 18 percent to 25 percent of its Endosurgery division.
Three games in which the the N.H.L.’s highest-scoring team was held to five goals have raised concerns among fans of freewheeling hockey.
Halliburton’s move to Dubai sends the message that even in the new economy, some of the old rules still apply, including that location matters.
The formula for picking a surprise team may be simple: write the wrong name and get lucky, or fill out several brackets with varying winners.
It’s blossom time in the almond orchards of California’s Central Valley.
The hedge fund industry seems resigned to no longer be a wallflower in Washington as it joins the lobbying dance with Congress.
A man who had been sitting with the suicide attacker was caught while trying to flee, then found to have explosives concealed on his body as well.
Forward Josh Heytvelt, charged with felony drug possession, has left a substantial void on a team unaccustomed to scandal.
Services in the Bronx for 10 victims of a fast-moving house fire were the culmination of days of heartbreak.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy has abandoned efforts to produce a new immigration bill and is proposing using legislation produced last March as a starting point for negotiations.
Lottery Numbers.
Outside the mosque holding the funerals of the 10 victims of a residential fire, it seemed at times as if a corner of the Bronx had been given over to the city’s African Muslims.
The Weinstein Company announced it had acquired Halston, the legendary fashion brand, in partnership with a private equity firm.
Republicans see their party as divided and are not satisfied with their choice of presidential candidates, a Times/CBS News poll found.
The explosion halted passenger train service and temporarily shut a section of the New York State Thruway, the authorities said.

A March 7 editorial on the conviction of Lewis Libby said incorrectly that Joseph Wilson IV was sent by the State Department in 2002 to Niger to check out a report that Iraq had tried to buy uranium there. Mr. Wilson was sent by the C.I.A.
A group of protesters from Code Pink, a women’s antiwar group, have camped in front of the home of Speaker Nancy Pelosi in San Francisco.
City officials in Hazleton, Pa., adopted ordinances intended to drive away illegal immigrants by punishing local landlords for renting to them and employers for giving them jobs.
A once-hip dining place on Union Square has become the latest restaurant cited for health code violations after the closing of a rat-infested Taco Bell.
The competition for the final spot in the Mets’ rotation figures to intensify, with Mike Pelfrey eclipsing Chan Ho Park.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the giant buyout firm, said it would pay $6.9 billion to take the discount retailer Dollar General private.
Some of the lawyers who helped negotiate a proposed settlement with State Farm withdrew their request for a federal judge to approve the multimillion-dollar deal.
After the news that the Purple Eagles would face Florida A&M in a play-in game, Coach Joe Mihalich said the committee had done his team a favor.
Members of Britain’s House of Lords declared that their chamber had functioned pretty well without elections for hundreds of years and that there was no need to rush into anything now.
A compromise by TV networks and advertisers on a system to count how many people watch commercials has hit a snag.
Money spent on computing technology delivers gains in worker productivity that are three to five times those of other investments, a new study said.
Pakistani police officers wielding batons beat lawyers in Lahore who were protesting government moves to fire the country’s chief justice.
Congressional Democrats suggested that Halliburton’s relocation was possibly part of an effort to dodge U.S. taxes and investigations.
The judge had been repeatedly rebuked by federal appeals judges for his hostile questioning of asylum-seekers.
Few landmarks of New York are as clearly divided between locals and out-of-town visitors as the Staten Island ferry.
A jury ruled that Merck’s painkiller contributed to an Idaho postal worker’s heart attack, and awarded him $20 million in damages.
Strikers at the Ingalls shipyard in Pascagoula, Miss., said they were demanding better wages and benefits to make up for sharp post-Katrina price increases.
A gap of less than a foot stands between the city and its goal of rejuvenating rail freight traffic between Staten Island and the rest of the country.
In October 1983, Vice Adm. Joseph Metcalf III was given less than two days to plan and start the controversial invasion of the Caribbean island of Grenada to overturn a Marxist coup.
The casino company said it hired Merrill Lynch to help it explore strategic alternatives, which could include the possibility of a sale.
Investors looked past problems in the subprime lending sector to another parade of acquisition deals.
A federal judge ordered a halt to seed sales and banning any planting of the crop after March 30.
Israeli officials, pressed by Washington, are suddenly finding much to praise in a Saudi peace proposal offered at the height of a series of Palestinian suicide bombings.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,184 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
Ford will raise $848 million toward its overhaul plan by selling Aston Martin, its British luxury sports car brand.
The bill would make New York City one of the first jurisdictions in the country to prohibit the use of metal bats in high school baseball games.
The departing American ambassador said that he did not see the Taliban as the major threat it appeared to represent a year or two ago.
Senator Chuck Hagel said he would concentrate on helping secure an end to the Iraq war.
The blaze killed three men and one woman, ranging in age from 23 to 27, after it spread upward from a  second-floor landing.
Express Scripts said it would not make a higher offer for Caremark, which some analysts said might mean a victory for CVS.
Thirteen tribes, along with environmentalists, had appealed the decision to allow spraying of treated wastewater on mountains considered sacred.
Officials believe that the discovery of four access ramps to the World Trade Center might lead to material from the collapse of the twin towers.

The federal Justice Department filed a lawsuit yesterday against the city Transportation Department, claiming that city officials discriminated against women when hiring bridge painters. The city, which employs about 100 painters to maintain about 700 bridges, has never hired or offered to hire a woman for the job, despite applications from several women, the suit said. The city has hired 13 bridge painters in the past 10 years, and four of the 56 applicants were women, according to the lawsuit. Georgia Pestana, the chief of the Labor and Employment Division of the city Law Department, said in a statement, “We are confident the court will determine that D.O.T.’s hiring practices for bridge painters comply with civil service requirements and are gender neutral.”.
Lt. Gen. Kevin C. Kiley is the third high-ranking official to lose his job over the shabby treatment of wounded troops.

A reputed captain in the Genovese crime family who was a fugitive for more than 10 years was arrested in Manhattan on Friday night in connection with a 1977 killing in Bridgewater, the state attorney general’s office said. The suspect, Michael Coppola, was charged with shooting John Lardiere five times outside the Red Bull Inn a few hours after Mr. Lardiere left prison on a furlough, the authorities said. Mr. Coppola disappeared from his Spring Lake home in 1996, just before being charged in the killing. In 2003, the authorities received tips that Mr. Coppola was in Florida, but they were unable to find him. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A third murder charge was brought yesterday against a factory worker accused of killing two women in the early 1990s, according to prosecutors. The suspect, Altemio Sanchez, left, was arrested in January after the police secretly collected his DNA from utensils he used at a restaurant. Mr. Sanchez, 49, who has been charged with killing Linda Yelem, 22, in 1990, and Majane Mazur, 32, in 1992, was charged yesterday in State Supreme Court with killing Joan Diver, 45, last September, said Frank Clark, the Erie County district attorney. Mr. Sanchez has pleaded not guilty.

The state’s child welfare agency and a national children’s rights group reached an agreement yesterday that requires Connecticut to do more to help find permanent homes for children in foster care. The agreement provides increased services to children younger than 12 living in group facilities and puts a special focus on children who have been in the system a year or more. The group, Children’s Rights, filed a class-action lawsuit in 1989 that resulted in the placement of the Department of Children and Families under federal oversight in 1991.

The city may use secret police intelligence in civil rights lawsuits to defend its policies during the 2004 Republican National Convention, but it will be penalized for failing to disclose the information earlier in the case, a federal judge ruled yesterday. The New York Civil Liberties Union, which is suing the city on behalf of seven people who claim they were wrongly arrested and detained during the convention, had argued that intelligence reports and testimony from David Cohen, the deputy police commissioner for intelligence, should be barred because the city missed deadlines for disclosing that Mr. Cohen and the documents would be part of its defense. Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV agreed that city lawyers had “offered no legitimate excuse” for being late and said the city would have to pay legal fees and other costs as punishment.

A Federal District Court judge has dismissed a jury and declared a mistrial in an international arms smuggling case that was scheduled to begin yesterday. The judge, Richard J. Holwell, acted after prosecutors said that their informant, Kelly Davis, had admitted himself to a psychiatric hospital for evaluation and had been on a suicide watch. In the case, Arthur Solomonyan, a 26-year-old Armenian who lived for a time in New York, and six others were charged in 2005 with arms smuggling and plotting to import military weapons for illegal sale. The prosecutors said they were ready to proceed without Mr. Davis, but defense lawyers said they wanted to question Mr. Davis about his role in the case. “He certainly is a key witness in the story that’s going to be told by either side,” Judge Holwell said, and he set a new trial date of June 4.

Officials said yesterday that they had filed a lawsuit accusing an energy company of overcharging the state more than $14 million since 1992 to heat and cool state office buildings. Attorney General Richard Blumenthal and Public Works Commissioner James Fleming said the company, TEN Companies Inc., had ignored requests to provide the state with information justifying the charges. In the lawsuit, filed in Hartford Superior Court, the state claims TEN did not follow an agreed-upon formula to determine charges for heating and cooling the buildings. There was no response yesterday to a message seeking comment that was left with a spokesman for CTG Resources Inc., the parent company of TEN. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Twenty students were arrested yesterday at an antiwar protest in an Army and Navy recruiting station at 157 Chambers Street. The protest began at noon when members of the group, Students for a Democratic Society, marched from the campuses of Pace University and the New School and converged near the recruitment center. The 20 staged a sit-in while about 40 others stood outside chanting antiwar slogans, banging steel drums and waving posters. Organizers said that the students were demonstrating against military recruitment practices, and that the protest was intended to call attention to the fourth anniversary of the start of the Iraq war, which will be next week. The police said the 20 would be charged with criminal trespass.

An Assembly committee approved a measure yesterday that would bar the state’s pension funds from investing in any foreign company with ties to or doing work in Iran. Citing the Iranian regime’s harsh denunciations of Israel, the bill’s sponsor, Assemblyman Neil M. Cohen, a Democrat of Union, said the measure would also require the divestment of securities in any such company to send a message that New Jersey had no support for “the Holocaust-like genocide” embodied in statements by Iranian leaders.

The body of a Brooklyn teenager who was reported missing last week has been found in the Hudson River, the police said. The teenager, Romona Mullings, 19, who was a pharmacy student at the Kingsborough Community College, was reported missing last Thursday by her family when she did not answer her cellphone. The telephone and global positioning technology led the police to the river, where they recovered her body on Sunday afternoon, not far from the Glenwood Metro-North railroad station. The cause of death was under investigation yesterday.
The government will offer households as much as $80 to convert TVs to receive digital broadcasts before the end of analog broadcasts in 2009.
Johnson & Johnson received subpoenas from federal prosecutors related to sales and marketing of three drugs.
The $2.6 billion purchase will give UnitedHealth, the nation's largest health insurance company, its first managed care presence in Nevada.
Delta Zeta attracted controversy when it evicted two-thirds of its DePauw University members late last year.
Mrs. d’Addario was the school’s ever-present doyenne who helped expand several programs, including pre-professional training, and helped form several junior touring ensembles.
Swisscom offered 3.74 billion euros, or $4.93 billion, to acquire FastWeb, one of the largest fixed-line phone companies in Italy.
Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin formally endorsed his political rival, the center-right candidate Nicolas Sarkozy, for president.
The executives were accused of committing accounting fraud to meet earnings forecasts and investor expectations.
The groups said their leaders had been beaten and hospitalized after the police arrested them during the violent breakup of an antigovernment rally.
Iraqis will lose out if their oil reserves are denationalized.
The Securities and Exchange Commission should stop pretending it can maintain fairness in the markets. There are other ways to punish criminal behavior on Wall Street.
Some companies are reviving travel, with options on destinations, as bonuses for their best workers.

FLYERTALK.COM SOLD FlyerTalk.com, the Web site with scores of vibrant forums on frequent-flier programs, loyalty points and travel, has been sold to Internet Brands by Randy Petersen, who founded the site almost nine years ago. Mr. Petersen will continue as a consultant for four years. In e-mail messages to members and to site moderators, Mr. Petersen said he decided to sell only after “plenty of sleepless nights.” Other travel companies that had expressed interest, he said, included American Express, Expedia, Travelocity and Condé Nast Interactive. Internet Brands operates e-commerce sites for cars, real estate, mortgages and travel. Mr. Petersen said he chose Internet Brands, which was not the highest bidder, because “they weren’t interested in making any changes” to FlyerTalk.com.

The Senegalese company’s piece on genocide, “Fagaala,” was so evenhanded it could easily have been mistaken for an unhurried, smoothly paced evocation of everyday life.
The company accepted a Harvard professor’s proposal that the chief executive’s pay be subject to approval by three-quarters of the independent directors.
Regis Philbin to have heart bypass surgery, Jonathan Lethem offers film option to his latest novel, a record label for Starbucks and more culture news.
Besides having some of the best first names on Broadway, the cast of “Journey’s End” shares a raucous sense of humor and a palpable camaraderie.

New this week is the four-disc boxed set “Animated Soviet Propaganda,” which opens a window on a lost art from a lost world.
The scar-busting properties of vitamin E are overstated, according to most studies.

The installation of Mr. Alÿs’s performance art at David Zwirner captures in a nutshell the thinking behind some of the most interesting art today.

“The Attic” is a smart, sensitive play about the phenomenon of hikikomori, in which Japanese youths isolate themselves in their rooms for months or even years at a time.
