To the Editor: Re ''The Failed Attorney General'' (editorial, March 11): Thank you for yet another superb editorial about the Bush imperial presidency. Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales is worthy of your criticism. Though I heartily applaud your recent series of editorials along those lines, they somehow remind me of artillery fire that has not yet found its proper target.

A federal appeals panel blocked a ski resort's plan to make artificial snow by spraying treated wastewater on mountains that Indian tribes consider sacred. In a unanimous ruling, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, overturned a lower court ruling from January 2006 that would have let the resort, the Arizona Snowbowl, to proceed with the snowmaking and other upgrades on the San Francisco Peaks near Flagstaff. Thirteen tribes, along with the Sierra Club and other environmentalists, had appealed the decision. They said using wastewater, no matter how clean, would offend deities and spiritually contaminate herbs and other plants used for medicine and religious ceremonies. RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
FIUME--Sarah. Beloved mother, mother - in - law, grandmother, sister, and great-grandmother. Services Wednesday 11:00 am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY.

Senior Bush administration officials began a series of high-level discussions on Monday with top executives from Wall Street, corporations and the major accounting firms. Many of the executives have urged the rollback of laws passed in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals as well as limits to liability from government and shareholder lawsuits. Vice President Dick Cheney opened the conference by speaking to the group at a private dinner on Monday evening sponsored by the Treasury Department. The group, which invited senior Republican and Democratic lawmakers, was also addressed by Warren E. Buffett, the investor and chairman of Berkshire Hathaway.

A Political Memo article on Thursday, about the challenges Rudolph W. Giuliani faces in running for president as a former New York City mayor, referred incorrectly to the timing of the two-term presidency of another New Yorker, Theodore Roosevelt. He began serving more than 100 years ago, in 1901; his presidency was not ''almost 100 years ago.'' A correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to Mr. Roosevelt's time as a public official in New York City. He was a police commissioner, not a former mayor.

Regis Philbin, the host of ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' announced to his audience yesterday that he would undergo heart bypass surgery tomorrow. Mr. Philbin, below, said he had received the news while he was on vacation after experiencing chest pains and other symptoms. After tests and consultations with several physicians, he said this was the course that all decided to take. In speaking with his co-host, Kelly Ripa, Mr. Philbin, 75, expressed a preference for angioplasty, a procedure that he underwent successfully 14 years ago. But he said his doctors told him he could be helped only by a full bypass. ''Anyway, I've got to do it, darn it,'' Mr. Philbin said on the air. ''I don't want to do it. Nobody wants to do it, I guess.'' He said he had spoken with his friend David Letterman, who had bypass surgery seven years ago, and that he had recommended the procedure. No timetable was set for Mr. Philbin's return, but the show will use guest hosts until he comes back. Today and tomorrow morning Anderson Cooper of CNN is scheduled to sit in. Damien Fahey, a host of MTV's ''TRL,'' is scheduled for Thursday and Friday. Other guest hosts who have agreed to appear include Howie Mandel, Neil Patrick Harris, Jeff Probst, Pat Sajak, Martin Short and Donald Trump. BILL CARTER

STEIN--Irwin L., on March 12, 2007 at age 83. Beloved husband of Claire of 62 years, devoted father of David (Karen) and Roni (David). Cherished grandfather of Rebecca, Richard (Pamela), Deborah and Andrew (Jaclyn) and great-grandfather of Mara. A kind and gentle man. 60 year member of the Goodfellowship Corset Club. Life Master bridge player, avid fisherman and great story teller. He will be lovingly remembered and deeply missed. Donations may be made to Hadassah or Sons of Israel Nyack.

Frick Collection Susan Platts, the young Canadian mezzo-soprano who in 2004 was selected to train with Jessye Norman as part of a mentoring project sponsored by Rolex, gave a recital of German lieder and art song on Sunday at the Frick Collection.

To the Editor: Re ''A Diagnosis for One, but an Impact Shared'' (Cases, March 6): It takes a lot of time, plus the help of a skilled family therapist, for a sibling of someone in recovery from an eating disorder to feel ''safe'' enough to express the complex emotions that swirl around such a maddeningly tenacious disease.

To the Editor: Re ''A Toast to Evolvability and Its Promise of Surprise'' (March 6): Your columnist Natalie Angier compares the excitement of ''the periodic and often radical overhauling of an existing cell type, body plan, limb shape, or brain design into something new and useful'' to the blah of unsurprising ''blue-green algae decorating an Australian rock,'' going on to say that ''an algal colony has yet to throw me a surprise party.''

Family to gather at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Wednesday March 14, at 9:30 am. Graveside services 11 am at the Wellwood Cemetery. Please call Frank E. Most of the Yankees took the team bus to City of Palms Park on Monday. The starting pitcher, Carl Pavano, made his own arrangements. It could have been an adventure. ''I'm glad he got here -- because he drove,'' Manager Joe Torre said, referring to Pavano's famous Florida car accident last August. ''I just kiddingly went by him and said, 'Whew, you're here.' ''

It's not quite a link-up between the Montagues and the Capulets, but in this superheated political environment it comes close. John Weaver, right, the senior strategist to Senator John McCain of Arizona, is marrying Angela Hession, who was the deputy chief of staff to Rudolph W. Giuliani right through his last day as mayor of New York at the end of 2001. Mr. Weaver and Ms. Hession met when he went to New York after the Sept. 11 attacks to help the city with communication efforts. Ms. Hession left Mr. Giuliani's inner circle when his term ended. In addition to marrying Mr. Weaver this summer, she is also now a strategist for Mr. McCain, who is Mr. Giuliani's chief rival at this point for the Republican presidential nomination.

Q. Would it really have been possible for Europeans to infect Native Americans with the smallpox virus by giving them blankets used by other victims? How long could the virus live on a blanket? A. It would be at least theoretically possible, experts at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said, though some historians doubt that the plan to infect enemy tribes, which the British general Lord Jeffery Amherst notoriously wrote about in 1763, during the French and Indian War, was actually carried out.

FRIEDMAN--A. Lisa, Ph.D., Eminent psychologist. Beloved wife of Bill for 66 years, cherished mother and mother-in-law of Susanne, Nina, Paul, Myron and Jean, nonny and grandnonny, died on March 10, 2007, aged 88. Born May 2, 1918 into a poor, working class, Sephardic Jewish family in New York City and forced by the Depression to leave college, Lisa went on to become Valedictorian of her Nursing class at Lebanon Hospital in 1939. While raising three teenagers, she completed both her Masters degree in Counseling and Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology at NYU. Lisa was a pioneer in the field of Multiple Family Marathon Therapy. She was a disciple of Danica Deutsch, the daughter of Alfred Adler, completing her internship at the Alfred Adler Institute in New York City. Lisa earned the highest distinction in her profession by earning the Diplomate in Marriage and Family Counseling. At the age of 80, she attained a degree in Neuropharmacology and continued to practice well into her 80s. Influenced in her early years by the Depression and the fight against fascism, she followed in the tradition of her activist, immigrant parents. Her personal and professional lives merged as she became an advocate for the poor and those who were not given a fair start in life. Drawing on her own life's struggles, embraced by a loving family, Lisa fervently believed in the capacity of the individual to overcome adversity and turn obstacles into stepping stones toward a rich, meaningful and purposeful life.

An article in the special Business of Green section on Wednesday about nontoxic and biodegradable products in restaurant kitchens misspelled the surname of a farmer who uses oil from a deep fryer to run his diesel truck, and it misstated part of the name of his farm. He is Michael Yezzi, not Yessi, and he owns Flying Pigs Farm, not Flying Pigs Farms.

MAYERS--Mollie. March 10, adored wife of the late Nathan Mayers and mother of the late Natalie Gordon. Beloved mother of Joyce (Dan) English, and grandmother of Laurie (Steve), David (Carlye), Stacey (Neil), Paul (Katie), and Ben (Kristin), and seven great-grandchildren.

Representative Ron Paul, a nine-term Republican from Texas, formally announced his presidential candidacy on Monday. It will be the second presidential bid for Mr. Paul, who ran in 1988 on the Libertarian line and got four-tenths of 1 percent of the vote. In an appearance on ''Washington Journal'' on C-Span, Mr. Paul said this time around, he had raised at least $50,000 ''with very little effort'' and had already spent three days in New Hampshire.

A music review on Thursday about the jazz trumpeter Ralph Alessi and his band, at the Center for Improvisational Music in Brooklyn, misidentified the organization in which his brother, Joseph, is a principal trombonist. It is the New York Philharmonic, not the Metropolitan Opera.

(Spike) BULLRUN Another new competition series, this one pitting 12 teams of two drivers against one another in a cross-country car race. Auto challenges and weekly eliminations are obstacles to the $200,000 prize. Tonight the drivers will choose between mapping their own journey and traveling a longer, safer route. The former professional wrestler Bill Goldberg is the host. 10 P.M. (HBO) COSTAS NOW Bob Costas begins a new season of this sports-news show with an episode devoted to college athletics. Mr. Costas will lead a panel discussion on the biggest issues confronting college sports; interview Duke basketball's head coach, Mike Krzyzewski; and take a look back at the 1957 N.C.A.A. championship, when the University of North Carolina defeated Kansas, 54-53, in an edge-of-your-seat triple-overtime final. 10 P.M. (Sundance) THE LAST TEMPTATION OF CHRIST (1988). Martin Scorsese was nominated for an Academy Award for his direction of this film, but he drew plenty of criticism as well from those offended by a perhaps too-human version of Jesus subject to all kinds of temptations, including lust. Paul Schrader adapted the screenplay from the 1951 novel by Nikos Kazantzakis. Willem Dafoe is Jesus, Harvey Keitel plays Judas and Barbara Hershey is Mary Magdalene.

An obituary on Wednesday about Martin A. Trow, a sociologist of education, incorrectly described one of the three co-authors of ''Union Democracy: The Internal Politics of the International Typographical Union'' (1956). Seymour Martin Lipset was then a member of the Columbia faculty, not a fellow doctoral candidate of Mr. Trow and James S. Coleman, who worked with Mr. Lipset on the project and were listed as co-authors.

Beyond a simple test of talent, the N.C.A.A. tournament is a caldron of pressure. And Brigham Young, more than any team in the field, would seem to have the maturity to handle it. The point guard is 25. Two top reserves are juniors, but they are six years removed from high school. Five of the players are married, and a sixth is engaged.
To the Editor: Re ''To Have, Hold and Cherish, Until Bedtime'' (front page, March 11): Thank you for removing the stigma attached to married couples sleeping in separate bedrooms.

Be Careful With That! The Italian Senator Paolo Amato, above left, chained himself to a column outside the Uffizi Gallery in Florence to protest the loan of Leonardo da Vinci's ''Annunciation'' to the Tokyo National Museum, The Associated Press reported. Culture Minister Francesco Rutelli insisted on the loan, despite the contention of about 100 leading cultural figures that the piece is too fragile to travel. The 38-by-85-inch tempera on wood painting, which Leonardo did between 1472 and 1475, shows the archangel Gabriel kneeling before Mary and informing her that she will conceive Jesus Christ. It was insured for 100 million euros (about $125 million) and secured in a waterproof and fireproof case for the trip. The painting is to be shown from next Tuesday through June 17 as part of the Italian Spring festival, a series of events promoting Italian culture. ''The Annunciation'' has been on the road before, but not since 1945. New Artistic Director For Bush Theater The board of directors of the 35-year-old Bush Theater in London announced the appointment of Josie Rourke as artistic director. Ms. Rourke, below, a Cambridge graduate, was an assistant director at the Donmar Warehouse, where she directed four productions, including, most recently, David Mamet's ''Cryptogram.'' She has also directed at the Royal Court Theater, and directed the premiere of ''World Music,'' by Steve Waters, at the Sheffield Crucible and the Donmar Warehouse. Last year Ms. Rourke directed Shakespeare's ''King John'' for the Royal Shakespeare Company's Complete Works Festival. ''I hope to continue to find and develop new voices and enable established playwrights to enter uncharted territories,'' Ms. Rourke wrote in an e-mail message. She replaces Mike Bradwell in April. Another Time for Ragtime The New York City Opera's scheduled production of Stephen Flaherty and Lynn Ahrens's ''Ragtime,'' planned for an April 8, 2008, opening, has been postponed indefinitely. The announcement cited the unexpected schedule conflicts of the director Frank Galati and the choreographer Graciela Daniele as the cause. Carnegie Hall announced that the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham would replace Dawn Upshaw as the soloist for a performance with the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra on March 31. Ms. Graham will perform Ravel's ''Shéhérazade,'' which will replace Britten's ''Illuminations'' in the program. Ms. Upshaw is canceling her appearance because of fatigue after a recent course of chemotherapy. E-N-D-N-O-T-E ''Broadway Night at the Bee'' is scheduled for Sunday's 7:30 performance of ''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee.'' Christine Ebersole (''Grey Gardens''), Raúl Esparza (''Company'') and Brian Stokes Mitchell (''Man of La Mancha'') will join the cast for that night only as guest spellers.

An article in Business Day yesterday about a dispute between the Democratic Party and Fox News over a presidential debate in Nevada referred incorrectly to one Democratic candidate who dropped out of the debate shortly before it was canceled. Bill Richardson is the current governor of New Mexico, not a former one.

Washington Irving High School Now that Leon Fleisher has recovered the use of his right hand, he has two repertories to choose from: the standard canon, which he is gradually reclaiming, and the repertory for left hand only, which has kept him going since 1965, when a neurological condition left his right hand incapacitated. At his recital on Saturday evening, part of the Peoples' Symphony Concerts at Washington Irving High School, Mr. Fleisher played works from both columns.

Reuben Droughns met Brandon Jacobs for the first time yesterday. The two will compete to become the Giants' starting running back. ''My God, I thought he was something,'' Droughns said when it was suggested that the 6-foot-4, 265-pound Jacobs looks like a defensive end. ''I had to look up and say hi to him. He's a nice-sized guy, man.''

The acclaimed teenager from the Dominican Republic assumed his stance in the batter's box yesterday at the aged Municipal Stadium in Pompano Beach, Fla., where the Texas Rangers once conducted spring training. Nearby stood Ismael Cruz, the Mets' director of international scouting. The player, José José, a 16-year-old outfielder, has drawn the interest of a number of baseball's big-money teams.
BRECKWOLDT--Christine. All of our love on your birthday and always. Sue, Mark and Buddy

A soldier was charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of a fellow soldier in Afghanistan. Master Cpl. Jeffrey Walsh was killed Aug. 9 when a gun discharged during a patrol outside Kandahar in southern Afghanistan. Master Cpl. Robbie Fraser was charged with one count of manslaughter in the case and one count of negligent performance of duty. Master Corporal Fraser has returned to his base in Shilo, Manitoba. Both were in Afghanistan as members of the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry. CHRISTOPHER MASON

That fat people are jolly is almost certainly a myth, but a study published yesterday has found a strong association between higher body mass index, or B.M.I., and lower risk of suicide. In a 16-year study that followed more than 45,000 male health professionals, researchers found a steady decrease in suicides as B.M.I. increased, even after controlling for variables including smoking, dietary factors, physical activity, marital status and alcohol use. There were 131 suicides during the time of the study.

Tenri Cultural Institute It's hard to know what to make of contemporary Japanese music. A decade ago a lot of it sounded as if it were stuck in the tonality wars of the 1950s and 1960s, allied to the most astringent currents of Serialism. It is probably no accident that Toru Takemitsu and Somei Satoh, the Japanese composers most successful in the West, kept clear of that battlefield and forged their own styles.

A March 7 editorial on the conviction of Lewis Libby said incorrectly that Joseph Wilson IV was sent by the State Department in 2002 to Niger to check out a report that Iraq had tried to buy uranium there. Mr. Wilson was sent by the C.I.A.

MIRZA--Muzzafar ''Muzzi''. We mourn the loss of our founder, partner and dear friend, Muzzi Mirza. Muzzi was endlessly creative, constantly energized, and a problem solver who always found the way through the most convoluted maze and taught us how to have fun doing it. Muzzi's remarkable warmth and open spirit resulted in a world where once you spent an hour with him you felt as if he was your friend -and he was. For Muzzi, the glass was not merely half full, it was always overflowing. He made us all better and what we do and in who we are. To his wife, Sue, and to his children, Alexander, Christina and Sean, we loved him too, and will miss him dearly. Odyssey Investment Partners $(6$)MIRZA--Muzzafar ''Muzzi''. For the past 17 years, Muzzi was my colleague, partner and friend. We taught each other our business. We argued constantly, laughed uproariously, struggled through bad and good times, and in the end worked it out everyday. He was a living antidote to pessimism, and enemy to gloom, the champion of keeping our options open and lifting spirit. When we wandered, Muzzi was ''not confused''. I am not confused now, Muzzi. It was very, very special. Stephen Berger $(6$)MIRZA--Muzzafar ''Muzzi'', beloved father, husband, son and best friend to so many people, passed away at home in Greenwich, CT after a courageous battle with cancer, on Saturday, March 10, 2007. Muzzi was born in Lahore, Pakistan in 1958 and moved to the US in 1976. Muzzi is survived by his beloved wife of 18 years, Susan, his precious children Alexander, Christina and Sean, his mother Anis, brother Mustafa and his wife Liz and their children, mother-in-law Patricia Scribner, brother-in-law Mark Scribner and his wife Dawn, his sisterin-law Nancy Ruscheinski and her husband Edward, his loyal companion Midnight and many loving nieces, nephews, cousins and close friends. He was predeceased by his father Akbar Mirza and father-in-law Howard A. Scribner, Jr. Muzzi is simply irreplaceable - there will never be another like him. He leaves all of us with wonderful memories of joy and laughter and the gift of his love and extraordinary generosity. A unique combination of keen intelligence, clarity of thought, sharp wit and persuasive charisma led to his extraordinary success. He was a founding partner of Odyssey Investment Partners, LLC, a leading private equity investment manager, and was a principal in its predecessor firm, Odyssey Partners. He served on the Board of Directors of Aviation Technologies, Inc., Dresser, Inc., United Site Services, Inc., Neff Corp, Norcross Safety Products, LLC., and Tri-Star Electronics, Inc. Prior to joining Odyssey, Muzzi was the head of the merchant banking group at GE Capital Corporation. Muzzi began his career at Marine Midland Bank after graduating from Claremont McKenna College and obtaining a graduate degree from the American Graduate School of International Management. Muzzi exemplified Rudyard Kiplings ideal man, equally comfortable ''talking with the crowds and walking with Kings.'' His huge heart allowed him to embrace everyone he touched. His simplicity, warmth and legendary zest for life were contagious and changed many lives for the better. His passions included golf, cars, music, the ocean and ''the art of the deal.'' He was a great host and loved the company of family and friends. He was completely outrageous, but with his warmth and humor, he disarmed everyone from family and friends to colleagues and caddies. People loved being with him because he would inspire them with his own joy for life, lifting them beyond their own capabilities. Muzzi was a wonderful husband and father who loved and cherished his family. He was a willing accomplice to his children's mischief and laughter and would egg them on, as the biggest kid in the family. Until his last day he remained serene and composed, and never lost his optimism. He was completely at peace with himself. We will all cherish and miss him. Burial will be private. A public celebration of Muzzi's life will be held on March 29th at the Greenwich Hyatt at 11am. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to the Muzzi Mirza Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund, to the attention of Dr. John Chabot, New York Presbyterian Hospital, Pancreas Center, 161 Ft. Washington Avenue, New York, NY 10032 $(6$)MIRZA--Muzzi. We express our deepest sympathy to the family of Muzzi Mirza, our hunting friend. Our prayers our with you. Ten Mile River Preserve

Men who take daily doses of aspirin, acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen may slightly increase their risk for high blood pressure, a new study reports. After adjusting for age, smoking, physical activity and family history of hypertension, researchers found that compared with nonusers, men who took either acetaminophen or anti-inflammatory drugs six or seven times a week increased their risk for high blood pressure by more than one-third. The same use of aspirin increased the risk by 26 percent. The study appears in the Feb. 28 issue of The Archives of Internal Medicine.

An article on March 2 about the slaying of Ken Gorman, a supplier of medical marijuana in Denver, included an erroneous estimate from Allen St. Pierre, the executive director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, on the number of legal marijuana providers who have been killed nationally. Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

With ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Brothers & Sisters'' in repeats on Sunday, CBS won a solid victory in total viewers for the night. CBS overshadowed the latter part of the evening with ''Cold Case'' at 9, with 15.3 million viewers, and ''Without a Trace'' at 10, with 17.2 million, according to Nielsen's estimates. At 7, however, CBS got off to a sluggish start with ''60 Minutes,'' which garnered 10.1 million total viewers and a third-place finish among adults 18 to 49. ABC was second for the night in total viewers, as ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' remained dominant at 8 (13.7 million) ahead of No. 2, ''The Amazing Race: All Stars'' on CBS (10 million). Among adults 18 to 49, Fox outperformed both CBS and ABC to rank first for the night, getting a boost from an overrun of its Nascar coverage in the 7 o'clock hour. Meanwhile, two episodes of Fox's new comedy, ''The Winner,'' at 8:30 (6.8 million) and at 9:30 (5.6 million) posted ratings in line with the show's debut last week. NBC was fourth over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

Members of Zimbabwe's political opposition and largest civic group said Monday that their leaders had been beaten and hospitalized after the police arrested them and scores of others during the violent breakup of a weekend antigovernment rally. Police officers remained out in force in Highfield, the neighborhood in Harare, the capital, where the rally was to have taken place on Sunday, as well as in the city's center, witnesses said Monday. The heavy police presence underscored the government's determination to contain what many opposition figures and analysts call growing unrest in the face of economic collapse.

STEITZ--Jack, 82, of Manhattan, died peacefully March 9. Proud son of the late John J. Jr. and husband of the late Kitty Montaner, Jack was a decorated World War II veteran who lived in New York City his entire life. A kind and generous man, he will be missed by those he touched. He is survived by his loving sons, Bradlee and Brian, his grandchildren Samantha, Jeffrey, and Maxwell, and daughters - in - law, Kathy Hipple and Ana Steitz. Part of our cherished Greatest Generation, Jack's sweetness and special love will be sorely missed.

Because of an editing error, a picture in some copies on Saturday with a front-page article about how a fatal fire in the Bronx united cultures in grief, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of passers-by in front of the burned house was by Librado Romero of The New York Times, not by the New York City Fire Department.

Brooklyn Academy of Music The concert presented by the Brooklyn Philharmonic on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music bore a grandiloquent title, ''Bridge to the Beyond.'' But the orchestra's music director, Michael Christie, in remarks from the stage during the first half, summarized with a single word what connected three works by Osvaldo Golijov and Mahler: memories.

After years of political dominance, Republican voters now view their party as divided and say they are not satisfied with the choice of candidates seeking the Republican presidential nomination in 2008, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. In a survey that brought to life the party's anxieties about keeping the White House, Republicans said they were concerned that their party had drifted from the principles of Ronald Reagan, its most popular figure of the past 50 years.
SCHER--Lewis J. February 8, 1914 to March 13, 1999. Daddy-I miss you so much. Love always, Vicki

The White House was deeply involved in the decision late last year to dismiss federal prosecutors, including some who had been criticized by Republican lawmakers, administration officials said Monday. Last October, President Bush spoke with Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to pass along concerns by Republicans that some prosecutors were not aggressively addressing voter fraud, the White House said Monday. Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, was among the politicians who complained directly to the president, according to an administration official.

It is not exactly The Congressional Register, but YouTube is being employed by growing numbers of politicians to put video of floor speeches and other statements online. And the trend is likely to accelerate as C-Span makes more video of Congress available. Speaker Nancy Pelosi's YouTube channel had 318 clips up as of Monday, about 100 of them posted in the past month and 4 last week; she posts clips of other Democrats as well as herself, especially about the Iraq war. The channel of Representative John A. Boehner, the Republican leader, had just nine video clips, the most recent featuring remarks he made on March 1.

A front-page article on Thursday about Chinese children who were adopted by Jews and are now going through the ritual of bat mitzvah referred imprecisely in one reference to the location in a synagogue where the Torah is read. It is a bimah, not an altar.

There are blogs out there for every political persuasion. But who is reading them? College graduates who are paying attention to the 2008 campaign are the prime audience, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Registered voters, particularly those who plan to vote in a primary, are more likely to visit blogs.

Starbucks, which has been trying to market cultural cachet with the same might it does coffee, is finally starting its own record label. The coffee chain's past efforts to refashion itself as musical tastemaker have included distributing albums from major-label stars like Norah Jones and, more recently, the first album from a previously little-known independent-label band, Low Stars. But now, under a deal with the existing label Concord Records, Starbucks will sign its own artists, with a first release anticipated before the end of the year. The label, Hear Music, is expected to pursue both new and established performers. The two partners scored big once before: Starbucks and Concord released Ray Charles's final new CD, ''Genius Loves Company,'' which has sold more than 5.5 million copies worldwide. JEFF LEEDS

As a video circulated around the Internet and on cable television featuring a 1989 speech in which Rudolph W. Giuliani promoted public financing for abortions, he was in Washington on Monday speaking about his ties to prominent conservatives. In the video of the 1989 address, Mr. Giuliani said, ''There must be public funding for abortion for poor women.'' That position is anathema to the Republican Party's conservative base, and is the latest example of how his stances on social issues could complicate his presidential campaign.

An article in Business Day yesterday about plans by the oil services company Halliburton to transfer its chief executive to a corporate headquarters in the United Arab Emirates city of Dubai misstated the surname of an analyst with Energy Intelligence Group, who commented on the move. She is Barbara Shook, not Barbara Struck.

Carnegie Hall Operatic tenors have assumed a hero status regularly assigned important athletes. Since the 1840s, when singers were first learning to muster every cavity in their bodies, the tenor's ear-tingling signature sound has become a sporting event, something almost independent of what the tenor happens to be singing or the musicality involved.

To the Editor: Re ''Years of Strife and Lost Hope Scar Young Palestinian Lives'' (''A Generation Lost,'' front page, March 12): I read the stories of young Palestinians desperate for a different future with tears in my eyes. Not only for youths living lives without hope, but for myself, a recent immigrant to Israel, and Israel's next generation.

To the Editor: Re ''Tough Question to Answer, Tough Answer to Hear'' (Personal Health, March 6): Telling a terminally ill patient that he or she has a short time to live may have dire consequences both mentally and physically. In 1961, at age 37, I had metastatic colon cancer. I was told I had ''polyps,'' and I didn't know my life was in danger. A year later there was a recurrence and again surgery. I was well for about five years and then my spleen was enlarged with cancer and that was removed.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about a campaign by Patrick M. Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, against a type of short selling, referred incorrectly to David Rocker, a short seller and former head of Rocker Partners. Mr. Rocker and his firm were not the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into possible manipulation of Overstock.com shares. (Mr. Rocker did testify in the course of an S.E.C. investigation of similar accusations against Gradient Analytics, a research firm. The S.E.C. recently sent a letter to Gradient saying that it would not pursue any action against the firm.)

A Political Memo article on Thursday, about the challenges Rudolph W. Giuliani faces in running for president as a former New York City mayor, referred incorrectly to the timing of the two-term presidency of another New Yorker, Theodore Roosevelt. He began serving more than 100 years ago, in 1901; his presidency was not ''almost 100 years ago.'' A correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to Mr. Roosevelt's time as a public official in New York City. He was a police commissioner, not a former mayor.

The scores of all 900 students who took the SAT exam in South Korea in January will be canceled, the Educational Testing Service announced in South Korea on Friday. Tom Ewing, a spokesman for the testing service, which is responsible for security issues involving the College Board's college admissions exam, said an investigation had shown that an unknown number of students had seen at least a portion of the test before the exam was given on Jan. 27. Because the number could not be determined, he said, all the scores were being canceled. Students will be able to retake the test or accept a refund. In the early 1990s, thousands of Graduate Record Exam scores were canceled across most of India, Mr. Ewing said, and in 1992 about 10,000 scores on the TOEFL, a test measuring fluency in English, were canceled in China. KAREN W. ARENSON

To the Editor: Re ''A United Kingdom? Maybe'' (March 6): As an ex-pat Englishman, I'm not surprised to discover that the English, Scots, Welsh and Irish are from the same gene pool. It explains why we have been at one another's throats for 400 years: we're family! Robin Prestage Fallsington, Penn.
