The legendary producer of artists like Pink Floyd, R.E.M. and Fairport Convention talks about his new memoir, 'White Bicycles,' about the scene in late 60's London.

John Maine pitched very well this afternoon against Detroit, allowing only a leadoff homer to Curtis Granderson in four innings, and he's no dummy, either. After watching a little bit of Mike Pelfrey's performance, Maine sat on a stool in front of his locker and asked a few reporters, "The story's Pelfrey, right?"Someone nodded, and Maine said, "That's what I like to be: under the radar and forgotten."To be fair, Maine isn't exactly under the radar, and he certainly isn't forgotten; he is, although Willie Randolph will not announce as much for a few weeks, penciled in as the team's No. 3 starter. But on this day, Maine was right: All Mike Pelfrey, all the time, and with good reason.

On the Internet right now, just one click away, you can find a wonderful movie made by NASA of a recent transit of the Moon past the Sun, but it is something very special. This version is viewed not from the Earth but from one of NASA's twin Solar Terrestrial Relations Observatories, satellites that recently were launched to study the Sun from space.
David Patten keeps the student ID card from Santa Ana College tucked in a shelf back home.

Rudolph W. Giuliani said tonight that weaning the United States off foreign oil must become a national purpose, that doing it within 10 to 15 years would be a centerpiece of a Giuliani presidency, and that he will have much more to say on the subject as the campaign wears on.

The call came at 5:35 p.m. today, when Phil Hughes walked into Manager Joe Torre's office for the demotion he knew was coming. For two minutes or so, he met with Torre and pitching coach Ron Guidry. They emerged with Guidry and Hughes talking some more.
The practice session in Sacramento is more than half over and a few key storylines have emerged:
Today's Spitzerism: "colossally misdirected," a reference to the Senate budget. [Capitol Confidential]
The New York City Council passed a bill on Wednesday banning the use of metal bats in high school baseball games, setting up a possible legal challenge from the metal bat industry.

Bob Knight has never been known for a charming reticence in his approach to the media. The Texas Tech basketball coach brought his trademark bluster to a news conference on Wednesday at Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Winston-Salem, N.C., as the No. 10 seed Red Raiders prepared to face No. 7 Boston College Thursday in the first round of the East Regional.
President Bush was peppered with questions about the dismissal of several federal prosecutors while on a trip to Mexico.

Admit it. We're less than 24 hours from the start of the N.C.A.A. tournament and you're starting to wish that you had taken Thursday and Friday off. You're asking your friends on IM right now: "Should I get food poisoning or the flu?" "Should I make up another distant relative's funeral to attend?"
There will be no announcement today.
Asked if she believed homosexuality was immoral, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton declined to answer the question in a television interview this morning and said it was for "others to conclude."

The South Region, bottom right in your bracket, has Ohio State as the top seed, with the powerful Greg Oden in the middle. Memphis, the second seed, hasn't lost since Dec. 20 and Texas A&M, the third seed, has Acie Law. Here's a game-by-game look at the first round.
A skit from Jim Gaffigan's DVD, "Beyond the Pale."

The blogosphere turned a little faster this week fueled by the furor over the firings of multiple United States attorneys. When President Bush spoke on the issue for the first time today, the keyboarding pace quickened even more.
Maybe Marist did deserve an at-large bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament after all.

I'd hoped to start parsing your theories on the gender gap in laughter today, but first we must deal with an emergency. In a shocking and unexpected development, readers reported laughing out loud at the muffin joke.
Beet.tv is not the final resting place for the Montessori-educated online funnyman Ze Frank's show. That's blip.tv, which is totally totally different but I get them mixed up in my head.
I took a tumble last Saturday while on my regularly daily run, but I didn't think much of it. My chest hurt, but I figured it would go away.
Research shows that separate bedrooms have become the latest craze among American couples (as The New York Times reports).

Another legal door was slammed today in the ever-contentious question of medical marijuana, when a federal appeals court ruled once again that Angel Raich of Oakland, Calif., could be prosecuted for smoking cannabis even though her doctor says it is the only drug keeping her alive.

Troubles in the mortgage market have put a spotlight on the arcane world of structured finance and the alphabet soup that includes CDO's and CMBS's. These woes may also be creating additional opportunities for Wall Street workers who know about such complex things, according to MarketWatch's David Weidner, who reports that "bankers and traders who have experience structuring collateralized debt obligations, or CDOs, are in high demand to feed departments handling securities backed by mortgages, assets, corporate debt and other loans."

Confirming reports that it was close a deal, Microsoft said Wednesday that it would buy Tellme Networks, an speech-recognition technology company. In a statement, Microsoft said that it plans to integrate Tellme's products into its mobile offerings, with a long-term goal of integrating the technology into the rest of its lineup.
Bolivia's new president, Evo Morales, is promising a dramatic shift in coca policy that could jeopardize the U.S. war on drugs.  Juan Forero reports. Producer: Brent McDonald.
Evo Morales's presidency heralds a dramatic shift to the political left for Bolivia, South America and perhaps beyond. (Producer: Brent McDonald)
A preview of the Discovery Times documentary 'Haiti: Democracy Undone.'Video courtesy Discovery Times Channel/CBC. Producers: Peter Bull, Walt Bogdanich, Pascal Akesson.
Soccer fans were executed by corrupt policemen in 2005. Video courtesy Discovery Times Channel/CBC. Producers: Peter Bull, Walt Bogdanich, Jenny Nordberg. Editor: Pascal Akesson.
Walt Bogdanich discusses the elections situation in Haiti. Video courtesy Discovery Times channel/CBC. Producers: Peter Bull, Walt Bogdanich, Jenny Nordberg. Editor: Pascal Akesson.

For months, pundits have been kicking around the (wildly speculative) idea of Microsoft buying Yahoo to take on Google, the giant of the Web search world. John Battelle, the editor of SearchBlog, a blog on search technology, was among them. But now Mr. Battelle, who also founded the online ad network Federated Media Publishing, thinks he has a better idea, though one he admits might sound "crazy": a joint venture between the two companies to create a "search monetization" business.

A judge dropped the charges Wednesday against Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman, Patricia Dunn, who had been accused of orchestrating the boardroom spying scandal at the Silicon Valley computer company.
A couple of hours before Alex Rodriguez turned all chatty on "Mike & the Mad Dog" yesterday, I found a subject he wouldn't touch.
Dear Times Reader Beta Testers,

In case anyone wondered what Senator John McCain thinks about the current Democratic resolutions and proposals on Iraq in the Senate, he just put it pretty clearly to the International Association of Fire Fighters.
Among New York City voters, that is.
At a news conference this morning in Brooklyn, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appealed for calm as a Queens grand jury seemed close to a decision on the Sean Bell shooting:

Two articles in The Times this morning have a bearing on the presidential quest of Rudolph W. Giuliani: one about Bernard B. Kerik, the other about the former mayor's rift with a national firefighters' union.The first is particularly interesting: It seems that federal prosecutors are not quite done with Mr. Kerik, Mr. Giuliani's former police and corrections commissioner, who came close to being the nation's homeland security chief.
GrandCentral.com will give you one universal phone number.

Firefighters did not endorse Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in her United States Senate race in 2000, but they applauded steadily this morning as she said that, as president, she would "be there with you when you need me."

Senator Barack Obama used quite a few firefighting metaphors in criticizing the nation's capital this morning, telling the International Association of Fire Fighters that Washington is the sort of place where people "create other kinds of fires" - whether it's messing with funding for first-responders or saying he is too green to run for president.

The Empire Zone read with interest the story in the Buffalo News this morning about the protest rally held by the Seneca Nation at which Gov. Eliot Spitzer was branded "an agent of satan" and compared to Adolph Hitler. All this because the governor wants the Indian nation to start collecting taxes on cigarette sales to non-Indians, an issue that has been a point of contention for many years and led to violent protests in the past.

Back in the booming dot-com heyday of the early oughts, some enterprising young Web company - and they were all enterprising back then - came up with a clever idea to promote its N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket game. It announced that it would reward one billion dollars for anyone who could pick every game correctly. This overexuberance was typical of the time - the Web just printed money back then, after all - but was nevertheless tantalizing. The N.C.A.A. tournament bracket is intimidating and enormous, yet somehow approachable. Every tournament game? Heck: I could do that.

In the wake of the infamous rats-at-Taco-Bell video, the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene's inspectors have been closing down restaurants at a furious pace. Between Feb. 26, the Monday after the rat video made its debut, and last Saturday, the department closed 94 restaurants and take-out outlets following inspections, records show.

Jeffrey McDermott, one of UBS's three global co-heads of investment banking, will step down on June 30 to "pursue outside entrepreneurial opportunities," Bloomberg News reported Wednesday, citing an internal memo. A UBS spokeswoman confirmed the memo's contents, but declined to comment further.

For the first time this session, Senate Democrats cleared the procedural hurdle of 60 votes to move forward and debate a resolution on the war in Iraq. Twice before the Republicans had voted against debating a single resolution embraced by Democrats (and some leading Republicans). This time, the Senate passed, 89-9, a procedural motion that will set the stage for formal debate.

Home Depot's chief executive, Frank Blake, offered a reality check Wednesday to those who are hoping his company will soon become the biggest buyout target in history. "We're not thinking about going private," Mr. Blake said at a Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce conference. "We're very pleased with the capital structure we have." There has been speculation that Home Depot's stalled stock price and its valuable real-estate assets could make the home-improvement retailer an attractive acquisition candidate for private equity firms. With a market capitalization of about $76 billion, though, Home Depot would be quite a tall order for even a posse of firms flush with cash.
Forward-looking goods from companies that go way, way back.

A grand jury could decide as early as today whether to indict any of the five police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell in Queens. In an article this morning, William K. Rashbaum and Cara Buckley handicap the case, based on interviews with lawyers for several of the officers. The consensus: the officers most vulnerable to criminal charges are the detective who shot first -- firing 11 times -- and a detective who fired the most shots, 31.The grand jury -- a group of 23 ordinary citizens working in secret on behalf of the government -- do not determine guilt or innocence. Their job is to determine whether there is sufficient evidence of a crime to warrant a criminal proeeding. Their decision does not have to be unanimous -- a minimum of 12 of 23 votes is required for action. (This site has more about how grand juries operate, including a discussion by a deputy prosecutor from Brooklyn.)
Punk rock anarchy meets the bourgeois notion of decorating, Swedish modernism, sleek, sculptural furniture and more.
Readers respond to David Brooks's Mar. 11 column, "The Vanishing Neoliberal."

The calls for Alberto Gonzales to resign as attorney general have created a "told you so" moment for the nation's editorial pages. The New York Times editorial page says Gonzales "has shown why he was such an awful choice for this job in the first place." The Washington Post says Gonzales's "tenure in office has served only to deepen our conviction that he should never have been confirmed." The Los Angeles Times editorial page implies that we might even want to pity the poor man: "[D]on't blame him for the lack of principled leadership at the Justice Department. Blame his boss. President Bush appointed a man clearly unqualified for the job."
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Mar. 12 column, "Overblown Personnel Matter."
They're watching the sky, the thermometer and the river in Montpelier, Vt., today, hoping it won't turn out to be 1992 all over again.
Chalk one up for Express Scripts.

The magazine empire that spawned a host of imitators filled with "hometown hotties" and college humor is up for sale, with bids due Wednesday for Dennis Publishing, the New York Post reported. Allen & Company is running a full-fledged auction for the company, which is looking to sell its flagship Maxim, as well as a sister publication, Stuff and Blender, a music magazine.

Former Senator John Edwards put down a marker this morning for the 10 other presidential candidates and politicians who will follow him in addressing the International Association of Fire Fighters in Washington today.
Yes, it is absolutely true that I (reluctantly) conceded we needed an architect.

Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, facing calls for his resignation mainly from Democratic senators and candidates over the firings of several United States attorneys, told CNN's Miles O'Brien in an interview this morning that his fate rested with President Bush.
If you're really longing for some good New Orleans food, you might consider heading for a visit soon to taste food from two women who embody New Orleans kitchen tradition.
It's a club whose membership is determined by eye, not by bank account.
Most of the Democratic and Republican 2008 possible contenders are appearing today before the International Firefighters Assocation's forum, with one conspicuous absence.

Richie Sexson was in left field yesterday shagging fly balls with some of his Seattle Mariners teammates. But Sexson was not merely catching the balls. He also used them for target practice. After Sexson snagged a ball, he would fling it about 120 feet into a storage room that housed the groundskeepers. Sexson had nifty aim, nailing his target about 10 times.

Alfonso Soriano, the $136 million man for the Chicago Cubs, is not pining for the Yankees as he had done in previous seasons. When Soriano was asked if he kept in touch with any of his former teammates, he said that he did not.

J.P. Morgan Chase is going Hollywood -- all the way. Already one of the major players in structuring and financing entertainment deals, the investment bank is planning a unit aimed at advising moviemakers on everything from financing arrangements to merchandising deals, according to The Wall Street Journal. The Journal noted that the plan is part of J.P. Morgan's effort to grow its business without relying on acquisitions.

Lehman Brothers on Wednesday reported a $1.15 billion profit in its fiscal first quarter, up nearly 6 percent from the comparable quarter a year ago. Net revenue rose 13 percent, to $5 billion, Lehman said. Separately, Lehman's stock posted its biggest decline in about five years on Tuesday amid concerns about rising mortgage defaults.

Travelport, a travel-services company owned by private equity firms, said Wednesday it plans to sell part of its Orbitz Worldwide unit in an initial public offering, which it expects to complete in the third quarter. The size of the stake to be sold and the price are still undetermined, Travelport said.

Ever since Google coughed up that $1.65 billion for YouTube, critics of the online video site have been predicting a landslide of copyright lawsuits. While that landslide has yet to occur, the first boulder has fallen. Viacom, the parent company of MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, filed a wide-ranging lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing it of "massive copyright infringement." Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages and an injunction prohibiting Google and YouTube from committing further infringement.

the financial services firm Cantor Fitzgerald has merged its previously separate United States pollutant brokerage with its carbon brokering business to try and cash in on expected expansion in carbon markets. Cantor wants to put its environmental brokerage, which until now has focused on markets in pollutants like sulfur and nitrous dioxide, to work in emerging carbon markets. A power shift in the Congress last autumn has raised hopes for a national carbon market, leading to a surge of interest among investors.

Juniper Networks, the computer network equipment maker, said Tuesday that the chief financial officer, Robert Dykes, and an executive vice president, Robert Sturgeon, have resigned, just days after the company filed previously delayed financial statements with federal securities regulators.

Magna International, Cerberus Capital Management and a team led by the Blackstone Group and Centerbridge Partners are among the frontrunners to buy DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler unit, Bloomberg News reported.

The medical products maker Baxter International said Wednesday its board had authorized the repurchase of an additional $2 billion of its common stock. The company, based in Deerfield, Ill., said the repurchase would be executed "upon completion of its existing share repurchase program." Baxter said it has about $800 million of "remaining authorization under the $1.7 billion program" the board approved in February 2006.

d Salzgitter, a German steel company, has dropped out of talks to buy a Canadian rival, Algoma Steel, after word of the secret negotiations leaked, driving up the price of a takeover and piquing the interest of other potential suitors. While Salzgitter has walked away four weeks after starting talks, there are other "interested parties" that surfaced after news of the Salzgitter discussions became public last month, Algoma said Tuesday, adding that it plans to enter into negotiations with them in hopes of salvaging a sale.

China's Intime Department Store has priced its initial public offering at the top of the range for a total of 2.43 billion Hong Kong dollars ($311 million), suggesting the recent market correction and subsequent volatility has not had much impact on the Hong Kong I.P.O. market. Other parts of the capital markets are finding the going tough at the moment, but FinanceAsia notes that companies that have chosen to go ahead with their Hong Kong I.P.O.s have found that investor demand is still there.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the former financing arm of the General Motors Corporation, said on Tuesday that it would receive $1 billion more from G.M. under the terms of its spinoff and warned that it would be affected by the weakening market for mortgages. GMAC said G.M. would transfer about $1 billion to the financing company in the form of stock by the end of the first quarter under the terms of its sale to a group led by Cerberus Capital Management.

It might yet turn out to be what everyone seems to hope and expect: a tale of sex and power, secrecy and scandal, hypocrisy and comeuppance. So far, though, what we seem to have is a tale of murky motives, shifting legal strategies and chutzpah.

After raising its offer for the Japanese brokerage Nikko Cordial by 26 percent on Tuesday, Citigroup said Wednesday that its offer is final. The boards of the two companies agreed to raise the tender offer price to 1,700 yen ($14.40) a share, from last week's initial bid of 1,350 yen ($11.44) a share after it was rejected by some of Nikko's largest shareholders.

Citigroup's total return to shareholders fell short of the returns of many of its peers in 2006, according to the compensation committee of the company's board, but the year was financially rewarding nonetheless for Charles O. Prince, the chairman and chief executive.

Boarding the trip home from Africa, I was so glad to be going home. I hadn't bathed much in the past two weeks. I hadn't eaten much either. We'd been held up twice by bandits, and I was starting to get sick from exhaustion and changing weather.

In a strange coincidence, Lehman Brothers' announcement that it had bought a 20 percent stake in D. E. Shaw, a $29 billion hedge fund that is among the largest and oldest funds in the business, came the same day that the House Financial Services Committee held a hearing on hedge funds.
Two police officers were injured in separate assaults on the night of March 13.

Massachusetts Secretary of State William F. Galvin said Tuesday he had ordered UBS Securities and Bear Stearns to turn over documents concerning their analysts' recommendations on subprime lenders such as New Century Financial. Among the questions that Mr. Galvin is examining is whether these banks' analysts published positive research on New Century, whose stock has plunged as problems in the home mortgage market have emerged, to bolster other financial relationships at the banks, The Boston Globe reported.

Two former managers for the engineering conglomerate Siemens told a German court on Tuesday that they participated in paying bribes of roughly 6 million euros in Italy as part of the company's plan to anchor itself in the booming market for power generation equipment. But the two men, Horst Vigener and Andreas Kley, mounted a vigorous defense of the payments, arguing that Siemens benefited greatly from them.

Responding to criticism from many corporate executives and business groups that rule changes in the wake of the Enron scandal went too far, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. suggested on Tuesday that the administration was considering a more business-friendly approach to regulation.

Mark V. Hurd, the chairman and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, would prefer that the discussion at the annual meeting Wednesday afternoon not focus on the revelations of last fall that a dysfunctional board spied on its members and on journalists.

It is no secret that venture capitalists have begun pouring billions into energy-related start-ups with names like SunPower, Nanosolar and Lilliputian Systems. But The New York Times notes that interest is now spilling over to many others in Silicon Valley - lawyers, accountants, recruiters and publicists, all developing energy-oriented practices to cater to the cause.

Another day, another round of funding for a "clean tech" start-up. LS9, a high-tech fuel company that's all about imitating nature, said it has received $5 million in funding, as the search for the next new thing in renewable energy continues. The company hopes to make what it calls "renewable petroleum," a synthetic version of petroleum and other oil-based industrial products. (It has trademarked the name.)
Google said it would start to make search logs anonymous after 18 to 24 months. Under current practices, the company keeps the logs indefinitely.
Playwrights Horizons’ 2007-8 season will include a new play by Sarah Ruhl and the Off Broadway directing debut of Blair Brown.
Lauren Ambrose and Oscar Issac will star in this summer’s first Shakespeare in the Park production, “Romeo and Juliet.”
The Postal Service is commemorating the 200th anniversary of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow’s birth with a new 39-cent stamp.
Cathy Horyn looks back at the fall runway season and discusses why there's reason to rejoice.
The U.N. found  evidence that Russian gunships aided in missile attacks on villages in Georgia.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Gear test with Michael Burgasser, yoga instructor.
Tian Zhuangzhuang’s biopic is a stately and respectful reflection on the life of Wu Qingyuan, one of the 20th century’s top players of go, a Japanese game said to rival chess in complexity.
A documentary grab bag of film clips, diary readings and desultory narration, “A Journey of Dmitry Shostakovich” peeks at the politics of this controversial composer.
The documentaries “Blockade” and “Amateur Photographer” offer a devastating look at World War II-era atrocities.
In the last five years, the small but lucrative market of coveted old wines has become a fat target for counterfeiters.
The F.D.A. ordered makers to print label warnings about risks and side effects like driving and eating while asleep.
Following is a transcript of an interview by Michael Gordon and Patrick Healy of The New York Times with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, conducted on Tuesday at her office on Capitol Hill.
The senator said in an interview that there were “remaining vital national security interests in Iraq” that would require a continuing deployment of U.S. troops.
The Iraqi military announced Wednesday that the level of violence in the capital had decreased substantially.
President Bush vowed to step up his efforts to persuade Congress to approve a bigger guest-worker program for Mexican migrants.
A study found that those who arrived at a hospital on a weekend were less likely to get aggressive treatment and were slightly more likely to die.
Charges against Patricia Dunn were dismissed in the corporate spying case. Three other defendants were ordered to perform community service.
A grand jury in Queens that is weighing evidence in the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell began deliberating in the case today.
The bill passed today with enough votes to override a potential veto by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
The Senate vote today to allow debate was not indicative of support for the actual withdrawal resolution.
A Canadian philosopher who believes that spirituality is an essential part of the study of philosophy has won the $1.5 million Templeton Prize.
President Bush said today that he was pleased that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales had acknowledged mistakes surrounding the dismissals.

An increasing number of players in the men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament wear No. 0 or No. 00.  Despite the negative connotation, players are embracing zero as a sign that they have something to prove.
North Korea will shut down a reactor but only after the U.S. ends sanctions, the U.N. inspector said today.
Neither the police nor prosecutors showed up at a court hearing at which the activists were to be charged, defense lawyers said.
China has mounted a violent crackdown on protests and arrested political activists in a bid to curb dissent during the annual session of its parliament, Human Rights Watch said in a report today.
The arrests are the first in the investigation into the attack in February on a train between India and Pakistan, in which 68 people were killed.
A plainclothes officer was shot in a Harlem gunfight that left a suspect dead. In Brooklyn, an officer was stabbed.
The agreement between Lenovo, the world’s third-largest PC maker, and Microsoft replaces a similar deal the Chinese computer maker had with Google.
Lance Mackey won the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race last night, becoming the first musher to win major long-distance North American sled dog races back-to-back.

Algoma Steel said it had failed to reach agreement on a takeover by Salzgitter of Germany and had scheduled preliminary discussions with other potential buyers. Algoma said in mid-February that it might be acquired by Salzgitter at a price lower than where the company’s shares were trading at the time. Algoma negotiated with potential buyers in 2005 and renewed negotiations in February 2006 without reaching an agreement.
With a victory over New Orleans, New Jersey is barely ahead of the Knicks and the Pacers in the playoff race.
In a radio interview, Alex Rodriguez threatened to invoke his contract’s free agent option if fans do not embrace him.
The officer was wounded and a suspect was killed. In Brooklyn, an officer was attacked on a subway platform.
New York slipped off the playoff-race tightrope despite dominating the first period and taking a 2-0 lead on goals by Michael Nylander.
The outside shooting of Clif Brown led the Rattlers to their school’s first N.C.A.A. tournament victory in 37 years.
New York now moves into the final five weeks of the regular season significantly short-handed in the battle for a playoff spot.

Goalie Rick DiPietro sustained a head injury late in the opening period of the Islanders’ 5-3 loss to the host Montreal Canadiens last night. DiPietro was taken to a hospital and released, and Coach Ted Nolan said the team would have no further information until the medical staff reviewed test results.
Point guard Mike Nardi played sparingly in the Big East tournament, but said nothing would keep him out of the game against Kentucky.

Because of an editing error, the Bangkok Journal article on March 6 about Bangkok’s successful effort to cut air pollution misidentified the gender of the public health faculty dean at Thammasat University there, who said a group of strong-willed environmental pioneers was largely responsible. The dean, Nuntavarn Vichit-Vadakan, is a woman.
Corrections: For the Record

Because of an editing error, an article in Sunday Business this week about coaching services for users of online dating sites misstated the Web address of one such service. It is EvanMarcKatz.com, not EvanMarkKatz.com.

An article on March 3 about smoking bans at gambling sites misstated the title of Russell Sciandra. He is the director of the Center for a Tobacco Free New York, a coalition of groups of which the American Cancer Society is a member. He is not the president of the American Cancer Society.

An article on Monday about child labor in Guatemala, one of the five countries President Bush visited on a trip to Latin America, misstated the minimum wage there. It is about $1 an hour, not $1 a day.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the use of statistics to identify possible surprise winning teams in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament misidentified the team that defeated Texas A&M in the Big 12 conference tournament quarterfinals. It was Oklahoma State, not Oklahoma.

A sports article yesterday about the Knicks’ progress under the leadership of Isiah Thomas as coach and team president misstated their record with 19 games left in the regular season. It is 29-34, not 19-34.

NEW HAVEN, March 13 — The head of the Police Department’s narcotics division was arrested on Tuesday, accused of bribery and stealing tens of thousands of dollars. The arrest was the culmination of a federal sting operation that also led to the arrest of a detective and three bail bondsmen.

A front-page article yesterday about White House involvement in the ouster of several federal prosecutors misstated the results in some copies for the 2004 presidential election in New Mexico, one of several states where Republicans raised concerns about how United States attorneys handled allegations of voter fraud. President Bush was the winner, not Senator John Kerry.

An article on Friday about a request by the winner of a Feb. 20 special election for a City Council seat that another election be held because of questions about his residency misstated the percentage of votes won by the candidate, Dr. Mathieu Eugene. It was 34 percent, not 43 percent. The error also occurred on Feb. 21 in an article about the election.

Cadbury Schweppes said a group led by the billionaire Nelson Peltz had ac-quired a 2.98 percent stake in the company, leading to speculation about a takeover. The company’s shares rose more than 10 percent. Mr. Peltz, left, has a record as a shareholder activist, buying stock in companies he sees as undervalued then agitating for change from within, and analysts said the market would be watching closely to see if he tried to gain a seat on the Cadbury board. Cadbury, which is based in London and makes Dairy Milk chocolate, Dr Pepper soft drinks and Trident gum, declined to comment beyond a brief statement to the London Stock Exchange acknowledging the Peltz investment.

Aer Lingus reported a loss in 2006 because of a pension fund shortfall, higher fuel prices and the cost of repelling a takeover attempt by Ryanair. Aer Lingus, which found itself under siege by Ryanair almost immediately after listing on the Irish and British stock exchanges in September, reported a net loss of 69.9 million euros ($92 million) for the year that ended Dec. 31, in contrast to a profit of 88.9 million euros in 2005. Exceptional expenses included a 104 million euros ($137 million) payment to the employees’ pension fund and 16 million euros ($21 million) to lawyers, stockbrokers and other advisers hired to thwart Ryanair’s bid. Fuel costs also rose by 75 percent, to 234 million euros ($308 million). Sales rose 11.3 percent.

An Indian drug maker, Ranbaxy Laboratories, said it had submitted a bid for the generics unit of the German drug maker Merck but did not disclose how much it was offering. Analysts say Merck’s generics unit could be worth as much as 5 billion euros ($6.6 billion). Merck said last month that it had started contacting companies that might be interested in acquiring its generics drugs unit. Two companies, Ranbaxy and the Actavis Group of Iceland, have publicly expressed an interest. Merck is based in Darmstadt.

The Royal Bank of Canada agreed to buy a money manager J. B. Hanauer & Company of New Jersey, in its sixth acquisition in the United States in the last year. Details of the purchase, which is expected to be completed in May, were not disclosed, Royal Bank said. J. B. Hanauer, created in 1931, specializes in fixed-income and wealth management services. The company, based in Parsippany, has five offices in three states, with about 300 employees including 147 financial consultants, and almost $10 billion in assets under administration.

The Intel Corporation has received approval to build a $2.5 billion chip plant in China amid the country’s booming demand for chips used in personal computers and cellphones. The factory is planned for the northeastern city of Dalian, according to the cabinet’s National Development and Reform Commission, the country’s top economic planning agency. Intel officials in Beijing and at the company headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif., declined to comment, saying no formal announcement had been made.

The police have arrested one of the country’s most feared gang leaders, known by his first name, Evans, the United Nations said. Known for organizing criminal activity in his corner of Cité Soleil, the seaside shantytown in Port-au-Prince, Evans led attacks against United Nations peacekeeping troops in recent months.

A group of fired legislators clashed with the police after forcing their way into Congress as President Rafael Correa’s plan to rewrite the Constitution continued to generate protests. Dozens of protesters supporting Mr. Correa also gathered in front of the building, screaming epithets to the group of about 20 legislators, who were dismissed last week by the Electoral Tribunal after trying to reverse a ruling that could have potentially eroded their power. Mr. Correa, who is seeking to diminish the easy ability of Congress to oust presidents in Ecuador, accused the fired legislators of “abusing the misery of the people.” Mr. Correa is Ecuador’s eighth president in 10 years.

The Court of Cassation, France’s highest appeals court, rejected as unlawful the first marriage by a gay couple in France and annulled the men’s union. Stéphane Chapin, at left in photo, 36, and Bertrand Charpentier, 33, were married by the mayor of Bègles in the southwest in June 2004. The government immediately said the union was outside the law, and a series of court decisions unfavorable to the couple has followed. In the latest decision, the court ruled that “under French law, marriage is a union between a man and a woman.” No other gay couple has married in France.

Militants fired six mortars at the presidential palace in Mogadishu, hours after President Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed moved to the capital from the government’s southern stronghold of Baidoa. He was unhurt in the attack, which killed a 12-year-old boy and wounded three of his siblings, witnesses and officials said. Ethiopian tanks quickly sealed off the area.

Prince Norodom Ranariddh, a former prime minister, was sentenced in absentia to 18 months in prison for selling the headquarters of the party he once led. He is accused of earning $3.6 million on the deal but denies the charge. Prince Ranariddh was ousted as party leader last year and is now abroad. He was ousted as co-prime minister in 1997 in a coup led by the other co-prime minister, Hun Sen, who now runs the country on his own. An aide said the prince, a son of the retired king, Norodom Sihanouk, might seek a pardon from the current king, Norodom Sihamoni, who is his brother.

A spokesman for the Hamas-led government, Ghazi Hamad, said the group had “definite information” about who kidnapped the BBC’s Gaza correspondent, Alan Johnston. He was abducted by gunmen on Monday. Palestinian security services in Gaza were making efforts to bring about his release. The kidnappers are believed to belong to a powerful Gaza clan that regularly engages in criminal activity.

Four Britons and a Frenchwoman kidnapped while sightseeing in the northeastern Afar region of Ethiopia on March 1 have been released in neighboring Eritrea, the British government said. Margaret Beckett, the British foreign secretary, said the five, all connected with the British Embassy in Addis Ababa, were released in good health and “with the help of the Eritrean government.” She declined to say whether a ransom had been paid and did not reveal who might have been behind the abduction. There was no immediate word on the eight Ethiopian guides who were traveling with the group.

The authorities said they had arrested four men in Beirut whom they described as members of Fatah al-Islam, a radical Palestinian faction, in connection with the bombing of two minibuses in the city last month that killed three people and wounded 23. Two other members of the group were being sought in the attack, on the eve of the second anniversary of the assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, a security official said. News reports said the men were detained after explosives were found in an apartment in the Christian neighborhood of Achrafieh.
Only three and a half games back, the Suns could slice another game off that deficit with a victory Wednesday in Dallas.
A cryptic remark by the German defense minister stirred up the controversy over whether the Iranian official had defected with the collusion of the West.
In judging which prosecutors to fire, the chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales factored in whether they “exhibited loyalty to the president and attorney general,” documents show.
Neither the league nor the players’ union considers dementia a football-related condition.
The suicide bombings in southern Afghanistan killed four people during a visit by an American assistant secretary of state to Kabul.
Lottery Numbers.
Mexico’s president warned President Bush that the only way to stem illegal migration and ensure regional security was to raise his country’s standard of living.
“Mistakes were made” sounds like a confession of error or even contrition, but it is not quite either one.
The president’s Latin American tour represented an attempt to stave off growing anti-American sentiment.
Accusing Google and its YouTube site of “massive copyright infringement,” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages.
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales insisted that he would not resign, but said, “I acknowledge that mistakes were made here.”

Major League Soccer is teaming with Germany’s Bundesliga to promote the sport in the United States and exchange knowledge on stadium construction and player development. The cooperation may include exhibition games or tournaments in the United States.
The treasury secretary questioned whether egulators had “struck the right balance between investor protection and market competitiveness.”

Dr. Don Catlin, one of the world’s leading antidoping experts, is leaving the U.C.L.A. Olympic lab he founded to devote his time to creating better tests to catch drug cheats. Catlin has developed numerous tests to detect performance-enhancing drugs and helped expose hundreds of cheating athletes. Catlin, 68, said his newly created Anti-Doping Research Institute in Los Angeles would focus on improving tests for human growth hormone and the endurance enhancer EPO (erythropoietin).

The New England Patriots signed the free agent Kelley Washington, another deal in an off-season overhaul of their receiving corps. Washington had 72 catches for 893 yards and 9 touchdowns in four seasons with Cincinnati. The Patriots have also signed the free-agent receiver Donte’ Stallworth, who played for the Eagles last season.
An illegal immigrant who lost four children and his wife in last week’s fire in the Bronx will be allowed to travel to and from his West African homeland to bury his family.
Manchester United turned David Beckham into an international star, and he gave an emotional farewell before leaving European soccer for the United States.

The Green Bay Packers signed the free-agent cornerback Frank Walker to a one-year deal that could be worth nearly $1.5 million with incentives, his agent, Harold Lewis, said yesterday. Walker spent the past four seasons with the Giants. In other N.F.L. news, Lance Briggs reiterated that he would not play another down for the Bears after they designated him as their franchise player, and the free-agent cornerback Nick Harper left the Colts to sign a three-year deal with the Tennessee Titans. Seahawks tight end Jerramy Stevens was accused of driving under the influence and possession of marijuana.
Frostbite, frigid temperatures and damaged equipment led the explorers Ann Bancroft and Liv Arnesen to suspend their expedition to the North Pole.
Senate Republicans said they were eager to critique and ultimately defeat the Democratic approach to ending the war.
A debate rages in Washington about the financing and motives of the Council on American- Islamic Relations.
The former leaders of the Gloria Wise Boys and Girls Club will be fined for stealing money intended for children and the elderly.
A federal appeals court panel decision imperils needed gun controls in jurisdictions around the country at a time when violent crime in many places is once again on the rise.
The firing of eight United States attorneys looks like a political purge, and President Bush and his White House are in the thick of it.
Folgers has opened a new flank in the coffee war: a “stomach friendly” coffee for Americans who think they can no longer handle the hard stuff.
The bill faces the threat of a White House veto because it offers expanded union rights to airport screeners.
President Bush has a clear responsibility to the nation’s wounded soldiers to fix a shamefully broken system.

A Newark municipal court clerk was charged yesterday with accepting bribes in exchange for altering a criminal record to allow someone to pass a federal background check, federal prosecutors said. The clerk, Louis March, 38, was charged in a criminal complaint by the F.B.I. with extortion under the color of official right, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. Mr. Christie said Mr. March accepted $4,000 in cash from an undercover agent who was posing as the boyfriend of someone with a criminal record who needed to pass a background check to work at La Guardia Airport.

A grammar school teacher who claimed she was fired after being branded as a witch by school officials had her federal $2 million lawsuit against the Hampton Bays School District rejected by a jury yesterday. The teacher, Lauren Berrios, 37, said in her lawsuit that Andrew Albano, the former principal at Hampton Bays Elementary School, had accused her of practicing and teaching witchcraft. The suit claimed that Mr. Albano was a born-again Christian bent on converting the school and that his anger over her refusal to be converted provoked him to fire her in 2001. “This woman was denied tenure and she came up with this witch claim, and the jury clearly found it far-fetched,” said Steven C. Stern, a lawyer for the school district.
After losing in the fourth round at the Pacific Life Open, Maria Sharapova simply shrugged, looking disinterested after her match against Vera Zvonareva.

Two Maryland truck drivers were killed early yesterday when a tractor-trailer slammed into the back of a truck that was pulled over on the side of the Thruway, the state police said. One driver, Gary Akehurst, 58, of Fallston, Md., was stopped under an overpass in the northbound lanes just south of Exit 16 when a truck driven by John Johnson III, 27, of Baltimore, crashed into the back of his truck about 2:30 a.m., the state police said. Mr. Johnson’s truck burned and both drivers were killed. Two of the three northbound lanes of the highway were closed for about nine hours after the accident.

More than 100 people were displaced yesterday after the facade of their Bronx apartment building collapsed about 11 a.m., but no injuries were reported, the authorities said. The building’s facade fell, “compromising the exits and entrances” and requiring an evacuation, said Jim Long, a Fire Department spokesman. Last evening, city officials were trying to determine the extent of the damage to the six-story building, at Aqueduct Avenue and 190th Street.

The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that emergency workers injured on the job could sue property owners and collect damages if the injury resulted from the owners’ negligence. In a unanimous decision, the court found that a 1993 state law effectively abolished a legal doctrine called the firefighter’s rule, which barred emergency responders from filing such lawsuits. Ruling in a case of a police officer who sued the owner and landlord of a tavern after he was hurt breaking up a fight in 2001, the court said that the lawsuit could proceed. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Princeton University has given back $782,375 to a foundation that is seeking the return of hundreds of millions more in grants it gave to universities. Princeton is returning the money, which was used for a now-defunct program aimed at supporting graduate students in economics, politics and sociology. The payment is the latest move in a battle to control the Robertson Foundation, which began as a $35 million gift to Princeton in 1961 by heirs to the A.&P. supermarket fortune, and has increased to more than $800 million. The Robertson family said that the gift was to be used to train foreign affairs specialists but that Princeton used some of it for other purposes. Princeton said in a statement it had not used the money improperly, although it did not adequately disclose the program’s nature to the foundation board.

Federal investigators examining what caused a freight train to derail and explode in central New York State said yesterday that they had discovered a flawed piece of track near the scene of the accident. The investigators, with the National Transportation Safety Board, said that they found the piece yesterday, during the initial stages of their investigation, one day after the train, which was carrying propane from Buffalo to Selkirk, exploded in Oneida. A spokesman for the agency, Keith Holloway, said investigators were examining the derailed cars for any signs of pre-existing flaws and would continue looking for other anomalies on the tracks. CSX Corporation, the train operator, said the company was working to pipe petroleum from some of the derailed cars into a pit where it would be burned.
Suicide bombers have recently turned on Pakistan itself as Islamic militants threaten to open a new front.

NBC Universal extended its commitment to maintain a presence in New York City under an agreement approved yesterday by the city’s Industrial Development Agency. NBC said it would move the operations of its MSNBC cable channel and 421 jobs to Rockefeller Center from Secaucus, N.J. It also agreed to keep at least 3,850 jobs in the city until 2023. In exchange, the agency gave NBC $1.5 million in real estate tax benefits. NBC had previously pledged to maintain 2,350 employees in the city until 2010.

A Queens man has been convicted of the 2002 killing of a New York City Department of Environmental Protection worker, prosecutors said. The man, Taiquan Williams, 25, of Jamaica, was convicted of second-degree murder on Monday evening in State Supreme Court. The worker, Eugene McMahon, was fatally shot as he sat in his department vehicle on Aug. 9, 2002, said Richard A. Brown, left, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Williams shot Mr. McMahon in the head during a robbery, and Mr. Williams faces up to 25 years to life in prison.
The undercover detective who shot first and a detective who fired the most of any of the officers appear to be the most vulnerable to criminal charges in the shooting of Sean Bell.
Officials said the fire started near a 15-foot-long extension cord to which a five-outlet power strip had been attached.
Leaders in Anbar Province, the epicenter of the Sunni Arab insurgency, have complained that the prime minister has neglected them.

A decision by the Interior Department to reactivate 20-year-old energy drilling leases in southern Utah areas that have since been set aside for protection and recreation will be challenged in court on Wednesday.
Scott Kazmir was pleased with his performance yesterday in the Devil Rays’ 11-8 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies in St. Petersburg, Fla.
Larry Brown, who coached the Knicks for one turbulent season, left his imprint, for better or worse, on the team’s bench in the form of his coaching protégés: assistants Dave Hanners and Phil Ford.
Inspectors have closed over 90 restaurants since the surfacing of a video of rats swarming inside a KFC/Taco Bell in Greenwich Village.
A lawyer for Bernard B. Kerik, the city’s former police and correction commissioner, said Mr. Kerik refused a plea bargain in which he would have pleaded guilty to tax fraud and wiretap conspiracy.
Pope Benedict XVI said that Roman Catholic politicians were “especially” obligated to defend the church’s stance in their public duties.
American officials see the step by the Treasury as a crucial part of the recent deal to disarm North Korea’s nuclear program.
In a virtually empty stadium, coaches gathered to watch Orlando Hernández and Pedro Martínez, both trying to return to form.
Every time the 49ers take the floor, they are also trying to carve a niche for themselves in the saturated Southern California sports market.
For two Long Island men, a simple real estate venture has turned into a mammoth effort to preserve the life’s work of an obscure artist.
Over 400 guests paid tribute to the unofficial mayor of Broadway and the owner of Sardi’s Restaurant, who died in January.
Off to a hot start in spring training, Hideki Matsui no longer carries the burden of a consecutive-games streak that began in Japan in 1993.
Firefighters and police officers who know Rudy Giuliani best, those in New York City, have mixed views of him, ranging from admiration to outright hostility.
A compact disc holding vital medical and other personal information of about 75,000 members of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has disappeared.
Some of the measures in the plan could be unpopular with voters even as they inspire politicians’ acclaim.
The rights to the aborted O. J. Simpson book, “If I Did It,” will be sold so that the family of the murder victim Ronald L. Goldman will receive all future proceeds from their sale, a judge ruled.
GlaxoSmithKline won permission yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration to sell a tumor-growth inhibitor called Tykerb to treat breast cancer.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned that widening inequality in the United States was “morally not right” and expressed concern about China’s surging economic growth.

The judiciary will ask Congress to add 67 judgeships to work on heavier caseloads. The Judicial Conference voted to ask for 15 seats on courts of appeals and 52 on district courts. District court case filings have risen 29 percent since 1990, and district judgeships 4 percent, to 674 from 645, the Administrative Office of the United States Courts said.
As a senator, John Edwards was skeptical about voting for the Iraq war resolution and advisers looking out for his future pushed him into it, a memoir will say.

The influential proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services reversed its stance yesterday and said that it would recommend that shareholders of Caremark Rx support a takeover proposal from the CVS drugstore chain.
Stocks fell broadly and sharply after a report on mortgage defaults indicated that the troubled housing market will weaken further.
Charles O. Prince was paid $25.98 million for his work in 2006, which represented an increase of about 13 percent  over 2005.
Senate Democrats cannot say where the money would come from for their plan that would reject President Bush’s spending cuts, keep taxes low and eliminate the deficit by 2012.
While investment banks are scrambling to get into the hedge fund business, officials say they need to know more about the industry.
Mr. Ladd played 112 consecutive games in the American Football League and appeared in the first Super Bowl before becoming a full-time wrestler.

The investor Carl C. Icahn bid $955.9 million yesterday for WCI Communities, the Florida builder of condominiums and single-family homes, after saying he wanted to oust the board because the stock was undervalued.

Some leaders of the Christian right had called for the National Association of Evangelicals to silence or dismiss its Washington policy director because of his involvement in the campaign against global warming.
Antigovernment activists were treated after the police arrested and beat them for their efforts to hold a meeting.
A backlash over a spate of advertising with suicide themes has raised questions about ads that are deliberately provocative.
The revelations that a dysfunctional board spied on its members and on journalists still casts a shadow on a company that by most measures is performing well.
A panel of judges rebuked the E.P.A. for flouting Congress and the courts in setting the standards governing hazardous air pollution emissions.
An up-to-date Israeli government register shows that 32.4 percent of the property held by Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank is private.
Brigham Young, more than any other team in the field, seems to have the maturity to handle the pressure of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
Eliot Spitzer wants a bigger Javits Center than the one being proposed, but city officials warn of added costs and delays.
Stocks plunged yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 240 points and troubles piled up for subprime lenders.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is courting Jewish support by supporting Israel while Senator Barack Obama is trying a more delicate strategy.
“The Mountain Man’s Field Guide to Grammar" is the brainchild of a man who loved to write, but hated learning the rules.
An assistant professor at Kean University in New Jersey resigned amid accusations of plagiarism, two decades after her father was accused of copying material for a book without credit.

DETROIT, March 13 (Reuters) — The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the former financing arm of the General Motors Corporation, said on Tuesday that it would receive $1 billion more from G.M. under the terms of its spinoff and warned that it would be affected by the weakening market for mortgages.
A Norwegian cellphone company claims that a Russian telecommunications company paid journalists in Ukraine to publish negative articles.
The Kroger Company, the nation’s biggest supermarket chain, said fourth-quarter profit rose more than analysts had anticipated as discounts spurred sales.
A widening corruption investigation opened by the new government has resulted in the jailing of prominent public officials and business figures.
For Japan, whaling is intricately tied to the country’s relations with the West, especially the United States.
The trial is one of a host of legal difficulties facing Siemens that has shaken the country unlike any other recent business scandal.
Michael Jordan, a part-owner of the Charlotte Bobcats, said that Bernie Bickerstaff would not return as coach but would be an “integral part” of the franchise.
The clothing retailer J. Crew Group reported a profit in the fourth quarter yesterday, in contrast to a loss a year ago, as sales rose.
Betty Hutton was a singer and actress celebrated as a “blonde bombshell” of Hollywood musicals and comedies in the 1940s and ’50s.
J.W. Marriott Jr.’s compensation included perks such as use of the company’s private jet and company paid life insurance and tax services.
Gen. Peter Pace had said that he believed homosexual conduct was immoral and akin to adultery.
Goldman Sachs reported profit of $3.2 billion, setting a record amid growing concern over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market.

EAST HANOVER, N.J., March 13 — Students and other residents of this small Morris County suburb were struggling on Tuesday to make sense of the weekend arrests of a high school football player and his volunteer coach in the third high-profile drug roundup since last spring.
An attack on Sunday night may aggravate the already tense relationship between the two countries.
A coalition of industrialists, environmentalists and energy specialists is banding together to try to eliminate the incandescent light bulb in about 10 years.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,185 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
The demolition of the the Stardust Hotel-Casino in Las Vegas ended a yearlong farewell to a 48-year-old resort that was, in its heyday, considered the ultimate in luxury and style.
Statements made by Samuel Eto’o, who recently returned from knee surgery, have upset some teammates and management at F.C. Barcelona.
Julia Mancuso is one of four women in contention for the World Cup trophy with five days of racing left in the season.
Edgar Baitzel was recruited to the Los Angeles Opera six years ago by Plácido Domingo and led the company to financial success as chief operating officer.
John Thow was a prolific composer of chamber, symphonic and stage works and a professor at the University of California at Berkeley.
Clear Channel Communications, the largest United States radio broadcaster, postponed a shareholder vote on its $19 billion sale by a month yesterday to improve the deal’s chances for approval.
Bill McKibben, who was one of the first laymen to warn of global warming, is now the philosopher-impresario of the program of climate-change rallies called Step It Up.
Mary Masterman, a senior at Westmoore High School in Oklahoma City, won the top prize of a $100,000 scholarship in the Intel Science Talent Search by building a spectrograph for $300.
If successful, Citigroup’s takeover of Nikko Cordial would be the biggest foreign acquisition of a Japanese securities company.
State officials insist that the new state song is not about the high you get from illegal drugs.
State legislators moved to nullify an executive order that required girls to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.
Xbox Live, Microsoft’s gaming network that serves some six million Xbox users, is scheduled to be opened to PC gamers on May 8.

The bill will be the basis for House efforts to reshape the Children’s Health Insurance Program, which expires Sept. 30, and will be a building block of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign platform.
Retail sales rose less than forecast in February as cold weather kept shoppers home.
Because we ask the ultimate sacrifice of the animals we eat, it is incumbent on us to ensure that they have decent lives.
Galvanized by the record profits at energy companies, the city has shaken off the effects of the Enron implosion.
The need for sweeping views of Central Park has caught on among companies searching for offices, especially in the financial services industry.
Whatever limits there are on Congressional power to determine particular tactical questions, decisions about the scope and goals of military action are easily within its authority.
Former dot-com entrepreneurs have found a new purpose in transforming the $1 trillion domestic energy market.

10:30 P.M. (Comedy Central) HALFWAY HOME A suspicious smell and an in-house narc lead to the residents of Crenshaw House being forced to take a drug test in the premiere of “Halfway Home,” an improvised comedy in which five ex-cons live together in a residential rehab facility.
Thom Mayne’s Federal Building in San Francisco might just be the bookend to a heady phase of government-sponsored architecture.
New landmarks for New York on Park Place, NBC and ABC News continue their battle for first, Sylvester Stallone is charged in Australian court and more culture news.
Conan O’Brien and Andy Richter are getting back together for a new series, “Andy Barker P.I.”
Are disposable gloves, the very objects that are supposed to keep diners safe from germs, a health menace themselves?
The Nederlanders, one of the big three Broadway theater owners, plan to present and market tours and live entertainment in China.

The Albright-Knox Art Gallery, a museum with a small endowment in a highly competitive art market, tries to raise money, angering its members.

What really astonishes in this new volume, “Revolutionary Chinese Cookbook,” are the extra-culinary insights that transport you to another place and time.

Josh Groban, wielding his indisputably beautiful voice with a surprising modesty and grace, brought pop balladry to Madison Square Garden on Monday evening.

In “Halfway Home,” which makes its debut Wednesday on Comedy Central, the premise of a halfway house stocked with stock characters comes off like “The Surreal Life,” just with convicts.
A genetic test brings about an unlikely pairing of two cousins — one from a cattle ranch in the Midwest, the other from the stages and church choirs of the Northeast.
Coach Farm in Pine Plains, N.Y., has sold the cheesemaking and distribution components of its goat cheese and yogurt business to Alain Foster of Best Cheese, in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
Seven nights. Seven hotels. Seven dinners. Seven breakfasts. Frank Bruni investigates room service around Manhattan.
To feed the demand for seedless mandarin oranges, farmers and scientists have been chasing new varieties and developing new technologies.
In its better moments, Glasgow Phillips’s darkly comic anti-memoir offers an acid critique of contemporary American culture and its twin obsessions: fame and riches.
Butter’s Good for You.
Ed McFarland, right, formerly of Pearl Oyster Bar, will open his own seafood shack in NoHo on Friday. Also, Japanese-Italian fusion, a new French-Morrocan restaurant and more.
How an American couple created a home abroad that honors its rich Dutch history, but features decidedly modern American amenities.
In this quickly-prepared recipe, squid is stir-fried with bitter greens and paired with two strong spices, jalapeños and garlic.
The parent company of MTV and Comedy Central is seeking $1 billion in damages for copyright infringement.
A handful of tips for what to do if the building plans for your weekend or vacation getaway don’t jibe with zoning regulations.
Yolato, part gelato and part frozen yogurt, arrives in New York, Brooklyn Brewery has a special new ale, and a clever cheese grater from Giro Gratta.
Most stock markets in Asia closed down between 2 and 3 percent today, and European stocks opened weak.
Two of LeBron James’s former high school teammates, now at the University of Akron, found their season ended earlier than expected.
It is unlikely anyone alive has as many firsthand memories of the Nazi leaders as Richard W. Sonnenfeldt.

A recipe for Hunan Beef with Cumin.
A recipe for Squid With Chilies and Greens.
Irish soda bread is baked in a heavy iron skillet so that the top and bottom crusts become crunchy while the raisin-studded center stays tender.
A recipe for Skillet Irish Soda Bread Served With Cheddar and Apples.
Homes on the market in Naples, Fla., Jackson, Wyo., and Malibu, Calif.

At Nish on the east side, the cooking reflects a fervent
internationalism, and the best dishes are terrific. The wine list is remarkably affordable, too.
The Spanish restaurants in New York almost never serve food that tastes particularly Spanish, but the team at Ostia, a new spot on Seventh Avenue South, does a better job than most.

As Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama compete for Jewish donors and voters, Mrs. Clinton is following a tried-and-true rule of hers from New York -- support Israel to the last -- while Mr. Obama is trying a more delicate strategy that hit some bumps this week. At a pro-Israel conference here on Monday night, Mrs. Clinton told an audience of 1,000 that Israel deserved ''every bit of our support'' and that Iran ''will not be permitted to have nuclear weapons.'' There were no shades of gray about Israel, which has been her style since falling into trouble with Jewish voters in 1999 when she did not quickly denounce controversial remarks about Israel made by Suha Arafat, the wife of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat.

Brian Williams broadcast from Iraq last week and Charles Gibson was on vacation, but the ratings competition between their network newscasts remained tight, according to figures released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research. While Mr. Williams's ''NBC Nightly News'' was seen by more people over all (about 8.99 million each night last week, compared with 8.94 million for ABC), ''World News'' on ABC (with Elizabeth Vargas, above, filling in for Mr. Gibson) drew more viewers between the ages of 25 and 54, the demographic used to determined advertising rates. With an estimated 7 million viewers over all, the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' drew nearly 2 million fewer viewers than its counterparts on NBC and ABC. JACQUES STEINBERG

A Newark municipal court clerk was charged yesterday with accepting bribes in exchange for altering a criminal record to allow someone to pass a federal background check, federal prosecutors said. The clerk, Louis March, 38, was charged in a criminal complaint by the F.B.I. with extortion under the color of official right, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. Mr. Christie said Mr. March accepted $4,000 in cash from an undercover agent who was posing as the boyfriend of someone with a criminal record who needed to pass a background check to work at La Guardia Airport.
