SPIRA--Bernard. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society mourn the loss of Bernard Spira of Los Angeles. Mr. Spira was a beloved friend and Technion Guardian, representing the highest level of support of the Technion. His ardent support of ATS endeavors in Southern California will be greatly missed. Mr. Spira was formerly a design engineer for McDonnell Douglas Aircraft Corp. and a World War II veteran. To his cousin, Mrs. Yona Nadelman, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. American Technion Society Joan Seidel, President Stephen A. Laser, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Charles Levin, Southern California Chapter President Nina Madden Sabban, Southern California Chapter Chair

MIRZA--Muzzafar ''Muzzi''. We mourn the loss of our founder, partner and dear friend, Muzzi Mirza. Muzzi was endlessly creative, constantly energized, and a problem solver who always found the way through the most convoluted maze and taught us how to have fun doing it. Muzzi's remarkable warmth and open spirit resulted in a world where once you spent an hour with him you felt as if he was your friend -and he was. For Muzzi, the glass was not merely half full, it was always overflowing. He made us all better at what we do and in who we are. To his wife, Sue, and to his children, Alexander, Christina and Sean, we loved him too, and will miss him dearly. Odyssey Investment Partners $(6$)MIRZA--Muzzafar ''Muzzi''. For the past 17 years, Muzzi was my colleague, partner and friend. We taught each other our business. We argued constantly, laughed uproariously, struggled through bad and good times, and in the end worked it out every day. He was a living antidote to pessimism, an enemy to gloom, the champion of keeping our options open and lifting spirits. When we wandered, Muzzi was ''not confused''. I am not confused now, Muzzi. It was very, very special. Stephen Berger

The Nets squandered lead after lead, and with only 40 seconds remaining, their 7-point advantage was gone. An 11-day trip was grinding to an end, and who could blame them for lacking the energy to win? But win they did, scoring 6 of the last 8 points for a 112-108 victory against the New Orleans Hornets. In his best performance since returning from right ankle surgery four games ago, Richard Jefferson led the Nets with 26 points, making 9 of 12 shots, and had 6 rebounds.

Brooklyn Brewery's new Local 1 Belgian-style ale is too good to pour with a sandwich while watching college basketball. In the waning days of winter, it deserves a casserole of choucroute piled with sausages or a plate of cured meats and ripe cheeses. The honey-gold brew is complex, with notes of spice and fruit and a refreshingly bitter finish. It is made by refermenting the ale in the bottle, like Champagne. That's a costly technique that seems to be coming back as brewmasters like Brooklyn's Garrett Oliver search for interesting challenges. The beer, in a 750-milliliter bottle with a Champagne-style cork, is at stores including Whole Foods ($7.99), D'Agostino ($8.99) and Bierkraft ($11.95).

Because of an editing error, the Bangkok Journal article on March 6 about Bangkok's successful effort to cut air pollution misidentified the gender of the public health faculty dean at Thammasat University there, who said a group of strong-willed environmental pioneers was largely responsible. The dean, Nuntavarn Vichit-Vadakan, is a woman.

The Transportation Security Administration announced that it would heighten security at Florida and Puerto Rico airports with added screening and limits on employees' access to secure areas after four arrests last week involving smugglers who, the authorities say, bypassed security at Orlando and sent guns and drugs to Puerto Rico. The agency has 160 security officers, air marshals and others at airports in Fort Lauderdale, Orlando, Miami, Tampa and Puerto Rico. AMY GREEN

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Militants Shift Attention To Attacks Inside Pakistan Islamic militants in Pakistan, who have been active preparing attacks inside Afghanistan, have turned their attention on Pakistan itself, carrying out six attacks in recent weeks. Diplomats see the bombings as proof of a spreading ''Talibanization,'' which has seeped into more settled districts of Pakistan. A1 Three bombs exploded in Afghanistan, killing four people and wounding at least 10, officials said. A10 Iraq Debate Looms in Senate The Senate will begin debate on a Democratic resolution calling for the withdrawal of most American troops from Iraq in 2008, with Republicans saying they are eager to critique and ultimately defeat the Democratic approach to ending the war. A12 Israelis Built on Private Lands An up-to-date Israeli government register shows that 32.4 percent of the property held by Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank is listed as private Palestinian land, according to the advocacy group. A6 Beaten Zimbabwean in Hospital The Zimbabwean opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai and 49 others opposed to the government were sent to a Harare hospital for treatment, two days after the police arrested and beat them for their efforts to hold a protest meeting. A8 Britain Seeks Emission Laws As nations and politicians in many parts of Europe compete to burnish their green credentials, Britain became the first national government to propose binding laws enforcing a steep cut in carbon emissions. A13 Russia Tied to Georgia Attacks A United Nations observer mission in Georgia opened an investigation into missile attacks in three remote Georgian villages, and the initial evidence suggested that Russian helicopter gunships were involved. A8 NATIONAL A14-20 Gonzales Will Not Resign But Admits to Mistakes Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, under criticism from both parties for the dismissals of federal prosecutors, insisted that he would not resign but said, ''I acknowledge that mistakes were made here.'' A1 Debate Over Islamic Group The Council on American-Islamic Relations has emerged as the most vocal advocate for American Muslims -- and an object of wide suspicion. The group defines its mission as spreading the understanding of Islam and protecting civil liberties. Yet a debate rages in Washington about its financing and motives. A1 Budget Raises Questions Senate Democrats have drafted a budget that would reject President Bush's spending cuts for health care and education, would keep taxes low and would eliminate the deficit by 2012. But they cannot say where all the money will come from. A16 Pace Explains Remarks on Gays The nation's highest-ranking military officer, Gen. Peter Pace, said that he should not have expressed his personal view that homosexual conduct was immoral and that he should have focused recent remarks on his support for current policy that prohibits openly gay people from serving in the armed forces. A15 Senate Passes 9/11 Bill The Senate passed legislation that would enact more recommendations made by the Sept. 11 commission, but it faces the threat of a White House veto because it offers expanded union rights to airport screeners. A16 Vaccine Order Hits Roadblock After Gov. Rick Perry issued an executive order making Texas the first state to require sixth grade girls to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer, the state House voted to nullify the order. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Officers May Face Charges In Queens Police Shooting Lawyers for several of the five police officers involved in last year's fatal shooting of Sean Bell in Queens said the undercover detective who shot first -- firing 11 times -- and a detective who fired 31 shots, the most of any, are the most vulnerable to criminal charges in the case. A grand jury has been hearing evidence since Jan. 22 and could vote as early as today on whether to hand up criminal charges. B1 City Shuts Restaurants With the images of rats swarming inside a Greenwich Village fast-food restaurant fresh in the minds of New Yorkers, the city health department has been closing down restaurants cited for violations at a furious pace ever since. B1 Plagiarism Case Has Twist Jacqueline R. Griffith resigned last week from her position as a tenured assistant professor at Kean University in New Jersey after being accused of having plagiarized sizable portions of her doctoral dissertation -- the same charge leveled against her father at Fairleigh Dickinson University 25 years ago. B1 ARTS E1-10 Ballyhoo of Broadway in China Next week the Nederlanders, one of the big three Broadway theater owners, are planning to announce the details of a new company they have formed that, among other things, will present and market tours and live entertainment in China. E1 OBITUARIES A21 Betty Hutton A singer and actress celebrated as a blond bombshell of Hollywood musicals and comedies in the 1940s and '50s, she was 86. A21 BUSINESS DAY C1-11 Silicon Valley Thinks Green Veterans of the Internet bust have regrouped and found a new mission in developing wind power, solar panels, ethanol plants and hydrogen-powered cars. A1 Mortgage Turmoil Spreads Stocks fell after a report indicated that the troubled housing market would weaken further before improving. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22--23 Editorials: Politics, pure and cynical; the right to ban arms; when warriors come limping home. Column: Judith Warner. Crossword E2 Weather A19 TV Listings E9

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the use of statistics to identify possible surprise winning teams in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament misidentified the team that defeated Texas A&M in the Big 12 conference tournament quarterfinals. It was Oklahoma State, not Oklahoma.

EDELMAN--Barry. A beautiful, kind and wonderful man has left us. My condolences go out to: Myrna, Arnold, Susan, Karen, Michelle, David, Zachary, Alex and Tony. There never was a spirit as warm and generous as my beloved cousin Barry. Zina Sylvia Landsberg

ALPERT--Warren. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with deep sorrow the passing of Warren Alpert, a former member of our Board of Overseers. Mr. Alpert demonstrated his philanthropic vision and commitment to medical education at Einstein by establishing an endowed scholarship that has benefited many of our students over the years, and will continue to do so in the future. His generosity also extended to biomedical research programs at Einstein, and to Yeshiva University. To his beloved family, we offer our heartfelt sympathies. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Morry Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

A grammar school teacher who claimed she was fired after being branded as a witch by school officials had her federal $2 million lawsuit against the Hampton Bays School District rejected by a jury yesterday. The teacher, Lauren Berrios, 37, said in her lawsuit that Andrew Albano, the former principal at Hampton Bays Elementary School, had accused her of practicing and teaching witchcraft. The suit claimed that Mr. Albano was a born-again Christian bent on converting the school and that his anger over her refusal to be converted provoked him to fire her in 2001. ''This woman was denied tenure and she came up with this witch claim, and the jury clearly found it far-fetched,'' said Steven C. Stern, a lawyer for the school district. COREY KILGANNON

The rights to the aborted O. J. Simpson book, ''If I Did It,'' will be publicly auctioned so the family of the murder victim Ronald L. Goldman will receive all future proceeds from their sale, a judge in Los Angeles ruled yesterday. Jonathan Polak, a lawyer for the Goldman family, said Mr. Simpson's original contract with HarperCollins stipulated that on May 8 the rights to the book would revert to Lorraine Brooke, which Mr. Polak called a shell corporation set up by Mr. Simpson to hide proceeds from the book.
To the Editor: Re ''Ban on Bats Made of Metal Moves Forward'' (news article, March 13):

An article on Friday about a request by the winner of a Feb. 20 special election for a City Council seat that another election be held because of questions about his residency misstated the percentage of votes won by the candidate, Dr. Mathieu Eugene. It was 34 percent, not 43 percent. The error also occurred on Feb. 21 in an article about the election.

MCHUGH--James J., of Westport, Connecticut, died March 7, 2007. He is survived by his wife, Marie; his children John, James, Anne, Peter, and Paul; his grandchildren Sarah, David, Jane, Sam, Kate, Peter, and Marie. A private memorial service is planned.

SCHUUR--Robert G. The attorneys and staff at Thelen Reid Brown Raysman & Steiner, LLP, are saddened by the passing of Bob Schuur. A true gentlemen lawyer for whom love of the law, lawyerly professionalism and commitment to firm were paramount. Bob has been an inspiration to all of us. We wish to express our deepest sympathies and condolences to Bob's family.

Many second-home owners dream of increasing the size of their weekend or vacation getaway -- putting up a second story, expanding the pool house, building a detached garage, adding a deck, installing an extra-long boat dock. Buyers of vacant land also often think big. The challenge, of course, lies in turning those dreams into reality. One reason is that buyers and owners must confront zoning limitations -- those rules in hamlets, villages, towns and cities across the country that can govern everything from the height of a house, to the number of structures allowed on the property, to distance of a home from the property line. Some municipalities even have rules about the size of the shadow a dwelling can cast on a neighbor's property.

Funeral services were held Thursday, March 8, 2007 at Bernheim-Apter -Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, NJ. A memorial service will take place in the near future in Florida. The Public Theater announced casting for the star-crossed lovers in this summer's first Shakespeare in the Park production, "Romeo and Juliet." Juliet will be played by Lauren Ambrose ("Awake and Sing!" and, perhaps appropriately, HBO's "Six Feet Under"). Romeo will be played by Oscar Isaac, from the 2005 Shakespeare in the Park revival of the musical version of "Two Gentlemen of Verona." Michael Greif ("Rent") directs.
To the Editor: Re ''Denying Rights in Nigeria'' (editorial, March 8):

A front-page article yesterday about White House involvement in the ouster of several federal prosecutors misstated the results in some copies for the 2004 presidential election in New Mexico, one of several states where Republicans raised concerns about how United States attorneys handled allegations of voter fraud. President Bush was the winner, not Senator John Kerry.

A few months ago, Gus Theodoro, above, reopened his Greek restaurant in Greenwich Village. Adding to the charm of his rustic little restaurant is a generous shelf filled with products imported from Greece. They include lush fig jam ($6 for 12.5 ounces), Greek coffee ($5 to $8 a pound), Cretan honey ($7 for 12 ounces) and dried Greek oregano ($2 for 1.4 ounces). There are also ''spoon sweets'' -- runny preserves -- in flavors like cherry with almond ($8 for a two-pound jar), which the Greeks eat with yogurt, and pastas like short, wide lazanaki noodles ($2 a pound ). Mr. Theodoro is holding a jar of whole preserved fruits. Gus's Place is at 192 Bleecker Street (Macdougal Street), (212) 777-1660.
To the Editor: Re ''Google, Master of Online Traffic, Helps Its Workers Beat the Rush'' (front page, March 10):

Representative Martin T. Meehan, a Democrat, will leave Congress to be chancellor of the University of Massachusetts-Lowell if approved by the trustees, as expected today Mr. Meehan, 50, is an alumnus. Mr. Meehan said the decision to leave Congress was the ''hardest of his life.'' KATIE ZEZIMA

Frozen yogurt is back, and Pinkberry, the Los Angeles company that put it in focus, has a new local competitor that serves a different type of treat. Yolato is where the creaminess of gelato meets frozen yogurt's refreshing tang in flavors like pistachio, hazelnut and chocolate. Yolato, which has its headquarters in Edgewater, N.J., opened its first New York store in January in Greenwich Village at 120 Macdougal Street (Bleecker Street). On Sunday it opened a second location on the Upper West Side at 2286 Broadway (82nd Street). The stores also sell sorbets, frothy drinks in flavors like green tea, frozen cakes and a fat-free, soft-serve frozen yogurt called Yoggi, made with Stonyfield Farm milk.

To the Editor: After reading the review of Robert's Steakhouse, I am left to ask two questions: First, could one consider this as a new form of combining lascivious food and lascivious surroundings, and refer to it as a Disroborative? And, do they do take out? Michael J. Brennan Fairfield, Conn.

NBC Universal extended its commitment to maintain a presence in New York City under an agreement approved yesterday by the city's Industrial Development Agency. NBC said it would move the operations of its MSNBC cable channel and 421 jobs to Rockefeller Center from Secaucus, N.J. It also agreed to keep at least 3,850 jobs in the city until 2023. In exchange, the agency gave NBC $1.5 million in real estate tax benefits. NBC had previously pledged to maintain 2,350 employees in the city until 2010. PATRICK McGEEHAN

FREILICHER--Gertrude D., age 96, died on Saturday, March 10, 2007. Wife of the late Morris Freilicher, mother of Morton and Yseult and Ira and Vivian; grandmother of David, Nancy, Judith, and Harlan; great-grandmother of Sophie, Sarah, Lucy and Jack; sister of James, Leonard, Blossom, and the late Herman. Funeral occurred on March 11, 2007. A brilliant student already in college at 16, Gertrude, as a woman of her era, sacrificed the balance of her higher education to become surrogate mother for her three younger siblings when her own mother was stricken with blindness. Family stalwart during WWII when her three brothers all served overseas, she overcame her challenges of severe cancer and repeated pneumonias while giving Bedrock support to loved ones at times of crises. A masterful knitter, she developed that skill to a fine art form. Memories of her love, competence, creativity, and strength will forever exist. Donations to a charity of your choice.

To the Editor: Re ''The Ultimate Cruelty: Abandoned by Ravioli'' (Feb. 28): While Alex Witchel laments branded food favorites she finds missing, nothing could prepare her for a move to a state where no light cream is sold.

The Giro Gratta all-in-one grater with cheese is a clever thing to have on hand when you are serving risotto or pasta and are not setting a fancy table. The plastic box comes with 8.9 ounces of imported Grana Padano, an excellent cheese that is a close cousin to Parmigiano-Reggiano. Turn the bottom of the box and grated cheese comes out. The grater, which is not reusable, is compact enough to tuck into the refrigerator so that the cheese does not dry out: the business end has a cover, too. Amish Markets have the grater on sale for $4.99, reduced from $7.99. It is $11.99 from igourmet.com. Kraft has introduced a similar product, Kraft Grate-It-Fresh Parmesan Cheese, $4.99 for 7 ounces in supermarkets, but its cheese is domestic Parmesan.

(Comedy Central) HALFWAY HOME A suspicious smell and an in-house narc lead to the residents of Crenshaw House being forced to take a drug test in the premiere of ''Halfway Home,'' an improvised comedy in which five ex-cons live together in a residential rehab facility. 4 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Ms. DeGeneres offers up a veteran and a newbie with careers as disparate as their ages: the game-show host Bob Barker and the 8-year-old opera singer Gwyneth Mackenzie. 7:30 P.M. (BET) ACCESS GRANTED Backstage with Snoop Dogg and the Game on their ''How the West Was One'' tour. 8 P.M. (11) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL New looks can kill as the girls receive makeovers and a contestant gets a phone call from home that sends her into a tailspin (the episode's title is ''The Girl Who Cries All the Time''). And tonight's photo shoot? Nude and candy coated. 8 P.M. (My Network TV) SAINTS AND SINNERS Yesterday's Montagues and Capulets are today's Martins and Capshaws in ''Saints and Sinners.'' Roman Martin and Julia Capshaw fall in love in spite of their families, rival owners of high-end hotels whose competition has spanned generations, in this updated ''Romeo and Juliet.'' If that's not enough, Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor are the (in Ms. Kidman's case, Oscar-nominated) eye candy in this absinthe-soaked story of an ill-fated dancer and writer in love. (ABC) IN CASE OF EMERGENCY The boys resort to desperate measures (and drag the women along) when Sherman convinces Kelly to help him kidnap his wife from an ashram and Harry reveals to Jason that he's having sex with Jason's mother. 10 P.M (National Geographic) NAKED SCIENCE In ''Prehistoric Americans,'' real scientists put the fictional CSI's to shame by using technology and fine-tuned forensics to prove that the first Americans arrived thousands of years earlier than previously thought.

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday unanimously approved landmark status for 23 and 25 Park Place, a pair of five-story buildings, right, in TriBeCa that once housed The Daily News. The buildings extend through the block, to 20 and 22 Murray Street, between Broadway and Church Street. ''These distinctive examples of the mid-19th-century double-store-and-loft buildings housed a vast array of tenants, including one of New York City's greatest institutions, The Daily News,'' said Robert B. Tierney, chairman of the commission. Completed in 1857, they were designed by Samuel A. Warner, architect of the Marble Collegiate Church at Fifth Avenue and 29th Street, an early Romanesque Revival structure that is also a city landmark. With seven bays on Park Place and five on Murray Street, the buildings have ornamental window treatments and pediments inspired by the Farnese Palace in Rome. The continuous stone cornices are decorated by a frieze of alternating panels and roundels. Two cast-iron storefronts, at 23 Park Place and 20 Murray Street, are original. A surgeon and a merchant developed the buildings and leased them to a series of dry-goods stores through the early 1880s. They were later used by manufacturers, booksellers, restaurants and financial concerns. The Daily News, founded in 1919, leased the buildings from 1921 to 1930. ''These buildings and the rich history created within their walls will be protected through this designation,'' said Marc Z. Kramer, chief executive of The Daily News. SEWELL CHAN

To the Editor: I write with distaste concerning Frank Bruni's review of Robert's Steakhouse, located in a strip bar. To the Editor: Re ''Another Kind of Appeal From Death Row: Kill Me,'' by Adam Liptak (Sidebar column, March 12):

A profile of Terence Tao, a world-renowned mathematician, in Science Times yesterday referred incorrectly to work he did with another mathematician on prime numbers. They proved that it is always possible to find, somewhere in the infinity of integers, a progression of any length of equally spaced prime numbers -- not a progression of prime numbers of any spacing and any length.

Murder charges were dropped against a man indicted in November in connection with serial shootings that wounded 17 people and killed seven. The man, Jeffery J. Hausner, 40, entered a guilty plea to a charge of aggravated assault for stabbing a homeless man and faces up to 8 3/4 years in prison at sentencing next month. Mr. Hausner's brother Dale S. Hausner is charged in the killings along with his roommate, Samuel J. Dieteman. Investigators have said the attack on the homeless man was connected to the serial killings, but have never specified the link other than that Mr. Dieteman was present. JOHN DOUGHERTY

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Martin's children, Randy and Ken, and Brenda and Jordan, and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales fell back on a classic Washington linguistic construct on Tuesday when he acknowledged that ''mistakes were made'' in the dismissals of eight federal prosecutors last year. The phrase sounds like a confession of error or even contrition, but in fact, it is not quite either one. The speaker is not accepting personal responsibility or pointing the finger at anyone else. It is a construction that other officials, from Richard M. Nixon's press secretary to Ronald Reagan to John H. Sununu and Bill Clinton, have used when someone's hand was caught in the federal cookie jar.

SQUID is all about speed: like scallops and shrimp, it's almost impossible to undercook. Old-timers used to say, ''Cook it for two minutes or two hours,'' and that's about right. From the time it hits the heat until it turns opaque -- a sign that it's ready -- is usually no more than a couple of minutes. After that it becomes tough, and it must be cooked a long time, with liquid, to become tender again.

To the Editor: ''Researchers Dispute Benefits of CT Scans for Lung Cancer'' (news article, March 7) addressed statistical issues of a new study based on death rate without much thought of the human side of this devastating disease.

A Queens man has been convicted of the 2002 killing of a New York City Department of Environmental Protection worker, prosecutors said. The man, Taiquan Williams, 25, of Jamaica, was convicted of second-degree murder on Monday evening in State Supreme Court. The worker, Eugene McMahon, was fatally shot as he sat in his department vehicle on Aug. 9, 2002, said Richard A. Brown, left, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Williams shot Mr. McMahon in the head during a robbery, and Mr. Williams faces up to 25 years to life in prison.

STEITZ--Jack, 82, of Manhattan, died peacefully March 9. Proud son of the late John J. Jr. and husband of the late Kitty Montaner, Jack was a decorated World War II veteran who lived in New York City his entire life. A kind and generous man, he will be missed by those he touched. He is survived by his loving sons, Bradlee and Brian, his grandchildren Samantha, Jeffrey, and Maxwell, and daughters - in - law, Kathy Hipple and Ana Steitz. Part of our cherished Greatest Generation, Jack's sweetness and special love will be sorely missed.

Flanked by national leaders in government and business, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned on Tuesday that widening financial inequality in the United States was ''not morally right'' and expressed concern about the surging economic growth of China. With the Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., sitting to his right, and Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, to his left, the mayor seemed to be in his element on Tuesday morning, referring several times to the financial information company he founded, Bloomberg L.P.

MINUCCI--Ulpio, 89, resident of Los Angeles, California, passed away March 9, 2007, at his home in Brentwood. Born in Italy, he is survived by his wife of 55 years, Catherine Minucci, also of Brentwood, his daughter Nina Minucci of Marlborough, New Hampshire, and his son Chieli Minucci of Forest Hills, New York, as well as three grandchildren.

Times Square is an unpretentious runway. Fashion struts onto the scene, as it did in these black and white photos taken in the early 1970s, twirls and poses, and then struts off, only to return reinvented, as in the recent color images. Bill Cunningham, the longtime fashion observer for The New York Times, defines fashion this way: ''Four holes. One for the neck, two for the arms, and one more for the legs, unless it's a pantsuit -- then it's five holes.''

Web search companies collect records of the searches people conduct, a fact that has long sparked fears among privacy advocates and some Internet users that this valuable personal data could be misused. Now Google is taking a step to ease those concerns. The company keeps logs of all searches, along with digital identifiers linking them to specific computers and Internet browsers. It said on Wednesday that it would start to make those logs anonymous after 18 to 24 months. Under current practices, the company keeps the logs indefinitely.

Six weeks after Gov. Rick Perry issued an executive order making Texas the first state to require that sixth-grade girls be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer, the State House of Representatives voted 119 to 21 yesterday to approve a bill that would nullify the order. If the Senate also approves the bill, the measure will go to Mr. Perry, a Republican, whose office declined to say whether he would veto it.

A two-hour ''Deal or No Deal'' gave NBC a ratings victory Monday night in total viewers, but NBC's continuing struggles at 10 p.m. cost it the outright lead among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Deal or No Deal'' averaged 16.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., the night's highest ratings in the 18 to 49 demographic. At 10, however, Episode 3 of ''The Black Donnellys'' ranked a distant second with 6.7 million viewers, far behind a repeat of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (14.2 million) although still better than ABC's ''What About Brian'' (4.8 million). With solid second-place finishes at 8 for a ''House'' rerun (9.7 million) and 9 for ''24'' (12.3 million), Fox tied NBC for first among adults 18 to 49. CBS finished third in the 18 to 49 set as the return of its comedy ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' stumbled at 8 (7.7 million) and 8:30 (8.3 million), underperforming the season average for previous occupants of that time slot, ''How I Met Your Mother'' and ''The Class.'' ABC, which broadcast the finale of ''Supernanny'' at 9 (7.5 million), ranked fourth over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

Even though he lives in an Amsterdam canal house built before 1593, Corey M. Reardon expects 21st-century, American-style service. And he has learned to go out of his way to get it. Every other week, Mr. Reardon stuffs a suitcase full of stained and soiled clothes and leaves his apartment along Amsterdam's swankiest canal, bypassing boatloads of envious tourists too busy admiring his residence to suspect his dirty little secret.

A sports article yesterday about the Knicks' progress under the leadership of Isiah Thomas as coach and team president misstated their record with 19 games left in the regular season. It is 29-34, not 19-34.

To the Editor: If The New York Times wants to run a story about strip clubs, it should by all means do so. From economics to what these spaces reveal about contemporary sexuality, there is plenty of worthwhile material to be explored there. But Frank Bruni's ostensible review of the steaks sold at the Penthouse Executive Club is neither a food review nor a frank examination of the club. With its stilted double-entendres, affected nonchalance and accompanying salacious photography, Bruni's article reads like something from a dusty men's magazine of 50 years ago.

Stallone Is Charged In Australian Court The actor Sylvester Stallone, 60, was charged in an Australian court yesterday with trying to bring the human-growth hormone Jintropin into Australia, where it is restricted, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Stallone, left, and his entourage were stopped and detained at the Sydney airport on Feb. 16, when customs officials searched the group's luggage and confiscated some items. At the Sydney premiere of ''Rocky Balboa'' the next day, Mr. Stallone shrugged off the incident, calling it a misunderstanding, but clearly the Australian authorities felt differently. Lawyers for Mr. Stallone represented him yesterday in court, where he faced a charge of importing a banned substance. Prosecution documents said the airport search revealed 48 vials of Jintropin, which is considered a performance-enhancing drug in Australia and therefore cannot be imported without a government permit. The case was adjourned until April 24, when Mr. Stallone's lawyers will be asked to enter a plea. On the Horizon: Sarah Ruhl and Others Playwrights Horizons' 2007-8 season will include a new play by Sarah Ruhl and the Off Broadway directing debut of the Tony Award-winning actress Blair Brown, the company has announced. The first production this fall will be ''100 Saints You Should Know'' by Kate Fodor (''Hannah and Martin''), to be directed by Ethan McSweeny. Other productions are: ''A Feminine Ending'' by Sarah Treem, directed by Ms. Brown; ''Doris to Darlene: A Cautionary Valentine'' by Jordan Harrison, directed by Les Waters; ''Dead Man's Cell Phone'' by Ms. Ruhl (''The Clean House''); and ''The Drunken City'' by Adam Bock (''Swimming in the Shallows,'' ''The Thugs''), directed by Trip Cullman (''Some Men''). The season's sixth production has not been announced. Ailey II Will Perform At Company's New Home The junior ensemble of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Ailey II, will perform for the first time on the stage of the Ailey Citigroup Theater at the two-year-old Joan Weill Center for Dance, on April 11to 22. The company recently completed a tour to more than 45 American and Canadian cities. Ailey II formed in 1974 as a workshop for the most promising scholarship students from the Ailey School. The coming season will include three New York premieres: ''Splendid Isolation II'' by Jessica Lang, ''Celestial Landscape'' by Darrell Grand Moultrie and ''Axis'' by Abdel Salaam. Tickets and information: alvinailey.org. Tribeca Film Festival Announces Lineup The 2007 Tribeca Film Festival will present 159 feature films and 85 shorts from 41 countries, selected from 4,550 submissions for the sixth annual event, scheduled for April 25 to May 6. The festival was founded in 2002 by Robert De Niro, Jane Rosenthal and Craig Hatkoff with the goals of helping to revitalize Lower Manhattan, assisting filmmakers in reaching a broad audience and promoting New York as a major filmmaking center. Festival passes and packages are available now, and single tickets go on sale online starting April 14; tribecafilmfestival.org.
Naples, Fla. WHAT: Four-bedroom house

The authorities said they had arrested four men in Beirut whom they described as members of Fatah al-Islam, a radical Palestinian faction, in connection with the bombing of two minibuses in the city last month that killed three people and wounded 23. Two other members of the group were being sought in the attack, on the eve of the second anniversary of the assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, a security official said. News reports said the men were detained after explosives were found in an apartment in the Christian neighborhood of Achrafieh. NADA BAKRI

An article on Monday about child labor in Guatemala, one of the five countries President Bush visited on a trip to Latin America, misstated the minimum wage there. It is about $1 an hour, not $1 a day.

When Hideki Matsui arranged his annual dinner with the Yankees' beat reporters, he first selected the same Tampa steakhouse as last year. Then he changed his mind. There was more than a meal to consider. The 2006 season was not kind to Matsui, who spent 110 games on the disabled list with a broken left wrist. The karma might be better, he decided, if he met the reporters at the Italian restaurant he had picked in years past.

Federal investigators examining what caused a freight train to derail and explode in central New York State said yesterday that they had discovered a flawed piece of track near the scene of the accident. The investigators, with the National Transportation Safety Board, said that they found the piece yesterday, during the initial stages of their investigation, one day after the train, which was carrying propane from Buffalo to Selkirk, exploded in Oneida. A spokesman for the agency, Keith Holloway, said investigators were examining the derailed cars for any signs of pre-existing flaws and would continue looking for other anomalies on the tracks. CSX Corporation, the train operator, said the company was working to pipe petroleum from some of the derailed cars into a pit where it would be burned. ANAHAD O'CONNOR

Wu Qingyuan, the subject of Tian Zhuangzhuang's stately and respectful biopic, was one of the 20th century's top players of go, a Japanese game involving the placement of pebbles on a board and said to rival chess in complexity. The intricacies of the game do not figure much in ''The Go Master,'' which is more concerned with the rituals of play and with the intensity of the hero's discipline and commitment. Mr. Wu, played by the Taiwanese actor Chang Chen (''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' ''3 Times''), was a Chinese go prodigy who spent most of his adult life in Japan. Born in 1914, he lived through a calamitous era in the history of both countries. Mr. Tian pushes war and politics decisively into the background, emphasizing the almost monastic qualities of a go-centered life, which leaves little room for other interests.

To the Editor: I am a regular reader of the Dining section, and although I usually read the food and wine articles with enthusiasm, never do I remember laughing out loud as I did when I was reading ''Where Only the Salad is Properly Dressed'' (Feb. 28). Great reading! However, the next time I want a good steak, I think I will go to Sparks, Luger's or Bobby Van's. Steve Stracquodaine Merrick, N.Y.

A report in the Today in Business column in Business Day on Feb. 17, about quarterly results at the Hormel Foods Corporation, misidentified the state in which the company is based. It is in Austin, Minn., not Texas.

The French Oil Giant Total is fighting criminal charges that it is responsible for an oil spill that devastated much of the Brittany coast in 1999, hoping to avoid a conviction that carries a relatively modest fine but could expose it to enormous civil damages. ARIANE BERNARD

Charles Ghigna Homewood, Ala.

Asian and European stock markets tumbled today, following the sharp drop in U.S. stocks on Tuesday, as concerns spread about the consequences of loose lending practices in the United States housing market. Most markets in Asia closed down between 2 and 3 percent. It was their biggest drop since the sharp declines two weeks ago that were triggered by the sell-off in China on February 27.

An article on March 3 about smoking bans at gambling sites misstated the title of Russell Sciandra. He is the director of the Center for a Tobacco Free New York, a coalition of groups of which the American Cancer Society is a member. He is not the president of the American Cancer Society.

Prince Norodom Ranariddh, a former prime minister, was sentenced in absentia to 18 months in prison for selling the headquarters of the party he once led. He is accused of earning $3.6 million on the deal but denies the charge. Prince Ranariddh was ousted as party leader last year and is now abroad. He was ousted as co-prime minister in 1997 in a coup led by the other co-prime minister, Hun Sen, who now runs the country on his own. An aide said the prince, a son of the retired king, Norodom Sihanouk, might seek a pardon from the current king, Norodom Sihamoni, who is his brother. SETH MYDANS

GLICKMAN--Richard, loving uncle and brother-in-law, trusted business partner. We will miss your warm smile, intellectual curiosity and deep store of knowledge. We are so happy you got to meet Bella Grace but so sad she won't get to know you. Going to the movies will never be the same. Our hearts and thoughts are with Ruth, Jodie, Eric, Jay and Bella Grace. Carol, Richard, Nathaniel and Jason $(6$)GLICKMAN--Richard, Passed away on March 13, 2007. A kind and honorable man, he fought his battle with cancer with dignity and grace. He leaves behind his adoring wife, Ruth Kintzer-Glickman, the light of his life, his daughter Jodi and his son-in-law Eric Brown, whom he loved like his own, his cherished son Jay, and the most beautiful baby he had ever seen, his new granddaughter Bella Grace Brown. He left us with a void that can never be filled and hearts that are shattered. Services Thursday, 4 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering, c/o Dr. Leonard Saltz, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021, would be most appreciated.

A choreographer for people who hate modern dance, Matthew Bourne is known for bringing both narrative and nudity center stage. (Jesse Green called Mr. Bourne's ''Swan Lake'' ''a psychosexual hybrid of Hitchcock's 'Birds' and an Abercrombie & Fitch catalog.'') So his balletic take on ''Edward Scissorhands,'' which opens tonight after a decade in development, may be even more delightfully weird than Tim Burton's version. With a score by Danny Elfman, a story by the film's original screenwriter, and the approval of Johnny Depp it's sure to be a cultural touchstone (with sharp edges). Through March 31. At 7 p.m. tonight at BAM, 30 Lafayette Avenue (Ashland Place), Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100; $30-$70. Tickets are also available for the opening gala, with cocktail reception and after-party.

The police have arrested one of the country's most feared gang leaders, known by his first name, Evans, the United Nations said. Known for organizing criminal activity in his corner of Cité Soleil, the seaside shantytown in Port-au-Prince, Evans led attacks against United Nations peacekeeping troops in recent months. MARC LACEY

LOFFREDO--Rudolph, on March 12, 2007. Born in the Bronx on November 27, 1923. Married the former Catherine Florio in 1949 and shared devoted love until her death in 1995. Survived by his children Susan, Stephen, and Sandie and by his beloved grandchildren Gina, Benjamin, Eliza, Giuliette, and Graham. Rudy attended the City College of New York and, after graduating, served during World War II on the heavy cruiser U.S.S. Pittsburgh in the Battles of Iwo Jima and Okinawa. A civil engineer, Rudy spent his professional life at the Karl Koch Erecting Company, where he supervised the steel construction of the World Trade Center and the Jacob Javits Convention Center, and from which he retired as president in 1988. Rudy was a gentleman, the consummate professional, a cherished friend, and the backbone of his family to which he was thoroughly and completely devoted. The wake is March 15, 7-9pm, and March 16, 2-4pm and 7-9pm, McMahon Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains. The funeral is March 17, St. Patrick's Church, 7 Pound Ridge Rd, Bedford. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: Alzheimer's Association, www.alz.org, 225 N Michigan Ave, Chicago, IL 60601, or Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research www.michaeljfox.org

The New York Philharmonic yesterday announced plans for a European tour May 3-18. Led by Lorin Maazel, the Philharmonic will play in Warsaw, Budapest, Vienna, Frankfurt, Cologne, Paris and Luxembourg. The soloists will be Glenn Dicterow, the concertmaster; the principal cellist Carter Brey; the pianist Emanuel Ax; and the violinist Julia Fischer. The repertory will focus on Brahms. DANIEL J. WAKIN

A spokesman for the Hamas-led government, Ghazi Hamad, said the group had ''definite information'' about who kidnapped the BBC's Gaza correspondent, Alan Johnston. He was abducted by gunmen on Monday. Palestinian security services in Gaza were making efforts to bring about his release. The kidnappers are believed to belong to a powerful Gaza clan that regularly engages in criminal activity. ISABEL KERSHNER

TODAY we have our choice of books that explore the regional cooking of France or Italy in rich, firmly grounded detail, but until recently, regional Chinese cooking was little-reconnoitered territory. The young English-born China hand Fuchsia Dunlop changed all that a few years ago with ''Land of Plenty'' (W. W. Norton, 2003), which created a sensation in food-writing circles for its vividly revealing look into the cuisine of Sichuan province.

Portland police officers used a taser stun gun on Monday to subdue a woman having a severe diabetic reaction. A roommate called 911 for help for the woman, Brandi Hess, 26. Ms. Hess punched and kicked responders. An officer used a taser twice to subdue her after she kicked him in the groin and stomach. ''The officer felt the taser was the most appropriate option for restraint at the time in order to give her immediate medical attention,'' a spokesman for the police, Brian Schmautz, said. Family members said the force was excessive. JUDITH BERCK

ECHOES OF A RECENT BOOM Many technology veterans of Silicon Valley's dot-com era have regrouped and found a new mission in alternative energy: developing wind power, solar panels, ethanol plants and hydrogen-powered cars. [Page A1.] VIACOM TAKES ON GOOGLE Viacom, the parent of MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, filed a lawsuit accusing Google of ''massive copyright infringement'' on its YouTube site. Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages. [C1.] FORECLOSURES POINT THE WAY DOWN Stocks fell broadly and sharply after a report on mortgage defaults indicated that the troubled housing market will weaken further before showing signs of improvement. [C1.] IMPACT OF SUBPRIME TURMOIL Mutual funds held mortgage-related debt securities issued by subprime lenders New Century Financial, Novastar Financial and others at the end of last year, indicating that everyday investors are among those who will likely be hurt by the turmoil that is tearing through the residential mortgage market. [C1.] SPYING CASE LINGERS Hewlett-Packard executives would normally have a lot to crow about at today's annual meeting, including rising profit margins across the company. But last fall's revelations of a boardroom meltdown cast a long shadow. [C1.] IT GOES DOWN EASY Folgers has opened a new flank in the coffee wars by offering a ''stomach friendly'' coffee for consumers who think they can no longer handle the hard stuff. [C1.] TURNING OFF THE LIGHT A coalition of industrialists, environmentalists and energy specialists is banding together to try to eliminate the incandescent light bulb in about 10 years and replace it with alternatives that are more efficient and last longer. [C3.] PROFIT UP 29 PERCENT Goldman Sachs reported a 29 percent increase in profit for its first quarter, setting a record amid growing concern on Wall Street over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market. The firm reported profit of $3.2 billion, or $6.67 a share, for the quarter that ended before the recent market slump and the problems involving subprime lenders. [C3.] ADMINISTRATION'S NEW ATTITUDE Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. suggested that the administration was considering a more business-friendly approach, a response to criticism that post-Enron rule changes had gone too far. [C3.] LEHMAN INVESTS IN HEDGE FUND Lehman Brothers, bought a 20 percent stake in the management companies of D. E. Shaw, a $29 billion hedge fund. The acquisition continued Lehman's strategy of buying stakes in hedge funds to gain exposure to the fast-growing alternative asset arena. For David Shaw, above, who has watched his company grow from $28 million in 1988 to $29 billion today, the deal was probably a way to diversify his wealth. [C2.] DISC WITH MEDICAL DATA MISSING WellPoint, one of the nation's largest health insurers, has begun notifying 75,000 members of its Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield unit in New York, that a compact disc holding their sensitive medical and other personal information has disappeared. [C2.] EX-SIEMENS MANAGERS ON TRIAL Two former managers for Siemens told a German court that they participated in paying bribes of roughly 6 million euros in Italy as part of the company's plan to anchor itself in the booming market for power generation equipment. [C9.] XBOX ONLINE SERVICE FOR PC'S TOO Microsoft announced that it was extending the online gaming service for its Xbox consoles to the millions of people who use Windows PCs to play games over the Internet. [C3.] THE HUMOR IS LOST Washington Mutual has stopped running a commercial that showed actors playing bankers poised atop a building as if about to jump, the latest spot to be pulled in a backlash against advertising with suicide themes. Advertising: Stuart Elliot. [C8.] AN OIL CITY IN BLOOM Houston has shaken off the effects of the Enron implosion six years ago and is enjoying its strongest resurgence in more than 20 years, galvanized by record profits at energy companies. [C6.] A BID TO CUT CARBON EMISSIONS Britain is proposing laws to enforce a cut in carbon emissions, in this case, a 60 percent decrease by 2050. [A13.] HAUTE CUISINE IN ROOM 932 More hotels are aiming and claiming to provide room service on a higher plane. But are they succeeding? The Times's restaurant critic packed a bag and endeavored to find out. [F1.] RIGHTS TO SIMPSON BOOK The rights to the aborted O. J. Simpson book, ''If I Did It,'' should be auctioned so the family of the murder victim Ronald L. Goldman will receive the proceeds from the sale of the rights, a judge in Los Angeles ruled. [A16.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE COSMETICS MAKER REVLON posted a fourth-quarter loss, in contrast to a year-ago profit, as sales dropped and the company had costs associated with a revamping program. (REUTERS)

To the Editor: Re: ''Trans Fat Fight Claims Butter as a Victim'' (March 7): The graphic for this story suggests that butter has more natural trans fat than other dairy foods and meat. But no one sits down to eat a stick of butter, and the other foods are all roughly serving sizes. For a one-tablespoon serving of butter, the number is .39 grams, too low to be listed on a label.

A plainclothes police officer was shot twice and seriously wounded last night in a gunfight in Harlem with a suspect who was killed, the authorities said. The officer was hospitalized and expected to survive. The gunfight broke out about 9:30 p.m. after the officer, Robert Tejeda, 35, approached the suspect with three other officers at a small restaurant on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard near West 136th Street called Café 22, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said.

LEFKOWITZ--Howard N. The attorneys and staff of Proskauer Rose, LLP, mourn the passing of Howard N. Lefkowitz, a senior partner in Proskauer's Corporate Department. We have lost not only a colleague and a friend but also a lawyer's lawyer who was known for his scholarship and pioneering spirit. In the 43 years Howard worked at Proskauer, he developed an impressive and diverse practice. A visionary in the emerging field of private equity, which would evolve into one of the firm's most active practice areas, he represented institutional investors-including Verizon, JPMorgan and others-in their investments in private equity funds that totaled in the billions. Nationally recognized for his work in partnership and limited liability company law, Howard authored the New York Limited Liability Company Forms and Practice Manual and co-authored Transactional Lawyers Deskbook: Advising Business Entities. He had extensive experience with alternative investment vehicles, and he lectured frequently on limited partnerships, limited liability companies and fiduciary obligations. In 2006, the American Bar Association presented Howard with the Martin I. Lubaroff Award in recognition of his work on partnership law. Howard, known for his love of the law, was a tremendous resource to his colleagues, who relied on his deep knowledge, particularly of New York law and Delaware partnership issues. As his friend and colleague Bruce Lieb remembers, Howard knew the answers to questions that many of us did not realize were questions. Howard retired in 2006 but continued to practice. He spoke and wrote frequently, and he contributed his professional time to organizations including the Private Investment Fund Forum, the ABA and the TriBar Opinion Committee. An expert on wine as well as the law, Howard enjoyed an extensive wine collection and contributed articles to food and wine magazines. Howard received his B.A. from Cornell University and his law degree from Columbia University Law School, where he was a Kent Scholar and an editor of the Columbia Law Review. Howard, who is survived by his wife, Midge, his two children and five grandchildren, will be greatly missed and affectionately remembered. Allen I. Fagin Chair, Proskauer Rose $(6$)LEFKOWITZ--Howard N., 70, born and raised in Utica, NY, now of New York City and Great Barrington, MA, died on March 12 of multiple myeloma. Survived by wife Midge; daughter Sarah and husband Ted; son David and wife Laurie; grandchildren Alex, Zachary, Adam, Anna Kate, and Talia; brother Manny and sisters Betty and Elinor; many nieces and nephews, and by a wonderful extended Sitrin family. Howard graduated Cornell University where he met Midge. Served as an officer in the US Navy in the destroyer fleet at Newport, RI, and graduated from Columbia Law School, where he became an editor of the Law Review and a Kent Scholar. Howard practiced corporate and partnership law at Proskauer, Rose, Goetz and Mendelsohn (now Proskauer Rose) his entire career of over 40 years, retiring as a senior partner in 2005. He enjoyed active participation in the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the ABA Section of Business Law Parnership Committee, the Tri-Bar Opinion Committee, and the Private Investment Fund Forum. He insisted that his avid interest in, and consumption of fine wine did not hasten his demise. Funeral Wednesday, 12 noon, at Gramercy Chapel, 152 Second Ave. at 9th Street. Contributions to Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, 383 Main Ave, Norwalk, CT 08651, would be appreciated.

To the Editor: Re ''For War's Gravely Injured, a Challenge to Find Care'' (front page, March 12): The reporting of the severe physical and mental disabilities of our service members illustrates the continuing betrayal of the Bush administration regarding the war in Iraq.

The Postal Service is commemorating the 200th anniversary of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's birth with a new 39-cent stamp, the latest in the annual Literary Arts series. Longfellow is best remembered for his epic poems, including ''Paul Revere's Ride'' and ''The Song of Hiawatha.'' The new stamp was designed by Kazuhiko Sano based on an 1870s photograph of Longfellow and shows scenes from Revere's ride in the background. It goes on sale at a ceremony at noon today that is free to the public, as part of a stamp show at Madison Square Garden through Sunday. The ceremony will include recitations by winners of the Poetry Out Loud National Recitation contest.

Because of an editing error, an article in Sunday Business this week about coaching services for users of online dating sites misstated the Web address of one such service. It is EvanMarcKatz.com, not EvanMarkKatz.com.

A group of fired legislators clashed with the police after forcing their way into Congress as President Rafael Correa's plan to rewrite the Constitution continued to generate protests. Dozens of protesters supporting Mr. Correa also gathered in front of the building, screaming epithets to the group of about 20 legislators, who were dismissed last week by the Electoral Tribunal after trying to reverse a ruling that could have potentially eroded their power. Mr. Correa, who is seeking to diminish the easy ability of Congress to oust presidents in Ecuador, accused the fired legislators of ''abusing the misery of the people.'' Mr. Correa is Ecuador's eighth president in 10 years. SIMON ROMERO

To the Editor: Thank you for your article ''Is Whole Foods Straying From Its Roots?'' (Feb. 28). Expired and less than fresh products from Whole Foods certainly is not a regional problem limited to New York City and Washington.

You could feel the hatred of Duke filling Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum on Thursday night in Winston-Salem, N.C., even though the Blue Devils were hundreds of miles north and playing in Buffalo.
Foreign bands are gaining an American foothold, as seen at the South by Southwest music festival in Austin., Tex.

The White House press secretary and Davidson alum Tony Snow didn't get to watch all of the 13th-seeded Wildcats' 82-70 loss to No. 4 seed Maryland on Thursday, but he saw the game's most entertaining action.

When people ask how a columnist chooses among the eight sub-regionals in the tournament, I could give a stuffy answer about potential upsets or strength of matchups. The fact is, I whined and begged to come to Kentucky because, in a way, it's home. More than three decades ago I was a young news reporter covering this area, and it got a hold on me.

Nevada Coach Mark Fox was bummed out that his best friend and former boss, Trent Johnson, got thumped by Louisville in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament on Thursday. Fox said that he'd been so wrapped up in his own team that he didn't even realize that Stanford was playing that day. Fox hadn't even looked at a full bracket until this morning.

The Bracket checked in with the N.C.A.A. tournament's most famous "almost hero," the former Western Carolina coach Phil Hopkins. Back in 1996, Hopkins' 16th-seeded Western Carolina team had two shots at the buzzer - one to win and another to tie - that missed against No. 1 Purdue. A No. 16 seed has never beaten a No. 1, and Hopkins' team may have come closest of any of the 90 teams that have tried.

You knew that New Mexico State's Reggie Theus was a different type of college coach when you heard the way his players spoke about him Thursday as they prepared to face Texas on Friday in the opening round of the East Region in Spokane.

Senator Barack Obama was wearing a wide smile tonight as he bounded out of the Senate chamber and rushed to catch a downward elevator. He had little time to spare; a fundraiser for his presidential campaign was soon to begin in Chevy Chase, Md.
The Ohio State fans have left the building and we finally have competitive basketball on the TV: Duke vs. V.C.U.

President Bush told Republicans tonight that the party can retain the White House and regain control of Congress in 2008, if they hold true to their values.

When the Davidson freshman shooting guard Stephen Curry fouled out Thursday with 20.9 seconds remaining in his team's 82-70 loss to fourth-seeded Maryland, he received a standing ovation from the crowd of 18,646 at HSBC Arena in Buffalo, N.Y.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A.O. Scott reviews "The Wind That Shakes the Barley," a film about the Irish uprising of the early 1920s.
A rare glimpse into Sutter Buttes, California. What has always been privately owned land may become the state's newest park.

Todd Wright is the strength coach for the Texas Longhorns and one of his strengths could one day win him an Oscar nomination. Wright supervises the making of motivational videos for Coach Rick Barnes to show to his players.
A trailer for "Hannah Takes the Stairs," a film by Joe Swanberg.

Eighteen residents of an isolated village in northeastern China, all over 80 years of age, are the last speakers of Manchu.
In a noisy Butler locker room following Thursday's victory over Old Dominion, forward Pete Campbell looked around the room with a smile, letting it all sink in.

Notre Dame is seeded sixth, which should make it the favorite to defeat No. 11 Winthrop in the first round of the East Region on Friday in Spokane. But the Eagles have more recent N.C.A.A. tournament experience than the Fighting Irish, who last qualified in 2003.
The South Beach area of Miami, Fla., is vibrant, sometimes chaotic and always fun.

There's no question that the views of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on the Iraq war and how to move forward -- to borrow a phrase -- light up the keyboards across the blogosphere. Especially on the left, which is still incensed because she won't apologize for her 2002 vote authorizing the use of force in Iraq. No matter how many times she says if she knew then what she knows now, it's not good enough (for the anti-war contingent).
Frank Blake, the new chief executive of Home Depot, is doing his best to come off as the un-Nardelli. The latest episode is his apology to angry customers on MSN Money:
An interview with the fugitive Palestinian leader Shakir al-Abssi.

Feathers could have been flying here at this N.C.A.A. tournament subregional in Columbus, Ohio. Chief Illiniwek, the college student dressed up to look like an American Indian for Illinois athletic events, and Virginia Tech's Hokie, which resembles a turkey, could have been trading barbs in the first-round game.
Dunleavy's shillelagh. [Gotham Gazette]

It's worth noting that, without fail, the poor souls charged with the thankless job of choosing the field for the N.C.A.A. tournament are called dolts by just about everybody. Teams that make the tournament feel they should have been granted a better seed, and teams that were seeded No. 1 feel they have the toughest route to the Final Four. But the truly aggrieved, those charged with the fiercest righteous indignation, are those who were left out of the tournament altogether. Last year the anger mobs were from Cincinnati, Michigan, Maryland and Missouri State. (You are forgiven if you didn't remember who the "snubs" were last year; it's possible not even the snubbed teams remember anymore.)

Iowapolitics.com is reporting: "Former New York Gov. George Pataki has told supporters he cannot guarantee he is going to run for president this cycle and has given his blessing for them to join other presidential campaigns." A couple of big names have apparently made the jump to Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts.

Yes, it has finally started, and the Thursday afternoon press conference and a few photos from the track attest to it: the drivers are itching to get on the track, and ready to race. Even the Kimi Raikkonen of Ferrari is looking just like the Kimi Raikkonen of McLaren, as this photo shows. Kimi is an inveterate yawner... but never while he is on the track racing, where he frequently makes us all leap out of our chairs rather than tend toward sleep.

With spring training more than halfway over now, I thought we'd check in again with C.J. Nitkowski, the longtime big league reliever who's embarking on a new career in Japan with the Softbank Hawks. C.J. has agreed to answer some questions here and there throughout the season.

The Creighton junior guard Nick Bahe is majoring in journalism and someday dreams of breaking down N.C.A.A. tournament games like Clark Kellogg and Jay Bilas. (For now he'll settle for coming off the bench to help the Bluejays advance in the N.C.A.A. tournament against Nevada on Friday.)

The city Health Department is investigating a case of drug-sensitive tuberculosis in a health care worker who works at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. Mothers, babies, patients, and staff who were in the maternity, neonatal, or psychiatric units at St. Barnabas from Nov. 1, 2006 to Jan. 24, 2007, may have been exposed and should be screened immediately.

You'd never know it in the Mets' clubhouse, where the televisions are tuned to the N.C.A.A. tournament games and players are (jokingly) plotting how to watch the next wave of games if they're supposed to be in the dugout.

Until a recent pleasure trip to Chicago, I didn't think it possible to encounter a menu with a category I'd never seen before. I didn't think menus could get any more segmented and complicated than they already had.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has issued a statement clarifying her earlier response to a question about the morality of homosexuality, and Barack Obama has also put out a statement, The Caucus reports.

J.P. Morgan Chase has hired Ian Connor as a managing director in its energy investment banking group, according to an internal memo. Mr. Connor, who was previously at Goldman Sachs, will focus on the power companies when he joins the firm in June. Prior to Goldman Sachs, Mr. Connor was a power and utilities banker at Lazard.

The new last-minute witness in the Sean Bell case testified this afternoon for less than an hour before the grand jury, according to a law enforcement official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.The 23 Queens residents on the grand jury have returned to their deliberations, the official said.

The campaigns of Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are in sync not only on the geopolitical importance of Selma, Ala., but also on the issue of whether homosexuality is moral or not. This afternoon, the Obama campaign released the following statement:

Cisco's acquisition strategy has been a bit of a puzzle lately. The company, best known for making routers that direct network traffic, got Silicon Valley talking earlier this month when it bought the technology assets of Tribe.net, a mostly forgotten social networking site. On Thursday, Cisco announced another offbeat (and much bigger) deal: the $3.2 billion purchase of WebEx, a Web-based video conferencing service.

I know we had a story in the paper today about the re-emergence of the number "0" on college jerseys, but for my money I'm watching the best name I've seen in a long time on the back of a jersey. It's sported by Texas A&M point guard Acie Law IV.
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's Mar. 15 column, "The Danger Zone."
Readers respond to David Brooks's Mar. 15 column, "The Long Exit."

Around the Winthrop basketball team, it is a compliment to be known as a "JunkYard Dog,'' such an honor that Coach Gregg Marshall presents a doll of a professional wrestler by that name after Eagles victories to the player who is judged to have played the toughest.

Hamilton College, a smallish but well-regarded liberal arts institution in upstate New York, announced today that it would stop awarding scholarships to students based on merit -- that is, academic achievements and qualifications -- next year.

Auxiliary police officers, like the two men killed in last night's shootout, are volunteers who do not carry guns. They wear uniforms identifical to paid officers, wear badge-like stars and carry nightsticks.
Mr. Mattei performs an aria from "The Barber of Seville."

The state education commissioner has added nine New York City schools to a list of those in danger of being closed for academic failure. Eight of the nine are middle schools, a clear sign of the deepening crisis in the quality of education in middle grades in the city.Commissioner Richard Mills announced the moves today, saying that various changes to the list would put the total number of "schools under registration review" at 65 statewide, 35 of them in New York City. Three schools each were added to the list in Buffalo, Syracuse and Rochester, and one each in Wyandanch and Yonkers. (Eight schools were removed: six in New York City, one in Hempstead, and one in Yonkers.)
Virginia Tech Coach Seth Greenberg can't turn around without seeing a familiar face or a familiar color here at the subregional in Columbus.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just released this statement on whether homosexuality is immoral, after being pressed by gay rights organizations to clarify her initial remarks.

Californians like a good backdrop, and so perhaps it is no surprise that Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger today chose The Stanford Mansion in Sacramento -- the site of the first presidential visit to California in 1880 -- to sign the bill that officially moves California's primary from June to Feb. 5.

City Councilman Miguel Martinez is threatening to deploy a novel weapon in the increasingly testy battle between organizers of the St. Patrick's Day Parade and the firefighters they are pushing to the middle of the procession: the boo coalition.According to news reports, John Dunleavy, the chairman of the planning committee, said that he moved the firefighters to the middle because they held up the parade last year allowing firefighters from New Orleans to unfurl a banner thanking New York for its help after Hurricane Katrina and because they show up to the celebration drunk.

Does Ned Yost, the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, prefer David Lee Roth over Sammy Hagar as the lead singer for Van Halen? As Hagar's vocals to "When It's Love" played over the sound system at Maryvale Baseball Park on Thursday, Yost waved up at the press box and ran a finger across his neck to indicate that he wanted the music turned off.

The Quinnipiac University Poll that showed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg ahead of Rudolph W. Giuliani in the race for president -- at least on their home turf of New York -- also had some interesting numbers about New Yorkers' view of the Sean Bell case (this was highlighted by Capitol Confidential last night.)The poll found that 57 percent of New York City voters support criminal charges against the officers who killed the unarmed Mr. Bell. (A grand jury in Queens is in its second day of deliberations on the matter, after hearing much evidence not available to people who answer polls.)
There was no lunch break during the House Appropriations Committee hearing today, but there was plenty of time to talk about spinach.

Over at The Caucus, Gerry Mullany notes that a big question hanging over the Giuliani campaign has been the role of his third wife, Judith Nathan, in the campaign. A video of Ms. Nathan seems to have answered that question.

It may end up being largely symbolic, but Calpers, the country's biggest pension fund and a major force on corporate governance issues, said it voted its shares against drugstore chain CVS's $23.5 billion acquisition of drug-benefits manager Caremark Rx. Objecting from both sides of the deal, Calpers said it opposed the transaction with its 3.1 million CVS shares and 2.1 million Caremark shares. Nevertheless, CVS shareholders approved the deal Thursday, leaving Friday's vote by Caremark shareholders as the final hurdle.

I'm sitting here courtside at the Louisville-Stanford game and thinking about Bruiser Flint, Jim Boeheim and Don Meredith. Flint and Boeheim, the Drexel and Syracuse coaches, each had better teams than Stanford and were shut out of the tournament.
Hear from lifestyle designer Adrienne Vittadini and other homeowners in Sarasota on the booming luxury second-home market on Florida's west coast.
Katharine Moser, who was at risk for Huntington's disease, decided to be tested for the gene that causes it. She now knows she will develop the disorder.

State Senator Malcolm A. Smith's district includes the Queens neighborhood where Sean Bell was killed by undercover police officers last year. Senator Smith is also the chamber's minority leader, and today he decided to hold a press conference warning of the consequences should a grand jury currently deliberating in the case decide not to hand down any indictments of officers.Mr. Smith stressed that he had no hard information on what the grand jury would do, but said he had been prompted to act by the news that investigators had offered up a last-minute witness who said he saw a man fire a gun at the police.

Hillary Rodham Clinton has used her spouse as a weapon on the campaign trail. And so has Mitt Romney. A big question hanging over the Giuliani campaign has been whether he would do the same, given the circumstances of his third marriage to Judith Nathan, which followed his headline-grabbing divorce from Donna Hanover.

On a day with much breaking and anticipated news, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had a light schedule to begin with: a speech at the Queens Chamber of Commerce's annual St. Patrick's Day Luncheon at Terrace on the Park, and no plans to take more questions from reporters.
New shows in New York include "Talk Radio," "The Attic" and "Moby Dick — Rehearsed."

Of the many obscure, untested and unproved theories that The Bracket will subject you to about the N.C.A.A. tournament, none is better than the Outpost Upset Theory.

It's this year's hottest must-have luxury item -- the $4,000 designer coffee table book. Some might have thought Gloria Books crazy when it decided last year to roll out 1,500 copies of a 12-kilogram tome on soccer star Pele for £1,600 -- or about $3,000 -- each. But the London-based publisher sold out within a few months.

Mr. Spitzer and Joseph Bruno, the Republican majority leader, had their blow-up after the bill-signing and news conference. (Gothamist has the metacoverage.) This morning, Danny Hakim of The Times reported, "Some lawmakers also said that Mr. Bruno was angry about which lawmakers were permitted to stand at the lectern and speak during the news conference."

More than a month after promising in their Mecca accord to do so, Hamas and Fatah, the two main Palestinian factions, have reached agreement on a slate of cabinet ministers in a joint "unity" government for the Palestinian territories. It is to be put to a formal vote of confidence in the Palestinian parliament on Saturday.

In a news release, the company said that its $8 billion deal to combine with CBOT Holdings, which runs the Chicago Board of Trade, would proceed as planned, despite Intercontinental's bombshell $9.9 billion offer for CBOT. Louisville's Rick Pitino knows a thing or two about this tournament, winning it with Kentucky in 1996 and reaching the Final Four on four other occasions. His Cardinals are a No. 6 seed, which hardly bothers him: he believes that this is a year when a team seeded fifth or lower can easily capture the tournament.

The general assumption in news coverage about the Justice Department/White House firing of federal prosecutors has been that it may have been sleazy, inappropriate and the subject of a cover-up, but that there was nothing illegal about it. That's probably the case with most of the individuals who were fired.
Update: Kenneth D. Moelis will resign from UBS, DealBook reported Monday. Go here for the latest item.

Michael R. Long, quoting Shakespeare's "The Tempest," expresses his disapproval this morning with Senate Republicans' budget proposal and conditional approval of Gov. Eliot Spitzer's own proposal. Mr. Long is the chairman of the state's Conservative Party -- which, as he reminds us all in his press release, was founded in the 1960s by conservative New Yorkers who felt that the Republican Party had lost its way.It's interesting in the context of the ongoing budget negotiations, in which Mr. Spitzer and the Senate Republicans don't even agree on what their respective proposals actually do: Senate Republicans, through Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader, insist that they are actually cutting money from Mr. Spitzer's budget, rather than adding it. Mr. Long's press release backs the governor, suggesting that the Senate Republicans are even more profligate than he thinks the Democrats usually are.
Last week, I attended my second TED conference, which stands for Technology, Entertainment, and Design. During the four-day conference, you hear 50 speakers, who are given 18 minutes each.
DES MOINES - The Straight Talk Express is back on the road today.

A short while ago, the jurors returned to continue their deliberations about the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell, according to the police bureau of The Times. The grand jury is weighing whether to indict any officers in the fatal shooting of Mr. Bell.
“Reclaimed” teak, a wood from the Far East, is increasingly popular with Americans.

The Spitzer administration has sent letters to the six would-be contenders for New York's horseracing franchise, outling how the bidding process will work now that the administration has decided to ignore the findings of the Pataki-era Ad Hoc Committee on the Future of Racing, which recommended that Excelsior Racing Associates get the franchise.Proposals are due on March 31, and the contenders will be asked to make public presentations on April 10 and April 11.

I've periodically said that the U.S. needs to improve its quantitative skills, because our students are so far behind those abroad in this area. The NY Times published a nice math quiz in which you can see how you measure up. The quiz consists of eight questions that were given Terence Tao, now one of the world's top mathematicians, shortly before he turned eight years old. One of the questions, for example, was: What angle does the hour hand of a clock describe in 20 minutes?

On the Republican side, there's been less interest, aside from Sam Brownback. But Rudy Giuliani weighed in last night in a major speech, and I'm hoping he's going to keep up the drumbeat. Obviously pressure from Republicans counts for much more in this White House than calls from Democrats or from hand-wringing op-ed columnists. Here's what Giuliani said:

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg addressed reporters after 2:30 a.m. about the fatal shootout in Greenwich Village last night, which left four people dead, including two auxiliary police officers, Nicholas T. Pekearo, left, 28, and Yevgeniy Marshalik, 19.

Has the IntercontinentalExchange sparked a bidding war? Investors seem to hope so. Shares of CBOT Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Board of Trade, rose 15 percent, to $191 in early trading Thursday after Intercontinental, an electronic marketplace for energy trades, announced its offer to merge with the exchange in a $9.9 billion stock swap. The surge put shares of CBOT, which is in the final stages of a merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, above the value of Intercontinental's bid, based on an exchange ratio of 1.42 Intercontinental shares for each CBOT share. (That comes out to $186.38 based on Incontinental's recent price of $131.25.)
Gone to U.S. houses, every one.

It can be easy for the West, its attention necessarily focused on violent extremism of an Islamist nature, to forget that there are other kinds abroad in the world. So when news breaks like the deadly attack on a police station in central India this morning, the identity of the suspected culprits can sometimes bring one up short: Maoists? There are still Maoists?

Viacom's $1 billion lawsuit over YouTube is only the latest indication that Google has no chance of winning a long-term battle against the entertainment industry over copyright law, suggests Dallas Mavericks owner and online video entrepreneur Mark Cuban on his personal blog. Even if Google wins the suit, Hollywood will lobby Congress to change the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, Cuban argues. He writes:
