Cisco Systems said Wednesday that it would buy WebEx, a collaboration-software maker, for $3.2 billion, or $57 a share. The deal is the latest in a string of unusual acquisitions for Cisco, the router giant, which has sought to bulk up on services it can provide over its network hardware.
David Pogue touts the Technology, Entertainment, and Design conference, and urges readers to go online to get a lesson in cutting-edge technologies.

General Electric and the Blackstone Group said Thursday that they would buy PHH, a financial-services and mortgage provider, for $31.50 a share, or $1.8 billion. The price represents a 13 percent premium to PHH's closing stock price of $27.81 on Wednesday. According to the terms of the deal, G.E. Capital will acquire PHH, holding onto the PHH Arval fleet management services unit while selling PHH Mortgage, a residential mortgage servicer, to Blackstone after the transaction closes.
The Rockefeller Apartments, opposite the Museum of Modern Art’s sculpture garden, are home to a self-selected group of architecture, design and art makers and aficionados.
Pictures from a surveillance video released by the New York Police Department show a gunman attacking two auxiliary police officers.

The Washington Post, in an editorial titled "The Reno Precedent," rebuts The Wall Street Journal's contention that Janet Reno's firing of all 93 United States attorneys at the start of Bill Clinton's first term is analogous to Alberto Gonzales's firing of eight United States attorneys in the middle of President Bush's second term:

Nelson Peltz may have broken the record for the time it took for an activist investor to elicit change from a company. Just days after Cadbury Schweppes disclosed that Mr. Peltz had acquired nearly 3 percent of its equity, the company announced Thursday that it would split into two businesses: one focused on drinks, the other on confections.

Bear Stearns, Wall Street's leading underwriter of mortgage-backed securities, said Thursday that earnings in its fiscal first quarter rose 8 percent from a year ago, but problems in the risky subprime loan sector hurt mortgage-related revenue. The investment bank said net income in the quarter increased to $554 million from $514 million in the year-earlier period.

The tobacco company Altadis said Thursday that it had received an unsolicited approach from the Imperial Tobacco Group of Britain that values the company, which makes Fortuna, Gitanes and Ducados cigarette brands, at 11.52 billion euros ($ 15.21 billion).
When the fall runway season ended, a week ago Sunday, there seemed more to consider than to sweep aside.

As the California attorney general's office dropped charges against Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, and accepted guilty pleas from three other defendants over a spying scandal, pundits are speculating over the reasons why. The most common refrain: The laws at the time did not warrant Ms. Dunn's conviction.

The testy relationship between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, veered into nastiness during an argument in the governor's office yesterday, just minutes after the two had appeared together at a solemn bill-signing ceremony."It was a spirited discussion between two guys who aren't effete," said Darren Dopp, the governor's communications director. He said Senator Bruno, the state's top Republican, used some vulgarities to describe the relationship between Malcolm A. Smith, a Democrat and the Senate minority leader, and the governor's posterior.

The IntercontinentalExchange said Thursday that it offered to merge with the Chicago Board of Trade, seeking to derail that exchange's agreement to combine with its hometown rival, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The surprise bid, valued at about $9.9 billion in stock, came just a few weeks before shareholders of CBOT, the parent of the Chicago Board of Trade, were scheduled to vote on its merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

If the first day of jury selection for the former press tycoon Conrad M. Black is any indication, then many in the potential jury pool have not forgotten the corporate scandals of a few years ago. Judge Amy J. St. Eve began the process on Wednesday of winnowing down a pool of more than 100 potential jurors in the criminal fraud trial of Mr. Black and three former associates in United States District Court by asking them about their attitudes toward money, titles and tax loopholes.

After struggling with the issue for more than six years, the Federal Communications Commission is finally making a serious stab at reinstating limits on the audience reach of cable operators and other subscription television providers. Such a move would limit the ability of certain providers to make any large acquisitions in the near future.

L-3 Communications Holdings, a maker of battlefield communications systems, was asked Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission for information on past stock option practices. The company plans to provide the requested material to the agency's enforcement division and will continue to cooperate fully, according to a report it filed with the S.E.C.

An investment fund of Australia's Macquarie Bank has agreed to buy the car-parking facilities of Britain's National Car Parks for 790 million pounds ($1.52 billion) from a private equity firm, the 3i Group. 3i will retain NCP's car-clamping and towing services unit following the demerger of the group. NCP operates about 850 car parks with about 50,000 spaces, accounting for more than half Britain's off-street parking market, and is the largest provider of spaces at airports and railway stations.

Merrill Lynch is considering providing debt financing for a private equity group hoping to mount a 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) bid for Alliance Boots, the British drugstore chain, The Guardian reported. Merrill's interest in backing a new bid emerged just a day after it quit as Alliance Boots' joint broker and two days after Alliance rejected an initial bid of 10 pounds a share from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the deputy chairman of Boots, Stefano Pessina.

Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market may throw a wrench into H&R Block's plans to sell its subprime mortgage group. While its tax business is showing signs of improvement, H&R Block cannot get rid of its subprime mortgage group, Option One, fast enough. H&R Block disclosed yesterday that its loss widened to $60.3 million in the third quarter as a result of continued problems at Option One, which the company put on the block last year.

The Smurfit Kappa Group, the world's largest maker of cardboard boxes, raised 1.3 billion euros ($1.7 billion) Wednesday in Ireland's biggest initial public offering in almost eight years. The shares were priced at 16.5 euros apiece, valuing the company at about 3.4 billion euros.
“My Brother” is billed as the tale of two poor, orphaned siblings, but it wants to be much more than that.

Mediaset, the broadcaster controlled by former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, is prepping a bid for Dutch reality TV producer Endemol, the creator of the genre classic "Big Brother." Mediaset's chief executive, Giuliano Adreani, told journalists that the company is planning a bid with Endemol's founder, John De Mol, who sold the company to Spain's Telefónica and now wants to get it back.

Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold's $25.9 billion cash-and-stock acquisition of a rival, Phelps Dodge, was approved Wednesday by shareholders of both companies. The deal would create the world's largest publicly traded copper company. In separate votes by shareholders of Freeport, which is based in New Orleans, and Phelps Dodge, based in Phoenix, the buyout was approved by about 98 percent of the votes cast, the companies said in a joint statement.
The recent volatility and pullback in Asian markets have prompted some investors to sound a familiar refrain: It's all the fault of the hedge funds.

Goldman Sachs was fined $2 million by market regulators Wednesday for allowing clients to make illegal short sales before stock offerings. Goldman did not follow procedures that might have uncovered a pattern of illegal trades from 2000 to 2002, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange said in statements.
“Adam’s Apples” — about a neo-Nazi sentenced to community service at a rural church — is a weird mix of glib humor with dead-serious spiritual inquiry.

Bank of America has agreed to pay $26 million to settle charges that its securities unit published fraudulent research reports on companies and failed to prevent leaks of reports that were used for improper trading, federal regulators said Wednesday. With the settlement, Bank of America becomes the last bank to settle an industrywide inquiry into possible conflicts of interest between analysts and bankers and ends a six-year investigation into the company's misuse of its own analysts' research.

Seeing green in more ways than one, some big names from Silicon Valley on Wednesday urged Washington to double its funding of energy research, The San Jose Mercury New reported. The chief executives and venture investors used a day of meetings organized by TechNet, an organization set up by technology executives, to try and convince members of the Bush administration and Congress, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, that they need a sustained federal commitment to research, and changes in tax policy to spur the development of clean technology.

At a time when mergers have reduced the number of banks in the nation, community banking start-ups are gaining favor among entrepreneurs. The New York Times notes that the number of banks in the United States has fallen to 7,402 at the end of last year from 14,411 banks in 1977.
The slim biographies will cover subjects including Andy Warhol’s soup cans, the Alfred Hitchcock classic “Psycho,” and Wagner’s “Ring” cycle.

“Andy Barker, P.I.” is a heavily plotted crime show that’s meant to evoke the 1970s.
“Raines,” a crime drama starring Jeff Goldblum as a detective who thinks he talks to the dead, in many ways is a homage to “The Singing Detective.”

A jury was asked to ponder some etiquette questions in the statutory rape trial of a private school principal and teacher accused of having sex with two of her students.
Bowie Kuhn was the commissioner of baseball during a tumultuous 15-year period when the game experienced dramatic growth accompanied by unprecedented labor strife.
Texas A&M, led by Acie Law’s 20 points, eventually dispatched Pennsylvania on Thursday, but not before turning back a determined effort from the Quakers.
Busloads of Belmont fans who travled to watch their underdog Bruins play No. 2 seed Georgetown went home disappoitned.  The heavily favore Hoyas advanced and will face Boston College.
The chief executive at Berkshire Hathaway took home the same $100,000 in 2006 that he has been earning for 25 years.
Stephen Curry, the son of former N.B.A. guard Dell Curry, scored 30, but it wasn’t enough for Davidson to overcome the Terrapins, who advanced to the second round.
A grand jury in Queens that is weighing evidence in the police shooting of Sean Bell interrupted its deliberations today to hear from a new witness.
The increase in the number of outposts is part of the plan to put American troops back on the streets.
The resolution would impose sanctions on Iran for its defiance of demands that it suspend nuclear enrichment.
Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who took responsibility for the Sept. 11 attacks, said he decapitated the American journalist Daniel Pearl, according to a revised transcript released today.
Israel said it would not deal with the new Palestinian government, which was announced today.
The Democratic resolution aimed at withdrawing most American combat troops from Iraq in 2008. A similar measure advanced in the House today.
The panel voted today to authorize the subpoenas as it investigates the dismissal of eight federal prosecutors.
At the Spring North American Championships, the winners of the Rockwell Mixed Pairs on Wednesday night were Mildred Breed of Austin, Tex., and Richard Zeckhauser of Cambridge, Mass.
The ambush appeared to be the biggest attack on Indian law enforcement in the last several years of insurgency.

Greenwich Village has long been the cheery, boozy living room of Manhattan, where the word “shoot” is most often a reference to a game of barroom pool, not street violence. Last night’s shootings — in which two auxiliary police officers, a bartender and their attacker were killed — jarred police helicopters, officers on horseback and the swirling lights of squad cars against laughter, tipsy college students and tourists with cellphone cameras.
The slayings of two auxiliary police officers last night came in a week that has underscored the dangers of routine police work in New York City.
Wal-Mart’s ambitions into consumer banking may extend beyond what the retail giant had previously disclosed.

China’s industrial output rose 18.5 percent in January and February, the National Bureau of Statistics said, after gaining 14.7 percent in December. That beat the 15 percent median estimate of 20 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. In February, China’s exports jumped the most they had in 12 years, and domestic sales accelerated.
Two days after Isiah Thomas was rewarded with a contract extension, the Knicks were roundly thumped by the Raptors, who came from nowhere to become the class of the Atlantic Division.
The maker of battlefield communications systems was asked by the S.E.C. for information on past stock option practices.

Small tremors emanating from Earth’s tectonic faults may help scientists forecast the likelihood of a major earthquake, according to a study. The tremors may precede the most destructive types of earthquakes, which occur in areas where two tectonic plates meet. The slow grinding of the plates causes low-frequency earthquakes. The study, to be published in the March 15 issue of Nature, linked low-frequency earthquakes and the tremors for the first time, according to scientists from Stanford and the University of Tokyo.
Jeffrey A. McDermott, one of three global heads of investment banking, will leave “to pursue outside entrepreneurial opportunities.”
The House overwhelmingly approved legislation to force government agencies to be more responsive to the millions of Freedom of Information Act requests for public documents they receive every year.

The state’s Department of Juvenile Justice reached a $5 million settlement with the parents of a 14-year-old boy who died in January 2006 after being beaten at a boot camp in Panama City. The agreement, orchestrated by Gov. Charlie Crist, would require approval by the Legislature. A lawyer for the boy’s parents, Ben Crump, said the family would seek another $5 million settlement from Bay County, which ran the boot camp. A criminal case is pending against the seven guards charged with beating the boy, Martin Lee Anderson, and against a nurse who watched.

Prosecutors dropped charges against six Guilford College football players accused of assaulting three Palestinian students and using ethnic slurs during a campus fight in Greensboro. Witness statements from nearly 30 people, including the Palestinians, give a “confusing picture” of what had happened and showed that the fight was not about ethnic intimidation, Assistant District Attorney Howard Neumann of Guilford County said.

The Roman Catholic archbishop of St. Paul and Minneapolis has forbidden the participants in a symposium on Catholicism and homosexuality to celebrate a Mass at their conference in Minneapolis this weekend. The archbishop, Harry J. Flynn, sent a letter to the organizers, New Ways Ministry, warning that the symposium “may well cause significant confusion to members of the faithful,” because some of the speakers have publicly questioned church teaching on homosexuality. About 500 participants have registered to attend the symposium, about half of them priests and nuns, and many others parish lay leaders.
Use of the anemia drugs will be reviewed by federal health insurance programs because of concerns that side effects may be harming patients.

The Navy temporarily lost communication with a submarine off Florida Tuesday night and sent ships and aircraft to search for the vessel before it was contacted early yesterday, military officials in Norfolk said. There were no problems with the Los Angeles class submarine, the San Juan, which is based in Groton, Conn. The Navy said it was investigating the incident.

Families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks cannot view hundreds of thousands of nonpublic documents used in the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, an appeals court said, overturning a lower court’s order. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, said the families were not entitled to view documents that were given to Mr. Moussaoui’s lawyers to aid his defense but were not made public. Mr. Moussaoui, 38, is the only person charged in the United States in connection with the attacks.

Time Warner Inc., the media company, withdrew its $900 million offer for TradeDoubler, an Internet advertising company, after failing to win the support of shareholders. The company’s AOL unit scrapped its 215-kronor-a-share bid after the deadline expired today, Time Warner said.

Nokia and Siemens said they planned to begin operating a joint venture phone network on April 1, with both companies having agreed to increase net asset contributions. Siemens will contribute 2.4 billion euros ($3.2 billion), while Nokia will add 1.7 billion euros to the venture, Siemens said. Nokia, based in Finland, and Siemens, based in Germany, agreed in June to merge their phone network units to close the gap with the market leaders, Ericsson and Alcatel-Lucent.

European Union regulators accused the Nippon Sheet Glass Company, the Asahi Glass Company and two competitors of fixing the price of glass used in construction. Asahi’s Glaverbel unit in Belgium, Nippon Sheet Glass’s Pilkington in Britain, the Guardian Industries Corporation in the United States and Saint-Gobain in France said that they were notified of the accusations and would respond. The companies have two months to reply.

The Smurfit Kappa Group, Europe’s market leader for cardboard products, raised 1.3 billion euros ($1.72 billion) as it floated shares on the Irish and British stock exchanges. The offering, which valued the Irish-Dutch company at 3.4 billion euros ($4.5 billion), was intended to help Smurfit Kappa reduce more than 4.5 billion euros ($5.9 billion) in debt. Smurfit Kappa’s chief executive, Gary McGann, above, said that about half the new shareholders would be institutional investors.

An investment fund of the Macquarie Bank has agreed to buy the car-parking facilities of National Car Parks of Britain for £790 million ($1.52 billion) from a private equity firm, the 3i Group. National Car Parks operates about 850 car parks with about 50,000 spaces, accounting for more than half Britain’s off-street parking market, and is the largest provider of spaces at airports and railway stations. A towing service will be spun off and retained by 3i.

The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, Asia’s largest oil refiner, will buy the Hong Kong petroleum products distribution unit of China Resources Enterprise for 4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($511 million). The two companies signed a framework agreement, and the final purchase price remains subject to review, according to China Resources. A formal agreement will be signed in mid-April, the company said. The Beijing-based China Petroleum and Chemical, which is known as Sinopec, is expanding its refining and fuel distribution system to keep pace with the rapidly growing Chinese economy.

The On Baseball column on Sunday, which began with a report about Terry Ryan’s ability as general manager of the Minnesota Twins to build a consistent winner with a relatively small payroll, omitted the writer’s credit in some copies. It was reported and written by Murray Chass from Fort Myers, Fla.

The Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about Coach Howie Dickenman of Central Connecticut State and his place in the collegiate basketball coaching fraternity, gave an incomplete list in some copies of former assistants to Jim Calhoun at the University of Connecticut who, like Dickenman, have led teams to this year’s N.C.A.A. tournament. Karl Hobbs of George Washington became the fourth former assistant — joining Dickenman, Dave Leitao of Virginia and Glen Miller of Pennsylvania — after his team won the Atlantic 10 tournament championship on Saturday.

An obituary on March 6 about Henri Troyat, the popular Russian-born French writer, referred incompletely to his survivors. Besides his son, Jean-Daniel, they include his stepdaughter, Michèle Troyat McKeown; three grandchildren; and six great-grandchildren.

An article in Science Times on Oct. 3 about an expedition to survey the debris field of the U.S.S. Macon, a Navy dirigible that crashed over the Pacific Ocean in 1935, referred imprecisely to the end of the Navy’s lighter-than-air program. While the crash of the Macon put an end to the use of rigid airships, the Navy continued to use blimps and semirigid airships; the last flight in the lighter-than-air program was in 1962. This correction was delayed because a reader’s e-mail message was not forwarded to the appropriate editors.
An obituary on Monday about the comedian Richard Jeni misstated his age. He was 49, not 45.

A picture caption with the London Journal article on Tuesday, about a plan to make the House of Lords into an all-elected legislative body, referred incorrectly to the British shorthand term for Parliament. It is Westminster — not Whitehall, which is shorthand for Britain’s executive branch of government.

An obituary on Friday about Nils Y. Wessell, a former president of Tufts University, referred incorrectly to the role of one of its schools when he became president in 1953. It had a school of law and diplomacy that introduced students to international law; it did not confer law degrees.

A headline in Business Day on Tuesday about the acquisition of the Organon BioSciences unit of Akzo Nobel misstated the purchaser. It is Schering-Plough, not Schering A.G., an unrelated German company. Also, the article referred imprecisely to an earlier deal in the drug industry. Bayer, the German drug maker, last year acquired Schering, not Schering-Plough.

A picture credit was omitted on the front page of Business Day on Friday with an article about the investment career of Nathaniel Rothschild, of the dynastic Rothschild family. The photograph of Mr. Rothschild was by Jack Guez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images. Also, the article carried incorrect information in a quotation from Charles G. Phillips, who likened Mr. Rothschild to Prince Hal in the Shakespearean play “Henry IV.” Prince Hal became Henry V — not Henry IV, as Mr. Phillips said.

An article in Business Day yesterday about an effort by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to notify 75,000 members that a compact disc holding their medical and other personal information had disappeared misstated the telephone number to call for information. It is 1-800-293-3443 — not 3433.

An article in Business Day on Friday about a project by the Internal Revenue Service to ask tax lawyers and accountants to write some of its new rules misstated the time at which John D. Graham, who was appointed by President Bush to streamline the federal rule-making process, became dean of the graduate school at the nonprofit research organization RAND. It was in October 2005, not last week.

A front-page article on Feb. 28 about a deal to overhaul the New York State workers’ compensation system misstated the average weekly pay in the state, as calculated by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. It is around $1,000, not around $1,200.
Corrections

Terry Stotts was fired yesterday as coach of the Milwaukee Bucks, who are struggling this season after injuries to key players. An interim coach was not announced for tonight’s game against San Antonio.

WHITE PLAINS, March 14 — A convicted killer serving a lengthy sentence pleaded guilty on Wednesday to another murder, for which one of the victim’s high school classmates was wrongfully imprisoned for 16 years.
Jocelyn Thibault stopped 25 shots Wednesday night for his first shutout in more than three years and the Pittsburgh Penguins won their third game in a row, defeating the Devils, 3-0.
The grand jury is trying to determine whether any of the five officers who fired bullets into Sean Bell's car will face criminal charges.
Eric Devendorf scored a career-high 34 points and Demetris Nichols added 15 last night as Syracuse rallied for a 79-73 victory against visiting South Alabama in the first round of the N.I.T.
The judge said he would need more time to determine damages for the plaintiffs, the families of the 17 sailors killed in the terrorists’ bombing of the U.S. destroyer.
“I was responsible for the 9/11 operation, from A to Z,” Khalid Shaikh Mohammed said, according to a Pentagon transcript.
SKIING.
President Bush’s critique underscored the tenuous nature of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales’s hold on his job.
Bush administration officials acknowledge that their key political goals for Iraq will take longer than they anticipated.
Through the first month, Mike Pelfrey and Chan Ho Park have emerged as the clear co-favorites for the No. 5 slot, with each offering evidence as to why the Mets should choose him.
Critics say that the firing of seven prosecutors is evidence that Alberto R. Gonzales, a longtime Bush loyalist, failed to distance himself from the White House.
WASHINGTON, March 14 — Following are excerpts from the interview on Tuesday with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton about Iraq:.

Following are excerpts from the testimony of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed on March 10 in a Combatant Status Review Tribunal hearing provided by the United States government. Parts were edited out. Mr. Mohammed’s statements, parts in English and parts in Arabic through a translator, came in response to instructions that he could say “whatever you’d like to say so long as it’s relevant”:.

More than a third of married couples in Japan — 35 percent — have sex less than once a month, according to an informal survey by the Japan Family Planning Association. It also indicated that 40 percent of men and women ages 16 to 49 years old had not had sex for more than a month. “The situation is dismal,” said Kunio Kitamura, the association’s director. “My research shows that if you don’t have sex for a month, you probably won’t for a year.” He partly blamed stress from work. For the survey, the association randomly handed out forms to about 2,700 people and received responses from 636 men and 773 women.

After a two-day debate, the House of Lords rebuffed demands to make it an elected body, setting the stage for a fight over the future of the upper chamber. Peers, as members of the Lords are known, voted by 361 to 121 in favor of having all members appointed. Last week, the House of Commons voted by a majority of 113 for a wholly elected Lords and to remove those members who inherit their seats. The gulf between the two houses raises the prospect of months of wrangling as the government searches for a compromise. Pressure to reform the Lords has gathered momentum as the police investigate allegations that the Labor Party offered seats in return for loans and donations.

Israel’s entry for the annual Eurovision Song Contest, “Push the Button,” has been approved by the competition’s organizers, despite earlier suggestions that its lyrics were inappropriate. The song, by a band called the Teapacks, has been interpreted as a protest against Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

Three days after mysterious military strikes against Georgian villages in the remote Kodori Gorge, the authorities displayed photographs in a closed meeting for diplomats in Tbilisi, the Georgian capital, showing the remains of military ordnance being collected by a United Nations team. The debris, apparently of guided missiles fired from attack helicopters and unguided BM-21 rockets fired from the ground, further suggested a coordinated military operation. Georgia said Russian attack gunships conducted the sorties. Russia denied it. No one was injured, but several buildings were damaged. The United Nations is expected to release findings as soon as next week.

Dr. Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, the controversial health minister, underwent a successful liver transplant in Johannesburg, officials said, a response to a long-term autoimmune disease. The health of Dr. Tshabalala-Msimang, 66, became an issue last month after she appeared at government meetings in an apparent state of confusion.

Suspected Muslim militants in southern Yala Province ambushed a commuter van carrying a group of Buddhists and killed eight of them, military and hospital officials said. Two of the dead were 16-year-old girls. “Thais have never seen such a cruel incident,” said Yala’s district chief, Suppanat Sirunthawinet. “.

The financier George Soros offered $3 million to finance a pilot project in Lesotho for fighting extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis, known as XDR-TB. Mr. Soros, in association with Partners in Health, a medical charity, hopes to cut the death rate to about 50 percent. XDR-TB was first reported in South Africa, which surrounds Lesotho.
Nearly all of the jurors in the Conrad M. Black trial confirmed that they knew little of him and the others accused in the trial.
A judge dropped charges against the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, Patricia C. Dunn, who was accused of fraud in a boardroom spying scheme.
Reporters covering the president’s five-nation trip could not make him utter the name of his chief Latin American nemesis, President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela.
The F.D.A. ordered makers to print label warnings about risks and side effects like driving and eating while asleep.
Lottery Numbers.
General Motors reported its largest quarterly profit in two and a half years. But some analysts fear that G.M.’s new products are not adequate to sustain its turnaround.
Fans may know Doug Mientkiewicz for catching the last out of the World Series with the Red Sox. But to Mientkiewicz, nothing has mattered as much as his role in turning around the Twins.
While H&R Block’s tax business is showing signs of improvement, it cannot get rid of its subprime mortgage group, Option One, fast enough.
The Education Departments’s inspector general detailed irregularities in the program, known as Reading First, which awards grants to states for their reading curriculum.
Although Ibrahim Jaaber came to Penn with a modest basketball background, he became a standout guard for Penn while it won the last three Ivy League championships.
North Korea pledged to honor its commitment to dismantle its nuclear arms program only after sanctions had been lifted on its funds frozen in a bank in Macao since 2005.
UNION, N.J., March 14 — Even by the participants’ accounts, the opening steps of the state’s budget dance, often a drawn-out and contentious exercise, were part of a rather choreographed affair.
Angels outfielder Gary Matthews Jr. said Wednesday that he had never used human growth hormone, offering his first comments about his reported connection to a nationwide drug distribution ring.
An increasing number of Americans in and out of the military now recognize that the current policy is indefensible.
Robust trading and overseas expansion drove Lehman’s first-quarter profit up 5.6 percent, matching Wall Street’s expectations.
The most plausible relief measures for the millions of American families who are in danger of losing their homes involve federal boosts to existing state and local loan programs.
As the country waits for Congress and the president to enact immigration reform, the indecency of existing policies is becoming intolerable.
Administration officials immediately issued a veto threat, even though the measure is considered unlikely to win final passage.

If the Communist leaders are willing to put aside ideology to continue their remarkable economic boom, why not take another essential step and make China’s National People’s Congress a real legislature?
Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold’s $25.9 billion acquisition of a rival, Phelps Dodge, was approved by shareholders of both companies.
Mohamed El-Erian, head of the $30 billion Harvard Endowment, has brought an international flair and bond expertise to the job.
In a statement to a military tribunal, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed took responsibility for 31 terror attacks or attempts, including the following:.
Home Depot said the full board will attend the annual shareholders’ meeting.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton initially declined to answer if she believed homosexuality was immoral, but later issued a statement saying she did not.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Senate Majority Leader Joe Bruno exchanged barbs in an increasingly nasty fight over the budget.
Steve Nash finished with 32 points, 16 assists and 8 rebounds to lead Phoenix over Dallas, snapping the Mavericks’ 23-game home winning streak.
The deal to buy Tellme Networks was said to be worth more than $800 million, making it Microsoft’s biggest acquisition since 2002.
There is an unsettling sense that Kentucky’s basketball universe is out of whack, with former Wildcats’ Coach Rick Pitino preparing Louisville for the N.C.A.A. tournament in his old backyard.
The degree of improvement was unclear and a U.S. general cautioned against reading too much into optimistic reports.
Li Na was the first Chinese tennis player to win a WTA Tour event, the first to break into the top 30 in the rankings, and the first to advance to the quarterfinals in a Grand Slam event.
The cancelled contract involved a “fast-response cutter,” which was part of the Coast Guard’s troubled modernization program.
The financial relationship with a company affiliated with one of the most outspoken critics of the United States potentially exposes Rudolph W. Giuliani to new scrutiny.
A missing CD containing confidential medical information on 75,000 Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield members was recovered in the Philadelphia area.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced what he called a milestone in his 10-year, $7.5 billion plan to build or preserve 165,000 units of low- to moderate-cost housing.
New Haven Police Lt. William White, who is charged with taking bribes and stealing, has a reputation of being a good cop and a bad cop.
The use of aluminum bats has been debated for years both from a competitive standpoint and increasingly for safety reasons.
A. J. Graves, one of the best guards in the country, shot 95.8 percent from the free-throw line this season. Matthew, once a star guard at Butler during the 1990s, is now their assistant coach.
A study showing that the state has the nation's highest per-capita prevalance of autism has sparked an effort to improve research and services.
Automotive High School in Brooklyn is trying to help replenish the shrinking ranks of qualified mechanics in New York City.
The word from many sleep experts was that, despite the federal warning, prescription sleeping pills are relatively safe drugs if taken as directed.
Several players have voiced sharp opposition to the AT&T National, an invitation-only event hosted by Tiger Woods, saying that limiting the field would rob many players of an opportunity to play.
The bank will pay $26 million to settle charges that its securities unit published fraudulent research reports on companies.
Google is taking steps to make anonymous the logs it keeps of all searches that people conduct.
The study found a gap of almost 1 percentage point in heart attack death rates over one three-year span, 12.9 percent for weekend patients and 12 percent for weekday patients.
In Sunni Arab neighborhoods, even Sunnis helping fellow Sunnis are viewed as traitors to the insurgent cause.
Chiquita reached a settlement with the Justice Department over protection payments that it made to terrorist groups in Colombia.
A scandal threatens to complicate national politics and sway the contest to lead the African National Congress.
The Vatican said the writings of a Jesuit priest well known in Latin America were “either erroneous or dangerous.”
Two unarmed auxiliary police officers were among those killed during a chase on Wednesday night.
Pete Rose bet on the Cincinnati Reds “every night” when he managed them and, despite his lifetime ban because of gambling, would like another chance in a major league dugout.
The Internet search giant announced that it would build a “server farm” in North Carolina where land is cheap.
Barbara Gittings was a prominent gay rights activist who a decade before the Stonewall rebellion of 1969 was agitating for the rights of lesbians and gay men.
The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists is among the finalists announced for the National Magazine Awards, the industry’s most prestigious prize.
Seattle residents appear to have rejected both choices put before them in a citywide advisory vote to fix a damaged elevated waterfront freeway.
Goldman Sachs was fined $2 million by market regulators for allowing clients to make illegal short sales before stock offerings.
The 12-member jury deliberated about an hour before voting, 10 to 2. to recommend the death penalty for the man convicted of raping and murdering Jessica Lunsford.
Yoko Ono’s former driver, Koral Karsan, who pleaded guilty to charges of trying to extort money from her, will be allowed to return to Turkey without further legal action.

A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed against the New York Police Department by a man who claimed that officers beat him during a 2004 burglary arrest in Brooklyn. The judge, Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court, issued a directed verdict on Tuesday, meaning that no reasonable jury could have found for the plaintiff, the City Law Department said. The plaintiff, Michael Julia, was arrested in Borough Park on Jan. 15, 2004, city officials said. He and an accomplice, his girlfriend, later pleaded guilty to second-degree burglary in connection with several break-ins, the department said. Connie Pankratz, a Law Department spokeswoman, said the city had a witness who would have testified that Mr. Julia fell and hit his head before the police arrived.

The former president of a Bahamas-based investment company was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to four years in prison after pleading guilty to money-laundering charges stemming from a federal sting operation. The former president, Martin Tremblay, 44, of Jonquiere, Quebec, pleaded guilty in November. Mr. Tremblay, the former president of Dominion Investments , was arrested after he was videotaped in a sting operation in which he agreed to launder large amounts of money from drug sales, prosecutors said. (AP).

The Anti-Defamation League reported yesterday that anti-Semitic occurrences were down last year in New York and New Jersey, states with the highest number of cases of vandalism and harassment against Jews, but that such events increased in Connecticut, which ranks seventh nationally. In 2006 there were 284 such cases in New York, down 25 percent from the previous year, the league said. There were 244 cases in New Jersey, down 8 percent, and 77 in Connecticut, up 35 percent from 2005. “While the decreasing numbers in New Jersey reflect a national trend, they also show a continuing need to erase the persistent scourge of anti-Semitism, especially among our youth,” said Etzion Neuer, the league’s regional director, based in New Jersey.

The State Merit Systems Board ruled yesterday that a man who lost his leg below the knee as a child should be allowed to enter training as a Paterson firefighter. The applicant, Isaac Feliciano, 33, played high school football and baseball and ranked 103rd among more than 615 candidates in the physical test for firefighters, said his lawyer, William J. Maniatis. Mayor Jose Torres of Paterson has said Mr. Feliciano will be welcomed once cleared by the state.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday criticized a decision by the organizers of the St. Patrick’s Day Parade to move the city’s firefighters to the middle of the procession from their traditional position near the front. “I think they should all be up front, and that’s always been the tradition,” the mayor said. The New York Post and The Daily News reported last week that parade organizers were upset with the firefighters for holding up the parade last year to allow firefighters from New Orleans to join them. The mayor also criticized the organizers’ longstanding refusal to allow gay groups to march. “I think all parades in this city should be open to everybody, no matter what your orientation or ethnicity or anything else is,” Mr. Bloomberg said.

A Southampton police officer pleaded not guilty in Suffolk County Court yesterday to charges that he helped two women evade arrest in exchange for sexual intercourse, the district attorney’s office said. The officer, Guy Giammatteo, 32, pleaded not guilty to coercion, receiving bribes and official misconduct, prosecutors said. One of the women was a fugitive with an outstanding warrant and the other was involved with narcotics, prosecutors said. Officer Giammatteo is also accused of exposing himself to a woman. He was suspended in January, according to the Southampton Police Department. William Keahon, Officer Giammatteo’s lawyer, said the accusations were false.

A Hamptons physician was charged yesterday with illegally selling prescriptions for painkillers to Medicaid recipients who traveled to his office from New York City, state prosecutors said. The doctor, Michael Chait, 46, an internist, was ordered held in $500,000 bail after his arraignment on charges of conspiracy, grand larceny and illegal sales of prescriptions, said Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Dr. Chait is charged with writing hundreds of unnecessary prescriptions for painkillers, including OxyContin and Dilaudid, between Jan. 1 and March 7, Mr. Cuomo said. His lawyer, Craig Schaum, declined to comment.
A federal appeals court ruled that the woman using marijuana was not immune from federal prosecution simply because of her condition.
Concern about mortgages continues to send stock prices bouncing.
Traders and brokers in the region say hedge funds are going to create even more unpredictable gyrations in the future.
The state’s legislature debates the placement of an apostrophe.
Lower oil prices and increased exports have sent the deficit to its lowest level in more than a year.
A political and legal maelstrom erupted after Pakistan’s president suspended the country’s chief justice last week.
Avon wants to ring billions of doorbells at the same time with the largest campaign in its 121-year history.
On the Upper East Side, the mysterious birth of a sinkhole.
Gareth Hunt was a British actor best known as the secret agent Mike Gambit on the 1970s spy series “The New Avengers.”
The Department of Defense has identified 3,187 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
The Venerable Maha Ghosananda called for peace and reconciliation after the overthrow of the Khmer Rouge.
President Bush vowed to step up efforts to persuade Congress to approve a bigger guest worker program for Mexican migrants.
Charles Taylor, a professor of law and philosophy, has written extensively on the sense of self and how it is defined by morals and what one considers good.
The Miss America organization wants its Miss New York competition to be more convenient for women from New York City.
Police fired on protesters, killing at least 11 people at a demonstration against one of the new Chinese-style economic zones.
The move is the latest in a struggle with the governor over a panel plagued by accusations of sexual assault.
A coalition of industrial and developing countries is pushing for stringent limits on a popular air-conditioner refrigerant.
F. Clark Howell was credited with transforming the study of human origins from just “stones and bones” to a broader discipline drawing on biology, ecology, geology and primatology.
Prime Minister Tony Blair faced down a mutiny in Parliament, winning a vote to renew Britain’s nuclear deterrent.
The study showed that the vaccine has sharply reduced the number of cases in children but that its protection does not last long.
The panel’s report heightens uncertainty about the future of the beleaguered prime minister, Ehud Olmert, and his government.
Two members of an Algerian Islamist militant group were killed when a roadside bomb they were planting exploded prematurely.
An unknown number remain hospitalized after riot police set upon a group at a prayer meeting on Sunday.
Community banks keep financing flowing to local entrepreneurs at a time when mergers have reduced the number of banks.

An increasing number of players in the men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament wear No. 0 or No. 00.  Despite the negative connotation, players are embracing zero as a sign that they have something to prove.
If the BBC models its Arabic television service on its Arabic radio service, yet another anti-Western, antidemocratic channel will find its place on the Arab screen.
A more prudent and realistic approach in the way the government seeks the death penalty in New York State is warranted.
Jean-Marie Le Pen, whose candidacy shook up France in 2002, officially joined France’s already volatile race for president.
Afghan officials said that the explosion appeared to have been an accident and that it had occurred in a place where gunpowder and dynamite were stored.
Rupert Holmes talks about writing the script for the new John Kander and Fred Ebb musical “Curtains” after the deaths of Peter Stone, the first writer, and Mr. Ebb.
Lauren Ambrose and Oscar Isaac will star in “Romeo and Juliet,” the film “300” is drawing ire in Iran and more culture news.
The Los Angeles County Museum of Art plans to collect significant pieces of midcentury residential architecture, including houses by Rudolf M. Schindler, Richard Neutra and Frank Lloyd Wright.

Too many ideas were bouncing around the Joyce Theater’s stage on Tuesday when Buglisi Dance Theater opened a weeklong season.

7 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: BETTY HUTTON A look back at the brassy star of 1940s and 50s Hollywood, who died Sunday at 86. This follows a mini-festival of Ms. Hutton’s (Left) films: at noon, “M.G.M. Parade Show No. 27” (1955); at 12:30 p.m., “The Stork Club” (1945); at 2:15 p.m., “The Perils of Pauline” (1947); and at 7 p.m., Cecil B. DeMille’s “Greatest Show on Earth” (1952).
This orchestra’s sound is remarkably trim and focused, with sharp-edged, virtuosic brass playing as one of its hallmarks.

Two unarmed auxiliary police officers were fatally shot last night during a chase with a gunman on a busy stretch of bars and restaurants in the heart of Greenwich Village, the authorities said. The gunman was shot and killed about 9:30 p.m. by regular police officers who quickly responded to the scene, the authorities said.

''Endurance,'' a show of new limited-edition works by the British designer Ross Lovegrove, opens March 21 at the Phillips de Pury auction house in Chelsea. The 10 pieces on display were inspired by organic shapes like dolphin vertebrae, using what Alexander Payne, the director of Phillips de Pury's design department, who organized the show, calls ''a new language of form.'' The polished aluminum Liquid Bioform Table, below, will sell for about $135,500 in an edition of eight; the Liquid Carbon Bench, made from carbon fiber in an edition of 12, will sell for about $155,000. Through April 4 at Phillips de Pury, 450 West 15th Street (10th Avenue), (212) 940-1200, phillipsdepury.com. MELISSA FELDMAN

Last week, I attended my second TED conference, which stands for Technology, Entertainment, and Design. During the four-day conference, you hear 50 speakers, who are given 18 minutes each. They are the most compelling, passionate, informed speakers you've ever heard (all right, maybe 45 of them are). Some bring back reports from the edge of medicine, archaeology, nanotech, neurology, psychiatry or the Web. Some, like Paul Simon, Tracy Chapman, and They Might Be Giants, perform live.
BARTH--Emanuel G. March 15th, 2003. Loving you and missing you every day. Your Family

BROWNE--Peter Carroll, a gentleman and valiant fighter, age 82, of Tupper Lake, NY and formerly of Lawrence, NY, died Sunday, March 4, 2007 at his home, surrounded by family. Mr. Browne was Commodore Emeritus of the Cedarhurst Yacht Club, Lawrence, NY. He is survived by his wife of 60 years Jean (Hancock) Browne; two sons Peter and Curtis; four daughters Pamela B. Kruger, Hilary B. Fitzpatrick, Prudence B. Purcell, Deirdre B. Griffith, 18 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A private service for family members was held at the Fortune-Keough Funeral Home, Saranac Lake, NY. Friends wishing to remember Peter Carroll Browne may make memorial contributions to The Cedarhurst Yacht Club or the Adirondack Medical Center, Lake Colby Dr., Saranac Lake, New York 12983.

The Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about Coach Howie Dickenman of Central Connecticut State and his place in the collegiate basketball coaching fraternity, gave an incomplete list in some copies of former assistants to Jim Calhoun at the University of Connecticut who, like Dickenman, have led teams to this year's N.C.A.A. tournament. Karl Hobbs of George Washington became the fourth former assistant -- joining Dickenman, Dave Leitao of Virginia and Glen Miller of Pennsylvania -- after his team won the Atlantic 10 tournament championship on Saturday.

DAVID PATTEN keeps the student ID card from Santa Ana College tucked in a shelf back home. ''I'll never throw it away,'' said Patten, Weber State's star forward. ''I need it to remind me of what I could be doing right now.''

ROWE--William, 87, of Convent Station, NJ, passed away at home, Tuesday, March 13, 2007. He was surrounded by family. Bill is survived by his beloved wife Eileen, his two sons Mark and Larry, their wives Cindy and Wendy, and four adored grandchildren, Sari, Josh, Misha and Arielle.

An article yesterday about competition for Jewish support between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama incorrectly described Mr. Obama's views about the culpability for stalled peace talks between the Palestinians and Israelis. Mr. Obama blames Hamas, which controls much of the Palestinian government, for the stalled peace talks; he does not blame Israel.

To the Editor: Re '' 'Mistakes' Made on Prosecutors, Gonzales Admits'' (front page, March 14): The latest case of the White House's being caught in the middle of a campaign to punish its political opponents serves only to illustrate how inappropriately and blatantly this administration will act to further its agenda.

FREILICHER--Gertrude D., age 96, died on Saturday, March 10, 2007. Wife of the late Morris Freilicher, mother of Morton and Yseult and Ira and Vivian; grandmother of David, Nancy, Judith, and Harlan; great-grandmother of Sophie, Sarah, Lucy and Jack; sister of James, Leonard, Blossom, and the late Herman. Funeral occurred on March 11, 2007. A brilliant student already in college at 16, Gertrude, as a woman of her era, sacrificed the balance of her higher education to become surrogate mother for her three younger siblings when her own mother was stricken with blindness. Family stalwart during WWII when her three brothers all served overseas, she overcame her challenges of severe cancer and repeated pneumonias while giving Bedrock support to loved ones at times of crises. A masterful knitter, she developed that skill to a fine art form. Memories of her love, competence, creativity, and strength will forever exist. Donations to a charity of your choice.

BUDD--Dorothy, on March 12, 2007, one month before her 96th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Saul J. Budd, loving mother of Robert and Martin Budd, devoted grandmother and great-grandmother. Funeral services were held on Wednesday at the Wellwood Cemetery. Please call Frank E. Campbell for Shiva information at 212-288-3500
An obituary on Monday about the comedian Richard Jeni misstated his age. He was 49, not 45.

CINER--Fay G. It is with profound sorrow that we record the parting of our cherished mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother, sister, and aunt who passed away peacefully with her family by her side Sunday evening. Fay valued ''learning for learning's sake'' and her wisdom touched the lives of all who knew her. May we be privileged to carry on her precious legacy.

It Will Never Play In Tehran The blockbuster epic ''300'' is attracting plenty of enthusiastic moviegoers in the United States -- to the tune of $70 million in its first weekend -- but in Iran it's mainly drawing ire. Hollywood's depiction of the 480 B.C. battle between Greek and Persian armies at Thermopylae has been denounced, Reuters reported, by the Iranian government and numerous blogs. They complained about how their ancestors were portrayed in the film: the Persian army as far more ruthless and far less intelligent than the Greeks. The film, though newly released in the United States, has already shown up in Tehran in low-quality, pirated copies. Gholamhossein Elham, a government spokesman, called ''300'' an insult to Iran. ''Not only would no nation or government accept this,'' he said in a press briefing, ''but it would also consider it as hostile behavior.'' The One-Song Concert The Who's lead singer, Roger Daltrey, walked off the stage during the band's first song at a concert in Tampa, Fla., on Tuesday night, and the guitarist Pete Townshend then announced that the show would be canceled and rescheduled for March 25. A note on the band's Web site (thewhotour.com) said that Mr. Daltrey ''experienced vocal challenges as a result of a medical condition.'' Footnotes The Goodman Theater in Chicago is to announce the lineup for its 2007-8 season today, including plays by Eduardo Machado, Horton Foote and others, as well as a Latino Theater Festival, set for August 2008. HarperCollins has set an April 30 publication date for ''At the Center of the Storm,'' the long-delayed memoir by George J. Tenet, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency. The book will be under a strict embargo, the publisher said.

North Carolina forward Tyler Hansbrough said he received a phone call from Duke's Gerald Henderson, who apologized for a forearm hit that broke Hansbrough's nose at the Smith Center on March 4. ''I accept his apology and things like that, but at the same time, I have a broken nose,'' Hansbrough said. VIV BERNSTEIN

The University of Louisville's Web site notes that 19 of Rick Pitino's former players or assistant coaches have gone on to jobs as head coaches. Several -- including Florida's Billy Donovan, Kentucky's Tubby Smith and Holy Cross's Ralph Willard -- join him in this year's N.C.A.A. tournament field. A number of those coaches' former assistants have taken the link one step further, among them: Virginia Commonwealth's Anthony Grant, who worked for Donovan; and Xavier's Sean Miller, who worked for Willard at Pittsburgh and for Herb Sendek, another Pitino disciple, at Miami of Ohio and North Carolina State.

An article in Business Day yesterday about an effort by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to notify 75,000 members that a compact disc holding their medical and other personal information had disappeared misstated the telephone number to call for information. It is 1-800-293-3443 -- not 3433.

MANY textiles and housewares companies now produce avant-garde products, but some have been doing so for years -- in fact, for centuries. One of the oldest is St.-Louis, the French glassworks, which has made fine crystal stemware since 1586 and is now making modern pieces. Wedgwood, the British china company, traces its history to 1759, when Josiah Wedgwood founded a pottery works and produced the first cream-colored earthenware. Nymphenburg porcelain has been run by the Bavarian royal family since 1761; today it makes very modern tableware by designers like Hella Jongerius, Ted Muehling and Khashayar Naimanan, a Londoner who started his career in graffiti.

A picture credit was omitted on the front page of Business Day on Friday with an article about the investment career of Nathaniel Rothschild, of the dynastic Rothschild family. The photograph of Mr. Rothschild was by Jack Guez/Agence France-Presse -- Getty Images. Also, the article carried incorrect information in a quotation from Charles G. Phillips, who likened Mr. Rothschild to Prince Hal in the Shakespearean play ''Henry IV.'' Prince Hal became Henry V -- not Henry IV, as Mr. Phillips said.

Israel's entry for the annual Eurovision Song Contest, ''Push the Button,'' has been approved by the competition's organizers, despite earlier suggestions that its lyrics were inappropriate. The song, by a band called the Teapacks, has been interpreted as a protest against Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. ISABEL KERSHNER

As he pressed his case to be confirmed as attorney general, Alberto R. Gonzales made a promise to the Senate Judiciary Committee -- and to the nation at large. ''I will no longer represent only the White House,'' he testified in 2005 as he prepared to leave his job as White House counsel. ''I will represent the United States of America and its people. I understand the differences between the two roles.''

An obituary on Friday about Nils Y. Wessell, a former president of Tufts University, referred incorrectly to the role of one of its schools when he became president in 1953. It had a school of law and diplomacy that introduced students to international law; it did not confer law degrees.

A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed against the New York Police Department by a man who claimed that officers beat him during a 2004 burglary arrest in Brooklyn. The judge, Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court, issued a directed verdict on Tuesday, meaning that no reasonable jury could have found for the plaintiff, the City Law Department said. The plaintiff, Michael Julia, was arrested in Borough Park on Jan. 15, 2004, city officials said. He and an accomplice, his girlfriend, later pleaded guilty to second-degree burglary in connection with several break-ins, the department said. Connie Pankratz, a Law Department spokeswoman, said the city had a witness who would have testified that Mr. Julia fell and hit his head before the police arrived.

To the Editor: ''Wearing the Green, and the Pink'' (editorial, March 9) criticizes St. Patrick's Day Parade organizers for not allowing homosexuals ''to wear any symbol declaring they are gay or lesbian.'' The parade's ''guidelines'' also discourage the wearing of green hats and sneakers and specifically say that ''no displays of any kind will be permitted.'' Moreover, ''shirts with advertising are not an appropriate form of dress.''

President Bush said Wednesday that he had confidence in Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, but that he was ''frankly not happy about'' the way Mr. Gonzales had handled the dismissal of federal prosecutors, a move that has led to a Congressional investigation into whether the White House allowed politics to interfere with law enforcement. As Mr. Gonzales defended himself in television interviews, Mr. Bush, in Mexico on the last day of his Latin America trip, offered reporters his first explanation of his own role, saying that although he had relayed complaints to Mr. Gonzales about federal prosecutors, ''I never brought up a specific case nor gave him specific instructions.''

The On Baseball column on Sunday, which began with a report about Terry Ryan's ability as general manager of the Minnesota Twins to build a consistent winner with a relatively small payroll, omitted the writer's credit in some copies. It was reported and written by Murray Chass from Fort Myers, Fla.

A14 If Clinton Is Elected ... In an interview, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that if elected president she would keep a reduced but significant military force in Iraq to fight Al Qaeda, deter Iranian aggression and possibly support the Iraqi military. A1 Better Treatment on Weekdays A study of nearly all heart attack patients in New Jersey finds that those who arrived at a hospital on a weekend were less likely to receive aggressive treatment and were slightly more likely to die than those who arrived on weekdays, researchers are reporting. A25 Appeal Lost in Marijuana Case Appellate judges in San Francisco ruled that a terminally ill woman using marijuana was not immune from prosecution simply because of her condition. In a separate case, a federal judge dismissed most of the charges against a prominent advocate for the drug. THE house that Robin Howe and her husband, Andy Grossman, share in Bridgehampton, N.Y., is only a year old, but their living room floor dates back a century. Made of wide-plank teak, the floorboards have "a lived-in feel that is attractive and old and gentle on the feet," said Ms. Howe, a fashion designer. Before the boards were in Ms. Howe's living room they were in the McCloud, Calif., warehouse of TerraMai, a company that sells so-called "reclaimed" wood from around the world; before that, they were the floors and walls of a factory, probably near the Burmese border in Thailand, 8,000 miles from Long Island.

The Anti-Defamation League reported yesterday that anti-Semitic occurrences were down last year in New York and New Jersey, states with the highest number of cases of vandalism and harassment against Jews, but that such events increased in Connecticut, which ranks seventh nationally. In 2006 there were 284 such cases in New York, down 25 percent from the previous year, the league said. There were 244 cases in New Jersey, down 8 percent, and 77 in Connecticut, up 35 percent from 2005. ''While the decreasing numbers in New Jersey reflect a national trend, they also show a continuing need to erase the persistent scourge of anti-Semitism, especially among our youth,'' said Etzion Neuer, the league's regional director, based in New Jersey. TINA KELLEY

An article in Business Day on Friday about a project by the Internal Revenue Service to ask tax lawyers and accountants to write some of its new rules misstated the time at which John D. Graham, who was appointed by President Bush to streamline the federal rule-making process, became dean of the graduate school at the nonprofit research organization RAND. It was in October 2005, not last week.
PERKINS--Alvista (nee Patton), passed away peacefully in her sleep at the age of 99 on March 12, 2007 in Los Angeles, CA. She will be truly missed by family and friends.

Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, long said to be the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, confessed to them at a military hearing held in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on Saturday, according to a transcript released by the Pentagon yesterday. He also acknowledged full or partial responsibility for more than 30 other terror attacks or plots. ''I was responsible for the 9/11 operation, from A to Z,'' he said.

When Julie Gaines and Dave Lenovitz, the owners of Fishs Eddy, a store known for its vintage tableware, discovered a North Carolina warehouse filled with hand-pressed American glass last winter, they were thrilled. ''American glass is still the most beautiful in the world,'' Ms. Gaines said. There are small factories that continue to manufacture it, she added, ''but nobody makes things in the range of unusual colors we found there'' -- Vaseline yellow, milk glass, pink, teal, plum, indigo and marbled. Some pieces are useful, like pitchers and saltcellars, while others are purely decorative, like the figurines below ($6.95 to $9.95). Fishs Eddy, 889 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 420-9020, fishseddy.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

The Postal Service is commemorating the 200th anniversary of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's birth with a new 39-cent stamp, above, the latest in the annual Literary Arts series. Longfellow is best remembered for his epic poems, including ''Paul Revere's Ride'' and ''The Song of Hiawatha.'' The new stamp was designed by Kazuhiko Sano based on an 1870s photograph of Longfellow and shows scenes from Revere's ride in the background. It goes on sale at a ceremony at noon today that is free to the public, as part of a stamp show at Madison Square Garden through Sunday. The ceremony will include recitations by winners of the Poetry Out Loud National Recitation contest. MATTHEW HEALEY

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday criticized a decision by the organizers of the St. Patrick's Day Parade to move the city's firefighters to the middle of the procession from their traditional position near the front. ''I think they should all be up front, and that's always been the tradition,'' the mayor said. The New York Post and The Daily News reported last week that parade organizers were upset with the firefighters for holding up the parade last year to allow firefighters from New Orleans to join them. The mayor also criticized the organizers' longstanding refusal to allow gay groups to march. ''I think all parades in this city should be open to everybody, no matter what your orientation or ethnicity or anything else is,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. SEWELL CHAN

A FEW years ago, Douglas McGrath, the screenwriter and director of "Emma" and "Infamous," was having lunch at Michael's with his friend Paul Blake, a producer of contemporary musicals like "Roman Holiday" and "White Christmas." The two were at one of the tables nestled in that restaurant's brightest corner, in the garden of the Rockefeller Apartments, the swankily modernist, bifurcated building whose two undulating facades erupt north onto 55th Street and south onto 54th Street, right across from the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden. Mr. McGrath's eyes wandered happily up and down the elegant, glassy bays and he said, as he recalled recently: "This is a building that looks like the architect actually cared about it. I've always wanted to live here. I wonder who I'd call?" And Mr. Blake said: "Well, I live here. I know exactly who to call."

To the Editor: Re ''G.O.P. Voters Voice Anxieties on Party's Fate'' (front page, March 13): If the United States were a nation of independent voters and open primaries, people could avoid the angst that goes with party affiliation.

Heart Attack Patients Fare Worse on Weekends A study of heart attack patients in New Jersey found that those who arrived at hospitals on weekends were less likely to receive aggressive treatment and were slightly more likely to die than those who arrived on weekdays. Giuliani's law firm has lobbied on behalf of an oil company controlled by the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez, a strident critic of President Bush and American-style capitalism. His humor, generosity, intelligence and warmth will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Memorial gathering will be held on Saturday, March 17, from 1-4 pm at the Pound Ridge Fire Department. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in memory of Bob Landau to the Pound Ridge Fire Department, 80 Westchester Avenue, Pound Ridge, NY 10576.

JORDAN ARANA--Felipe. Died March 7th, 2007. Your good friends who loved you and were your family, Herman, Aurora and Julio and the two girls that were the love of your life, Lucy and Roxy, and the members of Dueto Salon, will miss you, but are certain that God will keep you in his glory. CHAPMAN--Ruth, a native of New York City, passed away at the age of 82 on March 8. She enjoyed so many of the wonderful things the City has to offer including the opera, theater and concerts. She is survived by her caring cousins and many friends who will miss her sense of humor and keen observations of life. A brief memorial service will be held on Friday, March 16 at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, at 12 noon.

The Public Theater announced casting for the star-crossed lovers in this summer's first Shakespeare in the Park production, ''Romeo and Juliet.'' Juliet will be played by Lauren Ambrose, top right (''Awake and Sing!'' and, perhaps appropriately, HBO's ''Six Feet Under''). Romeo will be played by Oscar Isaac, bottom right, from the 2005 Shakespeare in the Park revival of the musical version of ''Two Gentlemen of Verona.'' Michael Greif (''Rent'') directs. The Public's second summer offering will be ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' directed by Daniel Sullivan (represented on Broadway by ''Prelude to a Kiss''). Oskar Eustis, the theater's artistic director, said in a statement that 2007 ''is the 40th anniversary of the Summer of Love, and we hope to revisit the utopian and joyous impulses of that era through the medium of two of the greatest of Shakespeare's plays.'' CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

MCHUGH--James J., of Westport, Connecticut, died March 7, 2007. He is survived by his wife, Marie; his children John, James, Anne, Peter, and Paul; his grandchildren Sarah, David, Jane, Sam, Kate, Peter, and Marie. A private memorial service is planned.

With the early arrival of daylight time, relatively warm weather across much of the nation and television lineups of mostly repeats, overall prime-time viewership declined considerably Tuesday from the same night a year ago. The decrease was most marked in the 8 p.m. hour where audiences in the 18-to-49 demographic were down 12 percent, according to Nielsen's estimates. The drop-off impacted the start of the finals on Fox's ''American Idol,'' which attracted 29.4 million viewers from 8 to 10, some 3 million viewers less than a year ago (32.7 million). CBS ranked a distant second for the night with reruns of ''NCIS'' at 8 (11.5 million), ''The Unit'' at 9 (7.7 million) and ''CSI'' at 10 (9.2 million). On FX, Monday's 10 p.m. debut of ''The Riches,'' with Eddie Izzard and Minnie Driver, drew 2.5 million viewers aged 18 to 49, the second-best tally ever for an FX series premiere. BENJAMIN TOFF
JOSEPH--Nicholas. Happy Birthday Mickey. You are always in our thoughts and in our hearts. Love Elliott, Ruth, Dena, David and Ronny

A picture caption with the London Journal article on Tuesday, about a plan to make the House of Lords into an all-elected legislative body, referred incorrectly to the British shorthand term for Parliament. It is Westminster -- not Whitehall, which is shorthand for Britain's executive branch of government.

REED--Barbara Ann, devoted mother and loving grandmother, died on March 4, 2007, after a courageous battle with cancer. She leaves behind family, friends and colleagues who will always remember her love of life, love of family and her beauty and elegance. She is survived by her daughters, Kim Itri and Daun Dees, and her six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Friday, March 16, from 5:00-8:00 pm at the University Club in New York City.

The financier George Soros offered $3 million to finance a pilot project in Lesotho for fighting extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis, known as XDR-TB. Mr. Soros, in association with Partners in Health, a medical charity, hopes to cut the death rate to about 50 percent. XDR-TB was first reported in South Africa, which surrounds Lesotho. DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
''My brother paid $1 to see your underwear.'' ''Gary, by the way, why are we wearing bras on our heads?''

The clashes were the bloody culmination of routine, if risky, police work: One officer was shot in a Harlem restaurant on Tuesday night, and another was stabbed in the head in a Brooklyn subway station about 90 minutes later. In each case, officers approached men they considered suspicious and tried to frisk them for weapons.

It was just a regular-season game, the rivals tried to say with a shrug but a perceptible glint in their eyes. This wasn't the playoffs? Tell that to Steve Nash and Dirk Nowitzki, who exchanged daggers as if they were deciding the M.V.P. award Wednesday night.

WARNING FOR SLEEPING PILLS -- The most widely prescribed sleeping pills, including Ambien and Lunesta, can cause strange behavior like driving and eating while asleep, the Food and Drug Administration said, announcing that strong new warnings would be placed on the labels of 13 drugs. But it still lost $2 billion last year, the second consecutive year of multibillion-dollar losses. Market Place. [C1.] CHARGES DROPPED IN H.P. CASE -- A judge dismissed charges against Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, in a corporate spying case that gained national attention. H.P.'s shareholders, at their annual meeting, appeared to give Mark V. Hurd, the new chairman, a vote of confidence and indicated they felt that last year's problems were now behind the company. [C3.] IMPORTS DOWN; EXPORTS UP -- The current-account deficit shrank in the fourth quarter of 2006 to its smallest in more than a year as lower oil prices took a bite out of imports and exports continued to rise. [A25.] MISSING MEDICAL DATA FOUND -- A missing compact disc containing sensitive medical and personal information on 75,000 Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield members was recovered. The purchase gives Microsoft voice-recognition programs it can combine with mobile phone applications. Steven A. Ballmer, above, the Microsoft chief executive, said that search on cellphones would be a battlegrounds between Microsoft and Google. Redstone's compensation for his role as chairman of CBS will be reduced after a shareholder lawsuit. At Citigroup, Charles O.
