Visiting Friday at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring Street, NYC 1-3 and 5-7 pm. Services to begin at 7 pm.

EDELMAN--Barry, 41, of Englewood, NJ, on March 12, 2007. Survived by his partner Tony Fuccillo, sons Zachary, Alex, and their mother Michelle (David) Ramirez, parents Arnold and Myrna, sister Susan, and Karen, and niece Jenna.

MANY baby boomers who grew up wearing contact lenses thought they were liberated from glasses forever. But sometime between the 40th and 50th birthdays a cruel reality sets in. Suddenly the type in the newspaper is smaller. The controls on the car dashboard are blurry. Menus and price tags become illegible. Perish the thought, but they need glasses again -- only this time it's the cheap plastic readers at the end of the pharmacy aisle. People who once brushed by the displays thinking ''those are for old people'' find themselves hijacking a pair to read the recommended dose on a bottle of antacid.

To the Editor: Re ''Top General Explains Remarks on Gays'' (news article, March 14): Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has refused to apologize for his remarks about what he called the immorality of homosexual conduct. While I understand that this is his opinion, it is not an opinion shared by everyone. But I think that most people would agree that bigotry is immoral.

Kara Mann, a Chicago-based interior designer, top right, is bringing some of her favorite furniture designers to her hometown with a new showroom opening next week. The 4,000-square-foot showroom will be the first in the United States to carry the work of Jimmie Martin, a London company that makes punk-inspired pieces like the silver-leaf crucifix-encrusted bureau ($6,500), right. Ms. Mann will also carry the company's English library chair ($4,500), top right, and its Word dining table ($6,000) and dining chair ($2,000), above, as well as pieces by BDDW, Ochre and Blackman Cruz. Kara Mann, 119 West Hubbard (fifth floor), Chicago, (312) 893-7550. LISA CREGAN

To the Editor: Re ''The Right to Organize'' (editorial, March 6): Having been a witness to union-organizing efforts, I think that there are some overlooked employee protections that are created by the secret ballot in union elections.
To the Editor: Re ''Another Warning on Warming'' (editorial, March 11): Anyone who still has any doubts about the problem of pollution and global warming need only visit China.

The kitchen and bathroom are obvious places for glass tile, but Piero Bisazza, the chief executive officer of Bisazza, the Vicenza, Italy-based tile company, doesn't see any reason to stop there. Mr. Bisazza, who describes himself as an ''anti-minimalist,'' envisions it throughout the house, even in the living room. Witness the exuberantly tiled wall and console, left, in the newly renovated Bisazza showroom in SoHo, which reopened to the public last week, designed by Carlo Dal Bianco. The wall is covered in an overscale floral pattern called Winter Flowers Oro Bianco (a 9.56-foot-high by 4.25-foot-wide module sells for $6,581.12), and the lacquered wood console in Damasco Oro Bianco ($15,000). The new showroom also has a fireplace covered in 24-karat gold leaf tile; a price has not yet been determined. Bisazza, 43 Greene Street (Grand Street), (212) 334-7130, www.bisazza.com. ELAINE LOUIE

If you are stuck in your cubicle today for the first of the two greatest sporting days of the year, here is The Bracket's best game guide by time slot. Times are obviously staggered. (All times Eastern because, as a commentator pointed out, we can't have an East Coast bias if we picked U.C.L.A. to win.) 12:20 P.M. No. 4 Maryland vs. No. 13 Davidson -- The best of the matinees openers, you can sweat out whether your boss notices you took a two-hour lunch while Gary Williams sweats through another Armani. 2:40 P.M. No. 3 Washington State vs. No. 14 Oral Roberts -- If Oral Roberts wins, do you think they will lift curfew? The Golden Eagles won at Kansas and will keep it close. 7:10 P.M. No. 6 Duke vs. No. 11 Virginia Commonwealth -- Since Duke managed an improbably high seeding, you did not think it would be given a bad time slot, did you? Perhaps the most polarizing program in college sports looks to fend off the upset. Now that is prime-time theater. 9:30 P.M. No. 3 Pittsburgh vs. No. 14 Wright State -- Wright State has really played well the past few months under the first-year coach Brad Brownell. And it is not in Pittsburgh's DNA to blow teams out. Plus, there is always that one game that people get to work tomorrow and say, ''Wait a minute, TEAM X lost last night? They were up 12 at the half. What happened?'' Friendly Confrontation In the eight years Tom Crean has coached Marquette, he has not scheduled Michigan State as an opponent. Crean was an assistant under Spartans Coach Tom Izzo for four years -- the two had worked under Michigan State Coach Jud Heathcote as well -- before accepting the Marquette job. Crean and Izzo had put their friendship first. Now they have no choice. Marquette, the No. 8 seed in the East Region, will face No. 9 Michigan State on Thursday in the first round.
Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below. - The Editors

As the night sessions come to a close on the opening weekend of the N.C.A.A. tournament, there's been a distinct lack of buzzer beaters and the so-called "Shining Moments." Sure, there's been some good, competitive games. But we've yet to see a defining play that will endure for years.
The Kentucky-Villanova game was all of three seconds old before a whistle blew. Dwight Perry was called for a foul.

The weather in the east is erratic as designers. A few days of spring, and today the view out my window is winter world. I don't think the dinner guest will make it through the snow and ice; he informs me that he's stuck under a boiler, and boilers come before roast chicken and potatoes. The potatoes are the French ones, and I boil them and coat them with sea salt and serve them like that. Bernard Alloux was very concerned, before I left Paris, that I had the right sea salt, and, I suppose, by that he meant the coarse kind you get in Brittany, where he has a little cottage with fruit trees. We talk a lot about food when we're driving around Paris, and I keep saying I want to drive by the butcher on the Ile St. Louis, where Alaia gets the most delicious steak. After I wrote an article for the Magazine about the meals that Alaia cooks in his kitchen, several years back, American travelers turned up at the butcher just to gaze at the meat. Why is this unsurprising? I bet some of them even thought about buying an electric plate and a frying pan, just to have that taste, that existence. I'll accept that as a definition for "lifestyle."
At home, games in the first two days of the tournament seem to just keep coming, and you can see bits and pieces of all of them, even if you don't want to.
Washington State guard Derrick Low showed up to his team's practice session at Arco Arena on Friday wearing a maroon T-shirt that read: "ALowHa Cougs!" In the middle was a flower.

The Bracket's bracket may be pretty well shot at this point, but there's one prediction that we can brag on. We said on Selection Sunday that the game between Nevada and Creighton would be the best game of the first round. So far, we can feel good about saying that we're right. (It's been the only overtime game of the tournament entering the night sessions on Friday.)
A trailer for "Black," a film by Sanjay Leela Bhansali.

Wisconsin Coach Bo Ryan is one of the most entertaining coaches to sit behind a microphone. After Wisconsin's come-from-behind victory against Texas A&M-Corpus Christi, he was trying to explain how out of sync his team was. He pretended to bounce a ball and move his head, out of rhythm, and said it was like Mervin Johnson.

Boston College didn't need to fret about unfamiliarity as it prepared to face No. 2 Georgetown on Saturday in the second round of the East Region in Winston-Salem, N.C. The two teams are old foes. Boston College, the No. 7 seed, and Georgetown were original members of the Big East Conference before the Eagles defected to the Atlantic Coast Conference in 2005.

Those readers who take any notice of bylines will not, perhaps, be surprised to learn that your blogger is of Irish extraction. I'm hardly unique that way -- some 34 million Americans claimed Irish ancestry in the 2000 census, nearly 12 percent of the population.

It's not easy anymore to find a school that has never made the N.C.A.A. tournament. The proliferation of conferences - major, mid-major and infinitesimal - have made the once-daunted task of sneaking in the N.C.A.A. tournament every decade or so decidedly simpler. With only 10 Division I-A teams unaffiliated with any conference (four of which will join a league next year; gone are the days of Notre Dame and DePaul scheduling at their whim), earning a bid, for most schools, is merely a matter of coming together for one key week in early March. With so many schools lacking a storied basketball tradition, in many smaller conferences they're simply rotating N.C.A.A. bids every few years.
Despite their shared past fighting in Vietnam, Senators Chuck Hagel and John McCain disagree profoundly about Iraq. Janny Scott reports.

With the 2005 Burgundies and Bordeaux on my mind I was about to offer a post on the tyranny of great vintages, but I've been distracted by the absorbing and sometimes heated discussion that is continuing in the comments section of my recent post on technology and winemaking. So many good and interesting points have been made that I feel compelled to respond to at least a few of them.
The Park Slope community leaders revoltedagainst the city's one-way traffic plan. [Streetsblog]

Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo didn't need to be reminded where he was playing when the Spartans faced Marquette on Thursday in the first round of the N.C.A.A. Tournament East Regional in Winston-Salem, N.C. All he had to do was listen to the cheers from the North Carolina fans in the stands as the scoreboard monitor showed a Tar Heel highlight reel during breaks of his game.
David Kraut and Rona Shalev met online, and he proposed with a video spoof of their favorite television show, "24."

As a longtime skeptic about the ability of the International Automobile Federation and the teams to return a Formula One weekend to the simplicity and glory of its greatest years, I am absolutely stunned to see that after finally creating a great qualifying session last year, the FIA has come up with a fantastic formula for Friday practice. (Which it had killed several years ago through various efforts at rewriting the rules.)

As Adam Liptak reported today in The Times, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed's claim that he murdered Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal journalist who was abducted and killed in 2002, might help another jihadi, Omar Sheikh, get off death row in Pakistan. Mr. Sheikh is the British-born Muslim who was found guilty in July 2002 of kidnapping and conspiring to kill Mr. Pearl and is appealing his death sentence.
Memphis Coach John Calipari's hip might be replaced and his waistline might be slightly larger, but he sure can talk like he did in his UMass heyday.

Thad Matta left Xavier for Ohio State three years ago, but Musketeer fans have long and bitter memories. Last night, when Matta found a seat along press row to scout Xavier and BYU in Lexington, he was lustily booed. Now, Xavier has a chance for revenge.
People you love and admire can have thriving, full-dress shows you don't even know about. They can have their own CHANNELS you don't know about. That's the fact in the world of online video.

SOMEWHERE in NORTHERN IOWA -- The unthinkable has happened. Senator John McCain met a question, while sitting with reporters on his bus as it rumbled through Iowa today, that he couldn't - or perhaps wouldn't - answer.

It's rare to find a new-build residence in the heart of very old London. But a luxurious low-built contemporary house -- brand new -- is on the market for £10 million -- or close to $20 million -- in London's posh Holland Park neighborhood. Developed by Spink Property, the house at 16 Portland Road boasts 5,129 square feet of space and includes parking for four cars. (This is a nice perk considering parking spaces in central London go for as much as £100,000 each.) The property centers around a two-storey open courtyard in the middle of the house. Wrapped around this courtyard is a vast open living area that's more than 78.9 feet in length. Nice features include a walnut staircase that weighs four tons. Check out more photos of this property by going to www.spinkproperty.co.uk.

CEDAR FALLS -- Senator John S. McCain offered an apology in Cedar Falls today after he used the word "tar-baby" in response to a rather arcane question from an Iowa voter about federal intervention in divorce and custody cases. The phrase is considered by some to be a racial epithet.
Before the game, CBS broadcaster Jim Nantz wasn't sure how to shorten the school's name for ease. "Just Corpus Christi, right?" he asked someone.

The California Public Employees' Retirement System has released its annual "Focus List" of companies it considered corporate underachievers. Calpers -- at $230 billion,the nation's biggest and most influential pension fund -- rates companies according to their earnings and their corporate government policies. Those that made the list are "the poster children for bad performance and bad corporate governance," said Calpers President Rob Feckner.
An exclusive video of "Smithereens" by El-P.

In one way, at least, there is a winner in the competition between private equity and hedge funds: Private equity, by a score of 30-17. This battle was fought not on Wall Street, or even in the leafy environs of Greenwich, Conn., but on a basketball court, in a 20-minute charity game on Thursday night. Reuters writer Michael Flaherty has some post-game color:

No matter where opinion might land on the CIA leak case and the fate of I. Lewis "Scooter" Libby, the spectacle of Valerie Wilson testifying this morning at a Congressional hearing offered new insights into the disclosure of her identity 3-1/2 years ago and the ramifications of a newly empowered Democratic majority on Capitol Hill.
[Updated, 4:30 p.m.]

As noted here earlier, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his weekly radio appearance today to talk about the ongoing flap between John Dunleavy, the head of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, and the city Fire Department. He said he would spend most of the parade tomorrow marching with firefighters to "stand up for them."

As reports emerge that buyout behemoth Blackstone Group is considering an initial public offering, here is the multibillion-dollar question: What would a publicly traded Blackstone be worth? It is difficult to guess, because most of the private equity firm's financial figures are, well, private. But a comparison with Fortress Investment Group, which recently opened its kimono as part of its highly successful I.P.O., gives some extremely rough guideposts.
The Queens grand jury investigating the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell has finished its work.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's Mar. 16 column, "Marching With a Mouse."

Here's something that might surprise Maryland basketball fans. Gary Williams, your long-time basketball coach, was rooting for A.C.C. rival Duke when the Blue Devils lost to Virginia Commonwealth in Buffalo on Thursday night.
Fifteen minutes before the Virginia-Albany tip-off here at Nationwide Arena in Columbus, there were empty seats galore.

Still trying to make a surf-and-turf special, seafood restaurant operator Landry's Restaurants on Friday increased its offer for the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group to about $84 million, topping a bid by the Patina Restaurant Group.

By launch a bid for Altadis, Britain's Imperial Tobacco has stirred up speculation that it may be a potential deal target as well. The potential acquiror? Altria. According to Reuters, because of antitrust regulations Altria's only plausible deal partner is Imperial, and should the British tobacconist reach a deal with French-Spanish Altadis, that window will close.

For the first 16 minutes, it looked like Memphis spent too much time out on Bourbon Street last night. The Tigers were sluggish, their offense impotent and North Texas was improbably controlling the game. The Mean Green played harder, crashed the boards and played with the verve of a team poised to pull an upset.

As the former media executive Conrad Black prepares for his trial, he may have a bigger worry than a lawyer with an ill-advised sense of humor. David Radler, the deputy chairman and chief operating officer at Hollinger International, has settled civil fraud charges for $29 million, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Friday.

Rupp Arena is the hallowed home of the Kentucky Wildcats, but you'd never know it this weekend. Instead of Big Blue from the rafters to the food court, it has been a sea of red and well, darker, blue.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "I Think I Love My Wife," Chris Rock's new film.

Chicago has a championship favorite (Kansas), it has a close-to-home favorite (Wisconsin) and highly intriguing games to start the day (Nevada-Las Vegas vs. Georgia Tech) and end it (Kentucky vs. Villanova).

More than any of the presidential candidates, John Edwards has come up with a specific and plausible plan that provides for health care coverage for all Americans. And he followed that up yesterday with an excellent speech on poverty at home and abroad, with some good and specific ideas.

Pete Gillen, the former coach of Virginia, was assigned the Columbus sub-regional pod three weeks ago as an analyst for Westwood One radio. He did not know at the time the Cavaliers would be put in the draw.
Senator Barack Obama is pushing back against former President Bill Clinton this morning over Mr. Clinton's apparent statement that Mr. Obama was initially ambivalent about the Iraq war.
Desperate fans held fistfuls of tickets to the sub-region here in Columbus. Face value: $61. Asking price? Whatever.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spoke passionately about the need to get illegal guns off the streets on his weekly radio interview this morning in the aftermath of the Greenwich Village shootout that left four people dead, including two auxiliary police officers.

Valerie Plame Wilson, the former C.I.A. operative whose cover was blown by White House officials and others, is testifying this morning before the House Government Oversight Committee on the chain of events that led to her name turning up in Robert Novak's syndicated column and to I. Lewis Libby, the vice presidential aide known as Scooter, being convicted of obstruction of justice and other charges.
Here are three explanations that readers came up for the Laugh Gap between the sexes:
It wouldn't be the St. Patrick's Day Parade in New York without a healthy dose of politics.

Viacom, controlled by Sumner Redstone, is suing Google for $1 billion for copyright violations on its YouTube video service. But CBS, also controlled by Sumner Redstone, is making licensing deals with Google for YouTube to use some of its content. What gives?

Hopefully you have somehow managed to take a half day today or to skip work all together. If you do go to work, heckling any Duke fans in the office would probably make it worth while. The relative lack of upsets on Thursday, just like last year, means that high seeds are likely to begin dropping in droves today. If you're headed to an early Happy Hour or stuck hitting refresh on the browser, here is The Bracket's guide to the best games today by time slot.

Yesterday, in my e-mail column, I described the TED 2007 conference, which was held last week in Monterey, California. And I promised to share with you some of my notes from the conference in a few blog entries.

Blackstone Group, one of the world's largest private equity firms, is preparing for an initial public offering, though the decision to go public has not yet been made, a person briefed on the plans told DealBook. CNBC's David Faber, who originally reported the I.P.O. preparations Friday morning, said Blackstone has been working with investment bank Goldman Sachs on an offering, adding that preliminary prospectus could be filed with regulators in two weeks. An I.P.O. would be just the latest audacious move for Blackstone chairman Stephen Schwarzman, who recently led his firm in a $39 billion purchase of Equity Office Properties Trust, the largest leveraged buyout ever completed. It would also represent a remarkable turn for Mr. Schwarzman, who, in his role as buyout king, has extolled the virtues of leaving public shareholders behind.

The three-month war over Caremark Rx is over, and the pharmacy chain from Woonsocket, R.I. has won. Caremark said Friday morning that its shareholders approved a $26.5 billion offer by CVS, the nation's largest drugstore chain, creating a new company with tremendous clout over drug prices.
In Iowa, Senator John McCain jumpstarts the Straight Talk Express, as he tours around the state, talking to voters and reporters about the war, his age and immigration (among other things).

Before the Congressional elections of 2006, a common meme among political writers was to assert that the Republicans had turned into 1980s Democrats: a corrupt, sleazy Congressional majority that had forgotten the principles that brought it to power. In the cover story for the redesigned Time magazine, Karen Tumulty suggests that a few months as the minority party haven't changed things. (Tumulty's critique also owes a debt to Slate editor Jacob Weisberg's notion of "interest-group conservatism"). Conservatives "are handcuffed to a political party that looks unsettlingly like the Democrats did in the 1980s, one that is more a collection of interest groups than ideas, recognizable more by its campaign tactics than its philosophy," she writes. She continues:

As rumors of a buyout dance around Dow Chemicals, the chemical giant is in talks with India's Reliance Industries to create a joint venture that would reduce its exposure to the volatile commodity chemicals market. The Financial Times said that reports have suggested that a deal might lead to a takeover of Dow by Reliance, India's largest public company, sending shares up 5 percent. But unnamed sources told the F.T. that such speculation was untrue.

Sure, the weather is kind of crummy in the Northeast this morning. New York area commuters woke up to find a little wet snow on lawns and car windows, a little slush on streets and sidewalks, some sleety flakes in the air and more expected later today. Not much fun but not a great big deal, at least not yet.
Does an apartment become subject to rent stabilization after the tenant is evicted?

Jeffrey M. Johnson, the former Los Angeles Times publisher whose stand against Tribune led to his ouster, has taken a position with Ronald Burkle's Yucaipa Companies, the private investment firm that is trying to acquire his former employer. The Times, which is owned by Tribune, said that Mr. Johnson will be a principal in the company, overseeing its media interests, including parts of Al Gore's Current TV channel.
While it might seem odd for a board to limit the rent amount, there is probably a good reason for the board’s action.

Two British firms -- Permira, the buyout group, and Centaurus, an activist hedge fund -- have proposed a 4 billion euro ($5.3 billion) deal for Atos Origin, a French information technology services group, the Financial Times reported Friday, citing unnamed sources. Atos confirmed Thursday that it had received an informal bid, but did not disclose the bidders. Shares in the company surged 25.2 percent to 49.50 euros a share on Thursday.
The Straight Talk Express, a vehicle that in the 2000 campaign became a potent symbol of Mr. McCain's message and appeal, is back.
Convinced we had found the architects who would be perfect for us, we headed down to Tampa to meet with Don Cooper of Cooper Johnson Smith. But the first impressions were far from favorable.
The Wall Street Journal editorial page condemns a different sort of March Madness:

Though many will be rooting for his conviction, Joseph Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, may escape from his trial on 42 insider-trading charges unscathed, according to lawyers watching the case. The trial, which begins March 19, will determine whether Mr. Nacchio is guilty of selling $101 million shares of Qwest from January to May of 2001 after getting internal warnings that the country's fourth-largest phone company would fall short of revenue expectations.

An article in The New York Times chronicling the pageantry of the upcoming fraud trial of Conrad Black, the former head of the Hollinger media empire, put Mr. Black's Canadian lawyer in a sticky situation Wednesday. The Guardian notes that Mr. Black's attorney, Edward Greenspan was hauled over the coals for making tongue-in-cheek remarks about his treatment as a foreigner in America's legal system.

The research analyst who is a key player in the fight between Fairfax Holdings and short-selling hedge funds was indicted Thursday on wire fraud charges unrelated to the case. Spyro Contogouris was formally charged in relation to a case related to a prior real-estate job; he was arrested for that matter last November. Mr. Contogouris, whose criticism of Fairfax drove several hedge funds to sell short the company, is part of a $5 billion lawsuit filed by the Canadian insurer alleging a conspiracy to drive its stock price down.
LOS ANGELES --William J. Bratton, the police chief here and one of Rudy Giuliani's former police commissioners, has shed some light on their private, eyebrow-raising meeting last week.

Virginia Commonwealth University is a public college based in Richmond. It is most famous for its medical school - it has America's oldest organ transplant center - and its arts school branch, which, bizarrely, is located in Education City, Qatar. (It also offers a degree in "Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness," so this is where the next Jack Bauer is coming from, for better or worse.) The trash metal costume band GWAR was formed there. It's a modest university of 30,000 students, and most of the time, it's nestled comfortably outside the public consciousness.

Evidence is weak that hedge funds are better stock pickers than mutual funds, a recent academic study suggests. The study was based on quarterly reports of funds' long positions filed with regulators, rather than on published hedge fund indexes, which some say paint a skewed picture of hedge funds' returns.
As reports surface that Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS's investment bank in New York, is threatening to leave the firm, speculation on the whys and wherefores of the situation is increasing.

Vivendi's Universal Music has offered to sell key catalogues, including the songbooks of Britney Spears and the Spice Girls, to win the European Union's go-ahead for its 1.63 billion euro ($2.17 billion) takeover of BMG Music Publishing, The Guardian reported.

AOL said Thursday it has withdrawn its cash offer for Swedish online marketing specialist TradeDoubler because it had not acquired enough shares by the bid deadline. AOL, a unit of Time Warner, offered in January to buy TradeDoubler in a cash deal that valued the company at around $900 million.

The Intercontinental Exchange's surprise $10 billion bid for the Chicago Board of Trade is expected to provide an added lift to Montreal Exchange's initial public offering, and could help boost the value of the upstart derivatives market to more than C$1.2 billion ($1 billion) when its shares begin trading later this month, The Globe and Mail said.

China Agri-Industries, a producer of biofuel, has raised $410 million after pricing its initial public offering at the top of the range following hefty demand from both institutional and retail investors. The strong interest came despite the Hang Seng Index shedding more than a thousand points last week. The retail tranche was 607 times oversubscribed, making it the second most popular I.P.O. with the Hong Kong public this year after China Huiyuan Juice, which drew $27.7 billion worth of retail demand.

The stock options expert whose research triggered a wide investigation into backdating says the pattern of option grants at Research In Motion does not appear to be the result of an accidental misunderstanding of accounting rules, as the company's chief executive officer has suggested.

Chicago bank holding company Corus Bankshares said its sizeable investment in the stock of troubled subprime lender Fremont General has caused Corus's position in Fremont to become "materially impaired," which will spark a hefty pretax charge that could be $14.3 million or even higher. While Corus emphasized that it has "the intent and the ability to retain its Fremont investment," the Chicago company believes that Fremont's recent travails require the company to record a charge in the first quarter of 2007, to reflect the decline in the value of its Fremont investment.

Texas' state Senate approved legislation Thursday that would strip TXU of some of its power plants and increase state authority over TXU operations -- including the right to approve the utility's proposed $45 billion sale to a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Texas Pacific Group.

Yahoo hasn't officially announced its Brickhouse program dedicated to launching innovative new products, but CNet News notes that word has leaked that it has hired a startup veteran to head up the program. Serial entrepreneur Salim Ismail, chairman of Confabb.com, a directory of conferences, and co-founder of PubSub, confirms on his blog on Thursday that he's joining Yahoo.
Images from the exhibition "Helio Oiticica: The Body of Color," at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston.
Another company is being accused of options backdating, but this time it's the shareholders pointing the finger.

For Wall Street investment bankers who have been looking for inventive ways to spend last year's record bonuses, there's something new on the menu: the $1,000 pizza. Manhattan restauranteur Nino Selimaj has added the pricey pie -- apparently the most expensive in the world -- to the menu at Nino's Bellisima on Second Ave., one of his six restaurants in the city. The uncooked pizza is topped with creme fraiche, chives, eight ounces of four different kinds of Petrossian caviar, four ounces of thinly sliced Maine lobster tail, salmon roe, and a little bit of spice with wasabi, according to CBS station WCBS-TV.

In a ruling that could have broader effects on the booming buyout business, a Delaware judge faulted Netsmart Technologies for excluding strategic buyers from its sale process and ordered the company to delay a vote on its proposal to be acquired by two private equity firms. In a memo to clients, law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz called the decision, issued late Wednesday by Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. of Chancery Court, a "major opinion" on a deal that, although small, had many of the same elements as large private-equity transaction.

Mitchel S. Guttenberg, the UBS banker who has been charged with conspiracy and securities fraud Thursday for allegedly masterminding an insider tarding scheme, apparently got his inside dope from his perch on an elite committee at UBS that signed off on all upgrades and downgrades, Businessweek says, taking another look at the banking scandal.

While many companies are starting tie the pay of chief executives to stock performance, don't expect Berkshire Hathaway to jump on the bandwagon anytime soon. For Warren Buffett, Berkshire's chief executive, such an arrangement would be a gold mine. His company's stock is valued at more than $106,000 a share. And last year, it rose 24 percent in value. But in a regulatory filing Thursday, the company said that "neither the profitability of Berkshire Hathaway nor the market value of its stock are to be considered in the compensation of any executive officer."

Takafumi Horie, the 34-year-old Internet tycoon once heralded as a symbol of new capitalism in Japan, was found guilty Friday morning by the Tokyo District Court of violating securities laws at his company, Livedoor. He was sentenced to two years and six months. Mr. Horie, who had pleaded not guilty and argued that the trial was politically motivated, is expected to appeal. Prosecutors, who depicted Mr. Horie as a greedy and lawless figure who had manipulated the books to inflate his company's stock price, had sought a four-year term.

AOL founder Steven Case, supermarket magnate Ronald Burkle and venture capitalist Vinod Khosla are teaming up to invest in a company that could produce up to 1 billion gallons of ethanol a year in Brazil, according to The Wall Street Journal. Brazilian Renewable Energy Company, known as Benco, closed an initial $200 million round of funding this week, The Journal said. The deal is expected to be officially announced Thursday, according to the newspaper.

The finance minister of Germany said Thursday that he favored the development of an internationally accepted "code of conduct" for the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry but that it would take the world's leading economies at least a year to decide how to establish a set of standards.

As a March 31 deadline nears for deciding the fate of Tribune, the proposal from Samuel Zell, the Chicago real estate billionaire, is falling from favor, according to The New York Times. The company, which has been on the auction block for more than five months, has all but dismissed three earlier bids. With Mr. Zell's bid losing steam, The Times said, management is forced to reconsider how the company might restructure.

Silicon Valley's technology investors have taken to the ramparts, threatening to tear down the oil and gas industries' dominance with its green-tech innovations that use ethanol, solar and wind. The cry has been raised by some of the Valley' most stored venture capital firms such as Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Its principals, John Doerr in particular, have passionately (and tearfully) advocated development of alternative energies as a way to create energy independence and clean up the carbon-saturated atmosphere.

There would seem to be plenty of differences between E. Stanley O'Neal and Deborah C. Wright. He heads Merrill Lynch, one of Wall Street's largest firms, while she leads Carver Federal Savings Bank, the country's largest black financial institution, but a fraction of Merrill's size.

General Motors, a company once known as the model of corporate accounting, warned investors on Thursday that its performance was threatened by "ineffective" controls over financial reporting, including inadequately trained personnel and failure to obtain management's approval for some transactions. The disclosure, made in G.M.'s annual report filed with federal regulators after a six-week delay, was the latest indication that the automaker is on shakier footing than first thought.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange may find it difficult to top Intercontinenental Exchange's $10 billion bid for the Chicago Board of Trade, analysts said yesterday. Under terms of ICE's proposal, the Board of Trade's shareholders would own about 51.5 percent of the combined company, which would be based in Chicago and have its headquarters at the Board of Trade's storied building in the financial district.
Chief Executive Carlos Ghosn will focus on leading Nissan and Renault, which he also runs, Nissan said today.
Living with six children in 800 square feet.
“Beyond Glory” will replace “The Home Place” as the final show in the Roundabout Theater Company’s current season.
Winter’s sharp edge is finally easing, and shoppers are seeking lighter coverage. This year’s crop of spring coats breaks out of the boring trenches.
There was one major upset in the quarterfinals of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams: the No. 1 seed lost to the No. 25 seed.
Cory Booker, the mayor of Newark, talks about his road from the suburbs to Oxford to public housing.
Gas-powered boots, first conceived by a Russian student in 1974, have been held up as a symbol of Russia's inability to convert rich scientific traditions into useful merchandise.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Highlights from the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
It may not be your first thought when planning a culinary journey, but Addis Ababa, the capital city of Ethiopia, has a vibrant food culture worth exploring.

The Web site of David R. Garvin, the gunman who killed a pizzeria worker and two auxiliary police officers in the West Village before he was shot dead Wednesday night, reveals a frustrated writer of screenplays with a dark and bizarre sensibility.
Even with a fiberglass body, it's hard to tell the difference between a classic and a replica.
Famous for their bruising defense and stubborn interior play, the Hoosiers hung out at the 3-point line Thursday night and took down the Gonzaga Bulldogs from long range.
No. 4 Seed Maryland (25-8) vs. No. 5 Seed Butler (28-6)
The first and only time Eastern Kentucky and North Carolina met on a basketball court, the year was 1950, Harry Truman was president and the Tar Heels were apparently no match for the Colonels.
Although sixth-seeded Duke was upset, 79-77, by No. 11 seed Virginia Commonwealth, the Blue Devils will be just fine.
In last year's N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, 11th-seeded George Mason made it all the way to the Final Four.
The sloppy, absent-minded “Premonition” is a step back in time and a giant leap backward for Sandra Bullock.
This documentary about the business of reality television illustrates the premise that if you lie down with dogs, you wake up with fleas.
Wisconsin trailed for most of its game against 15th-seeded Texas A&M-Corpus Christi. The Badgers ultimately fended off what might have been the biggest upset bid in tournament history.
A British soldier who died four years ago after an American pilot opened fire on his convoy in Iraq was killed unlawfully, a coroner ruled today.
The company reported that Stephen P. MacMillan met nearly all of the board’s goals for him in his second year as chief executive.
Notre Dame came to the N.C.A.A. tournament early, played early and left early as the Winthrop Eagles upset the Fighting Irish in a first-round game filled with drastic shifts of momentum.
The government repeated today that there was no evidence that the Japanese military had forcibly recruited women into sex slavery during World War II.
Ten inmates at a British military internment facility in Basra used an audacious plan to escape, a spokesman said.
Despite all the trappings of an N.C.A.A. tournament upset, North Texas simply couldn't get past No. 2 seed Memphis.
The reversal was prompted by what the retailer said was “manufactured controversy” surrounding the proposal.
President Bush’s spokesman backed away today from earlier assertions that the former White House counsel  was responsible for the idea to fire U.S. attorneys.
The Runnin' Rebels' first-round game with Georgia Tech made for a testy and sloppy low-scoring affair, marked by referee whistles, splayed bodies, mishandled passes and missed shots.
There was not a spot on the floor Friday where Virginia’s J.R. Reynolds could not make a shot. His 28 points on 9 of 13 shooting led the Cavaliers over No. 13 Albany.
A Queens grand jury voted to indict three city police detectives in the November killing of Sean Bell, an unarmed 23-year-old black man, a defense lawyer in the case said.
No one was hurt in the apparent kidnapping attempt on the Gaza director of the United Nations refugee agency.
Speaking in public for the first time about the case, Valerie Plame Wilson told a House panel today that she felt betrayed by officials who failed to protect her identity.
Five victims of last week’s deadly fire in the Bronx today began their journey to Africa for burial.
The report suggested that a weakening economy has not yet caused inflation to slow.
The Nets remain in the playoff picture after the loss, but they continue to show that they are simply running in place.
CVS shareholders voted to approve the company’s $23.9 billion plan to buy pharmacy benefits manager Caremark Rx.
A judge has barred Netsmart Technologies from polling shareholders on a $115 million offer to sell out to private equity firms.

The All Nippon Airways Company had its offices in Los Angeles searched for nine hours yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to a statement from the carrier. The FBI declined to say why the office was searched. ”We don’t know why they raided the office, but we confirmed with our staff there that it wasn’t anything to do with the operation of the aircraft or terrorism,” a spokesman at All Nippon, Rob Henderson, said. The customer service center in Los Angeles is the headquarters of the airline’s North American operations and is responsible for passenger and cargo sales for the western and southern United States.
Duke led for much of the game, but could not put Virginia Commonwealth away as they failed to reach the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1996.
Kei Igawa was hard to hit when he faced the Atlanta Braves on Thursday, but he threw more balls than strikes over three innings.
Takafumi Horie was found guilty by the Tokyo District Court of violating securities laws at his company, Livedoor.
Corrections: For the Record
An article on Wednesday about the shooting of a New York City police officer in a gunfight with a suspect misspelled the officer’s surname in some copies. He is Officer Robert Tejada, not Tejeda.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a white Missouri man and a black Harlem woman who found out through genetic testing that they were related referred imprecisely to the given name of a performer who entertained during a New York family reunion. She goes by Cissy Houston, not Emily. (She was born Emily Drinkard.).

A sports article on Tuesday about strategies used by successful players in last year’s ESPN.com Tournament Challenge basketball contest referred incorrectly to the number of brackets submitted in the game. It was more than 3 million, not 750,000.

A front-page article on March 6 about Thomas DiBiagio, who said that he was forced out as the federal prosecutor in Maryland in 2005 because of political pressure stemming from investigations involving associates of then Gov. Robert Ehrlich Jr., referred incorrectly to the office Mr. Ehrlich held in 2001, when he recommended Mr. DiBiagio for appointment. He was a Republican member of Congress. He was not Maryland’s sole statewide Republican officeholder.

A picture caption with an article yesterday about antiwar legislation in Congress misidentified the Senate majority leader in come copies. He is Harry Reid of Nevada, second-from-left, not Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, left. (They were among four Democratic senators shown preparing remarks.).

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Michael F. Summers, a biochemist who promotes training programs to increase diversity in science, misstated his age. He is 49, not 59. The article also misstated the given name of an analytical chemist whom Dr. Summers named as one of his mentors. He is Isiah Warner, not Isaiah Warner.
Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Shane MacGowan of the Pogues misspelled the title of a song by the band. It is “Sally MacLennane,” not “Sally MacLennan.”.

A museum review on Saturday about the U.S.S. Monitor Center in Newport News, Va., misidentified the site where the Monitor was built. It was the Continental Iron Works in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, not the Brooklyn Navy Yard. (The ship was outfitted and commissioned at the yard.).

An article on Wednesday about the winners of the Intel Science Talent Search referred incorrectly to the 40 finalists. There were 20 women and 20 men; they were not “almost equally” divided by sex — as were the top 10, which included six women. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the night the winners were announced. It was Tuesday, not Monday.
The Dow Minute-by-Minute chart in Business Day yesterday misstated the market’s close for Tuesday. It was 12,075.96 — not 12,133.40, which was Wednesday’s close.
U.C.L.A. did not grab control of Thursday’s game against Weber State until the end of the first half, but the Bruins led by 20 early in the second half and went on to an easy victory.

An article yesterday about the close ties between Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and President Bush misidentified President John F. Kennedy’s brother, the attorney general from 1961 to 1964 and one of President Kennedy’s closest advisers. It was Robert F. Kennedy, not his son Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
An official says the cost of retirement benefits promised to employees may exceed projections by billions of dollars.

Nissan Motor plans to cut production at two plants in Japan from April 2 until the end of June because of weaker demand. Nissan will cut a shift on a production line in Kanagawa and in Tochigi Prefectures, a spokesman, Yuichi Nakagawa, said. Each plant has two lines. The plant in Kanagawa makes subcompacts like the March, and the Tochigi plant builds Skyline sedans and other vehicles. Nissan’s domestic vehicle sales, excluding minicars, fell for a 17th straight month in February.

Bayer, the drug and chemicals maker, said its fourth-quarter earnings surged, helped by growth in its health care business, and forecast a 5 percent increase in annual sales as it benefits from the acquisition of Schering. The company, based in Leverkusen, said it earned 311 million euros ($410 million) in the period, compared with 46 million euros a year earlier. Sales during the fourth quarter rose 25 percent, to 7.97 billion euros ($10.51 billion) from 6.37 billion euros. Sales in its health care unit rose 75 percent, to 3.78 billion euros ($4.98 billion). The company’s crop sciences unit posted fourth-quarter sales of 1.3 billion euros ($1.71 billion), down 5.4 percent. Bayer’s chief executive, Werner Wenning, above, said Bayer expects an increase in group sales this year of more than 10 percent, which would come to about 5 percent when adjusted for the rising euro.

A bid by a private equity consortium to take over Qantas Airways appears to be in trouble after improvements in the airline’s earning prospects have left the offer looking inadequate. The Airline Partners Australia consortium, which includes the Texas Pacific Group, Macquarie Bank and Allco Equity Partners, made the takeover bid last year, valuing Qantas at 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.75 billion). At the time, many were surprised that the bidders believed the airline was worth so much, but with recently growing passenger loads and stable fuel prices, that view has changed. “The underlying conditions in the airline market have improved and have made the original bid look a bit skinny,” said Matthew Crowe, the transportation analyst at JPMorgan in Sydney.

Luxury home prices in London rose at an annual rate of 31 percent in February, the fastest pace in 28 years. The average price of London’s most expensive houses and apartments gained 2.6 percent on a monthly basis, according to data compiled by Knight Frank, a real estate broker based in London. “Prices in central London have for the past two years been growing at three times the rate” of the rest of Britain, said Liam Bailey, the partner in charge of residential research at Knight Frank.

The Russian flag carrier Aeroflot will acquire 22 A350 Airbus wide-body jets and Qatar Airways is in talks with Airbus on a purchase of 80 A350s, the airlines said. Aeroflot also could soon sign a contract to buy 10 to 15 smaller A330s as part of a major upgrade of its fleet, a spokeswoman, Irina Dannenberg, said. Delivery of the A330s would begin by the end of 2008, while the A350s would be delivered starting in 2015, Ms. Dannenberg said. A final contract for both models will be signed in coming weeks. She declined to say how much the deal would be worth. A major A350 sale would help Airbus at a difficult time.
The Queens grand jury weighing evidence in the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell interrupted its deliberations yesterday to hear from a new witness, a law enforcement official said.
The Buckeyes stood outside Central Connecticut State’s two-three zone and poured in one 3-pointer after another as they routed the Blue Devils in the first round.

Fiat said it would go ahead with plans to build a low-cost car, joining a growing number of automakers seeking to emulate Renault’s success with the Romanian-built Logan. “This will be our answer to the Logan,” said Fiat’s chief executive, Sergio Marchionne. Mr. Marchionne said Fiat would build the car in Brazil and might expand its production to China, India and Turkey, where it has plants. Faced with flat growth and increasing competition in their home markets, Fiat and other automakers are expanding in the developing world, where markets are growing very fast.

The body of a 6-year-old boy who vanished a week ago while playing near his home in Brunswick was found by a state ranger about three miles from the home. This week, the police arrested four people — a convicted child molester living in the same area, his parents and a friend of theirs — in connection with the disappearance of the boy, Christopher M. Barrios, left. Investigators said the four had told a tangle of stories, that they knew nothing about the disappearance, that the boy was still alive and that he had been abducted, killed and buried. Chief Matt Doering of the Glynn County Police Department said all four would probably be charged with murder in the slaying.

A burglary suspect was arrested after he left behind an Illinois Department of Corrections identification card that he used to jimmy a lock, the authorities said. Officers said they arrested the suspect, Robert A. Fry of Rock Island, Ill., after investigating the theft on Tuesday of a plastic jug containing about $400 in change from an apartment in Bettendorf. They said they found Mr. Fry’s Corrections Department ID card at the apartment and arrested him on Wednesday at a motel. Mr. Fry, 43, was released from the Illinois prison system in January, having served two years and three months of a 10-year term for burglary.

A woman whom Gov. Deval L. Patrick hired as chief of staff for his wife, Diane, has resigned less than a week after it was disclosed that Mrs. Patrick was being treated for depression and exhaustion. The woman, Amy Gorin, who with her husband led fund-raising for Mr. Patrick’s campaign for governor, was appointed to the $72,000-a-year position last month. Mr. Patrick also announced that he was hiring a senior aide to the State Senate president, Robert E. Travaglini.

A federal appeals court granted the request of a condemned Arizona murderer who asked to end his appeals and be executed, even though a dissenting judge said there were grounds to reverse the death sentence. Ruling 14 to 1, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, said the condemned man, Robert C. Comer, could end his appeals and be executed by lethal injection for the 1987 murder of an Apache Lake camper in a series of crimes in which he also raped a woman after tying up her boyfriend.

Presiding Bishop Katharine Jefferts Schori of the Episcopal Church invalidated the election of a bishop in the Diocese of South Carolina, which has rejected her authority because of her liberal theological outlook. The Very Rev. Mark Lawrence, a priest in the conservative Diocese of San Joaquin, was elected on the first ballot last September as South Carolina bishop. The San Joaquin Diocese has rejected Bishop Jefferts Schori’s authority, and in December took the first step toward a formal break with the denomination. Some believed that Father Lawrence planned to follow suit in South Carolina. He vehemently denied it. Bishop Jefferts Schori concluded that several dioceses had failed to submit proper written consent for the South Carolina election.

A legislative panel unanimously approved a bill to create a Confederate heritage month. The bill, sponsored by State Senator Jeff E. Mullis, a Republican, would designate April as Confederate History and Heritage Month. The vote by the Senate Rules Committee, which sends the bill to the full Senate, was days after black lawmakers announced plans to ask the state to apologize officially for its role in slavery and segregation-era laws.
Richard Jefferson is willing to believe in a team that has had difficulty believing in itself this season.

Longstanding restrictions that bar the reporting of federal election results from eastern districts while polls are still open in western time zones are constitutional, the Supreme Court ruled in a 5-to-4 decision. Rejecting an argument that the prohibition violated free speech, the court said the temporary nature of the ban made it permissible. It upheld the conviction of Paul Bryan, a software developer in British Columbia, who posted vote tallies from Atlantic Canada in the 2000 election on a Web site while polls in his far western province were still open. He was fined $1,000 by a lower court. The rules were introduced in 1938 to cover radio broadcasts in the belief that voters in western time zones (there are five time zones across Canada) might be influenced or even discouraged from voting by results from the eastern zones.

President Robert G. Mugabe dismissed international condemnations of his government’s violent assaults on opposition members, saying of his Western critics, “They can go hang.” Speaking after a meeting with Tanzania’s president, Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete, Mr. Mugabe, left, said Western governments ignored violent acts by the opposition Movement for Democratic Change in favor of criticizing his regime “when it tries to prevent violence.” The police beat at least 50 protesters when they tried to hold a meeting on Sunday; many, including the leader Morgan Tsvangirai, were hospitalized.

A nuclear power plant operator, the Hokuriku Electric Power Company, shut down a reactor in central Ishikawa Prefecture for inspection after it admitted that it had covered up a 15-minute uncontrollable nuclear chain reaction in 1999.

The assistant secretary of state for south and central Asia, Richard A. Boucher, announced a $750 million aid package for the development of Pakistan’s tribal areas on the Afghan border, where Al Qaeda and the Taliban operate. “Pakistan has been a very strong ally with President Musharraf as leader,” Mr. Boucher said at a news conference at the well-guarded United States Embassy in Islamabad. Pakistan has come under persistent criticism over the past year for its failure to stem the infiltration of insurgents into Afghanistan or to tackle Qaeda camps in the border areas.

A court in Périgueux convicted a doctor, Laurence Tramois, in the 2003 poisoning death of a terminally ill cancer patient and gave her a one-year suspended prison sentence in a trial that has brought the issue of euthanasia to France’s presidential race. The court also ruled that the doctor’s conviction should not be kept on file, which will allow her to continue to practice medicine. A second defendant, a nurse who delivered the fatal dose of potassium chloride prescribed by the doctor, was acquitted. Euthanasia is illegal in France. Last week, 2,000 doctors and nurses signed a petition urging the decriminalization of euthanasia and saying they had helped patients die.

The Federal Security Services, working with the police in Russia and other countries, said it had broken up a ring accused of trafficking people from Southeast Asia and former Soviet states through Russia and to Western Europe. It said the operation had been directed by an unidentified Russian government official.
After an uneasy start to his campaign, Senator John McCain is back on board the Straight Talk Express.
The senior presidential adviser inquired about firing in January 2005, e-mails  show.
Lottery Numbers.

The 440 faculty members at the Camden campus of Rutgers University received e-mail messages this week from an associate provost asking questions about the activities of State Senator Wayne R. Bryant, the embattled legislator who collected up to $35,000 a year for four years to lecture at the law school there but who records say hardly did so.
An 18-month evaluation of California’s public schools has concluded that the state’s educational system is in need of sweeping reforms that could cost billions of dollars.

A Staten Island man was convicted yesterday of attempted rape in a 2005 attack in which a woman grabbed his knife and chased him from her home, prosecutors said. The man, Michael Delgado, 26, of Nicholas Avenue, was found guilty of robbery and attempted rape in State Supreme Court, said Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney. Mr. Donovan said that Mr. Delgado tried to rape the woman, a mother of four, at knife-point after breaking into her apartment on May 10, 2005, but that when he put down his knife, she grabbed it and chased him. He faces up to 25 years in prison, Mr. Donovan said.

A bomb squad was called to an upstate mall yesterday morning after a worker found what appeared to be a pipe bomb, the state police said. A maintenance contractor found the device around 7 a.m. in a parking lot at Aviation Mall in Queensbury, about 50 miles north of Albany. The state police said the pipe was six inches long, with a diameter of one and a quarter inches. It was capped off at both ends, and bomb disposal officers found a powdery material inside it. The device was turned over to the F.B.I., the state police said.

A state trooper accused of vehicular homicide in a crash that killed two teenage sisters last September pleaded not guilty in State Superior Court yesterday. The trooper, Robert Higbee, was patrolling in Upper Township on Sept. 27 when he crashed into a Dodge Caravan carrying the sisters, Jacqueline Becker-Caiafa, 17, and Christina, 19. Trooper Higbee was issued a summons for careless driving and later indicted. At yesterday’s hearing, he briefly embraced the girls’ mother after asking to speak with her. “This was a tragic and unfortunate accident,” said David Jones, president of the State Troopers Fraternal Organization. “It certainly wasn’t a crime.”.

A federal Defense Department employee has been charged with failing to disclose foreign contacts and making false statements as part of a security check, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The employee, Beatrice Ruiz, 55, of Norwalk, worked as a federal engineer at the Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation in Stratford, prosecutors said. Prosecutors said Ms. Ruiz used her official computer to run a consulting business with foreign companies and failed to disclose the business when completing security forms. Her lawyer, Robert Altchiler, has denied the charges and attributed them to a language barrier.

A building contractor working for the City Sanitation Department was accused yesterday of filing false records with the city certifying that he had hired a local subcontractor, the Department of Investigation said. The contractor, Chaudhry Ali, 43, president of Shawn Construction, was charged with criminal possession of a forged instrument, said Rose Gill Hearn, the commissioner of investigation. He had not yet appeared in court yesterday afternoon, prosecutors said. Ms. Gill Hearn said Mr. Ali was required to subcontract a certain portion of a roofing contract to a local company, and falsely certified that a Brooklyn company had done the work. She said the Brooklyn company was unaware that it had been identified as the subcontractor and did not perform the work.

Federal regulators yesterday approved a new 50-year license for the state’s largest hydroelectric plant, the 2,755-megawatt Niagara Hydroelectric Project. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved agreements by the plant’s owner, the New York Power Authority, that will deliver $279 million to Erie County for waterfront development over 50 years and $694.2 million for Niagara County environmental and recreational projects during the same period. By diverting water from Niagara Falls for electricity production, the Niagara plant generates 10 percent of the state’s power. The project’s current 50-year license expires at the end of August.

A Texas man was charged yesterday with fatally beating an elderly man at a rest stop on the New Jersey Turnpike after the man declined to buy his religious CDs, the state police said. The suspect, Brian K. White, 26, of Humble, Tex., was charged with murder, the state police said. The state police said witnesses told them that Mr. White beat Michail J. Makarenko, 75, of Virginia, with a rock after he refused to buy the CDs. Mr. White then drove away in his Chevrolet Camaro, leading the police on an hourlong chase before he pulled over in Teaneck, left his car and charged at state troopers, the state police said. “He possibly is delusional,” said Maj. Mary Beth Mahlmann of the state police.

Raritan Bay Medical Center has agreed to pay $7.5 million to settle federal lawsuits that accuse it of improperly increasing charges to Medicare patients, the Justice Department announced yesterday. The hospital received larger reimbursements than warranted from the federal program from 1998 to 2003, and it will make changes meant to ensure compliance with Medicare regulations, the department said. In a statement, the hospital said that at the time, it believed that its billing practices were in accord with regulations.

A former Pace University student was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years of probation and 100 hours of community service after he admitted making fake drivers’ licenses, prosecutors said. The student, William Gerhard, 20, of Yorktown, pleaded guilty to second-degree forgery in November, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Ms. DiFiore said Mr. Gerhard made and sold New Jersey drivers’ licenses out of his dorm room. She said the licenses were sold to students, who mainly used them to buy alcohol.

The Justice Department filed a civil rights lawsuit yesterday against the State Department of Correctional Services, which runs the state’s prisons. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, claims that the department discriminates “by failing or refusing to reasonably accommodate” Muslim employees who cannot comply with the department’s uniform or grooming rules because of their religion. Last year, a Muslim guard, Abdus Samad N. Haqq, at a work release institution on West 110th Street, filed a lawsuit seeking an order permitting him to wear his kufi, a cap Muslims wear to signal devotion. His case is pending. A spokesman for the state attorney general’s office did not respond to a request for comment.
Friends and family of two slain officers spoke of their earnestness and altruism, of a simple wish to do good.
In vowing to reform the earmark process, the House of Representatives set a narrower definition of the term in the process.
The paths of an ex-marine whose life had been unstable for years, a pizzeria bartender and two auxiliary police officers intersected in a mere 10 minutes.
Intercontinental Exchange made a $10 billion bid to wrest the Chicago Board of Trade away from its planned merger partner, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
With spins progressing from 900-degree revolutions, to 1080s, called 10s, and on to 1260s, some riders have suggested the sport is blurring its most important element: style.
In acknowledging his role in more than 30 terrorist attacks and plots, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed  may have complicated the prosecution of his former colleagues.
Fred F. Fielding is the White House front man in a high-stakes showdown with the new Democratic majority on Capitol Hill.
The closer and more intently we look at nature, the more species we find, at home and in places like the Heart of Borneo.
Significant numbers of Republicans voted with Democrats to reverse the erosion of the public’s right to know how its government operates.
A similar measure advanced in the House, and Democratic leaders vowed to keep challenging President Bush to change course in Iraq.
The country’s largest black financial institution is teaming up with Merrill Lynch to help the firm entree into minority neighborhoods.
Dozens of colleges and universities are said to have accepted financial incentives from student loan companies to steer student business their way.

The accusation that United States attorneys were insufficiently aggressive about voter fraud is a way of saying, without actually saying, that they would not use their offices to help Republicans win elections.
The focus in the Mets’ clubhouse was on N.C.A.A. tournament games and the teams’ divided loyalties.
It remains shockingly easy for airport employees to sneak into secure areas and carry dangerous materials onto a plane without detection.
With David R. Garvin's death, it is difficult to burrow into the motives and inner thinking that led to Wednesday night's explosion of violence.
Before arriving at North Texas to play basketball, Rich Young served four years in the Marines and did missions in Iraq, Kenya, Kosovo and Djibouti.
A jury was selected in the racketeering trial of Conrad M. Black and jurors were instructed to return Monday for opening statements.
The proposal from Sam Zell is said to be falling from favor, forcing  management to reconsider how Tribune might restructure.
Growing up, basketball kept Kansas guard Sherron Collins off the street and in the gym.
Prices rose broadly and sharply for businesses in February as an array of goods, from children’s toys to tobacco, became more expensive.
The attack was one of the biggest since the resurrection of armed leftist rebellion in the last several years.
Michael G. Oxley was named a nonexecutive vice chairman of the Nasdaq Stock Market, a newly created position.
Signs of strength in corporate takeover activity, jobs and overseas markets allowed investors to stomach a sharp rise in wholesale inflation.
Russia, Greece and Bulgaria signed an agreement to build an oil pipeline bypassing the crowded Bosporus in Turkey.
The man who was shot in the pizzeria in the Greenwich Village shooting was remembered as a peaceful man who stayed away from drugs and trouble.
General Motors warned investors that its performance was threatened by “ineffective” controls over financial reporting.
The ambush wounded the mayor and complicated U.S. efforts to rein in a powerful Shiite militia in Sadr City.
General Electric’s leasing, financing and asset management business plans to buy the PHH Corporation for about $1.8 billion.
Thursday was a day of reflection and acute caution for uniformed patrol officers after a two-day spate of violence against police.
Seven days apart in Florida, two graduates of Milton High School’s class of 1992 narrowly missed putts that would have given them victories.
Singapore’s government is being forced to tap its sand hoard after Indonesia banned sand exports, the latest in a string of disputes between the country and its neighbors.
The small nonprofit group that compelled European banks to pay billions in Holocaust restitution  has dismissed its leader, Israel Singer, after three years of controversy.
The continued failure in many of the city’s middle schools comes two years after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced $40 million in additional spending on the middle grades.
The Assembly voted Thursday to move New Jersey’s presidential primary to Feb. 5 in an effort to have more say in who runs for president.
The finance minister of Germany said he favored an internationally accepted “code of conduct” for the hedge fund industry.
The Bear Stearns Companies, Wall Street’s largest underwriter of mortgage securities, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 8 percent despite turmoil in the subprime lending sector.
Supporters hope the measure secures the legal foundation for private entrepreneurs and urban home owners.
Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS’s investment bank in New York, is threatening to leave the firm, according to people briefed on the matter.
The report suggests that sparks generated inside the Sago Mine were the likely cause of the blast that killed one miner and led to the asphyxiation of 11 others.
Bowie Kuhn was the commissioner of baseball during a tumultuous 15-year period when the game experienced dramatic growth accompanied by unprecedented labor strife.
Some technology investors that portray themselves as green-friendly are inconsistent with their marketing message.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) — Following is the 50-to-48 roll-call vote in the Senate on Thursday by which Republicans turned back Democratic a resolution to require a United States troop withdrawal from Iraq to begin within 120 days. The 48 votes were 12 short of the 60 needed for passage. A “yes” vote was a vote to support the measure. Voting “yes” were 46 Democrats, 1 Republican and 1 independent. Voting “no” were 2 Democrats, 1 independent and 47 Republicans. Two senators did not vote.
In the Knicks’ 10-point loss to the Toronto Raptors Eddy Curry was held to 13 points and took only nine shots.
The $3.2 billion deal to acquire the online meeting company WebEx furthers Cisco’s push into the business communications market.
James S. Oddo is the crusading New York City councilman and self-identified boy-of-summer behind the Council’s decision to ban metal bats from high school baseball in the city.
Imperial Tobacco, a British cigarette maker, made an 11.5 billion euro ($15.2 billion) takeover bid for Altadis, its Madrid-based rival.
In a city near Miami known for its whimsical architecture, officials are fleeing a crumbling, vermin-infested City Hall.
Some major manufacturers, while contending that they carefully monitor product safety, are not as rigorous as they should be.
Madison Avenue’s ability to contribute phrases to the vernacular has always been prized as a way to amplify an ad campaign.
Richard F. Scruggs, the lawyer representing homeowners affected by Hurricane Katrina, has turned the case into a nightmare for the insurance industry.
The Palestinian government announced a unity coalition with Fatah. But the document does not fulfill international demands.
Police found three handguns, three rifles and more than 500 rounds of ammunition in a raid on Tank Johnson’s home in December.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,189 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Police officers and rioters clashed after about 100,000 people rallied to demand that the Socialist prime minister resign.
Under pressure from gay rights groups, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama issued statements saying they believed homosexuality was not immoral.
The measure expands a roster from an earlier resolution that lists companies and individuals in Iran subject to an assets freeze.
A recent civil case is the first time that a military officer has been formally called to account for the torture of political prisoners.
As Mexico’s finance minister in the 1960s, Antonio Ortiz Mena was the architect of a period of remarkable growth known as the “Mexican miracle.”
The measure will remove officials who collaborated with the secret police before the Poles began their transition from Communism to democracy in 1989.
As Mitt Romney seeks the Republican presidential nomination, his fiscal and economic achievements are central elements of his campaign.
The Los Angeles Lakers and their coach, Phil Jackson, were each fined $50,000 by the N.B.A. yesterday after Jackson said the league was conducting a “witch hunt” against Kobe Bryant.
Carla Berry, a Louisiana State assistant women’s basketball coach, reported the former head coach Pokey Chatman’s alleged improper conduct with a former team member.
The president of the leading Southern Baptist seminary has suggested that scientific research “points to some level of biological causation” for homosexuality.
Germany’s love of speed on the autobahn is colliding with fears about global warming, as its drivers spew tons of carbon dioxide into the air.
With a swipe of his pen, some flowery remarks and a good backdrop, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger moved California’s presidential primary to February of next year from June.
Vanderbilt blew out George Washington Thursday with the kind of force usually reserved for early December, when national powers take on mid-major patsies.
The current vice president dismissed the charges as politically motivated and says he is going fight to get his name on the ballot.
An employee at a Bronx hospital has tuberculosis and may have exposed hundreds of patients and co-workers, including more than 200 newborn babies, officials said.
A spacecraft has scanned deposits of ice at the south pole of Mars so plentiful they would blanket the planet in 36 feet of water if they were liquid, scientists say.
After a tedious first half that ended with Old Dominion leading by 20-19, Butler pulled away in the second half with a barrage of long-range shooting.
People.
There are thousands of space objects that could hit Earth in the next century that could cause severe damage, if not total destruction.
Rodents  in restaurants, while distasteful, are more a distraction than a disaster for public health.
On Wednesday at City Center Paul Taylor’s expansive vision was particularly entrancing in “Airs,” a 1978 masterwork that takes dancers on a free-flowing journey.
At Wednesday’s concert, themed “Island Journeys,” the  best vocal moments were in the more exotic song groups, most notably Rinat Shaham’s take on a work by Ravel.
The conviction of Nikolai G. Zavadsky did little to resolve the full mystery of the missing works, worth an estimated $5 million, from the State Hermitage Museum in Moscow.
Korean publisher withdraws anti-Semitic comic, Brandon Rogers loses on “American Idol,” the president of First Look Pictures steps down and more culture news.
The National Geographic Channel’s in-depth film on the island’s unique inhabitants is the kind of visually stunning program your high-definition television was made for.
Despite his recent successes, the self-deprecating, profanity-free comic remains mindful of his past.
Peter Mattei, an elegant baritone who has also received high praise for his acting, is a prime example of a new generation of opera singers.
Washington State played with the kind of intensity expected from midmajor teams like Oral Roberts, rallying from a first-half deficit and rolling to a victory in the first round.
Philip Taaffe’s new paintings at the uptown Gagosian Gallery are suavely eye-popping. Also, Tony Oursler at Lehmann Maupin and Bill Jensen at Cheim & Read.
The combination of guards Tyrese Rice and Sean Marshall along with the A.C.C. player of the year Jared Dudley was too much for Texas Tech as Boston College advanced to the second round.

Barbara Cassidy’s new play quickly bogs down into a series of disjointed scenes that go in no particular direction.
The Mexican rock band’s show at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday was tight as a drum, stripped of longeurs and entertaining, in a businesslike way.
The young American pianist has stunning technical control and tasteful sense of phrase, as proven in his program of Liszt and Rachmaninoff on Wednesday.

Auxiliary officers are not real cops. They do not carry guns. But they do wear blue, and that can be enough to make them targets.

They carry nightsticks but not guns. They wear uniforms but not bulletproof vests underneath, unless they buy the extra protection on their own. They have police radios that buzz with reports of crimes in progress.

The matter-of-fact, slightly laughable sculptures by the Brazilian Conceptual artist Tunga at the Luhring Augustine gallery look much like bedside lamps, except that they are 12 feet tall, with an assortment of objects about their bases: braided iron wire, zinc-galvanized iron nets, glass goblets, epoxy-resin skulls and animal bones, cast-aluminum canes, gold-mesh shoji screens and oversize insect wings made of soldered iron. What does it all mean? The sculptures probably wouldn't be worth pondering had this 55-year-old artist not made use of a remarkable talent for poetic juxtapositions and combined the ingredients in such a way as to suggest a delicate balance between order and chaos, form and formlessness. The effect is bewitching when it comes off, which is not always the case with the dozen or so sculptures on display through March 24. The best emit an enigmatic glow, while others look as if they might collapse in a sudden heap with a snap of the fingers. One of the sculptures that feels fully resolved is ''La Mouche'' (2007), right, which in its lamplike way resembles all the other pieces, though installed alone in a large, darkened gallery under spotlights. Its shininess somehow evokes an ambience of decadence, leaving the viewer to contemplate the meaning of every little element, every symbolic reference, and the elusiveness of assemblage sculpture. (Luhring Augustine, 531 West 24th Street, Chelsea, 212-206-9100 or luhringaugustine.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

An article on Wednesday about the winners of the Intel Science Talent Search referred incorrectly to the 40 finalists. There were 20 women and 20 men; they were not ''almost equally'' divided by sex -- as were the top 10, which included six women. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the night the winners were announced. It was Tuesday, not Monday.

Lehmann Maupin 540 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through March 24 Some artists are in love with their materials; others are in perpetual conflict. Tony Oursler's struggle with video is a primary characteristic of his work, and it is interesting to watch him interrogate his medium.

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Anders Thomas Jensen In Danish, with English subtitles Not rated; 91 minutes The Danish writer and director Anders Thomas Jensen's 2005 feature, ''Adam's Apples'' -- about a neo-Nazi sentenced to community service at a rural church run by a sunshine-and-lollipops vicar -- is one of the latest examples of the post-''Pulp Fiction'' bloody comedy. It's also one of the weirdest, mixing glib humor with dead-serious spiritual inquiry.
