(Jon Pareles) CHIEFTAINS (Tonight and tomorrow night) The Chieftains spearheaded a revival of Irish traditional music, playing only the oldest instruments: fiddle, harp, wooden flute, uilleann pipes, bodhran, tin whistle. Then they decided that Irish tradition wasn't enough and started to look further afield: to Spain, to China, to rock. But they have been returning to their Irish core, and there's a great ensemble behind the shtick. Tonight at 8, New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722, njpac.org; $22 to $68. Tomorrow night at 8, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $30 to $85. (Pareles) DAUGHTRY (Monday) Like Jennifer Hudson, Chris Daughtry -- who drops his first name when performing with a band -- is a sign of why ''American Idol'' doesn't work perfectly: he reached only as high as No. 4 last season, but his album, ''Daughtry'' (RCA), with arena-size, fist-pumping rock songs, has become one of the biggest and steadiest sellers of the year. At 9 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; sold out. (Sisario) DECEMBERISTS (Wednesday and Thursday) He might not exactly have a lot of competition, but Colin Meloy, the songwriter and strategist of this band from Portland, Ore., can set old Irish epics and alliterative fables about Dickensian chimney sweeps to progressive folk-rock like nobody else. Opening the show is My Brightest Diamond, led by Shara Worden, who in a slippery and dexterous voice spins fantasies that leap in scale from music boxes to heavenly bodies. At 8 p.m., Landmark Loew's Jersey Theater, 54 Journal Square, Jersey City, (866) 468-7619, loewsjersey.org; $27.50 to $30. (Sisario) THE DOUBLE (Tonight and tomorrow night) Something is always intriguingly askew in the songs of this local band: jagged guitars, David Greenhill's neurotic sing-speak vocals, the asymmetric gurglings of its Vox Continental organ. But the oblique lines come together in unexpected and sometimes hauntingly beautiful ways. With Mike Wexler tonight, and the Japanese Beetles and Crystal Stilts tomorrow. At 8, Cake Shop, 152 Ludlow Street, between Stanton and Rivington Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 253-0036, cake-shop.com; $8. (Sisario) EXPLOSIONS IN THE SKY (Tuesday) The epic instrumentals by this band from Austin, Tex., begin in peace, with single notes twinkling amid darkness, and gradually build to turbulent vortexes of noise. Borrowing a few tricks from Pink Floyd, Explosions in the Sky keeps the pace majestic and the vistas cinematic, and takes its time. With the Paper Chase and Eluvium. At 7 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; sold out. (Sisario) RUTHIE FOSTER (Wednesday and Thursday) A veteran of the acoustic folk circuit, this Texas singer and guitarist has turned to the sound of cozy 1960s soul on her new album, ''The Phenomenal Ruthie Foster'' (Blue Corn Music). That suits her friendly alto fine, but her power and sass come through better in bare, bluesy songs, like her version of Son House's boiling ''Grinnin' in Your Face.'' Wednesday at 8 p.m., with Amy Helm of Ollabelle, at the Tap Bar at the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3132, knittingfactory.com; $12 in advance, $15 at the door. Thursday at 10 p.m., with Lucy Wainwright Roche, at Pete's Candy Store, 709 Lorimer Street, between Frost and Richardson Streets, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 302-3770, petescandystore.com; free. (Sisario) Fujiya & Miyagi (Sunday through Tuesday) This British trio, which derives part of its name from ''The Karate Kid'' -- ''We are only pretending to be Japanese,'' goes one lyric -- plays bubbly, perpetual-motion figures of guitar and keyboard, and never breaks a sweat. Its sound has been heard plenty of times before, from '90s groups like Stereolab and from earlier German experimentalists, but it's too fun and innocuous to ever tire of. Sunday at 8 p.m., Tuesday at 10 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; sold out. Monday at 9 p.m., McIntosh Student Center, Barnard College, Broadway at 117th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-6538, wbar.org; $5. (Sisario) * GILBERTO GIL (Tuesday) This pillar of Brazilian music, a creator of the postmodern Tropicália style in the '60s and now his country's minister of culture, makes a rare appearance at Carnegie Hall. At 8 p.m., (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $23 to $72. (Sisario) * LEVON HELM (Tonight and tomorrow night) After a hiatus for recovery from throat cancer, Mr. Helm, the former drummer of the Band and the singer of hits like ''The Weight,'' has returned with a raspier but still powerfully expressive voice. These shows have an unusual setting: the Beacon Theater. Lately Mr. Helm has preferred to play for small groups at his home studio in Woodstock, N.Y. At 8 p.m., 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 307-7171, beacontheatrenyc.com; sold out. (Sisario) INDIGO GIRLS (Tuesday and Wednesday) Guitar strumming, close harmonies, coffeehouse earnestness and songs about the perpetual struggle for love, self-affirmation and a clear conscience have made the duo of Emily Saliers and Amy Ray perennials for the collegiate at heart. With Kaki King. At 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171, the-townhall-nyc.org; $40. (Pareles) KODO (Tonight and tomorrow night) This Japanese drum troupe doesn't need microphones for some of its music: taiko ritual pieces made to be heard for miles, pounded on drums as large as the people who play them. From that foundation, the group has also fused its music with rhythms from India, Brazil and elsewhere. Tonight, as part of its 25th-anniversary tour, Kodo members play a rare small-scale show at Joe's Pub with Kaoru Watanabe, a former member now based in New York. At 9:30 and 11:30 p.m., 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $35; $60 for both shows. Tomorrow night at 8, New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722, njpac.org; $20 to $58. (Pareles) * LAMB OF GOD (Thursday) Lamb of God, from Richmond, Va., derives some of its grinding, jackhammer-fast churn from Slayer and Pantera, and without any irony or sarcasm calls its style ''pure American metal.'' With Trivium, Machine Gun and Gojira. At 6:45 p.m., Roseland, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, roselandballroom.com; $26 in advance, $30 at the door. (Sisario) SUSAN McKEOWN (Today) A regular on the Irish music scene of New York, Ms. McKeown, who was born in Dublin, performs traditional music and contemporary songs about the immigrant experience in a strong, forthright voice. At 12:30 p.m., Winter Garden, World Financial Center, West Street, south of Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505, worldfinancialcenter.com; free. (Sisario) MEW (Thursday) This Danish band straddles the arty and sentimental extremes of Radiohead, indulging in dense guitar textures but leaving room for crying, emotive vocals. At 9 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; $18.50 in advance, $20 at the door. (Sisario) Jane Monheit (Tonight and tomorrow night, and Tuesday through Thursday nights) The beauty of her sultry voice performing bossa nova ballads triumphs over liabilities that include obvious shyness and rushed, perfunctory patter. At 8:45, with additional shows at 10:45 tonight, tomorrow and Thursday, Café Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-1600, thecarlyle.com; $75 cover at tables, $55 at the bar. (Holden) * WILLIE NELSON, MERLE HAGGARD AND RAY PRICE (Thursday) On their new album, ''The Last of the Breed'' (Lost Highway), these mellow titans of country music lean back and savor every sweet note of classic songs by Hank Williams, Kris Kristofferson and others, recreating with pedal steel guitars and harmonies by the Jordanaires the sound of a Nashville recording studio, about 1960. At 8 p.m., Radio City Music Hall, (212) 307-7171, radiocity.com; $46.50 to $81.50. (Sisario) * OOIOO (Tuesday) O.K., maybe this offshoot of the Japanese band the Boredoms is not quite as cartoonishly antic as that group, which for nearly two decades has been one of the planet's most unpredictable musical forces. But the tribal drums, electronic squeaks and jazz-fusion guitar and trumpet on OOIOO's new album, ''Taiga'' (Thrill Jockey), come pretty close. Also on the bill is I.U.D., featuring Lizzie Bougatsos of the experimental New York band Gang Gang Dance. At 8 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3132, knittingfactory.com; $12 in advance, $15 at the door. (Sisario) * POGUES (Tomorrow) The band that made traditional Irish music seem like punk rock -- and vice versa -- plays the last of three shows for what Guinness calls the ''St. Patrick's Day season.'' Last year the Pogues played their first shows in New York in 15 years with Shane MacGowan, their Dionysian former singer, and Mr. MacGowan is back on board again. With the Tossers. At 8 p.m., Roseland, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, roselandballroom.com; sold out. (Sisario) RODRIGO Y GABRIELA (Wednesday) Once thrash-metal bandmates in Mexico, this guitar duo discovered what the Gipsy Kings have long known: Europeans and Americans go crazy for virtuosic acoustic renditions of their favorite '70s rock ballads. The Gipsy Kings did it with ''Hotel California,'' and Rodrigo y Gabriela's repertory includes a lush ''Stairway to Heaven.'' With Krystle Warren. At 8 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; $22 in advance, $25 at the door. (Sisario) RALPH STANLEY (Sunday) Mr. Stanley's stark, unflinching ''O Death'' leaped out of the soundtrack of ''O Brother, Where Are Thou?'' and introduced a few million new listeners to a gripping, venerable singer whose songs about sin, temptation and salvation are cornerstones of country music. Leading his own band, Mr. Stanley is more avuncular than apocalyptic, but his songs still have eerie moments. At 8 p.m., B. B. King Blues Club & Grill, 237 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144, bbkingblues.com; $30 in advance, $33 at the door. (Pareles) Suishou no Fune (Tuesday) This Tokyo group, whose name means crystal ship, carries on a Japanese underground rocktradition of immersion in both tranquil, spooky psychedelia and rumbling sonic chaos. Like Fushitsusha, its earliest ancestor, Suishou no Fune is transcendent in either extreme. At 8 p.m., with Madeline and Dynamite Arrows, Cake Shop, 152 Ludlow Street, between Stanton and Rivington Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 253-0036, cake-shop.com; $7. (Sisario) * JUSTIN TIMBERLAKE, PINK (Wednesday) Like Michael Jackson or Prince, Justin Timberlake is the kind of pop star who makes it all look easy. But even more endearing, the guy can truly make fun of himself: his brilliant ''Saturday Night Live'' skit with Andy Samberg, bleeped on television but uncensored on the Internet, was the equivalent of a chummy high-five with his audience. Opening the show is Pink, the spark plug who once bragged of getting the party started and now ridicules ''stupid girls'' who torture themselves for men. At 7:30 p.m., Nassau Coliseum, 1255 Hempstead Turnpike, Uniondale, N.Y., (631) 888-9000, nassaucoliseum.com; $53 to $151. (Sisario) YOUNG KNIVES (Tuesday and Thursday) The Young Knives, from the tiny English town of Ashby-de-la-Zouch, are not the first to pick up Gang of Four's legacy of jagged guitars, uptight punk-funk and lyrics about the angry boredom of the workaday life, but on ''Voices of Animals and Men'' (Transgressive/Ryko), the band does it with worthy verve and wit. Tuesday at 9:30 p.m., Luna Lounge, 361 Metropolitan Avenue, at Havemeyer Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, lunalounge.com; $12 in advance, $14 at the door. Thursday at 10 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; $10. (Sisario) Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. BARBARIAN HORDE (Tonight) The tenor saxophonist Tony Barba leads this deliriously kinetic improv-funk band, which celebrates the release of an album called ''Your Pleasure Is Our Business'' (Barbariansmusic). At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Tea Lounge, 837 Union Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 789-2762, tealoungeny.com; donation, $5. (Nate Chinen) STANLEY CLARKE (Tuesday through Thursday) On electric or acoustic bass, Mr. Clarke is a fleet-fingered marvel with a particular gift for funk and soul. He works with the drummer Lenny White, his former rhythm section partner in the fusion flagship Return to Forever, and the pianist and singer Patrice Rushen, with whom he has recorded several albums, including last year's ''Standards'' (Kind of Blue). (Through March 25.) At 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Chinen) ANAT COHEN QUARTET (Tomorrow) The clarinetist and saxophonist Anat Cohen previews material from a pair of forthcoming releases, ''Poetica'' and ''Noir'' (Anzic), with a group consisting of Gilad Hekselman on guitar, Edward Perez on bass and Ferenc Nemeth on drums. At midnight, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $10, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) KRIS DAVIS AND CHRIS SPEED (Tomorrow) Sparse and intense duets, courtesy of Ms. Davis, an articulate pianist, and Mr. Speed, a thoughtful clarinetist and tenor saxophonist. At 8 p.m., Center for Improvisational Music, 295 Douglass Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (212) 631-5882, schoolforimprov.org; cover, $12; $8 for students. (Chinen) DOMINIC DUVAL (Sunday) Mr. Duval, a bassist active in free-jazz circles, presents a quartet with the violinist Gregor Hubner, the cellist Thomas Ulrich and the pianist Yuko Fujiyama; in the next set he performs duets with Ivo Perelman, a coloristic yet often fearsome Brazilian saxophonist. At 8 and 10 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) LIBERTY ELLMAN QUINTET (Tomorrow) Liberty Ellman, a guitarist and composer, leads a coolly experimental ensemble consisting of Steve Lehman, alto saxophone; Jose Davila, tuba; Thomas Morgan, bass; and Damion Reid, drums. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $15. (Chinen) ORRIN EVANS (Tonight) Mr. Evans, a pianist with a rugged and percussive style, presents two separate projects: a new piece, ''Suite for Juanita,'' for a quartet featuring the saxophonist Brian Hogans (at 9) and a band he calls the Nu Quintet, with Ralph Bowen on saxophones, Ron Jennings on guitar, Mike Boone on bass and Obed Calvier on drums. At 9 and 10:30, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $15. (Chinen) FINAL FOUR (Wednesday and Thursday) An all-star team with post-bop proclivities, courtesy of the tenor saxophonist Javon Jackson, the pianist Steve Kuhn, the bassist Buster Williams and the drummer Jimmy Cobb. (Through March 24.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) JAKOB GARCHIK'S YORE (Sunday) Mr. Garchik, a trombonist who often traffics in free improvisation, employs a compositional framework in this ensemble, featuring the vocalist Judith Berkson, the clarinetist Oscar Noriega, the guitarist Mary Halvorson and the drummer Johnny McLellan. At 7 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $8. (Chinen) * JERRY GONZALEZ AND FORT APACHE (Tonight and tomorrow night ) A powerhouse of Afro-Latin jazz for more than 20 years, Fort Apache, led by the trumpeter and conga player Jerry Gonzalez, brings crackling energy to a wide array of rhythmic conceits. In addition to Mr. Gonzalez and his brother Andy Gonzalez, a bassist, its roster currently includes Joe Ford on saxophones, Zacai Curtis on piano and Victor Jones on drums. At 8, 10 and midnight, Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, West Village, (212) 255-3626, sweetrhythmny.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) J. A. GRANELLI AND MR. LUCKY (Tuesday) Groove and texture are equals in this ensemble, which has a new album called ''Homing (a feeling in nine parts)'' (Love Slave). Along with J. A. Granelli, a bassist, the group consists of the guitarist Brad Shepik, the pedal steel guitarist Gerald Menke, the organist Nate Shaw and the drummer Mike Sarin. At 10 p.m., Bowery Poetry Club, 308 Bowery, near Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 614-0505, bowerypoetry.com; cover, $8. (Chinen) * ROY HAYNES (Tuesday through Thursday) The redoubtable drummer Roy Haynes just turned 81, though you'd never guess it by the freshness and ferocity of his playing. His excellent working quartet features musicians many years his junior: the alto saxophonist Jaleel Shaw, the pianist Martin Bejerano and the bassist David Wong. (Through March 25.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) JOHN HEBERT'S BYZANTINE MONKEY QUARTET (Tonight) This ensemble features the original music and bass playing of John Hebert, along with a pair of inventive saxophonists, Tony Malaby and Michaël Attias, and a restless drummer, Tom Rainey. At 9 and 10:30, Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, 212 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) ALAN HOLDSWORTH (Tonight through Sunday) Mr. Holdsworth is a guitarist's guitarist, celebrated for his head-spinning technique and intricate compositional sense. Progressive rock and fusion provide the best precedents for what he does with his trio, which includes the bassist Jimmy Johnson and the drummer Chad Wackerman. At 8:30 and 10:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow night, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) LINDSEY HORNER (Sunday) Mr. Horner, a sure-footed bassist and a sensible composer, revisits music from his recent album, ''Don't Count on Glory'' (Cadence), accompanied by the guitarist Bruce Saunders, the pianist Neal Kirkwood and the drummer Lieven Venken. At 8:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) ROBERT HURST QUARTET (Tonight and tomorrow night) The bassist Robert Hurst has long been a fine small-group composer, as well as an underappreciated bandleader. He applies those skills to a cadre of sharp young players: the guitarist Lionel Loueke, the pianist Robert Glasper and the drummer Eric Harland. At 8, 10 and 11:30 p.m., Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662, smokejazz.com; cover, $25. (Chinen) * VIJAY IYER: DUETS (Monday) A pianist and composer given to restive energies and rhythmic conundrums, Vijay Iyer teams up with three distinct collaborators: the expressive pianist and vocalist Amina Claudine Myers; the in-demand young tabla player known as Suphala; and the incisive alto saxophonist Rudresh Mahanthappa, with whom Mr. Iyer recently recorded ''Raw Materials'' (Savoy), a full album of probing duologue. At 8 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3330, kaufman-center.org; $25 in advance, $30 on Monday. (Chinen) INGRID JENSEN (Monday and Wednesday) A fiery post-bop trumpeter with a book of smart original tunes, Ms. Jensen leads a group with Orrin Evans on keyboards, Matt Clohesy on bass and Jon Wikan on drums. On Wednesday the saxophonist Sharel Cassidy joins as a guest. Monday at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $15. Wednesday at 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, near Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) * THE LATIN SIDE OF WAYNE SHORTER (Tonight through Sunday) Continuing an experiment that has already tapped the songbooks of John Coltrane and Miles Davis, the trombonist Conrad Herwig tilts his ear toward another titan of jazz modernism. Among his partners in clave are the trumpeter Brian Lynch and the pianist Eddie Palmieri, who recently won a Grammy for their collaborative album, ''Simpático.'' At 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Chinen) TONY MALABY TUBA TRIO (Wednesday) Tony Malaby, a versatile and increasingly prominent tenor saxophonist, leads a band with Marcus Rojas on tuba and John Hollenbeck on drums and percussion; the name is appropriate, given the central role Mr. Rojas assumes. At 8 and 10 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) MAT MANERI QUARTET WITH DAVE BURRELL (Thursday) Mat Maneri is a violist with an elastic approach to pulse and pitch. He teams up with the estimable avant-garde pianist Dave Burrell, along with the bassist John Hebert and the drummer Randy Peterson. At 10 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) DONNY MCCASLIN GROUP (Monday) On ''Soar'' (Sunnyside), his last album, the tenor saxophonist Donny McCaslin applied his extroverted style to a Latin American-inspired contemporary fusion. He does much the same here, benefiting greatly from the contributions of the guitarist Ben Monder, the bassist Hans Glawischnig and the drummer Ted Poor. At 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, near Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) NOT FOR PROFIT (Tonight) The bassist Kevin Tkacz showcases his own compositions in this trio, with the pianist Bill Carrothers and the drummer Mike Sarin. They perform here in preparation for a recording session. At 8:30 p.m., Center for Improvisational Music, 295 Douglass Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (212) 631-5882, schoolforimprov.org; cover, $10; $6 for students. (Chinen) EIVIND OPSVIK'S OVERSEAS (Tuesday) Eivind Opsvik is a Norwegian bassist and composer who balances avant-gardism with poplike lyricism, as he best demonstrates in this working band with Tony Malaby on tenor saxophone, Jacob Sacks on piano and Kenny Wollesen on drums. At 9 p.m., Nublu, 62 Avenue C, near Fifth Street, East Village, (212) 979-9925, nublu.net; cover, $5. (Chinen) KEN PEPLOWSKI QUARTET (Tonight through Sunday night) Ken Peplowski, a versatile clarinetist and tenor saxophonist, leads a group full of accomplished peers: the pianist Bill Charlap, the bassist Greg Cohen and the drummer Joe LaBarbara. At 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $30, $25 on Sunday. (Chinen) TED ROSENTHAL TRIO (Tonight and tomorrow night) There aren't many modern jazz pianists more dexterous than Ted Rosenthal, who performs with the experienced rhythm team of Martin Wind, bassist, and Matt Wilson, drummer. At 8 and 9:45, Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, Manhattan, (212) 885-7119, kitano.com; cover, $25, with a $15 minimum. (Chinen) SING INTO SPRING FESTIVAL (Tonight through Thursday night) Singers take over Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola through the rest of March, appearing with uniformly first-rate backing ensembles. Mark Murphy appears this weekend, followed by Meredith d'Ambrosio on Monday, Sheila Jordan on Tuesday and Gloria Lynne on Wednesday and Thursday. (Through April 1.) At 7:30 and 9:30, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 258-9595, jalc.org; cover, $30, with a minimum of $10 at tables, $5 at the bar. (Chinen) TYFT (Thursday) This adventurous trio -- the guitarist Hilmar Jenssen, the alto saxophonist and bass clarinetist Andrew D'Angelo and the drummer Jim Black -- fashions roughly contoured music out of grainy texture and surging propulsion. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Tea Lounge, 837 Union Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 789-2762, tealoungeny.com; donation, $5. (Chinen) BEN WALTZER QUARTET (Tomorrow) The pianist Ben Waltzer manages a thoughtful modernism that coexists more than peaceably with a buoyant and un-self-conscious swing. His quartet features Tony Malaby on tenor saxophone, Chris Lightcap on bass and Eric McPherson on drums. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a $6 minimum. (Chinen) DOUG WAMBLE (Thursday) Mr. Wamble specializes in a rustic Southern sound, from the bluesy cry of his vocals to the quavering twang of his acoustic guitar. Whether alone or with his sharp-honed working band, he's a casually gripping performer. At 10 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) * RANDY WESTON (Tuesday through Thursday) The pianism of Randy Weston can recall Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk, but as a composer he reaches beyond strict jazz traditions. His longstanding African Rhythms Trio temporarily becomes a quartet starting on Thursday, with the addition of the soulful tenor saxophonist Billy Harper. (Through March 25.) At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $25. (Chinen) Classical Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music. Opera 'DIE ÄEGYPTISCHE HELENA' (Monday) Not your everyday Richard Strauss opera has a new production at the Metropolitan Opera, and performances continue on Monday. Deborah Voigt stars in the title role, and Fabio Luisi conducts. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $80 to $175. (Bernard Holland) 'ANDREA CHENIER' (Thursday) Set in the 18th century but very much a product of the 19th, Giordano's Italian drama of the French Revolution returns to the Met with a cast that is able to sing very, very loudly, if not always especially elegantly or with particular Italian flair: Violeta Urmana, Ben Heppner and Mark Delavan. Marco Armiliato, emerging as a solid presence in the pit, conducts. At 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $175. (Anne Midgette) * 'IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) Bartlett Sher's breezy new production of Rossini's opera, which was introduced in November and returned on Wednesday night, conveys the comic confusions of the story through its fluid staging and a wonderfully abstract set: a matrix of movable doors, staircases and potted orange trees, behind which characters spy on one another. The heated sexuality of the characters also comes through strongly, thanks to Mr. Sher's subtle directing of a handsome cast. The baritone Peter Mattei is a robust and agile Figaro. The tenor Juan Diego Flórez, sounding fresher than in the fall, could not be more adorable as the amorous Count Almaviva. The captivating mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato is a vocally agile and feisty Rosina. The virile bass-baritone John Relyea makes the wily Don Baisilio seem delightfully dangerous. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $42 to $120 tickets remaining for tomorrow, $15 to $65 for Wednesday. (Anthony Tommasini) * 'LA DONNA DEL LAGO' (Thursday) New York City Opera's last foray into the little-known world of Rossini's serious operas was successful enough that the company is going back for more, with the same two leads featured in ''Ermione'' a few seasons ago. Alexandrina Pendatchanska is an intense, committed soprano; Barry Banks, the tenor, is emerging as someone to watch. Chas Rader-Shieber, the director, has brought an antic touch to his two previous outings with the company, ''Flavio'' (which returns this spring) and ''Orlando.'' George Manahan conducts. At 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $120. (Midgette) 'FAUST' (Tomorrow) Gounod's lush score is back at the Met in Andrei Serban's staging, now less hyperactive than when it was introduced in 2005. Alas, someone appears to have gotten to its soul before Méphistophélès had the chance: the singers, though all fine, put the drama at arm's length, so the work's intense passions don't quite come through. In the cast: Ramón Vargas in the title role, Ruth Ann Swenson as Marguerite and Ildar Abdrazakov as Méphistophélès. At 1:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $120 to $220 remaining. (Allan Kozinn) 'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' (Tomorrow) City Opera continues its run of Puccini's weepy masterpiece. At 1:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $115. (Holland) 'THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE' (Tonight through Sunday, Tuesday and Wednesday) At City Opera, Lillian Groag avoids the topical updating that has become a Gilbert and Sullivan tradition and focuses on the work's own satirical targets, which range from Victorian British society to the conventions of Italian grand opera. Even so, her direction is inventive and lively, as are the performances by a cast that includes Sarah Jane McMahon as Mabel, Matt Morgan as Frederic, Marc Kudisch as the Pirate King and Mark Jacoby as Major General Stanley. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday afternoon at 1:30, Tuesday and Wednesday night at 7:30, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $130. (Kozinn) 'LA TRAVIATA' (Tonight and Tuesday) For its revival of Franco Zeffirelli's extravagant 1998 production, the Met is rotating casts, with three sopranos sharing the role of Violetta. The earthy Bulgarian soprano Krassimira Stoyanova, who made her Met debut in 2001 and who was recently heard at the house as Nedda in ''Pagliacci,'' sings Violetta, the role of her debut. The compelling German tenor Jonas Kaufmann is Alfredo, Violetta's impulsive lover. And the veteran American baritone Dwayne Croft is Alfredo's tragically interfering father, Germont. Marco Armiliato conducts. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $205. (Tommasini) Classical Music ALARM WILL SOUND (Sunday) This ensemble of young new-music specialists makes a point of ignoring genre barriers. Included in this retrospective are the group's own arrangements of electronica by Aphex Twin, as well as pieces by several of the ensemble's performers. In this context, John Adams (represented by ''Scratchband'') may seem the most conservative composer on the program, and how often does that happen? At 3 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $28 to $40. (Kozinn) DIANA DAMRAU (Wednesday) This fine German coloratura soprano, in town for the Met's new production of ''Die Äegyptische Helena,'' takes time out to make her New York recital debut with a program of French-language songs by Liszt and Barber, songs (sung in English) by Rachmaninoff, Berg's ''Seven Early Songs,'' Zemlinsky's ''Gesänge'' (Op. 6) and, of course, songs by Strauss. Stephan Matthias Lademann is the accompanist. At 7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; $34. (Midgette) * INGRID FLITER (Wednesday) The career of this Argentine pianist has taken off since winning the 2006 Gilmore Artist Award and its $300,000 prize. Ms. Fliter makes her New York recital debut with a program including Beethoven's C minor Variations (WoO 80); Schubert's Sonata in A (D. 959); and Chopin's Nocturne in D flat (Op. 27, No. 2), ''Barcarolle'' (Op. 60), Ballade in F minor (Op. 52) and Three Mazurkas (Op. 59). At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $35 to $40. (Vivien Schweitzer) ANDREA GRUBER and RUSSELL THOMAS (Sunday) The wood-paneled auditorium at the Morgan Library & Museum is a warm, resonant space, and it should resound aplenty with the voice of Andrea Gruber, the opera soprano, who will appear in recital with Russell Thomas, a young tenor, under the aegis of the George London Foundation, which pairs established singers with rising ones. The program should contain at least a whiff of opera: it includes music by Beethoven, Duparc, Ponchielli, Puccini and Verdi. Ken Noda is the accompanist. At 4 p.m., 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 877-6347, themorgan.org; $45. (Midgette) TANIA LEÓN (Thursday) This Cuban-born composer, now a fixture on the New York new-music scene, presides over a program that includes her own ''Mistica,'' as well as Conlon Nancarrow's ''Two Canons for Ursula'' and Frederic Rzewski's ''Mayn Yingele.'' The performers are the pianists Ursula Oppens and Jade Simmons, and the Brasil Guitar Duo. At 7:30 p.m., Thalia at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $21 in advance, $25 at the door. (Kozinn) * IVAN MORAVEC (Tonight) A 76-year-old Czech master, Mr. Moravec has long been a pianist's pianist, admired for his articulate, probing, nuanced and unostentatious performances. He plays his only New York recital of the season tonight, a program of works by Mozart, Franck, Debussy and Chopin. At 8, Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $50. (Tommasini) * NICO MUHLY AND VOX VOCAL CHOIR (Tonight) Mr. Muhly, a dynamic 25-year-old Juilliard-trained and stylistically eclectic composer, will perform his own works as a keyboardist with a group of regular collaborators that includes a clarinetist, a harpist, a cellist and a percussionist. The program will offer Mr. Muhly's ''Clear Music'' and the premieres of his works ''It Goes Without Saying'' and ''The Only Tune.'' The Vox Vocal Ensemble, led by George Steel, will perform Tudor choral pieces by Taverner, Byrd and Weelkes. At 7:30, Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $25 to $35. (Schweitzer) NATIONAL PHILHARMONIC OF RUSSIA (Tomorrow through Monday) Its imposing name belies its short history: this orchestra was founded in 2003 for the violinist-turned-conductor Vladimir Spivakov and is now midway through its United States debut tour. Its New York-area programs all feature the Shostakovich Festive Overture, followed by Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 2, showcasing the winner of the 2001 Van Cliburn competition, Olga Kern. The final piece on the program varies: tomorrow it's Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony; on Sunday, his sixth; and on Monday, Rachmaninoff's ''Symphonic Dances.'' Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Tilles Center for the Performing Arts, at the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University, Brookville, N.Y., (516) 299-3100, tillescenter.org; $50 to $110. Sunday at 3 p.m., New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722, njpac.org; sold out. Monday at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $35 to $69. (Midgette) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC (Today, tomorrow and Thursday) Alan Gilbert led the Philharmonic in a beautifully played concert a few weeks ago, and now he's back with a program that includes Bach, as arranged by Stokowski (the Toccata and Fugue in D minor) and Webern (a ricercar from ''A Musical Offering''), as well as Schumann's Symphony No. 3 and Ligeti's Violin Concerto. His soloist is the superb violinist Christian Tetzlaff. On Thursday Colin Davis returns to the orchestra to conduct Haydn's Symphony No. 85 and Schubert's Symphony No. 4, as well as Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 19 with Mitsuko Uchida. Today at 2 p.m., tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $24 to $99. (Kozinn) ORCHESTRE PHILHARMONIQUE DE RADIO FRANCE (Sunday) Myung-Whun Chung conducts music native to, or originating from, France. Vladimir Feltsman will be the pianist in Ravel's Concerto for the Left Hand. Mr. Chung conducts Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring,'' which had its controversial beginnings in Paris. At 2 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $28 to $87. (Holland) PRAZAK QUARTET (Tonight) Founded in 1972, when its members were students at the Prague Conservatory, the Prazak Quartet has won acclaim for its vibrant performances and its 20 recordings for Harmonia Mundi. For this appearance, presented by Carnegie Hall, the quartet offers a 1923 work by the Prague-born composer Erwin Schulhoff, ''Five Pieces for String Quartet,'' along with quartets by Haydn and the ultimate Czech composer, Dvorak. At 7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $44. (Tommasini) RUSSIAN NATIONAL ORCHESTRA (Sunday) Mikhail Pletnev, a pianist who has become a persuasive conductor, and Nikolai Lugansky, a pianist who has remained at the keyboard, join forces in Rachmaninoff's ''Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini,'' the centerpiece of a program that also includes Tchaikovsky's ''Francesca da Rimini'' and Glazunov's Symphony No. 6. At 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $35 to $69. (Kozinn) GIL SHAHAM AND FRIENDS (Thursday) Mr. Shaham, a sweet-sounding violinist, is seemingly everywhere these days, this time joining colleagues for an all-Brahms evening. With Yefim Bronfman, Cho-Liang Lin, Cynthia Phelps and Lynn Harrell. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $23 and $28. (Holland) * YOUNG CONCERT ARTISTS COMPOSERS CONCERT (Monday) Though best known for promoting performers, Young Concert Artists continues its commitment to composers with its annual program of new and recent works by members of the new generation heralded by this estimable organization. This concert offers works by Mason Bates, Benjamin C. S. Boyle, Daniel Kellogg, Kevin Puts and Kenji Bunch. The performers include Young Concert Artists alumni. At 7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $25 to $35. (Tommasini) Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. BALAM DANCE THEATER (Tomorrow and Sunday) Directed by Islene Pinder and Carlos Fittante, Balam performs modern dance inspired by Balinese theater. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Dance New Amsterdam, 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, TriBeCa, (212) 563-9111, balamdance.org; $20; $15 for students and 65+. (Jennifer Dunning) BUGLISI DANCE THEATER (Tonight through Sunday) A rich repertory includes new works by Jacqulyn Buglisi, among them ''Caravaggio Meets Hopper,'' which juxtaposes images from the two painters, one passionate, the other detached. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m. and Sunday at 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $36. (Jack Anderson) COMPAÑIA NACIONAL DE DANZA 2 (Tomorrow) This contemporary ballet troupe from Spain will perform choreography by its director, Nacho Duato, a popular guest choreographer at American Ballet Theater. At 8 p.m., Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts, at Brooklyn College, one block from the junction of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, Flatbush, (718) 951-4500, brooklyncenteronline.org; $15 to $25. (Dunning) THE 4 TANGO SEASONS (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) This show explores nature's cycles as seen by a man and a woman in love. (Through April 1.) Tonight and Thursday night at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 4 p.m., Thalia Spanish Theater, 41-17 Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718) 729-3880, thaliatheatre.org; $30; $27 for students and 65+. (Dunning) KEIKO FUJI (Tomorrow) Ms. Fuji, a teacher based in Osaka, Japan, has visited New York with her modern-dance company many times. This time she will perform a solo program, ''Hana (the Flower),'' drawn from an ancient Japanese tale. At 8 p.m., Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, (212) 772-4448; $25; $15 for students and 65+. (Dunning) IRISH MODERN DANCE THEATER (Tonight through Sunday) The company director, John Scott, describes the repertory of this Dublin troupe as a mix of performance art, contact improvisation and mainstream modern-dance techniques. The program includes Mr. Scott's work and dances by the German choreographer Thomas Lehmen and by Chris Yon of New York. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 4 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 4 p.m., Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101, ps122.org; $20; $15 for students and 65+. (Dunning) KINESIS PROJECT DANCE THEATER (Thursday) The company will perform Melissa Riker's ''Right Before You Fell,'' a program Ms. Riker describes as a playful and sensuous athletic dance that explores the moments when something is not being said. (Through March 25.) At 9 p.m., Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street, West Village, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $20. (Dunning) BETH LEONARD (Sunday) Ms. Leonard will present ''On Possession,'' a series of short dance studies that explore the fierce and mysterious human need to communicate, on a shared program with the musicians Matt Diaz, Rob Meador, G. Doug Pierson and Ian Stell. At 5 p.m., Construction Company, 10 East 18th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 924-7882, theconstructioncompany.org; $15. (Dunning) LE VU LONG/TOGETHER HIGHER (Tonight and tomorrow) In ''Stories of Us,'' the Vietnamese choreographer Le Vu Long mingles various dance forms with striking visual designs to comment on gender stereotypes and life-threatening illness. At 7:30 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; $20; $12 for students and 65+. (Anderson) CRISTINA MOURA (Thursday) How can you not be curious about a dance titled ''like an idiot''? Danspace Project presents the New York premiere of this Brazilian choreographer's 2002 work. (Through March 24.) At 8:30 p.m., St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194, danspaceproject.org; $15. (Claudia La Rocco) 'MOVING MEN' (Tuesday) Choreographers in this showcase, chosen by Janusz Jaworski, are Will Rawls, Brian Brooks, Juan Merchan and Alethea Adsitt. At 8 p.m., Dixon Place, 258 Bowery, between Houston and Prince Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 219-0736, dixonplace.org; $12; T.D.F. vouchers accepted. (Dunning) THE NETA DANCE COMPANY 2007 A.W.A.R.D. SHOW! (Sunday) This free monthly series is dedicated to presenting new dance -- this time by Erica Rebollar, Ellis Wood, Daniel Clifton and Nelly van Bommel -- followed by discussion and an audience vote for best in show. At 7 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479. (Dunning) 92nd STREET Y HARKNESS DANCE FESTIVAL (Tomorrow and Sunday) Zvi Gotheiner's ZviDance closes the festival with his new ''Gertrud,'' inspired by an early mentor, the Israeli dance teacher Gertrud Kraus, and ''Les Noces.'' Tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m., Ailey Citigroup Theater, 405 West 55th Street, Clinton, (212) 415-5500, 92Y.org/harknessfestival; $20. (Dunning) * LAURA PAWEL DANCE COMPANY (Tonight through Sunday) A quiet, longtime presence in downtown dance, Ms. Pawel and her dancers delight not in pushing the envelope but in opening it up and peering inside. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 5 p.m., Dance Forum, 20 East 17th Street, west of Union Square, Manhattan, (212) 873-9073; $15. (Dunning) * PEAK PERFORMANCES: VINCENT DANCE THEATER (Thursday) From Sheffield, England, Charlotte Vincent and her modern-dance troupe will make their American debut with ''Broken Chords'' in the Peak Performances avant-garde showcase at Montclair State University. Inspired by Ms. Vincent's divorce, this piece has been described as a portrait of grief, both searing and funny. (Through March 25.) Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Alexander Kasser Theater, Montclair State University, One Normal Avenue, Montclair, N.J., (973) 655-5112; $25. (Dunning) * DESMOND RICHARDSON AND THE ALL STARS PROJECT (Tonight through Sunday) Mr. Richardson and 15 performers from All Stars, a cultural program for teenagers from New York City and Newark, have created ''Homeland Security: Bringing Dr. King Up to Date,'' a multimedia piece that questions American notions of ''homeland'' and ''security.'' (Through April 4.) Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2 p.m., All Stars Project Theater, 543 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 941-1234, allstars.org; $30 and $35; T.D.F. vouchers accepted. (Dunning) * Tamango's Urban Tap (Tuesday through Thursday) One of America's few great indigenous art forms, tap is the result of diverse cultures meeting -- and mixing. In ''Bay Mo Dilo (Give Me Water),'' the wonderfully inventive Tamango draws on his Creole roots to continue this cross-cultural tradition, bringing together dancers, musicians and artists from Guadeloupe, Haiti, Ivory Coast, Jamaica, France and his native French Guiana. (Through March 25.) Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $36. (La Rocco) * PAUL TAYLOR DANCE COMPANY (Tonight through Sunday) The company's annual season closes this weekend with performances of Mr. Taylor's dark new ''Lines of Loss'' (tonight and tomorrow afternoon); his zany new ''Troilus & Cressida (reduced)'' (tomorrow night); major revivals of his 1976 ''Polaris'' (tonight); and his 1979 ''Profiles'' (tomorrow night). Also, old favorites like ''Company B,'' set to World War II songs sung by the Andrews Sisters (tonight); the lush and serene ''Roses'' (tomorrow afternoon); the hushed ''Sunset,'' and ''Esplanade,'' a feat of athletic dancing that is unruly and calm by turn (Sunday). Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212, citycenter.org; $15 to $125. (Dunning) URBAN BALLET THEATER (Tomorrow and Sunday) Ballet meets break-dancing in choreography by the company's director, Daniel Catanach, complete with a live D.J., on a program with pieces by Andres Gonzalez and Randy Luna. (Through March 24.) Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side, (212) 352-3101, henrystreet.org/arts; $15. (Dunning) * ANN LIV YOUNG (Tonight, tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday) Ms. Young's ''Snow White'' departs from the traditional to explore (what else?) the psychosexual tensions between Snow White, her Evil Stepmother (could they be an item?) and her Prince, which run rampant in claustrophobic interiors and kitschy woodlands. (Through March 24.) All performances at 8 p.m., the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, Ext. 11, thekitchen.org; $12. (Dunning) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums * American Folk Art Museum: MARTíN RAMíREZ, through April 29. Ramírez, a Mexican peasant who immigrated to Northern California and died there at 68 in 1963, spent the last 32 years of his life in a mental hospital, making some of the greatest art of the last century. He had his own way with materials and color and an unforgettable cast of characters. But most of all, Ramírez had his own brand of pictorial space, established by rhythmic systems of parallel lines, both curved and straight, whose mesmerizing expansions and contractions simultaneously cosset and isolate his figures. This show should render null and void the distinction between insider and outsider art. 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040, folkartmuseum.org. (Roberta Smith) * Asia Society: Glass, Gilding, and Grand Design: Art of Sasanian Iran (224-642 A.D.), through May 20. With some 70 examples of silver, glass and silk textile fragments, many from European museums, this is the first major exhibition of its kind in this part of the world for more than 30 years. For about four centuries, the Sasanians ruled territory stretching from present-day Iran and Iraq to North Africa. Their only rivals were Rome, Byzantium and, at the very end, the early Islamic dynasties. Much of their surviving art is a sterling example of empire in action. 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400, asiasociety.org. (Holland Cotter) FRICK COLLECTION: 'GEORGE STUBBS (1724-1806): A CELEBRATION,' through May 27. One of the finest horse painters ever, Stubbs knew his subjects from head to hoof and skin to bones. He painted other mammals too: dogs, lions, tigers, oxen, monkeys and humans. This intimate show of 17 Stubbs paintings from English collections reveals his admirable range, although the people he portrayed in two large, late canvases, elegiac celebrations of farm workers, have the stiffness of figures on a candy box. His horses are his true monuments. 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700, frick.org. (Grace Glueck) Guggenheim Museum: 'Family Pictures,' through April 16. The museum's news release extends the exhibition's exploration into ''representation of families and children in contemporary art and video.'' Images of children, you quickly realize, can operate as a completely different genre. Rineke Dijkstra's ''Beach Portraits'' of adolescents posing awkwardly against stark seascape horizons are isolated (and isolating) images of children on the threshold of adulthood. You don't think about family when gazing at these photographs. Sally Mann is perhaps the best-known contemporary photographer of children, specifically her own. Ms. Mann, represented here by black-and-white photographs from the late 1980s and early 1990s of her ethereally gorgeous children, has been accused of everything from neglect to child abuse. The questions raised by her dual role as artist and mother, simultaneous protector and potential exploiter of the family, remain vitally interesting. 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, guggenheim.org. (Martha Schwendener) * Metropolitan Museum of Art: 'Mother of Pearl: A Tradition in Asian Lacquer,' through April 1. Ornamentalism is the term for this show of some 40 objects so preposterously exquisite that they might have been conceived with a modern museum conservator's soft white cotton gloves in mind. The technique for creating mini-mosaics from slivers of mollusk shell is an ancient one that was perfected in China before traveling to Korea, Japan, Thailand and India. Examples from all those places are here in writing boxes and tea trays guaranteed to appeal to any window-shopper's acquisitive yearnings and magpie eye. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Cotter) * The METropOlitan museum of art: 'ONE OF A KIND: THE STUDIO CRAFT MOVEMENT,' through Sept. 3. Focusing on the postwar development of artist-craftsmen, this display of furniture, glass, ceramics, metalwork, jewelry and fiber includes funny, quirky, provocative and sometimes gorgeous things. Among its stars are a witty bust by the California funk ceramicist Robert Arneson (1920-92), portraying the mother of the 16th-century painter and printmaker Albrecht Dürer, and Bonnie Seeman's fetching ceramic coffeepot and tray, whose mock cabbage leaves and rhubarb stalks evoke the genteel tradition of 18th-century British and continental china, but can also be read as human rather than vegetative tissue. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Glueck) Museum of modern art: 'COMIC ABSTRACTION: IMAGE-BREAKING, IMAGE-MAKING,' through June 11. This unimaginative and uniformed treatment of a big idea -- the healthy and essential contamination of Modernist abstraction by popular culture -- should be seen if only because it is such a dispiriting symptom of the Modern's paralysis where contemporary art is concerned. Although it promises work that addresses ''perplexing questions,'' nearly everything here is perfectly pleasant and innocuous. The exceptions are provided by Gary Simmons, Ellen Gallagher and Sue Williams. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Smith) * Moma: 'JEFF WALL,' through May 14. This majestic show makes a great case for Mr. Wall as the most complete, if traditional, of the untraditional artists who emerged from the turmoil of Conceptual Art. His often immense color transparencies are enthralling visual vehicles, intent on giving pleasure while making a point or two about society, art, history, visual perception, the human animal or all of the above. An imposing blend of painting, street photography and movies, they blur reality and artifice, narrative and form, detail and the big statement. You can't stop looking at them. (See above.) (Smith) * National Academy Museum: HIGH TIMES, HARD TIMES: NEW YORK PAINTING, 1967-1975, through April 22. Organized under the auspices of International Curators Incorporated, this exhibition is the first to tackle a neglected subject: New York painting during the period it was supposed to be dead. The show's 42 works by 37 artists reveal that, far from dead, painting was in fact in an uproar that was commensurate with the artistic, social and political turbulence of the times. The alternation between artists who remained loyal to stretched canvas and those who abandoned it, which makes for clear installation, also tidies up history. The main problem is that the exhibition sticks too purposefully to the margins. Too much of this work is as derivative now as it was then, and functions more as artifact than art. 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880, nationalacademy.org. (Smith) Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Gordon MaTTA-cLARK rETROSPECTIVE,' through June 3. I have no doubt that Matta-Clark is now being turned into a hot commercial commodity, but at least at the Whitney you can see what he aspired to be. At the center of the exhibition is ''Splitting.'' To a plain single-family suburban frame house in Englewood, N.J., he made a cut straight down the middle, bisecting the building, then severing the four corners of the roof. The retrospective consists of films, drawings, photographs and some of the architectural pieces he cut out of buildings. The big message was: Life as art, and art as life, a philosophy dependent on our being properly attuned and keen to the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org. (Michael Kimmelman) * Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Lorna Simpson,' through May 6. This tight, refined and impassioned survey covers more than 20 years of Lorna Simpson's career, from her photo-and-text meditations on race and sexism in the 1980s, to her more recent short films, which unite American history and personal history in forceful and lyrical ways. It would be easy to put some of this work on a shelf as ''identity art,'' but with an African-American woman holding one of the highest offices in the United States government, an African-American man running for president, and the nation embroiled in what some people view as an ethnic war, this art is entirely of the moment. (See above.) (Cotter) Galleries: Chelsea Michael Waugh: 'Lead me astray' Mr. Waugh's work is about close reading. Several large drawings of 19th-century landscapes are composed of handwritten phrases, cut and pasted in nonsensical order, from American presidential inaugural speeches. A drawing of the Spanish colonial explorer Cabeza de Vaca, who landed in Florida, is installed in a room plastered with promotional materials from a different colonialist enterprise, the last Art Basel/Miami fair. Schroeder Romero, 637 West 27th Street, (212) 630-0722; through March 24. (Cotter) Last Chance * Cathy Begien The reason to see this first solo show by the San Francisco filmmaker Cathy Begien is an ingenious, surprisingly intense short video called ''Black Out.'' In it the blindfolded artist delivers an episodic account of a bad-trip, club-hopping night on the town, as friends pop into the frame from the side to hand her drinks and cigarettes and act out parts of the story. When Ms. Begien breaks down toward the end of the film, it's hard to tell whether she's laughing or crying. Both responses make sense. Winkleman Gallery, 637 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 643-3152; closes tomorrow. (Cotter) * ALINE KOMINSKY CRUMB: 'NEED MORE LOVE' On the occasion of her wonderfully forthright, lavishly illustrated book of the same title, one of the premier cartoonists of her generation and a force in the development of the confessional graphic novel lets quite a bit of it all hang out in paintings, drawings and, best of all, comic strips dating from 1973 to the present. Adam Baumgold Gallery, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338; closes tomorrow. (Smith) EVA AND FRACO MATTES: '13 MOST BEAUTIFUL AVATARS' This artistic duo, best known for media hacking and culture jamming, has turned to digital canvas portraits of avatars -- digital surrogates -- from the online virtual world Second Life. With their flat colors, slightly blocky features and assertive hair, these images have a jaded artifice worthy of ''Blade Runner,'' but are also eerily effective as paintings. Postmasters, 459 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-3323; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * BAKER OVERSTREET: NEW PAINTINGS Like Keegan McHargue and Devendra Banhart, this young artist has a penchant for tribal motifs, which he flattens into symmetrical compositions and renders with an outsider roughness. The works in his debut show evoke the imagery of the space-ship-obsessed, self-taught artist Ionel Talpazan, as well as Alfred Jensen and Forrest Bess. Their notion of the visionary is both self-conscious and familiar, but they are painted with energetic dispatch and a sure sense of scale, color and wit that encourage you to stay tuned. Fredericks & Freiser, 536 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 633-6555, fredericksfreisergallery.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG: TRANSFER DRAWINGS FROM THE 1960S This is the first exhibition devoted to the artist's large transfer drawings of the 1960s, which function less as works of art than as refined filtering systems. Their hazy, flickering surfaces mix bits of history (the space race, the civil rights movement, the cold war) with eruptions of weirdly rotelike graphic finesse -- the windshield-wiper strokes with which Rauschenberg brought his images to the surface. Extraordinarily beautiful and hauntingly multifarious, these works show us art, art history and the very times we live in taking shape. Jonathan O'Hara Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-3533; closes tomorrow. (Smith) Studio Museum in Harlem: 'Africa Comics' Intense is the word for the stealth-potency of this first-time United States survey of original designs by 35 African artists who specialize in comic art. The work is intense the way urban Africa can be intense: intensely zany, intensely harsh, intensely warm, intensely political. We are on familiar Marvel Comics ground with the adventures of the charismatic Princess Wella, a Superwoman with a ceremonial staff and braids. But more often than not, humor is sugarcoating for varying degrees of disquiet, including images of jabbing violence. 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500, studiomuseum.org; closes on Sunday. (Cotter) * 'What F Word?' The ''F word'' in question for this group is feminism, though others come under its purview. The work spans decades, from an apt updating of a Flemish Madonna and child by the estimable and too long overlooked Anita Steckel, to very recent art by Dana Frankfort, Jane Hammond and Shay Nowick. In a brand-new piece, Elaine Reichek brings Ezra Pound into the picture. Ulrike Muller pays tribute to Mina Loy. Patricia Cronin contributes an image of a tomb sculpture she designed, depicting herself and her lover, the artist Deborah Kass (also in the show), embracing on a bed. Cynthia Broan Gallery, 546 West 29th Street, Chelsea, (212) 760-0809, cynthiabroan.com; closes tomorrow. (Cotter)

IN Philip Taaffe's book nothing is ever used up. Any motif, whether man-made or taken directly from nature, can have a new and vital life, with proper placement and adjustments in scale and color, of course. Ditto any technique. This point is driven home by the suavely eye-popping new paintings in Mr. Taaffe's latest show at the uptown Gagosian Gallery. They partake of everything from Northwest Coast Indian masks to Islamic ornamental patterns to marbleizing and gilding, and the word recycling doesn't begin to do them justice. These works serve notice that Mr. Taaffe is one of the best painters of his generation, one who has extended both 1970s Pattern and Decoration and the '80s practices of appropriation and juxtaposition into new areas. He has been aided by important cues from his elders -- Warhol's washy colors and ghostly, touch-free surfaces, and Jackson Pollock's all-over dripped unities. He has warmed up and slowed down these twin peaks of technique with his own brand of weirdly nonchalant labor-intensiveness. Once you absorb the dazzle and cultural references of Mr. Taaffe's surfaces, you may spend time simply trying to fathom how they are made.

CRYSTAL--Sheila (nee Maurer), formerly of Hewlett Harbor, NY, passed away peacefully at her home in Boynton Beach, FL after a long illness. Survived by her husband Leonard, son Stuart, and mother Eve Maurer. She was predeceased by her son Jonathan, father George Maurer, and brother Jerold.

Cheim & Read 547 West 25th Street, Chelsea Through March 24 Bill Jensen has never settled down with one style, although he's probably best known for paintings that feature eerie biomorphic shapes hovering in caverns of deep space: strange, seductive canvases that are the visual equivalents of weird progressive rock songs, and were inspired by American artists like Arthur Dove and Albert Pinkham Ryder, who fall mostly outside the reigning postwar painting dialogues.

'BIGLITTLETHINGS' (Tomorrow) One of those little things is big indeed: a dinosaur, to be wrestled by cavemen. That's just one of the illusions by Imago Theater, a duo that uses masks, costumes, props and choreography. At noon and 3 p.m., Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 760-0064, queenstheatre.org; $17; $15 for ages 65+; $14 for 17 and under. 'CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS' AND 'THE FIREBIRD' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Magical creatures are the stars of these brief versions of dance classics, presented by New York Theater Ballet for ages 2 to 6. Children receive bags of small props, enabling them to play along with the stories. At 11 a.m. and 1 and 3:30 p.m., Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 355-6160, nytb.org; $30; $25 for 12 and under. CHILDREN'S THEATER COMPANY (Tomorrow and Sunday) These young performers explore tolerance in four short musicals. Tomorrow ''Providence: The Story of Roger Williams'' focuses on the Rhode Island Colony founder who befriended the Narragansett Indians, while ''Farmer Rabbit's Fiesta'' deals with a selfish animal. On Sunday ''Freedom Song: Youth Can Move the World'' relates the history of the civil rights movement, and ''Stone Soup'' reinterprets a folk tale as a metaphor for the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. (Through April 7.) At 4:30 p.m., Baha'i Unity Center, 53 East 11th Street, East Village; $12. Reservations required: (212) 633-6629. 'DANDELION' (Tomorrow ) The Paper Bag Players' latest production charts the history of the universe from the Big Bang to the invention of written language in inventive sketches that are as much fun for grown-ups as for 3- to 9-year-olds. (Through April 1.) At 2 p.m., Goldstein Performing Arts Center, Kingsborough Community College, 2001 Oriental Boulevard, Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, (718) 368-6686;$10. 'DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS!' (Sunday) Sounds like reasonable advice. But what if the pigeon were to plead, bribe and even sing? That's the situation in this show, based on the picture book of the same title by Mo Willems. At 3 p.m., Center for the Arts, College of Staten Island, 2800 Victory Boulevard, Willowbrook, (718) 982-2787, cfashows.com; $10, $12 and $15. 'FARE FOR ALL AT THE MOUNT VERNON HOTEL' (Sunday) The Mount Vernon Hotel Museum & Garden delves into its history with this interactive musical about its early-19th-century days as a country inn. The score and lyrics are by Mark Hollmann (''Urinetown''). At 1 p.m., 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan, (212) 838-6878, mvhm.org. Tickets include museum admission: $10; $8 for members; $5 for 12 and under. 'THE FURTHER ADVENTURES OF UNCLE WIGGILY: WINDBLOWN VISITORS' (Tonight through Sunday) In this new musical Uncle Wiggily, the kindly rabbit in the stories by Howard R. Garis, is protector of a human child who ends up in New York after Hurricane Katrina. (Through March 25.) Tonight at 8, tomorrow and Sunday at 3 p.m., Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, at 10th Street, East Village, (212) 254-1109; $12; $5 for 12 and under. 'LIFEBOAT' (Tonight through Sunday) In 1940 a ship evacuating children and teenagers from wartorn Britain was sunk by a German torpedo. This play tells the true story of two survivors: Bess Walder and Beth Cummings, who clung for 19 hours to an overturned lifeboat. For 8 and older. (Through March 25.) Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., Sunday at noon and 5 p.m., the New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200; $12.50, $25 and $35. MATA FESTIVAL'S INSTRUMENT PETTING ZOO AND CONCERT (Sunday) Instruments may not nuzzle or purr, but they can be as much fun as animals. At this event the audience can meet the musicians as well as try out instruments. At 3 p.m., Brooklyn Lyceum, 227 Fourth Avenue, at President Street, Park Slope, (718) 857-4816, gowanus.com; $10; free for under 15. NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL CHILDREN'S FILM FESTIVAL (Sunday) The festival ends with a screening of the new film ''TMNT'' (Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles), at 1:15 p.m., and ''Best of the Fest,'' its presentation of awards and screening of prizewinners, followed by a party, at 4 p.m. At Directors Guild of America, 110 West 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 349-0330, gkids.com. ''TMNT,'' $10; ''Best of the Fest,'' $20. PASSOVER FAMILY PROGRAM (Sunday) The musician Shira Kline will lead children in a celebration that will include the making of puppets and chocolate matzo. From 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., Museum of Jewish Heritage, 36 Battery Place, Lower Manhattan, (646) 437-4300, mjhnyc.org. Tickets: in advance, $15; $10 for 12 and under; $40 for a family of four. At the door: $20, $10 and $45. Family-level members: $10, $5 and $35. SKOPPA & SKRITLA: ICELANDIC CHILDREN'S THEATER (Tomorrow) These Nordic characters live in Adventureland, where everyone sings and dances. Actors and audience will do both in this 40-minute preschool show. At 11:30 a.m. (in Icelandic) and 1 p.m. (in English), Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, (212) 847-9740, scandinaviahouse.org; $6; $4 for members. THEATRESPORTS (Tomorrow) It may involve actors, but it's still athletic: the members of Freestyle Repertory Theater, an improv troupe, break up into two teams and perform skits based on audience suggestions. Children not only vote for a winner but also participate. At 11 a.m., Gallery Players, 199 14th Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 595-0547, galleryplayers.com; $8 for 18 and under; free for adults.

A former Pace University student was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years of probation and 100 hours of community service after he admitted making fake drivers' licenses, prosecutors said. The student, William Gerhard, 20, of Yorktown, pleaded guilty to second-degree forgery in November, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Ms. DiFiore said Mr. Gerhard made and sold New Jersey drivers' licenses out of his dorm room. She said the licenses were sold to students, who mainly used them to buy alcohol.

ROWLAND--Herb. Our dear friend, Herb Rowland was the quintessential gentleman. His integrity, intelligence, and humor were among his outstanding qualities and we cherish the memories we have of our long and wonderful friendship. Our love goes to Patty and his children and his grandchildren. We are privileged to have known this extraordinary person. Judy and Bruce Newman

To the Editor: Re ''California Coasting'' (March 9): Thank you for capturing the natural beauty of San Onofre State Beach park and specifically the San Mateo campground, in an ''unspoiled, oak-lined river valley'' where coyotes, quail, rabbits and owls bring us to peacefulness away from the pace of modern life. It is a valley of clean air and clean ocean that should not be lost. For 10 years I have listened to developers and Orange County politicians promise to protect our open spaces and keep our ocean clean, but they have failed. Laguna Beach was a crystal jewel 10 years ago, but now the water is a murky green. San Onofre must be protected lest Eden be lost and our grandchildren will not be able to say, ''We were glad to have seen it . . . .'' Marni Magda Laguna Beach, Calif.

HANDLING BAD NEWS How do medical device manufacturers react when they start receiving reports of injuries caused by their products? Some case studies are revealing. [Page C1.] BID FOR THE BOARD OF TRADE The Intercontinental Exchange surprised financial markets by making an unsolicited $10 billion bid to wrest the Chicago Board of Trade away from its planned merger partner, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. [C1.] FOR THE PLAINTIFFS Richard F. Scruggs, the trial lawyer representing homeowners seeking money to pay for Hurricane Katrina damage, is folksy and smooth as molasses in court. He has turned the case into a financial and public relations nightmare for the insurance industry. [C1.] G.M. WARNS ON ACCOUNTING General Motors, a company once known as the model of corporate accounting, warned investors that its performance was threatened by ''ineffective'' controls over financial reporting. [C3.] CADBURY TO GO TWO WAYS Cadbury Schweppes, which is based in Britain, said that it planned to split off its American beverage unit, which makes Dr Pepper and Snapple drinks, from its candy businesses, after pressure from shareholders. Separating the businesses would help Cadbury focus on its confectionary unit, which analysts consider to be the center of the company. [C3.] A GAUGE OF INFLATION GOES UP Prices rose broadly and sharply for businesses in February as an array of goods, from children's toys to tobacco, became more expensive. [C3.] OPEC WON'T INCREASE PRODUCTION OPEC ministers said that they would keep oil production at current levels, despite calls to pump more supplies into an increasingly tight market. [C3.] A CODE FOR HEDGE FUNDS The finance minister of Germany said that he favored the development of an internationally accepted ''code of conduct'' for the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry. [C2.] RETURNS VS. CONSISTENCY Many of Silicon Valley's technology investors have proclaimed their passion for alternative energy, seeking innovations that use ethanol, solar and wind. But a number of them have also invested in companies that promote fossil fuels -- the source of many of the problems their other investments are meant to fix. V.C. Nation. [C1.] A CATCHY PHRASE? PRICELESS Madison Avenue's ability to contribute phrases to the vernacular -- think ''the pause that refreshes'' or ''where's the beef?'' -- is becoming more valuable as so-called buzz marketing or word-of-mouth marketing grows increasingly important to advertisers. [C4.] TRIBUNE OFFER LOSING FAVOR A proposal from Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate billionaire, to purchase the Tribune Company is falling from favor, according to people close to the situation. [C4.] TWO BANKS, ONE PARTNERSHIP Carver Federal Savings Bank, the country's largest black financial institution, and Merrill Lynch have struck an unusual alliance that will provide the Wall Street firm entree into minority neighborhoods. [C7.] MARKETS OVERCOME INFLATION DATA Stocks managed a moderate advance as signs of strength in corporate takeover activity, jobs and overseas markets allowed investors to stomach a sharp rise in wholesale inflation. [C6.] NEW PIPELINE BYPASSES BOSPORUS Russia, Greece and Bulgaria signed an agreement to build a 175-mile oil pipeline bypassing the crowded Bosporus in Turkey. [C2.] GAME ON Sony's PlayStation 2 has lost its stature in the gaming world to more advanced (and expensive) machines. But a new game for the PS2, called God of War II, is perhaps the best single-player action-adventure game yet made for any console. A review. [E27.] COLLEGES AND LOAN COMPANIES Dozens of colleges have accepted financial incentives -- including cash payments and expense-paid trips -- from student loan companies to steer student business their way. [A16.] ONLINE ALL ABOUT EXECUTIVE PAY The chief executive at Berkshire Hathaway took home the same $100,000 in 2006 that he has been earning for 25 years. More coverage of executive pay packages and interactive features are in a special section on the executive pay at nytimes.com/business. RECONSIDERING THE BYPASS After more than a decade-long decline, is bypass surgery poised for a comeback? An article and audio slide show are at nytimes.com/health. EAT YOUR GREENS Restaurant owners are finding ways to handle the garbage and mess of a professional kitchen while reducing the effects on the environment. A special section on business and the environment is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. SHAREHOLDERS OF THE CVS Corporation, the drugstore chain, voted yesterday to approve the company's $23.9 billion plan to buy pharmacy benefits manager Caremark Rx. (REUTERS) NETSMART TECHNOLOGIES may not poll shareholders on a $115 million offer to sell out to private equity firms until it tells investors more about how the software company was shopped, a Delaware judge ruled. (AP)

What's green, has more than 200,000 bare legs and plays the bagpipes in the middle of Manhattan? Begosh and begorrah, it's the New York City St. Patrick's Day Parade, and tomorrow is the 246th annual version. The marchers step off at 11 a.m. at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street and strut and shout and jump and jig their way up the avenue to 86th Street, and then many fan out to the bars across the Upper East Side. The viewing, above, is grand from anywhere you stand along the avenue. Suggested admission is a shouting voice and an outfit of green. As much a tradition as the kilts, pipes and broad banners honoring Irish counties is the sublime chaos along the parade route: the laughing lasses with ''Kiss Me, I'm Irish'' shirts; the reserves of rowdies with smuggled-in hooch from the suburbs; the proud old gentlemen in wool sweaters and caps; the bands of bored policemen directing pedestrians; and the hometown hustlers hawking green plastic derbies. Related activities around the city tomorrow include the traditional Solemn Pontifical Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 50th Street and Fifth Avenue, at 8:30 a.m., and a traditional St. Patrick's Day Mass conducted in Irish Gaelic at St. Agnes's Church, 143 East 43rd Street, Manhattan, at 10 a.m., with Father Michael O'Shea from County Kerry celebrating the service, along with Father Aiden O'Driscoll from County Cork. The Irish Arts Center, at 553 West 51st Street, Manhattan, has a free daylong program of Irish music, dance, song and language, as well as a tin whistle workshop. (Information: irishartscenter.org; reservations required for workshop: 212-247-3231.) COREY KILGANNON

A museum review on Saturday about the U.S.S. Monitor Center in Newport News, Va., misidentified the site where the Monitor was built. It was the Continental Iron Works in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, not the Brooklyn Navy Yard. (The ship was outfitted and commissioned at the yard.)

Wisconsin's star forward, Alando Tucker, was asked Thursdayhow to avoid becoming the fifth second-seeded team in history to lose to a No. 15 team in the N.C.A.A. tournament. ''You can't underlook anybody,'' he said. He meant overlook or underestimate, but in either case, his words left a sense that things might already be askew.
While Butler is perhaps the team with the lowest profile in the Round of 16 thus far, the private, liberal arts university in Indianapolis boasts an eclectic list of former students and faculty.
Michigan's firing of Coach Tommy Amaker on Saturday reverberated loudly throughout the Big Ten.
Every time Tennessee's Chris Lofton scores 20 points in a game, Kentucky Coach Tubby Smith gets beat up for not signing Lofton, who was Mr. Basketball in Kentucky in 2004.

Pole position for Kimi Raikkonen at Ferrari, Fernando Alonso second fastest, Nick Heidfeld third fastest and Lewis Hamilton crowning a great weekend with a fourth position. And Felipe Massa, the favorite of the winter testing finishing...16th after his car broke down with a gearbox problem. That's the surprise... but should it be?

One of The Bracket's favorite recent N.C.A.A. tournament underdogs emerged in 2004, when a Nevada point guard named Todd Okeson led the No. 10 seed Wolf Pack to upsets of Michigan State and Gonzaga in the first weekend of the tournament. Okeson had the straight-from-central-casting story: he was from Weskan, Kan., a town of about 300 people, and he had received no other Division I scholarship offers.

Given the week of storms that we've had, bookended by congressional hearings into the firings of United States attorneys, calls for Attorney General Alberto Gonzales to resign (and a presidential scolding from Mexico to boot), the Senate Democrats defeated (again) on an anti-war resolution, the House moving forward on its own and, no small matter, the appearance and voice - after long, long silence - of former C.I.A. officer Valerie Wilson testifying on the Hill, the Sunday news show lineup of guests reflects the gamut of politicians circling a White House under fire.

St. Patrick's Day in Columbus, and everybody in O'Shaughnessy's, the pub around the corner from Nationwide Arena, is wearing green. It is tough to pick out the Buckeyes fans because they are not wearing the usual scarlet and gray.

The ticket brokers who will try to sell tickets outside Nationwide Arena in Columbus, Ohio, for Sunday's second-round games are going to be watched very closely by the police. There are 550 stolen tickets on the loose.

Thousands of pieces of bright-green clothing, stashed in closets and drawers for 364 days, found their way to downtown Chicago on Saturday morning. The people wearing the festive wear watched the Chicago River turn green. Dying the river is a tradition dating to 1961. The tradition of wearing garish green T-shirts requesting a kiss and plastic leprechaun-style hats is unknown.

The battle of Ohio is under way - Ohio State vs. Xavier - and the first half has been spirited, both on the floor and in the stands. Both teams' fans traveled well and have perhaps a third of the arena. The Xavier faithful may still bear hard feelings for Buckeyes Coach Thad Matta for the way he left the Musketeers three years ago after indicating he had no intention of leaving Cincinnati.

Eighth-seeded Kentucky's victory over No. 9 seed Villanova on Friday night pushed its streak of advancing to the N.C.A.A. tournament's second round to 16 straight years. But it hardly diminishes the pressure on Coach Tubby Smith.
The Times's Amy Harmon was drawn to a dilemma of DNA testing: Is it better to know you will develop a disease, even if there is nothing that can be done?

Louisville Coach Rick Pitino had a good point the other day (not exactly the first time).
