He was talking about the scrutiny on all coaches, particularly in the northeast, and then he noted: "It was a lot easier to get into coaching 15 years ago when there was no Internet or talk radio. Back then, the premise was that the fans knew that you knew more than them."
The playfully self-aware touches of “Dead Silence” distract from its leaden pacing, three too many final twists and various behavioral idiocies.

Vanderbilt never trailed against George Washington Thursday and won by 33 points. North Carolina never trailed against Eastern Kentucky later that night and won by 21. Xavier trailed by 9 with a little more than 16 minutes to play and rallied to beat B.Y.U. by 2. Texas A&M trailed by 2 with 13 minutes left and came back to beat Penn by 16.
Here's a rundown of some of the 2008 campaign coverage in several of the nation's newspapers.
Michelines Maynard of The Times describes the “simple but classic” lunch that Ina Garten prepared -- a meal that included corn chowder, a cheese selection and brownies.

My Sunday column is about U.S. policy toward Israel and the Palestinian territories, and the lack of a more open debate about it in U.S. political circles. I'm leaving Saturday on a reporting trip to Afghanistan and Pakistan (though next Tuesday's column will be one I've written in advance about Cheney), but please post your comments below on the Middle East column. And don't just comment on my column -- comment on each other's posts, or if you have expertise and someone raises a question, please answer it.

The first round of the 2007 NCAA Tournament is completed, and it's safe to say, as much fun as it was, it's unlikely that any snapshots from the past two days will be included in one of those misty highlights packages CBS trots out to advertisers. The closest we came to a buzzer-beater was Virginia Commonwealth guard Eric Maynor's jump shot with 1.8 seconds left to beat Duke, and the first round lacked the signature upset that has become the hallmark of sports' most democratic event.
Barcelona striker Samuel Eto'o sat down to talk with Jack Bell of The New York Times in his apartment in Spain a day after a game against Real Madrid.
The serial-killer parody “Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon” has nerve, rapier-sharp observations and a firm grasp of tone.
The most valuable player for Southern Illinois in its 61-51 victory over Holy Cross on Friday night scored 4 points.
“Nomad: The Warrior” looks and feels like an old-school American western. Not a great western, but a reasonably good example of that genre.
The 64-board final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at the Spring North American Championships will start at 2 p.m. Eastern time.
Randolph Morris finished with 19 points and 11 rebounds, and eighth-seeded Kentucky flexed its muscle in the second half for a victory over ninth-seeded Villanova in the West Regional.
A missed Xavier free throw opened the door for Ohio State to push the game into overtime where the Buckeyes managed to earn a hard-fought N.C.A.A. tournament victory.
The three men, all advanced certified divers, made a risky trip into the dark passages and compartments of a sunken vessel 60 miles south of Miami.
Three suicide attacks in Anbar Province employed a tactic that insurgents began using earlier this year, the U.S. military said.
Kentucky’s Randolph Morris had 19 points and 11 rebounds. Villanova’s Scottie Reynolds kept his team close with 23 points, but had little offensive support from his cold-shooting teammates.
Down by 10 with less than five minutes to play, the fifth-seeded Hokies dug in on defense and held Illinois scoreless for the last four minutes 29 seconds to advance to the second round.
Steve Francis’s frenzied, off-balance 3-pointer at the buzzer rolled across the rim and out, and the Knicks lost to the Hornets.
For 20 minutes against No. 16 Jackson State on Friday, Florida looked vulnerable.  For the second 20 minutes, Florida showed why the selection committee seeded the Gators as first overall.
Bobby Abreu took batting practice in the indoor cages at Legends Field in Tampa for the first time since sustaining the injury Feb. 26.
Under the prime-time spotlight, Kevin Durant scored 27 points to lead the Texas Longhorns to a victory over New Mexico State Friday night.
A harsh winter storm descended on the Northeast, burying parts of the region in damp snow and stranding thousands of travelers.
The victory was seen as a small hurdle cleared for the Jayhawks, who had lost in the first round of the past two N.C.A.A. tournaments.
Alexei Zhitnik’s slap shot on a power play 2 minutes 18 seconds into overtime last night gave the Atlanta Thrashers a victory against the Rangers.
The victory means that Washington University will play DePauw University or the national championship Saturday, while N.Y.U. will play the University of Mary Washington for third place.

An article yesterday about disputes between Singapore and its neighbors referred incorrectly to an article in the newspaper Business Times that proposed that the government create a charitable foundation to go with its investment activities in the region. The article was a bylined column by Vikram Khanna, associate editor; it was not an editorial representing the views of the newspaper.

A picture caption in some copies with a sports article last Saturday, about Georgetown’s 84-82 victory over Notre Dame in a Big East men’s basketball tournament game, misidentified the Notre Dame player in the No. 2 jersey. He is Tory Jackson, not his teammate Russell Carter. (As the caption correctly noted, Carter scored 21 points and missed a late shot for the lead. Jackson scored 20 points.) Also, the article referred imprecisely in some copies to the father of Georgetown’s current coach, John Thompson III. His father, the longtime coach at Georgetown, is John Thompson Jr. — not Sr.

A front-page article yesterday about the contents of e-mail messages sent by government officials concerning the dismissals of United States attorneys misspelled the surname of a former White House lawyer who received one of the e-mails. He is David Leitch, not Leatch.
A test to help doctors rapidly distinguish between viral meningitis and less common but more severe spinal cord and brain infections caused by bacteria received federal approval.
The man accused of setting a blaze that killed five firefighters last fall is being charged with additional counts linking him to 13 other fires, the authorities said.
A former trash company supervisor was convicted of murdering six women whose strangled bodies were found scattered in the Kansas City area in 1986 and 1987.
A review on Tuesday of Cecil Taylor’s trio and John Zorn’s Masada, at the Rose Theater, misstated the year that Lincoln Center began regularly presenting jazz concerts. It was 1987, not 1988.

An article in some copies on Tuesday about the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony misspelled the given name of a musician who paid tribute to the punk-rock-pioneer Patti Smith. He is Zack de la Rocha of Rage Against the Machine — not Zach.
A headline on Tuesday with the obituary of Edgar Baitzel, an executive of the Los Angeles Opera, misstated his title. As noted in the article, he was chief operating officer, not chief executive.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a convicted killer pleading guilty to a second murder for which another man had served 16 years in prison before being exonerated omitted the given name of a spokesman for Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. He is Lucian Chalfen.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a coalition of industrialists, environmentalists and energy specialists who are trying to eliminate the incandescent light bulb misstated the name of a business-environmental group that cooperates on global warming issues. It is the United States Climate Action Partnership, not the United States Carbon Action Program.

Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about a decision by the Supreme Court of Canada upholding restrictions that bar the reporting of federal election results from eastern time zones while polls are still open in western time zones misstated the number of time zones in Canada. It is six, not five.

A picture caption on March 4 with an article about Leroy Nicholas Barnes — a former heroin dealer from Harlem who is the subject of “Mr. Untouchable,” a book and a documentary — carried incorrect information from the producer of the film about the photograph. Mr. Barnes and Marc Levin, the film’s director, were seated at a chessboard; they were not playing chess because the board was rotated 90 degrees from its proper orientation. (The producer, who supplied the picture, said the board was set up that way to get the best images of Mr. Barnes’s hands on the chessboard.).

An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on Thursday about using cellphones overseas misstated the charge to T-Mobile USA customers for placing a call in Britain. It is 99 cents a minute, not $1.99. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of CDMA cellphone technology in Australia. While CDMA phones from American carriers do not operate there, other CDMA phones are in use; they are not “basically nonexistent.” And the article also referred incompletely to a source of low rates for calls from Britain. The rates — 26 cents a minute for local calls and 9 to 14 cents a minute for calls to the United States — are available with use of a SIM card sold by Telestial.
A review yesterday of Annie Ross, who is singing at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evenings, misstated the club’s telephone number. It is (212) 206-0440.
Corrections
Two people who were removed from a presidential event in 2005 filed a lawsuit against three White House staff members on the grounds that their rights to free speech had been violated.

A front-page article last Saturday about the shared grief of Muslim Malian immigrants in New York following a fire that killed members of two families misspelled the surname of the owner of Makbarat As-Salaam, a cemetery in Millstone, N.J., where some of the victims were eventually buried. He is Anthony Suleiman Sparno, not Spano. (Mr. Sparno, known as Tony, also uses Suleiman as a surname.).
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, offered an apology in Cedar Falls after using the term “tar baby” in answering a voter’s question about federal intervention in divorce and custody cases.
Battling shock and grief, Iola Latman greeted those who came to pay tribute to her son Nicholas T. Pekearo, who was killed with his partner in the line of duty.

The police said they had found $206 million in United States currency inside a house in a wealthy neighborhood of Mexico City and said the cash belonged to drug smugglers who imported chemicals used in methamphetamine production. They said wads of $100 bills were found stuffed into drawers, suitcases and closets and hidden in walls. The attorney general’s office said it was largest seizure of drug money ever in Mexico. Seven people at the house were arrested. A crackdown on illegal drug laboratories in the United States has recently pushed more methamphetamine production to Mexico.

Pope Benedict XVI will make his first trip to Latin America in May, a visit to Brazil to address Roman Catholic bishops, the Vatican said. He will leave Rome on May 9 and remain in São Paulo until May 11, when he goes to the city of Aparecida to open a once-a-decade meeting of the Episcopate of Latin America and the Caribbean. Bishops from the United States, Canada, Spain and Portugal will also attend. Brazil is the largest Roman Catholic country, but the church has been steadily losing members throughout the region to Pentecostal denominations and others. Benedict is to return to Rome on May 14.

A court in Moscow has for the second time ordered Mikhail M. Kasyanov, a former prime minister, to return a luxury home he bought from the state in 2004, ruling that he had acquired it illegally. Mr. Kasyanov, who served under President Vladimir V. Putin from 2000 to 2004, dismissed the decision as politically motivated and vowed to appeal, as he did when a court ordered the return a year ago. The purchase came under scrutiny after he declared his opposition to Mr. Putin and vowed to run for president next year.

President Robert G. Mugabe appeared to lash out at officials in his own party, warning the party’s Youth League in a speech of “an insidious dimension where ambitious leaders have been cutting deals with the British and Americans” to unseat him. Some in the party, known as ZANU-PF, have sought to engineer the retirement of Mr. Mugabe, 83, fearful that the nation’s economic freefall will loosen their grip on power. Mr. Mugabe has defied them, hinting that he may seek another six-year term. Zimbabwe has been on alert for weeks in the face of increasingly defiant protests.

Greek health inspectors seized more than 200 pounds of bad meat from an Athens restaurant hours before President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia dined there Wednesday with the prime ministers of Greece and Bulgaria, the government’s food safety agency said. “We always inspect restaurants where foreign dignitaries are due to visit,” the agency’s director, Yiannis Vlemmas, said. State-run NET TV reported that the office of Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis, not the restaurant, had handled the catering. The agency seized 51 pounds of beef and 168 pounds of pork, all considered unfit for consumption. Mr. Putin and the two prime ministers had the fish.

A 54-year-old nurse stands accused of killing six patients with injections at Europe’s biggest hospital, the Charité in Berlin, and of trying to kill another two, a prosecutor said. The nurse is said to have confessed, saying she wanted to spare the mostly elderly patients further suffering. Last year, another German nurse was sentenced to life in prison for administering lethal injections to 28 mostly older patients.

The High Court has struck down a 19th-century law against begging, ruling in favor of a beggar who had argued that his arrest in 2003 violated the right to freedom of expression. A section of the Vagrancy Act of 1847, enacted in the Great Famine, made begging in a public place an offense and provided for a sentence of up to three months. In 2004, Prime Minister Bertie Ahern unveiled plans to repeal thousands of English and British laws, some dating to William the Conqueror in the 11th century, that were enacted before Irish independence in 1921 and remain in force.

Ramzan Kadyrov, the new president of the restive southern region of Chechnya, condemned what he acknowledged was systemic torture but sought to shift the blame to federal security officers, not local Chechen ones. His remarks came three days after the Council of Europe reported finding significant evidence of illegal detentions and torture of suspects in Chechnya, and accused Russian officials of ignoring the problem. The report noted that many of the accusations of abuse are leveled at Chechen forces loyal to Mr. Kadyrov. His remarks also underscored the tensions between Chechen and Russian officials, despite President Vladimir V. Putin’s open support of Mr. Kadyrov.

President Thomas Yayi Boni was unharmed after his convoy was fired on in what his office described as an assassination attempt. He was retuning to Cotonou, the economic capital, on Thursday night from a political rally in the north when assailants with machine guns fired on the convoy, a presidential spokesman said. The president’s car was not hit. “There are several in our ranks that were hurt, but the president is safe and sound,” the spokesman said. “It was the return fire of the Republican Guard that caused the attackers to flee.”.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,195 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Two of the detectives were charged with second-degree manslaughter and a third with the lesser charge of reckless endangerment.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Constitutional amendments soon to be voted on by Parliament are meant to create a more open, balanced government. They are almost sure to do the opposite.
For better and quite often for worse, this man was my role model from junior high through college. His powerful songs were my soundtrack.
The Fremont General Corporation said that Credit Suisse had increased a line of credit to the company to $1 billion.
It’s time for Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson to use his powers of persuasion  to solve the domestic side of the trade problem.
Wal-Mart abruptly withdrew its application to obtain a special banking charter after a firestorm of criticism.
A feeling of uneasiness is percolating among moderate Republicans who are facing pressure to respond to public sentiment against the war.
The Blackstone Group is preparing for an initial public offering that could value the firm at more than $30 billion.
Riot police officers and protesters clashed and the political opposition joined forces with lawyers who have been rallying for days.
Lottery Numbers.
The former business partner of Conrad M. Black settled a case over funds that regulators say were fraudulently diverted from Hollinger International.

To legal experts, yesterday’s decision reached by a grand jury in the Sean Bell case appeared to be a compromise between those who think the police are too quick to shoot at unarmed black men and those who saw the hail of bullets as the officers’ justified efforts to protect their own lives.
Forcing people to pay to pollute would do more than any other known incentive to bring new technologies to commercial scale. That is the task before Congress.
The co-sponsor of a new law said its centerpiece is a clause giving school administrators the authority to ensure that clubs do not violate “the boundaries of socially appropriate behavior.”
Daisuke Matsuzaka’s start against the Los Angeles Dodgers  provided a glimpse of what might have been for the Dodgers, one of the teams that entered the Matsuzaka sweepstakes in November.
Ten inmates in a British military prison in Iraq switched places with visitors as part of an audacious escape plan.

Less than a year after Kelvin Sampson arrived at Indiana from Oklahoma with a U-Haul full of problems, the Hoosiers are playing U.C.L.A. on Saturday in the second round and fans are chanting his name.
Wendy Reves donated more than 1,400 works she and her husband collected to the Dallas Museum of Art.
The emotional and psychological factors that caused David R. Garvin to unleash a torrent of violence on Wednesday night in Greenwich Village remain difficult to comprehend.
Valerie Wilson, a former C.I.A. agent, finally spoke after almost four years at the silent center of a political scandal.
Part of being Irish in America is a nostalgia for the old sod. And now you can buy it for a few dollars per pound.
Richard S. Prather, a hugely popular mystery writer of the 1950s and ’60s, was known for novels with swift violence, loopy humor and an astonishing number of characters with no clothes on.
Appeals by companies that lost out in a round of bidding could cost hundreds of millions of dollars in gambling tax revenue and delay promised property tax relief.
The three men, all advanced certified divers, made a risky trip into the dark passages and compartments of a sunken vessel 60 miles south of Miami.
Middle school teachers often lack expertise in subject matter and the mysteries of the adolescent mind.
Disney concluded an internal investigation and cleared Steven P. Jobs of any misconduct in issuing backdated stock options at Pixar.
Eustace Lycett made characters in “Mary Poppins” walk on smoke and seemingly empty suits of medieval armor engage in combat in “Bedknobs and Broomsticks.”
Tobacco companies will be prohibited from marketing cigarettes overseas as “low tar” and “light,” a move applauded by antismoking activists.
The Coast Guard reported that a man who had jumped into the water during a cruise off Florida suffered from mild hypothermia but was otherwise in good condition.
The presidential candidate’s racial consciousness and political curiosity appear to have begun far from Illinois.
The government repeated that there was no proof that the Japanese military forced women into sexual slavery during World War II.
Iranian goods are flooding Iraqi markets and Iraqi cities are looking to Iran for basic services.
Two days after an armed man shot and killed a bartender in a Greenwich Village restaurant, there were signs of human life — or, more accurately, of life interrupted.
Daniela Hantuchova, who called the 107-degree-heat at the first women’s semifinal at the Pacific Life Open “very, very difficult,” won against Li Na, 7-5, 4-6, 6-1.
Harriet E. Miers’s former colleagues and fellow loyalists of President Bush are pointing fingers of blame at her in the dismissal of seven federal prosecutors.
Three investigators have been reviewing thousands of pages of prescription lists from the pharmacy charged with illegally dispensing drugs.
A new strategy to get around the new Palestinian political detente appears to be emerging — one that falls back on elements of Saudi Arabia’s five-year-old peace proposals.
The gas-powered shoe is a symbol of both Russia’s deep scientific traditions and the country’s inability to convert that talent into useful merchandise.
The Runnin’ Rebels’ first-round game with Georgia Tech made for a testy and sloppy low-scoring affair, marked by referee whistles, splayed bodies, mishandled passes and missed shots.
Aaron Brooks led Oregon with 18 points in a narrow victory for the Ducks, their seventh in a row. They improved to 13-4 in games decided by less than 10 points.
A federal appellate panel ruled that the Union Pacific Railroad Company did not discriminate against its female employees because its insurance did not cover contraception used by men either.
The reconstruction plan sets up targets for overhauling the Iraqi government over the next five years.
A British soldier who died four years ago after a U.S. pilot opened fire on his convoy in Iraq was killed unlawfully, a coroner ruled.
Investors this week showed that while they are still ready to sell at a moment’s notice, they remain unpredictable.
Caremark shareholders approved a $26.5 billion acquisition by CVS, creating one of the largest competitors in the prescription drug industry.
Ivory Coast’s president signed a decree creating a joint military command center, the first step toward unifying government and rebel forces.
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad vowed that Iran would never dismantle its nuclear program, even in the face of toughened sanctions.
A Tunisian immigrant is the first person to be remunerated for being falsely arrested under an antiterrorism law introduced soon after 9/11.
California’s stem cell agency will give out about $75 million to a dozen universities and nonprofit laboratories.
The Afghan government backed away from an earlier accusation that the U.S.-led coalition had mistakenly killed five Afghan police officers.
Virginia Commonwealth Coach Anthony Grant took over as coach last April under difficult circumstances after the popular Jeff Capel left suddenly but gained the trust of his team.
Carlos Ghosn will give up North American operations and focus on the revamping under way at Nissan and Renault.
Snowboarder Shaun White will join six other athletes, representing five action sports, in an astronaut training exercise to experience weightlessness.
Applications may take up to 10 weeks to be processed now that passports are required for air travelers returning from Mexico, Canada and most places in the Caribbean.
The Soumare family began their long journey back to Africa Friday morning — quietly, anonymously, delicately.
Chest compressions — not mouth-to-mouth resuscitation — seem to be the key in helping someone recover from cardiac arrest, according to new research.
Prime Minister Wen Jiabao deflected questions about China’s rising power and suggested that it would not disrupt the world order dominated by the U.S.
After beating Arnold Palmer by two strokes when he was 19, Rocco Mediate may get a trophy from him on Bay Hill’s 18th green Sunday.
A rebound in energy prices pushed inflation higher in February, suggesting that a weakening economy has not yet taken much pressure off rising prices.
Democrats fear that the rising number of homeowners who cannot repay their mortgages could cause broader economic problems.
A ninth grader in Florida who spent a month with the hiccups had been free of them for two weeks before they resumed.
Notre Dame came to the N.C.A.A. tournament early, played early and left early as the Winthrop Eagles upset the Fighting Irish in a first-round game filled with drastic shifts of momentum.
Mr. Thicke is a 30-year-old white guy — the son of the Canadian actor and songwriter Alan Thicke — who also happens to be the fastest-rising star in R&B.
Girls’ weightlifting, a high school sport sanctioned only in one state, is embraced by girls of all shapes, sizes and athletic abilities.
A museum exhibit titled “The Proper Way to Hang a Confederate Flag” depicts the emblem being lynched from a 13-foot-high wooden gallows.
Jovan Zebic, an associate of the late Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, was charged with siphoning off state money in the 1990s.
“Hélio Oiticica: The Body of Color” is an exhilarating survey that emphasizes the earlier, lesser-known stages of the artist’s career.
Another reading on inflation deflated hopes that the Federal Reserve would start moving toward an interest rate cut when it meets next week.
Marc Torsilieri looked like a ginger-bearded lumberjack and played the part in splendid fashion by annually felling the Christmas tree for Rockefeller Center.
Jorge Torres will defend his title Saturday morning in the United States men’s 8-kilometer championship run in Central Park. Or, at least one can only assume that is Torres wearing bib No. 1.

A Bronx woman who was an advocate for Central American and Caribbean immigrants pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to defrauding immigrants of more than $1 million, prosecutors said. The woman, Maria Elena Maximo, charged immigrants $500 to $2,500 to apply for work permits and green cards for which they were not eligible, the prosecutors said. In some cases, they said, her faulty applications led to deportation proceedings. Ms. Maximo pleaded guilty to two counts of mail fraud and faces a maximum of 20 years in prison for each count.

The former mayor of Waterbury pleaded guilty yesterday to racketeering conspiracy in connection with a federal investigation of the mob’s influence over the trash industry in Connecticut and New York, prosecutors said. The former mayor, Joseph J. Santopietro, who was a consultant for Diversified Waste Disposal, admitted participating in a scheme in which trash haulers carved out routes for one another and agreed not to poach customers, prosecutors said. Mr. Santopietro, 48, a Republican, spent more than six years in prison on corruption charges in the 1990s. He was one of 29 people charged over the summer in the scheme, which prosecutors said forced prices up for trash pickup. He faces 12 to 18 months in prison when he is sentenced in June. Prosecutors said co-defendants told Mr. Santopietro to use his influence to dissuade a competing trash hauler from honoring a contract with a new customer who had previously used one of the companies involved in the case.

Police officers and firefighters said yesterday that they would boycott Newark’s annual St. Patrick’s Day parade tomorrow because the procession will honor a congressman who they say failed to show support for a slain Philadelphia officer. Chuck West, president of the Newark Firefighters Union, said that off-duty firefighters and police personnel who would have been able to take part in the parade were being asked to stay away. In December the congressman, Donald M. Payne, was among 31 House members who voted against a resolution, which eventually passed, condemning a French town’s decision to name a street in honor of Mumia Abu-Jamal, who was convicted in 1982 of killing Officer Daniel Faulkner. A federal judge overturned Mr. Abu-Jamal’s death sentence in 2001 but upheld his conviction, and appeals from both sides are pending. Mr. Payne, a Democrat who has represented Newark since 1989, did not return phone calls seeking comment, but he has said he shares in the anger over the murder of Officer Faulkner. He has said his reasons for objecting to the resolution include his belief that it would be “setting a poor precedent by involving Congress in the affairs of a French town.”.

Promising that he would be relentless in upholding his “solemn responsibility” to deter terrorist attacks at New Jersey’s industrial facilities, Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced a proposal yesterday to enact tighter security measures at more than 50 plants that use the kind of deadly chemical gases that could pose a threat to thousands of people in the surrounding communities. Since 2005, 42 of the state’s most vulnerable plants have been forced to evaluate ways to reduce risks, and several have changed chemicals or processes. Mr. Corzine’s proposal would require more stringent regulations to be adopted at 52 additional facilities, including water treatment plants and food processing factories, which use deadly chlorine gas. If adopted by the Legislature, the regulations would be among the tightest in the nation. Rick Hind, legislative director for the Greenpeace toxics campaign, urged Congress not to enact a Bush administration proposal, supported by the chemical industry, that would allow looser federal guidelines to supersede New Jersey’s regulations.
The Met and the dramatic soprano Deborah Voight come together to present the overlooked Richard Strauss opera, “Die Ägyptische Helena.”

Federal prosecutors charged a prominent Southampton real estate broker with possession of child pornography.
American bands are using the South by Southwest music festival in Austin, Tex., to arrange bookings in other countries and otherwise export themselves.

Captain America was never the eternal symbol — he was the publicity stunt who grew on the page into a failed but likable human being, and was therefore believably mortal.

7 P.M. (TLC) MY LIFE AS A CHILD In “Different From You,” the fourth installment of this series of life stories made by and about young people, four children describe what it’s like not to fit in and tell how they deal with teasing. This episode features an 11-year-old girl who just wants to play football, a 9-year-old boy who is ostracized for his unorthodox style, an 11-year-old American Indian girl and a 10-year-old boy whose older brother is autistic.

8 P.M. (National Geographic) GALÁPAGOS Until a few centuries ago, this isolated archipelago — 13 major volcanic islands, 6 smaller islands and 107 rocks and islets — off the coast of Ecuador remained a mystery to much of the world. Then a visit to the pristine islands, and their vast number of endemic species, in 1835 inspired Charles Darwin to come up with his theory of evolution by natural selection. Today the Galápagos’ rich environment has been increasingly decimated both by tourists and by local populations, who have introduced plants and animals that prey on native species and destroy their habitats. This new three-part special, made over 20 years, journeys from the rim of the Sierra Negra volcano on the island of Isabela to the active shores, retraces Darwin’s route and examines the efforts of conservationists to preserve this once-pristine oasis.
10 P.M. (SNY) BOXING: EVANDER HOLYFIELD VS. VINNY MADDALONE Mr. Holyfield’s third fight since coming out of retirement in a quest to win a fifth world heavyweight championship.

The decline of the Manchu language has become a serious obstacle for historians studying the Qing Dynasty archives. Only a fraction of the extensive Manchu-language records held in Beijing and other regional centers have been translated and there are fewer than 40 translators working in these archives.

After a week of mounting tension in southeast Queens, the news that three officers would face criminal charges in the shooting of Sean Bell came as a relief to Bishop Erskine Williams. He heard it on television yesterday afternoon and could not stop smiling.
An elected upper house in Britain can make sense only in the context of a new written constitution that redefines the separation of powers.
How can we expect our daughters to navigate the cultural rapids of becoming sexual beings when we ourselves are flying blind?

HOBOKEN, N.J., March 15 — Department stores start to haul out their Christmas tinsel around Halloween these days, and pumpkin picking starts soon after Labor Day. Now you can add St. Patrick’s Day, which, with its accompanying parades, is becoming a matter of Erin go on and on.

The Bush administration has been knocked back on its heels all week by a clash with the Democratic majority in Congress over the dismissal of federal prosecutors.
The problem for both Google and Viacom is that copyright law is filled with compromises and ambiguity.

Aaron Heilman found out last season what it was like to pitch for an extended period with tendinitis. It put a painful asterisk on the year for Heilman, who is resigned to more of the same this season. ''Unfortunately at this point in time, I don't think it is going to miraculously clear up,'' Heilman said after returning from a week's absence with arm soreness to pitch a perfect inning in the Mets' 5-4 loss to the Florida Marlins in Jupiter, Fla. ''It's also probably not going to get worse, either. So I'll have to manage, hopefully like I did last year.''

Jorge Torres, a former national champion at the University of Colorado, was to defend his title this morning in the United States men's 8-kilometer championship in Central Park. Torres won the last time the race was held, in 2005 on Randalls Island. Last year, he won the national 10k title. After the race here, he said his priority would be the 10k in the national championships June 21-24 in Indianapolis. He hopes to qualify there for the world championships Aug. 24-Sept. 2 in Osaka, Japan.

He did not know at the time that the Cavaliers would be playing at the site. Gillen was fired two years ago, but his designs are all over the Virginia team. He recruited and signed the five starters, who won a share of the A.C.C. regular-season championship.

President Robert G. Mugabe appeared to lash out at officials in his own party, warning the party's Youth League in a speech of ''an insidious dimension where ambitious leaders have been cutting deals with the British and Americans'' to unseat him. Some in the party, known as ZANU-PF, have sought to engineer the retirement of Mr. Mugabe, 83, fearful that the nation's economic freefall will loosen their grip on power. Mr. Mugabe has defied them, hinting that he may seek another six-year term. Zimbabwe has been on alert for weeks in the face of increasingly defiant protests. MICHAEL WINES

A picture caption in some copies with a sports article last Saturday, about Georgetown's 84-82 victory over Notre Dame in a Big East men's basketball tournament game, misidentified the Notre Dame player in the No. 2 jersey. He is Tory Jackson, not his teammate Russell Carter. (As the caption correctly noted, Carter scored 21 points and missed a late shot for the lead. Jackson scored 20 points.) Also, the article referred imprecisely in some copies to the father of Georgetown's current coach, John Thompson III. His father, the longtime coach at Georgetown, is John Thompson Jr. -- not Sr.

Georgia Tech averaged more than 79 points a game during the season. Nevada-Las Vegas averaged 75. INTERNATIONAL A3-9 As an Economic Partner, Iran Builds Its Role in Iraq While the Bush administration works to stop Iran from meddling in Iraq, the economies of both countries, the largest Shiite-majority countries in the world, are becoming closely integrated, with Iranian goods flooding Iraqi markets and Iraqi cities looking to Iran for basic services. A1 President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad vowed that Iran would never dismantle its nuclear program, even in the face of a new round of sanctions from the United Nations Security Council. A6 An Elaborate Escape in Basra Ten Iraqis being held in a British military detention center in Basra carried out an audacious escape plan over the past several days: they switched places with visitors, British authorities said. A7 A British soldier who died four years ago after an American military pilot in Iraq opened fire on his convoy was killed unlawfully, a coroner ruled. The American military already concluded that the shooting was an understandable mistake. A7 Gaza Gunmen Fire on U.N. Car In what was apparently a kidnapping attempt, Palestinian gunmen fired 14 bullets into the armored car of the Gaza director of the United Nations refugee agency. No one was hurt. Agent Speaks Out Valerie Wilson finally spoke, testifying to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, after almost four years at the silent center of a political scandal that touched Washington's most rarefied circles of government and news media. Two of the detectives were charged with second-degree manslaughter and a third with the lesser charge of reckless endangerment. One of the timeless story lines in the N.C.A.A. tournament is a big-time player from a small conference program carrying his team. From Weber State's Harold Arceneaux to Rhode Island's Lamar Odom to Miami of Ohio's Wally Szczerbiak, the names are indelibly intertwined.

Wisconsin's star forward, Alando Tucker, was asked Thursdayhow to avoid becoming the fifth second-seeded team in history to lose to a No. 15 team in the N.C.A.A. tournament. ''You can't underlook anybody,'' he said. He meant overlook or underestimate, but in either case, his words left a sense that things might already be askew.

Opened yesterday nationwide. Directed by James Wan 90 minutes ''Dead Silence'' begins with a young couple opening a mysterious parcel containing a ventriloquist's dummy. Moments later, the husband, Jamie (Ryan Kwanten), goes for takeout, and the doll kills and mutilates his wife. Jamie, now a murder suspect shadowed by a smart-aleck detective (Donnie Wahlberg), drives to the couple's old hometown, buries his beloved and tries to learn if her demise had to do with an old local ghost story about a vengeful ventriloquist named Mary Shaw (Judith Roberts). Um, yeah.

Virginia Tech is a football school in a basketball-first league. What it needs are signature victories in the N.C.A.A. tournament to make itself more accepted with the round ball, and it got one here Friday night. The Hokies defeated North Carolina twice this season, but their 54-52 victory against Illinois in a West Region first-round game was bigger than both of those wins. It was their first N.C.A.A. tournament victory since 1996.

SOUTH No. 4 Virginia and No. 5 Tennessee routed their opponents to set up a second-round meeting. No. 2 seed Memphis had a tougher time but advanced to face Nevada, which didn't need its star player to defeat Creighton in overtime. WEST No. 1 Kansas made it out of the first round this year, creating a matchup with Kentucky usually seen later in the tournament. No. 5 Virginia Tech topped one Illinois team (Illinois) and will next play another (Southern Illinois). EAST With the spotlight on him, the freshman star Kevin Durant scored 27 points in his first N.C.A.A. tournament game to lead No. 4 Texas. MIDWEST Several highly seeded teams were in trouble, but only No. 6 Notre Dame lost. No. 3 Oregon escaped No. 14 Miami of Ohio and next take on upset-minded Winthrop. No. 2 Wisconsin also survived and will meet seventh-seeded U.N.L.V. No. 9 Purdue eliminated struggling Arizona and will face surging Florida, which scored 71 points in the second half last night.

Fox's ''Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?'' established itself as a serious contender Thursday in the 8 p.m. hour, one of network television's most competitive time slots. According to Nielsen estimates, the quiz show led with 12.2 million viewers, Fox's largest audience for a scheduled show in that time period since ''World's Wildest Police Videos'' in November 1998. ABC ranked second at 8, as ''Ugly Betty'' drew a below-average 10.8 million viewers. CBS was third, broadcasting N.C.A.A. basketball tournament coverage in lieu of ''Survivor: Fiji.'' ABC won the night over all, dominating the 9 o'clock hour with ''Grey's Anatomy'' (22.4 million). ABC's new drama ''October Road'' finished first at 10, with 14.3 million viewers. Fox and CBS tied for second for the night among adults 18 to 49. NBC ranked fourth. The premiere of its new comedy ''Andy Barker, P.I.'' attracted 5.8 million viewers at 9:30, and at 10, ''Raines,'' its new detective show with Jeff Goldblum, earned 10.3 million total viewers and a third place among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF
A review on Tuesday of Cecil Taylor's trio and John Zorn's Masada, at the Rose Theater, misstated the year that Lincoln Center began regularly presenting jazz concerts. It was 1987, not 1988.

The uniforms and the names of the universities were familiar, but their place in the world of college basketball seemed distant. Kentucky and Villanova, former champions of the N.C.A.A. tournament searching for a bright cap to disappointing seasons, found themselves meeting as middling participants of the opening round. It had a big-game feel, but it was uncertain why, with both teams not much better than average in their own conferences. But they put on an interesting show, with eighth-seeded Kentucky advancing with a 67-58 victory against ninth-seeded Villanova in the West Region.
To the Editor: Re ''General Pace and Gay Soldiers'' (editorial, March 15):

Ramzan Kadyrov, the new president of the restive southern region of Chechnya, condemned what he acknowledged was systemic torture but sought to shift the blame to federal security officers, not local Chechen ones. His remarks came three days after the Council of Europe reported finding significant evidence of illegal detentions and torture of suspects in Chechnya, and accused Russian officials of ignoring the problem. The report noted that many of the accusations of abuse are leveled at Chechen forces loyal to Mr. Kadyrov. His remarks also underscored the tensions between Chechen and Russian officials, despite President Vladimir V. Putin's open support of Mr. Kadyrov. STEVEN LEE MYERS

A rising Mexican rock guitar duo has had to cancel an American tour because of visa problems, its record label said. The performers, Rodrigo y Gabriela, were scheduled to begin the tour last Sunday in Miami, but the visa renewal for one, Rodrigo Sanchez, had been held up because his name is similar to that of another foreigner who is barred from entering the United States, said Chris Tetzeli, of the band's American record label, ATO. The duo, which specializes in rapidly played acoustic arrangements, including a version of Led Zeppelin's ''Stairway to Heaven,'' was to play at the South by Southwest Festival in Austin, Tex., on Thursday and at Webster Hall in New York next Wednesday. Mr. Tetzeli said he hoped the pair would still be able to play scheduled American shows in April. A spokeswoman for the State Department said that it did not comment on individual cases. BEN SISARIO
A review yesterday of Annie Ross, who is singing at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evenings, misstated the club's telephone number. It is (212) 206-0440.

''People don't know that, because we've had some great games over the last eight or nine years. But we're good friends.

On a Wing and a Prayer Leonardo da Vinci's ''Annunciation,'' the 15th-century masterpiece that almost never leaves its home in the Uffizi Gallery in Florence, Italy, safely reached the National Museum in Tokyo yesterday, the Associated Press reported. An Italian senator had earlier chained himself to the Uffizi to protest the lending of the work, which will anchor an exhibition called ''Italian Spring'' that opens on Tuesday. ''We verified that the condition of the painting is the same as when it left,'' said Antonio Godoli of the Uffizi. It is only the third time that ''The Annunciation,'' above, has left the museum. For the trip, the roughly 6 1/2--by-3-foot painting was encased in three protective crates filled with shock absorbers and sensors to monitor humidity and temperature. In its Tokyo gallery, the painting must be viewed through a $50,000 bulletproof crystal window, itself set into a steel case designed to survive an earthquake. The painting will be shown through June 17. The Albright-Knox Wins A New York State Supreme Court judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit filed by a group seeking to stop the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo from auctioning more than 100 antiquities and pieces of Renaissance and medieval art to raise money to buy newer pieces. The judge, Diane Y. Devlin, declined a request for an injunction to stop the auctions, the first of which is scheduled to begin on Tuesday at Sotheby's in Manhattan. She said that the sales' opponents had failed to make a compelling case that the museum had deviated from its mission in deciding to sell the pieces, among other claims. Museum officials said the decision to sell was difficult, but that for an institution focused on mostly Modern and contemporary art, the antiquities were a luxury it could no longer afford. The sales are expected to add at least $15 million to the museum's $58 million endowment. Richard E. Stanton, a lawyer for the group opposing the sales, said no appeal was planned. A Comedian's Comeback? No, He Never Left Reports of the death of Sinbad, below, the actor and comedian, were greatly exaggerated, Reuters said on Thursday. Rumors of his demise had circulated after someone altered his Wikipedia entry to announce that he had died of a heart attack. Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia, allows almost anyone to edit entries and leaves it to its user community to catch errors. In this case, by the time the error was caught, e-mail links to the erroneous page had been forwarded to hundreds of people. A Home for Cage Trust The John Cage Trust, which oversees the works of that avant-garde composer (and performances of them), will move to Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., this spring, MusicalAmerica.com reported yesterday. Leon Botstein, Bard's president, called the trust ''an extraordinary asset'' and promised to make its holdings accessible to both those associated with Bard and the general public. Previously the trust had been in the Archive Building in Greenwich Village; after Sept. 11, it was moved to Phoenix. Dr. Laura Kuhn, the trust's executive director, will retain her post and join the Bard faculty as the John Cage professor of performance arts. A Penalty for Trashing Art A High Court judge in England has ordered an art storage company to pay £350,000 ($677,769) to a collector for accidentally destroying a sculpture by Anish Kapoor, a winner of the Turner Prize in 1991, the BBC reported yesterday. The judge ruled that the 1984 sculpture, ''Hole and Vessel II,'' was put in a trash hauling bin in 2004 and later destroyed at a waste plant. Fine Art Logistics initially offered to pay £587.13 ($1,137) for accidentally destroying the piece, which had been taken to it by Ofir Scheps, the work's owner. Footnotes The murder trial of the rock producer Phil Spector begins on Monday, more than four years after an actress was found shot to death at his mansion outside Los Angeles. The trial, delayed repeatedly since Mr. Spector was indicted in 2003, will be televised live. The first annual Jackson Poetry Prize, a $50,000 award for poets of ''exceptional talent'' who have not received ''major national acclaim,'' has been given to Elizabeth Alexander, a professor of African-American studies at Yale. She was selected by a committee of three poets: Lucille Clifton, Stephen Dunn and Jane Hirshfield. The Who, which is scheduled to perform in Mexico City today, has postponed the show because the singer Roger Daltrey, 63, still has bronchitis. Mr. Daltrey abandoned the stage in the middle of his opening song during a concert in Tampa, Fla., this week. The New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York has joined with Altoids to create the Altoids Award. Starting in 2008, a biennial prize will be awarded to four emerging American artists, each to receive $25,000 as well as a joint exhibition in the museum's new building on the Bowery.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a coalition of industrialists, environmentalists and energy specialists who are trying to eliminate the incandescent light bulb misstated the name of a business-environmental group that cooperates on global warming issues. It is the United States Climate Action Partnership, not the United States Carbon Action Program.

An article yesterday about disputes between Singapore and its neighbors referred incorrectly to an article in the newspaper Business Times that proposed that the government create a charitable foundation to go with its investment activities in the region. The article was a bylined column by Vikram Khanna, associate editor; it was not an editorial representing the views of the newspaper.

Purdue is a program built on hustle and gutsy play, where floor burns and bloody noses are more valued than McDonald's all-Americans. So it was fitting that against a program with the pedigree of Arizona, the defining basket in No. 9 Purdue's victory in New Orleans came from a player on the ground.
WILKINS--Arthur H., dear brother, now you are at peace -the rest you so courageously deserve. My love to you always. Shirley Liebowitz

Bobby Abreu took another step Friday in his cautious recovery from a strained oblique muscle. While many of his Yankees teammates headed here for a 4-3 loss to Houston, Abreu took batting practice in the indoor cages at Legends Field in Tampa for the first time since sustaining the injury Feb. 26. After 55 swings over four rounds, Abreu said that he was confident he would be ready by opening day.

A Bronx woman who was an advocate for Central American and Caribbean immigrants pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to defrauding immigrants of more than $1 million, prosecutors said. The woman, Maria Elena Maximo, charged immigrants $500 to $2,500 to apply for work permits and green cards for which they were not eligible, the prosecutors said. In some cases, they said, her faulty applications led to deportation proceedings. Ms. Maximo pleaded guilty to two counts of mail fraud and faces a maximum of 20 years in prison for each count. WILLIAM GLABERSON

Samuel Eto'o turned 26 years old on Saturday, March 10, the same day 10-man Barcelona earned a rousing 3-3 draw against archrival Real Madrid at the Camp Nou Stadium in Barcelona. Eto'o, who injured his knee in a European Champions League game in September, recently returned to full-time duty with the two-time defending Spanish champions. Against Real, he played only one half. The star striker from Cameroon, who led La Liga last season with 26 goals, has had a fitful return, playing primarily as a substitute. But he refused to enter a game against Racing Santander with a few minutes left, a decision that sparked controversy in soccer-mad Barcelona.

A front-page article last Saturday about the shared grief of Muslim Malian immigrants in New York following a fire that killed members of two families misspelled the surname of the owner of Makbarat As-Salaam, a cemetery in Millstone, N.J., where some of the victims were eventually buried. He is Anthony Suleiman Sparno, not Spano. (Mr. Sparno, known as Tony, also uses Suleiman as a surname.)

There was not a safe spot on the floor for Albany's Jamar Wilson. His first shot was a wild fling at the hoop on a reverse layup after three Virginia players ran at him. His next shot was a rushed 3-pointer that had no chance. His third shot, a 7-footer in the lane, was through a maze of hands waving in his face and also missed. ''It was hard to see,'' Wilson said.

ROTHENBERG--Charles D., Senior Vice President of North Fork Bank, passed away on March 15, 2007. He is survived by his devoted wife of 41 years, Arline B. Rothenberg; his two loving children, Rob and Deborah (Robert); and his two grandchildren, Lauren Mollie and Michael Joseph. He will be deeply missed by his family and friends. Services Sunday, March 18, 2007, 11am at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I.

HEINZE--Frank J. 70, longterm resident of Ramsey, NJ and Westhampton Beach, NY died on March 15, 2007. He was born in Bronxville, NY in 1936, was educated at Iona Prep, the University of Notre Dame (class of 1958) as a chemical engineer, and Columbia University as a Master of Chemical Engineering. He was a chemical process engineer with American Cyanamid Company, Stauffer Chemical Company, and American Home Products Corporation. He was a lifetime member of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers and greatly enjoyed his hobbies of deep-sea fishing and train-spotting. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Carol O'Connell Heinze, his son John and daughter-in-law Joy De Vries Heinze, his daughter Martha and son-in-law Paul Hansen, his son Mark and daughter-inlaw Claudia Villegas, his son Neal and daughter-in-law Ellen Lafontaine Heinze and his beloved grandchildren Justin, Emma, William, and Caroline Heinze. Visitation will be held on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 pm at the Van Emburgh-SneiderPernice Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave, Ramsey, NJ. A Funeral Service will be held on Monday March 19, 2007 at 10am at the funeral home. Interment will follow at Westhampton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Heifer International or the University of Notre Dame.

A court in Moscow has for the second time ordered Mikhail M. Kasyanov, a former prime minister, to return a luxury home he bought from the state in 2004, ruling that he had acquired it illegally. Mr. Kasyanov, who served under President Vladimir V. Putin from 2000 to 2004, dismissed the decision as politically motivated and vowed to appeal, as he did when a court ordered the return a year ago. The purchase came under scrutiny after he declared his opposition to Mr. Putin and vowed to run for president next year. STEVEN LEE MYERS

A front-page article yesterday about the contents of e-mail messages sent by government officials concerning the dismissals of United States attorneys misspelled the surname of a former White House lawyer who received one of the e-mails. He is David Leitch, not Leatch.

Promising that he would be relentless in upholding his ''solemn responsibility'' to deter terrorist attacks at New Jersey's industrial facilities, Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced a proposal yesterday to enact tighter security measures at more than 50 plants that use the kind of deadly chemical gases that could pose a threat to thousands of people in the surrounding communities. Since 2005, 42 of the state's most vulnerable plants have been forced to evaluate ways to reduce risks, and several have changed chemicals or processes. Mr. Corzine's proposal would require more stringent regulations to be adopted at 52 additional facilities, including water treatment plants and food processing factories, which use deadly chlorine gas. If adopted by the Legislature, the regulations would be among the tightest in the nation. Rick Hind, legislative director for the Greenpeace toxics campaign, urged Congress not to enact a Bush administration proposal, supported by the chemical industry, that would allow looser federal guidelines to supersede New Jersey's regulations. DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

A picture caption on March 4 with an article about Leroy Nicholas Barnes -- a former heroin dealer from Harlem who is the subject of ''Mr. Untouchable,'' a book and a documentary -- carried incorrect information from the producer of the film about the photograph. Mr. Barnes and Marc Levin, the film's director, were seated at a chessboard; they were not playing chess because the board was rotated 90 degrees from its proper orientation. (The producer, who supplied the picture, said the board was set up that way to get the best images of Mr. Barnes's hands on the chessboard.)

An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on Thursday about using cellphones overseas misstated the charge to T-Mobile USA customers for placing a call in Britain. It is 99 cents a minute, not $1.99. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of CDMA cellphone technology in Australia. While CDMA phones from American carriers do not operate there, other CDMA phones are in use; they are not ''basically nonexistent.'' And the article also referred incompletely to a source of low rates for calls from Britain. The rates -- 26 cents a minute for local calls and 9 to 14 cents a minute for calls to the United States -- are available with use of a SIM card sold by Telestial.

For 39 minutes 51 seconds, Justin Cage had played flawlessly and had Xavier on the precipice of an unlikely upset against top-seeded Ohio State in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament Saturday. He had scored 23 points and battled the Buckeyes' star center, Greg Oden, all afternoon. And now, out of frustration, Oden shoved Cage to collect his fifth foul. With 9.3 seconds remaining and his ninth-seeded Musketeers ahead by 61-59, Cage, a senior, had two free throws and a chance to send the Buckeyes back to Columbus, and perhaps Oden to the N.B.A. On the opposite end of the floor, Ohio State's senior guard, Ron Lewis, told his freshman backcourt mate, Mike Conley Jr., that he wanted the ball if the Buckeyes had a final shot to send the game into overtime.

Dori was cherished by her family and many friends and will always be remembered for her warmth, loving nature, keen intelligence, and passion for learning. The government said Friday that soldiers of the American-led coalition had mistakenly killed five Afghan police officers on Thursday in the volatile Helmand Province. But the government later backed away from the accusation after the coalition strongly denied that its soldiers were involved. A spokesman for the Interior Ministry said the five officers had been shot after a police vehicle came under fire from the Taliban in the Gereshk district.

The N.C.A.A. tournament provided a prime-time showcase Friday night for the freshman Kevin Durant for viewers on the East Coast. Durant responded by scoring 27 points to lead the fourth-seeded Texas Longhorns to a 79-67 victory against 13th-seeded New Mexico State in the first round of the East Region. It was the pilot show of a series that will last at least one more episode, and perhaps four more after that. Durant also had eight rebounds, three steals and a blocked shot as he displayed a collection of skills that seem sublime and subtle in a still-growing body that is listed as 6 feet 9 inches and 225 pounds.

My last column told the story of the diminishing scope of the establishment clause of the Constitution. Once understood as prohibiting state actions that endorse, benefit or advance religion, the clause has in recent decades been re-read in ways that permit, among other things, taxpayer financing of evangelical student newspapers and the construction of buildings at sectarian (mostly Christian) schools. This result has been accomplished by shifting the inquiry from the traditional establishment clause question - does this amount to government funding of religious activities? - to a free expression clause question - would denying the religious institution this benefit or subsidy be an unfair instance of viewpoint discrimination? By substituting the requirement of fairness for an investigation of a law's effects, the courts have moved dramatically away from James Madison's insistence that not even three pence of public funds should be spent for religious purposes and have rendered the establishment clause nugatory.Some of those who commented on the column attributed the pattern I described to the nefarious forces of organized religion or to the machinations of the Bush administration (always the default villain for Times readers), but a deeper explanation might be found in a religion-clause jurisprudence so fissured that one might even call it schizophrenic. The division is between two views of the assumptions that should be kept in mind when an establishment clause case or a free exercise case is being adjudicated. One view stresses history and cultural traditions; the other embraces the iron logic of principle.

Nothing warms the cockles of sports fans' hearts quite as much as a good controversy. When you have a controversy in politics, you can find yourself stuck in a war you don't know how to get out of. In sports, the stakes aren't nearly as high. Comparatively speaking, sports controversies are harmless. Did the ball hit the ground during the Immaculate Reception? Did Michael Jordan push off Bryon Russell during his famous N.B.A. title-winning shot over the Jazz? Did Don Denkinger really miss the call during the 1985 World Series that badly? We can debate them for decades, we'll never know the answer and it absolutely will not matter. If we had a definitive answer, that would be the end of the fun, and then we'd all be forced to pay attention to politics.

I ended up among the “true people” in a place called the “Belly Button of the World.”.

Popular routes from New York to Nairobi are through London on British Airways (www.ba.com) or through Amsterdam on Northwest/KLM (www.klm.com), each less than $1,600 round trip for tickets purchased a month in advance. The fare downtown runs around 1,000 Kenyan shillings (about $14, at 71 shillings to the dollar).
