To the Editor: Re ''Rejecting the Levy Way'' (editorial, March 11):

ENLOE--Emma. Our beloved mother and grandmother, Emma Bonnadell Clibourn Enloe, aged 90, died peacefully at her home in New York City, surrounded by family and friends, on March 15, 2007. Mrs. Enloe was born on her family's farm in Cole County, Missouri, where she grew up before graduating from Jefferson City High School. She worked for many years in the Missouri State Department of Revenue and later as an administrator at Charles E. Still Hospital. Mrs. Enloe was an active member of the First Baptist Church and a regular participant in local Democratic politics. She was born August 21, 1916, near Russellville, Missouri, a daughter of Charles Adolph and Estella Clilbourn, who predeceased her, as did her sister Margaret Clilbourn Pealer and her brother James Clibourn. Mrs. Enloe leaves a daughter, Sharon E. Baum, and a son, David H. Enloe, both of Manhattan, where Mrs. Enloe lived and worked for over 40 rears after joining her children there. She is also survived by two sons-in law, Stephen H. Baum and Ronald Harte, as well as a grandson, Benjamin Clibourn Baum and his wife Heather Gaillard of Minneapolis, and a second grandson, Samuel David Baum, of Los Angeles. A private funeral service was held yesterday at the Church of the Resurrection in Manhattan, with interment in a local New York City Cemetery. Her spirit of strength and determination will be an inspiration to all of us for the rest of our lives. The family requests that any donations be made to the First Baptist Church of Jefferson City Missouri or to Ms. Trudy Lampert, I Love Animals, 136 East 64th Street, New York, NY 10021.
MAUSNER--Marvin, died Tuesday, March 6th. Memorial service Sunday, April 15th, 6pm at the Central Unitarian Church of Paramus, NJ.

A picture caption last week with an article about a Web site for Chinese art students referred incorrectly to a work by Zhang Yue. It is a portrait of Yang Dan, not a self-portrait. (The image is from series in which the artist questions the notion of truth in self-portraiture.)

Suddenly, everything seemed oddly familiar in Albany, with the governor praising one house of the legislature while accusing the other of stalling. When there are three sources of power, as there are in New York State's lawmaking apparatus, it often comes down to two against one. And the only difference between this dynamic and any ordinary sandlot tussle is that the odd man out -- in this case, the Republican leader of the State Senate, Joseph Bruno -- is capable of making lots of mischief. Last week, lawmakers put forward their budget proposals so that there are now three budgets on the table. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has proposed a $120.6 billion budget. The Assembly calls for $121.2 billion in spending, and the Senate version is the fattest of all, which is odd coming from Republicans who usually boast about fiscal responsibility. Their budget tops out at over $123 billion.

The wealthiest people don't get that way from collecting payroll checks. A case in point is Warren E. Buffett, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, whose salary for 2006 was revealed last week in a regulatory filing. It was $100,000 -- just as it has been since 1980. (He made an additional $114,250 through serving on various boards.)

Even when skies are clear and the nation's air traffic control system is running perfectly, airlines have to contend with problems that cause delays. The 482 Boeing 737s that Southwest Airlines operates make about 3,200 flights a day. As at other airlines, something is always going wrong. In daily internal reports, Fred Taylor Jr., senior manager of proactive customer communications at Southwest, gives a lighthearted, at times sketchy recap of the operating mayhem that is airline routine. The reports are used by others at Southwest to explain delays to customers. Excerpts from December 2006: DEC. 9 -- Salt Lake City-to-Los Angeles flight took off and then returned after ''a rather large bird took the scenic route through the left engine.'' Inspection found no problem. Departed again 1 hour, 15 minutes late. DEC. 11 -- Chicago-to-Phoenix flight diverted to Denver for medical emergency. CPR was performed and the onboard defibrillator was used. New Orleans-to-Dallas flight lands with an ''unresponsive customer.'' ''Not sure if we got a deep sleeper, someone with an extreme hangover, or otherwise.'' DEC. 23 -- ''On a serious note,'' a Manchester-to-Baltimore flight ''had a customer pass away upon arrival.'' ''On a less serious note, the Burger King in the [Sacramento] airport had a grease fire causing a five-minute evacuation -- no fries, chips.'' (A spokeswoman for the Burger King outlet, Bryn Punt, said there was smoke but no fire.) DEC. 24 -- ''One woman was full of the Christmas spirit of peace and good will toward mankind, and while traveling,'' Phoenix-to-El Paso, ''she hit another woman. A nice way to spend Christmas Eve in the [El Paso] jail.'' DEC. 26 -- Phoenix-to-Reno flight hit ''severe turbulence on approach'' to Reno and diverted to Oakland. Three hours later, flight canceled and passengers bused to Reno. Two planes pushing back from the gates in San Diego bumped into each other. Both returned to the gates and passengers were put on other flights. ''Our folks are conducting an investigation and working with the'' National Transportation Safety Board. More excerpts are at nytimes.com/business.

PSEG Fossil, a subsidiary of the Public Service Energy Group, says it will spend more than $1 billion to clean up two coal-fired power plants, in Jersey City and Hamilton, to make them more environmentally sound. This follows a $6 million penalty that the federal Environmental Protection Agency levied against the utility in November for failure to comply with a 2002 order for the upgrades.

To the Editor: Re ''The Year of Hoping for Stage Magic'' [March 4]: In her article about turning ''The Year of Magical Thinking'' into a play, Joan Didion describes the first read-through ''with an actress sitting in a chair onstage.'' This was before Vanessa Redgrave signed on. I am thinking about that unnamed actress. She first voiced Joan Didion's words and captured her breath, but she is not dignified by name. The omission places her firmly within that working performer hell: Not Economically Viable.

Rona Shalev, a daughter of Diane Shalev and Isaac Shalev of New York, is to be married this afternoon to David Todd Kraut, the son of Deborah Schneider Kraut and Dr. Jeffrey A. Kraut of Santa Monica, Calif. Rabbi Marvin Tokayer is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanu-el in Closter, N.J. The bride, 30, is completing a postdoctoral fellowship in school psychology at the Orchard School in Yonkers, which is part of the Andrus Children's Center there, a mental health agency with a residential treatment center, outpatient clinics and community services. She graduated from Washington University in St. Louis and received a doctorate in school clinical psychology from Yeshiva University.

Adonal Foyle used the word ''we'' last week to talk about the United States and, for the first time, he could be accurate as well as proud. Born on the island of Canouan in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Foyle, who turns 32 tomorrow, became a United States citizen last Tuesday in San Francisco.

IT WAS JUST BAD P.R. The News -- Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales said on Tuesday that the dismissals of federal prosecutors had been badly handled but were not improper, and that he would not resign. Behind the News -- It can't be a good sign when your boss says publicly that he is ''frankly not happy'' about an embarrassing bungle of yours, as President Bush did on Wednesday. Congressional critics, unpersuaded that the dismissals were not a political purge, geared up later in the week to issue subpoenas, as pressure kept on mounting on Mr. Gonzales to step down. THE LENDER WAS SUBPRIME The News -- New Century Financial, the huge, struggling subprime mortgage lender, said in a regulatory filing Monday that its banks had frozen its credit lines. Trading in its stock was suspended, and investors rushed to sell shares of other financial companies, sending stock indexes tumbling. Behind the News -- New Century's once profitable, now risky strategy of lending to people with dicey credit has been coming apart for months as the housing market cooled, but Wall Street woke up late: just a day before it went into default, Morgan Stanley extended the company new credit. WISHES HE HADN'T TOLD The News -- Gen. Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs, said on Tuesday that he should not have discussed his view that homosexuality was immoral in an interview with The Chicago Tribune on Monday. Behind the News -- General Pace reignited debate about the military's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy, which bans openly gay people from the service but tolerates those who keep their homosexuality private. The general insisted he was only trying to support the policy; instead, he made himself a lightning rod for critics who say the policy stopped making sense long ago. KEEPING BAD COMPANY The News -- Chiquita Brands International, the fruit company, agreed on Wednesday to a $25 million fine to settle charges that it illegally paid a right-wing militia to protect its banana plantations in Colombia, and hid the payments on its books. Behind the News -- Much of the Colombian countryside is beyond government control, and it is not unusual for foreign companies operating there to buy protection from shady groups. But Chiquita executives ignored warnings from the company's own lawyers that it was improperly doing business with drug-dealing terrorists. THE SHOW CAN'T GO ON The News -- A concert by the Who in Tampa, Fla., on Tuesday ended halfway through the first song when Roger Daltrey, the lead singer, abruptly walked off. Behind the News -- Mr. Daltrey, 63, had taken the stage despite having bronchitis that left him barely able to talk, never mind sing in his usual leather-lunged style, as his surprised bandmate Pete Townshend told the crowd after walking off after him to find out what was wrong. Mr. Townshend announced that the show would be rescheduled for March 25. The song Mr. Daltrey couldn't finish? It was ''I Can't Explain.''

MURPHY--Edward L. of Garden City and McLean, VA, man of the world but always a New Yorker, died March 15, 2007. Loving husband of Eleanor, survived by Edward, Maryann, Francis and Laura, and many grandchildren. Wake Fairchild Sons 5-9PM March 19, funeral St. Joseph's 10AM March 20, both in Garden City.

CHESS--Stella. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of the New York University Child Study Center and the Bellevue Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry are saddened by the death of Stella Chess, M.D., the first Professor of Child Psychiatry at NYU. Dr. Chess created the legendary and pivotal New York Longitudinal Study, which delineated the crucial role of individual temperament in child development and ''goodness of fit'' between parent and child. Dr. Chess was a beloved and distinguished teacher and member of our faculty. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her children and grandchildren. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair; Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D., Director NYU Child Study Center

ORSECK--Jeffrey J., Attorney. Born March 6, 1947, passed away peacefully on March 15, 2007. Jeffrey Orseck spent his childhood in New York City and Harriman, NY, where his family owned several businesses including the legendary restaurant, Orseck Boys. He attended Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service in Washington, D.C., where he formed many notable associations including a close personal friendship with the future President of the United States William Jefferson Clinton. After earning his Bachelor of Science from Georgetown in 1969, he attended Fordham University School of Law in New York. In 1996, Mr. Orseck was honored to be appointed by President Clinton as a Diplomatic Envoy to oversee the transfer of the Panama Canal, a role in which he served with distinction. He will be remembered for his great character and wit. He was much loved by his family, honored by his colleagues and enjoyed by all of his friends. He will be missed. Mr. Orseck is survived by his sister Judy Katz, his sister-inlaw Joan Orseck, and their families. Funeral services will be held in Florida on Sunday, March 18, 2007. In lieu of flowers please send a donation to the Broward County Humane Society. Services by Menorah Gardens Funeral Chapels 954434-1531.

The old days don't look terribly good in Lionel Rogosin's narrative documentary ''ON THE BOWERY'' (1956), but they do look astonishing. A slice of down-and-out life, this black-and-white (and newly restored) portrait of lost New York tracks the arrival and rapid downward spiral of a young man (Ray Sayler), who lands on the Bowery with a suitcase and a deceitful thirst. He soon falls in with an old timer (an excellent Gorman Hendricks), whose face is creased with cunning and booze. A sympathetic view from the gutter, the film balances gritty documentation with obviously scripted interludes, affirming that the greatest nonfiction films aren't a question of nominal objectivity, but morality. Writing in The New York Times the indefatigable Bosley Crowther noted that the film had picked up awards abroad, at the Venice Film Festival and elsewhere, but complained: ''This is a dismal exposition to be charging people money to see. You can see the same thing in many places in this city without going too far from where you live. Indeed, it is merely a good montage of good photographs of drunks and bums, scrutinized and listened to ad nauseam. And we mean ad nauseam!'' Exactly! Justly nominated in 1957 for an Oscar for best documentary (Jerome Hill's ''Albert Schweitzer'' won), ''On the Bowery'' is a classic of its kind and a must-see for anyone who cherishes the old soul of New York. Mr. Rogosin, a onetime long-time owner of the great and greatly lamented Bleecker Street Cinema, died in 2000 at the age of 76. A retrospective of his films is certainly overdue. Friday through March 25, Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 505-5181.

Robin Marantz Henig's article (March 4) was a well-balanced essay on a profound topic, but she gives the impression that the scientists she met with view religion or faith as either adaptive or a ''by-product'' of adaptation. It can be both. The human mind is intensively self-aware, restless and always seeking explanations. But since we can't know everything, a natural by-product of our highly adaptive intelligence may be to devise supernatural explanations.
The Life's Work column in some editions last Sunday, about bringing dogs to the office, misspelled the breed of the writer's dog. It is a wheaten terrier, not a Wheaton.

To the Editor: I was moved by Michael Winerip's March 11 Parenting article, ''They'll Do It Themselves, Thanks,'' about the campaign of Jason Kingsley, Yaniv Gorodischer and Raymond Frost Jr., three men with Down syndrome, to obtain a sidewalk for their busy street in Greenburgh. The three young men deserve congratulations for their energetic efforts.

CAR trouble came naturally to our family. If we didn't quite invite it, we always made a place for it, expecting it and welcoming it. This is probably because my father never thought cars were anything you could much count on. You could depend on friends and family, possibly, and if material accessories were something you considered turning to, you might look to books or a decent fishing rod. But cars, no. He never did much to keep up the faux-woodie Country Squire, so when it got a flat, ran out of oil or started wheezing, it was just another sign of the innate frailty of the mechanical world. Whether he pulled over and called AAA or just kept puttering along, it was always with the same resigned acceptance. My 18-year-old son, Noel, is named for his grandfather. And though we didn't know this at the time we named him, he shares his grandfather's terseness, dry wit, laconic humor. Both also share a philosophical approach to things and the sense of equanimity that seems to spring from an ability to see life from all sides. It's a gift, to be sure, but one that can drive other people a little nuts. My father was a journalist, skilled in looking at things from all angles. ''He couldn't tell you what time it was without qualifying it,'' an exasperated friend of his once said. Likewise, even when Noel was young, he wasn't given much to direct answers. ''Is it blue?'' I might ask in a game of 20 questions. ''Some people might think so,'' he would reply.
''Why me?'' KATHARINE MOSER, who discovered she carries the gene for Huntington's disease, the incurable brain disorder. [1]

IN many ways, commuter railroads are a victim of their own success. Thanks to high gasoline prices, perpetually clogged highways and a strong economy, the three major commuter rail lines that serve the New York metropolitan area are handling more passengers than ever. Last year, ridership on New Jersey Transit trains jumped 6.8 percent, to 74 million, setting a record for the second consecutive year. Metro-North also hit a record last year, carrying 2.4 million additional riders. And the Long Island Rail Road, which saw a big decline in traffic after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, rose for the second straight year in 2006 after three years of decline.

To the Editor: Your March 11 editorial ''Fiasco in Brooklyn'' placed blame on a candidate while not acknowledging the role of two of the agencies overseeing the 40th District's special election: the Board of Elections, which placed candidates on the ballot who lived outside the district, and the City Council, which failed to anticipate the confusion over residency. While prior residency might have been best, residency status wasn't a secret to the voters on Election Day, and they chose accordingly, in a convincing fashion. The common-sense presumption: residency could be ''cured'' once the vote was known -- and before swearing-in.

The sound that defines Purdue basketball was heard early and often in their second-round matchup with top-seeded Florida Sunday. Purdue players dove on the floor four times in the first half to corral loose balls, and with each lunge came the distinct screech of skin meeting the hardwood floor. By controlling the tempo and outhustling Florida, Purdue managed to do today what few thought they could -- hang with Florida. But guts and hustle can only carry a team so far, and Florida overcame a 7-point first-half deficit to advance to the Round of 16 with a 74-67 victory. They will head to St. Louis to play Butler, the Midwest Region's No. 5 seed, on Friday.

It was a brazen defense, and in the end the jury didn't buy it. Andrew N. Yao, who was chief executive of the former Student Finance Corporation, claimed that he did not commit fraud when he lied in federal bankruptcy court about wiring $669,000 to his mistress at the time, a former Playboy Playmate of the Month. Though he initially said the money was for maintaining his private jets, he later acknowledged that it was for his girlfriend. But he said he wasn't trying to deceive his company's creditors or the court. He said he was lying only so that his family wouldn't find out about the affair.

CAHILL--Helen (nee Fitzsimmons), age 99, of New York City and East Hampton, Long Island died on March 14, after severe pneumonia. Widow of the late Robert Livingston Cahill, who died in 1984. Theirs was an idyllic marriage of 57 years. She is survived by their son, Robert L. Cahill, Jr. Their daughter Barbara Healey died in 1998. She leaves her sister Mrs. James (Eileen) Murray, her granddaughter, Robin Gibson and husband Gary Gibson, and her great-granddaughter Kaley Gibson. Predeceased by her sister Mrs. William (Mimi) Meehan and her brother Charles S. Fitzsimmons. Helen Cahill was the oldest living alumna of the Convent of The Sacred Heart in New York City. Mass of The Resurrection will be celebrated Tuesday, March 20 at 10:30 am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave and 76th St. A reception will follow at the community center of the church. The family will greet friends at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave and 81st St. Monday, March 19 from 5 to 8 pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcomed by the St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31st St. NY, NY 10001.
SCHWARTZ--Rosalie. Beloved ''YoYo'', my wonderful grandmother. 25 years seems like a moment when I think of your radiant smile and kindest of hearts. Andrew Cohen

If only for the sake of convenience, everyone likes to play in the backyard. Hence the history of plays and musicals about the dramas that unfold when the curtain falls. Backstage stories are front and center this week, as two major openings pay tribute to the blood, sweat and greasepaint-tinged tears of the theatrical life. For his new comedy opening at Manhattan Theater Club, CHARLES BUSCH turned to a woman who rated a footnote in American history, not just theatrical annals. Laura Keene was an actress and manager whose path intersected with Abraham Lincoln's on a most unfortunate night for him. Keene was onstage at Ford's Theater in ''Our American Cousin,'' when Lincoln was felled by John Wilkes Booth. Mr. Busch's reverence for the gritty lives and sublime artistry of great actresses has informed his career as a playwright and actor. Reading history one day he got to wondering about the fate of the footnote. ''OUR LEADING LADY,'' which stars KATE MULGREW as Keene, mixes fact and fancy in imagining what went on backstage on that epochal evening. Opens Tuesday, City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212 or nycitycenter.org; $50. Funnily enough, murder most foul -- albeit fictional -- also plays a leading role in ''CURTAINS,'' the new musical starring DAVID HYDE PIERCE as a detective called in to investigate when backstage backstabbing becomes peculiarly vehement. Set in Boston in the 1959, where a troubled musical is trying out, ''Curtains'' won cheerful reviews at its own tryout last summer in Los Angeles. A mix of comedy, mystery and music, ''Curtains'' is particularly anticipated as a last encore for JOHN KANDER AND FRED EBB, the songwriting team whose careers were burnished anew by the recent revivals of ''Chicago'' and ''Cabaret.'' Their fruitful partnerships ended when Ebb died in 2004. Opens Thursday, Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200 or telecharge.com; $61.50 to $111.60.

To the Editor: The cover story ''Patagonia in a New Light'' (March 4) undervalues scientists' views on climate change and glacial retreat a bit too much and too often. Having never visited Patagonia before, perhaps the glacial retreat situation there wasn't very obvious to the writer. He might want to consider other sites in the Andes, such as Peru's Quelccaya ice cap, where land beneath the glacier has been exposed for the first time in at least 5,000 years, and where the melting has accelerated in the last 30 years to the point that thousands of years of ice could disappear within just a few years.

DALLAS List price: $949,000 Bedrooms: 4 Bathrooms: 3.5 Interior: 4,250 sq. ft. List price: $995,000 Bedrooms: 3 Bathrooms: 3 Interior: 2,600 sq. ft. The town of Del Norte (population 1,700) is a half mile away. MONTREAL List price: about $1,030,000 Bedrooms: 5 Bathrooms: 3.5 Interior size: 3,000 sq. ft. List price: $1,049,900 Bedrooms: 3 Bathrooms: 2.5 Interior: 2,950 sq. ft. Lot size: 0.33 acre Date built: 2002 Nestled on a ridge that provides clear views of red-rock buttes, this contemporary Santa Fe-style home offers several distinctive touches -- including a foyer with 15-foot ceilings, art niches, a dumbwaiter and a covered rear patio with a built-in barbecue. There are three golf courses and several hiking trails nearby. The whirlpool tub in the master bathroom offers a view of Courthouse Butte. TOWN AND COUNTRY, MO. List price: $995,000 Bedrooms: 5 Bathrooms: 6 Interior: 5,000 sq. ft. Lot size: 1 acre Date built: 1984 Set in a St. Louis suburb, this home sits at the end of a quiet cul-de-sac but is only a two-minute drive from I-64, the city's major thoroughfare. The home has four fireplaces, high ceilings, a four-car garage and an eat-in kitchen with a double-sided island. It's a short drive to Queeny County Park with its Olympic-size swimming pool, running trails and ice-skating rink. SCARSDALE, N.Y. List price: $995,000 Bedrooms: 4 Bathrooms: 2 Interior: 2,200 sq. ft. Lot size: 0.13 acre Date built: 1917 Set on a cul-de-sac, this colonial-style stucco house is just three blocks from the Metro-North station, with only a 40-minute ride into Midtown Manhattan. Recent renovations include a new roof, fresh exterior and interior paint and a new staircase. There is a private playground in the backyard, surrounded by a fence and shrubbery. SAVANNAH, GA. List price: $989,000 Bedrooms: 4 Bathrooms: 4.5 Interior: 4,500 sq. ft. Lot size: 0.9 acre Date built: 1995 This modern estate sits in a gated community of 500 homes surrounded on all sides by water and accessible only by a private causeway. The house's 20-by-24-foot master suite has a screened-in porch and a fireplace. There is a two-car attached garage and a two-car detached garage with a workout room, a greenhouse and changing rooms for an in-ground pool. Community tennis courts are within walking distance. SILVER SPRING, MD. List price: $995,000 Bedrooms: 5 Bathrooms: 4 full + 2 half Interior: 5,000 sq. ft. Lot size: 0.19 acre Date built: circa 1893 This idiosyncratic Victorian home was literally falling apart three years ago, and many neighborhood residents assumed it would be demolished. But a local developer decided to rescue it and spent about $800,000 on a thorough renovation. Eleven of the original windows were saved, as well as other authentic touches like the reclaimed heart-pine floors and tin-roof overhangs above the two porches, while modern conveniences like gas fireplaces were added. CHICAGO List price: $995,000 Bedrooms: 5 Bathrooms: 4.5 Interior: 3,700 sq. ft. Lot size: 22 by 150 feet Date built: 1890 This gray-stone row house is located in Hyde Park, a short walk from the University of Chicago. Many homes in Hyde Park, once one of the city's wealthiest neighborhoods, were subdivided into apartments during and after World War II, but this house remained intact. It retains its original woodwork and high ceilings. The house also has five fireplaces and a spacious one-car garage. FORT LAUDERDALE, FLA. List price: $999,000 Bedrooms: 3 Bathrooms: 3.5 Interior: 2,600 sq. ft. Lot Size: n.a. List price: $950,000 Bedrooms: 3 Bathrooms: 2.5 Interior: 2,000 sq. ft. Lot size: 0.15 acre Date built: 1882 This home in an upscale neighborhood known as the Western Promenade was built as a carriage house for a larger estate. During a recent renovation, the original slate roof was restored and a local blacksmith refurbished the original wrought-iron fence and gates. The house has been equipped with high-end modern amenities, including surround-sound audio capacity wired directly into the walls, but the hardwood floors and cast-bronze door latches help retain a historic feel. DR. ALAN ROSS did not develop a passion for school bus safety until 10 years ago, when his son asked why there were no safety belts on the bus he rode to school in Litchfield County, Conn. ''I was your typical parent, and I just assumed we had this covered in a school bus,'' said Dr. Ross, who is now the president of the National Coalition for School Bus Safety, a volunteer group. ''That started my quest to improve things. The state of school bus transportation is a very sad one.''

HAHN--Elizabeth Harris. October 13, 1916 to March 13, 2007. Elizabeth ''Betty'' Hahn, passed away of natural causes. Born in Bronxville, NY to Isaac F. and Elizabeth H Harris. Growing up in Tuckhoe and Rye. She married and moved to Kansas City Idaho Falls, Berkley, then Sacramento. She spent her working years teaching the deaf. Divorced years ago she is survived my numerous nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers please send donations to The Parodi Trust Fund for the Deaf 39350 Gallaudet Dr., Freemont, CA 94538.

Thanks to Alexandra Jacobs for her exposé of college pornography (March 4). She's reminding parents why it's so important to research where you want to spend $100,000 or more for your kid's higher education. Fortunately, we uptight parents also have tools of technology to click on college Web sites, peruse course catalogs, look up faculty and their publications and sort through college newspapers (a great place to get the ''feel'' of a school).

He was a devoted husband to Edythe Werner, a loving father to Karen Abrahamson, Marilynn and Kenneth Hopman and Laurie Greenberg, a proud grandfather of Ember and Kevin Newell, Aileah and Joe Slepski and Victor Hopman. Box 266, Rhinebeck, NY 12572, National World War II Museum, 954 Magazine St., New Orleans, LA 70130 or a charity of your choice.

SAT scores included in the New Jersey School Report Card this year were inaccurate because of a computer problem, the State Department of Education said last week. But students and parents have little to worry about, said Jon Zlock, a spokesman for the department. Colleges and universities will receive the correct test scores with students' applications; the score inaccuracies are only within the state system.

123 Norma Road, Harrington Park, N.J. Midcentury modern, 4-bedroom house (1969-1977) My family integrated the neighborhood. My parents were among the earliest black executives at I.B.M., and they moved to northern New Jersey for work. The real estate agent said the house had been sold, which it hadn't. They confronted him. There was actually a melee. My father used to joke we were like the four raisins living in a tub of vanilla ice cream. But despite the trouble we had getting in, it turned out to be a very supportive community. 11 Parkhill Road, Harrington Park, N.J. Three-story converted barn with sauna (1977-1991) The house was a dramatic change. It was a gorgeous modern structure; it had a spiral staircase; there was an island in the kitchen. My father fought my mother to buy it, even though it was a financial stretch. It signified how far he had come from the segregated South. 35 Campus Drive, Palo Alto, Calif. 24-hour counseling center (1989-1990) My junior year at Stanford University, I lived in a tiny room in the back of the Bridge, an organization that did crisis counseling. I was one of five leaders there. It was the first time I dealt with staffers, budgets, fund-raising, communications. It was my first training as an executive. Queen's College, Oxford, England One-bedroom in 300-year-old dorm (1993-1994) I was on the second floor of this ancient college, with a beautiful sitting area, washroom and bedroom. They didn't have showers, just tubs. I met people there from New Zealand, Nigeria, all over the world, and I saw some of America's weaknesses through their eyes. I came away loving my country more deeply than before, but in a mature, textured way. 685 Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, Newark, N.J. Two-bedroom apartment in affordable- housing development (1998-2006) During Yale Law School, I moved to Newark. I lived in Brick Towers, a housing development in the Central Ward. The rent was $575 a month. It was a violent area. There was a crack house across the street. The heat stopped working. Hot water was rare. The elevators only worked when they wanted to. We fought a big battle against the landlord, and we got the buildings handed over to the federal government. 435 Hawthorne Avenue, Newark, N.J. Three-bedroom apartment in a townhouse (2006-present) The beauty of this place is that it has hot water every day. It is nice and spacious. The rent is $1,200 a month. I have a bedroom, an office and a workout room. But this is the South Ward. There are drug and crime issues. There have been shootings. Now as mayor my responsibility is to keep every neighborhood safe in the city. I want to be in the midst of it. Unfortunately, I have had death threats, so I have security all the time.
ABBIE IVES was 5, and skating on a local pond with her father, when she pointed toward a bunch of teenage boys racing back and forth and asked, ''Dad, what's that?'' ''Hockey,'' her father answered.

SCHLESINGER--Arthur M., Jr., 89. Husband of Alexandra, father of Stephen, Katharine, Christina, Andrew, Robert and Peter; adoring grandfather of Hugh, Sarah and Chun. Professor and student of history, distinguished author, public servant, activist and incandescent personality, he will be greatly missed. Memorial services will be at the Cooper Union on Cooper Square at 10:30am on April 23. Charitable donations in his name can be directed to the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, 10 Garden Street, Cambridge, MA 02138 (should include ''Arthur Schlesinger memorial''); or to the Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr. Award in American History at the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute, 4079 Albany Post Road, Hyde Park, NY 12538.

To the Editor: I respectfully disagree with some elements of your editorial about the practice of eminent domain (''Don't Cripple Eminent Domain,'' March 11). It is my view that unless in the rarest of circumstances, eminent domain should not be used. A vital part of the American dream is land ownership, and while redevelopment of our cities is important, it pales in comparison to the right of individuals to keep their land until they, not government officials, see fit. Steven M. Clayton Ocean

To the Editor: Pay raises are long overdue for New York's judiciary, which has maintained its longstanding excellence even in the face of staggering caseloads and increasingly complex legal issues (''Upgrading New York's Courts,'' editorial, March 11). The continuing failure to provide judicial salary increases is simply unwise public policy.

GURFEIN--Jay J., passed peacefully in his sleep March 9, 2007. Our mighty oak has fallen, but his spirit lingers on. Jay enriched all who knew him, lovingly sharing his knowledge and wit. He had an elegant presence and great love of family, giving pleasure wherever he walked. Very charismatic, filled with high energy and joy of life. The legal profession has lost one of its eagles. He will be missed by all those he touched. Beloved husband of Maggie, loving father to Michelle, Robin, Jim, and the departed Doug. Fun loving grandfather to Jackson, Dillon and Cameron. Son-in-law to Randy and Josh, sister-inlaw to Ginger and Linda, brother-in-law to Joe and Al, wonderful brother to Helene. You will never leave our hearts.

STICKNEY--Mori, 87, died on February 20, 2007, in Glen Ridge, NJ. Mori was a prolific poet, and she inspired all who knew her with he spirit of aliveness. A memorial service with jazz pianist Barry Harris will be held Sunday, April 1st, at 7:30 pm at St. Peter's Church, 54th and Lexington, NYC.

North Korea sent mixed signals on its nuclear disarmament plans on Saturday, claiming that it had begun preparations to shut down its main facility for making nuclear fuel but also that it would not take action unless it received all the money frozen when the United States slapped financial penalties on a Macao bank. As a new round of nuclear talks was scheduled to get under way in Beijing on Monday, Kim Kye-gwan, North Korea's envoy, said the country ''will not stop its nuclear activity'' until its full $25 million at Banco Delta Asia in Macao is returned. The United States maintains that the return of the money is now up to banking officials in Macao, a Chinese territory.

LIEBMAN--Alan. Our beloved friend and neighbor, Alan Liebman, was the president of our co-op board for many years. Alan loved our community and worked with enormous energy on our behalf. It's hard to imagine our building without him. Our thoughts are with Rosalie, Georgia and Mariel. We share their grief and loss. The residents of 300 West End Ave. $(6$)LIEBMAN--Alan S. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Graubard Miller greatly mourn the passing of our esteemed counsel, Alan S. Liebman. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Rosalie, and his daughters, Georgia and Mariel, of whom Alan constantly spoke with enormous love and admiration. We will greatly miss his indomitable spirit, friendship, wise counsel and, most of all, his inspiring example of how to carry on with grace, determination, courage and wit in the face of great obstacles. Graubard Miller $(6$)LIEBMAN--Alan S. Your courage and strength continually amazed us, particularly these last three years. We will always be there for your beloved girls, Rosalie, Georgia and Mariel. Rest in peace, dear friend. Kleiner and Rippe Families $(6$)LIEBMAN--Alan, a good friend... a good partner... a bear of a man... we will miss him. Our prayers and thoughts are with Rosalie, Georgia and Marielle. Les and Maddy Cohn Jeff and Janice Rodner

To the Editor: Re ''One Bullet Away From What?'' (Week in Review, March 11): The Taliban and Al Qaeda are killings our citizens and soldiers and nearly assassinated Pakistan's president and prime minister. So how can our intelligence agency ''play a direct role in arming and financing'' the Taliban?

To the Sports Editor: The context of a sporting event is not a reason to turn a blind eye to a pure and simple assault. Chris Simon of the Islanders was hit by a clean check. He later chose to launch a completely unwarranted assault on the other player with a weapon (his hockey stick ) to his face. The N.H.L. has consistently sent ridiculous messages to its players, wrist slaps at best.

To the Editor: ''Rooms With a View: Street Theater at the Pull of a Curtain'' (Journeys, Feb. 25) made me wistful for the apartment my husband and I shared in Rome from 2001 to 2003. We passed on a two-bedroom place with a view of Palatine Hill for a one-bedroom studio in Trastevere. This fourth-floor walk-up didn't look out onto the domed city either, but onto a courtyard with a bird's eye view of our neighbors' terraces.

A jury in Wilmington, Del., heard arguments from prosecutors last week that James Cooke Jr. deserves to be executed for the murder of Lindsey Bonistall, a college student from White Plains. The jury convicted Mr. Cooke of first-degree murder on March 8. Ms. Bonistall was a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of Delaware when she was killed. Prosecutors said that on May 1, 2005, Mr. Cooke broke into her off-campus apartment, raped and strangled her, then set the apartment on fire to cover his crime.

BARBER--Irene, on March 17, 2007 beloved wife of the late Daniel M., loving mother of Fern Wides, cherished grandmother of Sean and Bradley. Services Sunday from Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. For information call 516-295-3100.
TAFTI--Joan Ph.D. 2/3/60-3/19/06. Psychologist, mother, wife and friend who brought out the best in everyone. Love always, Ariana & Peter

To the Editor: Re ''Local Rule,'' by William Ouchi (Op-Ed, March 11), about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's latest proposed reforms of the New York City school system: I would direct readers to The Times's Jan. 28 editorial ''New York's Public Schools,'' which observed that the reforms potentially undermine successful schools, deprive principals of necessary support services, and rush into action budgetary reallocations whose consequences have not been fully considered by the administration or aired before the public.

To the Editor: I have taken my dog to Coindre Hall Park (''Living the Good Life, Off the Leash,'' March 4) for many years. We are harassed and ticketed. Now the parks department wants to force us to accept a 1.5-acre dog park that no one thinks is in a good location -- dog owners and non dog owners alike. Michael Marcotte Huntington

BROWN--David A., ''Gaga'', 92, died peacefully on March 12. His life was devoted to family, art, and a just society. He leaves his wife Amy, his children Susan, of Los Angeles, Rick and Liz, of New York City, six grandchildren, two great-grandchildren, and a sister, Betty.

Because of a production error, a map with an article last Sunday in T: Men's Fashion magazine, about restaurants, stores and other businesses in the Central district of Hong Kong, incorrectly located all of the businesses in the area. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/magazine.
To the Editor: Re ''Paying a Price to Conserve Energy'' (March 11):

To the Editor: I thought that ''Boulder, Colo.: Fine Dining With a Hippie Past'' (Surfacing, Feb. 25) was misinformed and misleading. I grew up in Boulder, and my family was and still is actively involved in the local food community. I pride myself on having grown up with a sense of gourmet food. and we certainly frequented diverse restaurants on a weekly basis -- none of which I can recall serving ''mush like overcooked lentils and brown rice.'' That statement, in my opinion, is insulting to longstanding Boulder establishments. If the reporter had done proper research instead of making bold generalized statements, she would have come across restaurants like Laudisio, Pasta Jay's, John's, Mediterranean, Orchid Pavilion, 14th St. Bar and Grill, the Greenbriar Inn, Flagstaff House and Lucile's.

A picture caption in the Calendar last week about a benefit concert today at the College of New Jersey in Ewing Township misdentified the performer shown. The photograph was of Sara Hickman, one of the scheduled performers -- not Lisa Bouchelle, who is opening the benefit event.

GENOVESE--Thomas Leonardo, a resident of Hilton Head Island, SC for over 12 years, passed away Tuesday, February 20, 2007 at his home. Born February 28, 1936 in Flushing, NY; he was the son of Jean Lundari and Robert P. S. Genovese. He was a graduate of The University of Virginia and Fordham Law School. After a career of many years, he was retired in 1994 from Grumman Corporation as Vice President, General Counsel. Surviving is his beloved wife, Linda LeMaire Genovese of Hilton Head Island, SC; his loving children, Torene Genovese David of Guatemala, Andrea Genovese-Candela of New Hyde Park, NY and Richard Crane of Charlotte, NC as well as seven grandchildren. He is also survived by his two brothers, Robert and Lawrence. Tom was dearly loved and will be greatly missed by his family and all who knew him.

The N.C.A.A. tournament was supposed to be a showcase for Acie Law IV, a silky-smooth senior point guard who led a hard-nosed Texas A&M team to 26 victories and newfound respect in basketball circles this season. They call him Mr. Clutch in Texas, and after he demonstrated why in the closing seconds here against Louisville, the third-seeded Aggies are returning to the Lone Star State and to the N.C.A.A. men's tournament's Round of 16 for the first time since 1980.

FRANCO--Anthony, on March 16, 2007. The longterm resident of Mamaroneck, NY arrived in Chicago from Italy in 1963. His brilliance and passion gave him the strength and vision to learn English and start an incredible career that saw him from the mail room at First Chicago to being one of its V.P. He later joined Banca Popolare di Milano as President and made it a great Italian presence in the U.S. He was magnanimous in his love and his spirit lives on through the many lives he touched. Many were blessed to have him as a father figure. Beloved husband to Sylvi, cherished father to Christina, Michele and Anthony, loving stepfather to Kara, proud and adoring grandfather to Anthony, Damian, Zach, Grant and Alex. Dear brother to Rita, Raffaelle and Aldo. Caring uncle to Vincenzo and Dina. Funeral services will be held at St. Augustine's Church in Larchmont, NY on Saturday, March 24th, at 10 am. Donations in his name can be made to the Eleanor and Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Research Center at Columbia University. 710 West 168th St., New York, NY 10032.

KUHN--Bowie K., age 80, former Commissioner of Baseball, died March 15th, 2007 of respiratory failure after a short illness at St. Luke's Hospital in Jacksonville, FL. Born in 1926 in Tacoma Park, Maryland, Kuhn graduated from Princeton University in 1948 after serving in the US Navy and then earned a legal degree from the University of Virginia. He joined the New York law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher where he represented Baseball's National League. A lifelong baseball fan, in 1969 Kuhn became Commissioner of Baseball, a position he would hold until 1984. Kuhn and his wife Luisa relocated to Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida in 1990, where he continued his many charitable and philanthropic activities. He served on numerous boards for many prominent corporations, hospitals, universities and foundations including the Baseball Hall of Fame and the Ave Maria Foundation. A dedicated Roman Catholic, Kuhn was a Knight of Malta and a founding member of Legatus. In his later years, he was particularly involved with numerous Catholic organizations and charities for which he worked tirelessly. He is survived by his beloved wife of 50 years, Luisa; his four children and 10 grandchildren. He will be greatly missed by his family and his many friends and colleagues. Visitation will be held Monday, March 19th from 5pm-8pm at QuinnShalz Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 1:00pm, Tuesday, March 20 at Our Lady Star of the Sea Catholic Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. A Memorial Mass also will be held in the spring at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Quiogue, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Ave Maria Foundation.

Suddenly, everything seemed oddly familiar in Albany, with the governor praising one house of the legislature while accusing the other of stalling. When there are three sources of power, as there are in New York State's lawmaking apparatus, it often comes down to two against one. And the only difference between this dynamic and any ordinary sandlot tussle is that the odd man out -- in this case, the Republican leader of the State Senate, Joseph Bruno -- is capable of making lots of mischief. Last week, lawmakers put forward their budget proposals so that there are now three budgets on the table. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has proposed a $120.6 billion budget. The Assembly calls for $121.2 billion in spending, and the Senate version is the fattest of all, which is odd coming from Republicans who usually boast about fiscal responsibility. Their budget tops out at over $123 billion.

To the Sports Editor: The N.C.A.A. men's Division I basketball tournament: 3 weeks, 65 teams, 64 games and 1 national champion. Could someone please explain to me again why the N.C.A.A. can't see fit to hold a Division I football playoff? Jeremy Sheaffer Hallowell, Me.

A soaring slam, bruising blocks, rising tempers and dueling technicals. Who knew an old-fashioned Big East bash would break out in the middle of the N.C.A.A. tournament? Georgetown and Boston College, the Big East original that left for the Atlantic Coast Conference two years ago, became reacquainted Saturday in the second round of the East Region at Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum. The match produced an early tournament classic.

CAR trouble came naturally to our family. If we didn't quite invite it, we always made a place for it, expecting it and welcoming it. This is probably because my father never thought cars were anything you could much count on. You could depend on friends and family, possibly, and if material accessories were something you considered turning to, you might look to books or a decent fishing rod. But cars, no. He never did much to keep up the faux-woodie Country Squire, so when it got a flat, ran out of oil or started wheezing, it was just another sign of the innate frailty of the mechanical world. Whether he pulled over and called AAA or just kept puttering along, it was always with the same resigned acceptance. My 18-year-old son, Noel, is named for his grandfather. And though we didn't know this at the time we named him, he shares his grandfather's terseness, dry wit, laconic humor. Both also share a philosophical approach to things and the sense of equanimity that seems to spring from an ability to see life from all sides. It's a gift, to be sure, but one that can drive other people a little nuts. My father was a journalist, skilled in looking at things from all angles. ''He couldn't tell you what time it was without qualifying it,'' an exasperated friend of his once said. Likewise, even when Noel was young, he wasn't given much to direct answers. ''Is it blue?'' I might ask in a game of 20 questions. ''Some people might think so,'' he would reply.

GREENE--Norma. Maimonides Medical Center mourns the passing of our dear friend Norma Greene, an esteemed Honorary Board Member and longstanding contributor to the medical center. Norma served as President of the Maimonides Women's Auxiliary for 26 years, led a dedicated group of volunteers, and was recognized for spearheading the library and newborn photography programs. She brought warmth and style to everything she did. She will be sorely missed. Her contributions to the Maimonides community will forever be appreciated. Our deep condolences to her family. Martin D. Payson, Chair, Board of Trustees; Pamela S. Brier, President and CEO, Maimonides Medical Center
NOVAK--Milton. Devoted husband of Shirley, loving father of David and Adele, Debbie and Amy, dear grandpa of Elena and beloved teacher. Memorial service to be announced.

A Dobbs Ferry man is suing the village after its Board of Trustees voted last week to block a referendum on changing the date of local elections to March from November. The referendum had been approved by the village clerk. The suit is the latest move in a politically charged saga that has pitted town Democrats against members of a splinter faction, the Dobbs Ferry Party. Three years ago, after the Dobbs Ferry Party took control of the village government, Democrats forced a referendum that changed the date of local elections to November, putting them on the same ballot as state and national races. After the date change, Democrats regained their majority on the town's seven-member Board of Trustees.
Chapter 23

Schumann: Symphonies Nos. 2, 4 Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, conducted by Riccardo Chailly. Decca 475 835-2; CD. EUGENE ORMANDY, a conductor known for malapropic pronouncements at rehearsals of the Philadelphia Orchestra, once said (more or less), ''Stravinsky wanted it like this, but he's dead, poor man, so let's do it my way.'' The idea of sacred texts has had a friend in the early-music movement, but with varying stealth, conductors have been doing it ''their way'' for a long time. Mahler, for one, felt no shame in ''improving'' Schumann's Second and Fourth Symphonies, and his retouchings come to us from Riccardo Chailly and the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra.

INTERNATIONAL 3-18 Shifting Focus in Baghdad Plan Deadly attacks by Sunni Arab militants have emerged as a major threat to the Baghdad security plan during the early weeks of the operation, prompting American commanders to focus on their bomb factories on the outskirts of the capital, military officials said. 1 Three suicide bombers driving trucks loaded with explosives and tanks of chlorine gas detonated their payloads in Anbar Province, killing at least two Iraqi police officers and wounding or sickening more than 350 people, the American military command said. 16 Palestinians' Unity Government The Palestinian legislature ratified a new national unity government by a show of hands, but the cracks were already apparent in the celebratory speeches given by the president and the prime minister. 4 Sudanese Refugees in Israel Some of the 300 Sudanese who were detained in Israel in 2005 after illegally entering from Egypt, where they were denied asylum, are beginning to be released to collective farms while their official refugee status can be determined. 3 Poisoning Mystery Deepens A new account in the mysterious poisoning death of a former K.G.B. agent in London further clouds an already murky case and suggests that sorting out the truth may ultimately be impossible, given the complex associations binding Russia to its exiles in London. 6 Oil Giant Hunts for Alternatives Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, the fourth-largest exporter of oil in the world with about 10 percent of the known reserves, is spending millions of dollars in an effort to become a center for the development and the implementation of clean-energy technology. 14 NATIONAL 20-27 Vietnam Haunts Iraq Debate Memories of Vietnam haunt the public debate on the war in Iraq. They also lurk in the private thoughts of a generation in Congress: men like Senators Chuck Hagel and John McCain, who lived through the earlier war, vote on the current one and, despite their shared past, now disagree profoundly on what the United States should do next. 1 A Divide on Speech Case A Supreme Court case about the free-speech rights of high school students has opened an unexpected fissure between the Bush administration and its usual allies on the religious right. As the stakes have grown higher, a case that once looked like an easy victory for the government side may prove to be a much closer call. 22 NEW YORK/REGION 29-33 Funeral for Auxiliary Officer Auxiliary Officer Nicholas T. Pekearo, one of two volunteer police officers killed last week after confronting a gunman , was given the formal funeral rites of a full-fledged police officer. 31 Chess 33 Obituaries 35 Weather 36

Mendelssohn: Violin Concerto; Bruch: Violin Concerto No. 1, Romance in F Janine Jansen, violinist, violist; Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, conducted by Riccardo Chailly. Decca B0007260-02; CD. JANINE JANSEN'S first recording, a vibrant chamber-scale account of Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons,'' was remarked on as much for its cover art -- a reclining Ms. Jansen in a gauzy, low-cut dress, dangling her violin over the arm of a chair -- as for the playing. Had the performance been less striking, that would have been that. But this young Dutch violinist proved a lively, imaginative interpreter with a strong technique and a sweet, rich tone. Now she has jumped to the heart of the Romantic concerto repertory, where those assets play on a larger stage and under a brighter spotlight.

To the Editor: In 15 chapters and 501 well-annotated pages, my book ''Medical Apartheid'' offers a careful, nuanced discussion of trends, cases, problems, ethics and persistent patterns in the disparate treatment of black research subjects. However, Ezekiel Emanuel's review (Feb. 18) ignores its rich content in order to claim that ''Medical Apartheid'' fails to place the experience of African-Americans in context. He dramatically misrepresents the work within an untrustworthy review that is rife with distortions, contradictions, errors, exaggerations and confusions.

Bonnie Diane Kerker, an epidemiologist, was married in New York last evening to Peter Joseph Ephross. Rabbi Andrew Bachman officiated at the Central Park Boathouse. The bride, 38, is keeping her name. She is the assistant commissioner of epidemiology services at the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. From August 1990 to October 1992, she served as a community education volunteer in the Peace Corps in San Juan de la Maguana, Dominican Republic. Ms. Kerker graduated from Tufts University and has two degrees in public health, a master's and a Ph.D., from Yale.

EAST Among the three overtime games yesterday, the No. 6 seed Vanderbilt played the longest, winning in double overtime. The Commodores will be joined in East Rutherford, N.J., by top-seeded North Carolina and No. 2 Georgetown. MIDWEST Fifth-seeded Butler reached the Round of 16 for the second time in four years. SOUTH With its 19th consecutive win, Ohio State reached the Round of 16 for the first time since 1999. After beating Louisville in Kentucky, Texas A&M will have the home-court advantage in the next round, which will be played in San Antonio. WEST Virginia Commonwealth's moment in the spotlight came to an end with an overtime loss to third-seeded Pittsburgh. The Panthers will face their former coach, U.C.L.A's Ben Howland, in their Round of 16 game next week in San Jose, Calif.

The Tennessee bench screamed, ''Foul him!'' In Nationwide Arena, where the Ohio State Buckeyes play some of their games, the Volunteers feared an Ohio State moment was coming. Virginia guard Sean Singletary weaved quickly up floor, his team down by 3 points with less than five seconds remaining. Singletary launched a 3-pointer and Tennessee held its breath.

To the Editor: Regarding the In Transit item on the new glass walkway over the Grand Canyon (March 4): I hope the great spirit in the sky -- the source of American Indian respect for Mother Nature -- failed to influence the Hualapai Indians to build their walkway, say, outside of Las Vegas. Please don't let me read again about the despoiling of nature in the name of making money. What's next? A McDonald's made out of native materials at the walkway's exit? Bob Rosen New York

To the Editor: Re ''Paying a Price to Conserve Energy'' (March 11): Problems with the shift to daylight saving time -- and with the shift of that shift to earlier in the year -- have everything to do with the biannual change and nothing at all to do with the relative timing of darkness and daylight.

An article last Sunday about ''The Earrings of Madame de ,'' a film based on a novel by Louise de Vilmorin, referred incorrectly to the writer's father. He was a botanist who helped run the French horticultural house Vilmorin-Andrieux; he was not a furniture manufacturer. Also, the article referred incorrectly to the career of Danielle Darrieux, one of the stars of the film. She appeared in a few films during World War II; she did not sit out the Occupation.
In ''The Pleasures of Circulating -- Thinking On Foot,'' Willard Spiegelman, writing in In Character, makes a case for pedestrianism as the poetry of a city's experience.

An article last Sunday about the dance-theater work ''Edward Scissorhands'' transposed the physical descriptions and backgrounds of the two men who alternate in the title role. Sam Archer is the harlequinesque dancer who was trained in musical theater, while Richard Winsor is the taller, heavier-boned dancer who was trained in ballet.

To the Editor: Your March 11 editorial ''When Words Collide'' concerns three juniors at John Jay High School in Cross River who ''got in trouble for saying the word 'vagina' at a school function after faculty members told them not to.''

EDELMAN--Barry. His accomplishments and pleasures were many and wideranging: father, businessman, world traveler, and joyful fan of the fabulous, but his true genius was for loving kindness. He was greatly loved in return, and his sudden death leaves gaping holes in so many lives. Long may he live in our hearts and memories; we are better people for having known him, and blessed to have called him nephew and cousin. The Wollman/Rubin/ Berkowitz Family

''VAN GOGH AND EXPRESSIONISM'' at the Neue Galerie traces his influence on German and Austrian Expressionist artists like Gustav Klimt, Egon Schiele and Otto Dix. The show includes masterworks like van Gogh's celebrated 1889 self-portrait and unexpected discoveries like Schiele's ''Artist's Bedroom in Neulengbach'' (1911). But its interest lies in its ability to uncover the hidden threads that bind one of the most studied artists in European history to a younger generation bent on pushing the boundaries of modernism further. Through July 2, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, neuegalerie.org. Feminist art is a slippery term. What does it mean today? The Brooklyn Museum sets out to give the notion form with ''GLOBAL FEMINISMS,'' the first exhibition dedicated to feminist artists from 1990 to the present. The show throws together a wide range of artistic approaches, from video installations to sculpture, painting, photography and performance art. More important is its global scope, which draws on artists like Lee Bul of Korea, Julia Loktev of Russia and Boryana Rossi of Bulgaria, as well as more familiar American and European names. Through July 1, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, brooklynmuseum.org. In a world where a new art fair seems to be born every day THE INTERNATIONAL ASIAN ART FAIR has a dusty Old World charm. And although that can mean that the displays have begun to feel more predictable over the years, it also means blue-chip dealers with some whopping good works of art. Perennial highlights include the Nancy Wiener Gallery. Friday through March 28, Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue, at 67th Street, haughton.com; $20.

8 P.M. (National Geographic) GALÁPAGOS -- Until a few centuries ago, this isolated archipelago -- 13 major volcanic islands, 6 smaller islands and 107 rocks and islets -- off the coast of Ecuador remained a mystery to much of the world. Then a visit to the pristine islands, and their vast number of endemic species (like these masked boobies, above), in 1835 inspired Charles Darwin to come up with his theory of evolution by natural selection. Today the Galápagos' rich environment has been increasingly decimated both by tourists and by local populations, who have introduced plants and animals that prey on native species and destroy their habitats. This new three-part special, made over 20 years, journeys from the rim of the Sierra Negra volcano on the island of Isabela to the active shores, retraces Darwin's route and examines the efforts of conservationists to preserve this once-pristine oasis. 8 P.M. Johanna Doshe, 32, a nurse from Stockholm, traveling with a friend (not pictured): ''We celebrated my friend's 50th birthday on a safari tour in Kenya, and after one week, we traveled to Zanzibar to relax for another week, to look around and take some swimming tours and dolphin tours and go snorkeling. The water was very salty and refreshing and very warm -- about 80 degrees. It's very nice to have summer in the wintertime, to take a vacation in the winter, especially when you live in Sweden. And it's also great to take a vacation and see something new, to experience a new culture, especially one like Zanzibar's, which is a mix of Arabian, African and Indian cultures. Most of the Swedes are going to Thailand now, so Zanzibar is also wonderful because it's less touristy. It's like Thailand was 20 years ago.'' As told to Austin Considine

To the Editor: Re ''A Wee Identity Crisis'' (Op-Ed, March 11): At the same time I mentally applauded the notion of a human family with more similarities than differences, it was rather shocking to read Alexander McCall Smith's characterization of the centuries of brutal English rule over the Irish as ''a much-resented indignity,'' which seems to imply that the Irish merely had their national pride hurt.
Hermann Maier acknowledges that he has lost the aggression that helped him become one of the greatest Alpine skiers. He said he would decide this summer whether to continue racing. nytimes.com/sports

SHORE--Philip H., 66, passed away on Thursday morning. A native of New Jersey he practiced law for 38 years and started his own firm of Shore and Zahn. He was a member of NJ and Florida Bar Associations, the American Bar Association, the Middlesex County Bar Association, the American Bankruptcy Institute and the New Jersey School Board Attorneys. He specialized in bankruptcy and school board law, and was the attorney for both Spotswood and Cranbury Board of Education for many years. He received his BS from New York University and his JD from Seton Hall Law School. He is survived by his beloved wife of 42 years Connie Michaels Shore, his two daughters Jennifer and Heidi, his son-in-law Hadi Habal, his grandson Mathias and his brother Bruce. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Esophageal Cancer Awareness Association, P.O. Box 7327, Ventura, CA 93006 or the American Cancer Society, P.O. Box 22718, Oklahoma City, OK 73123-1718. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, March 18, 2007 at 11:30 am at The Goldstein Funeral Chapel, Inc., 2015 Woodbridge Ave., Edison, NJ (732) 777-0032.

The test, the counselor said, had come back positive. Katharine Moser inhaled sharply. She thought she was as ready as anyone could be to face her genetic destiny. She had attended a genetic counseling session and visited a psychiatrist, as required by the clinic. She had undergone the recommended neurological exam. And yet, she realized in that moment, she had never expected to hear those words.

TAYLOR--Shirley Anna Hopkins Taylor, of Kirby, Montana died peacefully Tuesday, February 27, 2007, in Billings, MT following a stroke. She was born September 29, 1923, in Chicago. Shirley was the only child of Farley Hopkins and Margaret von Maur Hopkins. She was raised in Chicago and Lake Forest and graduated from Ethel Walker's School in Connecticut. Her first trip to the west was as a guest at the HF Bar Ranch near Buffalo, WY in the mid-1930s. She married Walter Jennings Taylor on April 15, 1944, in Lake Forest, Ill. They began their life together in Cold Spring Harbor, NY and moved to Kirby, MT -50 miles by gravel road from Sheridan, WY-in the winter of 1949 after Walt purchased the Dick Glenn ranch. Leaving behind everything she had known, Shirley began her new life in ranching by moving into a two-bedroom and one-bath cabin with a newborn baby and two children, ages two and four. Shirley shared more than 60 wonderful years with Walt, becoming involved in ranching and many local activities around Sheridan and Aspen, CO where they had a home for many years. She was an accomplished breeder of Thoroughbred racehorses, owning many Group 1 stake winners. She was a part owner of the well-known racehorse Alleged, winner at the Curragh in 1976 and the Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe in 1977 and 1978. She parlayed her winnings from Alleged into a very successful mare breeding program. She was active in many causes over the years and instrumental in the formation of the Big Horn Equestrian Center in Big Horn, WY. She served as: a board member in various capacities at the Memorial Hospital of Sheridan County in the early 1950s; one of the few female members of the Jockey Club beginning in 1989, the President of the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association from 1984 to 1987; and a member of the Board of Directors of Sheridan Memorial Hospital Foundation from 1997 to 2001. Shirley was preceded in death by her parents and husband, Walt. She is survived by her four children: James Taylor and his wife Anne of Billings and their children Marett Taylor and Farley (Stuart) Lansing; Susanna Meyer and her husband David of St. Paul, MN and their children David Meyer, Etta Meyer, Stacy Meyer and Stephanie (John) Levy; Walter Watty Taylor, Jr. and his wife Lila of Kirby and their children Kirby Taylor, Peter (Amanda) Taylor, and Walter Jay (Cherie) Taylor III; and Margaret Margie Taylor of Bozeman. She also treasured her great grandson Will (Jay and Cherie) and her many cousins, nieces and nephews. Memorial services were held 3:00 pm Friday, March 9 at St. Peters Episcopal Church in Sheridan, WY. Memorials in lieu of flowers may be made to Heart of the Valley Animal Shelter, PO Box 11390, Bozeman, MT 59719; GraysonJockey Club Research Foundation, 821 Corporate Drive, Lexington, KY 40503; or Big Horn Equestrian Center, PO Box 6413, Sheridan, WY 82801. Bullis Mortuary of Hardin. MT has been entrusted with the services.

Several pianists are poised to claim attention this week. In January 2006 INGRID FLITER, an Argentine pianist living in Milan, was the recipient of the Gilmore Artist Award, a prize of $300,000 bestowed on an unsuspecting pianist. Ms. Fliter will finally have a major recital appearance in New York, performing works by Beethoven, Schubert and Chopin at Carnegie Hall. I have yet to catch a live performance by the young Russian pianist NIKOLAI LUGANSKY, winner of the 1994 Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow. His impressive recordings include a 2000 Erato release of his scintillating yet refined accounts of the complete Chopin études. He is the soloist on Sunday afternoon at Lincoln Center with the Russian National Orchestra, playing Rachmaninoff's ''Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini,'' with Mikhail Pletnev conducting. And the excellent and probing Canadian pianist LOUIS LORTIE plays a recital of works by Liszt and Chopin juxtaposed with bracing scores by the audaciously original British composer Thomas Ades. Ms. Fliter, Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $35 to $40. Mr. Lugansky, Sunday at 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $35 to $69. Mr. Lortie, Saturday at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; $24 to $82. Every year Young Concert Artists presents a program of new and recent works by emerging composers who have been heralded by this estimable organization. Monday's concert at Carnegie Hall offers works by MASON BATES, BENJAMIN C. S. BOYLE, DANIEL KELLOGG, KEVIN PUTS and KENJI BUNCH. The performers, naturally, include Young Concert Artists alumni. 7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, (212) 247-7800; $25 to $35. Those wanting to prep themselves for the Metropolitan Opera's production next season of Philip Glass's ''Satyagraha'' might attend the Collegiate Chorale's presentation of ''THE JUNIPER TREE,'' a chamber opera composed by Mr. Glass and Robert Moran based on the Grimm Brothers fairy tale. Tuesday at 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, (212) 721-6500; $25 to $65. Meanwhile at the Met BEN HEPPNER, continuing to branch out from the Wagnerian tenor repertory, sings the heroic title role in Giordano's impassioned ''ANDREA CHÉNIER,'' which opens this week. Thursday at 7:30 p.m., (212) 362-6000, metoperafamily.org; $15 to $175.

SITTING at the dinner table, my 12-year-old daughter placed her fork on her plate and chewed the baked shad topped with stewed tomatoes and sliced almonds slowly, deliberately, all the while looking up pensively. ''It's not bad,'' she said finally. ''A little pitchy at times, but decent overall tone. Not the best performance we've seen this season, but it's all right. Good enough for the next round.''

IN many ways, commuter railroads are a victim of their own success. Thanks to high gasoline prices, perpetually clogged highways and a strong economy, the three major commuter rail lines that serve the New York metropolitan area are handling more passengers than ever. Last year, ridership on New Jersey Transit trains jumped 6.8 percent, to 74 million, setting a record for the second consecutive year. Metro-North also hit a record last year, carrying 2.4 million additional riders. And the Long Island Rail Road, which saw a big decline in traffic after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, rose for the second straight year in 2006 after three years of decline.
Serving at the will of the president, United States attorneys have always inhabited an odd, hybrid world of politics and purity. Week in Review.

At various moments in his career GILBERTO GIL put forth some of the last century's great pop records (a short list: the pop-art bricolage ''Gilberto Gil,'' from 1968; the moody mixtures of pop-funk and Brazilian roots styles in ''Refavela,'' from 1975; and ''Refazenda,'' from 1977). Happily, his latest record to be released here, ''Gil Luminoso'' (DRG), can be listed among those. It's a retrospective of his own music, recorded in 1999 and originally packaged to accompany a Brazilian book about his work. The record contains 15 songs with just voice and guitar, and it represents not a weary I've-tried-everything-else move, but the core of Mr. Gil's aesthetic. Underneath his records has always been this: a brilliant small-scale singer-songwriter with guitar. Do your best to see Mr. Gil this week at Carnegie Hall. He seldom plays here, given his job as Brazil's minister of culture, and few performers are better at radiating generosity. As on the album, the concert will be just Mr. Gil and his guitar, which hasn't happened in New York before. Tuesday at 8 pm, Isaac Stern Auditorium, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $23 to $72. The inventive band Animal Collective has been sluicing out records over the last few years with a highly malleable sense of what a group is. Some records that sound like a full band involve just one or two of the four members. They do side projects too, and the best yet is ''Person Pitch,'' by PANDA BEAR, the band's drummer and singer, which comes out on Tuesday from the label Paw Tracks. Pity he's not from California; if he were, geography would confirm that he is the artistic heir to Brian Wilson and Lindsay Buckingham. Instead Panda Bear's vocal-choir harmonies and tribal rhythms will have to be understood purely as products of the imagination.

DR. ALAN ROSS did not develop a passion for school bus safety until 10 years ago, when his son asked why there were no safety belts on the bus he rode to school in Litchfield County, Conn. ''I was your typical parent, and I just assumed we had this covered in a school bus,'' said Dr. Ross, who is now the president of the National Coalition for School Bus Safety, a volunteer group. ''That started my quest to improve things. The state of school bus transportation is a very sad one.''

To the Editor: Pay raises are long overdue for New York's judiciary, which has maintained its longstanding excellence even in the face of staggering caseloads and increasingly complex legal issues (''Upgrading New York's Courts,'' editorial, March 11). The continuing failure to provide judicial salary increases is simply unwise public policy. The disparity between private-sector and judicial salaries grows every year. Any 2007 first-year associate at a major Manhattan law firm will immediately earn more than every judge in the state, including Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye. The more this disparity widens, the more difficult it will be to both attract and retain a qualified and dedicated judiciary.

To the Editor: Re ''History, Digitized (and Abridged)'' (March 11), about the far-from-complete digitization of important documents and other materials: It is depressing to think of what will not be known if the triage that is necessary to make selections of digital-worthy documents is shaped by profit-making entities. The best history often results from the discovery of papers once considered to have no lasting importance.

ROTHMAN--Sylvia, a longtime resident of Cedarhurst, NY, died on March 15 at her home in Boca Raton, Florida. Mrs. Rothman would have been 92 years old on May 12. Mrs. Rothman was a devoted New Yorker who loved to visit art museums and galleries, and was a regular at the ballet, opera and theatre. An active supporter of the arts and many charities, Mrs. Rothman gave generously of her time as a dedicated volunteer. Beloved by her family, Mrs. Rothman is survived by her daughter, Madeleine, of Weston, FL; her son, Andrew, of Anacortes, WA; her grandchildren, Adam Sidel, of Washington, DC, Aaron Rothman of San Francisco, Alexis O'Leary of Salisbury, MD and Felicia Creegan of Baltimore; three great - grandchildren and her dear cousin and lifelong friend, Helen Jonas, of Boca Raton. A funeral ceremony will be held Sunday, March 18 at 11:30 am at the Boulevard-Riverside Funeral Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, followed by interment at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont. The family will sit Shiva on Sunday and Monday at the Garden City Hotel.

Schiesser of Boxborough, MA, Elizabeth Lee of Westport, NY and Nicholas F. Lee and wife, Jane of Wilton, CT. Grandfather of Nayeli and Valentina Rodriguez, Katie and Anna Schiesser and Margaret and Henry Lee. Brother of the late JeanneMarie Lee. Memorial Service 11:00 a.m., Saturday, March 24th, The First Church in Chestnut Hill, 26 Suffolk Rd, Chestnut Hill, MA. Burial privately in Westport, NY. Contributions can be made in his name to the American Heart Association. Please visit his life story at www.mem.com.

One of the more interesting underdogs in recent N.C.A.A. tournament history emerged in 2004, when a Nevada point guard named Todd Okeson led the No. 10-seeded Wolf Pack to upsets of Michigan State and Gonzaga in the first two rounds. Okeson had the straight-from-central-casting story: he was from Weskan, Kan., a town of about 300 people, and he had received no other Division I scholarship offers. When asked how he could tell that Okeson was from a small town, one of Okeson's teammates gave a particularly memorable answer. ''Man, he cuts his own hair,'' the player responded, indignantly.
ABBIE IVES was 5, and skating on a local pond with her father, when she pointed toward a bunch of teenage boys racing back and forth and asked, ''Dad, what's that?'' ''Hockey,'' her father answered.

The ''In the Region'' article in New Jersey copies on Feb. 18, about the conversion of two old buildings in New Jersey into up-to-date residences, misstated the area of Hoboken in which one of the properties, the Coconut Building warehouse, is located. It is in the city's northeast section, not the northwest. The article also misidentified the shopping area nearest the property. It is Washington Street, not Hudson Street.

LEVINE--Howard J., died on Thursday, March 15, 2007. Beloved husband of Marilyn Kroll Levine for 60 years. Loving father to Sandra (Michael Tannenbaum), Susan (David Andrade), Marsha (Gary Goldstein). Adoring grandfather to Andrew, Wendy, Matthew, Allison, Carrie, Dana, Jessie and Samantha and great-grandfather to Eli. Founder and President of American Bias Binding Corp. Funeral services to be held on Monday, March 19th at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY, at 10 am. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcomed by Temple Israel of New Rochelle and/or The National MS Society. $(6$)LEVINE--Howard. The partners and staff of Tannenbaum Helpern Syracuse & Hirschtritt are deeply saddened by the loss of our good friend and client, Howard Levine. He was instrumental in the founding of our law firm. He was the father-in-law of one of our founding partners, Michael G. Tannenbaum. We extend our sincere sympathies to his dear wife, Marilyn, Sandy and Michael Tannenbaum, his grandchildren and the entire Levine and Tannenbaum families.
