WASSERMAN--Bernard. He was a peaceful soul with a quiet strength. His death on February 23rd left his loving wife Marlene and two step children Daniel and Claudia Jaul, and Anna Hamer with a profound sense of loss. Bernie we love you.

BEATTIE--Charles R. Jr., 77, of Hilton Head Island, SC, formerly of New York City died Wednesday at the Hilton Head Regional Medical Center. He was born on April 12, 1929 in New York City and was the son of the late Mildred Fahnestock Beattie and Charles Robert Beattie. He was a 1951 graduate of Princeton University and served in the U.S. Marine Corp during the Korean Conflict. He was with the New Jersey Bell Telephone early in his career and retired as a Vice President of the Bank of New York. He was the devoted husband of Jane Richardson Beattie; father of Brenda Ucich of East Hampstead, NH. Wendy Reed of Cockeysville, MD and Bruce Beattie of Chico, CA and grandfather to Travis and Jamie Reed, Greg and Allie Ucich and Grace L. Beattie. Memorial contributions to the Hilton Head Regional Medical Center Cardiac Care Unit, Attn: Hilton Head Hospital Auxiliary, 25 Hospital Center Blvd., Hilton Head Island, SC 29926.

NOVEY--Joseph, 97, died peacefully on February 9, 2007. He was a graduate of St. John's University and Columbia University School of Social Work. He is survived by his children, Walter and Judy, and a granddaughter Dora. His wife, Marjorie Mayer, predeceased him. A man of uncommon intellect, curiosity, and independence, he survived hardship with determination and resourcefulness. An avid reader and thinker, Joe, cherished education in general and his reading of the New York Times in particular. He was famous for his sense of irony and quick wit, which endeared him to many and remained with him throughout his life.

Choreographers will bring all sorts of people together this week in works that can be considered microcosms of the human experience. H. T. Chen is mingling members of his company, H. T. CHEN AND DANCERS, with ordinary people in ''Apple Dreams,'' his new site-specific work in the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center. With its barrel-vaulted glass atrium dominated by 16 giant palm trees, the space itself is a spectacle. And Mr. Chen is filling it with professional dancers, families and elderly people in pedicabs in a celebration of urban bustle and urban hope, a theme that will be emphasized as parents happily pause and lift their babies to the trees. Rehearsals are open to the public too. Friday and next Saturday at 7 p.m., 220 Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, worldfinancialcenter.com; free. Dancers, percussionists and artists from Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Haiti, Ivory Coast and France will be gathering when TAMANGO'S URBAN TAP presents ''Bay Mo Dilo'' (''Give Me Water''), an exploration of the mythology and culture of global Creole heritage. The festive choreographic collage will be enhanced by visual collages created by JEAN DE BOYSSON, a video artist. Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m., next Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., next Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800 or joyce.org; $36. There will be only one woman onstage throughout CRISTINA MOURA's ''like an idiot.'' Nevertheless this Brazilian dancer and choreographer will let her solo reveal the multitudinous personalities that can exist within a single person, and at times she may give the impression of dancing duets with herself: some fanciful, some absurd, some charged with raw emotional power. Thursday through Saturday at 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, at Second Avenue, East Village, (212) 674-8194 or danspaceproject.org; $15.

Donations to Cabrini Hospice 227 East 19th St. NYC, 10003. Condolences to 758 Atkinson, Detroit, MI 48202.

A picture caption with an article last Sunday in T: Men's Fashion magazine, about the actor Richard Gere, carried an incorrect identification from Everett Collection, a photography archive, for the actress shown with Mr. Gere in a scene from the film ''The Hoax.'' She is Julie Delpy -- not Hope Davis, another cast member.

Mozart: Symphonies Nos. 38, 41 Freiburg Baroque Orchestra, conducted by René Jacobs. Harmonia Mundi France HMC 901958; CD. THE symphony had pretty well separated itself from opera by Mozart's time, certainly by the time of his mature creations. Yet Mozart's Symphony No. 38 is in some ways the most operatic of his symphonies.

HEINZE--Frank J. 70, longterm resident of Ramsey, NJ and Westhampton Beach, NY died on March 15, 2007. He was born in Bronxville, NY in 1936, was educated at Iona Prep, the University of Notre Dame (class of 1958) as a chemical engineer, and Columbia University as a Master of Chemical Engineering. He was a chemical process engineer with American Cyanamid Company, Stauffer Chemical Company, and American Home Products Corporation. He was a lifetime member of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers and greatly enjoyed his hobbies of deep-sea fishing and train-spotting. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Carol O'Connell Heinze, his son John and daughter-in-law Joy De Vries Heinze, his daughter Martha and son-in-law Paul Hansen, his son Mark and daughter-inlaw Claudia Villegas, his son Neal and daughter-in-law Ellen Lafontaine Heinze and his beloved grandchildren Justin, Emma, William, and Caroline Heinze. Visitation will be held on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 pm at the Van Emburgh-SneiderPernice Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave, Ramsey, NJ. A Funeral Service will be held on Monday March 19, 2007 at 10am at the funeral home. Interment will follow at Westhampton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Heifer International or the University of Notre Dame.

To the Editor: ''The Hospital's Bill of Rights,'' by Brett Harwood (Op-Ed, March 4), about how to save New Jersey's medical centers, does not acknowledge a critical point. In the United States there are annually 2 million cases of hospital-associated infection, resulting in approximately 90,000 deaths. This death rate is increasing rapidly because of the appearance of new strains of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. The average hospital-associated infection requires extra days in the hospital and is expensive to treat. As a result, the overall annual cost to hospitals exceeds $30 billion. This places a huge financial burden on the system and greatly undermines the standard of care.

A picture caption last Sunday with the continuation of an article about the making of ''High School Musical 2'' misspelled the surname of a cast member. He is Lucas Grabeel, not Gabreel. The caption also misidentified the location of a rehearsal. It took place in Salt Lake City -- not in St. George, Utah.

The Mets played two games Saturday, and their pitchers struggled in both. Chan Ho Park, competing for the fifth spot in the rotation, allowed three home runs and seven runs, four earned, in three innings as a Mets split squad lost to the Washington Nationals, 13-1, in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended March 3, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Editors's Choice Other recent books of particular interest HEYDAY, by Kurt Andersen. (Random House, $26.95.) A busy novel, laced with keen observations, about a Briton in 19th-century America. CURVES AND ANGLES: Poems, by Brad Leithauser. (Knopf, $24.) Where the human world meets that of bugs, ants, snow and falling stars. at the same time: Essays and Speeches, by Susan Sontag. Edited by Paolo Dilonardo and Anne Jump. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) Passionately engaged writings from Sontag's final years that reveal a darkening vision of America. DRY MANHATTAN: Prohibition in New York City, by Michael A. Lerner. (Harvard University, $28.95.) A solid account of the calamitous folly that was the 18th Amendment. OIL ON THE BRAIN: Adventures From the Pump to the Pipeline, by Lisa Margonelli. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.) The author follows oil back to its source, finding plenty of corruption and mayhem along the way. WINIFRED WAGNER: A Life at the Heart of Hitler's Bayreuth, by Brigitte Hamann. Translated by Alan Bance. (Harcourt, $35.) The enthralling, repellent life of Wagner's daughter-in-law. THE SOLITUDE OF THOMAS CAVE, by Georgina Harding. (Bloomsbury, $23.95.) A 17th-century sailor is transformed by his winter in the Arctic. DEATH COMES FOR THE FAT MAN, by Reginald Hill. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) A densely plotted detective story about vigilante terrorism. THE TALE OF PALE MALE: A True Story, by Jeanette Winter. (Harcourt, $16. Ages 3 to 7.) The adventures of New York's most famous hawks. FLORA SEGUNDA: Being the Magickal Mishaps of a Girl of Spirit, Her Glass-Gazing Sidekick, Two Ominous Butlers (One Blue), a House With Eleven Thousand Rooms, and a Red Dog, by Ysabeau S. Wilce. (Harcourt, $17. Ages 12 and up.) A lively fantasy tale about a feisty 13-year-old. THE POLICE CLOUD, by Christoph Niemann. (Schwartz & Wade/Random House, $15.99. Ages 3 to 7.) A daffy premise (a cloud that wants to be a police officer) is worked out with dreamlike logic. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

The ticket brokers selling tickets outside Nationwide Arena in Columbus, Ohio, for today's second-round games are going to be watched very closely by the police. There are 550 stolen tickets on the loose. A tournament official confirmed that the tickets were stolen from a car of a Tennessee athletic department official yesterday morning.

To the Editor: I was moved by Michael Winerip's March 11 Parenting article, ''They'll Do It Themselves, Thanks,'' about the campaign of Jason Kingsley, Yaniv Gorodischer and Raymond Frost Jr., three men with Down syndrome, to obtain a sidewalk for their busy street in Greenburgh, N.Y. The three young men deserve congratulations for their energetic efforts.

GINSBERG--Sidney, WWII Veteran, recipient of five bronze service stars, survivor of the D-Day Invasion, Bridge at Ramogan, Liberation of Dachau, witness to his brother Harold's death while serving together in the 9th division, succumbed at the age of 90 on March 16, 2007 to multiple medical problems. A hero to his adoring daughter Joan and his son-in-law Bob whom he loved like a son, devoted granddaughter Stacey and her husband Andrew, loving grandson Richard and wife Suzanne, and greatgrandchildren Jack and Annabel. We all loved him and will miss him dearly. The world has lost a true hero. A memorial service will be held on Monday, March 19, 2007 at 10:00 am at I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Road, East Northport, NY. 631-499-6060.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article adapted from a new book about Thomas Edison referred incorrectly in some copies to Sarah Bernhardt, who was concerned that recording technology of the early 1900s would not do justice to her voice. She was an actress, not a singer.

Boston College did not need to fret about unfamiliarity as it prepared to face No. 2 Georgetown yesterday in the second round of the East Region in Winston-Salem, N.C. The teams are old foes. Boston College, seeded No. 7, and Georgetown were original members of the Big East Conference before the Eagles defected to the Atlantic Coast Conference in 2005. The move provided Boston College's players with a unique perspective, having played in two of the top conferences. The conferences have produced five of the past six N.C.A.A. tournament champions, including Syracuse (2003) and Connecticut (2004) of the Big East, and Duke (2001), Maryland (2002) and North Carolina (2005) of the A.C.C.

IN many ways, commuter railroads are a victim of their own success. Thanks to high gasoline prices, perpetually clogged highways and a strong economy, the three major commuter rail lines that serve the New York metropolitan area are handling more passengers than ever. Last year, ridership on New Jersey Transit trains jumped 6.8 percent, to 74 million, setting a record for the second consecutive year. Metro-North also hit a record last year, carrying 2.4 million additional riders. And the Long Island Rail Road, which saw a big decline in traffic after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, rose for the second straight year in 2006 after three years of decline.

Tom DeLay, the fiery former House majority leader, knows why his party lost control of Congress last year. And he is not to blame. In his new book, Mr. DeLay, a polarizing figure whom Democrats sought to make a symbol of Republican corruption, attributes the Republican defeat in November to frustration with President Bush, the war and ''a general perception of Republican incompetence and lack of principles.''

RAND--Sidney, M.D., 81 years old, after several years of illness, passed away on January 10, 2007. He was the beloved husband of Marcia and loving father to David, Jonathan, and Sara. He served in the U.S. Navy in WWII, then attended medical school in Switzerland. He practiced otolaryngology for 40 years in Elmhurst, NY. He was a kind, compassionate man, who cared very much for his family, patients, and friends. He will be missed by all who knew him.
To the Editor: ''No Comfort'' (editorial, March 6), about sex slavery, leaves the impression that force and rape are somehow separate from prostitution. This impression is wrong.

RUNNING RACE IS POSTPONED -- The snow and ice storm that swept the Northeast on Friday and early yesterday forced a one-day postponement of the United States men's 8-kilometer championship. The race, scheduled for 9 a.m. yesterday in Central Park, was initially moved to 9:30, then was rescheduled for 9 a.m. today. ''The decision was made at 4:30 a.m.,'' said Richard Finn, a spokesman for the sponsoring New York Road Runners. FRANK LITSKY COLLEGE BASKETBALL AMHERST WINS DIVISION III TITLE -- Andrew Olson scored 15 points and Brian Baskauskas added 14 to lead Amherst (30-2) to its first N.C.A.A. Division III title with an 80-67 victory over Virginia Wesleyan on Saturday night in Salem, Va. (AP) CRICKET UPSETS AT THE WORLD CUP -- Ireland and Bangladesh turned the World Cup upside down yesterday with stunning victories over the traditional powerhouses Pakistan and India.

Jay Leno The administration is still taking a lot of heat for firing eight U.S. attorneys. This just shows you how unpopular the administration is -- when people are siding with the lawyers. Halliburton is moving its headquarters to Dubai to avoid paying taxes in the United States. That's crazy! When did Halliburton start paying taxes? Is that new?

Different Directions It has been assumed for months that the Celtics, among other teams, were giving up on the season in hopes of receiving a top draft pick, to land Ohio State's GREG ODEN or Texas' KEVIN DURANT. One bottom-feeding team that does not seem interested in tanking is the Bobcats, who have done their part as giant killers, beating the Spurs once and the Pistons twice.

CAR trouble came naturally to our family. If we didn't quite invite it, we always made a place for it, expecting it and welcoming it. This is probably because my father never thought cars were anything you could much count on. You could depend on friends and family, possibly, and if material accessories were something you considered turning to, you might look to books or a decent fishing rod. But cars, no. He never did much to keep up the faux-woodie Country Squire, so when it got a flat, ran out of oil or started wheezing, it was just another sign of the innate frailty of the mechanical world. Whether he pulled over and called AAA or just kept puttering along, it was always with the same resigned acceptance. My 18-year-old son, Noel, is named for his grandfather. And though we didn't know this at the time we named him, he shares his grandfather's terseness, dry wit, laconic humor. Both also share a philosophical approach to things and the sense of equanimity that seems to spring from an ability to see life from all sides. It's a gift, to be sure, but one that can drive other people a little nuts. My father was a journalist, skilled in looking at things from all angles. ''He couldn't tell you what time it was without qualifying it,'' an exasperated friend of his once said. Likewise, even when Noel was young, he wasn't given much to direct answers. ''Is it blue?'' I might ask in a game of 20 questions. ''Some people might think so,'' he would reply.

Q. If the renewal rent on a rent-stabilized apartment goes from below $2,000 to above $2,000, my income for the last two years was over $175,000 each year and my landlord takes all of the appropriate steps to destabilize the apartment, will I be allowed to live out the term of my new lease? A. Yes, with one exception. Sherwin Belkin, a Manhattan lawyer who represents landlords, said that if the Division of Housing and Community Renewal issues an order of deregulation, the order deregulates the apartment upon the expiration of the tenant's current lease.

Shannan Elizabeth Carter and Michael Rinehart Hollingsworth were married yesterday. Msgr. Robert B. O'Connor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. The bride, 37, will continue to use her name professionally. She is the founder of Shannan Carter Nutrition, a group in New York providing information to diabetes, cancer and AIDS patients. She is also an adjunct professor of clinical nutrition at New York University, from which she received a master's degree in that subject. She graduated from the University of Rhode Island. She is a daughter of Beverly A. Carter and James G. Carter of Washington Township, N.J.

MURRAY--Tucker, 64, of Key West, died March 9, 2007. He was President of Liberty Industrial Gases and Welding Supplies in Brooklyn, NY. Young at heart and in spirit, he lived his life with enthusiasm and a passionate commitment to travel, boating and new adventures. He will be dearly missed by family and friends.
Don't go overboard with the hors d'oeuvres. One good one is enough -- along with nuts or olives -- since nobody wants to fill up before dinner.

SITTING at the dinner table, my 12-year-old daughter placed her fork on her plate and chewed the baked shad topped with stewed tomatoes and sliced almonds slowly, deliberately, all the while looking up pensively. ''It's not bad,'' she said finally. ''A little pitchy at times, but decent overall tone. Not the best performance we've seen this season, but it's all right. Good enough for the next round.''

To the Editor: Re ''A Perfect Lawn, Mowed and Muted'' (editorial, March 12): Central Park has been our common backyard for almost 150 years. The park was the site of ''mega-events'' -- concerts, rallies -- only in recent decades, when virtually no limitations on its use resulted in its becoming the ''Great Dust Bowl.''
Fourteen hours after boarding a plane at Kennedy International bound for North Africa, passengers were returned to the gate. Page 29.
To the Editor: Re ''No Textbooks, No Resources, Parents Complain'' (March 11):

The Kentucky-Villanova game Friday was all of three seconds old before a whistle blew. Dwight Perry was called for a foul. Perry was not supposed to be in the game. He rarely leaves his spot at the end of the Kentucky bench. A freshman, he entered three games during the season, officially compiling zero minutes.

The sight was odd, to say the least. As the Philadelphia Phillies tapped fists in the infield after an apparent 3-2 victory against the Yankees on Saturday, Jorge Posada jogged onto the field in his catching gear, and the home plate umpire, Scott Barry, signaled the ball boy to bring him two more baseballs. So what was this? A spring training bending of the rules.

Illustrations of William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge on Page 18 of the Book Review today with a review of ''The Friendship: Wordsworth and Coleridge,'' by Adam Sisman, are reversed, and the credit for the engraving of Wordsworth is rendered incorrectly. Wordsworth, who is shown on the right, should be on the left and the credit should read: Mansell/Time Life Pictures -- Getty Images.

To the Editor: Pay raises are long overdue for New York's judiciary, which has maintained its longstanding excellence even in the face of staggering caseloads and increasingly complex legal issues (''Upgrading New York's Courts,'' editorial, March 11). The continuing failure to provide judicial salary increases is simply unwise public policy.
ABBIE IVES was 5, and skating on a local pond with her father, when she pointed toward a bunch of teenage boys racing back and forth and asked, ''Dad, what's that?'' ''Hockey,'' her father answered.

To the Editor: Re ''How Do You Solve a Crisis Like Darfur?'' (column, March 13): Nicholas D. Kristof suggests that the top priority for Darfur should be a negotiated peace settlement. President Omar al-Bashir has refused to allow a United Nations peacekeeping force to augment African Union troops in Darfur, as provided for by Security Council Resolution 1706. He has done so because of the waning influence of the United States on Sudan and Sudan's close relationship with China.

KRONES--Robert. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend and Director Emeritus Robert ''Bob'' Krones. Bob began his Greenwich House affiliation as a member of the Music School Advisory Board on which he served tirelessly for 25 years. His dedication to the organization led to his election to the Board of Directors where he served for 17 years, providing invaluable counsel, leadership and support in numerous ways. We extend our sincere condolences to his brother Ed, family and friends. George A. Davidson, Chair Board of Directors Roy Leavitt, Executive Director & CEO Greenwich House, Inc. BC Vermeersch, Director Greenwich House Music School

DR. ALAN ROSS did not develop a passion for school bus safety until 10 years ago, when his son asked why there were no safety belts on the bus he rode to school in Litchfield County, Conn. ''I was your typical parent, and I just assumed we had this covered in a school bus,'' said Dr. Ross, who is now the president of the National Coalition for School Bus Safety, a volunteer group. ''That started my quest to improve things. The state of school bus transportation is a very sad one.''

Usually, an activist hedge fund wants to oust the managers of a company it is battling to control -- not keep them. But William A. Ackman, founder of Pershing Square Capital Management, issued a statement last week lamenting the departure of Douglas M. Neve, chief financial officer of the Ceridian Corporation, the information services company. Calling Mr. Neve a ''first-class C.F.O.,'' Mr. Ackman said that his exit was ''a real disappointment,'' because he had overhauled the company's accounting and finances and improved margins at one of Ceridian's two key business units.

To the Sports Editor: In an article published March 4 (''Why Match Play Doesn't Work in Golf''), Lucius J. Riccio stated about match play in golf, ''More often than not, the format is a dud.'' We could not disagree more.
To the Editor: Re ''The Price of Keeping the Lights On'' (editorial, March 11):

RUNNING a credible campaign for president has always required an elusive mixture of star power and experience. But Barack Obama's strong challenge to Hillary Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent surge past Senator John McCain in the polls raise an interesting question: How much does experience matter now in presidential politics? After 9/11 it seemed that high-level government experience would be more important than ever. And yet, neither Mr. Obama nor Mr. Giuliani have the kind of governing experience traditionally seen as a prerequisite for White House service. Mr. Obama spent nine years in the Illinois State Senate and two years in the United States Senate, while Mr. Giuliani has served two terms as mayor of New York.

Since the Village of Rye Brook was established in 1982, its 8,600 residents have used the Port Chester Library. It was a natural arrangement based on proximity and history, and it benefited both communities since Rye Brook, with about one-third of the residents of Port Chester, paid 30 percent of the operating costs. Now, some Port Chester residents are balking at the financial arrangements and Rye Brook's request that the library be renamed the Port Chester-Rye Brook Public Library. Both villages are in the Town of Rye.

FEUERRING--Ralph R., of Florida and New York, beloved husband of Marlene, devoted father of Denise Weiner, Nicole Hill and Kent. Most precious grandfather of Lauren, Lesley, Travis, Alexis, Kevin and Jonas, loving great-grandfather of Amanda. Funeral services, Monday, March 19th at 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., New York. For additional Information please call 1-800938-6372

HATKOFF--Doris Wildove, beloved mother of Susan Patricof, Amy Hatkoff and Craig Hatkoff, mother-in-law of Alan Patricof and Jane Rosenthal, grandmother of Juliana and Isabella Hatkoff and Mark, Jonathan and Jamie Patricof, great-grandmother of Lily, Nina, Jack, Chloe and Riley Patricof, and sister of Beatrice Dicker, died peacefully in Palm Beach after a long illness. A woman of grace and great beauty, she will be deeply missed by all. Contributions in her memory can be made to the NYU Child Study Center, Northside Center for Child Development, and Prevent Child Abust New York.

America's 21st-century wars are inspiring a wave of fact-based filmmaking, and several of the more acclaimed results are washing up on television this week. Sundance Channel presents a double bill on Monday night: Patricia Foulkrod's examination of the American soldier's experience from recruitment to homecoming, ''THE GROUND TRUTH,'' which was shortlisted for best documentary feature at the Oscars (9 p.m.); and Michael Winterbottom's and Mat Whitecross's film about British citizens detained by the United States as terror suspects, ''THE ROAD TO GUANTÁNAMO,'' winner of the Independent Spirit Award for best documentary (10:15). On Tuesday night at 7, Cinemax's Reel Life documentary series presents ''IRAQ IN FRAGMENTS,'' James Longley's impressionistic portrait of daily life in the country. A. O. Scott of The New York Times called the film, an Oscar nominee for best documentary, ''entrancingly, almost disturbingly beautiful.'' Fallbrook, Calif. -- near Camp Pendleton -- might not be the first place you think of when you think bed-and-breakfast. But what if you could stumble downstairs and have your eggs en cocotte cooked by Tori Spelling? That's the promise of ''TORI & DEAN: INN LOVE,'' a new reality series on Oxygen (10:30 p.m. Tuesday), in which a very pregnant Ms. Spelling, with the help of her husband, Dean McDermott, tries to eke out her $800,000 inheritance by running a B&B in San Diego County. Other stops on the B-list: ''DANCING WITH THE STARS'' begins on ABC (8 p.m. Monday) with built-in plot lines centering on John Ratzenberger, nobly subbing for Vincent Pastore, and Heather Mills, nobly trying a dance competition with a prosthetic leg. And the 2007 MISS USA pageant on NBC (9 p.m. Friday) brings the reign of Tara Conner to an end.

Five years ago, Jim and Brandy Brow sold their three-bedroom house in southern Vermont, bought five wooded acres nearby and moved in with Brandy's father while Jim set about building a new seven-bedroom home. Living with Dad got difficult, so the Brows purchased a 1978 trailer, had it hauled to their land and moved in. Money and building supplies soon ran out, and today Jim, 33, a roofer; Brandy, 34, a writer; and their kids -- Isaac, 12; Chanyn, 10; Solomon, 8; Noah, 5; Elijah, 4; and Natasha, 1 -- share 832 square feet. ''I hated this trailer,'' says Brandy, who walked us through the family's life there. ''But it has given us benefits. We've grown close. I hope our relationships are solid enough that we will choose to be together when we have space.'' BUGGED OUT ''The trailer sits on blocks. In the summer it's hot; in the winter supercold. Last winter we put hay around the base, and it wasn't so cold. Until summer, when we had mites crawling around. They were living in the hay. The hay had to go.'' BUNK BEDLAM ''This room is a new addition to the trailer. We built it this winter. It's about 8 feet by 14 feet. The bunk beds are built into the wall. The boys sleep in this room, all four of them. This is the first time they have had a space of their own, so it's a big deal for them. Prior to this, the boys slept on fold-out foam beds on the living-room floor. They kind of slept on top of each other. Every night we'd have to take out the beds and fold them up each morning. It was like a sleepover party every night. Now and then we had to separate them by telling one of them to go and sleep under the kitchen table. They didn't like that, and it quieted them down. The dresser next to the bunk beds used to be stacked on top of the dresser in my bedroom. Once it fell over and nearly killed Noah. Jim caught it and saved him.'' CLOSET CASE ''A big issue is finding a place to put shoes and coats. As bad as the coats are for taking up space, the worst is the shoes. They end up blocking the front door. We have a shoe rack, but it can only hold so much. That white thing under the coats is actually a freezer. The fridge in the kitchen is too small for us. Just bread for the week doesn't fit inside it.'' FEEDING FRENZY ''We eat the main meal at lunch and a light meal at dinner. It's healthier and cuts down on how many people I have underfoot during the big meal, because we have four children in public school, and they eat breakfast and lunch there. We were given this big table, which means we can seat all eight people at once. The biggest challenge is trying to fit everyone in and move around to serve. Most of the time, my husband will eat on his recliner in front of the television because it's quieter there. I have to use the table as a kitchen countertop, because there isn't enough work space. So I have to maneuver between table, stove and sink, which isn't easy. We use stools in the dining room, because chairs with backs take up too much space. The stools can be stacked and put out of the way.'' CHORE SCOREBOARD ''This is the chore board and the behavior ladder. The chore board is based on a dartboard, with symbols for different chores in each space. Each child has a colored peg, and this is used to assign him a different chore each day. I instituted this because the kids were becoming resistant to being told what to do. This puts the chores on them. That's where the ladder comes in. It has eight levels. On the highest level you get your weekly allowance and can go over to friends' houses overnight. The lowest level means you are grounded, with extra chores and no allowance. Depending on your behavior and how well you complete your chores, you are sent up or down the ladder. Some of my children have a harder time with the system than others, but we give them all mercy. At the beginning of each month, on birthdays and holidays, everyone gets reset to the highest level.'' ALL WASHED UP ''We have the younger kids up on the sink, because everyone can't get to the sink at the same time without that. Why they don't take turns I really don't know. Part of it is they like to hold each other accountable as to who did the best job brushing. In general, we use the bathroom in shifts. Jim and I usually shower during the day. The children shower in the evenings. Half of them shower one day and half the next. The bathroom is constantly occupied, so you get in when you can, and you have to hurry. I tell them if they really need to go, they can use the woods.''

SITTING at the dinner table, my 12-year-old daughter placed her fork on her plate and chewed the baked shad topped with stewed tomatoes and sliced almonds slowly, deliberately, all the while looking up pensively. ''It's not bad,'' she said finally. ''A little pitchy at times, but decent overall tone. Not the best performance we've seen this season, but it's all right. Good enough for the next round.''

For now, it appears, all bets are off for an out-of-court settlement between former Gov. James E. McGreevey and his estranged wife, based on an amended complaint he filed seeking the court's input on child custody, support and visitation. Challenging news reports that he was seeking sole custody of the couple's 5-year-old daughter, Jacqueline, Mr. McGreevey said last week that he had filed a revised pleading after failing to reach an agreement with his wife, Dina Matos McGreevey. ''Unfortunately, we were unable to come to an amicable resolution, so now we seek the benefit of the courts to determine what's best for our daughter,'' he said. ''It's an all too human set of circumstances.''

SCHWEITZER--Dr. Daniel Lawrence, passed away peacefully at his home in Scarsdale on the evening of March 14th. He was an eclectic, loving, spirited man who will be greatly missed and who made a lasting impression on all those that knew him. He is survived by his daughter, Dina Schweitzer Leitch, son-in-law, William Leitch, and his two granddaughters, Kaylia and Madeline Leitch, all of San Anselmo, California; his son, David Schweitzer and companion Daisy Luna; his dedicated and caring partner, Susan Rowley, and her two daughters, Betsy and Chrissy Rowley; his brother Richard Schweitzer, sister - in - law, Nancy Schweitzer, and niece and nephew, Marlowe and Jonathan Schweitzer. He is also survived by former wife Carole Wiley Henry. His brother Leonard prede ceased him. Dr. Schweitzer is the son of the late Honorable Mitchell and Sylvia Schweitzer of New York City. Services will be held Tuesday, March 20th at noon at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY 10552. Telephone 914-664-6800. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Jansen Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

An article last Sunday about the digitization of historical documents referred incorrectly to a 1968 letter from Jacqueline Kennedy to Leonard Bernstein, part of a Bernstein collection that was donated to the Library of Congress. The letter, which thanked Bernstein for conducting a Gustav Mahler work at the funeral of Robert F. Kennedy, was referring to the Adagietto movement from Mahler's Fifth Symphony; Mrs. Kennedy did not thank him in the letter for conducting ''Mahler's Requiem.'' (Mahler never composed a requiem.)

Steve Francis has played in fewer than half of the Knicks' games this season and returned to the lineup only recently. But he was issued a challenge by Coach Isiah Thomas on Saturday. ''In terms of being a leader, I want more out of him,'' Thomas said at the Knicks' practice facility. Thomas added that he wanted Francis ''to be a more vocal part of the group, not just a part of the team; I don't want him to take a back seat to anyone.''

A picture on March 4 with an article about a screenplay of ''Paradise Lost'' was printed upside down. The rebel angels should have appeared in the lower half of the illustration by Gustave Doré, which was inverted by Art Resource.

Winter's sharp edge is finally easing, and shoppers are seeking lighter coverage. This year's crop of spring coats breaks out of the boring trenches with sexy, feminine tailoring and witty details that give a modern twist to Sunday best. Below are eight ways to do Winnetka with a wink and Greenwich with an I-Don't-Think-So. 1. A bright green cotton coat by Milly has a cool silk geometric-print lining and flashy gold buttons; $653 at Neiman Marcus.

A nanny who said that Daniel M. Snyder, owner of the Washington Redskins, had underpaid her won $44,880 last week when a Montgomery County Circuit Court in Maryland agreed that she had not been compensated for overtime hours she had worked. Juliette Mendonca sued Mr. Snyder for $60,000 in overtime that she said she had earned while caring for the three children of Mr. Snyder and his wife, Tanya. This was on top of the $162,000 she was paid during that same period, from April 2003 to November 2004.

After his team lost to Wisconsin in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Texas A&M-Corpus Christi coach Ronnie Arrow did not hesitate to predict Wisconsin's demise. He said that Nevada-Las Vegas matched up well with the Badgers and would beat them. ''Ronnie's been around,'' Wisconsin Coach Bo Ryan said when he was told about Arrow's assessment. ''He knows. That scares me. He knows.''

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. --Senior advisers to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama clashed intensely tonight at a forum for campaign managers here over the positions of the two candidates on the war in Iraq and the tactics being used by both campaigns.
Wondering what this presidential campaign might look like in the world of "Web 2.0" social networking sites?

Some conservatives despairing of the Republican field are hoping that former Senator Fred Thompson goes beyond his musings about entering the presidential race. Now, two Tennessee congressmen are creating a "Draft Fred Thompson 2008" committee.
The list of ways video games have damaged our world has gotten slightly longer: They are now alleged to encourage risky driving.
1199's "Remember Me" ad: "Governor Spitzer, I want you to look at me." [The Politicker]

Though shipping company EGL has agreed to a $1.7 billion, $38-a-share management-led buyout, its board may have to contend with another persistent suitor. DealBook has obtained a letter that the buyout firm Apollo Management sent Monday to EGL's board, in which it said it has made an even higher offer of $40 per share.

That's the latest finding from the city Health Department. The Bloomberg administration has been aggressive in fighting smoking, whether through tax policy, smoking bans or publishing disturbing pictures of smokers' teeth in press releases (check out the link):
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's Mar. 19 column, "Death of a Marine."
Readers respond to David Brooks's Mar. 18 column, "Your Brain on Baseball."

No politicians raise money quite like the Clintons, whether it's their success or ferocity or creativity (remember those White House teas, those Lincoln bedroom sleepovers?). Well, Bill Clinton is about to go where no other former president has gone before, arguably, in service to enriching his wife's presidential campaign warchest.

After four days and 48 games, The Bracket takes a breath and spends some down time examining its bracket, and the brackets of the 27,000-plus participants in The New York Times's online Bracket Tournament. Get ready for some mild-to-moderate number crunching ...
There's a strong argument that the Florida center Joakim Noah is the most relevant and charismatic figure in college basketball since Bill Walton was roaming the paint in Westwood in the early 1970s.
Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, explains the ins and outs of making falafel at home.
The New York Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a TheMinimalist, takes French toast south of the Pyrenees.

The first video news I watched on a cellphone was a smoke signal. I saw it in the back of a cab. The Pope had died, and CNN had its cameras trained on the chimney over St. Peter's Square. Viewers were told to expect white smoke when the cardinals had elected his replacement.
Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares pasta with anchovies for people who hate anchovies.

The question from Mark Schroeder, a Times reader in New York, was a good one. "How can someone who does not speak the language of the people involved quote them and determine an accurate set of facts for an article?" he asked in a Feb. 23 e-mail.
Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares (and deconstructs) a savory Korean pancake called pa jun.
. The country was in horrible straits then and sadly things have only worsened.
Here is a copy of the indictment [pdf] filed today in the death of Sean Bell, against Detectives Michael Oliver, Gescard Isnora and Marc Cooper of the New York Police Department.

For a mere $40,000 a day, you can get away in style at a luxury villa in the Bahamas that comes with a 48-foot yacht, 24-seat movie theater, full staff, and two Hummers. Check out the other places you can go for a truly high-end vacation at http://www.homeaway.com/index.cfm/tgt/top-10-luxury-vacation-rentals/index.html

It's easy to write off the warnings about Wall Street losing its position as the center of the financial universe as merely the cries of prideful opportunists. After all, even if foreign exchanges are taking bigger shares of the world's stock offerings lately, it's not as if Wall Street is hurting much. One look at last years record bonuses will tell you that.
The Pentagon's Combatant Status Review Tribunal released its latest transcript today from a senior Al Qaeda operative. Today's special guest is Walid Ba'Attash.

Flatpack housesSure, everyone's heard of flatpack furniture but now you can own a flatpack house to go around it. Indeed the Swedish furniture chain Ikea has just launched its own range of houses in England and Scotland. Priced at less than £100,000, flatpack houses are being seen as a solution to Britain's lack of affordable housing. But here's the best news: the timber-framed homes come already built.

The new site Uncivilservants.org seems to be stirring up some city employees who use -- some say abuse -- their parking privileges. Commenters claiming to be police officers say the site is putting them at risk. And there's a suggestion that the Internal Affairs bureau is monitoring the site.

These days, a first-year lawyer at a top firm can earn more than an associate justice of the Supreme Court. This is just one of the points made by Susan Hackett, general counsel of the Association of Corporate Counsel, as she argues that there is no good reason for the recent rise in legal associates' pay. Her organization represents the in-house legal departments that pay for outside lawyers.

Bristol-Myers Squibb has inspired all kinds of takeover speculation recently. There has been less talk about Wyeth, an even larger pharmaceuticals giant that Catherine Arnold, an analyst at Credit Suisse, thinks could be an acquisition target as well. In a report Monday on possible mergers and acquisitions activity in the drug industry, Ms. Arnold also identified two drugmakers that appear to be "natural acquirers": GlaxoSmithKline and Novartis.
Lobbyists spent a new record -- $151 million -- in 2006, trying to influence policy in Albany, according to the latest report from the state's Temporary Comission on Lobbying.

Evelyn Y. Davis, a shareholder gadfly with a long history of haranguing corporate executives, wants the board at Goldman Sachs to stop handing out stock options. And she wants them to quit cold turkey.

In the four years since the start of the war in Iraq, the American public has grown more and more critical, and now they describe the war as going badly and believe the United States should have stayed out of Iraq in the first place.
The office of the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, has posted his statement [pdf] outlining the grand jury indictments of three detectives in the Sean Bell case.

While the troubled subprime mortgage market has weighed down Wall Street -- Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers both reported that their 1st-quarter revenues were hurt by the sector -- others see a buying opportunity. Buyers like Goldman Sachs have said that they see a chance to acquire beaten down assets cheaply, anticipating a rebound, rather than a continued implosion.
The home of the quadruple cheeseburger and the world's tallest thermometer is playing host to the next giant of the skies. The Airbus A380 has landed in New York.

Reports that the British bank Barclays might bid for ABN Amro, the Dutch financial group, sent ABM Amro's shares surging to a record Monday. The stock gained as much as 10 percent, despite skepticism from some analysts who questioned whether such a merger would actually happen. With the increase, ABN's market capitalization swelled to about $76 billion.
Two major national titles were decided on Sunday, the concluding day of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring North American Championships.
It's a 75-minute drive from Tampa to Anna Maria Island. After our incredibly disappointing meeting with the architect Don Cooper, it seemed as if the ride took four times as long.

It's official: Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS' investment bank, is leaving. DealBook obtained a copy of an internal memo by Huw Jenkins, the chairman and chief executive of UBS' investment bank, and Peter A. Wuffli, the president of the firm's Group Executive Board, announcing the veteran investment banker's departure.

Before the sun rose this morning, three detectives left their homes and arrived at central booking in Queens shortly after 7 a.m. There they went through the familiar routine of criminal defendants: getting fingerprinted and photographed, turning over their possessions and filling paperwork.

Iraq is hardly the kind of story that needs an anniversary to suddenly thrust it back onto front pages. Every day, multiple strands compete for our attention, from Washington and the campaign trail to Baghdad and Basra. Still, it must be said.
The Wall Street Journal's Amy Schatz writes that "differing online strategies of the various campaigns are starting to emerge -- and diverge somewhat."

Hercules Offshore, an oil and gas drilling company, said Monday that it would acquire a larger rival, Todco, for about $2.3 billion in cash and stock, gaining a larger footprint in the global oil rig market. Under the terms of the deal, Todco shareholders will receive .979 Hercules shares and $16 in cash for each of their shares, for a total of $42.01 per Todco share. The deal represents a 28 percent premium to Todco's closing price Friday.
Staring down the barrel of a proxy fight, Take-Two Interactive Software has blinked.
Some more of my notes from this year's TED conference, which I described the other day.

If Barry Schwarz had his way, getting into the college of your choice really would be like winning the lottery. Elite universities ought to take a page from Hogwarts and draw the names of all qualified students out of giant Sorting Hat, suggests Schwarz, the author of "The Paradox of Choice," on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. He writes:
Democrats learned a few things from Republicans over the years, and one of them was how to name legislation in a way that makes opponents seem like they are attacking apple pie.

At a time when Hollywood is crawling with hedge funds, private equity and other aspiring film financiers, Media Rights Capital, a company spun off from a talent agency, Endeavor, best known as the players behind the HBO industry satire "Entourage," is helping to shift the balance of power in movie-making by giving filmmakers and stars more earning power and ownership of their projects, notes The New York Times.
Meet the Black Lips, the hardest working band at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex.

In an article on the ubiquity of hedge funds in Hollywood these days, The Economist says that the survival rate of the new wannabe studios backed by investment pools may not be high. Noting that three-quarters of the newly financed outfits may be gone within five years, it also notes that the film industry's real problem is not so much a shortage of films as a shortage of eyeballs.

Microsoft's move to buy Tellme for about $800 million represents a boon for Benchmark Capital, as well as Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers, but no home run on the order of Google, says The Red Herring.

Lawyers for Banc of America Securities presented e-mail evidence in a New York federal court Friday that they say shows that the law firm Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman knowingly used privileged documents in order to bring a case against several hedge funds on behalf of Biovail Pharmaceuticals, a drugmaker.

The FCStone Group, a commodities risk management firm, rocked the market for initial public offerings on Friday, rising 30 percent after pricing at the high end of its estimated range. FCStone offered 5.1 million shares at $24 a share, at the top end of its $21-$24 range, raising $122 million. The stock opened at $27.50 and rose to end its first trading day at $31.13.

The Carlyle Group has agreed to take a reduced stake in Xugong Group Construction Machinery of China in a bid to help speed approval of the deal, which has been awaiting government approval for more than a year, according to The Wall Street Journal. Carlyle has signed an agreement to take a 45 percent stake in Xugong, The Journal said.

ServiceMaster, which provides home services such as house cleaning and pest control, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by a group led by the private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice for about $4.7 billion. ServiceMaster said in November it had hired Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs to explore strategic alternatives for the company, including a possible sale.

Once the center of power, the desk of Enron's former chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, is up for sale on eBay. The desk is being sold by a charity, Saving Animals Across Borders, which is also auctioning the desks that Jeffrey Skilling and Richard Kinder used when they were presidents of the now-defunct energy company. Mr. Lay and Mr. Skilling, who also served as chief executive, were convicted in May 2006 for their role in the accounting fraud that led to the collapse of Enron in 2001.

Walt Disney, concluding an internal investigation, cleared Steven P. Jobs on Friday of any misconduct in issuing backdated stock options at Pixar, the computer animation studio that Disney bought last year. A brief statement by John E. Pepper Jr., Disney's chairman, did not mention Mr. Jobs by name. But the statement said that "while options were backdated at Pixar prior to the acquisition, no one currently associated" with Disney was involved in "any intentional or deliberate acts of misconduct."

In 2006, the hottest story in college basketball was the battle for the N.C.A.A. scoring title between Gonzaga's Adam Morrison and Duke's J.J. Redick. In a college basketball landscape that had been decimated by players leaving early for the N.B.A., the two players were purported to be all that was right with the sport. Not only did they devote themselves to the college game - though Morrison did leave after his junior year - they were best pals; they even played the video game Halo online against each other all hours of the night. What college student can't relate to all-night video game sessions? These guys were what college was supposed to be all about.

The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group are leading a consortium that is considering making a rival bid for TXU, The Financial Times and Reuters reported Monday, citing undisclosed sources. Such a move could spark a bidding war for the Texas energy giant, which recently agreed to be acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group for $45 billion.
Will Time Warner log out of AOL?

Merrill Lynch's chief executive, E. Stanley O'Neal, could receive $251.4 million if he were to resign from the company under certain circumstances, the company disclosed Friday. The estimated payout would be triggered if Mr. O'Neal was terminated without cause or resigned for good reason, Merrill's annual proxy statement said.

Google purchased a video game advertising firm, Adscape, to expand into in-game advertising, Google said on Friday. Financial details were not disclosed, but Red Herring last month reported the value of the expected deal at about $23 million.

Royal Dutch Shell is on the verge of taking over Shell Canada, announcing early Saturday that it had scored a significant victory in its bid of 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion) for the firm. Royal Dutch, one of the largest public oil companies in the world, already owns about 78 percent of Shell Canada and is trying to buy the rest.

Behind the scenes of the battle for control of Friendly Ice Cream is a tale of two brothers who founded the company during the Great Depression only to become estranged after disagreements over its future.

Hyperactive Technologies, the maker of Hyperactive Bob, a product that helps fast-food restaurants manage their kitchens, has received $8.4 million in a second round of venture funding, VentureWire reported. Hyperactive Bob, a robotic camera system, pans walk-ins and the drive-through line to organize cooking. The company was spun out of Carnegie Mellon University, CNEt News.com notes, adding that the firm has "the best company name ever."

It was widely reported earlier this month that Motorola's chief executive, Edward Zander, received no annual bonus last year, after Motorola's cell phone business derailed during the fourth quarter, hammering the company's profits.
These are strange days in the capital.

Wall Street is eager to get its hands on the Blackstone Group's prospectus to get a peek inside the private equity powerhouse, which, in keeping with its description as private guards its secrecy. But The New York Times suggests that investors may be disappointed at what few details they discover if the firm decides to go ahead with the initial public offering it is said to be considering.

When the markets get choppy, risky investing categories like initial public offerings tend to suffer. But, says BusinessWeek, the recent market turmoil that started with the sell-off in China has not overwhelmed the I.P.O. scene, and it may create opportunities. Stock in companies like BigBand Networks, which helps cable companies deliver high-definition video, have risen as much as 30 percent above their opening prices.

Viacom's $1 billion copyright-infringement lawsuit has turned fears that Google's purchase of YouTube would end up being a legal quagmire into a reality. Now, attention is turning to whether other predicted pitfall's of the $1.65 billion deal -- namely that the site will end up being a financial black hole -- will also come true.

A business partner of Conrad M. Black and three companies will pay $63.4 million to settle claims and debt with the Sun-Times Media Group, the company said Sunday. Mr. Black's partner, F. David Radler, 64, was president and chief operating officer of the Sun-Times Group when it was known as Hollinger International. The payment means that Mr. Radler and firms he controls have paid a total of $72 million to settle claims and debt owed to the publisher, the Sun-Times Group, based in Chicago, said Sunday in a statement.

In a review of "Top Design," the reality show on Bravo Networks, a staff writer for the Web site Televisionwithoutpity.com mused that in the future, the show would be "just another filthy memory whose outcome I've long since forgotten."

Quanta Services, a provider of engineering support to power companies, said Monday it had agreed to buy InfraSource Services, a Pennsylvania company that also provides services to utilities, for $1.26 billion in stock.

After an avalanche of reports surfaced that Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS's investment bank, was considering ditching the firm following a series of run-ins with the Swiss bank's management over private equity deals, The New York Times reports that Mr. Moelis, who helped turn the Swiss bank into a mergers and acquisitions giant, is indeed leaving.

Imperial Tobacco of Britain said on Sunday that it would continue "friendly" efforts to buy a Franco-Spanish rival, Altadis, which rejected its initial attempt at 45 euros a share. Imperial, which makes Lambert & Butler and Embassy cigarettes, offered 11.5 billion euros ($15.3 billion) for Altadis on Thursday, beginning a possible bidding war in the consolidating tobacco industry.

Barclays, one of Britain's largest banks, has made an informal takeover approach for ABN Amro Holding, the largest bank in the Netherlands, which is under pressure from hedge funds to consider a merger or asset sales to bolster its lagging share price.

Community Health Systems, a hospital operator, was near a deal over the weekend to buy Triad Hospitals, which has already agreed to be acquired by a group of private equity funds, The Wall Street Journal reported. Community Health, which runs acute-care hospitals, has been seen by some analysts as a potential buyout target itself.
“King Hedley II” and Bebe Neuwirth extend their engagements, and “Xanadu” adds two new muses.
Encores! Summer Stars, a new summertime series, will begin with “Gypsy,” starring Patti LuPone as Mama Rose.
Photographs from Matthew Bourne's production of "Edward Scissorhands."
Dr. Frans de Waal argues that human morality would be impossible without certain emotional building blocks that are clearly at work in chimp and monkey societies.
This new anthology series, which stars John Waters as a character called the Groom Reaper, is good sickly fun.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
John W. Backus assembled and led the I.B.M. team that created Fortran, the first widely used programming language.
Russia said it will withhold nuclear fuel unless Iran suspends its uranium enrichment as demanded by the Security Council.
In an affidavit, David Hicks contends that he was beaten during interrogations and saw abuse of other prisoners.
A former White House official who softened reports on global warming defended himself before Congress today.
An Al Qaeda operative admitted his role in the U.S.S. Cole bombing and other attacks, according to a transcript.
A methane gas explosion today in a region notorious for mine accidents trapped almost 200 miners underground.
President Bush marked the fourth anniversary of the invasion by warning that hard days lie ahead.
Two New York City police detectives pleaded not guilty to charges of manslaughter. A third pleaded not guilty to lesser charges in the shooting.
Several officials and bystanders were injured in the suicide car bombing in Kabul today, the embassy said.
At least six were killed in a Shiite mosque in Baghdad today and car boms in Kirkuk killed 18 people.
Although it blew out its first-round opponent, the night was tinged with bad news for fourth-seeded Rutgers.
Gunfire broke out Sunday night as thousands of teenagers left Madison Square Garden after a high school championship basketball game, the police said.
Corrections: For the Record

An article by Reuters on Saturday about the creation of a joint military command for Ivory Coast, a step toward unifying government and rebel forces, incorrectly described the current military situation. The government controls the south, while the rebels control the north, not the other way around.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the account by Dmitri V. Kovtun, a Russian business consultant, of his dealings with Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer who died of radioactive poisoning in November, omitted part of a credit. Alan Cowell not only contributed from his home base in London, but he also reported from Moscow with Steven Lee Myers.
An article on Thursday about plans by the Internet search giant Google to build two facilities in Lenoir, N.C., misstated the month it announced the decision. It was January, not February.

A review on Friday of “Incisive Images: Ivory and Boxwood Carvings, 1450-1800,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misidentified a figure on the Lamentation, a relief by Adam Lenckhart. It was St. John the Apostle, sometimes known as St. John the Beloved Disciple, grasping the robe of the Virgin — not John the Baptist. The review also misstated the source of the items in the exhibition. Five of the nearly 100 pieces were borrowed from private collections; not all came from the Met’s collection.

An architecture review on Tuesday of housing complexes in the skid row area of Los Angeles misidentified the location of the planned New Carver Apartments. They are slated for a site along the 10 Freeway, not the 110 Freeway. Also, a picture caption with the review carried an incorrect credit. The image, of a model of the Carver Apartments, was by Michael Maltzan Architecture — not Will Carson/Michael Maltzan Architecture.

Katherine N. Lapp, the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from 2002 through 2006, has been appointed executive vice president for business operations at the University of California. Ms. Lapp, 50, will be paid $400,000 a year to oversee administrative operations for the university system, managing real estate, human resources, information technology and procurement. A lawyer, Ms. Lapp worked on criminal justice issues in New York in the administrations of Mayor David N. Dinkins, a Democrat, from 1990 to 1993; Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, from 1994 to 1997; and Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, from 1997 to 2001.

About 300 people were evacuated from more than 50 homes in Sunset Park for several hours yesterday because of a carbon monoxide gas leak resulting from a manhole fire, the Fire Department said. Seven people, including two unconscious women and two paramedics, were taken to area hospitals after the evacuations, which took place shortly after noon on 55th Street near Seventh Avenue; none suffered serious injuries, the department said. Others were treated at the scene, above. A resident, Danny Lee, 26, said he called 911 after his carbon monoxide detector went off and he smelled smoke coming from his basement. “It worked,” he said of the detector. “That’s why I’m standing here talking to you.”.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell’s proposed budget calls for reducing state payments in lieu of taxes to some Connecticut cities. The state distributes the payments, called pilot grants, to compensate municipalities for colleges, hospitals, parks, office buildings, garages, courthouses and other state properties that are exempt from property taxes. State officials said that this year’s payments were inflated by a one-time bonus and that next year’s should be about even with the base payment this year; they also said towns and cities were scheduled to receive increases in state aid for schools next year.

A report released yesterday by the New York Civil Liberties Union said the organization had received hundreds of complaints of foul language, rough treatment and unwarranted arrests by the Police Department’s 4,827 school safety agents in recent years. Donna Lieberman, the group’s executive director, said the agents often treated students like suspects. Paul J. Browne, a Police Department spokesman, called some of the report’s allegations “insulting and baseless.” Since the Police Department assumed responsibility for school safety in 1998, he said, violent incidents in the schools are down 20 percent and major crime on campuses is down 33 percent. He said the report offered an inaccurate depiction of safety agents, who are civilians and do not carry firearms.

A day after graduating from the Suffolk County Police Academy, an off-duty officer arrested a driver on Saturday who was running from the scene of a crash on Route 25, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The officer, Anthony Napolitano, who had seen the crash from inside his car, arrested the driver, Steven Kowalski, after a brief pursuit in a wooded area, the police said. Mr. Kowalski, 31, of Farmingville, was charged with driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident with injury, the police said. The two occupants of the other vehicle involved in the crash, which occurred about 5:30 p.m., suffered injuries that were not life-threatening, the police said; their names were not released. Officer Napolitano is to officially begin work today at the Fourth Precinct in Hauppauge.

Two firefighters were arrested and charged with assault in separate incidents on Saturday, the police said. The first firefighter, Harry Pfeiffer, 27, and his friend Nicola Ciaramella, 27, are charged with attacking a third man, Ronald Buonagura, 31, with a shovel at Mr. Buonagura’s home in Howard Beach, Queens, about 7 p.m., the police said. Mr. Buonagura in turn stabbed Mr. Pfeiffer and Mr. Ciaramella with a knife, the police said; none of the men were seriously injured. All three were charged with weapons possession and assault, the police said. They said the fight appeared to be over a woman. The second firefighter, Douglas Barry, was arrested shortly before 11 p.m. at Broadway and Warren Street in Manhattan and charged with third-degree assault, the police said. He is accused of punching a woman in a dispute over a cab.

Thousands of war protesters, including union members, veterans and church groups, marched through Midtown yesterday afternoon, starting at Bryant Park and moving along 42nd Street, up Third Avenue to 57th Street and down Second Avenue to 47th Street. The demonstration was one of several nationwide, including one on Saturday in Washington, in advance of the fourth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq, which is tomorrow. The police lined the sidewalks along the route, which passed the offices of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer. No violence was reported during the march, and no arrests were made, the police said.

More than 100 inmates at the Monmouth County jail who were arrested by federal immigration agents mounted a peaceful protest over conditions in the jail, officials said yesterday. Undersheriff Ted Freeman told The Asbury Park Press that 132 inmates, about 10 percent of those in the jail, began refusing to eat or take part in activities because they wanted more food, Spanish-speaking officers and repairs for a broken television. Undersheriff Freeman said inmates were given three meals a day and had access to a commissary. He said last night that officials were working to end the protest.

City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Representatives Jerrold Nadler and Anthony D. Weiner put their weight behind an effort to unionize 362 Verizon telephone workers yesterday, confirming that a majority of the workers had signed cards saying they wanted to join the Communications Workers of America. The three political leaders confirmed that 219 of the 362 workers had signed pro-union cards as union officials called on Verizon to grant union recognition because of this majority showing. But Verizon is invoking its right under federal law to ask for a secret-ballot election overseen by the National Labor Relations Board to determine whether a majority wants a union. The 362 employees, who install telephone equipment for businesses, work for a unit called Verizon Business. They worked for MCI before Verizon acquired MCI last year. The group was not unionized under MCI.

It is expected to keep the benchmark interest rate steady at 5.25 percent, as it has since June, but analysts will be looking closely at its statement for clues to where interest rates are heading.

To the Editor: Re ''The Right to Ban Arms'' (editorial, March 14):

Senate Republicans, meanwhile, are rejecting a proposal by the governor to create a state false-claims act for health care fraud, which encourages employees to blow the whistle on malfeasance. The Senate argues in its budget report that such an act ''would be redundant and unnecessary'' because there is already a federal False Claims Act that allows the state to share in half of all fraud recoveries. But recent federal legislation adds an incentive for states that have their own false claims acts, increasing their share of recoveries to 60 percent from 50 percent -- a difference that can amount to tens of millions of dollars. The provision was inserted into legislation by Senator Charles E. Grassley, above, an Iowa Republican, who has been a champion of false claims acts.

Police in Columbus, Ohio, walked the streets around Nationwide Arena an hour before the start of yesterday's Virginia-Tennessee game looking for the tickets stolen the day before from the car of a Tennessee athletic department official. The 550 tickets were invalidated and replaced. They were not honored at the door, so some unsuspecting fans may have been stuck with a $61 souvenir.

NASSAU--Belle, died on March 17th, 2007 at age 95. She was the devoted wife of Benjamin, and loving mother of Michael and Susan, and grandmother of Stephanie, William, and Lesley. Funeral service will be held on Monday March 19th, at Riverside Chapel, 25 West Broad St., Mt Vernon, NY at 12 Noon.

INTERNATIONAL A3-7 As Afghanistan Struggles, One More Threat: AIDS H.I.V. and AIDS have quietly arrived in Afghanistan. It remains almost completely underground, as the government struggles with the help of American and NATO forces to rebuild the country. Surveys tell of 69 confirmed cases, but health officials warn that the incidence is certainly much higher. A1 Zimbabwe Blocks Critics' Travel Zimbabwe's crackdown on the nation's political opposition expanded to block foreign travel by leading government critics. Nelson Chamisa, the spokesman for the largest faction of the party, was severely beaten while en route to Harare's airport for a flight to Brussels, a party official, William Bango, told news services in Harare. A5 Mideast Policy Shows Fissures The first fractures surfaced in the Israeli and American approaches to the new Palestinian unity government, with Israel's cabinet voting overwhelmingly to boycott it, while the United States Consulate refused to rule out contacts with some individual Palestinian ministers. A7 Police Officials Held in Mexico Three high-ranking state police commanders and a former police chief were being held for questioning in the attempted killing of the Tabasco state secretary of public security, after hundreds of soldiers and federal agents raided the police headquarters the day before. A5 End of North Korea Impasse The United States and North Korea have resolved a standoff over North Korean funds frozen in a bank account in Macao, clearing the way for talks to focus on putting in place a nuclear disarmament accord, Chinese and American officials said. A5 Iraqi Official's Home Raided Iraqi security forces seized a large cache of weapons, detained a man with a sniper rifle and found four cars with traces of explosives during a raid on the home of a prominent Sunni Arab lawmaker this month, a senior Iraqi military spokesman said. A6 NATIONAL A8-13 Accounting by Shriners Raises Concerns An examination of the 135-year-old fraternal organization, the Shriners, yields a picture of lax accounting procedures and oversight under which money earmarked for the Shriners Hospitals for Children instead financed temple activities. A1 Senator Wants Aides to Testify Senator Patrick J. Leahy, leading the inquiry into the dismissal of federal prosecutors, insisted that Karl Rove and other top aides to President Bush must testify publicly and under oath, setting up a confrontation between Congress and the White House over the fate of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzalez. A1 Lawsuit Centers on Adoption Olive F. Watson, a granddaughter of Thomas J. Watson, the founder of I.B.M., is involved in a lawsuit with her former same-sex partner, whom she adopted under Maine law. Her partner sued for part of a multimillion dollar inheritance after the couple separated, saying she was technically a grandchild of Mr. Watson. A1 Uproar Over Unpaid Utility Bills Memphis Light, Gas and Water allowed a member of theMemphis city council to forgo paying thousands of dollars in overdue bills without having his power cut, and kept a list of local politicians used to prevent discontinuing their service if they failed to pay their utility bills. The situation has infuriated a city where nearly a quarter are poor and the local utility is publicly owned. A8 Towns Put Climate on Agenda One-hundred-eighty of New Hampshire's 234 cities and towns are voting on a resolution asking the federal government to address climate change. Organizers also hope to use the effort to force presidential candidates to address climate change issues during the state's primary. A8 Early Warnings of F.B.I. Lapses Before the Federal Bureau of Investigation publicly admitted that it had ignored its rules when demanding telephone and financial records about private citizens, a top official in the program warned the bureau about widespread lapses in 2005, his lawyer said. A10 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Atlantic City Rethinks Image as Revenues Fall Faced with competition from new casinos in Pennsylvania and slot machines at Yonkers Raceway in New York, Atlantic City casino operators, who have seen a fall in revenue for the year's first two months, are wagering large sums that they can transform the low-rent gambling factory into a world-class entertainment destination. A1 Robber Has Novel Defense Juan Medina, a man imprisoned at Rikers Island, claims he was working as an undercover operative and committed robbery with the full knowledge and cooperation of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency. The D.E.A., while admitting he was a paid confidential informant, has not come to his aid, and is helping prosecute him on charges of burglary, robbery and criminal possession of a weapon. B1 ARTS E1-8 Competition for N.P.R. Staple The New York public radio station WNYC is teaming up with the distributor Public Radio International to produce a national morning radio program that will compete with National Public Radio's long-running ''Morning Edition.'' The program is intended to expand the public radio audience by focusing on a younger, more multicultural listener than public radio typically draws. E3 OBITUARIES B6 Stuart Rosenberg A director of series television and theatrical films who captured the simmering anti-authoritarianism of the late 1960s in the Paul Newman prison drama ''Cool Hand Luke,'' he was 79. B6 Jay Kennedy An editor in chief of King Features Syndicate who revived ''Prince Valiant'' and introduced the newspaper comic strips ''Curtis,'' ''Mutts'' and ''Zits,'' he was 50. B6 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Cashing In on Video Ads Television networks like Nickelodeon are heavily promoting digital offerings, like online video, to advertisers this spring as video advertising becomes more lucrative. C1 Overture to European Bank Barclays, one of Britain's largest banks, made an informal takeover approach for ABN Amro Holding, the largest bank in the Netherlands, which is under pressure to bolster its share price. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: The Medicaid documentation mess; training workers for good jobs; still not fixing the Army Corps; Adam Cohen on the firing of United States attorneys. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E6 Crossword E6 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E8 Weather D10

A review to find an agency for the tourism campaign for Empire State Development, known by its theme, ''I Love New York,'' will proceed without the incumbent since 2003, Eric Mower & Associates. A required review for the assignment began last month. Mower ''has chosen not to submit a proposal,'' Robert J. Bellafiore, the partner in the Albany office who oversees the account, said last week in an e-mail message. Mower was the first upstate agency to handle the assignment, which has had 11 agencies since its introduction in 1977.

Thousands of war protesters, including union members, veterans and church groups, marched through Midtown yesterday afternoon, starting at Bryant Park and moving along 42nd Street, up Third Avenue to 57th Street and down Second Avenue to 47th Street. The demonstration was one of several nationwide, including one on Saturday in Washington, in advance of the fourth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq, which is tomorrow. The police lined the sidewalks along the route, which passed the offices of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer. No violence was reported during the march, and no arrests were made, the police said. KAI MA

7 P.M. (TLC) MY LIFE AS A CHILD -- In ''Different From You,'' the fourth installment of this series of life stories made by and about young people, four children describe what it's like not to fit in and tell how they deal with teasing. This episode features an 11-yearold girl who just wants to play football, a 9-year-old boy (Forrest, left) who is ostracized for his unorthodox style, an 11-year-old American Indian girl and a 10-year-old boy whose older brother is autistic. 7:30 P.M. (BET) PRIDE -- A coach starts a swim team for troubled teenagers in Philadelphia in this film, featuring Terrence Howard, Bernie Mac and Kimberly Elise. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS -- Laila Ali's fast footwork has already made her a super middleweight boxing champion, and Billy Ray Cyrus certainly knows how to boot scoot, but will those skills help wow the judges in the fourth season of this competition? The talk-show host Leeza Gibbons, the former model (and estranged wife of Paul McCartney) Heather Mills and the Olympic speed-skating champion Apolo Anton Ohno are also among the competitors. 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO -- Mark Ruffalo (far right, with the show's host, James Lipton) discusses his acting career, most recently as an animal-cracker- loving, serial killer-hunting police detective in ''Zodiac.'' 9 P.M. (History) LOST TREASURES OF PETRA -- The builders of the ancient ''rose-red city'' of Petra were believed to be some of the wealthiest denizens of the ancient Middle East. But after carving the city into the side of Jordan's Shara mountains more than 2,500 years ago, the civilization simply vanished. Josh Bernstein, the adventurer host of ''Digging for the Truth,'' examines Petra's single surviving parchment manuscript and the ruins of the city. 9 P.M. (VH1) I LOVE NEW YORK -- In-laws or in trouble? The three remaining ''suitors'' introduce their mothers to New York. Meanwhile, her mother offers one of the men $5,000 to quit the competition. 10 P.M. (Court TV) 'TIL DEATH DO US PART -- In this new scripted comedy, the cult director John Waters has a new role: a commentator on the literal demise of love. Married couples turn on each other and at least one ends up dead as ''the Groom Reaper'' (Mr. Waters, above) guides the audience through the first pangs of newly wedded bliss and the last breaths of an unlucky spouse. 10:15 P.M. (Sundance) THE ROAD TO GUANTÁNAMO -- (2006). In September 2001, a group of British Muslims arrived in Pakistan for a wedding. Soon after, the men were arrested in Afghanistan by the United States and detained at the base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. This film, directed by Michael Winterbottom and Mat Whitecross, mixes documentary and fictional techniques to tell the men's stories. LORI MOORE
