Katherine N. Lapp, the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from 2002 through 2006, has been appointed executive vice president for business operations at the University of California. Ms. Lapp, 50, will be paid $400,000 a year to oversee administrative operations for the university system, managing real estate, human resources, information technology and procurement. A lawyer, Ms. Lapp worked on criminal justice issues in New York in the administrations of Mayor David N. Dinkins, a Democrat, from 1990 to 1993; Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, from 1994 to 1997; and Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, from 1997 to 2001. SEWELL CHAN

OFFER FOR ABN AMRO -- Barclays, Britain's third-largest bank, has made an informal takeover offer for ABN Amro, the largest bank in the Netherlands, which is under pressure from hedge funds to consider a merger or asset sales to bolster its lagging share price. [Page C1.] UPFRONT WITH NICKELODEON -- Nickelodeon, a Viacom unit, was the first of many television networks promoting their digital ventures this spring as advertising executives determine how to spend their clients' budgets at the annual previews known as the upfronts. Viacom also has a lot of content appealing to younger viewers, like ''The Colbert Report,'' starring Stephen Colbert, above. [C1.] VENTURE CAPITAL FOR FILMS -- A fledgling film-financing company called Media Rights Capital may help shift the balance of power in Hollywood by increasing opportunity for idiosyncratic movies like the multilingual ''Babel,'' and by giving filmmakers and stars more earning power and ownership of their projects. [C1.] MUCH ANTICIPATION, FEW DETAILS -- Wall Street investors may be disappointed at what few details they discover from the Blackstone Group's prospectus if the firm decides to go ahead with the initial public offering it is said to be considering. [C3.] WEBCASTERS PROTEST A RULING -- Several Internet radio companies are arguing that a recent decision by the Copyright Royalty Board that they must pay royalties when users listen to a song would make it almost impossible for them to stay afloat. [C4.] A DISLIKED DATING SITE -- True.com has seemingly come out of nowhere to become one of the most visited sites in the $700 million-a-year online dating industry, drawing in 3.8 million people last month. But its provocative ads have made it controversial: ''loathed by everybody,'' is how one industry insider puts it. [C1.] NEWSPAPER FACES LABOR SUIT -- The National Labor Relations Board will prosecute The Santa Barbara News-Press for firing eight reporters from its newsroom, the agency announced. [C3.] TRACKING SPAM WEB PAGES -- Tens of thousands of junk Web pages, created only to lure search-engine users to advertisements, are proliferating like billboards strung along freeways. Now Microsoft researchers say they have traced the companies and techniques behind them. [C4.] ADS IN THE FORM OF 'LOST' KEYS -- At a modest cost, Nissan hopes to promote its 2007 Nissan Altima sedan by ''losing'' 20,000 key rings in bars, concert halls, sports arenas and other public places in seven large urban markets. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] AMAZON, THE SYMPHONY STORE -- Amazon.com, the Internet merchant, has opened a classical music discount store. Thomas May, Amazon's senior music editor, above, says that classical music is one of the fastest-growing music genres on the site. [C4.] TOBACCO COMPANY REJECTS BID -- Imperial Tobacco of Britain said that it would continue ''friendly'' efforts to buy Altadis, a rival based in Spain that rejected its initial offer of 45 euros a share. [C2.] BRAVO TO BUY A WEB SITE -- Bravo, a division of NBC Universal, is buying Television Without Pity, the television review Web site that has bitingly criticized the network's shows. [C4.] CHOICES MEAN REPEAT BUYERS -- Consumers are more likely to repurchase products when the initial buying experience is packed with ''superfluous choices'' -- like the color of a CD case. [C3.]
To the Editor: Russell L. Schweickart's warning about objects striking the Earth was a thoughtful call to action (''The Sky Is Falling. Really,'' Op-Ed, March 16).

About 300 people were evacuated from more than 50 homes in Sunset Park for several hours yesterday because of a carbon monoxide gas leak resulting from a manhole fire, the Fire Department said. Seven people, including two unconscious women and two paramedics, were taken to area hospitals after the evacuations, which took place shortly after noon on 55th Street near Seventh Avenue; none suffered serious injuries, the department said. Others were treated at the scene, above. A resident, Danny Lee, 26, said he called 911 after his carbon monoxide detector went off and he smelled smoke coming from his basement. ''It worked,'' he said of the detector. ''That's why I'm standing here talking to you.'' ANN FARMER

CAHILL--Helen (nee Fitzsimmons), age 99, of New York City and East Hampton, Long Island died on March 14, after severe pneumonia. Widow of the late Robert Livingston Cahill, who died in 1984. Theirs was an idyllic marriage of 57 years. She is survived by their son, Robert L. Cahill, Jr. Their daughter Barbara Healey died in 1998. She leaves her sister Mrs. James (Eileen) Murray, her granddaughter, Robin Gibson and husband Gary Gibson, and her great-granddaughter Kaley Gibson. Predeceased by her sister Mrs. William (Mimi) Meehan and her brother Charles S. Fitzsimmons. Helen Cahill was the oldest living alumna of the Convent of The Sacred Heart in New York City. Mass of The Resurrection will be celebrated Tuesday, March 20 at 10:30 am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave and 76th St. A reception will follow at the community center of the church. The family will greet friends at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave and 81st St. Monday, March 19 from 5 to 8 pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcomed by the St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31st St. NY, NY 10001.

To the Editor: I didn't think that the Bush administration was capable of appalling me any more than it already has, but ''Whose Oil Is It, Anyway?,'' by Antonia Juhasz (Op-Ed, March 13), proved me wrong.

It was the usual circle of hysteria by a team trying to get itself ready for a game in the tunnel leading out to the arena in Columbus, Ohio. But it seemed awfully loud. The curious came out from behind curtains and put down their lunches to see what the commotion was all about.

EAST Georgetown survived a scare from Boston College, but its style does not lend itself to blowouts. Look for the Hoyas to beat North Carolina, which plays Southern California first, in a scintillating regional final. HOYAS ON THE RISE No. 1 North Carolina vs. No. 5 U.S.C. Not easy for the Tar Heels because of U.S.C.'s defense and experience. Look for a close game, but the Heels are too deep. No. 6 Vanderbilt vs. No. 2 Georgetown Vanderbilt abandoned a Princeton-style offense (which the Hoyas use) and has had success. But the Hoyas have too much. SHINING STAR NICK YOUNG, a 6-foot-6 junior forward from Los Angeles, scored a team-high 22 points and grabbed 7 rebounds in U.S.C.'s upset victory over Texas. Young also scored 20 points in the Trojans' victory over Arkansas in the first round. MIDWEST Florida probably just played its toughest game until it reaches Atlanta. With Butler on Friday and the winner of Oregon-U.N.L.V. after that, the Gators should sail to Atlanta. GEORGIA ON GATORS' MIND No. 1 Florida vs. No. 5 Butler The Bulldogs have beaten tough teams, including Tennessee and Notre Dame. But they have no chance against Florida. No. 3 Oregon vs. No. 7 U.N.L.V. It's difficult to gauge Oregon, which is led by the streaky Aaron Brooks. Look for the steady Rebels to reach the Round of 8. SHINING STAR Al Horford hit 7 of 9 shots from the field and scored 17 points against Purdue to help the Gators rally to victory yesterday. Horford showed his polished post moves and sealed the victory with a dunk with one minute remaining. SOUTH Up-tempo Tennessee can make Greg Oden a nonfactor and advance; earlier this season, the Vols lost a close game in Columbus. Texas A&M will have home-court advantage, which should carry the Aggies. NO PLACE LIKE HOME FOR A&M No. 1 Ohio State vs. No. 5 Tennessee Greg Oden had 24 points and 15 rebounds when these teams met in a 2-point Buckeyes win in Columbus. Not this time. No. 3 Texas A&M vs. No. 2 Memphis The Aggies have the athleticism to stay with Memphis. They'll also have many fans in San Antonio to lift them. SHINING STAR The sophomore guard Antonio Anderson scored 14 points and grabbed 10 rebounds in Memphis's victory over Nevada. He scored on a backdoor layup to seal the win and had a key save of an inbounds pass. WEST The West is the chalk region, with the top four seeds -- Kansas, U.C.L.A., Pittsburgh and Southern Illinois -- all advancing. Look for the Bruins to have an advantage thanks to a home crowd in San Jose. BRUINS OFFER A CLINIC No. 1 Kansas vs. No. 4 Southern Illinois The Salukis can guard as well as any team in the country. Still, it's hard to imagine Kansas not advancing. No. 2 U.C.L.A. vs. No. 3 Pittsburgh The week's most-hyped game, with Ben Howland facing his protégé Jamie Dixon. Look for the mentor to prevail. SHINING STAR Jamaal Tatum scored 21 points, shooting 7 of 15, in 31 minutes in the Salukis' blowout of Virginia Tech yesterday. That's good news for Southern Illinois; Tatum rebounded from a 2-of-9 shooting performance against Holy Cross.

Colombian officials said over the weekend that they would consider seeking the extradition of senior executives of Chiquita Brands International after the company pleaded guilty in United States federal court to making payments to paramilitary death squads. Chiquita, one of the world's largest banana producers, agreed to pay a fine of $25 million last week to the United States Justice Department to settle the case. Chiquita told the Justice Department that from 1997 to 2004, a subsidiary in Colombia had paid $1.7 million to right-wing paramilitary groups, which are classified by the United States government as terrorist organizations.

Glittering legal résumés abound among the 23 people Governor Spitzer appointed earlier this month to five screening committees that will review candidates for the state bench. Among Mr. Spitzer's appointments are senior partners at some of New York City's leading law firms, eminent law-school professors and several retired state judges. But many of the appointees have another qualification, too. Ten of them contributed to Mr. Spitzer's gubernatorial campaign, including the leaders of all five committees, who are selected by the governor. (Each committee will eventually have 13 members, including members appointed by the state bar association, the leaders of the State Assembly and Senate, the attorney general and others.) The positions are unpaid.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the account by Dmitri V. Kovtun, a Russian business consultant, of his dealings with Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer who died of radioactive poisoning in November, omitted part of a credit. Alan Cowell not only contributed from his home base in London, but he also reported from Moscow with Steven Lee Myers.
An article on Thursday about plans by the Internet search giant Google to build two facilities in Lenoir, N.C., misstated the month it announced the decision. It was January, not February.

City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Representatives Jerrold Nadler and Anthony D. Weiner put their weight behind an effort to unionize 362 Verizon telephone workers yesterday, confirming that a majority of the workers had signed cards saying they wanted to join the Communications Workers of America. The three political leaders confirmed that 219 of the 362 workers had signed pro-union cards as union officials called on Verizon to grant union recognition because of this majority showing. But Verizon is invoking its right under federal law to ask for a secret-ballot election overseen by the National Labor Relations Board to determine whether a majority wants a union. The 362 employees, who install telephone equipment for businesses, work for a unit called Verizon Business. They worked for MCI before Verizon acquired MCI last year. The group was not unionized under MCI. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

SAYERS--Elliseva, 95, Irishborn newspaperwoman who became a public relations consultant in New York City for over 40 years, writer and poet, died February 27 in Manhattan. Trinity College Dublin Honors graduate, student of Samuel Beckett, and correspondent of George Bernard Shaw, she was active in the international press community and Irish-American affairs. Memorial service to be announced. Memorial donations to The Lighthouse, 111 E 59th St., New York City, 10022.

A day after graduating from the Suffolk County Police Academy, an off-duty officer arrested a driver on Saturday who was running from the scene of a crash on Route 25, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The officer, Anthony Napolitano, who had seen the crash from inside his car, arrested the driver, Steven Kowalski, after a brief pursuit in a wooded area, the police said. Mr. Kowalski, 31, of Farmingville, was charged with driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident with injury, the police said. The two occupants of the other vehicle involved in the crash, which occurred about 5:30 p.m., suffered injuries that were not life-threatening, the police said; their names were not released. Officer Napolitano is to officially begin work today at the Fourth Precinct in Hauppauge. FERNANDA SANTOS

Robert Glasper ''In My Element'' (Blue Note) The depth of the pianist Robert Glasper's art so far has been about coordination: making all members of his piano trio move together as a single organism. It's the best part of his gigs, this stealthy motion; it's coordinated and dense, hard to separate into neat metrical divisions. It addresses an old challenge in jazz: how to be fast and quiet.
FEUER--Rona. Our dearest Rona, you were too good and kind for such a tragic end due to ALS. We'll miss and love you. Rest in peace. Ginger and Mike

Modest Mouse ''We Were Dead Before the Ship Even Sank'' (Epic) Lots of indie rockers can convey the sensation of being adrift. Isaac Brock, the leader of Modest Mouse, prefers to make you feel wind-tossed and battered, with a saline tang on your tongue. On ''We Were Dead Before the Ship Even Sank,'' the band's fifth album, he fixates on nautical imagery with comic intensity. The results are enthralling, even when they seem to be thrashing at coherence.

SCHWEITZER--Dr. Daniel Lawrence, passed away peacefully at his home in Scarsdale on the evening of March 14th. He was an eclectic, loving, spirited man who will be greatly missed and who made a lasting impression on all those that knew him. He is survived by his daughter, Dina Schweitzer Leitch, son-in-law, William Leitch, and his two granddaughters, Kaylia and Madeline Leitch, all of San Anselmo, California; his son, David Schweitzer and companion Daisy Luna; his dedicated and caring partner, Susan Rowley, and her two daughters, Betsy and Chrissy Rowley; his brother Richard Schweitzer, sister - in - law, Nancy Schweitzer, and niece and nephew, Marlowe and Jonathan Schweitzer. He is also survived by former wife Carole Wiley Henry. His brother Leonard prede ceased him. Dr. Schweitzer is the son of the late Honorable Mitchell and Sylvia Schweitzer of New York City. Services will be held Tuesday, March 20th at noon at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY 10552. Telephone 914-664-6800. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Jansen Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

LINTZ--Worth B., Dr., respected New York City physician and long time resident of Westchester, died peacefully on Saturday, March 17, at age 83. Dr. Lintz began practicing medicine in 1953, joining his father in private practice at his midtown office. He retired in 1991. He is survived by his wife, Annette Pare Lintz, his five children and their spouses, and six grandchildren. A memorial mass will be celebrated at 10:00am on Wednesday, March 21, at Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Dobbs Ferry. Donations to March of Dimes are requested in lieu of flowers (www.marchofdimes.com).

These are strange days in the capital. When the Republican-led State Senate called last week for spending more in next year's budget than did the Democratic governor, Eliot Spitzer, or the Democratic-led State Assembly, newspapers around the state marveled at what one called a political ''Freaky Friday'' and another termed ''Bizarro world,'' a nod to the alternate, topsy-turvy universe of Superman and ''Seinfeld'' fame. That through-the-looking glass quality was only heightened when Michael R. Long, the chairman of the state's Conservative Party, wrote a letter to Governor Spitzer in support of his budget, saying, ''as difficult as your budget is, what the Republican-controlled Senate is proposing forces me to re-evaluate your proposals.''
NOVAK--Milton. Devoted husband of Shirley, loving father of David and Adele, Debbie and Amy, dear grandpa of Elena and beloved teacher. Memorial service to be announced.

Joss Stone ''Introducing Joss Stone'' (Virgin) There comes a time when a young diva wants to break free of her handlers and declare herself a career-controlling woman. So Joss Stone, the 19-year-old British R&B singer, did what any girl who wants respect as an auteur would do. She stripped naked, got slathered with psychedelic body paint and straddled her producer for the liner art to her new CD.

Daughter-in-law to William Carlton and the late Mildred, sister - in - law to Barbara Goodman (Barry). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, March 20, at 9:30 am at the Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

SPORTSMONDAY, PAGE D1

Two firefighters were arrested and charged with assault in separate incidents on Saturday, the police said. The first firefighter, Harry Pfeiffer, 27, and his friend Nicola Ciaramella, 27, are charged with attacking a third man, Ronald Buonagura, 31, with a shovel at Mr. Buonagura's home in Howard Beach, Queens, about 7 p.m., the police said. Mr. Buonagura in turn stabbed Mr. Pfeiffer and Mr. Ciaramella with a knife, the police said; none of the men were seriously injured. All three were charged with weapons possession and assault, the police said. They said the fight appeared to be over a woman. The second firefighter, Douglas Barry, was arrested shortly before 11 p.m. at Broadway and Warren Street in Manhattan and charged with third-degree assault, the police said. He is accused of punching a woman in a dispute over a cab. MICHAEL WILSON

WEXLER--Beatrice, Passed away March 17 peacefully. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Mother of Annette Schmell (David(d)), and Susan Wexler (d). Grandmother of Rachel and Joshua, sister of Etty Shepp (d) and Fradle Goldberg. Funeral March 19, 11 am at Gramercy Chapels, 152 2nd Ave, NYC.

In a movie that might be called ''Six Degrees of Separation From Being John Malkovich,'' Mr. Malkovich plays a man who gains entree to British high and low society by pretending to be the film director Stanley Kubrick. ''Color Me Kubrick'' opens on Friday. Mr. Malkovich is known for portraying complex villains, like in ''In the Line of Fire,'' and for bringing a subtle wit to his roles, too. At one point in ''Kubrick'' the faux director even mentions some actor named John Malkovich as a potential cast member. The reply is ''who?'' SHELLY FREIERMAN

Crime Mob ''Hated On Mostly'' (Crunk Incorporated/G's Up /Reprise) Remember 2004? Back then hip-hop was going through one of its rowdy phases. The screaming producer Lil Jon was everywhere, and the hyped-up Southern sound known as crunk was all over the radio. And sometime during this magical year (ah, nostalgia), a spectacularly unruly group known as Crime Mob emerged with a hit called ''Knuck if You Buck,'' which was designed to make clubgoers stop dancing and start fighting. Their self-titled debut album contained more of the same: half a dozen manic teenagers, all threatening fisticuffs.
''I feel like I'm going to collapse. It's taken over my days, my nights.'' INTISAR RASHID whose husband, an Iraqi police officer, has been missing for two months. [A1]

If people whose language skills are limited to English can revel in grand opera sung in Italian or French, is there anything really so odd about comic operetta sung in Yiddish? Well, no and yes.

There may be some money coming into state coffers next year that no one is accounting for. Under the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, a multistate pact intended to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from power plants, New York State could be in a position to begin auctioning emissions allowances to power plants in January. Those auctions could yield more than $250 million a year, officials said.

When the dance company Palissimo presented ''Le Petit Mort/Now It's Time to Say Goodbye'' at Performance Space 122 in the East Village in December, the title proved too apt. During an especially difficult duet on opening night, one dancer tore cartilage in his knee. Although he finished the show, remaining performances were canceled. Now that dancer, Saar Harari, has recovered; and the company, led by the choreographer Pavel Zustiak, is returning to the same theater to try it again from April 12 to 15. The space will also feature an accompanying photo exhibit by Jose Aragon, inspired by the production. STEVEN McELROY

While Butler is perhaps the team with the lowest profile in the Round of 16 thus far, the private, liberal arts university in Indianapolis has an eclectic list of former students and faculty. Peter Lupus, an original member of the television series ''Mission: Impossible,'' is an alumnus of the 4,415-student university. So is David Starr Jordan, a member of the class of 1878 who went on to become Stanford's first president.

A review on Friday of ''Incisive Images: Ivory and Boxwood Carvings, 1450-1800,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misidentified a figure on the Lamentation, a relief by Adam Lenckhart. It was St. John the Apostle, sometimes known as St. John the Beloved Disciple, grasping the robe of the Virgin -- not John the Baptist. The review also misstated the source of the items in the exhibition. Five of the nearly 100 pieces were borrowed from private collections; not all came from the Met's collection.
