The devoted staff at Janet Brown mourns the loss of our fashion icon. $(6$)BROWN--Janet, (born in Philadelphia, PA, March 23, 1947), died suddenly in a car accident on Friday, March 16th, as she drove to work. Janet enjoyed an iconic career as founder of Janet Brown Ltd., the chic Long Island boutique. She was loved by her friends, respected by her colleagues; her quick irreverent sense of humor and extraordinary heart will be missed by all. She is survived by her sister Elaine Edelstein, of Villanova, PA, her brotherin-law Marc, and her niece and nephew Brandon and Melissa, in addition to her countless friends. Funeral services will be held Tuesday March 20, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison and 81st street. Donations may be made in the name of Janet Brown to the New York Child Study Center, 577 1st Avenue, New York City, NY 10016.

It's Kennedy versus Kennedy as two members of Congress from the same family face off over competing versions of legislation that would require many health insurance companies and employers to provide more generous benefits to people with mental illness. Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, Democrat of Rhode Island and chief sponsor of the House bill, has criticized as inadequate the Senate bill introduced by his father, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. Representative Kennedy is trying to mobilize mental health advocates to lobby for what he describes as ''the stronger of the two bills, the House bill.''
TAFTI--Joan Ph.D. 2/3/603/19/06. Psychologist, mother, wife and friend who brought out the best in everyone. Love always, Ariana & Peter

Applebee's International, Overland Park, Kan., placed its creative account in review after seven years at Draft FCB, Chicago, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Spending was estimated at $175 million. Draft FCB resigned the account by declining to take part in the review. Kraft Foods, Northbrook, Ill., shifted the creative assignment for Miracle Whip to the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, from the Chicago office of JWT, part of the WPP Group, which had done the work since 1933. Spending was estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

Magic Johnson, Michigan State's most famous basketball alumnus, showed up to give the Spartans a pep talk before they played North Carolina in the second round of the East Region in Winston-Salem, N.C., on Saturday night. He stuck around to console them, too, after the Spartans lost to the Tar Heels, 81-67. ''I do want to publicly say how much I appreciate the guy jumping in an airplane in L.A., pick up his dad in Lansing, just to come here and watch a game that for sure not many people thought we could win,'' Spartans Coach Tom Izzo said. ''I guess that's the greatest thing about being a Spartan for me.

WILLIAMS--Mary G. Died March 15, following a hospital procedure. Born in Cleveland, OH, she was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Quincy Adams of Youngstown, OH, and a graduate of Wooster College. She was 89. After working as a reporter on the Youngstown Vindicator, she served for 3 years during WWII in India and Europe in the American Red Cross. After the war, she was a secretary to the foreign editor of the New York Herald Tribune. For nearly 56 years she was married to John D. Williams, a veteran journalist with the Wall Street Journal. She loved to follow politics. Visitations will be held Monday, March 19, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 81st and Madison 2-4pm and 6-8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Red Cross would be appreciated.
To the Editor: Re ''Department of Injustice,'' by Paul Krugman (column, March 9):

Tracey Thorn ''Out of the Woods'' (Astralwerks) It has been eight years since the last album by Everything But the Girl, the British duo of Tracey Thorn and Ben Watt. And it has been 25 years since the previous -- and first -- solo album by Ms. Thorn. Those are just two reasons why ''Out of the Woods,'' her long-delayed second solo album, is such a shock.

An architecture review on Tuesday of housing complexes in the skid row area of Los Angeles misidentified the location of the planned New Carver Apartments. They are slated for a site along the 10 Freeway, not the 110 Freeway. Also, a picture caption with the review carried an incorrect credit. The image, of a model of the Carver Apartments, was by Michael Maltzan Architecture -- not Will Carson/Michael Maltzan Architecture.

GINSBERG--Sidney, WWII Veteran, recipient of five bronze service stars, survivor of the D-Day Invasion, Bridge at Ramogan, Liberation of Dachau, witness to his brother Harold's death while serving together in the 9th division, succumbed at the age of 90 on March 16, 2007 to multiple medical problems. A hero to his adoring daughter Joan and his son-in-law Bob whom he loved like a son, devoted granddaughter Stacey and her husband Andrew, loving grandson Richard and wife Suzanne, and greatgrandchildren Jack and Annabel. We all loved him and will miss him dearly. The world has lost a true hero. A memorial service will be held on Monday, March 19, 2007 at 10:00 am at I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Road, East Northport, NY. 631-499-6060.

Five days turned grouchiness into sunshine. Mike Mussina stood in the Yankees' clubhouse at Legends Field on Sunday afternoon with ice wrapped around his right shoulder and with a grin on his face, eager to discuss his first effective outing of the spring -- one, he felt, that had been too long in coming. ''A day of relief,'' Mussina called it after he pitched five scoreless, three-hit innings in the Yankees' 8-1 exhibition victory over Pittsburgh.

For better or for worse, Bowie Kuhn had a major effect on much of baseball history as commissioner from 1969 to 1984. He put the World Series in prime time and the designated hitter in the American League. Instead of attending the game in which Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth's career home run record, he sent an emissary. He rejected Curt Flood's plea to overturn his trade from the Cardinals to the Phillies. He suspended George Steinbrenner, Ted Turner and Denny McLain. He barred Mickey Mantle and Willie Mays for promoting casino gambling. But none of those decisions by Kuhn, who died Thursday at 80, altered the game on the field, at least in the A.L. East, as much as his 1976 voiding of the stunning sales at the June 15 trading deadline by Charles O. Finley, the Oakland Athletics' obstreperous owner, of three players he deemed too expensive to re-sign: the ace left-hander Vida Blue to the Yankees for $1.5 million, and the future Hall of Fame reliever Rollie Fingers and outfielder Joe Rudi to the Red Sox for $1 million each.

A review for a big new assignment from Nike will take place without the lead Nike creative agency, Wieden & Kennedy. Nike, which has used Wieden & Kennedy as its principal creative shop since 1982, is seeking an agency to create worldwide campaigns for running shoes as part of a reorganization of product categories. When Nike said it would consider other agencies for the assignment, Wieden & Kennedy decided to forgo the review and focus on its other Nike work. Nike spends more than $200 million a year on advertising.

An article by Reuters on Saturday about the creation of a joint military command for Ivory Coast, a step toward unifying government and rebel forces, incorrectly described the current military situation. The government controls the south, while the rebels control the north, not the other way around.
Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below. - The Editors
A defiant President Bush warned Democrats to accept his offer to have top aides speak about the firings of federal prosecutors privately and not under oath.

A few weeks ago, The New Yorker published a story about "24" co-creator Joel Surnow, who, as it turns out, is a self-described "right-wing nutjob" and personal friends with Rush Limbaugh, and who produces a show that inspired Dick Cheney's wife to proclaim she is "an extreme '24' fan." I live in Brooklyn, so it goes without saying that the majority of my friends are liberals, at least those willing to speak about their political beliefs in the borough's (somewhat) open air. Also, the majority of my friends are "24" fans. And they suddenly found themselves confused.

The Bracket has touched ground in San Antonio and is perched in his hotel room overlooking the Alamodome . (I can't think of The Alamo itself and not think of Pee-wee's Big Adventure, when Pee-wee reaches the Alamo and is crestfallen that there's no basement. A fortune teller had told him his bicycle was there.)
For Nicholas D. Kristof, getting a trim from a street barber is a great gauge of how things are going in Afghanistan.
That the movie "300" was able to weather an unusually fierce barrage of bad reviews on its way to becoming the No. 1 movie in America is prompting a simple question. Should critics just ... stop?

It was very clear from President Bush's brief statement and short news conference just ended that he does not intend to back down from his support of Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, nor will he allow his top White House staff -- adviser Karl Rove and former White House counsel Harriet Miers and their deputies -- to be subjected to open public testimony on Capitol Hill.

The White House, in the latest chapter of the ever-evolving U.S. attorney saga, said that Karl Rove and Harriet Miers would be available to Congress to be interviewed, but only under strict conditions and not under oath. The left-leaning blogs did not seem surprised at the move.

In a week of deals, the specter of yet another buyout sent the stock of one company spiking. Trading volume for shares of Archers Daniel Midland, the food-processing giant, spiked on Tuesday as the market responded to rumors of a takeover. But analysts remained skeptical of such a deal.
A commercial pod from the CW Network.
Mayor Bloomberg qualifies his months-old comments about "excessive" force in the Sean Bell shooting. [The Politicker]

Scientists have built a better mosquito: one that doesn't spread malaria. Researchers at Johns Hopkins University report in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences that these genetically modified mosquitoes, which are resistant to the malaria parasite in mice, gradually replaced other mosquitoes when they both fed on infected mice.

In the time since Mike Pelfrey last pitched -- Wednesday, when his fastball was nonexistent -- he has done more to get ahead in the fifth-starter's derby than he did on that blustery afternoon in Lakeland. Check out his competition:

Omar Minaya said Ruben Sierra, reassigned to minor-league camp last Thursday, has been granted his release and is trying to hook up with another team. Also, Duaner Sanchez is expected to begin throwing from a mound by the end of the week. He will need to throw a few bullpen sessions and some live batting practice before he will be ready to pitch in a game. Minaya seemed skeptical that would happen before the Mets leave Port St. Lucie after next Friday's game.

Faster than a thumb-typing Treo addict, rumors about a Palm takeover were flying Tuesday. The chatter, which began earlier in the day with a report on the Web site Unstrung.com, grew louder after blogs and news reports started seeing a potential connection between the purported Palm auction and the decision by Motorola chief executive Edward Zander to cancel a speech at a major industry conference next week. A Motorola spokesman told the Chicago Tribune the cancellation was because of "an unforeseen scheduling conflict," but there was speculation that Mr. Zander might be too busy negotiating a bid for Palm.

When Scholastic announced that it would be printing 12 million copies of the final Harry Potter book, the number inspired more awe than practical concerns. Chiefly, where is all that paper going to come from?
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is looking on the bright side about a dark video about her that's been making the rounds on YouTube.

The New York Post reported this morning that the city has shut down Brasserie LCB on West 54th Street (the new, less expensive incarnation of La Côte Basque). According to Page Six, the owner, Jean-Jacque Rachou, got into "a profanity-laced spat" with the inspectors after they stayed for hours.
A meeting of the House Democratic caucus broke up shortly after lunchtime. Before the doors swung open, a booming round of applause could be heard inside the room in the basement of the Capitol.

It's official: Claire's Stores, purveyor of costume jewelry and accessories to preteens, said Tuesday afternoon that it will be acquired by Apollo Management for about $3.1 billion in cash. Under the terms of the deal, Apollo will pay $33 a share for the company, a premium over Monday's closing price of $30.76.

Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly sat down last Tuesday for an interview with Lx.Tv, a lifestyle channel on the Web. Most of the questions are softballs but he does address the Sean Bell case about six minutes in: "The central question to this incident: is this an aberration or is it an indication of a systemic problem? And that's what we want to find out."

Sanford I. Weill's reign as the banking industry's top deal-maker may be coming to an end. If Barclays and ABN Amro succeed in their merger talks -- they announced further progress Tuesday, including agreements on location and management structure -- the deal would likely carry a price of more than $80 billion, which would surpass the value of Travelers' landmark merger with Citicorp in 1998. That transaction is widely seen as the defining moment of Mr. Weill's career and, up until now, no bank deal has topped its $72.6 billion price tag.
Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, who is Gov. Eliot Spitzer's nominee to head the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, got his day in the Senate today -- but it won't be his last.

New Yorkers, you are not alone when it comes to being perplexed by mystery odors. Recall the sweet smell that wafted over the city at least twice, perhaps three times, in 2005, and the gassy odor that swept through earlier this year, causing evacuations and transit disruptions.
U.N.L.V. is the lowest seed still alive in the Round of 16. But as a No. 7, the Runnin' Rebels are still in the top half of the bracket, if just barely.

Halcyon Asset Management, a hedge fund that manages $10 billion in assets, said Tuesday it hired Kyle Ransford as a managing principal to expand its real-estate investment activities. Mr. Ransford is a co-founder of Cardinal Real Estate Investments, a firm whose holdings include commercial and residential properties in New York and Los Angeles and islands in Fiji, according to its Web site. Mr. Ransford will remain a general partner at Cardinal, Halcyon said.

With a Darwin Deason as an ally, Cerberus Capital Management might seem to have the buyout of Affiliated Computer Services all wrapped up. After all, Mr. Deason is Affiliated Computer's founder and chairman, and he has a voting stake of nearly 42 percent in the company, a provider of technology outsourcing services. But after Mr. Deason and Cerberus announced their plan Tuesday to take the company private in a deal valued at $8.2 billion, including debt, Bryan Keane, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group, speculated that Mr. Deason might be open to teaming up with someone else.

It seems that the official talks between Barclays of Britain and ABN Amro of the Netherlands have been fruitful: The two have already hashed out agreements over location and management structure. In a statement, the two banks said that they have agreed to keep their headquarters in Amsterdam, and will maintain a primary listing on the London Stock Exchange and a secondary listing in Amsterdam.
Grand Canyon National Park encompasses most of the wonder of the world it is named for, but there are slices of the canyon's rim that have endured for years outside the park's control.

Some harsh words, including the F-bomb, livened up the usually bland world of regulatory filings last week. The colorful exchange, noted by Paul Kedrosky on his blog Infectious Greed, was directed at Robert Chapman, the chief of Chapman Capital, whose grandiloquently harsh criticism of the companies he invests in regularly raises executive ire. (DealBook readers may recall that Mr. Chapman recently complained about not receiving a return phone call from the chief executive of eSpeed, another company he has pressured for change.)

Surprising news item on the Decanter magazine website. Apparently sales of wood chips to Bordeaux wine producers have soared in the last few months. It was surprising to me, at least, because I thought that in 2006 the French had banned the use of wood chips in response to the European Union's decision in 2005 to allow their use. It turns out that though the Institut National des Appellations d'Origine, which regulates French A.O.C. wines, had last November banned the use of wood chips, the ban hasn't yet been signed into law. Ah, bureaucracy.

The philanthropist, former junk-bond mogul and ex-convict Michael Milken is in deal-making mode. Bloomberg News reports that he is looking to sell $1 billion worth of equity in Knowledge Universe, his privately held group of education companies, and has hired Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse to help him find buyers.

In recent years, when Albany's leaders have forsaken their customary three-men-in-a-room meetings to discuss the budget in public, they almost always avoided debate on substantive issues - like what to do about health care and education -- and focused on procedural issues - like, whether they were all free the next week to continue the talks.
The competition, held in the West Indies, has seen the death of Pakistan Coach Bob Woolmer, the benching of the England captain and a good run of form for New Zealand and South Africa.

Mitch Lasky, who as chief executive of Jamdat led the company to the top of the cellphone-games market, is leaving his post as head of Electronic Arts's mobile-games unit to join Benchmark Capital as a general partner. The move suggests that Benchmark, a Silicon Valley venture firm that just celebrated the sale of portfolio company Tellme Networks to Microsoft, will be considering more investments in gaming startups.

After a nearly four-month auction that sparked little excitement, Claire's Stores may have finally found a bidder. The New York Post reported Tuesday that Apollo Management, the buyout firm run by Leon Black, is close to signing a $3 billion deal for the company, which sells jewelry and accessories to preteens. Citing unnamed sources, the paper said that Apollo would pay between $32 and $34.50 a share. Shares in the chain were up 1.33 percent at $31.17 in mid-morning trading Tuesday.

Golf courses are becoming the focal points for luxury developments around the world. And they are drawing buyers who have no intention of teeing off. Indeed developers have realized that buyers can be lured with manicured lawns, beautiful views, and resort-style living. Above is the championship golf course that's featured at Pezula, a luxury residential project along South Africa's celebrated Garden Route. Only about 25 percent of the buyers there are golfers. Houses typcially cost between £429,000 and £500,000 -- or between about $810,000 and $1 million. www.pezula.com
Tour the vacation home of Barbara Benish, an artist, and Petr Kalny, an architect, in the mountains of southern Bohemia in the Czech Republic.
Tour an island home off the North Carolina coast, a log-style house in Beulah, Colo., and a contemporary condo in Seattle.

While everyone's still sorting through last night's e-mail dump from the Justice Department on the fired United States attorneys (some 3,000 pages of documents released a few hours before midnight), President Bush called Attorney General Alberto Gonzales this morning to express his support.

The Times's Adam Nagourney has a major policy piece on immigration today that spells out the liabilities for Republican candidates on the issue, especially Senator John McCain. The Arizona senator has been his party's most vocal proponent of "comprehensive" immigration legislation, which would include a path to citizenship for those currently in the country illegally. But in response to questions from Iowans recently, Mr. McCain said he would be open to supporting a different bill that would force illegal immigrants to return home before applying for citizenship.

With dozens dead in clashes in the northwest and continuing fallout over President Pervez Musharraf's suspension of the chief justice of the country's Supreme Court, Pakistan hardly needed to hit the bad-news trifecta.

After 10 years, Blockbuster is running the closing credits on chief executive John Antioco. The video-rental chain, which has struggled to compete with changing movie-viewing habits and upstart services such as Netflix, said Tuesday that Mr. Antioco, who has led the company since 1997, would step down by the end of the year. The agreement drew praise from activist investor Carl Icahn, who sits on Blockbuster's board. In previous years, Mr. Icahn has sparred with Mr. Antioco about how to run the company and how much Mr. Antioco gets paid.

The muted international response to Khalid Shaikh Mohammed's confession that he plotted the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, is evidence that the Bush administration's policies on the detention and treatment of enemy combatants have harmed the interests of the United States, says Washington Post columnist Anne Applebaum. She writes:

In one of the three-minute interstitial talks at the recent TED conference, presenter Steve Beshara demonstrated a high-end oven that cooks food up to 15 times as fast as a traditional oven. As the "Mission: Impossible" theme played, he attempted to bake a rack full of soufflés in 90 seconds. (Needless to say, he succeeded.)

"Mad Money" host Jim Cramer has gained a huge following, and more than a few critics as well, with his explosive stock-picking patter. But in a revealing video interview with TheStreet.com, the financial Web site he cofounded, Mr. Cramer drops some bombshells that go well beyond his usual chair-throwing, 'Booyah'-shouting routine. In the clip, which has drawn lots of commentary on YouTube, Mr. Cramer brags about his ability as a former hedge-fund manager to game the stock market and offers what amounts to a how-to to aspiring stock manipulators, The New York Post reported Tuesday.
Before Easter, eating the meat of capybara, reputed to be the world’s largest rodent, has a status in Venezuela similar to that of turkey during Thanksgiving.

Last week, New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson, a candidate for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination, signed a law banning cockfighting, making Louisiana the last state in the union to permit the practice. Weekly Standard senior editor Christopher Caldwell doesn't appear to like cockfighting, but he thinks the eagerness of "comedians and columnists alike" to lampoon Richardson "for opining there are 'strong arguments on both sides'" illustrates how something fundamental in American politics has changed. "It used to be, under the U.S. system, that one could do anything that was not expressly forbidden," Caldwell writes in The Financial Times. "Now one is forbidden to do anything one cannot make an explicit case for. The burden of proof has shifted."
Second Avenue Subway: "We are praying that they run out of money." -- Sally Ardrey, whose East 72nd Street home would be torn down.

For Naomi Campbell, preparing to pay her debt to society -- five days of community service for hitting her maid with a cellphone -- did not simply require the summoning of enough humility to leave the fashion world for the blue-collar one. It also required a thorough examination of her fashion options.

Affiliated Computer Services's chairman, Darwin Deason, and Cerberus Capital Management said Tuesday they had offered to take the technology outsourcing company private for $59.25 a share in cash, or about $8.2 billion including assumed debt. The offer represents a 15.5 percent premium to Affiliated Computer's closing share price Monday.

Palm, the iconic but struggling maker of smartphones and handheld devices, could reach a deal to sell itself by this Thursday for at least $20 a share, the Web site Unstrung reported citing unnamed sources. Among the four leading bidders is Nokia, the world's largest cellphone maker, according to the site. But Unstrung reported that Palm management would prefer a private equity bidder, naming the Texas Pacific Group and, tentatively, Silver Lake Partners as in the running.

Dubai Aerospace Enterprise is nearing a deal to buy a series of aviation businesses from the Carlyle Group for more than $1.5 billion, Reuters reported Monday, citing an unnamed source. As part of the agreement, DAE, an investment firm, would buy Landmark Aviation, an aircraft maintenance provider, and Standard Aero, which provides repair and overhaul services at airport terminals for small-jet aviation and some military transports, according to Reuters' source.

After Take-Two Interactive Software, the video game publisher announced Monday that it was mulling a sale, analysts appeared divided on whether the company could pull off a deal, and if so, with whom. Take-Two said that it was weighing options including a possible sale of the company, days after a group of private equity and mutual funds that control 46 percent of the outstanding shares said it would seek to oust the board and possibly the top management.

The Communist Party USA has donated a vast archive of documents to New York University, Patricia Cohen reports today. The cache contains decades of party history including founding documents, secret code words, stacks of personal letters, smuggled directives from Moscow, Lenin buttons, photographs and stern commands about how good party members should behave, and the hand-written last will of the labor activist Joe Hill, which was later set to song. Liberal and conservative historians were enthusiastic about the addition of so many original documents to the historical record, though it could take years to catalog them all.

Landry's Restaurant Group, which is battling Patina Restaurant Group for control for Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, is claiming that Wollensky's chief executive, Alan Stillman, is pushing the Patina deal because he stands to personally gain if the Los Angeles group walks away the winner.

China's securities regulator barred companies from using proceeds from share sales to invest in stocks in an attempt to damp overheating financial markets. Companies are also banned from buying derivatives and convertible bonds with share sale proceeds, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said Tuesday.

A biotech firm, NimbleGen Systems, filed an initial public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to $75 million in common stock. The company, based in Madison, Wis., makes microarrays, or biological assays, and related products for the life sciences research market.

The production company Nu Image/ Millennium Films is reportedly in talks to buy the hedge-fund backed First Look Pictures, whose chief executive and largest shareholder, Henry Winterstern, recently resigned. The move is an about face since Mr. Wintersten was himself planning to make a run at Nu Image before he fell afoul of a backer Prentice Capital Management, reportedly for his lavish spending habits and inability to pick a winner.

BlackRock has added its name to the list of those opposing the $60.50 per share, $3.1 billion buyout of Laureate Education. But the go-shop window has closed without a better offer. BlackRock sent a letter Monday to the Laureate independent board members stating that without an increase it would not support the management buyout backed by a consortium including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Citigroup Private Equity and SAC Capital Management.

Investors were flush with love for Intarcia Therapeutics, despite a failed initial public offering in 2005 and abandonment of its lead-drug program a year ago. The 10-year-old drug developer returned to the well to raise $50 million in a venture capital round led by new investor New Leaf Venture Partners to advance drug delivery programs for hepatitis and diabetes.

Bear Stearns and China's richest man, Huang Guangyu, set up a $500 million fund to invest in retailers in China. Mr. Guangyu, chairman of Gome Electrical Appliances Holdings, will use his closely held Eagle Investment Group to invest $250 million for buying non-appliance retailers, with the New York-based investment bank contributing the remainder, the companies said in a joint statement Tuesday.

Rosneft, Russia's state-run oil company, will borrow $22 billion to buy assets, including those of bankrupt Yukos Oil, helping President Vladimir Putin seal control of the nation's energy industry. Rosneft's board on March 15 approved borrowing $13 billion and $9 billion in credits arranged by banks including Goldman Sachs and BNP Paribas, the company said in a statement Tuesday.

Joining a growing chorus from American businesses, more than 50 major investors, who together manage $4 trillion, asked Congress on Monday to enact tough federal legislation to curb carbon emissions and to overhaul energy policies nationwide. It marks the first time that a group of major money managers, including Merrill Lynch and the California Public Employees' Retirement System, have requested that Congress take such extensive action on global warming.

Quanta Services, a builder of energy and telecommunications networks based in Houston, said Monday that it would buy InfraSource Services for $1.26 billion to expand its services and increase its national presence. The all-stock deal calls for the exchange of 1.223 shares of Quanta's common stock for each outstanding common share of InfraSource. That is about $30.13 a share, a 17.4 percent premium over the closing price of InfraSource stock last Friday, according to the companies.

Jury selection began on Monday in the $101 million insider trading trial of the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, Joseph P. Nacchio, who watched prospective jurors and actively consulted with lawyers.

SAC Capital, the hedge fund, continues to show its activist side. SAC disclosed on Tuesday a 9.5 percent stake in WCI Communities, a Florida homebuilder that the billionaire financier Carl Icahn recently offered to acquire, and said it might enter into discussions with the company's management.

The American Medical Association asked the Justice Department on Monday to block the UnitedHealth Group's proposed $2.6 billion purchase of Sierra Health Services, saying the deal would be anticompetitive. The A.M.A. estimated that if the merger were completed, UnitedHealth would control 78 percent of the market for health maintenance organizations in Nevada and 95 percent of the market in the Las Vegas-Paradise area.
Perhaps the seat was a little too hot.

The former head of Citibank's worldwide commodities trading desk was sentenced to 15 months in prison Monday after pleading guilty to conspiracy last year in connection with a plan to inflate trading profits by as much as $20 million. At a hearing in Manhattan, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of United States District Court also ordered the former trader, David Becker, to pay $200,000 in restitution and a $25,000 fine. The prison term will be followed by two years of supervised release.

The chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, received compensation valued at nearly $23 million in 2006, according to a regulatory filing Monday. Mr. Lewis, 59, received $1.5 million in salary, $6.5 million in nonequity incentive plan compensation, and stock and option awards that were valued by the company at $14.6 million on the dates they were issued.
As Democratic House leaders move toward a critical vote this week on Iraq spending legislation, one of their most difficult challenges has been gauging the restlessness on the party's left.

CBOT Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Bord of Trade, and IntercontinentalExchange, the energy derivatives market, are moving quickly after a proposal on Thursday by ICE to buy the Chicago exchange for $9.9 billion. The parent of the Chicago exchange said Monday that its board had authorized talks with ICE, adding it had not changed a recommendation that shareholders vote next month in favor of a merger struck with CME Holdings, parent of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

Confirming myriad reports, Barclays, the British bank, said Monday that it was in talks with ABN Amro Holding about a possible takeover. Analysts esimated the price of a deal at 60 billion euros ($80 billion), which could make it the biggest ever in the financial services industry.

Delta Air Lines said Monday that its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, who has shepherded the carrier through reorganization, would not receive any stock, incentive payments or severance when the company exits bankruptcy protection this spring.

The criminal trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black and three associates ran into some delays on Monday after lawyers for Mr. Black raised concerns about the timing of two large settlements by a chief witness in the case.

Triad Hospitals ditched its deal to sell itself to a private equity consortium after it received a better offer from a rival, Community Health Systems. Triad said Monday that it had accepted Community Health's $5.1 billion offer to create the biggest publicly traded hospital chain in the nation.

A federal appeals panel ruled Monday that a class-action lawsuit against investment banks over their role as advisers to Enron cannot go ahead, dealing a blow to shareholders who lost billions of dollars after the company collapsed in 2001.
The text of President Bush’s remarks on the dismissal of United States attorneys, delivered on March 20, as provided by the White House.

Blackstone Group's reasons for considering a initial public offering probably include a desire for a way for insiders to cash out more easily, as well as a bit of hubris, according to MarketWatch's David Weidner. "Having the biggest market capitalization and making the first splash could be worth more than the purely financial reward to someone who already has all the money he could ever want," Mr. Weidner writes.
In yet another televised marriage of stars, this time for Oxygen, Tori Spelling and her husband resemble a couple of kids with nothing but their dreams, striking out on their own.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Four years after the U.S. invasion of Iraq, most Americans still have no direct sense of the war beyond the television set, Alessandra Stanley writes in today's Arts section. And news programs are not the only place where viewers are exposed to the conflict; it has surfaced as a subplot or subliminal theme on reality shows and sitcoms.

I welcome your comments on my Tuesday column about whether Dick Cheney is an Iranian mole. If you have other suggestions for who should be investigated as a possible mole, list them here as well. Also, here are links to a column about Cheney from last month (and the reader comments) and and a related blog post.

Greetings from Afghanistan, where I'm sitting in the New York Times bureau at the moment, going through my email. My Sunday column on Israel generated plenty of both blasts and praise. At one end of the spectrum, The New York Sun published an extraordinary editorial, "The New Blood Libel," which began:
The ensemble featured strong performances of works by John Adams, John Orfe, Gavin Chuck and Stefan Freund at Zankel Hall on Sunday.
The chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, received compensation valued at nearly $23 million in 2006.
The remotely operated rocket managed to reach space, but a roll problem brought it back down to earth minutes later.
Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco was politically damaged by a shaky post-Hurricane Katrina performance.
A new stables for the police department’s mounted unit was dedicated today, clearing the way for expansion of the Hudson River Park that runs along the city’s west side.
Adam Sandler, who had been scheduled to be the lead guest on tonight’s “Late Show With David Letterman,” has been enlisted to step in as the host of the show.
Teenage use of alcohol and drugs dropped significantly in New York City in 2005 compared with past years, officials said, citing the results of a survey.
Insurgents blew up a car with two children in it after using the children as decoys to get through a military checkpoint in Baghdad, an American general said.
Company deficiencies “at all levels” were responsible for an explosion and fire that killed 15 workers at BP oil in Texas City, a federal safety panel reported today.
Records show 229 same-sex couples have applied for civil union licenses since Feb. 19, when they became legal.
Mr. Haefliger was most renowned as an interpreter of German art song and oratorio roles.
Ms. Brown brought important designers to the wealthy clientele of her small store on Long Island.
The president said he would not allow his key aides to testify under oath about the dismissal of U.S. attorneys, while Democrats insisted they would settle for no less.
Officials blamed the fire on safety violations in the building and a night watchman’s negligence.
The explosion, one of the most deadly in recent years, occurred in a region notorious for mine accidents.

An article on Friday about the dismissal of Israel Singer, a leader of the World Jewish Conference, referred incorrectly to the health of the organization’s president, Edgar M. Bronfman, who has said he wants his son Matthew to succeed him. Dr. Adam Rosenbluth, Mr. Bronfman’s doctor, said Mr. Bronfman is in “very good health. He has no chronic debilitating illness nor does he have any illness that would have impact on his longevity and his ability to lead” the congress. He is not in poor health.
E-mail released by the Justice Department shows tensions at the highest levels of the agency as officials tried to contain a political brushfire.
At least 20 people died early Tuesday when a fire destroyed a retirement home in southern Russia.

A janitor was arrested yesterday on and charged with raping an 8-year-old girl in the basement of Public School 91 on Albany Avenue near East New York Avenue, the police said. The janitor, Francis Evelyn, 58, of Brooklyn, was charged with first-degree rape, sex abuse and endangering the welfare of a child. Melody Meyer, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education, said that Mr. Evelyn had “been removed from the schools pending disposition of the case.” According to the police, the child told her mother about the sexual attacks, which they said took place between Feb. 1 and March 9.
Demonstrators disrupted a meeting of the Panel for Educational Policy and denounced the Bloomberg administration’s plans for further restructuring of the city’s schools.

By pursuing first-degree manslaughter charges against two detectives in the death of Sean Bell, prosecutors in Queens were probably influenced by what happened in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, criminal law experts said yesterday.
The post office will begin selling “forever” stamps before the cost of mailing a first-class letter goes up to 41 cents on May 14.
Corrections

The speaker of the Louisiana House said he would support a bill outlawing cockfighting if it were to take effect two or three years from now, to give people in the industry time to adjust. Speaker Joe R. Salter, who once opposed a ban, said his decision was partly influenced by last week’s passage of a cockfighting ban in New Mexico, which had been the only state other than Louisiana where the practice was legal. A House bill backed by Mr. Salter would impose a six-month jail term, $1,000 fines or both on people found guilty of organizing cockfights or taking part in them. It would take effect in 2010.

A chart with a front-page news analysis article on March 11 about a looming crisis in the mortgage market mislabeled the size of the market that trades mortgage-backed securities. It trades in hundreds of billions of dollars a day, not hundreds of millions.
A town in Alaska’s frozen interior that offered free land to people willing to put down roots had it all spoken for within hours of its being offered.

A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about the spending of money raised by Shriners misstated the state in which a leader at the Decatur Shrine Club raised concerns about proceeds from bingo. It was Alabama, not Georgia.

An article on Wednesday about Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s first official visit to Anbar Province, center of the Sunni insurgency, included an incorrect geographic comparison. At 52,282 square miles, Anbar occupies about the same amount of area as North Carolina — not Utah, which is almost 85,000 square miles.

The Georgia House voted to give $1.2 million to a man wrongly imprisoned for nearly 25 years for a rape committed in 1981. The man, Robert Clark, 46, was exonerated by DNA evidence two years ago; the rape victim had identified him from photo and police lineups, even though she had said earlier that the rapist was much shorter than Mr. Clark, who is 6-foot-1. The resolution, which passed by a vote of 132 to 25, pays Mr. Clark based on the income he lost while imprisoned, personal injury, injury to his reputation and other damages.

Because of an editing error, a headline and film review on Wednesday about “The Go Master” referred imprecisely to the game Go. Although the game flourished in Japan and is an important part of Japanese culture, it is believed to have originated in China. It is not a Japanese game.

Federal prosecutors announced a 19-count indictment against a San Francisco Bay Area wine entrepreneur in an October 2005 fire that destroyed a warehouse and millions of dollars’ worth of bottled wine. The charges against the businessman, Mark Anderson, include arson, tax evasion, mail fraud, using a fake name and interstate transportation of fraudulently obtained property. They are the first stemming from the fire, which burned the Wines Central warehouse on Mare Island, a former naval base in Vallejo, about 30 miles northeast of San Francisco. It destroyed the inventories of more than 80 vintners, worth about $100 million. Mr. Anderson had stored wine at the warehouse but had removed most of it after being asked to do so by business managers several months before the fire. He had been under investigation partly because he was at the warehouse when the fire erupted. The federal public defender in Sacramento, Matthew C. Bockmon, declined to comment on the case.

A man accused of setting a wildfire that killed five firefighters was in court to face additional arson charges as the first detailed evidence on the fires was presented. The man, Raymond L. Oyler, left, is charged with 5 counts of first-degree murder, 17 counts of using an incendiary device and 23 counts of arson. Mr. Oyler, 36, an auto mechanic, pleaded not guilty to the additional arson charges before the start of a preliminary hearing on whether there was enough evidence against him for a trial. He was arrested Oct. 31, soon after a wind-whipped fire raced through the foothills near Banning, about 90 miles east of Los Angeles, overrunning firefighters as they tried to protect a house. A state fire investigator, Capt. Charlie DeHart, testified that Mr. Oyler probably experimented with different arson methods as early as five months before the fatal fire. Captain DeHart said he had found the remains of ignition devices at fires in the area as early as May 16, 2006.

An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Microsoft researchers to trace the origins of fake Web pages that lure search-engine users to advertisements misspelled the surname of a cybersecurity investigator for the company. He is Ming Ma, not Ming Wa.

Rescuers searched for a third day for a 12-year-old Boy Scout who disappeared while camping with his troop in the rugged mountains of western North Carolina, above. The scout, Michael Auberry, vanished in the heavily wooded area after lunch on Saturday. Searchers found his mess kit late Saturday within a mile of the campsite but no other sign of him, the authorities said. “We’re still confident in calling it a search-and-rescue operation,” said Tina White, a spokeswoman for the National Park Service. Temperatures fell to the 20s before dawn on Monday, but sunny skies and temperatures in the 50s prevailed during the day. Overnight, the weather was expected to be milder, with lows in the 40s, and there was a chance of rain today.

The South Carolina Supreme Court ruled that a state ban on video poker also applied to the Catawba Indian Nation, the only federally recognized tribe in the state. The Catawbas had argued that a 1993 land deal with the state allowed them to use video poker machines, which were outlawed statewide in 2000, on their reservation. The state contended that the land deal meant that the tribe’s reservation fell under state, not federal, gambling laws. State Attorney General Henry McMaster said the court had made “a sound decision.” A lawyer for the Catawbas, Jay Bender, called the ruling a setback but said the tribe would appeal to the federal courts.
New York avoided a fifth consecutive overtime game against the Penguins by the slimmest of margins.
An orange-clad crowd of 26,752, the largest in N.I.T. history, gave the game a championship atmosphere, and Syracuse did not disappoint.
The wake for a pizzeria employee murdered last week in Greenwich Village marked the end of many things for his companion and his two brothers.
Josh Childress scored a season-high 25 points and Zaza Pachulia had 23 to help host Atlanta to a 99-76 victory against the Sacramento Kings, the Hawks’ largest win of the season.
Nikki Flores scored 21 points to lead Marist to victory, snapping Middle Tennessee’s 27-game winning streak.

Sanyo Electric said its chairwoman, Tomoyo Nonaka, resigned yesterday, ending her career as one of the few top female executives at a major Japanese company. The resignation came as the company was facing an inquiry into possible accounting problems and was headed for its third consecutive annual loss because of revamping costs and sluggish sales. Ms. Nonaka, left, 52, a former journalist, took the post as chief and chairwoman in June 2005, becoming the first woman to head a major Japanese electronics company. The position of chief was eliminated last year.

China Mobile Communications invited bids for contracts worth as much as 24 billion yuan ($3.1 billion) to build the country’s first high-speed phone network. The company asked equipment makers to submit bids for the network, based on a homegrown standard, said Chen Haofei, the secretary general of an industry group backing the standard. China Mobile, based in Beijing, will spend 4 billion yuan on subsidies for third-generation handsets, and the network will cover eight cities in China, including Beijing and Shanghai.

A budget released by the minority Conservative government on Monday would phase out special tax concessions for investors in oil sands projects by 2015. The current system dates back to 1972 and allows oil companies to depreciate capital investments in oil sands operations at a highly accelerated rate. Intended as a method of promoting oil sands developments, it effectively postpones all taxation on income from the projects until their billions of dollars in investment costs are fully written down. The left-leaning New Democrat Party has said that the current rush to develop the oil sands makes special tax concessions unnecessary.
Lottery Numbers.
In the past week, Channing Frye shoved his way back into the picture for New York, scoring 20 points in consecutive games for the first time this season.
Newark Mayor Cory A. Booker is working to unseat a number of state legislators who he says are standing in the way of his ambitious agenda.

The Suffolk County police are investigating a fire that injured a woman late Sunday in Bohemia, the police said yesterday. The fire, at 883 Wall Street, started about 11:40 p.m. in the living room of a ranch house. Three teenagers escaped and alerted a neighbor. After the police were called, a neighbor, Joseph Imperato, 53, a New York City firefighter, entered the house to search for the woman, but was driven back by the fire. The woman, Donna Blieka, 46, was rescued by firefighters and taken to the Nassau University Medical Center. She was in critical condition yesterday, the police said. The fire was not considered suspicious, the authorities said.

In anticipation of the 100-year anniversary of the national parks system, the National Park Service has scheduled a public meeting today at Federal Hall National Memorial to listen to comments on the future of the parks, officials said. The session, from 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. at 26 Wall Street, is one of a series scheduled around the country. Although the centennial is 10 years away, officials said they were seeking input now to allow a 10-year lead time for projects to commemorate the anniversary. “We are asking the public what they would like us to do with their parks,” said Darren Boch, a spokesman for the service.

A doctor from Livingston pleaded guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to writing thousands of phony prescriptions for a drug gang that illegally sold prescription painkillers like OxyContin, prosecutors said yesterday. The doctor, Mario Comesanas, 51, pleaded guilty to first-degree racketeering, Attorney General Stuart Rabner said. Dr. Comesanas, who faces 15 years in prison and must forfeit his medical license, admitted writing fraudulent prescriptions at the home of another man charged in the case, Mr. Rabner said. He said 17 other people, including a pharmacist, had also been charged in the case. The ring sold 20,000 to 30,000 OxyContin and Percocet pills a week, with most of the drugs going to another group in the Bronx, Mr. Rabner said.

A former city police officer pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to drug trafficking charges, federal prosecutors said. The former officer, Jose Torrado, admitted helping his brother distribute large quantities of cocaine and marijuana in the New York area from 2002 to 2005, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Torrado, 31, of the Bronx, joined the Police Department in 2001 and resigned in 2006 as a result of the investigation, Mr. Garcia said. He added that while Mr. Torrado served as a police officer, he worked with a group that smuggled drugs from Mexico to New York in trucks.

A Cape May County couple claimed half of a record $390 million lottery jackpot yesterday. Harold Messner, 57, and his wife, Elaine, 56, of Upper Township, chose the cash option from the Mega Millions drawing on March 6. They will receive $116,557,083 before the 25 percent federal withholding tax. A truck driver in Georgia had the other winning ticket. Mr. Messner, a general contractor, bought the quick-pick ticket at Campark Liquors in Woodbine, officials at New Jersey Lottery said. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Prospects for an on-time budget seemed unlikely yesterday as Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders could not even agree on how much money was available to spend. The governor said he would prefer a late budget to a bad one, underscoring his intent to overhaul the way the state spends money on Medicaid and education. “I will in no way regret having a late budget if it is the only way we contain the rapid spending that has been too often the story line here up in Albany,” Mr. Spitzer said. “If we need to tolerate week after week after week without a budget, we will do so.” Joseph L. Bruno, above, the Senate majority leader and the state’s top Republican, has proposed restoring many of the governor’s health care cuts and reshaping his education proposal. Mr. Spitzer and the Democratic-led Assembly urged Senate Republicans to scale back their spending proposals so serious negotiations could begin. The budget deadline is April 1.

A Bedford teenager was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to one to three years in prison in connection with two automobile accidents, one of which killed a passenger. The teenager, Ralph Tarchine III, 19, of Bedford, pleaded guilty to vehicular manslaughter and driving while impaired in connection with an accident in December 2005 that killed Michael Plunkett, 17, of Ridgefield, Conn. He pleaded guilty to vehicular assault and driving while intoxicated after an accident that injured another passenger in January. He originally accepted a plea bargain in which he would have been sentenced to six months in jail, but the judge discarded it after protests from the victims’ families.

Three New Jersey men who died after becoming trapped in a sunken ship while scuba-diving off the coast of Key Largo, Fla., were carrying spools of line to find their way out but apparently did not use them, investigators said yesterday. The men — Kevin Coughlin, 51, of Chatham Borough; Jonathan Walsweer, 38, of Westfield; and Scott Stanley also of Westfield but whose age was not released — died on Friday while attempting to enter the interior of the sunken vessel. Detective Mark Coleman, of the Monroe County Sheriff’s Office, said rescue divers found large amounts of silt inside the ship, which would have made it difficult for the men to find their way out.
More than 37,000 people in all 50 states took part in some 1,188 vigils, according to the grass-roots organization MoveOn.org.
Russia said it will withhold nuclear fuel unless Iran suspends its uranium enrichment as demanded by the Security Council.
The declining readiness of the First Brigade of the 82nd Airborne Division is a sign of the Iraq war’s toll.
The district attorney will not pursue charges against the Islanders forward Chris Simon for his two-handed slash of Rangers forward Ryan Hollweg.
Coby Karl, the son of Denver Nuggets Coach George Karl, will have surgery to have cancerous lymph nodes removed.
The family of Bob Woolmer, the Pakistan coach who died Sunday, has allowed the authorities to carry out a post-mortem, a team official said.

Falling ice around the metropolitan area injured at least four people yesterday, prompting the authorities to temporarily shut down roads and streets to remove potential hazards, police and fire officials said.
Chelsea and Manchester United advanced to the semifinals of the Football Association Cup with victories in quarterfinal replays.
The Jets re-signed offensive tackle Anthony Clement.
The International Olympic Committee president said that he wanted to start an Olympics for teenagers in 2010.
India recorded the biggest-ever World Cup winning margin, 257 runs, against Bermuda Monday in Trinidad.
More than 60 million cans and pouches of Menu Foods’ wet-style food have been recalled, and owners of cats and dogs around the country remained concerned.

Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, the bureaucrat who ascended to the presidency last month, will restore pensions for the elderly, scrapping one of the harshest cuts of his autocratic predecessor, Saparmurat Niyazov. Mr. Niyazov, who died in December, ordered big cuts in state pensions a year ago, robbing many older people of their sole source of income.

Air force jets bombed and destroyed a Tamil Tiger naval base near the northeastern town of Mullaittivu, the military said. It had no immediate details of casualties. The attack came a day after the navy sank two large rebel ships off the east coast that it said were transporting arms for the Tigers, and as the government pushed on with a declared plan to destroy the rebels’ military machine. “We have taken selected targets,” an air force spokesman said. “This is a Sea Tiger base. We believe it is fully destroyed.”.

The Constitutional Council released the official list of presidential candidates for next month’s elections, a dozen hopefuls from Trotskyists to a militant farmer. The president of the Nation Assembly, Jean-Louis Debré, read the list of 12 candidates, which included the antiglobalization farmer José Bové, who had said he was unsure if he had the required 500 endorsements from mayors and other elected officials needed to run. The front-runners, Nicolas Sarkozy, Ségolène Royal and François Bayrou, who have dominated news coverage, will now have to share the spotlight with the other candidates. By law, television and radio outlets will be required to grant equal time to each candidate before the first round of voting on April 22. A run-off between the top two candidates in the first round of voting will be on May 6.

The H5N1 strain of avian flu has killed a rare species of eagle in Sagara, on the southern main island of Kyushu, the Environment Ministry said. The bird, a female mountain hawk eagle listed as endangered in Japan, was found sick on Jan. 4 and died shortly after. The ministry said it planned to resume surveillance of wild birds around the site where the eagle was found. The species does not migrate, and eats small birds and animals.
There is no mechanism to prevent doctors with unpaid taxes from receiving Medicare payments, a report says.

Intensifying a continuing legal crisis, six judges from Sindh and Punjab Provinces resigned to protest the suspension of the chief justice of the Supreme Court, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, by President Pervez Musharraf on March 9 for alleged abuse of office. Incensed lawyers and opposition activists who accuse General Musharraf of trying to subdue the judiciary clashed with the police in Islamabad, the capital, and Lahore last week, and lawyers have staged protests in other cities. In an interview with a private television news channel, General Musharraf defended the action and sought to dispel speculation that emergency measures would be imposed in the country or that army troops would be called on to quell the unrest on the streets.
The company gave no reason for the departures nor did it say if the company had chosen successors for the directors.

A court in Moscow convicted six men for selling forged copies of number plates reserved for senior Kremlin officials and the presidential bodyguard. The gang had sold the plates as part of a package — plate, supporting documents, and a flashing blue light, or migalka, left — for as much as $200,000, according to prosecutors. The plates and flashing blue light, viewed as a status symbol, provide immunity from traffic rules and relief from traffic problems. One package included a plate number with the code for the Federal Guard Service, which protects the Kremlin elite, including President Vladimir V. Putin. There was no evidence that the fake plates and documents had been used to breach Kremlin security. News reports said the gang, which drew prison sentences of two and seven years, was caught after two cars with the same special number plate belonging to a senior officer in the Federal Guard passed a traffic police cordon within two minutes of each other.
The party has donated a vast collection of papers and photographs never before seen publicly.

In the four years since Justice Gerald P. Garson was charged with taking payoffs from a lawyer in his Brooklyn chambers, a turbulent chapter of legal and political history has unfolded, with more characters than a Robert Altman movie.
He was the highest-ranking official from the former Iraq government to be executed after Saddam Hussein himself.
The issue of how to deal with illegal immigrants is causing particular complications for Senator John McCain.
The decision stymies any mass effort by shareholders to recoup $40 billion in losses from Wall Street banks that had earned fees from Enron.
In the highly nuanced and little-known world of court reporters, accuracy is supreme.
MySpace, the Web’s largest social network, has gradually been imposing limits on the software tools that users can embed in their pages.
President Bush marked the fourth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq by warning that hard days lie ahead.
The Episcopal Church bankrolls much of the Anglican Communion’s operations, making severing ties difficult.
The Senate moved to revoke the authority it granted the Bush administration to name federal prosecutors.
It would be a serious mistake to weaken the Sarbanes-Oxley corporate reform law.
For over 100 years, the New York Botanical Garden has been trying to maintain beautiful living things that every year seem more endangered.
Documents showed hundreds of instances in which a White House official edited reports on global warming.
In the “Bong Hits 4 Jesus” case, the Supreme Court should reaffirm the pronouncement that students do not shed their right to free speech “at the schoolhouse gate.”
Zimbabwe’s president, Robert Mugabe, seems to have descended into total power-madness.
Exxon Mobil, Chevron, BP and others have poured billions into Angola in the last decade to unlock petroleum resources, and the payoffs are finally coming in.
An official audit made public on Monday reported that the official, Peter Smith, had violated Unesco’s rules by granting contracts without an open bidding procedure.
An American soldier was sentenced to 10 years in prison after a court-martial found him guilty of killing three Iraqi detainees.
All three pleaded not guilty to numerous charges — including, for two of them, first- and second-degree manslaughter — in the shooting death of Sean Bell.
Increasing attendance and embracing neutrality is a delicate balancing act for the women’s tournament.
The Texas Rangers are putting the Ballpark back in their ballpark.
Jury selection began on Monday in the $101 million insider trading trial of the former chief executive of Qwest Communications.
Naomi Campbell, the supermodel with a temper, did community service after pleading guilty to hurling a cellphone at her maid.
Lumberton has the most active community of eBay buyers and sellers on a per-capita basis in the United States, according to the Internet auction site.
With a tight N.H.L. playoff race in the Eastern Conference, the points won in hockey shootouts have been particularly crucial.
The British bank confirmed that it was in exclusive talks with ABN Amro Holding about a possible takeover that could be the biggest in the financial services industry.
Lawyers for Conrad M. Black raised concerns about the timing of two large settlements by a chief witness in the case.
What started as fistfights in the stands later escalated into mayhem in the streets and subway stations near the Garden and up to Times Square.
Since his capture, David Hicks, an Australian detainee now seeking British citizenship, says he has been stripped, beaten and given injections.
A trade association representing Broadway theaters and producers wants state officials to dismantle the laws that limit the resale of tickets to events.
Mississippi’s largest insurer said it would work through state regulators to speed the flow of money to storm victims, losing the court’s oversight.
As it looks toward the construction of the Second Avenue subway, the M.T.A. will have to pay about $54 million more than it had anticipated due to rising real estate prices.

Worried about tourism and the 2010 Winter Olympics, several states and Canadian provinces are pressing for a delay in the start of a measure requiring people entering the United States to show a passport.
The New Jersey attorney general’s office said that over the next few months it would set up procedures to log votes and produce a paper trail.
LOS ANGELES, March 19 (AP) — Fremont General said Monday that it had notified some of the 2,400 employees in its subprime lending unit that they would lose their jobs by May 18.
CBOT Holdings Inc. and IntercontinentalExchange are moving quickly after a proposal by ICE to buy the Chicago exchange for $9.9 billion.
The American Medical Association asked the Justice Department to block the UnitedHealth Group’s proposed purchase of Sierra Health Services.
Brian McKeever’s childhood ambition of skiing in the Olympics was formed long before he lost his vision.
Walid bin Attash made his statement, according to a transcript, to a combatant status review tribunal in Guantánamo Bay.
Coors is planning an interactive initiative that promotes 4:53 p.m. as the new 5 o’clock.
While the Giants had hoped for stronger play from Eli Manning in his first three seasons, they have no intention of trying to improve without him.
Kansas City Power and Light and the Sierra Club announced a deal on Monday under which the utility will take steps to cut carbon dioxide output.
After winning the national title in 2006 and forgoing the N.B.A. to return to school, Florida’s stars insist they have no regrets, no matter what happens next.
Ohio’s new secretary of state said that she had demanded the resignations following a series of voting scandals.
Chief executive Gerald Grinstein will not receive any stock, incentive payments or severance when the company exits bankruptcy protection this spring.
The oil and gas drilling rig company Hercules Offshore said it had agreed to buy a larger rival, Todco, for $2.3 billion in cash and stock, giving it a stronger position in the Gulf of Mexico.
Republicans argue that Senator Charles E. Schumer’s investigation into the firing of some federal prosecutors is more political than impartial.
Gunmen ambushed a pickup in Pattani, a province where separatist violence has occurred over the past three years.
Kyrgyzstan demanded Monday that the United States hand over for trial an American airman who shot and killed a truck driver in December.
ServiceMaster said it had accepted a $4.7 billion takeover bid from a group led by the private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice.
A 14-year-old Afghan bystander was killed and an American security guard seriously wounded, officials said.
Coach Rick Peterson tells his staff that while fastballs can lead to a lucrative contract, mastering pitch location is the key to lasting success.
Shares of the biotechnology company AtheroGenics fell sharply yesterday after its lead experimental heart disease drug failed a late-stage clinical trial.
Triad Hospitals has agreed to be bought by Community Health Systems for $5.1 billion in a deal that will create the biggest publicly traded United States hospital chain.
Russia signaled its opposition to the United Nations proposal to settle the status of Kosovo and said a new negotiator should be appointed and fresh talks started.
Quanta Services Inc. said it would buy InfraSource Services Inc. for $1.26 billion to expand its services and increase its national presence.
Detroit’s automakers are getting some help from the federal government, at least in terms of their efforts to find flaws in the new pickup built by their Japanese rival Toyota Motor.
The explosion, one of the most deadly in recent years, occurred in a region notorious for mine accidents.
A civic group reported a series of attacks on neighborhood activists and local leaders of the nation’s main opposition party.
The armed wing of Hamas claimed responsibility for the attack, its first since a shaky cease-fire came into effect last November.
The Supreme Court was considering whether to create a drug exception to students’ First Amendment rights.
A memorial tribute to the drama and literary critic Richard Gilman will take place on Monday at 1 p.m. at Symphony Space.
Auditors complain that they are being forced to close corporate cases prematurely, allowing billions in tax dollars to go unpaid.
Mr. Nasher was a real-estate developer and banker who amassed one of the world’s best collections of Modern and contemporary sculpture and built a lavish public home for it in downtown Dallas.
Pitney Bowes Inc. announced Monday that it would shift its top leaders, naming a new chief executive and adding him to the company’s board.
Companies are expected to spend more on mobile technology and business travel.
With a salary cap of $109 million this season, teams have spent lavishly on players who in past years would have been second-tier free agents at best.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,206 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Mr. Backus assembled and led the I.B.M. team that created Fortran, the first widely used programming language.
The Lebanese Army maintained a heavy presence on Monday in a Palestinian refugee camp where an Islamic militant group is based.
One hundred children have tested positive for H.I.V. after being given blood transfusions they might not have needed.
EGL Inc., the parent of Eagle Global Logistics, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by its chairman and chief executive, James R. Crane.
Former catcher Tony Peña, in his second season as the club’s first-base coach, has become a mentor for Jorge Posada.
Franz A. Dextra and Leslie U. McKinnon have helped many tenants avoid homelessness and are among six recipients of this year’s Sloan Public Service Awards.
The Federal Railroad Administration said that it was speeding up inspection of 1,300 miles of track after several derailments upstate in recent months.
Wall Street joined overseas markets in riding a wave of merger news yesterday to bounce back from a losing week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 115 points.
Harmony Pharmacy and Health Center, opening on Thursday at Newark Liberty International Airport, will be the first such retail service at an airport in the United States.
The former head of Citibank’s worldwide commodities trading desk was sentenced to 15 months in prison on Monday after pleading guilty to conspiracy.
Rondra J. Matthews, who assumed the position in October, said she was stepping down for personal reasons.
Delivering shoes to people in the developing world proves to be an adventurous, and sometimes dangerous, job.
Frequent fliers who take a hiatus from traveling for family or other reasons often find their elite status gone when they return.
The results of Monday’s auction for three- and six-month Treasury bills.
The distress in the mortgage market is not reflected in the amounts Novastar, a mortgage lender, has recently paid to its executives.
Only one thing is certain in the Sean Bell case: tragedy.
The board has been working to regain investors' trust after coming under fire for the sky-high compensation package paid to former chief executive Robert Nardelli.
Since the invasion of Iraq, the war on terror has surfaced as a subplot or subliminal theme on many shows, and most echo the public’s disenchantment of the war’s failures.
YouTube to honor the best user-created videos of 2006, this year’s inductees announced for the Songwriters Hall of Fame, a new opera by John Zorn and more culture news.
The Propeller Company’s all-male productions of Shakespeare’s “Taming of the Shrew” and “Twelfth Night” are boisterous and inventive.
Shares of Take-Two Interactive Software rose 8.4 percent after the company postponed its annual meeting and said it would consider alternatives to a proposed hostile takeover.
A series of exhibitions in London this year will be focused on Britain’s deep engagement in the slave trade and the role it played in forging the nation’s wealth and power.

10:30 P.M. (Oxygen) TORI AND DEAN: INN LOVE It has been quite a year for Tori Spelling, left, who lost her father, feuded with her mother and as of last Tuesday plunged into parenting herself, when she gave birth to a baby boy, Liam Aaron McDermott. Now she and her husband, Dean McDermott, above, are about to embark on another adventure — that of innkeepers. This reality series follows them as they leave their Hollywood lives behind to invest Ms. Spelling’s $800,000 inheritance in a bed-and-breakfast in Southern California.

Kathy Halbreich, who helped turned the museum into a risk-taking multidisciplinary institution, said on Monday that she was retiring after 16 years as director.
When ice crystals link, it seems, they can just keep going and going, with few limits in sight.
A Juilliard School chairman looks to lure new converts to the organ with vibrant, emotive performances and by stressing the importance of education.
E8 describes the symmetries of a 57-dimensional object that can in essence be rotated in 248 ways without changing its appearance.
New this week is Universal’s box set “W. C. Fields Comedy Collection: Volume 2,” drawn from Fields’s Paramount and Universal periods.
The vernal equinox in 2007 arrived at the querulous hour of just seven minutes past midnight, universal time, on March 21.
The concert on Friday night at the Rose Rehearsal Studio, which featured music selected by students for students, was ambitious, wide-ranging and sold-out.
Barbara Carroll transformed every selection into a shapely composition with improvisations and quotations in her show at the Oak Room on Sunday.
