As a critic, Clive James has always demonstrated a magpie’s taste, and these essays show as much familiarity with “Dallas” as with the poetry of Rilke.
An Israeli worker for an electric utility company was wounded by a sniper near the border with the Gaza Strip today, and the armed wing of Hamas claimed responsibility.
Dr. Frans de Waal argues that human morality would be impossible without certain emotional building blocks that are clearly at work in chimp and monkey societies.
In ancient iceballs, astronomers are finding clues to the solar system’s evolution.
The pianist Vladimir Feltsman and the orchestra performed an excellent account of Paul Wittgenstein’s one-movement Concerto for the Left Hand on Sunday.
Researchers have found that people with musical training have an easier time learning Chinese.
Measuring lightning’s role in climate change, the color of fertile soil and more.
Patients who have trouble paying their medical bills do significantly worse in the year after heart attacks than patients under less financial pressure, a new study finds.
A new study provides a possible explanation for why exercise appears to help fight memory loss.
A new study suggests that African-American children may react to secondhand smoke more strongly.
The world’s largest passenger plane, plagued by delays, will stop at several American airports this week.
An outbreak of extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis killed 52 people in South Africa, raising questions about a global program meant to keep the disease under control.
After an obsessive quest to help a long-suffering patient, an unexpected reward.
Keep on Truckin’.
A conclusion that seems obvious today took most of a century to reach.
Does the “good oil” in nuts turn to a trans fat when the nuts are roasted?
Readers respond to articles in Science Times with thoughts on climate science and Al Gore, laughter and scars.
Having surgery to remove cataracts has its risks, but the deceptively simple operation can be life changing.
Chronically bad skin or the occasional nasty breakout can be a major source of stress.  What about the reverse?
The new Airbus A380 superjumbo jet flew into both New York and Los Angeles on Monday, but there were a few differences between the flights.
As baseball prepares to celebrate the 60th anniversary of Jackie Robinson’s integration of the game, fewer and fewer blacks are playing it.
The play of Greg Oden and Kevin Durant illustrates that the rule will make college basketball stronger.
Bowie Kuhn, whose tenure was riddled by five of baseball’s eight work stoppages, was at the heart of the poor relationship between owners and players.
Wal-Mart filed a legal brief on Monday directly contradicting the statements of two former marketing officials who were fired late last year.
The United States needs to be honest about what it wants from Afghanistan and what it can achieve.
Contrasts between the Sean Bell case and that of Amadou Diallo are palpable. The most significant difference, though, is in the charges.
In an unusual move, Joe Roth, the executive who is producing Ms. Taymor’s film, “Across the Universe,” has created his own version of the film without her agreement.
Is Dick Cheney an Iranian mole?

GILE--David Emery, died peacefully at home in Greenwich, CT on Thursday, March 15, 2007. Mr. Gile was born in Cambridge, MA on June 7, 1922 and was the youngest child of Clement and Anne Gile. He graduated from Phillips Andover Academy in 1940 and Yale University in 1944. At Yale he sang in the Whiffenpoofs and was a member of The Elihu Club. Mr. Gile was a Lt. J.G. during WWII in the Pacific and served as Commanding Officer of LSM 500. After the War, he graduated from the University of Pittsburgh Law School in 1949, earned an LL. B. and was elected class president. He married Patricia Schoen in 1949 and three children followed: Nancy (1950), David Jr. (1952) and Larry (1955). Mr. Gile was a banker, first as an assistant trust officer with the Union National Bank of Pittsburgh then as a commercial lending officer with Pittsburgh National Bank and then Marine Midland Bank. Following retirement from banking, he served as Vice President for the Council for Aid to Education. Mr. Gile felt strongly about serving his community and church and was active in many organizations. Among his noteworthy activities and accomplishments: awarded the Yale Medal, President of the Rye Presbyterian Church Board of Trustees, recipient of the Whiffenpoof Cup, honorary LL.D. from the Berkeley Divinity School at Yale, member of the Yale Club Council, Secretary of the Rye Rotary Club, member of the Rye, NY City Council (he was a lifelong Republican) and volunteer at The Osborn Home and United Hospital. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Patricia Gile and sons David Jr. and Larry. A memorial service will be held at Rye Presbyterian Church on Saturday March 24, 2007 at 11:00 am with a private reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church Mission Fund.
CHAYKIN--Irving. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of our beloved member Irving Chaykin. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife and family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas Lawrence Glass

Prospects for an on-time budget seemed unlikely yesterday as Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders could not even agree on how much money was available to spend. The governor said he would prefer a late budget to a bad one, underscoring his intent to overhaul the way the state spends money on Medicaid and education. ''I will in no way regret having a late budget if it is the only way we contain the rapid spending that has been too often the story line here up in Albany,'' Mr. Spitzer said. ''If we need to tolerate week after week after week without a budget, we will do so.'' Joseph L. Bruno, above, the Senate majority leader and the state's top Republican, has proposed restoring many of the governor's health care cuts and reshaping his education proposal. Mr. Spitzer and the Democratic-led Assembly urged Senate Republicans to scale back their spending proposals so serious negotiations could begin. The budget deadline is April 1. DANNY HAKIM

Presidential candidates test the waters with well-publicized scripts, establishing exploratory committees and making announcements that they plan to make announcements. But those who decide not to run do so away from the klieg lights. Whatever remaining doubt there may be that George E. Pataki, the former governor of New York, will be skipping the Republican race appears to be dissipating. He recently released any supporters he might have had in New Hampshire and Iowa and took a job at a law firm in New York. And yesterday, one of his closest former aides, Michael McKeon, signed on with Rudolph W. Giuliani's presidential exploratory committee.

In anticipation of the 100-year anniversary of the national parks system, the National Park Service has scheduled a public meeting today at Federal Hall National Memorial to listen to comments on the future of the parks, officials said. The session, from 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. at 26 Wall Street, is one of a series scheduled around the country. Although the centennial is 10 years away, officials said they were seeking input now to allow a 10-year lead time for projects to commemorate the anniversary. ''We are asking the public what they would like us to do with their parks,'' said Darren Boch, a spokesman for the service.

KENNEDY--Jay, 50, beloved husband of Sarah Jewler, friend to many. Vigilant, passionate, kind, Jay was a vibrant defender of the integrity of the cartoon and culture. His friends, particularly in New York and the North Fork, will miss him deeply.

Coverage of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament propelled CBS into first place in the ratings on Sunday night, though its typical Sunday competitor, ABC, was resilient in reruns. CBS's live coverage carried over deep into the 7 p.m. hour, pushing back the network's prime-time lineup of ''60 Minutes,'' ''Amazing Race,'' ''Cold Case'' and ''Without a Trace'' by roughly 45 minutes. The overrun made Nielsen's preliminary estimates for the individual CBS shows unreliable; but CBS's overall dominance was conclusive. In second place ABC and NBC fared about evenly well. ABC's lineup of repeats, led by ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (10.6 million), posted a slight advantage among adults 18 to 49, while NBC edged ahead in total viewers, buoyed by ''Deal or No Deal'' at 9 (12 million). Meanwhile NBC's ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' earned a distant fourth place finish at 8 in the 18 to 49 demographic and 6.6 million total viewers. ''The Apprentice'' on NBC fared relatively better, drawing 7.2 million viewers to rank second place at 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

To the Editor: Re ''From a Rapt Audience, a Call to Cool the Hype'' (March 13): Al Gore's critics are quick to pounce on his use of science. And yet they apparently have no qualms about implicitly employing pop theories of social change and labeling forecasts of dire biophysical change as scaremongering.

A doctor from Livingston pleaded guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to writing thousands of phony prescriptions for a drug gang that illegally sold prescription painkillers like OxyContin, prosecutors said yesterday. The doctor, Mario Comesanas, 51, pleaded guilty to first-degree racketeering, Attorney General Stuart Rabner said. Dr. Comesanas, who faces 15 years in prison and must forfeit his medical license, admitted writing fraudulent prescriptions at the home of another man charged in the case, Mr. Rabner said. He said 17 other people, including a pharmacist, had also been charged in the case. The ring sold 20,000 to 30,000 OxyContin and Percocet pills a week, with most of the drugs going to another group in the Bronx, Mr. Rabner said.

A former city police officer pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to drug trafficking charges, federal prosecutors said. The former officer, Jose Torrado, admitted helping his brother distribute large quantities of cocaine and marijuana in the New York area from 2002 to 2005, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Torrado, 31, of the Bronx, joined the Police Department in 2001 and resigned in 2006 as a result of the investigation, Mr. Garcia said. He added that while Mr. Torrado served as a police officer, he worked with a group that smuggled drugs from Mexico to New York in trucks.

BROWN--Janet. Dearly beloved friend. We are so sad to lose you to this tragic automobile accident at the prime of your life. Your memory will be in our hearts always. Charlotte, Roger, Eric, Lisa, Beth, Peter, Marc, Ellen, and family $(6$)BROWN--Janet. We will miss the timeless grace, wit and panache of our dear friend and client, Janet Brown, whose spirited style will live on in the memories of all those she touched. We will always be one accessory too short without you. Lisa and J.J. $(6$)BROWN--Janet. We are so sad. Sitting at your ''square table'' was the best. The answer is you're not -your smile looks down on every woman you helped make a correct fashion decision and every man who waited patiently for hours as his wife shopped from your glorious collection. You were never a store owner -you were and always will be simply Janet Brown, Friend. Nancy and Donny $(6$)BROWN--Janet. Rescued dripping from Georgica Pond. Not a good sport, the best sport. Summer house courtier. Pulling us dancing out to the edge and there, mischievous and sparkling and wise, balancing. Who wants to go out, knowing you won't be there? A $(6$)BROWN--Janet. My dearest friend, I shall miss you so much. Love Always, Dagmar $(6$)BROWN--Janet. We are so terribly saddened by the tragic death of our longtime friend. She was a part of our lives and she will be greatly missed. Rochelle and Hal Lipton $(6$)BROWN--Janet, (born in Philadelphia, PA, May 23, 1947), died suddenly in a car accident on Friday, March 16th as she drove to work. Janet enjoyed an iconic career as founder of Janet Brown Ltd., the chic Long Island boutique. She was loved by her friends, respected by her colleagues; her quick irreverent sense of humor and extraordinary heart will be missed by all. She is survived by her sister Elaine Edelstein, of Villanova, PA, her brother-in-law Marc, and her niece and nephew Brandon and Melissa, in addition to her countless friends. Funeral services will be held Tuesday March 20, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison and 81st street. Donations may be made in the name of Janet Brown to the New York University Child Study Center, 577 1st Ave, NY, NY 10016. $(6$)BROWN--Janet. We will miss your outrageous honesty, your lack of political correctness, your ability to have a good time and make sure everyone else had a better time. Your relentless pursuit of fun with your innumerable friends. Everyone loved you for your enduring indomitable spirit. Our family has suffered a loss that will never be replaced. We'll miss you at all of our family celebrations, our vacations, and our parties. Life will never be the same without you and your endless dance moves. Brooke, Dan, Jon, Stephen and Mallory. $(6$)BROWN--Janet. Over 30 years ago we shared our dreams. So happy they came true. I'll miss you, my dear friend. Eileen $(6$)BROWN--Janet. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of the New York University Child Study Center mourn the loss of Janet Brown, a great friend and supporter of the Child Study Center. We will miss her wit, her generosity and her passion for old and young. Our thoughts are with all those who love her. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D., Director $(6$)BROWN--Janet. Your special, unique love, personality and soul along with your style and wit will always be remembered. There will never be another you! Our family who adores you, will miss you and be always thinking of you. So much admiration and love. Bunny and Charles

LISTER--Carol. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of our longtime colleague and friend, Carol Lister, Deputy Director of Marketing and Communications. Drawing her nearly 40 years with ADL, Carol served as Director in our Columbus and New York Regional offices and held senior positions in the national office. She was a consummate professional who mentored new staff. We will miss her counsel, creativity and friendship. We extend our condolences to her son Doug, his wife Laura, and the entire family. Glen S. Lewy, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director $(6$)LISTER--Carol, a longtime senior executive of the AntiDefamation League (ADL), died March 17, 2007, after a year-long struggle against pancreatic cancer, during which she remained at work until a week before her death. She was a loving mother, devoted friend, and caring colleague. She and her family were profoundly grateful for the extraordinary support of her colleagues and friends during her final illness. She is survived by her son Douglas and daughter-in-law Laura of Washington, DC. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, March 21, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, at 11:30 am. Donations, in lieu of flowers, may be made to the ADL.

To the Editor: Re ''Talking About Israel'' (column, March 18): Nicholas D. Kristof's suggestion that the United States press Israel to be more forthcoming in negotiating with the Palestinians reminds me of the story of the rabbi who gave a sermon about charity and deemed it 50 percent effective: he persuaded the poor to accept.

CASDIN--Joseph C., 93, former mayor and city councilor of Worcester, MA. died on Saturday, March 17th. Beloved husband of Miriam (Whitman) Casdin, devoted father of Ruth Ann wife of Stephen Friedberg, Deborah Casdin and the late Jeffrey Casdin of NYC, father-in-law of Sharon Casdin, grandfather of Adam, Alexander, Eli, Rachel, Jeremy, Jessica, Salem, Isaiah and Saul and had nine great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at 2 pm on Wednesday, March 21 in Temple Emanuel, 280 May St. Worcester, MA. Perlman Funeral Home of Worcester is directing the services .

The former vice president of Iraq, Taha Yassin Ramadan, was hanged shortly before dawn Tuesday, the prime minister's office said. He was the highest-ranking person from Saddam Hussein's government to be executed after the former president himself.

Loving mother of Todd and Laura Joe, proud grandmother of Carly, Haley, Jordan and Mark, inseparable sister of Vicki Bernstein and beloved partner to her ''dear Danny''. Services private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Lung Association. ''They can't take you away from us''.

HUSSAKOWSKY--Andrew, died on March 17 of heart failure. Survived by loving wife Merci. Will be missed greatly by all your friends in the entertainment and music field and Wall Street. Your good friend, Alan Stone

Theirs was an idyllic marriage of 57 years. She is survived by their son, Robert L. Cahill, Jr. Their daughter Barbara Healey died in 1998. She leaves her sister Mrs. James (Eileen) Murray, her granddaughter, Robin Gibson and husband Gary Gibson, and her great-granddaughter Kaley Gibson. Predeceased by her sister Mrs. William (Mimi) Meehan and her brother Charles S. Fitzsimmons. Helen Cahill was the oldest living alumna of the Convent of The Sacred Heart in New York City. Mass of The Resurrection will be celebrated Tuesday, March 20 at 10:30 am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave and 76th St. A reception will follow at the community center of the church. The family will greet friends at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave and 81st St. Monday, March 19 from 5 to 8 pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcomed by the St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31st St. NY, NY 10001.

A chart with a front-page news analysis article on March 11 about a looming crisis in the mortgage market mislabeled the size of the market that trades mortgage-backed securities. It trades in hundreds of billions of dollars a day, not hundreds of millions.

The Suffolk County police are investigating a fire that injured a woman late Sunday in Bohemia, the police said yesterday. The fire, at 883 Wall Street, started about 11:40 p.m. in the living room of a ranch house. Three teenagers escaped and alerted a neighbor. After the police were called, a neighbor, Joseph Imperato, 53, a New York City firefighter, entered the house to search for the woman, but was driven back by the fire. The woman, Donna Blieka, 46, was rescued by firefighters and taken to the Nassau University Medical Center. She was in critical condition yesterday, the police said. The fire was not considered suspicious, the authorities said.

MORRISON--John J., of Sarasota, Florida and Madison, NJ on Saturday, March 17, 2007 after a short illness. He was 74 years old. Born in Staten Island, Mr. Morrison lived in Summit for 30 years, before moving to Florida and Madison in 2000. He oversaw the International Treasury Department at Pfizer, Inc. for 30 years, retiring as the Assistant Corporate Treasurer in 1994. Mr. Morrison graduated from St. Peters College in Jersey City in 1954 with a Bachelor's degree. He also earned an MBA from Wagner College in 1968. He was a member of Canoe Brook Country Club in Summit, NJ, as well as the Meadows Country Club in Sarasota, FL. Mr. Morrison served in the U.S. Army from 1954-1956. He is survived by his wife Mary (Graham) Morrison of Sarasota, Florida and Madison, NJ; his daughter Katherine Holland and her husband Craig of New Providence; and his sons Thomas Morrison and his wife Allison of Hoboken; and James Morrison and his wife Jennifer of Hoboken. He is also survived by his grandchildren: Cameron Holland and Eva Morrison. A funeral service for Mr. Morrison will be held on Thursday, March 22,2007 at 8:30 am at Burroughs, Kohr & Dangler Funeral Home, Inc., 106 Main Street, NJ. A funeral mass will follow at 9:30 am at Corpus Christi Church, 234 Southern Boulevard, Chatham, NJ. Interment will be at St. Teresa Cemetery in Summit, NJ. Visiting will be on Wednesday, March 21, 2007 from 2-4 and 7-9 pm at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Morrison's name can be made to: Tidwell Hospice, 5955 Rand Blvd., Sarasota, Florida, 34238 or Community Foodbank of NJ, 31 Evans Temple Road, Hillside, NJ 07205.

Three New Jersey men who died after becoming trapped in a sunken ship while scuba-diving off the coast of Key Largo, Fla., were carrying spools of line to find their way out but apparently did not use them, investigators said yesterday. The men -- Kevin Coughlin, 51, of Chatham Borough; Jonathan Walsweer, 38, of Westfield; and Scott Stanley also of Westfield but whose age was not released -- died on Friday while attempting to enter the interior of the sunken vessel. Detective Mark Coleman, of the Monroe County Sheriff's Office, said rescue divers found large amounts of silt inside the ship, which would have made it difficult for the men to find their way out. CARMEN GENTILE

A budget released by the minority Conservative government on Monday would phase out special tax concessions for investors in oil sands projects by 2015. The current system dates back to 1972 and allows oil companies to depreciate capital investments in oil sands operations at a highly accelerated rate. Intended as a method of promoting oil sands developments, it effectively postpones all taxation on income from the projects until their billions of dollars in investment costs are fully written down. The left-leaning New Democrat Party has said that the current rush to develop the oil sands makes special tax concessions unnecessary. IAN AUSTEN

ESKELL--Barrett Bertram, 84, of Huntington, L.I. on March 16, 2007. Born in New York City. Retired from Citibank in New York as a Vice President. Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Hobart College in Geneva, NY and Veteran of the Army Air Corps in WWII with the 8th Air Force/436th Fighter Squadron. POW in Germany for seven months. Mr. Eskell was an avid perennial gardener, gourmet cook, gracious host, passionate, liberal and marvelous father, grandfather and friend. He was predeceased by his wife of 48 years, Joyce Kale Eskell and sister Pamela Scallan. Survived by daughters Lisa Hill of Melbourne, FL, Stephanie Brown of Northport, NY, grandchildren Heath Keirstead, Gwendolyn and Kathleen Hill, Nicole and Brett Balinski, sister Peggy Eskell of London, England. Services will be private. Donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

An article on Wednesday about Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki's first official visit to Anbar Province, center of the Sunni insurgency, included an incorrect geographic comparison. At 52,282 square miles, Anbar occupies about the same amount of area as North Carolina -- not Utah, which is almost 85,000 square miles.

WILKINS--Dr. Arthur H., died March 14, in Manhattan at age 88. He graduated from Columbia Grammar, Yale University, and received his Ph.D in Sociology from University of Chicago. After teaching at Brown, Dr. Wilkins became Director of Market Research at Papert Koenig Lois and Grey Advertising. He was an erudite person with varied interests and an engaging sense of humor. One of his great passions was jazz. In lively conversations, he was as likely to quote from the Great American Songbook as from Shakespeare. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Patricia, and their daughter Sarah; his first wife Kathleen and two of their children, Thomas, and Patricia Parker; six grandchildren and a great-grandson; and his sister Shirley Liebowitz. His eldest son John died in 2003. Donations may be made in his name to Arts for Art, 107 Suffolk St. NY, NY 10002

To the Editor: Re ''What's So Funny? Well, Maybe Nothing'' (Findings, March 13): Your article on laughter listed many noncomedic reasons people laugh, including to punctuate a point or to curry favor with an authority figure. But it failed to emphasize that laughing at a joke is indeed the fun kind of laughter, and fun is what draws people to watch television and to frequent comedy clubs. But there's nothing like analysis to take the fun out of comedy. Some things are probably best left unexplored. Shaun Breidbart Pelham, N.Y.

To the Editor: Re ''Taming Fossil Fuels'' (editorial, March 17): ''Forcing people to pay to pollute,'' as you suggest, is an old concept: environmental regulation has extracted penalties for noncompliance from violators for decades.
''Wait until it flies over Manhattan. It will block out the sun.'' JAMES FAZIO chief operating officer of JFK International Airport Terminal, on the Airbus A380. [C8]

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Russia to Hold Nuclear Fuel Until Iran Ends Enrichment Russia has informed Iran that it will withhold nuclear fuel for the nation's nearly completed power plant in Bushehr unless Iran suspends its uranium enrichment as demanded by the United Nations Security Council, European, American and Iranian officials said. A1 Russia Mine Explosion Kills 78 A methane gas explosion in a Siberian coal mine, in a region notorious for mine accidents, killed at least 78 people, and dozens were trapped underground, a local official said. A11 A Former Iraqi Leader Is Hanged The former vice president of Iraq, Taha Yassin Ramadan, was hanged shortly before dawn for his role in the killing of 148 Shiites in 1982, according to the prime minister's office. A8 Blast Hits U.S. Convoy in Kabul A convoy from the United States Embassy was hit by a suicide car bomb on a busy road in Kabul, Afghanistan, killing a 14-year-old Afghan bystander and seriously wounding an American security guard in the convoy, officials said. A9 Israeli Civilian Shot Near Gaza An Israeli worker for an electric utility company was wounded by a sniper near the border with the Gaza Strip, and the armed wing of Hamas claimed responsibility. It was the first attack since a shaky cease-fire went into effect in November. A3 Detainee Claims Abuse by U.S. David Hicks, the first detainee to be formally charged under the new military tribunal rules at Guantánamo Bay, said in a court document that while in American custody he was beaten several times during interrogations and witnessed the abuse of other prisoners. A10 NATIONAL A12-17 New E-Mail Gives Details For Attorneys' Dismissals Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales was ''extremely upset'' that his deputy told Congress that a federal prosecutor had been fired for no reason, according to e-mail released by the Justice Department. A1 The Senate moved to revoke the authority it granted the Bush administration last year to name federal prosecutors, with Democrats accusing the administration of abusing its appointment power. A15 U.S. Pays Doctors Owing Taxes Thousands of doctors and other health professionals who participate in Medicare are delinquent in paying federal income and payroll taxes, owing more than $1.3 billion, but they continue to receive Medicare payments because the government does little to check their background, federal investigators said. A12 Immigration Divides G.O.P. Immigration, an issue that has divided Republicans in Washington for the last several years, is reverberating across the party's presidential campaign field and causing particular complications for Senator John McCain of Arizona. A1 Debate Over Climate Reports Democratic lawmakers released documents that showed hundreds of instances in which a White House official who was previously an oil-industry lobbyist edited government climate reports to play up uncertainty or play down evidence of a human role in global warming. A16 Calls to Ease Border Control Worried about trade and tourism, several states and Canadian provinces are pressing the Department of Homeland Security to ease some restrictions planned for the increasingly tight border between the United States and Canada. A12 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 3 Indicted Dectectives Deny Charges in Killing The three New York police detectives facing charges in the death of Sean Bell, an unarmed black man who was shot as he was leaving a Queens nightclub on the morning of his wedding, pleaded not guilty as their indictment was unsealed. Two are accused of manslaughter and other charges; the third is charged with reckless endangerment. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 The Building Blocks of Morality Some biologists argue that certain social behaviors exhibited by primates are the precursors of human morality, and believe that if morality grew out of behavioral rules shaped by evolution, it is for biologists, not philosophers or theologians, to say what those rules are. F3 Health & Fitness F5 ARTS E1-10 Britain Confronts Its Slavery With the support of the government and a $20 million grant, national museums and community groups across Britain have begun re-examining Britain's deep engagement in the slave trade in earlier centuries and the fundamental role slavery played in forging the nation's wealth and power. E1 OBITUARIES B7 John W. Backus A software developer who assembled the I.B.M. team that created Fortran, the first widely used programming language that opened the door to modern computing, he was 82. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-11 No Class-Action Enron Suit A federal appeals panel ruled that a class-action lawsuit against investment banks over their role as advisers to Enron cannot go ahead, dealing a blow to shareholders who lost billions of dollars when the company collapsed in 2001. Islanders forward Chris Simon will not face criminal charges for his two-handed slash of Rangers forward Ryan Hollweg earlier this month, the Nassau County district attorney announced yesterday. The decision was reached, a spokesman said, after Hollweg met with prosecutors last week and told them he did not wish to press charges.

To the Editor: Re ''Vitamin E Helps Remove Scars '' (Really?, March 13): Ten years ago, I had a torn right biceps. The incision to reattach the tendon extended, basically, from my elbow to my wrist. Once the cast was removed, each morning I applied vitamin E, waited five minutes for it to dry, then applied S.P.F. 30 sunblock. I repeated this routine for one year. Everyone, including my surgeon, was amazed at the results. I defy anyone to notice my so-called scar. Franz Del Favero Douglaston, N.Y.

Intensifying a continuing legal crisis, six judges from Sindh and Punjab Provinces resigned to protest the suspension of the chief justice of the Supreme Court, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, by President Pervez Musharraf on March 9 for alleged abuse of office. Incensed lawyers and opposition activists who accuse General Musharraf of trying to subdue the judiciary clashed with the police in Islamabad, the capital, and Lahore last week, and lawyers have staged protests in other cities. In an interview with a private television news channel, General Musharraf defended the action and sought to dispel speculation that emergency measures would be imposed in the country or that army troops would be called on to quell the unrest on the streets. SALMAN MASOOD

DENHOFF--Lee. The Board of Trustees, Associate Board, Parker League, Administration & staff of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care & Rehabilitation are deeply saddened by the passing of Lee Denhoff, beloved mother of our friend, Trustee and Assistant Secretary of the Board, Mike Denhoff. In her later years, Lee Denhoff faced illness with remarkable courage, grace, faith and independence. Her magnificent spirit will live forever in the minds of all whose lives she touched. An eloquent advocate for the health care of older adults, she will remain a beacon of hope for those who face physical challenges, and a guiding light for those who care for the elderly. It is our hope that fond memories, love of family, and the heartfelt condolences of friends help the Denhoff family during this very difficult time. Jerry Landsberg, Chairman of the Board Michael N. Rosenblut, President/CEO

As Democratic House leaders move toward a critical vote this week on Iraq spending legislation, one of their most difficult challenges has been gauging the restlessness on the party's left. To some antiwar advocates, the bill does not go far enough to try to force President Bush to end the war. To others, it is the best option available and a start on limiting the White House's ability to conduct the war on its terms. MoveOn.org, the liberal advocacy group, put the matter to a referendum of its members. The result, announced yesterday, was that MoveOn would endorse the bill being backed by the House Democratic leadership.

An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Microsoft researchers to trace the origins of fake Web pages that lure search-engine users to advertisements misspelled the surname of a cybersecurity investigator for the company. He is Ming Ma, not Ming Wa.

BAUER--Stephen Bruce, of Pound Ridge, NY and Naples, FL, born November 5, 1941, died suddenly on March 18, 2007. He was 65 years young. Steve was the beloved son of the late Shirley and David Bauer; loving husband of Linda, adored father of Diane and Eric Orlinsky, Lauren and Daniel Zinman, and David Bauer, cherished grandfather of Rachel, Charlie, Matthew, Samantha, Lexi, Sara and Ava; and loving brother of Renee Goodman and Joyce Shwab. Steve was the managing director of RSM McGladrey in Stamford, CT and a former member of the Board of Directors. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Columbia College and Columbia Business School. He was an avid exerciser and a voracious reader. He had two great passions in life -golf and his grandchildren. For more information call the Zion Memorial Chapel at 914-381-1809.

Wondering what this presidential campaign might look like in the world of ''Web 2.0'' social networking sites? We have our answer: the buzz-generating Internet advertisement featuring Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as a Big Brother figure conducting her campaign ''conversation'' on a giant screen to dronelike humans.

A report in the Around the Regions N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament summary on Sunday, about Ohio State's overtime victory against Xavier, referred incorrectly in some copies to its significance. It put the Buckeyes in the Round of 16 -- not the Final Four -- for the first time since 1999.

To the Editor: Re ''Letter From California: In the Kingdom of the Garage Door Opener,'' by Verlyn Klinkenborg (Editorial Observer, March 13): I have an answer for Mr. Klinkenborg on what houses in the ''urb'' will eventually give way to: strip malls!

While the Giants had hoped for stronger, more consistent play from quarterback Eli Manning in his first three seasons, they have no intention of trying to improve without him. The Giants have paid Manning a $5 million bonus, keeping him under contract through 2009. Without the bonus, Manning could have become an unrestricted free agent after the 2007 season.

ZIPRIN--Martin. On March 17, 2007. Beloved husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Marshall, and Lorna Leibowitz. Cherished Pop-pop of Gabriel. Dear brother of Adele Leventhal. Service Tuesday at 1:00 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

To the Editor: It is with great sorrow and amazement that I mark the beginning of the fifth year of this war in Iraq. Our administration felt so strongly about this move to overthrow Saddam Hussein that it was willing to use false information to justify our going in. It was intended to help fight the war on terrorism. Yet we have created another unstable region in the Middle East.

SOIFER--Enid McKenna. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are profoundly saddened by the passing of our much loved and admired lay leader, Enid McKenna Soifer, a source of inspiration to her many friends and colleagues in the United States and Israel. Devoted to Israel, the Jewish people, and The Hebrew University community of students and faculty, Enid served as an AFHU national board member, chaired the Campaign Committee and led wonderful, soul-satisfying missions to Israel. No one cared more about students than did Enid, whose advocacy and philanthropy ranged from establishing the Howard H. Soifer Student Scholarship Fund to supporting the Scopus Student Village. Deeply engaged in Jewish Studies, Enid, a Guardian of The Hebrew University, will be posthumously awarded an Honorary Fellowship at the Board of Governors Meeting in June 2007. Together we mourn the loss of this magnificent individual and cherish her life and example. We offer deepest sympathies to her children Jonathan and Randi Zimmerman, and to the entire family, who are in our thoughts and prayers. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, all contributions go to AFHU, One Battery Park Plaza, New York, NY 10004. AFHU George A. Schieren, Ira Lee Sorkin, Chairman Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director The Hebrew University Prof. Menachem Magidor, President $(6$)SOIFER--Enid, 63, died on Sunday, March 18th at her home in Warwick, NY. She is survived by her children Randi and Jonathan and her brother Allen, and her beloved pets, Simcha and Leon. Enid was elected to two terms of service on the Community School Board of District 28, in Queens. For 12 years she helped students attend the college of their choice at her company Educational Counseling and Placement. A lover and patron of the arts, Enid assisted with the expansion of the collections at the Bronx Museum of the Arts and the Roig House in Humacao, Puerto Rico. Most recently she was the Chairperson of the National Campaign for the American Friends of the Hebrew University. Her family requests that any contributions in her name be given to American Friends of the Hebrew University or the Bronx Museum of the Arts. $(6$)SOIFER--Enid. It is with deep self sympathy that Hineni acknowledges the passing of our dear friend Enid Soifer. Condolences to her children. Jonathan, Jeannine, Randi, and Enid's brother Alan. Rabbi Yisrael Jungreis, Spirtitual Leader Rebbetzin Esther Jungreis, President Barbara Janov, Executive Director

A House committee released documents Monday that showed hundreds of instances in which a White House official who was previously an oil industry lobbyist edited government climate reports to play up uncertainty of a human role in global warming or play down evidence of such a role. In a hearing of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, the official, Philip A. Cooney, who left government in 2005, defended the changes he had made in government reports over several years. Mr. Cooney said the editing was part of the normal White House review process and reflected findings in a climate report written for President Bush by the National Academy of Sciences in 2001.

A janitor was arrested yesterday on and charged with raping an 8-year-old girl in the basement of Public School 91 on Albany Avenue near East New York Avenue, the police said. The janitor, Francis Evelyn, 58, of Brooklyn, was charged with first-degree rape, sex abuse and endangering the welfare of a child. Melody Meyer, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education, said that Mr. Evelyn had ''been removed from the schools pending disposition of the case.'' According to the police, the child told her mother about the sexual attacks, which they said took place between Feb. 1 and March 9. JENNIFER 8. LEE

No politicians raise money like the Clintons, be it their success or ferocity or creativity. (Remember those White House teas and those Lincoln bedroom sleepovers?) Now Bill Clinton is going where no former president has gone before, to enrich Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign. Mr. Clinton will drop by a spinning exercise class on Thursday on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and speak briefly about health care and his wife's candidacy to more than 30 women and men wearing spandex, sweat shorts and the like.

CHALIAPIN--Helen (Helcia), age 98, formerly of Easton, CT and Marion, MA, died on March 6, 2007 at the Hebrew Senior Life Center in Roslindale, MA. Helcia was the beloved wife of portrait painter and Time Magazine cover artist Boris Chaliapin, daughterin-law of Russian operatic bass Feodor Chaliapin, and sister-in-law of actor Feodor Chaliapin Jr. She is survived by her brother, Morris Davidson, her sister-in-law Marina Chaliapin Freddi, her stepgrandson Christopher Murphy, her nieces and nephews, Rema Sessler, Maggie Salvatore and Michael Davidson, as well as great-nieces and nephews, Adlyn Loewenthal, David Schwartz, Eric Schwartz, Joshua Sessler, Nina Englander, Tracy McIntosh, Dassia Posner, Gabriella Salvatore, and many greatgreat-nieces and nephews. Helicia's dry humor and wit, her kindness and grace, as well as her unending beauty will be deeply missed by all. A memorial service will be held privately. In lieu of flowers, memorials can be sent to the American Heritage Center at the University of Wyoming for the ongoing care and digitization of the finding aid for the Boris Chaliapin collection. American Heritage Center; Apt 3924; 1000 E. University Ave.; Laramie, WY, 82071-2000. http://ahc.uwyo. edu/default.htm

A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about the spending of money raised by Shriners misstated the state in which a leader at the Decatur Shrine Club raised concerns about proceeds from bingo. It was Alabama, not Georgia.

Q. Is it true that the ''good oil'' in nuts turns to a trans fat when the nuts are roasted? A. No, said Christina Stark, a nutritionist with the division of nutritional sciences at Cornell University. ''Roasting nuts doesn't create any significant trans fat.''

Raymond D. Nasher, a real-estate developer and banker who, along with his wife, Patsy, amassed one of the world's best collections of Modern and contemporary sculpture and built a lavish public home for it in downtown Dallas, died on Friday in Dallas. He was 85. Mr. Nasher had become ill the day before on an airplane while returning home from a business trip in Europe, officials in Dallas said.

An article on Friday about the dismissal of Israel Singer, a leader of the World Jewish Conference, referred incorrectly to the health of the organization's president, Edgar M. Bronfman, who has said he wants his son Matthew to succeed him. Dr. Adam Rosenbluth, Mr. Bronfman's doctor, said Mr. Bronfman is in ''very good health. He has no chronic debilitating illness nor does he have any illness that would have impact on his longevity and his ability to lead'' the congress. He is not in poor health.

HOUSTON--Anita Fouilhoux, 94, died Friday, March 16, at the Norwalk, CT. Hospital after a brief struggle with cancer. She and her husband, the late Isaac Hayne (Ike) Houston, raised their four children on Lambert Road in New Canaan, Connecticut. Mrs. Houston was active as a volunteer for the Democratic Party and various organizations which supported the United Nations. She served as cochairman of the UN Hospitality Committee and most recently chaired the UN Study Group. Surviving is a son, Andre Fouilhoux Houston of Washington, D.C.; three daughters, Katherine Houston Bradford of New York, NY, Jean Clark Houston of Portland, Oregon and Marianna Houston also of New York, NY, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A funeral will be held at the St. Aloysius Church in New Canaan, CT on Thursday, March 22 at 10 am. Memorial contributions may be made to the UN Committee of New Canaan, 107 Lambert Road, New Canaan, CT 06840.

Because of an editing error, a headline and film review on Wednesday about ''The Go Master'' referred imprecisely to the game Go. Although the game flourished in Japan and is an important part of Japanese culture, it is believed to have originated in China. It is not a Japanese game.

When Marv Levy was the coach of the Buffalo Bills in the 1980s and 90s, he never knew how much money his players made. He did not have an agent, and his own salary negotiations consisted of the Bills' owner, Ralph Wilson, telling him what he would be paid. When Wilson asked Levy to be the Bills' general manager last year, Levy, never comfortable with numbers, immediately told Wilson that someone else would have to negotiate player contracts.

Democratic presidential contender John Edwards, who curtailed his Iowa trip on Tuesday to be with his wife, Elizabeth, for her post-cancer medical appointments this week, announced tonight that they would be holding a news conference tomorrow at noon in Chapel Hill.

Elaine Orbach's campaign to have a Midtown intersection named for her late husband, the actor Jerry Orbach, received unanimous approval tonight from members of Community Board 4. A neighboring panel, Community Board 5, had failed to endorse the idea.Fortunately for Mrs. Orbach, the intersection she had her eye on - 53rd Street and Eighth Avenue - straddles the two districts. Based on tonight's meeting, Community Board 4 will be more receptive to the ceremonial name -- Jerry Orbach Corner -- when the full board votes on April 4. Then the matter goes to the City Council.

A political mystery was solved on Wednesday with the unmasking of the maker of a much-discussed Internet advertisement that portrayed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as Big Brother. The creator, it turned out, worked for consultants to Senator Barack Obama, a rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.
The Ohio State freshman point guard Mike Conley Jr. and the freshman center Greg Oden live together in student housing, but their lifestyles are as different as their personalities.

The Texas A&M Coach Billy Gillispie is the only bachelor coach remaining in the N.C.A.A. tournament. He's also the only coach in the tournament who doesn't have any children. His single status has earned him the nickname "College Station's Most Eligible Bachelor." Gillispie said in an interview on Monday at Reed Arena that he wasn't sure if he would ever get married again.

Thom Browne, the men's designer who has an agreement with Brooks Brothers to produce a special line of men's and women's clothes, squeezed in some tweeds and top coats yesterday before everyone had put the fall season to bed. My own feelings about the collection were mixed, though they did not include disappointment. I think Browne fulfilled his mission to give Brooks something different without completely overturning the traditions of the 189-year-old company. Admittedly, the fit and proportion of the clothes (more Browne than Brooks), the solemn stiffness of the tweeds, the muscular legs in knee socks and the odd bespectacled model induced, at times, a thought of Austin Powers. Still, the overcoats and blazers were eye-catching and different, and I can imagine a woman having a good old time with the men's capes and tweed plus fours, pinching the elements that would look sexy and fun for her. A woman with a very subjective sense of style (and a slim, hipless figure) will know what to do with a small-fitting wool pantsuit, its trousers cropped, embroidered with the Brooks fleece logo. The collection seems evenly divided between men's and women's looks.

If you're a fan or alum of any of the 16 teams remaining in the N.C.A.A. tournament, you are willingly blinded by your loyalty. Two weeks after acquiring ResMae Mortgage, Citadel Investment Group on Wednesday took a further step into the subprime mortgage market with a 4.5 percent stake in Accredited Home Lenders Holding. The stake of 1.13 million shares is worth about $13.5 million based on Accredited's closing stock price of $11.96, a rise of about 11 percent.

New York State is jumping on the bandwagon and joining the mega-primary. A bill moving the state's presidential primary to Feb. 5 from March 4 passed both houses of the New York State Legislature today, and with Gov. Eliot Spitzer pledging support for the idea, the bill seemed almost certain to be signed into law. More details at The Caucus.

If there is a better place to watch a spring training game than here at Dodgertown, in Vero Beach, I have yet to find it. For those unlucky enough never to have made it here, my condolences because time is running out: the Dodgers will train here only one more season before moving across the country to Arizona.

The Round of 16 tips off tomorrow and this is when The Bracket Tournament points start to add up. Each game picked correctly is worth 4 points in the online standings, with each upset giving you another 3 points. But having a partly dead bracket is, well, deadly, and some of us simply can't win.

Bruce Wasserstein, the veteran deal maker and head of investment bank Lazard, could be getting out of the legal publishing business. Mr. Wasserstein's investment firm, Wasserstein & Company, said Wednesday that it hired Credit Suisse to consider strategic options for portfolio company ALM, including a possible sale. ALM publishes 34 magazines and newspapers, including American Lawyer and the National Law Journal. The decision to seek out potential buyers came about 10 years after Mr. Wasserstein's firm acquired ALM through its U.S. Equity Partners fund.

CNBC was reporting Wednesday afternoon that a "major Palm shareholder" expects cellphone giant Motorola to announce a deal to acquire the company for about $2 billion. The announcement could come as soon as Thursday, the unidentified shareholder said. Rumors about such a deal made the rounds Tuesday after the Web site Unstrung.com reported that four parties -- Motorola, cellphone company Nokia and private equity firms Silver Lake Partners and Texas Pacific Group -- were considering a bid for Palm. None of those firms, nor Motorola, have commented on the deal speculation.

In December, the U.S. Supreme Court agreed to hear an antitrust case involving Credit Suisse. This week, Justice Anthony Kennedy abruptly recused himself, most likely because his son Gregory is a managing director at the investment bank.

Amaranth Advisors, which managed $9 billion in assets before imploding after its energy-market trades went bad, is the best-known hedge fund casualty of 2006. But there were lots of others: At least 83 of these private investment pools gave up the ghost, according to a survey by the industry publication Absolute Return. Many of these were small funds, but nine (including Amaranth) had assets of at least $1 billion before calling it quits. That is a sharp contrast from 2005, when no billion-plus funds folded.
The governor's office recently contacted bidders for the state's thoroughbred franchise to let them know how administration plans to conduct background checks on them.

On Tuesday, Reuters reported unusual trading activity related to agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland, which some traders chalked up to rumors of a possible takeover, either by another company or by a private equity firm. The speculation drew out some skeptics, including a Merrill Lynch analyst who called a leveraged buyout of the company "unlikely" and an unnamed options trader who dismissed the chatter to Reuters as the "latest of a long series of recent rumors in all kinds of stocks."
