Finally, some affordable housing in London. "The Sunday Times" reports that the most expensive rental in London is a six-bedroom house at 10 Park Street in the posh Mayfair neighborhood, just a short stroll from Hyde Park. Developer Paul Davies wants £40,000 -- or nearly $80,000 -- a week for a short-term rental or £30,000 a week for six months or more. The property comes with a mews house for the staff and a 38-foot swimming pool in the basement. Real estate experts I contacted agreed that the price is a bit steep, arguing that Davies is more likely to get £20,000 or £25,000 a week. Yeah, now that's more reasonable.

As private equity bigwigs were trying to keep the Texas legislature from messing with their TXU deal, the chiefs of Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio were working to sell their proposed merger to regulators and lawmakers. The two companies said Wednesday that if they combine, the enlarged company will offer tiers of service, including a cut-rate package of radio programming consisting of fewer channels.

In the spirit of built-in coffee makers and other futuristic designs, along comes a fireplace that doubles as -- drum roll, please -- a plasma TV! Picture House at www.plasmafireplace.co.uk will unveil the Kiara plasma TV fireplace later this week at the Smart Home Show in Birmingham, England.
In Monday's installment, Paul claimed that his comments about the architect's high fees made me cry.
Kakuro is simply elegant, nurikabe ends in a rush of excitement, while masyu has no numbers. Could one of these three logic puzzles become as popular as sudoku?

The mayor's budget director, Mark Page, sent a letter [pdf] on Monday to the heads of city agencies warning that they might have to cut 1.5 percent from their budgets this year and 4 percent in the next fiscal year. The agencies have been asked to submit proposed cuts by the end of the month. Only the schools have been spared from the exercise.

Morgan Stanley said Wednesday that its net income surged 70 percent from a year ago to $2.67 billion in its fiscal first quarter. Morgan Stanley's chief executive, John Mack, said the results reflected "effective, disciplined risk-taking" at the firm's institutional securities arm.

When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new "period of restrained growth" for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

Last night in Washington, over 1,000 donors paid, at minimum, $1,000 to eat finger foods and see that dynamic duo, former President Bill and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, give stump speeches in a hotel ballroom. The evening netted $2.7 million for her presidential campaign.

Michael Kinsley, now a Time magazine columnist, is squatting at the Time staff blog Swampland this week, where he announces that he's skeptical of the significance of the scandal over the "Gonzales Eight." Citing Adam Cohen's Editorial Observer column in The New York Times, Kinsley writes, "I'm not sure that I buy it." He explains:
"It was a bright, cold day in April and the clocks were striking thirteen."

The Chicago Board of Trade postponed a shareholder vote on its proposed merger with its crosstown rival, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on Tuesday night in a delay the exchange said would allows its investors to review the Intercontinental Exchange's higher bid. Yet the C.B.O.T. also said that the Merc merger "remains in effect."
The story of Pakistan's cricket team that lost to Ireland in the World Cup on Saturday took another surprising turn last night as the death of their coach was labeled "suspicious" by Jamaican police.
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Mar. 19 column, "Don't Cry for Reagan."

A new report published by the National Venture Capital Association says that companies backed by venture capital providers over the past three decades employed nearly a 10th of private-sector workers and generally outperformed their non-venture-funded counterparts in 2005. The study, conducted by Global Insight, said that American companies that received venture capital funding from 1970 to 2005 accounted for 10 million jobs in 2005, or 9 percent of private-sector positions, $2.1 trillion in revenues, and 16.6 percent of total gross domestic production.
The ancient practice of lining the cave with animal hides gets a crisp new edge.

Virgin America, a proposed start-up airline backed by Richard Branson, won tentative approval from the Transportation Department to operate after agreeing to jettison its chief executive and revamp its financing to reduce the influence of Mr. Branson and other non-citizens of the United States.
Museums around the city are coming to grips with the outpouring of work from China that is shaking up the art world.
Congress is taking aim at the identity theft scourge as a major consumer protection problem.

Michael Mayo, the outspoken analyst who runs the financial-services research team for the Prudential Equity Group, is leaving to join Deutsche Bank. Mr. Mayo, who has been at Prudential since 2001, will bring his five-person team to Deutsche, where they will continue to cover financial stocks.

John F. Antioco, the chief executive of Blockbuster, who has been locked in a dispute with company directors over the size of his bonus, has agreed to leave his job at the end of the year, but he will exit with far less than he initially wanted. Among those most satisfied by the outcome: board member Carl C. Icahn, who started the fight over Mr. Antioco's pay.

Top executives from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and tje Texas Pacific Group on Tuesday urged Texas legislators not to create new regulatory hurdles to their $45 billion purchase of the electric utility TXU. According to the Associated Press, Henry Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis suggested the private equity firms might walk away from the deal, which would be the largest leveraged buyout ever, if such measures were passed. But the Dallas Morning News said the investors "stopped short" of suggesting new regulations could kill the deal.

Bertelsmann, Europe's largest media company, is joining forces with private equity groups to establish a novel 1 billion euro ($1.33 billion) investment partnership that could herald a shopping spree for the company, which owns RTL and Random House, according to The Financial Times.

An automobile wheelmaker, Hayes Lemmerz International looks like it might finally be on a roll despite difficult times in the American auto-parts sector. Shares of the Northville, Mich., company have risen sharply since Hayes Lemmerz announced Friday that it plans a rights offering of up to $180 million worth of common stock, taking advantage of receptive capital markets to lower its debt.

The News Corporation and Hearst have teamed up with Patrick McGovern, the billionaire tech publisher, to back a new venture in China that plans to make movies, DVDs and computer and virtual-reality games for the Chinese market, The New York Post reported. The venture, known as the China New Media Fund, has a total of $50 million in funding from the three media giants, The Post said.

Jerome B. York, former chief financial officer at Chrysler and Kirk Kerkorian's right-hand man, may be advising possible bidders on a Chrysler buyout, David Welch wrote in BusinessWeek's Auto Beat blog.

Aegerion Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company whose backers include a private equity firm, Advent International, filed with regulators to raise as much as $86 million in an initial public offering.

Talk of a deal between the computer maker Gateway and strong>Acer of Taiwan has been rampant ever since Acer's chief executive, JT Wang was quoted earlier this month as saying he planned to make an acquisition in the PC industry this year.

Take-Two Interactive Software, which is locked in a proxy battle with several hedge funds, has a "gaping hole" in its antitakeover defense, a director at Institutional Shareholder Services tells The Deal. Under certain conditions, the company's charter allows shareholders to replace Take-Two's board of directors without the need for a formal vote.

Examining the escalating battle between the white-shoe firm Sullivan & Cromwell and a former associate, Aaron B. Charney, who claims he was harassed because he is gay, The New York Observer concludes that this is a case of "lawyers behaving badly".

A hedge fund, Farallon Capital Management, rode to the rescue of a suffering subprime mortgage lender, Accredited Home Lenders Holding, extending a five-year $200 million loan after the company's financial backers cut it off.
Beacon Rock Capital, a hedge fund, was charged with defrauding mutual funds of $2.4 million through market-timing trades, the United States attorney in Philadelphia said.

The former chief executive of Qwest Communications, Joseph P. Nacchio, deceived investors and the public when he secretly sold $101 million in stock before its share price fell sharply, a federal prosecutor declared during opening statements Tuesday in Mr. Nacchio's insider trading trial.

Two wildly different portraits of Conrad M. Black were presented to the jury in opening arguments Tuesday at the criminal trial of the former newspaper baron and three colleagues. In the version put forward by a prosecutor, Lord Black is a thief who is different from a bank robber only in that his methods involve artfully worded memoranda and he wears suits and ties.

Affiliated Computer Services should hold out for a higher price from Darwin Deason and Cerberus Capital Management, according to Breakingviews and the Financial Times's Lex column. Mr. Deason, who is Affiliated Computer's chairman, and Cerberus offered Tuesday to buy the company for $59.25 per share, but a Prudential analyst thinks Mr. Deason might be open to other bidding partners.
59E59 Theaters announced the full lineup for its fourth annual festival of new theater from across the pond, “Brits Off Broadway.”
Art exhibitions flourish across the country. Here is a selection of the latest offerings.
A way to live the country life in the manner of a master, fanciful frames for a budding collection and more.
On the season premiere of the ABC hit series “Dancing With the Stars,” Heather Mills, Paul McCartney’s estranged ex-wife, found refuge from a messy divorce and a disability on the dance floor.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

One of the highlights Tuesday was Nick getting a trim near the Kabul market. The sight of a western journalist getting his haircut on the street didn't draw as large of a crowd as Nick's visit to the barber in the refugee camp in Sudan. This isn't the first time he's done this in Afghanistan (or even the second.) Was the third time the charm? Watch the video and then make your comments about Nick's hair.
Al Gore has said many times, if never quite definitively, that he has no plans to run for president in 2008, but that has not stopped his fans from speculating, or hoping.
Tristan Bauer’s film portrays the Falklands War in 1982 as a mismanaged, vainglorious spasm of nationalism.
Like other former winemaking backwaters of Europe, the Navarre region of northern Spain has begun producing some notable wines in recent years.
John Edwards called a news conference for Thursday to discuss the future of his campaign.
Expert advisers who receive money from a drug or device maker would be barred for the first time from voting on whether to approve that company’s products.
The Federal Reserve edged away from previous signals that its next move on interest rates would be up.
It appears to be the first time prisoners have been openly exchanged for a hostage in the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.
Full-scale fighting broke out in Mogadishu and furious crowds mutilated the bodies of government soldiers, chanting, “We will burn you alive!”
The director of one of the first major rock concert benefits, which was released in 1972,  died on March 3 from heart failure.
People with a rare injury expressed increased willingness to kill or harm another person if doing so would save others’ lives.
Bishops rejected a demand to create a parallel leadership to serve the minority who oppose their church’s liberal stand on homosexuality.
Former Vice President Al Gore insisted today that global warming requires an aggressive federal response.
A subcommittee authorized subpoenas for Karl Rove and other White House officials in the inquiry into the firing of eight prosecutors.
After years of bitter political rivalry, President Jacques Chirac endorsed Nicolas Sarkozy for president today.
There has been fierce fighting in the past three days between Uzbek militants and local tribesmen.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y., March 20 — The Suffolk County Legislature defeated a bill Tuesday that would have prevented day laborers looking for work from congregating near public roads. It was a measure that the county executive, Steve Levy, supported in part as a way to deal with illegal immigrants who, he said, threaten the quality of life on Long Island.
Lindsey Harding had 13 of her 18 points in the first half, and top-seeded Duke withstood eighth-seeded Temple’s comeback bid Tuesday night to win, 62-52, in the second round.
John McKay, the former United States attorney for western Washington, said it was “not for me to say” whether the attorney general should stay in his job.

Dell Inc., the personal computer maker, unveiled a low-cost PC for China, its fastest-growing market. The PC is priced from about $335 to $520, the company said in a statement. Earlier this month, Dell reported a sharp drop in quarterly profit while revenue fell short of Wall Street expectations, adding that it foresaw pressure on growth and profit margins in the next several quarters as it spends money to restructure. The company had lost market share to the global industry leader Hewlett-Packard in the fourth quarter and in January. In China, the world’s second-largest PC market, Dell ranks third behind the Lenovo Group and Founder Technology.
There were chants of “M.V.P.” Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden as Dirk Nowitzki’s campaign picked up steam, leading the Dallas Mavericks to a rout of the Knicks.
North Carolina State nervously lost an 11-point lead before recovering in overtime to defeat Baylor, the 2005 national champion, 78-72, in the second round of the tournament.
The Nets missed yet another opportunity to defeat a worthy opponent Tuesday night. They are 3-2 in their last five games, but none of those victories have come against a high-caliber team.

Gerald Wallace had 27 points and 11 rebounds, Adam Morrison hit the go-ahead 3-pointer in overtime and the Charlotte Bobcats beat visiting Cleveland, 108-100, last night to snap the Cavaliers’ eight-game winning streak.

An article on Saturday about the recent proliferation of St. Patrick’s Day parades in the New York region misstated the given name in some copies of the president of the Chamber of Commerce in Rockville Centre, N.Y., which began its parade in 1997. He is Michael Shenker, not Eric. The article also misstated the population of Hoboken, N.J., which held its parade on March 3 this year. It is 39,900, according to a 2005 census estimate — not 70,000.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about problems in the subprime lending market referred incorrectly to a statement by the investment manager, the Pacific Investment Management Company. While Pimco did indeed say in a report to clients that losses on subprime mortgages would affect other “aggressively underwritten” loans, it was referring to the market in general — not specifically to investments under Pimco’s control.
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a pet food recall included an erroneous phone number in some copies for a manufacturer hotline. It is (866) 895-2708.

The East Village Journal article on Feb. 18, about a dispute between a theater and an anarchist bookstore that have shared space in the same building for six years but are now going their separate ways, gave an erroneous location in some copies for the Anarchist Switchboard, another countercultural bookstore that used to be in the neighborhood. It was on East Ninth Street, not St. Marks Place. The article also rendered incorrectly the name of another former bookstore in some copies. It was the Peace Eye Bookstore, not Peace Eye Books. A reader pointed out the error shortly after the article was published, and this correction was delayed for research.

A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday, about Adrienne Truscott’s “genesis, no!” at Performance Space 122, misstated the time of the matinees on Saturday and Sunday. They will be at 5 p.m., not 4 p.m.

The Lumberton Journal article yesterday, about the New Jersey town’s ranking as the most active community, per capita, of eBay buyers and sellers in the United States, misstated the amount the company donated to a local animal shelter. It was $10,000, not $100,000.
Corrections
The videotape shows two lawyers, a veteran and a younger man, discussing strategy in a divorce case.

NEW HAVEN, March 20 (AP) — The state is reviewing an undisclosed number of drug cases because the head of the New Haven police narcotics unit was arrested on theft charges in a federal sting, the state’s attorney here said on Tuesday.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has maintained an inclusionary tone since the Sean Bell shooting, but some residents want him to take a closer look at what they call overly aggressive police tactics.
Kia Vaughn led Rutgers with 16 points as the Scarlet Knights overcame their latest roadblock — playing Michigan State on its home court — with a 70-57 victory.

David Letterman went home sick yesterday afternoon, forcing his CBS program to quickly call in reinforcements from its guest list. Adam Sandler, who had been scheduled to be the lead guest on “Late Show with David Letterman” last night, was hurriedly enlisted to step in as host. Mr. Letterman has been forced to call in guest hosts on two previous occasions because of illness. This time, Mr. Letterman contracted the stomach virus that has been raging in the New York area and was too ill to perform, a spokesman for the show said. Mr. Sandler called in Don Cheadle to be the lead guest on last night’s show. Mr. Cheadle is the co-star in the movie Mr. Sandler intended to promote last night, “Reign Over Me.”.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it had signed the first contract for construction of the new Second Avenue Subway. The contract, awarded to a joint venture of construction companies called S3 Tunnel Constructors, is worth $337,025,000, the authority officials said. The contract allows construction to begin on the first phase of the project, which will run from 96th Street to 63rd Street before connecting to existing train service, officials said. When the project is finished, plans call for the subway line to stretch from 125th Street to Hanover Square in Lower Manhattan.

A state judge has upheld the State Department of Environmental Conservation’s 2004 decision to close 54 roads in the Adirondacks to all-terrain vehicles. State Supreme Court Justice Joseph C. Teresi, left, rejected the challenge by the Black River Valley Four-Wheeler Club to the department’s closing 54 roads on state land in Lewis, St. Lawrence, Herkimer and Oneida Counties to the vehicles. The agency closed the roads after finding that riders were damaging preserve lands.

A man who was awaiting trial in the March 2006 death of his infant son has died, apparently in a suicide, his lawyer and jail officials said yesterday. The boy, Eric Rivera, died after being shaken, and the authorities said the father, Julio Rivera, 26, had blown PCP-laced marijuana in his face. Mr. Rivera was found hanging from a sheet shortly before midnight on Monday, said Chief Alan Otto of the Suffolk County Sheriff’s Department.

The Metropolitan Transportation Agency and the union representing transit workers have joined with the Police Department in offering a $22,000 reward for information leading to the killer of a transit worker, James Plucica, agency officials said yesterday. Mr. Plucica, a guard for the transit system, was fatally shot on his way home early on March 11. The police said he was shot in the chest on Ralph Avenue about 1 a.m. as he waited for a bus.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that it would spend $2 billion in improvements to the port over the next 10 years. Cargo volume at the port has increased, with port officials reporting a record $149 billion worth of goods moving through the port in 2006. The work over the next 10 years includes improvement to roads, a 50-foot harbor-deepening project and upgrades to dockside rail service.

Charges were dismissed yesterday against a man arrested in Flemington in the summer of 2005 after the police said he organized an antiwar protest in the borough without receiving a permit. The man, Bob Flisser, was fined $100 after the police charged he organized a protest of 24 people in front of the courthouse in Flemington, said his lawyer, Fernando M. Pinguelo. The American Civil Liberties Union argued that the town’s ordinance was overly broad and helped Mr. Flisser appeal. Yesterday, Flemington officials asked a State Superior Court judge to dismiss the charges. The borough’s lawyer, Barry Goodman, said that borough officials did not want to spend the money to fight the appeal.

David R. Garvin, the man fatally shot by the police after he killed a bartender and two auxiliary police officers in Greenwich Village last week, was discharged from the Marine Corps in the fall of 1988 for failing to show up for required training that was part of his military commitment as a reservist, a spokesman for the Marines said yesterday. The spokesman, First Lt. Brian P. Donnelly, said that Mr. Garvin, a private, was discharged on Oct. 24, 1988, and that the discharge was classified as “general under other than honorable conditions.” Mr. Garvin began his service on March 4, 1986, and his specialty was field radio operator.

Three more gun dealers have agreed to settle a federal lawsuit filed by the city by allowing a special master appointed by the court to monitor their operations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The settlements bring the number of dealers who have agreed to the monitoring arrangement to 12, the mayor said. The special master will have the right to monitor their records and inventory and videotape their operations to ensure compliance with federal laws, Mr. Bloomberg said. The city filed two lawsuits in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last year against 27 out-of-state gun dealers, claiming their operations had created a public nuisance, said Eric Proshansky, a lawyer for the city.

A division of Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, has agreed to buy Maher Terminals, which runs terminals at the Port of Elizabeth in New Jersey and the Port of Prince Rupert in British Columbia. The deal, which must be approved by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Committee on Foreign Investments in Washington, comes a year after Dubai Ports World tried to buy a terminal in Newark run by a British company. A division of the American insurance giant AIG closed a deal last week for that terminal. RREEF Infrastructure, the Deutsche Bank subsidiary, will retain Maher to continue running its terminals. Terms of the deal were not announced.

A Putnam man died Monday after a weight fell on his neck during a workout at a gym, the police said yesterday. The man, Joshua Peterson, 24, was attempting to lift free-weight equipment about 11:30 a.m. at Midtown Fitness, the police said. Mike Bogdanski, the manager, said Mr. Peterson worked out regularly at the gym, and workers called 911 as soon as the accident occurred. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Vincent Lecavalier got his 49th goal of the season and Filip Kuba scored 55 seconds into overtime last night as the Tampa Bay Lightning stopped a three-game losing streak with a 4-3 victory against the visiting Islanders.
ALBANY, March 20 — Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, can probably now relate to Richard Grasso, Maurice Greenberg and other corporate executives who have tangled with Eliot Spitzer.
For the 15 police horses assigned to Mounted Troop B in Midtown Manhattan, life just got sweeter.

Commerzbank, a German banking company, is selling its Jupiter Asset Management unit to an investment group that includes TA Associates, a private equity firm in the United States, and managers of the unit, for more than 1 billion euros ($1.33 billion). Commerzbank said it expected to book a gain of 300 million euros ($400 million) from the deal, which it described as part of an effort to focus its asset management activities more strongly on its core German market. Jupiter Asset Management is based in Britain.

The United States will make a final attempt at clearing barriers to trade in automobiles, medicines and rice as part of a free-trade agreement with South Korea by sending a trade official to Seoul next week. Deputy Trade Representative Karan Bhatia, who will make the trip, said it is the last chance to get a pact. American and Korean negotiators must reach an accord this month to get it to their legislatures before President George Bush’s “fast-track” trade negotiating authority ends July 1. An agreement would be the largest American trade deal since the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994.

China’s securities regulator barred companies from using proceeds from share sales to invest in stocks in an attempt to damp speculative buying. Companies are also banned from buying derivatives and convertible bonds with share sale proceeds, the Securities Regulatory Commission said. “Regulators are concerned that proceeds are fueling the stock market frenzy,” said Gabriel Gondard, a money manager at Fortune SGAM Fund Management, a venture of Société Générale in Shanghai.

China approved four foreign banks to begin local currency services to individual Chinese customers, opening up access to the country’s 30 trillion yuan ($3.9 trillion) in household savings and surging demand for credit cards and other financial services. The four banks approved are the locally incorporated entities of Citigroup, the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation unit of HSBC Holdings, Standard Chartered and Bank of East Asia, the China Banking Regulatory Commission said. Branches of the four will be able to offer a full range of yuan services to Chinese clients once they register their licenses, it said.

The Delphi Corporation, the auto parts maker, said it had filed for bankruptcy protection for a Spanish unit as part of a plan to close a money-losing plant in Cadiz, Spain. The parts maker will spend about $70 million this quarter for severance costs for the 1,570 workers at the plant, which makes steering mechanisms. Delphi, based in Troy, Mich., disclosed the measure in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company has not yet reached a severance agreement with the Spanish union. The Cadiz plant is the primary asset of Delphi Automotive Systems España, Delphi said.

Toshiba and Hynix Semiconductor agreed to end patent disputes over flash memory chips used to store data in electronic devices like digital cameras and MP3 players. Financial terms were not disclosed. Each company will get a license to the other’s semiconductor technology and signed product supply agreements. The accord settles all patent-related litigation in Japan and the United States, including three disputes before the International Trade Commission in Washington. The legal battles between the companies began in November 2004 when Toshiba, which is based in Tokyo, sued Hynix, based in Ichon, South Korea, after the companies failed to extend a licensing agreement.

The main French business federation said that the French economy would be unable to grow at its full capacity under programs put forth by the existing candidates for president and announced an economic program of its own. The federation, Medef, called for looser labor rules, lower taxes and incentives to bolster investment and innovation. Laurence Parisot, left, president of Medef, said there was little hope of achieving what she called “an ambitious but realistic goal” with the platforms of the three leading presidential candidates: Nicolas Sarkozy, Ségolène Royal and François Bayrou. “If you look at the three principal programs, none of them is proposing what we believe is right,” she said at a news conference. The first round of voting in the election is scheduled for April 22 with a runoff set for May 6.
The police have recommended to prosecutors that Thaksin Shinawatra, ousted as prime minister in a coup in September, be charged with three counts of lèse-majesté.
Substitutes for 21 of the 57 lawmakers dismissed by the Electoral Tribunal this month after they tried to reverse President Rafael Correa’s plan to rewrite the Constitution were sworn in.
The Berlin Zoo rejected claims by animal rights campaigners that a 3-month-old polar bear cub should be killed because he has become too dependent on humans.
Sixty-five people were killed when a truck taking them to a weekly market in Koudou fell into a lake as it crossed a bridge.
Four suspected drug traffickers were arrested on charges that they helped orchestrate the killings of three Salvadoran politicians and their driver in Guatemala last month.

Judges, lawyers and opposition activists have been holding demonstrations across the country to condemn chief the justice’s suspension this month as an attempt by General Musharraf to muzzle the judiciary.
Jamont Gordon had 16 points and 7 assists and host Mississippi State neutralized one of college basketball’s most dynamic players in defeating Florida State, 86-71, Tuesday night.
Al Gore’s return to Capitol Hill on Wednesday is akin to a recovering alcoholic returning to a neighborhood bar.
The Bush administration has been warning energy companies that penalties are possible if they pursue oil and gas deals with Iran.
The president and Congress appeared headed toward a showdown over demands for White House documents and advisers’ testimony.
Robert Joseph is the latest to leave an administration that some conservatives say has lost its clarity of mission.
Police said that the suspect came at Natasha Ramen from behind, encircled her with a bear hug and then plunged a knife into her neck.
Gov. Kathleen Blanco, a Democrat, was damaged politically by her post-Hurricane Katrina performance.
Differences between John F. Antioco and the company’s board over his compensation package have dragged on for nearly two years.
Two different portraits of Conrad M. Black were presented in opening arguments at the criminal trial against the former newspaper baron.
Consumer Reports said its quest for independence kept it from reaching out to experts who might have helped it avoid one of its biggest mistakes.
Minnesota records provide a window on the financial ties between drug companies and the doctors who prescribe their products.
Coach Tim Floyd believes the signing of the top high school prospect  has improved the team’s overall attitude as it prepares to play top-seeded North Carolina in the Round of 16.

The State House passed a measure intended to stop businesses from selling lollipops, gumdrops and other candies flavored with hempseed oil to taste like marijuana. The measure passed by a vote of 133 to 26 and now moves to the Senate. Marketers say the treats, which have drug-inspired names like Kronic Kandy and Pot Suckers, are a harmless novelty, and many advise retailers to sell the candy only to customers 18 or older. The legislation says the candies promote drug use and give children the “false impression that marijuana is fun and safe”; it would ban sales of the candies to minors and impose fines of up to $1,000 for each offense. Vote Hemp, a national organization that promotes the use of hemp products, said the measure would make Georgia the first state to ban the sale of the candy to minors. Sales have already been banned in Alameda County, Calif.; Chicago; and Suffolk County, N.Y.

Two Border Patrol agents examining packages of marijuana that had floated ashore along the Rio Grande were fired upon by unseen assailants on the Mexican side of the river, the authorities said. The agents, who returned fire, were not injured, and there was no sign that their bullets had struck anyone, said Oscar Saldana, a Border Patrol spokesman. It was the second such episode this year along a narrow part of the Rio Grande near Donna, about 13 miles northeast of McAllen. Mr. Saldana said the shooting was most likely a response by drug smugglers to the Border Patrol’s more intensive searches of the area.

Vandals upset over the Iraq war defaced Representative Mike Rogers’s office overnight, a spokesman said. The unknown individuals splattered red paint on the building, in Lansing, and put up a sign saying Mr. Rogers, a Republican, had blood on his hands. They also spray-painted the sidewalk with the words “no more deaths,” glued shut the front door of the building and destroyed security cameras, said Andy Keiser, Mr. Rogers’s chief of staff. Mr. Rogers supported President Bush’s decision to go to war in Iraq four years ago but has opposed his recent plan to send extra troops to the country.

Vice President Dick Cheney went to George Washington University Hospital after experiencing discomfort in his left lower leg, where a blood clot was discovered earlier this month. After consulting with his doctors, Mr. Cheney was asked to return to the hospital for ultrasound imaging of the deep venous thrombosis, or clot, in that leg, said a spokeswoman, Megan McGinn, who added that “the ultrasound revealed no extension or complication of the clot.” Mr. Cheney returned to the White House to resume his normal schedule, Ms. McGinn said.

The Mississippi Senate voted 31 to 20 to reject an effort that would have cut the state’s 7 percent grocery tax in half and raised the cigarette tax. Gov. Haley Barbour, left, a Republican, has said that he opposes raising taxes but that the time is not right to reduce the grocery tax because Mississippi faces too much economic uncertainty in its recovery from Hurricane Katrina. A Senate resolution would have allowed the filing of a bill to cut the grocery tax and to raise the cigarette tax to $1 a pack from 18 cents, the third lowest in the nation. Mississippi residents pay the nation’s highest taxes on groceries, yet rank among the lowest-paid households in the country.
The U.S. and the Europe have led a boycott, but they provided more aid to the Palestinians in 2006 than 2005.
The rationalization of life’s conflicts as merely a “failure to communicate” is Mr. DeLay’s approach to explaining the Republicans’ loss of Congress last year.
The warning against giving the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu to teenagers follows reports that some children who took the drug exhibited bizarre behavior, news reports say.
Both sides are mindful that the White House possesses a powerful weapon, executive privilege, which is the constitutional equivalent of a declaration of war.

The European Court of Human Rights awarded a woman 25,000 euros, about $33,000, in damages after doctors refused to grant her permission to terminate her pregnancy despite serious risk to her eyesight.
In their first advertisements of the 2008 election cycle, Democrats seek to link a Republican member of Congress to the controversy.
Lottery Numbers.
Russia has apparently decided that it can do even better financially if it starts pressuring its longtime client Iran to curtail its nuclear appetites.

Congress has the right and the duty to fully investigate the firing of eight United States attorneys, which may have been illegal, and Justice Department officials’ statements to Congress, which may have been untrue.
Carol C. Lam’s decision to focus on high-level offenders appears to have been a political miscalculation of the highest order.
Deportees who arrive in Jamaica find politicians and police officers blaming them for the island’s spiraling crime, and neighbors and even relatives turning their backs on them.

BROWN--Janet. Dearly beloved friend. We are so sad to lose you to this tragic automobile accident at the prime of your life. Your memory will be in our hearts always. Charlotte, Roger, Eric, Lisa, Beth, Peter, Marc, Ellen, and family $(6$)BROWN--Janet, Dearly beloved Janet, you were a very special friend. You will be truly missed by all and especially me and my family. Joey, Lisa and Rachel $(6$)BROWN--Janet, A woman of great style. She will be missed both for her taste and herself. Marion and Jerry Sussman $(6$)BROWN--Janet. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of the New York University Child Study Center mourn the loss of Janet Brown, a great friend and supporter of the Child Study Center. We will miss her wit, her generosity and her passion for old and young. Our thoughts are with all those who love her. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D., Director $(6$)BROWN--Janet. We will miss your outrageous honesty, your lack of political correctness, your ability to have a good time and make sure everyone else had a better time. Your relentless pursuit of fun with your innumerable friends. Everyone loved you for your enduring indomitable spirit. Our family has suffered a loss that will never be replaced. We'll miss you at all of our family celebrations, our vacations, and our parties. Life will never be the same without you and your endless dance moves. Brooke, Dan, Jon, Stephen and Mallory. $(6$)BROWN--Janet. Your special, unique love, personality and soul along with your style and wit will always be remembered. There will never be another you! Our family who adores you, will miss you and be always thinking of you. So much admiration and love. Bunny and Charles $(6$)BROWN--Janet. My old friend, you did everything before anyone else, and did it brilliantly. This time you messed up-too soon for you to go. Adele Frankel Loeb $(6$)BROWN--Janet, (born in Philadelphia, PA, May 23, 1947), died suddenly in a car accident on Friday, March 16th as she drove to work. Janet enjoyed an iconic career as founder of Janet Brown Ltd., the chic Long Island boutique. She was loved by her friends, respected by her colleagues; her quick irreverent sense of humor and extraordinary heart will be missed by all. She is survived by her sister Elaine Edelstein, of Villanova, PA, her brother-in-law Marc, and her niece and nephew Brandon and Melissa, in addition to her countless friends. Funeral services will be held Tuesday March 20, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison and 81st street. Donations may be made in the name of Janet Brown to the New York University Child Study Center, 577 1st Ave, NY, NY 10016.

SCHNEIDER--Estelle C., age 80, much loved wife of Dr. Philip Schneider, passed away on March 19th. She is survived by her devoted husband, adoring children (Marcie Schneider and her husband Michael Ader, Cindy Bogorad and her husband Len Bogorad), five grandchildren, her sister and brother-in-law (Judy and Howard Seed), and nieces and nephews. She will be missed by many.

Ernst Haefliger, a Swiss tenor who was most renowned as an interpreter of German art song and oratorio roles, died on Saturday in Davos, Switzerland, where he maintained a second home. He was 87 and lived in Vienna. Charlotte Schroeder, his American manager, announced his death.

The Metropolitan Transportation Agency and the union representing transit workers have joined with the Police Department in offering a $22,000 reward for information leading to the killer of a transit worker, James Plucica, agency officials said yesterday. Mr. Plucica, a guard for the transit system, was fatally shot on his way home early on March 11. The police said he was shot in the chest on Ralph Avenue about 1 a.m. as he waited for a bus.

Thatcher Drama-Documentary Planned After the success of ''The Queen,'' moviegoers can look forward to the prime minister. BBC Films and Pathé Productions are developing a drama-documentary film about Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in the 17 days leading to the Falklands War against Argentina in 1982, the BBC reported. ''The proposed film will be a revealing and intimate portrait of Margaret Thatcher as she battles to save her career in the 17 days immediately preceding the war,'' Pathé said in a statement. ''The 17-day period is relevant because it was the duration of the British fleet's voyage to the Falklands. During that period, Thatcher had to confront her private fears, face down the men who doubted her and forge the image that even today casts a shadow across the political landscape.'' Ms. Thatcher, sometimes called the Iron Lady, was prime minister from 1979 to 1990. Last month, Helen Mirren won the Academy Award for best actress for ''The Queen,'' portraying Elizabeth II in the days after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales. Mezzo-Soprano and Quartet Win Segal Awards The mezzo-soprano Kate Lindsey, below, and the Daedalus Quartet, right, were awarded $5,000 each yesterday as winners of the 2007 Martin E. Segal Awards at a luncheon at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center. The awards, established by the center's board when Mr. Segal retired as Lincoln Center chairman in 1986, are given annually to two rising young artists in recognition of outstanding achievement. The nominees are chosen on a rotating basis by two of Lincoln Center's 12 resident arts constituents. Ms. Lindsey is in her third and final year in the Metropolitan Opera's Lindemann Young Artist Development Program. Founded in 2000, the Daedalus Quartet is made up of the brother-and-sister violinists Kyu-Young Kim and Min-Young Kim, the violist Jessica Thompson and the cellist Raman Ramakrishnan. The quartet is in the final year of its three-season residency in the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Chamber Music Society Two program. Horror Film Ads Prompt Outrage ''Captivity,'' a horror film starring Elisha Cuthbert, below, as a woman abducted, held captive and tortured, hasn't opened yet, but its ads -- on 1,400 New York City taxis and on 30 billboards in the Los Angeles area -- have offended so many people that the producer said they would be withdrawn, Reuters reported. The complaints, via e-mail messages and telephone calls, were prompted by four images, each with a caption: ''Abduction'' showed Ms. Cuthbert with a gloved hand across her face; ''Confinement'' showed her behind a chain-link fence with a bloody finger poking through; ''Torture'' showed her face covered in white gauze, tubes up her nose; and ''Termination'' showed her, head thrown back, seemingly dead. Lionsgate Films, the distributor, said the ads were handled by its partner, After Dark Films, and that it had no involvement with them. After Dark said the billboards were posted without its approval. The Motion Picture Association of America declined immediate comment pending a decision about the matter. ''Captivity,'' directed by Roland Joffé, whose credits include ''The Killing Fields'' and ''The Scarlet Letter,'' is to open on May 18. Who's Watching? The typical American home received 104 television channels last year, The Associated Press reported, citing Nielsen Media Research. In 2000, the number was 61, and in 1990 it was 33. But Nielsen reported that last year viewers watched only 15 percent of the available channels for any appreciable length of time. Museum Mile Festival Set The 29th annual Museum Mile Festival, when Fifth Avenue from 82nd Street to 105th Street becomes a stroller's delight, has been scheduled for on June 12 from 6 to 9 p.m. Nine leading New York cultural institutions will be open free to the public: El Museo del Barrio; Museum of the City of New York; Jewish Museum; Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum; National Academy Museum; Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum; Neue Galerie; Goethe-Institut New York; and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

To the Editor: While the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit may have ruled that it is not discriminatory for Union Pacific to exclude contraceptive coverage in its health plan, it is clearly fiscally irresponsible (''Court Says Health Coverage May Bar Birth-Control Pills,'' news article, March 17).

The East Village Journal article on Feb. 18, about a dispute between a theater and an anarchist bookstore that have shared space in the same building for six years but are now going their separate ways, gave an erroneous location in some copies for the Anarchist Switchboard, another countercultural bookstore that used to be in the neighborhood. It was on East Ninth Street, not St. Marks Place. The article also rendered incorrectly the name of another former bookstore in some copies. It was the Peace Eye Bookstore, not Peace Eye Books. A reader pointed out the error shortly after the article was published, and this correction was delayed for research.

With its highest-rated debut yet, ''Dancing With the Stars'' kicked off its fourth edition on Monday, leading ABC to an easy victory in the ratings. This premiere dominated overall from 8 to 10 p.m., drawing 21.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, improving over its September 2006 premiere by 1.5 million viewers. At 10, ABC's ''What About Brian'' (7.4 million) received a slight boost from the added exposure, earning a second-place finish ahead of ''The Black Donnellys'' on NBC (5.8 million). CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' led the 10 p.m. hour as usual, with 17.4 million viewers. In a three-way race for second place on Monday, CBS had an advantage in total viewers, but Fox edged ahead among adults 18 to 49 with ''Prison Break'' at 8 (8.3 million) and ''24'' at 9 (11.9 million). NBC ranked third in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic as a two-hour episode of ''Deal or No Deal'' averaged 14.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. BENJAMIN TOFF

An article on March 7 about a debate over natural and manufactured trans fat misspelled the surname of a professor of epidemiology and nutrition at the Harvard School of Public Health, who commented on the chemical makeup of trans fat. He is Walter Willett, not Willet.

To the Editor: Re ''Sniffing Out Fraud in the Bottle'' (March 14): The article serves to remind us that when our desire for a thing approaches ''excessive exuberance,'' the provenance of quality is open territory for fakers and frauds. It also reminded me of two old semisecular proverbs I learned growing up in a modest Midwestern neighborhood.

An article on Saturday about the recent proliferation of St. Patrick's Day parades in the New York region misstated the given name in some copies of the president of the Chamber of Commerce in Rockville Centre, N.Y., which began its parade in 1997. He is Michael Shenker, not Eric. The article also misstated the population of Hoboken, N.J., which held its parade on March 3 this year. It is 39,900, according to a 2005 census estimate -- not 70,000.

David R. Garvin, the man fatally shot by the police after he killed a bartender and two auxiliary police officers in Greenwich Village last week, was discharged from the Marine Corps in the fall of 1988 for failing to show up for required training that was part of his military commitment as a reservist, a spokesman for the Marines said yesterday. The spokesman, First Lt. Brian P. Donnelly, said that Mr. Garvin, a private, was discharged on Oct. 24, 1988, and that the discharge was classified as ''general under other than honorable conditions.'' Mr. Garvin began his service on March 4, 1986, and his specialty was field radio operator. SERGE F. KOVALESKI

Should you crave something stronger than apple juice or chocolate milk to go into your box lunch, there are now individual Tetra Pak boxes of wine. Three Thieves Bandit wines from California -- a refreshingly tart pinot grigio and a fruity, young cabernet sauvignon -- are being sold in handy 250-milliliter boxes (about 8.5 ounces), in packs of two and four. There is also a white zinfandel that may be drinkable, very cold, at the beach in a couple of months. All that's missing is a straw. They are sold at Best Cellars in Manhattan in packs of two ($6) or four ($12). A pack of four sells for $7.49 at Red White & Bubbly in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and for $10 at threethieves.com.
FLEISCHER--Gilbert, on March 20th, 2007. Beloved husband of Terry. Loved by many, and he will be dearly missed. Funeral service Friday, 11am at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

WEHLE--L. Brandeis Jr., 88, of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., NY, died March 17th, of multiple myeloma. Survived by Anne, his wife of 61 years; children, Nancy Aboff, Susan, Jonathan and Robert; grandchildren Matthew, Susannah and Gareth; and step-grandchildren Gage and Justin. Alumnus of Lincoln School and Harvard College Class of 1940. Aerospace Engineer with Grumman Corp for more than 40 years. A contributor to post-war naval and general aviation and the construction of the first lunar module. A dedicated runner, tennis player and sailor, he was noted for his dry wit, keen intelligence and his courtesy and kindness to all. Memorial service Wednesday, March 21st at Old First Presbyterian Church, Huntington, NY. Donations may be made in his name to Huntington Hospital.

A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday, about Adrienne Truscott's ''genesis, no!'' at Performance Space 122, misstated the time of the matinees on Saturday and Sunday. They will be at 5 p.m., not 4 p.m.

Four suspected drug traffickers were arrested on charges that they helped orchestrate the killings of three Salvadoran politicians and their driver in Guatemala last month. Interior Minister Carlos Vielman said the suspects, three men and a woman, had ordered corrupt police officers to kidnap the lawmakers to recover money and drugs from their car. None were found. Four police officers arrested in the case were later killed in jail. A fifth officer remains in custody and one is at large, officials said. MARC LACEY

Is the identity theft scourge getting better or growing worse? There is little consensus on whether financial institutions and law enforcement agencies are making headway in combating identity theft. But Congress is nonetheless taking aim at the crime as a major consumer protection problem.

To the Editor: Re ''For Teachers, Middle School Is Test of Wills'' (front page, March 17): Yes, middle school is a test of wills, but it is also a lot of fun. It makes me sad to read that so many middle school teachers have not had the good luck that I have had.

The main French business federation said that the French economy would be unable to grow at its full capacity under programs put forth by the existing candidates for president and announced an economic program of its own. The federation, Medef, called for looser labor rules, lower taxes and incentives to bolster investment and innovation. Laurence Parisot, left, president of Medef, said there was little hope of achieving what she called ''an ambitious but realistic goal'' with the platforms of the three leading presidential candidates: Nicolas Sarkozy, Ségolène Royal and François Bayrou. ''If you look at the three principal programs, none of them is proposing what we believe is right,'' she said at a news conference. The first round of voting in the election is scheduled for April 22 with a runoff set for May 6. KATRIN BENNHOLD

Natasha Ramen, 20, above, had accused a fellow Guyanese immigrant of raping her in 2005. After she was fatally stabbed outside her home in Hollis, Queens, last week, the defendant in the rape case, who was free on bail while awaiting trial, has been charged with her murder. Article, Page B3.

Charges were dismissed yesterday against a man arrested in Flemington in the summer of 2005 after the police said he organized an antiwar protest in the borough without receiving a permit. The man, Bob Flisser, was fined $100 after the police charged he organized a protest of 24 people in front of the courthouse in Flemington, said his lawyer, Fernando M. Pinguelo. The American Civil Liberties Union argued that the town's ordinance was overly broad and helped Mr. Flisser appeal. Yesterday, Flemington officials asked a State Superior Court judge to dismiss the charges. The borough's lawyer, Barry Goodman, said that borough officials did not want to spend the money to fight the appeal.

GILE--David Emery, died peacefully at home in Greenwich, CT on Thursday, March 15, 2007. Mr. Gile was born in Cambridge, MA on June 7, 1922 and was the youngest child of Clement and Anne Gile. He graduated from Phillips Andover Academy in 1940 and Yale University in 1944. At Yale he sang in the Whiffenpoofs and was a member of The Elihu Club. Mr. Gile was a Lt. J.G. during WWII in the Pacific and served as Commanding Officer of LSM 500. After the War, he graduated from the University of Pittsburgh Law School in 1949, earned an LL. B. and was elected class president. He married Patricia Schoen in 1949 and three children followed: Nancy (1950), David Jr. (1952) and Larry (1955). Mr. Gile was a banker, first as an assistant trust officer with the Union National Bank of Pittsburgh then as a commercial lending officer with Pittsburgh National Bank and then Marine Midland Bank. Following retirement from banking, he served as Vice President for the Council for Aid to Education. Mr. Gile felt strongly about serving his community and church and was active in many organizations. Among his noteworthy activities and accomplishments: awarded the Yale Medal, President of the Rye Presbyterian Church Board of Trustees, recipient of the Whiffenpoof Cup, honorary LL.D. from the Berkeley Divinity School at Yale, member of the Yale Club Council, Secretary of the Rye Rotary Club, member of the Rye, NY City Council (he was a lifelong Republican) and volunteer at The Osborn Home and United Hospital. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Patricia Gile and sons David Jr. and Larry. A memorial service will be held at Rye Presbyterian Church on Saturday March 24, 2007 at 11:00 am with a private reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church Mission Fund.

ASK cooks about their culinary emergency funds -- for use in case of a rainy day, citywide blackout, severe illness or case of laziness -- and you'll get answers like boxes of pasta and jars of tomato sauce, cans of black beans or a stack of well-worn takeout menus. For me, it's sausages. Sausages tucked away in the freezer mean that no matter how late I get home past the supermarket's closing time, I'll still be able to make something good to eat.

FENG--Shao Chang, on March 17, 2007, of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved husband of Kuo Chen, loving father of Arleen and Clarence (Dorothee), grandfather to Christine and Carolina, also survived by his brother Chen Chang. Uncle to Harry, Judy and Ling, and other nieces and nephews in Canada and China. Shao was a founding member of the Chekiang University Alumni Association. He installed aircraft radios for the Flying Tigers in World War II and went on to develop early portable transistor radios in the United States. Memorial visitation at Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 98-07 Ascan Ave., Forest Hills, Sunday, March 25, 2007, 1-4 pm. Donations in lieu of flowers to your favorite charity in his name are appreciated.

Three more gun dealers have agreed to settle a federal lawsuit filed by the city by allowing a special master appointed by the court to monitor their operations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The settlements bring the number of dealers who have agreed to the monitoring arrangement to 12, the mayor said. The special master will have the right to monitor their records and inventory and videotape their operations to ensure compliance with federal laws, Mr. Bloomberg said. The city filed two lawsuits in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last year against 27 out-of-state gun dealers, claiming their operations had created a public nuisance, said Eric Proshansky, a lawyer for the city.

Misery loves company, and no one in turn loves misery more than newbie filmmakers. That, at least, is one of the conscience-thwacking lessons of the 36th edition of New Directors/New Films, the annual joint venture of the department of film at the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center that opens tonight. Dedicated to the work of what the festival terms ''new or emerging'' filmmakers, New Directors/New Films has served as an early stopping point for former up-and-comers from Chantal Akerman to Spike Lee and Wong Kar-wai and many more filmmakers who faded from view or never finished emerging. Whether because of the state of the world, the states of mind of the festival's half-dozen programmers or those of the filmmakers, this year's slate of 26 features -- some of which have yet to secure American distribution -- and miscellaneous shorts seems to mete out a greater abundance than usual of sorrows from around the globe. Some of these offerings feel as exploitative as anything produced by Hollywood at its most craven; a few veer close to unhappy art-house self-parody.

F.B.I. Warned on Misuse of Data Collection Tools House Republicans joined Democrats in warning the F.B.I. that it could lose the power to demand that companies turn over customers' telephone, e-mail and financial records if it did not swiftly correct abuses of the investigative tools known as national security letters. Critics say the letters have been used to gather private data illegally. PAGE A18 Governor Won't Run Again Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco of Louisiana, a Democrat who has struggled politically since Hurricane Katrina, ended months of speculation and said she would not seek a second term. PAGE A14 Brainteasers From Japan A Japanese company called Nikoli, run by the self-proclaimed godfather of sudoku, has plenty more where that came from: kakuro, for instance, a logic puzzle that, like sudoku and crossword puzzles, involves filling squares. Will Shortz, puzzle editor of The Times, sampled it and, in a review, calls it one of the most elegant puzzles around. This summer, 50,000 Manhattanites, including Mayor Bloomberg, Spike Lee and Tom Wolfe, will be cast out of 10021 and relegated to one of two new ZIP codes. PAGE B3

OFTEN on a dessert table in a bistro or trattoria in Europe there will be a big bowl of plump prunes poached in wine. It's a dessert I love, but one that is rarely offered in the United States. Except at my house. Everyday merlot or Chianti are the wines I prefer for poaching prunes. But the reds we tasted from Navarre suggested that they could easily suit this purpose, too. Several of them were jammy, with suggestions of rich cooked fruit, spices and earthy tannins on the palate. I also picked up hints of prune in more than one of these wines. And many of them are around $10, making them perfect for poaching prunes to serve at the end of a simple, rustic dinner of grilled flank steak with blistered red peppers and roasted potatoes.

Times Square explodes with grown-up giddiness: Alfred Eisenstaedt's photograph of that ecstatic kiss between soldier and nurse celebrating the victory over Japan; crazed bobby-soxers clamoring to see Frank Sinatra at the Paramount in 1943; throngs of theatergoers in line for the latest coveted Broadway seat; New Year's Eve frenzy. But it also offers a wide-eyed introduction to the spectacle, enjoyed by this toddler with her father and doll, in 1969.
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a pet food recall included an erroneous phone number in some copies for a manufacturer hotline. It is (866) 895-2708.

An article on March 7 about libel lawsuits that have been filed against restaurant critics misidentified a newspaper whose restaurant reviewer lost such a case. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was The Irish News, of Belfast, Northern Ireland, not The Irish Times, of Dublin.

To the Editor: Re ''Protecting Wages in a Global Economy'' (editorial, March 18): It is important to understand that those who support updating the American worker safety net through the existing wage insurance program do not believe that this should be the only or even the first priority in dealing with job loss.

THERE is French toast, and then there are torrijas, the Spanish version. The origins of both are undoubtedly the same: yet another way to make good use of bread that's no longer fresh. Though torrijas, like French toast, can be served at breakfast, they can also be a knockout dessert. In fairness, the French take their pain perdu more seriously than we take French toast, generally making it sweeter and more bread-pudding-like. But nothing prepared me for my first bite of torrijas. They are pretty much over the top: bread drenched in milk (I've had them made with cream, too), sugar and eggs, and then fried, seriously fried, in olive oil.

GILBRIDE--John T., 90, the former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Todd Shipyards Corporation, a longtime resident of Greenwich, CT, and recently of Stamford, passed away at Stamford Hospital on March 17, 2007. Mr. Gilbride was elected as Director of Todd in 1951, President of the Corporation in 1958 and Chairman and Chief Executive Officer on June 30, 1975, which office he held until his retirement in 1986. A staunch advocate of American sea power and a leading spokesman on behalf of the reconstruction of naval forces and the American Merchant Marine. Mr. Gilbride was appointed by President Nixon, in January of 1971, to the Commission of American Shipbuilding, serving until December 1973. He was a Trustee of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, Emigrant Savings Bank, Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, the United States Merchant Marine Academy, and the United States Research Council. He was a member of the Board of Managers of the American Bureau of Shipping, a member of the Executive Committee, and American Committee of Llyod's Register of Shipping, and a member of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, and held numerous positions in organizations related to the maritime industry. He is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Rosemary Shelare Gilbride of Stamford, his son Frank J. and his wife, Carol R. of Greenwich, his son John T. Jr. and his wife, Victoria of Media, Pennsylvania, his son Gary G. and his wife, Angela of Old Greenwich, his former daughter-in-law Bari Taylor of Greenwich, seven grandchildren and five, soon to be six, great-grandchildren. Calling hours will be held Wednesday, March 21, 2007, at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, Connecticut, from 4:00 to 8:00 pm. A Mass of Christian Burial is scheduled for 11:30 am on Thursday, March 22, 2007, at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic, 469 North Street, Greenwich, Connecticut, to be followed by burial in St. Mary's Cemetery in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, Connecticut 06830, or to the Paget Foundation, 120 Wall Street, Suite 1602, New York, NY 10005.

To the Editor: I appreciate Nicolette Hahn Niman's efforts in raising awareness about the conditions in which pigs are raised (''Pig Out,'' Op-Ed, March 14), but I was struck by her comment that it is incumbent on us to ensure that animals have decent lives because we ask them to make the ultimate sacrifice for us. This doesn't ring true, suggesting as it does that we actually ask the animals to make a sacrifice for our sake.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about problems in the subprime lending market referred incorrectly to a statement by the investment manager, the Pacific Investment Management Company. While Pimco did indeed say in a report to clients that losses on subprime mortgages would affect other ''aggressively underwritten'' loans, it was referring to the market in general -- not specifically to investments under Pimco's control.

ZEBROWSKI--Kenneth P. With great sorrow, the New York State Assembly mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Assembly Member Ken Zebrowski. Speaker Sheldon Silver and the members of the New York State Assembly offer our sympathy and our prayers to the Zebrowski family, to Assembly Member Ken Zebrowski's many friends, and to the citizens of New City, Haverstraw, and all of Rockland County. From the moment he was elected to the county legislature in 1973, Ken Zebrowski served the communities of his beloved Rockland County with dedication and joy. Elected to the Assembly in 2004, Ken Zebrowski was known for the profound respect he held for the law, and for his unshakable faith in the legislative branch of government. Throughout his service, Ken was guided by three simple and oft-stated maxims: The Legislature is the people's best window for immediate access to their government. Legislation offers the most direct and effective response to my constituents' concerns and problems. The needs of every Rockland County resident are my concern. In the State Capitol, Ken Zebrowski was admired for his leadership and integrity, his wisdom and wit, his compassion and most of all, his generous spirit. Ken was a valued member of several Assembly committees. He was committed to improving public education, reforming the state's healthcare system, protecting the elderly, and assisting those communities hurt by the Mirant Utility Company bankruptcy and assessment challenge. It was an honor to serve with him and a privilege to know him both as a friend and as a colleague. We will miss him dearly. Sheldon Silver Speaker of the NYS Assembly

Two Border Patrol agents examining packages of marijuana that had floated ashore along the Rio Grande were fired upon by unseen assailants on the Mexican side of the river, the authorities said. The agents, who returned fire, were not injured, and there was no sign that their bullets had struck anyone, said Oscar Saldana, a Border Patrol spokesman. It was the second such episode this year along a narrow part of the Rio Grande near Donna, about 13 miles northeast of McAllen. Mr. Saldana said the shooting was most likely a response by drug smugglers to the Border Patrol's more intensive searches of the area. STEVE BARNES

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Despite Ban, Palestinians See More Aid Under Hamas Despite the international embargo on aid to the Palestinian Authority since the election victory of Hamas, significantly more aid was delivered to the Palestinians in 2006 than in 2005, official figures indicate. His resignation reflects what some hawks see as a drift in the administration toward too much compromise and caution. American soldiers had stopped the car but allowed it to pass after seeing the children. A3 Britain Considers Veil Rule British authorities proposed new rules to allow schools to forbid Muslim students from wearing full-face veils in class, reflecting a wider debate over Britain's relationship with its Muslim minority. A11 Scores Die in Pakistan Clashes Fierce fighting between foreign militants and local tribesmen in northern Pakistan in the past few days has left nearly 60 dead, government and security officials said. Miers, the former White House counsel, and two other officials regarding the firing of federal prosecutors. But Democrats promptly rejected the offer. A1 Governor Will Not Run Again Gov. House Republicans joined Democrats in warning the F.B.I. that it could lose the power to demand that companies turn over customers' telephone, e-mail and financial records if it did not correct abuses of the investigative tool known as national security letters. A18 Massachusetts Sets Benefits Massachusetts took a major step in its near-universal health care overhaul, with the board that oversees the plan voting to require health insurers to provide certain minimum benefits, including coverage of prescription drugs. The decision is subject to final approval in June. A18 SCIENCE/HEALTH Doctors' Ties to Drug Makers Records in Minnesota, one of the first states to pass a law requiring drug makers to disclose payments to doctors, provide a window on the financial ties between pharmaceutical companies and the doctors who prescribe their products. A1 Alzheimer's on the Rise More than five million Americans have Alzheimer's disease, a 10 percent increase from the last tally five years ago and a number expected to more than triple by 2050, absent a cure, as baby boomers move into their late 60s and 70s. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 New Congresswoman Carefully Picks Projects Kirsten Gillibrand arrived in Congress two months ago, ready to tackle national problems like health care, immigration and the war in Iraq. But few issues are as challenging as the one she has been confronting for the past few weeks: picking pet projects for her upstate New York district. B1 No Rush to Civil Unions Preliminary figures show that 229 same-sex couples applied for civil union licenses in New Jersey in the first month since they became available, far fewer than the 1,700 who registered as domestic partners in the state within a month of that becoming an option in 2004. B1 Rape Victim Slain; Suspect Held After Natasha Ramen was raped, she went to the police and obtained an order of protection against the man she said was her attacker. That did not prevent him from killing her on a Queens street, the police say. To the Editor: In the article about fake wines, Eric Asimov writes, ''Ordinary wine lovers are unlikely to be affected by scammers, unless they buy old wine or buy their wines from secondary sources, like brokers or through Internet auctions.'' Mr. Asimov's implication that fraudulent wines are more prevalent on Internet wine sites than at traditional auction houses or, for that matter, brick and mortar retail stores that sell older wines, is simply incorrect.

Seth Greenberg, right, grew up baking with his father, William Greenberg Jr., whose sleek chocolate cakes, sticky buns, buttery cookies and distinctively decorated celebration cakes had a deservedly loyal following for decades. The Greenbergs sold their bakeries about a decade ago and Mr. Greenberg retired. But now Seth, who confesses to having missed the allure of butter, sugar and chocolate, has gone back into baking and is offering a limited array of temptations that can be ordered for delivery in Manhattan. Seth Greenberg's Just Desserts offers freshly baked cookies in eight varieties ($40 a pound), mini sticky buns ($38 a dozen), small linzer cookies ($36 a dozen), lemon squares ($34 a dozen) and fudgy brownies without nuts ($28 a dozen) and with nuts ($32 a dozen). Orders may be placed with the distributor, East End Cookie Company, at (646) 290-9204. Add $15 for delivery, which is made after 3 p.m. Tuesdays through Saturdays.
SEBOLSKY--Hyman, 1916 2007. A courageous and beloved husband, father, grandfather. Forever in the Winner's Circle of our hearts.

The two leading network evening newscasts -- ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC and ''NBC Nightly News'' with Brian Williams -- could each lay claim to a ratings title last week, as they did a week earlier, according to figures from Nielsen Media Research released yesterday. ''World News'' was the most watched of the so-called Big 3, drawing an estimated 8.64 million viewers a night on average, 320,000 more than watched NBC's program (8.32 million) and nearly 2 million more than tuned in to the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' (6.76 million). But Mr. Williams's program on NBC was the most-watched among viewers 25 to 54, the demographic to which advertisers pay closest attention for evening news programs. Because CBS's coverage of the N.C.A.A. college basketball tournament pre-empted Ms. Couric's broadcast in some parts of the country late last week, audience figures for CBS include only last Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. JACQUES STEINBERG

Protests against the suspension of Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry by President Pervez Musharraf continued as Deputy Attorney General Nasir Saeed Sheikh and another senior judge from Sindh Province resigned. Mr. Sheikh said it was difficult to work in the current judicial crisis. Judges, lawyers and opposition activists have been holding demonstrations across the country to condemn chief the justice's suspension this month as an attempt by General Musharraf to muzzle the judiciary. SALMAN MASOOD
