A PUZZLING BUSINESS A Japanese publishing company called Nikoli, widely regarded as the world's most prolific wellspring of logic games and brain teasers, is looking for the next big puzzle to follow the sudoku craze. [Page C1.] PENALTIES FOR DEALING WITH IRAN The administration has been warning energy companies and the governments of China, India, Pakistan and Malaysia that they face penalties from the United States if they assist Iran in producing oil and natural gas. [C1.] PARTING COMPANY A nearly two-year dispute between John F. Antioco, the chief executive of Blockbuster, and his company's board ended with Mr. Antioco's decision to step down before the end of the year. He will receive a bonus for 2006 of $3.1 million; he thought he was entitled to $7.65 million. [C1.] DRUG MAKERS AND DOCTORS The widespread financial ties between pharmaceutical companies and the doctors who prescribe and recommend their products are becoming more visible, because a handful of states now require drug makers to disclose payments to doctors. [A1.] NEW AIRLINE WITH BRITISH ROOTS A proposed start-up airline backed by Richard Branson, called Virgin America, has won tentative United States approval, and could become a major new player in the market for flights between the East Coast and West Coast. [C3.] A BID TO TAKE A COMPANY PRIVATE Affiliated Computer Services, a provider of corporate computer services, is the target of a $5.9 billion buyout bid led by the company's founder, Darwin Deason, and the investment fund Cerberus Capital Management. [C4.] SUBPRIME SCOREBOARD New Century Financial, once the nation's largest independent provider of subprime mortgages, was dealt a setback when Fannie Mae said it would no longer buy its loans made to borrowers with poor credit. And People's Choice, a privately held lender, filed for bankruptcy protection. But in a hopeful sign for subprime lenders, Accredited Home Lenders Holding said it had won fresh financing from a hedge fund. [C2.] NEW HOME CONSTRUCTION Construction of new homes rebounded in February, rising 9 percent after a steep slide in January, but a further decline in building permits was seen as worrisome for the troubled housing industry. [C8.] PRENUPTIAL AGREEMENT The British bank Barclays and a Dutch rival, ABN Amro, who are discussing a merger, announced how they would organize the joint company: it would be listed in London, have its headquarters in Amsterdam and would split the top two jobs. [C8.] A LEGISLATIVE SOLUTION There is little consensus on whether financial institutions and law enforcement agencies are making headway in combating identity theft. But Congress is nonetheless taking aim at the crime as a major consumer protection problem. [C3.] MILKEN SELLING A STAKE Michael R. Milken, the former junk bond chief who served prison time for securities fraud, plans to sell a $1 billion stake in his group of educational companies called Knowledge Universe. Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse are helping find investors for the private sale, according to regulatory filings. Mr. Milken, above, is chairman of Knowledge Universe. [C2.] ORACLE'S QUARTERLY PROFIT UP Oracle, the software maker, reported that its profit increased 35 percent during the third quarter, exceeding even management's expectations of 24 percent to 29 percent. [C3.] DON'T TOUCH THAT DIAL ABC is considering changes in the way it interrupts programs for commercial breaks, hoping to encourage viewers to stick around rather than reach for the remote or race to the refrigerator. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] INFANT CAR SEAT SAFETY Consumer Reports magazine said that the mistakes that forced it to retract a report on the safety of infant car seats stemmed from its failure to consult outside experts when devising a side-impact test. [C5.] TAKEOVER BIDS HELP LIFT SHARES Shares rose as takeover activity in the technology sector reassured investors about equity valuations and offset apprehension about a monetary policy meeting under way at the Federal Reserve. [C9.] LAPSES LED TO OIL EXPLOSION An explosion and fire that killed 15 contractors and injured 180 other workers at the BP oil refinery in Texas City two years ago was caused by company deficiencies ''at all levels,'' a federal safety panel reported. [A15.] ONLINE THE EXECUTIVE PAY PACKAGE Coverage of executive pay packages and interactive features are in a special section on executive pay at nytimes.com/business. WEEKEND BUSINESS In a podcast, reporters and editors from The Times's Sunday Business section offer perspective on the week in business and beyond. Information on subscribing is at nytimes.com/business. THE BUSINESS OF GREEN Companies are seeking economies of scale in alternative energy. A special report on the business of environmental conservation is at nytimes.com/business.

Nearly a century ago, a handsome, well-to-do miller in a rural Czechoslovak village proposed to a young woman. Unexpectedly, she turned him down to marry a musician from a neighboring town. Today, that young woman's grandson lives at the mill and, along with his wife and two daughters, has embarked on a project to make it a home, art gallery, museum and international art camp.

CLANCY--Joseph M., of New York, on March 18, 2007. Father of Michael. Grandfather of Shawn and Miranda. Brother of Maureen, Patricia and the late James and Kevin. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 8:30 and 9:30am, Saturday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, at 10am.

David Letterman went home sick yesterday afternoon, forcing his CBS program to quickly call in reinforcements from its guest list. Adam Sandler, who had been scheduled to be the lead guest on ''Late Show with David Letterman'' last night, was hurriedly enlisted to step in as host. Mr. Letterman has been forced to call in guest hosts on two previous occasions because of illness. This time, Mr. Letterman contracted the stomach virus that has been raging in the New York area and was too ill to perform, a spokesman for the show said. Mr. Sandler called in Don Cheadle to be the lead guest on last night's show. Mr. Cheadle is the co-star in the movie Mr. Sandler intended to promote last night, ''Reign Over Me.'' BILL CARTER
FEINSTEIN--Muriel, March 19. Survived by husband Jerome, and family Jack, Miles, Lynn, Connie, Zeke, Khudayja, Gudell and Gabrielle. Memorial March 22, 3pm, Wien & Wien Funeral Home, Hackensack, NJ.

LIEBMAN--Alan S. With deep affection we remember our dear friend whose larger than life personality will remain with us forever. He shared his wisdom, enthusiasm and love for us over our families' lifetimes. His spirit will live within us all. Shirley, Jack, Leigh and Romy Silver $(6$)LIEBMAN--Alan. The Trustees and staff of The Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum mourn the passing of our wonderful council, Alan Liebman, whose vigilant spirit will carry us forward. We extend our sympathys to his family, his beloved wife, Rosalie and their daughters. Samuel Sachs II, Chairman Jenny Dixon, Director The Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it had signed the first contract for construction of the new Second Avenue Subway. The contract, awarded to a joint venture of construction companies called S3 Tunnel Constructors, is worth $337,025,000, the authority officials said. The contract allows construction to begin on the first phase of the project, which will run from 96th Street to 63rd Street before connecting to existing train service, officials said. When the project is finished, plans call for the subway line to stretch from 125th Street to Hanover Square in Lower Manhattan.

ROBERTS--Nancy Lee (nee Rhodes), on Wednesday, March 14, 2007, of Easton, MD, beloved wife of John Joseph Roberts, devoted mother of Christopher Lee Roberts of Princeton, NJ, also survived by two granddaughters, Pierra A. Roberts and Eugenie Roberts, both of New York, NY, and one brother, Walter Edgar ''Dusty'' Rhodes of Chester, MD. She was predeceased by a son, John Peter Roberts. A graveside service will be held on Tuesday, April 24, 2007, at 11:00 am, at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. The family requests that memorial contributions be directed to the Maryland Institute of Art, 1300 Mount Royal Ave., Baltimore, MD 21217. Services by Fellows, Helfenbein and Newman Funeral Home, P.A., Easton, MD. www.fhnfuneralhome.com

A finishing touch on a dish in a restaurant is often a scattering of tiny leaves, or microgreens, packing intense flavor. Now home cooks can add this same professional grace note with fresh snippets of baby plants direct from the refrigerator. Lauri Roberts, an entrepreneur in Warwick, R.I., has started a company called Farming Turtles (''I wanted a name that was funny and memorable,'' she said) to grow nine kinds of microgreens.

SHILTON--Leon Gustave, age 63, of Rumson, NJ, died at his home on Sunday, March 18, 2007. Dr. Shilton was a Professor of Finance at Fordham University. Loving husband of Robertamarie Kiley; adored father of Sean, Moriah, Alycia, Lillith, and Sonjelle; cherished grandfather of Dylan Lloyd; brother of David Shilton and Marla Batchelder. A memorial service will be held Friday at 10:00 am at Christ Church, 380 Sycamore Ave., Shrewsbury, NJ. Damiano Funeral Home, Long Branch is in charge of services. Letters of condolence may be sent through our web address: damianofuneralhome.com

A division of Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, has agreed to buy Maher Terminals, which runs terminals at the Port of Elizabeth in New Jersey and the Port of Prince Rupert in British Columbia. The deal, which must be approved by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Committee on Foreign Investments in Washington, comes a year after Dubai Ports World tried to buy a terminal in Newark run by a British company. A division of the American insurance giant AIG closed a deal last week for that terminal. RREEF Infrastructure, the Deutsche Bank subsidiary, will retain Maher to continue running its terminals. Terms of the deal were not announced. KEN BELSON

SHAPIRO--Ruth of Little Neck, NY. Died on March 19,2007. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Barry and Neil Shapiro and Robin Beinhorn. Cherished grandmother of Henry, Stephanie, Harrison and Jill Shapiro and Nicole and Eric Beinhorn. Devoted sister of Dale Collins and dearest motherin-law of Steven Beinhorn and Ivy Shapiro. Services Thursday 12:15pm, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

MILLER--Martin W. of Riverdale and Fleischmanns, New York, passed on March 17, 2007. Devoted and loving husband to wife Miriam, father to sons Michael and Daniel, father-in-law to Rochelle, and beloved grandfather to Lauren and Allison. Born in Frankfurt, Germany on October 2, 1923. Veteran Master Sergeant U.S. Army CounterIntelligence in World War II. Principal Mundial Export Corporation of New York City and Tarrytown, New York for over 60 years. Memorial donations may be sent to the American Cancer Society. A man of integrity.

59E59 Theaters will announce today the full lineup for its fourth annual festival of new theater from across the pond, "Brits Off Broadway," running from May 3 through July 1. This year's crop of seven shows will bring Alan Ayckbourn's 1982 series of plays, "Intimate Exchanges," to town for its New York premiere. The prolific Mr. Ayckbourn, whose "Private Fears in Public Places" was a hit of the 2005 festival, will direct "Intimate Exchanges," an eight-part series sparked by one character's problem: to smoke or not to smoke.

The Federal Aviation Administration had been laying the groundwork to allow in-flight cellphone use. But the Federal Communications Commission will give up on the idea of allowing cellphone use on airplanes, the chairman said, because it is not clear whether the network on the ground can handle the calls.

As the House wrangles over the emergency war spending bill, the National Republican Congressional Committee -- responsible for getting people elected and re-elected to the House, put out this tonight:

Well, it's about time that people stop underestimating Memphis. The No. 2 Tigers just completed a scintillating victory against No. 3 Texas A&M in the most hostile of environments. Amid a sea of Texas A&M maroon, the Tigers stayed calm down the stretch and again overcame their supposed nemesis - free throw shooting.
Presidential candidate John Edwards says he will continue with his '08 campaign despite news that his wife Elizabeth's breast cancer has returned.
Want to get some attention on the Web? Wave your virtual arms inside a packed chat room and yell "YouTube killer!!!"

The announcement today that Elizabeth Edwards, wife of John, is facing a recurrence of cancer, gave the blogs a brief respite from acrimony, finger-pointing and, to a large part, politics itself. While some posts did consider the political ramifications for Mr. Edwards and the inaccuracy of early reports that he would quit or suspend his campaign, most simply offered their condolences.

Lots of humor at the old ballgame today. Jerry Springer had a seat behind home plate. The foul poles had the words "Terry's Plumbing" written vertically from top to bottom. As Peter Abraham shows us in his blog, there was a clown statue (designed by Springer -- seriously) outside the Yankees' clubhouse.
Should anyone be worried about oil oozing from the ground in Williamsburg? No, says the city. Smells O.K. [Gowanus Lounge]
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Reign Over Me,' starring Don Cheadle and Adam Sandler.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Offside,' an Iranian film about a group of young women who sneak into a soccer stadium.

"This is a happy day," House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said earlier today. "It is an historic day. It is a day when the people of the District of Columbia will finally have their voices heard and represented."

In his first public comments on the matter, Rudolph W. Giuliani today took a wait-and-see view of the firings of several United States attorneys, saying he did not know enough yet to judge whether anyone in the White House or the Justice Department had acted improperly.

With the surprising news today that the Kentucky Coach Tubby Smith was headed to Minnesota, expect one of the big storylines for tonight's game between Texas A&M and Memphis to be whether the A&M coach Billy Gillispie would jump to Lexington.

When the Florida Gators practiced today in preparation for Friday's regional semi-final against Butler, the reporters around courtside wanted to ask Coach Billy Donovan if he would be interested in moving to Kentucky to replace Tubby Smith, who is leaving the Wildcats to coach Minnesota.

Within the drama of Elizabeth and John Edwards' announcement that her cancer had returned dwelled a separate drama, about the hazards of a news cycle grown so heated that exclusives are measured in minutes - if not seconds - and the deadline is always past.

Arguably the hottest restaurant opening of early 2007 is Morandi, if you bear in mind that Gordon Ramsay at the London opened in late 2006, as did the Waverly Inn, which officially never opened - at least according to the coyly articulated position of the Graydon Carter Fabulosity Institute. It may never open, instead remaining content and profitable in some hyper-exclusive limbo where phones are never answered and hoi polloi are reduced to quivering, pointless supplication.

Few people will watch the game between U.C.L.A. and Pittsburgh with more mixed emotions tonight than the the Manhattan College coach Barry Rohrssen. Rohrssen, who is nicknamed Slice, just finished his first season at Manhattan after a seven-year stint at Pittsburgh as an assistant coach and associate head coach under both Ben Howland and Jamie Dixon. Howland and Dixon are the best of friends - their relationship stretching back to when Howland recruited Dixon as a high school player.
It's in.

Randomly placed among a mountain of media fact books about Texas A&M's basketball team on a table in the press room of the Alamodome was a 2003-04 Football Writers Association of America Directory, a subtle reminder that football is still king here in Texas.
In a media spectacle, the A380 touched down in New York this week. But the world's largest passenger plane has not yet sold to any American carriers.
What's the best age for a president of the United States? It depends who you ask, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

Rock stars and media giants are not the only ones worried about their creations being given away for free on the Web. Merrill Lynch, the giant securities firm, is taking new steps to protect its stock research, which it described in a note to clients as being "Napster-ized" -- a reference to the Web site that used to be a hotbed of wanton song-swapping before it went bankrupt and relaunched as a subscription-based service. In Thursday's letter, Candace Browning, Merrill's chief of global securities research and economics, began with an anecdote about how Merrill's research had recently been duplicated "with plagiaristic precision" on a Web site based in New Jersey. Now, she wrote, the firm is taking stronger measures to safeguard its analysis.
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's Mar. 22 column, "Stepping on the Dream."
Readers respond to David Brooks's Mar. 22 column, "A Proper Distinction."
The Yankees have a pretty full roster here in Sarasota to play the Reds. The only regulars left behind were Johnny Damon, Doug Mientkiewicz and Hideki Matsui.

In the wake of the Essjay controversy and a history department's ban, Wikipedia's founder has sought to restore credibility in the Web site in a well-established fashion. He set new policies and granted confidence-building interviews in national magazines.

Reporting the Midwest regional in the shadow of the Gateway Arch puts me in a good frame of mind and it is not just because of the positive memories of how well this Mississippi River city hosted the Final Four in 2005.

My Times colleague Jacques Steinberg has a very nice piece today about Ann Curry's latest journey to Sudan, including her interview with President Bashir, the butcher of Darfur. Ann is doing superb work, and I just hope the other TV networks follow her trail to the killing fields.
Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has struck a deal with the leaders of the Legislature to require most recipients of member items to disclose any connections they have to the lawmakers who give them.
A reader asks:
Democratic presidential contender John Edwards and his wife Elizabeth announced today that Mrs. Edwards's cancer had returned, this time in a rib on her right side.

Gerald S. Strober and Deborah H. Strober, authors of "Giuliani: Flawed or Flawless? The Oral Biography," have taken to YouTube to promote their book, a collection of interviews with 40 of Mr. Giuliani's longtime associates, teachers, friends, opponents, critics and "other astute political observers."
Photographs from the new Broadway musical "Curtains."

Bruce Wasserstein's name disappeared from investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort last year. But it will be resurfacing somewhere else. Harvard Law School said Thursday that it received a $25 million gift from Mr. Wasserstein and would name a new building after the Lazard chairman.
The scene as the former Vice President faced former colleagues, including James Inhofe of Oklahoma, one of Al Gore's most persistent critics.
Today in The Times, I reviewed the Apple TV box--and, for context, a couple of its rivals from Microsoft and Netgear.

McLeodUSA, the twice-bankrupt telephone provider once backed by Theodore Forstmann, is hearing the call of the public markets again. The company on Thursday filed with regulators to raise as much as $172.5 million in an initial public offering. We use the term "initial" loosely: McLeodUSA's predecessor company went public in 1996, and the company has since been through two Chapter 11 reorganizations.
The Edwards campaign is exceptionally tight-lipped this morning about what John and Elizabeth Edwards will say about her health at their noon press conference in Chapel Hill, N.C.

Pitching from the mound for the first time since undergoing shoulder surgery last August, Duaner Sanchez threw 11 pitches before feeling what he called "a pop" by his shoulder. He stopped immediately, and a consultation with a doctor revealed that the sensation was nothing more than scar tissue breaking apart.

What man wouldn't welcome comparisons to Jay Gatsby, the filthy rich, soiree-throwing subject of Fitzgerald's Great American Novel? Conrad Black, that's who. In a response to a column in The London Times, Mr. Black, the former press tycoon now on trial for fraud, wrote:
David Pogue reviews Apple's TV box, which can connect your computer to your TV without wires.
More by David Pogue on the early attempts to bridge the gulf between computer and TV.

Now that The Huffington Post has identified the creator of the Macintosh-inspired, anti-Hillary YouTube ad for Barack Obama's presidential campaign as an employee (now former employee) of a political-consulting firm that does business with Obama, will there be lasting effect from the discovery?
A substratum of dedicated — even fanatical — amateur ballet dancers do exist.
For some reason the Lab has turned into Animal House lately. As an encore to the laughing rats and the malaria-busting mosquitoes, we now present, for your viewing enjoyment, the fighting falcons.

It seems the seesaw that is the Tribune drama has tipped back toward Samuel Zell. The Chicago billionaire's bid to take the media conglomerate private may have fallen out of favor last week, but the Chicago Tribune reported Thursday that the company's directors are taking another look at his plan.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange insists that its $8.97 billion bid for its crosstown rival, the Chicago Board of Trade, will prevail in the end. But as the InterContinental Exchange touts its $9.9 billion higher bid, the Merc may have lost one of its highest-profile supporters: a certain Illinois senator running for president.

Glu Mobile, a publisher of games for mobile phones, raised $84 million in an initial public offering that priced late Wednesday. The offering, which values the entire company at $327 million, comes amid what the GigaOm blog calls a slow resurgence of technology I.P.O.'s.

Vulcan Capital, the venture-capital vehicle of Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, is creating a joint venture with Bankers' Capital Group to look for investments in the banking sector in the southeast United States. Bankers' Capital was launched last year by a group of executives that cleaned up troubled bank Flag Financial and sold it to RBC Centura, the Financial News reports.
The new site Uncivil Servants, which publishes pictures intended to document abuse of city-issued parking placards, has stirred the ire of some police officers, as we noted here the other day.
The independent film producer Nu Image has acquired a controlling interest in troubled First Look Studios, an independent film distributor with hedge-fund backing, the company announced on Wednesday.

Motorola, the subject of rampant deal rumors on Wall Street this week, on Wednesday sliced about $1 billion off of its revenue projections for the quarter and announced a management shake-up. The beleaguered cellphone giant also said it was expanding a stock-buyback program, addressing a demand of the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who has become a major Motorola shareholder.

Europeans love sunshine. And that's why it's no surprise that Spain has long been the top choice for people seeking a place to retire or to have a second home. But recently the country's image has suffered as the result of press reports of corrupt developers and dodgy construction. We talked with Mark Stucklin, a Barcelona-based monthly columnist for the "Sunday Times" of London who also runs the Spanish Property Insight consultancy www.spanishpropertyinsight.com, to find out if Spain is still a good investment.

Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway won approval from European regulators Thursday to buy U.S. company TTI, which distributes electronic components that other companies use to make a range of products. The European Commission cleared the deal automatically after identifying no antitrust problem and receiving no complaints from rivals within a deadline of 25 working days.

Moving quickly, Bertelsmann, the media group, is considering a bid for Thomson Learning, a textbook publisher, just one day after announcing that it had formed an unusual partnership with two several private equity funds to target media companies, The Financial Times reported.

Critics of colorful "Mad Money" host Jim Cramer have been having a field day lately with comments he made in an video interview with TheStreet.com, during which he talked about his ability as a former hedge-fund manager to game the stock market. His description of certain legal and illlegal -- but all somewhat dubious -- practices reignited the long-running debate on whether he is a market genius or a hack.

Several media giants are teaming up to fight YouTube on its own turf. News Corp. and NBC Universal plan to announce as soon as Thursday that they are creating an online video site stocked with TV shows and movies, plus clips that users can modify and share with friends, according to The Los Angeles Times.

If bidders want all of Coles Myer, the Australian retailer, then they will have to pay in three different installments. The Australian Financial review reported that the board of directors of Australia's second-largest retailer is meeting Friday to formally approve a three-part, A$20 billion ($16.1 billion) auction.

On the back of record earnings, Morgan Stanley had more to celebrate Wednesday: The firm also won an appeal of a $1.57 billion jury verdict against it, stemming from a lawsuit brought by Ronald O. Perelman. The surprising decision by the state District Court of Appeal in Florida removes a legal and reputational pall that hung heavily over the firm during the bitter leadership battle that led to the return of John J. Mack, the investment bank's chief executive.

Citigroup, Macquarie Bank and Citic Securities are poised to reap the benefits of $2 billion initial public offering of China Railway Construction. Bloomberg News reports that China Railway has hired the three banks to prepare it for the I.P.O., which could take place as soon as the end of this year.

Two co-defendants of Conrad M. Black, accused of helping him steal $60 million from Hollinger International, did nothing illegal or were in the dark about any wrongdoing at the company, their lawyers said Wednesday.
Elton John decided on Wednesday to release his catalog to iTunes, just in time for "the latest sign of the seismic shift in the way consumers acquire music."

David A. Stockman, a former congressman who served as President Ronald Reagan's first budget director, is expected to be indicted on charges of accounting fraud related to his role as chairman of auto parts supplier Collins & Aikman, The New York Times reported.

ING Group reiterated that it would participate in consolidation within the banking industry, as merger talks progressed between British bank Barclays and ABN Amro. On Thursday, a Dutch newspaper reported that ING had hired Goldman Sachs and J.P. Morgan to help it find options to expand in Europe.
Citigroup seems to be having a tough time trying to convince Nikko Cordial's largest shareholder, Harris Associates, to turn over its shares in the Japanese brokerage.

Amp'd Mobile apparently knows how to push the right buttons with venture investors. The two-year-old startup, which offers prepaid cellphone service along with downloadable videos, songs and games, has raised $107 million in a Series E round of funding from a list of big-name firms, according to several reports.

Fremont General, which is seeking a buyer for its subprime mortgage unit, said Wednesday that it would sell $4 billion of subprime mortgages, reducing its exposure to the risky loans. The sale will result in a $140 million pretax loss, less than investors expected, and its disclosure helped push up shares of the company by 16 percent, to $10.19.

Blackstone Group chairman Stephen Schwarzman may want to pay himself as little as possible if his private equity firm decides to go public, according to Breakingviews. That is because each dollar he foregoes is likely to boost his firm's earnings and make his stake balloon in value.

A former Bear Stearns municipal bond banker on Wednesday won dismissal of federal criminal charges that he was involved in a kickback scheme tied to the construction of a hospital in the Chicago area. The banker, P. Nicholas Hurtgen, was indicted in 2005 on charges of wire fraud, mail fraud and extortion. He was accused of helping a member of the Illinois Health Facilities Planning Board force the hiring of a politically connected construction company to work on medical buildings.

Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications who is on trial for insider trading, knowingly repeated unreliable growth forecasts in 2000 and 2001, a former company official testified Wednesday.

St. Jude Medical is stepping in to prop up a start-up company that it hopes can help revive the stagnating $6 billion market for implantable heart defibrillators. The start-up, Cambridge Heart, based in Bedford, Mass., said Wednesday that St. Jude Medical would take over efforts to sell its product: stress test equipment that doctors use to assess patients as candidates for defibrillators.
Cities from Los Angeles to Chicago are offering incentives for builders who use environmentally friendly green roofs.
As families begin to return to the Baghdad neighborhoods they fled, the threat of sectarian violence remains very real.

NYMEX Holdings, the parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange, sold shares valued at $956 million in a secondary offering of shares held by NYMEX stockholders. The offering is expected to close on March 27.
Cuyahoga County, including Cleveland and 58 suburbs, has one of the country’s highest foreclosure rates and officials say the worst is yet to come.
Take a tour of this stunning ski resort in the Laurentian Mountains of Quebec.
Alexandra Lipsitz’s breezy competition documentary “Air Guitar Nation” contains droll humor and wild performances that are hard to resist.
The public radio show “This American Life” comes to television with a belief that everyone has a story to tell.
In the idealistic “Pride,” a swim coach leads an inner-city recreational center’s swim team to victory.
Set amid the chaos of late-70s Vietnam, “Journey From the Fall” recounts one family’s endurance in a sturdy, old-movie style.
Q. Allan Brocka’s absorbing drama follows an emotionally repressed gay hustler as he rebels against the obsessions of his culture.
In “TMNT,” these superheroes in a half shell have firmly been co-opted by the industry their creators once sought to spoof.
This sluggish psychological thriller advances more slowly than a cure for Alzheimer’s.
Invoking Lewis Carroll, “E.T.” and Tibetan Buddhism, “The Last Mimzy” is an overstuffed yet warmhearted sci-fi drama.
Images from "The Event" at the Jeu de Paume in Paris.
Elizabeth Edwards's cancer has returned, but her husband will continue his presidential campaign.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
The scene as the former Vice President faced former colleagues, including James Inhofe of Oklahoma, one of Al Gore's most persistent critics.

The Conlin-Beavan family is four months into a yearlong lifestyle experiment in environmentalism that they call No Impact. Its rules are evolving but to date include eating only food (organically) grown within a 250-mile radius of Manhattan; (mostly) no shopping for anything except said food; producing no trash (except compost); using no paper; and, most intriguingly, using no carbon-fueled transportation.
The war spending bill would set a timetable to bring American troops home from Iraq.
A judge turned down a German Muslim woman’s request for a fast-track divorce on the ground that her husband beat her.
They are the first arrests since four suicide bombers killed themselves and 52 travelers on the London transit system.
The paper and its editor were accused by two Muslim groups of “publicly abusing a group of people because of their religion.”
The 1998 law made it a crime for commercial Web sites to allow children to gain access to “harmful” material.
John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat, said today that his wife’s cancer had returned, but that his bid for the presidency “goes on strongly.”
The Senate Judiciary Committee today authorized the issuing of subpoenas that would call Karl Rove and other aides to testify under oath about the dismissals of prosecutors.
Pyongyang has demanded the return of up to $25 million frozen in a Macau bank before it continues negotiations.
Seconds before the mortar struck, the U.N. secretary general had been discussing security improvements in Iraq during a news conference.
On the night Brendan Shanahan returned to play, the stretcher made a chilling return Wednesday night as Philadelphia’s Todd Fedoruk was knocked cold by the Rangers’ Colton Orr.
figure skating.

ALBANY, March 21 — Pressure grew on Senate Republicans on Wednesday to strike a budget deal with Gov. Eliot Spitzer as the State Conservative Party stepped up criticism and the governor tried to divide hospital groups that have opposed his spending plan.

A soldier pleaded guilty to being an accessory to the rape and murder of a 14-year-old Iraqi girl and the killing of her family. The soldier, Pfc. Bryan Howard, 19, also pleaded guilty to conspiracy to obstruct justice. Under a plea deal, Private Howard will not serve more than 27 months if he obeys certain conditions. Private Howard’s rank will be reduced, and he will be dishonorably discharged. He will also have to testify against others charged in the attacks last year in Mahmoudiya, 20 miles south of Baghdad.

A former sailor was indicted on charges of material support of terrorism and disclosing previously classified information relating to the national defense. The sailor, Hassan Abujihaad, formerly known as Paul R. Hall, was arrested in Phoenix on March 7 and is being prosecuted in Connecticut. He is accused of providing information about his battle group’s movements while stationed in the Middle East to a suspected terrorist organization, Azzam Publications, which had his Navy e-mail address in its files. He faces up to 25 years in prison.

A federal judge approved a preliminary settlement between the City of Chicago and lawyers who alleged that the city had violated a federal decree prohibiting the awarding of jobs and promotions to politically connected applicants. The ban, in effect since 1983, applies to about 37,000 city jobs. Among other provisions, the settlement calls for a $12 million fund to pay claims of $100,000 or less to individuals who say they were discriminated against Accusations of corruption in hiring have dogged the administration of Mayor Richard M. Daley. In 2005, a federal monitor was appointed to keep watch on the city’s hiring practices.

Coast Guard cutters off Panama intercepted a ship on Sunday carrying 42,845 pounds of cocaine, a record for a maritime drug bust, officials said. The ship, carrying about $300 million worth of cocaine bound for Mexico, was spotted by a Coast Guard patrol aircraft, which had received a tip about it. Fourteen Panamanian and Mexican crew members were arrested and were being transferred to the United States and Panama for prosecution.

A federal appeals court reversed the conviction and sentence of a former Republican National Committee official accused in a phone-jamming plot on Election Day 2002. The man, James Tobin, was convicted in 2005 of helping to arrange more than 800 hang-up calls that jammed get-out-the-vote phone lines set up by the state Democratic Party and the Manchester firefighters’ union. Mr. Tobin was sentenced to 10 months in jail for telephone harassment. But the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, ruled that the statute under which Mr. Tobin was convicted “is not a close fit” for what he did and questioned whether the government showed that he intended to harass.

The owner of the Sago Mine, where 12 men died after an explosion in January 2006, said it has idled the coal operation because of high production costs and weak prices. Ira Gamm, a spokesman for the company, International Coal Group Inc., described the shutdown as “a business decision, part of our ongoing evaluation of our operations.”.
Daniel Brière and Derek Roy scored power-play goals, rallying the Sabres’ sputtering special teams in a 5-2 victory over the Washington Capitals Wednesday night in Buffalo.

The killing of a 20-year-old Queens woman, and the arrest of a man who was under court order to stay away from her, has raised troubling questions for law enforcement and the young woman’s family about apparent miscues that preceded the attack.

Japan’s trade surplus unexpectedly widened in February after a decline in oil prices caused import growth to slow. Export growth slowed. The surplus rose 7.7 percent, to 979.6 billion yen ($8.3 billion), compared with February a year earlier, the government reported. The entire Lunar New Year holiday fell in February, cutting short the time companies could ship goods to markets that observe the holiday, and the economist Noriaki Haseyama said it was too early to determine if exports are stalling.

The new chief executive of Total, the French oil company, was questioned for a second time in six months over suspected kickbacks in Middle East energy deals. The executive, Christophe de Margerie, left, and two other executives were summoned for questioning in an investigation of an offshore gas deal with Iran, Total said, which denied any wrongdoing. Mr. de Margerie, who ran Total’s Middle East operations at the time of the 1997 Iranian deal, is already under investigation in a separate inquiry of irregularities in United Nations sanctions in Iraq. Mr. de Margerie became chief executive last month.

South Korea’s economy expanded 0.9 percent in the fourth quarter, more than first estimated, as exports declined less than initially anticipated, the Bank of Korea said. The figure was revised from an initial estimate of 0.8 percent and was down from a revised 1.2 percent rate in the third quarter. Goods exports fell 0.5 percent, less than the initial estimate of a 1 percent decline, the report showed. It was the first quarterly drop in exports since the three months ended Sept. 30, 2004. Business investment rose 0.1 percent in the fourth quarter from the previous three months and construction climbed 0.6 percent in the quarter. Private spending advanced 1 percent in the quarter, compared with an earlier estimate of a 0.8 percent increase, the report showed.

The Australian airline Virgin Blue Holdings said it would buy six Boeing planes for 2.2 billion Australian dollars ($1.8 billion) as it accelerates plans for long-haul flights to the United States. Virgin Blue said it would buy six Boeing 777-300ER widebody aircraft, with an option for six more, and had signed an agreement with the International Lease Finance Corporation for a seventh, taking the total price to 2.6 billion Australian dollars. The purchase is part of Virgin Blue’s plans to start flights to the United States beginning in 2008 as it seeks new ways to beat competition on its routes within Australia and to islands in the South Pacific.

BASF and the Monsanto Company said they would collaborate to develop higher-yielding crops that are more tolerant to adverse conditions like drought. The companies will dedicate a joint budget of up to $1.5 billion over the life of the partnership to study crop yields and tolerance to stress for corn, soybeans, cotton and canola. The joint pipeline of products will include the companies’ existing and planned yield stress and tolerance programs, with the first products expected to reach the market in the first half of the next decade. The link will allow the companies to bring more new products to the market than either could have done on its own, they said. Monsanto is based in St. Louis, and BASF is based in Ludwigshafen, Germany.

A Japanese court on Thursday sentenced the former chief financial officer of the dot-com company Livedoor, Ryoji Miyauchi, to 20 months in prison for inflating earnings reports. Two other Livedoor officials, Fumito Okamoto and Osanari Nakamura, were each given one-and-half-year terms with a three-year suspended sentence. A third, Fumito Kumagai, received a one-year prison term with a three-year suspended sentence. The sentences came a week after the same court sentenced the company’s founder and former chief executive, Takafumi Horie, to two and a half years in prison. The executives were accused of using complex schemes to fabricate 5 billion yen, or $42.5 million, in earnings.
A calendar of events in the Dining section yesterday misstated the day for a tasting of Burgundy wines by the New York Wine Guild. It will be on Wednesday, not Tuesday.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an increase in aid to the Palestinian Authority in 2006 despite an international embargo imposed after the Islamic militant group Hamas came to power misstated the political affiliation of Salam Fayyad, the finance minister in the new Palestinian unity government. He belongs to the Third Way, a party he started in 2006; he is no longer a member of Fatah, the political organization that is a Hamas rival. Also, a caption with the article misstated the type of aid that Mr. Fayyad said had more than doubled in 2006 compared with 2005. It was money to support the Palestinian Authority’s budget — not the total amount of aid, including humanitarian, for Palestinians.

An article by Reuters on Tuesday about the sentencing of Raymond L. Girouard, an American soldier convicted of killing three Iraqi detainees, misstated his rank. He is a staff sergeant, not a sergeant. (After his court martial documents are processed in a few months, he will be reduced in rank to private.).

An article yesterday about a rise in the prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease misstated the amount the federal government spends yearly for the average Medicare beneficiary who does not have the disease. It is $4,454, not $2,454.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the bribery trial of Gerald P. Garson, a former state judge in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to the location of the courtroom where he once presided. Mr. Garson, a matrimonial judge, heard cases in the municipal building on Joralemon Street — not in the courthouse on Jay Street, the venue for his trial.

An article yesterday about Carol C. Lam, one of eight federal prosecutors dismissed last year, misstated the name of a health care company she prosecuted. It is Tenet Healthcare Corporation, not Tenant Health Care Corporation.
Chris Bosh had 34 points and 16 rebounds in outplaying his fellow All-Star big man, Dwight Howard, in the host Toronto Raptors’ 92-85 victory against the Orlando Magic last night.
Pakistan rallied around Inzamam-ul-Haq on Wednesday to ensure his last match was a tribute for the late coach Bob Woolmer and not another debacle.
Elaine Orbach’s campaign to have a Midtown intersection named for her late husband received a positive response from members of a community board.

ALBANY, March 21 — Like hardy perennials, or creatures of the undead, proposals to broaden New York’s bottle-recycling laws rise up each spring in the Capitol. And just as regularly, those proposals are defeated.
Former Vice President Al Gore insisted that global warming requires an aggressive federal response.
The new rules would bar government advisers who receive money from a drug or device maker from voting on that company’s products.
The House panel did not issue the subpoenas, saying it wanted to avoid a showdown over separation of powers.

When an 8-year-old girl came forward this week with allegations that she had been raped and sodomized by a custodian at her Brooklyn elementary school, it seemed like a straightforward case. The custodian was arrested on Monday and charged with rape.

Tens of thousands of public sector workers went on strike over unpaid wages for some municipal workers, causing the cancellation of flights in and out of the country and closing down many government offices.
Three Muslim militants were found guilty of decapitating three Christian schoolgirls in Poso, in Sulawesi Province.
Inter-factional violence flared again in the Gaza Strip, days after the formation of a national unity government.
The mayor of Salt Lake City has become a national spokesman for the impeachment of President Bush.
The police restored calm to southeastern villages after two weeks of sporadic street fighting between Kazakhs and ethnic Chechens.
At least 26 people were killed and 45 others injured when Maoists and militants from the Madhesi ethnic groups clashed in the southern town of Gaur.
France replaced a regional school board president, Alain Morvan, for vigorously opposing a new Muslim high school.
President Levy Mwanawasa of Zambia urged southern Africa to take a new approach to Zimbabwe, which he compared to a “sinking Titanic.”

Ripudaman Singh Malik, an Indian-born Canadian Sikh acquitted in 2005 of involvement in the bombing 20 years earlier of an Air India plane traveling from Toronto to New Delhi that killed 329 people, has filed a lawsuit.
Bishops rejected a demand to create a parallel leadership to serve the minority who oppose their church’s liberal stand on homosexuality.
Democrats on Capitol Hill say there are almost no e-mail messages dated between Nov. 15 and Dec. 7 in the documents the White House has released.

A Brooklyn man was sentenced to 240 years in prison yesterday for taking hostages and shooting three people in an East Village bar in 2002. The man, Steven Johnson, 39, was convicted of attempted murder, assault and other charges. The police said Mr. Johnson, carrying three pistols, a samurai sword and a container of kerosene, invaded Bar Veloce on June 16, 2002, while 15 patrons were inside. He wounded three people and sprayed kerosene on others, threatening to set them ablaze. The police said he told them he wanted to avenge the mistreatment of black people.

A 46-year-old woman was charged yesterday with fatally stabbing her 9-year-old son, officials in Monmouth County said. The police found the woman, Kathlene M. DeMichele, in her apartment about 10:30 p.m. on Tuesday, bleeding profusely from self-inflicted wounds, said the Monmouth County prosecutor, Luis A. Valentin. Ms. DeMichele’s son, Charles, was found with several stab wounds in a van parked outside the building, Mr. Valentin said. Ms. DeMichele was hospitalized in critical condition.
To the Editor:.

A pharmacist who until recently owned the Terrace Pharmacy in Oceanside was charged yesterday with illegal drug sales, prosecutors said. The pharmacist, Howard Topchik, 74, was one of 28 people arrested in connection with an investigation into illegal sales, said Kathleen Rice, the Nassau County district attorney. She said his pharmacy sold twice as much Vicodin in 2005 as the average pharmacy. She said some of the prescriptions were photocopies, were written in crayon or had names superimposed over the original ones. Mr. Topchik was charged with criminal sale of a controlled substance.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is increasing police patrols on commuter trains and in stations to guard against terrorist attacks, the agency’s executive director, Elliot G. Sander, said yesterday at the Spuyten Duyvil Metro-North station in the Bronx. As part of the effort to bolster security, the federal Transportation Security Administration will assign air marshals, who normally ride on commercial airliners, to take part in some train patrols. Mr. Sander said riders on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad would see more officers from the authority’s police force walking through trains, checking bags and patrolling platforms, stations and parking lots.

A 13-year-old boy wearing just his underwear was discovered handcuffed to a tree yesterday. The boy, whom the authorities did not identify, told investigators that he was walking to a bus stop when a man with a knife forced him into the woods near Narrows Road South, in Grasmere, officials said. Two passers-by heard the boy yelling about 9 a.m., the police said, and flagged down a car carrying two agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The two, John Delatorre and Jennifer Sarasky, helped the boy and called the police, said Joseph Pentangelo, the society’s assistant director. The boy was taken to Staten Island University Hospital North. Law enforcement officials said he did not claim to have been sexually abused.

A judge dismissed charges yesterday against a political activist who was arrested for approaching and photographing Gov. M. Jodi Rell during her inaugural parade in January. The photographer, Ken Krayeske, 35, was charged with breach of peace, and the Hartford police said his name was on a list of people they had been told might disrupt the proceedings or threaten the governor. The Legislature is considering establishing an oversight committee to review such lists.Compiled by John Sullivan.
The Senate has a chance to restore discipline to the federal budget, a first step in remedying years of damage from profligate tax cuts in the face of immense spending.
To the Editor:.

Nine contractors who do business with the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation have been charged with paying thousands of dollars in bribes to undercover agents in an effort to skirt wage laws, city officials said yesterday. The Department of Investigation said the contractors, who had a total of more than $7 million in construction contracts, paid bribes of $1,000 to $5,000 during a sting operation that lasted from 2005 to 2006. The department said the contractors paid the money to lift “stop-payment” orders issued by the city for underpaying at least 25 employees. The defendants, eight construction company owners and one foreman, have been charged with bribery, officials said.

The city’s Department of Education misspent as much as $784,943 in funds intended to provide prekindergarten services in Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson, Jr. said yesterday. Mr. Thompson, left, said that an analysis of spending on nonpublic schools in Regions 6 and 7 during the 2004 and 2005 fiscal years found more than $400,000 in questionable bank transactions, including a cash withdrawal to repay an undocumented loan to the owner of a school building. The analysis also found that money intended for school services was used to pay for items like karate uniforms and an air-conditioner delivered to a nonschool location. Lindsey Harr, an Education Department spokeswoman, said that the city would take steps to ensure that any money owed was returned, but that the audit “greatly exaggerates the amount of money that may have been improperly spent.”.
The plan, which would pay pilots $150 for each wolf they kill, is intended to protect their prey, including moose and caribou, state wildlife officials said.
Cambridge Heart said St. Jude Medical would take over efforts to sell its stress test equipment that doctors use to assess patients as candidates for defibrillators.
HBO’s chief executive is preparing for life after the “The Sopranos” with a cachet of new offerings.
The Veterans Affairs’ network of 1,400 health clinics and hospitals is beset by maintenance problems like mold and leaking roofs, an internal review says.
The creator of the video attacking Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton worked for consultants to Senator Barack Obama, a rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.

A month after a special election to fill a vacant City Council seat, the streets of central Brooklyn are once again the scene of intense signature collection and campaigning as another election approaches — for the very same position. And many residents seem bewildered that they are being approached again by candidates eager for their votes.
Lenders and the government are being urged to cushion the blow to troubled borrowers and find ways to enable them to remain in their homes.
Profit fell 2 percent in the fiscal third quarter from a slowing economy, severe winter storms and lower fuel surcharges.
Illegal immigrants have turned increasingly to bona fide documents, stolen or bought by traffickers from actual Americans.
Paul McCartney will become the first artist to sign with Hear Music, a label being created by Starbucks.
The city hopes to create incentives to reduce the time children are in foster care and to make private agencies that provide such care more accountable.
Members of Congress have been more worried about currying favor with the chemical industry, a major campaign donor, than with safeguarding their constituents.
By deciding not to run for re-election as governor of Louisiana, Kathleen Blanco has done the best thing for a state desperately in need of new ideas.

The House should vote yes, by an overwhelming, bipartisan margin, to impose benchmarks for political progress on the Iraqi government — and link them to the continued presence of American combat forces.
With the mobile Web, publishers and content providers are trying to avoid coming in late on another advertising bonanza.
Faculty members at California State University, the nation’s largest four-year university system, overwhelmingly authorized a strike.
A gunrunning ring based in New York City used cellphones to send pictures of guns about to be purchased in Virginia to potential buyers in New York, prosecutors said.
Lottery Numbers.
President Bush is sending a message to Democrats that he will protect those closest to him, defend his presidential powers and run his White House the way he sees fit.
The deal appears to be the first time prisoners have been openly exchanged for a hostage in Afghanistan and Iraq.
Talks meant to carry out a deal that calls on the North to shut its main nuclear reactor have stalled over a delay in transferring frozen funds.
Maricopa County in Arizona, which includes Phoenix, swelled by 100,000 people in the year ending last, according to census figures.
Pet owners and veterinarians say they have been angered by a lack of information about how to proceed after Menu Foods products were linked to the death of several pets.
Six students have filed a lawsuit against the school and the Napa Valley Unified School District saying the dress code is “unconstitutionally vague, overbroad and restrictive.”
Nu Image acquired a controlling interest in the troubled First Look Studios, an independent film distributor.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s strategist has highlighted Senator Barack Obama’s votes to finance a war he says he opposes.
The findings show that humans’ native revulsion to hurting others relies on a part of neural anatomy.
The former chief of Qwest Communications knowingly repeated unreliable growth forecasts in 2000 and 2001, a former company official testified.
Facing sluggish profits, Motorola dropped its quarterly revenue forecast by a billion dollars and announced a management shake-up.
A millionaire's dreams of a casino next to the Monticello Raceway in the Catskills is almost within reach, but legal troubles are keeping the man abroad.
Marist, which is only the third 13th seed in the history of the women’s tournament to make it into the final 16, has been to the tournament three times in the past four years.
The Supreme Court looked the boundaries of an 11-year-old federal law which limits when a federal court can grant habeas corpus to a state prisoner.
Menu Foods is little known because it lacks its own brands. But it has come to dominate the business of making wet pet food for retailers.
Democrats on the left and the right have broken with their leaders over a plan for a deadline for troops to leave.
Four young men pleaded guilty yesterday in the beating of a Manhattan singer who was subjected to antigay slurs as he was attacked.
In a profession full of quirky workaholics, Texas A&M Coach Billy Gillispie is known as one of the most eccentric.
Of the right-handed relievers the Mets are counting on this season, one has tendinitis, one’s sleeping habits hindered his being ready for opening day and another is suspended until late May.
A Moscow court ruled against the editor not for the contents of the article, but for commenting publicly on the controversy surrounding its publication.
A day after losing to the Dallas Mavericks, the Knicks’ walking wounded, which included Jamal Crawford and Channing Frye, were out in force Wednesday at the team’s practice facility.
David A. Stockman, a former Reagan budget director, is expected to be indicted on charges of accounting fraud related to his role as chairman of the auto parts supplier.
New York State is joining what is shaping up as the presidential mega-primary next Feb. 5.
Two co-defendants of Conrad M. Black did nothing illegal or were in the dark about any wrongdoing at the company, their lawyers said.
Calvert G. DeForest gained cult status on David Letterman’s late-night shows as the comic figure Larry (Bud) Melman.
The Guardian Angels has broadened its presence around the country, with more than 50 chapters established in places like Peoria, Ill.
With Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco’s political exit this week, the dysfunctional relationship between Louisiana and Washington, could shift sharply.
A federal report suggests that the gulf between military and civilian efforts in wartime be bridged by structural changes in the United States government.
About 160,000 Iraqis have moved to the mountainous Kurdish north, according to the first comprehensive figure that has been released by any organization.
The number of retirees in China will double between 2005 and 2015, threatening the underpinnings of the economy.
K. C. Rivers had a career-high 29 points as Clemson advanced to the National Invitation Tournament semifinals with a 74-70 victory against Syracuse.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York asked for at least $150 million in annual aid to monitor and treat people who became ill after being exposed to dust and debris at ground zero.
Against a backdrop of speculation about the clause that allows Alex Rodriguez to opt out of his contract after this season, Brian Cashman said Wednesday that he had no plans to work out an extension.
Three people managed to steal nearly $12,000 worth of bras and panties at a Victoria’s Secret in Jersey City as customers milled about.
Morgan Stanley’s earnings soared and the firm won a $1.57 billion court appeal. For its chief executive, it doesn’t get better than this.
Richard Jefferson realizes that he will not feel healthy until the season is over, but his return from arthroscopic knee surgery has boosted the Nets’ playoff chances.
Bruce Wasserstein, the chairman of Lazard, is considering selling his stake in ALM, publisher of American Lawyer Magazine and other legal publications.
The case, involving a man who is accused of killing a judge and three other people, has caused Georgia to ponder the cost of defending suspects in death-penalty cases.
Don't expect to see the high-scoring Bruins of the John Wooden era take the court tonight against Pittsburgh.  This team has a different approach.
Lawyers said the government had moved immigrants arrested in a raid to detention centers in Texas too quickly and denied them adequate access to lawyers.
A former Bear Stearns banker won dismissal of charges that he was involved in a kickback scheme tied to the construction of a hospital in the Chicago area.
Securities regulators approved new rules making it easier and faster for foreign companies to withdraw their stocks from the U.S. market.
There has been an absence of pass-first leaders in college basketball the past few years.
The incumbent chief executive blames emissions from mainland China for air pollution while his challenger contends that Hong Kong is not doing enough to address the issue.
A House panel began an inquiry into the marketing and regulation of widely used anemia drugs that have raised safety concerns.
At least 110 people have been killed since Monday in the tribal area of South Waziristan, government and security officials said.

It is a Sisyphean task that politicians on Long Island have struggled with for decades: how to eliminate some of the hundreds of often overlapping municipalities and special districts that have resulted in a maze of regulations and driven up taxes.
Jacques Chirac’s endorsement of his longtime younger rival, Nicolas Sarkozy, came without passion or enthusiasm.
A Web site allows anyone to post photos of cars that seem to be parked illegally in New York City.
Dr. Chess helped develop the influential theory that children are born with distinct temperaments that can powerfully affect their outlook and relationship with their parents.
The Federal Reserve raised investors’ hopes that it had warmed to the idea of lowering short-term interest rates.
B. Franklin Kahn was one of the first developers to recognize that real estate investments could trade much like mutual funds.
Wolfgang Puck said that he would use eggs and meat only from animals raised under strict humane standards.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,216 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Tiger Woods and Roger Federer compete in sports with distinct athletic movements, and they have forged a friendship based on respect and appreciation.
The Bush administration will also set new conditions for monitoring aid to the security forces of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, officials said.
R2-D2, the endearing android of “Star Wars” fame, is now collecting mail for the Postal Service.

Martti Ahtisaari, the United Nations chief negotiator for the Serbian region for 13 months, studiously avoided the word in the past.

Bishop G. E. Patterson was the presiding bishop of the Church of God in Christ, the nation’s largest African-American Pentecostal denomination.
Fencing Coach George Kolombatovich led the Columbia men’s and women’s teams to Ivy titles, the university’s first sweep since 2001.
Worsening air pollution has become one of the most contentious issues in the vote on Sunday for Hong Kong’s next chief executive.
The move, which would reduce the company’s exposure to such risky loans, helped push up shares of Fremont General up by 16 percent, to $10.19.

Saul Swimmer directed the documentary “The Concert for Bangladesh,” showing the 1971 show organized by George Harrison and Ravi Shankar to raise money for refugees.
Ann DeChiara Malamud’s marriage to Bernard Malamud helped him determine his course as a writer.
A celebrity divorce shows that as South Korea’s wealth grows, choosing the right wedding gifts for the new in-laws is becoming fraught with pitfalls.
In a rare burst of defiance and activism, students have made accusations that teaching standards and living conditions have been severely eroded at one of Russia’s most prestigious universities.
In a scene reminiscent of 1993, furious crowds mutilated the bodies of government soldiers, chanting, “We will burn you alive!”

An Op-Ed article on March 3, about Morocco’s proposal for an autonomous Western Sahara, should have more fully disclosed the background of the author, Frederick Vreeland. Mr. Vreeland, a former American ambassador to Morocco, is also the chairman of a solar-energy company that has had contracts with the Moroccan government.
To the Editor:.
Ann Curry is on a very short list of American broadcast journalists who have reported even once from Sudan, where the conflict is estimated to have claimed more than 200,000 lives.
Britney Spears leaves rehab, “World News” adds news, new arrivals stud the Billboard chart, “Idol” numbers slide and more culture news.

Major League Baseball spurned a revised offer Wednesday by leading cable operators to retain the Extra Innings package of out-of-market games, which may now become the exclusive satellite domain of DirecTV.
Frank Gehry is adding a much-needed touch of lightness to the Manhattan skyline just as the city finally emerges from a period of mourning.
David Rockefeller plans to sell a seminal painting by Mark Rothko for what Sotheby’s hopes will be more than $40 million.
From the outside, the Tugendhat House doesn’t look like one of the most important residential buildings of the 20th century, but the house is the subject of a bitter custody battle.

9 P.M. (22) BARENBOIM ON BEETHOVEN The Argentine-born pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim, left, began learning the Beethoven sonatas as a young boy; by 17 he could play the entire cycle. “No matter that my fingers have been playing the same notes since I was 8 years old,” he said. “The fingers know it, the brain knows it, and yet I find something new in it.” In this “Great Performances” special, taped on June 25, 2005, at the Berlin Staatsoper, Mr. Barenboim performed five of Beethoven’s 32 piano sonatas — Nos. 5, 11, 19, 20 and 23, the “Appassionata” — as part of an eight-concert series. The special also presents excerpts from Mr. Barenboim’s master classes with the pianists Lang Lang, Jonathan Biss and Shai Wosner.
You’ve lost your president, gallery director, executive vice president and education director. What better time to celebrate your 100th anniversary?

A picture caption last Thursday with an article about environmentally-conscious rock musicians misidentified a member of the rock group Guster. He is Ryan Miller — not Adam Gardner, who helped established Reverb, an organization that consults with performers on greener rock tours.
