If the Democrats really want to play a role in the current Iraq debate, they should take a look at what John McCain and Rudy Giuliani are up to.
Some of the eight prosecutors were fired for proper political reasons and some were fired for improper ones.

BROWN--Janet. Dearly beloved friend. We are so sad to lose you to this tragic automobile accident at the prime of your life. Your memory will be in our hearts always. Charlotte, Roger, Eric, Lisa, Beth, Peter, Marc, Ellen, and family BROWN--Janet. Your special, unique love, personality and soul along with your style and wit will always be remembered. There will never be another you! Our family who adores you, will miss you and be always thinking of you. So much admiration and love. Bunny and Charles BROWN--Janet. We will miss your outrageous honesty, your lack of political correctness, your ability to have a good time and make sure everyone else had a better time. Your relentless pursuit of fun with your innumerable friends. Everyone loved you for your enduring indomitable spirit. Our family has suffered a loss that will never be replaced. We'll miss you at all of our family celebrations, our vacations, and our parties. Life will never be the same without you and your endless dance moves. Brooke, Dan, Jon, Stephen and Mallory. BROWN--Janet, (born in Philadelphia, PA, May 23, 1947), died suddenly in a car accident on Friday, March 16th as she drove to work. Janet enjoyed an iconic career as founder of Janet Brown Ltd., the chic Long Island boutique. She was loved by her friends, respected by her colleagues; her quick irreverent sense of humor and extraordinary heart will be missed by all. She is survived by her sister Elaine Edelstein, of Villanova, PA, her brother-in-law Marc, and her niece and nephew Brandon and Melissa, in addition to her countless friends. Funeral services will be held Tuesday March 20, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison and 81st street. Donations may be made in the name of Janet Brown to the New York University Child Study Center, 577 1st Ave, NY, NY 10016.

To the Editor: ''Proposals for Mental Health Parity Pit a Father's Pragmatism Against a Son's Passion'' (news article, March 19) offers a timely and astute analysis of the legislative and family dynamics surrounding current efforts to expand access to comprehensive, nondiscriminatory coverage for the treatment of mental illness and substance use disorders.

The This Land column on Sunday, about plaques honoring World War II veterans at the Taylor County courthouse in Butler, Ga., that are segregated by race, misstated the name of the organization headed by John Cole Vodicka, who is pushing to have the plaques removed. It is the Prison and Jail Project, not the Jail and Prison Project.

Over the last week, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign has opened a new offensive against Senator Barack Obama: Former President Bill Clinton has asserted that Mr. Obama was initially ambivalent about the Iraq war, and Mrs. Clinton's strategist has highlighted his votes to finance a war he says he opposes. But a review of Mr. Obama's statements on Iraq since 2002 shows that he has opposed the war against Saddam Hussein consistently, calling it ''dumb'' and ''rash.'' Yet when it came later to hypothetical questioning about how he would have voted on the 2002 Iraq war resolution, Mr. Obama has been more circumspect.

The New York Red Bulls were in Manhattan yesterday for their annual media day, and Coach Bruce Arena said he liked the changes he has seen after three weeks of training in Florida and two in California. ''I inherited a team that was pretty quiet in the locker room, there was not a lot of leadership,'' Arena said. ''That is not the case now. When I look, I see a better team. We want to be better. I've never said our goal is winning a championship, you can't change things overnight.''
PILMAR--Howard, it is 11 years since your brutal murder, I miss you so much and pray for justice. Love, Dad

Anthropologie, the clothing and home furnishings company, is offering furniture in colorful textiles created in the 1940s by the Swedish designer Josef Frank. The Jayne sofa ($3,498), left, in a pattern called Hawaii, ''is English with a twist,'' said Jaimee Seabury, the furniture buyer at Anthropologie, who fell in love with Frank's work on a trip to Stockholm. The company is also selling a wingback chair in Frank's Grona Faglar pattern, which has oversize birds and trees ($2,498). The fabrics can be purchased separately as well ($100 a yard); (800) 309-2500 or anthropologie.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

Ripudaman Singh Malik, an Indian-born Canadian Sikh acquitted in 2005 of involvement in the bombing 20 years earlier of an Air India plane traveling from Toronto to New Delhi that killed 329 people, has filed a lawsuit against the governments of Canada and British Columbia, where he was tried, claiming unspecified damages for wrongful imprisonment and malicious prosecution. Mr. Malik, once a millionaire businessman, claims the charges caused him to lose his savings and his reputation. CHRISTOPHER MASON

Inter-factional violence flared again in the Gaza Strip, days after the formation of a national unity government. A militant belonging to Fatah, identified as Rami Sroor, was killed in a clash with Hamas militants in northern Gaza. ISABEL KERSHNER

SHIRRELL--Robert Donald, of Millbrook died of lung cancer on March 19, at age 86 with his family by his side. A WWII veteran, he graduated from the University of Michigan in 1948. Mr. Shirrell was with General Electric for 35 years. He is survived by daughters Ann (Walter) Rand of Pawling and Sarah (Earl) Carlin of Millbrook, and six grandchildren. His wife, Barbara, died in 2001.
A calendar of events in the Dining section yesterday misstated the day for a tasting of Burgundy wines by the New York Wine Guild. It will be on Wednesday, not Tuesday.

BRONFMAN--Naum. The American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra Board of Directors and staff extend our deepest condolences to Board Member, Yefim Bronfman, on the death of his father. We are indebted to Naum and his wife Polina for nurturing the talent of their musician children Yefim Bronfman and Elizabeth Krupnik. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire Bronfman family from their IPO family. Zubin Mehta and Itzhak Perlman, Co-Chairmen Elaine R. Wolfensohn, President David A. Hirsch, Charles I. Petschek, Lauren Veronis Vice-Presidents Suzanne K. Ponsot, Executive Director BRONFMAN--Naum. To Polina, Lisa, and Yefim, we extend our deepest sympathies on the passing of their beloved husband, father and grandfather. On behalf of Vera Stern and the whole family of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation.

John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat making a second bid for the presidency, called a news conference for Thursday to discuss the future of his campaign, a day after he and his wife, Elizabeth, visited Mrs. Edwards' doctor to assess her recovery from a bout of breast cancer. Mrs. Edwards, in a brief interview from her home in Chapel Hill, N.C., said she and Mr. Edwards would discuss her health at the news conference, but she declined to elaborate.

Artwork may be serious, but who says frames have to be? Two new inexpensive options for framing children's art or decorating summer rentals are cardboard and inflatable vinyl. Cardboard frames come in plain, gold, silver, white or black and in various sizes, from 16 by 20 inches to 20 by 24 inches. Prices range from $29.98 for three plain corrugated frames to $59.98 for two ''gilded,'' ''carved'' ones; (866) 286-1871 or cardboardframe.com. Inflatable frames -- also gold and ''carved'' -- are 11 by 16 inches, above, and cost $11 at the American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

CLUB makers are offering golfers a new advantage: drivers with heads designed to resist twisting, making them more forgiving. Increased moment of inertia -- or M.O.I., as this measure of forgiveness is known -- means off-center hits fly straighter down the fairway. Last May, the United States Golf Association set a cap to prevent ever-escalating M.O.I. The clubs shown here flirt with this limit. Some have square or composite heads; others embed inserts in the club face.

An article yesterday about Carol C. Lam, one of eight federal prosecutors dismissed last year, misstated the name of a health care company she prosecuted. It is Tenet Healthcare Corporation, not Tenant Health Care Corporation.

The police restored calm to southeastern villages after two weeks of sporadic street fighting between Kazakhs and ethnic Chechens. A brawl at a bar in Kazatkom, a village near the capital, Almaty, with a large Chechen population, set off the violence, which spread to other villages and included fistfights, shootouts, arson and mass demonstrations. Dozens of people were injured. Local news outlets reported that two Kazakhs and a Chechen were killed. ILAN GREENBERG

Of the right-handed relievers the Mets are counting on this season, one has tendinitis, one's sleeping habits hindered his being ready for opening day and another is suspended until late May. In other words, the Mets would not mind if Ambiorix Burgos or Jorge Sosa, the hard throwers acquired over the winter, emerged as immediate options. Their early success has given way to recent struggles, leaving Manager Willie Randolph with some difficult decisions over the next 10 days. Their performances during Wednesday night's 6-2 victory against the Los Angeles Dodgers were hardly conclusive. Taking over for a stellar Oliver Pérez, Burgos allowed a run and three hits in one inning. Sosa pitched a scoreless ninth.

DANE--Goody. The Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale mourns the passing of Goody Dane, founder, and wife of first president Oscar Dane (z''l). A passionate advocate for children's Jewish education, her home and heart was open to the entire community. Rabbi Barry Dov Katz Susan J. Schwartz, President DANE--Goody. Beloved wife of the late Oscar, cherished mother of the late Marsha Stern (late Stanley), Gail Propp (Ephraim), Sharon Dane, and Wilma Kule (Stephen). Adored and adoring grandmother, and greatgrandmother; we looked forward to celebrating your 94th birthday this March 24. We will miss your zest for living, wise counsel, and elegance.

Tens of thousands of public sector workers went on strike over unpaid wages for some municipal workers, causing the cancellation of flights in and out of the country and closing down many government offices. But it was short-lived, as state representatives and the head of the labor federation Histadrut came to an agreement, ending the strike by late afternoon. ISABEL KERSHNER

SLADE--Terry, 97, of New York City, on March 20, 2007. Designer of custom made furniture. Loving father of his son Michael (Cookie), daughter Doren (Lisa). Adored grandfather of Daphne (Dave), David (Jenny), Danielle (Rikesh). Proud greatgrandfather of Kira, Acadia, and Felix. Services are Friday, 10:00am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

Testifying at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pleaded for at least $150 million in annual federal aid to monitor and treat thousands of people who became ill after being exposed to dust and debris at ground zero. The mayor also called for the creation of a special fund to compensate those who became sick, urging that the city and its contractors be protected from potentially ruinous liability as a result of lawsuits brought by rescue and recovery workers who have argued that they were not adequately protected from the environmental hazards left by the World Trade Center's collapse.

DEVINE--Charles Patrick, NYPD, USMC, (surrendered to AIDS after 17 years) formerly from Woodside and Hollis, NY; From your devoted sisters Pat O'Keefe, Chattanooga, TN; Betty Baiardi, Santa Monica, CA; Eileen Huarte, Pacific Palisades, CA; and Linda Sproule, NYC. It's been ten years and we still hear stories of your kindness and love to so many people who crossed your path. Even during the last few hours of your life you were trying to help family members; God Bless you Charlie, we miss you so much.

The Colony Palms Hotel in Palm Springs, Calif., reopens next month after a $15 million makeover by Martyn Lawrence-Bullard, a British-born, California-based interior designer. The 56-room hotel, which was once a brothel and speakeasy, and later a hotel run by Robert Howard, a son of the owner of the racehorse Seabiscuit, has been redone in a 1940s Mediterranean style with Moorish elements. The new rooms have seven-foot headboards covered in tribal rugs woven in Uzbekistan, vintage photography and Eames-inspired stools (Mr. Lawrence-Bullard's sole concession to Palm Springs's legendary midcentury modernism). Colony Palms Hotel, 572 North Indian Canyon Drive, Palm Springs, Calif., (800) 557-2187, colonypalmshotel.com. KATHRYN HARRIS
To the Editor: Re ''Court Hears Whether a Drug Statement Is Protected Free Speech for Students'' (news article, March 20):

At least 26 people were killed and 45 others injured when Maoists and militants from the Madhesi ethnic groups clashed in the southern town of Gaur. The United Nations, which is investigating the clashes, said the violence erupted as the groups held simultaneous rallies in the area. TILAK POKHAREL

HORTON--Henie of Boca Raton, FL, and Hackensack, NJ, died Wednesday, March 21, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Roy Horton, devoted mother of Sherri and her husband Howie Lippman and Jane and her husband Larry Kielt. Cherished grammy of Jordan and his fiance' Heather Benjamin, Ariel, Blair, Cecelia, and Andrew; and loving aunt of Carrie Mumford, Amy Harris and Nina Otis. Services 12:30 PM, Friday, at Temple Sholom, 385 Howland Avenue, River Edge, NJ

ALTOMONTE--Barbara, on March 20, 2007. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, she lived in Crofton, MD, since 1966. Survived by her loving husband, John (aka Jack), two devoted sons Dennis and Paul, and three grandchildren, and two brothers, Bill Maughan and Gerard Maughan and two sisters, Judy Amend and Maureen Maughan. She was a full time high school English teacher for 18 years. Funeral mass will be held on March 24, 11am at Our Lady of Peace in North Brunswick, NJ.

A 13-year-old boy wearing just his underwear was discovered handcuffed to a tree yesterday. The boy, whom the authorities did not identify, told investigators that he was walking to a bus stop when a man with a knife forced him into the woods near Narrows Road South, in Grasmere, officials said. Two passers-by heard the boy yelling about 9 a.m., the police said, and flagged down a car carrying two agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The two, John Delatorre and Jennifer Sarasky, helped the boy and called the police, said Joseph Pentangelo, the society's assistant director. The boy was taken to Staten Island University Hospital North. Law enforcement officials said he did not claim to have been sexually abused. AL BAKER

MILLER--Martin W. of Riverdale and Fleischmanns, New York, passed on March 17, 2007. Devoted and loving husband to wife Miriam, father to sons Michael and Daniel, father-in-law to Rochelle, and beloved grandfather to Lauren and Allison. Born in Frankfurt, Germany on October 2, 1923. Veteran Master Sergeant U.S. Army CounterIntelligence in World War II. Principal Mundial Export Corporation of New York City and Tarrytown, New York for over 60 years. Memorial donations may be sent to the American Cancer Society. A man of integrity.

MOTOROLA EXPECTS LESS EARNINGS Motorola sharply revised its earnings estimates for the first three months of the year, dropping its revenue projections by a billion dollars for the quarter. The company also announced a management shake-up. [Page C1.] FED IS COY ON NEXT MOVE The Federal Reserve edged away from previous signals that its next move on interest rates would be up, implicitly acknowledging hints of trouble in the economy. It held the overnight federal funds rate steady. [C1.] NEW RULES FOR F.D.A. ADVISERS Expert advisers who receive money from a drug or device maker would be barred for the first time from voting on whether to approve that company's products under new rules announced for the F.D.A.'s powerful advisory committees. [A1.] AVOIDING A DEFAULT For many homeowners with subprime mortgages facing foreclosure, the options are few. [C1.] SUBPRIME LENDER MAKES A SALE Fremont General said that it would sell $4 billion of subprime mortgages, reducing its exposure to the risky loans. The sale will result in a $140 million pretax loss, less than investors expected, and its disclosure helped push up shares of the company, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., by 16 percent. [C10.] LIFE AFTER 'SOPRANOS' Before too long, ''The Sopranos'' will be history, and HBO will have to carry on without its signature show. The channel's chief executive has been preparing for this denouement for many months. [C1.] SAFETY OF ANEMIA DRUGS A Congressional committee looking into the safety and regulation of anemia drugs has requested information from Amgen and Johnson & Johnson, the drugs' marketers. [C2.] PROFIT SLIPS AT FEDEX FedEx said that profit fell 2 percent in its most recent quarter as a result of a slowing economy, severe winter storms and lower fuel surcharges. [C9.] STOCKMAN MAY BE CHARGED David A. Stockman, who served as President Reagan's first budget director, is expected to be indicted on charges of accounting fraud related to his role as chairman of Collins & Aikman, an auto parts supplier. [C3.] SPOTLIGHT ON A PET FOOD GIANT The manufacturer of the pet food that has been linked to the deaths of more than a dozen animals, Menu Foods, is little known because it lacks its own brands. But over the last few years, it has come to dominate the business of making wet pet food for retailers. [C4.] JOURNALISTIC CHILL IN MOSCOW The editor in chief of the Russian edition of Forbes magazine was found guilty of defamation in a dispute over an article about a business run by the wife of the mayor of Moscow. A city court in Moscow ruled against the editor, Maksim V. Kashulinsky, above, not for the contents of the article, but for commenting in a radio interview on the controversy surrounding its publication. Advertising. It is also drawing the attention of computer security experts, who say major sporting events become targets for computer hackers seeking high-profile hits. Mack, the chief executive approaching his two-year anniversary. BRUCE WASSERSTEIN, the chairman of Lazard, is considering selling his stake in ALM, publisher of American Lawyer Magazine and other legal publications. In a statement, Wasserstein & Company said it had hired the Credit Suisse Group to advise it in ''in exploring various strategic alternatives'' for its investment in ALM, including a possible sale of the company. (NYT)

McGOWAN--Vivian P. of Riverdale, NY, on March 17th. Wife of the late William J. McGowan, devoted mother of Marianne, Elizabeth, and William J. Loving grandmother of Emily, Nicholas, Peter and Timothy Prokesch and Andrew, Kara and Paulina McGowan. Daughter of the late Julius F. and Julia F. Pitassy. Sister of the late Reginald F. and Caesar L. Pitassy, and of Helen P. York of Brewster, NY. A graduate of the College of Mt. St. Vincent and Fordham Law School, she was a partner in the firm of McGowan & McGowan. Formerly with the Coorporation Counsel of the City of New York, she was an attorney with the Supreme Court of the State of New York, for more than 30 years, most recently as a principal appellate court attorney in the Appellate Term First Department, and was a past president of the Bronx County Bar Association. Funeral Saturday, March 24th, at 11:00 am, at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 10 W. Stevens Avenue, Hawthorne, NY 10532. Contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

Nine contractors who do business with the city's Department of Parks and Recreation have been charged with paying thousands of dollars in bribes to undercover agents in an effort to skirt wage laws, city officials said yesterday. The Department of Investigation said the contractors, who had a total of more than $7 million in construction contracts, paid bribes of $1,000 to $5,000 during a sting operation that lasted from 2005 to 2006. The department said the contractors paid the money to lift ''stop-payment'' orders issued by the city for underpaying at least 25 employees. The defendants, eight construction company owners and one foreman, have been charged with bribery, officials said. RAY RIVERA

Six new albums entered the Billboard Top 10 this week, though none were big sellers. The R&B singer Musiq Soulchild, who has a hit with the song ''Buddy,'' opened at No. 1 with his album ''Luvanmusiq'' (Atlantic), which sold 149,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Lloyd, another R&B singer, is No. 2 with 144,000 sales of ''Street Love'' (The Inc.), and the rapper Rich Boy reached No. 3 with his new, self-titled album (Interscope), which moved 112,000 copies. A vintage Neil Young recording, ''Live at Massey Hall 1971'' (Reprise), is the surprise this week, reaching No. 6 with 57,000 copies; it is the second-highest-charting album of Mr. Young's career. The new British R&B singer Amy Winehouse, a star at South by Southwest last week, opened at No. 7 with ''Back to Black'' (Universal), and 8Ball & MJG's ''Ridin' High'' (Bad Boy South) reached No. 8 in its first week. Music sales for the year are down 16.6 percent from last year at this point, at 99.2 million units. BEN SISARIO

OFTEN, the women let out a little gasp. I look up, a hair twisty dangling from my mouth, a clump of my 5-year-old daughter's hair clenched in one fist, a comb in the other, ready for attack. She squirms on the bench in the family locker room at the local Y, freshly showered after a swim class and bracing for her hair appointment with me, her father, hellbent on taming those tresses. ''Wow, you are really good,'' one approving mother says one morning as my fingers weave three strands into a tight braid. I nod thanks and press on, fussing with another braid as I demand again and again, ''Lyla, keep still for heaven's sake.''

An article by Reuters on Tuesday about the sentencing of Raymond L. Girouard, an American soldier convicted of killing three Iraqi detainees, misstated his rank. He is a staff sergeant, not a sergeant. (After his court martial documents are processed in a few months, he will be reduced in rank to private.)

Calvert G. DeForest, the dweebish man who gained cult status on David Letterman's late-night shows as the comic figure Larry (Bud) Melman precisely because he was not funny, died Monday in Babylon, Long Island. He was 85. He suffered from a long illness, according to a statement by Mr. Letterman, on whose shows Mr. DeForest appeared dozens of times.

Britney Spears Leaves Rehab Britney Spears is out. What remains to be seen is if she'll be around. Ms. Spears, 25, checked out of the Promises Malibu Alcohol and Drug Rehab Treatment Facility ''after successfully completing their program,'' her manager, Larry Rudolph, said in a statement released by Jive Records late on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Rudolph asked that Ms. Spears's privacy be respected. She entered the center on Feb. 22 after a well-documented spasm of bizarre behavior that included shaving her head, being tattooed and hammering a car with an umbrella. Those actions followed a year when she mishandled her babies; parted from her club-hopping husband, Kevin Federline; and appeared in public without underpants. Under a temporary agreement, Ms. Spears and Mr. Federline have joint custody of their sons, Jayden James, 6 months, and Sean Preston, 18 months. Woody Harrelson's Father Dies in Prison Woody Harrelson's father, Charles Harrelson, 68, has died in the high-security federal prison in Florence, Colo., where he was serving two life sentences for the murder of a federal judge, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Mr. Harrelson, who appeared to have died of natural causes, was found unresponsive in his cell on March 15, according to Felicia Ponce, a Bureau of Prisons spokeswoman in Washington. He was convicted of murder in the slaying of United States District Judge John Wood Jr. outside his home in San Antonio on May 29, 1979. Prosecutors said a drug dealer hired Mr. Harrelson to carry out the killing to prevent the judge from presiding at the dealer's impending trial. Mr. Harrelson denied involvement, saying he was in Dallas, 270 miles away, when the slaying took place. Hawaii Pats 'Dog' Hawaii's House of Representatives has passed a resolution honoring the television bounty hunter Duane Chapman, known as Dog, and his wife, Beth, for their achievements in capturing criminals, The Associated Press reported. (Above, from left, Gene Ward, a Republican state representative; Mr. Chapman; and his wife.) The honor came as Mexico seeks the extradition of Mr. Chapman, 53, and two associates on charges that they illegally arrested Andrew Luster, a fugitive convicted rapist, in Puerto Vallarta in 2003. A resolution before the Hawaii Legislature urges Mexico to drop its efforts. Mr. Chapman is the star of the Hawaii-based A&E reality series ''Dog the Bounty Hunter.'' Opera Star Wins Her Case The soprano Kiri Te Kanawa yesterday won a lawsuit featuring underwear, but her declared sensitivity to airborne panties could cost her $102,000. Ms. Te Kanawa, below, was sued in New South Wales Supreme Court in Australia for as much as $1.5 million after she canceled appearances with the 57-year-old Australian pop star John Farnham (known as the Voice) upon discovering that his performances prompted women to toss their underwear at him. ''How could I, in my classical form, perform in this way?'' Ms. Te Kanawa, 63, asked the court in February. In its decision yesterday, the court dismissed the lawsuit brought against her by the concert promotion company, Leading Edge. Although Judge Patricia Bergin ruled that no binding contract existed when Ms. Te Kanawa withdrew from the concerts, planned for Australia and New Zealand, she ordered her company, Mittane, to pay $102,000 to Leading Edge for costs. The judge said Mittane was not truthful to Leading Edge about her reasons for withdrawing, adding that the underwear was not the chief reason for the soprano's withdrawal. She said Ms. Te Kanawa had become ''extremely resentful'' that Mr. Farnham had not attended a planned meeting with her. Footnotes The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has awarded its 2006-7 Elise L. Stoeger Prize to the composer Pierre Jalbert. The $25,000 honor, given every two years, recognizes significant contributions to the chamber music repertory. Because of a death in his family, the pianist Yefim Bronfman has withdrawn from his performance tonight in the ''Gil Shaham & Friends'' concert at Zankel Hall. He will be replaced by Akira Eguchi. In Newport, R.I., this summer's Dunkin' Donuts Newport Folk Festival will take place on the weekend of Aug. 3 to 5, and the JVC Jazz Festival-Newport will be held on the weekend of Aug. 10 to 12. After life on radio and television and in comic books and novels, the crime-fighting Green Hornet (actually the millionaire newspaper publisher Britt Reid) is headed for the big screen, Variety.com reported. Columbia Pictures has optioned rights to the property. Angelina Jolie and her newly adopted son, Pax Thien Jolie, 3, left, departed Vietnam yesterday for the boy's new home in the United States, The Associated Press reported. The Nobel laureate Nadine Gordimer, Salman Rushdie and Steve Martin, as well as the playwright Sam Shepard, the musician Patti Smith and the actor and filmmaker Sydney Pollack are expected to take part in the third annual PEN World Voices festival in New York from April 24 to 29. The theme of the event is ''Home and Away.''

HELLER--Miles. The Yeshiva University and Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary families note with sadness the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Deborah, father of Ira Heller and Betty (and Larry) Schusterman and brother of RIETS Honorary Trustee, Jacob W. (and Esther), Heller and Esther (and David H.) Kolatch, grandfather and great grandfather. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. To the Editor: Re ''Bush in Conflict With Lawmakers on Prosecutors'' (front page, March 21):

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is increasing police patrols on commuter trains and in stations to guard against terrorist attacks, the agency's executive director, Elliot G. Sander, said yesterday at the Spuyten Duyvil Metro-North station in the Bronx. As part of the effort to bolster security, the federal Transportation Security Administration will assign air marshals, who normally ride on commercial airliners, to take part in some train patrols. Mr. Sander said riders on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad would see more officers from the authority's police force walking through trains, checking bags and patrolling platforms, stations and parking lots. WILLIAM NEUMAN

RADDOCK--Deborah Susan, age 64, died peacefully in her home on March 19, 2007. The cause of death was melanoma. Deborah's memory is cherished by her husband, Richard D. Raddock; her mother, Grace Charleston; her sons Daniel, Michael, and Robert; her five grandchildren; and by her many loving friends and family members. Her kindness, nurturing spirit, intelligence and sense of humor will be missed. Family and friends will gather at her home in McLean, VA, at 11 am on Friday, March 23, to share memories of Deborah. She asked that any memorial contributions be donated to the charity of your choice.

An Op-Ed article on March 3, about Morocco's proposal for an autonomous Western Sahara, should have more fully disclosed the background of the author, Frederick Vreeland. Mr. Vreeland, a former American ambassador to Morocco, is also the chairman of a solar-energy company that has had contracts with the Moroccan government.

A 46-year-old woman was charged yesterday with fatally stabbing her 9-year-old son, officials in Monmouth County said. The police found the woman, Kathlene M. DeMichele, in her apartment about 10:30 p.m. on Tuesday, bleeding profusely from self-inflicted wounds, said the Monmouth County prosecutor, Luis A. Valentin. Ms. DeMichele's son, Charles, was found with several stab wounds in a van parked outside the building, Mr. Valentin said. Ms. DeMichele was hospitalized in critical condition. JOHN HOLL

BEROLATTI--Louis Joseph, on March 20, 2007, of New Rochelle, NY. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Ann, devoted father of Michael and Mary Beth, grandfather of Ryan and Kyle Bowen. Alumnus of the University of Illinois and the University of Chicago. He served as First Lieutenant in the USMC before a long career with Union Carbide. His quiet strength, keen intellect and dry humor have always been admired by his family and friends. Reposing at Lloyd Maxie & Sons, Beauchamp Chapel, 16 Shea Place, New Rochelle, Friday 4-8pm. Funeral Mass, Saturday 9:30am, at Holy Family Church, New Rochelle, NY.

WHITE--Clyde Small, of Burlington, NC, passed away on March 19, 2007. A graduate of College of Charleston, and an MBA graduate of Elon University, he was editor and publisher with Carolina Biological Supply Company. A memorial service will be held at Powerline Church of the Nazarene, 701 Manning Avenue, Elon, NC, on Friday, March 23, 2007, at 11:00 am, by The Reverend Tim Taylor. Survirors include his mother, Mary B. Small Brown, and his stepfather, Harry Brown, of Melbourne Beach, FL; Sister and Brother-in-law, Betty and Robert Pagozalski; brother and sister-in-law, Charlie and Gina White; and four nephews. Donations may be made to the Church or to NIDDK, Attention: Dr. John F. Tisdale, Building 10, NIH, Bethesda, MD 20892.

ZEBROWSKI--Kenneth. The faculty and staff of the Nathan S. Kline Institute for Psychiatric Research mourn the loss of our dear friend Assemblyman Kenneth Zebrowski. We will miss his optimism, his passion and his commitment to improving the lives of others. We send our sympathy to Linda and his entire family. Harold S. Koplewicz, Director

WEHLE--L. Brandeis Jr., 88, of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., NY, died March 17th, of multiple myeloma. Survived by Anne, his wife of 61 years; children, Nancy Aboff, Susan, Jonathan and Robert; grandchildren Matthew, Susannah and Gareth; and step-grandchildren Gage and Justin. Alumnus of Lincoln School and Harvard College Class of 1940. Aerospace Engineer with Grumman Corp for more than 40 years. A contributor to post-war naval and general aviation and the construction of the first lunar module. A dedicated runner, tennis player and sailor, he was noted for his dry wit, keen intelligence and his courtesy and kindness to all. Memorial service Wednesday, March 21st at Old First Presbyterian Church, Huntington, NY. Donations may be made in his name to Huntington Hospital.

FERGUSON--Katharine, (nee Crowninshield), 72, died of cancer on March 18, 2007 in Gulf Stream, FL. She is survived by her husband, David L. Ferguson, her sister Louise C. Riemer, two nieces, two nephews, a great-niece and a great-nephew. A service will be held on March 29, 2007 at Trinity Church, Boston, MA at 11 am. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory can be made to Tower Hill Botanic Garden, 11 French Drive, Boylston, MA 01505, or Garden Club of America, 14 E. 60th St., NY, NY 10022. Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach.
AKINS--Charles A. March 22, 2006. Always in our thoughts, always in our hearts. Love, Irene and Harvey

LIEBMAN--Alan S. With deep affection we remember our dear friend whose larger than life personality will remain with us forever. He shared his wisdom, enthusiasm and love for us over our families' lifetimes. His spirit will live within us all. Shirley, Jack, Leigh and Romy Silver

For four consecutive Mondays beginning on April 2, ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC will devote five additional minutes to reporting the news, which it intends to accomplish by shrinking its lineup of advertisements by five minutes, ABC announced yesterday. The network will sell the remaining commercial time (about three minutes' worth) to a single sponsor each night. The only one of those advertisers announced yesterday by the network was CVS pharmacy, which is underwriting the April 23 broadcast. At least some of the editorial time recovered will be devoted to a series of special reports from around the world by Bill Weir, an ABC correspondent. ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' added more time for news on its broadcast one night last year in a similar arrangement with a lone sponsor, Philips Electronics. JACQUES STEINBERG

AARON--George, 81, died March 20th, residence Sarasota, formerly Tenafly. Survived by his loving wife Diana and sister Shirley Aaron of New York City. In lieu of flowers a contribution in his name to a charity of your choice.

The pictures are striking in a new memoir by Pedro E. Guerrero, the photographer known for chronicling the life and work of Frank Lloyd Wright. But it is the story of Mr. Guerrero's life, told in his own modest words, that is richer and more urgent, particularly when he writes about serving as the sole dove on a draft board during the Vietnam War, which cost him a lucrative 20-year career at House & Garden. ''Pedro E. Guerrero: A Photographer's Journey'' was just published by Princeton Architectural Press ($55); a documentary, ''Pedro Guerrero: Portrait of an Image Maker,'' will have its premiere at Taliesin West in Scottsdale, Ariz., on March 31, (480) 488-2691 or gnosisltd.org. PENELOPE GREEN

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an increase in aid to the Palestinian Authority in 2006 despite an international embargo imposed after the Islamic militant group Hamas came to power misstated the political affiliation of Salam Fayyad, the finance minister in the new Palestinian unity government. He belongs to the Third Way, a party he started in 2006; he is no longer a member of Fatah, the political organization that is a Hamas rival. Also, a caption with the article misstated the type of aid that Mr. Fayyad said had more than doubled in 2006 compared with 2005. It was money to support the Palestinian Authority's budget -- not the total amount of aid, including humanitarian, for Palestinians.

''We think that the life of a person is very precious. So if there is a chance to save a life, we must do all we can do.'' SILVIO SIRCANA, spokesman for Italy's prime minister, on the deal to free a hostage in Afghanistan. [A15]

An article yesterday about a rise in the prevalence of Alzheimer's disease misstated the amount the federal government spends yearly for the average Medicare beneficiary who does not have the disease. It is $4,454, not $2,454.

Democrats Weigh Iraq Vote As the House prepares to vote on an Iraq spending bill, which calls for a troop withdrawal by fall 2008, Democrats of all stripes are engaged in an anguished debate. PAGE A14 Earlier Primary in New York With votes by the Legislature, New York is poised to become the latest of several states that will have presidential primaries on Feb. 5. PAGE B3 15 Die in Firefight in Somalia A battle between Somali government soldiers and armed rebels in Mogadishu left 15 dead. Crowds mutilated the soldiers, chanting, ''We will burn you alive!'' PAGE A3 Bill Clinton Chronicles The historian Taylor Branch plans a book based on wide-ranging conversations with Bill Clinton during his presidency. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 Grim Forecast at Motorola Motorola, facing sluggish profits in its cellphone business, dropped its quarterly revenue forecast by a billion dollars and announced a management shake-up. PAGE C1 Frank Gehry in New York The architect's first New York building, the IAC headquarters in Chelsea, suggests the casual confidence of an aging virtuoso rather than the brash innovation of a rowdy outsider. A review by Nicolai Ouroussoff. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

Two years ago, the interior designer David Easton and his partner, James Steinmeyer, an artist, sold Balderbrae, the Suffern, N.Y., house they built over two decades ago. It was filled with the pieces -- the Delft pottery, the overstuffed chairs, the round tables stacked with books -- that made up Mr. Easton's signature style. ''It's the paisley throw over the back of the chair,'' said Mary F. Cunningham, a specialist in furniture and decoration at Doyle New York, the Upper East Side auction house, describing Mr. Easton's talent for freshening up, Americanizing, the English country-house look. ''The table that's just the right height for your cup of tea and your book. The pieces from Colefax & Fowler and Gene Tyson it's such a yummy combination.''

INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Italian Journalist Freed In Swap for 5 Jailed Taliban An Italian journalist who was held hostage by the Taliban in Afghanistan was ransomed for Taliban prisoners, the Italian government said. The move, criticized by Washington and London, appears to be the first time prisoners have been openly exchanged for a hostage in the recent wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. A1 Retiree Boom Threatens China By midcentury, according to United Nations projections, about a third of China's population will be retirees, a portion that will place enormous demands on the country's finances and could threaten the underpinnings of the Chinese economy. A1 Democrats Anguish Over Iraq As the House of Representatives prepares to vote on a bill calling for American troops to withdraw from Iraq in 2008, an anguishing debate has played out for many Democratic lawmakers as leaders try to gather support from both the party's jittery conservative wing and from liberals who want a faster withdrawal. A14 About 160,000 Iraqis from outside the mountainous Kurdish north have moved into Iraqi Kurdistan to flee a growing civil war, according to a draft of a report by an international group that tracks refugees. A14 Fighting Worsens in Somalia Fifteen people were killed as fighting broke out in Mogadishu, Somalia, between crowds and Ethiopian and Somali government soldiers. The crowds burned the bodies of government soldiers and dragged them through the streets. A3 Chirac Endorses Political Rival President Jacques Chirac of France, saying that he was setting aside his personal feelings for the sake of his party, endorsed his longtime younger rival, Nicolas Sarkozy, as the person best suited to succeed him. A12 U.S. to Reduce Palestinian Aid The Bush administration will reduce the amount of aid it is seeking from Congress for the security forces of the Palestinian president and will set new conditions for monitoring the funds, officials said. A6 NATIONAL A16-22 House Allows Subpoenas For Aides in Firing Inquiry A House panel authorized subpoenas requiring Karl Rove and four other senior Bush administration officials to testify under oath into the inquiry on the dismissals of eight federal prosecutors. A1 Immigrants Sue Over Raids Lawyers for some of about 350 immigrants arrested this month in a raid on a leather factory in New Bedford, Mass., appeared before a federal judge, charging that the government had acted in bad faith, moving the immigrants to detention centers in Texas too quickly and denying them adequate access to lawyers. A22 Bishops Reject Key Demand Responding to an ultimatum from leaders of the worldwide Anglican Communion, bishops of the Episcopal Church have rejected a key demand to create a parallel leadership structure to serve the conservative minority of Episcopalians who oppose their church's liberal stand on homosexuality. A16 Edwards Plans Announcement John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat making a second bid for the presidency, called a news conference for today to discuss the future of his campaign, a day after he and his wife, Elizabeth, visited Mrs. Edwards' doctor to assess her health to follow up on her recovery from a bout of breast cancer. A20 Case Drains Budget in Georgia A multiple-murder case has drained the budget of Georgia's public defender system and brought all but a handful of its 72 capital cases to a standstill. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH New Rules for Drug Experts Experts who receive more than $50,000 from drug or device makers will no longer be allowed to serve on powerful advisory committees that vote on whether to approve those companies' products, according to rules announced by F.D.A. Commissioner Dr. Andrew C. von Eschenbach. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 With New York Safer, Guardian Angels Expand When the Guardian Angels, a citizens' watch group with a paramilitary look, was first formed, it was easy to find dangerous New York City neighborhoods to patrol. But crime has plummeted in the city, and in an act of reinvention and expansion, the Guardian Angels has extended its presence to other parts of the country. B1 City Reforms Foster Care The Bloomberg administration unveiled an ambitious plan to move children through foster care more swiftly, with fewer moves within the system and more limited use of institutional care. B1 New York to Move Primary A bill moving the state's presidential primary to Feb. 5 from March 4 passed both houses of the State Legislature, and with Gov. Eliot Spitzer pledging support for the idea, the measure seemed almost certain to be signed into law. B3 OBITUARIES A23 Stella Chess A psychiatrist who helped develop and popularize the influential theory that children are born with distinct temperaments that can powerfully affect their outlook and relationship with their parents, she was 93. A23 Bishop G. E. Patterson The presiding bishop of the Church of God in Christ, the nation's largest African-American Pentecostal denomination, he was 67. A23 ARTS E1-10 Historian Plans Clinton Book Conversations between Bill Clinton and the historian Taylor Branch began when Mr. Clinton was still the president-elect and continued for eight years. Those sessions, nearly 80 in all, are the fodder for a new book by Mr. Branch, tentatively titled ''Wrestling History: The Bill Clinton Tapes,'' that Simon and Schuster plans to publish in late 2008, the publisher said. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Grim Forecast at Motorola Motorola, one of the world's biggest makers of cellphones, dropped its quarterly revenue projection by a billion dollars. C1 Investors Like Fed's Signals The Federal Reserve, implicitly acknowledging hints of trouble in the economy, edged away from previous signals that its next move on interest rates would be up. Investors reacted with relief. ROSS--Alan Gordon. It's been 6 years, and we miss you every day. Love Mom, Dad and Chris

France replaced a regional school board president, Alain Morvan, for vigorously opposing a new Muslim high school in a Lyon suburb and for publicly complaining about pressure from the government to stop obstructing its opening. The school began admitting students this month after an eight-month struggle with Mr. Morvan, who said the school's founders were ''fundamentalists.'' It is the third Islamic school in France. JOHN TAGLIABUE

New York State is jumping on the bandwagon and joining what is shaping up as the presidential mega-primary next Feb. 5. A bill moving the state's presidential primary to Feb. 5 from March 4 passed both houses of the State Legislature on Wednesday, and with Gov. Eliot Spitzer pledging support for the idea, the measure seemed almost certain to be signed into law.
Today in The Times, I reviewed the Apple TV box--and, for context, a couple of its rivals from Microsoft and Netgear. Let me tell you, I haven't worked so hard on a column in a very, very long time.

A political mystery was solved yesterday with the unmasking of the maker of a much-discussed Internet advertisement that portrayed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as Big Brother. The creator, it turned out, worked for consultants to Senator Barack Obama, a rival for the Democratic presidential nomination. A spokesman for the Obama campaign said last night that the maker of the advertisement had not worked on the Obama campaign account.

EATON--Meghan, of Manhattan, on March 20, 2007. Beloved sister of Dorothy Stapleton. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 7-9 pm at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home Inc., 1380 New York Ave., Huntington Station. Private cremation to follow.

The Bush administration will reduce by about 40 percent the aid it is seeking from Congress for the security forces of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and set new conditions for monitoring the money because of concerns that some of it could end up with Hamas, the militant Islamist organization, administration officials said Wednesday. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, who is returning to the Middle East this weekend for another round of shuttle diplomacy, told a House panel on Wednesday that she would soon send Congress a revised package that would try to restrict the use of the money to security forces loyal to Mr. Abbas, whom the United States considers more moderate than Hamas.

BUKIET--Belle. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of the beloved wife of Al Bukiet, who, with him and his late brother, Joseph (and Rose) Bukiet, are YU Guardians and together dedicated the Bukiet Family Holocaust Collection of Yeshiva College in remembrance of the Holocaust in which their family perished. Condolences are extended to Al, to her children, Bruce (and Gail) Bukiet, Caryn Bukiet, and Michael (and Karen) Bukiet; to her brothers George (and Bernice) Glatter and Herb (and Lynne) Glatter, and to her nine grandchildren. May the entire Bukiet family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman, Board of Trustees

To the Editor: Re ''Hot Tots, and Moms Hot to Trot,'' by Judith Warner (column, March 17), takes moms to task for sexualizing the dress and style of their young children, urging them to become better role models who are comfortable within themselves instead of obsessed with their own physical appearance.

MILNE--Bessie Rilla Bacon, 84, of Darien, CT, passed away March 17, 2007. Daughter of Frederick S. and Lenice I. Bacon of Newton, MA. She attended House in the Pines and Vassar College, Class of 1944. She married the late Douglas D. Milne, Jr. in 1949. She is survived by sons, Douglas D. III and Gordon S. Milne and daughter, Leslie W. Milne and grandchildren, Jason C. and Ashley W. Milne. Memorial Service, April 28, 2007, at 11:30am, the First Congregational Church of Darien, CT.

FUR and leather flooring has come a long way since the bearskin rug. Some designers are now making area rugs out of intricately arranged bits of leather mixed with materials like brass to create a mosaic-like effect, while others are using black-and-white cowhide squares to form abstract patterns.
To the Editor: Re ''Army Brigade, Long a Symbol of Readiness, Is Stretched Thin'' (front page, March 20):

COHEN--Selma. After a long illness and just prior to her 94th birthday, Selma passed away on the morning of March 21, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Harris (Harold), devoted mother of Richard and Paula, loving grandmother of Jonathan, Lisa and the late Harris and adored greatgrandmother of Jake and Benjamin. Her passions beyond family included her professional life as a self employed Interior Designer and Decorator for over 60 years and her love of and excellence in the world of Duplicate Bridge. Her determination and courage led her to overcome enormous obstacles after the premature death of her husband almost 50 years ago. Graveside service.

The city's Department of Education misspent as much as $784,943 in funds intended to provide prekindergarten services in Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson, Jr. said yesterday. Mr. Thompson, left, said that an analysis of spending on nonpublic schools in Regions 6 and 7 during the 2004 and 2005 fiscal years found more than $400,000 in questionable bank transactions, including a cash withdrawal to repay an undocumented loan to the owner of a school building. The analysis also found that money intended for school services was used to pay for items like karate uniforms and an air-conditioner delivered to a nonschool location. Lindsey Harr, an Education Department spokeswoman, said that the city would take steps to ensure that any money owed was returned, but that the audit ''greatly exaggerates the amount of money that may have been improperly spent.'' DIANE CARDWELL

HOUK--Bruce Victor, writer and traveler, 68, died January 11, 2007, in Queens, NY, due to a heart attack. Born March 16, 1938, to Rudy J. Houk and Sally Homer. Attended Bard College, Columbia Graduate School and graduated Hunter in 2000. He lived as he wanted; the last ten years he was an office assistant at Fountain House. He is survived by a former wife Lilly and son Jesse, brother John Hikory of Vermont, and nieces and nephews. Predeceased by his parents and his brother Rudy Houk, of New Hampshire.

The ''American Idol'' finalists continue to draw enormous audiences week after week, but lately ratings for that singing competition have been falling short of their levels a year ago. Tuesday night was no different, as the 11 remaining contestants performed, and Sanjaya Malakar won atypical praise from the judges. The two-hour show garnered 29.4 million viewers from 8 to 10, according to Nielsen's estimates, a decline of about 6 percent from the same night in 2006. Some of the year-to-year decline, a trend that has persisted for several weeks, can be attributed to this year's early change to daylight saving time, which reduces television audiences over all. The decrease is so small that it has not kept Fox from dominating Tuesday nights, as it did again this week. CBS was No. 2 for the night, as both ''NCIS'' at 8 (15.5 million) and ''The Unit'' at 9 (12 million) ranked second in their time slots. A repeat of CBS's ''CSI'' (10.4 million) led the 10 o'clock hour ahead of ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (9.1 million) and a rerun of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (7.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the bribery trial of Gerald P. Garson, a former state judge in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to the location of the courtroom where he once presided. Mr. Garson, a matrimonial judge, heard cases in the municipal building on Joralemon Street -- not in the courthouse on Jay Street, the venue for his trial.

A picture caption last Thursday with an article about environmentally-conscious rock musicians misidentified a member of the rock group Guster. He is Ryan Miller -- not Adam Gardner, who helped established Reverb, an organization that consults with performers on greener rock tours.

HARRIS--Philip E., passed from this life on March 21st at the age of 91. He was a community leader and entrepreneur who lived in Scranton, PA, and Miami Beach, FL. He will be remembered for his courage in the face of adversity, his extraordinary resilience and a tremendous capacity to embrace life. He is survived by his children, Stewart (Gloria) Harris, Judy (Stuart) Poloner, Suri Harris and Malki (Gary) Gartenberg. A daughter, Susan, died in 1995. Mr. Harris' surviving siblings are Samuel and David Harris, Shirley Gross, Muriel Davidowitz and Malka Stern. In addition, he is survived by 18 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Funeral services and burial will be in Scranton, PA.

George Vecsey had a column Thursday about his foray to find one of the few places in Manhattan to watch . If he were here he'd have to go to great lengths to avoid cricket.

It was a late-arriving crowd at Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., where tip-off was a few minutes away and half of the mauve-colored seats were still empty. The game had not started, but the bands were in a fierce competition, playing at the same time, creating a cacophony of chaos. (Georgetown sounded like it was playing some version of "Go Tell It On the Mountain," while Vanderbilt was playing something familiar but not quite recognizable.) It is hard to tell which side most of this crowd will take - there is a spunky contingent of Vanderbilt fans behind Jim Nantz and the CBS crew, but the Georgetown fans seem to have spread themselves out a bit more. I imagine we'll see, and hear, a lot from the North Carolina fans during the second game.

Morgan Stanley announced Friday its long-expected plans to spin off its Discover credit card operations in an initial public offering. It was not immediately known how much the nation's second-largest investment house expected to raise from the I.P.O., which Chairman and Chief Executive Officer John Mack had promised would be undertaken after he took the leadership at Morgan Stanley in June 2005.

While the Yankees were losing here in Bradenton, 3-2 to the Pirates, Chien-Ming Wang felt some discomfort in his right hamstring while running at the Yankees' complex in Tampa. The Yankees shut him down for the rest of the workout and say they'll have no more details until tomorrow.
After splitting up after college, Hilary Poris and Andrew Macklin realized they were meant to be together.

Though it briefly reigned last year as the largest leveraged buyout ever, the $33 billion deal to take HCA private almost ended with a drink and a shrug. So say Alan Hartman and Jim Forbes, the Merrill Lynch investment bankers who advised the hosital chain, in an interview with Dealmaker magazine. The proposed buyers -- Merrill Lynch, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital and the hospital giant's management -- spent a final week of tough negotiations with advisers to HCA's special committee, haggling over a price.

Though the names most often mentioned as potential buyers of Chrysler have been private equity firms like the Blackstone Group and Cerberus Capital Management, several reports highlight a lesser-known firm with roots in the car business. In quick succession, natural death turned to a "suspicious" one, and now Jamaican police say Bob Woolmer was murdered in the hours after he coached Pakistan to a humiliating defeat to Ireland.
