Are private equity deals getting too expensive? A reader of the Financial Times's Web site posed that timely question to Philip Purcell, the former chief executive of Morgan Stanley. His answer was a definite maybe. Mr. Purcell, who is now the president of Continental Investors, replied that prices are high enough that some buyout firms might see lower returns on current deals than they saw over the past 15 years. "History would say that some buyers are overpaying," he said during an online Q&A.
Gregory Dicum tours the city's coffee bars. With its traditional botequins and sleek espresso bars, it's easy to catch a buzz in Rio.

Positioned in the heart of the exclusive resort of Verbier, Switzerland, this development of four apartments offers a chalet feeling but all the advantages of a "lock and leave" apartment. There are two private lifts, two parking spaces for each apartment, and a "reserve" that can be used as a wine cave, cinema room, bedroom, or even a spa. Prices start from £1,799,000 -- or approximately $3.5 million -- for 261 square meters of living space. The property is being marketed by Chesterton International in London at international.property@chesterton.co.uk

As money-manager-cum-TV-personality James Cramer was apologizing Thursday for parts of his recent treatise on how to manipulate stock prices, his nemesis, stock-analyst-cum-writer Henry Blodget, was tapping out a column for Slate suggesting that Mr. Cramer may have destroyed his own career.
The real effect of the subprime mortgage debacle is not yet clear, but today's Times has no fewer than three articles assigning blame.
If I marry, would my wife be able to succeed me upon my death?

Anyone interested in sending Carlos Delgado a baby gift better get to work soon. His blue maserati is gone, and according to Mets PR man Jay Horwitz, Delgado left an hour ago to fly back to Puerto Rico for the birth of his first child, Carlos Antonio.

Yesterday, I tried to help out fans without any specific team loyalty decide whom to root for during last night's games, the official Out Of Bounds Right-Thinking, Good-Hearted, Pure-of-Spirit Human Being's Guide To Whom To Root For In The Sweet 16. (O.O.B.R.T.G.H.P.O.S.H.B.G.T.W.T.R.F.I.T.S.S.) How'd my advice go? The teams I recommended cheering for went 0-4; I hope I caused you no heartache. Let's see if I can bring you more joy with a look at whom you should pledge your allegiances to tonight.FRIDAY

Southern California freshman point guard Daniel Hackett has the most eclectic set of tattoos. He grew up in Italy (moving to the United States about four years ago), where his father was a player and a coach. On Hackett's left arm is one that reads "Italian Stallion." He said the high-school cheering section at St. John Bosco in Southern California called him that.
What do you think hotels should do to accommodate their guests' allergy needs?

For the Democratic field, appealing to Nevada's union workers will be the focus of the weekend. Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and Christopher J. Dodd, as well as Gov. Bill Richardson are scheduled to speak at a culinary workers' rally in Las Vegas to kick off contract negotiations. On Saturday, that set will be joined in Sin City by several others, including John Edwards, for a health care forum sponsored by the Service Employees International Union and the Center for American Progress, a liberal think tank.

The first question for North Carolina Coach Roy Williams at his press conference Thursday was about "the whole atmosphere." Since it was in the bowels of Continental Airlines Arena, The Bracket would have answered "stuffy." And in the tiny locker rooms of the teams -- seriously, the size of a spare bedroom -- it was "smelly."
John Thompson III, the Georgetown coach, sat under the bright lights, between a microphone and the N.C.A.A. backdrop, answering questions.

Vanderbilt and Georgetown, a pair of small, private schools in different conferences, have played in each of the past two seasons. Vanderbilt won in December 2005, and Georgetown won last November, 86-70.

Sorry, Jesus, no bong hits for you: Jonathan Zimmerman, director of the history of education program at New York University, says "both sides are wrong" in the Supreme Court case over whether a high school student can display a banner that says "Bong Hits 4 Jesus." Zimmerman writes in The Christian Science Monitor: "The banner was a foolish vulgarity, unworthy of court-affirmed protection for politically meaningful speech. Under the school's theory, meanwhile, educators could censor any speech that contradicted their goals or ideas."

Since 2000, according to census figures released last year, the number of children under age 5 living in Manhattan mushroomed by more than 32 percent. And though their ranks have been growing for several years, a new analysis for The New York Times makes clear for the first time who has been driving that growth: wealthy white families.At least half of the growth was generated by children who are white and non-Hispanic. Their ranks expanded by more than 40 percent from 2000 to 2005. For the first time since at least the 1960s, white children now outnumber either black or Hispanic youngsters in that age group in Manhattan.
Tour a handful of vacation communities on the shores of northern Michigan’s pristine lakes.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi called a mandatory 8:30 a.m. meeting for all House Democrats. The topic, of course, was Iraq. The reason? To make one final check to see if her Democrats did not change their minds overnight on the party's signature Iraq legislation to be voted on in a few hours.

An anonymous - because he (I think it's a he) is required by law to remain that way - "president of a small Internet access and consulting business" writes in a Washington Post op-ed about his experience as the recipient of a national security letter from the F.B.I. "Three years ago, I received a national security letter (NSL) in my capacity as the president of a small Internet access and consulting business," the author writes. "The letter ordered me to provide sensitive information about one of my clients. There was no indication that a judge had reviewed or approved the letter, and it turned out that none had. The letter came with a gag provision that prohibited me from telling anyone, including my client, that the F.B.I. was seeking this information."

Blackstone Group, confirming a firestorm of speculation, said Thursday it would seek an initial public offering that would value the firm at as much as $40 billion. The preliminary prospectus offered a first glimpse inside Blackstone's closely guarded money machine, which churned out $2.3 billion in profit in 2006. The offering is being structured to allow Blackstone to retain many advantages of a private business -- a setup that Breakingviews compares with Berkshire Hathaway under Warren Buffett.
Offering world-class natural beauty and a low-key lifestyle, Saugatuck, Mich., appeals to many families seeking a retreat from city life.

By lifting restrictions on air traffic between the United States and Europe, the so-called "open skies" agreement that European Union officials approved on Thursday may herald a renewed push for airline consolidation. Under the accord, European and American airlines will be allowed to fly any route between any European city and one in the United States. The change, which will take effect in March 2008, is expected to markedly increase competition in many European countries.

Shortly after Motorola disappointed shareholders and analysts by cutting its revenue forecasts and failing to make a bid for rival Palm, its biggest gadfly has increased his stake in the company. Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, increased his stake in the beleaguered cellphone maker to 2.7 percent from 2.48 percent, according to a regulatory filing made on Friday.

Pearson shares rose the most in 14 months amid speculation that the company, which owns Penguin Books and the Financial Times newspaper, may receive an offer from a buyout firm or be split up, Bloomberg News reported. The stock was up as much as 4.2 percent Friday. A Pearson spokeswoman did not confirm or deny the rumors.

Greg Oden, who went through puberty as an embryo, will be one of the top two players selected in the N.B.A. draft. At 19, he is already his own conglomerate, which is impressive considering he plays for free. He was actually invited to play on the United States national team last year with LeBron James, Carmelo Anthony and Amare Stoudemire even though he'd never played a game at a competitive level above high school. (This put him at the same level, at the time, as me.) His legend is such already that professional basketball franchises -major corporations with hundreds of thousands of fans, personal seat licenses and a dozen tall men they pay millions for running up and down a floor - appear to be losing games on purpose to maximize the opportunity that he might play for them and their fans are perfectly O.K. with this.

In a blow for the Mays family, one of Clear Channel Communications' largest shareholders said Thursday that it planned on voting against a proposed $18.7 billion management buyout. Highfields Capital Management, which owns roughly 5 percent of the radio giant, said the $37.60-a-share offer was too low.

One day after announcing record earnings, Morgan Stanley on Thursday a reorganization of its securities sales and trading businesses that would eliminate the traditional equities and fixed income divisions. The move will also give more autonomy to the European and Asian regions, both of which are generating increasing portions of the firm's profits.

Though Barclays' negotiations with Dutch rival ABN Amro are exclusive right now, another bidder may want to bust in. Executives within Citigroup are pushing for the American banking giant to make its own bid for ABN Amro, the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday. Citigroup, itself the product of a series of mergers, is studying the possibility of an unsolicited bid, the paper said citing unnamed sources.

An Endless Election: "I'm not sure why this has been so complicated." -- Dr. Mathieu Eugene, who is running again in a special election in the 40th Council District (the second of four elections this year in the district).

Enel, the Italian utility, and Acciona, the Spanish construction and energy group, confirmed on Friday that they were in talks about launching a joint bid for Endesa, the Spanish electricity group, that is currently the subject of an offer from Eon of Germany.

After several rounds of negotiations, General Electric said Friday that it will buy Sanyo Electric Credit, the financing affiliate of struggling electronics maker Sanyo, in a transaction that could top out at 135 billion yen ($1.14 billion). In a statement Friday, Tokyo-listed Sanyo Electric Credit said the company had agreed to a tender offer from General Electric under which the U.S. conglomerate will pay 3,250 yen ($27.51) per share, a premium of nearly 62 percent from the closing price of 2,010 yen ($17.02) on Friday.

Citigroup is setting up a global commercial banking operation in London that will push into medium-sized corporate lending in Britain and Germany. The move is part of a broader restructuring of Citigroup's corporate bank that reflects the efforts of the bank's chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, to boost organic growth while streamlining the organization.

Limelight Networks, a digital-content delivery provider backed by Goldman Sachs's private equity arm, filed to raise as much as $201 million in an initial public offering of stock. In July, Goldman Sachs Capital Partners led a $130 million funding round for Limelight, whose network helps media companies to distribute video, music, games and downloads over the Internet.
This picturesque Wisconsin vacation enclave is known as the Hamptons of the Midwest.
One of Qantas Airways' largest shareholders has rejected a Macquarie Bank-led A$11.1 billion ($9 billion) buyout of the Australian carrier, threatening the world's biggest airline takeover.
It always makes us happy to know that you are reading along as we stumble forward in our quest to build our dream home.

Japanese pharmaceutical titan Eisai said Thursday it will bulk up its cancer drug pipeline with a deal to buy Morphotek for $325 million. The move will expand Eisai's presence in the United States. It will also bring the traditional pharmaceutical company deeper into the biologic therapeutics field, where products are generally made using living cells. Venture-capital backed Morphotek develops monoclonal antibodies for the treatment of cancer, inflammation, and infectious diseases.
With a shareholder showdown looming at Take-Two Interactive Software, two proxy advisories are placing good odds on an investor group's move to take control of the beleaguered video game publisher.

Classified advertising web site Oodle, founded by three former Excite.com employees, said Wednesday it raised $11 million in venture funding. The company collects classified ads from different sources and lets users search them on its site. Jafco Ventures, a new investor, led the round. Greylock Partners and Redpoint Ventures, both of which gave money in the company's previous funding round, also contributed to the new round.

Internet marketer Vertrue, which runs the online matchmaking service LavaLife, agreed to be acquired by a trio of investment firms and its senior managers for $48.50 a share in cash, or about $800 million including debt. J.P. Morgan's private equity arm One Equity Partners, venture capital firm Oak Investment Partners, and Rho Ventures, a venture investor, along with managers led by Vertrue chief executive and co-founder Gary Johnson, will invest an undisclosed amount of equity in the deal, which is slated to close by Sept. 30.

Palm shares took a beating Thursday when a much-anticipated bid from Motorola failed to materialize. Palm shares lost nearly 9 percent after traders interpreted Motorola's silence on the subject as evidence that it won't be acquiring Palm.

Carlyle Group, the Washington-based private equity giant, is putting together a $15 billion fund for buyouts in the United States, which would be nearly twice the size of its previous fund, Reuters reported, citing undisclosed sources.

The insurance broker Hub International said Thursday that its recently announced agreement to be acquired has been amended to increase the purchase price for each share to $41.50, from $40. In February, Hub said it would be acquired by the private equity firm Apax Partners, together with Morgan Stanley Principal Investments, for about $1.7 billion. The increase in consideration followed "competing proposals," the company said in a statement.

Jurors at Conrad M. Black's trial were told on Thursday that a major investor in Mr. Black's giant media company blew the whistle on fees and perks that he and his lieutenants were collecting and that Mr. Black was out of a job not long after that.

A former director of Qwest Communications testified Thursday that the board had agreed to give Joseph P. Nacchio, then its chief executive, a raise and 7.25 million shares in stock options about a month after the phone company acknowledged for the first time that it had used one-time transactions to help meet financial targets.

The ferocious and long-running battle between Oracle and its German rival, SAP, for pole position in the business software industry took a turn for the courthouse Thursday. Oracle sued SAP accusing the world's No.1 business software maker of intruding into its computer systems to carry out "corporate theft on a grand scale."

The New York Times takes a look at how Carrefour, the world's second-largest retailer, was put into play. Last month, the American real estate investment firm Colony Capital and the richest man in France, Bernard Arnault, announced that they had acquired nearly 10 percent of Carrefour's shares and hoped to translate that value into a fat capital gain.

India's drive to become a global economic powerhouse faces a huge roadblock in its inefficient, largely state-controlled financial system, The New York Times reports. Two-thirds of India's banking business is conducted through less than 5 percent of its branches, and its growing corporate sector has headed overseas for financial advice and loans.

The New York Times Company, under pressure from investors because of its stagnant stock performance, announced Thursday that it would raise its quarterly dividend by 31 percent. The new dividend - 23 cents a share a quarter, up from 17.5 cents - is payable on June 13 to shareholders of record on June 1.
Images from "Facing Fascism: New York and the Spanish Civil War."
VH1’s show, which allows viewers to play television executive, reeks of esoterica that is too obscure for audience consumption.
A Paul Rudolph architectural road trip to Tracey Towers, in the Bronx, as well as buildings in Middletown, N.Y., New Haven, Conn., and South Dartmouth, Mass.
Stanley Ho’s casino empire in Macao is under assault from a group of ambitious Las Vegas tycoons.
After his team's miraculous 85-84 comeback victory over fifth-seeded Tennessee on Thursday night, the Ohio State freshman center Greg Oden received several stitches in his chin.

One of the distinct pleasures of covering the N.C.A.A. Tournament is being able to watch your bracket crumble right before your eyes. That's pretty much what happened in San Antonio tonight, as two one-point games put a distinct stench in the The Bracket's bracket. I'd picked both Tennessee and Texas A&M to reach the Regional Final here in the South. Both were logical picks that seemed quite realistic, even in the waning minutes.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
A pointed little thriller with metaphysical pretensions, “First Snow” is shrewd enough to approach basic philosophical questions in sneaky, offhand ways.
Muscles bulge and heads explode in this thoroughly reprehensible, satisfyingly violent entertainment about men and guns and things that go boom.
“Reign Over Me” uses the rhythms and moods of comedy to explore, and also to contain, overpowering feelings of loss.
In “The Prisoner,” an Iraqi journalist shares his anguish, his outrage, his fear, his despair, his hope...his Iraq.
In “The Page Turner,” rather big questions vibrate inside this rather small film, shaking it like a V-8 engine dropped in a Volkswagen Bug.
Even if it doesn’t add up to more than a fitfully amusing collection of comic sketches, “Color Me Kubrick” is a platform for John Malkovich to burst into lurid purple flame.
Connoisseurs of craziness need wait no longer. “Cobra Verde” is here in all its feral, baffling glory.
D. Kyle Sampson has agreed to testify next Thursday before a Senate panel investigating the controversial firings of eight U. S. attorneys.
Whatever the flaws of the plan approved today, it was won with a strikingly unified vote from House Democrats.
After a stunning World Cup loss, Pakistan’s coach planned to “sleep on it.” By the next morning, he was dead.
Paul Cortez was sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison for the killing of a young dancer from Ohio.
The discovery comes nearly a week after more than 60 million cans and pouches of wet pet food were recalled.
United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said today that a mortar round that struck close by him in Baghdad would not deter him from expanding the U.N. presence in Iraq.
The general did note that China’s recent test of an anti-satellite weapon sent a confusing message to the world about its military intentions.
After a highly emotional debate, the House voted 218-212 to set a timetable for bringing American troops home. Republicans said the measure amounted to micromanaging the war.
J. Steven Griles pleaded guilty today to obstruction of justice and lying to a Senate committee about his ties to Jack Abramoff.
Fifteen British sailors were captured at gunpoint in the Persian Gulf and taken into custody by Iranian forces today, the British Ministry of Defense said.
Deputy Prime Minister Salam al-Zobaie was wounded in a blast inside a hall behind his house. Two bodyguards and two others were killed.
The huge range in spending among the state’s 615 school districts is starkly laid out in new survey.
Ohio State followed up its stunning overtime win against No. 9 Xavier in the second round of the tournament with perhaps an even more impressive effort against Tennessee.
U.C.L.A. and Pittsburgh are often portrayed as identical teams. But with better perimeter players and many more ways to score, the Bruins defeated the Panthers.
Judith Nathan had been married twice, and not once as generally believed, before she wed Rudolph W. Giuliani in 2003.
A hall monitor at Roslyn High School was arrested yesterday after two bags of cocaine fell out of her pocket in a hallway, the Nassau County police said.
After making two free throws with 3.1 seconds left, Memphis guard Antonio Anderson was the hero of the second-seeded Tigers’ wild victory against third-seeded Texas A&M.
David Lee made a surprise comeback, but was on the bench for the final minutes of a loss to Portland, proving once again that the Knicks’ deficiencies run deeper than an injury or two.
The top-seeded Jayhawks, hoping to expel their midmajor demons, barely escaped them. Kansas will play in the West Regional final Saturday after holding off Southern Illinois on Thursday night.

An article yesterday about a vote authorizing a strike by the faculty of California State University gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a university spokeswoman who said she does not foresee a shutdown of the university. She is Clara Potes-Fellow, not Portes-Fellow.

A news analysis article on Wednesday about the history and scope of executive privilege misstated the academic position held by Mark J. Rozell, who said that President Bush has invoked the privilege relatively sparingly. He is a professor at the School of Public Policy at George Mason University, not a law professor at George Mason.

Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday, about a measure passed by the Georgia House to ban the sale of candy made to taste like marijuana, misidentified the substance that marketers say is used to flavor the candy. It is hemp essential oil, not hempseed oil.

A sports article on Monday about Connecticut’s victory over Maryland-Baltimore County in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament misstated the year UConn last won the national championship. It was 2004, not 2003.

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the Sotheby’s auction of antiquities from the collection of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo misstated Sotheby’s commission on objects sold. It is 20 percent of the hammer price for the first $500,000 and 12 percent of the rest — not 20 percent of the first $200,000 and 12 percent of the rest. (The commission was raised in January.).

A picture with a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about the winners of the 2007 Martin E. Segal awards, which recognize outstanding achievement by young artists, carried an erroneous credit, and a credit was omitted from another picture with the report. The photograph of the Daedalus Quartet was by Steve J. Sherman — not by Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times. Mr. Ito took the picture of the mezzo-soprano Kate Lindsey.
Gordon Paris, who succeeded Conrad M. Black as head of Hollinger International accused Mr. Black and his associates of running a “corporate kleptocracy.”

An article on Saturday about appeals filed by companies that lost out in bidding for casino licenses in Pennsylvania misstated the number of slots-only casinos that are operating in the state. It is four, not three. (In addition to those in Wilkes-Barre, Bensalem and Chester, one is operating in Erie.).

An article on Wednesday about violence in Iraq misspelled the surname of an American general who described a car bombing in which he said insurgents had used two children as decoys to deceive soldiers at a Baghdad checkpoint. He is Michael D. Barbero, not Barbaro.

A front-page article on Tuesday about possible financial consequences for the Anglican Communion if it severs ties with the Episcopal Church in the United States for consecrating an openly gay bishop misspelled the surname of a priest who said the American church “is not a pariah to everybody.” She is the Rev. Lisa Fischbeck, not Fishbeck.
Corrections: For the Record
Wal-Mart said that about 80 percent of hourly workers would split more than half a billion dollars.
Rick DiPietro turned aside 37 shots, and the Islanders snapped a four-game losing streak by defeating the Pittsburgh Penguins, 3-1, last night at Nassau Coliseum.
Hub International said its recently announced agreement to be acquired has been amended to increase the purchase price for each share to $41.50, from $40.
Pfizer said that a court ruling upholding the company’s patent on the blood pressure medication Norvasc was reversed by a federal appeals court.
Kobe Bryant became the fourth player in N.B.A. history to score at least 50 points in three consecutive games.

Royal Ahold, the operator of the Stop & Shop grocery chain in the United States, reported a sharp rise in fourth-quarter earnings. The company, which is based in Amsterdam, earned 239 million euros ($318 million) for the last three months of 2006, up from 103 million euros a year earlier. Profit was helped by lower financing costs. In the United States, sales were flat at the Stop & Shop and Giant-Landover chains.

Peter Mandelson, the European Union’s top trade negotiator, said he would not seek a second term after his current tenure ends in 2009. As European trade chief, Mr. Mandelson has been coordinating the bloc’s strategy in World Trade Organization talks and defending Airbus in a dispute with the United States government and the Boeing Company. He has held the post since November 2004 and said he would not leave before his term expires in November 2009.

Brazil’s securities regulator said in a ruling late Wednesday that Arcelor Mittal, the world’s biggest steel maker, must pay about 49.75 reais ($24.17) a share for stock of a local unit, Arcelor Brasil. The regulator said the company must pay more than the 35 reais ($17) a share it originally offered. Arcelor was required to offer to buy out minority shareholders in Arcelor Brasil to comply with local legislation after Mittal Steel’s takeover of Arcelor last year.

Harris Associates rejected Citigroup’s $13.4 billion bid for Nikko Cordial, the Japanese brokerage firm, saying the price was still too low. Harris, which is Nikko’s largest shareholder, with a stake of about 7.5 percent, has no plan “at this stage” to accept Citigroup’s bid of 1,700 yen ($14.47) a share, David G. Herro, Harris’s chief investment officer, said. Citigroup raised its offer to 1,700 yen a share from 1,350 after Harris and other funds opposed the bid.

Colombia, the world’s third-biggest banana shipper, filed a new complaint with the World Trade Organization against European rules that it said discriminated against banana exports. The trade organization first ruled against Europe in September 1997, backing claims brought by Ecuador, the United States, Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico almost two years earlier. The new request starts a fresh challenge to a tariff of 176 euros ($234) per metric ton.
A contracting company that worked for the city’s Department of Housing Preservation and Development  did not pay required wages, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., said.
A former gossip writer for The New York Post sued a California billionaire and The Daily News yesterday, claiming they defamed him and cost him his job as a Post contributor.

A driver who pleaded guilty to manslaughter and driving while intoxicated in an accident in which a retired priest was killed last summer was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 4 to 12 years in prison.
The city’s tourism agency opened an office in Moscow yesterday, officials said.
Two men have been arrested and charged with killing a bodega owner during a robbery five months ago, Hudson County officials said.

The county executive, Andrew J. Spano, said yesterday that he would establish a Housing Land Trust to assure that after moderate-income housing is built in Westchester, it remains affordable to its tenants forever.

A bus driver was seriously injured and at least seven passengers were hurt when a New Jersey Transit bus collided with a dump truck about 6:50 a.m. at the corner of West Side Avenue and 69th Street in North Bergen.
The Brooklyn Public Library has a new executive director, Dionne Mack-Harvin, who is the first black woman to run a major public library system in the state, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said.
A Camden police officer was indicted on charges that he conspired to rob a drug dealer, provided a gun for the robbery and agreed to launder the proceeds, state prosecutors said.
John Edwards noted that many patients with the same diagnosis as his wife had lived for many years.
John Edwards proclaimed that he would continue his bid for the presidency, saying, “The campaign goes on strongly.”
The National Center for Space Research opened its files on U.F.O.’s, putting them on a <a href=

At least 13 people were killed and 100 injured when the country’s largest arms depot exploded in Maputo, the capital, witnesses and doctors said. “We have so many patients,” said a doctor at the capital’s central hospital. “We have open fractures, amputations, multiple amputations.” Officials said hot weather set off the explosion of bombs, mines and ammunition. A United Nations official said the armory held thousands of tons of weapons and ammunition.

Foreign Minister Taro Aso said “yellow-faced” Japanese could play a more constructive role in Middle East diplomacy than Americans. “Japan is doing what Americans can’t do,” he said, according to the newspaper Nikkei. “Japanese are trusted. If you have blue eyes and blond hair, it’s probably no good.” Mr. Aso is often mentioned as a successor to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

Foreign Minister Massimo D’Alema said he did not discuss with American officials the deal in which five Taliban prisoners were traded this week for the freedom of a kidnapped Italian reporter in Afghanistan. Despite strong criticism from officials in the United States and Europe, Mr. D’Alema told reporters in Rome, “I am not the slightest bit repentant for having saved” the reporter, Daniele Mastrogiacomo, adding that it “is preferable to have a controversy over having saved him, rather than for having had him killed.”.

A Palestinian was killed in Gaza City when members of his family, associated with Fatah, clashed with Hamas’s Executive Force. Earlier, gunmen forced out the driver of a United Nations refugee agency car and made off with the vehicle. The driver, a local employee, was unharmed. A United Nations spokesman said agency cars would temporarily stay off Gaza’s roads.
pro football.

Legislation to give the District of Columbia a full vote in the House of Representatives stalled when Republicans unexpectedly injected the volatile issue of gun control. Democrats decided to put off action indefinitely on the voting rights measure, which had appeared to be moving toward passage though President Bush had vowed to veto it. Republicans, protesting the delay, sought a quick vote on their effort to repeal the District’s ban on handguns. Mayor Adrian M. Fenty said there was no local support for repeal of its tough gun-control laws. He said that when people learned that residents had again been denied voting rights, “I think it is going to backfire on those who have done this procedural maneuver.”.

The former head of Chicago’s largest municipal department, who was also a top official with a powerful citywide political campaign organization, was indicted on nine counts of mail fraud. The charges, announced by Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the local United States attorney, are the latest in a continuing federal investigation of fraudulent Chicago hiring and promotion practices that has resulted in 44 convictions since early 2004. The indictment alleges that the official, Alfred Sanchez, commissioner of the Streets and Sanitation Department until 2005 and a leader with the Hispanic Democratic Organization, engaged in a scheme from 1994 to 2005 to provide city jobs, promotions and other employment benefits to induce and reward political campaign work. Mr. Sanchez, 59, is the 47th person to be charged in the investigation.
One reason for Rutgers’ success since being blown out by Duke in December has been the steady progress of the freshmen Epiphanny Prince, Brittany Ray, Rashidat Junaid and Myia McCurdy.
Alberto R. Gonzales and Dick Cheney’s office expressed strong objections to moving detainees to the U.S.

The Tulare County Board of Supervisors approved a plan Tuesday for two 160-acre megadairies to be built across from Colonel Allensworth State Historic Park, a site dedicated to the history of California’s first and only black planned community. The county approved the proposal by a local rancher to establish two dairies with some 16,000 cows near the park, in a remote corner of the Central Valley. Citizens, including some from the original Allensworth Colony, and environmentalists have protested the plan.
A fatal fire this month in the Bronx revealed a clandestine practice that probably involves thousands of immigrants.

Yellowstone Park grizzly bears have rebounded so successfully that they have been removed from the endangered species list, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service said. From the bears’ perspective, the move means little, said Chris Servheen, a wildlife biologist with the service. Mr. Servheen said the population of bears, which had been listed as “threatened,” would be monitored under a conservation agreement involving Wyoming, Montana, Idaho and a group of federal wildlife and natural resource agencies. The service said there were only about 300 or fewer bears in the park when they were listed as threatened in 1975; today, they number at least 500.
The eight art museums of the Smithsonian Institution are “drastically underfunded,” particularly compared with its history and science museums, according to a report.

Coastal regulators and environmental groups separately sued the Navy over of its decision to continue sonar training exercises off California without precautions that opponents contend are necessary to protect marine life. Earlier this year, the California Coastal Commission approved the exercises for a two-year period only if the Navy obeyed restrictions, including avoiding coastal waters with a large whale and dolphin population. The Navy sought the commission’s approval for the maneuvers, then said the commission lacked the authority to impose the restrictions. The commission contends federal law gives it the power to limit the Navy’s exercises to comply with state law. In a separate suit, a coalition of environmental groups faulted the Navy for not preparing an environmental impact statement on the planned drills.

An appeals court ruled that California’s medical marijuana law does not automatically shield patients from searches by law enforcement. The unanimous ruling by a three-judge panel of the State Court of Appeal said a Napa County sheriff’s deputy had probable cause to search the vehicle of Gabriel Strasburg, who claimed to have a medical marijuana card, in October 2005. The law limits patient possession to eight ounces. The deputy claimed Mr. Strasburg had about 23 ounces and a scale and was smoking in a parked car. Mr. Strasburg pleaded no contest to misdemeanor possession but appealed, claiming an unlawful search. In the decision, Justice James Marchiano said the amount of marijuana found in the search left “a strong suggestion” that Mr. Strasburg “was using the act as a façade to conceal illegal activity.”.

STAVROPOULOS--Theo, artist and teacher, died Sunday, March 11, 2007 at his home on Chebeague Island, Maine. He was born in Athens, Greece, studied art at the Ecoles des Beaux Arts in Paris, France and at Yale with Josef Albers. For over 20 years, he taught at Lehman College in the Bronx. He exhibited widely and successfully. He is survived by his wife, Susan, his daughter, Dominique Williams and his son-in-law, Claudio, a sister, Marie and other relatives in Greece. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to: American Parkinson Disease Assoc., 1250 Hylan Blvd. Suite 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305.

Rozell, who said that President Bush has invoked the privilege relatively sparingly. He is a professor at the School of Public Policy at George Mason University, not a law professor at George Mason.

PATTERSON--Glenn Scott, 69, of Manhattan, died peacefully after a long illness on March 1, 2007, (retired NYC Parks Department and Local 147-Sandhogs). Son of the late Mary Crawford Patterson and Anslow Patterson; survived by cousins in Canada and the US. His charm and loyalty gained him the friendship of many. Memorial Mass, Thursday, March 29 at 4 pm, Epiphany Church, 22nd Street and 2nd Avenue.

Britney Spears Takes On the British Press Britney Spears has won an injunction from High Court in London to bar the British press from printing details of her recent stint in a rehabilitation clinic in Malibu, Calif., the BBC reported. A statement from her lawyers in London said she ''intends to challenge false allegations that have already been published.'' They are also applying for a court order to force British publications to divulge the sources of their articles about her monthlong treatment at the Promises Malibu Alcohol and Drug Rehab Treatment Facility. '300' Irks Iranian President President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, below, obliquely attacked the hit Warner Brothers film ''300'' in a televised speech to mark the Iranian New Year on Wednesday, Variety.com reported. While not mentioning the film, about the Battle of Thermopylae in 480 B.C., by name, he accused Western powers of ''trying to tamper with history by making a film and by making Iran's image look savage.'' Last week, his cultural adviser, Javad Shangari, declared the film ''part of a comprehensive U.S. psychological warfare aimed against Iranian culture.'' Warner Brothers said, ''The studio developed this film purely as a fictional work with the sole purpose of entertaining audiences; it is not meant to disparage an ethnicity or culture or make any sort of political statement.'' Marvel Superheroes To Inhabit Dubai Coming in 2011 to Dubai: Spider-Man, the Incredible Hulk, the X-Men and their ilk. Marvel Entertainment and Al Ahli Group, based in the United Arab Emirates, are joining forces to build a $1 billion theme park based on Marvel superheroes and scheduled to open in four years, Variety.com reported. Mohamed Khammas, chief executive of Al Ahli, said, ''Family destinations have not evolved in pan-Arabia, and thus it's time we cater to that demand.'' Surf's Up for Russell Crowe Russell Crowe, the actor, is to make his debut as a feature film director with ''Bra Boys,'' about a tattooed, often violent gang of antiauthoritarian, antisocial surfers in Sydney, the BBC reported. Mr. Crowe, right, recently narrated a documentary about the gang, also titled ''Bra Boys,'' which is currently No. 4 at the Australian box office. Movie fans eager to arrange their social calendars may want to know that the 80th Academy Awards ceremonies will be held on Feb. 24, 2008, at the Kodak Theater in Hollywood. Nominees will be announced on Jan. 22, Agence France-Presse reported. Tim Burton, the director of ''Edward Scissorhands'' and ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,'' will receive the Golden Lion for Lifetime Achievement at the Venice Film Festival, scheduled from Aug. 29 through Sept. 8, The Associated Press reported. Nights of Comedy Jackie Hoffman, Cory Kahaney, Jessica Kirson and Cathy Ladman will star in ''The J.A.P. Show, Jewish American Princesses of Comedy,'' a tribute to post-World War II female comics, including Pearl Williams, Belle Barth, Totie Fields and Jean Carroll. The Off Broadway show begins previews on April 4 and opens officially on April 18 at the Actors Temple Theater, 399 West 47th Street in Hell's Kitchen. Harriet Harris, Margaret Colin and Lily Rabe have been cast in the Roundabout Theater Company's Broadway revival of the John Van Druten's 1940 drawing-room comedy ''Old Acquaintance,'' directed by Michael Wilson. After previews starting on June 1, the show will open officially on June 28 for a limited run, through Aug. 19 at the American Airlines Theater. ''A Catered Affair,'' with a book by Harvey Fierstein and score by John Bucchino, set in the Bronx and based on the 1956 film written by Gore Vidal and adapted from a Paddy Chayefsky television play, will open on Broadway next spring at a theater to be named, Jujamcyn Theater has announced. John Doyle, who won a Tony Award for his staging of ''Sweeney Todd'' and is now represented on Broadway by ''Company,'' will direct. Footnotes The violinist Joshua Bell, below, has been named the recipient of the 2007 Avery Fisher Prize for achievement and excellence in music. He is to receive $75,000 on April 10 in ceremonies at Lincoln Center. The designers Santo Loquasto and Bob Mackie are to be honored today when the annual TDF/Irene Sharaff Awards are presented at a reception at the Hudson Theater. Mr. Loquasto, who has designed the sets or costumes for 58 Broadway productions, will receive the Robert L. B. Tobin Award for Lifetime Achievement in Theatrical Design, and the costume and fashion designer Mr. Mackie, a nine-time Emmy Award winner, will receive the TDF/Irene Sharaff Lifetime Achievement Award. The awards are named for the costume designer Irene Sharaff.

With the surprising news yesterday that Kentucky Coach Tubby Smith was headed to Minnesota, one of the big story lines before last night's game between Texas A&M and Memphis became whether A&M Coach Billy Gillispie would jump to Lexington, Ky. In talking to about a dozen people around Gillispie over the past three days, there was a strong feeling that he would consider the Kentucky job. Gillispie avoided a question about Kentucky with his typical homespun humility. ''I think you have to try and be happy where you are,'' he said. ''The best job that I've ever had is always the one I currently possess.''

All things must change, the Tao tells us. New York City's Asia Week is not exempt. When this early spring week of sales and shows was officially begun a dozen years ago, a brand-new International Asian Art Fair was its centerpiece. Installed at the Seventh Regiment Armory, it was a charismatic event. You went each year expecting to get your socks knocked off, and you weren't disappointed. European dealers like Gisèle Croës, John Eskenazi and Rossi & Rossi brought Chinese and South Asian objects so magnificent as to cast even the most masterly old masters of other fairs into the shade.

WHO -- Angela Williams, 41, a real estate broker in Atlanta WHAT -- 3-bedroom condominium WHERE -- Tybee Island, Ga. When I was a little girl, I would come to Tybee Island with my family. I'd count the palm trees as we'd drive across the bridges. And the minute we'd parked the car, I'd dash across the sand. I was always first to reach the shore. I'd bury my toes, pulling up sand dollars. This was a very special place to me. So, when the time came for my husband, Phillip, and I to look into buying a second home, my thoughts naturally turned to Tybee.

Family requests, in lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

The Neue Galerie's exhibition ''Van Gogh and Expressionism'' explores this Dutch artist's influence on German and Austrian artists, and offers some of the works that inspired them, including ''Fishing Boats on the Beach at Les Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer.'' Martha Schwendener's review, Page 30.

Pace/MacGill Gallery 32 East 57th Street, Manhattan Through March 31 When Paul Strand photographed something, it stayed photographed. His works from the 1910s may be among the pillars of early Modernist photography, but his later work, the subject of this rare exhibition, is nearly as powerful. The 38 images here bring Strand's characteristic sense of calm, respectful deliberation and rigor to potentially sentimental rural subjects.

Foreign Minister Taro Aso said ''yellow-faced'' Japanese could play a more constructive role in Middle East diplomacy than Americans. ''Japan is doing what Americans can't do,'' he said, according to the newspaper Nikkei. ''Japanese are trusted. If you have blue eyes and blond hair, it's probably no good.'' Mr. Aso is often mentioned as a successor to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. NORIMITSU ONISHI

JUDSON--Alan, on March 21, 2007. Beloved brother of David, Bennett Charles and the late Morris. Graduate of Dartmouth and Tuck Business School. Former member of The City Athletic Club. Service Sunday, 12 noon at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-On-Hudson, NY.

As Fox's ''American Idol'' narrowed its slate of contestants to 10 on Wednesday, Stephanie Edwards, below, did not make the cut. The 19-year-old singer from Savannah, Ga., received the fewest of the approximately 30 million votes cast after Tuesday's performances. The half-hour ''American Idol'' results show at 9 p.m. drew 26.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen estimates, about 1.4 million fewer than the same night a year ago. Among adults 18 to 49, the episode marked the 13th consecutive broadcast of ''American Idol'' that has fallen short in the ratings from year-to-year. Fox remained the night's leader over all, as a 9:30 episode of '' 'Til Death'' (14.6 million) helped the network round out the 9 p.m. hour on top. At 8, however, Fox's ''Bones'' (10.3 million) ranked second behind a special edition of CBS's ''Survivor: Fiji'' (12.7 million). CBS was No. 2 for the night behind Fox. ABC finished third, as ''Lost'' at 10 (12 million) earned its lowest ratings ever among adults 18 to 49. On CW, a solid ''America's Next Top Model'' (5 million) ranked third at 8 in the 18 to 49 demographic. BENJAMIN TOFF

A Palestinian was killed in Gaza City when members of his family, associated with Fatah, clashed with Hamas's Executive Force. Earlier, gunmen forced out the driver of a United Nations refugee agency car and made off with the vehicle. The driver, a local employee, was unharmed. A United Nations spokesman said agency cars would temporarily stay off Gaza's roads. ISABEL KERSHNER

The Brooklyn Public Library has a new executive director, Dionne Mack-Harvin, above, who is the first black woman to run a major public library system in the state, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Ms. Mack-Harvin, 34, has been interim executive director since June. She began her career with the Brooklyn system in 1996 as a librarian at the Crown Heights Library and has been a branch manager, regional librarian and chief administrator of the Central Library. DIANE CARDWELL
To the Editor: Re ''Atlantic City Aiming Higher as Casinos Slip'' (front page, March 19):

Some jazz record labels are fortunate enough to catch the spirit of a moment. Blue Note chronicled the arrival of hard bop in the 1950s; in the '60s it housed both soul jazz and the avant-garde. These days it's harder to say what's happening where, but a few labels do project the current dimensions of a style, or at least a scene. Cryptogramophone is one of these. Formed nine years ago in Los Angeles by the violinist Jeff Gauthier, the label demonstrates a preference for improvised music that's open-ended yet compositional, and usually string-instrument-based. It isn't really free jazz, though free-form playing is involved, and it's not fusion, though it's unimaginable without the precedent of Miles Davis's ''Bitches Brew.'' If that sounds like an indistinct definition for a subgenre, so much the better: one clear principle of Cryptogramophone is an aversion to definitions. But a recognizable aesthetic should prevail during Cryptonights, next week's festival of label-affiliated bands. Mr. Gauthier leads the charge on Monday night with his Goatette, featuring the guitarist Nels Cline and his brother, the drummer Alex Cline. Then the drummer Scott Amendola, above, presents a group with Nels Cline, the bassist John Shifflett and the violinist Jenny Scheinman. On Wednesday the pianist Myra Melford leads the scintillating quintet she calls Be Bread. And in a two-night run that starts on Thursday, Nels Cline revisits music from ''New Monastery,'' his fine recent tribute to the pianist Andrew Hill. (As it happens, Mr. Hill himself will perform elsewhere on Thursday afternoon; see jazz listings, below.) The festivities run through next weekend, when Cryptonights features the multireedist Benny Maupin, whose connection to the label goes further than a recent release: many years ago he took part in the sessions that yielded ''Bitches Brew.'' (Monday through April 1 at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, 212-576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $25.) NATE CHINEN

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the Sotheby's auction of antiquities from the collection of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo misstated Sotheby's commission on objects sold. It is 20 percent of the hammer price for the first $500,000 and 12 percent of the rest -- not 20 percent of the first $200,000 and 12 percent of the rest. (The commission was raised in January.)

An article on Saturday about appeals filed by companies that lost out in bidding for casino licenses in Pennsylvania misstated the number of slots-only casinos that are operating in the state. It is four, not three. (In addition to those in Wilkes-Barre, Bensalem and Chester, one is operating in Erie.)

COHEN--Selma. After a long illness and just prior to her 94th birthday, Selma passed away on the morning of March 21, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Harris (Harold), devoted mother of Richard and Paula, loving grandmother of Jonathan, Lisa and the late Harris and adored greatgrandmother of Jake and Benjamin. Her passions beyond family included her professional life as a self employed Interior Designer and Decorator for over 60 years and her love of and excellence in the world of Duplicate Bridge. Her determination and courage led her to overcome enormous obstacles after the premature death of her husband almost 50 years ago. Graveside service.

Around Town Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Central Park West and 79th Street. Monday night at 7:30, ''2007 Isaac Asimov Memorial Debate: Pioneer Anomaly,'' a discussion about the unmanned planetary probes launched in the 1970s; sold out, but tickets for live video projections in Kaufmann and Linder Theaters are $7; $6 for members, 60+ and students. Through May 28, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' a display with hundreds of butterflies in a re-creation of their natural habitat. Through Aug. 19, ''Gold,'' with coins, jewelry and other artifacts. Timed tickets to ''Gold'' and ''The Butterfly Conservatory,'' which include museum admission, are $21; $16 for students and 60+; $12 for 12 and younger. The architect Renzo Piano has withdrawn from a project to build an 80-story tower in Boston that would have involved the demolition of a 1960 building by Paul Rudolph, left, that is valued by preservationists, a spokeswoman for Mr. Piano said yesterday. The spokeswoman declined to give a reason for the architect's decision, but Mr. Piano said earlier this month that he was resisting pressure from the project's developer, Steven Belkin, to increase the width of the building. Mr. Piano also said at the time that if his project were to proceed, the 13-story Rudolph structure, also known as the Blue Cross/Blue Shield building, would have to be removed to make room for a plaza. Preservationists are battling to save the Rudolph building, whose somewhat ornate exterior ran counter to the then-prevailing Modernist preference for unornamented exterior glass walls. The Boston Landmarks Commission imposed a 90-day delay in the demolition of the Rudolph building on March 13, but Mr. Belkin said that the Boston firm CBT Architects intended to ''implement Piano's design, making appropriate refinements as needed during the design review process.'' DAVID HAY

Ben Howland showed Thursday night why coaches generally leave schools like Pittsburgh for schools like U.C.L.A. At Pittsburgh, a coach can attract above-average players, sell them on the value of defense and guide them to the Round of 16.

An article on Wednesday about violence in Iraq misspelled the surname of an American general who described a car bombing in which he said insurgents had used two children as decoys to deceive soldiers at a Baghdad checkpoint. He is Michael D. Barbero, not Barbaro.

A picture with a report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Wednesday about the winners of the 2007 Martin E. Segal awards, which recognize outstanding achievement by young artists, carried an erroneous credit, and a credit was omitted from another picture with the report. The photograph of the Daedalus Quartet was by Steve J. Sherman -- not by Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times. Mr. Ito took the picture of the mezzo-soprano Kate Lindsey.

A sports article on Monday about Connecticut's victory over Maryland-Baltimore County in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. women's basketball tournament misstated the year UConn last won the national championship. It was 2004, not 2003.

RONSON--Howard P., the International Chairman of the HRO Group, passed away surrounded by family and friends in Monaco on March 21, 2007. Born in London, England on May 28, 1943, Mr. Ronson graduated from Carmel College in England. In 1962, he joined his family's residential and commercial real estate firm. By the late 1960's, Mr. Ronson had begun to research commercial office development prospects in France. In partnership with the U.K.'s Chesterfield Properties, Plc he founded Chesterfield Ronson Europe, Limited, and became one of the first pan-European commercial developers active across France, Germany, Spain, the Netherlands, and the U.K. In the late 1970's, Mr. Ronsons keen eye for market opportunity took him to the United States where he started HRO International, Limited and quickly established himself among the most active and successful developers in New York City. During the following decade he built 11 large projects totaling over 550,000 m2. Seeing similar market opportunity in Europe in the mid 1990's, Mr. Ronson re-established HRO's presence in Paris bringing with him its well established high-tech capabilities. Again, demonstrating extraordinary market timing, HRO went on to develop 19 major projects, creating what are generally viewed as Europe's leading buildings in Paris, London and Frankfurt. The HRO Group is one of the leading privately held international commercial real estate development firms and a major force in both the European and American markets, having developed more than 1.5 million m2 of prime office property in 55 projects over the past four decades. The firm includes 30 partners and professional staff in Paris and New York, and will continue operating as it has, with the Ronson family. Mr. Ronson is known as a driven and intensely dedicated individual, who strove for excellence and professionalism. He earned numerous international industry awards for design, management and development excellence. Everyone who met him was drawn to his warm and clearly brilliant mind. Mr. Ronson's energy also extended to exceptional philanthropic endeavors. Envisioning the need for a top quality religious educational institution (Yeshiva) in the Tel Aviv-Jerusalem corridor, he conceived, built and nurtured the Genesis Center, a campus serving 150 Jewish students. He recently initiated construction of a new synagogue (Yakar) in Tel Aviv. Mr. Ronson is survived by his wife Angelika, their twin daughters Gisele and Livia, his stepson Stanley, his sister Benita, nieces Tanya and Ali, and nephew Oliver. A memorial service shall be held at the Millennium Hotel, in Grosvenor Square, London at 2 pm on Sunday March 25, 2007 followed by a burial service at 4 pm. In lieu of flowers or gifts donations may be made in Mr. Ronson's memory to a charity of choice. $(6$)RONSON--Howard. The governors, members, and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Howard Ronson, former REBNY governor and an active and generous REBNY member for 25 years. REBNY extends its sincere condolences to the entire Ronson family. Stephen M. Ross, Chairperson Steven Spinola, President
To the Editor: Re ''A Proper Distinction'' (column, March 22):

Foreign Minister Massimo D'Alema said he did not discuss with American officials the deal in which five Taliban prisoners were traded this week for the freedom of a kidnapped Italian reporter in Afghanistan. Despite strong criticism from officials in the United States and Europe, Mr. D'Alema told reporters in Rome, ''I am not the slightest bit repentant for having saved'' the reporter, Daniele Mastrogiacomo, adding that it ''is preferable to have a controversy over having saved him, rather than for having had him killed.'' IAN FISHER

An obituary yesterday about G. E. Patterson, the presiding bishop of the Church of God in Christ, misstated the relationship of some of his survivors. Mary Hawkins and Lee Ella Smith, both of Memphis, and Barbara Davis of Detroit are his sisters, not his daughters. The obituary also gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the name of the magazine of which he was editor and publisher. It is Bountiful Blessings Magazine, not Bountiful Blessing Magazine.

The marvelously zany installation artist Devorah Sperber recreates classics with a pizazz that breathes new life into familiar, even hackneyed images. Her latest exhibition, installed in a roomy mezzanine gallery at the Brooklyn Museum, applies this formula to paintings by Leonardo da Vinci, Picasso and Jan van Eyck, among others. This time the images are remade using thousands of spools of colored thread arranged in seemingly abstract patterns that suddenly pull into focus when viewed through a circular device resembling a crystal ball. There is a reproduction of Picasso's portrait of Gertrude Stein dressed in a suit and looking much like a man, made using 5,024 spools of thread, and a life-size re-creation of Leonardo's ''Last Supper'' made from 20,736 spools of thread. (Above, ''After the Mona Lisa 1,'' 2005). These works boggle the mind and entrance; they might even make you say ''wow.'' As much about art as about optics, they are hung upside down to account for the way the optical device, like the human eye, inverts imagery. From a few feet away, they look like fields of vague, pixilated color. But through the optical device, you see a perfect reproduction of the paintings. It's like magic. (Through May 6, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, 718-638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

To the Editor: ''Family Hearth Moves to the Backyard'' (news article, March 21) was a perfect metaphor for our wasteful society: throwing away thousands of dollars for something that burns increasingly scarce fuel, pollutes the environment and provides almost no benefit to the user.

The Ohio State freshman point guard Mike Conley Jr. and the freshman center Greg Oden were high school teammates and live together in student housing, but their lifestyles are as different as their personalities. The outgoing Conley said he often spends his free time playing video games like Madden 07 and March Madness 07.

(Former President of the Women's Division of the Toronto Real Estate Board, Retired Journalist Hamilton Herald Tribune and member of Grace Church on-the-Hill, Toronto), Peacefully at Kensington Gardens, Toronto, on Wednesday, March 21, 2007, in her 101st year. Elder daughter of the late Chas and Maude Heming of Hamilton, sister of Ruth Heming and of the late Paul and Basil. Widow of the late Wing Commander James L. Jackson (RAF and RCAF). Dear mother of Patricia Simpson of New York City, Thomas and Peter Hand of Toronto. Loving grandmother of Gillian, Sylvie, Kate, Rachel and David, and great-grandmother of Michael, William, Jock, Martin, Ben, Lucas and Nora. Fondly remembered by Susan and Richard. ''I'm absolutely ready for this. I mean, I don't look sickly, I don't feel sickly. And I'm as ready as any person can be for that.'' ELIZABETH EDWARDS, on her husband John's Democratic campaign for president, after they announced that she had incurable cancer. [A1]

Gering & López Gallery 730 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street Through April 28 When you think about artificial intelligence, Mark Rothko isn't the first name that comes to mind. But ''Field,'' the software-driven sculpture at the heart of Leo Villareal's third New York show, makes the leap. A computer code written by Mr. Villareal generates an autonomous system that illuminates thousands of colored LEDs, hidden behind a panel of opaque acrylic. Soft-edged shapes float on luminous grounds in sequences of pattern and palette that in theory never repeat.

The story of his coming to America with his family is at the heart of this musical, being given its world premiere by the Poppy Seed Players. The touring ensemble Revels Circle of Song will portray it in a musical history featuring Irish, Italian and Eastern European Jewish characters immigrating in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. At 3 p.m., Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street, (212) 534-1672, mcny.org. Free with suggested admission: $9; $5 for students and 62+; free for under 12; $20 for families. Presented by Theatreworks/USA, this musical adaptation of Lucy Maud Montgomery's 1908 novel about an intrepid young Canadian sent to live with a spinster and her brother begins previews tonight and opens on Thursday. (Through May 5.) Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., Sunday at 1 and 4 p.m., Tuesday through Thursday at 7 p.m., Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 279-4200; $25. CROSS-GENERATION CHESS (Sunday) The chessboard is common ground in this monthly program that brings together children from kindergarten through high school with elderly adults. Interested chess players -- of any level -- meet for games, live classical music, light refreshments and, most important, conversation. From 1 to 5 p.m., Sirovich Senior Center of the Educational Alliance, 331 East 12th Street, East Village; free. Registration: (917) 822-3141 or crossgeneration@aol.com 'THE FURTHER ADVENTURES OF UNCLE WIGGILY: WINDBLOWN VISITORS' (Tonight through Sunday) In this new musical, Uncle Wiggily, the elderly rabbit who helped young animals in the stories by Howard R. Garis, is protector of a child: Merilee, who ends up in New York after her home is devastated by Hurricane Katrina. Tonight at 8, tomorrow and Sunday at 3 p.m., Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 254-1109; $12; $5 for 12 and under. 'THE GAME BOY' (Tomorrow and Sunday) This new musical from Vital Children's Theater is about a boy, Chase, who is so wrapped up in his favorite video games that he starts to neglect the real world outside the screen. Sound familiar? (Through April 22.) At 11 a.m. and 1 p.m., the McGinn/Cazale Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street, fourth floor, (212) 352-3101; $18. 'THE GAZILLION BUBBLE SHOW' (Tonight through Sunday) Children love bubbles, and Fan Yang, in his interactive show, promises not just a gazillion, but also some of the largest ever blown (he holds the world record), along with light effects and lasers. (Through Sept 2.) Tonight at 7:30, tomorrow at 2 and 7:30 p.m. and Sunday at 3 and 7 p.m., New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200; $34.95 to $45. 'JABBERWOCKY' (Sunday) What a brillig, or brilliant, idea: Tales & Scales, the quartet combining music and storytelling, is presenting an updated version of its dramatization of Lewis Carroll's famous nonsense poem about that mythical creature, the Jabberwock. O frabjous day! At 4 p.m., Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, 58 Seventh Avenue, at Lincoln Place, Park Slope, (718) 622-3300; $10; $5 for students and 65+. 'A KID'S LIFE: THE MUSICAL' (Sunday) The kid's life here may not be quite familiar to New Yorkers: Zack, 5, lives in a town, which he explores with his dog and his friend Zoe. But there are elements that might be associated with a city that never sleeps: an owl and a talking clock. MILKSHAKE (Tomorrow) This is the kind you taste with your ears. A band for young rockers (3 and older), Milkshake will offer songs from a CD whose title continues the sweet theme: ''Bottle of Sunshine.'' 'MACBETH: THAT OLD BLACK MAGIC' (Tonight) Shakespeare and Sinatra may seem a rather unlikely combination, but leave it to the Scots to make ''Macbeth'' work in a new context. This production is from the Gordonstoun School near Elgin, Scotland (Prince Charles is an alumnus) and will feature its teenage students and a live band performing Sinatra songs as commentary on the play. Young drumming enthusiasts (and what child isn't one?) are encouraged to arrive at 10:30 and make their own instruments for the concert at 11. WOMEN'S HISTORY MONTH GARMENT FACTORY WORKSHOP (Sunday) Experience what it was like for early immigrants to work in a clothing factory -- except have a lot of fun. Two men have been arrested and charged with killing a bodega owner during a robbery five months ago, Hudson County officials said. Fidelina A. Claros, 47, the owner of the G & P deli and grocery, was shot twice in the head and once in the back during the robbery, on Oct. 30, prosecutors said. The men, Richard Salcedo, 25 and Antwan Shannon, 41, both of Jersey City, were charged with murder, said Hudson County Prosecutor Edward J. De Fazio. JOHN HOLL

It's hard enough to teach little humans to sit still, follow directions and calmly accept vaccinations; how difficult is it when those who are learning are even wilder types, like Stella, Beebe and Alexis? They're sea lions at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, and with fellow residents -- meerkats, cotton-top tamarins and alpacas -- they're among the stars of Keeping Up With Keepers Weekend. The other stars, of course, are zookeepers. ''It's everything you've always wanted to know about being a zookeeper but were afraid to ask,'' said Patricia Cole, the zoo's assistant director and curator of animals. Tomorrow and Sunday the staff members will demonstrate training techniques and present their furry charges with enrichment: treats that stimulate intelligence by requiring ingenuity. At 11 a.m. the meerkats will go after grubs concealed in paper bags. (Yum.) At 2:30 p.m. the tamarins, a type of monkey, will receive cricket rocks, stones drilled with holes and filled with insects. ''They're like time-release cricket cookies,'' Ms. Cole said. The training, while fun to watch, is not solely entertainment. The object of teaching ''targeting'' (following a stick with a rubber ball at the end) and ''stationing'' (remaining on a colored tile), is to make the animals easier to transport and examine. The meerkats are trained to go into crates, while the tamarins learn to step onto scales. At 3 p.m. visitors will see how alpacas (the zoo's are Pukara, left, and Loki) get used to halters. And at 11:45 a.m. and 2 and 4 p.m., the sea lions go through their paces. ''Every sea lion gets its mouth and eyes looked at daily,'' Ms. Cole said, ''and we'll ask them to show us their flippers.'' Teaching them to take shots is dicier. ''You go through many days of poking them with your finger,'' she explained. Children at the event can also go on scavenger hunts, see puppet shows, make crafts and even feed and pet Pukara and Loki. ''They're very cute,'' Ms. Cole said. ''Except when they spit.'' (Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m, 450 Flatbush Avenue, Prospect Park, Brooklyn, 718-399-7339, prospectparkzoo.com. Free with admission: $6; $2.25 for 65+; $2 for 3 to 12; free for under 3.) LAUREL GRAEBER

BRONFMAN--Naum. The loss of husband, father and grandfather Naum Bronfman is mourned by his loving family members Polina, Elizabeth, Yefim, Yael, Daniel and many other relatives and friends both in the United States and Israel. Mr. Bronfman died at the age of 95 on Tuesday morning, March 20, 2007. He is greatly missed by all whose lives he touched. A memorial service was held for Mr. Bronfman on Thursday, March 22, 2007 at 11:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, in Manhattan.

Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition. Theater Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater. Previews and Openings 'THE ACCOMPLICES' In previews; opens on April 9. The New Group presents a play by Bernard Weinraub, a former reporter for The New York Times. Based on historical events, it is about an activist who seeks American help during World War II to rescue European Jews from the Nazis (2:00). Acorn Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. 'ALL THE WRONG REASONS: A TRUE STORY OF NEO-NAZIS, DRUG SMUGGLING AND UNDYING LOVE' Previews start today. Opens on April 15. John Fugelsang is the son of an ex-nun and a former Franciscan brother. He tells his story in this solo show. New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 460-5475. 'BLACKBIRD' In previews; opens on April 10. Jeff Daniels stars in the United States premiere of this provocative play about a man coming to terms with a troubling relationship from his past. Joe Mantello directs (1:30). Manhattan Theater Club at City Center Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. 'ESSENTIAL SELF-DEFENSE' In previews; opens on Wednesday. Romance blooms in the new Adam Rapp play about a man who signs up to be an attack dummy (2:15). Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. 'EXITS AND ENTRANCES' Previews start on Tuesday. Opens on April 4. Athol Fugard's new autobiographical play is about a friendship between a young man and an older actor (1:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200. 'FACE THE MUSIC' Performances start on Thursday. Closes on April 1. Encores! presents this Moss Hart-Irving Berlin musical about a desperate Broadway producer looking to raise some money for a new revue (2:20). City Center, Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. 'INHERIT THE WIND' In previews; opens on April 12. This revival of the classic courtroom drama based on the famous ''monkey trial'' stars a lineup of heavy-hitters: Brian Dennehy, Christopher Plummer, Denis O'Hare and Byron Jennings (2:00). Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. 'A MOON FOR THE MISBEGOTTEN' Previews start on Thursday. Opens on April 9. Kevin Spacey and Eve Best star in the London transfer of this Eugene O'Neill classic. Howard Davies directs (3:00). Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, (212) 307-4100. 'OLIVER TWIST' Previews start on Thursday. Opens on April 1. Ned Eisenberg plays Fagin in the United States premiere of this adaptation of Dickens's novel (2:30). Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, 899 10th Avenue, at 58th Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. 'THE PIRATE QUEEN' In previews; opens on April 5. A new musical from the ''Les Misérables'' team, about a 16th-century swashbuckler (2:30). Hilton Theater, 213 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100. 'SOME MEN' In previews; opens on Monday. Terrence McNally's episodic drama about gay life darts through history after kicking off with a marriage ceremony (2:00). Second Stage, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422. 'THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING' In previews; opens on Thursday. Vanessa Redgrave stars in this adaptation of Joan Didion's heartbreaking memoir. David Hare directs (1:40). Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Broadway 'A CHORUS LINE' If you want to know why this show was such a big deal when it opened 31 years ago, you need only experience the thrilling first five minutes of this revival. Otherwise, this archivally exact production, directed by Bob Avian, feels like a vintage car that has been taken out of the garage, polished up and sent on the road once again (2:00). Schoenfeld Theater, 236 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Ben Brantley) * 'THE COAST OF UTOPIA' Lincoln Center Theater's brave, gorgeous, sprawling and ultimately exhilarating production of Tom Stoppard's trilogy about intellectuals errant in 19th-century Russia. A testament to the seductive powers of narrative theater, directed with hot and cool canniness by Jack O'Brien and featuring a starry cast (Brian F. O'Byrne, Jennifer Ehle, Martha Plimpton, Josh Hamilton and Ethan Hawke, among others) in a tasty assortment of roles. Vivian Beaumont Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'COMPANY' Fire, beckoning and dangerous, flickers beneath the frost of John Doyle's elegant, unexpectedly stirring revival of Stephen Sondheim and George Furth's era-defining musical from 1970, starring a compellingly understated Raúl Esparza. Like Mr. Doyle's ''Sweeney Todd,'' this production finds new clarity of feeling in Sondheim by melding the roles of performers and musicians (2:20). Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE DROWSY CHAPERONE' (Tony Awards, best book of a musical and best original score, 2006) This small and ingratiating spoof of 1920s stage frolics, as imagined by an obsessive show queen, may not be a masterpiece. But in a dry season for musicals, it has theatergoers responding as if they were withering houseplants finally being watered after long neglect. (1:40). Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 45th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) * 'GREY GARDENS' Christine Ebersole is absolutely glorious as the middle-aged, time-warped debutante called Little Edie Beale in this uneven musical adaptation of the notorious 1975 documentary of the same title. She and the wonderful Mary Louise Wilson (as her bedridden mother), in the performances of their careers, make ''Grey Gardens'' an experience no passionate theatergoer should miss (2:40). Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'JOURNEY'S END' A splendid revival of R. C. Sherriff's 1928 drama of life in the trenches during World War I. Acutely staged (by David Grindley) and acted by a fine ensemble led by Hugh Dancy and Boyd Gaines, this production offers an exemplary presentation of that theatrical rarity, an uncompromising, clear-eyed play about war and the experience of day-to-day combat. An essential ticket (2:40). Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'MARY POPPINS' This handsome, homily-packed, mechanically ingenious and rather tedious musical, adapted from the P. L. Travers stories and the 1964 film, is ultimately less concerned with inexplicable magic than with practical psychology. Ashley Brown, who sings prettily as the family-mending nanny, looks like Joan Crawford trying to be nice and sounds like Dr. Phil. (2:30). New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley) 'LES MISÉRABLES' This premature revival, a slightly scaled-down version of the well-groomed behemoth that closed only three years ago, appears to be functioning in a state of mild sedation. Appealingly sung and freshly orchestrated, this fast-moving adaptation of Victor Hugo's novel isn't sloppy or blurry. But its pulse rate stays well below normal (2:55). Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'PRELUDE TO A KISS' Craig Lucas's broken-hearted romantic comedy from 1990 receives a first-rate remounting, courtesy of the Roundabout Theater Company. Alan Tudyk and Annie Parisse play a young couple whose marriage founders shortly after the bride receives a kiss from an elderly stranger (John Mahoney). The kiss awakens all three to an unsettling awareness of love's frailty and, paradoxically, of its durability too (2:00). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300. (Charles Isherwood) * 'SPRING AWAKENING' Duncan Sheik and Steven Sater's bold adaptation of the Frank Wedekind play is the freshest and most exciting new musical Broadway has seen in some time. Set in 19th-century Germany but with a ravishing rock score, it exposes the splintered emotional lives of adolescents just discovering the joys and sorrows of sex. Performed with brio by a great cast, with supple direction by Michael Mayer and inventive choreography by Bill T. Jones (2:00). Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) * 'TALK RADIO' The most lacerating portrait of a human meltdown this side of a Francis Bacon painting. Playing an abrasive radio talk show host with a God complex, the astounding Liev Schreiber seems to fill the air as inescapably as weather in Robert Falls's gut-grabbing revival of Eric Bogosian's 1987 play (1:40). Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'TRANSLATIONS' The estimable Irish director Garry Hynes (a Tony winner for Martin McDonagh's ''Beauty Queen of Leenane'') has assembled an ensemble of an extraordinarily high caliber and consistency for the third major New York production of Brian Friel's 1980 play. Set in Ireland in 1833, as the local tongue is being supplanted by the language of the English occupying forces, the play explores the seriocomic truth that language can divide as easily as it unites, and can never hope to translate the rich music in our souls with the delicacy we yearn for. A top-flight Broadway revival (2:15). Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) Off Broadway 'BILL W. AND DR. BOB' This insightful new play about the founders of Alcoholics Anonymous subtly makes the claim that the recovery movement was born as a series of accidents. Patrick Husted is excellent as Bob Smith, Bill Wilson's partner in combating addictions (2:15). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Ginia Bellafante) 'BLINDNESS' Joe Tantalo's adaptation of José Saramago's best-selling novel, about an unnamed city struck with an inexplicable epidemic of ''white blindness,'' is set in a cell-like space surrounded by white scrim. This setting and the mostly strong acting drive home the fearful basic circumstances. Unfortunately, the script also streamlines Mr. Saramago's reflective story to the point of draining it of moral complexity (1:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200. (Jonathan Kalb) 'THE CAVE DWELLERS' This revival of William Saroyan's 1957 play about a group of misfits inhabiting an abandoned theater examines the virtue of charity and the nobility of failure but feels as stifling and constricted as the building in which the outcasts find themselves. A production that asks us to revere the theater without inviting reverence itself (1:30). Pearl Theater, 80 St. Marks Place, East Village, (212) 598-9802.
