(Bellafante) 'CHICKEN' Michael Batistick's new play about cock fighting and emasculation could benefit from subtler metaphors but manages to touch us gently even as it deploys a heavy hammer. E J Carroll, Michael Imperioli and his ''Sopranos'' castmate Sharon Angela give fine performances as struggling urban nobodies (1:45). Studio Dante, 257 West 29th Street, Chelsea, (212) 868-4444. (Bellafante) (1:45) 'DEFENDER OF THE FAITH' This grim tale by Stuart Carolan of low-level I.R.A. agitators trying to identify the informer in their midst features some visceral performances and a set by Charles Corcoran that makes excellent use of the Irish Rep's small stage. If only the cause itself didn't feel so small in these days of global terrorism (1:30). Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2737. (Neil Genzlinger) 'THE DIRECTOR' A likable if naïve young woman, who is seduced by an unnamed, unseen and presumably unscrupulous film director, seeks other of his victims and tape records their experiences for no clear purpose in a play that has no clear idea of what it wants to say (1:30). Flea Theater, 41 White Street, between Broadway and Church Street, TriBeCa, (212) 352-3101. (Wilborn Hampton) * 'DYING CITY' Christopher Shinn's crafty and unsettling play about grief and violence, set in the shadow of the Iraq war. Directed by James Macdonald and fiercely acted by Pablo Schreiber and Rebecca Brooksher, this quiet, transfixing production turns passive aggression into a theatrical dynamic. (1:30). Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-7600. (Brantley) 'THE FANTASTICKS' A revival -- well, more like a resuscitation -- of the Little Musical That Wouldn't Die. This sweet-as-ever production of Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt's commedia-dell'arte-style confection is most notable for Mr. Jones's touching performance (under the pseudonym Thomas Bruce) as the Old Actor, a role he created when the show opened in 1960. Mr. Jones also directs (2:05). Snapple Theater Center, 210 West 50th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'GUTENBERG! THE MUSICAL' A very funny if not terribly original satire of musical theater features what must be the worst backers' audition of all time. (2:05). Actors' Playhouse, 100 Seventh Avenue South, at Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 239-6200. (Jason Zinoman) * 'IN THE HEIGHTS' Lin-Manuel Miranda's joyous songs paint a vibrant portrait of daily life in Washington Heights in this flawed but enjoyable show. Essentially a valentine to the barrio -- conflict of a violent or desperate kind is banished from the picture -- the musical contains a host of vibrant, funny performances and brings the zesty sound of Latin pop to the stage. (2:10). 37 Arts, 450 West 37th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Isherwood) * 'JACK GOES BOATING' Bob Glaudini's gentle comedy about pothead losers in love is a reminder of how engrossing uneventful lives can be in the hands of the right actors. Peter DuBois directs the easygoing ensemble, brilliantly led by Philip Seymour Hoffman (2:00). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555. (Brantley) * 'KING HEDLEY II' The Signature Theater Company concludes its season dedicated to August Wilson with a gritty, strongly cast revival of this play set in a violence-ravaged Pittsburgh in the 1980s. Russell Hornsby gives a galvanizing performance in the title role, as a man struggling to live down the errors of his past and plant the seeds for a promising new life (2:45). Peter Norton Space, 555 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529. (Isherwood) 'LOS ANGELES' Julian Sheppard's play about a gamin lost in a Hollywood of aimlessness and empty sex is as thin as the slip dress she keeps wearing and, presumably, taking off (1:20). Flea Theater, 41 White Street, between Broadway and Church Street, TriBeCa, (212) 352-3101. (Bellafante) 'MY TRIP TO AL-QAEDA' Lawrence Wright, author of a deeply researched book about the rise of Islamic terrorism, conducts a theatrical seminar about the events leading to the horror of 9/11. He combines a linear narrative of the development of Al Qaeda with reminiscences about the experience of writing the book. Absorbing, and chilling too (1:30). Culture Project, 55 Mercer Street, at Broome Street, SoHo, (212) 352-3101. (Isherwood) 'NO CHILD' Teachers will love Nilaja Sun's one-woman show about the challenges of teaching drama at Malcolm X High School (1:10). Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 239-6200. (Anita Gates) 'ROOM SERVICE' The Peccadillo Theater Company puts a charge into this comedy from the 1930s, thanks to a brisk pace by the director, Dan Wackerman, and a dozen dandy performances. David Edwards is the would-be producer whose bills threaten to swamp his efforts to put a show on Broadway, and Fred Berman is particularly fine as his director (2:00). SoHo Playhouse, 15 Vandam Street, South Village, (212) 691-1555. (Genzlinger) * 'SPALDING GRAY: STORIES LEFT TO TELL' A disarming collage of selections from the monologues and journals of Mr. Gray, the ultimate stand-up solipsist, who died in 2004. Directed by Lucy Sexton, and read by five performers, none of whom resemble Mr. Gray, with an affection that shrewdly stops short of hero worship (1:30). Minetta Lane Theater, 18 Minetta Lane, Greenwich Village, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'TALL GRASS' Brian Harris's three short plays, black farces all, are not nearly as slight as any sound-bite synopsis would have them seem. Here Harris, a former stock analyst, explores the alliances formed between love and brutality in scenarios in which the tension builds to culminating shock (1:30). The Beckett Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200 (Bellafante) * 'THE TAMING OF THE SHREW' AND 'TWELFTH NIGHT' In these boisterous and inventive productions, from the London-based all-male Propeller Company, the poetry may be pretty, but the comedy definitely is not. The director Edward Hall uncovers the baleful underbelly in Shakespearean slapstick, memorably demonstrating that boys will be brutes. (Each is 2:40.) Harvey Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. (Brantley) 'TEA AND SYMPATHY' The specter of the Ted Haggard scandal hangs over the Keen Company's revival of Robert Anderson's 1953 play about life in a psychologically stifling boys' boarding school. Girded by Jonathan Silverstein's skillful, understated direction, the play attains an unexpected timeliness as it evolves into a story about the dangers of sexual repression (2:00). Clurman Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. (Bellafante) * 'WAKE UP MR. SLEEPY! YOUR UNCONSCIOUS MIND IS DEAD!' Richard Foreman's latest film-theater hybrid is a memorial service, of sorts, for the intuitive self, killed by a surface-worshiping world. It is also a dazzling exercise in reality shifting that is as invigorating as it is mournful (1:05). Ontological Theater at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101. (Brantley) 'THE WAITING ROOM' An amusing play about some uncomfortable truths a group of friends and relatives faces while sitting in a hospital waiting room. While it has its share of laughs, it has things to say about the importance of family, even those members you might wish were not a part of it (2:00). 45th Street Theater, 354 West 45th Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. (Hampton) 'WIDOWERS' HOUSES' An adaptation of George Bernard Shaw's play, updated to 1990s Harlem, tests the limits of credibility (1:40). Kirk Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. (Zinoman) Off Off Broadway 'JACKIE WITH A Z' Delectably outrageous (1:30). Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555. (Lawrence Van Gelder) 'MEN OF STEEL' This darkly comic twist on super heroes is a loony guilty pleasure (2:00). Center Stage, 48 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-3101. (Zinoman) 'THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE' A joyful treat (1:30). JCC in Manhattan, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, (212) 279-4200. (Van Gelder) Long-Running Shows 'ALTAR BOYZ' This sweetly satirical show about a Christian pop group made up of five potential Teen People cover boys is an enjoyable, silly diversion (1:30). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) 'AVENUE Q' R-rated puppets give lively life lessons (2:10). Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'BEAUTY AND THE BEAST' Cartoon made flesh, sort of (2:30). Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley) 'CHICAGO' Irrefutable proof that crime pays (2:25). Ambassador Theater, 219 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE COLOR PURPLE' Singing CliffsNotes for Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel (2:40). Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'HAIRSPRAY' Fizzy pop, cute kids, large man in a housedress (2:30). Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52nd Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'JERSEY BOYS' The biomusical that walks like a man (2:30). August Wilson Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE LION KING' Disney on safari, where the big bucks roam (2:45). Minskoff Theater, 200 West 45th Street at Broadway, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'MAMMA MIA!' The jukebox that devoured Broadway (2:20). Cadillac Winter Garden Theater, 1634 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA' Who was that masked man, anyway? (2:30). Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE PRODUCERS' The ne plus ultra of showbiz scams (2:45). St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'RENT' East Village angst and love songs to die for (2:45). Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) 'SPAMALOT' A singing scrapbook for Monty Python fans (2:20). Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE' ''A Chorus Line'' with pimples (1:45). Circle in the Square, 254 West 50th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) 'WICKED' Oz revisited, with political corrections (2:45). Gershwin Theater, 222 West 51st Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) Last Chance 'THE ATTIC' The playwright Yoji Sakate looks at hikikomori, the Japanese phenomenon in which teenagers retreat from society, isolating themselves for weeks, months and sometimes even years. With a deft ensemble cast, the results are illuminating, original and darkly funny. 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200; closes on Sunday. (Bellafante) 'BAAL' The director Charmian Creagle's bright idea for staging Bertolt Brecht's often offensive first play -- about a poet and singer who is a monster of appetite -- was to cast the title role as a woman. The production is so poorly acted and drearily directed, however, that the casting does nothing to illuminate the play or open a meaningful inquiry into habitual reactions to it (2:15). Looking Glass Theater, 422 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 307-9467; closes on Sunday. (Kalb) 'KING LEAR' Or ''Lear Lite,'' featuring New Age music; eye-soothing, color-coordinated costumes; and the charming Kevin Kline in the title role. Directed by James Lapine, this is a whimsical story-book production that feels perversely out of touch with the soul-wrenching depths of Shakespeare's most devastating tragedy (3:00). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555; closes on Sunday. (Brantley) 'THE MADRAS HOUSE' A century-old drama about ''the woman question,'' this rare revival of Harley Granville Barker's fascinating play is more contemporary than you might think (2:30). Mint Theater, 311 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 315-0231; closes on Sunday. (Zinoman) 'MARY ROSE' J. M. Barrie wrote this distaff variation on themes from ''Peter Pan'' in 1920, and it has mostly lain on the shelf since. A young English girl (an exuberant Paige Howard) acquires the odd habit of disappearing and reappearing some time later, untouched by time's passing. Gentle and melancholy, handsomely mounted by Tina Landau, ''Mary Rose'' is nonetheless itself touched by the mark of time (1:45). Vineyard Theater, 108 East 15th Street, (212) 353-0303; closes on Sunday. (Isherwood) 'MOBY DICK -- REHEARSED' A gripping revival of Orson Welles's 1955 adaptation of Melville's classic (2:00). Richmond Shepard Theater, 309 East 26th Street, (212) 868-4444; closes on Sunday. (Zinoman) 'PARTICULARLY IN THE HEARTLAND' You can almost feel the self-congratulation in the hearts and minds of the writers and performers of this surrealist ensemble piece as they try to understand how the Red states think and live. The results? A well-intentioned mess of emoting over the current political divides (1:30). Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101); closes on Sunday. (Bellafante) * 'THE VOYSEY INHERITANCE' David Mamet has cleanly and cannily adapted Harley Granville Barker's 1905 play about corruption in the genteel world of Victorian finance. An excellent cast and a sumptuous production bring extra immediacy to a tale of embezzlement and entitlement that feels as fresh as tomorrow's stock options (1:50). Atlantic Theater, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 239-6200; closes on Sunday. (Isherwood) Movies Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/movies. 'AMAZING GRACE' (PG, 120 minutes) Michael Apted's prettified take on the life and times of the 18th-century reformer William Wilberforce carries a strong whiff of piety but is generally pleasing and often moving, and features fine performances from newcomers and veterans alike. (Manohla Dargis) * 'BEHIND THE MASK: THE RISE OF LESLIE VERNON' (R, 92 minutes) Scott Glosserman's mockumentary about a celebrity-seeking serial killer is sustained by rapier-sharp observations and a firmer grasp of tone than that in many more generously financed projects. Appealing more to the brain than the gut, the movie subtly prods at the sick dance between the news media and über-criminals without belaboring its point or lowering its tone. If Christopher Guest ever turned his attention to psycho killers instead of folk singers and dog breeders, this is exactly the sort of movie he would make. (Jeannette Catsoulis) 'BLACK SNAKE MOAN' (R, 116 minutes) Christina Ricci as a Tennessee nymphomaniac and Samuel Jackson as the blues singer who tries to cure her by fastening her half-naked self to his radiator with a chain. In spite of that summary, it's mostly corny uplift, from Craig Brewer, who also wrote and directed the down-home pimp fairy tale ''Hustle & Flow.'' (A.O. Scott) 'BLOCKADE' and 'AMATEUR PHOTOGRAPHER' (No rating, 78 minutes total running time) Two short movies assembled from archival material explore the siege of Leningrad and the eastern front during World War II. (Stephen Holden) 'BREACH' (PG-13, 110 minutes) In his fine, no-nonsense account of the capture of the F.B.I. agent-turned-mole Robert Philip Hanssen, the director Billy Ray manages to excite and unnerve despite our knowing the ending. Chris Cooper and Ryan Phillippe star. (Dargis) * 'BRIDGE TO TERABITHIA' (PG, 95 minutes) Grounded more in reality than in fantasy, this adaptation of Katherine Paterson's novel offers an affecting story of a transformative friendship between two gifted children. Beautifully capturing a time when a bully in school can loom as large as a troll in a nightmare, the director, Gabor Csupo, keeps the fantasy in the background to find magic in the everyday. (Catsoulis) 'A JOURNEY OF DMITRY SHOSTAKOVICH' (No rating, 75 minutes) A documentary grab bag of film clips, diary readings and desultory narration, ''A Journey of Dmitry Shostakovich'' peeks at the politics of this controversial composer through a flurry of archival curiosities. But in their struggle to portray a man compromising his art to save his life, the directors, Oksana Dvornichenko and Helga Landauer, adopt a scattershot approach that's ultimately as ambiguous and impenetrable as its subject. (Catsoulis) 'DEAD SILENCE' (R, 90 minutes) In this new film from the makers of the ''Saw'' series, a young man (Ryan Kwanten) whose wife was murdered by a demonic ventriloquist's dummy returns to his hometown to unravel the roots of a century-old curse. The film's playfully self-aware touches (like a grand old theater named the Guignol) distract from its leaden pacing, three too many final twists and various behavioral idiocies. (Matt Zoller Seitz) 'EXTERMINATING ANGELS' (No rating, 100 minutes, in French) The French director Jean-Claude Brisseau's film is a piece of highbrow smut about a French filmmaker directing a piece of highbrow smut. A must for fans of highbrow smut. No complaints here. (Scott) * 'THE HOST' (R, 119 minutes, in Korean) A loopy, feverishly imaginative genre hybrid -- part carnival of horrors, part family melodrama -- about the demons that haunt us from without and within. The talented South Korean filmmaker Bong Joon-ho directs his monster and humans with equal flair. (Dargis) 'I THINK I LOVE MY WIFE' (R, 94 minutes) An unusually smart and brisk comedy of marital frustration and sexual temptation, based on Eric Rohmer's ''Chloe in the Afternoon,'' with Chris Rock (who directed and is co-author of the script) as a Manhattan investment banker distracted by the charms of a bombshell played by the wonderful Kerry Washington. (Scott) * 'INTO GREAT SILENCE' (No rating, 162 minutes, in English and Latin) Philip Gröning's documentary about the lives of Carthusian monks living in a valley in the French Alps is slow, quiet and utterly spellbinding for the way it conveys the experience of spiritual devotion in simple, lovely images. (Scott) 'MUSIC AND LYRICS' (PG-13, 96 minutes) Drew Barrymore and Hugh Grant phone in passable impersonations of themselves in this competent romantic comedy, which is somewhat enlivened by parodies of bad pop songs from both the 1980s and the present. (Scott) 'NORBIT' (PG-13, 97 minutes) Eddie Murphy plays a nebbish, a fat woman and a Chinese restaurant owner in this crude, sometimes mean, but often funny farce. (Scott) 'THE NAMESAKE' (PG-13, 122 minutes) Color is the stuff of life in the movies of Mira Nair, the Indian-born director whose newest film, adapted from Jhumpa Lahiri's popular novel, follows two generations of a Bengali family from late-1970s Calcutta to New York City. Her lush palette lends her films a throbbing physicality that invites you to step into the screen and embrace the sensuous here and now. (Holden) NOMAD: THE WARRIOR' (R, 111 minutes) This epic adventure film from Kazakhstan is about attempts to unify that country in the 18th century, but it sure does look like an old-fashioned American western. A reasonably good western, all things considered, despite a formulaic plot and a high cliché count in the dialogue. Horses, horses, horses, dazzlingly handled. (Neil Genzlinger) 'THE NUMBER 23' (R, 95 minutes) An accidental comedy starring a deadly serious Jim Carrey that owes something to David Fincher, a little something else to Robert Anton Wilson and next to nothing, at least intentionally, to the gods of laughter, be they Gelus (Greek) or Jerry Lewis (American). (Dargis) 'PREMONITION' (PG-13, 97 minutes) This sloppy, absent-minded psychological thriller scrambles time in the life of a desperate housewife (Sandra Bullock) whose husband is dead one day, alive the next. (Holden) 'STARTER FOR TEN' (PG-13, 96 minutes) This amiable, nostalgic British comedy tackles a lofty subject -- the allure of knowledge --with down-to-earth charm, following a working-class kid (James McAvoy) during his first year at Bristol University and an appearance on the TV quiz show ''University Challenge.'' But beneath the formulaic embarrassments and fumbled learning curve lurks a more somber theme: the inevitable rupture between those who pursue an education and those left behind. (Catsoulis) '300' (R, 116 minutes) Greeks versus Persians in the big rumble at Thermopylae, via Frank Miller's graphic novel. As dumb as they get. (Scott) 'WILD HOGS' (PG-13, 100 minutes) Tame slop. (Scott) * 'THE WIND THAT SHAKES THE BARLEY' (No rating, 127 minutes) Stringent, serious history from Ken Loach, in which the Irish uprising and Civil War of the early 1920s test the loyalties and consciences of two brothers, played by Cillian Murphy and Padraic Delany. (Scott) * 'ZODIAC' (R, 158 minutes) David Fincher's magnificently obsessive new film tracks the story of the serial killer who left dead bodies up and down California in the 1960s and possibly the '70s, and that of the men who tried to stop him. Set when the Age of Aquarius disappeared into the black hole of the Manson family murders, ''Zodiac'' is part police procedural, part monster movie, a funereal entertainment that is a testament to this cinematic savant's gifts. (Dargis) Film Series FASHION IN FILM FESTIVAL (Tomorrow and Sunday) A series devoted to the art and business of fashion concludes this weekend at the Museum of the Moving Image. Tomorrow Frederick Wiseman's cinéma-verité study ''Model'' (1980) is followed by ''Assuming a Pose,'' a program of European and American newsreels that is spiced up with Kenneth Anger's ravishing avant-garde film ''Puce Moment.'' The day concludes with Elsa Kvamme's 1999 documentary, ''Lady With a Hat,'' about the Jewish hatmaker and World War II hero May Aubert. Sunday starts with a pair of fiction films from Europe -- Vera Chytilova's Czech project ''Ceiling'' (1962) and William Klein's ''Who Are You, Polly Magoo?,'' filmed in Paris in 1966 -- and then moves on to two documentaries, Bruce Weber's ''Chop Suey'' (2001) and Douglas Keeve's ''Unzipped'' (1995), and finishes up with David Byrne's 1986 phantasmagoria of American life, ''True Stories.'' Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718) 784-0077, movingimage.us; $10. (Dave Kehr) FRENCH SEVENTIES: CINEMA AFTER MAY '68 (Tonight through Tuesday) A rich series of films influenced by the political upheavals in France in May 1968 concludes this week with three major titles. Tonight at 7 there's a rare screening of Ariane Mnouchkine's 1978 ''Molière,'' an epic, 260-minute study of the great French comic playwright as staged by one of the leading theater directors of the 1970s and starring Philippe Caubère. Tuesday brings two weighty films for the strong of heart: Jacques Rivette's 1982 ''Le Pont du Nord,'' in which a '60s radical (Bulle Ogier) is released from prison into an unrecognizable 1980s Paris, and Jean Eustache's essential 1973 work ''La Maman et la Putain'' (''The Mother and the Whore''), in which the New Wave aesthetic reaches some sort of terminal point, as Jean-Pierre Léaud, Bernadette Lafont and Françoise Lebrun discuss the intricacies of male-female relationships for 215 fascinating minutes. French Institute Alliance Française, Tinker Auditorium, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 355-6100, fiaf.org; $9. (Kehr) VERDICT ON AUSCHWITZ: THE FRANKFURT AUSCHWITZ TRIAL 1963-1965 (Sunday and Tuesday) As their camera roams the now empty modern courtroom where the Auschwitz trial look place, the German filmmakers Rolf Bickel and Dietrich Wagner make use of audiotapes recorded during the trial to make the voices of survivors and executioners heard again. Originally a German television program in three parts, it will be shown as a continuous 180-minute screening at 4:30 p.m. on Sunday and 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday. Thalia Film, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, www.symphonyspace.org; $10. (Kehr) Pop Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. CHRISTINA AGUILERA, PUSSYCAT DOLLS, DANITY KANE (Tonight) Frau Farbissina of the ''Austin Powers'' movies said it best: ''Send in the Fembots!'' Ms. Aguilera may have the most virtuosic voice of her generation of bubblegum pop stars, but as she showed with her endless melismatic protraction of James Brown's ''It's a Man's Man's Man's World'' at the Grammys last month, she can sometimes seem like a singing robot gone berserk. Her tour includes a hit burlesque girl group (the Pussycat Dolls) and an imitation hit burlesque girl group (Danity Kane). At 7:30, Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; $54 to $99.50. (Ben Sisario) * ALLMAN BROTHERS (Tonight, tomorrow, Monday, Tuesday and Thursday nights) The best spring ritual on the Upper West Side is the arrival of this archetypal Southern rock band for its annual series of concerts at the Beacon Theater. This year there are 13 shows over three weeks, and in addition to the long, long guitar solos by Warren Haynes and Derek Trucks, highlights usually include lots of guest stars. At 8, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 307-7171, beacontheatrenyc.com; $54.99 and $84.99 (sold out tonight, tomorrow and Thursday). (Sisario) JOE BOYD (Tuesday) As a record producer in the 1960s, Joe Boyd hopped easily from psychedelia (Pink Floyd) to rustic folk-rock (Fairport Convention, Nick Drake), and his new memoir, ''White Bicycles,'' is just as adroit, tracing a music life through jazz, blues, folk and rock with a revealing clarity. For this reading and performance at Joe's Pub, he will be joined by Geoff Muldaur and Jenni Muldaur. At 7 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $15. (Sisario) DANU (Tomorrow) Danu is an Irish traditional band that plays old-fashioned acoustic instruments, with a repertory that reaches from fierce fiddle reels to pensive ballads. Its arrangements show an ear for texture that allows for both drive and delicacy. At 8 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 545-7536, symphonyspace.org or worldmusicinstitute.org; $27; $15 for students. (Jon Pareles) DO MAKE SAY THINK (Wednesday and Thursday) The budget alternative to South by Southwest: scan that festival's schedule and see which of the most notable bands are coming through New York on their way back from Texas. This Toronto group plays multitextured instrumentals that veer from clangy turbulence to pastoral, acoustic daydreams. Wednesday at 9 p.m., Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, near Sterling Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236, spsounds.com; $15. Thursday at 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $15. (Sisario) JOHNNY DOWD (Tomorrow) Johnny Dowd applies his stoic Texas twang to songs about passion, sin and death; his band plays a version of honky-tonk that sounds as if it had been dragged through a swamp and encrusted with misfiring electronics. At 10 p.m., Rodeo Bar, 375 Third Avenue, at 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 683-6500, rodeobar.com; no cover. (Pareles) ELECTRIC SIX (Tomorrow and Thursday) Electric Six looks fondly back to the early 1980s merger of rock guitars, disco beats and electro blips, with arch and gleefully overblown songs about dancing and romance, like ''Danger! High Voltage'' and ''Nuclear War'' (''on the dance floor''). With Test Your Reflex and Night Kills the Day. Tomorrow night at 9, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $17 in advance, $20 at the door. Thursday at 8:30 p.m., Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 653-1703, maxwellsnj.com; $15. (Pareles) FLESHTONES (Tomorrow) Year in and year out, the Fleshtones have held on to the sound of 1960s garage-rock, with its distortion-edged guitars and hoarsely exuberant vocals. Once it sounded like punk; now it's starting to sound like diehard purism. At 8 p.m., Magnetic Field, 97 Atlantic Avenue, between Henry and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn Heights, (718) 834-0069, magneticbrooklyn.com; $10. (Pareles) * ROBYN HITCHCOCK AND THE VENUS 3 (Tuesday and Wednesday) Not many pop songwriters can credibly be called surrealists. But Robyn Hitchcock, who emerged in the late 1970s with the Soft Boys, has an irrepressible jabberwocky side, and in front of an audience he is a hilarious monologuist-improviser. Here he plays with the Venus 3, featuring Peter Buck of R.E.M. and two auxiliary members of that band, Scott McCaughey and Bill Rieflin. With Johanna Kunin. At 8 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3132, knittingfactory.com; $25. (Sisario) ESSIE JAIN (Tuesday) A British singer and songwriter who lives in New York, Ms. Jain builds stark and entrancing miniatures out of a few light strums of guitar and harmonies that can be warm or ghostly. With Kelley McRae and Alice Smith. At 7:30 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; $10. (Sisario) * LIGHTNING BOLT, BARR, MARNIE STERN (Tomorrow) At first it's hard to believe that all the glorious chaos of Lightning Bolt is being made by only two people. But as the sound comes into focus, a playful give-and-take becomes clear, as the bassist Brian Gibson and the drummer and vocalist Brian Chippendale toss back and forth gigantic metal riffs and giggly high notes, creating rainbows of dissonance. Over bare stutters of piano and drums, Brendan Fowler of Barr lets loose an endlessly self-regarding logorrhea, questioning his every thought and instinct in a naked, paratactic melancholy. Marnie Stern has become indie-rock's newest guitar heroine, with a distinct kind of virtuosity, playing cascades of quick staccato notes and cathartic blasts of noise that recall both Van Halen and Sleater-Kinney. With Ecstatic Sunshine and High Places. At 9 p.m., Third Ward, 195 Morgan Avenue, at Stagg Street, East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 715-4961, 3rdwardbrooklyn.org or toddpnyc.com; $10. (Sisario) * MENOMENA, FIELD MUSIC (Wednesday) Menomena, from Portland, Ore., uses a homemade computer program to help write songs, resulting in shufflings and reshufflings that keep otherwise standard indie-arty elements -- meandering piano, sensual electronics and plain, mournful vocals -- playful and fresh. Field Music, from Sunderland, England, finds a middle ground between angsty post-punk and the wistfully melodic folk-rock of ''Village Green''-era Kinks. With Land of Talk. At 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; sold out. (Sisario) RHETT MILLER (Tonight) Whether with his country-flavored bar band Old 97s or in solo heartthrob mode, Rhett Miller is an unrepentant honky-tonker with a keen gift for melody. With Keegan DeWitt. At 8, Hiro Ballroom, 371 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (866) 468-7619, hiroballroom.com; $25. (Sisario) JANE MONHEIT (Tonight and tomorrow night, and Tuesday through Thursday nights) The beauty of her sultry voice performing bossa nova ballads triumphs over liabilities that include obvious shyness and rushed, perfunctory patter. At 8:45, with additional shows at 10:45 tonight, tomorrow and Thursday, Café Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-1600, thecarlyle.com; $75 cover at tables, $55 at the bar. (Stephen Holden) PELA, TIM FITE (Tonight) It's never easy to see a good New York rock club go down, but it's especially painful when it happens to the same place twice. In the late 1980s and early '90s, Sin-é, on St. Marks Place in the East Village, was a cozy coffeehouse frequented by singer-songwriters like Jeff Buckley and the occasional Joan Osborne or Joe Jackson; it reopened on the Lower East Side in the early '00s as a plain, friendly stage for local rock bands -- an increasingly rare opportunity in Manhattan -- but will be shutting down again next month, and some notable bands are paying their last respects. Pela calls its style ''pastoral punk,'' which means wide-open skies of bouncy, Pixiesesque basslines and sharp, sparkling guitars. Tim Fite builds songs on staticky drum-machine beats and samples of old country music, rapping wryly: ''This is not a hit song/It's not even a good song.'' At 10, 150 Attorney Street, at Stanton Street, (212) 388-0077, sin-e.com; $10. (Sisario) PONYS, BLACK LIPS (Monday) These two bands have found ways -- noisy ones, mostly -- to keep the sound of '60s garage-rock vital. The Ponys, from Chicago, evoke the endurance drones of the Stooges and Sonic Youth, while the Black Lips, from Atlanta, play a grisly version of the 13th Floor Elevators' ragged guitar jangle, sounding deliberately damaged. With Panthers. At 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $13 in advance, $15 at the door. (Sisario) * PTERODACTYL, ONEIDA (Tomorrow) It may be the best New York avant-rock band of the last decade, but for good or ill, it is still possible to see Oneida in places as tiny as Tonic, and for this late-night show the band plays with Pterodactyl, a kindred spirit that has signed to Oneida's new record label, Brah. At 11 p.m., 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501, tonicnyc.com; $5. (Sisario) ROCHES (Tonight) Maggie, Terre and Suzzy Roche have been harmonizing together in various permutations for more than 30 years, but ''Moonswept'' (429 Records), released this week, is their first album as a trio in 12 years. At 8, the Concert Hall at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171, concertstonight.com; $32.50 and $37.50. (Sisario) SNOW PATROL, OK GO (Tuesday and Wednesday) Like Coldplay with a more forceful drummer, Snow Patrol, a band from Scotland made up of men mostly from Northern Ireland, joins lovesick melodrama to sharp, hummable hooks. With all the focus on OK Go's dancing skills -- its ingenious treadmill skip was the highlight of the MTV Video Music Awards last year -- not much attention has been paid to its jaunty, merely adequate Cars-like power-pop. (So expect more dancing.) At 8 p.m., Theater at Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; sold out. (Sisario) * JUSTIN TIMBERLAKE, PINK (Thursday) Mr. Timberlake is the kind of pop star who makes it all look easy. But even more endearing, the guy can truly make fun of himself: his brilliant ''Saturday Night Live'' skit with Andy Samberg, broadcast in bleeped form and uncensored on the Internet, was the equivalent of a chummy high-five with his audience. Opening the show is Pink, the spark plug who once bragged of getting the party started and now ridicules ''stupid girls'' who torture themselves for men. At 7:30 p.m., Continental Airlines Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900, meadowlands.com; $56 and $92. (Sisario) TK WEBB (Tomorrow) A Brooklynite by way of rural Missouri, this singer and guitarist plays ragged, stark Delta blues about desolation and dying young, surrounding his creaky tenor with a halo of reverb. With Kapow!, Sounds of Greg D, Half Cleveland and Crescent Moon. At 7:30 p.m., Luna Lounge, 361 Metropolitan Avenue, at Havemeyer Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, lunalounge.com; $8. (Sisario) GENE WEEN (Tonight) This singer, one-half of the ingenious and underrated comedy-rock-turned-jam-band duo Ween, is on a rare solo tour. With Chris Harford and the Band of Changes. At 9, Gramercy Theater, 127 East 23rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171; $20.50. (Sisario) * LUCINDA WILLIAMS (Tonight) With homely details and the names of Southern cities, Ms. Williams maps a geography of loss and longing in her songs. The twang and determination in her voice and her rock-ribbed melodies insist that she won't crumple. With the Heartless Bastards. At 8, Radio City Music Hall, (212) 307-7171, radiocity.com; $35 to $70. (Pareles) YOU AM I (Sunday) With its exhilarating rave-ups and Tim Rogers's windmill guitar slashes -- both recalling the best of the Who -- You Am I is one of the most exciting bands to come out of Australia in a decade, though it has struggled for recognition here. A strong new album, ''Convicts'' (Yep Roc), might change that. With White Rabbits and Bon Savants. At 7:30 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $15. (Sisario) Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. GERI ALLEN (Tonight) Ms. Allen's piano playing reflects a spectrum of blues and gospel tonalities, and rarely settles for complacent facility. She performs a solo recital at the Klavierhaus piano workshop. At 8, Klavierhaus, 211 West 58th Street, Manhattan, (212) 245-4535, pianoculture.com; $25. (Nate Chinen) OMER AVITAL (Tomorrow) Mr. Avital, a rugged bassist and insistently creative composer, marks the release of his new album, ''Arrival'' (Fresh Sound New Talent), with a group including Omer Klein on piano and Ferenc Nemeth on drums. At 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778, joespub.com; cover, $15, with a two-drink minimum. (Chinen) DAVE BALLOU/JACKSON MOORE (Tomorrow) Mr. Ballou, an incisive trumpeter with an expansive sense of timbre, leads a trio with John Hebert on bass and Randy Peterson on drums. In the following set, Mr. Moore, a coolheaded alto saxophonist, investigates hypnotic rhythmic concepts with a quintet that includes the trumpeter Jonathan Finlayson. At 8:30 and 10 p.m., Rose Live Music, 345 Grand Street, near Marcy Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-0069, newlanguages.org; $10. (Chinen) JAMIE BAUM SEPTET (Thursday) Ms. Baum, a flutist, features her own meticulous yet pliable compositions with this group, which includes Shane Endsley on trumpet, Doug Yates on reeds and Vincent Chancey on French horn. At 8:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) ANDY BISKIN (Tonight) Revisiting the premise of a recent album, ''Early American: The Melodies of Stephen Foster,'' the clarinetist Andy Biskin leads an inventive crew: Theo Bleckmann on vocals, Chris Washburne on trombone and tuba, Pete McCann on guitar and John Hollenbeck on drums. At 8:30, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $21. (Chinen) JANE IRA BLOOM (Sunday) Ms. Bloom, a probing soprano saxophonist, introduces a composition called ''Beyond the Brain,'' with a rhythm section consisting of Dawn Clement on keyboards, Mark Helias on bass and Matt Wilson on drums. At 8 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501, tonicnyc.com; cover, $15. (Chinen) * ANTHONY BRAXTON (Thursday) Mr. Braxton, a sphinxlike eminence in the avant-garde, has an extravagant new box set that chronicles an engagement here last year. Once again he wields an array of reed instruments and an ensemble stocked with smart acolytes, like the cornetist Taylor Ho Bynum and the guitarist Mary Halvorson. (Through April 1.) At 8:30 and 10:30 p.m., Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $32.50, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) CHRIS BYARS (Tonight, tomorrow and Wednesday) Mr. Byars, an industrious young saxophonist, appears tonight and tomorrow at Smalls, his regular haunt; on Wednesday he formally celebrates the release of a likable new album, ''Photos in Black, White and Gray'' (Smalls). Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30, Smalls, 183 West 10th Street, West Village, (212) 675-7369; cover, $20. Wednesday at 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778, joespub.com; cover, $15, with a two-drink minimum. (Chinen) GERALD CLAYTON QUINTET (Tonight and tomorrow night) The pianist Gerald Clayton leads a promising post-bop ensemble, with Gretchen Parlato on vocals, Dayna Stephens on tenor saxophone, Matt Brewer on bass and Jamire Williams on drums. At 9 and 10:30, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $15. (Chinen) JOEL FORRESTER (Monday and Thursday) Mr. Forrester, a pianist with a wry and omnivorous style, plays several hours unaccompanied on Monday nights in TriBeCa. On Thursday, in Park Slope, he presents a hard-bop quintet he calls the Truth. Monday from 8 to midnight, Brandy Library, 25 North Moore Street, TriBeCa, (212) 226-5545; no cover. Thursday at 8 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $8. (Chinen) JACOB GARCHIK/DAN WEISS (Wednesday) On his recent album, ''Abstracts'' (Yestereve), the trombonist Jacob Garchik offers a bouquet of appealingly compact excursions for a trio with the pianist Jacob Sacks and the drummer Dan Weiss, who join him in an early set here. Then Mr. Weiss leads a trio with Mr. Sacks and the bassist Thomas Morgan. At 8 and 10 p.m., Barbes, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) HENRY GRIMES AND AMINA CLAUDINE MYERS (Wednesday) Mr. Grimes, a bassist, and Ms. Myers, a pianist and vocalist, are unpredictable entities in the jazz avant-garde; if they find common ground, their dialogue should be intriguing. At 10 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) JOEL HARRISON'S STRING CHOIR (Tonight) The compositions of the drummer Paul Motian can convey shadowy depths even as they echo the simplicity of folk songs. Here they benefit from string arrangements by the guitarist Joel Harrison for an improvising string sextet. At 9 and 10:30, Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) * ANDREW HILL TRIO (Thursday) With ''Time Lines'' (Blue Note), the pianist and composer Andrew Hill delivered one of last year's standout recordings, and one of the strongest of his distinguished career. His trio, with John Hebert on bass and Eric McPherson on drums, traffics in mysterious harmonies and elliptical tempos; the group should sound marvelous in a parish setting. At 1 p.m., Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 602-0800, trinitywallstreet.org; no cover. (Chinen) JAZZ IS A BEAUTIFUL THING (Tonight) An aptly named evening with a luxuriously comfortable all-star quintet: Frank Wess on tenor saxophone, Cecil Bridgewater on trumpet, Harold Mabern on piano, Rufus Reid on bass and Ben Riley on drums. At 8, Flushing Town Hall, 137-35 Northern Boulevard, at Linden Place, Queens, (718) 463-7700, flushingtownhall.org; $40. (Chinen) KNEEBODY (Tonight and Tuesday) Blending rock, jazz and funk in a convincing amalgam, the collective known as Kneebody plays tonight at midnight and shares a bill on Tuesday with Blood Orange, an ensemble featuring some of the same members, but led by the bassist Todd Sickafoose. Tonight at midnight, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $10, with a $10 minimum. Tuesday at 8 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501, tonicnyc.com; cover, $15. (Chinen) BRIGGAN KRAUSS (Tonight) Mr. Krauss, a texture-minded alto saxophonist, presents ''Lensing,'' a suite of pieces for eight musicians, including the trumpeter Ron Horton, the clarinetist Chris Speed and the baritone saxophonist Andy Laster. At 8:30, Roulette, 20 Greene Street, at Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 219-8242, roulette.org; $15. (Chinen) DANIEL LEVIN QUARTET (Tonight) The cellist Daniel Levin revisits some of the material from his engagingly experimental last album, ''Some Trees'' (Hat Hut); he also reconvenes the same ensemble, with Nate Wooley on trumpet, Joe Morris on bass and Matt Moran on vibraphone. At 8, the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) * JAMES MOODY (Monday through Thursday) The effervescent saxophonist James Moody celebrates his 82nd birthday on Monday with an all-star concert to benefit aspiring young players. The next night Mr. Moody begins a weeklong double bill with another breezy old-timer, the trumpeter Clark Terry. Monday at 8 p.m., B. B. King Blues Club & Grill, 237 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144, bbkingblues.com; $100. Tuesday through Thursday at 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Through April 1.) (Chinen) KEVIN NORTON (Tomorrow) Mr. Norton is a drummer, vibraphonist and composer, although not always in that order; this concert marks the premieres of several new chamber pieces for an ensemble including J. D. Parran on reeds, Angelica Sanchez and Connie Crothers on piano and Esther Noh on violin. At 8:30 p.m., Roulette, 20 Greene Street, at Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 219-8242, roulette.org; $15. (Chinen) OPSVIK AND JENNINGS (Tuesday) The bassist Eivind Opsvik and the guitarist Aaron Jennings have maintained this intelligent electro-acoustic duo collaboration for a handful of years; their new album, ''Commuter Anthems,'' will soon be released on the Norwegian label Rune Grammofon. At 10 p.m., Nublu, 62 Avenue C, near Fifth Street, East Village, nublu.net; cover, $5. (Chinen) RALPH PETERSON'S FO'TET (Tonight and tomorrow night) This explosive post-bop band, a longtime flagship of the drummer Ralph Peterson, resurfaces with a promising lineup: Greg Osby on alto saxophone, Bryan Carrott on vibes and Belden Bullock on bass. At 8 and 10, Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, West Village, (212) 255-3626, sweetrhythmny.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) DAVE PIETRO (Tuesday and Thursday) On Tuesday Mr. Pietro, a versatile saxophonist, presents his new ''Chakra Suite,'' with an ensemble including the guitarist Rez Abbasi and the pianist Gary Versace. On Thursday he joins a more mainstream ensemble descriptively titled New York-Tokyo Connection. Tuesday at 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $12. Thursday at 8 and 9:45 p.m., Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, (212) 885-7119, kitano.com; no cover. (Chinen) MATANA ROBERTS'S COIN COIN (Thursday) The alto saxophonist Matana Roberts weaves history, folklore and genealogy into ''Coin Coin,'' an audacious performance piece; she also enlists imaginative colleagues like Jason Palmer on trumpet and Beatrice Anderson on vocals. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $12. (Chinen) DAVE SCOTT (Monday) Mr. Scott, an intelligent trumpeter, presents a version of the hard-bop quintet heard on his new album, ''Naiveté'' (Steeplechase): Rich Perry on tenor saxophone, Gary Versace on keyboards, John Hebert on bass and Take Toriyama on drums. At 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, near Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; information on cover charge is available by phone. (Chinen) SING INTO SPRING FESTIVAL (Tonight through Thursday night) Singers reign at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola through the rest of March, appearing with uniformly first-rate backing ensembles. Gloria Lynne appears this weekend, followed by Giacomo Gates on Monday, Anne Ducros on Tuesday and Ernestine Anderson on Wednesday and Thursday. (Through April 1.) At 7:30 and 9:30, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 258-9595, jalc.org; cover, $30, with a minimum of $10 at tables, $5 at the bar. (Chinen) STEVE SMITH AND VITAL INFORMATION (Tonight through Sunday night) The drummer Steve Smith has led this energetic fusion outfit for more than 20 years. As on the new album, ''Vitalization,'' the group includes Tom Coster on keyboards, Baron Browne on bass and Vinny Valentino on guitar. At 8 and 10, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) E. J. STRICKLAND QUINTET (Tomorrow) The drummer E. J. Strickland -- like his brother Marcus Strickland, who joins him here on saxophone -- hails from a generation fluent in jazz conventions but not beholden to them. At midnight, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $10, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) * CHARLES TOLLIVER QUINTET (Wednesday and Thursday) The trumpeter Charles Tolliver leads a hard-charging post-bop band, with Billy Harper on tenor saxophone, George Cables on piano and Victor Lewis on drums. Dwayne Burno is the bassist on Wednesday; Christian McBride takes over on Thursday. (Through March 31.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) MICHAEL WEISS QUINTET (Tuesday through Thursday) The pianist Michael Weiss showcases his own thoughtful compositions with a post-bop group featuring the alto and soprano saxophonist Steve Wilson. (Through April 1.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $20, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) Classical Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music. Opera * 'DIE ÄGYPTISCHE HELENA' (Tonight and Tuesday night) With its convoluted libretto by Hugo von Hofmannsthal and unevenly inspired score by Richard Strauss, this wry contemporary take on the Helen of Troy myth has remained a rarity since its 1928 premiere. But the Metropolitan Opera's fancifully surreal new production by David Fielding, mounted for the soprano Deborah Voigt, makes a compelling case for this intriguing work, thanks to Ms. Voigt's vocally lustrous and affecting portrayal of the title role, as well as the vibrant and insightful conducting of Fabio Luisi. The brilliant coloratura Diana Damrau is wonderful as the sorceress Aithra, who lures the unfaithful Helena and her avenging husband, Menelas, to her enchanted island to patch up their marriage. The German tenor Torsten Kerl, who because of illness had to be replaced halfway through the performance on opening night, is scheduled to sing Menelas for the remaining performances. At 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $70 to $295 tonight; $80 to $175 for Tuesday. (Anthony Tommasini) 'ANDREA CHÉNIER' (Monday and Thursday) Set in the 18th century, but very much a product of the 19th, Giordano's Italian drama of the French Revolution returns to the Metropolitan Opera with a cast that is able to sing very, very loudly, if not always especially elegantly or with particular Italian flair: Violeta Urmana, Ben Heppner and Mark Delavan. Marco Armiliato, who is becoming a solid presence in the pit, conducts. Monday at 8 p.m., Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $275. (Anne Midgette) * 'IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA' (Tomorrow) Bartlett Sher's breezy production of Rossini's opera conveys the comic confusions of the story through its fluid staging and a wonderfully abstract set: a matrix of movable doors, staircases and potted orange trees, behind which characters spy on one another. The heated sexuality of the characters also comes through, thanks to Mr. Sher's subtle directing. The baritone Peter Mattei is a robust and agile Figaro. The tenor Juan Diego Flórez could not be more adorable as the amorous Count Almaviva. The captivating young mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato is a vocally agile and feisty Rosina. The virile bass-baritone John Relyea makes the wily Don Basilio seem delightfully dangerous. Maurizio Benini conducts. At 1:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out. (Tommasini) * 'LA DONNA DEL LAGO' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) The New York City Opera's last foray into the little-known world of Rossini's serious operas was successful enough that the company returned to another one, with the same two leads featured in ''Ermione'' a few seasons ago. Alexandrina Pendatchanska is an intense, committed soprano; Barry Banks, the tenor, is emerging as someone to watch. Chas Rader-Shieber, the director, has brought an antic touch to his two previous outings with the company, ''Flavio'' (which returns this spring) and ''Orlando.'' George Manahan conducts. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $130. (Midgette) 'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' (Tonight, Sunday and Tuesday) Mark Lamos's austere and effective production gets perfectly acceptable singing in this New York City Opera revival of Puccini's weepy masterpiece. With Angela Maria Blasi and Raúl Melo. Tonight at 8, Sunday at 1:30 p.m., Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $125. (Bernard Holland) * 'THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE' (Tomorrow and Thursday) Lillian Groag avoids topical updating and focuses on the work's own satirical targets. Even so, her direction for this City Opera production is inventive and lively, as are the performances by a cast that includes Sarah Jane McMahon as Mabel, Matt Morgan as Frederic, Marc Kudisch as the Pirate King and Mark Jacoby as Major General Stanley. Gerald Steichen conducts. Tomorrow at 8, Thursday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $130. (Allan Kozinn) 'LA TRAVIATA' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) For its revival of Franco Zeffirelli's extravagant 1998 production, the Met is rotating casts, with several sopranos sharing the role of Violetta this season. Tomorrow evening, for only one performance, the Violetta will be the Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu, whose portrayal of this role in a Covent Garden production made her famous. On Wednesday the earthy Bulgarian soprano Krassimira Stoyanova sings Violetta, the role of her 2001 Met debut. For both performances the compelling German tenor Jonas Kaufmann sings Alfredo, Violetta's lover, with the veteran American baritone Dwayne Croft as Alfredo's tragically interfering father, Germont. Marco Armiliato conducts. Tomorrow and Wednesday at 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $27 to $150 tomorrow; $15 to $175 for Wednesday. (Tommasini) Classical Music * AMERICAN COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA (Monday) Dennis Russell Davies, who was the orchestra's conductor from its founding until 2002, returns to celebrate its 30th anniversary. The program is devoted mostly to concertolike works in which the composers are the soloists. The works are Steven Mackey's ''Deal'' (for electric guitar); ''Inventions'' by the jazz pianist Vijay Iyer; Kurt Rohde's ''White Boy/Man Invisible'' (for viola); Harold Meltzer's ''Virginal'' (for harpsichord); Andrew McKenna Lee's ''Arabescata'' (for guitar); Min Xiao-Fen's ''Blue Pipa'' (for the pipa, a Chinese lute); and Tania León's ''Indígena.'' At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $32 to 40. (Kozinn) CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER (Tonight and Sunday) The Society turns its attention to wind instruments in many formulations. The solo works include Debussy's ''Syrinx'' for solo flute, and Stravinsky's modernist ''Three Pieces for Clarinet Solo.'' Chamber works include Elliott Carter's ''Esprit Rude/Esprit Doux II'' for Flute, Clarinet and Marimba; Hindemith's ''Kleine Kammermusik'' for Woodwind Quintet; Mozart's Quintet for Piano and Winds (K. 452); and Spohr's Grand Nonetto in F for Winds and Strings (Op. 31). The musicians include Ida Kavafian, a violinist; Anne-Marie McDermott, a pianist; Ransom Wilson, a flutist; Stephen Taylor, an oboist; Edgar Meyer, a double bassist; and David Shifrin, a clarinetist. Tonight at 8, Sunday at 5 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org; $28 to $50. (Vivien Schweitzer) * GERALD FINLEY (Tonight) This 47-year-old Canadian baritone had long been respected for his warm voice and discerning musicianship when his riveting portrayal of J. Robert Oppenheimer in the world premiere of John Adams's ''Doctor Atomic'' at the San Francisco Opera in 2005 brought him deserved international attention. For his Zankel Hall recital he sings songs by Schumann, Ives, Barber and Ned Rorem, accompanied by the elegant pianist Julius Drake. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $36 to $42. (Tommasini) * LOUIS LORTIE (Tomorrow) Mr. Lortie, a superb, intellectual Canadian pianist plays Chopin's Sonata in B minor (Op. 58) and the Nocturne in B (Op. 62, No. 1). Liszt is another specialty. Here he will play the Overture to Wagner's ''Tannhäuser'' and ''Vallée d'Obermann,'' part of Liszt's ''Années de Pèlerinage.'' Mr. Lortie also champions the music of the British composer Thomas Adès and will round out the recital with Adès's ''Darknesse Visible.'' At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $26 to $82. (Schweitzer) * MAKING MUSIC: GEORGE BENJAMIN (Thursday) It is hard to generalize about the English composer George Benjamin, 47, a prodigy who wrote his first works 40 years ago. He has explored diverse styles and schools. He will discuss his work, including his renewed interest in vigorous counterpoint, with Ara Guzelimian, host of the Making Music series at Zankel Hall. Several of Mr. Benjamin's works will be performed, including two piano pieces composed for, and played by, the brilliant Pierre-Laurent Aimard, who is back in New York to continue his Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $25. (Tommasini) MATA FESTIVAL (Tomorrow) This downtown festival, now in its ninth year, has moved across the East River to the Brooklyn Lyceum, but is still finding fresh scores by young, inventive composers. Tonight the Knights ensemble plays new works by Matthew Barnson, Andrew Norman, Filippo Perocco and Christopher Tignor. There is also a preconcert panel discussion with the composers, moderated by the critic Alex Ross. At 8 p.m. (the discussion is at 6:45), 227 Fourth Avenue, at President Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 857-4816, matafestival.org; $15. (Kozinn) * NDR SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Monday and Tuesday) The classical world was startled when the conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi, having left a successful tenure at the Cleveland Orchestra, took over the reliable but less internationally glamorous orchestra of North German Radio. Now, that orchestra is getting a new hall (the Elbphilharmonie) in Hamburg, and is showing its stuff in two concerts with the violinist Vadim Repin: Schnittke's Violin Concerto No. 4 and Brahms's First Symphony on Monday, and Mendelsson's concerto, Ligeti's ''Lontano'' and Mahler's First Symphony on Tuesday. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $28 to $89. (Midgette) * NEW AMSTERDAM SINGERS (Tonight and Sunday) Matt Haimovitz, an innovative cellist, joins the New Amsterdam Singers and Clara Longstreth in ''Après Moi, le Déluge,'' by Luna Pearl Woolf, a composer and Mr. Haimovitz's wife. The work was inspired by Ms. Woolf's distress at the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina and takes its title from a quotation often attributed to the decadent and irresponsible Louis XV of France. The program also includes Bach's Cello Suite No. 2 (with Mr. Haimovitz as soloist) and choral works by Brahms, Carissimi, Purcell, Bach and Kirke Mechem. Tonight at 8, Sunday at 4 p.m., Holy Trinity Church, 316 East 88th Street, Manhattan, (212) 842-1511, nasingers.org; $20; $15 for students and 65+. (Schweitzer) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC (Tonight, tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday) Mozart is writ large this week at the Philharmonic, but in two very different hands. Make that four hands: two of them belonging to Mitsuko Uchida, who this weekend offers the Piano Concerto No. 19 (K. 459), and the two others belonging to Radu Lupu, who will play the Piano Concerto No. 27 (K. 595) on Thursday. The two pianists join in a program on Wednesday that includes the piano concertos, as well as Mozart's Concerto for Two Pianos in E flat. Colin Davis conducts the three concerts, which also include the Schubert Fourth (this weekend), Mozart's Symphony No. 32 in G (Wednesday) and Sibelius's ''Lemminkainen'' Suite (on Thursday). Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Wednesday and Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $28 to $99. (Midgette) MURRAY PERAHIA (Sunday) This distinguished American pianist, long a resident of Britain, comes home for a program of comfortable dimensions: music by Beethoven, Bach, Schumann and Chopin. At 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $26 to $51. (Holland) * STEVE REICH (Tonight and tomorrow) The Miller Theater is celebrating Steve Reich's 70th birthday with an installment of its Composer Portraits series in which So Percussion and friends will perform Mr. Reich's epochal ''Music for 18 Musicians'' and his somewhat less epochal but still riveting ''Music for Pieces of Wood.'' At 8, Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-7799, millertheater.com; $25. (Kozinn) ST. THOMAS CHOIR (Tonight) With Easter approaching, performances of Bach's Passion settings are about to become plentiful in New York's churches and concert halls. This superb choir of men and boys, joined by Musica Angelica Los Angeles and the Vienna Academy Orchestra, gets in early with what looks like a promising performance of the ''St. Matthew Passion.'' Martin Haselböck conducts, Andreas Karsiak is the Evangelis, and Stephen Salters sings Christus, with Christine Brandes, Carlos Mena and Mark Bleeke filling out the roster of soloists. At 7:30, St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, (212) 664-9360, saintthomaschurch.org; $20 to $80. (Kozinn) * STUTTGART CHAMBER ORCHESTRA (Thursday) Since regaining the use of his right hand, which for decades was afflicted with focal dystonia, the pianist Leon Fleisher has made a successful return to performing and recording two-hand piano repertory. On Thursday he appears with the Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra as soloist (conducting from the keyboard) in Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 12 in A, and as conductor in Boccherini's Symphony in D minor, Mendelssohn's String Symphony No. 10 in B minor and Haydn's Symphony No. 45. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $50. (Schweitzer) TRINITY CHOIR (Tuesday) Owen Burdick and his excellent choir continue their tour of European choral music with a program of works by the Haydn brothers -- Joseph, represented by the ''Lord Nelson'' Mass, and Michael, whose Requiem will be performed. The choir will be accompanied by the Rebel Baroque Orchestra. At 6 p.m., Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 602-0747, trinitywallstreet.org; $20 to $40; $15 for students and 65+. (Kozinn) TRIO MEDIAEVAL and CRASH ENSEMBLE (Wednesday) The vibrant Dublin-based Crash Ensemble, a new-music group specializing in multimedia performances, makes its New York debut playing works by its founder, Donnacha Dennehy, including the United States premiere of ''Gra Agus Bas'' and the world premiere of ''Stainless Staining.'' It will be joined by the superb Scandinavian singers of Trio Mediaeval for this concert, the final event this season in Merkin Concert Hall's New Sounds Live series. At 8 p.m., 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3330, kaufman-center.org; $35 in advance, $40 at the door. (Schweitzer) * WOLFIADE: WOLFGANG HOLZMAIR SINGS HUGO WOLF (Tuesday and Wednesday) On the model of a ''Schubertiade'' -- a festival of Schubert's songs -- comes a ''Wolfiade,'' devoted to the songs of Hugo Wolf and featuring another Wolf, the baritone Wolfgang Holzmair. The mini-festival will include three free recitals at Weill Recital Hall -- the first, on Tuesday, features Wolf's Goethe songs, with Mr. Holzmair and the mezzo Hermine Haselböck; the next two feature the complete Italian and Spanish songbooks -- as well as a series of master classes during which six selected singers will work on refining Wolf songs for a concluding recital on April 4; the first master class is on Wednesday. Tuesday at 8 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; free. Wednesday at 2 p.m., Austrian Cultural Forum, 11 East 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 319-5300, acfny.org; free. (Midgette) Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. IVY BALDWIN DANCE (Wednesday and Thursday) In her new ''Don't Worry, It's Only Me,'' Ivy Baldwin burrows into the animal-like instincts in all of us, a theme that sounds just right for her gift for dark comedy. (Through March 31.) At 8 p.m., Dance New Amsterdam, 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, TriBeCa, (212) 279-4200, dnadance.org; $17; $12 for members. (Jennifer Dunning) H. T. CHEN & DANCERS (Tonight and tomorrow night) Mr. Chen's new ''Apple Dreams'' is a site-specific dance event to be performed not only by his own dancers but also by neighborhood parents and children and elders in pedicabs. At 7, Winter Garden, World Financial Center, 220 Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505; free. (Dunning) DANCES PATRELLE (Tonight through Sunday) New ballets by Mr. Patrelle and Leda Meredith will explore the battle of the sexes and the challenges of caring for aging parents on a program that also features the guest dancers Jenifer Ringer and Stephen Hanna, both New York City Ballet principals, and Jonathan Porretta, a principal with Pacific Northwest Ballet. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 6:30 p.m., Ailey Citigroup Theater, 405 West 55th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444, dancespatrelle.org; $35; $150 for a gala tonight with a reception. (Dunning) 'EDWARD SCISSORHANDS' (Tonight through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) Conceived, directed and choreographed by Matthew Bourne, this re-envisioning of Tim Burton's dark 1990 film of the same title revisits the theme of the outsider, here a gentle boy with scissors for hands. (Through March 31.) Tonight at 7:30, tomorrow at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Tuesday through Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 1 and 6:30 p.m., Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $30 to $80. (Dunning) THE 4 TANGO SEASONS (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) This show explores nature's cycles as seen by a man and a woman in love. (Through April 1.) Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 4 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Thalia Spanish Theater, 41-17 Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718) 729-3880, thaliatheatre.org; $30; $27 for students and 65+. (Dunning) Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana (Tuesday through Thursday) This popular Spanish-American company will focus on the use of castanets in a new work and also offer traditional flamenco dances accompanied by onstage musicians. (Through April 1.) Tuesday and Wednesday at 7.30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $40; $30 for Joyce members. (Roslyn Sulcas) Levi Gonzalez (Thursday) Mr. Gonzalez, who has performed with John Jasperse and a host of A-list downtown choreographers, brings a new work with a name unsuitable for print in this publication. In any event, news releases claim that it ''smashes through codes, indulges in extremity and excess, and embraces chaos.'' Bet you haven't guessed that title yet. (Through March 31.) At 7.30 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 691-6500, dtw.org; $20; $12 for students, artists and 65+. (Sulcas) LYDIA JOHNSON DANCE (Tomorrow) Lydia Johnson does interesting things with the formal concepts of classical dance. This program includes a new piece set to music by Ray LaMontagne. At 8 p.m., South Orange Performing Arts Center, One SOPAC Way, South Orange, N.J., (973) 313-2787, sopacnow.org; $35; $10 for students and 65+. (Dunning) * MADE IN CATALUNYA: CATALAN CULTURE IN NEW YORK (Monday) Sol Picó's multimedia ''Kiss Me the Cactus'' addresses powerful images of fear, but with humor. It is one of two free dance programs -- the other is by the august Cesc Gelabert on March 31 -- to be presented in this weeklong festival of Catalan dance, theater, music and poetry, held in conjunction with the exhibition ''Barcelona and Modernity: Gaudí to Dalí,'' at the Metropolitan Museum. At 8:30 p.m., Baryshnikov Arts Center, 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan, (212) 279-4200 for reservations (required), baryshnikovdancefoundation.org. (Dunning) MIRO MAGLOIRE'S NEW CHAMBER BALLET (Tonight and tomorrow night) In this ''Italian Evening,'' the musically astute Miro Magloire will present ballets set to music by Italian composers from Berio to Corelli, performed live. At 8:30, City Center Studio 4, 130 West 56th Street, Manhattan, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com. Tickets: $20; $10 for students and 65+. (Dunning) Eliza Miller (Thursday) Eliza Miller trained as a pianist before beginning to dance, and she retains a particular interest in the musical side of things. Her new work, ''O Death,'' is a collaboration with the British composer Oscar Bettison, who has composed a requiem Mass, played live by a Dutch music group, Ensemble Klang. (Through April 1.) At 8.30 p.m., Danspace Project, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194; $15; $10 for members. (Sulcas) * PEAK PERFORMANCES: VINCENT DANCE THEATER (Tomorrow and Sunday) From Sheffield, England, Charlotte Vincent and her modern-dance troupe will perform ''Broken Chords'' in the Peak Performances avant-garde showcase at Montclair State University. Inspired by Ms. Vincent's divorce, this piece has been described as a portrait of grief, both searing and funny. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Alexander Kasser Theater, Montclair State University, 1 Normal Avenue, Montclair, N.J., (973) 655-5112; $25. (Dunning) DESMOND RICHARDsON AND THE ALL STARS PROJECT (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) Mr. Richardson and 15 performers from All Stars, a cultural program for teenagers from New York City and Newark, have created ''Homeland Security: Bringing Dr. King Up to Date,'' a multimedia piece that questions American notions of ''homeland'' and ''security.'' (Through April 4.) Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2 p.m., Thursday at 7:30 p.m., All Stars Project Theater, 543 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 941-1234, allstars.org; $30 and $35; T.D.F. vouchers accepted. (Dunning) MELISSA RIKER & KINESIS PROJECT (Tonight through Sunday) The company will perform Ms. Riker's ''Right Before You Fell,'' a program she describes as a playful and sensuous athletic dance that explores the moments when something is not being said. Tonight at 9, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m., Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street, West Village, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $20. (Dunning) SALON 651: CHOREOGRAPHY IN DEVELOPMENT (Thursday) Christalyn Wright will present her new ''Struggles with Words, Attitudes and Great Expectations,'' inspired by the Sue Monk Kidd novel ''The Secret Life of Bees,'' with video by Liza Johnson. At 8 p.m., BRICstudio, 57 Rockwell Place, near Fulton Street, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4181, Ext. 2229, 651ARTS.org; $5. (Dunning) AMY DAWN VEREBAY (Thursday) A member of the wild and wacky Circus Amok, Ms. Verebay will present a dance-theater production called ''Once in Love with Amy'' that chronicles her attempts to turn ''her life's lead into gold,'' as she puts it. At 8 p.m., WOW Café Theater, 59-61 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 545-5334; $12. (Dunning) * ANN LIV YOUNG (Tonight and tomorrow night) Ms. Young would probably have no quarrel with describing her new "Snow White" as lewd, crude and socially unattractive, attributes she cultivates cheerfully in this tale of psychosexual involvements between the heroine, her Prince and the Evil Stepmother. At 8, the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, Ext. 11, thekitchen.org; $12. (Dunning) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums * American Folk Art Museum: MARTíN RAMíREZ, through May 13. Ramírez, a Mexican peasant who immigrated to Northern California and died there at 68 in 1963, spent the last 32 years of his life in a mental hospital, making some of the greatest art of the last century. He had his own way with materials and color and an unforgettable cast of characters. But most of all, Ramírez had his own brand of pictorial space, established by rhythmic systems of parallel lines, both curved and straight, whose mesmerizing expansions and contractions simultaneously cosset and isolate his figures. This show should render null and void the distinction between insider and outsider art. 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040, folkartmuseum.org. (Roberta Smith) * Asia Society: Glass, Gilding, and Grand Design: Art of Sasanian Iran (224-642 A.D.), through May 20. With some 70 examples of silver, glass and silk textile fragments, many from European museums, this is the first major exhibition of its kind in this part of the world for more than 30 years. For about four centuries, the Sasanians ruled territory stretching from present-day Iran and Iraq to North Africa. Their only rivals were Rome, Byzantium and, at the very end, the early Islamic dynasties. Much of their surviving art is a sterling example of empire in action. 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400, asiasociety.org. (Holland Cotter) FRICK COLLECTION: 'GEORGE STUBBS (1724-1806): A CELEBRATION,' through May 27. One of the finest horse painters ever, Stubbs knew his subjects from head to hoof and skin to bones. He painted other mammals too: dogs, lions, tigers, oxen, monkeys and humans. This intimate show of 17 Stubbs paintings from English collections reveals his admirable range, although the people he portrayed in two large, late canvases, elegiac celebrations of farm workers, have the stiffness of figures on a candy box. His horses are his true monuments. 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700, frick.org. (Grace Glueck) Guggenheim Museum: 'Family Pictures,' through April 16. The museum's news release extends the exhibition's exploration into ''representation of families and children in contemporary art and video.'' Images of children, you quickly realize, can operate as a completely different genre. Rineke Dijkstra's ''Beach Portraits'' of adolescents posing awkwardly against stark seascape horizons are isolated (and isolating) images of children on the threshold of adulthood. You don't think about family when gazing at these photographs. Sally Mann is perhaps the best-known contemporary photographer of children, specifically her own. Ms. Mann, represented here by black-and-white photographs from the late 1980s and early 1990s of her ethereally gorgeous children, has been accused of everything from neglect to child abuse. The questions raised by her dual role as artist and mother, simultaneous protector and potential exploiter of the family, remain vitally interesting. 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, guggenheim.org. (Martha Schwendener) * The METropolitan museum of art: 'INCISIVE IMAGES: IVORY AND BOXWOOD CARVINGS,' through Nov. 25. This extraordinary show, drawn almost entirely from the Met's vaults, presents an array of nearly 100 carved figures, crucifixes, reliefs, containers, hand-held weapons and the occasional piece of furniture. It is an engrossing hive of religious fervor, Classical erudition (and occasional naughtiness), style shifts and multicultural cross-currents. And among the many feats of drop-dead artistic skill are several of traffic-stopping caliber. Don't miss it. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Smith) * The Met: 'Mother of Pearl: A Tradition in Asian Lacquer,' through April 1. Ornamentalism is the term for this show of some 40 objects so preposterously exquisite that they might have been conceived with a modern museum conservator's soft white cotton gloves in mind. The technique for creating mini-mosaics from slivers of mollusk shell is an ancient one that was perfected in China before traveling to Korea, Japan, Thailand and India. Examples from all those places are here in writing boxes and tea trays guaranteed to appeal to any window-shopper's acquisitive yearnings and magpie eye. (See above.) (Cotter) Museum of modern art: 'COMIC ABSTRACTION: IMAGE-BREAKING, IMAGE-MAKING,' through June 11. This unimaginative and uniformed treatment of a big idea -- the healthy and essential contamination of Modernist abstraction by popular culture -- should be seen if only because it is such a dispiriting symptom of the Modern's paralysis where contemporary art is concerned. Although it promises work that addresses ''perplexing questions,'' nearly everything here is perfectly pleasant and innocuous. The exceptions are provided by Gary Simmons, Ellen Gallagher and Sue Williams. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Smith) * Moma: JEFF WALL, through May 14. This majestic show makes a great case for Mr. Wall as the most complete, if traditional, of the untraditional artists who emerged from the turmoil of Conceptual Art. His often immense color transparencies are enthralling visual vehicles, intent on giving pleasure while making a point or two about society, art, history, visual perception, the human animal or all of the above. An imposing blend of painting, street photography and movies, they blur reality and artifice, narrative and form, detail and the big statement. You can't stop looking at them. (See above.) (Smith) WADSWORTH ATHENEUM MUSEUM OF ART: 'FAITH AND FORTUNE: FIVE CENTURIES OF EUROPEAN MASTERWORKS,' through Dec. 9. Celebrating the return of its famous Renaissance, Baroque and Rococo paintings and objects of art from a three-year national tour, the Wadsworth has arranged a feast of a show. One of the most appealing things about this gathering of some 400 treasures is the mix, with knockout paintings keeping period company with small sculptures, elaborate table furnishings, decorative platters, Meissen knockoffs of Chinese pottery, a porcelain birdcage and vases and such. Strolling through the galleries, you'll find treasures like ''Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy'' (about 1594-95), said to be the first authentic Caravaggio in an American museum. But the pièce de résistance is an entire gallery made into an art and curio cabinet, with a planned clutter of brilliant objects that play to a viewer's inner acquisitor: exotic shells mounted in gold; an extraordinary Baroque ivory carving (presumed to be before 1650) of Adam and Eve; an automatic tabletop clock (about 1619) with a standing lion that could roll its eyes, open its jaws and stick out its tongue when the hours struck. Dazzlement prevails. 600 Main Street, Hartford, (860) 278-2670, wadsworthatheneum.org (Glueck) Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Gordon MaTTA-cLARK rETROSPECTIVE,' through June 3. I have no doubt that Matta-Clark is now being turned into a hot commercial commodity, but at least at the Whitney you can see what he aspired to be. At the center of the exhibition is ''Splitting.'' To a plain single-family suburban frame house in Englewood, N.J., he made a cut straight down the middle, bisecting the building, then severing the four corners of the roof. The retrospective consists of films, drawings, photographs and some of the architectural pieces he cut out of buildings. The big message was: Life as art, and art as life, a philosophy dependent on our being properly attuned and keen to the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org.
