(Michael Kimmelman) * Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Lorna Simpson,' through May 6. This tight, refined and impassioned survey covers more than 20 years of Lorna Simpson's career, from her photo-and-text meditations on race and sexism in the 1980s, to her more recent short films, which unite American history and personal history in forceful and lyrical ways. It would be easy to put some of this work on a shelf as ''identity art,'' but with an African-American woman holding one of the highest offices in the United States government, an African-American man running for president, and the nation embroiled in what some people view as an ethnic war, this art is entirely of the moment. (See above.) (Cotter) Galleries: Uptown * PHILIP TAAFFE This artist's first New York show since 2000 anoints him as one of the best painters of his generation, and maybe the only one to extend both 1970s Pattern and Decoration and 80s appropriation into new areas. Aided by Warhol's tinted colors and Pollock's all-over rhythms, and some ingenious printing techniques of their own, these suavely eye-popping new paintings sample everything from Northwest Coast Indian masks to Islamic ornamental patterns to marbleizing and gilding. They define visual culture as a great chain of being in which anything can be connected with proper placement, color and scale in an inspiring message of unity in difference. Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-2313, www.gagosian.com, through March 31. (Smith) Last Chance PIERO GOLIA It's Dada redux in the New York debut of a clever young Italian post-Conceptualist who, for the occasion, comes up with novel ways to tell time. A drop of water falls from the gallery's ceiling once a minute. A broom rotates once a second. And 17 minutes after every hour, a clay pigeon is shot at a wall, creating a nice build-up of debris. The regularity of nature, labor and pointless human violence (and trash) are sparely but effectively evoked. Bortolami Dayan, 510 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2050, bortolamidayan.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: 'Spanish Painting from El Greco to Picasso, TIME, TRUTH, AND HISTORY' This show is spectacularly grand and avoids the familiar piety of the standard masterpiece potpourri by virtue of its eloquent installation in the museum's loopy ramp, still the weirdest-coolest place to look at art and at other people looking at art. It's carried along on its sheer star power and optical finesse. There are dozens of Goyas and Velázquezes and Zurbaráns and El Grecos and Riberas and Dalís and Picassos, many famous, many not. The show's big point is that Spanish art did not constantly reinvent itself over time. It was a bubble culture, sustained for centuries by its political and religious isolation and its national loner mindset. Velázquez's painting of a dwarf is alone worth crossing a continent to see. 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, guggenheim.org; closes on Wednesday. (Kimmelman) MERLIN JAMES: PAINTING TO PAINTING Nearly three dozen small canvases by this British artist prove that old-fashioned appropriation -- forthright homages to other painters' paintings -- remains pertinent. Tribute is paid to works like Millet's ''Sower,'' Daumier's ''Don Quixote and Sancho Panza'' and ''Bonnard's ''Self-Portrait in the Bathroom Mirror.'' Some are instantly recognizable. Others border on the abstract. But all achieve a sense of life and mystery on their own terms, in the here and now. And the use of precedents reduces the arbitrariness that can afflict Mr. James's work. New York Studio School, 8 West Eighth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 673-6466, www.nyss.org; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK: 'A CITY ON PAPER: SAUL STEINBERG'S NEW YORK' This display of some 40 drawings focuses on New York, with a special section putting his work in dialogue with items from the museum's collection. An architect, Steinberg was particularly attracted to the city's edifices like the Chrysler Building, which appears here in one incarnation, looming majestically over humble brownstones and in another incarnation, from a perspective directly below it, looking positively squat. New York people, in Steinberg's eyes, could be monuments, too, like the public relations executive Benjamin Sonnenberg, depicted in 1950 adorning a pompous Victorian interior, a short figure tightly buttoned into a bespoke suit, his head topped by a derby, his face decorated by a handlebar mustache. And no one ever fully appreciated the impact of upscale New York women until Steinberg the misogynist came along. ''Fur Coats'' (1951) portrays four expensive baroque pelts wearing four women, and it's dead on. You may think you know Steinberg's work, but this show makes it new. 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street, (212) 534-1672, mcny.org; closes on Sunday. (Glueck) * DAVID SALLE: 'BEARDING THE LION IN HIS DEN' This re-creation of a haunting installation Mr. Salle exhibited at the Kitchen in 1977, just before he took up painting, gives a glimpse of the influence of 1970s anti-object art on 80s painting. The accompanying Tim Buckley song may carry a little too much of the emotional load, but the piece is nonetheless a fascinating skeleton key both to Mr. Salle's coolly romantic sensibility and his penchant for juxtaposition and layering, as are some early works on paper. Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 343-7300, www.deitch.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith) COURTNEY SMITH: BUILD UP The main attraction among these sculptures tailored from sliced-up furniture and furniture seemingly fashioned from white abstract sculpture is a wild and conflicted parquet floor. The levels and colors vary, but the conventional herringbone formation is strictly maintained. Roebling Hall, 606 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-8180, www.roeblinghall.com; closes on Wednesday. (Smith) Michael Waugh: 'Lead me astray' Mr. Waugh's work is about close reading. Several large drawings of 19th-century landscapes are composed of handwritten phrases, cut and pasted in nonsensical order, from American presidential inauguration speeches. A drawing of the Spanish colonial explorer Cabeza de Vaca, who landed in Florida, is installed in a room plastered with promotional materials from a different colonialist enterprise, the last Art Basel/Miami fair. Schroeder Romero, 637 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 630-0722; closes tomorrow. (Cotter)

NATHANSON--Irwin B., of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Purchase, NY died suddenly on March 20th, 2007 at age 85. Born in Pittsburgh. He graduated from George Washington University. His long and successful business career included working for Monsanto and senior executive positions for United Merchants and Manufacturers and Troy Mills before founding Trans World Products. He served on the boards of Jewish Board of Family and Children's Service and Linden Hill Schools. He was a member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club and the Chemists Club. In his retirement, he lived life to its fullest through golf, his grandchildren and travel. He is survived by his devoted wife of 54 years, Sally, his brother Bennett, his loving sons Larry and Andy and their wives Larraine and Elyse and his beloved grandchildren Lilly, Brian, Charlie, Alison, Kevin and Jack.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 British Police Arrest 3 In '05 Transit Bombings The British police seized three men for offenses related to the bombings in the London transit system on July 7, 2005, in which suicide bombers killed themselves and 52 passengers. The arrests were the first in Britain in connection with the attack. A3 A Bittersweet Return for Iraqis Under the protective cover of the latest Baghdad security plan, a small number of families who had fled their neighborhoods because of soaring sectarian violence are returning. Many are finding, however, that the threat of violence that drove them away remains very real. A1 A mortar shell fired into the Green Zone landed about 80 yards from the home of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki while he and the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, held a news conference on Mr. Ban's first Baghdad visit. A9 North Korea Talks Halted Talks in Beijing aimed at dismantling North Korea's nuclear weapons program were halted by China after they stalled over the failure to release up to $25 million in a Macao bank that North Korea had demanded be returned before it continued negotiations. A7 Egypt Standoff Shows Unrest A standoff in Egypt between the government and poor families being evicted from a village that sits atop some of the world's most ancient tombs, illustrates the challenges facing a government that for decades imposed its will on the people but now seeks to adjust the social contract without causing unrest. A10 Law and the Koran in Germany A German judge caused an uproar in a ruling that underlines the tension between Muslim customs and European laws, citing the Koran in turning down a physically beaten Muslim woman's request for a divorce. A10 NATIONAL A11-19 Despite Wife's Cancer, Edwards Will Press On John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat, said that his wife's cancer had returned in an incurable form. But he plans to continue his bid for the presidency, saying, ''The campaign goes on strongly.'' A1 Housing Woes Hurt Suburbs In a sign of the spreading economic fallout of mortgage foreclosures, several suburbs of Cleveland, one of the nation's hardest-hit cities, are spending millions of dollars to maintain vacant houses as they try to contain blight and real-estate panic. A1 Army Desertions are Higher A total of 3,196 active-duty soldiers deserted the Army last year, or 853 more than previously reported, according to revised figures from the Army. A11 Online Pornography Ruling A federal judge in Philadelphia struck down a 1998 law that made it a crime for Web sites to allow children to gain access to material deemed ''harmful.'' The ruling is the second major setback in federal efforts to control Internet pornography. The United States Supreme Court struck down a similar law in 1997. A11 Florida May Move Primary Date Florida could move its presidential primary to as early as Jan. 29 -- a week before the date that California set this month and that New York, Texas and a flurry of other states are considering -- after the House of Representatives approved the change this week. A16 Ousted Prosecutor Speaks Out The ousted United States attorney in western Michigan, Margaret M. Chiara, said she was told last November that she was being forced out to make way for another lawyer the Bush administration wanted to groom, not because of management problems. A19 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Polygamy Follows Immigrants From Africa Polygamy in America tends to be associated with Mormon splinter groups out West, but a fire in the Bronx that killed 10 Malian immigrants from two families revealed its presence in New York. No one knows how prevalent polygamy is in New York, but dozens of interviews with African immigrants, officials and scholars suggest that it involves thousands. A1 Baby Boom for Wealthy Whites The number of children under age 5 living in Manhattan has grown by more than 32 percent since 2000, and a new analysis for The Times shows that wealthy white families have been driving that growth. B1 Boy Recalls Shooting Horror An 11-year-old boy who witnessed a shooting and robbery in a Queens deli owned by his father tells the harrowing tale of what he saw. B1 ESCAPES F1-10 An Eco-Hideaway in Mexico A Texas-based developer is making the first large-scale attempt to build an environmentally sensitive, master-planned residential project in the inland region of the Riviera Maya in Mexico, best known for beach resorts and the night life of Cancún. F1 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-8 Top Coach to Go to Minnesota After leading the University of Kentucky to the N.C.A.A. Tournament for 10 straight years, Tubby Smith will become the University of Minnesota's next head coach, a school official confirmed. The move is considered a step down in the college basketball world. D4 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 States Team Up With Eli Lilly Eli Lilly offers to help states to monitor doctors who treat Medicaid patients to make sure they are not wasting money on mental illness drugs. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: A cleaner food and drug agency; new coin of the realm; foiled by the gun lobby; Verlyn Klinkenborg on California doughnuts and ground squirrels. Column: Thomas L. Friedman. Crossword E31 TV Listings E26 Weather A18
MARTIN--George, 74, of Melbourne, Florida, formerly of New York City, passed away March 15th, 2007. Condolences may be sent to: beachfuneralhome.com

LITTLEJOHN--Barbara, age 89, of New York, NY on Monday, November 19th. Founder of Barbara Littlejohn Inc., an executive search firm for the retail industry. She conducted her personal life and business affairs with great integrity and generosity and is survived by many loving friends. There will be no memorial service at the direction of the deceased.

Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday, about a measure passed by the Georgia House to ban the sale of candy made to taste like marijuana, misidentified the substance that marketers say is used to flavor the candy. It is hemp essential oil, not hempseed oil.

A front-page article on Tuesday about possible financial consequences for the Anglican Communion if it severs ties with the Episcopal Church in the United States for consecrating an openly gay bishop misspelled the surname of a priest who said the American church ''is not a pariah to everybody.'' She is the Rev. Lisa Fischbeck, not Fishbeck.

In the dense tropical forest west of the Mayan ruins of Tulum, a Texas-based developer is creating a jungle community, hoping to attract buyers more interested in exotic birds and wild orchids than ocean views. The project, Los Árboles Tulum (www.losarbolestulum.com), is the first large-scale attempt to build an environmentally sensitive, master-planned residential project in the inland region of the Riviera Maya, the Mexican vacation destination best known for beach resorts and the night life of Cancún.

Elective Affinities Tracy Williams Ltd. 313 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village Through April 21 Jennifer Nocon has titled her first solo show after Goethe's romance novel ''Elective Affinities.'' The book's premise is that when like is attracted to like, passion will ignite in disastrous ways, but when opposites come together, ardor is low, and so the potential exists for a long-term relationship. Ms. Nocon follows Goethe's lead but also suggests another possibility.

WYTON--Alec, 85, died March 18 at Danbury Hospital. Service March 23, at 3pm at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 351 Main St., Ridgefield, CT. Memorial contributions, in lieu of flowers, may be made to St. Dominic's Home, 500 Western Highway, Blauvelt, NY 10913.

LILLY OFFER HAS STRING ATTACHED -- Eli Lilly offers to help state Medicaid drug programs offset the expense of Zyprexa, its anti-psychotic drug, by monitoring patients' prescriptions to make sure they are not taking any drugs needlessly. But this free offer comes with a catch -- Lilly pays for the service only if the states let doctors prescribe Zyprexa without first seeking permission from the state. [Page A1.] ORACLE TAKES SAP TO COURT -- Oracle sued its rival in the field of business software, SAP, accusing the German company of intruding into its computer systems to carry out ''corporate theft on a grand scale.'' [C1.] THE UNDERWRITING MACHINE -- The engines that drove big increases in subprime mortgage applications and approvals were new computer programs that used the Internet to screen borrowers with weak credit histories in seconds. [C1.] BANK REGULATORS UNDER FIRE -- Democratic and Republican senators in Washington criticized banking regulators for failing to respond more quickly to curb the growth in risky home loans to people with weak credit. [C4.] CONCERN OVER EMPTY HOMES -- In a sign of the spreading economic fallout of mortgage foreclosures, several suburbs of Cleveland are spending millions of dollars to maintain vacant houses as they try to contain blight and real-estate panic. [A1.] HOME BUILDER'S PROFIT SINKS -- KB Home said that net profit for its fiscal first quarter fell 84 percent and warned that foreclosures and tighter lending standards could prolong weakness in the sector. The spring selling season is proving unstable, and that condition could persist, said KB's chief executive. [C4.] BLACKSTONE SET TO GO PUBLIC -- The Blackstone Group, the largest private equity firm in the nation, said that it would seek an initial public offering that would value the firm at as much as $40 billion and that would offer a first glimpse inside its closely guarded money-machine. It would be the first of the major private equity firms to go public.[C1.] CELLPHONE USE IN PLANES -- The Federal Communications Commission is expected to block the idea of allowing cellphone use on airplanes over concerns that the network on the ground could not handle the calls. [C3.] MOTOROLA'S CHIEF -- The future of Edward J. Zander, the chairman and chief executive of Motorola who announced sharply lower earnings estimates on Wednesday, may depend on his ability to come up with another hit like the Razr V3 cellphone. [C3.] BORDERS'S CHANGE OF DIRECTION -- The Borders Group, one of the nation's largest book retailers, announced a strategic plan to close nearly half of its Waldenbooks stores, sell off or franchise most of its 73 overseas superstores, sever its relationship with Amazon.com and start its own online retail site. [C2.] 'OPEN SKIES' APPROVED IN EUROPE -- The European Union approved the so-called open skies agreement, a deal with the United States to open the trans-Atlantic aviation market to more competition. But the deal quickly produced complaints. [C8.] TIME TO GO SHOPPING -- Carrefour, the world's second-largest retailer, is in play -- the result of a dynastic squabble, the dismissal of a senior executive, pressure from powerful interlopers hunting for profit, and growing interest in the store's high-priced commercial real estate. [C1.] ONE WORD: COAL -- Consol Energy has started a campaign to burnish the image of coal producers, and attract more people to a career in mining. Advertising. [C3.] CAUTION ON THE STREET -- The Dow Jones industrial average rose for a fourth consecutive session, but barely, and investors were cautious, awaiting new data to assess whether the hopes of some analysts for an interest rate cut were justified. [C10.] EDITOR RESIGNS IN LOS ANGELES -- The editorial page editor of The Los Angeles Times, Andres Martinez, resigned after saying that he had been undermined by his publisher over what Mr. Martinez described as a ''perception of a conflict of interest.'' [A15.] TIMES RAISES DIVIDEND -- The New York Times Company, under pressure from investors because of its stagnant stock performance, announced that it would raise its quarterly dividend by 31 percent. [C7.] INTEL LOOKING TOWARD CHINA -- Intel appears ready to announce it will build a chip fabrication plant in northern China, a move that could improve the company's competitiveness. [C3.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Wal-Mart Stores made its annual bonuses for store employees public for the first time in two decades, saying that about 80 percent of hourly workers would split more than half a billion dollars. (ASSOCIATED PRESS) Jurors at Conrad M. Black's trial were told that a major investor in Mr. Black's giant media company blew the whistle on fees and perks that he and his lieutenants were collecting and that Mr. Black was out of a job not long after that. (REUTERS) Hub International, the insurance broker, said that its recently announced agreement to be acquired had been amended to increase the purchase price for each share to $41.50, from $40. (REUTERS) Pfizer said a court ruling upholding the company's patent on the blood pressure medication Norvasc was reversed by a federal appeals court, possibly paving the way for a generic version of the drug six months ahead of schedule. QUINN--Patrick. Actors' Equity Association invites you to celebrate the life of Patrick Quinn, former AEA President and Exec. Director Designee, on Monday, March 26, 2007 at 2pm, St. James Theatre, 246 W. 44th St., NYC. Doors open at 1pm. Info: 212-869-8530 x 409

Opens today in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. Directed by Q. Allan Brocka Not rated; 88 minutes Based on the novel by Matthew Rettenmund, ''Boy Culture'' is a slick and absorbing drama about an attractive gay hustler named X (Derek Magyar), with an extensive investment portfolio and a restricted clientele of 12 wealthy men. When not servicing his ''disciples,'' X conducts a volatile relationship with his two roommates (Darryl Stephens and Jonathon Trent) and criticizes the gay lifestyle in cynical voice-over. Only when he takes on a reclusive and much older client (elegantly played by Patrick Bauchau) is he forced to pay attention to a story other than his own.

Matthew Marks 523 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through April 14 Nan Goldin's last outing at Matthew Marks was an affecting slide presentation that explored her older sister's teenage suicide and Ms. Goldin's own descent into self-mutilation and a stint in rehab. There was a codalike aspect to the work, however, that made you wonder: where would Ms. Goldin go from here?

Projects 84: The Alpine Cathedral and the City-Crown The Museum of Modern Art Through April 9 The success of Josiah McElheny, a MacArthur fellow, lies in his ability to dazzle the mind and the eye, marrying history, science and aesthetic theory with virtuosic presentations of hand-blown glass. A recent sculpture inspired by the chandeliers at the Metropolitan Opera, for instance, also incorporates in its structure astronomical theories on the birth and history of the universe.

When the Florida Gators practiced yesterday in preparation for today's regional semifinal against Butler, the reporters at courtside wanted to ask Coach Billy Donovan if he would be interested in moving to Kentucky to replace Tubby Smith. ''I'll be right back,'' Donovan said. But he never emerged from the locker room, and team officials discouraged the further presence of members of the news media. Jeremy Foley, Florida's athletic director, said such a question would be highly inappropriate.

John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat, said Thursday that his wife's cancer had returned in incurable form. He proclaimed that he would continue his bid for the presidency, saying, ''The campaign goes on strongly.'' The announcement here by Mr. Edwards and his wife, Elizabeth, followed an emotional 72-hour stretch.

ZEBROWSKI--Kenneth. The faculty and staff of the Nathan S. Kline Institute for Psychiatric Research mourn the loss of our dear friend Assemblyman Kenneth Zebrowski. We will miss his optimism, his passion and his commitment to improving the lives of others. We send our sympathy to Linda and his entire family. Harold S. Koplewicz, Director

H2NY Alexander and Bonin 132 10th Avenue, near 18th Street Chelsea Through March 31 An original, card-carrying Young British Artist, Michael Landy made his New York solo debut in 1989 with a project for the windows of Grey Art Gallery at New York University. In 2001 he made international news with a work called ''Break Down,'' for which he built a large machine, installed it in the window of an unused London department store and systematically crushed or pulverized absolutely all his earthly possessions, save his cat.

Consolidation in European banking, while long expected, has come only in fits and starts. Politics and management issues have made cross-border deals a challenge. But the $80 billion-plus merger being discussed between Barclays of Britain and ABN Amro of the Netherlands might finally ignite a wave of deal making.

MILLER--Martin W. of Riverdale and Fleischmanns, New York, passed on March 17, 2007. Devoted and loving husband to wife Miriam, father to sons Michael and Daniel, father-in-law to Rochelle, and beloved grandfather to Lauren and Allison. Born in Frankfurt, Germany on October 2, 1923. Veteran Master Sergeant U.S. Army CounterIntelligence in World War II. Principal Mundial Export Corporation of New York City and Tarrytown, New York for over 60 years. Memorial donations may be sent to the American Cancer Society. A man of integrity.

The city's tourism agency opened an office in Moscow yesterday, officials said. The office of the agency, NYC & Company, is among 11 recently opened overseas by New York City. The agency said New York is a top destination for Russian visitors to the United States and that about 46,000 Russians visited the city last year, an increase of 24.3 percent over the previous year.

''Offside,'' the new film from the Iranian director Jafar Panahi, is a sports movie in which the game takes place entirely out of sight. The setting, most of the time, is a stadium in Tehran, where the Iranian national soccer team is facing Bahrain in a qualifying match for the World Cup. We hear the cheers and groans of the crowd and some improvised play-by-play from a few spectators, but like the film's main characters -- die-hard supporters of the team, some of them adorned with face paint in the red, white and green of the Iranian flag -- we never see what is happening on the field. Those unlucky fans are young women, whose attempts to see the match live are stymied by the police and by strict rules forbidding the mixing of the sexes. Trying to pass for boys, a half-dozen of them have been rounded up and confined to a makeshift holding pen on a ramp outside the stadium walls. The young soldiers who are their captors seem to be just as confused and demoralized as the women themselves, and the film's rich, pointed comedy arises from the sense that all of them, men and women alike, are trapped in an absurd, insoluble predicament.

The New York Times Company, under pressure from investors because of its stagnant stock performance, announced today that it would raise its quarterly dividend by 31 percent. ''This dividend increase, which is another important step in creating value for our shareholders, puts our dividend yield and payout ratio significantly above that of the S.& P. 500 and others in our industry,'' the chairman of the company, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., said.

Loving husband and partner of Marilyn, devoted father of Lisa Rovner (Arthur), Jonathan (Betty), Andrea Rachman (Marc), and Bill Bergofin (Lisa). Special grandpa Ira to Aaron, Michel, Rachel, Hannah, Zachary, Gabriela and Annika. Beloved brother of Marty, special friend and ''toastmaster'' to many. Thank you to Jedd Wolshok, M.D., and Carolyn Quinn, RN, and staff at MSKCC. Services Sunday, 11:15am, at The Riverside 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

When the 3LD Art & Technology Center was under construction last year, workers unearthed a silent black-and-white film from beneath a concrete slab. A 1927 movie, it told the dark tale of a maid and a long-suffering valet who set out to murder their sinister boss. The film has been restored and is being shown at 3LD. O.K., not really, but that is the premise for ''The Curse of the Mystic Renaldo The,'' which really is onstage at 3LD and has been extended through April 28. ''Curse,'' right, is a noir-tinted comedy that mixes elements of film, vaudeville, cabaret, theater and rock to create, well, an oddity of experimental theater. Aldo Perez, the show's creator and star, is Renaldo The, whom audience members (munching free popcorn handed out preshow) first see in a movie clip. Renaldo's chambermaid (Jenny Lee Mitchell) and his valet (a resolutely deadpan Richard Ginocchio) are plotting his murder, and just as they are doing the deed, the movie screen falls to the floor, revealing live actors. A dream sequence, of sorts, ensues -- perhaps Renaldo's life is flashing before our eyes? All who attend must abandon the search for narrative structure, unless perhaps the story of 3LD's stagehands will suffice. They are visible throughout, and they are just as intriguing as the characters onstage. Renaldo's free-associative monologues and a series of hallucinatory vignettes mix with rock music interludes, courtesy of Mr. Perez and members of his band, Psycho the Clown, as psychosexual power struggles play out among the three main characters. ''Curse'' even has a slight touch of ''The Carol Burnett Show'' about it -- at moments, Mr. Perez and his fellow actors seem to fight against laughing at their own shenanigans. Or are they smirking at that rubber chicken that becomes an unlikely object of Renaldo's affection? (Fridays and Saturdays at 10 p.m., through April 28, 3LD Art & Technology Center, 80 Greenwich Street, between Edgar and Rector, Lower Manhattan, 212-352-3101, theatermania.com; $20). STEVEN McELROY

COLLIER--Daniel. The members of the Board of Directors and the Officers of Park Hill Tenants Corporation mourn the passing of their colleague, friend and neighbor. His unstinting service to the Board of Directors and his neighbors, his kindness and unfailing courtesy earned him the respect and affectionate regard of all who worked with him. Opens today nationwide. Directed by Bob Shaye 94 minutes Invoking Lewis Carroll, ''E.T.'' and Tibetan Buddhism, ''The Last Mimzy'' is an overstuffed yet warmhearted sci-fi drama about a dying planet, resourceful kids and a science teacher firmly in touch with his spiritual side.

Opens today nationwide. Directed by Sunu Gonera 104 minutes ''Pride,'' about a swim coach (Terrence Howard) leading an urban recreational center's swim team to a championship, about 1971, illustrates the adaptability and limitations of the sports movie.

The Buckeyes followed up their stunning overtime win against No. 9 Xavier in the second round of the tournament with perhaps an even more impressive effort.

Opens today in New York and Los Angeles. Directed by Bennett Davlin 98 minutes In ''Memory'' Billy Zane plays Dr. Taylor Briggs, a researcher specializing in memory loss who becomes infected by a powdery substance while examining a patient in Brazil. Before you can say, ''What's that again?,'' Taylor is having dream-infused seizures, during which he sees running children, flapping vegetation and a masked man in a black duster. The more he investigates the source of his visions, the more we are treated to shots of him staring at a computer while furrowing his brow. Audiences will leave the theater wearing a similar expression.
CHAPLIN--Arthur. 8 long, quiet years and we still say ''Thank You''. Mimi, etc.

Judith Nathan had been married twice, and not once as generally believed, before she wed Rudolph W. Giuliani in 2003, aides on the Giuliani presidential campaign said last night. The first marriage, to Jeffrey Scott Ross in 1974, was reported yesterday by The New York Post on its Web site. Ms. Nathan, then Ms. Stish, was about 20 at the time of her first marriage, the article said.

Few people watched last night's game between U.C.L.A. and Pittsburgh with more mixed emotions than Manhattan Coach Barry Rohrssen. Rohrssen just completed his first year at Manhattan after a seven-year stint at Pittsburgh as an assistant coach and associate head coach under both Ben Howland and Jamie Dixon. Howland and Dixon are the best of friends -- their relationship stretches back to when Howland recruited Dixon as a high school player.

LEVINE--Barry J. On March 21, 2007, after a two-year battle with multiple myeloma. Born on June 6, 1945, Mr. Levine graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1970. After a stint with the Nassau County District Attorneys Office, he established a private law practice and represented the Garden City Hotel, in Garden City, New York, for many years, never missing a day of work until three months before his death. Mr. Levine is survived by two daughters, Rachel and Amy; a son, Bradley; Rachel's husband, Michael Hyman; two grandchildren, Jordan and Max Hyman; Amy's husband, Phil Raskin; his loving companion, Margie Lefkowitz, and her children, Michelle and David; a brother, Bill Perry, his wife, Enid, and a nephew and niece, Adam and Alison Perry; a sister, Nancy Levine, her husband, Dr. George Hafitz, and their son, Michael Jacko; and his mother, Dolly. His father, Julius Bub Levine, predeceased him. The funeral will be conducted at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island, on Sunday, March 25, at 1:00 pm.

A Camden police officer was indicted yesterday on charges that he conspired to rob a drug dealer, provided a gun for the robbery and agreed to launder the proceeds, state prosecutors said. The officer, Cpl. Michael Anthony Hearne, 42, of Woodbury, was charged with giving a .38-caliber pistol to another man, who he believed was going to commit the robbery, said Attorney General Stuart Rabner. Corporal Hearne was arrested at the Super 8 Motel in Bellmawr on Nov. 10, 2006, as he went to meet with the second man, the state police said, and was suspended. Corporal Hearne's lawyer did not return a telephone call yesterday afternoon. TINA KELLEY

Opens today in New York and Orange County and San Jose, Calif. Directed by Ham Tran In Vietnamese and English, with English subtitles. 135 minutes Dying is easy, comedy is hard, and melodrama is almost impossible. The writer-director Ham Tran achieves the impossible in ''Journey From the Fall,'' a sprawling tearjerker about a war-splintered South Vietnamese family trying to survive the aftermath of the American withdrawal and then seek a new life in the United States.

CHAYKIN--Irving. The Baruch College community is deeply saddened at the passing of Irving Chaykin, 1932, Professor Emeritus in the Stan Ross Department of Accountancy, on March 18. Irving Chaykin arrived at Baruch in 1929 and never left us. He was a beloved faculty member for more than 35 years and a loyal alumnus his entire adult life. The famed Chaykin CPA Review course trained generations of accountants. In 1995, the College preserved his legacy by dedicating the Irving J. Chaykin Conference Room in his honor. Baruch alumni everywhere remember him with deep affection and respect. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Clarice, his wife of more than 60 years, to his children, Daniel, Maury and Debra, to his many grandchildren, and to his former colleagues and students. Kathleen Waldron, President, Baruch College Larry Zicklin 1957, President, The Baruch College Fund

(Monday through Thursday) Documentaries have been among the most memorable films in the annual New Directors/New Films festival, a joint presentation of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art. This year, as a sidebar to the main event, the festival is presenting ''Essential Documentaries,'' a selection of its greatest nonfiction hits of the last 35 years. Mark Lewis's perennially popular and side-splittingly funny 1988 Australian film ''Cane Toads: An Unnatural History'' (with Mr. Lewis, above) begins the series of matinee screenings at Lincoln Center at 1 p.m. Monday, followed by Bill Brand's 1990 look at New York street dwellers, ''Home Less Home.'' Tuesday brings Monteith McCollum's ''Hybrid,'' a 2000 study of his grandfather, a creator of hybrid corn, followed by Jehane Noujaim's provocative 2003 study of the news agency Al Jazeera, ''Control Room.'' On Wednesday a double bill pays tribute to the late documentarian and festival favorite Christian Blackwood, with his 1980 history ''Tapdancin' '' and his 1978 show business portrait ''Roger Corman: Hollywood's Wild Angel.'' On Thursday Lee Grant's 1980 study of a bank strike led by women, ''The Willmar 8,'' is followed by Julia Loktev's intimate, devastating ''Moment of Impact'' (1998), a portrait of her father, the victim of severe head trauma, and his injury's toll on his family. (Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5600, filmlinc.org; $10.) DAVE KEHR
To the Editor: Re ''Communist Party USA Gives Its History to N.Y.U.'' (front page, March 20):

On both sides of the Capitol, Democrats considered emergency war spending proposals, which they are trying to use as vehicles to change course in the four-year-old Iraq war. The Senate Appropriations Committee adopted a nonbinding goal of removing troops by March 31, 2008, setting the stage for a vote by the full Senate as soon as next week. In the House, Democratic leaders said they were confident a plan to set a timeline to bring troops home from Iraq by Sept. 1, 2008, would pass today by a slim margin, though they conceded there was little room for error. Article, Page A8.

The National Center for Space Research opened its files on U.F.O.'s, putting them on a Web site that was quickly jammed by heavy traffic. The archive, at www.cnes-geipan.fr/geipan/, spans 50 years. JOHN TAGLIABUE

A contracting company that worked for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development has been barred from performing work for the city and state for five years after city investigators found it had not paid required wages, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., said yesterday. Mr. Thompson said a city administrative law judge determined that the company, Integrity Construction and Consulting Services, of Queens, had underpaid four carpenters, two laborers and a bricklayer who worked on a renovation of 536-38 West 163rd Street, by a total of $189,633.22.

BROWN--Janet, (born in Philadelphia, PA, May 23, 1947), died suddenly in a car accident on Friday, March 16th as she drove to work. Janet enjoyed an iconic career as founder of Janet Brown Ltd., the chic Long Island boutique. She was loved by her friends, respected by her colleagues; her quick irreverent sense of humor and extraordinary heart will be missed by all. She is survived by her sister Elaine Edelstein, of Villanova, PA, her brother-in-law Marc, and her niece and nephew Brandon and Melissa, in addition to her countless friends. Funeral services will be held Tuesday March 20, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison and 81st street. Donations may be made in the name of Janet Brown to the New York University Child Study Center, 577 1st Ave, NY, NY 10016. $(6$)BROWN--Janet. We will miss your outrageous honesty, your lack of political correctness, your ability to have a good time and make sure everyone else had a better time. Your relentless pursuit of fun with your innumerable friends. Everyone loved you for your enduring indomitable spirit. Our family has suffered a loss that will never be replaced. We'll miss you at all of our family celebrations, our vacations, and our parties. Life will never be the same without you and your endless dance moves. Brooke, Dan, Jon, Stephen and Mallory.

McGOWAN--Vivian P. of Riverdale, NY, on March 17th. Wife of the late William J. McGowan, devoted mother of Marianne, Elizabeth, and William J. Loving grandmother of Emily, Nicholas, Peter and Timothy Prokesch and Andrew, Kara and Paulina McGowan. Daughter of the late Julius F. and Julia F. Pitassy. Sister of the late Reginald F. and Caesar L. Pitassy, and of Helen P. York of Brewster, NY. A graduate of the College of Mt. St. Vincent and Fordham Law School, she was a partner in the firm of McGowan & McGowan. Formerly with the Coorporation Counsel of the City of New York, she was an attorney with the Supreme Court of the State of New York, for more than 30 years, most recently as a principal appellate court attorney in the Appellate Term First Department, and was a past president of the Bronx County Bar Association. Funeral Saturday, March 24th, at 11:00 am, at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 10 W. Stevens Avenue, Hawthorne, NY 10532. Opens today nationwide. Directed by Kevin Munroe 90 minutes As Hollywood falls over itself to produce greener movies with ecologically correct themes, only the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles remain willing to suggest that there is an upside to toxic waste. Spawned by sludge and grandiosely named after Renaissance artists, these crime-fighting reptiles have been rechristened ''TMNT'' and redrawn by an army of computer-generated-imagery specialists. Nevertheless, the now-23-year-old gang -- perhaps to connect better with its target audience -- is still living at home.

An article yesterday about a vote authorizing a strike by the faculty of California State University gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a university spokeswoman who said she does not foresee a shutdown of the university. She is Clara Potes-Fellow, not Portes-Fellow.

Two years ago a shipment of more than 1,100 wild orchids was intercepted in Miami. Packed in just a dozen unmarked cardboard boxes, they had been gathered and sent illegally from the Philippines and were in bad shape, dehydrated with broken stems, wilted flowers and crushed leaves. The waning treasures -- some were worth as much as $500 -- were sent to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx for rehabilitation, one of the few places in the country capable of that kind of care. Now these wayward blooms have been nursed back to health and are on display as part of the fifth annual Orchid Show there. The country's largest curator-organized exhibition, it features more than 8,000 individual flowers, from the platystele, a miniature dotted with tiny blossoms smaller than the head of a pin, to the cattelya, which has a 10-inch flower. Unlike a juried floral competition, this display features history and information about the seeding, care and biology of the orchid, a plant that has fascinated people since at least 1000 B.C., when it appeared in the writings of Confucius, said Marc Hachadourian, the exhibit's curator.

''Cobra Verde,'' Werner Herzog's 1987 film starring Klaus Kinski, center at right, is only one of 16 movies crowding onto screens this weekend. (A. O. Scott's review is on Page 12.) Times critics sort through the pack, which also includes ''Reign Over Me,'' starring Don Cheadle and Adam Sandler; ''First Snow,'' with Guy Pearce; ''The Shooter,'' with Mark Wahlberg; ''Color Me Kubrick,'' with John Malkovich; ''The Page Turner''; and for children ''The Last Mimzy'' and the return of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in ''TMNT.'' Reviews begin on Page 8.

SLADE--Terry, Shareholders and previous residents of 465 West End Avenue have enjoyed Terry Slade's cheerful presence for over 60 years, but now are deeply saddened by his passing on March 20. We are indebted to him for his assistance in designing our lobby, and to his beloved wife, Joan, who died in 1990, for her part in establishing the co-op corporation as well as serving on the board for many years. Our sincerest condolences to his children and his family. The Board of Directors
FISHER--Grace. Happy Anniversary, my love. Your spirit lives on in our hearts, and you inspire us everyday. Your greatest gift is my present happiness. Jake and Murphy send love.

A hall monitor at Roslyn High School was arrested yesterday after two bags of cocaine fell out of her pocket in a hallway, the Nassau County police said. A teacher and a student at the school told the police that they saw the cocaine drop from the monitor's pocket while she was on duty, the authorities said. The monitor, Evelyn J. Garza, 46, of Roslyn Heights, was expected to be arraigned on drug possession charges last night, the police said. The monitor's identity was confirmed by a hallway security camera, according to the Roslyn School District. Ms. Garza was suspended without pay after her arrest, the district said. NICOLE COTRONEO

Defiance in Pharaohs' Valley About 80 families are defying Egypt's plan to evict them from mud brick houses atop ancient tombs, and are rejecting offers of villas in a kind of Levittown. They say they want more from a government that is reluctant to use brute force. PAGE A10 Paper's Editorial Chief Quits After a special section was canceled, the editorial page editor of The Los Angeles Times resigned, saying he had been undermined by his publisher. The funniest moment of Thad Matta's postgame press conference came when a reporter from Ohio decided to point out the pink elephant in the room.
During Ohio State's 92-76 victory against Memphis on Saturday, a woman sat near mid-court with a white sign that read, "Calling Coach C, UK Line 1."

In the spring of 2004, when Greg Oden and Mike Conley Jr. were sophomores in high school, I took a trip to Indianapolis to write about Oden. An assistant college coach in Indiana had told me that Oden was the best center prospect he'd ever seen, the sure-fire No. 1 pick in the 2006 N.B.A. draft.

Its hard to miss Greg Oden. The center for Ohio State, Oden is arguably the most recognizable player in this N.C.A.A. tournament, a 7-foot reminder of the impact of the N.B.A.'s new early entry rules.

The lineup for the Sunday news shows seems split between two of the main topics of the week just ended: first, the firings of United States attorneys and the constitutional battle that is thundering between the White House and Congress; second, the vote on the Iraq war spending that face a certain veto by President Bush. A third topic, the continuing presidential campaign of former North Carolina Senator John Edwards, despite the news that his wife's cancer has now spread, is bound to weave its way through some of the interviews and chatter around the roundtables.

The women's game might be growing, but drawing fans is still a concern for N.C.A.A. tournament officials. That's why No. 1 Duke was sent just 50 miles west of Durham, N.C., to play in the Greensboro Regional this weekend. The Blue Devils have a strong following and drew 6,392 to Greensboro Coliseum for their game against No. 4 Rutgers on Saturday.

The Duke women's basketball coach, Gail Goestenkors, has been named in several reports as the No. 1 candidate on Texas' wish list as the Longhorns look to fill the opening created by Jody Conradt's resignation. Goeskenkors declined to address the speculation on Saturday after her top-seeded Blue Devils, the N.C.A.A.tournament favorite, were knocked out by No. 4 Rutgers, 53-52, in Greensboro, N.C.

I just received some cool photos from Luc Willems, the Spa circuit press officer. Spa in the snow is one thing, but Spa as it undergoes its partial redesign, is quite another. Here are a couple of the shots. I might do an image gallery later. Both shots below are taken from the Source hairpin. The first shows the garage side - with the garages on the left - while the second shows the old garage side, leading down to Eau Rouge. You can see the first layer of repaving on the track, too, incidentally. I'm looking forward to seeing this revamped Spa in mid-September at the Belgian Grand Prix...when, I suspect, it will also be snowing....

Now that Coach Tubby Smith has left Kentucky for a new job at Minnesota, people at the Midwest Regional in St. Louis keep asking Billy Donovan of Florida if he is interested in taking over the Wildcats.

Arizona State made it to the Round of 8 for the first time in team history with a 67-49 victory Saturday against Bowling Green in the regional semifinals at Greensboro, N.C. When Rutgers followed by upsetting Duke, 53-52, in the other semifinal, it set up what is likely to be an emotional game between the Sun Devils and the Scarlet Knights on Monday in the regional final.

A gay migration has traveled up the West Side to Hell's Kitchen. This new gay presence, however, is very different from what went before. In the West Village and Chelsea, gay culture was in many respects the prevailing culture. But in Hell's Kitchen, the gay community is just one of many subcultures that share and sometimes compete for a common turf. As gays migrate to Hell's Kitchen, some say that harassment against them is a greater issue than in the more heavily gay neighborhoods of Greenwich Village and Chelsea.

Georgetown forward Jeff Green, along with his teammates and coach, met with the media on Saturday. It took 21 questions -- good thing it was not a game of 20 Questions -- before someone asked Green if he had seen a replay of his winning basket against Vanderbilt on Friday night, and whether he thought he had traveled before taking the shot.
Chances are decent, it would seem, that if you are reading this blog, you are not old enough to remember the 1982 national championship game between North Carolina and Georgetown.
Some stuff you couldn't make up if you tried. This is now a statement of fact: Carl Pavano is lined up to be the Yankees' opening-day starter.

The Memphis sophomore guard Antonio Anderson, the hero of the Tigers' victory against Texas A&M on Thursday night, went down with what appeared to be a gruesome injury with 3:25 remaining in the first half Saturday.Anderson was inadvertently elbowed in the face by his teammate Robert Dozier, who came down after leaping for a rebound and inadvertently connected with the right side of Anderson's face. Anderson lay on the court for about two minutes as two Memphis trainers tended to the bleeding on Anderson's face, then escorted him off the court.Anderson, who made the decisive free throws with 3.1 seconds remaining to beat Texas A&M, is one of the Tigers' key players, a starter who averages 7.9 points a game. A Memphis team official said he had a small cut above his right eye. He was receiving stitches and was expected to return.

The boisterous Ohio State band was cruising the riverwalk in a boat here in San Antonio more than three hours before today's game between the top-seeded Buckeyes and the No. 2-seeded Memphis Tigers in the N.C.A.A. tournament's South Regional final.
The 3 a.m. text messages that Ohio State Coach Thad Matta receives don't surprise him anymore.
How has a self-described timid mother put the leader of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, on the ropes? Nicholas Kristof reports from Islamabad.
The Memphis junior forward Joey Dorsey made headlines here in San Antonio on Friday with his trash talk about the Ohio State freshman center Greg Oden.
Fifty years after the company's first cars came to America, collectors are finding interest in Toyota.

The Mets play their final split-squad games of the spring today, meaning no more bus rides for guys like Mike Carp, Ben Johnson and Lastings Milledge. The regulars, as usual, are staying back in Port St. Lucie for a game against Baltimore, but a few members of the coaching staff are down in Jupiter for a game against the Marlins.

The Yankees received the results of Chien-Ming Wang's M.R.I. this morning, and the news was not good. Wang, who was lined up to pitch on opening day, will start the season on the disabled list and not return to the Yankees until the end of April, at the earliest.

This month's political best seller list, an exclusive to The Caucus, continues to carry some of the months-long hot books, but there are newcomers moving up that offer historical perspectives with parallels to the present, as well as current perspectives and examinations of events here-and-now.

My late grandfather, a military man with a crewcut you could balance a sheet of carbon paper on, loved nothing more than umpiring Little League games in Moweaqua, Ill. He was a modest, kind man, but he savored the power of being an umpire, the sense of order and justice it provided him. The world was chaotic, but inside the diamond, it was not, and only he had the ability to answer the unanswerable. In small-town Illinois youth baseball, games had only one umpire, and I don't think he would have wanted it any other way. There can be only one voice of truth.
Christina Aguilera is a bold performer with a huge voice and an unshakable faith in her own instincts. And that last fact probably helps explain Friday night’s rather disappointing show.
On bicycle, on foot and often behind the wheel, users of digital devices present potentially dangerous scenes every day.
Nature often looks better at a distance. “Planet Earth,” an 11-part mother of all nature series, understands this truth.
“The Hills Have Eyes 2” is essentially a catalog of transgressive images, lighted and edited like a heavy-metal video.
In a second podcast on disillusioned youth around the world, Calvin Sims discusses Britain’s young poor with Times London correspondent Sarah Lyall.
The province’s biggest Protestant party balked at joining a government with  Roman Catholics only two days before a deadline to restore a power-sharing local government.
Britain demanded “the immediate and safe return” of 15 naval personnel seized yesterday near disputed waters.
Secretary General Ban Ki-moon was seeking help in influencing Sudan to accept U.N. peacekeepers.
In a dazzling display of shooting, TajuanPorter scored 33 points Friday night to lead Oregon to a victory against Nevada-Las Vegas.
The young, gifted Tar Heels are capable of exploding at any moment, and that was what they did Friday night as they roared back from a 16-point second-half deficit.
Two people were wounded last night in a shooting outside a Bronx deli that drew a second gunman, who then fired at officers and fled, the police said.

The authorities said they had been unable to determine the precise source of the E. coli bacteria found in bagged fresh spinach last year that killed three people and sickened more than 200. But in a report released by the federal Food and Drug Administration and the California Department of Health Services, officials said they were able to identify environmental risk factors that probably contributed to the outbreak. Contaminated irrigation water, uncomposted manure used as fertilizer, the presence of wildlife and livestock and the hygiene of the workers handling the crops all might have served to transport the E. coli 0157:H7 bacteria, they said. “We do not know, ultimately, how that contamination happened,” said Dr. Kevin Reilly of the California Department of Health Services.
Kobe Bryant finished with 50 points Friday night to become the second N.B.A. player to hit that mark in four consecutive games, leading the Lakers over the Hornets.
For the second straight night, the Knicks looked thoroughly disjointed as they scored a season-low 68 points and are now a season-high nine games below .500.

State residents will be able to use driver’s licenses to cross the border from Canada as part of a pilot program to make identification requirements more flexible, the Homeland Security Department said. Residents can apply for a driver’s license that is “slightly more expensive” than a standard license and requires proof of citizenship and residence similar to that needed for a passport, according to a department statement. Currently, residents can use a conventional driver’s license or birth certificate, but starting as soon as January 2008, American citizens may be required to show a passport before re-entering the country via land or sea from Mexico, Canada, the Caribbean, Bermuda, Central America and South America.

A judge has ordered the state to halt pumping water out of the Sacramento-San Joaquin River delta within 60 days unless it complies with environmental laws that protect endangered fish. The ruling Thursday by the judge, Frank Roesch of Alameda County Superior Court, found that the State Department of Water Resources lacked the proper permits to run a crucial station that pumps water from the delta into the California Aqueduct. Specifically, Judge Roesch said the water agency should apply for permits that would allow it to kill spring and winter runs of salmon and delta smelt, which are protected under state law. At issue is the Harvey O. Banks Pumping Plant west of Stockton, which funnels 10,688 cubic feet per second of water through 11 pumps into the 444-mile long aqueduct.

Former Gov. Fife Symington trotted out an aide dressed as an alien 10 years ago to spoof the frenzy surrounding mysterious lights in the Phoenix sky. Now, he says he saw the lights, too, and believes they were extraterrestrial. He said he did not acknowledge his encounter at first because he did not want to cause a panic. He discussed the sighting with a documentary filmmaker and in interviews this week. He told CNN that the craft he saw March 13, 1997, “just felt otherworldly.” The Phoenix lights, which appeared in a V shape as they moved across the sky, were widely explained as flares dumped by a military training flight.

Coal mines will get increased scrutiny from state inspectors under legislation signed into law by Gov. Ernie Fletcher. The law will require inspectors from the Office of Mine Safety and Licensing to double their visits to underground coal mines to a minimum of six a year. Two of the annual inspections must focus on electrical work inside mines. The law also requires at least one member of every underground crew to have a detector to monitor for the explosive gas methane. Miners working alone would also have a detector. The law follows one of the deadliest years in recent history for Kentucky coal miners; 16 miners were killed in 2006.

With 2.5 seconds left, Jeff Green delivered a shot high off the glass from the right side of the lane that gave Georgetown a victory over Vanderbilt Friday night.
Corrections

A report by The Associated Press yesterday in the National Briefing column, about a study of the Smithsonian Institution’s eight art museums, misidentified one of two museums that the report said should be reorganized under one director. It is the National Portrait Gallery — not the National Gallery of Art — that would be joined with the American Art Museum.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the recurrence of cancer in Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of John Edwards, a Democratic presidential candidate, misstated Paul E. Tsongas’s political status when he ran for president in 1992 after having been treated for non-Hodgkins lymphoma. He was a former senator from Massachusetts, not a senator.

An article on Thursday about a lawsuit against the Napa Valley Unified School District and Redwood Middle School over a student dress code misstated the role of the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California and of a San Francisco law firm in some copies. Lawyers for the A.C.L.U. and lawyers for the law firm are providing legal services for the plaintiffs; they are not the plaintiffs.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Thursday about the return of Nets small forward Richard Jefferson from injury, referred incorrectly in some copies to his medical treatment. He had arthroscopic ankle surgery, not knee surgery.

A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Wednesday, about United States national team preparations for friendly matches, misidentified one team member’s professional affiliation. Jonathan Spector plays for West Ham United in the English Premier League — not for Charlton. (He played for that English Premier League team last season.).

An article on Thursday about questions raised by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign about the consistency of Senator Barack Obama’s opposition to the Iraq war incorrectly rendered a statement by Bill Burton, a spokesman for Mr. Obama. Mr. Burton said that it was Mr. Obama who would not comment on a hypothetical question about how he might have voted on the resolution authorizing the war had he been in the Senate in 2002. Mr. Burton did not say that he, as a spokesman, would not comment on that hypothetical question.

An article on Wednesday about a recall of pet food misidentified the hometown of Elizabeth Krottinger, who said her dogs were hospitalized with kidney damage after eating the food. It is Addison, Tex. — not Anderson.

An obituary on March 14 about Ernie Ladd, who was the only man elected to both the American Football League Hall of Fame and the World Wrestling Entertainment Hall of Fame, referred incorrectly to some of his football accomplishments. He did not play in the first Super Bowl in 1967, and he played in four — not three — A.F.L. championship games.

An obituary yesterday about Tanya Reinhart, an Israeli linguist and critic of her country’s policies toward the Palestinians, misstated her birth year. It was 1943, not 1944. (As the obituary correctly noted, she was 63.).
Florida was not stylish, but the Gators were too experienced, too talented and too poised to lose to Butler Friday night as they advanced to the Midwest Regional final.

At least 20 separatist Tamil Tiger rebels and 3 government soldiers were killed in two days of fierce fighting in the northwestern Mannar district, the military said. The battle marked the opening of a new front in escalating hostilities between Sri Lankan soldiers and the Tamil guerrillas in the northwest, as fighting had been concentrated in northern and eastern districts.

In advance of an anti-Kremlin protest march set for today in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia’s third-largest city after Moscow and St. Petersburg, the police detained several planners and confiscated 60,000 copies of an opposition newspaper, organizers of the protest, called the Dissenters’ March, said. One protest planner, Oksana Chlysheva of the local Foundation to Support Tolerance, said that the police and other security officers had begun to mass in the city and that unidentified people have visited schools, universities and stores warning people not to attend.

Soldiers of the two top politicians in Congo battled on in the streets of Kinshasa, the capital, for a second day, but by nightfall, troops loyal to President Joseph Kabila had gained the upper hand after hundreds of fighters commanded by Jean-Pierre Bemba, left, a former vice president and failed presidential candidate, fled across the Congo River. Witnesses said the fighting began when the presidential guard tried to disarm Mr. Bemba’s men, who responded with machine-gun fire. The government then wheeled in tanks and heavy artillery. By yesterday, more than two dozen people had been killed. Bodies were sprawled in the streets. Some of the fallen fighters wore grass headdresses and amulets thought to bestow magical powers. The authorities issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Bemba, accusing him of “high treason.” He and his wife holed up in the South African Embassy, one of the most heavily fortified buildings in Kinshasa.

At least 93 residents of the capital, Maputo, were dead a day after colossal explosions at a military armory on the city’s edge spewed munitions for miles in every direction, and officials feared the toll would rise. More than 400 people were injured, and the central hospital ran out of blood. Many of the injured were “kilometers away” from the armory, said Paul Fauvet of the Mozambique news agency AIM. “It’s as if they were being fired on with rockets and mortars,” he said. “It looked like a mushroom cloud.” The Defense Ministry said the explosions were probably touched off by the late-summer heat. President Armando Guebuza pledged to relocate the arsenal, while critics said the military had been slow to carry out promises to destroy the aging rockets and shells, dating from the nation’s long civil war, which ended in 1994.

PICKETT--Sybil A. (nee Alger), of Delray Beach, FL and Lake Placid, NY, born July 4, 1917, beloved daughter of the late Martin J. Alger and Muriel S. Alger of Bronxville, NY, and Tuscon, AZ, devoted wife of the late Winston H. Pickett, Jr., passed away peacefully on March 19 following a stroke. In addition to her three children, Sybil is survived by grandchildren Sybil V. Wilson, Hillary V. Dietz, Courtney C. Hawes, Matthew H. Hawes, Gerrit M. Veeder, Adam M. Pickett, Alexandra Z. Pickett, as well as great-grandchildren Whitney J. Dietz, Jack A. Dietz and Samantha G. Veeder. A Memorial Mass was held in Delray Beach, FL on March 24, 2007. Memorials may be made to the Adirondack Trust, 2284 Saranac Ave., Lake Placid, NY, 12946 or Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc., 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407. Interment will be in Lake Placid, NY, in the summer.

THE Federal Reserve Board's decision not to raise rates and to move away from its bias toward raising rates would have dominated headlines in most weeks. But big personalities and big corporate news stole the show this week. GOING PUBLIC -- The Blackstone Group filed for an initial public offering, giving investors a first look inside the nation's largest private equity firm. The much-anticipated filing described the extraordinary profits that Blackstone, led by Stephen A. Schwarzman, has earned by taking companies private and then selling them or taking them public again.

LACOMBE--Edward J., of Hillsdale, NJ, died peacefully, at home, surrounded by his family on March 23, 2007. Born September 5, 1916 in Montmagny, Quebec, became a naturalized US citizen at the age of 21. Beloved husband of 60 years to his wife Mary. Cherished father to Katherine, Peter, Paul, James, Ann, Mary, Denise and Edward. Father-in-law to Jeff, Patty, Cindy, Cathy, Tom, Don, Dennis and Ilene. Grandfather to John, Danielle, Michael Peter, Jessica, Michael Paul, Christopher, Gabriella, Fiona, Brian, Colin, Julia, Katie, Annie, Sarah, Andrew, Caroline, Steven and David. Survived by his sister Josephine and brothers Patrick and Leo. Loved by many in-laws, nieces, nephews and friends. Veteran of World War II, Army Air Corps. Graduate of NYU, a CPA and former President of the Savings Bank Retirement System. Visiting hours will be held on Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Mother of The Church in Woodcliff Lake, NJ on Monday, at 10:00am. Interment Ascension Cemetery, Airmont, NY.

The Jets signed quarterback Marques Tuiasosopo yesterday to compete with Kellen Clemens for a backup position. Tuiasosopo, 28, has spent six seasons in the N.F.L. with the Oakland Raiders, but has attempted only 88 career passes. The Jets need to solidify their depth at quarterback behind their starter, Chad Pennington.

A wave of corporate courtship washed over the markets this week, led by talks involving two of Europe's largest banks that result in the biggest takeover ever in the financial services industry. On Monday, Barclays, the British bank, confirmed reports that it had started exclusive talks with ABN Amro of the Netherlands. Though a deal is far from certain, analysts have speculated that Barclays would pay 60 billion euros ($80 billion) to create a giant European financial institution.

A Museum Sale Sets a Record A 10th-century granite statue owned by the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo went for $4.07 million yesterday at Sotheby's in New York, setting an auction record for a work of traditional Indian art. The statue, depicting the Hindu god Shiva as Brahma, above, was purchased by John Eskenazi, a London dealer assumed to be acting for an anonymous buyer. The previous auction record for classical Indian art was set on Wednesday at Christie's, where a bronze statue of a goddess went for $2.7 million. The auction is one of a series at Sotheby's through which the Albright-Knox is divesting itself of centuries-old pieces of Chinese, Indian, South American and ancient Roman art. The museum said the pieces were irrelevant to its central mission, which is contemporary art, but the decision has stirred controversy in Buffalo and the art world. The 11 works offered by the Albright-Knox in yesterday's sale brought in $7.2 million, including Sotheby's commission. On Tuesday the museum made more than $18 million in a sale of Chinese artifacts. Star Power The actors Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, whose only film together, ''Titanic,'' in 1997, earned more than $1.8 billion at the box office, the most of any movie in history, will star in ''Revolutionary Road,'' Variety reported yesterday. DreamWorks will make the film, which is based on the 1961 novel by Richard Yates about disillusionment in 1950s America, as told through the disintegrating marriage of a suburban couple. Sam Mendes, the director of ''American Beauty'' and Ms. Winslet's husband, will direct. Justin Haythe will write the screenplay. A Big Book Prize The Jewish Book Council named Tamar Yellin, the author of ''The Genizah at the House of Shepher,'' a novel that follows a biblical scholar as she tracks her family's history in Jerusalem and the Middle East, the first recipient of what will be the annual $100,000 Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature. The prize was established in honor of Mr. Rohr by his family to recognize emerging writers of exceptional literary merit whose work stimulates an interest in Jewish themes. Two runners-up -- Amir Gutfreund, author of ''Our Holocaust,'' and Michael Lavigne, author of ''Not Me'' -- will each receive the Choice Award and $7,500. The awards committee included the novelist Rebecca Goldstein; Jeremy Dauber, a professor of Yiddish at Columbia; Daisy Maryles, executive editor of Publishers Weekly; Jonathan Rosen, the editorial director of Nextbook; and Ruth Wisse, professor of Yiddish and comparative literature at Harvard. The three winners will be honored at a ceremony in Manhattan on May 21. Ancient Art, Home Safely Two rare artifacts that Greece says were looted from its soil have arrived in Athens after their handover by the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, the Greek Culture Ministry said yesterday. A ministry official said the items, a gold funerary wreath from the fourth century B.C. and a marble woman's torso from the sixth century B.C., were in excellent condition and would be permanently exhibited at the Archaeological Museum in Athens. The Getty agreed to return the two objects last December after reviewing evidence presented by the Greek government, which had argued for about a decade that the pieces had been illegally removed from the country. The Getty acquired both objects in 1993 for about $4.4 million. The wreath figures into a Greek investigation of a former Getty museum curator, Marion True, and Christophe Léon, a Swiss-based art dealer involved in the Getty purchase. Last summer the Getty transferred ownership of a fourth-century-B.C. engraved funeral stele and a late fifth-century-B.C. engraved sculpture to Greece. Practice, Practice Carnegie Hall announced on Friday that the soprano Anna Netrebko would make her Carnegie Hall debut in a concert of opera arias and duets with the baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky and the Orchestra of St. Luke's on May 30 in the Stern Auditorium/Perelman Stage. The program will include selections from operas by Rachmaninoff, Tchaikovsky, Rimsky-Korsakov and Verdi. The Gang's All Here Warner Brothers said yesterday that Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson would continue to play Harry Potter, Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger in ''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince'' and ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,'' the final two movie adaptations of J. K. Rowling's book series, according to Business Wire. There had been rumors that Ms. Watson might not want to continue in her role.

An article on Thursday about a lawsuit against the Napa Valley Unified School District and Redwood Middle School over a student dress code misstated the role of the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California and of a San Francisco law firm in some copies. Lawyers for the A.C.L.U. and lawyers for the law firm are providing legal services for the plaintiffs; they are not the plaintiffs.

Private equity firms bidding for Qantas Airways scrambled to keep their proposal on track, extending the closing deadline by two weeks as a key shareholder rejected the terms of their offer of 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.9 billion). Balanced Equity Management, which holds about 4 percent of Qantas, announced that it would not accept the offer, noting: ''Since the announcement of the bid in December 2006, equity markets have appreciated significantly.'' The bidding consortium issued a terse statement in response: ''Airline Partners Australia is considering a range of alternatives in light of the announcement.'' The consortium has postponed the closing date from April 3 to April 20. TIM JOHNSTON

J. Raymond Elliott, who announced in November that he will be stepping down as chairman and chief executive of Zimmer Holdings by June 30, earned just under $12 million in 2006, according to a proxy statement filed Friday. Zimmer makes orthopedic products. Mr. Elliot, 57, received a base salary of $750,000, $1.14 million and stock valued at $2.33 million for meeting performance goals, and stock options valued at $6.88 million, according to the proxy. Just over $88,000 of Mr. Elliott's compensation was allocated to personal use of corporate aircraft.

DUBIN--Eleanor. The North Shore-LIJ Health System mourns the passing, Thursday, of Eleanor Dubin wife of our esteemed trustee, Mel Dubin. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire family. Our thoughts are with you during this difficult time. Michael Dowling, President & CEO Saul Katz, Chairman

The Nederlanders unveiled their plan to take Broadway to China at a news conference on Wednesday in Beijing, and what did it look like? Pretty much like their road show business in this country. Beijing Oriental Broadway International Theater Management Company, a joint venture between the Nederlanders and a Chinese company, will manage tours of Broadway musicals, some of which will be performed in Chinese. The company will also work with theater managers on marketing and customer service and help establish a network of theaters. The first show, a touring production of ''42nd Street,'' in English, that kicks off in September, is planned for five cities. ''It's going to grow substantially from there,'' Robert Nederlander Jr., president of Nederlander Worldwide, said. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

Fifth-seeded Butler entered last night's Midwest Regional game against the No. 1 seed Florida, the defending champion, as an underdog. But the Bulldogs were a bigger underdog in 2000, when they were seeded 12th and almost defeated No. 5 Florida in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
