Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Massive Christian burial Tuesday 10am St. Patricks Cathedral 5th Ave. at 50th St NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Guiding Eyes for the Blind, Yorktown Heights, NY.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential bid has won an important endorsement from former Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa, a leading politician in the state with the first presidential caucus, according to two Democrats with first-hand knowledge of the endorsement. Mr. Vilsack himself had been a candidate for the Democratic nomination until late last month, when he dropped out after weeks of modest fund-raising and facing long odds in a crowded field led by Mrs. Clinton, of New York; Senator Barack Obama of Illinois; and former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina.

Former Interior Aide Pleads Guilty to Lying J. Steven Griles, the second highest official at the Interior Department in President Bush's first term, pleaded guilty to lying to a Senate committee about ties to Jack Abramoff, the lobbyist who is now in prison. Nine other people with ties to Mr. Abramoff have been convicted or have pleaded guilty. PAGE A9 Rat Poison Found in Pet Food Rat poison has been found in pet food blamed for the deaths of 14 animals, federal and New York State officials said, but they said they were unsure how it got there. The poison was found in wet food manufactured by Menu Foods and distributed under more than 90 brands. PAGE A8 Close Calls for High Seeds Georgetown, a No. 2 seed, needed a basket in the final seconds to edge Vanderbilt and reach the Round of 8 at the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. North Carolina and Florida, each a No. 1 seed, rallied to win, and third-seeded Oregon also advanced. SPORTSSATURDAY, PAGE D1 Iran Seizes 15 Britons in Gulf Fifteen naval troops carrying out an inspection in the Persian Gulf were seized by Iranians in what British officers said were Iraqi waters. There was no gunfire, but the episode quickly added to tensions between the West and Iran. PAGE A7 Play on War Divides School A principal's decision to cancel an original play about the war in Iraq by students in an advanced theater class has divided a Connecticut high school. PAGE B1 THIS WEEKEND Washington's Back Channel Journalists and government officials have long traded in a kind of information black market. It's not pretty. But it's crucial. MAGAZINE T: Travel The New York Times Style Magazine unearths little-known wonders of the world, from the mystical Faroe Islands in the North Atlantic to the Yemeni island of Socotra. Images of Horror, in the Government Spotlight Horror movies are taking over big screens, as well as billboards, the airwaves and the Internet, just as Hollywood braces for a new government review of the marketing of violent entertainment to youths. THE ARTS, PAGE B7

In advance of an anti-Kremlin protest march set for today in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia's third-largest city after Moscow and St. Petersburg, the police detained several planners and confiscated 60,000 copies of an opposition newspaper, organizers of the protest, called the Dissenters' March, said. One protest planner, Oksana Chlysheva of the local Foundation to Support Tolerance, said that the police and other security officers had begun to mass in the city and that unidentified people have visited schools, universities and stores warning people not to attend. MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

To the Editor: In ''Our Cricket Problem'' (Op-Ed, March 23), Shashi Tharoor writes that ''nothing about cricket seems suited to the American national character: its rich complexity, the infinite possibilities that could occur with each delivery of the ball, the dozen different ways of getting out, are all patterned for a society of endless forms and varieties, not of a homogenized McWorld.''

AUERBACH--John, of Roslyn Heights, LI, NY, a leader of the American bicycle industry, died at 96 on March 21, 2007. He is survived by Isabelle, his wife of 68 years, daughter, Joan, of New York City, son, Robert, of Auckland, New Zealand, and grandsons, Jason and Shane. John Auerbach served the American bicycle industry for more than 50 years. As Executive Director of the Bicycle Institute of America and successor organizations, he promoted the creation of bikeways from abandoned railroad tracks. He encouraged school districts across the country to include bicycle safety education in their curricula. He testified before congressional committees in support of a Federal bicycle safety standard. He helped popularize bicycle racing in the United States. His many and varied contributions led to a resurgence in the popularity of bike riding by people of all ages for transportation, fitness and recreation. Beloved husband, beloved father, you are in our hearts forever.
To the Editor: Increasing the size of the Army certainly makes a great sound bite (''The Army, After Iraq,'' editorial, March 18), but is far more problematic in practice.

At least 93 residents of the capital, Maputo, were dead a day after colossal explosions at a military armory on the city's edge spewed munitions for miles in every direction, and officials feared the toll would rise. More than 400 people were injured, and the central hospital ran out of blood. Many of the injured were ''kilometers away'' from the armory, said Paul Fauvet of the Mozambique news agency AIM. ''It's as if they were being fired on with rockets and mortars,'' he said. ''It looked like a mushroom cloud.'' The Defense Ministry said the explosions were probably touched off by the late-summer heat. President Armando Guebuza pledged to relocate the arsenal, while critics said the military had been slow to carry out promises to destroy the aging rockets and shells, dating from the nation's long civil war, which ended in 1994. MICHAEL WINES

An article on Wednesday about a recall of pet food misidentified the hometown of Elizabeth Krottinger, who said her dogs were hospitalized with kidney damage after eating the food. It is Addison, Tex. -- not Anderson.

RODMAN--Marilyn, of Rye Brook, NY, wife of the late Harold, mother of Jesse, Daniel and Ellen Farina, nana of eight, grandnana of four, sister of Joan Serling. Marilyn's life was devoted to her family and her lifetime love of women's fashion, which included her stores in Mamaroneck and Rye Brook. Visitation Saturday, 7-9pm, services Sunday, 11am, Ballard-Durand, White Plains, NY.

An obituary yesterday about Tanya Reinhart, an Israeli linguist and critic of her country's policies toward the Palestinians, misstated her birth year. It was 1943, not 1944. (As the obituary correctly noted, she was 63.)

A 46-year-old man suspected of using fake explosives to rob three banks in Brooklyn in the past two weeks was arrested yesterday, the police said. The man, Michael Contreni of Brooklyn, was arrested at the Farragut Housing Projects in Downtown Brooklyn and charged in federal court with three counts of bank robbery. According to the police, Mr. Contreni used the $3,100 taken in the robberies to buy drugs for himself and others. In each robbery, a man walked into a bank in Brooklyn Heights, threatened to detonate a box filled with explosives, then demanded money from a teller and fled. And in each case, the police were forced to shut down several streets for hours at a time while bomb squads examined the devices, all of which turned out to be harmless. One of the boxes was empty, a second had a container of milk, and the third held battery cables and two containers of liquid, Sgt. Robert Young said. Mr. Contreni was arrested shortly after the last robbery, which took place about 4 p.m. on Thursday at a Citibank at 376 Court Street. Seven hours later, a person who saw surveillance images of the robber in a newspaper called the Crimestoppers hot line and identified the man as Mr. Contreni. ANAHAD O'CONNOR

Student productions at Wilton High School range from splashy musicals like last year's ''West Side Story,'' performed in the state-of-the-art, $10 million auditorium, to weightier works like Arthur Miller's ''Crucible,'' on stage last fall in the school's smaller theater. For the spring semester, students in the advanced theater class took on a bigger challenge: creating an original play about the war in Iraq. They compiled reflections of soldiers and others involved, including a heartbreaking letter from a 2005 Wilton High graduate killed in Iraq last September at age 19, and quickly found their largely sheltered lives somewhat transformed.

He is survived by his beloved wife Ruth, adoring daughters Vicki and Elaine Miles Resner, and loving grandchildren Jennie (Jeremiah), Maureen, Michelle (Zach), Stephanie and (Arnie). Funeral services will take place on Sunday, March 25th at Mount Sinai, Hollywood Hills, 5950 Forest Lawn Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90068, (800)600-0076. Contributions in his memory to: Alzheimers of CA Southland, 5980 Wilshire Blvd., Ste. 1100 Los Angeles, CA 90036, would be appreciated. Partners & Staff of Perelson Weiner LLP

After his team's 85-84 comeback victory against fifth-seeded Tennessee on Thursday night, the Ohio State freshman center Greg Oden received several stitches in his chin. Saddled by foul trouble, he scored 9 points in 18 minutes. He also blocked four shots, including the potential winner by Ramar Smith at the buzzer.

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has hired a veteran New York elections lawyer to be his special counsel on public integrity issues, his office said yesterday. The lawyer, Jerry H. Goldfeder, will begin work on Monday in the attorney general's Manhattan office. Mr. Goldfeder's long experience in advising candidates on how to stay on the right side of the law will help Mr. Cuomo prosecute those who have wandered onto the wrong side of it, Mr. Cuomo's office said.

CALAGNA--Caterina ''Aunt Tina'', died Wednesday March 21, 2007 at her home in NYC. She was born in Corleone, Sicily on February 16, 1909. She is survived by her nephew Tom, his wife Judith and their children Vanessa and Jesse. She was ''Aunt Tina'' to countless others whom she loved and loved her. She was sent by God on a mission to feed all who came her way, her mission was accomplished. Mass will be held at St. Gregory's Church on 90th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Ave., Monday March 26, at 11am.

''Grey's Anatomy'' led ABC to a relatively easy victory in the ratings on Thursday, drawing 21.9 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. The ''March Madness'' coverage on CBS averaged 10.5 million viewers from 8 to 11, putting CBS in second. During the 8 o'clock hour, ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (10.5 million) tied for first with Fox's ''Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?'' (10.4 million), although the quiz show did slightly better among adults 18 to 49. Fox ranked third for the night, and NBC finished fourth as its new drama ''Raines'' (8.6 million) finished last at 10, behind ABC's new drama ''October Road'' (12.3 million), which led the hour. BENJAMIN TOFF

A report by The Associated Press yesterday in the National Briefing column, about a study of the Smithsonian Institution's eight art museums, misidentified one of two museums that the report said should be reorganized under one director. It is the National Portrait Gallery -- not the National Gallery of Art -- that would be joined with the American Art Museum.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Thursday about the return of Nets small forward Richard Jefferson from injury, referred incorrectly in some copies to his medical treatment. He had arthroscopic ankle surgery, not knee surgery.

Adored wife of the late Lewis, beloved daughter of Gracie Weisbrot, devoted mother of Jeffrey and his wife Jody Falco, Peter and his partner Todd Geringswald, and Robert and his wife Hilary, and loving grandmother of Carlo, Lucy, and Paulina. All of us at Goldfarb & Fleece mourn the passing of our friend, Joan Steinman. Our thoughts and prayers are with her family.

Trevor Nunn's adaptation of the Gershwins' ''Porgy and Bess,'' which opened in November at the Savoy Theater in London, will close on May 5. Reviews were mixed to great, but an audience is a sometime thing, and ticket sales were flattening, said Tom Viertel, one of the show's producers. Plans for a New York production, with American actors, are still on track. ''We're committed to doing it on Broadway,'' Mr. Viertel said, adding that the producers were still looking to the spring of 2008. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

Charges were dropped yesterday against a custodian at a Brooklyn elementary school who had been accused of rape and sodomy by an 8-year-old girl earlier this week. Jerry Schmetterer, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office, said the case was dropped because of insufficient evidence. The custodian, Frank Evelyn, 58, who started working at Public School 91 in East Flatbush in 1988, will be reinstated immediately, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education said. Questions dogged the case, and a law enforcement official said the victim told conflicting stories about what took place. After the girl made the allegations, education officials reassigned Solomon Long, the school's principal, to an administrative job, saying he failed to report the child's previous claims of abuse involving someone who did not work at the school. The girl had also complained about being sexually abused by her father and a young classmate, a city official said. CARA BUCKLEY
GENDLER--Paul. 123/25 3/24/05. Dad -not a day goes by when I don't need your advice or want to share something with you. You are the wind beneath my wings. Ellen

An article on Thursday about questions raised by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign about the consistency of Senator Barack Obama's opposition to the Iraq war incorrectly rendered a statement by Bill Burton, a spokesman for Mr. Obama. Mr. Burton said that it was Mr. Obama who would not comment on a hypothetical question about how he might have voted on the resolution authorizing the war had he been in the Senate in 2002. Mr. Burton did not say that he, as a spokesman, would not comment on that hypothetical question.

John Thompson III, the Georgetown coach, sat under the bright lights, between a microphone and the N.C.A.A. backdrop, answering questions. A few minutes later, John Thompson Jr., the former Georgetown coach and the current coach's father, stood near the news media work room Thursday and answered questions. He might have faced more questions than his son.

To the Editor: ''Trade and the Home Front'' (editorial, March 17) correctly identifies the downward pressure on some wages created by imports as a reason for growing domestic opposition to free trade. But the remedies you recommend -- upgrading the Trade Adjustment Assistance program and better education -- are no more than palliatives for what is really torpedoing public support.

It was a good week for John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley. Net earnings grew 70 percent for the first quarter, blowing by the best of Wall Street's estimates. Just as satisfying was a surprise legal victory when an appeals court in Florida reversed a jury verdict that Morgan Stanley should pay $1.57 billion in damages for its role in advising Sunbeam in its merger with the Coleman Company, controlled by Ronald O. Perelman.

Soldiers of the two top politicians in Congo battled on in the streets of Kinshasa, the capital, for a second day, but by nightfall, troops loyal to President Joseph Kabila had gained the upper hand after hundreds of fighters commanded by Jean-Pierre Bemba, left, a former vice president and failed presidential candidate, fled across the Congo River. Witnesses said the fighting began when the presidential guard tried to disarm Mr. Bemba's men, who responded with machine-gun fire. The government then wheeled in tanks and heavy artillery. By yesterday, more than two dozen people had been killed. Bodies were sprawled in the streets. Some of the fallen fighters wore grass headdresses and amulets thought to bestow magical powers. The authorities issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Bemba, accusing him of ''high treason.'' He and his wife holed up in the South African Embassy, one of the most heavily fortified buildings in Kinshasa. JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Friday that a mortar shell that landed near him on Thursday in Baghdad had surprised and scared him but would not deter him from expanding the United Nations presence in Iraq. In a wide-eyed account to reporters here, Mr. Ban called it a ''very big, loud boom'' and said, ''I could see the wind and the dust inside the room, and it looked very dangerous.''

A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Wednesday, about United States national team preparations for friendly matches, misidentified one team member's professional affiliation. Jonathan Spector plays for West Ham United in the English Premier League -- not for Charlton. (He played for that English Premier League team last season.)

COLLIER--Daniel. We mourn the loss of a good friend and dedicated Board Member. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. The Officers, Directors and Staff of Brown Harris Stevens Management, LLC Alan Kersner, COO

Five people were hospitalized yesterday morning after a kitchen fire filled their apartment with smoke, and three remained in critical condition last night, fire officials said. Neighbors called 911 shortly after 1:30 a.m. when they noticed smoke coming from a first-floor window of the four-unit, brick-front building at 1717 Unionport Road, just south of Morris Park Avenue. A neighbor said he heard an explosion before he saw the smoke. Firefighters contained the fire just after 2:15 a.m. Efrain Ramos, 49; his son, also named Efrain Ramos, 18; his two daughters, Jennifer Ramos, 17, and Jessica Ramos, 11; and a male relative, 50, whose name was not immediately released by the Fire Department, were treated for smoke inhalation at Jacobi Medical Center. Mr. Ramos and his son were upgraded to stable from critical condition yesterday afternoon, while the others were still in critical condition, a hospital spokesman said. Fire officials said they were investigating the possibility that the stove was the cause of the fire.

MEIZLISH--Beatrice, 84, died March 23. Longtime payroll secretary Madison High. Devoted wife of Nat, loving mother Diane Reichlin, and Jay, grandchildren, Pamela and David Reichlin, Eric, Jason and Matthew Meizlish, great-grandchilden Joshua and Samantha Swerdloff.
To the Editor: Re ''The Really Real Hillary,'' by Judith Warner (column, March 14):

The nation's pediatricians, the foot soldiers in the campaign to vaccinate America's children, are starting to revolt. The soaring cost and rising number of new vaccines, doctors say, make it increasingly difficult for them to buy the shots they give their patients. They also complain that insurers often do not reimburse them enough, so they can lose money on every dose they deliver.
To the Editor: Re ''Stepping on the Dream'' (column, March 22):

These are tough times for plaintiffs' lawyers handling securities class-action lawsuits. On Monday, a federal appeals panel ruled that a class-action lawsuit against several Wall Street investment banks for their role as advisers to Enron could not go forward. The panel said the banks, at most, ''aided and abetted'' in Enron's demise but that they did not have a duty to Enron's shareholders.

JUDSON--Alan, on March 21, 2007. Beloved brother of David, Bennett Charles and the late Morris. Graduate of Dartmouth and Tuck Business School. Former member of The City Athletic Club. Service Sunday, 12 noon at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-On-Hudson, NY.

''The American people have lost faith in the president's conduct of this war. The American people see the reality of the war; the president does not.'' SPEAKER NANCY PELOSI, a California Democrat, in bringing an end to a charged debate in the House. [A1]

An obituary on March 14 about Ernie Ladd, who was the only man elected to both the American Football League Hall of Fame and the World Wrestling Entertainment Hall of Fame, referred incorrectly to some of his football accomplishments. He did not play in the first Super Bowl in 1967, and he played in four -- not three -- A.F.L. championship games.
WARDALL--Thomas Ronald. Born March 23, 1965. Died March 24, 1965; NYC. In loving memory always. Your mother, Elizabeth Hartley Filliat

The criminal fraud trial of Conrad M. Black and three former associates began in Chicago. The jurors scribbled notes as they strained to understand the complex holding structure and business arrangements that existed within Mr. Black's faded newspaper empire, which at one point was the third largest in the world and included The Daily Telegraph in London and The Chicago Sun-Times. Two widely divergent portraits of Mr. Black were presented: to the prosecution, he's a cavalier criminal in a suit; while to the defense, he's a persecuted, betrayed entrepreneur, whose gigantic ego doesn't make him guilty.

GERMAIN--Lawrence. Memories are precious. As time travels on. When you long for a face, and the smile that is gone. It seems like only yesterday, you took me by the hand and there you placed a special ring. A golden wedding band. Together on life's journey. We shared happiness and tears. And I would not trade anything. For all those precious years, I sit alone at evenings and think about our life and all those lovely happy years, we had as man and wife. Your memory is a treasure. With which I will never part. God has you in his keeping. I have you in my heart. Sadly missed by your loving wife. Sheila

INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Deeply Split House Votes To End War by Late '08 A deeply divided House of Representatives voted to bring most American combat troops home from Iraq next year, with Democrats employing their new Congressional majority to create the most forceful challenge yet to President Bush's war policy. A1 Inquest on London Bombing The British police began interrogating three men apprehended under counterterrorism laws for alleged offenses related to the July 7, 2005, suicide bombings on the London transit system. In a separate case, evidence emerged of a possible link between the bombings and a failed attack two weeks later. A7 Sunni Deputy Premier Wounded Iraq's deputy Sunni prime minister, Salam al-Zubaie, suffered chest wounds from shrapnel when one of his guards blew himself up as Mr. Zubaie led mid-day prayers. The explosion left nine people dead and appeared to be another in the mounting number of cases of Sunni-on-Sunni violence. A7 Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations said that a mortar shell that landed near him in Baghdad had surprised and scared him but would not deter him from expanding his organization's presence in Iraq. A3 Plane Shot Down Over Somalia A cargo plane was shot down over Mogadishu's livestock market, a known hide-out for insurgents, witnesses and Somali officials said. According to government officials, the plane was ferrying technicians working for the African Union peacekeeping force in Somalia. A4 Iran Seizes 15 on British Ship Fifteen British sailors and marines carrying out an inspection in the Persian Gulf were seized and taken into custody by Iranian naval forces, the British government said. A7 NATIONAL A8-11 Gonzales and Advisers Met 10 Days Before Firings Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and senior advisers discussed the plan to remove seven United States Attorneys at a meeting on Nov. 27, 2006, 10 days before the dismissals were carried out, according to a Justice Department calendar entry. A1 Ex-Official Pleads Guilty J. Steven Griles, the second-highest official at the Interior Department during President Bush's first term, pleaded guilty to lying before a Senate committee about his ties to Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist who is now in prison. A9 Rat Poison Found in Pet Food Rat poison has been found in pet food blamed for the deaths of 14 animals, federal and New York State officials said, but they said they were unsure how it got there. A8 Texas May Release Youths Battered by a sexual abuse scandal in the juvenile justice system, Texas may free most of the 4,000 jailed youths who have served their minimum sentences but are still being held for often indeterminate reasons. A8 Senate Passes Budget The Senate passed a Democratic spending outline that proponents said would balance the federal budget by 2012, provide more money for programs like children's health care and extend some of President Bush's tax cuts beyond 2010. A11 No Degree for Jeb Bush The Faculty Senate at the University of Florida, the largest university in the state, rejected a proposal to award former Gov. Jeb Bush an honorary degree. Some members openly criticized his policies. A9 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Play on War in Iraq Divides a High School A play written by the advanced theater class at Wilton High School in Wilton, Conn., about the war in Iraq, compiled from reflections of soldiers and others involved, was canceled by the school's principal, causing the latest in a series of free-speech squabbles at the school. B1 Dancer's Killer Sentenced Paul Cortez, an actor and yoga teacher convicted of killing Catherine Woods, a young dancer in Manhattan, was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison. B1 Gifts to Labor Chief Questioned Carla Katz, the former companion of Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey and the president of a state union, has long contended that she has no obligation to disclose large sums of money Mr. Corzine gave her when he was in the Senate. But in 2005, the United States Department of Labor formally requested that she disclose anything of value he gave her. C1 Tax Cut Favors Foreigners President Bush's 2003 tax cuts include a provision that gives some foreign companies a financial advantage over competitors in the United States. C1 The Cost of Vaccines Pediatricians say soaring costs and low insurance reimbursements keep them from offering the newest and most costly vaccines. Pondering his options after eight years in office, former Gov. Jeb Bush can cross one off the list, honorary degree recipient at the University of Florida, the largest university in the state. The Faculty Senate there rejected a proposal on Thursday to award Mr. Bush an honorary degree this spring. Some members openly criticized his policies.
Witty design extends beyond the topsy-turvy skyline of Holland’s second city.
What's the worst time to buy a car? Eat at a fine restaurant? Get arrested? Times writers shared their thoughts on Sunday in Week in Review.

Suddenly the Atlantic is looking like an even easier hop. 'Open skies' on routes between Europe and the United States would boost travel between many more cities. But environmentalists are crying foul, saying the likely boost in sales would wipe out European initiatives to cut aviation emissions. Airlines are vowing to clean up their act. Richard Branson of Virgin says he will plow billions of dollars into research into cleaner fuels. British Airways emphasizes the need for more efficient engines. Many carriers encourage their passengers to "offset" their emissions by funding green projects. But will any of these efforts help to cancel out the effects of new flights serving the 25 million extra air passengers who are expected to take advantage of 'open skies' over the next five years?

Whether the North Carolina-Georgetown game is labeled, oxymoronically, as an instant classic probably depends on which side you cheered for. But it would seem that a true classic game required both teams to play well -- not just for about 35 minutes, but all the way until the end.

The great philosopher Charlie Brown once, while trying to inspire his charges during a conference at the pitching mound, said that "no one remembers who finished in second place." (Linus, ever the plucky contrarian, began rattling off World Series losers throughout history.) The founding, organizing tenet of sports states that the only goal is to win a championship; anything less than that was a waste of time. You might as well have finished last.

Of all the questions facing mankind, perhaps the most fascinating is concerned with life beyond the Earth. Does it exist - if so, where? - and what will it be like? So far we do not have the answers, and some people still maintain that we are alone in the universe. Since there are around a hundred thousand million stars in our galaxy, many of which are attended by planets, this seems unlikely, but we cannot be sure because we have no positive proof of life anywhere except on Earth. However, I have the feeling that at least one of these fundamental points may soon be cleared up.

Nick's Sunday column, "The General vs. The Housewife" is about a mother of three who is partly responsible for the street protests in Pakistan against the country's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. You're invited to read the column or watch the video and then add your comments on this post.

After stunning No. 1 seed Duke in the Greensboro Regional semifinal on Saturday, No. 4 Rutgers is considered by many to be the heavy favorite going into its Round of 8 game against No. 3 Arizona State. The teams play on Monday in Greensboro, N.C., with the winner advancing to the Final Four in Cleveland.

Three guys wearing blue sweatshirts, each with a large letter on the front, stood behind the Georgetown bench. "H-O-Y" they read. Minutes later, another guy appeared. He wore an "S." An empty seat was between the "Y" and the "S." The "A" must have been stuck in the concessions line.

With North Carolina's mascot Jayson K. Ray in a New Jersey hospital after being hit by a car on Friday, his counterparts in St. Louis at the Midwest regional were thinking about him and taking sympathetic action an hour before the game between Oregon and Florida.

The saddest sidebar to the N.C.A.A. tournament involves a 21-year-old North Carolina student named Jason Ray (or Jayson, as there seems to be some uncertainty over the spelling of his first name) who lies in a coma, on life support, in a New Jersey hospital.

Near the beginning of a news conference with North Carolina Coach Roy Williams and his players on Saturday, someone with a video camera poked through a blue curtain, discreetly aiming the camera at the stage where the coach and players sat. The N.C.A.A.-appointed moderator quickly told the person to leave, because the only cameras allowed were the two at the back of the room.

Wouldn't you know, a few minutes after today's game ended, Willie Randolph called Mike Pelfrey into his office. In came the pitching coach Rick Peterson, too. The door closed, and less than a minute later, Pelfrey walked out wearing a poker face."You hear things," Pelfrey said. "I was prepared for the worst, but I guess it turned out good."

Sean MacPherson and his restaurant Swingers defined early-'90s Los Angeles. A decade later, his Park restaurant and Maritime Hotel turned Manhattan's West Chelsea into a tailgate party for groovy young things. Now, after his glamification of the Waverly Inn (with Graydon Carter and others) in the West Village, his new Bowery Hotel is giving devotees a reason to head east. Why the Bowery? "I love the street's history and its location, even its sound. And the neighborhood is shifting. Besides us, the New Museum and a Whole Foods are coming." The look? (These schools are so small that they don't have players' names on the backs of their jerseys, because they can't afford not to recycle uniforms from year to year.) The favorites were Winona State University of tiny Winona, Minn.; the Warriors had won 57 consecutive games and were the defending champions. Their opponents? Christiane Franchi Gallois and Stephen Dale Klein are to be married in a civil ceremony today at their country home in Spinnerstown, Pa. Mayor Albert Haynes of Trumbauersville, Pa., is to officiate. Jeffrey Rosen’s article (March 11) captures many of the salient issues emerging from the new field of “neurolaw.” Last month, Steven Hyman, the Harvard provost, and I organized a symposium at the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on the use of functional M.R.I. technology to detect lying. The consensus view among the neuroscience, legal and ethics experts who presented papers is that one should be careful not to invest too much faith in the capacity of brain imaging to reveal individuals’ true motives and motivations; it is far from the silver bullet for law enforcement, prosecutors or defense attorneys that its champions claim.

An article on March 11 about Chris Rock’s “I Think I Love My Wife” and other remakes of French New Wave films misidentified to the actress who tempts Mr. Rock’s character. She is Kerry Washington, not Gina Torres.

An article last Sunday about movie download services referred incorrectly to the availability of the film “Black,” starring the Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan. It was indeed released theatrically in the United States, in 2005, and is out on DVD; it was not unreleased here in theaters or on DVD.

An article last Sunday about Tatum O’Neal and her forthcoming roles, including one on the television show “Rescue Me,” misstated the number of seasons the series has been on the air. In June, it will be starting its fourth season, not its third.

Schooleys Mountain General Store in Schooleys Mountain is picture-perfect. With its tin ceiling and potbelly stove, this old-fashioned outpost in Morris County seems unchanged since 1830, when it first opened. Now, as then, you can stop by for groceries like milk and eggs or to mail a letter (the local post office is inside). But today the store also sells satisfying sandwiches.

Tacos al pastor, made with chili-soaked pork spit-roasted beneath a dripping, slowly caramelizing pineapple, are a popular street snack in Mexico City. And New Rochelle’s Little Mexican Cafe offers the genuine article, as you can plainly see if you sit at its worn wooden bar. The electric spit is strung with marinated pork pieces running with the amber juices of the pineapple above. The pork is wrapped in warm corn tortillas along with chopped cilantro and onion. (Ask for a couple of chunks of roasted pineapple to be added to the mix.).

The Explorer column on March 11 about dining in Myanmar misstated the value of the kyat, the Myanmar currency, and the price in kyats of meals there. A meal at Napi, also known as Fatty Lady’s Place, in Ohnoma cost about 1,250 kyats, not 7 — the equivalent of $1 a person. Meals at several roadside joints in the countryside rarely cost more than 1,800 kyats, not 10. (Although the official exchange rate is seven kyats to the dollar, almost all private transactions use rates of 1,000 to 1,250 or more kyats to the dollar.).

GRAY--Timothy, lyricist/ playwright/director. Born in Chicago, IL. September 5, 1927 died March 17, 2007 in Sarasota, FL. Wrote and worked on Broadway and in London. Credits include: Make A Wish, Love From Judy and High Spirits with Hugh Martin. Musical Revues Welcome Darling (starring Tallulah Bankhead), Airs on a Shoestring, From Here and There, Taboo Revue, September Song, The Musical World of Kurt Weil. Vocal arrangement with Hugh Martin: Good News, Ziegfeld Follies, Revlon Revue with Peggy Lee, The Patrice Munsel Show, and Washington Square with Ray Bolger. Timothy starred in London in SCAPA. Hugh Martin writes of Timothy, '' You were the best witting partner I ever had, and working with you was emotional and visceral, a truly synergistic phenomenon. Looking back at the finished product, it is difficult at times to distinguish between your work and mine. The name Timothy Gray is not a household word. But in my personal Pantheon, it is a name that lights up the sky with laughter, lyricism and love.'' Timothy is survived by Carlo Thomas his life partner of 36 years, a sister Violet Gray Fabbri, nieces Terri Chonez, Bonnie Fabbri of Minden, NE, Sandra Gray Seems, Lani Lee Seems of Genoa City, WI.
To the Editor: Re ''The Commuting Conundrum'' (March 18):

To the Editor: Re ''But I Didn't Do It!,'' by Stanley Fish (column, March 21): My family arrived in America long after the institution of slavery was abolished -- and yet I am still sorry that it happened; not because I personally advocated or participated in slavery, but for two other reasons.

Alex Gordon made his living by selling lighting fixtures and designs, but his real passion was art. A native New Yorker, Mr. Gordon spent a lifetime amassing a collection that totaled more than 1,000 pieces, from pre-Columbian artifacts to Russian iconographic works to Old Master paintings and drawings. The eclectic collection was kept on display in his homes in Chicago and New York ''from floor to ceiling, and in stacks in between,'' said his niece, Dale Schlein of Waccabuc. When Mr. Gordon died at 80 in 2003, family members sold and dispersed the collection according to his instructions. Last week, in keeping with his wish that his legacy go toward art education, the Alex Gordon estate bequeathed $1 million to the Purchase College Foundation/Neuberger Museum of Art Endowment in Purchase.

Yes, Miss Marple had one, but there is something about an old-fashioned three-speed bicycle that is more vintage sports car than the preferred transportation of Nosy Parkers. The Skeppshult Ladies Promenade, newly imported from Sweden, is described as ''the perfect bicycle for shopping;'' being an attention-grabbing ruby-red, it may not be so good for sleuthing. The Promenade is sold stateside at Clearly First, 980 Madison Avenue, (212) 988-8242. ''It's everything I love, simple, classic, quality,'' said Hélène Hellsten, the store's owner, who rides hers at home in Copenhagen. (With a basket for purchases, small dogs and tulips, $1,795; the men's version is $2,100.) SUSAN GUERRERO

TEICHMAN--Norma Padwe, age 78, of Stratford, CT, died suddenly February 20, 2007. Survived by husband Saul, sons Daniel and Michael, sister Sara Simon, and four grandchildren.

You could say that John Leahy, the top salesman at Airbus, has given his heart to the new double-decker, super-jumbo A380 that landed at Kennedy Airport last week. Mr. Leahy called it a ''personal honor'' to be on the inaugural flight because, in his youth, he was a cab driver who picked up fares at Kennedy and watched the planes fly overhead. (A video tour of the Airbus can be viewed at nytimes.com. ) This week, he was Airbus's man of the hour, chatting up analysts, investors and the media, and being the master of ceremonies on Wednesday as the A380 took a V.I.P. swing over the skies of Manhattan -- with all-important money managers and Wall Street analysts in first class and others back in economy. There was no executive more ubiquitous than Mr. Leahy and his rapid-patter promotion of the virtues of the eight-story-high, 1.3-million-ton aerial behemoth on its maiden voyage to New York.

RONSON--Howard P. The Genesis Foundation, Jerusalem/ NY and the Genesis Center, Bet Shemesh mourn the loss of our Chairman of the Board, Mr. Howard P. Ronson. Devoted husband, father and brother. A visionary leader, passionate lover of Israel and dedicated patron of Jewish education. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Angelika; daughters Gisele and Livia; sister, Benita and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mr. Jay Zises, President, Genesis Foundation Rabbi Jay Marcus and Family and the entire Genesis staff $(6$)RONSON--Howard P., a true visionary and master builder extraordinaire. His kindness and philanthropic commitment to friends and the community will be irreplaceable. He will forever remain in our hearts and minds. Our prayers and thoughts are with the Ronson family. E & P $(6$)RONSON -- Howard. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President
ABOOBAKER--A. Sattar, 81, beloved husband of the late Jean. Devoted father of Cris and Kim. Adored grandfather of Amber. ''Schwartz Bros.Jeffer'' 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

THERE'S nothing wrong with drug makers publicizing their products, but the lure of lucrative government contracts can prompt them to play fast and loose. In lobbying state lawmakers to make its latest vaccine mandatory, Merck has greatly exaggerated both the threat of a disease and the ability of a drug to prevent it. (True, Merck has promised to stop lobbying, but lawmakers and the public are still suffering under misconceptions that the drug company has done nothing to correct.) The drug in question is Gardasil, a vaccine for four types of human papillomavirus, or HPV, two of which are responsible for 70 percent of cervical cancer cases. The Food and Drug Administration approved Gardasil last year for use against HPV in females aged 9 to 26.

The Arabic bath house Medina Mayrit is an oasis of candlelight, gurgling fountains, mellow music and Moorish décor. Coed bathers wade in near silence -- and bathing suits -- between hot, tepid and cold pools, then ease into a massage beneath the arches of a restored underground cistern. On weekends, locals reserve a table at the restaurant upstairs for couscous and mint tea after their soak. For evening sessions, call in advance. Atocha, 14; 011-34-90-233-3334; www.medinamayrit.com.

Earlier this month, between the few hours when the first warm rain of the season fell and the last severe storm of winter blew through, wood frogs and spotted salamanders exited their woodland homes and began a trek to vernal ponds to begin the mating process. In some cases, the journey involves hundreds of amphibians simultaneously crossing busy roads. So for the last several years environmental officials across the state have been closing roads to give the amphibians a fighting chance against the crushing wheels of vehicular traffic.

The Language Mavenhood is becoming less pluralistically ignorant. That is not a good lead sentence. In one swell foop, it raises the question: What is the Language Mavenhood? And poses another question: What is pluralistic ignorance? (It poses and raises but does not beg any question. Never use that to mean ''plead for an answer''; the phrase, from petitio principi, means ''to assume what needs to be proved,'' and such circular reasoners offend every logician. Use ''begs the question'' only when you mean ''ducks the question.'')

To the Editor: Re ''Facing Life With a Lethal Gene'' (front page, March 18), about Katharine Moser, a 25-year-old woman who learned two years ago that she carries the gene for Huntington's disease, which usually strikes in middle age: What a tremendous example and inspiration Ms. Moser is. She is facing her future with a huge amount of courage and determination and doing the best she can with what life has handed her.
A cabaret review yesterday of Marilyn Maye, who is singing tonight at 7:30 at the Metropolitan Room, 34 West 22nd Street, misstated the club's telephone number. It is (212) 206-0440.

Georgetown forward Jeff Green, along with his teammates and coach, met with the news media yesterday. It took 21 questions -- good thing it was not a game of 20 Questions -- before someone asked Green if he had seen a replay of his winning basket against Vanderbilt on Friday night, and whether he thought he had traveled before taking the shot. The ball banked in with 2.5 seconds left, giving Georgetown a 66-65 victory.

PEDONE--Vito S. Colonel, beloved husband of Merrie L. Davis and the late Geraldine C. Pedone passed away Saturday, March 24, 2007. Co-pilot who led Normandy invasion, WWII. Assisted in development of NATO, appointed Chairman of Command and Control Committee for Joint Chiefs of Staff, briefed presidents Johnson and Kennedy. Flew 245 combat missions. Ph.D. in International Affairs. Also survived by his son, Lt. Col. Stephen (retired), grandchildren; Lisa, Michelle and Stephen, great - grandchild ren; Kristen, Ashley, David and Maddie. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Thursday, March 29 from 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm. Interment Arlington National Cemetery.

GREENBERG--Evelyn, on March 9, 2007, in Las Vegas, Nevada. Beloved wife of the late Leo Greenberg, mother of Charles, Marlene and husband, Ralph, aunt to Rhoda, Eugene, and Yola. She will be dearly missed by all who knew her.

Sander Koyfman, 34, an addiction psychiatrist from Fort Lee, N.J.: ''The paraglider becomes an extension of yourself. You envision where you want to go: up, down, left, right, to that mountain, to that river. And you go. To me, it's an addiction. I've been flying now for over seven years, essentially every weekend it doesn't rain, it doesn't snow, or the wind is not too strong. The picture catches me landing in a crowd of my closest friends. My fiancée is starting to appreciate how addictive this thing is: a month after getting engaged, I was off to Brazil for a month to feed my habit. Unfortunately, the trip got cut short after I had an accident on landing. Now, three weeks later and almost fully recovered, I struggle to say something deep, something perspective-changing about it, but in reality I simply want to be back in the air.'' As told to Seth Kugel

To the Editor: Regarding the explosion in a Siberian coal mine that killed more than 100 people (news articles, March 20 and 21): As a correspondent for the public radio program ''Marketplace'' in 1991, I went to the Abashevskaya mine near Kemerovo to interview miners about their grievances. The reluctant mine manager agreed to let me visit the underground operation and handed me a safety kit. When I asked him how to use it, he answered, ''If you need it, you're already dead.''
DEAN--Andy Chen. MD, PhD. On your 47th birthday, your sense of humor, devotion to loved ones and dedication to your profession continue to inspire your family. We love you and miss you.

The Interior Department allocated about $2 million last Tuesday to buy land for conservation within New Jersey and the other three states that make up the Highlands, a mountainous area that is a source of much of the region's drinking water. New Jersey's share has not yet been determined, and a consortium of public and private groups will make recommendations, said Frank J. Quimby, a department spokesman. Connecticut, Pennsylvania and New York will also receive money.

THE small-city department store has had a tough few decades. Once a one-stop shop for overcoats and makeup, with a smiling operator in the elevator, the stores began struggling to compete against suburban malls in the 1970s and then against big-box retailers in the 1990s.

With many candidates running unopposed, most village elections last Tuesday in Nassau and Suffolk Counties barely caused a ripple. But there were exceptions. In an upset in Malverne, Patti Ann McDonald, the wife of a New York City police officer who was paralyzed from the neck down in 1986 after being shot three times by a 15-year-old boy, defeated the incumbent mayor, Anthony Panzarella, by a wide margin.

To the Editor: Ayaan Hirsi Ali and her new book, ''Infidel,'' deserved better than Ian Buruma's review (March 4). While expressing admiration for her ''courage,'' he rejects her ''descriptions of life in the West'' as ''idealized,'' with an ''almost comic-book quality.'' Elsewhere, he derides her view of the West as ''a caricature of sweetness and light.'' Meanwhile, he challenges the notion, presumably Hirsi Ali's, that ''Europeans who argue ... that Muslims might feel more at home in the West if we offered a modicum of respect for their religion, instead of insulting them at every turn, are 'stupid' or worse.''

IT was the beginning of the third and final session of the parenting course ''Discipline Is Not a Dirty Word,'' and the instructor, Nancy Olsen-Harbich, wanted to know how people had done on their homework. Cari Jacino, who has 2-year-old twin boys, was feeling overwhelmed. ''I can see why some people take this course twice,'' she said. ''There's so much to remember.''

Here is one more possible reason for JetBlue Airways's fiasco during the winter's storms. It did not fill the position of vice president for its hub operations at Kennedy Airport in New York for half a year -- the half that has the ice and snow.

Karol Szymanowski: Mazurkas Anna Kijanowska, pianist. Dux 0417; CD. ONE of the comforts of listening for a living is, after many years, still to come upon music one ought to know and doesn't. Karol Szymanowski's mazurkas for the piano bring the past forward more fluently than most 20th-century composition. Chopin's legacy is served. Polish folk dance is honored. But this remains piano music that speaks in the present tense as well as the past. The recording, from the Dux label, is played by Anna Kijanowska, an excellent young Polish pianist now teaching at the College of William & Mary in Virginia.

The tour is called METAL FOR THE MASSES, named after the compilation series of the same name. But like many heavy-metal tours, this one succeeds by ignoring ''the masses'' altogether. Metal bands long ago made the happy discovery that they could survive, even thrive, without support from rock radio or mainstream music magazines (or, for that matter, mainstream music blogs). The genre encourages obsession, and more than just about any other fans, metal fans have learned to track their favorite sounds and musicians across international borders. Americans are often accused of ignoring so-called world music, but metal is one kind of world music that thrives here. The tour, which arrives at the Gramercy Theater on Monday, brings together three Swedish bands and a Canadian one. Among other things Sweden is the home of a triumphant-sounding metal subgenre called melodic death metal; DARK TRANQUILLITY is one of the standard-bearers and the grandiose SCAR SYMMETRY is one of the newest exemplars. THE HAUNTED was founded by Swedish veterans, including former members of the influential melodic death-metal band At the Gates. Last year the Haunted released ''The Dead Eye'' (Century Media), a twisted and twisty album that ranges from thrash to progressive rock. The Canadian band is INTO ETERNITY, an unpredictable group from Regina, Saskatchewan, that jumps from warp-speed riffs to off-tempo breaks to old-fashioned howling refrains, which should inspire plenty of singing along on Monday. 8 p.m., 127 East 23rd Street, (212) 777-6800; $16 in advance, $19 at the door.

BERGER--Robert S., Captain USNR Retired, passed away Monday, March 19, 2007 at the age of 90. He was born in New York on February 13, 1917. Bob was a resident of Los Angeles for the past 41 years. He was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania (1936), Columbia University (1939) and Harvard Law school (1939). Bob served six years on active duty in World War II and two years during the Korean War. He was the founder, past President and CEO of Rittenhouse Paper Company, founded in 1947 in Chicago, Illinois, where he resided with his family for fifteen years. Bob was the beloved husband for 55 years of Nancy, dear brother of George, loving father of Jill (Marty) and Kathy, devoted grandfather of Julie (Peter), Andrew (Tamara), Amy (Lance) and Ben (Kristin), and the cherished greatgrandfather of Parker, Liam, Charlie, Wil, Hallie and Edith. Bob touched many lives and will be in our hearts forever.

FINKELSTEIN--Mary (Boesman) 65, passed away in her Columbia, Missouri home on March 16. Funeral Services were at Columbia Cemetery on March 19. Beloved by all who knew her, Mary, the daughter of Frank and Ruth (Pounds) Boesman, was born May 14, 1941, in Pittsburgh, PA. She graduated from Juniata College and received her Doctorate in Biochemistry from NY University in 1970. After a postdoctoral period in Lausanne, Switzerland, she joined the faculty of Microbiology of The University of Texas Southwestern Medical School in Dallas, where she met her husband Richard A. Finkelstein, Ph.D., Professor of Microbiology. The two worked together in Texas and since 1979 at The University of Missouri-Columbia School of Medicine on the Pathogenesis and Immunology of the disease, Cholera. They published and traveled together extensively during their 31 years of marriage. They had one daughter, Sarina N. Finkelstein, M.F.A., Photo Editor of Time Out New York Kids & Guides. She is also survived by a sister, Ruth Williams of Arkansas and by her stepchildren, Sheri Schoenwald, Mark Finkelstein and Laurie Charsinsky and seven grandchildren.

HERMAN--Marilyn MacHardy, 81, died peacefully March 17, 2007 in Devon, PA. Marilyn lived a full and vibrant personal and professional life. Born in New York, raised in Rye, she was happily married for 35 years to Dr. Myron Herman. They raised their four children in Yonkers and Lake Placid, NY. Marilyn received a Nursing Degree from Presbyterian Hospital, and an MA in Education from Columbia. She began her two decade career at The Ethical Culture Schools in NYC as school nurse, eventually becoming Director of Admissions. Marilyn influenced the lives of hundreds of students and leaves a legacy of service to family and community. She was active in the Westchester Alzheimers Association, and served as its president for several years. Marilyn is survived by her children Deborah, Randolph, Hollis, and Allison, and their spouses, and seven grandchildren and their spouses. She will be sorely missed by her family and many friends. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Heartland Hospice Service, 4070 Butler Pike, Suite 100, Plymouth Meeting, PA 19462.

AS drivers pick their way down the West Side Highway of Manhattan, the noise is often more annoying than the traffic -- and it's not just the honking. What's so irksome is the static from the car's sound system, a result of congestion in the radio frequency spectrum in an area packed with AM and FM stations. But that analog annoyance may fade away as radio broadcasters, carmakers and consumer electronics companies make the transition to digital radio.

When J. J. Redick, a guard for the Orlando Magic, was in eighth grade, he used an outlet that he learned from his favorite teacher, Terri Steffen, to cope with the death of his maternal grandfather. That outlet was poetry. ''I'm very close to my mom and I didn't know how to deal with it, so to just get through that period I just started writing poetry about that situation,'' Redick said.

To the Editor: ''A Real-Life Rocky, Still Stirring the Crowd'' (March 11), your fine article about Chuck Wepner, reminded me of an incident that took place while I was growing up in Bayonne in the 1950s. I played with a group of Jewish basketball players in the Catholic Youth Organization League. One evening, our team faced a ruffian group led by Mr. Wepner and the local football star, George Stridio. As I was coming to the basket for an easy left-handed layup, Chuck used his elbow to uppercut me under the chin.

To the Editor: Re ''Zoning Out the Future'' (Op-Ed, March 17): Vince Polimeni and his fellow developers pitch their ideas in ways that try to convince the rest of us that their primary goal is altruistic -- that the continued construction of amusement parks and strip malls is really in the public interest. Sorry, but we're not buying it.

AUERBACH--John, of Roslyn Heights, LI, NY, a leader of the American bicycle industry, died at 96 on March 21, 2007. He is survived by Isabelle, his wife of 68 years, daughter, Joan, of New York City, son, Robert, of Auckland, New Zealand, and grandsons, Jason and Shane. John Auerbach served the American bicycle industry for more than 50 years. As Executive Director of the Bicycle Institute of America and successor organizations, he promoted the creation of bikeways from abandoned railroad tracks. He encouraged school districts across the country to include bicycle safety education in their curricula. He testified before congressional committees in support of a Federal bicycle safety standard. He helped popularize bicycle racing in the United States. His many and varied contributions led to a resurgence in the popularity of bike riding by people of all ages for transportation, fitness and recreation. Beloved husband, beloved father, you are in our hearts forever.

A review on Feb. 25 about ''Remainder,'' by Tom McCarthy, rendered incorrectly the name of the test that distinguishes androids from humans in ''Blade Runner,'' the 1982 science-fiction film based on a novel by Philip K. Dick, whose work was compared with McCarthy's. In printed references to the film, it is Voight-Kampff, not ''void comp.'' (In Dick's novel ''Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?'' it is spelled Voigt-Kampff, without the ''h.'')

To the Editor: In light of recent revelations that critically lauded piano recordings marketed under Joyce Hatto's name were actually illegal copies of other artists' discs, Mr. Tommasini is surely correct in noting that context influences how we hear music. Were it otherwise, concert attire and program notes would presumably be superfluous. But isn't the underlying reason for this fiasco that today's professional-level classical performances all sound pretty much alike? So long as performers continue to place much more emphasis on fidelity to a score than on interpretative individuality, context will be practically all that matters. Ben Givan Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

James J. Cramer, CNBC's televangelist of trading with his manic ''Mad Money'' show, now says that those sins he was confessing were not his own. In a video interview taped in December for TheStreet.com that quickly turned into a big hit on YouTube last week before CNBC had it removed, Mr. Cramer laid out in bombastic detail how to really make mad money on Wall Street. He would ''foment,'' he said, to push a stock up or down. If he wanted a stock's price to fall, he recommended spreading negative information about the company to a ''bozo reporter'' at The Wall Street Journal. Bob Pisani, a CNBC reporter, is another useful conduit of damaging rumors, he said. ''No one else in the world would ever admit it,'' he said of the various methods, ''but I don't care.''
Epilogue
To the Editor: Re ''www.movies.now'' [March 18]:

Dynamometers, the auto-emission testing systems that raised the ire of politicians and the blood pressure of drivers after they were introduced to state-run inspection stations seven years ago, are being dismantled and removed. Dynamometers were installed to test for carbon monoxide and nitrous oxide emissions in vehicle exhausts at various levels of acceleration in response to federal standards, but they frequently broke down, resulting in hourslong waits for motorists at inspection stations.

The ''shock jock'' Howard Stern has been very important to the success of Sirius Satellite Radio. Subscriptions surged after he agreed to bring his raucous show to the service. But now that Mel Karmazin, chief executive of the company, wants to merge with XM Satellite Radio Holdings, he is making it clear to members of Congress that subscribers who object to the talk show do not have to feel as if they are paying Mr. Stern's $100-million-a-year salary.

By day, lawmakers feud over the state budget with new-found intensity. But at dusk, Albany's legislative routines revert to normal. Sundown is fund-raising hour in the state capital, the time when every restaurant or club or hotel has a room or two with an open bar and a few tough canapés and a lawmaker shaking hands in exchange for campaign checks. To be fair, nobody much enjoys these evening routines -- not the politicians and not even the lobbyists. But they all know that New York's public servants have to party, party, party every night after work if they're going to milk their share of the available special-interest money.

To the Editor: Re ''Phony Baloney at Rutgers'' (editorial, March 18), about the university's plan to cut six varsity-level sports because of budget cuts: There are a number of concerned alumni like me who have contacted university officials offering to lead fund-raising efforts to save the teams slated for elimination.
Bring on the cats and dogs.
To the Editor: Re ''Your Brain on Baseball'' (column, March 18): As a liberal, I find myself agreeing with David Brooks only occasionally.

An essay on March 4, ''Confessions of a Book Abuser,'' by Ben Schott, defended the ways people physically ''mistreat'' books. Readers have subsequently pointed out a number of resemblances between Schott's essay and ''Never Do That to a Book,'' an essay on the same subject by Anne Fadiman that was part of her 1998 collection ''Ex Libris: Confessions of a Common Reader.'' Among several thematic similarities that readers commented on are ones involving a system of dog-earing pages either at the top or at the bottom depending on referential purpose and travelers who rip previously read sections from paperbacks and discard them before boarding an airplane. But the most striking resemblance occurs in the opening lines of each essay. Schott's begins: ''I have to admit I was flattered when, returning to my hotel room on the shores of Lake Como, a beautiful Italian chambermaid took my hand. ... Escorting me to the edge of the crisply made bed, the chambermaid pointed to a book on my bedside table. 'Does this belong to you?' she asked. I looked down to see a dog-eared copy of Evelyn Waugh's 'Vile Bodies' open spread-eagle, its cracked spine facing out. 'Yes,' I replied. 'Sir, that is no way to treat a book!' she declared, stalking out of the room.''

THE small-city department store has had a tough few decades. Once a one-stop shop for overcoats and makeup, with a smiling operator in the elevator, the stores began struggling to compete against suburban malls in the 1970s and then against big-box retailers in the 1990s.

IT'S official: middle schools are a mess. If you didn't already suspect this, a battery of standardized tests, some of which are required under the No Child Left Behind law, have confirmed that in rich and poor school districts alike, reading and math scores drop from fifth to sixth grade, when most students move to middle school. What's worse is that the scores continue to decline through eighth grade, as do students' self-esteem and engagement in school. Sadly, no one seems to know what to do about these schools, which generally serve 11- to 13-year-olds. The solutions that most educators have come up with tend to involve restructuring the schools, including assigning students to fewer teachers during the day, decreasing class size or the school size, or changing the schools to either kindergarten through eighth grade or sixth through 12th grade. These responses, however, have not altered the pattern of decline during the middle school years.

LAZAROW--Al, on March 20, 2007, at 90 years of age. Loving husband for 66 years of Regina; brother of Sidney; father of Madeleine, Marty, and Richard; grandfather of Erica, Michelle and Andrew. Active in B'nai B'rith, Uja, Israel bonds and JCC of West Hempstead. Loved by all the hearts he touched.

POEPPLEIN--Ronald F. Beloved friend and colleague. Ron graduated Brooklyn Law School in 1978 and immediately became a student of the law, an outstanding trial attorney, an accomplished legal writer and appellate attorney. He was a fellow of The American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers, one of the youngest ever elected, and had been president of the Criminal Courts Bar Association of Nassau County. He was also a member of the American, New York State and Nassau County Bar Associations. He was included in Who's Who in American Law. In 1996 he co-authored the second edition of a two-volume work on separation agreements and marital contracts. For many years he shared his legal wisdom as an adjunct professor at Adelphi University where he taught matrimonial law in the Lawyers Assistant Program. His reputation for skillfully litigating complex cases was well known in the legal community. There was never a task too big for Ron. It was a privilege for all of us to work with Ron. Our hearts go out to his loving wife Lorraine, and his family. The wake will be held at the Cassidy Funeral home, 156 Willis Avenue, Mineola, New York, on Sunday, March 25, 2007, from 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm. A mass will be held on Monday, March 26, 2007, at the Corpus Christi RC Church, 155 Garfield Avenue, Mineola, New York (off Willis Avenue) at 9:30 am. All of Rons friends and colleagues at Schlissel, Ostrow, Karabatos & Poepplein will miss him dearly.

An article last Sunday about Tatum O'Neal and her forthcoming roles, including one on the television show ''Rescue Me,'' misstated the number of seasons the series has been on the air. In June, it will be starting its fourth season, not its third.

Q. A recent letter from our managing agent about our co-op's insurance coverage suggested that residents' homeowners' policies include a loss-assessment rider to ''cover certain types of losses incurred by the corporation, which would then be assessed on all shareholders in the form a loss assessment.'' Is the suggested rider necessary, or is it simply a matter of cost shifting by the co-op? A. ''Loss-assessment coverage is automatically included under a cooperative or condominium homeowners' policy,'' said Robert E. Mackoul, the president of Mackoul & Associates, an insurance brokerage in Long Beach, N.Y.

Riot police officers swarmed on a group of several dozen journalists and demonstrators on Saturday in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia's third-largest city, cutting off a protest against the government of President Vladimir V. Putin. The police, vastly outnumbering the protesters and wielding night sticks and metal shields, detained about 30 people, the Interfax agency quoted a spokesman as saying. A protest organizer said the number of people detained at the raid was more than 100, plus another 100 who had been arrested in an earlier roundup. Among those detained were several foreign and Russian journalists, including a photographer for The New York Times who was later released.

BOSE--Arun. 73. Bengali artist and art professor at Lehman College for 35 years, died at his home in North Salem, NY on February 7, after a long illness. He is survived by his wife Araceli and a daughter, Rebecca. He will be missed. A painter and a master printmaker, his wide-ranging body of work was rooted in remembrances of his beloved city of Kolkata. He exhibited around the world, and his works are featured in several museums and art collections. He received his art education at the Government College of Art & Craft Kolkata, India; the Ecole Superieur des BeauxArts, Paris -under a French government scholarship where he also studied printmaking with Stanley William Hayter at the prestigious Atelier 17; and Pratt Graphic Center, Manhattan, NY. At that time, 1968, he received the John D. Rockefeller, III Fellowship. He was proud to have been a member of the Robert Blackburn Printmaking Workshop, NYC. As noted by the Kolkata newspaper The Telegraph -at the time of his retrospective exhibition in 2004 -Arun Bose's legacy as artist and teacher, his very own art expression, will remain that of ''A New Yorker with Bengal in his canvas''.

Super Mario is still able to leap over Wall Street's highest-paid chief executives in a single bound. Mario J. Gabelli, the chairman of his own mutual fund company, Gamco Investors, received $58.2 million in compensation in 2006. That was more than the pay of any senior executive of a major Wall Street firm, topping even the $54.7 million received by Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs.

To the Editor: Re ''At 'The Agency,' It Isn't Pretty'' by Lola Ogunnaike (March 11): I am a 13-year-old girl, and I was upset because the article made me wonder why the modeling business is so harsh. Becky Southwick, an agent, was angry at a model named Chloe, comparing her to the Pillsbury Doughboy because her hip size had gone up to 36 1/2 from 35. To me, she looked unhealthy and depressed.
This spring, good things come in teeny-weeny packages. So if you've got it milk it.

To the Editor: As a former employee of a rare-book library and the fiancé of an archivist, I read "History, Digitized (and Abridged)" (March 11) with interest. Even if many archived documents are not digitized, the digital age provides a tool previous generations lacked: the so-called finding aid, an online description of an archive and its contents.

Richard Panek's dazzling, well-calibrated article on dark matter and dark energy (March 11) put everything else in Sunday's New York Times -- from brain sciences to men's style to the weekend news -- in perspective. As higher primates, we continue to make valiant attempts to decipher what we conveniently refer to as ''the universe.'' Yet we are limited by our sensory and cognitive capacity, even with all of the mechanical extenders thus far devised.

Let Them Score In what might be a major blow to what high school coaches teach players across the country, it appears that defense in basketball may be overrated. Most teams in the N.B.A. have played about 70 games this season and there are currently 11 teams giving up more than 100 points a game. Amazingly, seven of those teams are competing for playoff spots because of their high-scoring offenses.

An article yesterday about the discovery that rat poison had been found in pet food blamed for the deaths of 14 animals misstated the status of a recall by Menu Foods. It did not expand its recall on Friday, but did ask retailers to remove all wet food products from shelves.

To the Editor: I was always under the impression that Dubai was a model of excess, so I was surprised to see in ''A Bargain Emirate: Dubai on a Budget? No, It's Not a Mirage'' (Practical Traveler, March 11) by Michelle Higgins that some lower-cost hotels and travel options were being made available to tourists and business travelers. It will be interesting to see if people take advantage of the cheaper alternatives, and if the cheaper alternatives, in turn, lower the prices of high-end destinations. Most markets are big enough for both, and it will be interesting to see how this plays out in Dubai. Steven M. Clayton Ocean, N.J.
For adventure . . . or whatever floats your boat.
