THERE'S nothing wrong with drug makers publicizing their products, but the lure of lucrative government contracts can prompt them to play fast and loose. In lobbying state lawmakers to make its latest vaccine mandatory, Merck has greatly exaggerated both the threat of a disease and the ability of a drug to prevent it. (True, Merck has promised to stop lobbying, but lawmakers and the public are still suffering under misconceptions that the drug company has done nothing to correct.) The drug in question is Gardasil, a vaccine for four types of human papillomavirus, or HPV, two of which are responsible for 70 percent of cervical cancer cases. The Food and Drug Administration approved Gardasil last year for use against HPV in females aged 9 to 26. New Mexico, Texas and Virginia have all recently mandated HPV vaccination for girls, and Connecticut may be next.

LANDAU--Mabel R. Two weeks prior to her 100th birthday, Mabel passed away on March 23, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Harold, devoted mother of Lawrence and Sandra, loving grandmother of Scott, Brian, Todd, Emily, Caroline and Katherine and adoring great-grandmother of Isabel, Zachery, Rylee, Amanda and Matthew. A 1928 graduate of Cornell University, Mabel was an enthusiastic lover of the opera, bridge, and all things cultural. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison, 1:30 on Monday, March 26, 2007.

BARZIN--Eleanor Close, died at her home in Paris, France, on November 27, 2006. She also resided in Fribourg, Switzerland. She was born Eleanor Post Close on December 3, 1909, in Greenwich, CT, to Edward Bennett Close and Marjorie Merriweather Post. She was preceded in death by her husband Leon Eugene Barzin (1999) and sister Adelaide Close Riggs (1998) and is survived by her son Antal Miklas Post de Bekessy; granddaughter Laetitia Allen Vere; sister Nedenia Hutton Hartley (Dina Merrill); and brothers Edward B. Close, Jr., and William B. Close, M.D. A service honoring her life was held on March 6, 2007, at Hillwood Museum & Gardens (DC).

Pegged to the fury of March Madness, HBO brings us ''THE UCLA DYNASTY'' (Monday at 10 p.m.), a documentary exploring the legend that was the men's basketball team of the University of California, Los Angeles, in the 1960s and '70s. Under the stewardship of the coach, John Wooden, now 96, and interviewed here, the Bruins captured an astonishing 12 N.C.A.A. championship titles from 1964 to 1975 and ignited a national fever over college basketball that has yet to cool down. The baby boomers who came of age during that period receive their very own tribute in ''THE BOOMER CENTURY: 1946-2046,'' another documentary, which will appear on PBS on Wednesday at 9 p.m. What more needs to be said of the narcissistic generation? The film doesn't just reflect wistfully on the Woodstock years -- because really, who could stand that? It examines how boomer psychology has shaped the market and the marketplace of ideas, for better and for worse. The great question of how boomers will handle retirement is explored too. Look forward to (or run away from) interviews with Oliver Stone, Erica Jong and Dr. Andrew Weil, among others. You've been aching to see them together again, and, your dream will no longer be denied. On Tuesday at 10 p.m., Jennifer Aniston makes a guest appearance on the season finale of FX's ''DIRT,'' the tabloid drama starring her former ''Friends'' cast mate Courteney Cox. Ms. Aniston will play a rival editor to Ms. Cox's Lucy Spiller, and she will play a lesbian.

CONLIN--Joseph H., 79, New York impresario, died on Monday, March 5, 2007, in West Palm Beach, FL. A kindly, imposing man of great wit, charm, and generosity -and an excellent ballroom dancer who possessed an encyclopedic knowledge of opera and piano repertoire -he suffered an aneurism behind the right knee in May of 2002, which led simultaneously to an amputation and kidney dialysis. With heroic cheerfulness, he continued to support his friends and clients from his electric wheelchair, building up his concert management and travel agency as a legacy for tenor and composer Brian Hunter, his partner for the last 15 years. After graduation from Columbia University, several years at NBC, and a stint in the US Army, he worked for John R. Fitzgerald of Rye Beach, NH, the largest purveyor of novelties in the world. In the 1950s, he established Conlin Associates, which became one of America's premier concert-management firms, responsible for numerous contracts in the U.S. of such European artists as Carlo Bergonzi, Maria Callas, Giuseppe di Stefano, and Ferruccio Tagliavini. Among his list of high-level cultural events were the first American recital of Renata Tebaldi at the Old Met, the American Farewell Concert Tour of the 65-year-old Beniamino Gigli, and the 1955 sensational Carnegie Hall recital of Jussi Bjorling when other presenters were afraid of the great tenor's alcoholism. An expert judge of musical talent, Conlin adjudicated numerous piano and vocal competitions across the country. In the 1980s, he served as general manager of the Palm Beach Opera and executive director of the Chopin Foundation of the US, in Miami.
MILTON--Arthur. Taken suddenly March 25, 2006. You always remain in my heart and mind. I remember all that was special and I keep that with me...until my last breath. Phyllis

The 52nd Venice Biennale takes place this summer, when the international art world descends on that magical city to examine what's happening in contemporary art. For now the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be exploring the Venice of centuries past. ''VENICE AND THE ISLAMIC WORLD, 828-1797,'' which opens on Tuesday and runs through July 8, focuses on this rich exchange of artistic ideas. Arranged chronologically, the exhibition begins in the year when two Venetian merchants stole St. Mark's body from Muslim-controlled Alexandria and took it to Venice. It ends when the Venetian Republic fell to Napoleon. Particularly fascinating will be the part that deals with the 15th and 16th centuries, when the Venetian interest in Islamic culture flourished. One artist, Gentile Bellini, made a diplomatic mission to the court of Sultan Mehmet II between 1479 and 1481 and began incorporating Islamic figures and settings in his paintings. Some pupils, including Vittore Carpaccio and Giovanni Mansueti, copied him. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. Illuminated manuscripts can also be seen at the Morgan Library & Museum. On view through June 17 is ''APOCALYPSE THEN: MEDIEVAL ILLUMINATIONS FROM THE MORGAN,'' commemorating the completion of a facsimile of ''Las Huelgas'' from 1220, the largest surviving manuscript from a Spanish tradition of illuminated works centered on the Apocalypse. Because the manuscript was unbound for the preparation of the facsimile, 50 of its miniatures can be seen side by side. 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 685-0008, morganlibrary.org. For those curious to see Asher B. Durand's ''Kindred Spirits,'' that much-publicized 1849 Hudson River School landscape, it will be hanging at the Brooklyn Museum starting Friday. The New York Public Library sold the painting to the Wal-Mart heiress Alice L. Walton in a sealed bid auction at Sotheby's two years ago for a reported $35 million. Depicting the painter Thomas Cole and the poet William Cullen Bryant standing on a rocky ledge overlooking the Catskills, it will be the centerpiece of ''KINDRED SPIRITS: ASHER B. DURAND AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE.'' 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org.

To the Editor: Regarding the ''Q&A'' about traveling from New York to Rome to Split (March 11): It is stated that one can earn Aadvantage miles while traveling on Iberia, a member of the Oneworld alliance. While this is true, readers should know that miles are only sometimes -- not always -- awarded. I recently traveled from New York to Málaga on Iberia. I asked before the trip if I would receive American AAdvantage award miles. I was assured that I would. However, Iberia later posted only 30 percent of the miles I'd accumulated, and American Airlines confirmed that this was normal, depending on the ticket price.

Washington, D.C. is the new Washington, D.C. Buzz is building inside the Beltway with new restaurants (Central Michel Richard and Il Mulino), a redone Park Hyatt and Kimpton's seventh D.C. boutique hotel, the Palomar -- not to mention Nancy Pelosi's chic suits.
(Photographs by Ted Schillinger (3); Roadfood.Com; Tony Cenicola; Jeanette Liang; Lucy Andersen; Tony Cenicola (2);

AS grime obscures my domain, I see through the window glass darkly. Spring is not really a time of optimistic budding, of vernal renewal. It is the season of grunge. The first bright shafts of light illuminate too much; sunshine exposes streaks, all manner of winter muck. Sitting in the kitchen of my house, I feel the call to battle against dirt. A primitive pride wells up within me, perhaps as the sap rises in the tired bare maples outside my window. I will clean house! I head for the caustic chemicals with a wild glee.

To the Sports Editor: Regarding Alan Schwarz's recent articles concerning football-related dementia, the greatest damage is caused by the hard-shell helmet and padding. The helmet was designed as protection. It has become the most lethal weapon in all of sport: to the opponent in the short term, and the wearer in the long run.

He is survived by his beloved wife Ruth, adoring daughters Vicki and Elaine Miles Resner, and loving grandchildren Jennie (Jeremiah), Maureen, Michelle (Zach), Stephanie and (Arnie). Funeral services will take place on Sunday, March 25th at Mount Sinai, Hollywood Hills, 5950 Forest Lawn Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90068, (800)600-0076. Growing up in Tuckhoe and Rye. She married and moved to Kansas City Idaho Falls, Berkley, then Sacramento. She spent her working years teaching the deaf. Divorced years ago she is survived my numerous nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers please send donations to The Parodi Trust Fund for the Deaf 39350 Gallaudet Dr., Freemont, CA 94538.

Besides museums like the Reina Sofía (www.museoreina sofia.es) and the newly redone Prado (museoprado.mcu.es), the city has powerhouse galleries filled with their own art-world stars.

Rob Schwimmer: 'Beyond the Sky' Rob Schwimmer, pianist and thereminist. NuNoise; CD. ROB SCHWIMMER is best known as a jazz pianist and composer, and as a member of Polygraph Lounge, a boundary-crossing, satirical rock duo (with the guitarist Mark Stewart). But threads of the classical tradition also run through his work, as does the kind of crisp, disciplined keyboard technique that thrives best in rhythmically complex and coloristically varied music.

LIEF--Harold I., M.D. The Trustees, Officers and Members of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis and Dynamic Psychiatry express profound sorrow for the loss on March 15, 2007 of Dr. Harold Lief, a Past President of the Academy. We express our condolences to his family. Sherry P. Katz-Bearnot, M.D., President Joseph R. Silvio, M.D., Secretary

When the Ritz-Carlton, Grand Cayman went shopping for a chef three years ago, it didn't go after a brand-name toque with an overcooked empire. It scored the critical darling Eric Ripert, who had yet to open a restaurant outside New York. Since then, hoteliers from Vegas to Boca are not out to get the old war horses -- Alain Ducasse or Wolfgang Puck -- but one of the hot new gastropreneurs.

To the Editor: Regarding ''Myanmar: A Culinary Odyssey, on a Path Blazed by Orwell'' (Explorer, March 11): As members of Amnesty International local groups 9, 11 and 280 in New York, we have been working for the release of prisoners of conscience who are being held under the most brutal conditions in the Union of Myanmar (Burma) solely for the peaceful expression of their beliefs. While Amnesty International takes no stand as to whether travel to Myanmar is desirable or not, we as Amnesty members do feel it is essential that anyone interested in traveling to Myanmar be given a balanced and comprehensive picture of conditions there.

Jeffrey Rosen's article (March 11) captures many of the salient issues emerging from the new field of ''neurolaw.'' Last month, Steven Hyman, the Harvard provost, and I organized a symposium at the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on the use of functional M.R.I. technology to detect lying. The consensus view among the neuroscience, legal and ethics experts who presented papers is that one should be careful not to invest too much faith in the capacity of brain imaging to reveal individuals' true motives and motivations; it is far from the silver bullet for law enforcement, prosecutors or defense attorneys that its champions claim.

An article on March 11 about Chris Rock's ''I Think I Love My Wife'' and other remakes of French New Wave films misidentified to the actress who tempts Mr. Rock's character. She is Kerry Washington, not Gina Torres.

Bullfighting in Spain faces the double-edged sword of youth apathy and rising animal rights activism. But much of the city remains passionate about the sport, and Madrid is still a great place to see it.

When the AMERICAN COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA played its first concert, in 1977, there was nothing quite like it. This full symphony orchestra was formed to play music by American composers, from Serialists and neo-Romantics to Minimalists (and beyond), and from early-20th-century classics to newly commissioned scores. DENNIS RUSSELL DAVIES, the orchestra's conductor from its founding until 2002, returns Monday to lead a 30th-anniversary program. This typically eclectic venture includes Tania León's ''Indígena,'' as well as a handful of concertos in which the composers are the soloists. They include Steven Mackey's ''Deal'' (for electric guitar), ''Inventions'' by the jazz pianist Vijay Iyer, Kurt Rohde's ''White Boy/Man Invisible'' (for viola), Harold Meltzer's ''Virginal'' (for harpsichord), Andrew McKenna Lee's ''Arabescata'' (for guitar) and Min Xiao-Fen's ''Blue Pipa'' (for the pipa, a Chinese lute). 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $32 to $40. NEW SOUNDS LIVE, the concert hall spinoff of John Schaefer's new-music show on WNYC-FM (93.9), offers a tantalizing mixture of the antique and the modern on Wednesday. TRIO MEDIAEVAL, the Norwegian vocal ensemble, mostly performs very old music, as its name suggests, but also recent works composed for it. Also on the bill is the CRASH ENSEMBLE, an Irish chamber group that will perform two new works by a compatriot, Donnacha Dennehy. 8 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3330, kaufman-center.org; $35 in advance, $40 at the door. The violinist MIRANDA CUCKSON has enlivened many a new-music concert in recent seasons, but there is more to her than that. At a recital on Sunday with THOMAS BAGWELL, the pianist, Ms. Cuckson will play works by Copland, Paul Schoenfield, Schubert and Brahms. 3 p.m., Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73rd Street, (212) 288-8920, mapc.com; $15, $10 for students and 65+. If you're a fan of PAUL MORAVEC's music, you may have to do some sprinting on Thursday: his ''Tempest Fantasy,'' which won the Pulitzer Prize in 2004, is included on a program by the TRIO SOLISTI and the clarinetist ALAN KAY. Works by Mendelssohn and Piazzolla are also on the program. 7:30 p.m., Thalia at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $21 in advance, $25 at the door. A few miles south, at Carnegie Hall, the superb flutist MARYA MARTIN is including Mr. Moravec's ''Marya's Song'' in her all-contemporary program, ''The Flute Book of the 21st Century,'' which includes scores by Eve Beglarian, Kenji Bunch, Chen Yi, Melissa Hui, Tania León, Ned Rorem and David Sanford. 8 p.m., Weill Recital Hall; $15.

The stage of the Peter B. Lewis Theater at the Guggenheim Museum isn't exactly what you'd call spacious. Sunday and Monday it should be bursting at the seams, as the Italian choreographer LUCA VEGGETTI presents a triptych of new works, performed by four members of the Cincinnati Ballet along with the Sacramento Ballet dancer R. COLBY DAMON. The chamber compositions of the Japanese composer Toshio Hosokawa make up the score, performed live by a flutist, an accordionist and a pianist. That's a lot of bodies, and cultures, for one little stage. But Mr. Veggetti is usually more interested in stillness and space than commotion, and Mr. Damon, a smart, fluid dancer with an exquisite attack, is good at making room for himself. The program, which is part of the Guggenheim's Works and Process series, will include a discussion with Mr. Veggetti and Victoria Morgan, the artistic director of the Cincinnati Ballet, and moderated by Alexandra Munroe, the museum's senior curator of Asian Art. Sunday and Monday at 7:30 p.m., (212) 423-3587, worksandprocess.org; $15 to $24. Another trio of dances can be seen starting Wednesday, as the Juilliard dance division, under the direction of Lawrence Rhodes, presents SPRING DANCES AT JUILLIARD. Sophomore, junior and senior students will be featured in the Twyla Tharp classic ''Deuce Coupe''; Jiri Kylian's 1980 all-male tribute, ''Soldiers' Mass''; and ''Name by Name,'' choreographed by Susan Marshall, a Juilliard alumna. Ms. Marshall's work, for 18 women and set to music by David Lang, is a premiere, but ''Deuce Coupe,'' from 1973, danced to the Beach Boys, is likely to be the real draw. Also featured is the 28-member Axiom ensemble, conducted by George Stelluto, and a men's chorus for Mr. Kylian's piece. Wednesday through next Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 3 p.m., Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 155 West 65th Street, (212) 721-6500, juilliard.edu; $10 to $20.

To the Editor: ''North Haven, Big-Box Central,Shifts Gears'' (March 18) describes a change in development for North Haven, from big-box stores to smartgrowth developments, through a zoning amendment passed by the town.

KIRCHMAN--Kenneth P. Kenneth Kirchman, a prominent Orlando businessman and founder of Kirchman Corporation, died at his home in Winter Park on Tuesday, March 13. He was 72. Mr. Kirchman founded Kirchman Corporation, a privately held banking software innovator, in 1968 and built the company into a multi-national corporation that served over 6,000 banking institutions around the world. Kirchman Corporation was a pioneer in the banking software industry and a leading provider of automation software and compliance services to commercial banks. It was acquired in 2004 by Metavante Banking Solutions. Mr. Kirchman contributed Stetson University's first $1 million gift to endow the Kirchman Chair of Humanities. His active and committed interest in the community led him to serve on Stetson University Board of Trustees and serve as President of the Alumni Association. He was also former Director of Public Radio and Television of Central Florida. He served on former Florida Governor Bob Graham's Economic Development Task Force and was a Trustee of Florida House in Washington, DC. He earned a B.S. from Stetson University, attended a business management course at Harvard Business School and was awarded an Honorary Doctorate of Law (LLD) from Stetson. He served as a First Lieutenant in the Guided Missile Branch of the U.S. Army and, prior to founding Kirchman Corporation, held positions with Sperry Rand Corporation, The National Cash Register Company and General Computer Services. He is survived by his wife, Deanna Pitman Kirchman and niece Victoria Pitman Smith. He has three children and a son-in-law: Kevin Kirchman, Karen Kirchman, and Kimberly (Mark) Fehl. He has two sisters and brothers - in - law: Arlene (Jack) Griffith and Jane (Neil) Linden and two brothers and sisters-in-law: Ronald (Linda) Kirchman and Arthur (Glenda) Kirchman. He has four grandchildren, Chantell Calivas, Brent Calivas, Kaiya Fehl and Marin Fehl and 11 nieces and nephews along with 16 grandnieces and grandnephews. The family will hold a memorial service for family and friends on Tuesday, March 27th at 11:00 am. The event will be held at Lake X, the Kirchman's 10,000 acre ranch south of Orlando, FL. The family requests that no flowers or donations be sent. Condolence cards can be addressed to the family and sent to P.O. Box 2519, Winter Park, FL 32790.

FERGUSON--Katharine Crowninshield. The Officers and Directors of The Garden Club of America express deep sorrow on the death of their former President, Katharine (Kitty) Crowninshield Ferguson, and extend deepest sympathy to her husband, David L., and her family and friends. She served the Garden Club with great distinction, inspiration and extraordinary ability as its 35th president (2003-2005) and in many other capacities that began with her membership in the Fox Hill Garden Club in Massachusetts. Beginning in 1987, Kitty served The Garden Club of America on a national level which included various committees including Judging, Long Range Planning and Visiting Gardens. She was a Zone Chairman, member of the Finance Committee, Policy Committee and was part of the Endowment Campaign. Kitty was the recipient of the Zone Creative Leadership Award. Mrs. Ferguson made considerable contributions to The Garden Club of America. She will be remembered for her warm, gentle and loving nature, her generous spirit and gracious manner. She was an inspiration to anyone who was fortunate enough to meet her. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory can be made to Tower Hill Botanic Garden, 11 French Drive, Boylston, MA 01505, or The Garden Club of America, 14 East 60th Street, NY, NY 10022. Alice Mathews, President
HOFFMAN--Lauren. To our angel with love. Time will never heal the wound in our hearts. Dad, Lynn, Robbie & Stacey

Sean MacPherson and his restaurant Swingers defined early-'90s Los Angeles. A decade later, his Park restaurant and Maritime Hotel turned Manhattan's West Chelsea into a tailgate party for groovy young things. Now, after his glamification of the Waverly Inn (with Graydon Carter and others) in the West Village, his new Bowery Hotel is giving devotees a reason to head east. Why the Bowery? I love the street's history and its location, even its sound. And the neighborhood is shifting. Besides us, the New Museum and a Whole Foods are coming. The look? Everything is handpicked, all antiques and old rugs, like our version of the Algonquin. Do you ever take a break?

Tristan Murail: 'Winter Fragments' Erin Lesser, flutist; Argento Chamber Ensemble, conducted by Michel Galante. Aeon AECD 0746; CD. RECENT concert seasons in New York have been greatly enriched by the efforts of the Argento Chamber Ensemble, an ambitious group founded by the conductor Michel Galante in 2000. The ensemble, whose roster includes some of the city's finest young musicians, specializes in toothier strains of contemporary composition. And it renders them not merely approachable but positively delectable through its mix of technical command and urgent advocacy.

CHESS--Stella, M.D. The Bellevue family mourns the loss of Dr. Stella Chess, an eminent clinician, researcher and educator. She loved Bellevue and the mission to care for the undeserved. Countless trainees and colleagues were privileged to have been taught by this pioneer in Child and Adolscent Psychiatry. She was vibrant, clinically astute and insisted on simple descriptive language rather than psychiatric jargon. We continue to strive to live up to her vision of listening, observing and above all, understanding a child's 'style'. Lynda D. Curtis, Executive Director Manuel Trujillo, M.D., Director of Psychiatry
What they never taught you in Spanish 101.

Samantha V. Chang's essay (Lives, March 11) reminds me of the stratification that exists in our society. None of the people from the working poor neighborhood that I grew up in could afford to indulge themselves in a variety of drugs with a variety of men and expect to emerge with their degree, a Tiffany wedding band and an attorney husband.

To the Editor: Re ''The Barefoot Impresario'' (March 18), about Ina Garten's career as a cookbook author, businesswoman and television host: I was struck by the parallels between Ms. Garten and a food celebrity from another era: the late Julia Child. Like Ms. Child before her, Ms. Garten is smart, funny and fond of France, and has a supportive husband as a main adviser. Both Ms. Child and Ms. Garten worked for the United States government early in their careers and came to television in their 50s. Just as ''The French Chef,'' Ms. Childs's show, provided an escape from the cold war, assassinations and the tumult of the 1960s, the nurturing ''Barefoot Contessa'' is about as far as one get on TV from Iraq, terrorism and political intrigue in Washington.
FOLEY--Mary E. (nee Hughes) In loving memory, of Watertown and Wayland, MA. September 11, 1922March 21, 2006. ''All of her daughters were virtuous and all of her sons were brave.''
For the trio behind bodega, boston is far from buttoned up.

Once the dowdy sister of stylish Barcelona, Madrid has at last emerged as Spain's coolest city. It may seem tied to tradition -- all those Goyas and ornate gardens -- but the city is also brimming with cutting-edge design and cuisine. And that's just before midnight, when the party really gets going. BY DALE FUCHS

The Explorer column on March 11 about dining in Myanmar misstated the value of the kyat, the Myanmar currency, and the price in kyats of meals there. A meal at Napi, also known as Fatty Lady's Place, in Ohnoma cost about 1,250 kyats, not 7 -- the equivalent of $1 a person. Meals at several roadside joints in the countryside rarely cost more than 1,800 kyats, not 10. (Although the official exchange rate is seven kyats to the dollar, almost all private transactions use rates of 1,000 to 1,250 or more kyats to the dollar.)

By day, lawmakers feud over the state budget with new-found intensity. But at dusk, Albany's legislative routines revert to normal. Sundown is fund-raising hour in the state capital, the time when every restaurant or club or hotel has a room or two with an open bar and a few tough canapés and a lawmaker shaking hands in exchange for campaign checks. To be fair, nobody much enjoys these evening routines -- not the politicians and not even the lobbyists. But they all know that New York's public servants have to party, party, party every night after work if they're going to milk their share of the available special-interest money.

FIELDSTEEL--Edmund S., of Roslyn Heights, NY died on March 23, 2007 in Mount Sinai Hospital, NY. He was the president of EMR Lighting Co., Hauppauge, NY, prior he was an executive with Kenroy Lighting, Farmingdale, NY. He was a graduate of NYU with a degree in business and a WWII navy veteran. Above all else he loved his family and is survived by his beloved wife Lori (Gold); devoted father of Scott and Sjaan Fieldsteel, Cathy and Steve Adler, Jan and Neal Simonsen, Jaime and John Inguagiato and the late Lisa Deen; dear father-in-law of Paul Deen; loving grandfather of Michael, Sara, Heather, David, Melissa, Rachel, Casey, Jason, Luke and his beloved ''Sweetie Pie''. All services are private, provided by the Dancy Funeral Home, Caldwell, NJ.
Spanish fashion houses may not have the international clout of their Italian and French neighbors, but a handful of Madrid designers are making a name for themselves at home and abroad.

Spruce Peak at Stowe, the Vermont ski destination's new base-area development, is the first mountain resort in the country to have earned the Audubon Green Community Award from Audubon International. Some of the property's practices include protecting more than 2,000 acres of wildlife habitat; financial support of the Stowe Municipal trolley system and bike path; and a transfer gondola that eliminates the need for bus transfers (www.livestowe.com). Campers and road-trippers looking for an environmentally friendly, fast and easy way to wash clothes might want to visit www.laundry-alternative.com, which is selling a mechanism called the Wonderwash. It is compact (12 by 12 by 16 inches), requires no electricity and uses 90 percent less water and detergent than a conventional washing machine. The Wonderwash, which costs $42.95, uses a hand-cranked pressure system that can wash five pounds of clothing in a few minutes. Travelers visiting Charleston, S.C., for the Spoleto Festival will also be able to enjoy a new exhibition at the Gibbes Museum of Art, ''Rodin: In His Own Words: Selections from the Iris & B. Gerald Cantor Foundation,'' on view May 25 through Aug. 12. The exhibition, which features about 30 original bronze casts of Auguste Rodin's sculptures, including ''Venus'' (left), also includes written works by the artist (www.gibbesmuseum.org). Norwegian Coastal Voyage Escorted Vacations is offering a 16-day trip, Scandinavian Smorgasbord, which goes by train, bus and cruise from Stockholm, to Copenhagen, Oslo, Lapland and the Lofoten Islands. Prices are $5,369 to $6,709 a person, double occupancy, and include airfare from New York, most meals and first-class hotels. There is a discount of up to $275 a person for booking by March 31. Trips are available from June 21 to Sept. 14. Go to www.norwegiancoastalvoyage.us and click on Vacations. HILARY HOWARD

I am a high-school student dismayed by much of the content my peers routinely exhibit through their blogs and MySpace profiles. In his advice to the college interviewer who Googled a prospective student, Randy Cohen (Ethicist, March 11) wrongly equates an online profile with the traditional ''pen-and-paper diary.'' When we teenagers allude to illicit activities and display revealing photographs, our chief motivation is exhibitionism, not secrecy. We want to attract attention from friends and strangers.

THE small-city department store has had a tough few decades. Once a one-stop shop for overcoats and makeup, with a smiling operator in the elevator, the stores began struggling to compete against suburban malls in the 1970s and then against big-box retailers in the 1990s.
Five disciples of the haute-cuisine guru Ferran Adrià, of El Bulli, are giving the Spanish capital its own taste of avant-garde cooking.

IT was the beginning of the third and final session of the parenting course ''Discipline Is Not a Dirty Word,'' and the instructor, Nancy Olsen-Harbich, wanted to know how people had done on their homework. Cari Jacino, who has 2-year-old twin boys, was feeling overwhelmed. ''I can see why some people take this course twice,'' she said. ''There's so much to remember.''

BOBETSKY--Victor, 83, of Brooklyn, NY. Father of Victor V. (Maria) and Chris J. Grew up in the Bronx, DUX club member. Graduate of Columbia University. Professor of German Language/ Literature at Polytechnic University (NY) for 43 years.

Hilary Sue Poris, the daughter of Carole Poris and Harvey M. Poris of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Andrew Ross Macklin, a son of Deborah M. Charles of South Orange, N.J., and a stepson of the late Dr. Seymour Charles. Rabbi Harvey Goldman officiated at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J. The bride and bridegroom, both 27, graduated from Emory University, and met on its summer abroad program in Oxford, England. They each received a law degree from Fordham.

REIS--Harold Frank, of Washington, D.C., died on March 23, 2007 of cancer. Born in 1916 Bronx, New York, son of the late Bernard and Rose Reis, survived by Ruthanne, wife of 56 years, son Alan (Dana), New York, New York; daughters Kate Grogan (Kevin), Augusta, Georgia, and Deborah Kennedy (Lee Bragg), Manchester, Maine; five grandchildren and many cousins, nieces and nephews. Sister Hilda Lantz predeceased him. A graduate of City College (NY) and 1940 from the Columbia University School of Law. Distinguished lawyer, he retired from the Department of Justice after 26 years, where he had been Executive Assistant to Attorneys General Robert Kennedy and Nicholas de. B. Katzenbach, and earlier as First Assistant Attorney General in the Office of Legal Counsel. Counseled in the Department on the creation of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and the Cuban missile crisis. Present in Mississippi on behalf of the Federal government as James Meredith enrolled in the University of Mississippi in October 1962. Awarded the Rockefeller Public Service Award in 1964. After retiring from his government career, he continued to actively practice law from 1967 to 1996 as a partner or shareholder first at Wilner, Scheiner and Greeley, then Lowenstein, Newman, Reis & Axelrad and its successors now Morgan, Lewis & Bockius LLP. Private family funeral. Memorial service in Washington, D.C. on a date to be announced.

Yadira A. Ramos, a daughter of Teresa Pérez of Oakland Gardens, Queens, and José Ramos of Jamaica, Queens, was married yesterday morning to Jeffrey L. Herbert, a son of Henrietta Herbert and Kirson Herbert of Hockessin, Del. The Rev. Thomas B. Henry, an African Union Methodist minister, officiated at the Mansion on Main Street in Voorhees, N.J., with the Rev. Robert E. Slade, a United Methodist minister, participating. Mrs. Herbert, 26, is an associate at Rivkin Radler, a law firm in Uniondale, N.Y. She graduated cum laude from St. Francis College in Brooklyn and received her law degree from the State University at Buffalo. Her father teaches music and computers at Public School 156 in Brownsville, Brooklyn. Her mother is the assistant principal of P.S. 35 in Jamaica.

A picture credit on Jan. 28 with an article about black fans of indie rock misspelled the photographer's surname. The photograph of the rock group Earl Greyhound was by Darren Ankenman, not Ankerman. The error was pointed out by Mr. Ankenman in an e-mail message on Tuesday.

Q: As a former presidential candidate and three-term Democratic senator from New Jersey, you are surprisingly hard on Democrats in your forthcoming book, ''The New American Story,'' in which you criticize the party for constantly awaiting rescue by a fairy-tale prince. One of their curses is the search for the charismatic candidate, which is really a search for how you felt during J.F.K.'s time and after the assassination.

JENKINS--Marion Gun, 85, died January 13, in Baltimore. A magna cum laude Radcliffe graduate, she was a wartime consular charge d'affaires in China. A teacher in Thailand and Cape Cod, she received her master's degree from St. John's College. Her husband, Felix Jenkins, died in 1975. Surviving is daughter, Eugenie Jenkins and her husband Brian Holmes of Baltimore, sons Patrick and Nicholas of Cape Cod, granddaughter Lucy Holmes, and many dear friends. Memorial gifts may go to the Radcliffe Institute Fund, 10 Garden St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

Podcast: Scheduled to appear this week are Rachel Donadio on the book dealer Glenn Horowitz (above); Christopher Benfey on ''Tales From the Torrid Zone''; Liesl Schillinger on Trezza Azzopardi; and Dwight Garner, senior editor, with best-seller news. Three years after resigning in disgrace, Richard M. Nixon sat down with the British journalist David Frost for a series of interviews in which Nixon came as close as he ever would to a mea culpa. Just think of it: A stubborn president finally shamed into taking responsibility for his mistakes in front of television cameras. It sounds like a fantasy produced by moveon.org, but the new Broadway show ''FROST/NIXON,'' which received rave reviews in its run at the Donmar Warehouse in London and is slated to be turned into a film directed by Ron Howard, has just as much to do with the media as it does with men in power. Mr. Frost, played by Michael Sheen (he was Tony Blair in ''The Queen''), has almost as much on the line as Nixon (Frank Langella) does. And it's not just his journalistic integrity. Mr. Frost, who has seen the play and apparently liked it, paid Nixon $600,000 to join him for the interview, one of the most famous examples of checkbook journalism in history. Previews begin Saturday; the play opens April 22 at Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, Manhattan, telecharge.com; $76.25 to $96.25. ROTOZAZA, a well-regarded avant-garde British company named after a work by the Swiss sculptor Jean Tinguely, produces shows that sound a little like lab experiments by evil scientists. They involve unrehearsed guest performers, who are different every night, following instructions from recorded voices. In ''DOUBLETHINK'' the audience sees how two people, separated by a divider, react differently to the same demand. ''FIVE IN THE MORNING'' places three guests in a swimming pool complex named Aquaworld. These shows have limited runs; see them while you can. ''Doublethink,'' Thursday through April 1, and ''Five in the Morning,'' April 5 through April 8, Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, ps122.org; $20, $10 members. A treat for NORMAN MAILER fans. The great man himself reads from his caustic play ''THE DEER PARK,'' adapted from his novel based on his experiences as a screenwriter in the '50s, and answers questions. Sunday at 7 p.m., Steinhardt Building, 35 West 67th Street, Manhattan, 92y.org; $15.

An article last Sunday about the multiethnic character of the Highbridge neighborhood in the Bronx misidentified the location of the Shady Moon Deli and Grocery, which is three blocks from the site of a fire on March 7 that killed 10 people. It is on Nelson Avenue, not Nelson Street.

A new report from the State Department of Education brought good news to one Long Island high school, but disappointment for two others. Hempstead High School was among eight schools in the state that were removed from the new list of Schools Under Registration Review, a designation for the state's lowest-achieving schools. Hempstead has been on the list for two years.

Born in Milwaukee, graduated UWM with B.A. including studies at Alberts Ludwig Universitat in Freiburg, West Germany in German Literature. Enjoyed a career of 19 years as in International Flight Attendant with American Airlines. He leaves behind his loving partner Dan Pierce of 30 years. An article last Sunday about movie download services referred incorrectly to the availability of the film ''Black,'' starring the Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan. It was indeed released theatrically in the United States, in 2005, and is out on DVD; it was not unreleased here in theaters or on DVD.

IT was the beginning of the third and final session of the parenting course ''Discipline Is Not a Dirty Word,'' and the instructor, Nancy Olsen-Harbich, wanted to know how people had done on their homework. Cari Jacino, who has 2-year-old twin boys, was feeling overwhelmed. ''I can see why some people take this course twice,'' she said. ''There's so much to remember.''

BUT NOT LAST WEEKEND The News -- The last of thousands of stranded air travelers made it home early this week after being marooned around the country when a winter storm struck the Northeast. Behind the News -- Pillow, anyone? The snow, sleet and freezing rain paralyzed airports in the Northeast last weekend and forced the cancellation of more than 3,300 flights. Computer glitches, staffing rules and the sheer volume of bookings because of spring break compounded problems. Travelers slept at airports, crowded into hotels -- or gave up and drove home in rental cars. TO EUROPE, FOR LESS The News -- The European Union's 27 member nations backed a deal with the United States to open up restricted trans-Atlantic aviation routes to new airlines. Behind the News -- The plan will allow European and American airlines to fly any route between any European city and United States city. The change, to take effect next March, is expected to increase competition in Europe and reduce the cost of air travel. The union's transport commissioner, Jacques Barrot, above, predicted it would boost annual trans-Atlantic traffic by 26 million passengers. INTO SPACE The News -- A company that hopes to make access to the cosmos cheaper launched a rocket that reached space before running into trouble and re-entering the atmosphere. Behind the News -- The company, Space Exploration Technologies called the launch from the Marshall Islands a success and said a roll-control problem that developed could be fixed. The company's first attempt to launch its Falcon 1 rocket failed last year. The Internet entrepreneur Elon Musk, who founded the company, says it plans to launch 2 satellites this year. ''Not a perfect day,'' he said of the launch, ''but a good day.'' WITH THE CELLPHONE OFF The News -- The Federal Communications Commission has given up on the idea of allowing in-flight cellphone use, the panel's chairman, Kevin Martin, said. Behind the News -- Air travel already can be tough -- what with the delays, security, tight seating and the, uh, food. A proposal to end the cellphone ban portended an added woe for passengers -- being subjected to a neighbor's high-decibel business deal or personal travails. But Mr. Martin said the wireless telecommunications industry also had an objection -- in-flight calls would interfere with their ground-based networks. AND 800 OTHERS The News -- The Airbus A380, the largest passenger plane in the world, made its debut in the United States. Behind the News -- The $300 million double-decker superjumbo jet is certified to carry up to 853 passengers -- about twice the capacity of the biggest version of the Boeing 747. Its arrival at Kennedy International Airport caused a media stir, but no American carrier has bought the plane. It's expensive, for one thing, and it may just be too big. Even so, said Edmund S. Greenslet, publisher of The Airline Monitor, ''To see it is to be impressed by its sheer magnitude.''

To the Editor: Re ''Evolution of a Feminist Daughter'' by Stephanie Rosenbloom (Sunday Styles, March 18): Having read about Rebecca Walker's book, ''Baby Love,'' I wonder why it isn't called ''Myself Love.''

CAPUTO--Emily Stull, of Riverdale, NYC, and formerly of Bridgehampton, NY, died on March 22, 2007, at age 89. Devoted and loving wife of Dante S. Caputo, and mother of Patricia P. Anderson of Mystic, CT, Pengwynne P. Blevins, M.D. of Arlington, MA, Priscilla Potter (deceased 1957), Peter Potter of Gaithersburg, MD, Pamela Potter of Smyrna, GA, Paul Potter of Shelburne, VT; Kathleen M. Caputo of Washington, DC and Thomas A. Caputo of Greenwich, (children by marriage), eight grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. She attended Smith College, graduated from the University of Kentucky and earned Master Degrees from New York University (in English Literature) and Columbia University (in Library Science). After completing her education at age 50, she was a tenured Reference Librarian and instructor at New York University Bobst Library. She was an avid golfer and tennis player. While in high school, she studied modern dance with Martha Graham. Emily was a devotee of the arts. She had a lifetime passion for reading and was a faithful member of the Shakespeare Club of Riverdale. She enjoyed dressing with style and entertained with lively wit and grace. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Christ Church, Riverdale, NYC, or to Wave Hill in Riverdale. A Memorial Service is planned for Saturday, April 21st, at 11:00am at Christ Church in Riverdale, NYC.

Given the howls of complaint nowadays about the declining quality of feature films, it's easy to forget that we are in the middle of what looks to be a golden age of documentaries. The venerable NEW DIRECTORS/NEW FILMS series, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, has always recognized the vitality of the genre. For the second year its ''classics'' sidebar is revisiting 10 of the most resonant documentaries it has screened over the years. For pertinence you can't beat Jehane Noujaim's 2003 ''CONTROL ROOM.'' This film examines the complicated politics and inner workings of the Middle Eastern news agency Al Jazeera, which in the wake of 9/11 was demonized in the United States as a propaganda tool of Islamic jihadists. The reality, however, is more ambiguous. Ultimately the film wonders whether journalistic objectivity is possible at any time, but especially during a war. For those who wonder how realistically Forest Whitaker captured the Ugandan military dictator Idi Amin in ''The Last King of Scotland,'' Barbet Schroeder's 1974 documentary portrait, ''GENERAL IDI AMIN DADA,'' offers an opportunity to compare the man and his Oscar-winning stand-in. Since it was directed partly by the dictator himself, the film is hardly impartial, but in many places it is monstrously funny. When it was first shown in 2003 ''MY ARCHITECT,'' Nathaniel Kahn's exploration of the mysterious life of his father, the architect Louis Kahn, struck a popular chord. A genius who led a double life and whose body was unidentified for two days when he died of a heart attack in Pennsylvania Station in 1974, the architect was a maddening enigma to his son. Besides being an enlightening posthumous profile of an artist, the film is a classic son-in-search-of-father drama, this one nonfiction. Monday through Friday, Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, filmlinc.com.

A brief item in the Paperback Row column on March 11, about ''A Family Daughter,'' a novel by Maile Meloy, misstated the year in which Meloy begins to follow her protagonist, Abby Santerre. It is 1979, not 1969.

KARDON--Robert (Bob), of Manhattan, formerly of Philadelphia, retired CEO of Kardon Industries, Inc., died in New York on March 23, 2007 of heart failure at the age of 85. Son of the late Morris and Sophie (Winkleman) and brother of the late Eugene and Lester Kardon. He leaves his wife of 57 years, Janet Stolker Kardon, director emeritus of the Museum of Arts and Design; sons Leroy Kardon and wife Gail of Merion, PA and Ross Kardon of Philadelphia; and daughter Nina Baran and her husband Dr. George Baran of Villanova, PA and Rome, Italy; grandchildren Matthew and Daniel Kardon; Alexander and Diana Baran. Bob served with the United States Army 1942-1946; studied at University of Miami, Florida, and Shriveham American University, Swindon, England. Formerly he was Chairman of the Board, B.T. Babbit Company, Inc.; Pittsburgh Mortgage Corporation; Murphree Mortgage Company., Nashville, TN; Kardon Investment Company Peoples Bond & Mortgage, Philadelphia and Chairman of the Board and Vice President, United Container Company; He retired as the CEO of Kardon Industries, Inc. He was also a former Trustee of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Board member, Merion Park Civic Association, Board member, Hilltop School, Ithan, PA. A member of Young Presidents Organization and World Business Council. Bob gave up his ambition to be a professional vocalist to become a successful executive. Besides his multiple business activities, Bob was a devoted family man, art collector, architecture connoisseur, music lover, gourmet, world traveler, tennis player, ocean swimmer, pilot, a great singer and dancer -and a loving friend. A funeral service will be held at 1 pm, Sunday, March 25th, at Joseph A. Levine & Sons, 4737 Street Road, Trevose, PA 19053. Contributions in Robert Kardon's memory can be made to The Philadelphia Museum of Art.

grass-roots / (gras roo ts) / adj. / being or originating on a small or informal scale. Increasingly used to describe localized ovements and projects that are giving unexpected places a new vibrancy, as in, ''Have you heard about the whole grass-roots art and music scene in Omaha?'' Also implies a sought-after vernacular flavor, e.g., ''Those Ace guys have done a supercool grass-roots hotel -- Army surplus and bikes and vintage and vinyl. Very Portland.'' ur- / (oor) / prefix / original or prototypical. Points up the obsession in travel with finding the ultimate -- as in, ''Forget those insipid loaves you get in Paris: the ur-baguette is made in the countryside of Le Perche'' -- as well as the desire to find places that reveal greater truths, e.g., ''If you want to understand class in America, go to Dallas, the ur-capital of consumption.'' tradical / (trad i kal) / adj. / coinage capturing the radical nature of the traditional, as in, ''Hats are really tradical now (didn't you love the cloches at Proenza Schouler?), so I'm off to the hat-making capital of Italy.'' Suggests the current interest of many travelers in places that haven't given themselves up to globalized homogeneity, e.g., ''We just got back from the Faroe Islands. Imagine, we saw the annual ram slaughter -- tradical!'' NATHAN LUMP

WEXLER--Milton. We miss our beloved and unique father, Milton Wexler, who died prematurely at home on March 16, 2007, at the age of 98. A renaissance man, Wexler transformed every boundary he met, from helping launch the Human Genome Project to creating innovative approaches to doing psychotherapy. He befriended and mentored people who changed the face of the arts and sciences. Educated at Syracuse University, he received a law degree from NYU, briefly practicing in Manhattan. He was lured by the tradition-breaking ideas of Sigmund Freud and escaped the law, earning his Ph.D. in clinical psychology from Columbia University and completing his psychoanalytic training. After serving in the Navy during World War II, Wexler moved in 1946 to become Chief Psychologist at the Menninger Clinic. At Menningers, he did seminal research on the treatment of schizophrenia as well as practicing psychoanalysis. In 1950, Wexler's world was shattered when each of his wife's three brothers was diagnosed with Huntington's disease (HD), a devastating and inevitably fatal hereditary brain disorder. Wexler moved his family to Los Angeles. He continued to specialize in treating schizophrenia. His practice expanded to include many creative people in all walks of life -artists, architects, actors, writers, businessmen and others. He experimented with group therapy using the combustible energy of the participants to liberate growth. In 1968, another blow struck the Wexler family. Leonore, his wife, was also diagnosed with HD, the same catastrophic neurodegenerative disease that had destroyed her brothers. The Wexlers realized that their daughters, Alice and Nancy, had a 50% risk of going down the same fatal path. Wexler immediately began the Hereditary Disease Foundation, dedicated to finding treatments and cures. He was particularly proud of creating the interdisciplinary Workshop Program that remains the linchpin of the Foundation. Using lessons gleaned from group therapy, Wexler transformed scientific discussions. He restricted the number to a small group of interdisciplinary participants and forbade slides. He realized it was essential for basic and clinical scientists to work together, share and collaborate. He also recognized that senior investigators as well as younger researchers had something unique to offer. His own presence, when he moderated and participated in the workshops, was catalytic. The synergism he created radiated far beyond the Foundation and broke new boundaries. Although by nature optimistic, Wexler was stunned when his team found the location of the HD gene in 1983. When stretched end to end, a single persons DNA spans the globe's circumference. Wexler's team had found the equivalent of one inch on the globe's circumference! This discovery helped launch the Human Genome Project. It meant that the strategies pioneered and proven by his team would work to find any gene. Wexler's team had found a DNA marker extremely close to the HD gene on the top of chromosome 4. Much work needed to be done to isolate the gene in this inhospitable terrain. Wexler formed an international team, encouraging collaboration to find the HD gene. To expedite progress, Wexler brought the Gene Hunters together many times a year for interdisciplinary workshops. He supported the research financially and became a close mentor and friend to over 100 scientists who made up the team. When the gene was discovered, the Gene Hunters published as a group. Spanning 40 years, Wexler served consecutively as President and Chairman of the Board of the Hereditary Disease Foundation. His inspiration changed the face of medical science. Many researchers he mentored are now transforming the world as leaders in academia, government and the private sector. Wexler continued to the end to be elated by advances in biology that draw us closer to treatments and cures. His excitement about science, creativity and the arts was infectious. His prodigious intellect, curiosity, passion and zest for life moved us and added dimensions to our own. His enthusiasm for Trollope, Huckleberry Finn and Benjamin Franklin, as innovators in psychology and science, opened our eyes. His love of writing expressed itself in creating screenplays and novels. We shared the pleasure of seeing some of his screenplay collaborations in cinemas! He finished an autobiography before macular degeneration robbed him of his sight. We miss his warmth, loyalty, empathy and steadfastness as a friend. We miss his astuteness about character, his dignity, and his generosity of soul. He met almost insuperable physical challenges with humor and grace. He was the ''elder of our tribe,'' the bedrock beneath our feet, and the ''helium'' of inspiration. He is irreplaceable and sorely missed. Send donations to the Hereditary Disease Foundation, 3960 Broadway, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10032; www.hdfoundation.org, 212.928.2121.
To the Editor: Re ''Living the Good Life, Off the Leash'' (March 4):

IT'S official: middle schools are a mess. If you didn't already suspect this, a battery of standardized tests, some of which are required under the No Child Left Behind law, have confirmed that in rich and poor school districts alike, reading and math scores drop from fifth to sixth grade, when most students move to middle school. What's worse is that the scores continue to decline through eighth grade, as do students' self-esteem and engagement in school. Sadly, no one seems to know what to do about these schools, which generally serve 11- to 13-year-olds. The solutions that most educators have come up with tend to involve restructuring the schools, including assigning students to fewer teachers during the day, decreasing class size or the school size, or changing the schools to either kindergarten through eighth grade or sixth through 12th grade.

An article last Sunday about the political experience of presidential candidates misstated the number of years that Barack Obama, a Democratic candidate for president, served in the Illinois State Senate. He served eight years, not nine. The article also omitted part of the name for the medal that John F. Kennedy won for his heroism in World War II. He won the Navy and Marine Corps Medal, not the Navy Medal.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Growing to Appreciate the N.B.A.'s Age Limit,'' March 20: Where else in the American economy is a citizen denied the right to ply his trade and receive market value compensation until he reaches an arbitrarily determined age? Athletes are entertainers -- their games are entertainment. Actors are free to work well before their 19th birthdays, the same with pop music stars. The child actors are too numerous to name, the same with musicians.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended March 10, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. THEN WE CAME TO THE END, by Joshua Ferris. (Little, Brown, $23.99.) Layoff notices fly in Ferris's acidly funny first novel, set in a white-collar office in the wake of the dot-com debacle. VILLAINS' PARADISE: A History of Britain's Underworld, by Donald Thomas. (Pegasus, paper, $16.95.) A lively social picture of criminality in postwar Britain, with the Krays and other crooks. POOR PEOPLE, by William T. Vollmann. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $29.95.) Earthy descriptions and photos lend documentary value to Vollmann's account of the world's marginalized. YOU DON'T LOVE ME YET, by Jonathan Lethem. (Doubleday, $24.95.) An indie rock band owes its success to an unwitting creative partner. WAITING FOR DAISY, by Peggy Orenstein. (Bloomsbury, $23.95.) A journalist trying to become a mother offers a personal look at her descent into the surreal community of the subfertile. THE FRIENDSHIP: Wordsworth and Coleridge. by Adam Sisman. (Viking, $27.95.) The poets and their circle, mainly through primary sources. SHOUT, SISTER, SHOUT! The Untold Story of Rock-and-Roll Trailblazer Sister Rosetta Tharpe, by Gayle F. Wald. (Beacon, $25.95.) Tharpe, mostly a gospel singer, defied genre and influenced Johnny Cash, Little Richard and Jerry Lee Lewis. SURVEILLANCE, by Jonathan Raban. (Pantheon, $24.) This novel of American dystopianism is set more or less in the recognizable present. THE FIRST MAN-MADE MAN: The Story of Two Sex Changes, One Love Affair, and a Twentieth-Century Medical Revolution, by Pagan Kennedy. (Bloomsbury, $23.95.) How Laura Dillon became a man between 1946 and 1949. THE HAPPIEST MAN IN THE WORLD: An Account of the Life of Poppa Neutrino, by Alec Wilkinson. (Random House, $24.95.) Neutrino's incessant wanderings make Jack Kerouac's epic trips look like Sunday school outings. BIOGRAPHY: A Brief History, by Nigel Hamilton. (Harvard University, $21.95.) A rich apologia for the art of biography, from Plutarch on. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

KRISTIN SOMERS was sitting in her 10th-grade English class at Hackettstown High last year when a call came over the intercom telling her to report to the office. Immediately. An honors student with a 3.8 average here in northwestern New Jersey, she wasn't being summoned to discuss her academic performance. And while she participates in an array of after-school organizations -- from soccer and softball to the National Honor Society and Key Club -- the issue wasn't her extracurricular activities or future plans.

ANTMAN--Max. On March 15, 2007, with his loved ones at his side. Beloved husband, father, stepfather, grandfather and friend. All who knew him know he was a special man. He will be greatly missed. Donations to the American Cancer Society or Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY would be appreciated.

Mention Rotterdam and most in-the-know aesthetes think of mind-bending architecture, courtesy of homegrown wunderkinds like Rem Koolhaas. The city is indeed a collision of jarring angles, glass cubes and steel beams, but witty design extends beyond the topsy-turvy skyline: Holland's second city offers some of the smartest -- and most original -- shops in all of Europe. Maura Egan

The average visit to Atlantic City used to last three hours, and it's not hard to remember why. If you weren't gambling, you weren't losing to the house, and this left casinos little incentive to wine and dine you. Today, of course, all that's changed: the marriage of gambling to dining, shopping and culture has glamorized the casino experience, and over-the-top has become the new run-of-the-mill. Americans, for their part, have embraced the highbrow-lowbrow mishmash of places like Las Vegas and Connecticut's Mohegan Sun, and now a little roulette between shopping at Prada and dinner at Thomas Keller's Bouchon seems like light entertainment on par with seeing Celine Dion. It's a phenomenon that has proved highly lucrative (Ceasars Forum in Las Vegas is North America's highest-grossing shopping area per square foot) and easily exportable, thereby reshaping not only the culture of gaming but also how and where we travel.

DUBIN--Ellie. A bright light has gone out of our lives. We will miss you. Ardith and David $(6$)DUBIN--Eleanor. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Eleanor Dubin, a major supporter and founder of the Long Island Women's Campaign, a Lion of Judah, and a trustee of a significant supporting foundation at UJA-Federation, whose commitment and generosity have impacted millions of lives. We extend our condolences to her beloved husband, Melvin; her son, Adam; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

To the Editor: The headline of Anthony Tommasini's March 18 article asks ''Can what you know affect what you hear?'' The answer is a resounding yes. Some years ago a friend, irritated by my comments about Alfred Brendel's ''cold, aloof'' playing, made a tape of two performances of Mozart's Piano Concerto in G (K. 453). I was told that one was by Mr. Brendel, and that I was to listen to both at least twice before deciding which one it was. After four sessions I chose unerringly -- wrong. The other version, incidentally, was by Arthur Rubinstein. Susan H. Llewellyn Manhattan

After a brutal stint of winter, shoppers are clearly in the mood for pineapple? And how. When a shipment of charming ceramic pineapple-shaped scented candles by Harry Slatkin arrived at Bath & Body Works stores two weeks ago, 13,000 of them flew off of the shelves in three days. Apparently, the sweet-tart Pineapple Mango scent combined with the retro Palm Beach look was too much for shoppers to resist. (The reasonable price probably didn't hurt. The small candles are $16.50; the large are $50.) A new harvest has arrived in stores and online, with the small size available in stores in the Sugared Passion Fruit scent as well. Light 'em while they last.
To the Editor: Re ''Pipe Dreams,'' by Alex Matthiessen, Andy Willner and Terry Backer (Op-Ed, March 18):

Now that the General Assembly session is at the halfway mark, one Democratic legislator summed up its biggest challenge this way: ''Who is going to be the grownup?'' In other words, with a budget surplus and two huge proposals dominating the agenda, what's a responsible legislator to do?

The next time someone tells you, ''There's no time like the present,'' ask them what day they had in mind. Researchers reported recently that a study of heart attack patients in New Jersey revealed that those who arrived at hospitals on weekends were less likely to receive aggressive treatment and were more likely to die. So, though you can't plan on having a heart attack, you can plan on what might happen when you do. But what about going to the theater? Flying or having a baby? Being arrested? Every topic has its ''worst'' day watch. Woe to the autumn auto buyer, when rebates are few. Or the air traveler in June, when storm clouds gather.
To the Editor: Re ''Debate Rages Anew on Uconn Hospital Expansion'' (March 18):
WYNN--Rita, 80, passed away peacefully on March 18th, 2007. Devoted wife of Dan, loving mother of Elisabeth and Andy and grandmother of Sam and Dylan. Memorial service to be announced.

Stacy Robyn Meyer, the daughter of Renée Meyer of White Plains, was married last evening to Bret Jonathan Danow, the son of Susan and Steven Danow of Pomona, N.Y. Rabbi Craig Scheff officiated at the Hilton Pearl River in Pearl River, N.Y. Mrs. Danow, 31, is a senior designer at the Cayre Group, a clothing manufacturer in New York. She graduated from the State University of New York College at Oneonta.

To the Editor: Shame on Bob Morris (''The Little Puritans,'' The Age of Dissonance, March 11). Instead of chastising his 12-year-old nephew, who expressed concern about his smoking, Mr. Morris should thank him. Yes, children shouldn't set the rules and ''commandeer every conversation,'' but Mr. Morris is selfish. I should know. I said the same thing to my father and uncle 40 years ago, but they didn't listen. Ten years ago, my pipe- and cigar-smoking father died of pulmonary fibrosis. Earlier this month, my uncle had surgery for lung cancer.

The Jacob Burns Film Center has received a $1 million grant to encourage cross-cultural understanding among the center's students through film and other media. The donation was made by Kathryn W. Davis, a Tarrytown philanthropist who turned 100 in February. Mrs. Davis is a longtime supporter of the film center and was the subject of a documentary made by high school students who participate in the center's ''Unscripted'' program.

To the Editor: Rebecca Walker, I have always respected your fierceness, creativity and willingness to reveal your struggles and perceptions. But you have broken my heart with your comment that being an ''adoptive parent involves a lesser kind of love.''

The Legal Center for My Sisters' Place, a nonprofit group based in White Plains that aids victims of domestic violence, celebrated its 10th anniversary this month. Paul J. Noto, a lawyer and former county legislator, said he had been a board member of My Sisters' Place for five years. ''People don't realize how prevalent it is,'' he said of domestic violence. ''Sometimes, when it impacts wealthy families, they're less likely to seek help at a shelter. They fear the social ostracism.''

KRAKOFF--Robert. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dearest friend. You were a prince among men, a devoted husband, loving father, adored grandfather and a most cherished friend. You will be in our hearts forever. Our thoughts and prayers are with Sandy and all the family. Marge Russell and family $(6$)KRAKOFF--Robert of Boston, MA and Palm Beach, FL. Suddenly on March 23, 2007 in Boston, MA of an apparent heart attack. Beloved husband of Sandra Gusky Krakoff. Adored father of Roger (Lisa), Hope (Wendy) and Reed (Delphine). Cherished grandfather of Alexandra, Sophie, Justin, Lily, Helen, Oscar and Maude Krakoff. Son of Della and the late Frank Krakoff. Services will be on Monday, March 26, 2007 at 10 am at Temple Israel, 477 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA. Parking on the Riverway. Donations in his memory may be made to Brigham and Women's Hospital, Development Office, 116 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA 02115. Chairman and CEO of Nielsen Business Media, New York. He graduated magna cum laude from Pennsylvania State University and received an MBA from Harvard Graduate School of Business. He was a member of Belmont CC, Palm Beach CC, the Lotos Club, the Harvard Club of Boston & New York, the University Club of Boston and the Core Club. He was loved and respected by all who knew him. Stanetsky Memorial Chapel www.stanetsky.com 1-800-842-4280 $(6$)KRAKOFF--Robert, The board, advisory board and staff of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation mourn the passing of Robert Krakoff, beloved husband of our devoted Advisory Board member Sandra. Lauder, Founder and Chairman Myra Biblowit, President Jeanette Wagner, Vice President Deborah Krulewitch, Secretary Treasurer Larry Norton, M.D., Scientific Director

KRISTIN SOMERS was sitting in her 10th-grade English class at Hackettstown High last year when a call came over the intercom telling her to report to the office. Immediately. An honors student with a 3.8 average here in northwestern New Jersey, she wasn't being summoned to discuss her academic performance. And while she participates in an array of after-school organizations -- from soccer and softball to the National Honor Society and Key Club -- the issue wasn't her extracurricular activities or future plans.

RODMAN--Marilyn, of Rye Brook, NY, wife of the late Harold, mother of Jesse, Daniel and Ellen Farina, nana of eight, grandnana of four, sister of Joan Serling. Marilyn's life was devoted to her family and her lifetime love of women's fashion, which included her stores in Mamaroneck and Rye Brook. Visitation Saturday, 7-9pm, services Sunday, 11am, Ballard-Durand, White Plains, NY.

Judith Verdino and Imani Romney-Rosa are to affirm their partnership this afternoon at the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn. Barbara J. Turk, a friend of the couple who is a student at the Union Theological Seminary, is to perform the commitment ceremony. Ms. Verdino (above, left) is 51. She is the vice president for special initiatives and H.I.V. programs at the Medical and Health Research Association of New York City, a nonprofit organization that operates a variety of public health programs around the city. She graduated from Purchase College of the State University of New York and received a master's degree in public administration from New York University.

To the Sports Editor: The melee after last Sunday's high school basketball tournament has led Madison Square Garden to reconsider playing host to the games in the future. More than a score of students were arrested during their rampage, which extended uptown to subway platforms at Times Square.
A woman should always come prepared.

TRIEBWASSER--Charles, February 25th, 1930 to March 24, 1987. We love you, Chuck. From his family and many friends

URBAN INN: CASA DE MADRID Arrieta, 2-2; 011-34-91-559-5791; www.casademadrid.com; doubles from about $341. PROS: The owner-decorator Marta Medina has filled seven rooms with antique furniture, sculptures and paintings she collected during her travels. CONS: No big-hotel amenities like a spa or gym. PERKS: Frescoes and friezes cover the walls. Medina often mingles with guests in the evening over a glass of Rioja.

KRISTIN SOMERS was sitting in her 10th-grade English class at Hackettstown High last year when a call came over the intercom telling her to report to the office. Immediately. An honors student with a 3.8 average here in northwestern New Jersey, she wasn't being summoned to discuss her academic performance. And while she participates in an array of after-school organizations -- from soccer and softball to the National Honor Society and Key Club -- the issue wasn't her extracurricular activities or future plans.
DuBOIS--Barbara C., 102, in Farmington, CT. She is survived by two daughters and four grandchildren.

The ready-to-wear world apparently cannot get enough of Juicy Couture. After embellishing oneself from top to toe with the company's signature velour and terry cloth and other not-terribly-subtle clothing and accessories, one must now also be fruitful. (And multiply!) This month, the company introduced Juicy Couture Baby, another recklessly cute variation on the theme. Tiny track suits, terry hoodies and, best of all, cotton kurta sets (at right) come in those same bubble-gum flavors and on-the-fence prices: just expensive enough to make you wince slightly ($48 for a onesie?) but not too dear to keep you from buying rafts of the items anyway ($48 to $118 at Bloomingdale's stores).

To the Editor: Re ''The Medicaid Documentation Mess'' (editorial, March 19): You describe vividly our government's ploy to deprive needy Americans of survival resources. But these paperwork barriers to health care for newborn American citizens are just one example of a broad campaign to use bureaucratic means to deny poor Americans the support that is rightfully theirs.

PUTTERMAN--Harold, of Lake Worth, FL, passed away March 19, 2007. Devoted father of Karen (and Enrique) Campos, Lanee (and John) Phillips; beloved grandfather of Carmel, Sarah, Michael, Daniel, and Rachel; loving brother Frieda, Marsha, Sarah, and Sol, and the late Anna, Tillie, and Sam; husband of the late Lenore. Survived by many nieces and nephews who adored him, and loving companion Marilyn Drucker. He cared deeply for his family and was always there to help those he loved. Funeral was March 22 in New York. Donations to the charity of your choice.

To the Editor: Fred I. Greenstein, the presidential historian at Princeton University, says Ronald Reagan was an above-average president (''Nowadays, a Candidate Can Seem Too Experienced,'' Week in Review, March 18). I disagree. After the nearly scandal-free Carter administration, the Reagan administration scandals involved top officials and harmed the country.

The side effect of Chien-Ming Wang's hamstring injury, which will land him on the disabled list to start the season, is an idea so preposterous it seems hard to fathom: Carl Pavano could be the Yankees' opening day starter April 2. Manager Joe Torre said Saturday that Andy Pettitte and Mike Mussina would not be lined up properly to make the start against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays at Yankee Stadium. That leaves Kei Igawa, who has never pitched in the majors, and Pavano, who essentially would be pitching on 643 days' rest.
The 3 a.m. text messages that Ohio State Coach Thad Matta receives do not surprise him anymore. But the person sending him the messages does: the Buckeyes' football coach, Jim Tressel.
Madrid's master craftsmen still whip up staples of Spanish style as they have for generations. And now a few modern designers are giving tradition a tweak.

An article last Sunday about the ways knowledge of an artist's background can affect listener perceptions misstated the academic affiliation of Denis Dutton, who has written on the topic. He teaches at the University of Canterbury, not Cambridge.

DANE--Goody. We are deeply saddened at the passing of the loving, darling mother of our sister-in-law Gail Propp. Mort and Enia Propp and family $(6$)DANE--Goody. We mourn the loss of an elegant and regal Eishet Chayil. A Silver Founder together with her late husband Oscar, Goody was known for her loyalty and courage. She personified and passed on a commitment to family to daughters Sharon Dane, Wilma Kule, and Gail Propp, Women's Division Board member and the late Marsha Stern. Our sincere condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Emeritus Lee Weinbach, President Women's Division
To the Editor: In ''Power to the People'' (Op-Ed, March 11), Phillip F. Schewe suggests that Con Edison should offer real-time pricing for electric use. In fact, Con Edison already does this.

They call it the marcha madrileña -- the city's collective crusade to dance until dawn. As soon as the cocktail bars quiet down, stylish nightclubs all over town overflow with chic Spaniards. Five top spots to get you in the groove:

As anyone holding his riddled N.C.A.A. tournament bracket will groan, records of college basketball teams -- 29-5 here, 18-10 there -- are often not what they seem. The collective strength of a team's opponents over a season plays a crucial role in a team's tournament future, by most estimates ranking only behind school colors and Menacing Mascot Index. Baseball, whose season dawns next weekend, as college basketball's sets, rarely hears the term ''strength of schedule'' because its 162 games are trusted to smooth out peaks and valleys. Yet thanks mostly to the increasing complexities of interleague play, some teams can see the 2007 playoff horizon more clearly than others.

AS grime obscures my domain, I see through the window glass darkly. Spring is not really a time of optimistic budding, of vernal renewal. It is the season of grunge. The first bright shafts of light illuminate too much; sunshine exposes streaks, all manner of winter muck. Sitting in the kitchen of my house, I feel the call to battle against dirt. A primitive pride wells up within me, perhaps as the sap rises in the tired bare maples outside my window. I will clean house! I head for the caustic chemicals with a wild glee.
For cool comfort on the go.

For decades it seems as if travel guides have stuck to the same old formula. But some new arrivals are out to reinvent the genre. In Taschen's Hotels and More series ($25; www.taschen.com), Angelika Taschen presents her edited version of top city sites (for Paris and London, with Berlin on the way), organized around favorite hotels and lushly illustrated with photography. Taking word of mouth to its logical conclusion is the photographer Ami Sioux. For her new Degree Books series, from Scintilla (about $33; www.scintillalimited.com), she asked locals to draw maps to their favorite places, and then paired each with a photo she took once there. So far she's covered Reykjavik, Iceland (right); Berlin, London, Paris and New York are promised soon. And Moleskine has entered the postmodern era, where the emphasis is on you: part journal, part guidebook, its new City Notebooks ($16.95; www.moleskine.com) let you write your own itinerary, aided by maps, pull-off tabs and room to scribble. Editions for 12 European cities are out, with eight for North America due in spring and fall. Aric Chen

The $492 million budget for the Brookhaven National Laboratory that was announced last week was better than had been expected earlier this year, the lab's director, Samuel Aronson said, even though it included no increase over last year. ''We were in jeopardy of losing some of our programs,'' Dr. Aronson said. ''After preparing for stagnation and layoffs, the amount we will be getting is quite good.''

In the most wide-open presidential election season since 1928, a mating ritual is under way that will determine which candidate raises enough money to get his or her party’s nomination–and which Wall Street backers have the most influence on policies affecting the economy, regulation, and global markets, BusinessWeek says.

With former Senator Fred Thompson pondering a bid for the Republican presidential nomination, the hunt is on to see if he has his conservative credentials in order or whether there might be some moderation lurking in his voting past.

Patrick has done his usual excellent job of outlining the importance of the discovery of life on Mars (or elsewhere in the solar system - Jupiter's moon Europa looks like an interesting outside bet), but it won't be long before we're able to look far beyond our own neighborhood. A month or two ago, the Spitzer Space Telescope obtained the first spectra of the atmospheres of extrasolar planets. These results were for large planets close to their parent stars, and relied on the planets happening to pass behind the star, but nonetheless a start has been made.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won't know until the night of the Iowa caucuses whether the backing of Tom and Christie Vilsack, the state's former governor and first lady, who formally announced today that they were endorsing her, will pay off. But Mr. Vilsack could reap benefits sooner.

In Tuesday's column I write about how ordinary people can use www.kiva.org to make loans to people in poor countries. There's also a video featuring Abdul Sattar and Storai Sadat. I welcome your comments below on that column -- or on other effective ways to donate to fight poverty.

The Bush administration has made a strategic mistake, I believe, in identifying itself so closely with Pervez Musharraf and in being so reluctant to criticize his dictatorial moves. I happened to run into an old friend, Asma Jahangir, who is a prominent Pakistani lawyer and a U.N. Rapporteur on human rights.

Pakistan often boasts of its free press, and it's true that President Musharraf has allowed a reasonably vigorous press and even tolerated criticisms of him. But at the same time he has "disappeared" occasional journalists, and I just heard today that a Pakistani who was finally released from Guantanamo wrote a book in Pashto about his experience -- and as it was about to be translated into English, Pakistan "disappeared" him again, a few months ago.

News about a merger in the world of immunoassays -- that is, blood tests -- has sent shares in one biotech company soaring and stock in another plummeting. Beckman Coulter said Sunday that it will buy Biosite, a maker of several blood tests, for $1.55 billion in cash, or $85 a share.
