Thanks to the seeming impasse between Gov. Eliot Spitzer the legislative leaders over Mr. Spitzer's proposed budget cuts, there's talk of a government shutdown in the air. We caught up with the Speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon H. Silver, in the halls of the Capitol this morning, and he commented briefly on the idea.

Today is my birthday, which I've always been proud to share with Phillies broadcaster Harry Kalas. The Yanks are playing the Phils today, but I didn't see Harry. Maybe he gets his birthday off. It's also the birthday of Jean Afterman, the Yankees' assistant general manager. Every year we wish each other happy birthday, and every year she's 29.
Appearing at today's family-planning confab in Albany, Gov. Eliot Spitzer took a light jab at Senator Craig Johnson, the newly elected Long Island Democrat.

For a stock analyst, writing a thoughtful, complete research note can be difficult when news changes by the minute. For instance, on Monday Merrill Lynch's Guy Moszkowski released a note examining the possibility that Citigroup might step into the negotiations between Barclays and ABN Amro.
Readers are always asking Nicholas D. Kristof how they can help. He found an inventive way via the Web.

Even with their record bonuses last year, Wall Streeters may have reasons to envy their counterparts in the Old Country. Bloomberg News reports that traders in London are making as much as 50 percent more in compensation than traders in New York, according to a study by Napier Scott Executive Search (a firm which just happens to be based in London). The report comes as New York is engaged some deep soul-searching about whether it is losing its edge to London as a venue for initial public offerings, hedge funds and other badges of status in the financial-services industry.

The Bloomberg administration hired an Albany law firm to prepare a 247-page report about the Queens blackout last July, along with 35 pages of comments, but failed to supply the City Council or members of the public with a copy until this morning, outraged City Council members said this morning.

Rehabilitation chain HealthSouth said Monday it has agreed to sell its surgery division to the Texas Pacific Group for about $920 million in cash plus a stake in the surgery business. The sale marks the second divestiture for HealthSouth this year as it restructures following a major financial scandal.
Brazil and Barcelona star Ronaldinho talked to The New York Times at his home in Castelldefels, Spain.
Today Maria Aspan has the boffo back story of the Lily Tomlin/David O. Russell brushfires on the set of "I Heart Huckabees," which were filmed for our instruction and entertainment.
The so-called sky islands of southern Arizona, formerly green havens above the desert, have experienced near collapse.
Carl Icahn must be smiling.

File this as intriguing but highly tenuous: Wal-Mart's British division, Asda, is trying to determine whether a bid for J Sainsbury would violate antitrust rules, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources. So far, Asda has not yet asked Britain's Competition Authority about its available options, ranging from a bid for the whole company to picking up pieces that a private equity buyer would spin off.

The consensus from reading a few newspapers at the airport this morning is that this is going to be a powerhouse Final Four. A few folks, like Drew Sharp of the Detroit Free Press, are disappointed by the lack of upsets. Others, like ESPN.com's Pat Forde, are looking forward to some heavyweights clashing in Atlanta.

Not surprisingly, the advertising barrage against Gov. Eliot Spitzer's health care cuts has produced a cut in Mr. Spitzer's favorability ratings. According to the new Siena poll, 62 percent of voters have a favorable view of the governor, down from 74 percent in February. That's a big change, but it still leaves him pretty popular. Time will tell what this investment of political capital returns.

J.P. Morgan Chase's asset-management group named Jonathan Ingram to lead the European higher alpha team. Mr. Ingram, who has worked at the securities firm since 2000, was previously a client portfolio manager in the asset-management division's currency group, Reuters reported.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber has agreed to sell almost all of its Engineered Products business, which makes hoses and conveyor belts, to a unit of the Carlyle Group for $1.475 billion, the tire maker said. Carlyle will make the acquisition through a portfolio company, EPD.

Is Barack Obama the new Eugene McCarthy? Or the new Gary Hart? Or the new Paul Tsongas? Or the new Bill Bradley? Or the new Howard Dean? Maybe, to all of those questions, says Ronald Brownstein from his new perch as a columnist on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. "Obama's early support is following a pattern familiar from the campaigns of other brainy liberals with cool, detached personas and messages of political reform, from Eugene McCarthy in 1968 to Gary Hart in 1984 to Bill Bradley in 2000," Brownstein writes. "Like those predecessors, Obama is running strong with well-educated voters but demonstrating much less support among those without college degrees." He continues:

This week marks the final days for campaign fundraising toward the presidential contenders' first round of quarterly reports. While some top-tier candidates have exceeded expectations, others are acknowleding their fundraising got off to a slower start. Still others are playing that low expectations game. The tallies are due for release April 15.
Budget talks might be stalled, but Gov. Eliot Spitzer appears to have worked out his biggest difference with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
A clip from the Teletubbies.

Guy Hands, a longtime British dealmaker, may wade into the battle for Alliance Boots, the Telegraph reported Monday citing unnamed sources. But he may have a tough time going up against a rival offer from the pharmacy chain's deputy chairman and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

Texas Pacific Group is considering making an offer to buy Iberia Airlines, Reuters reported Monday, citing people familiar with the matter. British Airways is also said to be interested the Spanish carrier, according to The Independent.

Citigroup, under pressure from its shareholders, is planning to shed thousands of jobs and sharpen its focus on its operations outside North America. Citigroup will announce a broad restructuring plan that could involve the elimination or relocation of as many as 15,000 high-cost jobs from areas including New York, London and Hong Kong, The New York Times reported, citing several executives briefed on the matter.

Enel, Italy's biggest utility, and Acciona said they will offer at least 41 euros ($54.37) a share for the stock they don't already own of Spanish power company Endesa, trumping a rival bid by E.On. The offer depends on E.On receiving less than 50 percent of Endesa in its tender, Acciona said in a statement Monday. The bid by Enel and Acciona, which together control 46 percent of Endesa, values all of Spain's largest power utility at a minimum of 43.4 billion euros.

The auction for a prized swath of spectrum that could reshape the debate over who controls access to the networks that deliver digital content to consumers is about to go into high gear. Among those maneuvering ahead of the auction for the spectrum, which could be used for voice services for cellular carriers, new frequencies for emergency responders, or a commercial high-speed broadband multimedia network, are the nation's four largest cellular providers, rural and regional wireless carriers, cable and satellite television companies and a range of technology companies - including Google and Yahoo.
It will be Senate Democrats (and a few Republicans) versus the Bush administration on two fronts this week.
Laura Osnes and Max Crumm were named the winners of ”Grease: You’re the One That I Want,” the Broadway casting reality show.

A federal judge in New York has ruled that French, British, and Dutch citizens who bought Vivendi shares before the French media and telecom group neared bankruptcy in 2002 are allowed to join a U.S. class action against the company that was initiated by Vivendi shareholders.
Jon Morgan, currently the executive producer at the Contact Theater in Manchester, England, is the new director of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

In a reversal, Morgan Stanley is in the process of holding an auction for $2.48 billion in mortgages from subprime lender New Century, The New York Post reported Monday. The loans represent the collateral given to Morgan for a $2.5 billion credit line the firm extended to New Century, which currently finds itself in a precarious financial and legal situation.

Although final bids are not due until April, the auction for Royal Ahold's U.S. Foodservice, a business worth an estimated $5.5 billion, is heating up. According to The Deal.com, buyout shops are jockeying for position, and food service heavyweight Sysco could team up with one to buy the target.

The Supreme Court will hear a case Tuesday that could affect the way banks cooperate with rivals and create syndicates to share the risks and rewards of initial public offerings. Eight of the nine justices will hear the oral argument in Glen Billing v. Credit Suisse First Boston, a class action that asks what role, if any, antitrust law should play in the regulation of the securities industry, and specifically in policing I.P.O.'s.

George Wimpey and Taylor Woodrow are merging to create Britain's largest housebuilder, a move that will lead to up to 700 job losses. The deal, announced this morning, will create a new company called Taylor Wimpey. It will have annual revenues of 6.7 billion pounds ($13.1 billion), and an estimated market capitalization of 5 billion pounds ($9.8 billion).

The investment arm of the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan of Canada has bought Telecom New Zealand's yellow pages directories business for about C$1.85 billion ($1.59 billion), the telecom provider said Monday. Private equity consortium of CCMP Capital and Teachers' Private Capital, the investment arm of the O.T.P.P., has bought the yellow and white pages directories, both print and online.

Swiss-based Xstrata appears to have succeeded in gobbling up another piece of Canada's mining industry with a friendly bid worth C$4.6 billion ($4.0 billion) for LionOre Mining International. The all-cash offer of C$18.50 per share was unanimously approved by LionOre's board of directors, both companies announced Monday.

As takeover rumors swirl around Palm, the maker of the Treo smartphone, technology analysis firm The 451 Group assesses the fit -- or lack thereof -- for a half-dozen potential acquirers, including Dell and Hewlett-Packard. The report calls a deal with Research in Motion, which makes the Blackberry handheld device, a "very intriguing possibility." Such a combination could allow Research in Motion to build a line of Windows devices that are still true BlackBerrys with relatively little effort, The 451 Group writes.

Much of the attention that venture capitalist John Doerr has drawn in recent months has focused on his environmental advocacy and investment in "green" technologies. But, says The San Jose Mercury News, thanks to his investment in search engine powerhouse Google, Mr. Doerr in recent months has been quietly amassing the kind of green that Silicon Valley traditionally favors.

Buyout firm Hellman & Friedman has agreed to buy labor management software company Kronos for $1.8 billion, Kronos said Friday. The Deal.com notes that Kronos was the fifth company to agree to be taken private by a buyout shop last week, adding that the five deals were worth a combined $12.9 billion.

Royal Bank of Scotland named the former Citigroup executive Ellen Alemany as chief executive of its RBS America unit on Friday as part of a management revamp to bring its United States businesses closer together.

The Internet start-up Livedoor was ordered to pay a $2.4 million fine Friday - the largest in Japanese corporate history - for violating securities laws. The fine is the latest blow in a scandal that has led to convictions of seven former executives and accountants. The Tokyo District Court ordered Livedoor to pay the fine - 280 million yen - and its subsidiary Livedoor Marketing to pay $338,000, a court official said on the customary condition of anonymity.

Blackstone Group's recent decision to form a charitable foundation is an important step -- though maybe just a baby step -- toward burnishing the image of an industry that has come under attack in Europe, and increasingly in the United States, as being overpaid and out of touch, DealBook wrote in Sunday's New York Times.

BP said on Friday that it planned to bid against the state-owned oil giant Rosneft in a bankruptcy auction for assets of the Yukos oil company, a surprise announcement that signaled BP's deepening involvement in Russia's turbulent energy sector.

Switzerland is known for its banks, some of them now global giants like UBS and Credit Suisse. But it is the smaller, more discreet banks that are changing the most these days, says The New York Times.

In the merger talks between Barclays, the British bank, and ABN Amro, a Dutch rival, hedge fund The Children's Investment Fund is the proverbial the grease for the wheel. Its activism in several deals, including the scuppered merger between the Deutsche Borse and the London Stock Exchange, has garnered the fund a lot of attention recently.
The "shock jock" Howard Stern has been very important to the success of Sirius Satellite Radio. Subscriptions surged after he agreed to bring his raucous show to the service.

Beckman Coulter, a maker and distributor of biomedical testing and laboratory products, agreed Sunday to acquire Biosite, a smaller maker of diagnostic blood tests, for about $1.55 billion in cash. The combination would bolster Beckman Coulter's offerings for blood tests, including those for heart failure, certain diseases and the presence of drugs.

Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners, the buyout shops behind the Mays family's bid to take Clear Channel Communications private, have been trash talking a Bears Stearns analyst who has pegged their $18.7 billion bid as too low, The New York Post reported.

The Internet age was supposed to mean that concentration of the media in just a few hands is yesterday's news because the barriers to entry in the online world are so low. But judging from the banter on a conference call for reporters last week by the News Corporation and NBC Universal, corporate control of the news media is still going strong. The companies were announcing a new joint venture for Internet video.

Porsche's decision this weekend to raise its stake in Volkswagen, along with DaimlerChrysler's recent decision to find suitors for Chrysler, reflect European automakers' desire to control their own fates, rather than see them decided by less friendly acquirers, The New York Times says.
A new crop of books, both fiction and nonfiction, are coming out that aim to capture, if not update, Wall Street's rich mix of greed, striving, intrigue and vanity.

The Tribune Company, it seems, is again warming up to the offer tabled by real estate mogul Samuel Zell. After reports surfaced last week that the Tribune Co. had cooled to the Mr. Zell's proposal, The New York Times says that the mercury is rising.
A group of right-wing activists is temporarily reoccupying a destroyed Jewish settlement in the West Bank in the hopes of signaling an official return.

Q) So what kind of house do you have?A) I bought a house in Punta del Estate that's three blocks from the beach for $160,000. I also have a two-bedroom apartment in Montevideo for which I paid $58,000. If you come to Uruguay as a resident, you are entitled to duty-free importation of your household effects. I'm also told that I'll be eligible for participation in the national healthcare system, but I have yet to prove that personally.
It was natural, perhaps even inevitable, that Elton John would celebrate his 60th birthday at Madison Square Garden.
Ben Weir, a former PGA Tour professional, tests new drivers with heads designed to resist twisting.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
The agreement for the release of $25 million from a Macao bank has been rejected by the largest account holder.
The report showed that the museum had provided lavish perks such as chauffeurs and private jets to its top official.
A Pentagon report concluded that investigations into Cpl. Pat Tillman’s shooting were initially mishandled.
Many heart patients routinely implanted with stents to open arteries gain no lasting benefit compared to those treated with drugs alone, researchers said.
Officials plan to introduce modifications to a law that restricts former Baathists  from holding government jobs.
Monica Goodling, an aide to  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, is refusing to  testify about the removal of eight U.S. attorneys.
An Israeli journalist traveling with U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon had been unable to obtain to obtain a visa to accompany him to Saudi Arabia on Tuesday.
A homeowner drew nationwide attention by staring down the forces of redevelopment that are sweeping China.
Indonesia refused to share its H5N1 bird flu samples with the organization’s researchers unless their country is guaranteed affordable access to vaccines.
The death of the centerfold and actress was evidently a result of the effects of a combination of drugs, officials said.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe offered so-called comfort women an apology, but refused to confirm a state role.
Sinn Fein’s Gerry Adams and the Protestant leader Rev. Ian Paisley held face-to-face negotiations.
The country’s deepening ethnic conflict took a perilous turn with the first air strike by the rebel Tamil Tigers.
Under pressure from shareholders, the bank intends to sharpen its focus on operations outside North America.
Jason Ray, the North Carolina student who suits up as the basketball team’s mascot, remained in critical condition after being hit by a car.
Elizabeth Edward’s health has sparked debate over whether her husband should continue to pursue his political ambitions.

Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he favored an overhaul of federal mortgage regulations, citing widespread concern about the surge in defaults and foreclosures involving subprime mortgages, risky home loans made to people with weak credit. Citing data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Census Bureau, Mr. Schumer said that about 91,000 households in New York State, including 53,000 in the New York City metropolitan area, were at risk of foreclosure by the end of 2008, as interest rates on adjustable-rate mortgages are reset. At a hearing on Thursday, members of the Senate Banking Committee criticized the Federal Reserve for failing to curb mortgage lending abuses. The chairman, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, said that new legislation might not be needed and that excesses could be addressed under existing regulations.

An article yesterday about deliberations over the dismissal of eight United States attorneys misquoted President Bush in some editions. Speaking in his weekly radio address about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales’s role in removing the attorneys, Mr. Bush said “I strongly support the attorney general in this decision,” not “in his decision.”.

A picture caption on Wednesday about an opening ceremony for a stable on Pier 76 in Manhattan misidentified the treat that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was feeding to a horse. It was a carrot, not sugar.

An article on Friday about new calculations by the Army that show a higher number of desertions than it previously reported misspelled the given name of an Army spokesman who said data errors were caused by confusion among employees who tally them. He is Lt. Col. Bryan C. Hilferty, not Brian.

A theater review last Monday about “Di Yam Gazlonim!,” a Yiddish version of “The Pirates of Penzance” that has returned to the JCC in Manhattan, misstated the year in which the operetta is set. While the libretto does not specify a time, elements of the plot point to either 1873 or 1877 — not to 1897. (The error first appeared in a Nov. 8 review of the opening of the production at the JCC. The review last Monday was a shorter version of the original review.).
Corrections

An article in some copies yesterday about Congressional criticism of the Justice Department inaccurately summarized a March 15 report in the National Journal about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and the National Security Agency’s program to eavesdrop domestically without court warrants. The National Journal report asserted that Mr. Gonzales continued to advise President Bush on a proposed internal Justice Department review of the N.S.A. program after learning that his own conduct would be scrutinized. The National Journal report did not explicitly allege that Mr. Gonzales tried to block the investigation.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a fund-raiser for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign held at SoulCycle, a spinning studio in Manhattan, misidentified the studio’s neighborhood in some copies. It is on the Upper West Side, not the Upper East Side.

A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about broad spying by the New York City police on people expected to protest in the city during the 2004 Republican National Convention referred incorrectly in some copies to the disposition of the property of one protester, Joshua Kinberg, who devised a bicycle equipped with cellphone, laptop and tubes that could spray the ground with messages in chalk. The spraying apparatus — not the bicycle — was held for more than a year before being returned; Mr. Kinberg says the authorities have still not returned his bicycle.

An article on Thursday about a Web site that posts pictures showing vehicles with government-issued parking permits that appear to be parked illegally in New York City included a quotation in which a police spokesman misidentified the police precinct that covers Chinatown, where 12 such vehicles were towed recently. It is the Fifth Precinct, not the First.

The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about “Too Far From Home: A Story of Life and Death in Space,” by Chris Jones, misidentified the space shuttle that broke apart on Feb. 1, 2003, in one of two references in the opening paragraph. It was the Columbia, not the Challenger. (The Challenger exploded in January 1986.).
Once North Carolina did not have to worry about Whitney Allen, the Tar Heels had no trouble with the rest of George Washington.
tennis.
With few big upsets, this year will be the first Final Four since 1993 with only No. 1 and  No. 2 seeds.
Lottery Numbers.
After defeating North Carolina, the Hoyas will face Ohio State while Florida will take on U.C.L.A. in the Final Four.
Many long-term-care policyholders say that years of premiums have resulted in only excuses about why insurers will not pay.
At the end of a round that began like an exhibition and ended with a scare, Tiger Woods secured his third consecutive CA Championship.
Joakim Noah and the Florida Gators will return to the N.C.A.A. Tournament semifinals to seek a second consecutive championship.
Luc Richard Mbah a Moute is getting ready to play in front of his father, the chief of his home village in Cameroon, for the first time in his life.
Spurred by grim test results, districts are moving to longer days, but many teachers and parents are critical.
Even while Georgetown was chipping away at North Carolina’s once-imposing lead, no one wearing Tar Heels blue seemed too concerned.
The war in Iraq has become the key to the political future of many Republicans seeking re-election next year.
Lawyers said the release of documents could hurt New York’s ability to defend itself in lawsuits over mass arrests.
New York’s highly lucrative thoroughbred horse racing franchise has attracted a frenzy of interest from major gambling and horse racing companies.
The departing senior envoy in Iraq held talks with men he believed represented major insurgent groups in a drive to bring militant Sunni Arabs into politics.
Guillermo Mota is expected to take part in his first workout with the Mets on Monday, showing up right as his teammates are preparing to leave.
Fifth-year senior Ron Lewis has led the Buckeyes in scoring the past three games with at least 22 points in each.
If Hamas wants American aid restored, it must meet the three conditions on ending terrorism, recognizing Israel and accepting past agreements.
After a victory in Bristol, Kyle Busch said it was frustrating to drive the car Nascar has designed to be cheaper, safer and better for competition.
No drastic change is expected in the Democrats’ slim 22-to-18 majority, but there is bound to be a change in the way the Senate goes about its business.
Many Palestinians are now saying the right to return to the homes they left in 1948 is becoming less feasible.
Wolfgang Puck, the universal restaurateur, has decided that his culinary businesses will now use products only from animals raised under strict humane standards.
Far more than in Shiite areas, sectarian hatred has shredded what remained of community life and created a cycle of violence in Sunni neighborhoods of Baghdad.
The Senate clings to its slo-mo evasion of the campaign finance law’s prompt disclosure duties by burying information for weeks upon weeks in the paperwork era.
A man fell to his death from the 19th-floor terrace of a Brooklyn apartment, apparently in an attempt to evade officers who were about to enter the front door.
An unusual auction of  “natural history” items at the I. M. Chait gallery featured  fossils, meteorites and a mummified hand.
There is little room for moral victories in the postseason, but the 13th-seeded Marist Red Foxes may have found one.

A dispute has been raging between elderly Holocaust victims and Burt Neuborne, a lawyer who helped win a $1.25 billion settlement from Swiss banks, over the size of the fees Mr. Neuborne has requested.
Racked by injuries, the Knicks prepared for the most important stretch of their season Sunday without two more regulars.
After one season as the lead analyst for “Monday Night Football” on ESPN, Joe Theismann will be replaced by Ron Jaworski.
In retaliation for U.N. sanctions, Iran announced that it would limit cooperation with the organization’s nuclear oversight agency.
A sexual abuse scandal at the Texas Youth Commission has prompted more than 1,100 investigations into new accusations of rape and other mistreatment.
Roadside bombs killed five U.S. soldiers including four in a single strike in the volatile province of Diyala.
Perhaps no one outside the Rutgers locker room believed the Scarlet Knights would knock out top-seeded Duke.
The secretary of state prodded the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to agree, at least, to negotiating objectives.
The four gold medals awarded Sunday, the opening night at the world championships in Melbourne, went to four different continents.
The government disputed a report of leaked C.I.A. intelligence linking the chief of the army to paramilitary death squads.
The system, which faces a financial deficit despite rising ridership, is a lifeline for many commuters who are not served by or cannot afford the train.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,227 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
The effusive Brazilian-born star, now a Spanish citizen, inhabits a world of high demands and endless commercial opportunities.
New York won its fifth straight victory and moved past idle Tampa Bay into sixth place in the crowded Eastern Conference playoff chase.
A dispute over the proper role of military defense lawyers is intensifying as military commissions reopen at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
To balance the state budget, the governor’s office has proposed closing what it says are loopholes that corporations have used to reduce their tax bills.
Issues of politics were overshadowed by more basic concerns, like lack of jobs, inadequate housing and the price of food.
Tamil Tiger rebels bombed an air force base next to Sri Lanka’s international airport, killing two airmen and wounding 17.
T-shirts of a Mormon angel with coffee flowing into his trumpet have upset the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

The State Ethics Commission says it does not have the authority to review an ethics complaint against Gov. Jon S. Corzine, the mayor of Bogota said yesterday, but he plans to refile his complaint today with another agency. The mayor, Steven Lonegan, a Republican, said that he would submit the complaint to the Advisory Ethics Panel, a two-member state board that makes determinations on the governor’s conduct. The complaint contends that Mr. Corzine’s gifts to Carla Katz, his former companion and a state labor leader, including a $470,000 loan that he eventually forgave, create an appearance of a conflict of interest. Mr. Corzine and Ms. Katz, president of Communications Workers of America Local 1034, which represents state workers, dated from 2002 until the summer of 2004. At the time, Mr. Corzine was a United States senator.

City health officials should change their method for evaluating restaurants and issue a letter grade from A to F, State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein said yesterday. Mr. Klein, a Bronx Democrat, said he would introduce legislation requiring restaurants to prominently post the letter grade. “No restaurant is going to want an F in their doorway,” he said yesterday. Andrew Tucker, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, said that the agency would review the senator’s proposal, but that the current scoring system allowed the agency to provide more detail about violations than a lettered grading system would.

A pair of bills introduced in the State Senate and Assembly would provide an estimated 1.1 million New York City households with an annual $300 rent credit on their city personal income taxes. The city would absorb the cost, $261 million a year. The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, proposed the credit on Feb. 15, but it requires the approval of state lawmakers. Flanked by tenant advocates and politicians at a City Hall news conference yesterday, Ms. Quinn said that two-thirds of city residents were renters and that they deserved relief similar to the $400 rebate on property taxes that city homeowners have received each year since 2004. Individual renters with incomes of less than $43,000 and families with incomes of up to $75,000 would be eligible for the credit. Where roommates split the rent, the credit would be evenly divided among them unless they agreed on a different arrangement. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has not said whether he supports the proposal.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell will submit a proposal to the state legislature pushing back the date on which utilities can shut off service for unpaid bills by more than a month to May 31, administration officials said yesterday. Current law allows utility companies to suspend service on April 15 for customers who have not paid their energy bills. Mitch Gross, a spokesman for Connecticut Light & Power, said the company would like to review the legislation but would abide by any changes. He said the company disconnects service only as a last recourse.

Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he favored an overhaul of federal mortgage regulations, citing widespread concern about the surge in defaults and foreclosures involving subprime mortgages, risky home loans made to people with weak credit. Citing data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Census Bureau, Mr. Schumer said that about 91,000 households in New York State, including 53,000 in the New York City metropolitan area, were at risk of foreclosure by the end of 2008, as interest rates on adjustable-rate mortgages are reset. At a hearing on Thursday, members of the Senate Banking Committee criticized the Federal Reserve for failing to curb mortgage lending abuses. The chairman, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, said that new legislation might not be needed and that excesses could be addressed under existing regulations.

An illegal immigrant trying to cross into the United States was rescued on Saturday morning from an ice floe less than a mile upstream from Niagara Falls, the authorities said yesterday. Guards at the Ontario Power Generation company’s water intakes on the Canadian side of the falls heard the man screaming for help about 4:30 a.m., company officials told The Buffalo News. The 42-year-old man, who was not identified by the authorities, was plucked from an ice floe by rescuers in boats. The authorities said the man was trapped when the section of ice he was on broke loose.
Top-seeded UConn will face Louisiana State Monday night, giving the Huskies a chance to return to the Final Four for the first time in three seasons.

A PATH train bound for the 33rd Street station in Manhattan derailed at 2:55 p.m. yesterday after leaving Hoboken, stranding about 300 passengers for roughly two hours, the authorities said. Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which manages the PATH system, said there were no injuries. After another PATH train was dispatched alongside the derailed train, he said, the passengers were transferred and taken to Hoboken, where they arrived at 4:15 p.m. He said one set of wheels on one of the train’s middle cars had left the tracks, for reasons that remained unclear. Direct service from Hoboken to Manhattan had not resumed late yesterday, and Mr. DiFulco said it was unclear whether it would be restored for commuters this morning. But he said PATH riders could travel from Hoboken to the Pavonia station in Jersey City and then to 33rd Street in Manhattan.

A Brooklyn teenager arrested last summer after a fatal water scooter accident in Mill Basin inlet has been indicted on charges of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, according to prosecutors. The teenager, Aristotle Plagianakos, 17, of Mill Basin, was charged in connection with a June 30 crash involving his water scooter and one driven by Paul Zaccaria, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes announced on Friday. Mr. Zaccaria, 17, also of Mill Basin, was killed; his body was not recovered until 37 days after the collision, prosecutors said.
Budget negotiations continued to stall over the weekend, raising the specter of the first late budget in three years.
American universities, eager to expand to markets abroad, are training their sights on India.
Jeff Karstens left his start against the Tigers with elbow stiffness, joining Chien-Ming Wang and Andy Pettitte on the list of ailing Yankee pitchers.
Kobe Bryant’s 50-point streak is over. But the Los Angeles Lakers’ season-high five-game winning streak goes on.
A temporary contract extension could ward off a threatened strike at the nation’s largest four-year public university system.
The city is confronting the possibility that its century-old elevated train system, the El, may be at a breaking point.
As inspector general for the Justice Department, Glenn A. Fine must confront agency colleagues with the excruciating details of how they have failed.
The Russian government has employed quiet but effective subterfuge to undermine even meager attempts at mobilizing dissent in the country.
The police investigation was complicated by the fact that many potential witnesses had already left Jamaica.
Ms. Seipp was widely known for poking fun at the liberal leanings popularly associated with Los Angeles.
Festivities were shadowed by a sense that the European Union has a divided present and an uncertain path ahead.
Jay Zeamer Jr. was awarded the Medal of Honor for fighting off enemy attacks during World War II.
John T. Gilbride was the former head of Todd Shipyards Corporation, once the largest independent shipbuilding company in the country.
Keeping a preschooler in day care increased the likelihood that the child would become disruptive, a study found.
The arrests were an attempt to thwart nationwide protests to denounce Gen. Pervez Musharraf’s suspension of the chief justice.
The arrests of three men of Pakistani descent in Beeston reinforced the homegrown nature of the country’s terrorism threat and left a host of questions unanswered.
Vilma Ebsen danced in the film “Broadway Melody of 1936” with her brother Buddy long before he became famous on “The Beverly Hillbillies.”
At 32, Representative Adam H. Putnam of Florida has become the unlikely mouthpiece for the beleaguered minority in the House.
Freddie Francis was a versatile British cinematographer whose talent for creating atmosphere won him two Oscars.
Comments by three Republican senators indicated waning support for the attorney general where he needs it most.

Results showed that Johnson & Johnson’s controversial heart drug, Natrecor, did not work in the population studied.

“The U.C.L.A. Dynasty,” a new documentary tonight on HBO, focuses on the tenure of John Wooden, the coach in the 1960s and early ’70s, when playoff glory was as assured for the Bruins as the rising of the sun.
Even with a big gun pointed at the newspaper business, most of the weapons at The Los Angeles Times seemed to be pointed inside.

ECONOMIC DATA The Commerce Department will release revised figures for fourth-quarter gross domestic product (Thursday), which are expected to confirm a 2.2 percent annualized growth rate for the quarter. The department will also release data on durable goods orders for February (Wednesday). Economists forecast a 3.5 percent increase in orders for durable goods for the month, after an 8.7 percent decline in January. The Labor Department will release its latest weekly reading of unemployment claims (Thursday).
You could see the fierce concentration on the faces of the five virtuoso percussionists as they performed Steve Reich’s “Music for Pieces of Wood,” creating dramatic surges of mesmerizing sound.
An uncomfortable reality underlies Kevin Sims’s documentary: The people hoping to have a busload of Iranians blown up en route from Tehran to Shiite shrines in Iraq are the pilgrims on it.
In his blistering family memoir, Robert Goolrick adeptly uses a slow, teasing way of revealing himself and the horrors of his young life to the reader.
Celebrating author Larry Brown in Oxford, Miss.
It’s worth the price of admission to see Jenifer Ringer, the glamorous New York City Ballet principal, playing an old woman hunched in a corner, her head covered with rollers.

The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.
No matter what one thinks of the folks in the White House, it seems clear that they have been put in a bind by the Supreme Court’s bad decisions on presidential pardons.

CASEY--Richard Conway, March 22, 2007, beloved father of Richard and his wife Michelle, cherished grandfather of Allison. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. A graduate of Holy Cross and Georgetown Law School who later served as a federal judge for the Southern District of New York. Friends may call Sunday 7-9 and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday 10am St. Patricks Cathedral 5th Ave. at 50th St NYC. A front-page article yesterday about the limits of multitasking misspelled the surname of a cognitive scientist at the University of Michigan, who said that '''Multitasking is going to slow you down, increasing the chances of mistakes.'' It is David E. Meyer, not Mayer.

PUTTERMAN--Harold. We are very saddened as a family to have lost a loving, caring, and wonderful cousin, uncle, and friend. He will never be forgotten. Our love goes out to his daughters and grandchildren. To know him was to love him. Harold, Rita, Jamie, Cindy, and Gary

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. Envoy Says He Held Talks With Iraqi Insurgents The senior American envoy in Iraq, Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad, said he held talks last year with men he believed represented major insurgent groups in a drive to bring militant Sunni Arabs into politics. He is the first American official to publicly acknowledge holding such talks. A1 U.S. Colleges Market to India American universities, eager to expand to markets abroad, are training their sights on India, where 40 percent of the population is under 18, and a scarcity of higher education opportunities is frequently cited as a hurdle to economic progress. A10 Political Arrests in Pakistan The police detained hundreds of political opposition members in an attempt to thwart nationwide protests planned to denounce Gen. Pervez Musharraf's suspension of the chief justice, opposition leaders said. A9 European Union Turns 50 Fifty years after its foundation was set in Rome as a trading bloc for six countries, the European Union marked a midlife milestone in Berlin with all-night parties, a laid-back street festival and a fervent plea for renewal by the German chancellor, Angela Merkel. A3 Obstacles in Cricket Inquiry The Jamaican police said that their investigation into the death the Pakistani cricket coach killed after his team lost a World Cup match, was complicated by the fact that many potential witnesses had already left Jamaica. A10 NATIONAL A12-19 Republicans Seek Balance In Forging Iraq Strategy Republicans find themselves searching for balance as they juggle three tasks: responding to their constituents' frustrations, resisting the demands of antiwar Democrats and not entirely abandoning the White House. A1 Tasks of an Inspector General As the inspector general at the Justice Department, Glenn A. Fine has confronted agency colleagues time and time again with their failings. Now, his office is examining the role of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and other officials in the dismissal of eight United States attorneys. A17 EDUCATION Move to Extend the School Day School districts are moving to lengthen the school day at struggling schools, prompted by test results suggesting that more than 10,000 schools will probably be failing next year. A1 SCIENCE/HEALTH Study on Children in Day Care A report on American child care has found that keeping a preschooler in a day care center for a year or more increased the likelihood that the child would become disruptive in class. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 New York Racing Franchise Draws Strong Interest New York's troubled but still highly lucrative thoroughbred horse racing franchise has attracted a frenzy of interest this year from major gambling and racing companies and their well-connected lobbyists, who are sparing little expense in their quests to become the official bookie of New York State. B1 Money Woes for Bus System The Long Island Bus system can be a lifeline for the growing number of commuters who live in New York City and work in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. But long waits and crowding could get worse if the system's $4 million deficit is not filled by July. B1 New Jersey Senate Turnover The New Jersey Senate is about to lose more than a quarter of its members, including the longest-serving legislator in the state's history. Though the Legislature's upper chamber is not expected to see any drastic change in the Democrats' slim majority, there is bound to be a change in the way the Senate goes about its business. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Games for the BlackBerry Gameloft, maker of games for cellphones, plans to announce that it is bringing its mobile games to the BlackBerry in hopes of grabbing a chunk of the device's expanding market. C4 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: The Hamas conundrum; of Senate snails and scriveners; a disputed fee; Mr. Puck's good idea. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E4 Crossword E6 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E8 Weather A18

AN OPTIMISTIC VIEW ON NEWS -- ''I've always been intrigued by inefficient markets,'' says Sam Zell, the billionaire real estate investor, who is in the midst of negotiations with the Tribune Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun. [Page C1.] A PESSIMISTIC REPORT ON ADS -- Revenues from newspaper advertising declined sharply in February, compared with February a year ago, and were generally weaker than analysts had expected. While ad spending on newspaper Web sites was up, many on Wall Street wondered if the declines signaled a deepening systemic problem. [C2.] VYING FOR SPECTRUM -- A prized swath of spectrum that is about to be sold at federal auction has touched off an intense lobbying effort pitting cellular companies against a variety of new players interested in the potential of the mobile Internet. [C1.] MUSIC BY THE SONG -- To the regret of music labels everywhere, people are not buying albums anymore. In the shift from CDs to digital music, buyers can now pick the individual songs they like without having to pay upwards of $10 for an entire album. [C1.] NOSTALGIA FOR TELETUBBIES -- A new campaign will promote the Teletubbies, introduced in 1997 in a BBC television series aimed at children ages 3 and under, and try to spread their popularity to an older audience. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C8.] WALL STREET IN PRINT -- Bringing to life the pathos of the fallen man has been a recurring theme in the best works that use Wall Street as center stage. Now a new crop of books, both fiction and nonfiction, aim to capture, if not update, this rich mix of greed, striving, intrigue and vanity. [C1.] AUTOMAKERS' STRATEGY -- Porsche's halfhearted takeover bid this weekend for Volkswagen, along with DaimlerChrysler's recent decision to find suitors for Chrysler, reflect European automakers' desire to control their own fates. [C5.] GAY AWARDS FOR STRAIGHT MEDIA -- On the eve of one of the highest honors in the gay community, the organization that gives awards for positive portrayals of gays and lesbians in the mainstream media is facing growing pressure to honor its own. [C6.] MOBILE GAMES FOR BLACKBERRYS -- GameLoft, a maker of games for cellphones, plans to take its line of mobile games to the BlackBerry in hopes of grabbing a chunk of the device's expanding market. [C4.] NEW NAME IN PUBLISHING -- Warner Books is taking on a new name -- Grand Central Publishing -- and a new logo. Because of its acquisition, it will no longer be part of the Time Warner Book Group. [C5.] SAFETY OF A HEART DRUG -- A large study of Natrecor, a controversial Johnson & Johnson heart-failure drug, raised no new safety concerns, but failed to prove that it helped a large set of patients. [C4.] BIGGER THAN BEANIE BABIES? -- The cuddly stuffed animals called Webkinz, which are in exceedingly high demand among the elementary school set, have also gained notice among Internet executives for their ability to bridge the online and offline worlds. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C4.] MEDIA CONTROL -- Judging from the banter in a conference call for reporters last week by the News Corporation and NBC Universal, corporate control of the news media is still going strong. [C7.] BIOTECHNOLOGY DEAL -- Beckman Coulter, a maker and distributor of biomedical testing and laboratory products, agreed to acquire Biosite, a smaller maker of diagnostic blood tests, for about $1.5 billion in cash. [C8.] OMBUDSMAN AT HARVARD -- When The Harvard Crimson announced last week that it had hired an ombudsman, reactions ranged from praise for the paper's diligence to disappointment with the scope of the writer's first column. And then there was the online satire. [C6.] THE HOLLYWOOD TANTRUM -- In a video clip from the set of ''I Heart Huckabees,'' the 2004 existential comedy directed by David O. Russell, which surfaced on YouTube.com and several gossip blogs last week, Mr. Russell unleashes a tirade so abusive that only one sentence is printable. [C7.]

Because of an editing error, an item in the Suits column in Sunday Business yesterday on a video clip in which James J. Cramer, a CNBC television personality, recommended ways to move stock prices, misidentified the organization that requested that the video clip be removed from YouTube.com. The request was made by TheStreet.com, which taped the original interview, not by CNBC.

A theater review last Monday about ''Di Yam Gazlonim!,'' a Yiddish version of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' that has returned to the JCC in Manhattan, misstated the year in which the operetta is set. While the libretto does not specify a time, elements of the plot point to either 1873 or 1877 -- not to 1897. (The error first appeared in a Nov. 8 review of the opening of the production at the JCC. The review last Monday was a shorter version of the original review.)

An article on Thursday about a Web site that posts pictures showing vehicles with government-issued parking permits that appear to be parked illegally in New York City included a quotation in which a police spokesman misidentified the police precinct that covers Chinatown, where 12 such vehicles were towed recently. It is the Fifth Precinct, not the First.

ZURROW--Milton, M.D. died on March 24. Beloved husband of the late Toby, cherished father of Robert and Stephen (Jane), devoted grandfather of Gabby, loving uncle to Richard, Bruce, Justin and Danielle. Services Monday, March 26, 9:30 am at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue, corner of 91st St.
To the Editor: Re ''A Slow Death,'' by Frederic Block (Op-Ed, March 15):

THE MATCHUP Florida blew out the Bruins in the national title game last season, but these teams are remarkably different. Florida has not improved much as a team, while U.C.L.A. has shown significant strides on offense while still playing with a defensive verve that has become Ben Howland's trademark. Look for the slightly more up-tempo Bruins to pull the upset, ending Florida's back-to-back title hopes. STAR TO WATCH Channeling the success he had at the Final Four last season, Lee Humphrey made seven 3-pointers and scored 23 points against Oregon. U.C.L.A.'s ability to limit his open shots will be a key in Saturday's game, as the Bruins will have to think twice before doubling off him.

As the clock ticked last week, Democrats and Republicans scrambled to position themselves so they could lay the blame for a late budget at the feet of their opponents. First there was the extraordinary meeting where Governor Spitzer publicly lambasted Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, below, likening his budget figures to ''three-card monte'' in an effort to portray the Senate as the holdup in budget talks. Next came the one-sided conference committee meetings, which Republicans called to chide Democrats for not publicly negotiating the budget. It was the fiscal version of an empty chair debate, or maybe of one hand clapping.

DAHL--Hartvig, M.D., on March 17th, 2007 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Virginia Teller. Devoted father of Christopher. Reposing at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleeker St., NYC, Friday, March 30th, 2007. Friends may visit from 9 to 10 am. Cremation, Greenwood Cemetery.

The Miller Brewing Company unit of SABMiller and two agencies have separated. One agency, Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, part of MDC Partners, created campaigns for Miller Lite and Miller High Life beers. The other, Creative on Demand, also in Miami, worked on Hispanic creative assignments for Miller Lite.

While the libretto does not specify a time, elements of the plot point to either 1873 or 1877 -- not to 1897. (The error first appeared in a Nov. 8 review of the opening of the production at the JCC. The review last Monday was a shorter version of the original review.)

DORMAN--David, On March 23, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Frieda. Devoted father of Joan Sherer. Loving grandfather of Samantha and Derek, Mara and Marc, Val and Jodi. Cherished greatgrandfather of Pacey, Jack, Sydney, Ella and Hannah. Beloved friend of Ruth Golden Katz. A loving family man who was generous to a fault and never stopped giving. He will be missed by all who loved him.

REIS--Harold Frank, of Washington, D.C., died on March 23, 2007 of cancer. Born in 1916 Bronx, New York, son of the late Bernard and Rose Reis, survived by Ruthanne, wife of 56 years, son Alan (Dana), New York, New York; daughters Kate Grogan (Kevin), Augusta, Georgia, and Deborah Kennedy (Lee Bragg), Manchester, Maine; five grandchildren and many cousins, nieces and nephews. Sister Hilda Lantz predeceased him. A graduate of City College (NY) and 1940 from the Columbia University School of Law. Distinguished lawyer, he retired from the Department of Justice after 26 years, where he had been Executive Assistant to Attorneys General Robert Kennedy and Nicholas de. B. Katzenbach, and earlier as First Assistant Attorney General in the Office of Legal Counsel. Counseled in the Department on the creation of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and the Cuban missile crisis. Present in Mississippi on behalf of the Federal government as James Meredith enrolled in the University of Mississippi in October 1962. Awarded the Rockefeller Public Service Award in 1964. After retiring from his government career, he continued to actively practice law from 1967 to 1996 as a partner or shareholder first at Wilner, Scheiner and Greeley, then Lowenstein, Newman, Reis & Axelrad and its successors now Morgan, Lewis & Bockius LLP. Private family funeral. Memorial service in Washington, D.C. on a date to be announced.

KARDON--Robert (Bob), of Manhattan, formerly of Philadelphia, retired CEO of Kardon Industries, Inc., died in New York on March 23, 2007 of heart failure at the age of 85. Son of the late Morris and Sophie (Winkleman) and brother of the late Eugene and Lester Kardon. He leaves his wife of 57 years, Janet Stolker Kardon, director emeritus of the Museum of Arts and Design; sons Leroy Kardon and wife Gail of Merion, PA and Ross Kardon of Philadelphia; and daughter Nina Baran and her husband Dr. George Baran of Villanova, PA and Rome, Italy; grandchildren Matthew and Daniel Kardon; Alexander and Diana Baran. Bob served with the United States Army 1942-1946; studied at University of Miami, Florida, and Shriveham American University, Swindon, England. Formerly he was Chairman of the Board, B.T. Babbit Company, Inc.; Pittsburgh Mortgage Corporation; Murphree Mortgage Company., Nashville, TN; Kardon Investment Company Peoples Bond & Mortgage, Philadelphia and Chairman of the Board and Vice President, United Container Company; He retired as the CEO of Kardon Industries, Inc. He was also a former Trustee of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Board member, Merion Park Civic Association, Board member, Hilltop School, Ithan, PA. A member of Young Presidents Organization and World Business Council. Bob gave up his ambition to be a professional vocalist to become a successful executive. Besides his multiple business activities, Bob was a devoted family man, art collector, architecture connoisseur, music lover, gourmet, world traveler, tennis player, ocean swimmer, pilot, a great singer and dancer -and a loving friend. A funeral service will be held at 1 pm, Sunday, March 25th, at Joseph A. Levine & Sons, 4737 Street Road, Trevose, PA 19053. Contributions in Robert Kardon's memory can be made to The Philadelphia Museum of Art.

Advance Auto Parts, Roanoke, Va., chose the Richards Group, Dallas, as the agency of record for its account, previously at Fogarty Klein Monroe, Houston. Spending for the assignment, including creative development, sports marketing and interactive ads, was estimated at $70 million. Shoney's, Nashville, the restaurant chain owned by the Royal Hospitality Corp., named Match, Atlanta, as the agency of record for its account, previously at Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, part of MDC Partners. Spending was estimated at $15 million. Lattimer Moffit Communications, Atlanta, which specializes in Hispanic marketing, will help Match develop a campaign.

New York's powerful alliance of hospitals and health care workers has begun an ambitious effort to beat back Governor Spitzer's health care budget cuts, knocking on more than 100,000 doors across the state, flooding the airwaves with television ads and delivering more than 130,000 postcards to legislators urging them to oppose Mr. Spitzer's plan. But it is the phone calls arranged by the alliance -- a joint venture of the Greater New York Hospital Association and a union, 1199 United Healthcare Workers East -- that appear to be getting the most attention from lawmakers. The effort involves ''patch-through'' calling, in which phone bank operators contact voters in a lawmaker's district, ask them if they want to stop the health cuts and then connect them with the lawmaker's office if they say yes.

BENANAV--Joshua Benanav, 84, of White Plains, NY, died Saturday, March 24, 2007. Born Joshua Szereny in Uzhorod, Czechoslovakia on November 18, 1922, he was the son of the late Bertha (Freiberg), who died in Auschwitz Concentration camp in 1944, and Bela Szereny, who died in Mathausen Concentration Camp in 1945. After escaping from a slave labor unit in Romania in 1944 Joshua and his wife emigrated to Palestine. In 1948-1950 he was an officer in the Israeli Army, where he led a unit participating in the liberation of Eilat. In 1949 Joshua changed his family name to Ben-Anav. In 1953, Joshua and his family emigrated to the United States. From 1957-1989 he was a real estate developer. He leaves his wife, Aviva (Rosen) Benanav; his three sons: Gary Benanav and his wife Ruth Benanav: Jay Benanav and his wife Lucy Kanson; and Dan Benanav; his grandchildren: Michael, Tami, Steven, Jesse, David, Sam, Aaron and Ethan: and his great-grandchildren, David, Sara, and Lucas. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, March 28, 2007 at 10:00 am in the Chapel of the Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Avenue, Hartford, CT. The family will sit shiva on March 28 at 20 Northmoor Road in West Hartford and on the afternoons of March 29 and March 30 at 333 East 57th Street in Manhattan. Contributions should be made to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, P.O. Box 90988 Washington, DC 20090-0988.

Lil' Flip ''I Need Mine'' (Asylum/Warner) In 2004 the Houston rapper Lil' Flip had a big hit and a bad year. The hit was ''Sunshine,'' a love song silly enough (''I'll treat ya like milk -- do nothin' but spoil ya'') to be a summer favorite. And the bad part was his disastrous feud with T. I., from Atlanta, who made Lil' Flip seem like a lightweight. After that he laid low, even as Houston became a hip-hop hotbed; the release of his new album, ''I Need Mine,'' was further delayed when he split with his old record company, Sony.

SIEGEL--Richard, M.D., Richard, your wit, wisdom and companionship will be sorely missed. We will never forget you, you were a friend to all of us. Ted, Larry, Greg, Mike, Jordan and the entire staff of Mid Island Eye Physicians and Surgeons.

Colombia's government disputed a published report on Sunday of leaked C.I.A. intelligence linking the chief of the army to paramilitary death squads, saying any accusations against him should be made formally through the judicial system. The information in the report, if confirmed, would represent the highest-level connection yet publicly established between military officials in the government of President Álvaro Uribe, a strong ally of the Bush administration, and the paramilitary squads, which are illegal and considered terrorists by the United States. A scandal over ties between some of Mr. Uribe's allies and the paramilitaries has been dogging him for months.

Budget negotiations continued to stall over the weekend, raising the specter of the first late budget in three years. But while Gov. Eliot Spitzer was at a stalemate with state Republicans, he appeared to have resolved the biggest point of contention with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, according to a person with knowledge of the discussions. The mayor had objected to the governor's move to cut $328 million in unrestricted annual aid to the city. Mr. Spitzer, in conversations with the mayor last week, agreed to restore a small amount of the money in the coming fiscal year, on the order of $20 million, and in the ensuing years to restore most, if not all, of the funding, the person said. Both houses of the Legislature had already proposed a similar restoration of some of the governor's cuts.

Good Charlotte ''Good Morning Revival'' (Epic/Daylight) Joel and Benji Madden are the twins who lead the pop-punk band Good Charlotte, and they're the kind of people who show up on magazine covers and start clothing lines and date Hilary Duff. (She spent a few years with Joel, who is now being photographed alongside Nicole Richie.) But ''The Chronicles of Life and Death,'' from 2004, was a dud, overblown and, not coincidentally, underbought. Now it's time for the Madden twins to make amends.

FISHMAN--Sylvia (Shemel) age 90, of Aventura, FL. formerly of NYC, NY, passed away March 19, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Seymour Fishman. Loving mother of Steven and Judith. Dear sister of Helene Susman and the late Sidney Shemel. Cherished grandmother of Laura and Stephanie and great grandmother of Jordan, Sydney, Alexander and Lia. She was the perfect partner to Seymour for over 60 years as he pursued various careers, last as Executive Director of the American Friends of the Hebrew University. The family will receive friends at Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, Aventura, Florida, Sunday, April 1, between 1:00 and 4:00 pm. For information call 1-800-327-9192. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions to Macular Degeneration Research Fund c/o Susan Ervin, Bascom Palmer Eye Institute, 900 NW 17th St., Miami, FL 33136, or American Friends of the Hebrew University, 1 Battery Park Plaza, 25th Floor, New York, NY 10004. Share your memories and condolences at: sfishman@fishmangroup .com

Young Buck ''Buck the World'' (G Unit/Interscope) After disappointing releases from Tony Yayo, Mobb Deep and Lloyd Banks, 50 Cent needs to prove that his G Unit label can still make hits. So along comes the Nashville rapper Young Buck with ''Buck the World,'' his second G Unit album.
