Cherished grandmother of Stacey Shubitz. Beloved wife of the late Morris Goldstein. Devoted sister of the late Joseph Brown and Sylvia Epstein.

8 P.M. (Encore) CLERKS -- (1994) ''Clerks,'' the innovative, gritty comedy about two convenience store clerks (above, Jeff Anderson, left, and Brian O'Halloran) who think they have better things to do (some of them illegal) than serve customers is the first of a Kevin Smith double-header. ''Mallrats'' (1995) -- about two guys dumped on the same day who use the local mall as a place to forget their troubles -- follows at 9:35 p.m. 8 P.M. (CW) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS -- There comes a time in every boy's life when he must chose between his family and a girl. Chris's comes tonight when he has to decide whether to ditch his dad and a baseball game to go to the movies with Tasha. In the meantime, Rochelle forgets to mail Tonya's letter to the Billy Ocean fan club. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) WILDFIRE -- Raintree Farm has seen its financial ups and downs lately, and in the season finale, everyone is trying to find new sources of income, including Kris. While she considers a lucrative offer from Sheik Omar, she also has to figure out a balance between dating Matt and remaining friends with Junior. 8 P.M. (Lifetime) SPOTLIGHT 25 -- Willow Bay examines the state of being 25 with profiles of women managing careers, families and finances. Ms. Bay also speaks with Jennifer Hudson (above, right, with Ms. Bay), who won an Oscar for her role in ''Dreamgirls,'' on success at a young age. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) THE PARTY NEVER STOPS (2007) -- Sara Paxton and Nancy Travis star in this film about college party life that escalates into binge drinking. 9 P.M. (Travel) BIZARRE FOODS WITH ANDREW ZIMMERN -- In tonight's episode, our intrepid eater seeks out the wild edibles of the American Gulf Coast. 10 P.M. (13, 49) PILGRIMAGE TO KARBALA -- A ''Wide Angle'' special follows a group of Iranian Muslims who embark on a difficult journey to visit holy sites in Iraq, and explores the roots of Shia and Sunni Islam. 10 P.M. (ABC) WHAT ABOUT BRIAN -- Simple plans spiral out of control on the series's season finale. Dave and Deena go away to renew their wedding vows, and Nicole is swamped with customers in their absence. Natasha's work emergency interrupts Brian (Barry Watson, above, with Stacy Keibler) and Adam while they are baby-sitting the girls, and Brian realizes that he has picked the wrong friend to help. LORI MOORE
To the Editor: Re ''Take a Rat to Dinner,'' by Steven A. Shaw (Op-Ed, March 16):

An article yesterday about deliberations over the dismissal of eight United States attorneys misquoted President Bush in some editions. Speaking in his weekly radio address about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales's role in removing the attorneys, Mr. Bush said ''I strongly support the attorney general in this decision,'' not ''in his decision.''

A picture caption on Wednesday about an opening ceremony for a stable on Pier 76 in Manhattan misidentified the treat that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was feeding to a horse. It was a carrot, not sugar.

Reporting on the contretemps at The Los Angeles Times last week brings to mind a scene in which you come upon a sinking vessel and see people scrambling everywhere. And then you realize they are not looking for buckets, but guns. At The Times last week, editors took aim at other editors, writers sprayed shots at their own newspaper, and the publisher drew a bead on his own foot. The shootout went off on the Web in real time, with blogs annotating every ricochet. Fittingly, the whole thing ended when the editorial page editor, after resigning, explained himself on a blog, using the digital platform to throw a grenade on the way out.

Prodigy ''Return of the Mac'' (Koch) The rapper Prodigy (not to be confused with the Prodigy, from Britain) is one half of the veteran Queens duo Mobb Deep; the two released an underwhelming 2006 album, ''Blood Money,'' on G Unit. But he has found a great way to rebound: by going solo and getting weird. In the 1990s Mobb Deep was known for elegant beats and grim narratives. And Prodigy's new solo CD (he calls it a mixtape), released by the independent label Koch and produced by the sample-happy producer the Alchemist, is a woozy trip back into that menacing world; it's also a reminder of how engrossing Prodigy can be.

An article on Friday about new calculations by the Army that show a higher number of desertions than it previously reported misspelled the given name of an Army spokesman who said data errors were caused by confusion among employees who tally them. He is Lt. Col. Bryan C. Hilferty, not Brian.

An article in some copies yesterday about Congressional criticism of the Justice Department inaccurately summarized a March 15 report in the National Journal about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and the National Security Agency's program to eavesdrop domestically without court warrants. The National Journal report asserted that Mr. Gonzales continued to advise President Bush on a proposed internal Justice Department review of the N.S.A. program after learning that his own conduct would be scrutinized. The National Journal report did not explicitly allege that Mr. Gonzales tried to block the investigation.

The State Ethics Commission says it does not have the authority to review an ethics complaint against Gov. Jon S. Corzine, the mayor of Bogota said yesterday, but he plans to refile his complaint today with another agency. The mayor, Steven Lonegan, a Republican, said that he would submit the complaint to the Advisory Ethics Panel, a two-member state board that makes determinations on the governor's conduct. The complaint contends that Mr. Corzine's gifts to Carla Katz, his former companion and a state labor leader, including a $470,000 loan that he eventually forgave, create an appearance of a conflict of interest. Mr. Corzine and Ms. Katz, president of Communications Workers of America Local 1034, which represents state workers, dated from 2002 until the summer of 2004. At the time, Mr. Corzine was a United States senator. SERGE F. KOVALESKI

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a fund-raiser for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign held at SoulCycle, a spinning studio in Manhattan, misidentified the studio's neighborhood in some copies. It is on the Upper West Side, not the Upper East Side.

With the North Carolina mascot, Jason K. Ray, in a New Jersey hospital after being hit by a car Friday, his counterparts at the Midwest Regional in St. Louis were thinking about him and taking sympathetic action an hour before the game between Oregon and Florida. Ryan Matthews, who dresses in the duck costume for Oregon, painted the words ''Get Well Soon, J'' and ''NC Mascot'' on the soles of his big webbed feet. He said he would try to persuade the Florida mascot to do something similar.

Penn State claimed its 10th national fencing title yesterday in Madison, N.J., winning 18 more bouts than the runner-up, St. John's. The Columbia-Barnard team finished third despite holding the lead through the first two days of the competition. In the individual events, Penn State earned only one gold medal, by Doris Willette in épée. Fencers from Harvard, Ohio State, Columbia and Wayne State won the other five individual titles. JOSHUA ROBINSON

A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about broad spying by the New York City police on people expected to protest in the city during the 2004 Republican National Convention referred incorrectly in some copies to the disposition of the property of one protester, Joshua Kinberg, who devised a bicycle equipped with cellphone, laptop and tubes that could spray the ground with messages in chalk. The spraying apparatus -- not the bicycle -- was held for more than a year before being returned; Mr. Kinberg says the authorities have still not returned his bicycle.

City health officials should change their method for evaluating restaurants and issue a letter grade from A to F, State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein said yesterday. Mr. Klein, a Bronx Democrat, said he would introduce legislation requiring restaurants to prominently post the letter grade. ''No restaurant is going to want an F in their doorway,'' he said yesterday. Andrew Tucker, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, said that the agency would review the senator's proposal, but that the current scoring system allowed the agency to provide more detail about violations than a lettered grading system would. TIM MURPHY

The funniest moment of Thad Matta's postgame news conference came when a reporter from Ohio decided to point out the elephant in the room. Matta was asked about the intentional foul called on Chris Douglas-Roberts that sparked a 19-6 run for Ohio State, changing the momentum in a victory against Memphis in the South Regional final on Saturday.

''The bottom line is that insurance companies make money when they don't pay claims. They'll do anything to avoid paying, because if they wait long enough, they know the policyholders will die.'' MARY BETH SENKEWICZ who resigned last year as a senior executive at the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. [A16]
DENENY--John Francis, Dear Dad, happy birthday. Always in my heart. Joan

THE MATCHUP The Hoyas showed remarkable resiliency and heady guard play by scrapping back into the game against North Carolina to force overtime. The Hoyas were one of the country's hottest teams heading into the tournament and have the size to neutralize Greg Oden inside. There is a good chance Oden will find himself in foul trouble again. Expect Georgetown's glut of size and its tricky style to end Ohio State's charmed run. STAR TO WATCH The freshman Mike Conley Jr. proved yet again this weekend in San Antonio that he was one of the elite point guards in college basketball. Memphis Coach John Calipari summed it up when he said that Conley's shot is ugly, but that it goes in when it matters. ''My kind of guy,'' Calipari said.

A Brooklyn teenager arrested last summer after a fatal water scooter accident in Mill Basin inlet has been indicted on charges of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, according to prosecutors. The teenager, Aristotle Plagianakos, 17, of Mill Basin, was charged in connection with a June 30 crash involving his water scooter and one driven by Paul Zaccaria, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes announced on Friday. Mr. Zaccaria, 17, also of Mill Basin, was killed; his body was not recovered until 37 days after the collision, prosecutors said. TRYMAINE LEE
FALCO--Louis, 3/26/93. Your greatly missed, thank you for your contributions to the world of dance & theatre & us

Three guys wearing blue sweatshirts, each with a large letter on the front, stood behind the Georgetown bench yesterday at Continental Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. ''H-O-Y'' they read. Minutes later, another guy appeared. He wore an S. An empty seat was between the Y and the S. The A must have been stuck in the concessions line.
To the Editor: Re ''Point-Blank Perspective,'' by Robert Leuci (Op-Ed, March 20):

GOTHELF--Sidney, of Brooklyn, NY on March 24, 2007. Beloved husband of Edith (nee Berkowitz) adoring father of Barbara (Ralph) Cohn. Grandfather of David. WWII Veteran. Leading New England life insurance agent. Services were held Sunday at Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, Brooklyn, NY.

The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about ''Too Far From Home: A Story of Life and Death in Space,'' by Chris Jones, misidentified the space shuttle that broke apart on Feb. 1, 2003, in one of two references in the opening paragraph. It was the Columbia, not the Challenger. (The Challenger exploded in January 1986.)

LISSER--Martha Schultz, On Friday, March 23, 2007, of Chevy Chase, MD, formerly of East Hampton and Riverdale, NY. Beloved wife of 60 years of Morton Lisser; cherished mother of Justine (Stephen Klitzman) and Amy (Matthew Frosch); adored grandmother of Zachary, Jeremy, Olivia and Isabelle; devoted sister of Sally Pearl, the late Sylvia Paley and sister-in-law of Stanley and Ann Lisser. Funeral services Monday, March 26, at 2:00 p.m. at Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Road NW, Washington, DC. In mourning Monday at 7:00 p.m. at the home of Morton Lisser, and on Tuesday, March 27, at 7:00 p.m. at the home of Justine Lisser. Memorial contributions to Martha's Table: www.marthastable.org.

Macy Gray ''Big'' (will.i.am music group/Geffen) Mr. Wrongs outnumber nice guys on ''Big,'' Macy Gray's first new album since 2003. That's good, since Ms. Gray sounds best when romance gets complicated. Her scratchy, quivery voice mixes comedy, vulnerability and willfulness, and she's grounded in the storytelling tradition of Southern soul music, which means that she brings out the words and drama before her vocals cut loose.

A PATH train bound for the 33rd Street station in Manhattan derailed at 2:55 p.m. yesterday after leaving Hoboken, stranding about 300 passengers for roughly two hours, the authorities said. Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which manages the PATH system, said there were no injuries. After another PATH train was dispatched alongside the derailed train, he said, the passengers were transferred and taken to Hoboken, where they arrived at 4:15 p.m. He said one set of wheels on one of the train's middle cars had left the tracks, for reasons that remained unclear. Direct service from Hoboken to Manhattan had not resumed late yesterday, and Mr. DiFulco said it was unclear whether it would be restored for commuters this morning. But he said PATH riders could travel from Hoboken to the Pavonia station in Jersey City and then to 33rd Street in Manhattan. THOMAS J. LUECK

FINELL--Connie Lyn, 49 of Westport, CT, on March 23, 2007. Beloved wife of Mark, devoted mother of Marissa, Laura and Rebecca, daughter of Carl Fruehling and the late Patricia, sister of Carl, Jr., Brian and James Fruehling. Service Tuesday, March 27th at 10:00 AM, Green Funeral Home, 88 Beach Rd., Fairfield, CT. Contributions to Smilow Family Breast Health Center, Norwalk Hospital.

Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he favored an overhaul of federal mortgage regulations, citing widespread concern about the surge in defaults and foreclosures involving subprime mortgages, risky home loans made to people with weak credit. Citing data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Census Bureau, Mr. Schumer said that about 91,000 households in New York State, including 53,000 in the New York City metropolitan area, were at risk of foreclosure by the end of 2008, as interest rates on adjustable-rate mortgages are reset. At a hearing on Thursday, members of the Senate Banking Committee criticized the Federal Reserve for failing to curb mortgage lending abuses. The chairman, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, said that new legislation might not be needed and that excesses could be addressed under existing regulations. SEWELL CHAN
DEAN--Andy Chen. MD, PhD. On your 47th birthday, your sense of humor, devotion to loved ones and dedication to your profession continue to inspire your family. We love you and miss you.

Three Republican senators voiced fresh concerns on Sunday about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales's handling of the dismissals of eight United States attorneys amid questions about whether the firings were politically motivated. The comments, made in separate televised interviews by Republicans with histories of breaking with the White House, provided further indication of waning support for Mr. Gonzales where he needs it most, among fellow Republicans.

A pair of bills introduced in the State Senate and Assembly would provide an estimated 1.1 million New York City households with an annual $300 rent credit on their city personal income taxes. The city would absorb the cost, $261 million a year. The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, proposed the credit on Feb. 15, but it requires the approval of state lawmakers. Flanked by tenant advocates and politicians at a City Hall news conference yesterday, Ms. Quinn said that two-thirds of city residents were renters and that they deserved relief similar to the $400 rebate on property taxes that city homeowners have received each year since 2004. Individual renters with incomes of less than $43,000 and families with incomes of up to $75,000 would be eligible for the credit. Where roommates split the rent, the credit would be evenly divided among them unless they agreed on a different arrangement. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has not said whether he supports the proposal. SEWELL CHAN

PELTON--Max, 73, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of NYC. Beloved husband of Cynthia, loving father of Bryan and Marissa, cherished grandfather of Owen. Services Wednesday, 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY. Contributions may be made to The Museum of Jewish Heritage, 36 Battery Place, New York, NY 10280.

LANDAU--Mabel R. Two weeks prior to her 100th birthday, Mabel passed away on March 23, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Harold, devoted mother of Lawrence and Sandra, loving grandmother of Scott, Brian, Todd, Emily, Caroline and Katherine and adoring great-grandmother of Isabel, Zachery, Rylee, Amanda and Matthew. A 1928 graduate of Cornell University, Mabel was an enthusiastic lover of the opera, bridge, and all things cultural. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison, 1:30 on Monday, March 26, 2007.

CAPUTO--Emily. The Officers, Members and Staff of The Riverdale Yacht Club mourn the passing of Emmy Caputo, beloved wife of Bick Caputo, the backbone of our club. We extend our condolences and deepest sympathy to her entire family. Jennifer Klein, Commodore
To the Editor: Re ''The Biased Broadcasting Corporation,'' by Frank H. Stewart (Op-Ed, March 15):

Dentsu is losing the leader of one of its American agencies after a reorganization involving its United States holdings. Rick Colby, 55, president and executive creative director at Colby & Partners, is leaving as his agency and its three offices disappear in the reorganization. He said he planned to open his own agency.

Poor Behavior Is Linked To Time in Day Care A report from the largest, longest-running study of American child care has found that keeping a preschooler in a day care center a year or more increased the likelihood that the child would become disruptive in class -- and that the effect persisted through sixth grade. The finding held up regardless of the child's sex or family income, or the quality of the day care center. PAGE A14 Dispute Over Legal Roles As American officials prepare for the reopening of the military commissions that will try some of the detainees being held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a dispute over the proper role of military defense lawyers in the planned war crimes trials is intensifying. PAGE A12 Fight Over Surveillance Files Lawyers for New York City have told a court that records of police surveillance leading up to the 2004 Republican convention, which included operations in several cities, should remain under seal. PAGE B1 More on Edwards Diagnosis Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of John Edwards, elaborated on her cancer diagnosis, saying the disease had spread to her hip. PAGE A19 The Music Album as Relic Music labels are trying to entice listeners to buy full albums rather than individual songs. BUSINESS DAY In Chicago, the El Is Ailing Chicagoans are confronting the possibility that the city's century-old, and deteriorating, elevated train system may be at a breaking point. PAGE A12 A Shift in Palestinian Goals Palestinians have long demanded the right to return to the homes they left in the 1948 fighting that led to Israel's creation. But now many of them say that as much as they want Israel to recognize their right to do so, they do not think that they would actually return to the lands their families left. PAGE A11

TRUEN--Arlene. Our beloved D'Arlene. Our life long sister who decorated our hearts and our homes with so much love. We will forever treasure our lives together. Richard and Robyn Chwatt $(6$)TRUEN--Arlene. We are deeply saddened by your untimely death and feel such a sense of loss. Our sincerest condolences to Craig, Cindy, Mitchell, and their families. We will miss you and your elegance. Eddie, Evie, and Laura Talmus

While it seems that half the people in line to buy movie tickets -- if not several whispering during the feature presentation -- are deep in conversation, many use their cellphones for more than talk. According to M:Metrics, which tracks mobile usage, a substantial portion do everything from reading the latest news to buying the latest ring tone at least once a month. Most users communicate by sending text messages and e-mail and by sharing pictures, which, at a thousand words per shot, can really push up the bill. SHELLY FREIERMAN
JUDSON--Alan, former members of the City Athletic Club mourn the loss of a good friend. He will be missed. Norman Jacobson

To the Editor: In ''Renewed Interest in Japanese Who Died in Epic Battle'' (Iwo Jima Journal, March 19), you say, ''Japan is not alone in struggling with how to remember a war that it lost, and those who died in it.'' You add, by way of analogy, ''During the Vietnam era in the United States, many soldiers came home to indifference and ridicule, and there was an emotional debate over the erection of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington.''

FOX--Ralph, age 87. Passed away March 24, 2007. Born and raised in NY, NY. He lived in Monroe Township, NJ, for the last 15 years. Ralph is survived by his loving wife Dinah of 60 years, a daughter Stephanie Morris (Robert) of NY, NY; two sons, Daniel (Elaine) of Rockville, MD, and Lawrence (Laura) of Pleasantville, NY; five grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Graveside services will be held Monday, March 26 at 1 pm, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations may be made to The Challah Fund Foundation, 205 Easton Ave, New Brunswick, NJ 08901.

The government of Iran yesterday denounced as illegal a sanctions package approved unanimously over the weekend by the United Nations Security Council, and in retaliation announced that it would limit cooperation with the United Nations' nuclear oversight agency. President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad issued a defiant statement that ''Iran's enrichment of uranium is a legal issue,'' maintaining that his nation's nuclear program was intended solely for energy production.
To the Editor: Re ''With a Record Number of Homeless Families, the City Vows to Improve Aid'' (news article, March 19):

Which would-be president are Silicon Valley’s moguls and tastemakers lining up to support? That is the question the ValleyWag blog set out to answer, drawing up a list based on “press clippings, attendance lists at fundraisers, and our own guesses.” Illinois senator Barack Obama and New York senator Hillary Clinton each get several names in their columns.

In what animal welfare advocates are describing as a "historic advance," Burger King has announced that it will begin buying eggs and pork from suppliers that do not confine their animals in cages and crates.

Staten Islanders have elected the borough's first openly gay elected official by selecting Matthew Titone to an Assembly seat on the island's North Shore, according to unofficial returns from today's special election.

In a major step toward passing a state budget by the April 1 deadline, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state legislative leaders agreed Tuesday night to add at least $850 million to his proposed budget and appeared to have resolved the main issues that divided them, Danny Hakim and Nicholas Confessore report this evening. The tentative deal involved several key concessions by the governor to Senate Republicans. Mr. Spitzer agreed to restore $350 million of the $1.3 billion worth of health care cuts he had proposed. He also said he would add $500 million in new education aid. He also agreed to distribute property tax rebate checks.
Hypernova, a young hip Iranian rock band, performs for the first time in New York City.

A Queens man hasdenied reports that he told the police that Sean Bell shot him in a drug-related dispute last year.The tale of the shooting appeared on the front page of The Daily News and was later repeated by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly at a news conference. He said the information had been passed along to the Queens district attorney, who is prosecuting three officers in the fatal shooting of Mr. Bell.
While waiting for the Senate to vote on an Iraq spending bill that includes a timetable for withdrawing troops, blogs passed the time with tales of senators and handguns.

The State Ethics Commission staff is too busy to join the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying for pizza on its monthly "Hawaiian Shirt/Dressdown" day. Also: Bad day for the budget talks. [Capitol Confidential]

Playing off Tyler's post, there aren't many roster decisions to be made (officially), but Lastings Milledge's hand injury may wind up putting a crimp in the Mets' plans. Milledge reinvented himself over the winter, showing up to camp six weeks ago with an improved attitude and, he said, 13 pounds of muscle. Until Matt Albers's fastball drilled him on the right hand Sunday, Milledge was batting .352 and his 28 total bases ranked second behind Jose Reyes.
Back in the old days (2004), political observers gauged a candidates' relative popularity based on his polling numbers, his cash totals and his endorsements.
Today's WNBC/Marist Poll provides more grist for those of us wondering how the millions of dollars' worth of anti-Eliot-Spitzer ads over the last few weeks have affected his popularity.

Senate Democrats considering an Iraq spending bill mustered enough votes late this afternoon -- (barely) at 50-48 -- to defeat a Republican amendment that would have stripped out language setting a timetable for withdrawal of troops from Iraq.
A Zone reader, Matt, is getting a lot of positive feedback for his proposal to solve the yellow cab shortage in Queens, Brooklyn, and the Bronx:

Billy Donovan, from any standard measure or perception, is a man at the top of his profession. In four days, he will attempt to become the first coach in 15 years to lead his team to consecutive national championships. He has revolutionized the grimy game of recruiting, adjusting to a world where your best players have little desire to hang around too long. He has followed in the footsteps of his mentor Rick Pitino in that the man knows how to wear a suit. (I've always considered Pitino and Donovan modern-day college basketball Gordon Gekkos; "winning, for lack of a better word, is good.") Most impressive, he has retained his dignity and respect despite being a grown man with the name "Billy."
The Senate is preparing for a critical vote - slated for 5 p.m. - on Iraq legislation.
This is what Carl Pavano said after completing six strong innings today against the Minnesota Twins: "I'm ready."

Kelly were asked about a report that was the wood of The Daily News this morning, in which a man claimed he had been shot by Sean Bell, who was killed in the November police shooting in Queens. Facing a crush of reporters today just outside the Senate chamber, Senator James Webb declined to comment on specifics of the case in which a close aide was arrested Monday trying to carry a loaded handgun into a Senate office building.

Alexander B. Grannis, the Assemblyman who Gov. Eliot Spitzer has nominated to head the Department of Environmental Conservatiom, has cleared his first hurdle. The Senate Environmental Committee voted to approve his nomination after today's round of questioning, which included not only some senators who had spoken before, but a couple of Assembly members who were along for the ride, too.
A relatively small deal announced Tuesday packs a wallop in the world of mixed martial arts, an increasingly popular but sometimes controversial sport.

On March 27, 2007, Times Reader launched as a subscription service for $14.95 a month or $165 a year. Access to TimesSelect and Premium Crosswords are included in the price. If you are currently a TimesSelect or Premium Crossword subscriber you will receive a pro rated refund on those products when you purchase Times Reader.
We're sweating it out here in muggy Fort Myers as the Yankees take on the Twins. Carl Pavano, the probable opening day starter, just gave up his fourth single in a row and it's tied, 2-2.

The consumer-electronics retailer Best Buy said Tuesday it would acquire Speakeasy, an Internet service provider that serves small businesses, for $97 million. The Seattle Times describes how Speakeasy began life as an Internet café in 1994 (which was quite early for Internet cafés) and grew into a national broadband provider. It stayed independent even as small Internet providers were being gobbled up by larger ones and by big telecom companies.

Bell Ranch, one of the last really HUGE working ranches in New Mexico, andalso a backdrop for the TV western "Rawhide" ("Move em' out, Head em' up") hasjust gone on the market for a whoppin' $115 million. Operated as a cattleranch since 1824, the property boasts 250,000 acres of mesas, canyons andcedar forests as well as a 5,700-square-foot home, 3,000 cows, one airportand its own ZIP code.

Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbank's asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

As former Amaranth Advisors energy trader Brian Hunter prepares to launch his new hedge-fund firm -- it is reportedly called Solengo Capital Advisors -- investors in his old firm, Amaranth, are still waiting to get what's left of their money back. Financial News reports that a group of investors in Amaranth, which collapsed after its bets on the energy market went bad, have offered to drop their legal claims against the firm in hopes of collecting their remaining capital more quickly.

In this video interview with The Politicker, City Councilman Charles Barron, one of three council members mentioned in secret New York police intelligence reports, promises an investigation: "This is absurd. They talk about some democracy? This is a hypocrisy."
Today, a few more notes from my visit two weeks ago to the TED conference...
Six months after a historic election, the fledging government is struggling to put Congo back together.
One of the definitive signs of March is when you walk into a press room and see copies of the official N.C.A.A. Final Four Records book spread out on tables.

If you picked the Final Four correctly, you should be proud of your accomplishment. But as Chief Bracket Correspondent Pete Thamel pointed out yesterday: "With top-seeded Florida and Ohio State meeting second-seeded U.C.L.A. and Georgetown next weekend in Atlanta, this will be the first Final Four since 1993 with no team seeded lower than No. 2."

In a special election today on the north shore of the island, voters will choose the successor to the late Assemblyman John W. Lavelle, who was also the chairman of the borough's Democratic organization. Mr. Lavelle, who was 57, died of a stroke in January.

Startup companies and their investors may be worried about the dry market for initial public offerings, but "happy hour" has quietly returned for money-losing startups that are seeking public capital, The Street.com's Kevin Kelleher writes.

Shortly before noon, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce that the city will begin providing bullet-resistant vests to its 4,800 auxiliary police officers. The news conference is scheduled to take place in the Greenwich Village police precinct where two volunteer auxiliary officers were fatally shot by a gunman on March 14.
Tour a six-bedroom house in Greenwich, Conn., and waterfront estates on Lakes Michigan and Tahoe.

Then we heard that new home sales plunged, and that was bad news. Today we get the S.&P. Case-Shiller index for January, which looks bad.

Senator John McCain cut short his campaign and fundraising events in Florida, returning to Capitol Hill because his vote may be needed by Republicans on the war spending bill. According to the Washington Post, Mr. McCain told a conservative radio station that he needed "to beat back this recipe for defeat that the Democrats are foisting off on the American people."
A weekend itinerary in the "other" Orlando, Fla., which offers a variety of cultural activities that have nothing to do with theme park attractions.

Monica Goodling, a Justice Department official who is counsel to the attorney general and liaison to the White House, is taking the Fifth rather than testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the firing of the Gonzales Eight. George Washington law professor Orin Kerr, writing at the group legal blog The Volokh Conspiracy, says he doesn't "follow the rationale" nor see "a legally valid reason" for Goodling to invoke her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. "The Fifth Amendment privilege is available if the witness has reasonable ground to believe that her testimony will be used against her to prove an element of a crime," Kerr writes. He continues:
In Newark and elsewhere, heavy mortgage debt has led many first-time homebuyers to the edge of financial ruin.

Are Blackstone Group's employees really worth an average of $50 million apiece? That value, based on reports that the private equity firm could be worth $40 billion in an initial public offering, "could well be the highest bounty ever placed on the heads of office workers," Breakingviews writes.

The estimated net assets of the global hedge fund industry rose by 6 percent in the final quarter of 2006 and by 24 percent over the year as a whole to reach $1.89 trillion, according to Hedge Fund Asset Flows & Trends Report 2006-2007, released by Institutional Investor News and HedgeFund.net.

Shares in Next, a British clothing retailer, reached an all-time high Tuesday after rumors of private equity interest in the company emerged. One market trader told The Times of London that shares in Next, which was up 78 pence at 23.06 pounds, had jumped on rumors of a leveraged buyout by the retailer's management or an approach by private equity firms.

Speculation that Carrefour, the French retailer, was headed for a takeover were dashed late Friday, setting off a sharp decline in the company's share price Monday. Takeover speculation ended when Bernard Arnault, a French investor, and Colony Capital, an American investment firm, said they would not acquire more than 20 percent of Carrefour until June 30, 2008, unless Carrefour's largest shareholder, the Halley family, decided to sell its 13 percent stake or a new shareholder bought more than 5 percent of the company.

Robert E. Diamond Jr., head of investment banking at Barclays, seems to be feeling pretty good these days. Mr. Diamond said on Tuesday the British bank was in a strong position in its talks on an $80 billion take over of its Dutch rival, ABN Amro. His comments also come after Barclay's revealed that Mr. Diamond out-earned his boss five-fold.

HSBC Holdings will buy Swiss Life Holding's stake in two ventures for 228.8 million euros ($305 million), as it seeks to bolster profit from insurance in France. The bank, based in London, will buy the remaining 50.01 percent stake it does not already own in a French life insurer, Erisa, and the property and casualty insurer Erisa IARD, HSBC said Monday in a news release.

A Citigroup employee who traded Patrick Corporation stock on the bank's account lied about his reasons for selling the shares, Australia's federal court was told Monday. "It is a misleading and dishonest answer you give today," Bret Walker, a lawyer for the Australian Securities & Investments Commission, told Andrew Manchee, a proprietary trader for Citigroup. "I disagree," Mr. Manchee replied on the second day of a trial in Sydney.

Credit Suisse Group said it paid its chairman, Walter Kielholz, 16 million Swiss francs ($13.2 million) last year, one-third more than a year earlier, after profit at the bank, the second-largest in Switzerland, rose to a record. Mr. Kielholz, who earned 12 million francs in 2005, received 9 million francs in cash and 7 million francs in share-based compensation, the bank said in its 2006 annual report, published Monday. Marcel Ospel, chairman of larger Swiss rival UBS AG, received 26.6 million francs.

EDP-Energias de Portugal agreed to buy Horizon Wind Energy of Texas from Goldman Sachs for $2.15 billion in cash. Adding Horizon, which is based in Houston and has assets in 15 states, more than doubles EDP's worldwide wind-power production capacity and raises its ranking to fourth from sixth among the world's largest producers of power from wind turbines.

A deal between Sanofi-Aventis, France's largest drug company, and Bristol-Myers Squibb of the United States could still be in the offing. The Times of London reports that if a battle of egos between Sanofi's chairman and its younger chief executive is resolved, the French company may dust off its $54 billion merger plans with Bristol-Myers.

With his career and his company's prospects on the line, Citigroup chairman Charles O. Prince III is preparing the most sweeping restructuring of the financial giant since it was forged from a merger a decade ago.

The auction for Tribune may indeed be set for another round. With less than a week to go before Tribune is scheduled to conclude its six-month strategic review, the Los Angeles billionaires Ronald Burkle and Eli Broad are considering raising their bid for the media company, The Chicago Tribune reported.

In the growing field of executive coaching, Marshall Goldsmith is among the cream of the crop -- and seems to be feeling very Zen about it. Mr. Goldsmith, who apparently has coached bigwigs at companies including Boeing, Motorola and Goldman Sachs, promotes a Buddhist-inspired path to enlightened leadership, according to a profile of the coach in The Chicago Tribune.

The news that the News Corporation and NBC Universal are teaming up to start an online video distribution network that may well rival Google's YouTube is a tale of big-name media giants trying to outmaneuver one another as they struggle to win control of content distribution on the Internet.

Northwest Airlines can begin seeking creditor approval of a plan to exit bankruptcy that values the company at an estimated $7 billion, a judge ruled Monday. Judge Allan L. Gropper of Federal Bankruptcy Court said that when Northwest revises its disclosure statement to include agreements reached on Monday, the statement could be released to creditors along with a restructuring plan.

Federal prosecutors on Monday accused the former chief financial officer of the military contractor Engineered Support Systems of backdating stock options without disclosing his actions and then making a false statement to investigators.

The former chief executive of Aspen Technology, a maker of software for oil and chemical companies, pleaded guilty Monday to federal charges that he lied to investors. The former chief, David L. McQuillin, 49, said that as chief operating officer of the company in 2001 and 2002, he entered into a secret side agreement with the Yukos Oil Company to help Aspen meet its revenue target.

Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, insisted on telling analysts the company could meet revenue targets that were later revised, an ex-finance chief testified on Monday.

Federal regulators censured the accounting firm Ernst & Young on Monday and ordered it to pay $1.6 million to settle charges that it compromised its independence and contributed to faulty accounting by a client in 2001.

A media executive told federal jurors on Monday how the sale of a half-billion dollars in assets by the Hollinger International newspaper conglomerate was structured to funnel money to a Canadian holding company controlled by the media baron Conrad M. Black. Michael Reed, a former chief executive of Community Newspapers Holdings, which bought several community newspapers from Hollinger in 1999 and 2000, said Hollinger executives insisted on including money for the Canadian company.

The chances that E.On, the German energy company, could win its protracted takeover bid for the Spanish utility Endesa took a step forward Monday. Endesa's board recommended E.On's bid of 42.4 billion euros ($56.3 billion) to its shareholders and a bank agreed to give E.On control of nearly 10 percent of the shares.

Bertelsmann, the German media company that provided financial backing to Napster when it was an unauthorized file-sharing service, has agreed to settle with the last of the major record companies that sued it for copyright infringement.

Less than a year after buying a $300 million stake in Forbes, Elevation Partners may be itching to see some results. Elevation, a private equity firm co-founded by U2 frontman Bono, which took a minority stake in Forbes in August, is pushing the media company to find new ways to increase revenue, according to The New York Post.

In December, AT&T closed on an $86 billion acquisition of BellSouth, capping a string of multibillion-dollar takeover deals, and leaving the company ready and needing to compete through execution, not acquisition, The New York Times reported Tuesday.

It may look like chicken feed in this era of mammoth executive pay packages, but a combined $21 million in stock payouts to five top executives at American Airlines is looming large in labor talks with pilots still angry about pay concessions made four years ago.

David A. Stockman, a former congressman who served as President Ronald Reagan's first budget director, was indicted Monday on charges that include bank fraud, conspiracy and obstruction of justice for his role as chief executive of the auto-parts supplier Collins & Aikman.

The weak performance of the initial public offering of the wireless carrier Clearwire has many in the telecom industry wondering how another wireless start-up, Aruba Networks, will fare in its market debut.
David Nasaw has been named the winner of the $50,000 New-York Historical Society American Book Prize.
There is a lesson in the strangely bland performances of Jennifer Aniston and Courteney Cox as they reunite as enemies in the season finale of FX’s “Dirt.”
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

The retrial of William Hurwitz (the subject of my Findings column) began Monday looking like a rerun of the first trial as the prosecutor spouted familiar horror stories and waved the same red flags. But this is already looking like a tougher case for the prosecution.

The editor of the new "Yale Book of Quotations" has a nice eye for recent bits of pop flotsam, Dwight Garner writes in Sunday's Book Review. But what happened to the literary fiction (and nonfiction) of the last 25 years?
In Newark, heavy mortgage debt has led many first-time homebuyers to the edge of financial ruin.
At least 4 people were killed today in the northern Gaza Strip and more than 30 injured when a sewage system collapsed.
The Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Defense continue to have problems collecting and sharing medical data, hampering treatment for wounded soldiers, lawmakers said.
Selected responses to a previous question on commuting in the region.
As a result, the W.H.O. will be able to keep tracking the evolution of the virus there and designing vaccines against the latest mutant strains.
The Senate defeated by a 50 to 48 vote an attempt to erase an American troop withdrawal date from an Iraq spending bill.
A protester ran to the front of Westminster Abbey during a service on Tuesday commemorating the 200th anniversary of the abolition of the slave trade, shouting, “You should be ashamed!”
In the town that launched the career of Ian Paisley, residents voiced approval of a deal with Sinn Fein.
A firefighter and a 31-year-old woman were seriously injured today in a fire at an apartment building less than a block east of Lincoln Center.
Tony Snow has suffered a recurrence of cancer, and the disease has spread to his liver, the White House said.
Attackers killed a prominent member of an Iraqi tribe that had taken a stand against Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.
More than 30 were injured when a sewage system collapsed, flooding a village with waste water.
The decision to provide bullet-resistant vests to the city’s 4,500 auxiliary police officers comes after the gun deaths of two officers.
Prime Minster Tony Blair said the campaign to free 15 naval personnel could move into a “different phase.”
Michael Phelps broke the 200-meter freestyle world record, and three others were broken as well.
Voters overwhelmingly approved amendments to the country’s constitution despite opposition organizations calling for a boycott.
A day after guerrillas bombed a military air base, a pair of suspected rebel suicide bombers tried to drive a tractor loaded with explosives into an army camp in the country’s east.
The announcement came after three days of shuttle diplomacy by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.

A 25-year-old construction worker was electrocuted while working at McKinley Elementary School at 1 Colonnade Place shortly before 10 p.m. last night, the Newark Fire Department said. The worker was on a lift, putting in new windows at the school, when he somehow came into contact with current from a power line, said John Brown, a spokesman for the Fire Department. The man, who was not identified, was taken to University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the authorities said.

A detective was arrested yesterday and charged with raping his companion, the police said. Detective Michael Seward of the Police Department’s Brooklyn warrants squad was arrested in Manhattan shortly after 9 a.m., according to the police. They said that Detective Seward was accused of rape by his companion after the couple had a dispute.
Louisiana State advanced to its fourth consecutive women’s Final Four, succeeding in the tournament despite the absence of its former coach.

Rasheed Wallace forced overtime with a 60-foot shot at the buzzer last night, then added another important 3-pointer in the extra period to help the Detroit Pistons defeat the Denver Nuggets, 113-109.

A privately owned investment group based in London said yesterday that it was buying 47 buildings in East Harlem and seven condominium units in the East Village for $250 million — its first major property acquisition in the United States. The investor, the Dawnay, Day Group, said its management subsidiary would manage the properties, which include 1,137 apartments and 55 commercial units in East Harlem. Dawnay, Day operates in markets around the world, specializing in property investment and financial services. It owns or manages about $10 billion worth of properties.
The Knicks held a three-point lead with just over a minute to play, but lost it in dramatic — and controversial — fashion.

A British home builder, Taylor Woodrow, agreed to buy a rival, George Wimpey, for more than £2.5 billion ($4.9 billion) in stock to create a market leader in Britain and combine businesses in the United States. The deal will create Taylor Wimpey, with 51 percent of the company held by Woodrow shareholders and 49 percent by those of Wimpey. Taylor Wimpey intends to cut costs by £70 million a year by buying in bulk and by cutting jobs. George Wimpey’s chief executive, Peter Redfern, above, said that fewer than 700 jobs, less than 5 percent of the two company’s combined work force of about 14,000, would be cut. Most of the job losses would be in Britain, he added. In the United States, Taylor Wimpey will combine the two companies’ operations in Florida, Arizona, Texas and California. Stock in both companies rose in response to the agreement.

Alcatel-Lucent, the telecommunications equipment maker, signed a $6 billion contract with Verizon Wireless, the telecommunications service provider, to help the company expand its network and offer new services. The three-year deal calls for Alcatel-Lucent to supply equipment, software and additional services for improvements at Verizon Wireless, which is a joint venture between Verizon Communications and the Vodafone Group, based in Basking Ridge, N.J. Work by Alcatel-Lucent, which is based in Paris, will allow Verizon Wireless to increase the coverage and capacity of its high-speed network and introduce services like voice-over-Internet protocol and mobile video telephony, the companies said.

CCMP Capital Asia and a unit of the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan agreed to buy the Yellow Pages unit of the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand for 2.24 billion New Zealand dollars ($1.6 billion). CCMP Asia, a buyout firm spun off from JPMorgan Chase, and Teachers’ Private Capital will pay 2.17 billion New Zealand dollars in cash for the print and online directories, Telecom New Zealand said. Telecom New Zealand also expects to get 75 million New Zealand dollars from the unit’s debtors, and plans to use income from the sale to return capital to shareholders, it said.

The deadline for Microsoft to reply to a new charge sheet brought by the European Commission has been extended to April 23 from April 3, a spokesman for the European Union said. The extension, granted at Microsoft’s request, was made by the hearing officer dealing with the case, the spokesman said. The commission has charged that Microsoft was unjustified in seeking payment from rivals for interoperability information so that their servers would work properly with its products.

Speculation that Carrefour, the French retailer, was headed for a takeover were dashed late Friday, setting off a sharp decline in the company’s share price yesterday. Takeover speculation ended when Bernard Arnault, a French investor, and Colony Capital, an American investment firm, said they would not acquire more than 20 percent of Carrefour until June 30, 2008, unless Carrefour’s largest shareholder, the Halley family, decided to sell its 13 percent stake or a new shareholder bought more than 5 percent of the company. Speculation that a takeover was imminent had swirled around the company since last month when Colony Capital and Mr. Arnault, together with a hedge fund, bought a 9.8 percent stake. Stock in Carrefour, which is based in Paris, fell 1.19 euros, or 2 percent, to 54.22 euros a share.
The Scarlet Knights have steamrolled past some of the best teams in the country in the postseason, from Connecticut to Duke and now Arizona State.

Four times since December, women have told the police about a frightening crime at the No. 7 subway line’s Fifth Avenue station: a man riding between cars grabbed their purses as the train pulled away, sometimes yanking the victims to the ground.
Teams assigned to make sure foreigners leave after being ordered out of the United States cannot accurately account for the whereabouts of those classified as “fugitive aliens,” the government said.

Gov. Timothy M. Kaine, a Democrat who objects to the death penalty, vetoed five bills that would have expanded the crimes punishable by death in Virginia. The bills would have made it a capital crime to kill judges or witnesses to influence a judicial outcome, and to arrange a murder-for-hire. Mr. Kaine noted that Virginia was second only to Texas in the number of executions it had carried out. The Republican-dominated General Assembly passed the five measures with sufficient votes to override the vetoes and will have the chance to do so in its one-day reconvened session on April 4.

Two men were convicted of murder in a subway shooting that injured a pregnant woman and prompted the emergency delivery, and later the death, of her baby. The men, Andre Green, 22, and Chimezie Akara, 23, were charged with killing the baby of Hawa Barry, an immigrant from Guinea who was shot as she rode a Boston subway train in February 2003. Her baby, a boy, died 45 minutes after emergency delivery, said Jake Wark, a spokesman for District Attorney Daniel F. Conley of Suffolk County. The baby was considered a “viable infant” under Massachusetts law. The men will be sentenced today. The murder convictions carry a mandatory sentence of life in prison without parole.

Federal investigators found “flagrant violations” at a Pennsylvania mine where a worker died last year in a methane gas explosion, the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration said. The R&D Coal Company did not ensure adequate ventilation, safe blasting practices or proper preshift safety checks at the mine, Buck Mountain Slope, directly contributing to the Oct. 23 death of Dale Reightler, 43, a veteran miner, federal officials said. The miners conducting the blasting that day were not qualified to handle explosives and set them off before other miners could get to a safe area, investigators found. State regulators have revoked R&D’s permit to operate the Buck Mountain site, in Schuylkill County about 80 miles northwest of Philadelphia. R&D officers did not respond to requests for comment.

An American border inspector was sentenced to nearly six years in prison for taking money and cars from smugglers, allowing them to shuttle illegal immigrants from Mexico into the United States. The inspector, Richard Elizalda, a 10-year veteran of Customs and Border Protection, worked at the San Ysidro Port of Entry between Tijuana, Mexico, and San Diego. Investigators said Mr. Elizalda sent text messages directing smugglers to his inspection lane, then waved their vehicles through. In return, he received as much as $1,000 for each immigrant, totaling $120,000 in cash starting in 2004. Mr. Elizalda was arrested in June. Agents seized $36,170 in cash from his home, along with a Lexus and a BMW given to him by the smuggling ringleaders. He pleaded guilty and had already paid a $20,000 fine.

A listing with a film review in Weekend on Friday about “The Prisoner or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair” misstated its opening dates for five cities. It opens in Austin, Tex.; Cambridge, Mass.; Chicago; and San Francisco this coming Friday, and in Los Angeles on April 6. It did in fact open in New York and Washington last Friday, but not in the other five cities.

An article on March 18 about flight delays at John F. Kennedy International Airport caused by a winter storm gave an erroneous name in some copies for an airline whose flight to Zurich was delayed. (The Practical Traveler column in the Travel section on March 18, about ways to cut the cost of flying to Africa, gave another rendering of the name.) It is Swiss International Air Lines, known as Swiss; it is not SwissAir or Swiss Air. (Swissair, the former national airline of Switzerland, went bankrupt in 2001.).

A picture in some copies with an art review in Weekend on Friday about “Van Gogh and Expressionism,” at the Neue Galerie, was published in error. It showed “The Rice Portrait of Jane Austen,” which accompanied the “Inside Art” column.

An architecture review on Thursday about Frank Gehry’s IAC headquarters building along the West Side Highway in Chelsea misspelled the name of the German city that is the site of his Vitra Design Museum, which the IAC building was said to bring to mind. It is Weil am Rhein, not Weil am Reim.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a plan by The New York Times Company to increase its dividend misstated the year that the company started its current dual-class share structure. It was 1957 — not 1969, the year the company went public. The article also misstated the procedure for changing the dual-class structure. A change can occur only with the approval of the Ochs-Sulzberger family trust, which controls the Times Company; it cannot be made by the company.

An article yesterday about deterioration in Chicago’s elevated train system misstated the timing of expansion work on the Brown Line. The work on the $529.9 million expansion began in 2004; it is not set to begin next month. (Some track closures and other construction are planned for next month.).

An article on Sunday about the election in Hong Kong gave the incorrect number of votes in some copies won by the incumbent chief executive, Donald Tsang. He received 649 votes from electors, not 645. The article also referred incorrectly to the vote in some copies. It was the first contested election for chief executive since the territory’s return to China in 1997; it was not the first contested election ever held in Hong Kong.

An article last Tuesday about efforts by Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark, to unseat state legislators who he says are blocking his agenda misstated the given name and title in some copies for a New Jersey Senate candidate he is backing, and incorrectly attributed a potential distinction to her. She is Teresa Ruiz, not Theresa, and she is deputy chief of staff to the Essex County executive, not chief of staff. If elected, she would be the first Hispanic woman in the New Jersey Senate — not the first Hispanic. (The first was Robert Menendez, now a United States senator.) The article also referred imprecisely to the 29th Legislative District. It includes all of Hillside Township, not just a slice of it.

An obituary last Tuesday about Raymond D. Nasher, a collector of Modern and contemporary sculpture who founded a Dallas museum to exhibit it, omitted his survivors. They include his daughters, Andrea Nasher, Joanie Nasher and Nancy Nasher Haemisegger, and three grandchildren.
Corrections: For the Record

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about Elizabeth Edwards and her cancer diagnosis gave an incorrect description in some copies for the cancer that afflicted Tony Snow, the White House spokesman, who expressed support for Mrs. Edwards. He had colon cancer, not prostate cancer.

Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about order being restored in parts of Kazakhstan after fighting between ethnic groups misidentified the country’s capital. It is Astana — not Almaty, which was the capital until 1997.
Lawyers for the Bloomberg administration are defending Con Ed’s decision not to shut down the electrical network that failed in western Queens last July.
baseball.
Of the major leaguers suspended for violating baseball’s performance-enhancing drug policy, few received the attention that Guillermo Mota did.

A hearing on a motion to dismiss the Onondaga Nation’s land claim has been adjourned for three months to give the Onondagas more time to persuade the United States Justice Department to join in the lawsuit, The Post-Standard of Syracuse reported. The Onondagas have asked the court to declare that New York illegally acquired roughly 4,000 square miles in five treaties from 1788 to 1822. Although they are not seeking evictions, the Onondagas want legal title to a swath of upstate New York, including most or all of the cities of Syracuse, Oswego, Fulton, Watertown, Cortland and Binghamton.

A Whitestone man was indicted yesterday on charges of trying to burglarize the home of a police union leader, prosecutors said. The man, Anthony Joseph Genovese, 40, was accused of attempted burglary, possession of burglary tools and other charges, the Queens district attorney’s office said. Prosecutors said Mr. Genovese was arrested after he pounded on the door of the home of Patrick J. Lynch, president of the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association, on Jan. 16 and tried to talk his way into the house. Mr. Genovese’s lawyer, Randall Unger, said: “I don’t think the attempted burglary charge is appropriate. I think when the case is established it will show he is not guilty of that charge.”.

A retired Jersey City police officer fatally shot himself yesterday inside a city police building, city officials said. The police said that the shooting was accidental and that the retired officer was cleaning his weapon at the time. The man was identified as Robert J. McGillis Jr., 53, who left the Police Department in 2000 and was rehired last year as a consultant for the K-9 unit.

A cruise line and the captain of a boat that capsized on Lake George in 2005, killing 20 elderly tourists, pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor charge. The cruise line, Shoreline Cruises, and the captain, Richard Paris, pleaded guilty in Warren County Court to failing to have the required number of crew members aboard the Ethan Allen tour boat when it flipped over on Oct. 2, 2005, throwing passengers into the lake. Captain Paris was the only crew member aboard, and navigation regulations required two crew members for the 47 passengers. Judge John S. Hall Jr. imposed fines of $250 each on Captain Paris and the company.

Wesley Autrey Sr., the construction worker who leapt to the subway tracks at West 137th Street in January to save the life of a stranger, has filed a lawsuit charging that a lawyer and a man who represented himself as an entertainment executive tricked him into signing an “unconscionable” contract allowing them to exploit his name and personality. In papers filed last week in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, his current lawyer, Barbara S. Mehlsack, charges that Diane L. Kleiman, a lawyer, and Mark Anthony, also known as Mark Anthony Esposito, injured Mr. Autrey’s reputation by, among other things, pressuring a school to pay him a speaker’s fee and demanding expenses from a magazine reporter as a condition for access to Mr. Autrey. The lawsuit seeks damages and the voiding of the contract. Ms. Kleiman did not return a message left on her telephone answering machine yesterday, and a phone number for Mr. Anthony could not be found.

A 24-year-old man who worked as an undercover operative for the Drug Enforcement Administration was convicted of armed robbery by a State Supreme Court jury last week, even though he claimed to have been on duty for the federal agency at the time of his arrest. The man, Juan Medina, who had helped the drug agency recover a discarded gun used in a crime and had led agents to a heroin operation, had been working for the agency for about two months when he and several others participated in a home invasion robbery in the Bronx in November 2004. Mr. Medina, who faces a 25-year prison sentence, told the police that he had infiltrated a drug gang and had tried to stop the robbery. He said he had informed a federal agent about the robbery before it occurred. But at Mr. Medina’s trial, the agent testified that Mr. Medina had not spoken to him about the crime.

A Continental Airlines flight from Hong Kong was held on the tarmac at Newark Liberty International Airport for nearly three hours yesterday while representatives of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention interviewed passengers with flulike symptoms. Karen Hunter, a spokeswoman for the agency, said seven passengers showed signs of fever and reported vomiting before Flight 98 took off. During the 14-hour flight, several more passengers, members of a Canada-based travel group, showed signs of illness. After the flight landed, an expert in contagious diseases determined that the passengers probably had a routine virus and were not infected with the avian flu, Ms. Hunter said. All of the 272 passengers on board were allowed to debark and continue their travels.
A 20-year-old division of labor between yellow medallion cabs and for-hire vehicles may become murky as development and growth penetrate the city.

A federal judge refused yesterday to reissue his order preventing disclosure of police documents about surveillance leading up to the 2004 Republican convention in New York City, saying the existing ruling to keep them secret still stands.
Life magazine will cease publication next month, the third time since Life’s founding in 1936 that its owner has pulled the plug.
The Supreme Court agreed to undertake its latest effort to define the permissible boundary between free speech and the government’s prohibition of child pornography.
At a coffee shop that showcases local artists, the works of two preschoolers are causing a sensation.
N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said that fighting was part of hockey and that some people had been “running off a little too fast on this topic.”
The move is part of a broad effort to cut costs and streamline the bank’s unwieldy global operations.
David Hicks, an Australian trained by Al Qaeda, is the first Guantánamo detainee to be convicted before a military commission.
A Pentagon investigation found no criminal wrongdoing in the shooting of Cpl. Pat Tillman but found that Army officers violated regulations by failing to disclose details of his death promptly.
Many heart patients routinely implanted with stents to open arteries gain no lasting benefit compared to those treated with drugs.
The outcome means Quebec will avoid another divisive referendum on whether the French-speaking province should separate from the rest of Canada.
Commissioner Roger Goodell said repeat offenders could face one-year suspensions and teams could face fines and the loss of draft picks.

Thousands of political opposition members rallied peacefully across Pakistan to denounce President Pervez Musharraf’s suspension of Chief Justice Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry. Around 2,000 protested in Lahore and 3,000 in Karachi. Leaders termed the turnout a success after the arrests of hundreds of opposition members over the weekend.

Prosecutors charged Pojaman Shinawatra, the wife of the deposed billionaire prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, and her brother and secretary with tax evasion. It is the first prosecution of a member of Mr. Thaksin’s family since the Sept. 19 coup. Analysts said the military government was trying to paint a picture of a family enmeshed in corruption, a justification for the coup. Mrs. Pojaman was arraigned in a Bangkok court. Her trial is to begin May 14.
As expected, Nicolas Sarkozy stepped down as interior minister to devote himself to his campaign for president. He was replaced by François Baroin, the minister for overseas territories.
The former chief of Qwest Communications insisted on telling analysts the company could meet revenue targets that were later revised, an ex-finance chief testified.

Some 800 tribal elders in northwest Bajaur pledged not to give shelter to anyone suspected of terrorist activity. The promise is a bid to bring peace to the tribal region near the Afghan border, where a strike by an American Predator drone in January 2006 came close to killing Al Qaeda’s second in command, Ayman al-Zawahri, and did kill 18 others. Last October, an airstrike by Pakistani forces on a religious school in the district reportedly killed 83 people. Similar promises made by tribal leaders in North and South Waziristan have been criticized because, in exchange, the government agreed to pull out troops. The Bajaur pledge comes with no such agreement by the government.

Sidi Ould Cheikh Abdallahi, left, a government minister in the 1970s, beat a longtime opposition politician, Ahmed Ould Daddah, 53 percent to 47 percent, in a runoff election for president Sunday. Mr. Abdallahi’s installation on April 19 will mark the first time that leadership will change hands as a result of an election. Mauritania has been plagued by coups and dictators since independence from France in 1960. It is currently ruled by a junta that seized power in 2005. The international community at first denounced the takeover but has since praised the junta leader, Col. Ely Ould Mohamed Vall, for increasing freedoms. Colonel Vall organized the election and refused to run, also banning any member of the ruling group from participating.

Prosecutors in Ankara are investigating whether Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan once referred to Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader, by the honorific “Sayin,” or esteemed, the Anatolian News Agency reported. Praising a criminal or criminal organization in Turkey is itself a crime. According to reports, Mr. Erdogan referred to Mr. Ocalan by the honorific in an Australian radio interview in 2000.

In response to a clinical trial at a London hospital last year in which six men nearly died, the European Medicines Agency proposed new guidelines for European Union researchers to take for high-risk medicines being tested for the first time in humans. The men signed up to receive TGN1412, an immune stimulant from a small German concern, and rapidly suffered multiple organ failure, requiring weeks in intensive care. The reaction had not been predicted from animal experiments. Under the guidelines, new high-risk drugs should be given to one volunteer at a time, allowing intervals to check for reactions. They also suggest that monitoring extend long after the initial experiment. In addition, British researchers have questioned conventional animal models, especially for immune molecules or long-acting medicines.
A mechanism rigged to fire tiny darts into the bellies of horses was found buried in the turf at the Happy Valley Racecourse.
Officials plan to introduce modifications to a law that restricts former Baathists from holding government jobs.
The former budget director for President Ronald Reagan was indicted on charges that he covered up the dire financial state at Collins & Aikman, the auto parts supplier he ran.
Monica Goodling invoked her right to refuse to testify in the investigation of the removal of eight U.S. attorneys.
CBS will bring back the former president of its radio division, Dan Mason, to succeed Joel Hollander as head of the 144-station group.
An audit showed that the museum had provided lavish perks such as chauffeurs and private jets to its top official.

10 P.M. (A&E) DRIVING FORCE The family that races together stays together. That’s according to John Force, who brought his three daughters — Ashley, now 24; Brittany, 20; and Courtney, 18 — into the family drag-racing business, having missed out on much of their childhoods. Tonight the Forces prepare to burn rubber in a second season of this reality series. TRAVEL COST MORE IN 2006 Average one-way domestic air fares paid by corporations, which dropped to a six-year low in 2005, rose last year to $231, the American Express Business Travel Monitor reported. Average one-way international fares continued a four-year climb, to $1,707, and average international daily hotel rates rose for the fifth consecutive year, to $230. Average daily car rental rates crept up again, to $69. Corporate pressure on business travelers to comply with booking policies held down the rate of increases, said Mike Streit, vice president of American Express Business Travel Advisory Services. The average air fare rates were calculated from hundreds of domestic and international routes negotiated for corporate clients by American Express, from discount coach to first class. The average rate for car rentals includes fuel, taxes and other charges. Among domestic hotels, average nightly rates rose most sharply in the cheapest niche, the budget category, to $179 in the fourth quarter of 2006 from $150 in the comparable 2005 quarter.

KEESING--Gustaaf, D.D.S., of Rye, NY, passed away on March 25, 2007, surrounded by his wife and family. Born in Amsterdam, the Netherlands in 1913, 50-year resident of Scarsdale, NY, he received his dental degrees from both the University of Utrecht in the Netherlands, as well as the University of Pennsylvania. He is survived by his cherished childhood neighbor and adoring wife of 67 years, Aleida van Tijn, his loving children Bette Sparago and Andrew (Linda), grandsons Daniel and Jeffrey Keesing, and his sister Henrietta van Voolen. His passions, beyond his devotion to his family, included his international dental practice, where his fluency in several foreign languages, enabled him to care for dignitaries from foreign governments and the United Nations during and after World War II. As a lover of the arts, he traveled the world, sharing his interests with his wife and family always at his side. Private funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the American Lung Association, 61 Broadway, NY, NY 10006.

Services and interment were held in Detroit and handled by The Ira Kaufman Chapel (800)325-7105 www.irakaufman.com

To the Editor: Re ''Snowflakes as Big as Frisbees? Could Be '' (March 20): The article on large snowflakes described reports of ''big ones the size of saucers,'' with ''their heaviness making them descend faster than small flakes,'' and said those reports were sketchy and fleeting. I'll bet they were. Galileo, some 400 years ago, established that a body falls at a rate, and accelerates at a rate, that is not affected by its weight. One would also suppose that a large snowflake would have more air resistance than a smaller one. Not a good science lesson from Science Times! Leonard M. Leiman New York

EDELSTEIN--Edith, died peacefully surrounded by her family after a long illness. Loved and loving wife of the late Leo, adored and adoring mother of Rhonda Harrison (Dr. Aaron) and Dr. Barbara Edelstein (Dr. Kenneth Goldman), and amazing grandmother of Jonathan and Alison Goldman and David and Brett Harrison. We love you and will miss you every day; but are so lucky to have had you for so long. Funeral services at Riverside NYC, Tuesday, March 27, 12:45 pm.

To the Editor: Re ''Scientist Finds the Beginnings of Morality in Primate Behavior '' (March 20): Nicholas Wade's article expands on whether the roots and reasons for ethical conduct ought to be sought in theology or biology. But why are these seen as a dichotomy?

Q. Is it true that needle biopsies leak lung cancer cells into the bloodstream, spreading cancer throughout the body? A. ''With any biopsy of any organ, you do loosen some cells, and some do get into the bloodstream, but very rarely do they stick and implant,'' said Dr. David F. Yankelevitz, professor of radiology at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital in New York. There is a very low incidence of tumors forming along the track of the needle, he said.

CAMPS--Helen Place of Rye, New York, passed away peacefully on March 25, 2007. Beloved wife and partner for 58 years of Lowell Crocker Camps. Her memory will be held forever in the hearts of daughter Linda Louise Camps of Greenwich, CT, son Jeffery Lowell Camps, his wife Judi of Larchmont, NY and her son Christopher Lowell Camps and his wife Loren of Katonah, NY. As ''Nana'' to her grandchildren Ashley, Jackson, Brooke and Hunter, they will always know they were the joy of her heart. A true renaissance woman, Helen was a club champion golfer and tennis player and as accomplished in the outdoors fishing as she was in creating her oil paintings and crafts. She made everyday special and the lives of her family and countless friends a little more complete. Her selfless love and sense of family will be our sense of purpose and memories of time with her cherished by all. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 29, 2007 at 10:30 am at the Rye Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York 10580. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church Memorial Fund in her memory.

To the Editor: Re ''Rise of a Deadly TB Reveals a Global System in Crisis '' (March 20): The spread of extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB), as reported by Dr. Lawrence K. Altman, is a man-made tragedy. It cannot be attributed just to the limitations of frail or faltering national health care systems, but to the world's failure to develop and make available easy and effective TB treatment. Progress in developing new diagnostics, vaccines and drugs for TB is being galvanized by public-private partnerships supported by some philanthropies and governments, but eliminating all forms of TB demands the combined efforts of governments and research, pharmaceutical and health care communities worldwide.

Daughter of Mayer and Rose Roth; sister of the late Charles; beloved wife of the late William; loving mother of Errol and Paula, David and Carol, and Michael and Sophie; proud grandmother of the late Bradley, Lori and Gregg, Michelle and Jonas, Kristen, Kimberly and Eric; and great-grandmother of Emma, Aaron, Chase, Bella, Layla, Milo and Gabriella. One strong lady who lived a full life. She was loved and will be truly missed...

To the Editor: ''Knight of the Living Dead,'' by Slavoj Zizek (Op-Ed, March 24), is an ominous reminder of how far America has drifted from its core values thanks to the exploitation of fear by the Bush administration. The officially sanctioned torture of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and the suspension of civil liberties are a permanent blight on the nation's moral character. We have already lost the ''war on terror'' since we have allowed ourselves to be deprived of our most important assets: our morality and respect for the rule of rational and civilized behavior.
