PARKER--Keith E., importer and seller of art works, passed away peacefully at Cabrini Hospice on March 20, after much suffering. He is survived by his partner of 20 years, Brian Richardson. He was born in Perth, Western Australia, to Ernest (deceased) and Peggy Parker and had six siblings, Ray, Maree, Julie, Jenny, Greg and Dennis. He is survived by a large extended family. His life was celebrated at a gathering of family and friends at their home on March 25. He was an inspiration to us all in his battle and will be greatly missed by all his family and friends. We will remember him always.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 North Ireland Rivals Agree To a Date for Joint Rule After years of hostility and recriminations, the leaders of Northern Ireland's dominant rival groups, Gerry Adams of Sinn Fein and the Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley, held their first face-to-face talks and agreed to form a joint administration for the province on May 8. A1 Baath Party Law to Be Changed Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki's office announced that he and President Jalal Talabani would introduce a modification of the law that sharply restricts former members of the Baath Party of Saddam Hussein from holding government jobs or receiving government pensions. A10 Darfur Relief Effort Threatened Bureaucracy and violence are threatening the humanitarian effort in Darfur. A United Nations official was temporarily denied access to a refugee camp, despite assurances from the Sudanese government that he would be unimpeded. Aid workers face the same obstacles every day, he said, and ''if there were one big incident, the humanitarian effort could collapse.'' A8 Iran-Britain Standoff Continues The stalemate over the 15 British naval personnel seized by Iranian forces north of the Persian Gulf last week continued, with Britain repeating its demands for their immediate release and Iran refusing to say where exactly they were being held or what would happen to them. A10 NATIONAL A12-17 Detainee Pleads Guilty To Aiding Terrorism In the first conviction of a Guantánamo detainee in a military commission, an Australian onetime Qaeda trainee pleaded guilty to providing material support to a terrorist organization. A1 No Benefits in Using Stents Researchers reported that many heart patients implanted with stents to open arteries gain no lasting benefit compared with those treated with drugs alone, despite an improvement in blood flow to the heart. A1 Smithsonian Chief Resigns The governing board of the Smithsonian Institution announced that it had accepted the resignation of its top official, Lawrence M. Small, after an internal audit showing that the museum complex had paid for his routine use of lavish perks like private jets, top-rated hotels and catered meals. A12 Army Misled Tillman Family Army officers violated regulations and misled family members by failing to disclose promptly in 2004 that Cpl. Pat Tillman was killed by his fellow soldiers, according to a Pentagon investigation that recommended the Army take action against the officers. A15 Gonzales Aide Won't Testify An aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales invoked her constitutional right to refuse to testify before a Senate panel investigating the removal of eight United States attorneys, her lawyer said. A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Brooke Astor's Estate Totals $131 Million A 12-page inventory of Brooke Astor's assets and finances, conducted by an accounting firm for the permanent guardians of her property, provides the most up-to-date picture of the socialite and philanthropist's $131 million fortune, one of New York's most legendary. B1 Police Focus on Subway Crimes The New York police, to combat subway crimes, are increasing their focus on people who ride or walk between the cars of a train. B3 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Shake-Up at Citigroup Charles O. Prince III, Citigroup's chief executive, will reshuffle more than 26,000 jobs and shed 10,000 to 12,000 employees, according to people briefed on the situation. They see the potential to use the squishable, relatively simple creations to find land mines, repair machinery in hard-to-reach spots and even diagnose and treat diseases. A picture in some copies with an art review in Weekend on Friday about ''Van Gogh and Expressionism,'' at the Neue Galerie, was published in error. It showed ''The Rice Portrait of Jane Austen,'' which accompanied the ''Inside Art'' column.

An article on March 18 about flight delays at John F. Kennedy International Airport caused by a winter storm gave an erroneous name in some copies for an airline whose flight to Zurich was delayed. (The Practical Traveler column in the Travel section on March 18, about ways to cut the cost of flying to Africa, gave another rendering of the name.) It is Swiss International Air Lines, known as Swiss; it is not SwissAir or Swiss Air. (Swissair, the former national airline of Switzerland, went bankrupt in 2001.)

Busta Rhymes Faces Jail The rapper Busta Rhymes found himself facing trial and possible jail time on assault charges yesterday after Judge Tanya Kennedy, of Manhattan Criminal Court, citing his recent arrest for driving with a suspended license, withdrew an offer of probation, community service and lectures to troubled youths, The Associated Press reported. ''The court's offer is off the table,'' she said. Lawyers for Busta Rhymes, right, 34, whose real name is Trevor Smith, then rejected an offer by the prosecution of a year in jail on each of two counts of assault, to run concurrently, and a $500 fine on the suspended license charge. Although his lawyers declined comment as they left court, one of them, Robert Kalina, had said that his client had been prepared to accept the initial plea offer. Judge Kennedy set May 8 for the start of the trial. The rapper is accused of beating his former driver, Edward Hatchett, 39, on Dec. 26, and of assaulting a fan after a performance in August on Randalls Island. New Director Is Named To Edinburgh Fringe The Edinburgh Festival Fringe has a new director. He is Jon Morgan, currently the executive producer at the Contact Theater in Manchester, England, Theatre.com reported. On June 7, when the program for the 61st festival is announced, he will succeed Paul Gudgin, who announced in January that he would leave to produce a variety of projects in Britain and abroad. Before joining Contact in 2003, Mr. Morgan worked with prominent performing companies and with the Scottish Arts Council in an advisory capacity on drama and dance and on the establishment of the National Theater of Scotland. Last year's 60th anniversary Fringe, regarded as the most successful ever, sold more than 1.5 million tickets to more than 1,800 shows. This year's event runs from Aug. 5 to 27. Carnegie Biography Wins History Prize David Nasaw has been named the winner of the $50,000 New-York Historical Society American Book Prize for his biography, ''Andrew Carnegie'' (The Penguin Press). Mr. Nasaw, left, is the Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. Professor of History at the City University of New York Graduate Center. His book tells the rags-to-riches story of Carnegie, who became a steel baron and the richest man in the world before deciding to give away his fortune. In announcing the prize with Louise Mirrer, president and chief executive of the Historical Society, Roger Hertog, the board chairman, called the biography ''magisterial'' and said of Carnegie: ''He set himself the ultimate goal of donating all his wealth to society, and at the same time he became a devoted advocate of world peace. The example set by this extraordinary life is remarkably relevant to us today.'' Professor Nasaw will accept his prize and be named the society's American history laureate in ceremonies on April 27. Filmmaking Awards To Honor Slain Actress The Adrienne Shelly Foundation, created in memory of the actress, writer and director who was murdered last year in Greenwich Village, announced the establishment of its first major awards since it was set up in December to foster the careers of talented female filmmakers. The awards, named in Ms. Shelly's honor, will be bestowed by the American Film Institute's Directing Workshop for Women, the Columbia University School of the Fine Arts Film Division, New York Women in Film and Television, the Maurice Kanbar Institute of Film and Television at the New York University Tisch School of the Arts and Independent Feature Project. More Protests of Movie Ads A week after protests prompted After Dark Films to withdraw torture-themed advertising for its horror film ''Captivity,'' suicide-prevention groups were protesting its campaign for its comedy ''Wristcutters: A Love Story,'' which follows a group of suicides through purgatory, Reuters reported. The images will depict people jumping off a bridge, electrocuting and hanging themselves. Robert Gebbia, executive director of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, wrote in a letter to the film's backers, ''You don't see people making fun of other causes of death, but you see it with suicide and mental illness.'' But Courtney Solomon, co-owner of After Dark Films, said ''Wristcutters'' may even help prevent suicide: ''The movie takes place in purgatory, and its message is that love is better than suicide.'' Footnote Mary Wilson, below, of the Supremes has been booked to close the season at Feinstein's at the Regency with an engagement from June 9 to 30. She will perform the Supremes' greatest hits and selections from the Great American Songbook. Thousands of political opposition members rallied peacefully across Pakistan to denounce President Pervez Musharraf's suspension of Chief Justice Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry. Around 2,000 protested in Lahore and 3,000 in Karachi. Leaders termed the turnout a success after the arrests of hundreds of opposition members over the weekend. SALMAN MASOOD

HESCHEL--Sylvia. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School community mourns the passing of our esteemed Honorary President, Sylvia Heschel. Mrs. Heschel was deeply connected to and involved with us from our inception beginning with giving us permission to use her beloved husband's name for the school. Over the years, she was a constant guest at our Benefit dinners and, on occasion, we delighted in hearing her play the piano. She took great pleasure in seeing the school grow and enjoyed the visits of our students over the last year when she was ill. We extended our sincerest sympathy to her daughter, Dr. Susannah Heschel, and the entire family. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School Peter Geffen, Founder HESCHEL--Sylvia. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the passing of Sylvia Heschel, nee Strauss, wife of Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel, Professor of Jewish Ethics and Mysticism at JTS and one of the most significant theologians of the twentieth century. Sylvia's compassion, intellect, and musical talents will be sorely missed. She was her husband's close companion, friend, and much-beloved muse, supporting him as he produced his prolific and influential writings. The generosity and hospitality she displayed to JTS students and faculty over the years will long be remembered. May her daughter, Susannah, and the rest of the Heschel family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor-elect Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman HESCHEL--Sylvia, on March 26. Concert pianist and beloved wife of the late Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel. Mother of Susannah and husband Jacob Aronson. Grandmother of Gittel and Avigael. Sister of Jack, and the late Reuben and Morris Straus. Services Tuesday 10am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

A Continental Airlines flight from Hong Kong was held on the tarmac at Newark Liberty International Airport for nearly three hours yesterday while representatives of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention interviewed passengers with flulike symptoms. Karen Hunter, a spokeswoman for the agency, said seven passengers showed signs of fever and reported vomiting before Flight 98 took off. During the 14-hour flight, several more passengers, members of a Canada-based travel group, showed signs of illness. After the flight landed, an expert in contagious diseases determined that the passengers probably had a routine virus and were not infected with the avian flu, Ms. Hunter said. All of the 272 passengers on board were allowed to debark and continue their travels. JOHN HOLL

To the Editor: Re ''House, 218 to 212, Votes to Set Date for Iraq Pullout'' (front page, March 24): The House of Representatives has finally lived up to the mandate of the last election. President Bush's assertion that this is mere ''political theater'' implies that he believes that the 2006 election was a meaningless exercise in political theater as well.

What worries you most? Decaying teeth, thinning bones, heart disease, stroke, diabetes, dementia, cancer, obesity? Whatever tops your list, you may be surprised to know that all of these health problems are linked to the beverages you drink -- or don't drink. Last year, with the support of the Unilever Health Institute in the Netherlands (Unilever owns Lipton Tea), a panel of experts on nutrition and health published a ''Beverage Guidance System'' in hopes of getting people to stop drinking their calories when those calories contribute little or nothing to their health and may actually detract from it.

GELB--Mae. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., expresses its deepest sorrow at the passing of Mae Gelb, cherished mother of Bev Klein and Sondra Myers. Mae was the treasured grandmother of five, great-grandmother of nine, and great-great-grandmother of one. As a Guardian of the Dream, Mae was a generous benefactor of Hadassah, devoted to Israel and the Jewish people. Her legacy will live on through the programs she supported at the Hadassah Medical Organization, Young Judaea and Youth Aliyah. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to her loved ones. May her memory be for a blessing, and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. June Walker National President Morlie Levin National Executive Director
Presidential candidates top the list of senators who have missed the most number of votes this year. As of Friday, the Senate has held a total of 114 votes.

SLEPPIN-ITZKOWITZ-Estelle. 1 year ago today a very special person passed away. Estelle's exhuberance, smile and positive outlook was her trademark. A Woman whose strength & determination was infinite. Small in stature, yet larger than life. A lover of friends, family & life. Estelle touched the lives of so many and is missed by them all. In response to a clinical trial at a London hospital last year in which six men nearly died, the European Medicines Agency proposed new guidelines for European Union researchers to take for high-risk medicines being tested for the first time in humans. The men signed up to receive TGN1412, an immune stimulant from a small German concern, and rapidly suffered multiple organ failure, requiring weeks in intensive care. The reaction had not been predicted from animal experiments. Under the guidelines, new high-risk drugs should be given to one volunteer at a time, allowing intervals to check for reactions. They also suggest that monitoring extend long after the initial experiment. In addition, British researchers have questioned conventional animal models, especially for immune molecules or long-acting medicines. ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

ALLEY--Frederick. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) is deeply saddened by the passing of beloved colleague and friend Fred Alley. A former GNYHA Chairman and longtime President and CEO of The Brooklyn Hospital Center, Mr. Alley was a charismatic leader whose talent and kindness earned him the respect and admiration of countless peers both in New York and nationally. We send our heartfelt sympathies to his wife Sharon, children Kirk and Nicole, grandchildren Jack and Tessa, his extended family, and his many friends and colleagues. Kenneth L. Davis, M.D. Chairman, GNYHA Kenneth E. Raske President, GNYHA ALLEY--Frederick, 66, of Sharon, CT, and New York City, passed away on Saturday, March 24th, 2007. Born in Detroit, Fred attended Ferris State University and received his graduate degree from Columbia University. After beginning his long career in health care management at Hackensack Hospital, Fred joined The Brooklyn Hospital Center, where he spent 34 years and was the longtime President and CEO. He served as Chairman of both the Greater New York Hospital Association and the Healthcare Association of New York State, and as a member of the Board of Directors of the American Hospital Association (AHA). Fred was also Chairman of the AHA's Regional Policy Board; founding director and first Chairman of HealthFirst, Inc; Director and past Chairman of the Board of Voluntary Hospitals of America, Metro New York, Inc.; and founder and past Chairman and Director of Combined Coordination Council, LTD. He published numerous articles, working papers and perspectives on a variety of health care-related topics including his efforts on behalf of the King's Fund, an organization of health care executives from Great Britain, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the United States. Fred's writings focused on increased competition in the health marketplace, future challenges in health care financing and delivery, the development of integrated delivery systems, and the state of health care in Brooklyn. He held academic appointments at Columbia University's School of Public Health and Administrative Medicine and at the Arnold and Marie Schwartz College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences of Long Island University. Fred's distinguished career was balanced by a deep commitment to his family, a passion for the outdoors, and various philanthropic pursuits. He is survived by his wife Sharon; son Kirk and his wife Kathy; daughter Nicole and her husband Albert; sister Bette and her husband Bill; and grandchildren Jack and Tessa. A memorial service at the New York Athletic Club in Manhattan will be held at a later date. Donations can be made in Fred's memory to the American Heart Association and Ruffed Grouse Society.

An article on Sunday about the election in Hong Kong gave the incorrect number of votes in some copies won by the incumbent chief executive, Donald Tsang. He received 649 votes from electors, not 645. The article also referred incorrectly to the vote in some copies. It was the first contested election for chief executive since the territory's return to China in 1997; it was not the first contested election ever held in Hong Kong.

The smattering of bald heads in the crowd of 300 at the City Club in Cleveland was the most visible sign that Elizabeth Edwards's campaign appearances might be unlike any before in American politics: more support group than stump speech. It was her first solo campaign appearance since she and her husband, John Edwards, announced Thursday that her cancer had come back, and she and the cancer patients in the audience yesterday agreed that the nation would benefit from a public conversation about mortality. They shared tips for not crying in front of the children and joked that there was no such thing as a bad hair day when you were bald. And many nodded knowingly when Mrs. Edwards spoke of the surreal balancing act of undergoing cancer treatment at the same time as ''soccer practice, a brief that has to be filed and buying pantyhose.''

To the Editor: Re ''Play About Iraq War Divides a Connecticut School'' (news article, March 24): Wilton, Conn., where I lived in the 1960s, was the inspiration for Stepford, the fictional town I later wrote about in ''The Stepford Wives.''

HATKOFF--Doris. The Board of Directors, staff, children and families of Northside Center for Child Development, Inc. mourn the loss of Mrs. Doris Hatkoff. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to our extraordinary Chairman of the Board, Susan Patricof, and the entire Patricof and Hatkoff family as we come together to remember Mrs. Hatkoff's remarkable life and spirit.

To The Editor: Re ''An Operation That Made Everything Clear http://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/20/health/20brody.html Read the Article.'' (Personal Health, March 20): As a new recipient of cataract surgery for both eyes, my most exhilarating moment after each surgery was the flood of brilliant color that had been missing from my vision for several years. It remains a breathtaking experience each day. The whole world seems, despite torrents of bad news, brighter and more beautiful than ever. Could this kind of eye-opening surgery help our political leaders? I would think so. Waddell Robey Camp Hill, Penn.

Prosecutors charged Pojaman Shinawatra, the wife of the deposed billionaire prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, and her brother and secretary with tax evasion. It is the first prosecution of a member of Mr. Thaksin's family since the Sept. 19 coup. Analysts said the military government was trying to paint a picture of a family enmeshed in corruption, a justification for the coup. Mrs. Pojaman was arraigned in a Bangkok court. Her trial is to begin May 14. THOMAS FULLER

To the Editor: Re ''Film's View of Islam Stirs Anger on Campuses'' (Arts pages, Feb. 26): Your article suggests that some feel that our documentary about the threat of radical Islam could ''spur hate crimes against Muslim students.'' We reject this notion.

A listing with a film review in Weekend on Friday about ''The Prisoner or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair'' misstated its opening dates for five cities. It opens in Austin, Tex.; Cambridge, Mass.; Chicago; and San Francisco this coming Friday, and in Los Angeles on April 6. It did in fact open in New York and Washington last Friday, but not in the other five cities.

A detective was arrested yesterday and charged with raping his companion, the police said. Detective Michael Seward of the Police Department's Brooklyn warrants squad was arrested in Manhattan shortly after 9 a.m., according to the police. They said that Detective Seward was accused of rape by his companion after the couple had a dispute. JENNIFER 8. LEE

An article on March 18 about flight delays at John F. Kennedy International Airport caused by a winter storm gave an erroneous name in some copies for an airline whose flight to Zurich was delayed. (The Practical Traveler column in the Travel section on March 18, about ways to cut the cost of flying to Africa, gave another rendering of the name.) It is Swiss International Air Lines, known as Swiss; it is not SwissAir or Swiss Air. (Swissair, the former national airline of Switzerland, went bankrupt in 2001.)

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a plan by The New York Times Company to increase its dividend misstated the year that the company started its current dual-class share structure. It was 1957 -- not 1969, the year the company went public. The article also misstated the procedure for changing the dual-class structure. A change can occur only with the approval of the Ochs-Sulzberger family trust, which controls the Times Company; it cannot be made by the company.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will not know until the night of the Iowa caucuses whether the backing of Tom and Christie Vilsack, the state's former governor and first lady, who formally announced yesterday that they were endorsing her for president, has paid off. But Mr. Vilsack could reap benefits sooner. Before ending his Democratic presidential bid on Feb. 23, Mr. Vilsack had accumulated a debt of about $430,000. The Clinton campaign has agreed to help erase at least some of that. A fund-raising appeal on his behalf could be landing in mailboxes of the senator's donors soon.

THE COLES GROUP, a large Australian retail conglomerate, has put itself up for sale, but it has put limitations on the size and composition of the private equity consortiums it will allow to bid. TIM JOHNSTON

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about Elizabeth Edwards and her cancer diagnosis gave an incorrect description in some copies for the cancer that afflicted Tony Snow, the White House spokesman, who expressed support for Mrs. Edwards. He had colon cancer, not prostate cancer.

Prosecutors in Ankara are investigating whether Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan once referred to Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader, by the honorific ''Sayin,'' or esteemed, the Anatolian News Agency reported. Praising a criminal or criminal organization in Turkey is itself a crime. According to reports, Mr. Erdogan referred to Mr. Ocalan by the honorific in an Australian radio interview in 2000. SEBNEM ARSU

As ''King of the Hill'' returned to Fox's lineup Sunday with just its fourth episode of the season, the network led the night among the younger viewers highly prized by advertisers. According to Nielsen's estimates, the 10-year-old animated series attracted 6 million total viewers at 8:30 p.m., wedged between ''The Simpsons'' at 8 (6.9 million) and ''Family Guy'' at 9 (8 million). Although Fox posted a fourth-place finish in total viewers, it was first among adults 18 to 34. Meanwhile, in the 18-to-49 demographic, CBS outstripped Fox for first place. Because of a significant overrun of CBS's live coverage of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament in the afternoon, Nielsen's preliminary estimates for its prime-time lineup were unreliable, but the network's overall margin of victory appeared conclusive. ABC's ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' won the 8 p.m. hour with 12 million viewers, but it was followed by low-rated repeats of ''Desperate Housewives'' at 9 (6.5 million) and ''Brothers & Sisters'' at 10 (4.3 million). ABC finished third for the night among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

She was the perfect partner to Seymour for over 60 years as he pursued various careers, last as Executive Director of the American Friends of the Hebrew University. The family will receive friends at Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, Aventura, Florida, Sunday, April 1, between 1:00 and 4:00 pm. For information call 1-800-327-9192. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions to Macular Degeneration Research Fund c/o Susan Ervin, Bascom Palmer Eye Institute, 900 NW 17th St., Miami, FL 33136, or American Friends of the Hebrew University, 1 Battery Park Plaza, 25th Floor, New York, NY 10004. Share your memories and condolences at: sfishman@fishmangroup .com

With former Senator Fred Thompson pondering a bid for the Republican presidential nomination, the hunt is on to see if he has his conservative credentials in order or whether there might be some moderation lurking in his voting past. Mr. Thompson, the Tennessee lawyer turned actor turned senator turned actor again, is getting a lot of attention in Republican circles. That is especially so among conservatives, who are debating whether he would be more ideologically appealing to them than the three leading Republican candidates, Senator John McCain of Arizona, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York and former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts.

A 25-year-old construction worker was electrocuted while working at McKinley Elementary School at 1 Colonnade Place shortly before 10 p.m. last night, the Newark Fire Department said. The worker was on a lift, putting in new windows at the school, when he somehow came into contact with current from a power line, said John Brown, a spokesman for the Fire Department. The man, who was not identified, was taken to University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the authorities said. JENNIFER 8. LEE

Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about order being restored in parts of Kazakhstan after fighting between ethnic groups misidentified the country's capital. It is Astana -- not Almaty, which was the capital until 1997.

An article yesterday about deterioration in Chicago's elevated train system misstated the timing of expansion work on the Brown Line. The work on the $529.9 million expansion began in 2004; it is not set to begin next month. (Some track closures and other construction are planned for next month.)

Wesley Autrey Sr., the construction worker who leapt to the subway tracks at West 137th Street in January to save the life of a stranger, has filed a lawsuit charging that a lawyer and a man who represented himself as an entertainment executive tricked him into signing an ''unconscionable'' contract allowing them to exploit his name and personality. In papers filed last week in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, his current lawyer, Barbara S. Mehlsack, charges that Diane L. Kleiman, a lawyer, and Mark Anthony, also known as Mark Anthony Esposito, injured Mr. Autrey's reputation by, among other things, pressuring a school to pay him a speaker's fee and demanding expenses from a magazine reporter as a condition for access to Mr. Autrey. The lawsuit seeks damages and the voiding of the contract. Ms. Kleiman did not return a message left on her telephone answering machine yesterday, and a phone number for Mr. Anthony could not be found. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice pressed Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel on Monday to agree to peace talks that would include three issues that have bedeviled Middle East negotiations since 1979. But late into the evening, Mr. Olmert still had not agreed to allow negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians to include discussions on the status of Jerusalem, the borders of an eventual Palestinian state, and the question of whether Palestinian refugees who fled, or were forced to leave, their homes would have a right to return to Israel.

DRUGS WORK AS WELL AS STENTS Researchers say many heart patients receiving stents to open arteries get no lasting benefit compared to patients treated with drugs alone. [A1.] DOUBT ABOUT TREATMENT New studies cast further doubt on the effectiveness of increasing so-called good cholesterol to fight clogged arteries, though researchers said it is too early to give up on the approach. [A13.] RUSSIA'S ENERGY STRATEGY A milestone in the Russian government's control of the country's energy wealth is expected to occur today when the remaining assets of Yukos Oil are auctioned. [A3.] LIFE SHUTTERED AGAIN Time Inc. has pulled the plug once again on Life magazine, this time because of poor advertising sales for the publication that has spent the last three years as a weekly newspaper supplement. Life, known for its superb photography, was first published in 1936. [C2.] CITIGROUP REVAMPS AND CUTS JOBS In its first major revamping since its creation a decade ago, Citigroup plans to trim up to 12,000 jobs so the financial services firm can gain greater control of its business overseas, where it believes there are growth opportunities. [A1.] NAGGING QUESTIONS FOR AT&T While Wall Street endorses AT&T's acquisition strategy, some questions remain. Is AT&T's broadband strategy flawed? Is its foray into TV in shambles and destined for failure? [C1.] SHOWING THE WAY? Analysts say the aggressive tactics used by Total of France, the energy company, may show the rest of the industry the way to go as shrinking reserves force companies to search harder for deals in difficult parts of the world. But the tactics have led to an investigation of Total's chief executive. [C1.] A QUESTION OF DISCOUNTS The Supreme Court hears arguments about whether retailers can discount a manufacturer's product, even if the maker does not want the price to go below a certain level. [C1.] STOCKMAN IS INDICTED David A. Stockman, the chief executive of Collins & Aikman and former budget director for President Ronald Reagan, has been indicted on charges ranging from bank fraud to conspiracy to obstruction of justice. [C1.] STOCK BONUSES UPSET PILOTS Pilots now in labor talks with American Airlines are angry over $21 million in stock bonuses to be awarded to five executives at the company. [C1.] MEDIA EXECUTIVE TESTIFIES The former media executive Michael Reed described how money was funneled to Hollinger, a Canadian holding company controlled by the media baron Conrad M. Black now on trial on charges of fraud. [C2.] BERTELSMANN SETTLES The German media giant Bertelsmann, which gave backing to Napster when it was an unauthorized file-sharing service, has a deal to settle with the last major record company that had sued it for copyright infringement. [C4.] FOUNDER OF MAGAZINES DIES Robert E. Petersen, who founded Hot Rod and Motor Trend magazines and endowed the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles, has died. [B7.] YAHOO CREATING A NETWORK Yahoo, looking to get a strong foothold in Web search and advertising on cellphones, will announce today that it is creating a mobile advertising network that will allow marketers to place ads not only on Yahoo's mobile services, but also on those of other online publishers. [C3.] PROFIT RISES AT WALGREEN Walgreen, the giant drugstore chain, has reported a 25 percent increase in quarterly profit thanks to strong holiday sales and continued growth in prescription drugs. The company also said a larger percentage of prescription sales came from generic drugs, which are more profitable, while the mix of general merchandise sales shifted to higher-margin items. [C6.] CHIPS IN CHINA After negotiating with the Chinese government and getting United States government approval, Intel will make 300-millimeter wafers to China. [C3.] LIBEL SUIT AMONG ADVERTISERS Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of the WPP Group, is suing two Italian advertising executives, Marco Benatti and Marco Tinelli, for libel, the first to be tried in a flurry of lawsuits stemming from Mr. Sorrell's dismissal of Mr. Benatti last year as WPP's manager in Italy. [C3.] A 380 WILL DO For some, an Airbus 380 will make a perfect private jet. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C7.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. An article last Tuesday about efforts by Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark, to unseat state legislators who he says are blocking his agenda misstated the given name and title in some copies for a New Jersey Senate candidate he is backing, and incorrectly attributed a potential distinction to her. She is Teresa Ruiz, not Theresa, and she is deputy chief of staff to the Essex County executive, not chief of staff. If elected, she would be the first Hispanic woman in the New Jersey Senate -- not the first Hispanic. (The first was Robert Menendez, now a United States senator.) The article also referred imprecisely to the 29th Legislative District. It includes all of Hillside Township, not just a slice of it.

An architecture review on Thursday about Frank Gehry's IAC headquarters building along the West Side Highway in Chelsea misspelled the name of the German city that is the site of his Vitra Design Museum, which the IAC building was said to bring to mind. It is Weil am Rhein, not Weil am Reim.

An editorial on Sunday about global warming gave the wrong number of votes needed to override a presidential veto in the Senate. That requires two-thirds of senators present and voting, not 60 senators.

GELBER--Joseph. You'll be in our hearts forever. Margie, our thoughts are with you. Bunny and Teddy GELBER--Joseph. Guiseppe, your love of life and commitment to helping others is a legacy you leave for all of us to cherish. We will never forget all of our great times. Barbara and Bernie GELBER--Joseph, Friar. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friar's Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved and esteemed member, Friar Joe Gelber. His loyalty and dedication to the Friar's Club will be deeply cherished. His untiring efforts to raise money for the Friar's Sunshine Committee were unsurpassed. We will miss his gentle nudges to buy raffle tickets so senior citizens can enjoy entertainment and underprivileged children can enjoy a movie or a day with clowns and laughter. We are honored and proud to have been touched by this charitable soul. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue. Tuesday March 27, at 11:45 am. Jerry Lewis, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Stewie Stone, Prior Fred C. Klein, Treasurer Stu Cantor, Scribe Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director GELBER--Joseph. Consummate New Yorker, devoted husband to Marge, best friend to many, garment center legend, ultimate fundraiser for many causes, reknowned member of the Friars Club. We are blessed to have known you. We greatly admire Marge for her loving care and devotion to Joe over the years. Marilyn and Harold Siegel Nina and Gary Madison Laura and Mitchell Cassel GELBER--Joseph. A dog's best friend is her man, (Joe). I'll miss you. Gigi GELBER--Joseph. Everyone who crossed your path was blessed to know your kind smile, your gracious thoughts and sentiments and your unwavering generosity of spirit. Your impact on the lives of others is unmeasurable. With your beautiful Marge by your side, a golden light was always shining. With love, Melissa Fields GELBER--Joseph, on March 24, 2007. Devoted son of the late Bertha and Ben, beloved husband of Marge, adored brother of Sam and the late Sol, Mary Rosenberg and Sylvia Katz, dear brother-in-law, uncle, great-uncle and friend. His was a life well lived. He will be missed by all who knew him. Service Tuesday 11:45 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St at Amsterdam Ave. GELBER--Joseph. Richmond Children's Foundation is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend. He will be missed by all for his generosity and ongoing dedication to the people we support. We extend our sympathy to his devoted wife Marge. Edward Spauster, Pres/CEO Carol Baron, Devel Dir GELBER--Joe. Our hearts go out to Margie at the loss of her beloved husband and to the family as they mourn the passing of a great man, a true gent and a loyal friend, especially to our own dear Norman. With deepest sympathies. The Buchbinder Family GELBER--Joe. Joe you were a true compassionate friend. Thank you for great times with Kenny and Margie in East Moriches and at the Friar's and understanding my love of nova. Your great heart, generosity and dedicated friendship were an inspiration. We miss you. Chris and Pippa

A 24-year-old man who worked as an undercover operative for the Drug Enforcement Administration was convicted of armed robbery by a State Supreme Court jury last week, even though he claimed to have been on duty for the federal agency at the time of his arrest. The man, Juan Medina, who had helped the drug agency recover a discarded gun used in a crime and had led agents to a heroin operation, had been working for the agency for about two months when he and several others participated in a home invasion robbery in the Bronx in November 2004. Mr. Medina, who faces a 25-year prison sentence, told the police that he had infiltrated a drug gang and had tried to stop the robbery. He said he had informed a federal agent about the robbery before it occurred. But at Mr. Medina's trial, the agent testified that Mr. Medina had not spoken to him about the crime. TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

SMITH--Janet D., attorney, on March 25, 2007, after a courageous battle with cancer. Survived by her loving husband, Scott J. Zevon, M.D., her beloved parents, Saul and Lillian Smith, her sisters Judy Green and Karen Smith, her brother Alan Smith, and extended family. Beautiful, strong, vibrant, active, wife, cherished daughter, caring sister, loving aunt. She left us with a void that can never be filled and hearts that are shattered. Services Thursday, 3pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. 212-362-6600.

Speculation that Carrefour, the French retailer, was headed for a takeover were dashed late Friday, setting off a sharp decline in the company's share price yesterday. Takeover speculation ended when Bernard Arnault, a French investor, and Colony Capital, an American investment firm, said they would not acquire more than 20 percent of Carrefour until June 30, 2008, unless Carrefour's largest shareholder, the Halley family, decided to sell its 13 percent stake or a new shareholder bought more than 5 percent of the company. Speculation that a takeover was imminent had swirled around the company since last month when Colony Capital and Mr. Arnault, together with a hedge fund, bought a 9.8 percent stake. Stock in Carrefour, which is based in Paris, fell 1.19 euros, or 2 percent, to 54.22 euros a share. CRAIG SMITH

America has voted, or at least a few Americans have voted, and the new production of ''Grease'' has its leads. Sunday night's episode of ''Grease: You're the One That I Want,'' was the last for the Broadway casting reality show. The winners were Laura Osnes and Max Crumm, above. Though the reality show was anything but a success -- it spent a much of its run in last place in its time slot -- it was fairly effective as a commercial for the $10 million Broadway production. Producers say the musical has an advance of $8 million, a comfortable sum for a show scheduled to begin performances in July. But Mr. Crumm and Ms. Osnes, neither of whom has Broadway or Broadway touring experience, have their work cut out for them. In other reality casting news, Connie Fisher, winner of the BBC show that cast Maria in the London production of ''The Sound of Music,'' has cut her schedule to six shows a week after taking a two-week sick leave for voice problems. Aoife Mulholland, a runner-up in that reality show, will substitute for her twice a week. Starting on April 17, Mo Rocca, the comedian and satirist, is stepping into the role of Vice Principal Douglas Panch in ''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee'' for a four-week engagement. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

Some 800 tribal elders in northwest Bajaur pledged not to give shelter to anyone suspected of terrorist activity. The promise is a bid to bring peace to the tribal region near the Afghan border, where a strike by an American Predator drone in January 2006 came close to killing Al Qaeda's second in command, Ayman al-Zawahri, and did kill 18 others. Last October, an airstrike by Pakistani forces on a religious school in the district reportedly killed 83 people. Similar promises made by tribal leaders in North and South Waziristan have been criticized because, in exchange, the government agreed to pull out troops. The Bajaur pledge comes with no such agreement by the government. ISMAIL KHAN

KEARNS--Lauretta, 89, beloved wife of the late James M. Kearns and devoted mother of Karen, Kevin, William, James Jr. and Thomas, grandmother of Jamie, Kate, Brian, Kathleen, Kay and Sarah and great-grandmother of Ryan. A graduate of Hunter College with a triple math, chemistry and physics major. Researched early radar technology at Sylvania Labs during World War II; painter and avid reader. Mom, Grammy, you will be in our hearts forever.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about Rudolph W. Giuliani's positions on gun control included an erroneous reference in some copies for Charles E. Schumer, with whom Mr. Giuliani was shown at a news conference in 1995. At the time, Mr. Schumer was a United States representative from New York, not a senator.
President Bush set aside his combative tone over the Iraq emergency war spending bill, to crack jokes before the Radio and Television Correspondents 63rd annual dinner tonight.
The reality is that George Steinbrenner will run the Yankees as long as he lives. His health may be failing, but if it is, Steinbrenner might never say so.

There is no pitcher more intriguing in Mets camp than Ambiorix Burgos. You can substitute the words electrifying, unpredictable, inconsistent and filthy if you please, too. In the Mets' 8-3 loss to Atlanta this afternoon, Burgos may have pitched his way onto the team. He threw two scoreless innings and struck out three. His ERA is still north of 7 but Burgos fills the mid-to-late inning power reliever role left vacant since Duaner Sanchez's shoulder injury turned more serious and Guillermo Mota got suspended for the season's first 50 games.
Homes can be romantic deal breakers. Some disappointed lovers shared their apartment horror stories with Joyce Wadler in the House & Home section. Share yours.

Everybody seems to have an opinion on Alex Rodriguez, because there are so many issues that complicate the picture: his regular-season success, his postseason failures, his personality, his contract, on and on and on. But say this for the guy: he really does work at his game. I can't think of any player in camp who does as much extra work before practice as Rodriguez.
The New York State budget, weighing in at a hefty $121 billion-plus at last count, is rumbling ahead as the clock ticks down to the weekend deadline before the start of the fiscal year on April 1.

Iraq As debate rages among Democrats and Republicans over whether to impose a timetable for withdrawing troops from Iraq, a poll conducted earlier this week by CBS News found that 59 percent of Americans agree with the House bill for a withdrawal date of September 2008.

Some of you out there who know me better as a rock guitarist (of Queen, et al.) may also know that I have elected to go back to Imperial College London, after an absence of 30 years or so (I was busy!), as a post-graduate student, re-registering for the Ph.D. in astrophysics that I began around 1970. Laying my cards on the table, I am very aware of my essentially amateur status, but eager to catch up on the last 30 years of astronomical research. I get to go to some pretty high-powered seminars, plus enjoy the privilege of being around scientists who are in touch with the most distant surface of the bubble of knowledge that we are pushing out into the observable universe. And this gives me wonderful opportunities for insight.
Like me, you may not get much fun out of learning that all your life you've misunderstood something important. I think you can have some fun with this. Wanna play?
President Bush has discovered bloggers. Iraqi bloggers.

Note to voters: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is so family friendly, she is "very conscious of not calling during bedtime hours" when her senior staff is home putting their kids to bed, according to Mrs. Clinton's campaign manager.
Hot off the presses! Hogwarts is being turned into luxury apartments!
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's March 28 column, "How Many Scientists?"

The Bracket is delighted to get one final post from our favorite contributor, the former Penn basketball star and Rhodes Scholarship finalist Stephen Danley. Loyal bracket readers will remember Danley's posts before the N.C.A.A. tournament, when he described life as an Ivy League player and the magic of being a senior on Selection Sunday. Below are his thoughts on the end of his playing career and his postcollege options.

Cadbury Schweppes has candy on the brain. Prodded by activist investor Nelson Peltz, the British company said earlier this month it would split off its beverage unit to focus on becoming a giant in the confections business. The announcement had many analysts speculating that both pieces of the company could be attractive takeover targets. But Cadbury Schweppes chief executive Todd Stitzer hinted at a different outcome this week, suggesting it would make sense for Cadbury to buy United States-based Hershey, something it unsuccessfully tried to do in 2002.

Given Wall Street's fascination with the proposed initial public offering of Blackstone Group, it was probably just a matter of time before someone set up a blog solely dedicated to the (potential) event. But the creator of "Inside the Blackstone I.P.O." is not some hardcore private equity wonk -- it is the Service Employees International Union, one of the biggest labor organizations in the United States. The anonymous blog's connection with the union was disclosed Wednesday in an S.E.I.U. press release, in which Stephen Lerner, assistant to the president of the Service Employees International Union, questioned the benefits to society of a publicly traded Blackstone:

Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat from Delaware and a candidate for president, is well known in Washington for liking to talk, about many subjects, with much detail and repetition, and at considerable length. One of his rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination - Senator Barack Obama of Illinois - may have paid the price for Mr. Biden's loquaciousness (Note: if you want some fun, trying Googling "Biden" and "loquacious") at a forum for Democratic presidential candidates before a labor audience in Washington this morning.

A common theme among pollsters so far in the 2008 presidential race has been the Republicans' lack of enthusiasm about their party's candidate. A recent Gallup/USA Today poll suggests that one prospective candidate might stir things up a bit in the Republican race should he decide to run - former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group have brought in a Texas-size posse of lobbyists in what seems to be an attempt to keep Washington from upsetting their proposed buyout of the energy giant TXU. The Washington-based publication The Hill reports that nearly a dozen lobbyists registered last week to represent the two private equity firms.
http://www.breitbart.com/article.php?id=070328041237.iwdgl7e0&show_article=1

Wow -- I was blown away by the response on the Tuesday colum about Kiva (so were the people at Kiva!). Thanks to all who became newly-minted financiers, and let me try to address some of your questions.

With all this talk about Hoyas and family, there's another famous son in the Georgetown program aside from John Thomson III and Patrick Ewing Jr. The freshman guard Jeremiah Rivers is the son of the Boston Celtics Coach Doc Rivers.
Here's your chance to name something much bigger than a street after yourself.

Ritchie Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm founded by a former college football star, A.R. Thane Ritchie, is close to a deal to sell about half of the assets in its main multistrategy fund to Reservoir Capital Group, according to news reports.

Mia Farrow and her son, Ronan Farrow, have an important piece in the Wall Street Journal today about China's shameful role in underwriting the genocide in Darfur. China is one of the few countries with real leverage over Sudan (most Sudanese oil exports go to China, and most Sudanese arms come from China). And so it is incredibly important to put pressure on China -- and one of its vulnerabilities is its hosting of the Olympics next year.

Charles Gargano, a major fundraiser for George E. Pataki who also served as chairman of the state's Empire State Development Corporation, billed the agency for a $3,579 trip to Rome during his last months on the job last year and for some $16,000 worth of meals at expensive restaurants, Tom Robbins reports in The Village Voice.
Images from the urban artscape that adorns the avenues of the city's Mission District.
The owner of a daycare center gave himself up after taking a busload of his students hostage.

Following an audit released today, City Comptroller William C. Thompson, Jr. is calling on the operators of the Central Park Boathouse to pay a $381,000 tab to the city after failing to report $2.4 million in gross receipts, including nearly $255,302 in free meals to employees and guests.The city's lost share of those meals alone is $40,798 for the two year period ending in December 2005, the audit found. The boathouse operators say some free meals are part of its effort to promote and conduct business. Mr. Thompson responds that the boathouse failed to provide any supporting documentation of that claim and notes that some of the free meals ranged from $800 to $2,600 each.
It's just after 11 a.m. Do you know where your confererence committees are?

What about the 85 U.S. attorneys who weren't fired? Andrew Sullivan cites "a month-old statistical study that seems to me to be worth wider examination," indicating that the Justice Department under President Bush may have engaged in "political profiling" by targeting local Democratic politicians for prosecution. Sullivan writes:

Citigroup has been down so long, it looks like up to John McDonald, an analyst at Banc of America Securities. Mr. McDonald on Wednesday raised his rating on Citigroup's stock to "buy" from "neutral," writing that "years of disappointing fundamental and stock price performance have set the bar low for Citi shares." The upgrade follows reports that Citi is preparing for its first major overhaul since being formed from the merger of Travelers and Citicorp a decade ago. In his research note, Mr. McDonald said that "even modest improvement in management execution and financial results could be positive catalysts for the stock."

The consumer electronics retailer Circuit City Stores said on Wednesday it will explore a possible sale of its Canadian unit InterTan and replace 3,400 employees with lower-paid workers in a cost-cutting move, sending its shares up 2.5 percent.
Still more notes from the TED conference:

As March money madness reaches its peak, the presidential candidates aren't the only ones dashing for cash. The Wall Street Journal reports that major donors to presidential candidates are also holding fundraisers for congressional contenders.
Steve Forbes, who ran for president twice on a flat-tax platform, endorsed Rudolph W. Giuliani today, saying the former mayor would symplify the tax code if elected president.
Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below. - The Editors

Americans agree with John Edwards's decision to continue his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination after his wife Elizabeth was diagnosed with a recurrence of cancer, according to a nationwide CBS News poll released this morning. Voters who say they expect to vote in the Democratic primaries next year are even more supportive of his decision.
Art exhibitions flourish across the country. Here is a selection of the latest offerings.

Former Tennessee senator and current "Law and Order" district attorney Fred Thompson finished third among the potential Republican presidential candidates in a weekend poll conducted by USA Today and Gallup. Ross Douthat, an associate editor at The Atlantic, writing at The American Scene, sees a problem with this, beyond the fact that a Fred Thompson candidacy would mean there would be two separate "Thompson '08" campaigns in the Republican primaries (though former Wisconsin governor Tommy Thompson seems to have prepared for this by using the rubric "Tommy '08").
Items that can work at home or go to work, discontinued pieces and samples have their day at the Conran shop and more.

MoveOn.org, the liberal activist group, is inviting its broad membership to take part in virtual question-and-answer sessions with some of the 2008 presidential contenders beginning next month -- each one focusing on a particular topic.

Our search for the right architect continued without success. I began to think that we were the problem. We wanted too much: an architect who designs gorgeous homes that are not too fancy - someone with a fine aesthetic sensibility who is practical and whose rates are affordable.

Even as analysts speculate whether the Blackstone Group is trying to challenge Wall Street's investment banks with its initial public offering, the biggest bank of them all is aggressively targeting private equity firms' turf. Goldman Sachs chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, said Tuesday that his firm's next buyout fund could reach $20 billion, which would be the largest such fund ever raised -- by either a bank or a private equity firm. The remarks, which Mr. Blankfein made at his firm's annual shareholder meeting, came as Blackstone is out raising a fund of its own that could end up a similar size.
David Pogue tests the SoundKase Sonic iBoom Backpack.

Bear Stearns said Tuesday it paid its chief executive, James Cayne, $40 million in cash, stock and other compensation last year, which was 32 percent more than in 2005. The Financial Times reported that Mr. Cayne's compensation was on a par with the $40.5 million paid to Lehman Brothers' chief executive Richard Fuld, but less than what the chiefs of Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs earned last year. Financial News said Mr. Cayne received 24 percent of the money Bear Stearns set aside for the bonuses of its top five executives.

British Airways is considering a 1 billion pound ($1.96 billion) bid for a rival British carrier, bmi, according to The Times of London. The paper said that bmi's chairman, Michael Bishop, who is also a 50 percent shareholder, has received approaches from a number of airlines interested in buying a stake.

With the floodgates of private equity cash securely open, investors are eyeing the full corporate landscape for buyout candidates. Based on a report from Goldman Sachs, BusinessWeek today wonders just who the next targets will be.

The Dutch banking giant ABN Amro said Wednesday that it would look for other possible deals should talks with Barclays fall through. ABN also urged shareholders to reject a motion to break up the company. While ABN said it was "excited" about a potential deal with Barclays, it is unclear whether talks will lead to a merger.

The president of the Japanese electronics giant Sanyo, Toshimasa Iue, is expected to resign early next week following a series of management failures and an accountancy scandal that has badly damaged the company's image, the Times of London reported, citing sources it did not identify.

In the ongoing saga of the Tribune auction, real estate magnate Samuel Zell appears closer than ever to winning the day. Tribune is expected to name a victorious bidder at the end of this week and Mr. Zell's $8 billion takeover offer is emerging as the most likely candidate, Bloomberg News said citing unnamed sources.

HSBC has hired a Credit Suisse banker, David Simons, as head of leveraged and acquisition finance in the Asia-Pacific region. Simons previously headed leveraged finance for non-Japan Asia at Credit Suisse. Mr. Simons will take up his new functions in May and will lead the bank's efforts to build its strengths in event-driven investment grade and non-investment grade financing in Asia.

ATS Automation Tooling Systems said Tuesday it had cancalled an initial public offering of 250 million Canadian dollars ($216 million) for its solar cell unit, Photowatt Technologies. The offering was in the works for more than a year and was postponed two weeks ago. ATS said Tuesday that two Photowatt orders, valued at more than $6.2 million, had been delayed by customers.

Aerovance, a drug maker, said Tuesday that Clarus Ventures had agreed to provide $32 million of financing that will allow it to independently pursue a clinical trial of its asthma drug Aerovant later this year. Aerovance is continuing to seek partnerships with pharmaceutical companies in support of trials that would give the partner licensing rights to Aerovant. The new funding will give Aerovance more freedom to select a partner for the drug's marketing and sales.

The Swiss metal company Xstrata is facing pressure to increase its all-cash $4.6-billion bid for LionOre Mining International, a nickel mining company, following recommendations from analysts who said the offer undervalues LionOre. Xstrata proposed the deal on Monday, bidding $18.50 a share, but the offer was met with derision by institutional shareholders looking for more cash.

A Web-based software provider, Vocus, has announced a secondary public offering of up to 3.3 million shares that could generate a total of more than $67 million. By selling about 1.2 million shares of common stock at just over $20 a share, Vocus expects to generate $23.2 million directly, after deducting underwriting fees. Certain selling stockholders are selling an additional 1.6 million shares.

General Motors will not make a bid for DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler unit, the Times of London reported, citing unnamed sources close to the talks. The report came after an analyst at Bear Stearns, quoted in the The Detroit Free Press, suggested that a merger between General Motors and Chrysler "would be challenged to pass antitrust scrutiny." Earlier in the week, the Detroit Free Press said that while General Motors held talks with DaimlerChrysler about a transaction in Janaury, it is not actively pursuing a purchase.
City National, a financial management company based in Los Angeles, said it had agreed to buy Lydian Wealth Management, an asset manager, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

Venture funding in San Jose, Calif., during 2006 totaled about $616.4 million, up 27.4 percent from the previous year, according to a report released Monday. The report, from VentureDeal and the Business Performance Management Forum, said San Jose's venture financing growth was more than double the national average.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg defended police spying on potential protesters in advance of the 2004 Republican National Convention, saying yesterday that it was necessary for security during an uneasy time:

Riviera Holdings, the owner of the Riviera Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas and the Riviera Black Hawk Casino in Black Hawk, Colo., is once again fielding a buyout offer from Riv Acquisition Holdings. The bidding group, which includes Starwood Capital's chief executive, Barry Sternlicht, said Monday it had offered $27 a share in cash for Riviera. A deal could be valued at $551.5 million. Shareholders in Riviera, which is based in Las Vegas, turned down a previous offer in 2006.

A nutritional supplement company, NBTY, is up for sale, The Deal reported, citing unnamed sources. The company's market capitalization is $3.3 billion based on Tuesday's trading. Bear Stearns and Bank of America are advising NBTY and first-round bids are expected in the next few weeks.

Wireless local-area-network technology developer Aruba Networks generated about $88 million in its first day of trading on Nasdaq Tuesday. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is one of a crop of venture capital-backed compaines to have done well in March I.P.O.s. Others include Glu Mobile and Sourcefire even though none of them has shown a profit. Still, Aruba is growing. Its revenue rose to $72.5 million last year from $12 million in 2005.

Arguments were laid out before the Supreme Court on Tuesday regarding whether the securities industry can be sued for allegations of antitrust violations in creating syndicates for initial public offerings. The court justices challenged the three lawyers who appeared before them by drilling down on the question of whether the Securities and Exchange Commission adequately polices the securities industry.

DoubleClick, an online advertising company controlled by a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman, is exploring a sale and is in talks with potential suitors including Microsoft, the Wall Street Journal reported. DoubleClick was publicly traded in 2005 when it agreed to be acquired by Hellman & Friedman for about $1.1 billion. The firm is hoping to get at least $2 billion in a DoubleClick sale, a source told the Journal.

The Federal Communications Commission has approved the $12.3 billion buyout of Univision Communications after the company agreed to pay a record $24 million fine and improve the quality of its children's programming.

German prosecutors arrested one of the top-ranking executives at Siemens on Tuesday in an investigation into suspected bribery, dealing the troubled company another blow in what has become a steady barrage of corruption accusations. The executive, Johannes Feldmayer, was detained as prosecutors searched company offices in Munich, where Siemens is based, and two other German cities, a spokeswoman for Siemens said.

After an auction that lasted just four minutes, the Russian state oil company Rosneft won the bidding Tuesday for assets of the bankrupt company Yukos, further tightening the Kremlin's control of energy industries in Russia. In the auction, Rosneft bid against a joint venture of BP and Russian partners, called TNK-BP, for 9.44 percent of Rosneft's own stock, which Yukos had acquired in a swap before its bankruptcy.

As Goldman Sachs raises $3 billion for a secondary buyout fund, Breakingviews reports on a study suggesting that buyers in secondary deals may often be paying top dollar for mediocre assets. While secondaries are useful because they give private equity investors a chance to cash out early, the buyers in these transaction should beware, Breakingviews suggests.

New Century Financial, the troubled subprime mortgage company, could file for bankruptcy protection as early as the end of this week, people briefed on the company's plans said Tuesday. The company stopped making loans this month after federal prosecutors and regulators began investigating it and is trying to tie up financing that would allow it to reorganize or sell itself through a prepackaged bankruptcy, rather than be forced to liquidate itself.

The law firm Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman may lose $4 million in fees after a United States Bankruptcy Court judge on Tuesday dismissed it from a case, citing a conflict of interest. Pillsbury represented SonicBlue, an electronics maker that declared bankruptcy in 2003. In 2002, the law firm promised three hedge funds that invested in a $75 billion bond issue that they'd be paid in full in the event of a bankruptcy.

When the State Legislature voted last week to move New York's presidential primary to Feb. 5 from March, lawmakers said they wanted to ensure that more candidates would actively campaign in the state. But if the bill is signed into law, it may have exactly the opposite effect.
The Times’s David Pogue on the pros and cons of alternative-fuel vehicles.
The Jewish food expert answered questions from readers about cooking and entertaining during Passover.
Police removed more than 450 right-wingers from the ruins of Homesh, a former Jewish settlement in the northern West Bank.
With its new design, location and mission, the New Museum of Contemporary Art plans to pose a bold challenge to established museums.

“The Boomer Century,” airing on PBS Wednesday, labors to convince viewers that the only way to see the last 60 years of civilization is through the collective ego of the American children born between 1946 and 1964.
Images from productions of “Romeo and Juliet” past and present.

Over the next several years, these 46 institutions will either expand, relocate or build new museums — often with bold designs by big-name architects — with openings planned through the end of 2010.  Roll over the circles to see information about the  new museum projects.
