A look at the work of Richard Rogers, the architect who is the 2007 recipient of the Pritzker Prize.

Ever since the Stern Report was released in the U.K. in December, it seems like politicians and green groups are thinking about how market forces can be harnessed to clean up the planet. Last week the World Conservation Union (ICUN), based in Gland, Switzerland, suggested that carefully developed "water markets" or "water payment schemes" can help prevent further degradation of the world's precious clean water sources.
Holiday ideas from Ana Benarroch de Bensadón, whose book, “Dulce lo Vivas,” contains Sephardic dessert recipes from Morocco and Spain.
If you’re looking for a documentary about the electronic music scene filled with historical lectures, performance clips and talking heads, “Headspace” isn’t for you.
No one can know whether Bizet would have approved of the movie musical “U-Carmen e-Khayelitsha.” But you suspect that he would have admired the filmmakers’ gall.
A sit-down with Todd and Jason Alström, whose Web site, beeradvocate.com, is a no-holds-barred outlet for the passions of beer lovers.
The husband of a woman who drove her minivan off a cliff last year, killing herself and injuring the couple’s two children, pleaded guilty today in a deal with prosecutors.
King Abdullah told Arab leaders the U.S. occupation of Iraq is “illegal” in a sign of the growing differences between Saudi Arabia and the Bush administration.
This is the first time that Israel has responded to rocket attacks since a shaky cease-fire came into effect in November.
Three decades after Paris’s Pompidou Center brought him fame, Richard Rogers received the profession’s top honor.
The mass extinction of 65 million years ago apparently did not clear the way for the rise of today’s mammals.
The president said the American people would blame lawmakers if there is any delay in approving money for the war effort.
The general asked his appointed prime minister to impose a state of emergency in Bangkok as opposition to the government grew.
Michael Phelps smashed another record Wednesday night, and this time it was his own. Phelps won the 200-meter butterfly, leading from the first wall to the finish, in 1 minute, 52.09 seconds.
Gunmen, some of them apparently police officers, dragged Sunni Arabs into the streets of Tal Afar and shot them in revenge for a bombing in a Shiite area.
Britain froze all “bilateral business” with Iran and the Iranians displayed some  of the prisoners on television. Iran indicated one sailor could be released soon.
The owner of a daycare center said he took a busload of his students hostage to criticize Manila’s education policies.

A city bus struck and killed a 23-year-old motorcyclist yesterday in Queens, the police said. The victim, Kristopher Thompson of Cambria Heights, was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The accident happened at about 6:45 p.m. when a bus traveling west on Hillside Avenue hit Mr. Thompson’s motorcycle, which was going east on Hillside, near the intersection with 173rd Street. The bus driver was not issued a summons.
Despite a five-game winning streak and a 2-0 lead after the first period Tuesday night, the Rangers gave up five goals in a miserable second period and lost to the Montreal Canadiens.
Voters in the borough selected Matthew Titone to a State Assembly seat on the island’s north shore.
Yahoo plans to offer unlimited e-mail storage to its roughly quarter of a billion users, starting in May.
West Virginia advanced to the championship game of the National Invitation tournament Tuesday night, thanks to a 3-pointer by Darris Nichols at the buzzer.

J. P. Dumont scored a goal and had two assists, and the Nashville Predators held off the visiting Edmonton Oilers, 4-3, last night and moved out of a tie with Buffalo and Detroit at the top of the N.H.L.
The convention center will provide a $200,000 discount on the rent at its exhibition hall during the event, to be held before the 2008 All-Star Game.
OLYMPICS.
The acting chief of the Ocean Beach Police Department was indicted on charges of assaulting a vacationer and three officers were accused of trying to cover up the attack.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state legislative leaders appeared to have resolved the main issues over the budget that divided them.

Jurors sentenced a woman to life in prison without parole for poisoning her boyfriend with antifreeze, the same way she killed her husband six years earlier. The woman, Lynn Turner, could have faced the death penalty for the 2001 murder of her boyfriend Randy Thompson. She is already serving a life term after her 2004 conviction in the death of her husband, Glenn Turner, in 1995. She has maintained her innocence in both cases. Prosecutors said she was motivated by greed for the victims’ life insurance money.

A judge denied three motions by defense lawyers for the fundamentalist Mormon polygamist leader Warren Jeffs, but left possible a change of venue to Salt Lake County. The judge, James L. Shumate, said if he determined during the jury selection process that an impartial panel could not be seated in Washington County, he would move the case. Mr. Jeffs, 51, is charged with two felony counts of rape as an accomplice in connection with his performance of an April 2001 spiritual marriage of a 14-year-old girl to her 19-year-old cousin. If convicted, he could face life in prison.

The State House of Delegates passed a resolution on Monday expressing “profound regret” for the role the state played in slavery. The resolution, passed earlier by the State Senate, had failed to pass the legislature last year. It mirrors similar legislation under consideration this year in Missouri. On Feb. 28, the Virginia General Assembly passed a resolution expressing “profound regret” for the role slavery played in that state. Slavery in Maryland dates to the state’s founding as a colony in 1634. It was officially ended in 1864 under a new state Constitution.

A youthful-looking sex offender who posed as a boy and enrolled in charter schools is competent to stand trial for numerous crimes, a judge has ruled. The defendant, Neil H. Rodreick II, 29, faces charges including possessing child pornography, assault, fraud, forgery and failing to register as a sex offender. Defense lawyers had claimed Mr. Rodreick suffered from “significant trauma” in his past. But that experience did not make him unable to assist in his defense, Judge Thomas Lindberg ruled Monday.

Perjury and other charges were filed against a state senator in the wake of the suicide of a 14-year-old neighbor. The boy, Louis Farrell, shot himself in July with a handgun owned by the lawmaker, Bob Regola. Mr. Regola was charged with three counts of perjury, one count of allowing possession of a firearm by a minor, one count of recklessly endangering another person and three counts of false swearing. The perjury and false swearing counts relate to testimony he made last month that his teenage son did not have access to the gun. That was contradicted by state troopers, who said Mr. Regola told them the gun was kept in his son’s room at one time.
At least 471 cases of pet kidney failure have been reported in the 10 days since a nationwide recall of dog and cat food and 104 of those pets have died, a veterinarians’ information service said.
The patents cover computer technologies involving DVD editing, processing ability, and power consumption and efficiency.

An article in Business Day on Monday about the decline of newspaper advertising revenues in February misstated the period in which print revenue declined 3.7 percent, to $13.2 billion. It was for the fourth quarter of 2006 compared with the same period in 2005 — not for the full year.

A sports article in some copies on March 19, about Lincoln High School’s victory against Boys and Girls High to win the Public Schools Athletic League’s AA division city boys basketball championship, referred incorrectly to an accomplishment by Coach Ruth Lovelace of Boys and Girls High. With that game, she became the first woman to coach a boys team in the P.S.A.L.’s highest division championship game at Madison Square Garden — not the first woman to coach a boys team in any championship game. (Noreen Begley was the first in 1992 when she coached the Murry Bergtraum boys to the finals in what was known as the B division.).

A picture credit in Weekend on Friday with the Books of The Times review, about “How Doctors Think,” by Jerome Groopman, misspelled the photographer’s surname. The picture of Dr. Groopman was by David Carmack, not Carmac.
Corrections

An article in The Arts yesterday about “The Boomer Century: 1946-2046,” a documentary on most PBS stations tonight, misstated the year Tony Snow, the White House press secretary, who appears on the program, was born. It was 1955, not 1957.
Because of an editing error, the byline on an essay in Science Times yesterday about hormonal treatment for prostate cancer referred incorrectly to the writer, Richard Wassersug. He is not an M.D.

A picture caption in some copies on Monday with a sports article about Tiger Woods’s victory at the CA Championship misstated his winning streak at Doral Golf Resort and Spa. It was his third victory in a row there, not his sixth.
When the Islanders took the ice against the Devils on Tuesday night, they were without goalie Rick DiPietro, who missed the game because of headaches.

A picture caption in Business Day on Monday, with an article about the shift by consumers to digital music from CDs, misstated the name of the band that had signed a deal to record two songs rather than a full album. It is Candy Hill, not Cherry Hill.

EDP-Energias de Portugal, an electric utility, said that it had agreed to buy Horizon Wind Energy of Texas from the Goldman Sachs Group for $2.15 billion to more than double its wind-power production. EDP, which is based in Lisbon, said it would borrow the money to pay for Horizon, which is based in Houston and has assets in 15 states. EDP has branched into Spain and the United States because it faces growing competition in Portugal. The market in the United States has gained appeal because the federal government has extended incentives for wind energy.

Gildan Activewear, one of the largest makers of T-shirts in North America, said it would close five plants in Canada, the United States and Mexico and eliminate 1,830 jobs to move production to lower-cost operations in Central America. The company will shut two textile plants in Montreal, two sewing plants in Mexico and a cutting factory in Bombay, N.Y., it said. Gildan will record a restructuring charge of $21.5 million, or 35 cents a share, in fiscal 2007, which ends in September. Gildan, based in Montreal, is shifting production from older plants in North America to newer factories in Central America. It expects to save $45 million a year starting in fiscal 2008 from lower expenses for production, shipping and duties.

A Bergen County grand jury indicted a New Jersey State Park Police officer yesterday on a charge of reckless manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a member of the Ramapough Mountain Indians last April that caused outrage among the tribe.

Japan and Chile have signed a free trade pact, Tokyo’s first with a South American nation and only its fifth over all. The agreement will eventually scrap more than 90 percent of tariffs on bilateral trade worth $8.2 billion last year. The two nations will work to bring the pact into effect by the time of a visit to Japan by Chile’s president, Michelle Bachelet, above, expected in September. Under the agreement, nearly all Japan’s exports to Chile, worth $1.07 billion, would be tariff-free, while 90.5 percent of Chilean shipments to Japan, worth $7.13 billion, would be exempt from tariffs within 10 years of the deal’s taking effect.

Airbus rescued a $16 billion order from Qatar Airways for 80 A350 XWB long-range planes after designing a wider body and wings to beat out Boeing’s rival 787 Dreamliner. “We have got what we want from them,” said Akbar al-Baker, chief executive of the state-owned Persian Gulf airline. He said he expected to sign a preliminary order in a few weeks and a firm order at the Paris Air Show in June. Mr. Baker threatened to buy Boeing’s rival 787 Dreamliner last month unless Airbus came up with a detailed redesign of the A350 by June..

UCBH Holdings, a bank that specializes in serving Chinese-Americans, said it would buy the Business Development Bank of Shanghai for $205 million to offer services to customers who do business in China. Business Development Bank, which is privately held, was established in 1992 as the first bank wholly owned by foreigners to operate in China. It will become a unit of United Commercial Bank, the operating unit of UCBH. Thomas Wu, chief executive of UCBH, said the purchase should save his company four to five years in achieving its expansion plans in China.
The former general counsel at Monster Worldwide was permanently banned from working as a director or officer of a public company as part of a settlement.
Rejecting a Republican effort to strip the date from a spending bill, the Senate delivered a strong rebuke to President Bush’s war policy.
For the past two springs, Aaron Heilman has fantasized how to escape from his relief role. But now he is as important to the team as he has ever been.
Prime Minster Tony Blair of Britain said the campaign to free 15 naval personnel could move into a “different phase.”
The changes would limit the ability of federal wildlife protection agencies to intervene on behalf of endangered species.
Hundreds of Iraqis have been crammed into detention centers designed to hold dozens of people, a monitoring group said.
In a calculated show of force, the United States Navy began a major exercise, part of a broader strategy to contain Iranian power.
While one high-profile member of Ian Paisley’s Democratic Unionist Party quit, many said their leader had done the right thing.

TRENTON, March 27 — Stepping up their investigation of possible corruption in the New Jersey State House, federal authorities have issued subpoenas to three lawmakers demanding that they explain their ties to organizations that have received $3.4 million in special grants.
Two reports urge greatly expanded use of M.R.I. scans in women with breast cancer or at high risk for it, but radiologists are not equipped for more demand.
In Newark and elsewhere, heavy mortgage debt has led many first-time homebuyers to the edge of financial ruin.
An ordinance believed to be the first of its kind in the nation bans non-biodegradable plastic bags in large grocery stores and pharmacies.
Samples of avian flu virus will be sent to the World Health Organization, on the understanding that they will not be shared with commercial vaccine makers.
The resignation followed the public disclosure of health and safety violations at a nursing home for veterans.
An appeals court overturned the 2006 conviction of the national railway SNCF for taking part in the deportation in World War II.
Frustrated by a battle to open a store in New York City, Wal-Mart’s chief said, “I don’t think it’s worth the effort.”
Democrats in the House proposed a series of revisions that won guarded praise from both organized labor and the Bush administration.
A group dedicated to destroying the poisonous cane toads that have killed millions of native animals said it had captured one the size of a small dog.

A suicide bomber dressed as an Afghan soldier detonated the explosives strapped to his body at the entrance of the police headquarters in Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, and killed four policemen.
Beazer Homes USA now faces a federal investigation into mortgage fraud and other accusations.
A pair of suicide bombers thought to be Tamil Tiger rebels tried to drive a tractor loaded with explosives into an army camp in the eastern district of Batticaloa.
The government has agreed to appoint Guillaume Soro, the main rebel leader, as prime minister under a new plan to reunite the north and south of the country.
The Security Council extended its investigation into the 2005 assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri for another year, until June 2008.

The central election committee, dominated by supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin, elected as its chairman a former colleague of Mr. Putin’s from St. Petersburg, Vladimir V. Churov. Mr. Churov, a member of the lower house of Parliament since 2003, worked with Mr. Putin in the St. Petersburg governor’s office in the 1990s. He replaces Aleksandr A. Veshnyakov, whom Mr. Putin ousted this month after he criticized new election laws. Russia is approaching elections for Parliament and president.

Security was stepped up at the United Nations headquarters yesterday after a bomb threat, said Farhan Haq, a spokesman for the organization. The federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency received an anonymous phone call saying a taxi would arrive at the headquarters at 10 a.m. with two backpacks filled with grenades, a diplomat said. The threat was relayed to the New York Police Department, said the diplomat, who spoke to The Associated Press on the condition of anonymity because details of the threat were not released.

Prosecutors opened their case in State Supreme Court yesterday against an off-duty police lieutenant accused of killing a tenant during a fight over the rent in May 2005. The lieutenant, Shamik Walton, a 19-year veteran of the Police Department, has been charged with second-degree manslaughter for the shooting of Byron Hearst, 27, a construction worker. Lieutenant Walton is free on $30,000 bail and has been working on modified duty. Kenneth M. Taub, the prosecutor, said Lieutenant Walton and Mr. Hearst had argued and shoved each other in a minor confrontation before the lieutenant shot Mr. Hearst three times. A defense lawyer, Anthony L. Ricco, portrayed Mr. Hearst as the aggressor, saying, “Shamik Walton was forced to use his service revolver on that day.”.

The two United States senators from New Jersey urged the United States United States Engineers yesterday to remove unexploded munitions from a section of beach in Surf City before Memorial Day. The devices, which date to World War II, were found during a beach replenishment project conducted by the Corps this month. A spokesman for the Corps told The Press of Atlantic City that the government could not guarantee that the beaches would be ready by Memorial Day. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The jurors in the trial of Lina Sinha, left, a schoolteacher accused of having had a sexual relationship with two male students from 1996 to 2002, beginning when they were junior high school students, indicated yesterday to Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court that they had reached agreement on 10 of the 19 counts in a revised indictment and that they were at an impasse on the rest. The jury did not disclose which counts they had agreed on. Eleven of the 19 counts are nonsexual charges against Ms. Sinha, such as making false calls to 911, witness tampering and bribing a witness. Justice Berkman instructed the jurors, who have deliberated for three and a half days, to continue to try to reach a verdict on all counts, and deliberations are to continue today.

An inspection of operations of the freight rail company CSX in 23 states has found 199 serious cases of noncompliance with federal regulations, including 13 possible violations in New York, the Federal Railroad Administration reported yesterday. The inspections were ordered after a CSX derailment in East Rochester on Jan. 16 that capped a seven-week stretch in which CSX had eight freight train derailments in four states. The inspection results “demonstrate that despite general improvement by CSX, the railroad is still not doing enough to make safety a top priority,” said Joseph H. Boardman, the railroad agency’s administrator. The inspection was not related to a derailment and fire outside Oneida on March 12. That crash is the subject of a separate investigation. A spokesman for CSX said it had not seen the report and could not comment. The company said, however, that it would conduct additional tests of its rail system in New York.

A human skeleton was discovered yesterday by landscapers clearing a wooded area in front of the Bloomingdale’s store in White Plains, the police said. Officers could not determine if the remains were of a man or a woman and did not know if a crime had been committed, said Deputy Police Commissioner Daniel Jackson. “It could be a homeless person; it could be someone was hit by a car and flew up in there,” he said. “It’s literally a skeleton. It’s obviously been there a long time.” He said the Westchester County medical examiner was investigating.

The state’s highest court ordered a new trial yesterday for a man convicted of fatally stabbing a livery-cab driver in 1991, saying that an expert on eyewitness identifications should have been allowed to testify on the defendant’s behalf. Nico LeGrand was convicted in 2001 of murdering the driver, Joaquin Liriano, on Morningside Drive in Manhattan after several eyewitnesses testified against him. Mr. LeGrand’s defense team wanted to present an expert about the reliability of eyewitness testimony, but the trial judge did not allow it. Yesterday, the State Court of Appeals ruled 7 to 0 that the expert should have been allowed to testify because conventional wisdom as to the fallibility of eyewitnesses had changed considerably over the years.

A silver maple tree infested with the Asian longhorned beetle has been found on Staten Island, the first evidence ever of the tree-damaging insect in the borough, the city’s Parks and Recreation Department said yesterday. Beetle eggs in the tree, in a privately owned woodland in Bloomfield, were discovered on Thursday by United States Department of Agriculture workers. When the maple was last inspected, in May 2006, it showed no signs of infestation, the parks department said.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would stop paying for health insurance for members of its board. The agency made the move in response to a legal opinion by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo that determined the practice was improper. The authority said that 4 of its 21 board members were receiving benefits through the New York State Health Insurance Plan. The combined insurance payments for the four would have cost the authority about $40,000 this year, said Jeremy Soffin, a spokesman for the authority. The four board members had been paying what would normally be considered employees’ shares of the premiums, Mr. Soffin said.

The City Council will begin reviewing money it allocates annually through programs known as Council initiatives, the speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said yesterday. There are 168 initiatives this fiscal year that award money to 900 community organizations. About 300 of those groups, which are set to receive $32.5 million, will be required to begin submitting quarterly performance reports with the Council this year. Another 300 groups will be required to do so in 2008, and the final 300 in 2009. Ms. Quinn said the new requirement would make the city’s $55 billion budget more transparent.

Three of the state’s biggest public employee unions sued yesterday to block New York State’s planned overhaul of the health care system. In November, a state commission recommended closing or shrinking about 20 small hospitals by mid-2008. Yesterday, the Civil Service Employees Association filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court challenging the recommendations regarding facilities in Buffalo and Syracuse and in Schenectady County. The United University Professions and the Public Employees Federation sued to challenge a recommendation to privatize University Hospital at the State University of New York Upstate Medical University in Syracuse by merging it with Crouse Hospital.
Covering the court like a tarp, Serena Williams suffocated top-seeded Maria Sharapova in 58 bloodless minutes Tuesday in the fourth round of the Sony Ericsson Open.
The ability to beam live sporting events to television screens on airplanes has changed the in-flight experience for sports fans and nonfans alike.
Pacman Jones’s repeated run-ins with the law have made him an example for the N.F.L.’s new personal conduct policy. He will have a hearing with Commissioner Roger Goodell on April 3.
Animal welfare advocates called the chain’s shift to more humane egg and meat production a “historic advance.”
Firefighters used a thermal-imaging camera to locate two people trapped inside an apartment filled with smoke.
Columbia University has warned or censured eight students who were involved in disrupting speakers from the Minuteman Project last October.
Jim Webb denied that he had given the weapon to an aide, who was arrested after he brought it into a Senate office building.
Coach Jeff Ruland led the Gaels to three N.C.A.A. tournament berths in nine seasons, but went 2-28 this season after reaching the tournament last year.
A Texas boy has become a scared-straight spokesman against a choking game after he nearly died playing it.
Keeping tabs on top prospects in the Frozen Four will be easy this year for the St. Louis Blues. The N.C.A.A. Division I hockey championships will be played at their arena.
Six months after a historic election, the fledging government is struggling to put Congo back together.
Jurors heard testimony about the possibility of secret government contracts that gave Qwest’s chief hope for the telephone company’s future.
A witness testified he saw a lawyer for Hollinger write a note directing payment of $9.5 million to Conrad M. Black and three other men from the sale of several small newspapers.
After nearly four full seasons in the N.B.A., Cleveland Cavaliers star LeBron James is still trying to define himself on the court.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,233 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Here was the star witness: slumped forward in his chair, sad-eyed, rocking slightly side to side, chastising himself in quiet fits of white-collar shame.
Whether the trial results lead to a change in the use of stents depends on how the doctors and patients react.
The $362 million MG production line began Tuesday, seeking to revive the historic brand both in China and overseas.
Officials said a “tsunami” of waste and mud killed five people and forced residents to flee Umm Naser, a village in the northern Gaza Strip.
Former Speaker J. Dennis Hastert is getting used to life among the proletariat in the “People’s House.”
Cubs Manager Lou Piniella made it official Tuesday: Wade Miller will be the Chicago Cubs’ fifth starter, which means that Mark Prior could start the season in the minors.
The colon cancer Tony Snow battled two years ago has returned and has spread, reaching his liver.
The head of the United Automobile Workers made clear at a bargaining convention that workers are done making sacrifices.
The victims of Hurricane Katrina should not have to keep paying the price for the Bush administration’s misplaced animosity toward low-income housing.
New data raised the possibility that weakness in the housing market would seep into the broader economy and crimp consumer spending.
The airline expects to emerge from bankruptcy protection with an eye on improving customer service and selling more assets to build shareholder value.
Several pieces of the Giants’ puzzle remain missing, even after the signing of Kawika Mitchell, a former starting linebacker for the Kansas City Chiefs, to a one-year contract Tuesday.
Child magazine will be printed for the last time this spring, but the magazine’s Web site will continue to post original content.
Paul C. Lauterbur shared the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 2003 for developing magnetic resonance imaging into a way to look inside living organisms.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday defended police spying on potential protesters in advance of the 2004 Republican National Convention, saying that it was necessary for security during an uneasy time.
As the Smithsonian’s governing board begins to deliberate over choosing a replacement for the ineffective Lawrence Small, we have three suggestions.
The new version is an appeal to an elite class of hard-core game players who would like a little more of everything.
The publisher for The Los Angeles Times canceled a program to select prominent people to edit the Sunday opinion section.
EDP-Energias de Portugal will buy Horizon Wind Energy of Texas for $2.15 billion to more than double its wind-power production.
Major League Baseball refused Tuesday to commit to a deal proposed by InDemand that cable operators carry the Extra Innings package of games at the same financial terms as DirecTV.
Jurors sided Merck over claims that its painkiller, Vioxx, was responsible for the death in 2003 of an obese 52-year-old woman.

A Congressional hearing may be needed to get an independent evaluation of just who pulled the strings to sugar-coat Pat Tillman’s death — a terrible battlefield accident — as an instance of heroism under hostile fire.
Since January, Bob Bradley, the U.S. national team interim coach, has used 31 players in the three matches, including six who made their international debuts.
With the first round of the presidential election looming, almost half the voters in France’s “average town” are undecided.
One can oppose illegal immigration and still approve of hiring sites, places where laborers can find shade, toilets and a safe place to negotiate jobs with contractors and homeowners.
Radio host Joe Crummey, who discusses Arizona politics on Phoenix’s popular KFYI, does his show from about 400 miles away in California.
Orin E. Atkins’s 16-year tenure as chief executive of Ashland Oil was also marred by improper business dealings.
The program to provide the vests will take roughly nine months and will have an initial cost of $3.3 million.
The only all-male historically black college in the country is hoping to keep consolidating its gains in the search for a new president.
Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. told a Senate committee that he was moving swiftly to fix the problems.
Moving New York’s presidential primary to Feb. 5 from March to ensure that more candidates actively campaign in the state may have exactly the opposite effect.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said there would be no discussion of “final status” issues, saying Israelis and Palestinians remain too far apart.
Congress seems poised to pass a bill to deal with climate change, but some ideas would do very little to change the situation.
Students are often accountable to state tests that determine if they are academically competent. But what about a state's accountability to keep students alive?
Carl Pavano completed his spring training without adding to the list of injuries that had sidelined him for 21 months. If he stays healthy, he is expected to be the Yankees’ opening day starter.
Steve Francis, who played only 12 minutes in Monday’s, was not happy after the game. Coach Isiah Thomas soothed the situation Tuesday, saying Francis would start Wednesday night.
The disputed measures empower the Egyptian president to dissolve Parliament, to suspend civil protections and to limit judges’ oversight of elections.
The collapse forced neighboring residents from their homes and disrupted some subway and Metro-North service.
David Hicks’s journey through the post-Sept. 11 military legal labyrinth has sometimes seemed as uncertain and tortuous as his life’s journey.
The night-vision goggle maker agreed to pay a $100 million penalty for illegally sending classified military information to other nations.
Cpl. Pat Tillman’s family called the investigation of their son’s death in Afghanistan “shamefully unacceptable.”
Heeb, a magazine marketed to young, urban Jews, ran parody ads that became so popular that the magazine has turned into a “quasi ad agency.”
On a night that produced four world records in two hours of competition, Michael Phelps came up with the most extraordinary performance at the world championships on Tuesday.
A question has emerged over whether a Queens man told police that Sean Bell had shot him last year in a drug-related dispute.
Rising gasoline prices and stock market turbulence undermined consumer confidence in March.
In recent weeks, workers in Indonesia have been dropping hundreds of giant concrete balls into the steaming vent known to scientists as “the big hole.”
The move comes after Univision agreed to pay a record $24 million fine and improve the quality of its children’s programming.
Walter C. Anderson, who once tried to turn the Russian Mir space station into an orbiting hotel, was sentenced for failing to report $365 million in income.
The unusual decree is one of several that the  leader implemented in an effort to purge vestiges of the former Soviet rule.
The Lennar Corporation also warned that it expected to fall short of its 2007 earnings forecast.
New Century is still hoping to find a buyer for the company, but the chances for such a deal appear to be dimming.
The parish is a largely conservative congregation that disagrees with the Episcopal Church’s decision to consecrate gay bishops and sanction same-sex unions.
New technology that could prevent catastrophic collisions, the chairman of the T.S.A. said.
The Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Defense continue to have problems collecting and sharing medical data, hampering treatment for wounded soldiers, lawmakers said.
Axel G. Rosin was a former president of the Book-of-the-Month Club and later the head of the Scherman Foundation.
The misconduct, involving 8 to 10 midshipmen, is said to have occurred aboard the Carnival Cruise Lines ship Glory over spring break, the United States Naval Academy said .
Manufacturers are drawn to Juárez, Mexico, which has both low-cost Mexican labor and easy access to the U.S. market.
The creation of the Service Research and Innovation Initiative represents the latest step to promote an emerging field called “service science.”
The chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is the first top regulator to urge a legislative solution for the subprime problem.
Pesticide contamination of food occurs because we operate, deliberately, in a world of poisons.
The empire strikes; Snoop Dogg and P. Diddy strike back, Mstislav Rostropovich celebrated, the Royal Academy names a new chief and more culture news.
In two new exhibits, the photographer James Nachtwey documents the consequences of war and disease.
The Long Island commercial real estate market scene now has new faces, as outside investors are increasingly buying up office buildings.
In the midst of mostly grim days for comedy, the cable channel that is self-proclaimedly in the comedy business, Comedy Central, has never been merrier.
The Signature Theater Company will not be included in a performing arts center to be designed by Frank Gehry, leaving the Joyce Theater as the sole resident.

The 36th New Directors/New Films series runs through Sunday at the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, and at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center. Ticket information: filmlinc.com or (212) 496-3809. The schedule through Sunday:.
On Monday night at Fat Baby bar on the Lower East Side, the four members of Hypernova reveled in the seemingly simple freedom of rocking out.
One of the chief pleasures of New Directors/New Films — perhaps the main reason to return to this program — is surprise.
Perhaps they were just saving the best for last.  In its final week, New Directors/New Films presents a selection worthy of the festival’s storied history.
To the Editor:.
The American Composers Orchestra celebrated its 30th anniversary on Monday night at Zankel Hall with little ceremonial pomp, but lots of eclectic, contemporary music.
Theodora Skipitares’s new work falls short of the heart-rending cruelty for which we turn to Greek tragedy.
Cullen Thomas's book is an affecting tale of an innocent, middle-class American who spent three and a half years in South Korean prisons for mailing himself a kilogram of hashish.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

8 P.M. (22), (26) THE STATE OF THE OCEAN’S ANIMALS Case studies from every corner of the globe illustrate the effects of global warming and illegal fishing on sea animals in this episode of “Journey to Planet Earth.” Matt Damon is host and narrator.
Convoluted economics and intense speculation have pushed up the price of uranium to levels not seen since the heyday of the industry in the mid-1970s.
German prosecutors arrested Johannes Feldmayer as part of an investigation into suspected bribery.
Jackie Hoffman just wants to be Jackie Hoffman. But with a movie option. Or at least an HBO special, for crying out loud.
The top executives of Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse received substantially bigger pay packages last year, but they still lagged behind their American counterparts.

In Sol Picó‘s “Bésame el Cactus,” performed on Monday night at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the choreographer placed herself in a world of risk, encountering prickly plants, blades and unbreakable glass.
The Burgundies of 2004.
Democracy at the Stove.
A new restaurant and entertainment venue with Kerry Simon, right, opens this week on Broadway, a third branch of P.J. Clarke’s opens and more.
An article last Wednesday about cooking with wine gave an incorrect neighborhood for Astor Wines & Spirits, 399 Lafayette (4th Street). It is in NoHo, not SoHo.

An article last Wednesday about Hispanic groceries misspelled the surname of a senior director of neighborhood marketing for one supermarket chain. He is Jim Carrado, not Corrado. The article also misidentified Mr. Carrado’s employer. He works for Winn-Dixie, not Publix.
How chicken livers and, perhaps, a few extra cocktails work palliative magic during restaurant run-ins with exes and grudges.
“Surreal Things: Surrealism and Design”.
A sprinkling of unusual programs for young and old around the country.
Owners of winter vacation retreats must prepare their homes for off-season hibernation just as rigorously as they would winterize a summer home.
In this up-and-coming city in southern Spain, Heidi Heinz and Enrique Parrilla found a way to combine their American lifestyle with a traditional European home.
A recipe for Scallops With Seaweed Butter Adapted from L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon.
A cheese-aging room in Manhattan’s newest Whole Foods Market, two new guides to kosher and Israeli wines and ancient teapots on display at the China Institute.
When full of vegetables, seafood or meat, pancakes are savory delights. The Minimalist explains how to make Korean, Scandinavian and Italian varieties.
A recipe for Sautéed Chicken Livers With Mushrooms and Sage Adapted from Quatorze Bis.
Where it once was a place for new experiences and ideas, the museum has become conventional and populist. It is up to outsider artists and new collectives to provide change.
Color is the central theme in three big, ambitious museum exhibitions.
To reach the state’s fast-growing Latino population, many California institutions have ramped up Spanish-language programs, easily outpacing the spotty efforts in the rest of the country.
As promises of media coverage, new donors, and more visitors beckon, the cultural building boom shows few signs of slowing.
Despite its new digs and a higher-profile space, the mission of Mocada (Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts) remains the same: giving artists of color a place to shine.
A storefront museum spotlights a rich mural collection in San Francisco’s Mission District.
Many contemporary museums are discovering an intriguing new challenge: finding ways to incorporate sound-based work.
With its new survey, “African Vision,” the Smithsonian Institution becomes a “must” for lovers of African art.
More gadgets on the market to guide you through the galleries.
Museums are encouraging the public to annotate their online collections by supplying descriptive tags, creating a new shared vocabulary.
At the Museum of Funeral Customs in Springfield, Ill., getting people to think and talk about the rituals of death — and disposal — is the mission at hand.
For personal museums built by wealthy collectors, long-term survival is a question.
Devotees of Mr. Goldman’s radio show are flocking to his class in Santa Monica to hear what he has to say about looking at art and buying it.
What’s worked (and what hasn’t) at projects in New York, Denver and Columbus, Ohio.
A Holocaust survivor shares her story with adults and students to broaden their knowledge about the Jewish experience in the 20th century.
Museums around New York are coming to grips with the outpouring of work from China that is shaking up the art world.
Recently resolved cases of looted antiquities or of art owe a debt to the lawyers who helped pioneer cultural property law.
In Grand Rapids, Mich., the art comes in a rainbow of colors, but the building is all green.
Natural history and science museums are finding that real, live animals are enormously popular. But they raise problems, too.
The Maui Ocean Center, this island’s only aquarium, is also home to the largest collection of living coral in the country.
When the museum becomes the Big Building on Campus.
Patrons of art institutions are now redefining what they donate by offering gifts like insurance, houses and industrial glass.
Today, the reigning values of the art world are money, prestige and power. As a result, museums have become part of a globalized creative industry.
Michael Govan, its new director, reframes the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
The sophistication of Rita Gomez’s work — as much a fine art as a science — is a sign of how essential packers have become to the flow of art around the world.
With its new wing and new curator, the High Museum of Art is giving its photography department a visible and intentional lift.
Derek Gillman, the foundation’s executive director, is overseeing the museum’s controversial move to downtown Philadelphia from its home in Merion, Pa.
The splashy new home of the Institute of Contemporary Art has been met with wide enthusiasm, even relief, by a community that has seen its share of frustrations.
A museum director’s infectious love of art provides the catalyst for collectors to contribute 900 works, valued at more than $300 million, to the Dallas Museum of Art.
The Indianapolis Museum of Art looks to raise its profile by focusing on contemporary and decorative arts.
You’re at the mystery section of an airport bookstore and you have three or four minutes to make a choice. How do you decide?
Inside a locker room or clubhouse, there is an expected refuge from the outside bias and ridicule that exists more than ever as sports become ethnically, religiously and racially diverse.
When the Boston Red Sox began their pursuit of Daisuke Matsuzaka last fall, one of their main motivations might have simply been to keep him from the Yankees.
A police officer was shot in the leg while trying to make an arrest on a busy Brooklyn intersection Tuesday night.
Australian Qaeda trainee David Hicks’s plea deal could set the tone for how future cases being handled by the Guantánamo commission are resolved.
In the pecking order of man and beast, there was no lower rung than the one shared by Randy Vargas and Foxy on the streets of Hoboken, N.J.
The Russian state oil company Rosneft won an auction for assets of Yukos, tightening the Kremlin’s control of energy industries in the country.
To receive a lesson from Joël Robuchon, the celebrated French chef,  is to learn how to make the humble dish sublime.
A recipe for Spinach Pancakes.

A recipe for Korean-Style Crisp Vegetable Pancake (Pa jun).

A recipe for Orange-Almond Flan Adapted from “Dulce lo Vivas,” by Ana Bensadón (Ediciones Martínez Roca).
A recipe for Italian-Style Vegetable Pancakes.

Museums used to smaller streams of visitors look to concert halls, sports arenas and airports for ideas on how to accommodate the hordes that come to blockbuster shows.
Homes on the market in Greenwich, Conn., Kenilworth, Ill., and Glenbrook, Nev.
Thank goodness for the way Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has built a Republican-Democratic coalition in California to blunt climate change.
Las Americas, a carnicería in Sunnyside, Queens, offers a modest restaurant in the back with an inexpensive and tasty menu of trencherman’s fare.
Frank Bruni samples the kaiseki dining at Rosanjin, a  new Japanese restaurant in TriBeCa.

MARRON--Dorothy (nee Jamin), 92, of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ, passed away on March 26, 2007. Born in Weehawken on August 1, 1914, she attended the Dwight (Englewood) School and graduated from Georgian Court University in 1936. She married Lawrence Peter Marron in 1943, who predeceased her in 1976. Her outstanding service to her community and extraordinary support of various philanthropic organizations led to numerous awards and recognitions including being the recipient of the Distinguished Service Award from West Bergen (NJ) Mental Health, the naming of the Marron Critical Care Floor at The Valley Hospital of Ridgewood, NJ and the Dorothy Marron University Chapel at Georgian Court University in Lakewood NJ, where she recently was awarded an honorary Doctorate in Humanities. Among other charities she was actively involved in and supported were: St. Joseph's School for the Blind; Doctors without Borders; Food for the Poor; and Mepkin Abbey in Moncks Corner, SC. Mrs. Marron, a championship golfer, began playing at the age of 13 and started her competitive career by winning the Ladies' championship at White Beeches Country Club at age 15. She was nine times Ladies' champion of The Ridgewood Country Club, where the annual Marron Cup tournament honors her achievements. She won numerous county, state and regional championships, was former Metropolitan Golf Association Girls Champion and was a member emerita of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association. She is survived by her sister-in-laws, Evelyn DelBalso Marron of Ho-HoKus, Doris Marron Glingler of Rome, Italy as well as numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. She was predeceased by her father J. William Jamin, General Manager of Todd Shipyards, in 1970, and her mother Mae Maltz Jamin in 1977. A funeral mass will be celebrated at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Ridgewood on Friday March 30 at 10:45 AM with interment at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to The Valley Hospital Foundation, 233 N. Van Dien, Ridgewood, NJ 07450. Arrangements C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood. www.vanemburgh.com

NOT WORTH THE EFFORT -- Wal-Mart may be scaling back its efforts to open its first store in New York City. The chief executive of Wal-Mart, H. Lee Scott Jr., said that trying to conduct business in New York was so expensive -- and exasperating -- that ''I don't think it's worth the effort.'' [Page C1.] BURGER KING'S HUMANE POLICY -- Burger King said that it would begin buying eggs and pork from suppliers that did not confine their animals in cages and crates. Animal welfare advocates called it a ''historic advance.'' [C1.] URANIUM RUSH -- Convoluted economics and intense speculation has pushed up the price of uranium to levels not seen since the heyday of the industry in the mid-1970s. [C1.] THE VALUE OF STENTS -- At a cardiology conference, the buzz was about a new study that found little value in giving stents to most heart patients, as long as they received the right medicines. Do stents have a future? It depends on whom you ask. Market Place. [C5.] U.A.W. LEADER TALKS TOUGH -- The head of the United Automobile Workers, who has been criticized by some union members for being too willing to accept wage and benefit cuts, made clear that workers were done making sacrifices. [C3.] URGING ACTION ON SUBPRIME LOANS -- Two top regulators testified before Congress on subprime mortgages. The chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Sheila C. Bair, said that Congress should set a standard to protect borrowers against predatory lenders. And Christopher Cox, above, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the commission had set up a 25-member enforcement unit to investigate possible fraud involving subprime mortgage lenders. [C2.] SEEKING BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION -- New Century Financial, the troubled subprime mortgage company, could file for bankruptcy protection as early as the end of this week, people briefed on the company's plans said. [C2.] HOME BUILDER'S PROFIT FALLS -- The Lennar Corporation, one of the nation's largest home builders, said that its quarterly profit fell 73 percent on continued softness in the housing market, made worse by problems with subprime lenders. [C2.] MERCK IS CLEARED IN VIOXX CASE -- Jurors in an Illinois state court sided with Merck & Company, the maker of the painkiller Vioxx, over claims that its drug was responsible for the death in 2003 of a 52-year-old woman. [C7.] CONSUMER CONFIDENCE TAKES A HIT -- Rising gasoline prices and stock market turbulence undermined consumer confidence in March, a widely watched index showed. The Conference Board said that its consumer confidence index fell to 107.2, from the revised 111.2 in February. Analysts had expected a reading of 109. [C7.] ROSNEFT BUYS YUKOS ASSETS -- Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, won an auction for assets of the bankrupt company Yukos, further tightening the Kremlin's control of energy industries in Russia. [C3.] SIEMENS EXECUTIVE ARRESTED -- German prosecutors arrested one of the top-ranking executives at Siemens in an investigation into suspected bribery. The executive was detained as prosecutors searched company offices in Munich, where Siemens is based, and two other German cities. [C3.] RAISES FOR EUROPEAN BANK CHIEFS -- Deutsche Bank and the Credit Suisse Group, two of Europe's biggest banks, rewarded their top executives with bigger paychecks last year, but their compensation still trailed that of their American counterparts. [C10.] XBOX 360, SPECIAL EDITION -- Microsoft is bringing out a new version of the Xbox 360 game machine that has a bigger hard drive, better high-definition video support and a stylish black finish, not an insignificant feature in a world where looking cool ranks high. [C5.] THE FUTURE OF SERVICES -- A group of technology companies, universities and professional associations are seeking to promote research into ways to increase productivity in the economy's service sector, which accounts for about 80 percent of the United States economy. [C5.] PARODY THEN; NOW FOR REAL -- The magazine called Heeb, a quarterly aimed at young, urban Jews, ran parody ads when it was introduced in 2002. The ads became so popular the magazine now creates real ads for real customers. Advertising. [C6.] REVIEW OF POTENTIAL CONFLICTS -- The publisher of The Los Angeles Times said the paper's readers' representative would review past editorial decisions to determine whether content had been improperly influenced by personal or professional connections. [C6.] UNIVISION TO PAY $24 MILLION FINE -- The Federal Communications Commission approved a buyout of Univision Communications after the company agreed to pay a record $24 million fine and improve the quality of its children's programming. [C6.] BUSINESS ALONG THE BORDER -- Juárez, Mexico, has become one of North America's fastest-growing markets for commercial real estate, as manufacturers build assembly plants for products like computers, appliances and medical devices. Across the Rio Grande, El Paso benefits from the growth. [C8.]

The Senate went on record for the first time on Tuesday in favor of a withdrawal date from Iraq, with Democrats marshaling the votes they needed to deliver a forceful rebuke to President Bush's war policy. By a vote of 50 to 48, with a few crucial votes shifting in favor of the Democratic position, the Senate rejected a Republican effort to strip from the military spending bill any mention of a withdrawal date. The legislation will now move forward with a nonbinding goal of beginning a gradual withdrawal of American troops from Iraq within 120 days of the measure's enactment, with a pullout by March 31, 2008.

The State House of Delegates passed a resolution on Monday expressing ''profound regret'' for the role the state played in slavery. The resolution, passed earlier by the State Senate, had failed to pass the legislature last year. It mirrors similar legislation under consideration this year in Missouri. On Feb. 28, the Virginia General Assembly passed a resolution expressing ''profound regret'' for the role slavery played in that state. Slavery in Maryland dates to the state's founding as a colony in 1634. It was officially ended in 1864 under a new state Constitution. MELODY SIMMONS

SCHWARTZ--Philip K, 93, died March 26 in Coconut Creek, FL. Highly respected in the field of advertising law, he was considered one of the leading experts on the Robinson Patman Antitrust Act. A partner for over 50 years in the New York law firm Davis and Gilbert and a graduate of John's Hopkins University and Columbia Law School. Phil was known for his integrity, loyalty, quiet dignity and sense of humor. His greatest love was his family. Predeceased by his beloved wife, Frances, he is survived by his children, Robert, Marilyn, Michael, Richie and Judy, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Memorial services will be held at the Star of David Funeral Home, 7701 Bailey Road, North Ft. Lauderdale, Florida.
An article last Wednesday about cooking with wine gave an incorrect neighborhood for Astor Wines & Spirits, 399 Lafayette (4th Street). It is in NoHo, not SoHo.

To the Editor: ''City Police Spied Broadly Before G.O.P. Convention'' (front page, March 25) sent a shudder through us and revived the feelings of frustration and anxiety that we experienced during the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York.
HOLLANDER--Benjamin (Holly). 2/17/1897-3/28/1960. I think of you everyday. You have a wonderful daughterin-law, grandson and grand children. Love, F.G.H.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Senate Calls for Timetable To Pull Troops From Iraq The Senate went on record for the first time in favor of a withdrawal date from Iraq, with Democrats marshalling the votes they needed to deliver a forceful rebuke to President Bush's war policy. A1 Hundreds of Iraqis detained in the Baghdad security crackdown have been crammed into two detention centers run by the Defense Ministry that were designed to hold only dozens of people, a government committee said. A1 Rice Cites Gain in Mideast After three days of shuttling between Israeli and Arab cities, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said she had persuaded Israeli and Palestinian leaders to hold talks twice a month. A7 Egypt Says Referendums Pass Egyptian officials said the public overwhelmingly approved changes to the Constitution in a vote on Monday, while opposition groups and human rights organizations dismissed the results as the product of widespread vote rigging. A8 Sterner British Warning to Iran Tensions escalated between Iran and the West over 15 Britons held by the Iranians, with Prime Minster Tony Blair warning that the campaign to free them would move into a ''different phase.'' A10 The United States Navy began a major exercise in the Persian Gulf, a move that Bush administration officials said was part of a broader strategy to contain Iranian power in the region. A9 NATIONAL A11-17 Call to Increase M.R.I. Use In Women With Cancer Two reports call for greatly expanded use of M.R.I. scans in women who have breast cancer or are at high risk for it. The new advice could add a million or more women a year to those who need M.R.I. -- a demand that radiologists are not equipped to meet, researchers say. A1 Veterans Service Chief Resigns The director of the Arizona Department of Veterans Services, Patrick Chorpenning, resigned days after the public disclosure of health and safety violations at a nursing home for veterans. The violations included patients left in soiled undergarments and covered in bodily fluids leaking from medical devices. A12 Snow's Cancer Recurs The press secretary to President Bush, Tony Snow, has suffered a recurrence of the colon cancer he battled two years ago, and the disease has spread, reaching the liver, White House officials said. A15 Concerns Over Patriot Act F.B.I. Director Robert S. Mueller III told a Senate committee that he is moving swiftly to fix the problems exposed in the latest report on the bureau's failures, primarily the mishandling of demands for records under the U.S.A. Patriot Act. A16 Virginia Senator Defends Aide Jim Webb, Democratic senator of Virginia, facing a barrage of questions about the arrest of an aide who tried to take a loaded handgun into a Senate office building, said the move was ''inadvertent.'' A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 In Newark, Rising Debt Puts Homeowners at Risk Mortgage debt has brought thousands of people in Newark close to financial ruin, local officials say, forcing many to change their lives in small and large ways. Driving the debt load are subprime mortgages, which are easier to obtain but carry much higher interest rates. A1 Deal Nears on State Budget In a major step toward passing a state budget by the April 1 deadline, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state legislative leaders agreed to add at least $850 million to his proposed budget and appeared to have resolved the main issues that divided them. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Wal-Mart Skips Manhattan H. Lee Scott Jr., the chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores, said trying to conduct business in New York was so expensive and exasperating that, ''I don't think it's worth the effort.'' His remarks were a surprising admission of defeat, given the retailer's vigorous efforts to enter urban markets. C1 Concession by Burger King Burger King, the restaurant chain, plans to begin buying eggs and pork from suppliers that do not confine their animals in cages and crates. Food marketing experts and animal welfare advocates said the shift would put pressure on other restaurant and food companies to adopt similar practices. HENNINGSEN--Victor W. , Jr, Sound Shore Health System mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Victor W. Henningsen, Jr. Together with his family, Vic was a steadfast supporter of Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester and a devoted member of the Board of Governors, serving from 1985 to the present. During this time he was Chairman of the Board from 1991-1994. His commitment to providing our community with the highest level of health care services by furthering the mission of the Medical Center will be forever remembered at Sound Shore. We will miss his guidance and support. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife Mayde and their children and grandchildren. Mauro C. Romita, Chairman John R. Spicer, President and CEO $(6$)HENNINGSEN--Victor William Jr., of Pelham Manor, NY, died March 26, 2007. Born May 19, 1924, he was a lifelong resident of the town of Pelham. He leaves his beloved wife of 58 years, Mayde, his children and their spouses: Vic and Susan, of Andover, MA; Kit and Caroline, of Stony Creek, CT; Mary and Chris, of Pelham Manor; Tim and Anne, of Wexford, PA; and eight grandchildren. Also survived by his brother, John T. Henningsen, of Rye, and sister, Ann H. Kneisel, of Boston, MA. Educated at Phillips Academy, the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, and Yale. During World War II he served in the Atlantic, Mediterranean and Indian Ocean war zones as a midshipman, third and second mate in the merchant navy, finishing as Lt. (JG) USNR. He spent his entire professional career with the family firm, Henningsen Foods Inc., founded by his grandfather in 1889. Starting as an office boy and plant worker, he retired as President and CEO in 1993 and served as Chairman Emeritus until his death. He was an international leader in the poultry and egg industry as a founder and chairman of the Egg Products Association, a trustee of the Nutrition Foundation and a longtime director of the Institute of American Poultry. He received many industry honors and awards. Profoundly committed to education, he was an active volunteer for Andover, the USMMA, Yale, and Sweet Briar College, where he was past president of the Board of Trustees. A longtime trustee of the Chapel of St. Thomas More at Yale, he was also past president of the Yale Club of NYC and of the American Friends of the Bermuda Maritime Museum. He devoted much time and energy to his native town, particularly the village of Pelham Manor, serving over the years as chair of the Pelham Community Chest, member of the village Planning Board, trustee and mayor of the village of Pelham Manor, cochairman of the Friends of the Pelham Town Library, and chairman of the board of the Sound Shore Medical Center. At his death he was still active in efforts to bridge political divisions and bring people together in service to the community he loved. Memorial Mass, 11 AM, Saturday, March 31, at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Fowler Ave, Pelham Manor, NY. Interment private. Contributions in his memory to the Friends of the Pelham Town Library, 530 Colonial Avenue, Pelham, NY, 10803; and the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester, 16 Guion Place, New Rochelle, NY, 10801.

Tony Snow, the press secretary to President Bush, has suffered a recurrence of the colon cancer he battled two years ago, and the disease has spread, reaching the liver, White House officials said Tuesday. Mr. Snow, a former television commentator for Fox News who joined the White House less than a year ago and has made his fight against cancer part of his public persona, underwent surgery on Monday to remove what he had said last week appeared to be a benign growth in his abdomen.

A pair of suicide bombers thought to be Tamil Tiger rebels tried to drive a tractor loaded with explosives into an army camp in the eastern district of Batticaloa and blew themselves up when they were intercepted by troops. Besides the bombers, seven people were killed. The bombing came a day after the guerrillas carried out an airstrike on a military base north of Colombo, the capital, their first since fighting began more than two decades ago. ANTHONY DAVID
HALPERN--Joel A. Twenty six years since your tragic fatal accident. Dad is by your side as he chose to be. We all miss you and love you. Mother and Family

A sports article in some copies on March 19, about Lincoln High School's victory against Boys and Girls High to win the Public Schools Athletic League's AA division city boys basketball championship, referred incorrectly to an accomplishment by Coach Ruth Lovelace of Boys and Girls High. With that game, she became the first woman to coach a boys team in the P.S.A.L.'s highest division championship game at Madison Square Garden -- not the first woman to coach a boys team in any championship game. (Noreen Begley was the first in 1992 when she coached the Murry Bergtraum boys to the finals in what was known as the B division.)

Isiah Thomas has taken a gentler approach to his point guards this season, a stark contrast from Larry Brown's caustic public comments last year. The Knicks have shown a united front this season, and Thomas referred to the team Tuesday as ''kind of respectable'' despite Monday's loss to the Orlando Magic, which damaged the Knicks' playoff hopes.

Spending half your life traveling from airports to hotels to planes and the other half tackling the heat and dust of Houston can make you yearn for something different. Just ask Heidi Heinz, an American who was on one of her frequent business trips as a consultant for the global management company Accenture when she had an epiphany. On a visit to Siberia four years ago, she felt the need to carry a company card that read, in three languages: ''If I get sick do not take me to a local hospital! Call this number instead.'' She realized that she needed to escape that life. And that her way out was to return to Seville, the Spanish city where she had fallen in love -- first, when she was a student 17 years ago, with the city and its laid-back, spontaneous way of life, and later with one of its citizens.
Bubble Bath, a public bubble-blowing event intended to bring people together, filled the airin Union Square Park with shimmering iridescence on the first Saturday of spring.

Prosecutors opened their case in State Supreme Court yesterday against an off-duty police lieutenant accused of killing a tenant during a fight over the rent in May 2005. The lieutenant, Shamik Walton, a 19-year veteran of the Police Department, has been charged with second-degree manslaughter for the shooting of Byron Hearst, 27, a construction worker. Lieutenant Walton is free on $30,000 bail and has been working on modified duty. Kenneth M. Taub, the prosecutor, said Lieutenant Walton and Mr. Hearst had argued and shoved each other in a minor confrontation before the lieutenant shot Mr. Hearst three times. A defense lawyer, Anthony L. Ricco, portrayed Mr. Hearst as the aggressor, saying, ''Shamik Walton was forced to use his service revolver on that day.'' MICHAEL BRICK

RYAN--John P., highly esteemed actor with over 60 film and television credits, died in Los Angeles on March 20, 2007, at age 70. Lifetime member of The Actors Studio. Well-known for roles in 'Runaway Train', 'It's Alive', 'Five Easy Pieces', 'The Right Stuff', 'The Cotton Club', 'Bound', 'Hoffa', and 'Three O'Clock High'. A devoted and beloved father and friend with inspirational spirit, faith and wisdom. Survived by two daughters, Cordelia and Maria, their mother, Maya Ryan; sisters, Jane Murphy and Violet Brennan; brother, Michael Ryan; and a loving extended family. Visiting: Wednesday 5-9 PM at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, NY. Funeral Mass: Thursday 11 AM at St. Francis of Assisi, Greenlawn, NY. Interment: Genola Rural Cemetery.

The latest Whole Foods Market, all 72,000 square feet of it, opens tomorrow at 95 East Houston Street (Bowery). Given its location, it pays homage to the Lower East Side with a stand for local pickle makers in a corner of its elaborate cheese department. There, in a room done in tile and unfinished spruce with temperature and humidity controls, cheeses will be aged and shoppers can select whole cheeses or have them cut to order. Jeff Turnas, right, a vice president, helped develop the Fromagerie, as it is called, and is working with Neal's Yard Dairy in London and with Hervé Mons, a cheese-aging expert in the Lyon area in France, to obtain cheeses. Aaron Foster, formerly at Artisanal Premium Cheese, is running the Fromagerie.
Because of an editing error, the byline on an essay in Science Times yesterday about hormonal treatment for prostate cancer referred incorrectly to the writer, Richard Wassersug. He is not an M.D.

Greenwich, Conn. WHAT: Six-bedroom house HOW MUCH: $6,995,000 PER SQUARE FOOT: $635.91 Built in 1999, this 11,000-square-foot shake-shingle-style house with a Dutch gambrel roof has a horseshoe drive. There is a double porte-cochere with stone pillars at the entrance, to shelter arrivals and departures. The 1.74-acre property abuts conservation land; it is in a private community, the Calhoun Drive Association, near town amenities, 26 miles north of Midtown Manhattan. The three-story house has an octagonal entryway that leads to a sunken living room with a fireplace and a window seat in a bow window. French doors open to a wraparound terrace. The kitchen has an island with commercial-grade appliances, an informal eating area and a family room with a stone fireplace and access to the terrace. The master suite is two stories high, with two baths and deep closets. The house has seven full and three half baths, three fireplaces, a media room, a climate-controlled wine cellar and a three-car garage. Taxes are $27,673 a year. The homeowners association fee is $1,000 a year. David F. Ogilvy, David Ogilvy & Associates, the exclusive representative of Christie's Great Estates in Greenwich (203) 869 9866; www.davidogilvy.com Kenilworth, Ill. WHAT: Seven-bedroom house on Lake Michigan with guest apartment HOW MUCH: $6,975,000 PER SQUARE FOOT: $775 This three-story 1924 Georgian waterfront house on Lake Michigan has 16 rooms and a separate guest apartment. Over the years there have been two large additions and a complete renovation. It is 20 miles north of Chicago, in a community called Kenilworth, established by Joseph Sears at the turn of the 20th century. This 9,000-square-foot brick house has large formal dining and living rooms and an updated kitchen that opens to an eating area and a family room. The entryway and every major room have lake views. A double-height lake room has a wall of windows with French doors that open to the patio. Stairs from the backyard lead to a beachside deck on Lake Michigan. There is also a roof deck off the guest apartment. The house has nine baths and two half baths, four fireplaces, an elevator, a three-car heated garage, walk-in closets, and a whirlpool in the master bath. The taxes are $60,460.16 a year. Cheryl Chambers, Chambers, Cross & Associates (847) 446-5010; www.chamberscross.com Glenbrook, Nev. WHAT: Three-bedroom house on Lake Tahoe HOW MUCH: $6,950,000 PER SQUARE FOOT: $1,175.77 This 5,911-square-foot house sits on 2.13 acres with about 100 feet of frontage on Lake Tahoe's Glenbrook Bay. The gated community of Glenbrook has sandy beaches and hiking trails. Homeowners have the option to buy memberships in private golf and tennis clubs as well as the opportunity to secure a buoy for boating. The house has an open floor plan with vaulted wood ceilings, floor-to-ceiling windows and a loft space. The great room has a double-height granite fireplace. The house has four and a half baths, four fireplaces, an indoor racquetball court, a game room, a two-car garage and a deck overlooking the lake. Taxes are $7,997 a year. The quarterly homeowners association fee is $1,014. Jean Merkelbach, Distinctive Homes Sotheby's International Realty (775) 588-7710; www.sothebysrealty.com
SILVERSTEIN--Mildred. There really was no other like the mother of my mother. Always in our hearts. Meryl & Matthew Rubin

Columbia University has warned or censured eight students who were involved in disrupting speakers from the Minuteman Project last October in a melee that cut short the program, a university spokesman said yesterday. In the televised fracas, protesters stormed a stage at the university and were attacked by others, shutting down speeches by the group, which opposes illegal immigration and has mounted civilian border patrols. The event hurtled the university back into the debate over free speech. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg chastised Columbia at the time.

Over on my blog (nytimes.com/pogue), I'm wrapping up my notes on the 2007 TED conference (Technology, Entertainment, Design), a reality-altering, four-day series of 50 speakers, most of whom are absolutely brilliant. But for me, one of the most enlightening talks this year took place "off-campus."

To the Editor: Stanley Fish (''Advocacy and Teaching,'' column, March 24) is right to say that university professors should not require public advocacy in the classroom. But he goes seriously off track when he insists that students should be taught to analyze social issues without reference to their own personal beliefs.

The Highline Ballroom, a new 700-capacity rock club in Chelsea, is to open April 30 with a concert by Lou Reed, below. One of several new midsize clubs in the city -- the Gramercy Theater on East 23rd Street opened this month, and the Music Hall of Williamsburg is to open later this year in Brooklyn -- the Highline, at 431 West 16th Street, is owned by the Bensusan family, which also owns the Blue Note and the B. B. King Blues Club & Grill. Among the acts already booked for May and June are Moe, Amy Winehouse, the Greyboy Allstars, Talib Kweli, the Disco Biscuits and Mos Def. Tickets for Mr. Reed's concert are $85. BEN SISARIO

From an overall ratings standpoint, at least, the competition for viewers among evening news shows last week continued to be a horse race between ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC and ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams,'' according to figures from Nielsen Media Research released yesterday. For the fifth time in seven weeks, Mr. Gibson's broadcast was the most watched of the network evening newscasts, with an average audience of about 8.4 million each night. Mr. Williams's program drew about 8.1 million viewers; the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' ebbed at an estimated 6.7 million viewers. Because CBS's coverage of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament pre-empted Ms. Couric's broadcast late last week, audience figures for CBS include only Monday through Wednesday. JACQUES STEINBERG

The state's highest court ordered a new trial yesterday for a man convicted of fatally stabbing a livery-cab driver in 1991, saying that an expert on eyewitness identifications should have been allowed to testify on the defendant's behalf. Nico LeGrand was convicted in 2001 of murdering the driver, Joaquin Liriano, on Morningside Drive in Manhattan after several eyewitnesses testified against him. Mr. LeGrand's defense team wanted to present an expert about the reliability of eyewitness testimony, but the trial judge did not allow it. Yesterday, the State Court of Appeals ruled 7 to 0 that the expert should have been allowed to testify because conventional wisdom as to the fallibility of eyewitnesses had changed considerably over the years. ALAN FEUER

To the Editor: Seeing what other home cooks thought of a recipe and how they adapted it is one of the democratic benefits of Web sites such as allrecipes.com (''For Orange Zest, Substitute Kool-Aid,'' March 21). I prefer to read such comments before making a dish; if most people write, for example, that more baking soda is needed, it would be stupid of me to ignore that. Last year, I organized and edited the Bryn Mawr College Cookbook, a fund-raiser for my alma mater. I incorporated ideas from testers (each submitted recipe was tested by several people) into a section on comments and suggestions.

A picture caption in some copies on Monday with a sports article about Tiger Woods's victory at the CA Championship misstated his winning streak at Doral Golf Resort and Spa. It was his third victory in a row there, not his sixth.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about Yankees pitcher Jeff Karstens, who struggled in a spring-training game against the Detroit Tigers, misstated his statistics in some copies. He had a 3-1 record and a 2.70 earned run average before facing the Tigers on Sunday, not after giving up six runs in two innings in that game.

The jurors in the trial of Lina Sinha, left, a schoolteacher accused of having had a sexual relationship with two male students from 1996 to 2002, beginning when they were junior high school students, indicated yesterday to Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court that they had reached agreement on 10 of the 19 counts in a revised indictment and that they were at an impasse on the rest. The jury did not disclose which counts they had agreed on. Eleven of the 19 counts are nonsexual charges against Ms. Sinha, such as making false calls to 911, witness tampering and bribing a witness. Justice Berkman instructed the jurors, who have deliberated for three and a half days, to continue to try to reach a verdict on all counts, and deliberations are to continue today. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

Eliot Spitzer and lawmakers agreed to add at least $850 million to his proposal, including restoring $350 million for health care, and appeared to have resolved the main issues on a spending plan.
