MAHONEY--Adrian D., 73, of New Canaan, CT died March 25, 2007. Born in NYC, NY. Survived by his beloved wife Kathleen Mahoney. Son of the late John T. Mahoney and Mary E. Mahoney. Survived by his children Sheila Flood, Regina Mahoney, Caroline Delaney, Elizabeth MahoneySantos and Stephen Mahoney. His grandchildren are: Daniel, Patrick, Meagan, Stephanie, Christian, Jack, Matthew and Michael. Only surviving brother, James Mahoney. He served honorably in the Army during the Korean conflict and was a Disabled American Veteran. Until his death he was a CFM, Vice President, Financial Advisor at Merrill Lynch in the Darien office, worked at several offices within Merrill Lynch, Wall St., Penn Plaza, White Plains. He was Senior Vice President for Kidder Peabody of the Garden City office. Working with Paine Webber, he had over 40 years in the financial service industry with an exemplary client service record. Mr. Mahoney had a long time commitment to empowering others. He received The Graymoor Franciscan Friars of the Atonement ''Community Service Award.'' He was a board member of the Westchester Halfway House. He co-founded the Westchester Halfway House Annual Golf Outing. He was a board member for the Cardinal Hayes Golf Outing. He served as a member of several organizations: The Cardinals Committee of the Laity, The Society of Friendly Sons of Saint Patrick in the County of Westchester and County of Manhattan, and was a long time friend of Bill Wilson with many years of service to others. He was affiliated with the New Rochelle Boys and Girls Clubs. He was on the Board of Governors of the Wykagyl Country Club serving as Treasurer and long time member. He was also a member of the Garden City Golf Club. Served as board member of the Empire College of New York. He attended Saint Johns University and Cardinal Hayes High School. Funeral service will be held on Thursday, March 29, at St. Aloysius Church at 10 AM, New Canaan, CT.

DINING out is one of the greatest pleasures of living in New York City. The variety! The quality! Unless, of course, you pick the wrong night. Because even though New York is a world class restaurant town, it is also a quintessential small town when it comes to the cataloging of slights, double-crosses and hurt feelings. People here pay lip service to ''forgive and forget'' but rarely do either. Like fine wine, a top-drawer grudge must be aged for years.

Two reports being published today call for greatly expanded use of M.R.I. scans in women who have breast cancer or are at high risk for it. The recommendations do not apply to most healthy women, who have only an average risk of developing the disease.

GELLER--Ruth. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club record the passing of our long time member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her daughters, Karen Kneller and Jill Lenchner, her four grandchildren, and her brother, Irving Nelson. Attilio Petrocelli, President Roger Blumencranz, Secretary

When homeowners close up a beach house after Labor Day, they have a checklist of things to do to prepare the home for the harshness of winter. Similarly, second-home owners with winter retreats -- from ski cabins that don't get much use after the slopes shutter, to desert houses that are silent well before triple-digit-temperature time -- must do everything necessary to prepare for the elements of summer. Second-home owners flock to Mammoth Lakes, Calif., 310 miles north of Los Angeles, for winter ski weekends, but the town sees less traffic in the warmer months and the shoulder seasons. ''There are long periods of time when houses are vacant,'' said Lars Pearce, the owner of Mountain High Concierge, a caretaker service in Mammoth Lakes. In some instances, when owners haven't taken measures to ensure adequate upkeep during their long absences, he said, ''there are entire streets where you can just tell that every house is vacant.''

The central election committee, dominated by supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin, elected as its chairman a former colleague of Mr. Putin's from St. Petersburg, Vladimir V. Churov. Mr. Churov, a member of the lower house of Parliament since 2003, worked with Mr. Putin in the St. Petersburg governor's office in the 1990s. He replaces Aleksandr A. Veshnyakov, whom Mr. Putin ousted this month after he criticized new election laws. Russia is approaching elections for Parliament and president. STEVEN LEE MYERS

SMITH--Janet D., attorney, on March 25, 2007, after a courageous battle with cancer. Survived by her loving husband, Scott J. Zevon, M.D., her beloved parents, Saul and Lillian Smith, her sisters Judy Green and Karen Smith, her brother Alan Smith, and extended family. Beautiful, strong, vibrant, active, wife, cherished daughter, caring sister, loving aunt. She left us with a void that can never be filled and hearts that are shattered. Services Thursday, 3pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. 212-362-6600.

Heather Mills, the estranged wife of Paul McCartney who has a prosthetic leg, drew rave reviews from the judges Monday during an extended two-hour edition of ''Dancing With the Stars.'' According to Nielsen's estimates, the competition garnered an average of 20.2 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., giving ABC a decisive victory for the night. At 10, ABC's ratings fell sharply for the season finale of ''What About Brian'' (7.6 million), which finished second in the hour behind a repeat of ''CSI: Miami'' on CBS (13 million) but ahead of ''The Black Donnellys'' on NBC (5.7 million). Fox was second for the night with ''Prison Break'' at 8 (8 million) and ''24'' at 9 (11.8 million). NBC ranked third, getting a boost from two episodes of ''Deal or No Deal,'' a rerun at 8 (10.8 million) and an original at 9 (12.1 million). CBS, with a lineup of all repeats, posted a fourth-place finish over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

A city bus struck and killed a 23-year-old motorcyclist yesterday in Queens, the police said. The victim, Kristopher Thompson of Cambria Heights, was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The accident happened at about 6:45 p.m. when a bus traveling west on Hillside Avenue hit Mr. Thompson's motorcycle, which was going east on Hillside, near the intersection with 173rd Street. The bus driver was not issued a summons. JENNIFER 8. LEE

Michael Phelps of the United States smashed another record Wednesday night, and this time it was his own. Phelps won the 200-meter butterfly, leading from the first wall to the finish to break his own world record by a stunning 1.62 seconds. As the one-man race progressed, there was more awe than applause in the stands, as fans put their hands to their foreheads and looked wide-eyed at each other and the clock and back at each other again. Phelps finished with a time of 1 minute, 52.09 seconds.

Both the Dane and Propp families have set an unparalleled example of philanthropic leadership and commitment to the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and worldwide. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Gail and Ephraim, and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O

An article in Business Day on Friday about a new strategic proposal by Borders Group, one of the nation's largest book retailers, misstated the company's plans for its international segment. It is exploring various alternatives that could eventually lead to the sale or franchising of the majority of its 73 superstores abroad, including those in Britain, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand; it is not closing the stores.

Just in time for Passover, which begins Monday at sundown, are two new guides to kosher and Israeli wines. ''The Wine Route of Israel,'' right, by Yaron Goldfisher and Eliezer Sacks (Cordinata Publishing House, 2006, $49.95), is a handsome, lavishly photographed and illustrated volume. It tracks the traditions of wine in the region back to biblical days, and follows the evolution of the modern Israeli wine industry, starting with Baron Edmond de Rothschild in the 1880s. Israel has eight designated regions, and the 75 wineries and their wines are described. The book is sold at Manhattan Judaica, 62 West 45th Street, and can be ordered from judaism.com or (800) 583-2476.

Steller, Jr. Grandmother of eleven; sisters Claire Grimes and Sally Riordan and brother James O'Gara. Memorial Mass at 11:00 a.m. on Saturday, March 31 at The Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, CT, followed by a reception.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would stop paying for health insurance for members of its board. The agency made the move in response to a legal opinion by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo that determined the practice was improper. The authority said that 4 of its 21 board members were receiving benefits through the New York State Health Insurance Plan. The combined insurance payments for the four would have cost the authority about $40,000 this year, said Jeremy Soffin, a spokesman for the authority. The four board members had been paying what would normally be considered employees' shares of the premiums, Mr. Soffin said. WILLIAM NEUMAN

NADELSON--Sally, passed away on March 20th, 2007, at the age of 92 after a brief illness. She was the quintessential Jewish mother, devoting her life to the health and wellbeing of her family. She is survived by two sons, Gerald Nadelson of Long Island and Kenneth Nadelson of Manhattan, and one daughter, Hon. Eileen N. Nadelson of Manhattan. She is also survived by four grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

To the Editor: Julia Moskin's article on cooking with cheap wine (''It Boils Down to This: Cheap Wine Works Fine,'' March 21) spoke of ''a California chardonnay so oaky it tasted as if it had been aged in a box of No. 2 pencils.'' This was witty but inaccurate. According to Henry Petroski's book ''The Pencil: A History of Design and Circumstance,'' the standard wood used in pencils is cedar, not oak. Ms. Moskin could surely taste the difference. John T. Durkin Ardmore, Pa.

THERE is a world of pancakes beyond breakfast. Some are familiar to experienced cooks: potato pancakes and their Swiss cousins, rösti; corncakes and their South American relatives, arepas; and the earthy buckwheat crepes of Brittany. Others are a little more advanced, like the ones we cook here. What all of these pancakes have in common is a certain off-the-cuff friendliness and flexibility. Once you understand that the batter essentially holds the more important ingredients together, and once you get the hang of what that batter looks like, you're free to start adding food almost at will, as you would with a soup or salad.

A front-page Inside summary on Sunday about a new translation of the Koran misstated a controversial interpretation of a verse about a husband's dealing with a rebellious wife. It says the husband should go away from the woman if her behavior does not improve; it does not say the woman should be ''sent away.''

Distinctive Yixing teapots (pronounced ee-shing) from China, unglazed and in distinctive shapes, were often fashioned by poets and calligraphers during the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911). Some of these, like the teapot incised with calligraphy, right, are on display through June 16 in an exhibition, ''Tea, Wine and Poetry,'' at the China Institute, 125 East 65th Street. Other rare wine and water vessels, like the pewter wine cup with a jade handle, above, some of them never before shown in the United Sates, are also in the show, as are calligraphy, drawings by the artists and rubbings, with translations, of the inscriptions and art on the objects.

WHITE--Gertrude S. The ORT America family (formerly American ORT and Women's American ORT) deeply mourn the passing of Gertrude S. White, Honorary National President of Women's American ORT and past President (1983-1987). An active member since 1952, she witnessed the growth and was involved in the major developments in the ORT network. She saw the effect of its mission in strengthening Jewish communities. Mrs. White viewed ORT as a vast family, from local chapter members to the highest leader in World ORT. As National Membership Chairman, she increased membership to record levels. She cared deeply about ORT and was a staunch supporter of its educational programs the world over. We will miss her dedication, loving spirit and vision. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to her three daughters, Ina, Loretta and Susan, and her two granddaughters. Judy Menikoff, National Pres. Joe Cohen, National V.P. Hope Kessler, National Exec. Dir.

An administrative appeals court in Bordeaux overturned the 2006 conviction of the national railway SNCF for taking part in the deportation of two members of a French Jewish family in World War II. The conviction last June, ordering compensation, set off 1,800 more claims. The appeals court said the case did not fall within its jurisdiction -- lawsuits brought against the state -- because SNCF is an independent entity. It did not rule on the case itself, brought by two members of the Lipietz family who were put on a train to the transit camp at Drancy near Paris in May 1944. They remained there until the camp was liberated a few months later, and brought the suit in 2001. Thousands of French Jews were transported from Drancy to Nazi death camps. A lawyer for the family said it would appeal. ARIANE BERNARD
CAMPS--Helen, died after a valiant battle. She will always be remembered for her spirit and devotion to family. Daniel and Eleanor, Robert and Anita Nelson

A 27-year-old police officer was shot in the leg last night while trying to arrest a man smoking marijuana on a busy Brooklyn street last night, according to the authorities. The officer was hospitalized in stable condition. A 23-year-old suspect was taken into custody, and the police were looking for a man who had been with him. Article, Page B3

FOR almost two hours on a recent afternoon, Joël Robuchon cooled his heels in the lounge by the entrance to L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon at the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown Manhattan. He ordered a coca light, which made the hostess hesitate for a few seconds until she realized he wanted a Diet Coke. He was waiting to give a lesson on cooking with shellfish (''March, April -- these are the best months for seafood,'' he said), but lunch customers were still lingering in the dining room. Worse, they were still sitting on the tall, comfortable stools at the restaurant's heart -- the horseshoe-shaped counter that surrounds the open kitchen. This counter is Mr. Robuchon's radical way of blurring the line between kitchen and dining room. But it was also holding up the class. These 20 stools (and the 26 seats at tables) are often reserved as long as a month in advance, and Mr. Robuchon didn't want the clatter of a cooking session to distract guests who had waited so long for lunch.

To the Editor: Re ''In Need of a Booster Shot: Rising Costs Make Doctors Balk at Giving Vaccines'' (Business Day, March 24): Once again business interests dominate health care delivery, demonstrated in the rising costs pediatricians incur to safeguard the health of our children and provide necessary vaccines.

WHITE--Lawrence (Larry), died on March 25, 2007. Born in Cohoes, NY, he was one of the pioneers of the early days of television broadcasting. He began his career at the Dumont Television Network. At CBS he was instrumental in developing the long running daytime programs, 'As the World Turns', and 'Hollywood Squares'. He then joined NBC daytime, and eventually became Vice President of Nighttime TV in Los Angeles. He was President of Columbia Pictures TV. He produced the award winning miniseries 'The Blue and the Gray'. A graduate of Syracuse University, he received their George Arents Alumni Award. He is survived by his devoted wife and partner, Catherine DeCarolo White, daughters Carol Bishop and Lauren White, son-in-law Alex Gansa, and grandchildren Michael and Steven Bishop, and William Gansa. Services will be held on Friday, March 30, at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison, at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to the Visiting Neighbors Association. 611 Broadway, NY 10012, Suite 510.

The Empire Strikes; Snoop and Diddy Strike Back The rappers P. Diddy and Snoop Dogg (above from left, in Helsinki, Finland, at the start of their European tour) canceled the British leg yesterday after Snoop Dogg was denied a visa to enter the country, the BBC reported. ''With late notice'' of the denial, a spokeswoman said, ''time has run out, and it is too late to reconfigure the show.'' They were scheduled to perform in London last night, before appearances in Cardiff, Manchester, Glasgow and Nottingham. The tour is to resume in Dublin on Saturday. Snoop Dogg, 35, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, was arrested last year in a disturbance at Heathrow Airport. In an interview with MTV in Amsterdam, he said, ''They knew I was coming six, seven weeks ago, so they could have denied me access then.'' The Foreign and Commonwealth Office said it could not comment on individual cases. Rostropovich Celebrated With the Kremlin as the setting, a feeble but pleased Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist and conductor, was honored last night on his 80th birthday, The Associated Press reported. At a gala celebration in a hall where the decorations resembled cellos, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia presented Mr. Rostropovich with a medal, below, the Order of Service to the Fatherland, after issuing a statement that saluted his accomplishments in music and his efforts on behalf of human rights. In remarks shown on Russian television, Mr. Rostropovich said, ''I feel myself the happiest man in the world.'' Observances of Mr. Rostropovich's birthday took place against a background of concerns about his health. He was hospitalized in February for an unspecified illness, and Russian news media reported that he had spent time in the country's leading cancer hospital. Royal Academy Names a New Chief Charles Saumarez Smith, director of the National Gallery in London, has stepped down and will become the Royal Academy's chief executive, the two institutions said yesterday. Mr. Smith's successor at the National Gallery has not been chosen. Mr. Saumarez Smith, 52, has run the National Gallery since 2002 and previously headed the National Portrait Gallery. His departure comes just over a week after The Sunday Times in London reported that he was engaged in a power struggle with the chairman of the gallery's board of trustees, Peter Scott, who was calling for his departure. But a spokeswoman for the National Gallery said Mr. Saumarez Smith had been ''headhunted'' for the Royal Academy position since late last year and added, ''The recent coverage has absolutely nothing to do with this at all.'' Footnotes Fans of the Tony Award-winning hit Broadway musical ''Jersey Boys'' will get plenty of its source material on June 5, when Rhino Records releases the boxed set ''Jersey Beat -- The Music of Frankie Valli & the 4 Seasons.'' The three CDs, featuring the lead singer Frankie Valli, the guitarist Tommy DeVito, the bassist Nick Massi and the keyboardist Bob Gaudio, include 76 tracks of the band's biggest hits and will be accompanied by a DVD of rare live performances, an 86-page booklet and other material. Fox will expand the ''American Idol'' results show to an hour beginning at 9 p.m. on April 11, Variety.com reported. '' 'Til Death,'' currently scheduled at 9:30, will end its run with a finale from 8 to 9 on April 11. In an innovation, the entire final season of ''Punk'd'' on MTV will be broadcast as a ''Sneak Peak Marathon'' in the afternoon of April 7. The eight segments will then be shown as scheduled, weekly at 9 p.m. starting on April 10, Variety.com reported.

If you're looking for a documentary about the electronic music scene filled with historical lectures, performance clips and talking heads, ''Headspace The Sound of Life '' isn't for you and doesn't try to be. Unlike previous documentaries about the topic, this feature by Jethro Senger tries to capture the essence of the music and the lifestyle associated with it. It's experimental rather than expository, bargain-basement visionary work that deploys evocative filmmaking devices (slow dissolves, frame blurs, slow and fast motion, strobe-flash effects) to induce a 3-a.m.-on-the-dance-floor mindset, a feeling that time is suspended and that the only thing that matters is the beat (described by one interview subject as ''fat kick always -- boom, boom'').

A picture with an entry in the News Summary on March 6 about the refusal by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan to apologize for his country's use of some 200,000 women as sexual slaves during World War II was published in error. It showed Koichi Haraguchi, Japan's envoy in charge of normalizing ties with North Korea -- not Mr. Abe.

The City Council will begin reviewing money it allocates annually through programs known as Council initiatives, the speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said yesterday. There are 168 initiatives this fiscal year that award money to 900 community organizations. About 300 of those groups, which are set to receive $32.5 million, will be required to begin submitting quarterly performance reports with the Council this year. Another 300 groups will be required to do so in 2008, and the final 300 in 2009. Ms. Quinn said the new requirement would make the city's $55 billion budget more transparent. SEWELL CHAN

One of the chief pleasures of New Directors/New Films -- perhaps the main reason to return to this well-respected, sometimes uneven program -- is surprise. A mini-festival presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, New Directors promises a yearly respite from the same old stuff, and perhaps also from the predictable forms of novelty for its own sake. That promise is kept in the very first moments of ''Congorama,'' a highlight of the program's second half. (This year's New Directors/New Films, which began last Wednesday, continues through Sunday.) Before anything has happened -- before the film's wayward, eccentric characters have been plunged into their hectic adventures; before the sudden appearance of an ostrich on a Quebec highway; before the disastrous product demonstration involving a power line de-icer made of plastic foam coffee cups -- the words ''two years earlier'' appear on the screen.

To the Editor: Re ''Time for Answers'' (editorial, March 27): Please let's not kid ourselves that the foul aroma emanating from our attorney general's office is the only reason we can't trust this administration's competence and honesty. Other examples abound, like yellowcake from Africa, the lack of adequate body armor for our troops, condoning torture, Katrina, the attempted Dubai ports deal, the C.I.A. spy leak, the Abramoff lobbying scandal, wiretaps without oversight, and the Walter Reed Army Medical Center disgrace.

An article in Business Day on Monday about the decline of newspaper advertising revenues in February misstated the period in which print revenue declined 3.7 percent, to $13.2 billion. It was for the fourth quarter of 2006 compared with the same period in 2005 -- not for the full year.

New York City has its very own entry into World Music Day. Based on the Fête de la Musique that started in Paris in 1982 and has spread to cities around the globe, ''Make Music New York'' will celebrate summer's arrival on June 21 with more than 1,200 free concerts that will stretch until 10 p.m. through the city's five boroughs and range from classical music at Lincoln Center to a gospel choir singing outside of its church. ''I think that having surprising musical events will give New Yorkers a chance to come out from under their headphones and actually interact with each other,'' said Aaron Friedman, one of the day's organizers. The outdoor festival will showcase amateur and local musicians as well as larger performance spaces, like a Bedford Avenue block party in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and a funk and reggae stage in Jamaica, Queens. Information: makemusicny.org. ASHLEY PARKER

A picture caption in Business Day on Monday, with an article about the shift by consumers to digital music from CDs, misstated the name of the band that had signed a deal to record two songs rather than a full album. It is Candy Hill, not Cherry Hill.

MISROCK--Barbara G., on March 27, 2007, of Chappaqua, NY. Wife of the late S. Leslie Misrock. Mother of Kathryn Misrock Goldstein, Victoria Misrock Stein, and the late David Misrock. Sister of Arline Gilbert. Grandmother of Ben, Sam and Stella Goldstein, and Levi Stein. Graveside service Thursday, 11 AM, Sharon Garden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, at Phelps Memorial Hospital, 777 North Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591, would be appreciated.

A report in The Caucus roundup yesterday, about fund-raising support offered by the presidential campaign of Senator Hillary Clinton to the defunct campaign of Tom Vilsack, Iowa's former governor, misstated the name of the House committee on which Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Vilsack's brother-in-law, Tom Bell, worked as aides during the Congressional investigations of Watergate. It was the House Judiciary Committee. (There was no ''House Watergate Committee.'')

ON the 500th anniversary of Spain's expulsion of Jews, King Juan Carlos went to a synagogue in Madrid and said, in essence, mistakes were made, welcome back. A little late, but Ana Benarroch de Bensadón appreciated it. She hadn't felt very warmly welcomed in 1963 when she and her husband moved to Madrid from Tangiers, in Morocco, where their families had lived for centuries until the instability following Morocco's independence forced them out.

ROSIN--Axel G. The Board and staff of the Scherman Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved chairman emeritus. A courageous man, leaving Nazi Germany and arriving in America in 1934, Axel Rosin went on to become the president of the Book-of-theMonth Club, founded by his father-in-law, Harry Scherman, and the extraordinary chairman and guiding spirit of the Scherman Foundation. His humanity, his vision, his unfailing sense of right and wrong have been critical touchstones to the work of the Foundation. He believed in the effectiveness of nonprofit leaders and encouraged our support of thousands of organizations in NYC and across the nation that advocate for a more just world, through their activities in nurturing community development, protecting the environment, upholding women's reproduction rights and health, defending human and civil rights, working for peace, and advancing the arts. We extend our love and condolences to his wife, our long-time board member, Kathy; his daughters Karen Sollins, our esteemed chairman, and Susanna Bergtold, our fellow board member; and his grandchildren Peter Sollins and Amy Bergtold. Board Members: Hillary Brown, David Jones, Gordon Litwin, John O'Neil, Tony Schulte, Marcia Thompson, John Wroclawski Sandra Silverman, President; Mike Pratt, Treasurer
''People want our troops home.'' SENATOR BEN NELSON, Democrat of Nebraska, on his shift in position to vote in favor of setting an Iraq withdrawal date. [A1]

STONE--Virginia. Formerly of 25 Central Park West, NY. Entered peacefully into rest at the age of 88 on March 27, 2007. Loving wife of the late Jerry Stone. Beautiful mother of Leslie and Marlene Stone. Very proud grandmother of Adam Osterweil and John Roesch. Grandmother-in-law of Mindy Roesch. Greatgrandmother of Johnny and Zachary Roesch. Loved by many, all of whom will miss her dearly. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 36-46 Bell Blvd., Bayside. Service Thurs. 12:30pm. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery. Visiting Wed. 6-8pm.
A listing of film reviews on the cover of Weekend on Friday misstated the title of one film. It is ''Shooter,'' not ''The Shooter.''

CHESS--Stella. We mourn the death of this distinguished psychiatrist, prominent psychoanalyst, superb teacher, world class researcher and extraordinary woman who taught, treated and supervised generations of New York University -Bellevue Hospital medical students and staff. Stanley L. Portnow, M.D. John M. Graham, M.D.

A picture credit in Weekend on Friday with the Books of The Times review, about ''How Doctors Think,'' by Jerome Groopman, misspelled the photographer's surname. The picture of Dr. Groopman was by David Carmack, not Carmac.

A silver maple tree infested with the Asian longhorned beetle has been found on Staten Island, the first evidence ever of the tree-damaging insect in the borough, the city's Parks and Recreation Department said yesterday. Beetle eggs in the tree, in a privately owned woodland in Bloomfield, were discovered on Thursday by United States Department of Agriculture workers. When the maple was last inspected, in May 2006, it showed no signs of infestation, the parks department said. TIMOTHY WILLIAM

A suicide bomber dressed as an Afghan soldier detonated the explosives strapped to his body at the entrance of the police headquarters in Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, and killed four policemen. ABDUL WAHEED WAFA

Around lunchtime in New Orleans, former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Richard Breeden told the audience at the Corporate Law Institute that he had a message for directors who think they can sit out the rise in shareholder activism: “Change will come. It’s only a matter of who brings it.”

The big investment banks are everywhere these days, underwriting public offerings, advising buyers and providing deal financing — often on behalf of the same company. This ubiquity has created some concern when a bank needs to be found to handle a “go shop” provision in a takeover agreement, which essentially creates a window during which the target tries to drum up better offers. The dilemma: Does the desire for a completely independent bank trump the desire for a bank with sufficient resources and relevant experience?

There are increasing complaints among shareholders that companies are selling out to private equity at bargain prices — leaving the buyout shops to enjoy the upside when the business gets sold or taken public again. But Robert Kindler, Morgan Stanley‘s vice chairman of investment banking, says these critics are generally off-base. In his opening speech Thursday to deal lawyers at Tulane Law School’s Corporate Law Institute, Mr. Kindler suggested that, in this torrid buyout market, most companies are getting top dollar when they agree to go private.

DealBook comes to you this morning from New Orleans, where Tulane University Law School’s 19th Annual Corporate Law Institute is just getting under way. Many of the nation’s most prominent deal lawyers, including Casey Cogut of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and Richard Katcher of Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, are here to talk tactics and drink mint juleps. Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. of Delaware’s Court of Chancery is here as well, and he is already talking about two of his favorite subjects: go shops and staple financing. We won’t dwell on the legal jargon, but we will bring you updates throughout the day and in tomorrow’s e-mail report.
We're still not quite finished testing your many theories for the hexagon above Saturn's north pole, but I can give you a brief progress report.

Ten years ago, most American airports offered visitors little more than a trifecta of coffee shops, greasy fast food and newsstands. But in just the last few years, United States airports have greatly expanded their amenities and offerings, including spas, upscale shopping malls and first-rate cuisine to make the travel experience more enjoyable.
The public gets a chance to play a million-dollar Stradivarius before it is auctioned.
Tomorrow, Joe Torre said, will be a busy day. He plans to announce his 25-man roster and his rotation, which means he'll have to tell all the players involved before he tells the media.

The Mets' opening day roster gained some clarity today when they reassigned seven players, most notably outfielder Ben Johnson, to minor-league camp and confirmed that Aaron Sele and Joe Smith have made the team. By my count, that accounts for 23 players, leaving four players -Jon Adkins, Ambiorix Burgos, Chan Ho Park and Lastings Milledge - to compete for the final two. I'm also operating under the assumption that the fifth starter Mike Pelfrey, who won't be needed until April 15, will begin the season in the minors to free up a roster spot.

I've got some good news to share. The latest word about day care from the nation's largest, longest-running, highest-quality, mega-government-financed study is this: it doesn't really matter much at all.

There is little difference between politics and performance, D. Kyle Sampson told a Senate panel today. But can a move that's largely political, though not necessarily partisan, pass the smell test? As the recently resigned chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales both contradicted and defended his boss today, the nuance of his claim became apparent in the context of the ouster of Carol C. Lam, one of eight United States attorneys whose dismissals called into question the credibility of the Bush Justice Department."The distinction between political- and performance-related reasons for removing a U.S. attorney is, in my view, largely artificial," Mr. Sampson said in his opening statement to the Senate Judiciary Committee. "A U.S. attorney who is unsuccessful from a political perspective, either because he or she has alienated the leadership of the department in Washington or cannot work constructively with law enforcement or other governmental constituencies in the district, is unsuccessful."
As went Gandalf's advice to Frodo, so goes -- apparently -- the legislative philosophy of Albany's leaders.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Meet the Robinsons" which features celebrated new graphics technology and tired old movie cliches.

The clever but blandly named blog Complete Sports pointed out yesterday that because Jim Nantz is once again CBS's broadcaster for the Final Four, we can all expect one of his jocular witticisms once the eventual champion is crowned. Nantz has made a habit of this, with three famous punny groaners:
The public "rollout" of Mrs. Giuliani on ABC: An inseparable couple, even in cabinet meetings? [The Caucus]
Honda, a company well known for the fuel efficiency of its cars, now wants safety to be part of its identity too.

Oh, I had low, low hopes for Justin.tv when I saw it on Joe Bua's first-rate nutter blog, I Am a TV Junkie. Yeah, it's another Web keyhole: another promise that you'll get to watch someone's random life full-time, and eventually to influence it.

Since I quoted the New York Sun editorial a couple of weeks ago denouncing me for spreading a new "blood libel" in my colum about Israel, I should also note that there are plenty of other commentaries that are much more measured. The Jewish Daily Forward had a very sensible essay that discussed my column and how to react to the broader debate about Israel. Here's an excerpt, but it's difficult to summarize and I recommend reading the entire essay.
Poronui Station, an exclusive high-country property on New Zealand's North Island, was listed among the world's top 20 properties for sale in 2005 by Forbes magazine.
The office of State Senator Tom Duane says his latest podcast is now up on iTunes and other podcast directories (and the the link should have it available soon as streaming audio).

Last year's implosion at Amaranth Advisors was so huge it caused many people to conclude that the hedge-fund business was in meltdown mode. But a new study paints a different picture, finding that there were fewer hedge fund liquidations in 2006 than there were in 2005. (There were fewer fund launches as well.)

Going private is a "long-term option" for McClatchy, according to Gary Pruitt, the newspaper chain's chief executive. But first, he told a crowd at Syracuse University's Newhouse School, he must put the company, which is the United States' third-largest newspaper publisher, "in a position to have the flexibility to go private."

Fox News Channel is announcing today that it has cut a deal with the Congressional Black Caucus Institute to sponsor two debates, one with Democrats and another with Republicans in the 2008 presidential race.

The first Bill-to-Hill crossover of the presidential season involved the career shift of Jay Carson, a respected political operative who has worked as Mr. Clinton's communications director since June 2005.
A roundup of real estate news:

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today in Brooklyn that the city was moving ahead with a bold anti-poverty experiment that will use private donations to pay 2,500 families $25 to $300 for meeting various targets -- better school attendance, higher test scores -- up to a total of $5,000 a year.

Following races in Belgium, Germany and Italy, the French Grand Prix may take a sabbatical next year, according to a statement today from the Federation Française de Sport Automobile, and as I pointed out last week after reading an interview with Bernie Ecclestone in AutoHebdo.

Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani would have no problem letting his wife Judith sit in on cabinet meetings, were he elected president. And she doesn't have any problem with becoming an adviser in the West Wing either, especially on issues of health care.

For those who complain that initial public offerings are having a tough time, Wednesday will have provided no solace. Three I.P.O.'s that opened that day raised about 21 percent less than they sought, potentially casting a shadow over three offerings set to debut this week. Bloomberg News notes that Super Micro Computer and SenoRx cut their prices to complete their deals, while GSI Technology lowered the number of shares offered. (The reasons why the companies' offerings were less successful than expected isn't clear. Bloomberg offers a slowing economy and declining stock prices as possible culprits.)

Edward F. Cox, a lawyer and a son-in-law of President Richard M. Nixon who briefly ran against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for Senate in 2005, will be the New York State chairman of Senator John McCain's presidential campaign.
Please tell me Brandon Armstrong is a classically trained anchorman.
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's Mar. 29 column, "The D.C. Tea Party."
Readers respond to David Brooks's Mar. 29 column, "No U-Turns."

Mechel, a Russian metals and mining company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, said Thursday it would acquire Southern Kuzbass Power Plant for about $265 million. The deal follows an auction for the power station, which was split off from Kuzbassenergo, a Russian utility, as part of a 2006 restructuring. Mechel said that the acquisition was part of a strategy to reduce costs by generating some of its own power.

Sidney Toledano, the chief executive of Dior, confirmed this morning that Hedi Slimane will no longer design Dior Homme, ending months of negotiations that were often at an impasse between the runway star and executives of Dior and LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton. Slimane has been replaced by Kris Van Assche, who signed his contract with Dior just a few hours ago in Paris.

Thursday's report that BCE, the owner of Bell Canada, might be acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in Canada's largest buyout drew this carefully worded statement from the company: There are "no ongoing discussions being held with any private equity investor with respect to any privatization of the company or any similar transaction."

So the big thing officials here in Albany point to when questioned about the lack of transparency in budget negotiations is the conference committee system, where the Senate and the Assembly are supposed to hash out the nitty-gritty details of the budget in public.

At a panel discussion last night about women in politics, the tireless Azi Paybarah of The Politicker was apparently one of the few men in attendance. He said that June O'Neill, the state Democratic Party chair, had this advice as she introduced the panelists: Shake hands. "It's a code."
Carlos Delgado rejoined the team this morning after spending the last six days with his wife after she gave birth to the couple's first son, Carlos Antonio, last Friday in Puerto Rico.
An ad campaign, with a budget estimated at more than $12 million, introduces the theme "Food loves French's," with a heart made out of yellow mustard in place of the word "loves."
We're back to five men in a room. (Is that better than three men in a room?)

If hedge fund managers want to dispel their air of secrecy, this is probably not the way to do it. The folks at Solengo Capital, the firm being opened by former traders of the collapsed hedge fund Amaranth Advisors, have apparently told at least two blogs to remove Solengo's marketing materials from their Web site, claiming they are not authorized to disseminate them. One of the blogs, Greg Newton's Naked Shorts, agreed to take down the brochure, telling Reuters that although he did not think he was legally required to do so, "something like this can very quickly be a big legal bill."
From rookie of the year to captain of the Yankees, a look back at Derek Jeter's career.

The media are ramping up their coverage of a possible Fred Thompson candidacy, and the former senator/current "Law & Order" star has done little to discourage the rampant speculation. The Washington Post's Michael D. Shear takes a look at Mr. Thompson's strengths and weaknesses relative to the existing G.O.P. field. Polls are already showing, at least, strong name recognition, and he has a fairly consistent conservative voting record (his support of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance legislation a major exception). Of course, he'd have to catch up on fundraising.
Do you think the government's restrictions on the amount of liquidsallowed as carry-on luggage has made you feel safer on your planetrips?

Advanstar, a business-to-business marketer, will be acquired by a consortium led by a media-focused private equity firm, Veronis Suhler Stevenson, for $1.14 billion in cash. Veronis and its partners, Citigroup Private Equity and New York Life Capital Partners, will buy the company from its current sponsor, Credit Suisse's DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, which has already approved the deal.

Writing on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times, Joseph D. Rich, chief of the voting section in the Justice Department's civil rights division from 1999 to 2005, alleges that there has been a "destructive pattern of partisan political actions at the Justice Department" under President Bush, long before the Gonzales Eight. "Over the last six years, this Justice Department has ignored the advice of its staff and skewed aspects of law enforcement in ways that clearly were intended to influence the outcome of elections," Rich writes. He adds:
I'm wrapping up my notes on the 2007 TED conference (Technology, Entertainment, Design), a reality-altering, four-day series of 50 speakers, most of whom are absolutely brilliant.

President Bush and the Republican leadership in both the House and the Senate have complained about many of the additions to the emergency war bill that would provide billions of dollars for domestic projects.
The meat-and-potatoes style of “Sacco and Vanzetti” seems less a failure of imagination than a means of putting in the foreground its intriguing subject matter.

The world's hedge funds managed more than $2 trillion at the end of 2006, 30 percent more than a year earlier, even as returns trailed, according to a survey. More than 350 hedge fund managers look after more than $1 billion each, according to HedgeFund Intelligence's first global review of the industry. Europe is the world's fastest-growing hedge fund market, while most assets in the category are managed out of the United States, the London-based researcher said.

United States Steel Corporation said it plans to buy Lone Star Technologies, a maker of welded pipe used in oil fields, in a $2.1 billion cash deal that will make it North America's largest producer of tubular steel.
Imagine an entire film infected with hangdog sensibility, unrelieved by humor or narrative interest, and you have “The Hawk Is Dying.”

The private equity group 3i said Thursday it would pay out 800 million pounds ($1.57 billion) to shareholders later this year, bringing its total payouts to investors over the last two years to 2 billion pounds. Buoyant financial markets have driven up its returns from asset sales in the financial year ending this month, the firm said.

The European Commission took Spain to the highest European Union court on Wednesday for interfering in the $56.5 billion bid by the German utility E.On for Endesa. The move marks the latest legal hurdle in the takeover battle for Endesa, Spain's biggest utility, amid accusations of economic nationalism and fears that the deal could spend years in litigation.

Upon announcing the $150 million acquisition of the local beer company Cintra on Wednesday, Brazil's leading brewer, AmBev, said it would invest about $2.4 billion in Brazil over the next five years. AmBev already has close to 70 percent of the country's beer market and said it required the record level of investment to expand its production capacity and take advantage of the growing beverage market.

The past week has not been kind to Stefano Pessina, the deputy chairman of Alliance Boots of Britani. While he and a partner, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, are expected to raise the 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) bid that his company rejected last month, rival suitors came into the picture. Then he was reportedly banned from the health and beauty store's central office.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is looking to make a friendly takeover bid for BCE, the owner of Bell Canada. A successful purchase would be the largest acquisition in Canadian corporate history, according to The Globe and Mail, and one of the world's largest leveraged buyouts.

Barclayshas hired Citigroup as an adviser on its takeover negotiations with ABN Amro, Reuters reported Wednesday. The move would effectively block the United States group from making a counterbid for the Dutch bank.

Gol will buy Brazil's former flagship carrier, Varig, in a cash and stock deal valued at about $275 million, Gol said Wednesday. Gol will also assume about $45 million of Varig's debt. Varig, which had been Brazil's top airline for decades, fell victim to crushing debt last year and was bought in bankruptcy proceedings by investors that included Brazilians and the United States investment fund Matlin Patterson.

Texas state regulators are demanding $210 million in fines from the energy company TXU for allegedly manipulating the wholesale power market in 2005. It would mark the largest penalty ever proposed by the Texas Public Utility Commission's staff. TXU, which is currently the subject of a $45 billion buyout proposal, called the accusations "flatly wrong" and said it planned to contest the findings.

Country Garden of China, a property development company, has set the price range for what will become the largest initial public offering by a mainland property company in Hong Kong. At the bottom of the range, the deal will total $1.3 billion, which would beat Shui On Property's $877 million 2006 offering by 48 percent.

In its initial public offering, Citic 1616 Holdings has raised $270 million, the maximum it sought on Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. The company, which provides connectivity between voice and data service providers in Hong Kong and China and telecom operators in about 50 other countries, benefited from a well-timed roadshow that coincided with a rebound in the Hong Kong market.

Warburg Pincus will invest $175 million in the Titan Petrochemicals Group, an oil logistics company listed in Hong Kong. The investment was announced on Wednesday and will be made in two parts. First is a $75 million purchase of equity and convertible preferred shares in Titan Petrochemicals, which will give Warburg Pincus a 9.9 percent stake in the business along with one board seat.

the Aurora Capital Group said Wednesday that it was close to finalizing its acquisition of a software developer, Mitchell International of San Diego, for more than $500 million. It was announced last month that Hellman & Friedman of San Francisco would sell Mitchell, but no price had been disclosed. General Electric Pension Trust is a co-investor in the purchase. Mitchell's management is also investing in the deal and will have a stake of about 15 percent.

Leonard Green & Partners said Wednesday it had closed its latest private equity fund, Green Equity Investors V LP, at $5.3 billion, nearly three times the size of its previous buyout fund, which closed four years ago.

Tragus, a portfolio company of the Blackstone Group, has made a board-recommended 96 million pound ($180 million) bid for the La Tasca Group, a chain of Spanish-food restaurants. Tragus intends to bolster its European presence with the addition of 58 La Tasca restaurants in Britain and four in the United States, adding to 175 restaurants it already operates in France and Italy. La Tasca is based in Lancashire, Britain.
Venture capital is thriving in the Bay Area, it seems: In the past two weeks, three private drug development companies raised a combined $136 million in venture funding.

Shareholders of John H. Harland, a software maker, have approved the company's $1.7 billion acquisition by M&F Worldwide. M&F, which is based in New York, will pay $52.75 a share for Harland, which is based in Atlanta. Harland provides software and printed products to the financial and educational markets and will become a wholly owned subsidiary of M&F Worldwide.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has reassembled a 2,600-year-old Etruscan chariot.

Home Depot's recently ousted chief executive, Robert Nardelli, has received a job offer from Cerberus Capital Management, CNBC reported, citing undisclosed sources. But the home-improvement retailer may try to prevent him from joining Cerberus, a private equity firm whose investments include tje General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the parent of Air Canada, by invoking his noncompete contract, CNBC said.

Pennsylvania's two largest health insurers agreed on Wednesday to merge in a deal that had been in the works for years and gives the two nonprofits control over most of the state's health insurance market. The boards of Independence Blue Cross of Philadelphia and Highmark of Pittsburgh separately approved a merger that would create the nation's third-largest health insurer behind the UnitedHealth Group and Wellpoint.

The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management has agreed to buy the bankrupt auto parts maker Tower Automotive in a deal valued at about $1 billion, the company said Wednesday. Tower, which filed for bankruptcy protection in February 2005, said the sale required court approval and was subject to an auction if other investors submit qualified bids.

The Blackstone Group, the buyout firm that bought Equity Office Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust, agreed to sell 10 buildings in Austin, Tex., to the Thomas Properties Group for $1.15 billion. The transaction includes five downtown office buildings with 2.5 million square feet and five properties in northwest Austin with almost 1 million square feet, Thomas Properties said Thursday.

Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief of Qwest Communications, who is on trial for insider trading, tried to hide $90 million in assets by transferring stock into accounts held solely by his wife, according to information that the prosecution is attempting to submit as evidence.
Porsche made a bid for Volkswagen that values the carmaker at 35.8 billion euros ($47.7 billion), a low offer intended to leave Porsche with a controlling stake rather than full ownership.

Credit Suisse's head of Europe, the Middle East and Africa, Leonhard Fischer, has resigned to become co-chief executive at a holding company controlled by the private equity firm Ripplewood Holdings. His departure comes six weeks after one of Mr. Fischer's colleagues was chosen as the Swiss bank's next chief executive.

General Motors, which significantly improved its financial performance in 2006 but failed to earn a profit, said on Wednesday that for a second consecutive year, it would not pay cash bonuses to top executives. Such bonuses would undoubtedly have rankled members of the United Automobile Workers union ahead of this summer's contract talks, although a G.M. spokeswoman, Renee Rashid-Merem, declined to say whether the pending negotiations were a factor.

In the battle of billionaires looking to buy Tribune, Eli Broad and Ronald Burkle may still make a comeback. The company has responded to a request for additional financial information from the two Los Angeles billionaires, whose bid for the company appeared to have been dismissed, people close to the company's auction said Wednesday.

The popularity of a new scripted TV show in Japan highlights the recent shift in attitudes toward corporate raiding, says the New York Times. Indeed, one of the hottest new shows on Japanese television is called "Vulture" and focuses on a fictional New York investment fund that buys ailing Japanese companies and imposes harsh American-style management changes.
Images from the renovated Audubon Gallery in the American Museum of Natural History.
Among the winners of the $10,000 prize was “The Looming Tower,” by Lawrence Wright.
Rights to “If I Did It” are to be auctioned pursuant to a judge’s ruling that proceeds from the sale be turned over to the family of Ronald L. Goldman.
The British publisher of the Dan Brown best seller has prevailed again over the two historians who contended that Mr. Brown plagiarized themes from their book.
The latest book club selection is a despairing account of a boy and his father lurching across the landscape of a post-apocalyptic world.

A growing number of New Yorkers, often with six-figure salaries and reasonably good credit, have begun to find that mortgages are harder to get as lenders try to stem losses from loans to the weakest, or subprime, borrowers.
The McIlhenny Company, which owns Tabasco and is now in its fifth generation as a family-run business, has been working to overcome flooding caused by Hurricane Rita in 2005.
The final hours of Suaada Saadoun’s life reveal the fierce pressure Sunnis face from Shiite militias in Baghdad.
The real thing for spring.
From flashlights to egg cups, it's all in the edit at Turpan.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
New shows in New York include "The Year of Magical Thinking" and "Exits and Entrances."

Josh Phelps will make the Yankees' roster this season, though Manager Joe Torre can't announce it yet. Andy Phillips is still here in spring training, and after striking out four times on Tuesday, he didn't play tonight. He's hitting .190. Phelps went 0 for 1 and is now batting .424.

Dear readers, I'm Liz Alderman, the IHT's Business Editor, and I invite you to check out the debut of a new column this week on the Business of Green. In Thursday's paper, Elisabeth Rosenthal writes about how everyone seems to be flying everywhere -- a function of busier lives, better air connections and the proliferation of really cheap tickets. The problem, she writes, is that while air travel is the -- dirtiest choice of transport -- in terms of the emissions that cause global warming, no one has figured out how to square the dramatic rise in air travel with the need to curb carbon dioxide emissions. So we'd like to ask: Have any of you purchased carbon offsets to cover your air travel? How did you choose an offset company and how did you research its green projects? If you would like your comments to be considered for publication in the IHT, please remember to include your full name and country. And thank you for coming to our new blog!

A suicide bomber blew himself up in an attack today on a military training area in Punjab province, killing one soldier and wounding seven others, military officials said.
An incendiary law to expand caste-based college admissions quotas, which had set off months of protest last year, was temporarily suspended Thursday by the country’s highest court.

A hospitalized prisoner at Kings County Hospital Center was shot by a police officer last night after he assaulted the officer with a bed rail, the police said. The prisoner, whose identity was not released, was arrested on March 26 in connection with an assault. Last night, shortly before 11, the prisoner broke off the plastic bed rail and hit the on-duty officer in the head, the police said, and the officer then shot the patient, who was taken to the operating room. The officer was treated for lacerations.

A small plane crashed and burned in a wooded area of this community near the Jersey Shore last night, killing the pilot, authorities said. Mayor Joseph DiBella said no one else was aboard. The pilot’s identity was not immediately released. Witnesses said the plane went down around 8 p.m. in a park in the township’s Ramtown section, about 100 yards from the nearest homes. No one on the ground was hurt. A Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman said the plane was a Piper PA-28, a single-engine aircraft. The F.A.A. and the National Transportation Safety Board are investigating the cause of the crash.

A captain in the Genovese crime family and his son participated in the 2005 slaying of a mob soldier whose body was found in a car trunk in New Jersey during his federal extortion trial, according to court papers released yesterday as part of an indictment. The captain, Michael Coppola; his wife, Linda Coppola; and the son, Louis Rizzo Jr., were charged with conspiracy to use false identity papers. Mr. Coppola was apprehended this month after being a fugitive for more than a decade, prosecutors said. A letter submitted by prosecutors details other crimes the two men are accused of, and describes a recorded conversation between them about the gun that was used to murder the soldier, Lawrence Ricci. John Buretta, an assistant United States attorney, said he expected additional charges to be filed.

The leading candidate for the presidency of New York City Transit, which runs the city’s subway and bus systems, is a former transit executive who has worked in New York and in Philadelphia, according to officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The candidate, Howard H. Roberts Jr., 67, ran New York’s bus system in the mid-1980s and became the second-ranking executive of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. He said yesterday that he had not had a job offer, but that he was “very interested.” The previous president, Lawrence G. Reuter, resigned in February.
The Museum of Television and Radio in a panel discussion examined why murder has been such a compelling ingredient to "The Sopranos."
The Nets showed Wednesday night exactly what it would take to make the playoffs: a staunch defense and an offense made effective by attacking the basket.

The leading candidate for the presidency of New York City Transit, which runs the city’s subway and bus systems, is a former transit executive who has worked in New York and in Philadelphia, according to officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The candidate, Howard H. Roberts Jr., 67, ran New York’s bus system in the mid-1980s and became the second-ranking executive of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. Mr. Roberts said yesterday that he had not been offered the job, but that he was “very interested.” The previous president, Lawrence G. Reuter, resigned in February. A decision is expected in the next few days.

A captain in the Genovese crime family and his son participated in the 2005 slaying of a mob soldier whose body was found in a car trunk in New Jersey during his federal extortion trial, according to court papers released yesterday as part of an indictment. The captain, Michael Coppola; his wife, Linda Coppola; and the son, Louis Rizzo Jr., were charged with conspiracy to use false identity papers. Mr. Coppola was apprehended this month after being a fugitive for more than a decade, prosecutors said. A letter submitted by prosecutors details other crimes the two men are accused of, and describes a recorded conversation between them about the gun that was used to murder the soldier, Lawrence Ricci. John Buretta, an assistant United States attorney, said he expected additional charges to be filed.
Steve Francis sprained his right ankle in a victory that ended the Knicks’ longest losing streak of the season and kept them alive in the race for the playoffs.
Royal County Down in Northern Ireland ousted the Old Course at St. Andrews to top Golf Digest magazine’s list of the 100 best golf courses outside the United States.

Fire broke out in a six-story office building in Houston, killing three people and injuring at least six, fire officials said. Flames shot out of the building’s top floors and heavy smoke blanketed a nearby 10-lane freeway, the 610 Loop, at evening rush hour. The cause of the blaze, which was confined to the fifth and sixth floors, was not yet known. Firefighters found the three bodies on the fifth floor, District Fire Chief T. J. Dowdy said. Three firefighters were among the injured.

Chris Bosh became Toronto’s career leader in double-doubles last night when he had 13 points and 17 rebounds to lead the host Raptors to a 96-83 victory that moved them ahead of the Miami Heat and into third place in the Eastern Conference.
For a second year, General Motors says that about 20 top managers, including the chief executive, will not get cash bonuses.
Jochen Hecht scored twice in leading the Buffalo Sabres to a 4-3 victory over the visiting Devils Wednesday night in a meeting of the Eastern Conference’s top two teams.
Prosecutors said the former chief of Qwest transferred $90 million in stock into accounts held solely by his wife.

An article on Saturday about the subway cars purchased by New York City in 1949 in anticipation of construction of a Second Avenue line referred imprecisely to the outcome of those plans. Although no tunnels were dug with the $500 million earmarked in the 1950s for subway construction, some tunnel segments were indeed dug in the 1970s, after the plans were revived.

The Cheering Section article in sports on Sunday, about an author’s contention that the Yankees have had 14 or 15 captains in their history instead of 11, misstated the publication date of a newspaper article about the team, and misspelled the surnames of two players mentioned in that article. The article from The Evening Star in Washington was published on April 20, 1903 — not 1902. The players were Dave Fultz, not Fults, and Jesse Tannehill, not Tannebill.

A picture with a report in the National Briefing column on Saturday about a revelation by Fife Symington, the former governor of Arizona, that he saw a U.F.O. in 1997 was published in error in some copies. The photograph showed Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, not Mr. Symington.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a vote by the Senate to support a date for withdrawing troops from Iraq misstated the withdrawal provision in the Senate legislation. Beginning a pullout of American troops within 120 days of the measure’s enactment is a requirement, not a goal. Completing the pullout by March 31, 2008, is a nonbinding goal of the legislation.

A report in the Vital Signs column in Science Times on March 20, about exercise and memory, misstated part of the name of a brain region associated with memory loss. It is the dentate gyrus, not dentate gyrate.

An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the role eunuchs have played in history — a reflection prompted by the author’s prostate cancer treatment, which resulted in chemical castration — referred imprecisely to one person who was a eunuch. He was St. Ignatius of Constantinople. (Other SS. Ignatius were not known to be eunuchs.).

An article yesterday about a plan by a conservative Colorado parish to leave the Episcopal Church in part because of the church’s policy on same-sex unions misstated that policy. Although the church allows dioceses and parishes to perform rites for same-sex couples, the denomination itself does not sanction such rites.

A music review on Tuesday about Elton John, at Madison Square Garden, misstated the title of a song he performed. It is “All the Girls Love Alice” — not “All the Young Girls Love Alice,” which is a phrase in the lyrics.

An obituary yesterday about Paul C. Lauterbur, who won a Nobel prize for developing M.R.I. technology into a way to look inside living things, misspelled the surname of a professor of physics at the University of Illinois who commented on his work. He is Charles Slichter, not Schlichter.
Corrections

The Ink column on Tuesday, about naptime in the Milstein Hall of Ocean Life at the American Museum of Natural History, misstated the location of the museum’s tigers. They are in the endangered-species exhibit near the Hall of Ocean Life and also in the Hall of Asian Mammals; they are not in the Akeley Hall of African Mammals. (Tigers are not native to Africa.).

The governor’s advisers said that local governments had increased property taxes an average of 6 percent annually over the last several years.
Devils defenseman Richard Matvichuk, who had an operation on his back last June to correct a pinched nerve, has not played a game this season.

The Postal Service unveiled 15 new first-class stamps featuring the gang from “Star Wars.”
The organization endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, for president and pledged to raise money for her from its 500,000 members.
A sorority accused of evicting members based on appearance and popularity sued DePauw University over its decision to expel the sorority.

Two executives at a fence-building company were sentenced to six months of home confinement for hiring illegal immigrants. The men, Mel Kay, founder, chairman and president of the business, Golden State Fence Company of Riverside, and Michael McLaughlin, a manager, had pleaded guilty to knowingly hiring illegal immigrants. In addition, the two were sentenced to three years’ probation. Also, Mr. Kay was fined $200,000; McLaughlin agreed to pay $100,000.

Lawmakers and the governor vowed to abolish the Texas Youth Commission’s board in favor of a juvenile prison czar. The plan puts the agency into a conservatorship for now and allows a single executive to take it over later. The commission has been in turmoil since a two-year-old sexual abuse investigation surfaced a month ago. Lawmakers still must introduce legislation and vote on the plan. Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican, made Jay Kimbrough the conservator. Mr. Kimbrough, left, said that he would fire immediately 111 commission employees who have felony convictions and that superintendents of commission facilities and other top officials would have to reapply for their jobs.

The number of naturalized citizens in the United States population in 2005 was 12.8 million, a record high, a study found.

In an effort to expand ferry service beyond the major tourist attractions to other parts of New York Harbor, city officials made an attempt yesterday to insert themselves into the federal government’s process of choosing a Statue of Liberty ferry operator.

The City Council passed two bills yesterday that expand tax benefits for Mitchell-Lama developments, which provide housing to families with low and moderate income. The first measure would eliminate the $40,000 cap on the assessed value of a unit qualifying for tax benefits for repairs and improvements. The second bill allows Mitchell-Lama co-op or condo developments to receive tax benefits for repairs and improvements and to finance them through government-subsidized loans. Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said the bills were intended to stop a loss of middle-income housing.

The Putnam County executive has signed into law a bill that bars convicted sex offenders from going within 2,500 feet of schools, parks, large apartment houses or any place where children congregate. Opponents said the law, signed by County Executive Robert Bondi on Tuesday, effectively prevents any convicted sex offender from entering or living in the county, The Journal News reported. Mr. Bondi said that he thought the law was a step in the right direction, but that he approved it with reservations because the restrictive zone was so wide.

A severed leg washed up yesterday on the Long Island Sound estate of James L. Dolan, the billionaire chairman of Cablevision and Madison Square Garden, the police said, speculating that the limb was linked to a torso discovered in a suitcase three weeks ago on a Westchester County beach. The police were also investigating whether a leg and foot discovered by a fisherman on Tuesday night in Cold Spring Harbor were also related to the Westchester County remains. The legs were found a little more than three weeks after a suitcase with a torso inside floated onto the beach in Mamaroneck. The police say the victim was a Hispanic or black woman, 5 foot 6 at most, weighing 180 to 200 pounds, with a tattoo of two red cherries on a green stem above her right breast.

Cabrini Medical Center agreed yesterday to pay $3.4 million to settle a federal claim that it improperly billed the New York State Medicaid program for operation of its detoxification unit, federal prosecutors said. The payment related to the operation of the unit from 1995 through 1999, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Cabrini did not admit wrongdoing, and the hospital’s lawyer, Howard Rogatnick, declined to comment yesterday.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would hold a ceremonial groundbreaking for the Second Avenue subway line on April 12. It will take place at Second Avenue and 99th Street, the southern end of a six-block segment of tunnel that was dug in the 1970s for the long-promised subway line. Plans were first formed in the 1920s and have been periodically revived and abandoned. The transportation authority now plans to spend $3.8 billion on the first phase of the subway, which includes stations on Second Avenue at 96th Street, 86th Street and 72nd Street. Preliminary construction work should begin next month. The line is scheduled to open in 2013.

Goldman Sachs Group and Monday Properties have agreed to buy the Helmsley Building on Park Avenue for $1.15 billion from Istithmar and Island Capital Group, Island’s founder, Andrew Farkas, said yesterday. The sellers paid $705 million for the 1.35-million-square-foot building 16 months ago, he said. The sale was reported yesterday in The New York Post.

A coalition of environmental groups called on Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday to declare a moratorium on major development in the environmentally sensitive Highlands area until a state council completes a master plan for development there. Last week, the state commission, established to create the development plan, extended the comment period by five weeks, to May 10. It is the fourth extension on a plan for the 400,000-acre area.

Six police officers were treated for minor injuries yesterday after their three police vehicles collided on the Bronx River Parkway just south of the Pelham Bay exit, the authorities said. The collision occurred about 9 a.m. as the officers responded to a call for help from officers chasing a driver, Harold Boyce of Third Avenue in the Bronx, who had run a stop sign at East 236th Street and Bronx Boulevard and refused to stop for a police car, the police said. They said he then attempted to drive south on the Bronx River Parkway, where his car struck the police car. No injuries resulted from that collision, and Mr. Boyce, who tried to run, was chased down and arrested. The injured officers were treated at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said, and Mr. Boyce was charged with resisting arrest, driving with an expired license and reckless driving.

Two public interest lawyers said yesterday that they planned to ask the United States attorneys for New Jersey and Washington to open a criminal investigation into whether Gov. Jon S. Corzine falsified disclosure statements he filed when he was a United States senator by not including a $470,000 loan to his companion. The lawyers, Carl J. Mayer and Bruce Afran, said they intended to ask the prosecutors to determine if Mr. Corzine, left, violated the False Statements Accountability Act of 1996 by not listing the loan to Carla Katz, a prominent state labor leader, in his Senate disclosure reports over three years. Last October, Mr. Corzine, facing scrutiny from the Senate Ethics Committee, amended those documents to reflect the loan, which he eventually forgave. Ms. Katz, president of Local 1034 of the Communications Workers of America, and Mr. Corzine dated from 2002 to 2004.

8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: JANE FONDA Ms. Fonda, who has been alternately revered and reviled, discusses her life and career with Robert Osborne. The army said it had recovered at least 70 percent of the still-unexploded munitions that were hurled into suburbs of the capital, Maputo, after a military arsenal crammed with decades-old arms exploded last week. Separately, the health minister, Ivo Garrido, told Radio Mozambique that the death toll from the blast had risen to 117. Teams of de-miners and army engineers have been combing residential neighborhoods for the remaining munitions. Many of the wounded were children, some of whom have been sent to South Africa for treatment. Children near the explosion site are still fearful of returning to school, reports said. Some classes were as little as half full this week. MICHAEL WINES

Congress was in turmoil after Jorge Cevallos, left, its elected leader, moved to void an effort to expel 57 opposition legislators for trying to block President Rafael Correa's plan to rewrite the Constitution to make it harder for Congress to topple presidents. The decision by Mr. Cevallos to accept a ruling by a provincial judge in the dispute over the fired lawmakers throws Mr. Correa's plan into doubt. After his surprising announcement, Mr. Cevallos, who swore in the fired lawmakers' substitutes just last week, sought refuge in his office, where he was protected by an elite police unit. The struggle to control Congress comes ahead of a referendum next month in which voters will decide whether to convene a constitutional assembly. SIMON ROMERO

It's a big day for fans of the Internet site cheddarvision.tv, where visitors have been watching a 44-pound round of cheddar mature 24 hours a day since Jan. 1. Today something will actually happen. As of last night, the site had counted more than 500,000 hits. About 55,000 fans are expected today, the BBC reported, when the camera, set up in a farmhouse by the West Country Farmhouse Cheesemakers, Somerset farmers who produces handmade cheddar, is given its first quality check. To ensure that the cheese is maturing properly (it is fully expected to take a year), an expert cheese maker will pull out a core and sniff and taste it, the BBC said. The sampling is at 10 a.m. local time, or 5 a.m. New York time.

Two public interest lawyers said yesterday that they planned to ask the United States attorneys for New Jersey and Washington to open a criminal investigation into whether Gov. Jon S. Corzine falsified disclosure statements he filed when he was a United States senator by not including a $470,000 loan to his companion. The lawyers, Carl J. Mayer and Bruce Afran, said they intended to ask the prosecutors to determine if Mr. Corzine, left, violated the False Statements Accountability Act of 1996 by not listing the loan to Carla Katz, a prominent state labor leader, in his Senate disclosure reports over three years. Last October, Mr. Corzine, facing scrutiny from the Senate Ethics Committee, amended those documents to reflect the loan, which he eventually forgave. Ms. Katz, president of Local 1034 of the Communications Workers of America, and Mr. Corzine dated from 2002 to 2004. SERGE F. KOVALESKI

An article on June 21, 2003, about the possibility that a bribery investigation involving a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn could lead to an overhaul in the way judges are chosen in New York State misstated the date of a meeting between prosecutors and a divorce lawyer who is now a witness in the case. It took place on Feb. 25, 2003, not Feb. 23. The error was discovered last week by a reporter covering the judge's trial.

An article on Saturday about the subway cars purchased by New York City in 1949 in anticipation of construction of a Second Avenue line referred imprecisely to the outcome of those plans. Although no tunnels were dug with the $500 million earmarked in the 1950s for subway construction, some tunnel segments were indeed dug in the 1970s, after the plans were revived.

The Bush administration withdrew its nomination of a Missouri businessman as ambassador to Belgium on Wednesday after it became clear that Democratic senators were lining up against him because he had helped finance attacks on Senator John Kerry's war record during the 2004 presidential race. ''Unfortunately, we received word that because of politics, some members of the Senate would have voted against his nomination, which would have prevented him from serving in this important position,'' said Dana Perino, a White House spokeswoman.

A music review on Tuesday about Elton John, at Madison Square Garden, misstated the title of a song he performed. It is ''All the Girls Love Alice'' -- not ''All the Young Girls Love Alice,'' which is a phrase in the lyrics.

There are passages worth exhuming in Edith Wharton and Ogden Codman Jr.'s anticlutter, anti-Victorian design classic, ''The Decoration of Houses,'' first published in 1897 and now reverently reprinted by Rizzoli ($35). Here's one: ''When the rich man demands good architecture his neighbors will get it too. The vulgarity of current decoration has its source in the indifference of the wealthy to architectural fitness.'' Take that, Toll Brothers. Still, snarky sentences like those notwithstanding, it is hard to get a pulse going for this, Wharton's first book. Her genius was in the particular, and there's not enough of that here, though you will find acres of type about hanging cornices and when overmantels went out of fashion (in England, in the late 18th century). You don't know, from her own words, for instance, that the place where she and her architect, Codman, hashed out their thesis was Land's End, Wharton's house in Newport, R.I.
