INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Bush and Democrats Await Clash Over Iraq Timetable With both houses of Congress now firmly on record in favor of withdrawing from Iraq, President Bush vowed not to negotiate a timetable with Democrats, and a confrontation appeared inevitable as each side prepared to blame the other for delays in providing money for the war. A1 Saudi Assails U.S. Role in Iraq King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia told Arab leaders that the American occupation of Iraq was illegal and warned that unless Arab governments settle their differences, foreign powers like the United States would continue to dictate the region's politics. A1 One of the bloodiest chapters in Iraq's sectarian strife unfolded over two days in Tal Afar, where gunmen, some of them apparently police officers, killed scores of Sunnis after a double suicide bombing in a Shiite neighborhood killed 83. A16 Crackdown Grows in Zimbabwe Hundreds of Zimbabwe political and civic advocates have been abducted and severely beaten in recent days by unidentified assailants, government critics said, in assaults that appear to be part of a government campaign to smother rising unrest. A3 Iran Shows Video of Britons The dispute with Iran over Britain's captured sailors and marines escalated sharply when Britain froze all ''bilateral business'' with Iran and the Iranians displayed some of the prisoners on state television -- an act condemned by the Foreign Office as ''completely unacceptable.'' A16 NATIONAL A18-22 Prosecutors Critical Of Gonzales and Firings At a private meeting, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales endured bruising criticism from federal prosecutors who questioned the firings of eight United States attorneys, complained that the dismissals had undermined morale and expressed grievances about his leadership, people briefed on the discussion said. A1 Immigrants Becoming Citizens Legal immigrants have opted to become American citizens in historically high numbers in the last decade, a study says. A18 Refugees Land in Florida More than 100 Haitian refugees landed on a South Florida beach after their overcrowded sailboat ran aground. One died while trying to get to shore, the authorities said. A19 EDUCATION Schools and Loan Companies There are often hidden relationships between loan companies and the colleges that students rely on for advice about how to finance their schooling. Critics say such relationships pose a conflict of interest. A1 SCIENCE/HEALTH Early Stages of Alzheimer's About half of the five million people in the United States with Alzheimer's disease are at the early stages of the disease and are struggling to pass for normal, studies have found. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Park Concession Accused Of Underpaying City The operators of the Central Park Boathouse have shorted the city out of $381,070 in fees and penalties by underreporting its income, according to an audit by the New York City comptroller. The concession holder denies the allegations. B1 Found DNA Frees Man A man who has spent more than 20 years in jail for two rapes in Buffalo has been exonerated by DNA tests, a prosecutor said. The DNA evidence that cleared him had languished in a Buffalo hospital for more than 20 years, despite numerous subpoenas, and was finally found last week, officials said. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Fed Maintains Its Flexibility Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said he does not expect the escalating problems in the mortgage lending business to spread to the rest of the economy, but noted that the Fed has given itself the ''flexibility'' to adjust interest rates should the outlook change for better or for worse. C1 The Spies at Wal-Mart Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, is known internally for its investigations of employees who break its ethics rules. Over the past five years, Wal-Mart has assembled a team of former officials from the C.I.A., F.B.I. and Justice Department to run its investigations. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Legislating leadership on Iraq; communication in the face of terror; mountaintop rescue; the vanishing arts at ground zero. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E9 TV Listings E10 Crossword E2 Weather B7 Obituaries A23

HENNINGSEN--Victor William Jr., of Pelham Manor, NY, died March 26, 2007. Born May 19, 1924, he was a lifelong resident of the town of Pelham. He leaves his beloved wife of 58 years, Mayde, his children and their spouses: Vic and Susan, of Andover, MA; Kit and Caroline, of Stony Creek, CT; Mary and Chris, of Pelham Manor; Tim and Anne, of Wexford, PA; and eight grandchildren. Also survived by his brother, John T. Henningsen, of Rye, and sister, Ann H. Kneisel, of Boston, MA. Educated at Phillips Academy, the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, and Yale. During World War II he served in the Atlantic, Mediterranean and Indian Ocean war zones as a midshipman, third and second mate in the merchant navy, finishing as Lt. (JG) USNR. He spent his entire professional career with the family firm, Henningsen Foods Inc., founded by his grandfather in 1889. Starting as an office boy and plant worker, he retired as President and CEO in 1993 and served as Chairman Emeritus until his death. He was an international leader in the poultry and egg industry as a founder and chairman of the Egg Products Association, a trustee of the Nutrition Foundation and a longtime director of the Institute of American Poultry. He received many industry honors and awards. Profoundly committed to education, he was an active volunteer for Andover, the USMMA, Yale, and Sweet Briar College, where he was past president of the Board of Trustees. A longtime trustee of the Chapel of St. Thomas More at Yale, he was also past president of the Yale Club of NYC and of the American Friends of the Bermuda Maritime Museum. He devoted much time and energy to his native town, particularly the village of Pelham Manor, serving over the years as chair of the Pelham Community Chest, member of the village Planning Board, trustee and mayor of the village of Pelham Manor, cochairman of the Friends of the Pelham Town Library, and chairman of the board of the Sound Shore Medical Center. At his death he was still active in efforts to bridge political divisions and bring people together in service to the community he loved. Memorial Mass, 11 AM, Saturday, March 31, at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Fowler Ave, Pelham Manor, NY. Interment private. Contributions in his memory to the Friends of the Pelham Town Library, 530 Colonial Avenue, Pelham, NY, 10803; and the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester, 16 Guion Place, New Rochelle, NY, 10801.

The City Council passed two bills yesterday that expand tax benefits for Mitchell-Lama developments, which provide housing to families with low and moderate income. The first measure would eliminate the $40,000 cap on the assessed value of a unit qualifying for tax benefits for repairs and improvements. The second bill allows Mitchell-Lama co-op or condo developments to receive tax benefits for repairs and improvements and to finance them through government-subsidized loans. Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said the bills were intended to stop a loss of middle-income housing. RAY RIVERA

Scalamandré's new line of 15 fabrics and 4 wallpapers, Cabinet of Curiosities, features designs of ''unusual things from faraway lands,'' said Julie Kaminska, the company's design director, explaining the name, which refers to the collections of exotica once assembled by kings and popes. The linen Coquina ($132 per yard), below, depicts Caribbean shells, which ''would have had pride of place in a cabinet of curiosities,'' Ms. Kaminska said. The wallpaper Zebras ($111 a roll), above, was commissioned in the 1940s for Gino Circiello's restaurant, Gino, at 780 Lexington Avenue (61st Street). Prices range from $99 to $128 for a five-yard roll of wallpaper and $93 to $375 per yard of fabric (to the trade): (800) 932-4361. ELAINE LOUIE

Bruno Racine, below, president of the Georges Pompidou Center since 2002, has been named to lead the French National Library, replacing Jean-Noël Jeanneney, who reaches the public sector's retirement age of 65 next month. Mr. Racine will be succeeded by Alain Seban, until now education and culture adviser to President Jacques Chirac, who himself leaves office in May. Although Mr. Seban, 42, has no museum management experience, he appears to have benefited from the tradition that outgoing French presidents place loyal aides in significant posts before they depart. Mr. Racine, 55, a former diplomat and part-time novelist, had also not worked before in culture, but he played a crucial role in expanding the Pompidou's horizons beyond Paris: it is building an annex in Metz, a city in the northeast, and plans to open a satellite in Shanghai. At the French National Library Mr. Racine will inherit a program initiated by Mr. Jeanneney to have Europe digitize its libraries, a response to Google's program involving numerous American universities and libraries. ALAN RIDING

SCHWARTZ--Philip K. The attorneys and staff of Davis & Gilbert LLP mourn the passing of our partner, mentor and friend Phil Schwartz. From the time he joined us in 1943 until his retirement several years ago, Phil extended to his colleagues and clients his extraordinary intellect, legal skills, judgment and persistence, offered good naturally and usually with a dose of humor. He was unceasing in his efforts on behalf of his clients often pushing fellow attorneys to consider novel approaches to troublesome problems. He was one of the principal architects of our firm and we shall be forever indebted to him. We offer our deepest sympathies to Phil's loving family and many devoted friends.

To the Editor: The emergence of cosmetic dermatology during the past 10 years is a fact of life. What ''The New Political Fixer: The Skin Doctor'' (Thursday Styles, March 22) did not mention is that, with the economic rewards for dermatologists who go the Botox route, real shortages in the availability of dermatologists to treat skin cancer, psoriasis, acne and warts are occurring in most of the urban areas of the country.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a vote by the Senate to support a date for withdrawing troops from Iraq misstated the withdrawal provision in the Senate legislation. Beginning a pullout of American troops within 120 days of the measure's enactment is a requirement, not a goal. Completing the pullout by March 31, 2008, is a nonbinding goal of the legislation.

He leaves behind his loving wife, Geraldine, of 60 years, his two cherished sons, Bruce and Michael, Michael's spouse Laura, two grandsons, Daniel and Jason. WAL-MART'S DETECTIVE AGENCY Wal-Mart, renowned for its elbows-out business tactics, is known internally for its bare-knuckled investigations of employees who break its ironclad ethics rules, with investigations led by a team of former officials from the C.I.A., F.B.I. and Justice Department. [Page A1.] LIMIT SEEN ON MORTGAGE CRISIS Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said that he did not expect the problems in the mortgage lending business to spread to the rest of the economy. [C1.] OFFLINE, GOOGLE IS NO GIANT Google's efforts to extend its dominance over online advertising into offline media like newspapers and radio are mixed, suggesting that its transition from online kingpin to credible player in traditional media is far from assured. [C1.] AN INCOME GAP LAST SEEN IN 1928 Income inequality grew significantly in 2005, with the top 1 percent of Americans -- those with incomes that year of more than $348,000 -- receiving their largest share of national income since 1928, analysis of newly released tax data show. [C1.] AN ACQUIRED TASTE IN MERGERS For decades, corporate mergers in Japan were virtually taboo. But they have risen sharply in the last three years, and are becoming something of a preoccupation even among ordinary people. [C1.] ROYALTIES WERE UNCOLLECTED A former auditor at the Interior Department accused top officials of barring him and other investigators from recovering hundreds of millions of dollars in underpayments from energy companies that drill on federal land and in federal waters. [C3.] MERCK'S SLEEPING PILL The drug maker Merck and a Danish partner canceled a joint project to develop a safe and effective sleeping pill. Studies of their product had found unusual side effects like hallucinations and disorientation. Merck called the termination of the project ''clearly disappointing.'' [C2.] JUNK FOOD COMMERCIALS A study by the Kaiser Family Foundation finds that 50 percent of advertising time on children's shows is for food. And among the ads aimed at children and teens, 72 percent are for candy, snacks, sugary cereals or fast food. Advertising. [C10.] UNION LEADER DRAWS A LINE The president of the United Automobile Workers said certain benefits for workers will not be up for negotiation at coming talks with the Detroit automakers. [C3.] PORSCHE BIDS FOR VW Porsche, which owns just under a third of fellow German automaker Volkwagen, has made a bid to acquire a controlling stake in the company. The bid helps block rival offers while a European court considers invalidating a German law that prevents a Volkswagen takeover. [C12.] TRIBUNE MAY RESTART BIDDING The Tribune Company has responded to a request for additional financial information from two Los Angeles billionaires, Eli Broad and Ronald Burkle, a move that may revive their bid to buy the company. [C3.] WPP CHIEF SETTLES LIBEL CASE Martin Sorrell, chief executive of the WPP Group, the advertising company, accepted a settlement of £120,000 (about $236,000) from two men he had sued for libel. [C10.] INTEL'S POWER-SAVING CHIPS Intel said that it was on track or even ahead of schedule in developing a new generation of chips that would achieve a significant increase in performance without consuming more power. [C4.] BANKING ON A DEMOGRAPHIC TREND Adult day care centers -- and many other businesses geared toward serving the aging population -- are increasingly cited as a good place for entrepreneurs to look for opportunities. Small Business. [C5.] DOW FALLS OVER INFLATION FEARS The Dow Jones industrials fell nearly 100 points after the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, repeated his concern that core inflation remained ''uncomfortably high.'' [C12.] LOAN COMPANIES' HELPING HAND When students call some colleges to ask about financial aid, they are transferred to a call center run by Nelnet, a student-loan company. Nelnet's role staffing the calls -- which is not disclosed to callers -- is a window into the relationships between loan companies and colleges. [A1.] INTERNET RADIO LISTENS TO YOU For all the talk about satellite radio, the most vibrant frontier in radio may be the Web. Some online radio is interactive, evaluating your musical tastes, and then serving up a stream of programming to match. [C7.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. PROSECUTORS IN THE INSIDER trading trial of the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, Joseph P. Nacchio, contend that Mr. Nacchio tried to hide $90 million in by transferring stock into accounts held solely by his wife. (AP)

The leading candidate for the presidency of New York City Transit, which runs the city's subway and bus systems, is a former transit executive who has worked in New York and in Philadelphia, according to officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The candidate, Howard H. Roberts Jr., 67, ran New York's bus system in the mid-1980s and became the second-ranking executive of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. He said yesterday that he had not had a job offer, but that he was ''very interested.'' The previous president, Lawrence G. Reuter, resigned in February. WILLIAM NEUMAN

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would hold a ceremonial groundbreaking for the Second Avenue subway line on April 12. It will take place at Second Avenue and 99th Street, the southern end of a six-block segment of tunnel that was dug in the 1970s for the long-promised subway line. Plans were first formed in the 1920s and have been periodically revived and abandoned. The transportation authority now plans to spend $3.8 billion on the first phase of the subway, which includes stations on Second Avenue at 96th Street, 86th Street and 72nd Street. Preliminary construction work should begin next month. The line is scheduled to open in 2013. WILLIAM NEUMAN

PLENTY of hard-core triathletes have avoided spinning studios because they say they train better on hills and roads. But now that triathlons are a sport for the masses, more indoor cycling classes attract rookie triathletes looking to avoid freezing rain or to complement their road miles. Meanwhile longtime triathletes are reconsidering indoor cycling classes. They can be a good place to focus on pedaling economy, said Joe Friel, the author of ''The Triathlete's Training Bible.'' The heavy flywheel of an indoor bike, he said, ''can help to improve the athlete's pedal mechanics.''

WHITE--Lawrence (Larry), died on March 25, 2007. Born in Cohoes, NY, he was one of the pioneers of the early days of television broadcasting. He began his career at the Dumont Television Network. At CBS he was instrumental in developing the long running daytime programs, 'As the World Turns', and 'Hollywood Squares'. He then joined NBC daytime, and eventually became Vice President of Nighttime TV in Los Angeles. He was President of Columbia Pictures TV. He produced the award winning miniseries 'The Blue and the Gray'. A graduate of Syracuse University, he received their George Arents Alumni Award. He is survived by his devoted wife and partner, Catherine DeCarlo White, daughters Carol Bishop and Lauren White, son-in-law Alex Gansa, and grandchildren Michael and Steven Bishop, and William Gansa. Services will be held on Friday, March 30, at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison, at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to the Visiting Neighbors Association. 611 Broadway, NY 10012, Suite 510.

Intel said Wednesday that it was on track or even ahead of schedule in developing a new generation of chips that would achieve a significant increase in performance without consuming more power. The new processor families -- Penryn, arriving this year, and Nehalam, due next year -- will in some cases help Intel catch up technically with its archrival Advanced Micro Devices and in other areas will consolidate performance categories where Intel already leads.

WANDERMAN--Rosalie, of Hollywood, FL, on March 27, 2007; age 100. A resident of NYC until her retirement, she was employed as office manager at Webster Hall in Manhattan for her entire career. Survived by her loving brother Dr. Sidney E. Wanderman, and nieces Lisa Wanderman Gottlieb and Marcia Wanderman Brill of Manhattan. Daughter of the late Phillip Wanderman and Helen Toft Wanderman of Manhattan. Sister of the late Florence and Annie Wanderman of Manhattan and Hollywood, FL.

The Cheering Section article in sports on Sunday, about an author's contention that the Yankees have had 14 or 15 captains in their history instead of 11, misstated the publication date of a newspaper article about the team, and misspelled the surnames of two players mentioned in that article. The article from The Evening Star in Washington was published on April 20, 1903 -- not 1902. The players were Dave Fultz, not Fults, and Jesse Tannehill, not Tannebill.

MacKENZIE--Frances Yvonne, of Brooklyn died March 24, 2007. Wife of the late Douglas C. MacKenzie and mother of Maureen and Deirdre. She will be deeply missed by her many friends and family. Services Friday 10am at First Presbyterian Church, 124 Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY.

An article yesterday about a plan by a conservative Colorado parish to leave the Episcopal Church in part because of the church's policy on same-sex unions misstated that policy. Although the church allows dioceses and parishes to perform rites for same-sex couples, the denomination itself does not sanction such rites.

To the Editor: Re ''A Better Society? Or a Better Résumé?'' (Week in Review, March 25):

A suicide bomber on foot detonated his explosives close to the car of a high-ranking Afghan intelligence official and near a crowded bazaar in Kabul. The official was not hurt, but four civilians were killed. ABDUL WAHEED WAFA

ROSIN--Axel. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Axel Rosin, a treasured leader who was deeply devoted to the Jewish people and cultural arts initiatives. Axel upheld his familys commitment to tikkun olam and has made an indelible impact through his generosity and vision. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife; Kathy; to his daughters, Karen Sollins and Susanna Bergtold; to his grandchildren, Peter and Amy; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the role eunuchs have played in history -- a reflection prompted by the author's prostate cancer treatment, which resulted in chemical castration -- referred imprecisely to one person who was a eunuch. He was St. Ignatius of Constantinople. (Other SS. Ignatius were not known to be eunuchs.)
BOW--Charles. Beloved father of Bing Lee, Bing Kam, Kenneth, Dewey and Ronald passed away March 18, 2007.

DAMBRA--Lucian J. ''Lee'' 79, a devotee to the ideal of lifelong learning, passed away March 4, 2007 at ''Hospice by the Sea'' in Boca Raton, FL. Lee was principal of the Shore Road and Winthrop Avenue elementary schools in Bellmore, NY for over 20 years. He and his late wife, Margaret Ann, were champions of education, developing opportunities for the underprivileged and working for a new public library in Farmingdale, NY. Lee was a devoted father of Lawrence and Richard, loving grandfather of Patrick and William, a U.S. Navy Veteran and an avid ballroom dance performer who rounded out his life with a profound love of opera and the arts. A volunteer at the Citrus County, FL Senior Center, he served meals, taught computer courses and played piano for the seniors. Donations in lieu of flowers to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL or the American Cancer Society. The family will receive friends Sunday, April 1, 2007 from 2-5pm and 79:30pm at The McCourt & Trudden Funeral Home Inc., 385 Main Street, Farmingdale. Funeral Mass Monday, April 2, 2007, 9:45am at St. Kilian R.C. Church, Farmingdale. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

To the Editor: In ''For 2008: An American Themistocles'' (column, March 25), David Brooks suggests that our next president must be cunning and possess idealism as his or her most important characteristics, and offers Bismarck and Sharon as examples of leaders who would best serve America in the years ahead.

RUBENSTEIN--Estelle, nee Bauman, born March 4, 1912, died peacefully in her home, March 27, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Murray Rubenstein. She was a brilliant financial advisor, and loyal colleague and friend to many. She is survived by her daughters, Judith Schaffer and Alice Brent, grandchildren Stacey, Jessica, Ava, and Alex, and great-granchildren Ella and Elsa. A longful life, well lived, a peaceful death at home with family. Rest in peace, Estelle, we love you. Service will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Calvary Hospital Hospice at (718) 518-2465.

President Bush has discovered bloggers. Iraqi bloggers. Mr. Bush -- a man not known for his love of the working press, and certainly no fan of anonymous quotes -- cited two Iraqi bloggers on Wednesday in a speech asserting that his troop buildup, despite Congressional criticism and calls for withdrawal, was helping improve everyday life for Iraqis.

PHREANER--Hester Gray, 92, of Naples, FL, died Tuesday, March 27, 2007. Survived by sons, David G. Phreaner and Andrew W. Phreaner and sister, Shirley G. Stevenson. Hester is survived by her husband C. Edgar Phreaner, Jr., to whom she was married for 67 years.

''I'm not a patient person by nature, and Mary's losing her mental capabilities so I have to slow down and adapt. And I have to remind myself that she still has feelings and perceptions.'' STEPHEN CARVER, whose wife is in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease. [A22]

If the Nets are to make the playoffs, and do anything noteworthy once they get there, they showed Wednesday night exactly what it would take: staunch defense and an offense committed to attacking the basket. That formula looked easy in their 118-94 victory against the Indiana Pacers, but it will undoubtedly be more difficult to execute as the season winds down, especially with the Nets facing the Eastern Conference-leading Detroit Pistons on Friday.

An obituary yesterday about Paul C. Lauterbur, who won a Nobel prize for developing M.R.I. technology into a way to look inside living things, misspelled the surname of a professor of physics at the University of Illinois who commented on his work. He is Charles Slichter, not Schlichter.

A New Book Club Pick by Oprah Oprah Winfrey has named ''The Road,'' by Cormac McCarthy, right, as her latest book club selection, The Associated Press reported. The novel, published in September by Alfred A. Knopf, is a despairing account of a boy and his father lurching across the cold, wretched, wet, corpse-strewn, ashen landscape of a post-apocalyptic world. In her review in The New York Times, Janet Maslin wrote, '' 'The Road' would be pure misery if not for its stunning, savage beauty.'' Ms. Winfrey said yesterday: ''It is so extraordinary. I promise you, you'll be thinking about it long after you finish the final page.'' According to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks about 70 percent of industry sales, ''The Road'' has sold 138,000 copies. A paperback edition of the novel, a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle prize and regarded as a contender for a Pulitzer Prize, was not planned until September, but Vintage Books is publishing one now. Historians Lose 'Da Vinci Code' Appeal The British publisher of the Dan Brown best seller ''The Da Vinci Code'' has prevailed again over the two historians who contended that Mr. Brown plagiarized themes from their book ''The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail'' (1982).The Court of Appeal in London rejected their appeal yesterday of a High Court ruling in April that Random House, the British publisher, had not infringed on the copyright of their book, the BBC reported. Both books are based on the theory that Jesus and Mary Magdalene married and had a child, and that the bloodline continues to this day. In a statement the authors, Michael Baigent and Richard Leigh, said, ''We believed, and still do, that nonfiction authors would suffer and be discouraged from extensive research if it was found that any author could take another's ideas, 'morph' and repackage them, then sell them on.'' Random House was awarded the costs of the appeal, estimated at $589,000, and Mr. Baigent and Mr. Leigh face a legal bill of $5.89 million. Simpson Book To Be Auctioned Rights to the O. J. Simpson book ''If I Did It'' are to be auctioned on April 17 pursuant to a ruling by Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Gerald Rosenberg that proceeds from the sale and any subsequent book profits be turned over to the family of Ronald L. Goldman, The Associated Press reported. In the book Mr. Simpson explains how he might have carried out the slayings of his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Mr. Goldman. Public outrage led to cancellation of the book and a companion television interview. Mr. Simpson was acquitted of the slayings in a criminal trial, but the Goldman family won a wrongful-death lawsuit against him in 1997 and has been trying ever since to collect a $33.5 million civil judgment. Lukas Award Winners ''The Looming Tower: Al Qaeda and the Road to 9/11'' (Alfred A. Knopf), Lawrence Wright's history of events leading to the destruction of the World Trade Center, has won the $10,000 J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize, the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism and the Nieman Foundation announced. The other winners of this year's J. Anthony Lukas Prize Projects Awards were James T. Campbell, recipient of the $10,000 Mark Lynton History Prize, for ''Middle Passages: African American Journeys to Africa, 1787-2005'' (Penguin Press), and Robert Whitaker, recipient of the $30,000 J. Anthony Lukas Work-in-Progress Award for ''Twelve Condemned to Die: Scipio Africanus Jones and the Struggle for Justice That Remade a Nation,'' to be published by Crown. Mr. Lukas, a journalist and author who won two Pulitzer Prizes, died in 1997. The prizes will be presented by Garrison Keillor on May 8 at Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism. Footnotes Denzel Washington, below, is to produce and perhaps star in ''Journal for Jordan,'' a film inspired by an essay in The New York Times by Dana Canedy, about her fiancé, First Sgt. Charles Monroe King, 48, who was killed in Baghdad in October, a month before finishing his tour of duty, Reuters reported. In the essay, Ms. Canedy, an editor at The Times, wrote of the 200-page journal kept by Sergeant King to impart wisdom to their son, Jordan, who was 5 months old when he saw him during a two-week leave in August. Escape Artists, a production house based at Columbia Pictures, acquired rights to the essay. Crown is to release a book based on the journal. The memoirs of the tennis star Andre Agassi will be published in hardcover by Alfred A. Knopf and in trade paperback by Vintage Books, Sonny Mehta, the chairman and editor in chief of Knopf, announced yesterday. No timetable for publication was immediately available.
COLMAN--Abe, age 101. He was a retired professional wrestling champion. Funeral services will be held at Schwartz 718-263-7600.

A hospitalized prisoner at Kings County Hospital Center was shot by a police officer last night after he assaulted the officer with a bed rail, the police said. The prisoner, whose identity was not released, was arrested on March 26 in connection with an assault. Last night, shortly before 11, the prisoner broke off the plastic bed rail and hit the on-duty officer in the head, the police said, and the officer then shot the patient, who was taken to the operating room. The officer was treated for lacerations. JENNIFER 8. LEE

HECHT--Mildred. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed Member, Mrs. Mildred Hecht, and extends sincere sympathy to the members of her family. Ira Eichner, President Arthur Loring, Secretary
Gunmen, some apparently police officers, executed scores of Sunnis in revenge for a suicide bombing in a Shiite area of Tal Afar. Page A16.

The National Organization for Women endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, for president and pledged to raise money for her from its 500,000 members. The group's effort on Mrs. Clinton's behalf, called Making History with Hillary, is intended to build on the campaign's effort to appeal to women and ultimately draw the greatest shares of votes and donations by women for any presidential candidate in 2008. PATRICK HEALY

As South Korean and American negotiators huddle in Seoul for trade talks this week, corporate South Korea is grappling with a troubling question: How can the country avoid being crushed by competition from low-cost China and high-tech Japan? CHOE SANG-HUN

Danny Almonte planned to graduate high school last year, then attend junior college in New Mexico. He had been bypassed in the major league draft in June and did not have the grades to play Division I college baseball. But Almonte, 20, has struggled with controversy since 2001, when his eye-opening performance in the Little League World Series was erased because he was two years too old. He never graduated high school, did not enroll in college, and on Tuesday signed his first professional contract, with the Southern Illinois Miners in Marion, Ill., of the Frontier League.
GROSS--Sidney, of New York City. Beloved brother of Lila Baron. Cherished uncle and great-uncle. Graveside services Friday, March 30th, 11am at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

A picture with a report in the National Briefing column on Saturday about a revelation by Fife Symington, the former governor of Arizona, that he saw a U.F.O. in 1997 was published in error in some copies. The photograph showed Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, not Mr. Symington.

The Ink column on Tuesday, about naptime in the Milstein Hall of Ocean Life at the American Museum of Natural History, misstated the location of the museum's tigers. They are in the endangered-species exhibit near the Hall of Ocean Life and also in the Hall of Asian Mammals; they are not in the Akeley Hall of African Mammals. (Tigers are not native to Africa.)

Last week six new albums entered the Top 10 of the Billboard chart, and this week four did the same, though once again the sales required to reach a single-digit position were notably low. The indie-rock stalwarts Modest Mouse opened at No. 1 with ''We Were Dead Before the Ship Even Sank'' (Epic), its highly anticipated new album featuring Johnny Marr, the former guitarist of the Smiths. It sold 129,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The No. 2 and 3 albums this week are also new. Joss Stone's ''Introducing Joss Stone'' (Virgin) sold 118,000, and the self-titled record by the ''American Idol'' alumnus Elliott Yamin -- released through an unusual arrangement with Mr. Yamin's publisher that sidestepped signing to a label -- moved 90,000. The R&B singer Marques Houston reached No. 5 with 69,000 sales of his new album, ''Veteran'' (Universal Motown). Chris Daughtry's ''Daughtry'' (RCA) is No. 4, and last week's top seller, ''Luvanmusiq'' (Atlantic), by the crooner Musiq Soulchild, dropped to No. 8 with sales of 54,000. BEN SISARIO

Dr. William F. Owen Jr., chancellor of the University of Tennessee Health Science Center, was approved yesterday as the new president of New Jersey's financially troubled state medical school. Dr. Owen, 51, a kidney specialist who earned his bachelor's degree from Brown University and his medical degree from Tufts University, has published more than 200 scholarly articles and spent 12 years as a staff physician with Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Dr. Owen also has 25 years of academic experience with Harvard Medical School and Duke University.

A report in the Vital Signs column in Science Times on March 20, about exercise and memory, misstated part of the name of a brain region associated with memory loss. It is the dentate gyrus, not dentate gyrate.

After two hours of some of the highest-rated reality shows on television, viewers by and large tuned out for ABC's ''Great American Dream Vote'' on Tuesday at 10 p.m. The new reality competition, with Donny Osmond as host, has audiences voting on which contestants' lifelong dreams are most deserving of coming true. According to Nielsen's estimates, the debut episode on Tuesday, which ABC called a preview, earned a paltry 6.1 million viewers and a third-place finish in the 10 p.m. hour. (The formal premiere was last night.) The show's ratings were striking, given ABC's strong performance at 9 for the ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show (17.6 million), in which the supermodel Paulina Porizkova became the first celebrity dancer to be eliminated this season. ABC finished the night solidly in second place behind Fox, which led at 8 with ''American Idol'' (26.8 million) and at 9 with ''House'' (22.2 million). (Estimates for ''House'' do not reflect a seven-minute overrun of ''American Idol'' into the 9 p.m. hour.) NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (12.8 million) led the 10 p.m. hour, and a repeat of CBS's ''Shark'' ranked second (7.7 million). NBC was third for the night, followed by CBS. BENJAMIN TOFF

KORNREICH--Mort. Mort, You were my other half and best friend since birth. You will live in our hearts forever. Matt and Sue $(6$)KORNREICH--Mort. Uncle Morty, our hearts are broken with your passing, though they are filled and enlightened for having known and loved you. Your philanthropy, activism, and creativity will always be an inspiration. We've been doubly blessed by having two fathers. Bill, Eileen, and Sarah Kathy, Sam, Lisa, and Andrew $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton, to our beloved ''Uncle Mort'' -a real mensch -one of the great guys. We will miss you. Love Dorothy, Richard, Sandi, and families $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton A. The Membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club in Boca Raton, Florida, announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend, esteemed member and former Governor, Morton A. Kornreich, and extend our sincerest condolences to his family. David C. Bubes, President Boca Rio Golf Club Inc. $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton A. You were loved and admired by so many, but most of all your family. You have been an exemplary role model to all of us. Your sense of humility and good nature shown through everything you did. All that came in contact with you instantly loved you for your incredible passion for life and ability to live every day to its fullest. You were the ultimate Renaissance man, cultivating many interests in literature, art and politics. Your generosity of spirit to the Jewish people was immeasurable. You are the role model that we all aspire to, and your legacy will live in our hearts forever. Your Loving Children, Jim, Meredith, Tom, Barbara, Nancy, Rob, and grandchildren, Todd, Zach, Jenny, Caroline, Molly, Adam, Maggie and Alex. $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton. Rob and Nancy, Tom and Barbara, Jim and Meredith, your father was the original ''stand-up'' guy. Lucy and Richard Halperin The Velocity Foundation $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton. To my darling brother Mort, thank you for always being there for me! Love, Norma Weinstein $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton, be loved husband of the late JoAnn. Devoted father of James and Meredith, Thomas and Barbara, and Nancy and Robert Reiger. Cherished brother of Matthew and Sue and Norma Weinstein. Adored and loving grandfather of Todd, Jennifer, Maggie, Caroline, Adam, Zachary, Molly and Alex. Dear friend of Larcenia Petty. Services 11 am Friday, Congregation Emanu-El, 2125 Westchester Ave, Rye, NY. Contributions may be made to UJA Federation or American Jewish Committee. For additional information, call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-7694400. $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton A. The American Jewish Committee is deeply saddened by the death of our beloved friend and longtime leader, Morton Kornreich. Mort was an AJC Vice President, a member of our National Board of Governors, former chair of our Koppelman Institute on American Jewish-Israeli Relations, and a member of the board of Commentary magazine. Devoted to Israel and the Jewish people, he lent his time and talents to a host of philanthropic organizations. Mort was a warm, wise and beneficent individual who will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. E. Robert Goodkind, President David A. Harris, Executive Director $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Morton Kornreich, a treasured friend whose deep commitment and boundless generosity strengthened our ability to serve those in need and enriched our initiatives in New York, in Israel, and around the world. Mort, a past president of United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York and chairman of the board of UJA-Federation of New York, has been a prominent figure in Jewish communal life. Mort, in addition, was national chairman of United Jewish Appeal and a significant leader of numerous Jewish organizations worldwide. Mort's children and grandchildren proudly continue his legacy to the Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mort's twin brother, Matt, and his wife, Suzanne; to his sister, Norma Weinstein; to Mort's children, Jim and Meredith Kornreich, Tom and Barbara Kornreich, and Nancy and Rob Rieger; to his grandchildren, Todd, Jennifer, Maggie, Caroline, Adam, Zachary, Molly, and Alex; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

THERE are reasons to raise a skeptical brow when a group as disparate as Miuccia Prada, Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan, Marc Jacobs and Madonna attempt to bring turbans of the Old Hollywood variety back into fashion. Turbans may be an appropriate visual accent in fashion's current fixation with early 20th-century revivals, along with the cloche styles favored by Paul Poiret, who is getting the curatorial treatment at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in May. But since Ms. Prada made the most conspicuous use of turbans, showing glamorous jewel-tone versions in her spring collection, fashion people have been wondering whether an accessory that fell out of favor in Western fashion after World War II could enjoy a renaissance.

The dispute with Iran over Britain's captured sailors escalated sharply on Wednesday when Britain froze all ''bilateral business'' with Iran, and the Iranians displayed some British prisoners on state television -- an act condemned by the Foreign Office here as ''completely unacceptable.'' One of the captured sailors, Leading Seaman Faye Turney, 26 -- the only woman among the 15 Britons -- was shown wearing a black head scarf and saying, ''Obviously we trespassed into their waters'' and praising her captors as ''very friendly, very hospitable and very thoughtful, nice people.''

To the Editor: ''Play About Iraq War Divides a Connecticut School'' (news article, March 24) left the impression that our administration reacted in a bureaucratic style to avoid a controversial issue.

A captain in the Genovese crime family and his son participated in the 2005 slaying of a mob soldier whose body was found in a car trunk in New Jersey during his federal extortion trial, according to court papers released yesterday as part of an indictment. The captain, Michael Coppola; his wife, Linda Coppola; and the son, Louis Rizzo Jr., were charged with conspiracy to use false identity papers. Mr. Coppola was apprehended this month after being a fugitive for more than a decade, prosecutors said. A letter submitted by prosecutors details other crimes the two men are accused of, and describes a recorded conversation between them about the gun that was used to murder the soldier, Lawrence Ricci. John Buretta, an assistant United States attorney, said he expected additional charges to be filed. WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

MORGANTE--Linda, RN, MSN, MSCN. Linda Morgante passed away yesterday after a courageous struggle with cancer. The nursing and MS world is stunned at her loss. Linda entered the world of MS nursing as the coordinator of nursing services at Maimonides Hospital MS Care Center in 1986, and over the next few years became active as a nurse-researcher, author, clinician, teacher, and nursing leader. She touched the lives of thousands of physicians, nurses, nursing students, and patients and their families during the past 20 years. In 2001, Linda won the IOMSN June Halper Award for Nursing Excellence and in 2005 she was awarded the Journal of Neuroscience Nursing's Writing Excellence Award as well as being inducted into the National Multiple Sclerosis Society's (NMSS) Volunteer Hall of Fame for Healthcare Professionals. Linda was a soughtafter presenter at educational events of the NMSS, the Consortium of MS Centers, and International Organization of MS Nurses. There will be a memorial service for Linda this Friday, March, 30th, at 3:00 pm, at the Woolworth Tower Kitchen. 233 Broadway (entrance on Barclay St.) Her friends and colleagues National Multiple Sclerosis Society New York City Chapter International Organization of MS Nurses

Last week the Institute of Classical Architecture and Classical America, a nonprofit group based in New York City, and Habitat for Humanity completed the first of several low-cost houses they are collaborating on to ''bring better architecture to the realm of affordable housing,'' said Paul Gunther, the institute's president. Although the three-bedroom, 1,400-square-foot house in Rochester cost just $90,000 (it was constructed by a volunteer crew), it has Greek Revival details that allow it to blend into the historic neighborhood, said Richard Cameron, the designer. Nilsa Rivera, 24, the local resident who was selected to live there, will move in this weekend with her 2-year-old daughter, her fiancé and her brother; in June the institute will publish ''A Pattern Book for Neighborly Houses,'' a guide to building well-designed affordable housing. ARIC CHEN

PATZ--Joseph, died Wednesday morning, March 28. Predeceased by his wife Sarah, he is survived by his sons Norman, Stanley, Jerrold and their families, and by his siblings David and Annie and by numerous nephews and nieces. He was active in Jewish and civic life. He was a mensch, loyal to his family and community. Barukh dayan emet.

Limited quantities of many of the Conran Shop's products will be on sale on April 6 from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. Merchandise will include discontinued pieces, floor displays, samples and slightly damaged items: one Eames lobby chair, in red leather, will sell for $2,940 (reduced from $4,200); a floor-model sleeper sofa will be $1,960 (reduced from $2,800); the Marie Galante folding vanity, above, will be $1,837 (it was $2,450); and a modern cuckoo clock will be $119 (reduced from $199). All sales are final. The Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue), (866) 755-9079. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

“Change will come — it’s only a matter of who brings it.”
Disella Larusdottir hopes to make her native Iceland proud and perform well at the prestigious Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions.
The son of Mexican immigrants, the Mayor believes Los Angeles, more than any other city, is where dreams can be realized.
As the demographics of Los Angeles shift, tensions are rising between blacks and Latinos, but the Mayor says such incidents are isolated.
With the help of the FBI, Mayor Villaraigosa says he will break apart the city's most violent street gangs.
Mayor Villaraigosa is known for his ability to help people transcend lines of race, class, ethnicity and geography.
Matthew Dowd, once a close political adviser to President Bush, became disappointed in the president's performance.
New York's 13,000 yellow cabs are easy to take for granted - until it's raining and you cannot find one.

The vehicle of the future may not be sleek and streamlined. Another recent view comes from Paul Saffo, one of the country's most cited futurists, although he prefers the term "forecaster."
Tattoos have become so common in college basketball that it is almost surprising to see a star player without one.

Several folks have written in to let us know that the crossword puzzle was not updating properly in the new reader. We've posted a new build of the reader that fixes this issue. If this has been happening to you please download the new build here.

The world's richest countries, which have contributed by far the most to the atmospheric changes linked to global warming, are far ahead of the poorest ones in adapting to climate change. Next Friday, a new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change will underline this growing climate divide, according to scientists involved in writing it, Andrew C. Revkin reports.

The blogs had three major pieces about Rudolph W. Giuliani to mull over today. One involved a Times scoop revealing that the former New York mayor testified that he'd been warned about Bernard B. Kerik's possible ties to organized crime before he elevated him to police commissioner - although Mr.Giuliani said he did not recall the briefing taking place, much less the content. That news has already stirred up many readers at our sibblog, The Empire Zone.
A chance encounter during N.Y.'s Santacon Event helped to rekindle romance between Jeffery Franklin Klier & Aislinn Weidele.

The city is filled with so many basketball celebrities that some pass by almost unnoticed. One was at the airport yesterday: Bill Frieder, who was the focus of much attention in Atlanta 18 years ago when he was the head coach of the Michigan Wolverines.

There was considerable buzzing a while back about the sales incentives and attractive financing deals that had become available on the once hot-selling Toyota Prius. The doomsday view was that interest in hybrid cars had peaked.
Ah, it's that time again: the monthly Critical Mass ride is tonight, with new police rules in place requiring permits for gatherings of 50 or more people. [Gothamist]
Why are two of America's friends jousting? Nicholas D. Kristof asks Afghanistan's president why he's so upset with Pakistan.
For the curious, here's copy [pdf] of the official state budget estimates, as they stand now.

Last night, my friend Bob Crowley, a set designer whose work appears in London and New York ("The History Boys," "The Coast of Utopia") invited me to join him for the Broadway opening of "The Year of Magical Thinking," the Joan Didion play based on her book, for which Bob did the simple but effective sets. It's nice to visit other worlds if only to check your bearings. I liked the play, and I liked the book. If you grew up reading - or, is it devouring? - Didion, you can't help but be riveted by her observations. Vanessa Redgrave does as a wonderful job as Didion, and afterward I heard a number of people say how beautiful she looks. Redgrave is 70.

Yes, this is a plug, but we thought readers of this blog might want to take a look at a few Empire Zone contributors on the TV. According to a promo for "The New York Times Close Up," on NY 1, this week's edition will feature Michael Cooper, the chief of the Albany bureau, reporting on "the rhythms of the budget dance."
The biggest off-court storyline at this Final Four is undoubtedly the possibility that Kentucky will pursue Florida Coach Billy Donovan for its open coaching vacancy.
In which your correspondents track the unusual verbiage of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a highly precise public speaker who often uses words that rarely alight upon the ears in normal conversation.
Carl Pavano was all smiles today when we talked to him about making the start on opening day. "I should be happy, shouldn't I?" he said. "Who wouldn't be excited at the opportunity?"

Pakistani complicity in the resurgence of the Taliban is a complex issue, and it's one that my Times colleague Carlotta Gall has done a superb job in reporting. One expert on the topic is Khawar Mehdi, a Pakistani journalist who knows the border areas well. Here's his take, from an email to me that he agreed to put on the record:

Bruce Wasserstein recently gave a $25 million gift to Harvard Law School, but his bank account is quickly being replenished. As chairman of Lazard, Mr. Wasserstein earned $22 million in compensation last year, up 61 percent from 2005, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Police Department's handling of the Republican National Convention in 2004 -- which included controversial surveillance of political groups and mass arrests -- was "perhaps the finest hour in the history" of the department, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly told Gabe Pressman of WNBC in an interview that will be broadcast at 6:30 a.m. Sunday. The Politicker has posted an advance transcript and here is the exchange:
Now what?
The Yankees still want Ron Villone. But for now, they want him to join their Class AAA team in Scanton. Villone, 37, said he'd think it over for a few hours and decide later today or tomorrow.

My column on Israel a couple of weeks ago is still prompting lots of mail, much of it indignant. Yesterday I posted a Forward editorial that was sympathetic to me; here's an email I received today from a woman named Marion. As you can see, it castigates me -- and the Times for good measure -- and it's fairly representative of the critical emails.

The other day I mentioned Mia Farrow's call for branding the 2008 Beijing Olympics as the "Genocide Olympics," as a way to pressure China to be more helpful in Darfur. A wire story today from Beijing shows that China is indeed feeling the pressure:

It's a cozy little place -- only 103 rooms. And it comes with its own helipads, panic room, marble driveways, five swimming pools, and 22 marble bathrooms. It also has 58 acres of gardens and woodlands and more than 50,000 square feet of living space. Updown Court in Surrey, England has been named the world's priciest home for sale by Forbes magazine. The property -- with a pricetag of $138 million -- has been on the market for more than two years. John Vaughan of Savills www.savills.com, the company handling the sale, said it's no surprise it's taking a while to sell it. "The number of people who have $138 million to spend on a house is pretty small," he said. But the house has drawn offers -- all below the asking price.

In the next 36 hours lawmakers in Albany will be asked to approve hundreds of pages of budget bills that they have not yet read, because they have not been printed. Key details of how some of the most important aspects of the budget work - the division of education aid and the way the property tax rebate will work - are still being worked out.

The Rev. Jesse Jackson has been enlisted by a grassroots online group, Color of Change, to denounce the deal announced on Thursday between Fox News and the Congressional Black Caucus institute for two presidential debates later this year.

Although Rudy Giuliani remains the top choice of Republican voters for their party's presidential nomination, his lead over John McCain has softened somewhat, according to the latest Time magazine poll. And while John Edwards is still in third place behind Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama among the Democrats, his support has grown.
This morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg half-heartedly praised an agreement reached in Albany last night that will create 50 new charter schools in the city.

They may be a few last-minute deals straggling in, but as the first quarter comes to a close, Goldman Sachs has a firm lead in the mergers-and-acquisitions league tables. Goldman had an advisory role in 104 announced deals with a total value of $311 billion so far this year, or about 29 percent of the $1.08 trillion of deals worldwide, according to Thomson Financial.
Tariffs on coated paper will end a policy of not applying duties to subsidized goods from non-market economies.
Following is an excerpt from the draft script of the weekly "Only in New York" audio podcast. Listen at left or download it to a portable player.
Just because people are putting on galoshes, that doesn't mean it's going to rain.

One of the best stories of the spring has been Joe Smith's rise from third-round draft pick to right-handed specialist in nine months. He learned the news yesterday morning, when equipment manager Charlie Samuels asked Smith join him for a second. "I figured I was going to try something on," Smith said.

Just for the record, we now have the complete roster of who's giving what for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's two-year experiment in paying poor people for certain behavior. The $42 million raised thus far breaks down as follows:

With Congress and President Bush apparently heading toward a stalemate reminiscent of the 1995 government shutdown, I wonder who will top the Wall Street joke of that year, which reported that the government planned to issue three new types of bonds to fund itself:1: Clinton Bonds, which had no principal.2: Dole Bonds, which had no interest.3: Gingrich Bonds, which had no maturity.
Some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned or under way in four states, the biggest expansion in the West's quest for water in years.

Updated 11:10 a.m. and 11:25 a.m.Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said during his weekly WABC radio appearance this morning that he will veto a bill that caps the number of pedicabs in the city at 325 and imposes other regulations on the burgeoning industry.

The Times's William Rashbaum reports today that records show Rudolph W. Giuliani testified that he was briefed on Bernard B. Kerik's ties to a company with suspected organized crime links before elevating him to New York City police commissioner in 2000 - but he doesn't actually remember the meeting or any of the information. Mr. Giuliani also pushed for Mr. Kerik's aborted nomination to be homeland security secretary in 2004. The campaign has denied that Mr. Kerik will pose a liability to the campaign.
Joe Torre had an early media briefing just now and settled most of the remaining questions about the makeup of the Yankees' roster and rotation.

With the first quarter of the year ending this Saturday, presidential campaigns are preparing to release their fundraising tallies on April 15. A look at fundraising efforts by the leading candidates.

"[T]he greatest obstacle to sustaining a healthy, globalised economy is no longer insufficient openness," writes Dani Rodrik, a Harvard professor of international political economy, in The Financial Times. Rodrik explains:

As interesting as Kyle Sampson's testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee was, it still didn't answer "the single biggest question" about the Gonzales Eight, notes Washington Monthly blogger Kevin Drum. "It's this: so why did you choose those particular eight prosecutors to fire, anyway?" Drum continues:
Growers intend to plant more than 90 million acres in an effort to meet demands for ethanol, food and feed.

A rift has arisen among larger technology companies and smaller venture capital firms over whether dramatic changes to U.S. patent law are necessary, CNet News.com reported Thursday. The differences in opinion played out during a Thursday hearing in the House of Representatives' Small Business Committee, which doesn't have the power to write patent laws but aimed to explore the small-business implications of Congress' ongoing push for sweeping changes in the area.
I like my mother-in-law. Honest.

Amaranth Advisors was sued by the San Diego County retirement fund for securities fraud, a step the hedge fund said may delay refunds to clients hurt when it collapsed under $6.6 billion in losses in September. The fallen hedge fund lied about trading strategies and made "excessively risky and volatile investments,'' according to a complaint filed yesterday by the San Diego County Employees Retirement Association. Amaranth said fighting the lawsuit, the first tied to the largest-ever hedge-fund failure, will drain remaining assets earmarked for investors.

Man Group, the British alternative asset manager, said on Friday it would demerge its U.S. brokerage unit and list it in New York. It also said group pretax profits were likely to be in line with consensus market expectations. The listing of a majority interest in the unit, Man Financial, will take place in the third quarter of 2007, subject to favorable market conditions, the firm said.

Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's history with Bernard B. Kerik looms as a likely issue in Mr. Giuliani's campaign for president. His own aides have anticipated that questions are likely to arise about Mr. Giuliani's judgment in, among other things, promoting Mr. Kerik for one of the country's most important national security posts.
Norma Rae, Wall Street insider?

Alinta, Australia's largest energy infrastructure group, recommended a A$7.4 billion ($6 billion) bid by a consortium led by Australia's Babcock & Brown on Friday and rejected a rival bid by Macquarie Bank.

Spanish airline Iberia said on Friday it had received a bid approach from private equity firm Texas Pacific Group which valued it at roughly 3.4 billion euros ($4.5 billion). The cash offer of 3.6 euros a share is below Iberia's Thursday close and also below media reports which estimated its price tag at 4.4 euros per share.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina have increased their bid for health and beauty chain Alliance Boots to $19.7 billion. The bid comes a day after reports said that Mr. Pessina, who is Alliance Boots deputy chairman, was banned from the group's central office.

Goldman Sachs has appointed Steve Park as a managing director and country head of its securities division in Korea. Mr. Park has been with Credit Suisse for nine years and is widely recognized as one of the most experienced bankers in the Korean market, said Finance Asia. He will be responsible for Goldman's securities business in Korea, except for businesses related to Goldman Sachs International Bank and will take up his new position in June.

Battery Technologies, which makes an ultrathin carbon-zinc battery, has raised $6.2 million to expand production. SunBridge Partners led the Series A financing round, which also included Early Stage Partners, Key Capital and Orix Capital.

As a vote on taking Four Seasons Hotels private looms, shareholder opposition is mounting. A major investor has said he will vote no which has in turn caused the stock to slump to $79.60, well below the bid price of $82 per share.

A New York state lawsuit accusing insurer Liberty Mutual of rigging bids and paying kickbacks to brokers will go forward despite the insurer's attempt to dismiss it. A New York Supreme Court judge upheld the merits of the suit brought last year by then-New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer against the sixth-largest U.S. property-casualty insurer.

Shareholders of Sabre Holdings, the parent of online travel-booking service Travelocity.com, on Thursday approved a $4.5 billion offer for the company from Silver Lake Partners and Texas Pacific Group. Affiliates of the two private equity groups will pay $32.75 per share in cash and assume about $550 million in Sabre debt. Sabre put itself on the block in September 2006.

Carl Icahn's demands on Motorola -- of which the activist investor owns 2.7 percent - have put the company at an "existential crossroads," Roben Farzad of BusinessWeek wrote. In his commentary, Mr. Farzad suggests that Mr. Icahn's calls for huge share buybacks could force the cellphone company to "mortgage future cash flows by taking on debt."

Energy startups EnerNoc and Comverge have both filed preliminary papers for initial public offerings. While neither company has said when an I.P.O. may occur and although both are relatively small, they are seeing rapid growth. Comverge's revenue at Comverge nearly doubled in the last two years from $17.9 million in 2004 to $33.9 million last year and EnerNoc has seen revenue rise from $800,000 in 2004 to $26.1 million in 2006.

BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, considered merging with rival Telus and has rejected approaches from private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, The Globe and Mail reported Friday. On Thursday, responding to a report of a possible buyout, BCE said there were no "ongoing discussions" with private equity funds.

As the deadline for bids for the Chrysler Group draws near, interested parties are said to be shifting alliances. BusinessWeek reported that private equity group Cerberus Capital Management has decided to go it alone and that its former bidding partner, Magna International, is teaming up with Ripplewood Holdings.

Texas state electricity regulators are considering a review of Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts' $45 billion buyout offer for TXU. While TXU officials have said the Public Utility Commission lacks the authority to review the deal, commissioners agreed Thursday to think about bending the rules to lay out how they could consider, and possibly nix, the deal.

Michael Dell's MSD Capital and the Rockpoint Group have acquired the Kona Village Resort. The 82-acre Kona Village Resort in Hawaii has 125 bungalows on the beach next to 865-acre Hualalai Resort, a master-planned residential resort community that includes the Four Seasons Resort Hualalai which is owned by MSD Capital and Rockpoint Group as well. The resort dates back to 1965 and has been listed by Forbes magazine as one of the top 10 family luxury resorts in the country.

With the influence of hedge funds over publicly traded companies back in the spotlight thanks to developments at Dutch financial services giant ABN Amro Bank, both hedge funds and private equity investors came under fire on several European fronts Thursday. Political leaders urged talks at the European Union level and Socialists in the European Parliament released a critical report on "secretive financial deals."

Talk of an I.P.O. for Gianni Versace is in fashion as the company posted net profits of $24.1 million for last year on Thursday. Speaking to Women's Wear Daily, chief executive Giancarlo DiRisio said that he is looking to get Versace on track for a possible stock market listing. But, he stressed it's up to the owners to decide whether they want to take the company public. A decision will be made later this year.

Voestalpine, the biggest steel maker in Austria, agreed to buy a specialty-steel producer, Boehler-Uddeholm, for 3.52 billion euros ($4.69 billion), foiling a bid by a private equity company, CVC Capital Partners. Voestalpine, based in Linz, said it had agreed to pay 69 euros a share for Boehler. The acquisition will give Voestalpine a steel maker with customers worldwide including Boeing and Airbus.

A Manhattan federal judge has dismissed a class-action lawsuit accusing J.P. Morgan Chase of helping Enron hide fraud. The plaintiffs asserted that they bought J.P. Morgan stock based on the bank's reputation for integrity and financial discipline, when in fact the company was helping Enron, a major client, hide billions of dollars of debt.

Discovery Communications said Thursday that it planned to buy out one of its three shareholders, Cox Communications, in a deal that included transferring the Travel Channel and $1.275 billion in cash to Cox for its 25 percent stake in the company. The transaction, to which the companies have not assigned a total value, also includes trading to Cox a business called Antenna Audio that provides headset tours of museums around the world.

Thursday's announcement that Leonhard Fischer, the head of Credit Suisse's European group, was leaving the bank to join a buyout firm is only the latest departure to showcase the growing power of private equity.

After breaking the record for mergers and acquisitions last year, deal makers have started 2007 at an even faster pace. With the first quarter drawing to a close, the value of corporate deals announced through Wednesday reached $1.08 trillion, according to Thomson Financial. That is 24 percent more than the value of deals in the first quarter of 2006.

The drama for control of Tribune intensified Thursday night as two Los Angeles billionaires put in a last-minute bid, topping an offer from the Chicago real estate magnate, Sam Zell, by a dollar a share. Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad, sent a letter Thursday night to Tribune management prior to the company's self-imposed deadline of Saturday, according to several reports Friday.

Take-Two Interactive Software, the video game maker mired in boardroom factions, grand jury subpoenas and bad fortunes, faced an insurrection from shareholders Thursday that claimed the chief executive and three directors who were at the center of a stock options backdating scandal.

With its accounting under scrutiny by federal regulators and prosecutors, Dell said Thursday that "evidence of misconduct" had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years. Dell said its board's audit committee had "identified a number of accounting errors, evidence of misconduct, and deficiencies in the financial control environment." The committee has been examining accounting and financial problems that the company previously said involved accruals, reserves and other balance-sheet items.
Five generations of the family that owns and operates the McIlhenny Company have kept the Tabasco sauce business going while weathering many storms.
Showtime’s series on Henry VIII’s love life is enjoyable but not exhilarating, engaging but not hypnotic.
Those who don’t like a rogue’s progress, preferring to cluck from a distance over the skeevy habits of today’s rich bachelors, should skip A&E’s reality series.
