Dining furniture for every taste.
April Lane Benson chose her apartment 20 years ago for its proximity to Charivari, the West Side’s first high-fashion store.
Our condo has old windows that make it expensive to heat and air-condition. Can the board force us to spend money on energy instead of replacement?
Heavy traffic in central Rome. Charlotta Smeds, Bloomberg News
“After the Wedding” is a modern creation with a classic theme involving haves and have-nots, bloodlines and family ties.
“Summer in Berlin” is a pointedly unglamorous slice of life that could be set in any urban neighborhood where real estate prices haven’t gone through the roof.
“The Lookout” is a new version of a very old story: A nobody falls in with scuzzball crooks who make him feel like somebody.
“Killer of Sheep,” largely hidden from view for three decades, is an American masterpiece, independent to the bone.
With “Blades of Glory,” Will Ferrell and Jon Heder stake an early claim to being the comedy couple of the year.
The center has appointed Brett Littman, who has been deputy director of the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, for nearly four years.
The Bush administration said Friday that it would reverse more than 20 years of American policy and impose potentially steep tariffs on Chinese manufactured goods.
David M. Hicks amplified on his Monday guilty plea during proceedings leading toward his sentencing, which is expected within days.
A searing speech and street battles against Iraqi soldiers today suggested a resurgence of Moktada al-Sadr’s militia.
Responding to testimony by his former chief of staff, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales defended his previous characterization of his role in the dismissal of United States attorneys.
The maker of Zelnorm, a medicine that treats irritable bowel syndrome, withdrew the drug from the market today after a request from federal drug officials.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said in interviews published today that Israel would not allow a single Palestinian refugee to return to Israel.
The helicopter crew was apparently killed as fighting in Mogadishu  showed no signs of letting up today.
Cheerleaders suffer more catastrophic injuries than athletes in all other sports combined.
Scientists have linked the chemical melamine to the illness and deaths of cats eating tainted food.
The military-backed government of Bangladesh has executed six Islamist militants in connection with the murder of two judges.
A British Royal Marine purportedly apologized “deeply” for entering Iranian waters last week without permission.

An off-duty narcotics detective spotted a house fire in Castleton Corners yesterday morning and rescued a 4-year-old boy from the burning building, the police said. The detective, Vincent DiCrescento, was driving past 70 Windsor Road about 5 a.m. when he saw the three-story house burning, the police said. After phoning 911, Detective DiCrescento knocked on doors and alerted residents. Spotting a man calling for help from a third-floor window, Detective DiCrescento used an extension ladder to climb halfway up the building and grabbed the child when the man lowered him from the window. The man and his wife, who were not named by the police yesterday, were later led to safety by firefighters, the police said. The fire was brought under control just before 6 a.m., the Fire Department said.

The city will play host to a new theater festival this spring featuring works by artists from New York, Latin America, the Caribbean and Spain, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The festival, TeatroStageFest, will run from April 30 through May 13 at sites in the East Fourth Street Cultural District, the mayor said. The festival will feature seven theatrical productions, panel discussions and concerts, Mr. Bloomberg said.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has reached a verbal agreement on contracts with two coalitions of unions on the Metro-North Railroad, ending a labor dispute that has dragged on for four years and averting the possibility that some of the unions would strike this summer. But the deal did not include track workers, who are represented by the Teamsters union. Representatives of unions and the authority last night confirmed the agreement, which is expected to be formalized today so that it can be sent to the rank and file for ratification. Metro-North workers have been divided for several years between two rival union coalitions and, with the exception of the Teamsters, this deal brings both groups together under contracts that are virtually identical, according to Norman Brown, a machinists union official who is also a member of the transportation authority’s board. The contracts give workers wage increases over the next three years of 10.5 percent.
Frank Young was named the tournament’s most valuable player after scoring 24 points to lead the Mountaineers to a 78-73 victory over Clemson.
Sidney Crosby had three assists to bring his N.H.L.-leading point total to 116, helping Pittsburgh to a 4-2 victory over the host Boston Bruins Thursday night.
Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad made a last-minute bid, topping an offer from Sam Zell by a dollar a share.

White House officials have issued a discussion document on immigration that calls for legislation that would grant legal status to illegal immigrants and guest workers, but would not put them on a path to citizenship.

Negotiations between the network and the Congressional Black Caucus Political Education and Leadership Institute had been closely watched since Nevada Democrats backed out of a presidential debate that was sponsored by the network.
Dr. Eric Keroack, the head of the federal agency responsible for providing women with access to contraceptives and pregnancy counseling, resigned.
Harvard College rejected 91 percent of applicants for the coming academic year, the highest rate in its history, after an expansion of financial aid encouraged more applications.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders agreed behind closed doors to double the number of charter schools in the state to 200 and create a fund for stem cell research.
A detainee at Guantánamo Bay said that top operatives of Al Qaeda informed him of the impending attacks the night before they occurred, according to a transcript of a closed hearing.
Health officials withdrew pergolide, a drug used to treat Parkinson’s disease, from the market, citing a history of safety concerns that include potentially fatal damage to heart valves.

An appeals court rejected the government’s renaming of the Limpopo town of Louis Trichardt to Makhado. Louis Trichardt was an Afrikaaner who led the trek to the area in the 1830s; Makhado was a local king there who resisted white invaders. The court said that officials did not sufficiently clear the change with the town’s residents. The decision was a rare victory for advocates who have sought to block the scrapping of apartheid-era names for South African cities, streets and natural features in favor of African names. The country’s Arts and Culture Ministry said it accepted the decision, which was based on procedural issues, but did not say whether it would reopen the matter.

Female students at an Islamic school in the capital, Islamabad, freed a woman they kidnapped on Tuesday as the owner of a brothel after the woman donned a burqa and promised to shun sin. Clad in a black burqa identical to the ones worn by the students when they raided the woman’s house, the woman, identified only as Shamim, left, was brought before reporters at the school and read out a confession. “I seek forgiveness for the sins that I have committed and declare I will live like a true Muslim and preacher of religion,” she read. “I do confess getting involved in certain acts which are considered moral crimes, with my house being misused for the purpose.” She denied that she had been forced to sign the statement but said several men had “tied and tortured” her before she got to the school, the Jamia Hafsa madrasa.

At least 60 people were killed when an open boat capsized off the coast of the capital, Conakry, state television said. A police official said that the boat had been traveling from Forecariah, 30 miles south. It was not immediately clear who the passengers were. Guinea’s road infrastructure is so poorly maintained that many people living in coastal communities use open boats to travel between towns.

A directive by Italian bishops telling Roman Catholic politicians that they have a moral duty to vote against gay rights legislation has prompted fresh charges of Vatican meddling in parliamentary affairs. The note, issued by the Italian Bishops Conference, comes as Parliament is considering a bill introduced by Prime Minister Romano Prodi’s center-left coalition that would guarantee rights in areas like inheritance and health care to homosexual and heterosexual unmarried couples. “Catholics have been warned,” the conservative newspaper Il Tempo said in a headline. Some Catholic and centrist politicians welcomed the directive as food for thought, but the interior minister, Giuliano Amato, accused the bishops of trying to weaken the government, the BBC reported. “This is something that happens in societies we criticize as Islamized,” he said. A leftist senator, Maria Luisa Boccia, said: “This continuous, daily interference by the church in Parliament’s activity is intolerable. What’s next, excommunication?”.

The Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, lashed out against American plans to increase use of renewable fuels, mainly ethanol, in a front-page article in the Communist Party newspaper, Granma, warning that food stocks for millions of people would be threatened. The article, titled “Condemned to Premature Death by Hunger and Thirst — More Than 3 Billion People of the World,” said that if the United States and other wealthy nations decided to import huge amounts of traditional crops like corn from poorer countries to help meet their energy needs, “you will see how many people among the hungry masses of our planet will no longer consume corn.” “Or even worse,” it continued, “by offering financing to poor countries to produce ethanol from corn or any other kind of food, no tree will be left to defend humanity from climate change.” They were his first comments on international issues since Mr. Castro took ill last July. In recent weeks, several senior Cuban officials have indicated that he might soon take a more active role and even return to the presidency.

The Bank of Nova Scotia said it planned to buy a 24.99 percent stake in Thanachart Bank, Thailand’s top provider of car loans, for 7.1 billion baht ($203 million). Scotiabank said it planned to raise its stake to 49 percent by the end of December if the Bank of Thailand gives its approval. Thanachart Capital, which owns 99.3 percent of Thanachart Bank, agreed to sell about 157 million shares in the Thai bank to Bank of Nova Scotia for 16.37 baht per share, a 72 percent premium to market prices, it said. The purchase would give Bank of Nova Scotia a foothold in Thailand’s retail banking business, analysts said.

Citigroup plans to expand its securities business and branch network in China this year after becoming one of the first banks approved to incorporate locally, its chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, said. Citigroup plans to expand its network in China from 16 offices to 30 and will aim at markets for investment and corporate banking and wealth management, Mr. Prince said. Citibank was one of four banks approved last week to incorporate a local subsidiary, a step toward entering China’s retail market. Beijing agreed to open the industry to foreign competitors as part of its World Trade Organization membership.

Japanese core consumer prices declined 0.1 percent in February from a year earlier, government data showed on Friday. That matched the consensus forecast of economists. The core index, which excludes volatile fresh food prices, was flat in January after hovering slightly above zero in previous months.

Voestalpine, the biggest steel maker in Austria, agreed to buy a specialty-steel producer, Boehler-Uddeholm, for 3.52 billion euros ($4.69 billion), foiling a bid by a private equity company, CVC Capital Partners. Voestalpine, based in Linz, said it had agreed to pay 69 euros a share for Boehler. The acquisition will give Voestalpine a steel maker with customers worldwide including the Boeing Company and Airbus. CVC Capital, which is based in London, said last week that it planned to bid for Boehler, but Boehler, based in Vienna, said it opposed the bid.

The Mexican wireless phone company Grupo Iusacell said it would merge with a smaller carrier, Unefon, consolidating the two companies controlled by the Mexican business magnate, Ricardo Salinas Pliego, left. The planned merger of Unefon Holdings into Iusacell will give Iusacell more than 3.4 million wireless subscribers, or about 7 percent of the Mexican market, the company said in a filing with the Mexican Stock Exchange. The dominant wireless carrier in the Mexican market, Telcel, a unit of América Móvil, ended 2006 with 43.2 million subscribers. Iusacell and Unefon began consolidating operations last year. Gustavo Guzman will remain as chief executive of Iusacell. The proposal values Iusacell at $1 billion and Unefon at $333 million.
Corrections: For the Record

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the success of the Comedy Central cable channel misstated the precedent for a video game based on “South Park,” a popular Comedy Central series. One was released in 1998; a cell-phone game based on “South Park” planned by Viacom, Comedy Central’s parent company, will not be the first.

An article in Science Times on March 13 about efforts to increase the number of minority students studying science referred imprecisely to the Meyerhoff Scholarship Program at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Although the program indeed emphasizes the need for more minority students, it is open to any undergraduate.

An article on Monday about the pending retirements of 11 of New Jersey’s 40 state senators referred incorrectly to a previous large turnover, when 24 senators were defeated or retired in reaction to the Watergate scandal, and misstated the year that Gov. Jim Florio pushed through an unpopular tax increase, which led to another turnover. The election defeats took place in 1973, not 1974, and the tax increase was enacted in 1990, not 1992. The article also misstated the home county of one of this year’s retiring senators, Robert J. Martin. He is from Morris County, not Bergen.

An article on March 12 about the last night at the Roxy, a discothèque in Chelsea, misstated its history. It first became known in 1990 as a gay nightclub on Saturday nights, at the direction of two promoters, Lee Chappell and David Leigh — not in 1991, the year that John Blair, the promoter with whom the club became associated, arrived.

A front-page article yesterday about living with the early stages of Alzheimer’s disease misstated the number of couples New York University had planned to accommodate in counseling sessions for Alzheimer’s patients and their spouses, and included erroneous information from the university on how many signed up. The sessions were to include 100 couples, not 200, and 26 couples enrolled, not 16. Also, a picture caption with the article misstated the age of Peter Hebert, who advocates for patients in Northern California. As the article noted, he is 67, not 76.

A Media Talk report in Business Day on Monday, about plans by The Harvard Crimson to hire an ombudsman, misstated the name of the independent student newspaper at Brandeis University that already has a similar position. It is The Justice, not The Brandeis Justice.

An article on Tuesday about the reoccupation of an evacuated Israeli settlement in the West Bank by about 2,000 right-wing activists referred incompletely to the name of the mainstream organization of Israeli settlers, which did not endorse the action. It is the Yesha Council, not Yesha. (Yesha is the Hebrew acronym used by many settlers for the West Bank and Gaza.).

An article last Friday about roofs covered by vegetation referred incorrectly to the roof planned for the new California Academy of Sciences building. It will be the largest continuous swath of native vegetation in San Francisco, according to Paul Kephart, who is the technical consultant for the roof; it will not be the largest continuous swath of vegetation of any kind in San Francisco.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday, about plans for a film inspired by an essay in The New York Times by Dana Canedy, a Times editor, misidentified the rights that were acquired by Escape Artists, a production house based at Columbia Pictures. They were the rights to the life stories of Ms. Canedy; her fiancé, First Sgt. Charles Monroe King, who was killed in Iraq in October; and their son, Jordan. It did not buy the rights to the essay.
Pitchers Joe Smith and Aaron Sele have made the Mets’ roster, that much is sure. The remainder of the team’s decisions will come Friday.

OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., March 29 (AP) — Investigators say they believe that a dairy company employee’s failure to flush cleaning solution from at least one machine contaminated a batch of chocolate milk, sickening eight Connecticut children and forcing a recall in four states.

Workers with the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene have begun approaching patrons outside some chain restaurants and offering them $2 MetroCards in exchange for their dining receipts.
Martine G. Guerrier, formerly an outspoken appointee to New York City’s Panel for Educational Policy, is the new chief family engagement officer for the Department of Education.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) — Kirk Hinrich hit two of three free throws with 2.8 seconds left, and the Chicago Bulls clinched their third straight playoff berth, pulling out an 83-81 victory against the Detroit Pistons on Thursday after blowing a 12-point lead in the fourth quarter.
The video game maker faced an insurrection from shareholders that claimed the jobs of the chief executive and three directors.
The more the administration tries to spin the prosecutor purge, the worse it looks.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,237 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
AT&T, Verizon and Qwest were selected to bid  on portions of the government’s contract while Sprint Nextel was left out in the cold.
soccer.
If George Steinbrenner names a replacement for his once presumed successor Steve Swindal, he will almost certainly look to his sons, Hank and Hal.
France’s presidential campaign has been seized by a subject dear to the extreme right: how best to be French.
Ten years after the British handed over the islands to the Chinese, it is time to bring universal suffrage to Hong Kong.
Robert M. Corrigan’s favorite table at his favorite Starbucks, just across Park Row from City Hall Park in Lower Manhattan, looks out on an ancient alley where he said rats often scamper.
The discounts on the Tundra may be another sign that Toyota is not cutting into the truck market as much as rivals feared.
What few have talked about amid a feel-good week at Georgetown is that the Hoyas recruited a player from an unaccredited prep school who compiled final grades of F in 12 courses.
A new law in Maryland would make eligible to vote all ex-offenders who have completed their sentences and finished parole and probation.
The final hours of Suaada Saadoun’s life reveal the fierce pressure Sunnis face from Shiite militias in Baghdad.
Although American officials were caught off guard by remarks by the Saudi king condemning the American intervention in Iraq, they sought to avoid tension over the comments.
The gun lobby is running into a commendable challenge from corporate America.
Dell said “evidence of misconduct” had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years.
The former principal of a Manhattan private school was convicted of having sex with one of her students in a classroom when he was about 13 and she was about 30.
The leaders of 21 Arab governments called on Israel to withdraw from the land it occupied in the 1967 war in exchange for full diplomatic relations with them.
Manager Joe Torre revealed his 25-man roster  Friday, with pitcher Sean Henn, catcher Wil Nieves, and first baseman Josh Phelps beating out older competition.
State Senator Wayne R. Bryant is accused of using his influence to gain a $37,000-a-year no-show job at the state medical school in exchange for bringing in grants.
Iran insisted that Britain admit fault before any of the 15 captured British sailors and marines are released.
A program will pay poor families up to $5,000 a year to meet certain goals like attending parent-teacher conferences.
The racially charged symbol for Uncle Ben’s rice products is taking center stage in a new campaign that makes him chairman of the company.
The seller of nutritional supplements rejected a takeover offer from the private equity firm Whitney & Company.
Blackstone’s co-founder Stephen A. Schwarzman gets a taste of the public hot seat in a union blog focused on his private equity firm.
A French nun testified to the Vatican that she was miraculously cured of Parkinson’s disease after praying to the late Pope John Paul II.
Dr. Robert Austrian’s research led to a pneumococcal vaccine that has saved the lives of hundreds of thousands of people.
The entanglements between Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey and a union leader he was dating have led to public fascination.
Lorena Ochoa made five birdies and opened with a three-under 69 in tough conditions, leaving her one shot behind Shi Hyun Ahn at the Kraft Nabisco Championship.
Quentin Richardson’s season is over and his future is somewhat clouded because of a back injury that apparently will require surgery.
The Massey Energy Company was fined $1.5 million for 25 violations that contributed to the death of two West Virginia coal miners in January 2006.
Flight attendants at Northwest Airlines are not allowed to strike, a federal appeals court ruled.
The deadliest attacks on Thursday were aimed at predominantly Shiite neighborhoods and appeared to be part of a fierce campaign by Sunni Arab insurgents.
Some music lovers were allowed to play one of the finest violins ever made ahead of an auction at Christie’s.
The $2.1 billion deal to buy Lone Star Technologies will make U.S. Steel the largest producer of tubular steel in North America.
The video game maker faced an insurrection from shareholders that claimed the jobs of the chief executive and three directors.
Older Americans are increasingly turning to video games for recreation.
After testing positive for a banned substance in June 2005, Guillermo Cañas was suspended from the ATP Tour.  Protesting his innocence, he returned last fall with a renewed purpose.
The bill provided more than $97.5 billion for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan but ordered troop withdrawals from Iraq to begin within 120 days.
At a luxury office building, Artie the security guard takes no time off for sleep, weekends, holidays or vacation.
Bill Byrne, the Texas A&M athletic director, told Arkansas officials that Coach Billy Gillispie intended to remain with the Aggies, an Arkansas official said yesterday.
Ronell Wilson was ordered to die for the murder of undercover detectives James V. Nemorin and Rodney J. Andrews.

Ollie’s, one of Manhattan’s best-known Chinese restaurant chains, was sued yesterday by 43 waiters, deliverymen and other workers who accused it of violating minimum wage laws by paying some employees as little as $1.40 an hour.
Josh Boone’s N.B.A. coming-out party has been light on scintillating spin moves and acrobatic dunks, and heavy on craft, quick thinking and positioning.
Investors weighed fears about mounting tension involving Iran against a report that indicated better-than-expected economic growth.
The Rangers said closer Eric Gagné had not had any health setbacks, but needed more time to come back from elbow and back operations..
Turmoil is building ahead of a referendum scheduled for April 15 for voters to decide on convening an assembly to rewrite the Constitution.
The government may not introduce evidence meant to show that Joseph P. Nacchio tried to conceal $90 million in assets in February 2002.
A Manhattan federal judge has dismissed a class-action lawsuit accusing JPMorgan Chase of helping Enron hide fraud.
In Sylvia Fowles, the Lady Tigers have a player who is beginning to realize her full potential. With great agility and a spacious wingspan, she anchors the nation’s top scoring defense.
A partial list of some of the most egregious earmarks shows that, despite lofty rhetoric about the Iraq war, the new Democratic Congress is already feeding at the trough.
We must keep talking to the Iranians, offering carrots even when these are contemptuously tossed into the gutter, because there is no credible alternative.
Christian Dior announced it had replaced Hedi Slimane, whose razor-thin suits helped revitalize the image of the house.
George C. Izenour, a pioneer in theater design and technology, helped bring automation to stagecraft.
This year’s birthday celebration for the philanthropist will be low-key.
Tornadoes cut through Colorado, Oklahoma, Texas, Illinois, Kansas and Nebraska.
Georgetown, coached by the Pete Carril disciple John Thompson III, reached this weekend’s Final Four with an offense borrowed from Carril’s days as Princeton’s coach.
Charlotte Winters was the last surviving woman to have served in the American armed forces in World War I and one of the first to enlist in the Navy.

A pilot who was killed Wednesday night when his small plane crashed into the woods in Howell Township radioed air traffic control moments before the crash and did not indicate that anything was wrong, officials said yesterday. The Federal Aviation Administration said the pilot, Eugene R. Pilot, 70, of Neptune, was returning to Allaire Airport in Farmingdale after an hourlong flight when his single-engine Piper PA-28 crashed just after 8 p.m. The cause of the crash is still under investigation, said Bob Gretz of the National Transportation Safety Board.

A Spring Valley building inspector said yesterday that the village would allow a rabbi to continue making matzo out of a large oven inside a school bus in his backyard. Rabbi Aaron Winternitz, who is also a schoolteacher, installed the oven in the bus, which sits behind his house, three years ago and has used it to make matzo for his congregation every Passover. But last week, after a neighbor complained of heavy smoke, village officials inspected the bus and ordered Rabbi Winternitz to shut it down. He was ordered to disconnect gas lines , move the bus further away from the house, and provide the village with engineering documents indicating that the oven was safe, said Manny Carmona, the deputy building inspector. Yesterday, however, Mr. Carmona said Rabbi Winternitz had been given a temporary reprieve because Passover, which begins Monday at sundown, is almost here.

A Rider University freshman was in critical condition yesterday after what prosecutors termed a possible hazing episode at a fraternity house, the Mercer County prosecutor’s office said. The student, Gary Devercelly, 18, of Long Beach, Calif., was taken to the Fuld campus of Capital Health System in Trenton around 2 a.m. yesterday after the police came to the Phi Kappa Tau fraternity house at Rider University because of a report that a student was vomiting after he drank too much, Prosecutor Casey DeBlasio said in a statement. Another student who left the house earlier was treated at the hospital for alcohol poisoning and released. Prosecutors said the matter was under investigation as a possible case of hazing.

The city will play host to a new theater festival this spring featuring works by artists from New York, Latin America, the Caribbean and Spain, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The festival, TeatroStageFest, will run from April 30 through May 13 at sites in the East Fourth Street Cultural District, the mayor said. The festival will feature seven theatrical productions, panel discussions and concerts, Mr. Bloomberg said.

An off-duty narcotics detective spotted a house fire in Castleton Corners yesterday morning and rescued a 4-year-old boy from the burning building, the police said. The detective, Vincent DiCrescento, was driving past 70 Windsor Road about 5 a.m. when he saw the three-story house burning, the police said. After phoning 911, Detective DiCrescento knocked on doors and alerted residents. Spotting a man calling for help from a third-floor window, Detective DiCrescento used an extension ladder to climb halfway up the building and grabbed the child when the man lowered him from the window. The man and his wife, who were not named by the police yesterday, were later led to safety by firefighters, the police said. The fire was brought under control just before 6 a.m., the Fire Department said.

New York City’s unemployment rate dropped to 4.8 percent in February, from 4.9 percent in January, the State Labor Department reported yesterday. The city’s jobless rate, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, has held below 5 percent for seven consecutive months, the longest stretch since 1988. The state’s jobless rate rose to 4.4 percent, from 4.3 percent in January, but remained below the national rate of 4.5 percent. The number of private-sector jobs in the state increased only slightly last month, rising by 5,200, or 0.1 percent, to 7.18 million. In the last 12 months, the state has added 103,100 private-sector jobs, a gain of 1.2 percent.

Manalapan Township has agreed to pay $275,000 to settle a lawsuit filed in State Superior Court by three black youths who said police officers searched them without justification and berated them in 2003, the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday. The three — Diamond Yorker, then 16, Randy Reina, then 17, and Sean Anderson, then 11 — were standing on a sidewalk with three white friends when officers searched them, while telling their friends they could leave, Deborah Jacobs, the chapter’s executive director, said in a statement. The township did not admit wrongdoing and its lawyers declined to comment yesterday.

Two people were charged with drug possession after a raid on a home in Egg Harbor on Monday yielded more than 500 marijuana plants, the police said on Wednesday. The attic held some of the plants, while others were concealed behind trap doors in the basement, the police told The Press of Atlantic City. The homeowner, Larry Sands, 34, and his girlfriend, Erin McGee, 24, were charged with drug possession, the police said.

The Coast Guard called off a search yesterday for a missing boater, concluding that the 52-year-old man probably did not survive the cold water of Long Island Sound. The man, Daniel Greene of Hamden, was reported missing Wednesday evening by two passengers on the sailboat. The passengers were below deck for about two hours and awoke about 6:30 p.m. to discover that Mr. Greene, who had been sailing the boat, was missing, the Coast Guard said. The passengers fired flares that were spotted by a tugboat. The tug’s crew called the Coast Guard, which conducted a 12-hour search for Mr. Greene. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Despite deep dissatisfaction with his rule, President Robert G. Mugabe seems poised to maintain his grip on the country he has ruled for 27 years.
The gross domestic product grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the final quarter of last year, healthier than previously thought.

TRENTON, March 29 — New Jersey’s commerce secretary and the widow of a 9/11 victim was appointed Thursday by Gov. Jon S. Corzine to a seat on the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the World Trade Center site.
A federal judge dismissed a bid by China to block the Bush administration from imposing tariffs on Chinese goods produced by heavily subsidized government companies.
The value of corporate deals reached $1.08 trillion in the first quarter, 24 percent more than the first quarter of 2006.
One of the largest home builders in the country said it had received a grand jury subpoena from a United States attorney’s office.
The third quarter of fiscal year 2007  starts April 1. Here are our picks for the ultimate office roster.
Leonhard Fischer resigned as the head of Credit Suisse Group in Europe a month after being passed over for chief executive.
The appointment provides a highly visible platform for an opposition figure in a region uniformly dominated by one-party politics.
About three-quarters of the cards had either expired at the time of the theft or data from their magnetic strips had been masked.
Fourth-quarter net income rose 15 percent, driven by an increase in used-vehicle sales and an income increase from its financing unit.
A vote in Congress would be purely symbolic but could make relations between Washington and Ankara unusually tense.
A suicide bomber blew himself up in an attack on a military training area in Punjab province, killing one soldier and wounding seven others, military officials said.
Prime Minister Surayud Chulanont of Thailand said that he still had the power to declare a state of emergency, but that the current situation did not merit the move.

The N.C.A.A. basketball tournament has avoided that inglorious moment in which a referee’s mistake leaves a lasting scar on a championship. But that could change if Georgetown or Ohio State wins the title.

Ethiopian troops stormed into the center of the capital, Mogadishu, setting off clashes that killed more than 30 people.
The first therapy that would direct a cancer patient’s own immune system to fight tumors moved closer to approval.
A restaurant owner received Chicago’s first fine under an April 2006 ordinance that is the first in the country to ban the sale of foie gras.
A new study is among the few to document the cascading effects that the loss of a top predator can have on a marine ecosystem.
The nation’s largest cable company paid its chief executive, Brian L. Roberts, a salary of $2.5 million, a bonus of $3 million and other payments including a cash bonus of $8.4 million.
The Supreme Court is likely to announce within days whether it will hear appeals filed on behalf of two groups of detainees at the naval base.
The city’s latest redevelopment plan involves concentrating resources in zones about a half-mile in diameter to stimulate investment and renewal.
Immigration officers raided a temporary job agency and eight sites where the agency had placed workers, including several warehouses in the city’s port.
The attorney general had been consulted regularly about firing U.S. attorneys, his former chief of staff testified.
Medical mistakes and delays in care have been caused by some hospitals’ reluctance to use a digital record system.
Rudolph W. Giuliani said that if he were president, his wife would be permitted to attend cabinet meetings and advise him on federal policy.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, could be closed as long as a way could be found to keep the most dangerous detainees behind bars.
The same two men are believed to have shot six people, including a group of college friends, in 48 hours last weekend.
The first fund-raising period, which ends at midnight Saturday, has become a major test in the campaign.
A Democratic spending plan envisions a balanced budget by 2012, but like its Senate counterpart, it implicitly requires tax increases in the years ahead.
Federal officials are opposed to a Montana woman’s plan for a business that would scatter the cremated remains of her clients on public land.

Prices are rising at the pumps again, but even as gas tops $3 a gallon, consumption has not gone down.
On Monday the public can ponder anew the affections and undercurrents that ran between two of the great figures of the 20th century.
Foxy Brown books her next fight, knighthood for Bono, a new name for Irving Plaza and more culture news.
The level of performing and the well-chosen selection of works at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater on Wednesday made it easy to imagine these students stepping right into professional careers.
The Canadian pianist’s exacting execution of “Sonetti del Petrarca” was thrilling in his mostly-Liszt program at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday.

To the Editor: President Bush had delusions of grandeur going into Iraq four years ago and now, today, has the delusion that victory there is possible (''Legislating Leadership on Iraq,'' editorial, March 29).

More than 100 people were killed in a series of attacks around Iraq that included two suicide bombings that struck crowded markets during the week's busiest shopping hours, the authorities said. The attacks extended an extraordinary surge of sectarian violence in Iraq this week, including a series of bombings and reprisals in the northern city of Tal Afar in which more than 140 people were killed in two days.

Ow Greenberg Van Doren Gallery 730 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street Through April 7 Upon entering Barry Ratoff's show, you see a small, black neon sculpture twisted into the word ''Ow.'' It -- the entire show in fact -- recalls the gothic darkness of a Banks Violette installation, not with the glamorous brutality of heavy metal's clashing riffs, but with the whine of youthful angst.

Foxy Brown Books Her Next Fight The rapper Foxy Brown (right, with her lawyer Fred Haddad) was scheduled for a June trial after pleading not guilty on Wednesday in a Florida court to two misdemeanor charges in connection with a dispute on Feb. 15 in a beauty supply store in Pembroke Pines, Fla., The Associated Press reported. ''I am going to stand up and fight and take care of this,'' she said outside the courthouse, according to The South Florida Sun-Sentinel. The judge, Joel Lazarus, set the trial date after withdrawing a warrant for her arrest, which was issued after she failed to appear for a court date. Defense lawyers told the judge that the notice to Ms. Brown, 27, whose real name is Inga Marchand, had been mailed to an outdated address. She is charged with battery and resisting arrest. In 2004 she was sentenced to probation and anger-management classes after a fight at a nail salon in Manhattan. Knighthood for Bono The Irish rock star Bono, below, became a knight of the British Empire yesterday, The Associated Press reported. ''You have permission to call me anything you want -- except sir, all right?'' he said after the lighthearted ceremony in Dublin at the home of the British ambassador, David Reddaway. ''Lord of lords, your demigodness, that'll do.'' Mr. Reddaway paid tribute to Bono's work as a campaigner against poverty and disease in Africa after asking if he was disappointed that becoming a knight no longer involves a sword or kneeling. ''Please,'' said Bono, his hand on the ambassador's shoulder, ''I wasn't expecting you to kneel.'' Bono, 46, the U2 frontman whose real name is Paul Hewson, was designated a Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire. He was accompanied by his wife, Ali, and their four children: Jordan, 17; Eve, 15; Elijah, 7; and John, 5, as well as the guitarist the Edge and the bassist Adam Clayton, his band mates. The Dublin-born Bono, who will not be entitled to use the title Sir because he is not a citizen of Britain or of a country in the Commonwealth of former British colonies, dismissed criticism from some Irish nationalists for accepting a British honor. ''I think Britain is great,'' he said. ''And Irish people support British football teams. And Irish bands sign British record labels. And Irish people speak English.'' And Now the Elgins Prime Minister Costas Karamanlis of Greece said yesterday that the pending completion of the new Acropolis Museum and recent repatriation of antiquities from the United States, Sweden and Germany ''evaporate the vague excuses'' for Britain's refusal to return the Elgin Marbles, Reuters reported. Cultural Minister George Voulgarakis expressed confidence that the government's efforts to reclaim the 2,500-year-old reliefs, known in Greece as the Parthenon Marbles and exhibited in the British Museum in London, would someday lead to their return. Their comments came at ceremonies in Athens, where Greece displayed two ancient looted artifacts returned by the Getty Museum in Los Angeles: a fourth-century B.C. Macedonian gold wreath and a sixth-century B.C. marble statue of a woman. Their return was part of a deal to return four objects added to the Getty collection as a result of smuggling and illegal sale. MCC Plots the Future Much news from MCC Theater: the appointment of a new executive director, Blake West, who has been the director of development at the theater since February 2006; and the lineup for the 2007-8 season. The season includes ''Grace,'' a new play by Mick Gordon and the philosopher A. C. Grayling; ''Spain,'' a romantic comedy by Jim Knable; and ''The Black Suits'' by Joe Iconis and Robert Maddock. Harry Hamlin and his wife, Lisa Rinna, will make their Broadway debuts when they enter the cast of ''Chicago'' at the Ambassador Theater on June 19 for a run through July 29. Footnotes Ending a six-and-a-half-year hiatus the Smashing Pumpkins will perform once again when they play a theater in Paris on May 22 at the start of a European tour, a spokesman said on Wednesday, Reuters reported.

An off-duty narcotics detective spotted a house fire in Castleton Corners yesterday morning and rescued a 4-year-old boy from the burning building, the police said. The detective, Vincent DiCrescento, was driving past 70 Windsor Road about 5 a.m. when he saw the three-story house burning, the police said. After phoning 911, Detective DiCrescento knocked on doors and alerted residents. Spotting a man calling for help from a third-floor window, Detective DiCrescento used an extension ladder to climb halfway up the building and grabbed the child when the man lowered him from the window. The man and his wife, who were not named by the police yesterday, were later led to safety by firefighters, the police said. The fire was brought under control just before 6 a.m., the Fire Department said.

At the end of ''Meet the Robinsons,'' a new 3-D computer-animated Disney film (loosely based on a popular children's book by William Joyce), the screen is filled with an inspiring quotation from Walt Disney himself. The gist of it is that ''around here'' -- meaning at Disney's entertainment workshop -- not a lot of time is spent looking backward. Instead, the motto is, as it is for some of the characters in the film, ''Keep moving forward.'' In other words, learn from your mistakes. And it seems appropriate that this great man's words appear at the end of this movie, since they implicitly invite you to forget what you have just seen and may even serve as a sort of apology. Whether or not it counts as a mistake -- movies tend to be made on purpose -- ''Meet the Robinsons'' is surely one of the worst theatrically released animated features issued under the Disney label in quite some time.

New Therapy for Cancer Moves Closer to Approval The first therapy that would direct a cancer patient's own immune system to attack a tumor moved closer to approval. The therapy, Provenge, for advanced prostate cancer, would open a new front in the cancer war because it differs from existing treatments, which attack cancer cells directly. HEIM--Richard M. President of Richard M. Heim Advertising, died on March 26th, at the age of 81, and worked until the last day of his life. Richard lived a full and vibrant personal and professional life and was loved by all who knew him for his kindness and generosity. He served in the U.S. Army Air Corps in WWII and was a tail gunner on a B-24. His plane was shot at and he was forced to parachute over Yugoslavia. He was missing in action for two months and received a Purple Heart. Richard then went on to graduate from Penn State and did graduate work in history at NYU. He belonged to the Pi Lambda Phi Fraternity and continued a life-long dedication to it, holding several positions on its various councils. As a trustee of the Educational Foundation, he raised substantial monies to support its scholarship programs. Richard loved young people and tried to encourage them to reach their potential and counseled them on alcohol abuse. Richard was passionate about golf. He belonged to the Whippoorwill Club in Armonk and served on many committees at the club, including being a board member for nine years. Richard was a devoted husband to his wife, Rose Tripp Heim. He is also survived by his brother, Robert, his nephew, Gregory, and his niece, Carolyn, her husband, John, and their two sons, Luke and Evan. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Madison Ave. and 81st St. on Wednesday, April 4th, at 3:30pm. Donations may be made to the Genitourinary Cancer Research Fund, c/o Dr. David Nanus, Payson Pavillion 3rd Fl., 525 East 68th St., NYC 10021

An article on March 12 about the last night at the Roxy, a discothèque in Chelsea, misstated its history. It first became known in 1990 as a gay nightclub on Saturday nights, at the direction of two promoters, Lee Chappell and David Leigh -- not in 1991, the year that John Blair, the promoter with whom the club became associated, arrived.

FARLEY--James Parker of Wilton, CT, died peacefully on March 29. Born in Newark, NJ on September 16, 1924, Jim leaves his beloved wife of 56 years, Irene, and their four children: James and wife Petra and children Devin, Colin and Carling of London; Catherine and son-in-law David Elkind and son Daniel of Greenwich, CT; Robert and daughter - in - law Maribeth and children Katherine and Patrick of Wilton, CT; and Margaret of Westport, CT. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law Thomas R. and Nancy Farley of West Orange, NJ and his sister Maryrose Swift of Upper Montclair, NJ. He was educated at St. Peter's Prep and Rutgers University (Class of 1949). He served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. His career started with General Electric Co. in 1949. He joined McCann-Erickson in New York in 1956 before moving to Tokyo in 1962 as part of the joint venture team that built McCannErickson-Hakuhodo, one of the earliest American-Japanese advertising partnerships. In 1964, he became President and CEO of the venture; in 1978 he became EVP McCann - Erickson Worldwide with responsibilities for the Pacific Region; returning to New York in 1980 until his retirement in 1984. Among his many retirement activities, Jim was an active supporter of Project Liberty Ship and its restoration of the John W. Brown on which he served during WWII. He was an active member of the New York Athletic Club's Anglers and Huckleberry Indians groups, and a member of the Foreign Correspondent Club (Japan and Hong Kong), Young Presidents Organization, Zeta Phi, Tokyo American Club (past President), Patterson Club (Fairfield, CT), Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club, Metropolitan Club (NYC), and the National Maritime Historical Society. Memorial Mass, 11am, April 14, Our Lady of Fatima Church, 229 Danbury Road, Wilton, CT. Burial and interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Grace C. Jones Nursing Scholarship Fund c/o the Norwalk Hospital Foundation, 24 Stevens Street, Norwalk, CT 06856.

STARK--Howard E. Cleveland native, a pioneer in television broadcasting, passed away March 12, 2007, at age 92, in New York City. He is survived by brothers Sol (Doris) of West Palm Beach, FL, and Cleveland, Mort (Mae, deceased) and Al (Joyce); and sister, Marilyn Micohn (Al), all of Cleveland; and numerous nieces and nephews throughout the country. He was preceded in death by a sister, Gertrude Rosenstein (Ben, deceased). Following graduation from John Adams High School, Stark left Cleveland, eventually settling in New York City. Stark is credited with single-handedly creating what is now the multi-billion dollar television and radio station brokerage industry; unheard of and unimagined until envisioned by Stark in the 1950's. Over his 50 year career, he was instrumental in virtually every strategic ownership transaction in the industry. Stark was called upon to broker the transaction that created WNET, the nation's first public television station in 1962. Never working with any more than a personal assistant, his client list spanned a generation of media giants including the Walt Disney Company, RKO, Metromedia, Knight Ridder, Viacom, Taft Broadcasting, Allbrittion Communications, Gannett, The Tribune Company and dozens more. In the 1970's when Wall Street began competing, Broadcast & Cable Magazine listed Stark as having closed over $1 billion in transaction in a single year, more than all of the combined Wall Street media transactions. Howard Stark lived in NY and did business throughout the United States and Europe. He was a world traveler and sophisticated business executive, yet privately he was a modest man, a fine tennis player and raconteur. Howard Stark was devoted to his extended family in both NY and Cleveland. He was a remarkable man who led a remarkable life. Known to all as simply, ''Howard'', his generosity and modesty was only exceeded by his style and wit. He will be deeply missed. Funeral services were private.

To the Editor: I was delighted to read ''Chief Says F.C.C. Is Against Cellphone Use on Airliners'' (Business Day, March 23) as I rode on a relatively uncrowded Metro-North train surrounded for 50 minutes by three somewhat heated cellphone conversations.

A detainee at Guantánamo Bay who has been described as a financier of the Sept. 11 attacks said at a closed hearing that top operatives of Al Qaeda informed him of the impending attacks the night before they occurred, according to a transcript released yesterday. The detainee, Mustafa Ahmed al-Hawsawi, said he was told by Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who has been identified as a top Qaeda operative, ''that next night there would be an operation.'' In the transcript of the March 21 hearing, he said he also discussed the attack with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who was quoted earlier this month as telling a similar closed hearing that he was the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. WILLIAM GLABERSON

In April, board members and shareholders of the McIlhenny Company plan to gather here for their annual meeting. Unlike well-publicized events at big public companies this year, where activist shareholders often hope to create a stir, a private gathering is planned, and the agenda will probably not be debated. The meeting promises to be what it always is: one part business and one part family reunion. Food is on the menu, and plenty of it: Cajun specialties, like boudin, corn-and-crab bisque and crawfish pie. There will be sweet tea, soda pop and bloody marys. And on every table, there will probably be all six flavors of Tabasco sauce. But for the McIlhennys, this is no idle condiment to spice up bland food. This is business.

An appeals court rejected the government's renaming of the Limpopo town of Louis Trichardt to Makhado. Louis Trichardt was an Afrikaaner who led the trek to the area in the 1830s; Makhado was a local king there who resisted white invaders. The court said that officials did not sufficiently clear the change with the town's residents. The decision was a rare victory for advocates who have sought to block the scrapping of apartheid-era names for South African cities, streets and natural features in favor of African names. The country's Arts and Culture Ministry said it accepted the decision, which was based on procedural issues, but did not say whether it would reopen the matter. MICHAEL WINES

A Spring Valley building inspector said yesterday that the village would allow a rabbi to continue making matzo out of a large oven inside a school bus in his backyard. Rabbi Aaron Winternitz, who is also a schoolteacher, installed the oven in the bus, which sits behind his house, three years ago and has used it to make matzo for his congregation every Passover. But last week, after a neighbor complained of heavy smoke, village officials inspected the bus and ordered Rabbi Winternitz to shut it down. He was ordered to disconnect gas lines , move the bus farther away from the house, and provide the village with engineering documents indicating that the oven was safe, said Manny Carmona, the deputy building inspector. Yesterday, however, Mr. Carmona said Rabbi Winternitz had been given a temporary reprieve because Passover, which begins Monday at sundown, is almost here. ANAHAD O'CONNOR

KENT--Miriam. Children of Arthur M. Sackler mourn the passing of Miriam Kent, whose loyalty, commitment, and never-ending energy served our father from 1952 until his death in 1987. For two decades she was Secretary of The Arthur M. Sackler Foundation and will be truly missed by its Staff and Board of Directors.

Fox News and the Congressional Black Caucus Political Education and Leadership Institute announced that they had agreed to sponsor two debates for presidential candidates this year. Negotiations between the network and the institute had been closely watched since Nevada Democrats backed out of a debate for Democratic candidates a few weeks ago that was sponsored by Fox News. The deal was canceled after liberal advocates and bloggers criticized the state's Democratic leaders and Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, for choosing the conservative-leaning network as a sponsor. The schedule for debates by Fox and the institute, includes a Sept. 23 event for Democratic candidates in Detroit. No date has been set for a Republican debate. KATE PHILLIPS

Opens today in New York and Los Angeles. Directed by Julian Goldberger Not rated; 106 minutes At this point in his career, the actor Paul Giamatti is pretty much the go-to guy for crumpled manhood, for characters whose disappointment with life is stamped on their spines and sagging jowls. In films like ''American Splendor'' and ''Sideways,'' he turned dejection into a seduction technique and self-pity into a reason for living. Now imagine an entire film infected with this hangdog sensibility, unrelieved by humor or narrative interest, and you have ''The Hawk Is Dying.''

KORNREICH--Mort. A good friend. A renaissance man. We'll miss you. Barney & Ethel Mayrsohn $(6$)KORNREICH--Mort. The Officers, Board of Directors, and the entire staff of The NIA Group and Kornreich NIA are deeply saddened by the passing of Mort Kornreich, CoChairman of the Kornreich Organization, on Tuesday, March 27th. Mort Kornreich joined his father Saul and his brother Matthew to help build S. Kornreich & Sons Inc. into one of the largest privately held insurance brokerage firms in the United States. The firm was a pioneer in offering multi-lines of insurance services and products to its clients. Mort was a Chartered Life Underwriter and a member of the Million Dollar Round Table. In addition to his many honors, he, along with his brother Matt, was named Mass Mutual Man of the Year in 1975. He was a dynamic mentor and coach, a talented professional, a compassionate human being, and a real gentleman. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his twin brother Matt and his wife, Suzanne; his sister, Norma Weinstein; his children, Jim and Meredith Kornreich, Tom and Barbara Kornreich, and Nancy and Rob Rieger; his grandchildren, Todd, Jennifer, Maggie, Caroline, Adam, Zachary, Molly, and Alex. Funeral services for Mort Kornreich will be held 11:00 am, Friday, March 30th at Congregational Emmanuel of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY 10580. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to United Jewish Appeal Federation, 701 Westchester Avenue, Suite 203 East, White Plains, NY 10604; or The American Jewish Committee, 235 Main Street, Suite 314, White Plains, NY 10601. $(6$)KORNREICH--Mort. Uncle Morty, our hearts are broken with your passing, though they are filled and enlightened for having known and loved you. Your philanthropy, activism, and creativity will always be an inspiration. We've been doubly blessed by having two fathers. Bill, Eileen, and Sarah Kathy, Sam, Lisa, and Andrew $(6$)KORNREICH--Mort. Mort, You were my other half and best friend since birth. You will live in our hearts forever. Matt and Sue $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton, to our beloved ''Uncle Mort'' -a real mensch -one of the great guys. We will miss you. Love Dorothy, Richard, Sandi, and families $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton. United Jewish Communities (UJC), its Board of Trustees and staff mourn the passing of Morton Kornreich, a true partner and friend of the continental Jewish federation system. Among his many leadership positions in the Jewish community, Morton served as national chairman of United Jewish Appeal from 1988 until 1990. Morton dedicated himself to the Jewish community, with kindness and dignity. He will be missed by all who knew him. UJC extends our deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolences to the entire Kornreich family. $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff of CLAL -The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership mourn the passing of Mort Kornreich, our esteemed past Chairman and Board member. He was deeply caring and committed to the Jewish community, and his advice and counsel will be greatly missed. CLAL extends deepest sympathy to his family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Fern K. Hurst, Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Rabbi Brad Hirschfield, President Rabbi Irving Greenberg, President Emeritus Donna M. Rosenthal, Executive Vice Chairman $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton. Dear Matt, Sue, Tommy, Barbara, Jimmy, Meredith, Rob, Nancy and all the grandchildren. If heaven ranks one for kindness, generosity, sense of humor and class, Mort will be at the head of the line. Our hearts are with you. Roni, Howard and Cody $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton, be loved husband of the late JoAnn. Devoted father of James and Meredith, Thomas and Barbara, and Nancy and Robert Reiger. Cherished brother of Matthew and Sue and Norma Weinstein. Adored and loving grandfather of Todd, Jennifer, Maggie, Caroline, Adam, Zachary, Molly and Alex. Dear friend of Larcenia Petty. Services 11 am Friday, Congregation Emanu-El, 2125 Westchester Ave, Rye, NY. Contributions may be made to UJA Federation or American Jewish Committee. Love, Norma Weinstein $(6$)KORNREICH--Morton. Funeral services are being held today at 11:00am at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester in Rye, NY. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his entire family. Our hearts go out to our dear friends; Jimmy and Meredith, Tommy and Barbara, and Nancy and Rob, and their children, on the loss of their beloved father and grandfather. Mort was a man of style and a true patriarch. His commitment to Jewish philanthropy was inspiring to all of us. He left his family a wonderful legacy. You were all his pride and joy. In the underwater world of Michael Phelps, records and gold medals are acquired seemingly at will. In the underwater world of everyone else, the outcomes are much more in doubt. On Thursday, the fifth night of these world championships, Phelps blew past his third world record in three days by winning the 200-meter individual medley in 1 minute 54.98 seconds.

THOMPSON--William Ives, 85, long a fixture of the office products industry, died March 22, 2007, at his home in Rockport, Maine after a long illness. He was born February 28, 1922 in Paterson, NJ. Thompson joined the Naval Air Corp in 1942. He flew 125 reconnaissance missions aboard the B-24 Liberator, and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, three Air Medals and a Gold Star. In 1946 he began his sales career with Diebold, Inc. In 1955, Thompson became national Sales Manager of Oxford Filing Supply Company. He served Oxford for 25 years, spearheading the development of the now legendary Pendaflex hanging folder. Named President of Oxford in 1969 and ultimately Chairman and CEO in 1975, Thompson also served as President of the National Office Products Association and as Chairman of the manufacturing division in 1969. After the company was sold to Esselte, Inc., Thompson served four years as President of CEO of Boorum and Pease Company in Elizabeth, New Jersey. Upon his retirement, Thompson mentored inner city youth in Newark, NJ, played a key role in the development of the business library at CW Post University and served on the Regional Advisory Board of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company. He was a member of the Chatham Fish and Game Protective Association. Mr. Thompson is survived by his wife Nancy, sister Eleanor, sons Dana, Laurance, and Woodman, daughter Eleanor, stepdaughters Wendi Sue Palone and Laurie Williams, six grandchildren and six stepgrandchildren. A celebration of life will be held at 2:00, Wednesday, April 11, at First Congregational Church of Camden, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Community Agencies Corporation, 25 James Street, Newark, NJ 07102.

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Peter Miller Not rated; 81 minutes This feature filmmaking debut by Peter Miller (a PBS veteran and longtime collaborator of Ken Burns) hews to standard television documentary format: archival photographs and talking heads. But the movie's meat-and-potatoes style seems less a failure of imagination than a means of putting in the foreground its subject matter: the tale of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, Italian immigrants and outspoken anarchists charged with the 1920 robbery of a Massachusetts shoe factory and the murder of two of its employees.

POSTOL--Elliott. ''Trust the universe -I am safe, it's only change''. With love and gratitude in our hearts we announce, for the many friends he had in the United States, the transition of our dearest Elliott Postol (September 14, 1947 (New York) -March 27, 2007 (Amsterdam)). Elliott inspired and guided all of us and many others with unconditional love. We will remember him with a smile. Amsterdam: Seymour Hayden, Cameron Chesson and Hans Hammelburg, Michael Debaise, Henning Ebbinge. Bussum: Ida and Eric Keyzer, Koos and Frank Schuringa, Maggia and Rijk Swets France: Mink and Otto ter Haar, Marijke and Gejus van der Meulen and all children. Correspondence address Brouwersgracht 244M, 1013HE Amsterdam, The Netherlands.

Irving Plaza, the venerable rock club on Irving Place in Manhattan, is getting a face-lift and a name change. On April 11, with a performance by the English singer Lily Allen, below, it will be inaugurated as the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, as part of a plan by its owner, Live Nation, to attach the Fillmore name -- after the club in San Francisco and its short-lived New York annex, which closed in 1971 -- to a series of midsize clubs around the country, the company announced. Some traditions and design elements of the Fillmore will be added to the Irving Plaza space, like chandeliers and vintage posters on the walls. The club's dressing rooms will be renovated, as will the balcony to provide better sightlines. ''It's more than decorative,'' Bruce Eskowitz, Live Nation's chief executive for North American music, said of the changes. The Theater of Living Arts in Philadelphia is to be renamed the Fillmore Philadelphia next month, and other clubs around the country will follow, Live Nation said. BEN SISARIO

REVOLT AT TAKE-TWO -- A shareholder insurrection at Take-Two Interactive, the video game maker, claimed the jobs of the chief executive and three directors who were at the center of a stock options backdating scandal. Dissident shareholders voted in new directors, who promptly met and named a new chairman. [Page C2.] GAS IS UP; INDIFFERENCE TOO -- Drivers have not been cutting back as gasoline has climbed over the last two months to a national average of more than $2.60 a gallon. In recent weeks, consumption has actually risen. [C1.] UNCLE BEN'S NEW ROLE -- Uncle Ben, the racially charged advertising character who has long been the symbol for Uncle Ben's rice products, is taking center stage in a Madison Avenue makeover that makes him the chairman of the company. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C1.] HONDA STRESSING SAFETY -- Honda is promoting safety as an essential part of its public image as an automaker, and the campaign is showing results, with some of the auto industry's best scores on crash tests. [C1.] DELL'S FINANCIAL PRACTICES -- Dell said that ''evidence of misconduct'' had been uncovered in an internal investigation of the company's financial practices over several years. [C1.] LAW FIRM SETTLES SHELTER CASE -- Jenkens & Gilchrist, once a highflying Texas law firm, will shut its doors and pay a $76 million fine as part of a deal with the Justice Department over questionable tax shelters. [C3.] CHIEF AT CREDIT SUISSE QUITS -- Leonhard Fischer, below, resigned as the head of Credit Suisse Group in Europe, a month after being passed over for chief executive, and will join RHJ International, a holding company linked to Ripplewood Holdings, the private equity firm, as co-chief executive. [C6.] UNIONS AND PRIVATE-EQUITY FIRMS -- Union leaders in the United States have begun to call attention to the growing power of private equity funds and their impact on employees of the companies they acquire. [C6.] TOYOTA CUTS PRICE ON PICKUP -- Toyota Motor continues to increase discounts on its new full-size pickup, the Tundra, a sign that it is shaking up the profitable truck market less than rival automakers had feared. [C3.] RULING COULD LEAD TO TARIFFS -- A federal judge dismissed a bid by China to block the Bush administration from imposing tariffs on Chinese goods produced by heavily subsidized government companies. The ruling could lead to new trade barriers. [C3.] BEAZER HOMES IS SUBPOENAED -- Beazer Homes USA, one of the largest home builders in the United States, said that it had received a grand jury subpoena from a United States attorney's office, which is seeking documents related to its mortgage origination business. [C3.] A BIG TELECOM CONTRACT -- The federal government selected AT&T, Verizon and Qwest Communications to bid on portions of the government's biggest telecommunications contract ever, which is valued at about $20 billion over 10 years but could grow to as much as $48 billion. The decision was a major blow to Sprint Nextel, which has a long history of working with federal agencies. [C3.] TWO MAKE BID FOR TRIBUNE -- Two Los Angeles billionaires, Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad, made a last-minute bid last night for the Tribune Company, topping the favored bid by Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate magnate, by a dollar a share. [C1.] DISCOVERY BUYS OUT COX -- Discovery Communications said that it planned to buy out one of its three shareholders, Cox Communications, in a deal that included transferring the Travel Channel and $1.275 billion in cash to Cox for its 25 percent stake in Discovery. [C2.] DIOR DESIGNER IS OUT -- Christian Dior has replaced Hedi Slimane, its men's wear designer, whose razor-thin suits helped revitalize the image of the house, and replaced him with Kris Van Assche, a former assistant to Mr. Slimane. [C3.] AFTER TURBULENT DAY, SHARES RISE -- Stocks ended higher in volatile trading as investors weighed fears about mounting tension involving Iran against a report that indicated better-than-expected economic growth. [C8.] IMMIGRATION RAIDS IN BALTIMORE -- Immigration agents arrested 69 immigrants in raids at a temporary job agency and eight sites where it had placed workers in the Baltimore area, including several warehouses in the city's port. [A25.] CANCER VACCINE CLEARS HURDLE -- The first therapy that would direct a cancer patient's own immune system to attack the tumor moved a step closer to approval when it was endorsed by a federal advisory committee. The therapy, called Provenge, was developed by Dendreon, a biotechnology company in Seattle. [A16.] ONLINE THE EXECUTIVE PAY PACKAGE -- The nation's largest cable company paid its chief executive, Brian L. Roberts, a salary of $2.5 million, a bonus of $3 million and other payments including a cash bonus of $8.4 million. More on this another executive pay news is at nytimes.com/business. IN THE LAB -- Mechanical caterpillars and salamanders may someday help find land mines and even diagnose disease. A report is at nytimes.com/science. TOYOTA'S FUTURE LEADERS -- As part of its strategy to hold onto its No. 1 global spot, Toyota has opened a technical high school to train future factory leaders. A report and slide show is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. A federal judge ruled that the government could not introduce evidence meant to show that Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications, tried to conceal $90 million in assets in February 2002. (AP)

Manalapan Township has agreed to pay $275,000 to settle a lawsuit filed in State Superior Court by three black youths who said police officers searched them without justification and berated them in 2003, the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday. The three -- Diamond Yorker, then 16, Randy Reina, then 17, and Sean Anderson, then 11 -- were standing on a sidewalk with three white friends when officers searched them, while telling their friends they could leave, Deborah Jacobs, the chapter's executive director, said in a statement. The township did not admit wrongdoing and its lawyers declined to comment yesterday.

The city will play host to a new theater festival this spring featuring works by artists from New York, Latin America, the Caribbean and Spain, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The festival, TeatroStageFest, will run from April 30 through May 13 at sites in the East Fourth Street Cultural District, the mayor said. The festival will feature seven theatrical productions, panel discussions and concerts, Mr. Bloomberg said.

To the Editor: Re ''A Road Trip Back to the Future'' (March 23): I was amazed to read that Tracey Towers in the Bronx had been designed by a renowned architect, Paul Rudolph. As a teenager in the early 1970s, I lived near those monstrosities and went to Bronx Science, which is just down the street from the structures. My friends and I had no idea we were witnessing great architecture being erected. We just complained about how ugly they were and wondered who would live in such dark, foreboding buildings that seemed to have so few windows. I distinctly remember sitting in math class gazing out at them and thinking, ''There goes the neighborhood. Ruth Raskin Scarsdale, N.Y.

Chase, a fourth grader, is skilled at pushing buttons, particularly those on his new video game, Marathon to Mars. But before long he's all too adept at pushing other buttons too: his parents', his science teacher's, even his friends'. Chase's predicament unfolds in the aptly titled musical ''The Game Boy,'' whose plot hums along to the blips, beeps and ice-cream-truck tinkling of a software adventure. Presented by Vital Children's Theater, it captures the allure of video games but doesn't make anyone's eyes glaze over. Adults won't be bored by the action, and children won't be so distracted by it that they miss the authors' gentle satire. (At least most won't be; when I attended, one mesmerized theatergoer anxiously hissed, ''Press up!'' when Chase was on the verge of digital annihilation.)

Sanjaya Malakar, below, the 17-year-old ''American Idol'' underdog who stunned judges with a faux-hawk hairstyle for his performance on Tuesday, made the cut on Wednesday's results show along with eight other contestants. Chris Sligh, 28, however, did not, receiving the lowest total of the more than 30 million votes cast. Preliminary overnight numbers from local television markets indicate that the half-hour results show at 9 p.m. gave Fox an easy victory for the night. In second place, CBS's lineup of repeats following ''Jericho'' at 8 bested ABC and NBC, which tied for third. The Discovery Channel's three-hour premiere of its 11-part series, ''Planet Earth'' reached 12 million viewers Sunday, earning the network its highest household rating in 18 months. And NBC's ''Saturday Night Live,'' with the Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning as host, posted its best results among adults 18 to 49 in more than a year, averaging 7.9 million total viewers. That was well above the 6.5 million viewers who watched in April 2005, when Tom Brady, quarterback of the New England Patriots, was host. BENJAMIN TOFF

Thirty-five years ago the guitarist Jim Hall, above left, and the bassist Ron Carter, above right, released ''Alone Together,'' the chronicle of an engagement at the old Playboy Club in New York. A study in effortless economy and subtlety, the album has long been a testament to their collaboration, which has since been repeated only infrequently. (They last performed together a decade ago.) It's a modest sort of landmark: after the springiest of welcomes, Sonny Rollins's calypso ''St. Thomas,'' it ambles through a handful of other themes, most just as untroubled and familiar. Along the way Mr. Hall finds myriad opportunities to practice his brand of humble virtuosity, and Mr. Carter takes quietly adventurous harmonic flights. They both sound superbly relaxed, whether engaging in improvisational dialogue -- the two-chorus solo portion of ''Softly, as in a Morning Sunrise'' consists entirely of back-and-forth exchanges -- or easing their way together through a theme. On ballads, including the title track, they wisely maintain a lightly strolling tempo; their nonballads employ much the same feeling, but at a brisker clip. There's no great range of volume or tempo, in other words, but the bright rapport enlivens the enterprise, keeping each song distinct from the rest. And along with the menu of standards come a surprise or two, like ''Receipt, Please,'' a postbop ditty by Mr. Carter, and an aptly named piece by Mr. Hall, ''Whose Blues?'' Of course it's unfortunate that ''Alone Together'' is currently out of print; the good news is that it can easily be found through various online sources, including the iTunes Music Store. Even better, Mr. Hall and Mr. Carter have decided to give their partnership another whirl next week at the Blue Note. Given that both musicians have sounded wonderful and wise in recent weeks, the sequel could well outdo the original. (Tuesday through April 8 at 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, 212-475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum.) NATE CHINEN

Four people were killed in Colorado, Oklahoma and Texas after 65 tornadoes swept through six states on Wednesday, officials said yesterday. Two people died when a tornado swirled through their rural neighborhood near Elmwood, Okla., a state emergency official, Dixie Parker, said. They were identified as Vance and Barbra Woodbury, a husband and wife.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column yesterday, about plans for a film inspired by an essay in The New York Times by Dana Canedy, a Times editor, misidentified the rights that were acquired by Escape Artists, a production house based at Columbia Pictures. They were the rights to the life stories of Ms. Canedy; her fiancé, First Sgt. Charles Monroe King, who was killed in Iraq in October; and their son, Jordan. It did not buy the rights to the essay.

Henry G. (Hank) Steinbrenner The eldest of George Steinbrenner III's four children will turn 50 on Monday. He is a senior vice president of the Yankees. He attended Culver Military Academy and then Central Methodist University in Missouri. He became chairman of Minch Transit Company in 1987, vice president of Bay Farms Corporation in 1985 and vice president of Mid-Florida Hotels Corporation in 1990. He and his sister Jessica oversee Kinsman Farm, the family's thoroughbred racing property in Ocala, Fla. He is responsible for horse matings and for choosing trainers. He was involved in the Yankees' brief venture into automobile drag racing. He and his wife, Joan, live in Clearwater, Fla. Harold Z. (Hal) Steinbrenner At 38, the youngest of the children, he is beginning his 17th season with the Yankees, his 12th as a general partner. He is also the chairman and chief executive officer of the family-owned Steinbrenner Hotel Properties. He supervises the Yankees' 49 percent financial interest in the Class A Staten Island Yankees, who have won the New York-Penn League championship the past two years. After graduating from the Culver Military Academy, which his father and grandfather attended, he earned a bachelor's degree from Williams College in 1991 and a master's in business administration from the University of Florida (Warrington) in 1994. He and his wife, Christina, live in Tampa, Fla. Jennifer Swindal Like her sister, she graduated from Culver Girls Academy. She earned a bachelor's degree in business from the University of North Carolina in 1981. She is now on the university's Board of Visitors, which advises the Board of Trustees. After college, she worked for a short time in the Yankees' public relations office, but later indicated that chauvinism turned her away. She told The New York Times in 2004: ''Even if I wanted to move up in the organization, I would've never been allowed. Not in this family.'' On Tuesday, after 23 years of marriage, she filed for divorce from Stephen W. Swindal, a general partner of the Yankees and, at least for now, the designated successor to George Steinbrenner III as head of the Yankees' organization. She is 47, with two grown children, and lives in Tampa. Jessica Lopez She is 43, with a sociology degree from Sweet Briar, a women's college in Virginia. There, she competed for the equestrian team, studied creative writing and published her first children's book. She and her brother Hank manage the 750-acre Kinsman Farm in Ocala, Fla. The layout has 35 broodmares and 25 thoroughbreds in training. Its best-known horse was Bellamy Road, who finished seventh in the 2005 Kentucky Derby as the 5-2 favorite. In 1987, she married Joseph Molloy, who joined the Yankees' organization that year (he has since left) after teaching high school science and physical education in Tampa. They had four children. They were divorced in 1997, and she is now married to Felix M. Lopez Jr. They live in Tampa. Felix M. Lopez Jr. This is Lopez's third season as senior vice president of the Yankees. He oversees operations at the Legends Field spring training base in Tampa, the nearby minor league development complex and the Class A Tampa Yankees. Lopez, who will turn 53 on Sunday, was born in Havana and moved to Tampa when he was 15. He is a graduate of the Cam Tech School of Construction, and before joining the Yankees he owned the commercial construction company Architecture Design Construction. FRANK LITSKY

INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Sectarian Raids Continue Despite Iraq Security Plan Efforts by Shiite militiamen to drive Sunni Arabs from their homes in Baghdad, often block by block, have continued despite the thousands of additional American troops and Iraqi soldiers sent to the capital as part of the new security plan.
