All dance is influenced to some extent by the artists who perform it. That makes for difficulties in restaging pieces with different dancers, and even calls authorship into question occasionally. (Did George Balanchine really create the unnerving solo that ends his ''Episodes,'' or did Paul Taylor, the man who danced it?) JOHN JASPERSE, a modern-dance choreographer with a gift for poetic insights and visual effects, cuts to the chase in a new piece, ''BECKY, JODI AND JOHN,'' which opens Wednesday at Dance Theater Workshop. It celebrates Becky Hilton, Jodi Melnick and Mr. Jasperse. The three, who will perform the piece, met nearly two decades ago and have remained friends. Mr. Jasperse explores the constancy of their personalities, and the role of dancing, in making their friendship possible. 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; $25. NORA CHIPAUMIRE is a relatively new modern-dance choreographer. Whatever else her new ''DARK SWAN'' may be, it will be performed by the powerful Ms. Chipaumire on Thursday at the BRICstudio in Brooklyn. Sadly, its theme is more pertinent than ever today. Born in wartime Zimbabwe, Ms. Chipaumire traces the journey of a woman as she loses her country, her family and even her bearings, in a solo inspired by the ballet classic ''The Dying Swan'' and set to its score, by Saint-Saëns. The performance is part of 651 Arts's ''Choreography in Development'' series. 57 Rockwell Place, next to the BAM Harvey Theater, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4181, 651arts.org; $5. And for bittersweet laughter, there is LARRY KEIGWIN at Symphony Space. Mr. Keigwin and his company will explore the ways gender can be ''bent, stretched, inverted, converted and manipulated'' to enhance self-scrutiny, with humor. Thursday through Saturday, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, larrykeigwin.com; $21, $25 on the day of the show.

The 36 Hours column last Sunday about Prague referred incorrectly to service on Czech Airlines from New York airports to Prague. The airline flies nonstop from Kennedy Airport only. It does not fly from Newark.

HEIM--Richard M. President of Richard M. Heim Advertising, died on March 26th, at the age of 81, and worked until the last day of his life. Richard lived a full and vibrant personal and professional life and was loved by all who knew him for his kindness and generosity. He served in the U.S. Army Air Corps in WWII and was a tail gunner on a B-24. His plane was shot at and he was forced to parachute over Yugoslavia. He was missing in action for two months and received a Purple Heart. Richard then went on to graduate from Penn State and did graduate work in history at NYU. He belonged to the Pi Lambda Phi Fraternity and continued a life-long dedication to it, holding several positions on its various councils. As a trustee of the Educational Foundation, he raised substantial monies to support its scholarship programs. Richard loved young people and tried to encourage them to reach their potential and counseled them on alcohol abuse. Richard was passionate about golf. He belonged to the Whippoorwill Club in Armonk and served on many committees at the club, including being a board member for nine years. Richard was a devoted husband to his wife, Rose Tripp Heim. He is also survived by his brother, Robert, his nephew, Gregory, and his niece, Carolyn, her husband, John, and their two sons, Luke and Evan. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Madison Ave. and 81st St. on Wednesday, April 4th, at 3:30pm. Donations may be made to the Genitourinary Cancer Research Fund, c/o Dr. David Nanus, Payson Pavillion 3rd Fl., 525 East 68th St., NYC 10021

I SPENT a night in jail. I was handcuffed, fingerprinted, had my mug shot taken and locked in a cell in the basement of the Lower Manhattan jail known as the Tombs for more than 17 hours until I was brought before an arraigning judge and released. My crime?

To the Editor: Your March 11 editorial ''Rejecting the Levy Way,'' regarding illegal immigration, is totally out of touch with mainstream America -- and Suffolk County. Those seeking to control our borders and enforce our housing codes and labor laws are called xenophobic.

Mexico City has long been dismissed as either a pit stop on the way to a beach resort or a megalopolis too vast and chaotic to tackle. But in recent years, the D.F. (Distrito Federal), as locals refer to Mexico's capital, has been exerting a cultural influence to match its size. It offers world-class shopping, jalapeno-hot night life and increasingly influential art and design movements that combine avant-garde influences with the traditions of one of the oldest civilizations in the world. Armand Limnander

WHEN local taxes grow so burdensome that they drive away the young professionals that businesses need, a region loses competitiveness. That's a threat now facing Long Island. Long Island shares the problem of high taxes with many suburban counties throughout the country. But two stand apart: Fairfax and Loudoun Counties in northern Virginia have far lower property taxes and the differences are significant. Local governments spend 45 percent, or $1,722, more per capita on Long Island than in northern Virginia.

POLITICS is not the sort of rough-and-tumble contact sport in which the lion lies down with the lamb. But that is precisely what seems to be afoot in Trenton. On April 12, the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, is to join the state's attorney general, Stuart Rabner, in an appearance before the Assembly Budget Committee to talk about their joint efforts on homeland security and programs to attack gang violence in the state -- and obtaining federal assistance for both.

MURRAY CHASS examines the strengths and weaknesses of the American League. East PROJECTED FINISH 1. YANKEES 2. RED SOX 3. BLUE JAYS 4. ORIOLES 5. DEVIL RAYS The Toronto Blue Jays were the division's big spenders last year, and they were rewarded for their extravagance with a second-place finish that dumped the Boston Red Sox uncharacteristically into third. Stunned by their failure to make the playoffs, the Red Sox made sure that this time around they were the big spenders. And did they ever spend big.

To the Editor: Michael Gross's ''Chasing the Ultimate Waterfall'' (March 18) and the accompanying photos of Victoria Falls capture well the area's history and poetry. When my wife and I walked from the Zambia side across a footbridge to a verdant mesa island not as tall as the falls, we were thoroughly watered by the mist and saw, for the only time in our lives, a 360-degree rainbow. It wasn't just extra-ordinary, it was extraordinary. Would that some of its beauty fall upon the suffering citizens of Zimbabwe these days. George Ubogy Greenwich, Conn. To the Editor: As a Zambian, I was delighted to see Victoria Falls splashed across the front page of the Travel Section. Then I spied the dreaded ''d'' word: discovery. In 2007 can The New York Times still be using this word? It's quite ironic considering that the same article says ''Livingstone began hearing about Victoria Falls -- called Mosi-oa-Tunya, or 'the smoke that thunders,' by Africans.'' If the locals had a name for them then they existed before he saw them. Being the first European to see them is not the same as discovering them. Are things only valued if they are seen through Western eyes? If I had been the first Zambian to see Stonehenge would anyone believe I had discovered it? Sylvia Chilufya New York

IT is no surprise that Sunday has become the new Saturday, a day of errands and chores, of tidying up odds and ends of work or sitting at the desk for hours at a time, with maybe a little exercise and television thrown in. I am surprised, though, that this bothers me. Like many baby boomers, I have spent a great deal of energy cultivating an unsentimental and even antitraditional attitude. But I just can't seem to shake my fond memories of a quiet day in Queens, with few cars on the streets, everything except maybe a drugstore and a restaurant or two closed, and three generations of my family laughing over the remains of a Sunday dinner cooked by my grandmother. Though Sunday may no longer be a day of rest, Sunday dinner can often define the rest of the day. And for many families -- unable to bring everyone to the table during the rest of the week because of soccer practices and music lessons, after-school programs and long workdays -- it is the only time to gather as one.

An article last Sunday about the Box, a Moulin Rouge-infused club that opened on the Lower East Side last December, misstated the role of Cordell Lochin in the business. He is a full partner, not a minor partner. The article also misspelled the surname of another partner. He is Richard Kimmel, not Kimmell.

In foggy 1950s Dublin, a pathologist becomes an accidental detective; by John Banville, writing pseudonymously. RUMSFELD: His Rise, Fall, and Catastrophic Legacy, by Andrew Cockburn. (Scribner, $25.) The roots of Rumsfeld's disastrous tenure. THE BEAUTIFUL THINGS THAT HEAVEN BEARS, by Dinaw Mengestu. (Riverhead, $22.95.) A first novel about an Ethiopian exile in Washington, D.C., evokes loss, hope, memory and the solace of friendship. TALES FROM THE TORRID ZONE, by Alexander Frater. (Knopf, $25.95.) Travels from Zanzibar to the Galápagos to Vietnam. THE BURIED BOOK: The Loss and Rediscovery of the Great Epic of Gilgamesh, by David Damrosch. (Holt, $26.) A history of a work written in ancient Mesopotamia and rediscovered by British scholars in the 19th century. INHERITANCE, by Natalie Danford. (St. Martin's, $23.95.) In this first novel, a young woman uncovers a family secret from Fascist Italy. LONELY AVENUE: The Unlikely Life and Times of Doc Pomus, by Alex Halberstadt. (Da Capo, $26.) This songwriter cracked rock 'n' roll's code in the early 1960s. LOST CITY RADIO, by Daniel Alarcón. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) A first novel set in a South American country 10 years after a dirty civil war. WINTERTON BLUE, by Trezza Azzopardi. (Grove, $24.) An unhappy young woman meets an even unhappier drifter. LENI: The Life and Work of Leni Riefenstahl, by Steven Bach. (Knopf, $30.) How Hitler's favorite director made ''Triumph of the Will'' and convinced posterity that she didn't know what the Nazis were up to. LENI RIEFENSTAHL: A Life, by Jürgen Trimborn. Translated by Edna McCown. (Faber & Faber, $30.) This biography is especially good on Riefenstahl's long later years, when she moved to Africa and outlived her enemies. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Fashion stylists have one of the most fungible, hard-to-define jobs on the planet. One day they'll be fussing over fabrics with a designer, or casting models for a show; the next, they're consulting with a celebrity about what to wear to a movie premiere or flying to Dubai with trunks overflowing with runway looks for a photo shoot. Take David Bradshaw, who is currently the editor of GQ Style, the glossy biannual offshoot of British GQ. During the past two decades, he has collaborated on videos for Michael Jackson, Madonna and Janet Jackson; steered the fashion content of Arena and Arena Homme Plus magazines; helped articulate the image of labels like Katharine Hamnett, Jil Sander and Calvin Klein; and worked as Miuccia Prada's right-hand man in men's wear. He is also, at least judging by the photos on these pages, not an ungainly model.

INTERNATIONAL 3-16 A Growing Divide on Climate According to a report by a United Nations body that analyzes global warming, the world's richest countries are spending billions of dollars to limit their own risks posed by climate change, but just tens of millions of dollars to limit climate hazards in the world's most vulnerable regions. 1 Signs of Hamas Buildup Senior Israeli officials say that Hamas, the dominant faction in the Palestinian government, is building its military capacity in the Gaza Strip. 1 Britain Takes Conciliatory Tone After more than a week of mounting confrontation over its 15 sailors and marines held in Iran, Britain sounded a more conciliatory tone, saying it had responded to a diplomatic message from Tehran and was ready to ''peacefully resolve this issue.'' 10 Death Toll Climbs in Bombing The Iraqi government gave its first official reckoning of the truck bombing Tuesday in the northern city of Tal Afar, putting the death toll at 152 people, a number about double early reports. 10 A 'Green' Palm Sunday ''Eco-palms'' are the rage in churches across the United States because of the social and environmental benefits they represent: they are collected in a way that helps preserve the forests in Mexico and Guatemala where they are harvested, and more of the sale price ends up in the pockets of the people who cut them. 3 Japan Rewrites History In another sign that Japan is pressing ahead in revising its history of World War II, new Japanese high school textbooks will no longer acknowledge that the Imperial Army forced mass suicides among civilians in Okinawa, the government announced. 14 NATIONAL 18-26 Ex-Adviser Critical of Bush President Bush's chief 2004 campaign strategist, Matthew Dowd, now says that his faith in Mr. Bush was misplaced. In speaking out, Mr. Dowd became the first member of Mr. Bush's inner circle to break so publicly with him. 1 Giuliani Speaks Out on Kerik Buffeted once again by bad news about Bernard B. Kerik, his disgraced former police commissioner, Rudolph W. FEDERBUSH--Herbert, 91, of 5581 Glen Abby Ct., Delray Beach, FL. March 30, 2007. Beloved husband of Norma, devoted father of Judy and David, brother of Harold. His benevolence and irrepressible sense of humor will be missed by family, friends, and all who knew him. Graduate of NYU, Levittown Eagle Columnist, Vice President for advertising and sales promotion for many years at Executone, Inc. of NYC. Moved to FL in 1992, occasional newspaper feature writer. Services at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 11115 Jog Rd., Boynton Beach, FL, 561732-3000 on Monday, April 2.

The METROPOLITAN OPERA will celebrate its 40th anniversary at Lincoln Center with ANNA NETREBKO and ROLANDO VILLAZÓN, the so-called love couple (at least onstage), who will appear in a gala of fully staged acts from ''La Bohème,'' ''Manon'' and ''L'Elisir d'Amore,'' along with the veteran bass Samuel Ramey and the rising baritone Mariusz Kwiecien. And there are still tickets available, from $250 to $1,250. Tuesday at 7 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org. Across the plaza City Opera is preparing a treat: a reprise of its 2003 production of Handel's ''FLAVIO'' by Chas Rader-Shieber. It's a bright, antic production that brings a delightful touch of zaniness to an opera that is by turns madcap and sober. It is also the company debut of Gerald Thompson, a countertenor who has been garnering rave reviews and who will go over to the Met at month's end to make his debut there in ''Giulio Cesare.'' Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Friday at 8 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $125. Hugo Wolf's songs are often found in small dollops on recital programs, but there are not many chances to hear his ''Spanisches Liederbuch'' in its entirety. To conclude the Austrian Cultural Forum's ''WOLFIADE,'' a three-part concert series with the baritone Wolfgang Holzmair, Susanna Phillips (a soprano) and Hermine Haselböck (a mezzo) will join the bill for a free concert at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday. This one should be well worth hearing. Mr. Holzmair has also led six selected singers through a set of master classes focused on Wolf; the results can be heard in a recital on Wednesday at the Austrian Cultural Forum itself. Master class, Wednesday at 8 p.m., Austrian Cultural Forum, 11 East 52nd Street, Manhattan; recital, Thursday at 8 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall. Free, but reservations are required: (212) 319-5300, acfny.org. Finally, one of the week's most interesting and wacky recitals takes place on Sunday night at Zankel Hall, where Pierre-Laurent Aimard, the ever more respected pianist, conducts a personal tour of the history of his instrument in a dazzling array of short pieces by 29 composers, from Scarlatti and Bach through Carter and Kurtag. Don't miss it. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $40 to $48.

After a decade of abuse from the weather and damage from the sun, more than 11,000 of the 12,000 signs bearing road names over intersections are being replaced by the State Department of Transportation. The project, to cost $6 million, is expected to be completed by Memorial Day.

The Mets ended spring training Saturday by setting an unwanted franchise record, losing for the 21st time this spring, 8-3, to Tampa Bay in St. Petersburg, Fla. Mike Pelfrey, the Mets' fifth starter, allowed 8 runs -- as many as he had all spring -- and 10 hits in four innings. Pelfrey returned to Port St. Lucie, Fla., where he will make one minor league start before the Mets recall him to pitch April 13 against the Washington Nationals.

BAZER--Jack on March 30, 2007. Professor of mathematics, Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, NYU. Loving husband of Carolyn, father of David and Laura, teacher and friend. Service Sunday 10am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

An article last Sunday in T: Travel, about hat making in Montappone, Italy, misspelled the name of a museum there. It is Museo del Cappello (Museum of the Hat), not Capello (Hair). Also, the headline rendered incorrectly the plural of hat. It is cappelli -- not capelli, which is the plural of hair.

Here is a smattering of things I did during the six-year quest to conceive my daughter: interrupt love-making to squirt raw egg whites into myself with a turkey baster (it's reputed to abet the feminine fluid that speeds sperm to egg); substitute two teaspoons of Robitussin for my morning coffee (its main ingredient thins and loosens mucous in the lungs, and although there is no actual proof, it's thought to work similar juju farther south); down ovulation-stimulating pills that triggered fits of rage; inject myself with the urine of postmenopausal Italian nuns (the original source of some fertility drugs, though it's hard to imagine how the goods are gathered); chug unidentifiable herbal potions that tasted like garden mulch; squander what would have been the college fund on long-shot in-vitro-fertilization treatments; imperil my marriage.

Kudos to Jeffrey Rosen (March 11) for reminding us that a form of phrenology is alive and well in the 21st century. Apparently there are some who posit that because a particular brain center for thought or emotion does or does not light up, we can draw a definitive conclusion about behavior. Let's get away from looking for easy answers and bumps on (or inside) the head to explain why we act as we do. The world, and we, are much more complex than that.

To the Editor: While environmental preservation in the Hudson Valley is an admirable goal we all support, I disagree with your March 18 editorial ''Nickels and Farms,'' advocating expansion of the bottle law and confiscation of unredeemed deposits.

PEAKE--Ann Journeay, beloved wife of the late David Wainwright Peake, mother of three children and a doting grandmother to seven grandchildren, died March 13, 2007. She was 81 years old and resided in Houston and Hunt, Texas. Born March 28, 1925 in Liverpool, England, she was the daughter of Hildegarde Storey and George Baldwin Journeay. Her father was an independent cotton broker, then based in Liverpool. She graduated from Chatham Hall in 1943 and Smith College in 1947. She married David Peake in 1948 and moved to Houston in 1950. She was a ''Proud Texan,'' in her words, with distinguished Texas ancestors dating back to the earliest days of the Republic. She counted among her ancestors a Texas Ranger, Civil War military leaders, judges, a lieutenant governor of Texas, a chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, and perhaps the best-known, her paternal great-grandfather, Henry Journeay, a survivor of the ill-fated Mier Expedition that in 1842 went to Mexico in retaliation for the Mexican raid on San Antonio. The Texans were defeated by Santa Anna and subjected them to a unique and brutal retribution commemorated in a Frederic Remington painting. A jar was filled with beans, every tenth bean being black, while the others were white. The ones who drew a black bean were immediately shot. Henry dug deep, pulled out a white bean and was spared. She is survived by her daughter Robin Peake Stuart and husband, Sandy of Lake Forest, Illinois, her son David Wainwright Peake, Jr. and wife, Katherine of Fredericksburg, Texas, her daughter Susan Storey Peake of Sea Island, Georgia and seven grandchildren, who were her true joy. Her love of family and friends and her wonderful sense of humor will be sorely missed by all. If desired, please make contributions to Chatham Hall, Chatham, Virginia, 24531.

JULIUS SHULMAN Born in 1910, Julius Shulman can honestly say that he has seen it all when it comes to 20th-century design. The architecture photographer, who reminisces in this issue about Arne Jacobsen's famous Egg chair (''The Egg and I,'' Page 162), is at work on a three-volume addendum to his 2000 book ''Modernism Rediscovered'' (Taschen), which he will promote with a tour around the world. Shulman shot to fame 60 years ago, photographing the work of mid-century architectural giants like Richard Neutra and Pierre Koenig (center), but he remembers Jacobsen with particular fondness. ''He was special because despite his great talent, he never promoted himself or openly sought attention,'' Shulman says. ''That makes him a true icon.''
This just in: space-age seating. no joke.
To the Editor: Re ''Unfurling the Hidden Work of a Lifetime'' by Steven Henry Madoff [March 18]:

IT is no surprise that Sunday has become the new Saturday, a day of errands and chores, of tidying up odds and ends of work or sitting at the desk for hours at a time, with maybe a little exercise and television thrown in. I am surprised, though, that this bothers me. Like many baby boomers, I have spent a great deal of energy cultivating an unsentimental and even antitraditional attitude. But I just can't seem to shake my fond memories of a quiet day in Queens, with few cars on the streets, everything except maybe a drugstore and a restaurant or two closed, and three generations of my family laughing over the remains of a Sunday dinner cooked by my grandmother. Though Sunday may no longer be a day of rest, Sunday dinner can often define the rest of the day. And for many families -- unable to bring everyone to the table during the rest of the week because of soccer practices and music lessons, after-school programs and long workdays -- it is the only time to gather as one.

KIRKNER--Curtis Bane, 76, died March 28, 2007. Curtis was born on Friday the 13th, 1930, an omen he laughingly felt was significant. He grew up in Salisbury, NC and graduated from Catawba College in 1953. He was an English major who immersed himself in the written word and particularly loved poetry. He touched many lives with his kindness and empathy. His life became a battle with mother nature 30 years ago and he fought valiantly and with great inner strength for many years accepting pain and limitation for the gift of life. He never tired of life and found quality in an evershrinking existence. He is survived by a wife who thanks him for taking her on an incredible journey and many family and friends who have marveled at his fortitude. The world is not better off without him but he is better off without the burden of his body. His memorial service will be in your heart and if you wish to remember your favorite charity in his honor. Lee Funeral Home & Crematory of Little River/North Myrtle Beach is serving the family.

Just as the little green buds emerge in the spring, so do the AUDUBONS at the NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, which has the world's largest collection of that artist's work. For the third year now the society is making a rite of displaying a selection of 40 fragile watercolors from the 435 that Audubon used for his masterwork volumes, ''The Birds of America.'' The newest batch, which went on view Friday, have been taken from protective storage, where they are kept away from light for years at a time. Alongside the watercolors, the society will also display documents and other historical materials. (Previous exhibitions have included stuffed birds and even Audubon's muzzle-loading shotgun, which he used to ensure that many of his elusive subjects stayed quite still while he was painting them.) The museum's Web site, nyhistory.org, offers a helpful list of birds that migrate through the New York area, including the red-tailed hawk, the great egret and even the turkey vulture, circling high over Manhattan in search of a free lunch. Through May 20, 170 Central Park West, (212) 873-3400. The historical society will also dig into its vaults to pull out portraits, landscapes, drawings and prints from its huge collections of work by Asher B. Durand, the Hudson River School master, to complement a major Durand show opening Friday at the Brooklyn Museum. ''The World of Asher B. Durand: The Artist in Antebellum New York,'' April 13 through Sept. 30. With landscapes in mind the work of a radically different sort of landscape artist are going on display Saturday in Manhattan, at two locations of the Gagosian Gallery. Works from the mid-1980s by WALTER DE MARIA -- probably best known for ''Lightning Field,'' his solemn grid of steel poles arranged on a remote New Mexico mesquite prairie -- are on display through May 5. ''A Computer Which Will Solve Every Problem in the World/3-12 Polygon,'' a stark, rhythmic floor arrangement of 75 polygonal bars, is at 522 West 21st Street, and ''13, 14, 15 Meter Rows,'' a similar meditation on matter and mathematical progression, is at 555 West 24th Street. The work of Mr. De Maria, who has spoken of the ''strangeness of the meaning of geometry,'' brings to mind natural mysticism in the mold of Pythagoras and numerology. But he cautions against easy interpretation: ''Every good work should have at least 10 meanings.''

It appears that Daniel Sadek, a real estate investor turned movie producer, got a rude surprise in the wake of filming ''Redline,'' about a daredevil driver caught up in a mob-run racing organization. In the $26 million movie from Chicago Pictures, one of Mr. Sadek's own luxury cars, a $200,000 Porsche Carrera GT, was totaled. He agreed to that car's being destroyed in the name of art. But then one of the film's stars, Eddie Griffin, smashed another of Mr. Sadek's cars -- a rare Ferrari Enzo, said to be worth $1.5 million -- while practicing last week at a track for a charity race to promote the movie.

STREAKS Albert Pujols of the Cardinals has four straight 40-homer seasons. Adam Dunn of the Reds and David Ortiz of the Red Sox have three straight 40-homer seasons. Miguel Tejada of the Orioles has played in 1,080 consecutive games, seventh most in history. If he plays in all 162 games this season, he'll finish at 1,242, which would move him up to fourth behind Cal Ripken Jr. (2,632), Lou Gehrig (2,130) and Everett Scott (1,307). Four pitchers have at least 15 victories each of the past three seasons: Roy Oswalt (Astros), Chris Carpenter (Cardinals), Randy Johnson (Diamondbacks) and Johan Santana (Twins). To the Editor: Richard B. Woodward's ''Paris; Making a Pilgrimage to Cathedrals of Commerce'' (Cultured Traveler, March 11) left out the most interesting bit of all. The panorama, circa 1800, was a device for exhibiting a huge painting, stretched across a stage between two posts. Viewers paid a small admission for the privilege of seeing the painting unfurled. The panorama was patented in France by an American artist and inventor living in Paris named Robert Fulton (known primarily for inventing the steamboat). The first painting exhibited on this particular panorama was ''The Burning of Moscow,'' painted by Mr. Fulton himself. Brayton Harris Mission Hills, Kan.

An article last Sunday about the ways in which presidential candidates deal publicly with illness referred incorrectly to the death of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who had lymphoma cancer. He died on Jan. 18, 1997, two days short of what would have been the end of his first term had he been elected president in 1992 -- not one day short. (The error first appeared on Oct. 3, 2004, in an article about the health of Senator John Kerry.)
Outdoor stools that multitask.

THE three exhibitions on the master builder Robert Moses -- at the Museum of the City of New York, the Queens Museum of Art and Columbia University -- that are on view in New York City have neglected the mass transit issue almost as seriously as Moses did. Perhaps Moses was doing what everyone else was doing, or perhaps he was leading the others. But it does a disservice to the region to ignore this piece of the Moses story, which deserves retelling.

When RAINER WERNER FASSBINDER died of a drug overdose in 1982, he had just turned 37 -- which still seems astonishing a quarter-century later. Part of the shock is the thought of what he might have gone on to accomplish as he matured alongside his baby-boomer colleagues in West Germany and beyond. His generational cohort included Steven Spielberg and Martin Scorsese as well as Werner Herzog and Wim Wenders; if any of their careers had ended when Fassbinder's did, the loss to cinema would have been grievous indeed. Even more stunning, though, is just how much he accomplished in so short a time. When it came to writing and directing, he was prolific, even compulsive, as if he knew his time was short. And perhaps for this reason his work has an urgency that has hardly diminished over time. His exhumations of German history -- a politically charged project in the 1960s and '70s -- have a ferocity rarely seen in costume drama, and his inquiries into sex and power are capable of delivering a jolt of discomfort even to jaded eyes that think they've seen it all before. An excellent and eclectic sampling of his films will be presented at the Museum of Modern Art starting Monday. Among the highlights are ''Lili Marleen'' and ''Veronika Voss,'' but the program, called ''Fassbinder in the Collection,'' represents the full range of his films. It also offers audiences a chance to rediscover the enigmatic, occasionally frightening charms of Hanna Schygulla, the great German actress who was Fassbinder's muse, alter ego and fetish object. (212) 708-9400, moma.org.
To the Editor: Re ''The Art's Here. Where's the Crowd?'' by Edward Wyatt [March 25]:

MY 7-year-old son, Ben, appears to have found his first, true, best friend. I can hear them one room over -- they sound as if they could hang out all day, deeply talking. ''Do you like the smell of wine?'' Joshua asks my son. Oh great, I think, soon they'll be going out drinking. ''Did you know Listerine can make bombs?'' he adds. I listen more closely. Later on they're playing ''restaurant management,'' and our kitchen counter is littered with pantry stock. I have the role of fussy patron, and as much as I'm trying to stay in character, I keep fast-forwarding to the final scene of me as busboy.

With the resignation last week of Ken Manning from the Port Chester Board of Trustees, there will be two vacancies on the board when Dennis Pilla, a trustee who was elected mayor, moves into his new position this week. Mr. Manning, 52, who recently became president of the Port Chester-Rye Brook-Rye Town Chamber of Commerce, said he had decided to resign about three months ago, before a federal judge's ruling that halted March 20 trustee elections.

ONE month before Zach O'Connor, a seventh grader at Brown Middle School here, came out about being gay, he was in such turmoil that he stood up in homeroom and, in a voice everyone could hear, asked a girl out on a date. It was Valentine's Day 2003, and Zach was 13. ''I was doing this to survive,'' he says. ''This is what other guys were doing, getting girlfriends. I should get one, too.''

Just in time for spring break, JetBlue Airways began service to Florida from Westchester County Airport last week, and by the end of the week the airline will offer four departures and arrivals a day serving Fort Lauderdale, West Palm Beach and Orlando. The only hitch for those heading south is that they should plan on getting a ride to the airport, because parking is limited. Last week, before JetBlue started its Florida runs, the parking lots were nearly full.

The two bonded over a cheeseburger lunch last fall in Omaha: the éminence grise of investing, Warren E. Buffett, and the Cleveland Cavaliers all-star forward LeBron James. And last Sunday there was Mr. Buffett in Cleveland, wearing a sparkly T-shirt and attending his first N.B.A. game in years. A few years and some billions separate the two men -- Mr. Buffett is 76 and worth an estimated $52 billion, and Mr. James, 22, who signed a three-year, $60 million contract extension in July, has endorsement deals worth about $150 million.

A picture last Sunday with an article about ''The Event,'' an exhibition of photographs at the Jeu de Paume in Paris, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of the French aviator Hubert Latham was by L'llustration, not Société de Photographie.
HENNINGSEN--Victor W., Jr. The Yale Club of NYC mourns the death of Victor W. Henningsen, Jr., Club President from 1966-1968. Our sincerest condolences to his wife and surviving family members.

More than a third of Americans want Barry Bonds to break the career record for home runs and almost as many hope he fails, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll. Asked, ''Are you rooting for Barry Bonds to break Hank Aaron's record, or do you hope he will fall short?'' 35 percent said they hoped he surpassed Aaron's mark, while 30 percent said they wanted him to fall short. Nineteen percent said they did not care, and 16 percent said they did not know or had no answer.

President Bush continued his new courtship of Latin America on home turf on Saturday, meeting and dining with President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil at the presidential retreat at Camp David. In their second meeting in a month, Mr. Bush and Mr. da Silva talked about the stalled Doha round of trade negotiations and their newly signed deal to cooperate in the development and production of ethanol.

NATIONALS The rule of thumb for picking the National League East winner was postulated here a year ago: Do not pick against the Atlanta Braves as long as they are defending their title. They did not finish in first place last season, so feel free to look elsewhere for a winner this year.

THE math isn't pretty. As of February, there were an estimated 636,000 ''fugitive aliens'' in the United States -- foreigners who have ignored orders to leave the country. They may have entered illegally and been caught (about 60 percent of all fugitives), or they may have visited legally but then overstayed their visas or committed crimes.

Democrats easily won two political seats in Nassau County, formerly held by fellow party members, in special elections with light turnout on Tuesday. Michelle Schimel, of Great Neck, who is the North Hempstead town clerk, won the 16th State Assembly District seat that was vacated by Thomas P. DiNapoli when he became state comptroller. She defeated the Republican candidate, Ryan DeCicco of Port Washington, with 86 percent of the vote. Only 6.8 percent of registered voters turned out.

IT is no surprise that Sunday has become the new Saturday, a day of errands and chores, of tidying up odds and ends of work or sitting at the desk for hours at a time, with maybe a little exercise and television thrown in. I am surprised, though, that this bothers me. Like many baby boomers, I have spent a great deal of energy cultivating an unsentimental and even antitraditional attitude. But I just can't seem to shake my fond memories of a quiet day in Queens, with few cars on the streets, everything except maybe a drugstore and a restaurant or two closed, and three generations of my family laughing over the remains of a Sunday dinner cooked by my grandmother. Though Sunday may no longer be a day of rest, Sunday dinner can often define the rest of the day. And for many families -- unable to bring everyone to the table during the rest of the week because of soccer practices and music lessons, after-school programs and long workdays -- it is the only time to gather as one.
The stuff Spring design is made of.

Jay Leno Three bodyguards of the Iraqi deputy prime minister assisted a suicide bomber in last week's failed attempt to assassinate the deputy prime minister. That's when you know you're in trouble. When you have to hire bodyguards to protect you from your bodyguards. In Florida a boatful of 100 Haitians has washed ashore ... and in their luggage 200 Cubans.

Baccarat's latest designer collaboration represents a sea change for the 243-year-old company. At the trade show Maison et Objet in January, it unveiled a line of lighting and tableware by the Paris-based designer Arik Levy that is both intellectual and, in the case of the single-armed Fantome chandelier (above), frugal. In a quest to make the tony brand more accessible to those without high ceilings and higher budgets, Levy -- who's known for his scientific approach to design -- proposed chopping up the classic chandelier (figuratively, that is) and selling it by the piece. At $1,990, ''FantÃ$(4$)me can be used as a design element, 55 lined up in a room, or as a complete object,'' he explains. ''The one arm brings the rest of the chandelier with it, psychologically. It feels like all the other arms are flying behind it, like ghosts.'' Monica Khemsurov

To the Editor: David Kamp slyly skewers a trite commonplace in his review of Jonathan Lethem's new book (March 18) when he reassures us that ''it's not one of those 'meditation on' deals.'' Unfortunately he is in the minority. Just two pages later we learn that Nigel Hamilton's latest title is a ''meditation on the history of biography.'' Three pages after that, a prize-winning novel by Lionel Shriver is described as a ''meditation on maternal ambivalence.'' Maybe the Book Review has had enough meditations for a while? Bob Goldfarb Manhattan

For those wondering just what Dina Matos McGreevey was thinking as she gazed, wide-eyed and smiling, at her husband while he was informing the world that he was a gay American, fear not. The estranged wife of former Gov. James E. McGreevey has a book coming out in May promising to tell ''the truth behind the lies,'' and a tour to follow, including appearances on ''Good Morning America'' and Oprah Winfrey's TV show. Exactly what she will say on any of these programs is anyone's guess. In an e-mail message, a spokeswoman for Hyperion, the publisher for her book, said Ms. Matos McGreevey was scheduled to appear on May 1, to coincide with the book's release. (A spokeswoman for Ms. Winfrey said only that she was scheduled to appear in a coming show.) Ms. Matos McGreevey will then sit for a two-part interview on ''Good Morning America'' on May 2 and 3.
To the Editor: Re ''The Rush to Vaccinate,'' by Sigrid Fry-Revere (Op-Ed, March 25):

The sky over Fairfield County could grow noisier if a planned new route for planes landing at La Guardia Airport is approved by the Federal Aviation Administration. The new route would have planes coming from the north and west cross over lower Fairfield County and then fly along the coasts of Stamford and Greenwich. The F.A.A. announced its preference for the route on March 23.

An article last Sunday about the motives behind community service misstated the sentence that the actor Russell Crowe received for throwing a telephone at a hotel desk clerk. He pleaded guilty to third-degree assault and was released on the condition that he avoid an arrest during the next year. He was not required to perform community service. The article also referred imprecisely to the recent discovery of rat infestation in a Greenwich Village restaurant. The restaurant was a KFC/Taco Bell, not a Taco Bell. (The reference was to a ''Taco Bell-loving rat.'')

RUBENSTEIN--Estelle, nee Bauman, born March 4, 1912, died peacefully in her home, March 27, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Murray Rubenstein. She was a brilliant financial advisor, and loyal colleague and friend to many. She is survived by her daughters, Judith Schaffer and Alice Brent, grandchildren Stacey, Jessica, Ava, and Alex, and great-grandchildren Ella and Elsa. A long, full life, well lived, a peaceful death at home with family. Rest in peace, Estelle, we love you. Service will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Calvary Hospital Hospice at (718) 518-2465.

As one of the scientists featured in Richard Panek's article (March 11), I want to emphasize that our Supernova Cosmology Project team did not invent the idea alone of measuring the expansion of the universe using supernovae as distance indicators. This was a large community effort, beyond even the work of the two main rival teams (the other being the High-Z Supernova Search, led by Brian Schmidt). In fact, several generations of scientists and dedicated projects previously studied and classified the supernovae and honed them in their role as ''standard candles'' (the Calan/Tololo Supernova Survey deserves particular mention).
C. J. MAY is not happy. ''My boss and others want to know if Harvard is doing better than Yale, and they want to know why,'' moaned Mr. May, 44, a Yale graduate turned Yale employee.

Rarely is the hand or touch of the artist visible in photography, in which mechanical reproduction is the norm. But an exhibition at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn., suggests that this may be a thing of the past. ''The Photograph as Canvas'' is organized by Stephen Maine, a Hartford-born artist, curator and critic who has lived in Brooklyn for many years. It evolved from a 2005 article that Mr. Maine wrote for the magazine Art on Paper, surveying the increasing trend among artists to paint and draw on photographs. The exhibition consists of two dozen works by 10 American and international artists.

To the Editor: Re ''Aged, Frail and Denied Care by Their Insurers'' (''Golden Opportunities'' series, front page, March 26): Long-term care insurance can be a valuable tool for a family's long-term financial planning. It is important that consumers receive recommendations of policies based on their financial objectives. People should receive thorough disclosures and suitable products offered by properly trained and monitored sales professionals.

What's in a Name Most buyers of baseball gloves no longer look for a signature in the pocket unless they're children. Page 7. A Voice That Echoes When It's Used Derek Jeter, the Yankee captain since 2003, defends his restrained reaction to the fans who are unrestrained about Alex Rodriguez. Page 2. Around the Majors Murray Chass takes a look at what to expect in the divisions this season, with projected starting lineups. Pages 4-5.

BUTTERLY--John, 90, a retired NYC Fire Lieutenant, Hook and Ladder Company 105, died Monday, March 29th at his home in Brick, NJ. A veteran of WWII he served in the Eighth Air Force from 1942 -1945. He is survived by his wife of 67 years Marcella, five children, five grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Services Monday April 2nd at 11 am. Services by Johnson-McGinley Funeral Home. 732-681-4455
Prologue

An article last Sunday about the ways in which presidential candidates deal publicly with illness referred incorrectly to the death of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who had lymphoma cancer. He died on Jan. 18, 1997, two days short of what would have been the end of his first term had he been elected president in 1992 -- not one day short. (The error first appeared on Oct. 3, 2004, in an article about the health of Senator John Kerry.)

To the Editor: Re ''Is This the Answer to Drug Use?'' (March 25): As a parent of two children who graduated from Delaware Valley Regional High School and an expert in the field of student drug testing, I absolutely support random student drug testing as a deterrent to help solve the problem of teenage drug use. I have been a very active participant at the high school in a variety of capacities, mostly with the school marching band as a chaperone, and can tell you that every school in our state has an issue with student drug use; to deny it is ludicrous and being ignorant to what peer pressure can do to our children.

To the Editor: Re ''Study Finds Rise in Behavior Problems After Significant Time in Day Care'' (news article, March 26): American day care is suffering, and it shouldn't take a $200 million study to see that.

To the Editor: ''36 Hours; Nairobi, Kenya'' by Jeffrey Gettleman (March 18) brought back pleasant memories of the Giraffe Center and the Karen Blixen Museum. I would like to call attention to one must-see opportunity that is identified on the map that accompanied the article, but was not mentioned by Mr. Gettleman. Nairobi National Park, Kenya's oldest national park, was established in 1946. Nairobi is the only major city in the world that neighbors a major game protection park. It is eerie when we review our photos that show this park with wildlife in a natural setting and the city skyline in the distance. We also saw incredible birds. It is well worth spending a few of those 36 hours here. Sondra R. Markman Edison, N.J.

The Morristown City Council was taking only an advisory vote last Tuesday night, but it drew a crowd that spilled out into the lobby of town hall. The council voted 6 to 1 to support a plan by the mayor in which city police officers would be deputized and trained to serve as federal immigration agents.

Suffolk County has approved a long-term plan for mosquito control and wetlands management, overruling findings by its own Council on Environmental Quality that the plan would harm wetlands and threaten marine life and human health. The council, an advisory group that reviews the environmental impact of proposed county actions, had called in majority votes for changes that would strictly limit the use of the larvicide methoprene in salt-water tidal wetlands and require a clearer distinction between mosquito spraying for nuisance control and disease control.

To the Editor: ''Debate Rages on UConn Hospital Expansion'' (March 18) quotes Dr. Peter J. Deckers, the University of Connecticut's executive vice president for health affairs and dean of the School of Medicine, as saying, ''Health care is a business, and we have just as much right to be competitive as anyone else.''
ROTZ--Wanda Ten Pas. On March 24, 2007, at age 85 at Penn Yan Manor. Beloved wife of Nicholas Rotz (deceased).
KREISBERG--Tracy. Happy 32nd Birthday to a beautiful daughter. We love you and miss you always. Love, Mom & Michael

The question posed in Robin Marantz Henig's article ''Darwin's God'' (March 4) may be answered in Richard Panek's article. Rational organisms require explanations, yet science has been incapable of providing an explanation of how the physical universe came to exist. No wonder that man has found it necessary to believe in gods, a belief not much removed from accepting that something called ''dark matter'' (which can't be demonstrated either) comprises 96 percent of the universe.

ONE month before Zach O'Connor, a seventh grader at Brown Middle School here, came out about being gay, he was in such turmoil that he stood up in homeroom and, in a voice everyone could hear, asked a girl out on a date. It was Valentine's Day 2003, and Zach was 13. ''I was doing this to survive,'' he says. ''This is what other guys were doing, getting girlfriends. I should get one, too.''

To the Editor: I couldn't believe that any article would espouse driving 10 to 12 times across the Brooklyn Bridge for pure pleasure (''Her Ride to Nowhere,'' by Sarah Shey, New York Observed, March 25).

I SPENT a night in jail. I was handcuffed, fingerprinted, had my mug shot taken and locked in a holding cell in the basement of the Lower Manhattan jail known as the Tombs for more than 17 hours until I was brought before an arraigning judge and released. My crime?

To the Editor: Not all gay men who move to Hell's Kitchen are young and living in tiny tenement walk-ups. ''Under the Rainbow'' (March 25) neglects to mention luxury buildings like Worldwide Plaza, with apartments (and prices) to rival any in Chelsea. The fact is, several gay men don't ''settle'' for Hell's Kitchen. They choose to live here.

BRONSTEIN--Burke, 98, on March 22, 2007, in Tamarac, FL. He leaves his beloved family including his wife Sylvie; his daughters Judith and Phyllis Bronstein, and son-inlaw Robert Rossel; his grandchildren Sharon, Steven, Andrew, Irene, David, Keith, Robin, Geoffrey, Elise, and Jolie, and their spouses and partners; and twenty great-grandchildren.

GINSBURG--Dr. Henry David, died March 29, 2007 at the age of 66 in New York City of complications following an aortic dissection. He is survived by his brother Carl Ginsburg of Bad Soden, Germany, and his sister Deborah Ramsden of Woodstock, NY. Son of the late Benjamin and Cora Ginsburg, Henry was a graduate of Columbia University and the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London. A resident of London for many years, he was a curator of Thai and Cambodian collections at the British Library until his retirement. An esteemed scholar of Thai painting, Henry was also an accomplished musician. He leaves many loving friends on three continents. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to Amnesty International or to Doctors Without Borders.

Emily Jane Bahr, a daughter of Ilene Bahr and Dr. Gerald Bahr of New York, was married last evening to Jason Sloan Granet, the son of Andrea Granet and Stephen Granet of North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Robert Summers officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Mrs. Granet, 28, is the medical staff office administrator at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. She graduated magna cum laude from Bowdoin College and received a master's degree in public health from Columbia.

The lights of Connecticut's Gold Coast could be powered by chicken manure under a plan to reduce the state's dependence on polluting fossil fuels. Among 11 alternative energy projects recommended last week by the Connecticut Clean Energy Fund, a quasi-public ratepayer-financed program, is a steam-generation plant in Bozrah that would be powered by gasifying the 340 tons of manure produced daily by more than 4.5 million chickens at the nearby Kofkoff Egg Farms, along with 1,000 tons of waste wood that comes from the state.

Ten players who are setting the standard at their positions. LF MANNY RAMÍREZ Red Sox With 470 home runs, he is one of four players with a chance at his 500th homer this season. It would be the first time that more than two players reached the milestone in the same season. CF ANDRUW JONES Braves Has won nine straight Gold Glove awards. Ranks fifth among outfielders behind co-leaders Roberto Clemente and Willie Mays (12) and Ken Griffey Jr. and Al Kaline (10). RF, CF ICHIRO SUZUKI Mariners Will try for his seventh consecutive 200-hit season, which would tie him with Wade Boggs and put him one season from tying Willie Keeler, who holds the record. 3B ALEX RODRIGUEZ Yankees Tied with Jimmie Foxx as the only players to compile at least 35 home runs, 100 runs and 100 runs batted in in nine consecutive seasons (1998-2006). SS JOSÉ REYES Mets Needs 44 stolen bases to reach 200 for his career. Is only the second shortstop since 1974 with at least 60 stolen bases in a season. Had 64 steals last season and 60 in 2005. 2B CHASE UTLEY Phillies Led all second basemen last season in runs (128), hits (198), homers (31) and runs batted in (100). 1B ALBERT PUJOLS Cardinals Has six consecutive seasons with at least a .300 average, 30 home runs and 100 runs batted in. DH JIM THOME White Sox Will try for his 10th season with 100 or more runs batted in. Only four other active players have knocked in that many in 10 or more seasons. C IVÁN RODRÍGUEZ Tigers Is 146 hits away from 2,500. Of his 2,354 hits, 2,266 have come as a catcher. Is the only catcher since 1974 with at least 2,000 hits. P JOHAN SANTANA Twins Has won his last 16 decisions at home and has a 1.93 E.R.A. during the streak. Ray Kremer holds the record with 22 consecutive home victories from 1926-27. (Sources by MLB.com, Elias Sports Bureau, Stats LLC, baseballlibrary.com, The SABR Baseball List & Record Book)

''Moneyball'' was supposed to have taught baseball a lesson. A 2003 best seller by Michael Lewis, the book recounted how Billy Beane, the general manager of the low-budget Oakland Athletics, won a string of division titles by assembling a roster of inexpensive, unathletic players whose ability to get on base was being undervalued by the market. Although the book riled many baseball traditionalists, it was also considered a watershed, one that would force even the most intransigent franchises to rely on statistical analysis if they hoped to remain competitive.

LEVINE--Barry J. Myron and Barbara Nelkin and family mourn the loss of Mr. Levine, who passed away on March 21, 2007. He waged a gallant fight with cancer, but he was taken much too soon, at the age of 61. For many years he was attorney for the Garden City Hotel and our family attorney as well, and his loyalty and devotion to us and to our business endeavors will never be matched. We were touched and gratified to see so many people in attendance at his funeral on Sunday, March 25. He will never be forgotten by his loving family and friends. All of us $(6$)LEVINE--Barry J. We at the Garden City Hotel note with sadness the death of Mr. Levine, on March 21, 2007. The hotels attorney for many years, he was much more than a co-worker; he was an inspiration and a true friend. No problem, professional or personal, was too minor for Mr. Levine to offer his advice and counsel. The funeral service on Sunday, March 25, was a fitting tribute to a man beloved by so many people, with over 300 friends and family members in attendance. He was always there for us, and we will miss him. The staff of the Garden City Hotel

To the Editor: I can appreciate why my colleague Peter Hoopes used this technology for our school production. The article notes the difficulty in locating players for such performances: ''try finding a harpist at a small boarding school.'' At St. Andrew's we do have a harp program. The main obstacles to including a harpist for ''Annie Get Your Gun'' was the small size of the pit and the difficulty of lowering the instrument through the stage floor. Frederick J. Geiersbach Middletown, Del. The writer is director of instrumental music at St. Andrew's School.

MY 7-year-old son, Ben, appears to have found his first, true, best friend. I can hear them one room over -- they sound as if they could hang out all day, deeply talking. ''Do you like the smell of wine?'' Joshua asks my son. Oh great, I think, soon they'll be going out drinking. ''Did you know Listerine can make bombs?'' he adds. I listen more closely. Later on they're playing ''restaurant management,'' and our kitchen counter is littered with pantry stock. I have the role of fussy patron, and as much as I'm trying to stay in character, I keep fast-forwarding to the final scene of me as busboy.

To the Editor: Re ''The Smithsonian Challenge'' (editorial, March 27), about the search for a new leader of this public institution: ''Public'' at the Smithsonian has meant free admission. But by not charging a fee, the Smithsonian is out of step with other countries' great national museums, like the Louvre. The Smithsonian museums cannot sustain their well-deserved reputation unless they are fully financed.

Preliminary results from the March 20 mayoral election in Sleepy Hollow put the Republican incumbent, Philip E. Zegarelli, ahead of his Democratic challenger, Thomas A. Capossela, by 29 votes. A recanvassing of the vote, sought last week by Democrats, confirmed Mr. Zegarelli's victory and widened his winning margin to 80 votes. The final count was 950 to 870. ''We absolutely feel vindicated,'' Mr. Zegarelli said. ''This was a fair vote and a fair count, and the people have spoken.''

A 14,000-square-foot mansion on five acres in Upper Brookville, auctioned off after being seized by the Internal Revenue Service, has sold for $8.3 million. On March 22, 42 bidders competed for the mansion, which has five bedrooms, six fireplaces, an indoor pool and spa, an elevator and two four-car garages. ''It was a packed house,'' said Tim Minoughan, vice president of the CWS Marketing Group, which conducted the auction. ''The bidding began at $4 million, and was over in 15 minutes. People showed up in Rolls-Royces and Lamborghinis.''

Andy England, 39, a jewelry seller from Portsmouth, England, near the remains of a capital city that was pillaged in 1565: ''I went with some friends through Goa for a three-week getaway, but we wanted to get a bit more of the cultural flavor of India, so we drove our small rental car inland to the modern city of Hampi and the ruins of Vijayanagar. We realized we should have been in a 4x4 when 22 kilometers of road that was meant to be a national highway just disappeared without warning. There is a spectacular train from Goa that we should have taken. When we finally got there, we were shown around this enormous rocky site with hundreds of temples. It's one of the most important Hindu pilgrimage sites in India. You got a real sense that it was once a cultural epicenter for that part of India. On another level, you're just blown away by the scenery and the integration of the archaeology with the geology. It was an epic journey.'' As told to Austin Considine

To the Editor: Re ''Theater's Alive With the Sound of Laptops'' by Jesse Green [March 25]:

KORNREICH--Morton A. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University notes with profound sorrow the passing of Morton Kornreich, respected member of the College's Society of Founders and beloved brother of our good friend and former Overseer, Matthew Kornreich. The Kornreich and Weinberg families have been leading supporters of medical research and education at Einstein for many years. To the entire family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, MD The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

What is modern, anyway? Is it classic 20th century (as in Modernism, with a capital ''M'') or contemporary (modern with a small ''m'')? The answer, of course, is both. And while you're at it, why not add something really old to the mix? Who wants to live in a period room, even if the period is the 1960s?

MY 7-year-old son, Ben, appears to have found his first, true, best friend. I can hear them one room over -- they sound as if they could hang out all day, deeply talking. ''Do you like the smell of wine?'' Joshua asks my son. Oh great, I think, soon they'll be going out drinking. ''Did you know Listerine can make bombs?'' he adds. I listen more closely. Later on they're playing ''restaurant management,'' and our kitchen counter is littered with pantry stock. I have the role of fussy patron, and as much as I'm trying to stay in character, I keep fast-forwarding to the final scene of me as busboy.

To the Editor: Your positive articles about Ethiopia, Kenya, Zambia and Zimbabwe didn't need to so ignore the plights of their people and the huge toll of H.I.V./AIDS. What about suggesting a sort of ''Robin Hood'' donation -- a small percentage of the amount it would cost a first-world traveler to visit Africa -- to local charitable organizations? In addition, direct purchases in grassroots markets and craft cooperatives are not only fun and provide wonderful gifts, but they also support large extended families in need. Augustus Nasmith, Jr. Rutland, Vt.

As a Kansas City Royal last season, Doug Mientkiewicz lobbied his manager to start on opening day against a left-handed pitcher. ''I rewarded him by going out there and striking out twice,'' Mientkiewicz said.

The narrator of the news segment on immigration intones, in the purest Lou Dobbsian tones, that the report will look ''at the human cost of Mexicans.'' The subject of the profile is one Raymond Boyle, a former senior vice president of Lucent Technologies who lost his $840,000-a-year job to a Mexican migrant worker, Alberto Fuentes, who was willing to work for a mere $600,000. Mr. Boyle, who has had to retrench, says, ''Unless you've been through it, you have no idea what it is like to live year-round in your second home.''
To the Editor: Re ''Ruffled Feathers'' (editorial, March 25):

CHAYKIN--Irving, born August 16, 1912 to David and Dora Chaykin, accomplished a great many things in his 94 years. Some of his proudest achievements include a tremendous career in Accountancy education at City College, his alma mater, where he was continually voted by the Student Body as most popular Instructor and later named Professor Emeritus. In addition to his private practice as a CPA and his college teaching, he founded the Chaykin CPA Review Course in 1950, which was acquired by the Washington Post in 1990. His training resulted in generations of Accountants who attribute part of their success to Mr. Chaykin. Among many other honors, he was awarded an Honorary Doctorate from Hofstra University, a conference room in his name at Baruch College and a Townsend Harris Medal for exemplary contribution in the field of Accounting Education. In addition to his professional contributions, Mr. Chaykin was an active synagogue President and Board Member, and a generous philanthropist, recognized time and again with his wife Clarice for their support of Jewish causes. Together, they were honored by Israel Bonds, Hadassah and the Jewish Theological Seminary, among many other organizations over the years. His deepest source of pride, however, was his family, and it is there that his legacy will live on most profoundly. Clarice, his wife of 61 years, his children Dan and Jackie, Maury and Susannah and Debbie and Harvey, as well as his grandchildren Carla, Alex, Molly, David, Zoe and Rose remember him, even in this time of loss and sadness, with great warmth, admiration and laughter. He is remembered lovingly by all whose path he crossed for his quick wit, his kind and gentle nature and a full life lived with integrity and generosity always.

FARLEY--James Parker, CT, died peacefully on March 29. Born in Newark, NJ on September 16, 1924, Jim leaves his beloved wife of 56 years, Irene, and their four children: James and wife Petra and children Devin, Colin and Carling of London; Catherine and son-in-law David Elkind and son Daniel of Greenwich, CT; Robert and daughter-inlaw Maribeth and children Katherine and Patrick of Wilton, CT; and Margaret of Westport, CT. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law Thomas R. and Nancy Farley of West Orange, NJ and his sister Maryrose Swift of Upper Montclair, NJ. He was educated at St. Peters Prep and Rutgers University (Class of 1949). He served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. His career started with General Electric Co. in 1949. He joined McCann-Erickson in New York in 1956 before moving to Tokyo in 1962 as part of the joint venture team that built McCannErickson-Hakuhodo, one of the earliest American-Japanese advertising partnerships. In 1964, he became President and CEO of the venture; in 1978 he became EVP McCann - Erickson Worldwide with responsibilities for the Pacific Region; returning to New York in 1980 until his retirement in 1984. Among his many retirement activities, Jim was an active supporter of Project Liberty Ship and its restoration of the John W. Brown on which he served during WWII. He was an active member of the New York Athletic Clubs Anglers and Huckleberry Indians groups, and a member of the Foreign Correspondent Club (Japan and Hong Kong), Young Presidents Organization, Zeta Phi, Tokyo American Club (past President), Patterson Club (Fairfield, CT), Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club, Metropolitan Club (NYC), and the National Maritime Historical Society. Memorial Mass, 11 am, April 14, Our Lady of Fatima Church, 229 Danbury Road, Wilton, CT. Burial and interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family request donations to the Grace C. Jones Nursing Scholarship Fund c/o the Norwalk Hospital Foundation, 24 Steven Street, Norwalk, CT 06856.
LICHTENSTEIN--Elsa T., 96, an extraordinary lady, left us on March 30, 2007. Memorial service Wednesday, April 4th, 2:00pm, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

It is not uncommon for executives to receive discounts on their companies' products -- or even freebies. But at American Standard there is a bit of mystery surrounding exactly what two executives received. In its proxy statement, the company disclosed that its chief executive, Frederic M. Poses, received a $7,800 tax gross-up to compensate him for the taxes he would have owed on free products. No description was provided of the products.

Emily Lorraine Fisher and Dennis Stephen Moore are to be married today at Jackson Square Park in New Orleans. The Rev. Dr. Jerry K. Schwehm, a Presbyterian minister, is to perform the ceremony. The bride, 32, is an occupational health nurse practitioner at Health Services, a clinic in South San Francisco, Calif. She received a degree in biology from the University of California, San Diego, and another in nursing from the University of Memphis. She received a master's degree in nursing from the University of California, San Francisco. She is a daughter of Cynthia Anne Fisher and Robert Harold Fisher of Pensacola, Fla. Her father, a former Navy pilot, retired as a pilot at Federal Express in Memphis.

KREIPKE--Sven A. Former President of Lummus, Sven A. Kreipke, 80, of Boca Raton, FL and Franklin Lakes, NJ passed away on March 30, 2007. Sven was the much beloved husband of Jytte, father of Per, Anette and Niels, father-in-law of Adrienne, Srdjan and Cheryl, and proud grandfather of six. Born in Taarbaek, Denmark, Sven came to the US in 1951 with an M.S. from the Technical University of Denmark as a plant engineer for E.I. du Pont, where he worked until joining Lummus in Newark, NJ, in 1957. While assigned to Lummus Spain, Sven met and married Jytte Engel-Andreasen. Sven held several senior management positions with Lummus in Europe and the US, and was appointed President of The Lummus Company in 1980, and eventually CEO of The Lummus Group. After his retirement in 1985, Sven continued his association with Lummus and its parent, ABB, as a Board member of ABB Lummus Global until 2003. Sven was notable for his honor and integrity: a man of convictions and great strength of character, he was a gentleman in all that he did, whether business or personal. His relationships with family, friends and colleagues were treasured by all who knew him, and he will be sorely missed. In celebration of Sven's life, a visitation and service will be held at Babione Funeral Home in Boca Raton on April 2nd from 3 to 6 (services at 5pm). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to United Cerebral Palsy (www.UCP.org).

Jessica Brand Liberman and Keith Todd Wilcox were married yesterday evening at the Montauk Yacht Club in Montauk, N.Y. Judge Debra Freeman of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated. The bride and bridegroom, both 35, met in prekindergarten at Hunter College Elementary School in Manhattan.

With eight closely bunched teams vying for the last four playoff slots in the N.H.L.'s Eastern Conference, an intriguing, even wacky finish could well be in store when the regular season draws to a close next weekend. But it would have to go a long way to be as bizarre and tension-filled as the denouement of the 1970 East Division playoff race.

THE long spring windup is over. Major League Baseball begins its 2007 season tonight, and for the league's 360 pitchers, the challenge not only will be to win, but to stay out of the doctor's office over the course of the 162-game regular season.

IT is no surprise that Sunday has become the new Saturday, a day of errands and chores, of tidying up odds and ends of work or sitting at the desk for hours at a time, with maybe a little exercise and television thrown in. I am surprised, though, that this bothers me. Like many baby boomers, I have spent a great deal of energy cultivating an unsentimental and even antitraditional attitude. But I just can't seem to shake my fond memories of a quiet day in Queens, with few cars on the streets, everything except maybe a drugstore and a restaurant or two closed, and three generations of my family laughing over the remains of a Sunday dinner cooked by my grandmother. Though Sunday may no longer be a day of rest, Sunday dinner can often define the rest of the day. And for many families -- unable to bring everyone to the table during the rest of the week because of soccer practices and music lessons, after-school programs and long workdays -- it is the only time to gather as one.

To the Editor: Re ''The D.C. Tea Party,'' by Bob Herbert (column, March 29): That yet another example of the hypocrisy of the Bush administration should be brought to light is hardly surprising. In fact, it seems as expected as the rising of the sun each day.
To the Sports Editor: ''Satellite TV Creates Sports Bar in the Sky'' (March 28) presents the increasing proliferation of television sets in public spaces as if it were a good thing. I beg to differ.

ONE month before Zach O'Connor, a seventh grader at Brown Middle School here, came out about being gay, he was in such turmoil that he stood up in homeroom and, in a voice everyone could hear, asked a girl out on a date. It was Valentine's Day 2003, and Zach was 13. ''I was doing this to survive,'' he says. ''This is what other guys were doing, getting girlfriends. I should get one, too.''

ZUCKERMAN--Matthew. We mourn the loss of a strong and gentle father, brother, grandfather and great-grandfather who served as a role model to his family. Beloved husband of the late Cookie and together with Ruth and Irwin Shapiro, Benefactors of the Hospital, Matt will be sorely missed. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

Back when it was one of the most overhyped new shows of the season, ''30 ROCK'' wasn't quite as good as people said it was. The strain of trying to be an alt-sitcom and still attract an audience was too apparent. But as the season went on, and Tina Fey grew more comfortable playing herself, and Alec Baldwin and Jane Krakowski were reliably funny as the preening network executive and the neurotic star, and Jack McBrayer made something brilliant out of the fey NBC page Kenneth, the show got better and better -- and the talk gradually subsided. Then it went away for a few weeks. It returns to the schedule on Thursday (NBC, 8:40 p.m.), and while the writers'-room high jinks are still dull, the plot involving Jack (Mr. Baldwin) using Kenneth as his Mata Hari in a battle with a gay network rival (Will Arnett) is the show at its giggly best. Andy Baldwin is a ruggedly handsome Navy lieutenant. He's a doctor (Duke undergrad; University of California, San Francisco, medical school). He's stationed in Honolulu. He's a triathlete. And to make it all just a teensy bit better, the award he won from an endurance-sports group wasn't for his athletic prowess; it was humanitarian of the year. But there's one less-than-perfect thing about this paragon: He's also a reality-TV star. Lieutenant Baldwin wields the roses in ''THE BACHELOR: OFFICER AND A GENTLEMAN,'' which begins Monday (ABC, 9:45 p.m.) with the traditional gathering of the 25 highly made-up bachelorettes, including the de rigueur drunken bachelorette falling down. Best pre-rose-ceremony moment: when one of the women sings the national anthem to the lieutenant. And damned if he doesn't tear up.

I was heartsick when I finished Sara Corbett's article (March 18). These women soldiers who served their country were treated with the utmost contempt by their own. Gen. Peter Pace, who is so worried about the effect of homosexual soldiers on the service, ought to look closely at what the heterosexual soldier is doing to his fellow soldiers. Officers using their rank to degrade, at the least, and rape, at the worst, bring all under suspicion. One hundred percent intolerance for such behavior is called for. Instead, the victim is afraid to ask for help. Always a supporter of women in the military, I now wonder if those who oppose them are right, that it is too dangerous, sadly not just on the battlefield but also in the barracks.

Martha Stewart's effort to trademark the name of her new hometown -- Katonah -- for her new furniture line has drawn the ire of some of her neighbors who fear that she wants the name all to herself. The Katonah Village Improvement Society has set aside $200 that could be used to fight her plan. It has until April 11 to file an objection with the United States Patent and Trademark Office. The society declined to comment on whether it would take action.

It was the first 3-pointer of the season for Duncan, a 7-footer from Wake Forest.

Aislinn Weidele and Jeffery F. Klier were married last evening at City Hall, a restaurant in New York. Judge Arlene Hahn of New York City Housing Court officiated. The bride, 38, is keeping her name. She is a graphic designer at Polshek Partnership Architects in New York. She graduated from the University of Maryland and received a Master of Fine Arts in sculpture from Queens College.

To the Sports Editor: In the early 1960s, I rooted against Roger Maris because I thought this would help my boyhood hero, Mickey Mantle. When Mantle was hurt down the stretch in '61 while chasing Babe Ruth's home run record, I prayed for Maris to get hurt. I'm sad now that I didn't revel in the greatness and synergy of the two men slugging their way through a remarkable Yankee season. I'm sad that I didn't root for the fine gentleman and great Yankee that Maris was.
