FOR Michael McDonough, vacation-scheduling takes care of itself. ''I block all of my vacation time each year on one day: When the Red Sox release their schedule in November,'' said Mr. McDonough, a 27-year-old public relations professional from Boston. ''Once the schedule comes out, it's straight to the calendar.''

Q. After a recent storm, a huge chunk of ice fell off the roof of a commercial building that is next to mine and overlooks my deck and skylight. The ice broke the skylight. My co-op lease says that the windows are my responsibility. The owners of the building next door say they are not responsible. Is that true? A. Steve Troup, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said a property owner in New York has an obligation to keep his building free from dangerous conditions, including a buildup of ice and snow, that he knows about or should know about. Mr. Troup said a number of factors would go into determining whether the owner knew or should have known about the ice and whether there was a reasonable opportunity to correct the problem.

Lawmakers in Albany have a bad habit of waiting until the chaotic closing days of the legislative session to focus on important legislation. One result is that useful measures that would benefit the citizens of New York often fall by the wayside. That, essentially, is what happened last year to a promising bill to crack down on sex and labor trafficking, offered by Assemblyman Jeffrey Dinowitz, a Democrat from the Bronx. The Assembly Codes Committee insisted on a much weaker version, and time ran out before there was a chance to undo the damage and hammer out a final bill with the Senate, which was promoting a weak version of its own.

MARCUS--Robert Allan, 72, died on March 17, 2007 in NYC. He was the son of James L. Marcus and the late Sophia Marcus, and the stepson of Helen Marcus. He is survived also by his brother and sister-in-law, Donald M. and Marianne T. Marcus, nieces Laura R. Marcus and Susan Marcus Mendoza (Jorge), and nephew James W. Marcus. He was a devoted friend to many, a doting uncle, and a brilliant man who had an unusually wide range of interests. He will be missed.

Saudis Assert Themselves The News -- King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia called the American occupation of Iraq illegal and warned that the United States would continue to dictate the region's politics unless Arab governments united. Behind the News -- His speech to the Arab League seemed to underscore growing differences between Saudi Arabia and the White House and suggested that the Saudis would not be beholden to the policies of the United States. But Saudi and other Arab officials suggested the king was positioning himself to get leverage in the Arab world and serve as a counterbalance to Iran. A Bloody Reprisal in Iraq The News -- One of the bloodiest episodes of Iraq's sectarian strife unfolded in Tal Afar, where gunmen, some of them apparently police officers, killed scores of Sunnis. Behind the News The revenge killings followed two suicide bombings in a Shiite area that killed 83 people and wounded many more. Witnesses said gunmen went house to house in a Sunni area, dragging people out to shoot them. As many as 70 may have been killed; bodies were carted to Mosul for identification, above. Some gunmen were identified by witnesses as police officers. The Iraqi Army intervened. Talking Again The News -- Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said she had persuaded Israeli and Palestinian leaders to hold talks twice a month. Behind the News -- The agreement followed three days of shuttle diplomacy by Ms. Rice. But the talks will deal only with day-to-day concerns such as movement by Palestinians and arms smuggling and not the big issues that have long bedeviled peace negotiations -- the status of Jerusalem, the borders of an eventual Palestinian state and whether Palestinian refugees would have a right to return to Israel. Into the Gulf The News -- The United States began a major military exercise in the Persian Gulf, dispatching two aircraft carriers and more than a dozen other ships there. Behind the News -- Bush administration officials said the calculated show of force was part of a broader strategy to contain Iranian power and to send a signal that even with its forces stretched thin by the Iraq war, the United States still has the means to project power in the region. It was the first time that two carriers conducted joint operations in the Persian Gulf since 2003, the year the United States invaded Iraq. Stalemate The News -- Britain froze all business ties with Iran as the dispute between the two countries escalated over Iran's seizure of 15 British sailors and marines in the Persian Gulf on March 23. Behind the News -- Iran claims the Britons had penetrated half a kilometer into its waters. Britain released navigational coordinates showing its sailors were nearly 2 miles inside Iraqi waters. Prime Minister Tony Blair warned the dispute would enter a ''different phase'' if the crew was not released; Iran called on Britain to admit fault.

In the library of bad jokes, there are plenty of responses to the immortal question ''How many actors does it take to screw in a light bulb?'' (My personal favorite: Five -- one to screw in the bulb and four to say, ''I could have done that better.'') The issue of just how many actors it takes to make a successful play has no comparably snappy answer. But New York audiences will have the chance this week to evaluate the relative merits of double- and single-digit ensembles with the opening of productions from creators famous for bringing bracing new perspectives to their genres: the South African playwright ATHOL FUGARD and the French composers ALAIN BOUBLIL and CLAUDE-MICHEL SCHÖNBERG. Mr. Boublil and Mr. Schönberg are the fellows who gave the world a strapping new breed of megamusical -- of epic sweep and steamroller score -- in the 1980s with ''Les Misérables'' and ''Miss Saigon.'' Two decades later they are hoping to re-establish themselves as the biggest and splashiest on the block with ''THE PIRATE QUEEN,'' a swaggering tale of love, rivalry and stage-sized boats in the 16th century, written in collaboration with Richard Maltby Jr. Frank Galati (''The Grapes of Wrath'') oversees a cast of 42 -- count 'em, 42. Hilton Theater, 213 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100; $51.25 to $111.25. Mr. Fugard has always worked on a canvas that seems diminutive by comparison. But his plays, among the first to deal with the moral consequences of apartheid, have consistently shown that big explosions can come in small packages. His greatest works, including ''Boseman and Lena,'' ''The Island'' and ''Blood Knot,'' have kept the dramatis personae to a potently bare minimum. His new two-character drama, ''EXITS AND ENTRANCES,'' inspired by his relationship with the South African actor Andre Huguenet, opens Wednesday. Stephen Sachs directs Morlan Higgins and William Dennis Hurley in the roles of actor and playwright. 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com; $60.

CLARKE--Thatcher, April 1, 1937-March 8, 2007, died in NYC where his career as a Ballet Dancer began: Broadway shows, original ''My Fair Lady'', movie ''Carousel'', Fonteyn/Nureyev World Tour, Ballet de Cuba, American Ballet, San Francisco Ballet, Thatcher's Theatre.

An article last Sunday in T: Travel, about the resurgence of Dallas, misidentified a street that is known for its mansions. It is Swiss Avenue, not Swift. The article also referred incorrectly to a retail, office and hotel complex designed by Philip Johnson. It is the Crescent, not the Crescent Court, which is a hotel.

The Day Out column last Sunday about coffee bars in Rio de Janeiro misspelled an option for preparing coffee. Adding a few drops of milk is called pingado, not pintado. The article also misstated the name of a coffee-growing region in Brazil. It is Sul de Minas -- not Sur de Minas, the name in Spanish.

Q. Do you know when and why the statues by J. Massey Rhind at the old Exchange Court building were taken down? Randall Gabrielan, Middletown, N.J. A. In 1898, the investor William Waldorf Astor built the Exchange Court office building at the southeast corner of Broadway and Exchange Place. The shell is still there, but it was rebuilt in 1981 and is no longer recognizable. Clinton & Russell, Astor's regular architects, designed a rich wedding cake of rusticated limestone, arranged in the shape of a C. The open court formed the entrance -- closed off at night by an elaborate bronze portcullis.

To the Editor: Re ''Will Diners Still Swallow This?'' (March 25), about the debate over portion sizes at restaurants: If chain restaurants really wanted to help consumers, they would stop trying to torpedo New York City's new requirement, effective this July, that certain chains list calories on their menus and menu boards. That disclosure will empower consumers and encourage restaurants to compete on the basis of nutrition.

KOKO TAYLOR, who comes to the B. B. King Blues Club on Friday, has always been a strong woman, the Chicago blues belter who treated the battle of the sexes like an all-out brawl. She has the classic blues pedigree: Born in 1935 near Memphis, she grew up working on a sharecropper's farm before heading for Chicago as a teenager and making her name in the blues. With her gutsy, leathery voice Ms. Taylor turned macho men's songs like ''Wang Dang Doodle'' into her own rough and ready testimonies, and she answered boasts like Muddy Waters's ''Mannish Boy'' with her own ''I'm a Woman,'' vowing, ''I'm an earthshaker.'' No one denied it. In 2003 Ms. Taylor had a medical crisis. After emergency surgery for gastrointestinal bleeding, she wound up unable to breathe, on a ventilator in intensive care. For some time it was uncertain whether she would sing again. But she pulled through, and her first new album since 2000, ''Old School'' (Alligator), tears into its blues with a vengeance. The album includes five new songs of her own -- more than she has written for any of her other albums -- and revives hardheaded lesser-known songs from Willie Dixon, Magic Sam, Memphis Minnie and others. ''You don't want to tangle with me,'' Ms. Taylor sings in ''You Ain't Worth a Good Woman.'' Through the years Ms. Taylor has sometimes simply blustered through songs. On ''Old School'' she's more nuanced and strategic, working her way up before unleashing a rasp. It's a lean, straightforward production -- guitar, piano, bass, drums and an occasional harmonica -- that deliberately looks back to the sound of 1950s and 1960s Chicago blues. Ms. Taylor sounds like she still knows exactly what she wants. Friday, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. 8 p.m.; $33 in advance, $38 Friday.

Cherished grandfather of Evan and Seth, and dear brother of Leonard. Funeral service Sunday, April 1, 1:30 pm at ''Temple Beth El'', 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY. To the Sports Editor: Re ''Williams Beats Sharapova, Again Leaving Little Doubt,'' March 28: Just because black athletes have a lot of money does not mean they (or their families) are always treated well or respected for their work as athletes. Rather, they are often stereotyped or targeted for their ''gaudy'' displays. Better reporting on Serena Williams's ''sense of alienation'' or discomfort might focus on racism within American society and the institution of sports itself. Or it might just discuss why she won. Jenny Irons Clinton, N.Y.
WHITNEY--George Quintard, artist and architect, July 1, 1938, to March 18, 2007. Remember him with a smile.

To the Editor: If I can't top them, at least I can add to ''Superfluous Hospitals'' (editorial, March 25). Capital Health System in Mercer County, serving mostly the capital city of Trenton, is also in poor financial health, according to Standard & Poor's, the credit rating firm. It wants to pull out of its major urban facility and relocate to the bucolic, sparsely populated Hopewell Township, bordering the Delaware River.

Goaltender Rick DiPietro missed his third consecutive game because of a concussion, and the flailing Islanders lost their third in a row, lamely falling to the Ottawa Senators, 5-2, Saturday night at Nassau Coliseum. Coach Ted Nolan said that the loss might have been just as bad if DiPietro, who is out indefinitely, was in goal instead of Wade Dubielewicz, who has spent most of the season with the Islanders' farm team in Bridgeport, Conn.

Oden began the second half with six points to raise his total to 17 and Ohio State managed to stay reasonably close to Florida.

Grant Thornton, the auditing firm, might have had the belated realization last week that auditing a subprime lender could almost be as risky as financing one. In any case, letters dated Tuesday, March 27 and disclosed today announced that the firm was resigning as auditor of Fremont General and Accredited Home Lenders, two troubled lenders.

Some rosters for the Florida Gators list the 6-foot-10 Al Horford as the center and the 6-11 Joakim Noah as a forward. Other rosters reverse the positions. Still others list both of these juniors as "center-forwards."

Flex, as in Funkmaster Flex, could describe the brand created by the man who began as a hip hop D.J. at Hot 97 in New York, before becoming a TV star, before applying his FMF logo to Lugz shoes and other products.

A Wall Street trade group put out combined profit statistics for the industry today, and they are impressive. The Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association says securities firms had combined pretax profits last year of $33.1 billion, up 88 percent from the prior year, and finally breaking the record they set in 2000 of $31.6 billion.

Needing relief from medieval churches and cutesy cafes on a trip to Prague a few years back (O.K., and a tax break), I paid a call on the Prague Stock Exchange, tucked in a blocky, Soviet-style building off the main drag. I climbed a few flights of poorly lit stairs and entered a dour, dusty-musty office. I didn't expect John Thain clapping with happy C.E.O.s at the opening bell, but heck, this place might as well have been a D.M.V. I started pining for stained-glass windows again. Nonetheless, I learned more in the next 20 minutes about how the world works than I had in the last 20 years sweating on Wall Street as an analyst and running a hedge fund.

For readers who want to help Shakira Parveen, the Pakistani woman in Tuesday's column who was pimped by her husband, the best route would be to send money through Mukhtar Mai and her aid organization. Mukhtar can pass on assistance and in any case is looking after people like Shakira.

In the age of the imperial chief executive, where a history of failure does not keep someone from getting another top job, some bosses think they should not be forced to actually live in the area where the company is located. They see no reason why their families should be uprooted.

For all the parsing of fund-raising numbers that has been going on over the past 24 hours - should Hillary Rodham Clinton have raised more than $26 million? How did Mitt Romney come from nowhere to raise more than $20 million? -- a first-quarter fund-raising report came out today that defied the effort of even the best political operative to spin it as anything but very bad news.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today that he intends to veto a City Council bill that would prohibit the use of metal bats in high school baseball games. The decision to veto the bill is the latest salvo in a long-running dispute that has divided youth baseball leagues, coaches, players and fans.Industry groups had hired lobbying and public relations firms to oppose the bill, while parents of players severely injured by balls hit off metal bats gave tearful testimony in support of it.

It was an announcement that could make one's head spin. The campaign of Senator John McCain, once considered the clear front runner for the 2008 Republican presidential nomination, said this afternoon that he had raised a disappointing $12.5 million in the first quarter.

Vneshtorgbank, Russia's second-biggest bank, could raise up to $6 billion when it makes its debut share offering with listings in Moscow and London next month. The state-owned bank plans to come to the market with an offering of 22 to 23 percent of its shares in May. Russia's Economic Development and Trade Minister, German Gref, has said the bank could raise between $3.5 billion and $4.6 billion, while the bank has indicated it wants to raise between $4 billion and $6 billion.
A timeline of the first hour of the Yankees season, beginning with Carl Pavano's first pitch (a ball) at 1:10 p.m. YDT (that's Yankee Daylight Time, according to the big clock on the scoreboard.)
We know Empire Zone readers have a lot of questions about metro news coverage in The Times. Now there's an opportunity to pose them directly to the metropolitan editor, Joe Sexton.
Moments after Cory Lidle's widow and son threw out the game's first pitches, the image of late Yankee pitcher came walking out from the dugout and into the tunnel by the team's locker room.
Is America really divided along cultural lines?

The ouster of Steven Heyer as chief executive of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide came as a surprise to analysts, who said that the company's strategy was sound. Of course, the news also prompted many to consider whether Starwood was a viable buyout candidate.

When the doors of the elevator lobby open on the Loge level of Yankee Stadium, the first thing you see is a giant photo of Bernie Williams holding the 2000 World Series trophy at Shea Stadium. In the corner of the photo, holding a microphone and beaming as widely as Williams, is Bobby Murcer.

The Midwest Air Group's board asked shareholders on Monday to hold off on responding to AirTran Holdings' revised bid for the airline. In a statement, the board said it would review the new offer of $15 ashare in cash and stock, and would make a recommendation to shareholders by April 13.

Does Kohlberg Kravis Roberts' planned $29 billion acquisition of First Data, one of the biggest credit-card payment processors, signal a field ripe for dealmaking? Adam Frisch, an analyst with UBS, on Monday suggested some other payment-processors that might also be good candidates for a leveraged buyout. Among them were Global Payments and Ceridian.

At least three potential candidates for mayor in 2009 -- the Bronx Borough President, Adolfo Carrión Jr., City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Representative Anthony D. Weiner -- are participating in a conference today on "The American Dream in the Big Apple: Is New York City Still a Middle-Class Town?"

Former Governor Mitt Romney of Massachusetts and former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York announced this morning that they had raised eye-popping sums in the first quarter of the Republican presidential primary race -- more than $20 million for Mr. Romney and $15 million for Mr. Giuliani.

And now, another exciting installment from the world of tech support--in this case, Dell's (surprise!). It was sent to me by reader Jack E., and its subtitle could well be, "When Tech Support is Outsourced--and Common Sense is Dead."
Real estate prices in London continue to be crazy. Is there no end in sight?
Another day, another 11-digit buyout deal.

Once a highflier in the booming market for making risky mortgage loans, New Century Financial tumbled to earth Monday as it filed for bankruptcy. In the largest bankruptcy to date in the subprime arena, New Century listed liabilities of more than $100 million in its Chapter 11 filing with the federal bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del.
About three hours before the scheduled first pitch today, Joe Torre took a phone call in his office: Bernie Williams was on the line.
With an emphatic and definitive victory over Ohio State, the Florida Gators left one final mark for their legacy as one of the great teams in college basketball.
DES MOINES - The field of Republican presidential hopefuls has just grown by one.
Joe Sexton, who oversees coverage of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, is answering reader questions this week.

With Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton setting the bar high -- raising a reported $26 million in the first quarter of the 2008 race, her campaign and those of other senators hit the road this week while they are untethered to Congressional duties. (They're in recess.)

The Hotline's Marc Ambinder thinks Hillary Clinton's record-breaking $26 million haul for the first quarter of 2007 isn't as impressive as it seems at first glance. "So - a good number? Yes, but really, not so much," Ambinder writes at Hotline's On Call blog. He explains:

ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering. Backed by the venture firm Accel Partners, which owns a 27 percent stake, comScore said it plans to use the proceeds for working capital, capital expenditures and possibly for acquisitions. ComScore, which competes with measurement firms such as NetRatings and Hitwise, reported $66.3 million in revenue in 2006. It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.

Sometimes things just swirl into clarity as if a camera lens is suddenly twisted into sharp focus. It was like that here at the Final Four yesterday when someone asked Joakim Noah of Florida about Bill Walton, who played for U.C.L.A. more than three decades ago.

The first time I walked into the dugout at Yankee Stadium in 2007 was a little past noon on Sunday. Before I could even sit down, a Yankees' employee asked me how I thought the Yankees would do this season.
Sam Zell won the bidding for the company that owns  The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune.

In researching a story I wrote for Play, the New York Times' quarterly sports magazine, I talked to a gaggle of statisticians whose primary goal - other than putting together expensive algorithms designed specifically to make us all feel stupid - was to figure out the proper way to fill out an NCAA Tournament pool sheet. Most of these men are not only not experts in the field of college basketball, they mostly don't know anything about the game at all. Their expertise is numbers, not hoops.

"[F]ree-traders have as much to fear from the Republicans who have been running the show in Washington" as they do from congressional Democrats, writes business journalist Daniel Gross on his personal blog. "Whether it was the Karl Rove-inspired steel tariffs of the first term, the persistence of absurd agricultural subsidies, or the general lack of interest in the ways in which the heightened insecurity surrounding jobs, incomes, and saps the support for free trade, or the general ability to convince foreign governments to see things our way, this administration hasn't done the cause of free trade a whole lot of good."

While Alison was searching for a new architect who wouldn't break her heart, I had a thought. What if we just sold our small piece of dirt, banked the money and reconsidered this whole building-the-dream-house thing, which was turning out to be harder than I expected.

Dubai Aerospace will buy Standard Aero Holdings and Piedmont/Hawthorne Holdings from the Carlyle Group for $1.8 billion, Standard Aero said on Monday in a regulatory filing. It said $1.034 billion of the total purchase price will be allocated to the purchase of Standard Aero.

Three-quarters of loans to junk-rated companies in the United States are now provided by hedge funds and other non-banks, according to a new report on the leveraged loan market. The Financial Times said that the study highlights the speed with which non-traditional investors are taking over from banks as lenders and changing the way loans are made and traded - a trend that has taken hold in Europe.

TXU said on Monday that it has not received a competing bid to the $32 billion takeover offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group, and its financial advisers do not expect it to receive one. The power company, which agreed in February to the buyout, said it had signed confidentiality agreements with nine groups as part of the 50 day "go-shop" agreement with its buyers allowing it to pursue alternative transactions.

Sam Zell, the flamboyant Chicago real estate tycoon, who has never run a newspaper, has won the battle of the billionaires for Tribune, which said it accepted his $8.2 billion takeover offer after he matched a bid from Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad.

Xerox said on Monday it would acquire the office technology products provider Global Imaging Systems for $1.5 billion to expand its reach in the small and mid-sized business markets. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., said the deal values Global Imaging at $29 a share, a premium of almost a 50 percent to its closing price Friday of $19.50. Global Imaging shares rose more than 46 percent in pre-market trade.

Showing a rare flash of humor, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued a press release on executive pay disclosure quoting spokeswoman "April Fuhrst" and economist "Anita Moore-Profit." In the release, the top market regulator in the United States sets out new rules on corproate pay and perks that Ms. Fuhrst said would "reveal a treasure trove of titillating information," The Financial Times reported.

The Carlyle Group is expected to announce on Monday the hiring of Coca-Cola's most senior executive in Asia to spearhead regional investments across consumer-related businesses. The recruitment of the executive, Patrick Siewert, Coca-Cola's chief operating officer for Asia-Pacific, is the second such hiring in recent weeks by the buyout firm and highlights the maturing of private equity in Asia.

Though Community Health Systems could soon boast of becoming the nation's largest publicly traded hospital chain when it closes its $5.1 billion offer for Triad Hospitals, TheStreet.com says that the company may soon regret it. To achieve that lofty post, the site's Melissa Davis writes, the efficiency-minded Community is buying a hospital chain known for making generous investments to lure patients in competitive markets.

Nicolas Sarkozy, the rightwing candidate in the French presidential race, joined the growing chorus of European voices criticizing hedge funds, the Financial Times reported Monday. Speaking at a television debate on Sunday, Mr. Sarkozy attacked what he called speculative capitalism, citing hedge funds in particular: "these aggressive funds ... that buy up a company, sell it off in pieces, sack 25 per cent of the staff in the meantime, collect 25 per cent profit and create zero wealth." He added: "I don't want a speculative capitalism. I want a capitalism that creates riches."

Since the wild success of the Fortress Investment Group's initial public offering, which has minted five new billionaires, Wall Street has been buzzing about who will be the next hedge fund to go public. According to Fortune, the latest crop of potential offerings could come from Avenue Capital, Perry Capital and the Citadel Investment Group, which has already staged a bond offering.

J.P. Morgan Chase, Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch are each in early talks with New York real-estate developers about building new trading floors in Manhattan, Bloomberg News reported, citing undisclosed sources. J.P. Morgan's talks, with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, related to plans for a building in downtown Manhattan that mighgt be as tall as 57 stories, Bloomberg said.

The board of Altadis is preparing to reject a revised bid from Imperial Tobacco, its British rival, that could come as early as this week, the Telegraph reported. Altadis, a Franco-Spanish tobacco group, is being courted by a number of private equity groups, a development that is thought to be behind the board's decision to reject Imperial's bid.

Barclays is planning to make cost cuts of more than 3 billion pounds in its proposed merger with ABN Amro, the Dutch bank. The move will likely lead to the loss of hundreds of jobs at ABN Amro's investment banking operations in London, the Telegraph reported.

Celesio, owner of Lloyd's Pharmacy, has emerged as a third potential bidder for Britain's Alliance Boots. Celesio would be in competition with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina, the deputy executive chairman of Alliance, who have already announced a $19.7 billion bid for Alliance, a chain of health and beauty stores.

As the Blackstone Group considers holding a $4 billion public offering, the private equity firm's unusual structure as a master limited partnership could leave room for the Internal Revenue Service to challenge its tax-law assumptions, some analysts and academics told Reuters.

An Australian credit checking company, Veda Advantage, has approved a buyout bid of 814 million ($656 million) Australian dollars from a private equity consortium of Pacific Equity Partners and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity, lifting its shares more than 7 percent. Allco Equity Partners, which has a 17.3 percent stake in Veda, has agreed to support the deal subject to a significant change in market conditions and in the absence of a superior offer, said Reuters.

Norbert Dentressangle of France is considering the acquisition of a British trucking company, Eddie Stobart, the Guardian reported. The French outfit intends to expand its British operations and has identified Eddie Stobart as a potential takeover target.

The London Stock Exchange has held talks with the Dubai International Financial Exchange about forging a strategic alliance and the possible acquisition of cross-shareholdings. According to the Guardian, sources who were not named confirmed that the London exchange is one of six parties who, according to Dubai officials, have expressed an interest in acquiring a stake in the exchange.

J.H. Whitney will withdraw its $2.7 billion offer for the nutritional and weight-loss supplement makerHerbalife, the group said Friday. Its offer was rejected and the group may sell the roughly 25 percent of Herbalife it currently owns or could even buy more shares.

In the first quarter of the year, initial public offerings have raised about $12 billion, 18 percent more than in the comparable period last year. The hedge fund manager Fortress Investment Group was the biggest first day earner with a pop of 67 percent at its opening and is the second-richest offering to open this year with a purse of $634 million.

NBC Universal and the hedge fund Citadel Investment Group have increased their takeover bid for Ion Media Networks in an attempt to appease a disgruntled investor group. That group, which includes AIG and Gradient Partners, were upset over the original bid, which they saw as short-changing preferred shareholders.

India's Tata Power announced this weekend that it is planning to take a 30 percent stake in coal mines owned by the Indonesian energy giant PT Bumi Resources for about $1.3 billion. Although Bumi failed to raise $3.2 billion through a share sale last year, there were at least six bidders vying for the coal companies this time around.

The Carlyle Group announced on Friday that it would invest $80 million for a 49 percent stake in China's Yangzhou Chengde Steel Tube Company. Yangzhou Chengde makes large-diameter seamless steel pipes and Carlyle's investment will help the company to expand its business both domestically and abroad. The investment comes from Carlyle Asia Partners II, a $1.8 billion fund that makes control and strategic minority investments in Asia outside Japan.

A new breed of wealthy investor is changing the way startups raise capital. Business Week took a look at a startup, Jaxtr, which makes software for routing calls from blogs to cell phones, and the unusual arrangement it made for its first round of financing.

The investment bank Jefferies said Monday that it had hired Ronald Openshaw to direct its European healthcare investment unit. Mr. Openshaw, who will be based in London, was previously chief financial officer at Asterand, a biotechnology company.
The countries that have produced most of the greenhouse gases in the atmosphere are also best equipped to deal with their effects.

Landmark Theatres has accquired the Ritz movie house chain in Philadelphia, marking an important step for the independent exhibitor. Landmark said Philadelphia was the only one of the top 10 American markets in which it was previously not present.

SKS Microfinance, a fast-growing Indian company that provides financing for entrepeneurs, has received an $11.5 million injection with Sequoia Capital putting up most of the funds. Sequoia, which has made such savvy previous investments as those in Google, Yahoo and YouTube, was joined in the round by Unitus Equity Fund, Vinod Khosla, Ravi Reddy, Odyssey Capital and prior investor Sidbi.

California-based Xponent Photonics raised $23 million in a series 3 round with American River Ventures leading the charge. American River Ventures put up a $5 million stake while Xponent's previous investors, including El Dorado Ventures, Arcturus Capital and the Samsung Group put up the rest. Xponent makes fast, small semiconductor chips using new optical technology.

AT&T said on Sunday that it was in negotiations to buy a major stake in Italy's largest telecommunications company, Telecom Italia. The proposal, which expires at the end of April, would give AT&T a one-third stake in Telecom Italia's holding company, Olimpia, but only if a Mexican wireless company America Movil buys an equal stake. AT&T, based in San Antonio, is an 8 percent owner of America Movil.

AirTran Holdings, the discount airline company, is planning to raise its hostile bid for the Midwest Air Group a third time, to $15 a share, people briefed on the offer said Sunday night. The company plans to announce the new bid Monday, these people said.

Data Domain, which makes data-storage appliances, filed to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering. The company's backers include venture firms Greylock Partners, New Enterprise Associates and Sutter Hill Ventures.

In its 16th-century heyday, Rochford Hall in Essex, England was a striking manor house with a medieval moat and a great hall. It was also the place where Henry VIII is said to have first laid eyes on Anne Boleyn. Boleyn's father purchased Rochford Hall in 1515, when she was about 14. Henry and Anne were married in 1533.

Google's acquisition of video-sharing site YouTube was driven by a culture of "nerd logic," which has slammed the company headfirst into the culture of New York's Big Media, Clive Thompson wrote in New York magazine. And, in a development that many had predicted, the deal has made Google the target of a major lawsuit from Viacom, which contends its copyrighted materials are being used without its permission.
The Fire Department, not normally part of the cast of the show “Room Service,” had a role to play in Saturday night’s performance.
Inside Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston, where Dr. Atul Gawande, a surgeon and writer, performs a thyroidectomy.
The story of the evangelist Aimee Semple McPherson feels like the career trajectory of practically everyone who has become even moderately famous in the last hundred years.
This new series is smarter than its lame title implies, thanks to the charm and intelligence of its host.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Jane Austen lived in an age when a woman's physical attractiveness was, next to her fortune, her greatest asset. Was she attractive or not? What if, to put it bluntly, she became a writer in part because she didn't have the looks to land a husband along the lines of a Mr. Darcy or a Mr. Knightley?
Details about the passage of the first budget of the Spitzer era:
Women collect water from a communal pump on the plains at the foot of Mount Kilimanjaro -- the mountain's ice cap is shrinking. Finbarr O'Reilly, Reuters
President Viktor Yushchenko ordered Parliament, the base of support for his rival, the prime minister, disbanded.

WASHINGTON, April 2 — The Supreme Court declined today to hear urgent appeals from two groups of detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The 45 men sought to challenge the constitutionality of a new law stripping federal judges of the authority to hear challenges to the open-ended confinement of foreign citizens held at the United States naval base in Cuba and designated as enemy combatants.
Citibank and five universities will pay $5.2 million to resolve an investigation into their student loan practices.
Law enforcement officials in Polk County Fla., arrested 28 men for soliciting sex with minors after setting up a weeklong sting operation.
More than a hundred Palestinian journalists and other civilians today demanded greater efforts to find and free Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent in Gaza.
In a 5-to-4 decision, the Supreme Court found that the Clean Air Act expressly authorizes the E.P.A. to regulate carbon dioxide emissions, contrary to the E.P.A.’s contention.
The rejection of the “de-Baathfication” proposal is likely to fuel sectarian hostility between Sunni Arabs and Shiites.
A formerly highflying seller of mortgage loans to buyers with risky credit has crashed to earth.
Iran’s chief negotiator said today that “there is no need for a trial” for the 15 captured British naval personnel.
The Chicago Cubs baseball team will be sold after the 2007 season as part of the $8.2 billion acquisition of the Tribune Company by the real estate mogul Sam Zell.
The quaint ritual leads up to a quadrennial sailing clash of high-tech vessels and billionaires, gritty sailors and global corporate giants.
The United States sealed its biggest pact since the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994.
An undersea earthquake sent huge tides rolling across low-lying areas of the Solomon Islands, inundating entire villages and causing an unknown number of deaths.
At this rate, Tom Glavine will reach his his 300th victory by the end of May.
The countries reached a bilateral deal that could increase their annual $72 billion trade by more than $20 billion.
On Tuesday, the Lady Vols will face Rutgers while seeking their seventh national championship under Coach Pat Summitt.
The Cardinals may have won the last game of 2006, but the Mets took the first one of 2007.
The governor’s staff and the Legislature began to dispute the portion on education of the $120.9 billion budget.
The Rangers are 16-5-5 since Sean Avery arrived in a midseason trade and helped them climb into the playoff race.

More than two-thirds of the dealers at the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino have voted to join a union, according to union officials. The dealers voted 324 to 149 late Saturday to join the United Auto Workers union, according to the union’s Web site. A Trump Plaza spokesman did not return a telephone call for comment. The Trump Plaza is the second Atlantic City hotel at which dealers have voted to unionize. Last week, a union was approved for dealers at Caesars Atlantic City after the casino’s parent company declined to contest a vote in which workers chose to join the United Auto Workers union. The union is also seeking certification for workers at a third casino, the Trump Marina Hotel Casino. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a law yesterday moving the state’s presidential primary to Feb. 5. The move is intended to give the state more influence in selecting presidential candidates. Last year, state legislators voted to move the primary from June to Feb. 26, but they voted to move it once again after a change in the national primary schedule potentially put New Jersey toward the back of the pack. New Jersey is the eighth state to move the state’s primary to the first Tuesday in February, according to the National Association of Secretaries of State. The New York Legislature passed a bill last month to move its presidential primary to Feb. 5, from March 4. The measure awaits action by Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

The clown who stars in the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus was reunited with his foot-high, 6-inch-wide bicycle yesterday after losing it on Friday during a performance at Grand Central Terminal. The clown, Bello Nock, lost the bike after he went to a shoe repair shop at the terminal with two other clowns. The bike disappeared shortly after the three gave an impromptu show outside the terminal. After public appeals for its return, Ricky Robinson, 54, of Bridgeport, Conn., took the bike yesterday to Madison Square Garden, where the circus was performing. Mr. Robinson, who said he spotted the bike outside a restaurant on the West Side of Manhattan, will receive a $1,000 reward, a new bike and tickets to the circus and a Knicks game.

Officers arrested two people yesterday morning while investigating two previous thefts at a church in Kensington, the police said. Carmen Sierra, 42, and her brother Juan Sierra, 43, were charged with attempted grand larceny and disruption of a religious service. The police said the two tried to steal money collected during services at the Holy Innocents Church, at East 17th Street near Beverley Road, shortly before 11 a.m. Ms. Sierra tried to break into a room while her brother served as a lookout, the police said. An undisclosed amount was stolen from the church on March 25, and an attempted burglary occurred on March 18, the police said. Mr. and Ms. Sierra have not been charged in connection with the previous crimes, the police said.

An off-duty New York City police officer was shot in the hand during a possible attempted robbery early yesterday, the Nassau County police said. The 25-year-old officer, whom the Nassau police did not identify, was treated at Nassau University Medical Center and then released. At 4 a.m., the off-duty officer was sitting in his car, which was parked on Kinkel Street between Prospect Avenue and Broadway, when a man with a handgun approached. A fight ensued, and the officer drove off after he was wounded in the left hand, the police said. The assailant was still at large last night.

A 29-year-old man was charged with assault in the stabbing of another man outside a Williamsburg restaurant yesterday morning, the police said. The man then fled the scene, right, and tried to blend in with several homeless people to avoid detection, witnesses said. The stabbing occurred shortly before 9 a.m. outside Las Palmera de Mi Pueblo, a restaurant and bar at 347 Broadway near Keap Street. Witnesses said the suspect, Pedro Torres, had been hanging out under the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway before the stabbing, then left and returned about an hour later, followed by the police. “They caught the dude over there, where we were standing,” said James Cone, 53, who is homeless. “We have a crate where we sit. He tried to sit there and hide.” The victim, whose name was not released, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center and was in critical condition, the police said.

A map in the special Museums section on Wednesday that highlighted museum construction projects around the country referred incorrectly to the scope and timing of several of them. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/museums.

A sports article on Thursday about Jim Harrick, the former college basketball coach who is now the head coach in California of the Bakersfield Jam in the N.B.A.’s Development League, misstated the name of a competing team in the state. It is the Anaheim Arsenal, not the Admirals.

A front-page article on Thursday about criticism of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales by federal prosecutors who questioned the firings of eight United States attorneys omitted a reporting credit. Rachel Mosteller contributed from Houston, where Mr. Gonzales was speaking; the article was written from Washington.
Corrections: For the Record

A picture caption in the special Museums section on Wednesday with an article about the relocation of the Grand Rapids Art Museum in Michigan misstated information about its site. The museum will be in a new building, not in a former federal office building.

A picture caption in the special Museums section on Wednesday with an article about campus galleries referred incorrectly to the status of the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive building at the University of California, Berkeley. The university is constructing a new building for the museum; there are no plans to raze the current building, which may be used for other purposes.

An obituary on Tuesday about Robert E. Petersen, the chairman of Petersen Publishing, omitted two of the four investors who paid $450 million for the company in 1996. The buyers included James Dunning Jr., who headed the team of investors, and Willis Stein & Partners L.P., a private equity fund based in Chicago. D. Claeys Bahrenburg, former president of Hearst Magazines, and Neal Vitale, former general manager of the Hollywood trade paper Variety, were not the only investors.

A front-page article on March 9 about Reading First, the Bush administration’s program for low-income children, referred imprecisely to the involvement of G. Reid Lyon in the National Reading Panel, which recommended effective ways to teach reading. Dr. Lyon, a former head of a branch of the National Institutes of Health, advised his former boss, Dr. Duane Alexander, about candidates nominated for the panel. The final selection of members did not rest with Dr. Lyon; the law creating the panel called for Dr. Alexander to make that decision.

An article in the special Museums section on Wednesday about hand-held technologies for audio tours in museums misstated the name of a company that develops electronic tours. It is Antenna Audio — not Antenna Audio/Arts Communications Technologies. The article also misstated the executive position that Chris Tellis holds at Antenna Audio. He is vice chairman, not chief executive.
AUTO RACING.
The raid on a nightclub in the predominantly white part of Zimbabwe’s capital was part of the government’s latest crackdown on dissent.
The future for many shop owners on River Avenue is uncertain, with the new Yankee Stadium set to open for the 2009 season.
Britain expressed “continuing regret” over the people killed on the eve of the 25th anniversary of the invasion of the islands by Argentina.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel invited Arab leaders to join him for talks in a regional peace meeting in Jerusalem.
A new generation of leaders has emerged under Osama bin Laden to cement control over the network’s operations, officials said.
Inexpensive genetic testing is turning the once-staid pursuit of genealogy into an extreme sport.
Design secrets of the defending America’s Cup champion, Alinghi, and its 11 challengers were on display Sunday.
In Iraq’s increasingly violent Diyala Province, the Third Brigade Combat Team of the First Cavalry Division has seen 39 soldiers die in five months.
A recent case has raised  questions about the ability of small hospitals to care for patients who suffer complications.
Tribune indicated that if Sam Zell made a high enough offer, it would be prepared to sell its media empire to him.
The credit-card processor is near a deal to be sold for nearly $27 billion to the private equity firm.
Not since his first year of professional baseball has Braden Looper stood on the mound and thrown the first pitch of a game.
April 1, 2007.
The Texas Legislature took a big step back from the immigration fight last week, as an unusual alliance rose up in support of humane, sensible reform.
Europe should remind Washington of the dangers of riling up the Russians.
Excessively favoring one form of income over another encourages wasteful gamesmanship, creates inequity and crowds out other ways to foster risk-taking.
Proposed changes to the Endangered Species Act, leaked to an environmental group, deserve attention.
Michael Phelps set another world record Sunday, and his seventh gold in a major meet tied Mark Spitz’s 1972 haul.
The demise of Saba al Bor is a lesson in how quickly things can change for the worse in Iraq and how difficult it has been to make things better.
Not a beauty pageant but a scholarship program, Junior Miss has been all but abandoned by city and suburban girls, who favor bustier, lustier, Trump-owned contests.
The attacks coincided with a visit to Iraq by Senator John McCain who said the security plan was “making progress.”
For 25 years, Canadian broadcaster Don Cherry has used his television platform to advocate the role of fighting in hockey.
First it was Patrik Elias, then John Madden and now Brian Gionta.
The 8.0 quake off the Solomon Islands sent a tsunami crashing onshore, killing several people.
When Johnson took the checkered flag for the victory Sunday at Martinsville Speedway, perhaps no one was more frustrated than his car owner.
After getting thrown together on the largest stages in college sports, the Buckeyes and the Gators have developed a healthy hatred for each other.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign said it had raised $26 million in the first quarter.
Based strictly on performance, Lastings Milledge has the edge on Shawn Green for the spot in right field.
The White House sought to increase pressure but took care to defer to Prime Minister Tony Blair, who emphasized that he is seeking a diplomatic solution.
AT&T said it was in negotiations to buy a major stake in Italy’s largest telecommunications company, Telecom Italia.
A battle to turn a former Christian church into a mosque underscored Britain’s unease with its Muslim minority.
In Tuesday’s final against Tennessee, the Scarlet Knights will play for their first N.C.A.A. title in any sport since 1949.
A negotiated budget deal ensures that New York City will receive full levels of aid next year, although the city will still have to find new revenue this year.
For most of their time as teammates, Mike Conley Jr. has been the coaster under the tall glass of drink named Greg Oden.
A major expansion of state-subsidized health insurance, especially for middle-class children, sailed with little debate into the New York state budget.
A group including the family of the Yankees principal owner has withdrawn from Excelsior Racing, which is among four bidders to run racing around New York.
The Justice Department has been embroiled in a dispute over a critical law enforcement question: Should interviews with criminal suspects be tape-recorded?
After years on the rise, Newark’s tide of violence might be ebbing and Mayor Cory A. Booker is hopeful the trend will continue.
With a championship team in football and a contender for the men’s basketball title, the Gators’ athletic director is enjoying his success.
The Yankees begin their season this afternoon against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays with some new faces and some old ones who have not played with the team in a while.
A three-year dispute over land in Dutchess County illustrates the difficulties in zoning a region that is growing quickly.
AirTran Holdings is said to be planning to raise its hostile bid for the Midwest Air Group a third time, to $15 a share.
The right-hander Dustin Hermanson was released yesterday by the Cincinnati Reds, who took him to spring training hoping that he could become their closer.
The attacks were part of a battle between Ethiopian and Somali troops against insurgents that has raged for a fourth day.
The Phoenix Suns defeated the Dallas Mavericks again yesterday, and this one was no down-to-the-wire thriller between the teams with the best records in the N.B.A.
The Ferry Building on Ellis Island is scheduled to reopen to the public Monday after a 5-year restoration project that cost $6.4 million.
Novak Djokovic dispatched Guillermo Cañas to become the youngest men’s champion in the tournament’s 23-year history.
The region around the Central African Republic has spawned one of the world’s deadliest and most complex crises.
Prime Minister Portia Simpson-Miller, who doubles as Jamaica’s sports minister, is hardly the only politician in the country to go cricket-crazy.

Morgan Pressel became the youngest major champion in L.P.G.A. Tour history yesterday with a game well beyond her 18 years, closing with a three-under-par 69 at the Kraft Nabisco Championship as everyone around her self-destructed.
A bill would force two pension funds to remove their money from any foreign company doing business in Iran.
Tommy G. Thompson said Sunday that he would seek the Republican nomination for president.
Mr. Carneal, a member of the broadcasters’ wing of the Baseball Hall of Fame, broadcast Minnesota Twins games for the past 45 seasons.
Mr. Cohen was a versatile mathematician whose path-breaking work in the field of logic helped resolve a fundamental question of mathematics.

The Chicago Cubs' 2007 marketing slogan exclaims, ''Play Like There's No Tomorrow!'' That will be literally true for the Tribune Company, which announced Monday that it would sell the Cubs, its storied subsidiary, later this year as part of the company's overall sale to the Chicago billionaire Sam Zell. The company did not reveal any prospective ownership groups, only that it planned to complete the transaction after the 2007 baseball season. That moment usually comes before the October playoffs for the Cubs, who have not won a World Series since 1908 or even participated in one since 1945.

Hilary Duff Dignity (Hollywood) Hilary Duff is 19, and she is responsible for some of the best teen-pop songs of the past few years (''Wake Up'' evoked the spirit of the Go-Gos), along with some of the worst (for starters: ''Cry,'' an excruciating ballad). Her new album, ''Dignity,'' sounds a lot like a break-up album; as her young fans know, she recently split with Joel Madden, from the pop-punk band Good Charlotte. The album's first words are, ''Nobody believes me when I tell 'em that you're outta your mind.''

Journalists have an uneasy awareness that public relations professionals keep tabs on them, the better to hone the way they pitch and spin ideas for articles. And while the extent of this practice normally is not aired in public, it was last week when Wired magazine posted a long memo about one of its reporters that had been sent by e-mail to him by Microsoft, accidentally. In February, during the course of reporting on a video blogging initiative at Microsoft called Channel 9, Fred Vogelstein inadvertently received a 13-page, 5,500-word internal memo from Waggener Edstrom Worldwide, a firm that represents Microsoft. The document, which was meant to prepare Microsoft executives for interviews, contained frank details, including some less-than-flattering observations (''Fred's stories tend to be a bit sensational, though he would consider them to be balanced and fair''), scripted responses to questions and a strong-arm list of the points the agency expected to see in the piece.

Calvin Sims of The New York Times talks with Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles about his political goals, the city's racial tensions and the lingering question of which is better: New York or Los Angeles. On being the first Latino mayor of Los Angeles in more than a century: ''It says a lot more about the people of Los Angeles than it does about me.'' On Los Angeles as the gang capital of the United States: ''We have 9,400 police officers for four million people, 456 square miles of city.'' The complete video interview: nytimes.com/conversation

A 29-year-old man was charged with assault in the stabbing of another man outside a Williamsburg restaurant yesterday morning, the police said. The man then fled the scene, right, and tried to blend in with several homeless people to avoid detection, witnesses said. The stabbing occurred shortly before 9 a.m. outside Las Palmera de Mi Pueblo, a restaurant and bar at 347 Broadway near Keap Street. Witnesses said the suspect, Pedro Torres, had been hanging out under the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway before the stabbing, then left and returned about an hour later, followed by the police. ''They caught the dude over there, where we were standing,'' said James Cone, 53, who is homeless. ''We have a crate where we sit. He tried to sit there and hide.'' The victim, whose name was not released, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center and was in critical condition, the police said. MICHAEL WILSON

ECONOMIC REPORTS -- The main news of the week will be the unemployment report for March (Friday). Other reports will include the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index for March (Monday), the institute's service index for March and factory orders for February (Wednesday), and wholesale trade for February and consumer credit for February (Friday). DISPUTE SETTLEMENT -- Shareholders of the News Corporation are expected to approve an $11 billion asset swap with Liberty Media, which would resolve a dispute between Rupert Murdoch, above, and John C. Malone (Tuesday). Sears Holdings, Hoffman Estates, Ill., placed in review the media planning and buying account for its Kmart and Sears chains. The assignments, with spending estimated at $750 million, are handled by two agencies owned by the WPP Group: MindShare, for traditional ads, and MEC Interaction, for online ads. Qwest Communications, Denver, is placing in review the creative part of its consumer advertising account, now handled by the New York office of Rivet, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Spending was estimated at $95 million. Rivet will be invited to participate in the review along with a short list of other agencies to be determined, said Kate Varden, a Qwest spokeswoman.

An article in the special Museums section on Wednesday about hand-held technologies for audio tours in museums misstated the name of a company that develops electronic tours. It is Antenna Audio -- not Antenna Audio/Arts Communications Technologies. The article also misstated the executive position that Chris Tellis holds at Antenna Audio. He is vice chairman, not chief executive.

A picture caption in the special Museums section on Wednesday with an article about campus galleries referred incorrectly to the status of the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive building at the University of California, Berkeley. The university is constructing a new building for the museum; there are no plans to raze the current building, which may be used for other purposes.

It's Not Game 7, but It'll Have to Do José Reyes and the Mets battered the St. Louis Cardinals, the defending World Series champions, 6-1, in the season opener.
