Children ages 2 to 12 have an average 58 hours of leisure time each week, according to the NPD Group, which they use for activities like playing with toys (85 percent); homework (67 percent); going to the park (52 percent) and talking on the phone (26 percent). Children use the computer for the same things that adults do, but most sit down to play games. Sixty percent of all children use the computer for non-homework related activities, the same percentage as those who pick up a book for fun. SHELLY FREIERMAN

''Crying doesn't make me any less of a man. To not show emotion, you're an idiot, or you're living a pipe dream. If someone were to tell me not to show emotion, I'd hit them in the lip.'' LT. COL. MORRIS GOINS, reflecting on soldiers' reactions to losing comrades in Iraq. [A10]
BERNSTEIN--Elliott. Today its been 13 years, but my memories of you and my love for you is still strong. Love, Mom

Paul J. Cohen, a versatile mathematician whose path-breaking work in the field of logic helped resolve a fundamental question of mathematics and won for him the prestigious Fields Medal, died of a lung disease on March 23 in Stanford, Calif. He was 72. Dr. Cohen's death was confirmed by his family. As a young mathematician at Stanford University in the 1960s, Dr. Cohen studied a question of set theory proposed in the 19th century by the mathematician Georg Cantor. The question, restated by David Hilbert in 1900 and then amplified by the influential logician Kurt Gödel, had been considered a problem of major importance for mathematicians in the 20th century.

Martina McBride Waking Up Laughing (RCA/Sony BMG Nashville) ''I got pitched every social issue song on the planet.'' That's how the country singer Martina McBride describes her career in the time after ''Independence Day,'' her hit single about a battered woman turned arsonist. She is too canny a star -- and too good a singer -- to be pigeonholed, but she certainly hasn't shied away from the ''social issue song.'' Her recent singles include ''Concrete Angel,'' about an abused daughter, and ''God's Will,'' about a brave little boy battling some deadly disease. (Can you guess his name?)

SIEGEL--Laura. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member Laura Siegel. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to her family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Michael W. Schwartz, President
To the Editor: Re ''Living With Alzheimer's Before a Window Closes'' (front page, March 29):

A picture caption in the special Museums section on Wednesday with an article about the relocation of the Grand Rapids Art Museum in Michigan misstated information about its site. The museum will be in a new building, not in a former federal office building.

A sports article on Thursday about Jim Harrick, the former college basketball coach who is now the head coach in California of the Bakersfield Jam in the N.B.A.'s Development League, misstated the name of a competing team in the state. It is the Anaheim Arsenal, not the Admirals.

For two months, the high-volume battle over Gov. Eliot Spitzer's cuts to hospitals and nursing homes has obscured a significant piece of his health care plan, a major expansion of state-subsidized health insurance, especially for middle-class children, which sailed with little debate into the state budget approved yesterday. The Legislature agreed to Mr. Spitzer's plan to set the nation's highest income ceiling for state-financed health care for children, making it, more than ever, a middle-class entitlement. Child Health Plus, the state-subsidized health insurance plan, was created in the early 1990s for the children of low-income families that were not quite poor enough to qualify for Medicaid, but income limits have risen over the years.

A woman and her former husband were fatally shot last night in a house in Elmont, on Long Island, and investigators were trying to locate the couple's 20-year-old son, the Nassau County police said. The couple, described as a man in his 50s and a woman in her 40s, were not identified by the police pending family notification.

A front-page article on Tuesday about the use of magnetic resonance imaging to diagnose breast cancer misstated the role of a coil that is part of the M.R.I. equipment. The coil sends and receives radio frequency signals used to produce the images. It does not create the magnetic field.
To the Editor: Re ''Child Wants Cellphone; Reception Is Mixed'' (Thursday Styles, March 29):

GIBBONS--James E. of Garden City, on March 31, 2007. Loving husband of the late Eleanor. Beloved father of Kathryn McGrath, Mary Ellen Pearson, Cynthia Gibbons and Anne Mah. Also survived by seven loving grandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City, 2-4 and 79pm, Tuesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, Wednesday 10am. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Diabetes Association appreciated.

Randi Weingarten, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, was overwhelmingly re-elected to a three-year term. The union, which represents 70,000 New York City public school teachers and 17,000 classroom paraprofessionals, announced on Friday that Ms. Weingarten had received 40,665 votes, or 87 percent of those cast, while her opponent, Kit Wainer, received 6,070. This will be Ms. Weingarten's fourth full term. In 1998, she was appointed to fill the remainder of Sandra Feldman's term, after Ms. Feldman ascended to become president of the parent union, the American Federation of Teachers. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

An obituary on Tuesday about Robert E. Petersen, the chairman of Petersen Publishing, omitted two of the four investors who paid $450 million for the company in 1996. The buyers included James Dunning Jr., who headed the team of investors, and Willis Stein & Partners L.P., a private equity fund based in Chicago. D. Claeys Bahrenburg, former president of Hearst Magazines, and Neal Vitale, former general manager of the Hollywood trade paper Variety, were not the only investors.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination said Sunday that it had raised $26 million during the first quarter of this year, about three times as much as the previous record at this stage of a presidential race. Officials from several other Democratic primary campaigns voluntarily announced their fund-raising totals as well, just hours after the quarter closed at midnight on Saturday night.

An off-duty New York City police officer was shot in the hand during a possible attempted robbery early yesterday, the Nassau County police said. The 25-year-old officer, whom the Nassau police did not identify, was treated at Nassau University Medical Center and then released. At 4 a.m., the off-duty officer was sitting in his car, which was parked on Kinkel Street between Prospect Avenue and Broadway, when a man with a handgun approached. A fight ensued, and the officer drove off after he was wounded in the left hand, the police said. The assailant was still at large last night. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

GORDON--Monte J., formerly of NYC, and of Henderson, NV, on Friday, March 30, 2007 at age 83. A retired Research Director of Financial Securities and a U.S. Air Force WWII veteran. Funeral services are pending in San Diego, CA. Survivors include his wife of 61 years, Arline Gordon, devoted father of Dale Gordon and Margery (Richard) Winters and loving grandfather of Joshua, Brandy and Jeffrey Bell and Andy Winters. Services are private. Contributions are to your favorite charity.
LEEDS--Richard C. My heart and love will be with you forever. Rhoda

The only incumbent agency taking part in a review for the creative account of the Volvo division of the Ford Motor Company has been eliminated. Spending for the assignment, now handled by various agencies in regional markets, was estimated at $150 million to $200 million a year. Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas, which creates campaigns for Volvo in markets like the United States, was eliminated from the review last week along with 180 in Amsterdam, majority-owned by the Omnicom Group.

APPLE AND EMI HAVE NEWS -- A joint news conference by the chief executives of Apple Inc. and the EMI Group, scheduled for today, has encouraged speculation that the two may be preparing to make an announcement on making the Beatles available on an iPod or even a more radical shift toward selling digital music without copy protection. [Page C1.] FIRST THE TOUR, THEN THE BOOK -- An increasing number of authors are enduring the pre-publication book tour, hoping to give their books a fighting chance in an industry that issues, by some estimates, more than 175,000 titles a year. [C1.] WARNER'S DIGITAL WATCHDOG -- Hollywood studios spent millions of dollars every year trying to get people to watch their movies. At Warner Brothers Entertainment, Darcy Antonellis is trying to get them to stop watching -- illegally, that is. [C1.] GUITAR TABLATURE ONLINE -- Because of an agreement in March between MusicNotes, an online music publisher, and the Harry Fox Agency, which represents 31,000 music publishers, guitar tablature -- a popular system for teaching and learning guitar -- will enter the legitimate business realm for the first time. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C6.] PET FOOD, À LA CARTE -- With tainted pet food being blamed for at least 16 pet deaths -- and some veterinarians predicting hundreds more to follow -- preparing homemade lamb stew for the family pet suddenly sounds sensible. [C4.] WEB ACCESS, AND A COMPUTER -- A French Internet service provider, Neuf Cegetel, is developing a low-cost computer using open-source software in an effort to attract customers who are unable or unwilling to buy a computer as well as those who find Windows-based computers too technologically challenging. [C6.] FOUND IN TRANSLATION -- Lucifer Chu, a 31-year-old from Taipei, Taiwan, has made a small fortune in a relatively new business, popular Chinese translations of fantasy novels. And using much of the $1 million in royalties from his versions of ''The Lord of the Rings'' series, Mr. Chu says he now devotes himself to distributing free Chinese translations of material provided online by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, among others, as part of the OpenCourseWare project. Link by Link. [C3.] LOGOS ON 'IDOL' -- Some members of the studio audience for ''American Idol'' last week held up placards with the corporate logo of the former employer of a contestant, LaKisha Jones, left, which are forbidden under the show's rules. [C4.] A WHIFF OF ADS TO COME -- In the increasingly popular realm of scented advertising, guests at Omni luxury hotels will soon find small scented stickers on the front pages of their free copies of USA Today, exuding a blackberry aroma and suggesting that guests start the day with a cup of Starbucks coffee ''paired with a fresh muffin.'' Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] THE NEW MAYTAG REPAIRMAN -- At a news conference today in Midtown Manhattan, Maytag will introduce Clay Jackson as the new Maytag repairman. Unlike his three predecessors, the tall (6 feet, 6 inches) Mr. Jackson is not an experienced actor. [C5.] RICH PRIZE FOR AN EFFICIENT CAR -- The same group that awarded $10 million to a team that built the first private spacecraft is preparing to start a contest for a commercially viable car that can run 100 miles on a gallon of gasoline. The price is expected to be more than $10 million. [C7.] HOW TO HANDLE A REPORTER -- Fred Vogelstein, contributing editor for Wired magazine, was preparing an article on Microsoft when he was inadvertently sent a 13-page memorandum written by the company's public relations firm to coach Microsoft's senior executives on how to handle his questions. [C4.] ADS BETWEEN THE LINES -- Fans of the rock bank Fall Out Boy who downloaded its new video last weekend also got a product placement ad for Tag All Nighter, a deodorant body spray aimed at young men. [C4.] LOOKING FOR A RADIO STAR -- The Public Radio Exchange, a nonprofit organization based in Cambridge, Mass., that connects independent radio producers and public radio stations looking for programming, is holding an online contest to find a new national radio star. [C6.]

The Minitel, a French government-sponsored minicomputer that was wired into 14 million homes at its peak in the mid-1990s, had a limited service offering, a black-and-white screen and slow connection speeds that doomed it to near-extinction in the face of the Internet. Now, a French Internet service provider, Neuf Cegetel, has taken inspiration from the Minitel to develop a computer based on a similar low-cost model, aimed at people who are unable or unwilling to buy a computer. In a gesture to high-technology enthusiasts, however, the system uses the open-source software beloved by many engineers and programmers.

A map in the special Museums section on Wednesday that highlighted museum construction projects around the country referred incorrectly to the scope and timing of several of them. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/museums.

An article in Business Day on March 21 about the influx of logic games and brainteasers misstated the role of Nikoli Publishing in the publication of its sudoku books and calendars in the United States. Nikoli served as the editor, not the co-publisher. (Workman Publishing is the publisher.) The article also misidentified the first newspaper in the United States that published a sudoku puzzle by Wayne Gould, who helped popularize the brainteaser. It was The Conway Daily Sun in New Hampshire in 2004, not The New York Post in 2005.

SAVITSKY--Helen, 88, died on March 25th. During WWII she served with the O.S.S. in Europe. She was married for 58 years to Dr. Elias Savitsky. She is survived by her children Joan and Richard, and a sister Marjorie Karter. Donations may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

The 57,478 seats at Yankee Stadium were empty yesterday on a chilly and gray afternoon. But shortly after 1 p.m., the ballpark began to hum with anticipation. First, Thin Lizzy's ''The Boys Are Back in Town'' played over the loudspeakers. Then the Yankees filed onto the field for their final workout before the 2007 season.
LICHTENSTEIN--Elsa T., 96, an extraordinary lady, left us on March 30, 2007. Memorial service Wednesday, April 4th, 2:00pm, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

An article on Friday about the coming auction of a 1729 Stradivarius at Christie's in Manhattan, which is allowing some patrons to try out the violin, referred imprecisely to the musical piece that one patron, Albert Cheng, played. It was the Bach Sonata No. 1 in G minor, not a Bach concerto.

A front-page article on Thursday about criticism of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales by federal prosecutors who questioned the firings of eight United States attorneys omitted a reporting credit. Rachel Mosteller contributed from Houston, where Mr. Gonzales was speaking; the article was written from Washington.

Officers arrested two people yesterday morning while investigating two previous thefts at a church in Kensington, the police said. Carmen Sierra, 42, and her brother Juan Sierra, 43, were charged with attempted grand larceny and disruption of a religious service. The police said the two tried to steal money collected during services at the Holy Innocents Church, at East 17th Street near Beverley Road, shortly before 11 a.m. Ms. Sierra tried to break into a room while her brother served as a lookout, the police said. An undisclosed amount was stolen from the church on March 25, and an attempted burglary occurred on March 18, the police said. Mr. and Ms. Sierra have not been charged in connection with the previous crimes, the police said. JENNIFER 8. LEE

WILSON--John E. on April 1, 2007 of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Cathleen. Loving father of Jennifer and John, John and Pam, Patricia, Ryan and Shannon. Cherished grandfather of eight. Brother of Jimmy and Min. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Tuesday 3-5 and 79pm. Funeral Mass, Wednesday 10am, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to St. Mary's School Scholarship Fund.

To the Editor: Re ''In Defense of Day Laborers'' (editorial, March 28): One of the obligations of an honorable lawmaker is to respect the law as it stands, whether or not he or she agrees with it. And like it or not, it is against federal law to hire illegal immigrants.

John Abercrombie The Third Quartet (ECM) The guitarist John Abercrombie has explored a number of stylistic regions throughout his long association with the ECM label, but with one aesthetic constant: an open and uncluttered lyricism. In recent years he has carried that quality over to a quartet with the violinist Mark Feldman, the bassist Marc Johnson and the drummer Joey Baron. The group, which will be playing at Birdland in Manhattan from April 11 to 14, has now released three albums together, each one stronger than the last.

In last-minute negotiations yesterday, executives for the Tribune Company were pushing Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate tycoon, to increase his bid for the company, according to people close to the talks. If Mr. Zell were to make a high enough offer, the company seemed prepared to sell its 160-year-old media empire to him, they said. Mr. Zell could still walk away from the talks. But even if he were to drop out, it seemed doubtful that Tribune would accept a rival bid from Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad, two Los Angeles billionaires; more likely, the board members would decide to restructure the company themselves.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Al Qaeda Heals in Pakistan While New Leaders Rise As Al Qaeda rebuilds in Pakistan's tribal areas, a new generation of leaders has emerged under Osama bin Laden and is cementing control over the network's operations, according to American intelligence and counterterrorism officials. A1 Unease Over Islam in Britain A decision to turn a Christian church into a mosque has underscored Britain's unease with its Muslim population. It may continue to regard itself as a Christian nation, but practicing Muslims will likely outnumber church-attending Christians in several decades, according to a new survey. A1 U.S. Keeps Pressure On Iran The White House sought to increase pressure on Iran to return the eight detained British sailors and marines, but took care to defer to Prime Minister Tony Blair, who has said he is seeking a diplomatic solution. A9 McCain Claims Progress in Iraq At least 24 people, including 4 American soldiers, were killed in attacks across Iraq that coincided with a visit by a Republican congressional delegation led by Senator John McCain, who declared that the new security plan was ''making progress.'' A11 A Crisis in Central Africa In two years of fighting in the Central African Republic, thousands of people have been killed. The violence has caused hundreds of thousands of the country's four million people to flee their homes, and in their desperation, some have sought refuge in their country's war-torn neighbors, Chad and Sudan. A3 NATIONAL A14-21 DNA Testing Is New Tool In Searching Family History The advent of inexpensive genetic testing has prompted a frenzy among amateur genealogists, who trace their family trees and often resort to extreme measures to retrieve DNA samples. A1 Darfuri Community in Indiana Years of village burning, rape and mutilation have driven 2.5 million people from their homes in the Darfur region of Sudan, and a community in Fort Wayne, Ind., has become one of the largest concentrations of Darfuri in the United States. A1 Crime Intensifies Taping Debate A crime involving a Navajo man charged with severely beating his girlfriend and then trying to cover it up as a suicide has intensified a debate within the Justice Department over a critical law enforcement question: whether interviews with criminal suspects should be tape recorded. A16 Mormon Tabernacle Renovation The Salt Lake Tabernacle, completed in 1867 by the faithful of the fledgling Mormon religion, reopened over the weekend after a two-year, top-to-bottom renovation. Some aspects of the tabernacle's renovation, like the replacement of its original pews, have drawn criticism. A19 Clinton's Fund-Raising Edge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination said that it had raised $26 million in the first quarter of this year, about three times as much as the previous record at this stage of a presidential race. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 School Aid Fight Erupts As State Budget Passes Almost immediately after state lawmakers passed a $120.9 billion budget, a dispute erupted over education spending. Governor Spitzer proposed doling out money to different districts based solely on need, but his plan appeared to fall short to some, with wealthier school districts faring better than poorer ones. A1 Newark's Overall Crime Falls Three months into 2007, overall crime in New Jersey's largest city had dropped some 40 percent from the previous year, but even as they continue to see a drop in shootings, burglaries, rapes and assaults, the police in Newark remain stymied by the rise in homicides. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Apple and EMI Conference A joint news conference by the chief executives of Apple Inc. and the EMI Group has encouraged speculation that the two may be preparing an announcement on making the Beatles available on an iPod or making an even more radical shift toward selling digital music without copy protection. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES A25 Paul J. Cohen A mathematician whose groundbreaking work in the field of logic helped resolve a fundamental question of mathematics, winning him a Fields Medal, he was 72. A25 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Taxing private equity; a law not to be trifled with; common defense; Lawrence Downes on Texas and immigration. Columns: Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E2 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather A20

Tim McGraw Let It Go (Curb) Last year the rookie country singer Taylor Swift had a breakthrough hit with ''Tim McGraw.'' Maybe it's a coincidence, but Mr. McGraw's ninth album, ''Let It Go,'' includes a song called, ''Kristofferson.''
To the Editor: Re your March 28 news article about David Hicks, the Australian imprisoned at Guantánamo Bay who pleaded guilty to providing material support to a terrorist organization:
To the Editor: Re ''Mr. Puck's Good Idea'' (editorial, March 26):

The Ohio State assistant Dan Peters and the Florida assistant Larry Shyatt break down the game from their perspective while other coaches weigh in. By PETE THAMEL LARRY SHYATT Florida assistant Their center is very healthy now, which he was not in December. With young players that they're playing, they're far more experienced after going through one of the best schedules in the country. When you're at the level these two teams are in terms of the talent and coaching ability, it's difficult to change a great deal at the end of the road because you've had so much success and the players have done so well up to that point. They're one of the most up-tempo teams that we played all year. I think our guys are comfortable with that pace. DAN PETERS Ohio State assistant Unfortunately, the officials have a lot to do with the game sometimes. You hope their players adjust quick enough to how they're going to call it. It hurts having officials who don't know how to officiate big guys. Maybe I'm wrong about this, but because kids in the last 10 years in college could leave high school to the N.B.A., you didn't have a lot of big guys. I think most officials know that people come to see the kids play. I told Thad: ''Why don't we walk up to the officials and ask what five minutes is Greg going to play in the first half? The beginning? The middle? Or the end?'' It's hard. That guy wants to play. MATT PAINTER Purdue played Ohio State three times this season and Florida in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Here is Purdue Coach Matt Painter's take on how the teams match up. It's going to be very important for Ohio State to keep Florida out of transition. I think that Florida has five guys that really push the ball up the floor. They're like piranhas when you take a bad shot, have a long rebound or turn the ball over. Taurean Green and Lee Humphrey feed off the inside-outside game, but they also get a lot of 3s in transition. I would say that Ohio State will try and play this game much more in the halfcourt than the first game because they're going to wait on Greg Oden. They're going to want to wait on their horse. JAY PRICE The Illinois assistant Jay Price saw Ohio State play many times in the Big Ten this season and offered these thoughts on the matchup. It's unbelievable how much better Oden has gotten since the first time these two teams played. He was out of shape and one-handed. He couldn't run up and down the court and was just getting his legs. There's no question that Ohio State is a much better team since it lost at Florida in December. It would not surprise me if Ohio State opened up in a zone. I think they'll mix it up. I thought they did a good job of getting Georgetown off balance with changing defenses. MIKE JONES Georgia played Florida three times this season, and the assistant Mike Jones offered this scouting report on tonight's game. Ohio State really tried to go up-tempo and play fast the first time around. It worked for a little while. It was a pretty close game in the first half, but they ended up losing by around 30. Ohio State will need to play like U.C.L.A. did in the first 10 minutes to have a better chance. It's got to be a brutal, grind-it-out kind of game.

A front-page article on March 9 about Reading First, the Bush administration's program for low-income children, referred imprecisely to the involvement of G. Reid Lyon in the National Reading Panel, which recommended effective ways to teach reading. Dr. Lyon, a former head of a branch of the National Institutes of Health, advised his former boss, Dr. Duane Alexander, about candidates nominated for the panel. The final selection of members did not rest with Dr. Lyon; the law creating the panel called for Dr. Alexander to make that decision.

CUTLER--Ethel. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to her sister Rhoda and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Sr Rabbi Amy A. B. Bressman, Chairman of The Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President
Now that the Supreme Court has ordered the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate emissions of carbon dioxide from cars, which of these scenarios is most likely?

The first pitch of 2007 was thrown to the Mets' Jose Reyes, who is from the Dominican Republic. Reyes is one of the most dynamic players in Major League Baseball, a sport that continues to expand internationally.
The last several days have been busy ones for Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and the blogosphere has trapped that buzz.

I was happy to learn the other day that Nicky Anosike, Tennessee's starting center in the N.C.A.A.'s women's national title game tonight, is back in my neck of the woods. We're old neighbors, one floor and a couple of decades apart.

The rain has stopped and the tarp is off the Busch Stadium infield, but the inclement weather still prevented the Mets from hitting outside. Some players hit in the indoor cage while others lounged on the clubhouse couches watching the Giants-Padres game and some lefthander named Barry Zito. Perhaps you've heard of him.
Do celebrities (pierced or not) really go to Starbucks? [Starbucks Gossip]
A sampling of some of the latest campaign goings-on in cyberspace:

Standard & Poor's is out with what it says are final figures for growth in S.&.P. 500 operating earnings per share in the fourth quarter of last year, finding them to be up 8.9 percent from the same quarter a year earlier. That ended a string of 18 quarters of gains of 10 percent or more.

The Drum Major Institute has posted a video of a panel discussion, "How Do We Make New York City a Place Where it is Possible to Become, and Remain, Middle Class?" The panel was part of a half-day conference at Baruch College on Monday. On the panel were Adolfo Carrión Jr., the Bronx borough president; Councilman John C. Liu of Queens; Maria Thomson of the Woodhaven Business Improvement District; and Representative Anthony D. Weiner of Queens and Brooklyn. The video is here:
It was a memorable Monday in the Bronx, for a lot of reasons. Here are some random observations a day later:
Just back from Florida and are my ears burning. No kidding. I didn't realize it was possible to sunburn your earlobes. But there you are, and I've got the peeling skin to prove it.

For all the sturm und drang college basketball's participants put themselves through to try to win a national championship, it is ultimately disappointing to see what they win for all their troubles: this trophy.

Starbucks stands accused by the National Labor Relations Board of breaking the law by retaliating against workers supportive of unionization at four of its coffee shops in Manhattan. Among the more unusual aspects of the complaint [Word document] is an accusation that Starbucks unfairly discriminated by selectively enforcing these two dress-code rules against pro-union employees:

Chicago Tribune columnist Phil Rosenthal offers a quick and handy guide to the months of machinations leading up to the agreement to sell Tribune Company -- which also happens to be Mr. Rosenthal's employer -- to real-estate magnate Sam Zell.

If you've been dying to see the Smart ForTwo that is bound for the United States and figure it must be hiding beneath some Hummer's skirt, brace for disappointment: The smallest car is the biggest no-show in New York. While the New York region could prove the prime American market for the 8.8-foot long urban runabout, officials of the Mercedes-owned Smart decided to focus marketing efforts on the higher-profile Detroit show last January and pass on New York until next April's show.

Though Blackstone Group is most often described as a private equity firm, TheStreet.com's James Altucher argues that it is really a money-management outfit that also runs hedge funds. As the group prepares to go public, Mr. Altucher declares that Blackstone "has the potential to eclipse every other financial institution."
This video summary of the first six seasons of "The Sopranos," by Paul Guylas and Joe Sabia, is an exquisite act of devotion to a television show.

Hofstra University is one of 19 institutions that have applied to host presidential debates, the Commission on Presidental Debates has announced. Of the 19, only two three are in the Northeast: Hofstra, Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., and VisitPittsburgh, the Greater Pittsburgh Convention and Visitors Bureau.The commission -- a nonprofit, nonpartisan corporation -- was established in 1987 to sponsor and produce debates for the United States presidential and vice-presidential candidates. The commission organized two presidential debates each in 1988 and 1996, and three each in 1992, 2000 and 2004.
Tour a condo on the Jersey shore, a Craftsman-style home in Galveston, Tex., and a house in the desert near Southern California’s Joshua Tree National Park.

Fred Wilson has made some lucrative exits in his career. The venture capitalist, of Union Square Ventures and Flatiron Partners, was an early investor in the Web site hosting service GeoCities.com, for example. That site was acquired by Yahoo for $3.6 billion in 1999, while the Internet boom was still in full swing.

CRAWFORDSVILLE, Iowa - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Democrats should not automatically accept defeat on the Iraq spending bill by assuming that President Bush will carry through with his veto threat.

Andy Pettitte realizes this could be his last season in the major leagues so he is doing things a bit differently. As Pettitte prepares to make his first start of the season in his second incarnation as a Yankee on Wednesday night, he explained how his wife and four children will be at the game.

President Bush ratcheted up the pressure on Congress today, tugging on the emotional strings of military families with relatives in Iraq as he outlined the consequences of war spending bills approved by the House and Senate that he has vowed to veto.
As observers continue to scrutinize Kohlberg Kravis Roberts's $29 billion deal for First Data, one thing has become clear: This deal is ambitious, even for a buyout heavyweight.
The proposal on the table would give Kosovo de facto nationhood, with its own civic institutions, army, constitution and flag.
A conference on the future of New York City's shrinking middle class on Monday featured clashes among several politicians who are considering running for mayor in 2009.

As aides to Senator Barack Obama boast of a $20 million Q-1 fundraising total, Christopher Drew and Mike McIntire draw insights from his technique during the 2004 Senate primary in Illinois. During that race, Mr. Obama recovered from a $20,000 debt generated during a failed congressional bid and accumulated more than $5 million:

Hey China, will you please dump some more cheap glossy paper over here? Harvard economist Greg Mankiw, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Bush, explains why the Bush administration should celebrate the subsidies China gives to its paper industry. Mankiw writes on his personal blog:
Additional images from the scene at this year’s WrestleMania.

Orbis Investment Management, a major shareholder of Nikko Cordial, stepped up pressure on Citigroup to raise its $14 billion bid for the Japanese broker by offering to sell its stake on the open market at a higher price. Analysts dismissed the move, which offers the shares at a price well above their current market value.
Candace Parker led the Lady Vols to their first national title since 1998.
A recipe for Neapolitan Ricotta and Wheatberry Pie.
OK, my jaw just hit the floor. This just in: Apple has persuaded EMI, one of the Big Four record companies, to offer its digital catalog of music without copy protection, starting in May.

The chief financial officer of an investment vehicle for Carl C. Icahn is leaving to take another job, the firm said in a regulatory filing Tuesday. The executive, Hillel Moerman, gave notice of his resignation to the Icahn company, American Real Estate Partners, last week, and the company said it did not make a counteroffer.
Gorgeous beaches, a Greg Norman-designed golf course, and Antonio Banderas as your neighbor. What more could you want?

The Carmel Group, the influential research firm whose analysis helped kill the 2003 merger of EchoStar and DirecTV, will release a new report Tuesday that outlines the strongest arguments yet against merging satellite radio companies Sirius and XM, The New York Post reported. Sponsored by the National Association of Broadcasters, which has already come out against the deal, the 11-page independent white paper includes a point-by-point rebuttal to the six main arguments put forth by Sirius and XM in favor of a merger.

Tribune's decision to use an employee stock ownership plan to help fund its sale to the real estate tycoon Samuel Zell has obvious benefits -- most notably tax breaks -- but also comes with some big risks, analysts said Monday. The clearest downsides are the large amount of debt in the Tribune deal and the potential hit to workers' savings if the publishing and broadcasting company runs into trouble.

Shares of Accredited Home Lenders Holding, a subprime mortgage lender, rose before the opening bell Tuesday after it said late on Monday that it had closed a loan from Farallon Capital Management, a hedge fund, to increase liquidity. In exchange for a five-year, $230 million term loan facility from Farallon, Accredited will give the hedge fund warrants to acquire about 3.23 million shares at an exercise price of $10 a share.

As Samuel Zell, the jeans-clad motorcycle rider, prepares to take over the conservative Tribune Company, he may have to deal with a bigger culture clash. The Los Angeles Times, the chain's marquee California newspaper, was nothing but trouble for Tribune, and it may prove even more of a challenge for Mr. Zell.

Wesfarmers, the biggest home-improvement retailer in Australia, and buyout firms led by Pacific Equity Partners bid 19.7 billion Australian dollars ($16 billion) for the Coles Group in what would be a record takeover of an Australian company.

The KCP Income Fund of Canada will sell itself to a private equity firm, Caxton-Iseman Capital of New York, for about 493 million Canadian dollars ($426 million). The deal was announced Monday. Caxton-Iseman will also assume about 311 million Canadian dollars of debt. The Globe and Mail pointed out that KCP, a bleach and consumer products manufacturer based in Toronto, has become the latest income trust to respond to Ottawa's new tax regime by selling out to an American private equity firm.

A government-appointed panel of antitrust experts has recommended the repeal of a 1930s-era antitrust law designed to protect small retailers, Reuters said. The commission has been meeting to deliberate various antitrust laws, including the Sherman Act and the Robinson-Patman Act, to see whether they were in line with the modern economy. The suggested repeal of the latter was the biggest change recommended by the commission. The Robinson-Patman Act bars suppliers from engaging in anticompetitive price discrimination.

Russian billionaire Alexey Mordashov is set to receive a $324 million dividend from his steel company Severstal. With his worth estimated at $8.5 billion, Mr. Mordashov was recently ranked Russia's seventh richest man by Forbes magazine. Although pre-tax profits at Severstal fell to $1.75 billion for 2006, Mr. Mordashov said the company's outlook for 2007 was positive. He added: "We will continue to drive value through strong organic growth and a disciplined approach to M&A."

The mortgage funding company Fannie Mae will lay off several hundred full-time employees by the end of 2007, according to a company spokesman. The job cuts are part of an effort to shave $200 million from operating expenses this year, the spokesman said.

Fears that the subprime mortgage market is on the verge of collapse have driven valuations of the companies down and one Wall Street firm, apparently seeing an opportunity there, has taken advantage. In a deal that was originally valued at $225 million, Barclays Bank has completed its purchase of one subprime mortgage lender, EquiFirst, from Regions Financial for just $76 million.

Augusta Medical, a subsidiary of Cytyc, has completed a tender offer for outstanding shares of Adeza Biomedical totaling about $403.6 million. Cytyc, based in Marlborough, Mass., said the company plans to complete the acquisition of Adeza as soon as possible. Adeza markets a test to determine whether pregnant women are at risk of giving premature birth while Cytyc makes diagnostic and surgical products.

Robert Van Securities of Oakland, Calif., said Monday it bought a New York investment bank, Blaylock & Company. No financial details for the deal were released. The newly combined company will be known as Blaylock Robert Van.

China Citic Bank, which jumped the final hurdle for its dual listing in both Hong Kong and Shanghai on Monday, could raise more than $4 billion in its planned initial public offering on April 27. Finance Asia suggests the listings could provide a genuine test of investor appetite for Chinese financial stocks.

As NCR moves to spin off its Teradata data-warehouse division, data-warehouse appliance startup Netezza has declared its own intentions to go public. An analyst firm, The 451 Group, takes a look at Netezza's prospects and suggests that the company is likely to get a rich valuation.
Alabama's primary schedule may have us all tied in knots.

A software company, Quovadx, has reached an agreement to be sold to Battery Ventures for $136.7 million, the company said. Battery Ventures is a venture capital and private equity firm with offices in Boston and the Silicon Valley.

San Mateo, Calif.-based Vyatta picked up $11 million in a second round of funding, the software company said Monday. The round was led by Comcast Interactive Capital, which may use Vyatta's technology in new potential managed service bundles for small and medium-sized business and enterprise markets. Also in the round were J.P. Morgan Partners, ComVentures and ArrowPath Venture Partners.

Stifel Financial of St. Louis has acquired First Service Financial and its subsidiary First Service Bank for about $38 million, the company said Monday. Stifel said it had completed a private placement March 30 of $35 million of 6.79 percent cumulative trust preferred securities and planned to use the proceeds for the acquisition of First Service Financial. The deal is subject to escrow settlement.

Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communicationswho is on trial on charges of insider trading, called for a repurchase of $1 billion in company stock in 2001, a former Qwest president testified on Monday. Mr. Nacchio, 57, is accused of selling $101 million in Qwest shares from January 2001 to May 2001, before the stock price plunged, based on inside information that the company would miss its revenue targets.

The German energy giant E.On on Monday withdrew its offer of 42.4 billion euros ($56.6 billion) for the Spanish utility Endesa in exchange for a promise from rival bidders to sell it part of Endesa's assets, ending one of Europe's most arcane takeover battles.

Russia's national airline, Aeroflot, made a surprise bid on Monday for all or part of Italy's national airline, Alitalia, as one of three potential buyers to meet a deadline set by the Italian ministry of finance. If successful, Aeroflot's bid for the Italian flag carrier would be its first large investment outside the former Soviet Union, and it would be in keeping with a trend of Russian state-owned businesses making strategic investments in Europe.

Second-lien lenders, claiming they've been shut out of their proposal to recapitalize Tower Automotive, are making noise about the company's plan to sell itself to Cerberus Capital Management for close to $1 billion.

Speculation as to possible suitors for the Tribune Company's Chicago Cubs baseball team ramped up Monday after Tribune said it would put the franchise on the block. The big names include Jerry Colangelo, chairman of the NBA's Phoenix Suns and a former owner of that team and baseball's Arizona Diamondbacks, and Mark Cuban, owner of the NBA's Dallas Mavericks.

Members of the Federal Trade Commission look likely to try and block the $1.13 billion acquisition of Giant Industries by Western Refining. Although Giant's shareholders approved the purchase more than a month ago, a government lawyer has said that the April 10 vote is expected to spark a second legal fight to stop a deal under its review. In March, the commission voted to halt a merger between two nonresidential natural gas suppliers in Pittsburgh, Equitable Resources and the Peoples Natural Gas Company. The deal is pending.

Sana Security, a maker of antivirus software, said it had received $12 million in venture funding in its latest round of financing, led by El Dorado Ventures, bringing its total venture funding to $40 million. Sana also named Don Listwin, who previously led Openwave Systems, as its chief executive officer.
Photographs of shows at the 2007 Humana Festival of New American Plays.
“The Phantom of the Opera,” the longest-running show in Broadway history, will hit the 8,000-performance milestone at its matinee on Wednesday.
The dangerous life of crabbers at sea continues to entice viewers to the Discovery Channel, possibly because of the authenticity of its characters and the beauty of its setting.
Inside the Golden Gloves semifinals on March 23 in the Bronx.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Federal investigators said the companies, which operate retail preparation stores, defrauded the Treasury out of more than $70 million.
Florida won its second consecutive N.C.A.A. title and equaled the successful run of Duke in 1991 and 1992, the last school to win back-to-back championships.

For the entirety of the N.C.A.A. Tournament so far, niggling observers have been pointing out that the Ohio State Buckeyes tend to improve when mammoth monolith Greg Oden is out of the game. The team plays looser, it feels less tethered to the paint and it seems to, you know, smile and have fun occasionally. Some even wondered if Oden was somehow holding back the Buckeyes.
Philip G. Zimbardo has made his reputation studying how people disguise the good and bad in themselves and under what conditions either is expressed.
The widow and associates of Alexander Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. agent poisoned in London last November, opened a foundation today to demand justice for him.
President Bush today renewed his promise to veto emergency war spending bills with Iraq withdrawal provisions.

Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic Speaker of the House, arrived in Damascus, the capital of Syria, today for a controversial visit that is seen as part of an attempt to sway American policy in the Middle East.
Viktor F. Yanukovich today defied an order by President Viktor A. Yushchenko to disband Parliament and called the decision a “fatal mistake.”
Prime Minister Tony Blair said that he was still hoping to win the release of 15 Britons through diplomatic means.
Gators guards Taurean Green and Lee Humphrey and the wing player Corey Brewer combined for 43 points.
Ohio State center Greg Oden, likely to be the No. 1 pick in the coming N.B.A. draft, showed that he could play smart, play hard and play angry.
The Florida Gators left one final mark for their legacy as one of the great teams in college basketball.
The Metavante Corporation would become its own company under a deal being completed by its parent company, the Milwaukee bank Marshall & Ilsley, and the private equity firm Warburg Pincus.
The players union could find itself caught between angry members who receive severe discipline and a much larger group who applaud the crackdown.

The police surveillance program leading up to the 2004 Republican National Convention was larger than previously disclosed to people who are suing the city over their arrests at the convention, according to papers filed in federal court yesterday.

Merrill Lynch & Company’s buyout fund and Pacific Equity Partners agreed to buy Veda Advantage, the biggest credit-checking company in Australia and New Zealand, for 814 million Australian dollars ($659 million). Veda, which is based in Sydney, said its directors endorsed the bid, which was for 3.61 Australian dollars a share. The deal comes as record household debt has spurred demand for Veda’s data.

Wesfarmers, Australia’s biggest home-improvement retailer, said it had bought an 11.3 percent stake in the Coles Group, the country’s second-biggest retailer, and is seeking talks with the company. Wesfarmers paid 16.47 Australian dollars ($13.40) a share for its stake, information from the Australian Stock Exchange shows, valuing Coles at 19.7 billion Australian dollars, or $16 billion. Coles, Australia’s second-biggest retailer, put itself up for sale in February, after saying it would not meet profit forecasts that had been cited to reject a bid of 18.2 billion Australian dollars by the private equity firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

A maker of bleach and other household products, the KCP Income Fund, said it would be acquired by a private equity firm, Caxton-Iseman Capital of New York, in a deal worth about 493 million Canadian dollars ($423 million). The companies said shares of KCP would be redeemed for 10 Canadian dollars each, a 25 percent premium to the closing price of 8 Canadian dollars on Friday. Shareholders of KCP said in November it had retained TD Securities and Genuity Capital Markets to help it review strategic alternatives. KCP said the move was set off by the Canadian government’s decision to start taxing income trusts.

Vehicle sales fell for a 21st straight month, led by Nissan and Toyota, capping their worst business year in three decades. Sales of cars, trucks and buses, excluding minicars, fell 12.6 percent, to 487,738 vehicles in March from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. Nissan’s sales fell 16 percent, while Toyota’s dropped 12 percent. Sales of vehicles excluding minicars dropped 8.3 percent, to 3.59 million units, the lowest level in 29 years, in the 12 months ended March 31.

An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about “United Black Girls,” a group show that closed at the Rush Arts Gallery in Chelsea on Saturday, omitted a co-curator and erroneously included another person as one. Derrick Adams was co-curator with Vanessa C. B. Riding; Courtney J. Martin contributed the introductory essay to the show but did not help put the show together.

An article yesterday about First Data, the credit-card processing company that is near a deal to be acquired by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, misidentified in some copies the payment network controlled by First Data. It is the STAR network, not the NYCE.

A graphic on Friday with an article about fund-raising for the 2008 presidential campaign referred incompletely to candidates this year who also sought their party’s nomination in 2004. Dennis Kucinich, who is seeking the Democratic nomination, also ran last time; John Edwards, another Democrat, is not the only such candidate.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a high-definition video projection system that can put an actor’s image on stage next to him omitted the opening date for the play “Losing Something,” which will mark the first use of the system by an American theater company. Previews begin tonight at the 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, and the official opening is Friday.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Morehouse College and its search for a new president misstated the former position of the college’s current president, Walter E. Massey. Dr. Massey was a director of the National Science Foundation, not of the National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts.
A Riverside Drive mansion that Turkish tobacco built is on the market for $20 million.
Corrections: For the Record

An obituary last Tuesday about Walter J. Turnbull, the founder of the Boys Choir of Harlem, referred incorrectly to the status of the Choir Academy of Harlem, a public school that was created in partnership with the choir. Although the school is no longer affiliated with the choir, it does remain open; it did not close last year when the choir was evicted from the building.
With Caron Butler out with a broken hand, the Washington Wizards need to advance deep into the playoffs for him to play again this season.

An academic conference on the state of the middle class became a mini-rehearsal for the 2009 mayor’s race yesterday, with three probable candidates outlining their priorities — and occasionally jousting — on how to attract and retain moderate-income New Yorkers.

Three employees of Disney World were among 28 men arrested and charged with soliciting sex from a child in a four-day sting operation outside Orlando. Sheriff Grady Judd of Polk County said most of the men were arrested after arriving at a house where officers were waiting. The men had communicated online, and in some cases by phone, with undercover officers posing as girls as young as 13. The Disney employees were identified as Thierry Ferron, 44, an electronics technician; Julio Segundo, 21, an intern in research and development; and Richard Gaugh, 55, a regional coordinator for Disney’s Animal Kingdom. A Disney spokeswoman said the three had been placed on unpaid leave.

The new conservator of the troubled Texas Youth Commission, Jay Kimbrough, has identified 552 juveniles due or overdue for release from custody and will begin freeing them tomorrow, said Jim Hurley, a spokesman for the revamped commission. Most will be supervised on parole. The group does not include additional hundreds of the more than 4,000 other confined youths whose cases will be reviewed by a special panel to see why their minimum sentences have been extended. Investigators are reviewing at least 1,200 complaints of sexual abuse and other mistreatment of juveniles in state custody.

A gunman killed a woman and shot himself to death at the University of Washington in Seattle, the authorities said. The shooting happened in an office where the woman, 25, worked in a division of the College of Architecture and Urban Planning. Ray Wittmier, assistant chief of police for the university, said the gunman, who was 41 and not affiliated with the university, was under a restraining order forbidding him from having contact with the woman.
The man who had been the chosen successor to lead the Yankees spent opening day at Yankee Stadium avoiding his wife and ducking the suite of the principal owner.
Bernie Williams, who does not want to play for anyone except the Yankees, called the clubhouse on Monday to wish them luck.
Philip J. Cline announced that he would retire early as his department tries to deal with two highly publicized videotaped beatings involving off-duty police officers.

The Chiang Mai Zoo in northern Thailand resorted to artificially inseminating its sole female panda, Lin Hui, after failing to stimulate amour between her and her cage-mate, Chuang Chuang, another panda on loan from China, by showing them videos of pandas having sex. “He just didn’t want to mate,” said Sophon Dummui, who oversees the country’s zoos. “He was looking at her as a friend.”.
A state of emergency was declared after the earthquake and tsunami caused widespread panic and killed at least 20 people.

Opposition parties said they would boycott legislative elections in June, accusing President Abdoulaye Wade’s government of buying votes and doctoring the electoral roll. The announcement was an embarrassment for the 80-year-old president, who easily won re-election a few weeks ago and will welcome heads of state and other dignitaries to his inauguration today.

More than a hundred Palestinian journalists and others held a sit-in outside the prime minister’s office in Gaza City to demand increased efforts to find Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent abducted there three weeks ago. In the West Bank city of Ramallah, local and international journalists also called on the government to do more. The Palestinian journalists’ union declared a three-day news boycott of the government and the office of President Mahmoud Abbas. BBC executives say there has been no information about Mr. Johnston’s whereabouts nor any message from his captors saying what they want.

The number of people in China who cannot read or write grew by 30 million over the past five years, to 116 million, wiping out years of gains against illiteracy, the state-run newspaper China Daily reported. The paper quoted an Education Ministry official as saying the main reason for the reversal was that many young rural poor were dropping out of school for migrant jobs in the cities created by China’s economic boom. “The situation is worrying,” said the official, Gao Xuegui. Literacy in China is defined as someone who can read and write 1,500 Chinese characters. College graduates are required to know 7,000 to 10,000 characters.
The community that earned Miami Beach nicknames like Little Jerusalem and Shtetl by the Sea is now largely gone.

Pope Benedict XVI said he could already hear the voice of John Paul II among the saints, indicating on the second anniversary of his predecessor’s death that he too was fully in favor of canonization. Benedict spoke during an open-air Mass in St. Peter’s Square in honor of John Paul hours after Roman Catholic officials formally closed their investigation into his life and virtues, a milestone in the process of elevating the late pope to sainthood. At a ceremony at the Basilica of St. John Lateran in Rome, left, five trunks filled with documents on the life of John Paul were sealed with red ribbon and wax, to be forwarded to the Vatican’s Congregation for the Causes of Saints. There is little chance that the case will languish there.

Northern Ireland’s political parties met and chose which ministries they will hold when they take over the running of the province next month. The Belfast-based regional administration will open for business on May 8. The Democratic Unionist Party, the biggest Protestant party, claimed the finance, economy, environment and culture portfolios, while Sinn Fein, the biggest Catholic party, took education, regional development and agriculture. The remaining ministries went to the moderate Ulster Unionist Party, which will take charge of health, employment and learning, and the moderate nationalist Social Democratic and Labor Party, which will control social development. The Rev. Ian Paisley, the leader of the Democratic Unionists, will be first minister, with Martin McGuinness, from Sinn Fein, as his deputy.
If the decision stands, some scientists and consumer groups say it could ease limits on research in the field.
The rejection by the Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani appears certain to fuel hostility between the majority Shiites and the former ruling Sunni Arabs.

The city’s Department of Correction wants to double the number of prisoners it plans to house at a reopened Brooklyn House of Detention as part of its effort to ease pressure on the aging jail complex on Rikers Island, officials said yesterday.
The National Labor Relations Board has accused Starbucks of breaking the law 30 times in fighting union activity at four of its coffee shops in Manhattan.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 2 — When the mother of an unemployed 20-year-old man tried to evict him from her Long Island home on Sunday, he killed her and his father, shooting them in the head, the Nassau County police said on Monday.

Not counting the player introductions, it took six minutes of the 2007 season for Yankees fans to boo Alex Rodriguez.

A fast ferry that carried passengers across Lake Ontario between Rochester and Toronto for eight months will be sold to a German ferry operator for $30 million, city officials said yesterday. The operator, FRS, will use the catamaran for service between Spain and Morocco, Mayor Robert Duffy said. The ferry operated for 11 weeks in 2004 before becoming tangled in debt; the city bought it at auction for $32 million, but shut down its operation after five months. Civic advocates had hoped that the ferry would boost tourism, but Mayor Duffy said that “this was not a project the city could sustain.”.

State officials have completed agreements to protect almost 260,000 acres of Adirondack wilderness and open much of it to public recreation. The deal, struck in 2004 with the International Paper Company, involved conservation easements on 257,000 acres in nine counties. Under the contracts, the Lyme Timber Company, which has since bought most of International Paper’s Adirondack land, will not sell the land for development, and the state will pay local taxes.

New Jersey Transit yesterday named Richard R. Sarles Sr. as its new executive director. Since 2002, Mr. Sarles has managed the agency’s $1.3 billion annual capital program and its three light rail lines. Before that, he worked at Amtrak directing the Northeast Corridor High-Speed Rail program. One of Mr. Sarles’s top priorities will be to oversee New Jersey Transit’s drive to build a second passenger rail tunnel under the Hudson River. He will also inherit a planned 9.6 percent fare increase, which is expected to go into effect on June 1. Mr. Sarles succeeds George Warrington, who said he was leaving to pursue other opportunities.

A Clinton Township police officer was arrested yesterday on a gun charge after he took a shotgun from a relative’s house and headed for Somerset County in his truck, the county prosecutor’s office said. Around 10:30 a.m., a countywide alert was issued for the officer, Jason Peltack, after a friend called the police and told them that the officer had taken a 12-gauge shotgun from a home in Bridgewater. As a precaution, the prosecutor’s office ordered Immaculata High School in Somerville to be locked down for about an hour, said Wayne J. Forrest, the Somerset County prosecutor. Mr. Forrest would not say why the school was thought to be in danger or how the officer had planned to use the gun. Officer Peltack, 27, was arrested around 11:20 a.m. in Raritan and charged with a fourth-degree firearms offense. He was placed on paid medical leave and ordered to undergo a psychological evaluation, the authorities said.

The city has positively identified two more Sept. 11 victims from thousands of unidentified human remains that have been retested in recent months, city officials said. The new identifications were made in the past week, said Ellen Borakove, spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner. She said the identified remains were recovered in the first year after the attacks. The names of the victims were not released yesterday; Ms. Borakove said the family of one victim asked the city not to make the name public, and the second has not decided whether to release the name.

The rape convictions of a Buffalo man incarcerated for more than 21 years were vacated yesterday, five days after prosecutors announced that newly discovered evidence had linked another man to the attacks. The man, Anthony Capozzi, 50, was not in court for the hearing, during which Judge Shirley Troutman of Erie County Court ordered his release. Mr. Capozzi, who is schizophrenic and is being treated at a state prison hospital in Marcy, was convicted of two rapes in the early 1980s. He was released after prosecutors said that another man’s DNA matched the DNA samples from the rapes. That man, Altemio Sanchez, cannot be charged with the rapes because of the statute of limitations, which was five years at the time, prosecutors said. Mr. Sanchez has been charged with three murders in the Buffalo area since 1990. He has pleaded not guilty.

Khalid Latif, 24, an imam who has served as a chaplain and adviser at Princeton University and New York University, was appointed yesterday as chaplain for Muslim members of the Police Department. Mr. Latif, who holds a master’s degree from Hartford Seminary, is the second Muslim to join the Christian and Jewish clergy members in the department’s chaplains’ unit. He succeeds Izak-El M. Pasha, a spiritual leader to thousands of black Muslims, who retired a year ago. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the number of Muslims in the department was “in the thousands.”.
Vice President Dick Cheney said it was pointless for Democrats to pursue Iraq spending measures that set a timeline for leaving Iraq that President Bush would veto.

A New York Police Department recruit was convicted in Suffolk County Court yesterday of conspiring to hire someone to murder his girlfriend, who stood by him throughout the trial. The recruit, Kabeer Din, 22, a former Baltimore police officer, was arrested last summer after meeting with a New York undercover police officer he thought was a hit man to discuss killing his girlfriend, Sherry Nohar, 24, for $3,000, prosecutors said. Mr. Din made a written confession to plotting to have her killed, and he was recorded discussing the scheme, the Suffolk County district attorney said. Jeremy Scileppi, an assistant district attorney, said that Mr. Din wanted Ms. Nohar killed because she did not want to marry him and he feared she would report something that would damage his reputation with the Police Department. He faces 8 1/3 to 25 years in prison when he is sentenced later this month.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he intended to veto a bill that would prohibit the use of metal bats in high school baseball games. “I don’t know whether aluminum bats are more dangerous or less dangerous” than wooden bats, the mayor said. “I have had friends who are professional baseball players call me and argue both ways, but I don’t think it’s the city’s business to regulate that.” The Council passed the bill on March 14 by a vote of 40 to 6; 34 votes would be required to override a veto. The bill’s main sponsor, Councilman James S. Oddo, said, “We’ll have a second vote, and there will be a second opportunity for the City Council to stand up on behalf of the kids.”.
Two former teammates from Murry Bergtraum High in Lower Manhattan will face off against each other in the women’s N.C.A.A. final.

After four days on the stand, the primary witness in a judicial bribery case finished his direct testimony yesterday, describing a series of gifts and cash payments made in exchange for legal assignments and favorable rulings. The defendant, Gerald Garson, a former State Supreme Court justice who oversaw matrimonial cases, has been charged with accepting bribes. The witness, a disbarred divorce lawyer named Paul Siminovsky, left, testified that he paid for meals for the judge and gave him a bottle of Scotch and other gifts as well as an envelope holding $1,000. On a surveillance recording played in State Supreme Court yesterday, the judge was seen accepting the money, then counting it and muttering profanities. On the recording, the judge returned the money and asked that it be given to his wife’s political campaign. Mr. Siminovsky gave the money back to the judge, clapping his arm and saying, “Don’t worry about it.” Mr. Siminovsky has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor.
Dr. Greisen was a physicist who helped broaden methods of studying cosmic rays, including sending unmanned balloons into the upper atmosphere.
In what was not a particularly well-kept secret, Gov. Jon S. Corzine officially endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president.
Two former executives also will pay fines to settle charges that the company exploited a Medicare loophole.
For David Murin, a professor of costume design at Rutgers University, nothing beats the excitement of having been selected costume designer for the circus.

Dana Altman was hired as Arkansas’s men’s basketball coach yesterday, ending the Razorbacks’ weeklong search to replace Stan Heath.

The Tribune Company announced it would sell the Cubs later this year as part of the company’s overall sale to the Chicago billionaire Sam Zell.
General Manager Lou Lamoriello will replace Claude Julien on the New Jersey bench with less than a week to go in the regular season.

All those critics who said that Kansas City overpaid for Gil Meche may be hard to find now. In his first start since signing a five-year, $55 million contract, Meche outdueled Curt Schilling yesterday and pitched the host Royals to a 7-1 victory against the Boston Red Sox on opening day.
The bidding lasted less than four minutes. The rare Stradivarius violin went for a high — but not a record — price of $2.4 million.

AT&T and its Mexican affiliate, América Móvil, have bid more than $6 billion for control of Italy’s largest cellphone company, Telecom Italia.

AIR TAXIS ADVANCE DayJet, a Florida-based company, took delivery of three Eclipse 500 very light jets on Saturday as it geared up to start air taxi service by the summer. With 239 orders for the $1.5 million jets, DayJet is Eclipse’s largest customer. DayJet plans to begin its on-demand service on routes of 300 to 600 miles in Florida, and expand later throughout the Southeast, using regional and community airports rather than major commercial airports. Eclipse, with more than 2,500 orders for its 500 model, is one of more than half a dozen manufacturers making very light jets. About 5,000 of the new planes will be operating within 10 years, the Federal Aviation Administration has said.
Temperature may be the key to solving one of the drawbacks to kidney dialysis, a new study suggests.

(22, 26) KINGS OF CAMOUFLAGE They may sound more “Star Trek” than sea life, but cuttlefish, above, can impersonate the opposite sex; change their shape and color to blend in with their environment; and kill faster than you can say “beam me up.” This “Nova” special goes in depth to see how intelligent these versatile beings are.

Here are four views of the climate divide. Twice a day, 25-year-old Harold Nkhoma checks a series of gauges at the government's weather station here in Malawi's second-biggest city. He skips the barometer because its light doesn't work and he can't read the figures. He has waited six months for new batteries.

Casey Motter, a termite inspector from Peachtree City, Ga., with a touch of a Southern accent, has been named the Atlanta Braves' public-address announcer. He will be behind the microphone when the Mets play the Braves at Turner Field on Friday in Atlanta's home opener. Frank Wren, an assistant general manager with the Braves, heard Motter announcing a youth league football game in November. Wren turned his video camera to the press box and recorded Motter.

COTTERILL--Charles. After a long courageous battle with cancer, passed away peacefully at home on February 9th, 2007. Born in England, there he earned degrees in Geology and Engineering. In 1960 he came to New York City and earned advanced degrees from Columbia in Mathematics and NYU in finance. He worked for American Express for 22 years, then as consultant for many other firms, lastly for Morgan Stanley. In retirement, he wrote a book ''Investment Performance Mathematics'', and devoted himself to environmental causes and protection of the Palisades Cliffs. He is survived by his devoted wife Sylvia, loving son Camille. His vast knowledge, talents, kindness and helpfulness will be missed by all, friends and relatives. Memorial Services will be held on Tuesday April 17th, 2007 at 3:00pm at Trinity the Church located on Broadway and Wall Street in New YorkCity.

Statewide surveys conducted by Quinnipiac University in Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania reveal that a significant number of voters do not yet have opinions of Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, and Mitt Romney, the former Republican governor of Massachusetts. Democratic voters have a more favorable impression of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York than they do of John Edwards, the former North Carolina senator. Republican voters have more favorable views of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor, than they do of Senator John McCain of Arizona.

NBC's weekend anchor, John Seigenthaler, above right, announced on his Sunday night newscast that he is leaving the network after 11 years there. Another prominent name from television news, Jeff Greenfield, below right, is leaving CNN for CBS, where he will be a senior political correspondent. CBS made Mr. Greenfield's appointment official yesterday. It was reported last week in The Washington Post. Mr. Seigenthaler had been the anchor for NBC's weekend newscast since 1999 and had also worked occasionally for NBC's cable news channel MSNBC. But executives at NBC News have said for some time that they have been looking for areas where it can combine jobs. Mr. Seigenthaler, who was well regarded by most of the executives at NBC News, had not been working on many assignments beyond the weekend anchor duties. His contract was expiring, and NBC declined to renew it. Mr. Seigenthaler did not announce any plans for future work, and NBC News has not yet chosen a replacement for him on the weekend anchor desk. But one senior NBC executive said it is likely whoever replaces Mr. Seigenthaler will have a number of other jobs in the news division. In signing on at CBS, where he will work on coverage of the 2008 presidential campaign, Mr. Greenfield will return to network television, where he was based for 20 years before joining CNN in 1998. Mr. Greenfield worked at CBS News from 1979 to 1983 before joining ABC News, where he worked until joining CNN. BILL CARTER

A caption on Saturday with a picture showing a Pakistani man on his bicycle carrying a painting of his son, who he says was abducted by Pakistani intelligence agents in 2001, misspelled the name of the Pakistani capital. It is Islamabad, not Islambad.

BOYER--Renee S. In memory of my mother, who died suddenly at Lenox Hill Hospital on April 3rd, 2006. Remembered as a gifted student and piano player, loving daughter and mother, and always as an animal lover, caring for many animals during her lifetime in Murray Hill. Rest in peace, you are dearly missed.

HAVIVI--Rita, died March 30, at home, at peace, surrounded by family. Born in Bialystock, Poland, in 1916, educated in France and the U.S., Rita served in intelligence in Panama during World War II. Fluent in nine languages, she later taught French and Russian in public school; her love of sharing knowledge pervaded everything she did. She retired as an archivist from the Frick Museum in October after 24 years, upon completing a major project on Romanesque sculpture. She was familiar with Renaissance and modern art, music from Baroque to Stravinsky, European history and literature; she joyfully articulated tightly reasoned opinions on any topic. She leaves her loving sister Rhoda Salter, nephews, nieces and their children, many dear friends, and a slightly diminished New York.

Over the last few decades, as scientists have intensified their study of the human effects on climate and of the effects of climate change on humans, a common theme has emerged: in both respects, the world is a very unequal place. In almost every instance, the people most at risk from climate change live in countries that have contributed the least to the atmospheric buildup of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases linked to the recent warming of the planet.

To the Editor: Re ''Trafficker or Healer? And Who's the Victim?'' (Findings, March 27): As a primary care physician who now practices partly in a hospice setting, I have gone from eyeing every request for opiates with suspicion to viewing pain assessment as ''the fifth vital sign'' to educating that there is no absolute upper limit to opiate dosing to relieve suffering.
SATZ--Marvin. Pals since First Grade. Smart and Witty, he will be sorely missed. Larry and Helene

HEWETT--W. Walter, III, 70, passed away on March 22, 2007 after complications from surgery. A life-long resident of Augusta, GA and Manhattan, he was the son of the late Nell Pope Hewett and William Walter Hewett Sr. A graduate of Georgetown University, Mr. Hewett was cofounder of MELTAWAY, which operates private in-home nutrition and well-being seminars throughout the Southeast. In New York, he worked with Greenleigh Associates and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. He was the author of two cookbooks focusing on weight control and behavior modification. Graveside services will be held on Tuesday, April 10th, 11am at Westover Cemetery in Augusta. Contact Thomas Poteet & Son at 706-364-8484 for details.
