Looking out over a sparkling blue bay on Australia's west coast, Gary Crisp, an alchemist for the new century, saw an ocean of drinking water. Behind him was an industrial park filled with tanks, pipes, screens, filters and chemicals for converting seawater into drinking water -- 17 percent of the water supply for this city of 1.5 million people.

NOALL--Roger, of New York City and Naples, FL, died suddenly on March 29, 2007, in Naples at the age of 71. He was born on April 1, 1935, to the late Albert Edward Noall and Mabel Sorenson Noall in Brigham City, UT. He graduated from the University of Utah in 1955 in two years with Honors. He completed his LL.B. from Harvard Law School in 1958 where he was a member of the Harvard Law Review and graduated cum laude. In 1959, he completed his LL.M. at the New York University Law School; and in 1973, completed an Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Business School. From 1959 to 1967, Roger practiced law in New York primarily at the firm of Olwine, Connelly, Chase, O'Donnell & Weyher where he became a Partner in 1965. From 1967 to 1983, he worked at Bunge Corporation, an agribusiness where he held positions including Director, Executive Vice President, Treasurer, and Controller. From 1983 to his retirement, Roger worked in Cleveland for various bank holding companies including Centran Corporation and Society Corporation. He retired in 2000 from KeyCorp where he held a variety of executive positions including Senior Executive Vice President, Chief Administrative Officer, and General Counsel and Secretary. He served on several boards, most recently for Alleghany Corporation and Victory Capital Management. A man of many diverse interests, Roger completed 13 NYC Marathons, summited Mt. Kilimanjaro, hiked extensively in Africa and Europe, and played tennis and backgammon throughout his life. His passions were dedicated to books, lifelong learning, world travel, and the arts and, most importantly, to the enjoyment of his family and his many friends. Roger is survived by his devoted wife, Colleen Mannion Noall; his sons, Brennan Courtney (Kelly) Noall of Ft. Myers, FL and Tyler Grey (Alison) Noall of Cleveland, OH; five grandchildren, Rachel, Weston, Madison, Lauren, and Dylan; his sister, Ruth Noall (Flint) Dickson; and his brother, David (Pat) Noall, both of Salt Lake City, UT. He will be missed by all those whose lives he touched. Contributions in Roger's memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders or the New York Central Park Conservancy. A private celebration of Roger's life will be held in New York at a later date. $(6$)NOALL--Roger. The best and the brightest. A man for all seasons. We will always have warm memories of his enthusiasm, generous spirit, and our many good times together. We will miss him. Phyllis and Murray Warschauer

WEISER--Joel, passed away on March 31st, 2007. Predeceased by his beloved son and our brother, Gary. He is survived by his beloved wife Muriel, his son Bernard, daughter Gertrude, grandchildren David, Sheri, Laurie, and Cindy, and his greatgranddaughters Lauren and Rachel. He will be missed and cherished in our hearts forever.

FLANAGAN - FARRELL-Kathryn Veronica. Kathryn Coady moved through many names in life. Her favorites were Mother and MaMere: Mother to nine, MaMere to 30. To the world, she was Mrs. Flanagan, or Mrs. Flanagan-Farrell, or simply Kate. Let's remember her like that: simply Kate. Kate died of complications from pneumonia on Friday, March 30, in Fairfax, Virginia. Surrounded by her family, she passed with the dignity and strength her generation inspired. She is sleeping now, at 81. Her graceful trip is done. Kate's story is the story of a century. She grew up in Greenwich Village in the 1930s, the daughter of FDNY fire chief Captain John Coady and Cassie O'Brien. One of nine children, Kate met Luis John Flanagan shortly after finishing high school and said ''yes'' when he proposed to her on the Staten Island Ferry, on the same day he graduated from West Point. Barely 18 at the time, Kate waited with her first son until Luis came home wounded from the Battle of the Bulge. After good years in Bridgehampton, NY, and Quincy, MA, Luis accepted a teaching position at the United States Military Academy in 1950. At West Point, Kate raised her nine children, for many years in a white house across the street from the cemetery, a cemetery that filled all too quickly as USMA classes of 1966, 1967, 1968 made their silent return. She raised her kids with elegance and a strong grip, and more than anything she believed in them. She was on their side. Her response when a teacher sent one of her children home with a poor grade? ''Well, she must not know you like I do.'' In 1975, Luis passed after a battle with cancer, and Kate became a single mom. A single mom with three daughters still at home and four little grandchildren already calling her MaMere. A son already at West Point and another headed in that direction. Undeterred, she found a job and bought a redbrick house and began her twelve years as a cadet hostess, grooming homesick cadets for life in the real world. She woke up every morning and drank her coffee and found a way. In 1982, Kate married Edward Leo Farrell, a longtime family friend who fought alongside Luis in World War II. In love again, Kate and Ed travelled to Europe, boated the Hudson, and spent their summers in Cape Cod. Kate turned in her station wagon for a convertible. Ed found a second chance at fatherhood. Widower and widow discovered a new life, and they were happy. When Ed died in 1998, Kate returned to her childhood home of New York City. With flair and a sense of humor, the city girl had returned to her roots for one last show. She would walk to the park and entertain grandchildren visiting her on the upper east side. She would go shopping with her daughters and laugh at the wonder of it all. She often confessed how amazed she was to have started ''all this'' -nine children, thirty grandchildren and now four greatgrandchildren. Our message to her, now that she is gone: there can only ever be one you, Kathryn Coady. And for all of us, you are still here and dancing up a storm. Kathryn is survived by her nine children: Brian Flanagan of Southport, NC; Deirdre FlanaganGaugash of Annapolis, MD; Cassie Sullivan of Fairfax, VA; Patricia Tenney of Ridgefield, CT; Timothy Flanagan of Roxbury, CT; Brendan Flanagan of Peach Tree City, GA; Meaghen FlanaganLeidig of Landenburg, PA; Sheelagh Flanagan of San Francisco, CA; and Brigid Flanagan of New York City, NY. Funeral services will be held on Monday April 9, 2007 at 10:00am at The Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the US Military Academy West Point New York. Interment to follow at the Post Cemetery West Point, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Uniformed Fire Fighters Association, Attention: Sheila Pettit, 204 East 23rd St. 5th floor, NY, NY 10010.

To the Editor: Re ''Scientists Hope Vigilance Stymies Avian Flu Mutations'' (March 27): Several important concerns should keep avian flu on our radar. First, as stated, the virus is continually changing, so at no point in this ongoing process is a potentially pandemic form less likely to surface. Second, the threat does not end with H5N1 in birds. There are many potentially dangerous versions of avian influenza.

An entry in the News Summary yesterday, about increased pressure by the White House to persuade Iran to release a group of British sailors and marines, misstated the number being held. It is eight sailors and seven marines -- not a total of eight sailors and marines.

Aided by ''Cold Case'' and ''60 Minutes,'' CBS won the title of most watched network on Sunday, but ABC surged ahead for the night among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Cold Case'' drew the night's largest audience with 13.1 million viewers, dominating the 10 p.m. hour. CBS's veteran newsmagazine ''60 Minutes'' also won the 7 p.m. hour with 11.4 million viewers, but an extended double episode of CBS's ''Amazing Race: All Stars'' averaged 9 million viewers, finishing third in both the 8 and 9 o'clock hours. Among adults 18 to 49, ABC remained on top with its lineup of an ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' rerun at 8 (9.8 million), followed by a ''Desperate Housewives'' clip show at 9 (9.8 million) and a new episode of ''Brothers & Sisters'' at 10 (9.1 million). Fox ranked third in the 18-to-49 demographic although new episodes of ''King of the Hill'' at 8:30 (6.3 million) and ''American Dad'' at 9:30 (5.9 million) finished first in their time slots among adults 18 to 34. NBC was fourth among those 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

SHEEHAN--Philip T. (Skip), 76, on March 31. Born August 31, 1930, Skip, a graduate of Brooklyn Prep and Manhattan College, spent his career in banking, starting with the Irving Trust Company in 1956. Skip's sense of humor and easy laughter enlivened many family gatherings, where he loved to reminisce about Brooklyn and summers at the Reservation in Long Branch. Skip's family often said he was a gentleman, which he truly was -gentle man who laughed often and rarely said a harsh word. He will be sorely missed. The 10th of 14 children of George and Loretto Sheehan, Skip is survived by his sisters, Sister Mary Sheehan, RSCJ, Fran Fountain, Liz Sheehan, and his brother, Mike. He is also survived by his son Rome and his wife Maria, his daughter Traci and her husband Chris Van Thull, his daughter Susan and her husband Ted Ferguson, his son Tim and his wife Sarah, and eight grandchildren. John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ, is in charge of services.

Yesterday's Supreme Court ruling on carbon dioxide emissions largely shredded the underpinning of other lawsuits trying to block regulation of the emissions and gave new momentum to Congressional efforts to control heat-trapping gases linked to climate change. Environmental groups and states that have adopted controls on carbon dioxide emissions from vehicle tailpipes responded with jubilation, while the auto industry and some of its backers, like Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, offered statements of resigned disappointment.

Representative Tom Tancredo, a Colorado Republican who has challenged his party to take a stronger stance against illegal immigration, formally declared his presidential candidacy here on Monday. Mr. Tancredo held no rallies and delivered no political speeches on his first day as an official candidate. Instead, he made his announcement on Iowa's most prominent conservative radio talk show, saying he was entering the race because no other Republicans were going to make illegal immigration ''the primary issue of their campaign.''

The Chicago Cubs' 2007 marketing slogan exclaims, ''Play Like There's No Tomorrow!'' That will be literally true this season for the Tribune Company, which announced yesterday that it would sell the Cubs, its storied subsidiary, later this year as part of the company's overall sale to the Chicago billionaire Sam Zell. The company did not reveal any prospective ownership groups, only that it planned to complete the transaction after the 2007 season. The end of the season usually comes before the October playoffs for the Cubs, who have not won a World Series since 1908 or participated in one since 1945.

Year after year, the Baghmati river swells with the rains and, rushing down from the Himalayas, submerges this back-of-beyond village into utter ruin. Year after year, it sweeps away cattle and goats. It sends mud houses collapsing back into the earth. It kills dozens of people in and around Dhanaur, and that's during a mild monsoon, like last year, when Pavan Devi's 19-year-old son, Vikas Kumar, went to a communal toilet in the fields and was swept away by a fast-moving stream.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Iraqis Say McCain's View Of Security Is Inaccurate After an American Congressional delegation led by Senator John McCain pointed to their visit to Baghdad's central market as evidence that the new security plan was working, the merchants there said they were incredulous about the Americans' conclusions. A1 Visits to Iraq have become a required part of the political wardrobe for lawmakers in the debate over the future of the war. They have brought up these visits, wielding their experiences to bolster their cases. According to the Pentagon, as of mid-March, 365 members of Congress had visited the country since May 2003. A12 Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the most powerful Shiite cleric in Iraq, has rejected an American-backed proposal to allow thousands of former members of the Baath Party of Saddam Hussein to return to government service, an aide to the cleric said. A12 5 Peacekeepers Dead in Darfur Five African Union peacekeepers were killed in a rebel ambush in Darfur less than a mile from their base along Sudan's border with Chad, the African Union said. A8 No Trial for Britons, Iran Says Iran said that all 15 captured British naval personnel had confessed to intruding illegally into Iranian waters on March 23, when they were detained. But Ali Larijani, Iran's chief negotiator, said in a British television interview that ''there is no need for a trial'' -- a course Tehran had threatened. A13 Ukraine Parliament Disbanded A power-sharing deal in Ukraine collapsed when President Viktor A. Yushchenko ordered the dissolution of Parliament, the base of support for his rival, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, whom the president accused of usurping power. A6 NATIONAL A14-19 E.P.A. Granted Authority To Control Gas Emissions The Supreme Court ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency had the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases in automobile emissions and could not sidestep its authority to regulate the gases that contribute to global climate change unless it can provide a scientific basis for its refusal. A1 The Supreme Court declined to hear urgent appeals from two groups of detainees at Guantánamo Bay who sought to challenge the new law stripping federal judges of the authority to hear challenges to the confinement of foreign citizens designated as enemy combatants. A18 Romney Raised $20 Million Mitt Romney's presidential campaign said that it raised $20 million in the first quarter, tapping two distant but rich networks -- Wall Street and the Mormon church -- to outpace his primary rivals. A1 Debate on Felons' Right to Vote Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida said he hoped to persuade members of his state's cabinet this week to end the practice of stripping all convicted felons of their right to vote. A19 Chicago Police Chief Resigns Police Superintendent Philip J. Cline of Chicago resigned amid a public outcry over the lack of swift disciplinary action against several police officers accused of involvement in two videotaped beatings of residents in the last several months. A15 EDUCATION Loan Company Pays Students Citibank, one of the largest providers of student loans, as well as five universities have agreed to pay $5.2 million to students and the New York State attorney general to resolve an investigation into their student loan practices, Andrew M. Cuomo, the attorney general, announced. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Japanese-Americans Test Ruling in Muslim Case Three relatives of Japanese immigrants interned during World War II are urging a federal appeals court to overturn a Brooklyn judge's ruling, in a lawsuit brought by Muslim immigrants, that the government has wide latitude to detain noncitizens indefinitely on the basis of race, religion or national origin. B1 Manhattan Housing Prices Rise The prices and number of apartments selling in Manhattan rose in the first three months of this year, according to data released by several of the city's largest real estate brokerage firms. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-10 Drugs in the Waterways Residues of birth control pills, antidepressants, painkillers, shampoos and a host of other compounds are finding their way into the nation's waterways, placing public health and environmental officials in a regulatory quandary. F1 Health & Fitness F7 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-8 Florida Repeats as Champion The Florida Gators, seen as one of the best teams in modern college basketball, defeated the Ohio State Buckeyes to become the first team to win consecutive national titles since Duke in 1991 and 1992. D1 ARTS E1-8 Possible Pollock Paintings Sold The discovery of paintings thought to be by Jackson Pollock set off an uproar, and questions about their authenticity may begin reverberating in the art market, as the man who found the paintings has quietly sold some of them. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Tribune to Go Private The Tribune Company, which owns The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune, The Baltimore Sun and other papers, announced that it had joined forces with Samuel Zell, a real estate tycoon, to take the company private. A1 Chapter 11 for Home Lender New Century Financial Corporation, one of the nation's largest mortgage lenders to people with subprime credit during the recent housing boom, filed for Chapter 11 protection in bankruptcy court. To the Editor: Re ''Religion and Truth,'' by Stanley Fish (column, March 31): Just because religious texts make truth claims doesn't mean the Bible shouldn't be studied academically in schools. We need not ''bracket'' those claims any more than we do when we study sociology or chemistry. At the Catholic school where I teach, students explore different traditions and perspectives. One goal is a more thoughtful engagement with their own faith commitments.

Those named by prosecutors as victims of Anthony Pellicano, the Hollywood private eye who faces federal charges of wiretapping and conspiracy, will have to wait six months to move forward with their civil lawsuits. Judge Peter D. Lichtman of Superior Court in Los Angeles issued a stay yesterday until late October of a host of lawsuits by those said to be victims, including the actor Keith Carradine, the screenwriter Bo Zenga and the journalist Anita Busch. The plaintiffs had sought to move ahead, noting that the most recent allegations occurred in 2002 and that witnesses' memories are fading. But lawyers for such civil defendants as the Paramount Pictures chairman, Brad Grey; the entertainment lawyer Bertram Fields; and the phone company argued that they would be severely hamstrung in defending themselves until the conclusion of the criminal trial, now set to begin on Aug. 22. The judge agreed, saying to go ahead now would create ''a judicial nightmare.'' DAVID M. HALBFINGER and ALLISON HOPE WEINER

To the Editor: Re ''Wal-Mart Chief Writes Off New York'' (Business Day, March 28):

Global warming will have highly uneven consequences in rich and poor regions of the world, experts say. Illinois, left, and Malawi, right, both face intensifying droughts. But American farmers have sophisticated devices to predict atmospheric changes; in Malawi, one of the world's poorest countries, weather stations are scattered and technology is out of date or not functioning. Reports from four fronts in the war on warming. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGES F4 AND F5

To the Editor: ''For Girls, It's Be Yourself, and Be Perfect, Too'' (front page, April 1) gets it right in many ways, from the overload of Advanced Placement courses to the whirlwind of extracurricular activities and the importance of being ''effortlessly hot.'' Many of us who gained admission to the so-called elite schools unburdened by the culture of college test-prep services were far less accomplished than these girls, whose achievements are in so many cases truly awesome.

Bill Richardson, the New Mexico governor and Democratic presidential candidate, won the admiration -- and at least one vote -- of a smoky constituency on Monday. ''He's the first candidate to actually sign a medical marijuana bill,'' said Reena Szczepanski, director of the Drug Policy Alliance New Mexico, after Mr. Richardson made New Mexico the 12th state to legalize marijuana for certain medicinal purposes.

A front-page article on Sunday about the experiences of high-achieving high school girls in Newton, Mass., misstated a verb property of Latin, which one of the girls in the article studies. It is the subjunctive mood; there is no subjunctive ''tense.''

He will always remain our finest exemplar of survival, with competence, compassion and humor intact. Our love to his family, especially his wife Ingeborg, whom we love almost as much as he did. Funeral at 9:30am on Thursday, at Plaza, 91st and Amsterdam.

More than a hundred Palestinian journalists and others held a sit-in outside the prime minister's office in Gaza City to demand increased efforts to find Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent abducted there three weeks ago. In the West Bank city of Ramallah, local and international journalists also called on the government to do more. The Palestinian journalists' union declared a three-day news boycott of the government and the office of President Mahmoud Abbas. BBC executives say there has been no information about Mr. Johnston's whereabouts nor any message from his captors saying what they want. ISABEL KERSHNER

Rudolph W. Giuliani's most intense week of campaigning to date, traveling in five states over four days, will begin and end in baseball stadiums. Mr. Giuliani, an avid Yankee fan, attended the team's opening game in New York yesterday afternoon before flying off to New Hampshire, followed by Iowa, Florida and South Carolina. On Thursday, he will throw out the first pitch for the Myrtle Beach Pelicans, a minor league team.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he intended to veto a bill that would prohibit the use of metal bats in high school baseball games. ''I don't know whether aluminum bats are more dangerous or less dangerous'' than wooden bats, the mayor said. ''I have had friends who are professional baseball players call me and argue both ways, but I don't think it's the city's business to regulate that.'' The Council passed the bill on March 14 by a vote of 40 to 6; 34 votes would be required to override a veto. The bill's main sponsor, Councilman James S. Oddo, said, ''We'll have a second vote, and there will be a second opportunity for the City Council to stand up on behalf of the kids.'' SEWELL CHAN

After four days on the stand, the primary witness in a judicial bribery case finished his direct testimony yesterday, describing a series of gifts and cash payments made in exchange for legal assignments and favorable rulings. The defendant, Gerald Garson, a former State Supreme Court justice who oversaw matrimonial cases, has been charged with accepting bribes. The witness, a disbarred divorce lawyer named Paul Siminovsky, left, testified that he paid for meals for the judge and gave him a bottle of Scotch and other gifts as well as an envelope holding $1,000. On a surveillance recording played in State Supreme Court yesterday, the judge was seen accepting the money, then counting it and muttering profanities. On the recording, the judge returned the money and asked that it be given to his wife's political campaign. Mr. Siminovsky gave the money back to the judge, clapping his arm and saying, ''Don't worry about it.'' Mr. Siminovsky has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor. MICHAEL BRICK
SHAPIRO--Amy S., (Klein). Lovingly remembered today and everyday. With much love, your family

To the Editor: Re ''You Can Disinfect a Kitchen Sponge by Microwaving It'' (Really?, March 27): Your article was a real eye-opener, but the suggestion that we simply throw smelly sponges away is another instance of our all-too-wasteful attitude toward consumer goods. A neighbor offered a better alternative to me several years ago: run sponges through the dishwasher every few days. It really works; it would save landfill space, and money, too! Ellen C. Schwartz Ann Arbor, Mich.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Morehouse College and its search for a new president misstated the former position of the college's current president, Walter E. Massey. Dr. Massey was a director of the National Science Foundation, not of the National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,239 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday: ARNETTE, Jason R., 24, Staff Sgt., Army; Amelia, Va.; 10th Mountain Division. FLORES, Wilfred Jr., 20, Specialist, Army; Lawton, Okla.; 10th Mountain Division.

The National Football League has postponed the preseason game between New England and Seattle that was scheduled for Beijing this summer, choosing instead to focus on the first regular-season game to be played outside North America. That game, between the Giants and Miami, will be played Oct. 28 in London. Staging two games overseas in less than three months threatened to stretch the resources of the N.F.L. The China game was rescheduled for 2009. JUDY BATTISTA

REILLEY--Elizabeth Kals. The Board, staff, and friends of The New York Botanical Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of Elizabeth Kals Reilley, garden lover, bibliophile, and librarian. She donated to the Botanical Garden her collection of more than 400 of the most important publications on European landscape design from the late Renaissance on. Featured in a 2003 special exhibition, European Pleasure Gardens, the Elizabeth Kals Reilley Collection continues to be available in the Gardens LuEsther T. Mertz Library for pleasure and study. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Wilson Nolen, Chairman of the Board Gregory Long, President Susan Fraser, Director, LuEsther T. Mertz Library

A graphic on Friday with an article about fund-raising for the 2008 presidential campaign referred incompletely to candidates this year who also sought their party's nomination in 2004. Dennis Kucinich, who is seeking the Democratic nomination, also ran last time; John Edwards, another Democrat, is not the only such candidate.

Q. Is it dangerous if you accidentally wake a sleepwalker? A. ''The short answer is no,'' said Dr. Charles Pollack, director of the Center for Sleep Medicine at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell, but it depends on circumstances. ''Is it a child or an adult?'' Dr. Pollack asked. ''It is not especially dangerous to wake a sleepwalker, except that in the throes of sleep, a person is groggy and risks a fall. Be sure to supervise him until he returns to quiet sleep.''

New Jersey Transit yesterday named Richard R. Sarles Sr. as its new executive director. Since 2002, Mr. Sarles has managed the agency's $1.3 billion annual capital program and its three light rail lines. Before that, he worked at Amtrak directing the Northeast Corridor High-Speed Rail program. One of Mr. Sarles's top priorities will be to oversee New Jersey Transit's drive to build a second passenger rail tunnel under the Hudson River. He will also inherit a planned 9.6 percent fare increase, which is expected to go into effect on June 1. Mr. Sarles succeeds George Warrington, who said he was leaving to pursue other opportunities. KEN BELSON

To the Editor: After Katrina, we got a clear view of the magnitude of the scourge that is the plastic bag (Week in Review, April 1). After the 20-to-30-foot surge of water that swept ashore, surveyors were sent out to determine the high-water mark at various locations. One indicator they used was the line of plastic bags in the trees. Jim Dishun Ocean Springs, Miss., April 1, 2007

The 'Phantom' Strikes Again The dictionary defines ''phantom'' as something that seems to appear to the sight but has no physical existence. Tell that to the actors, musicians and stagehands at the Majestic Theater, where ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' the longest-running show in Broadway history, will hit the 8,000-performance milestone at its matinee tomorrow. The Andrew Lloyd Webber Tony Award-winning musical about a furtive masked figure smitten with a young soprano at the Paris Opera House will observe the occasion with a special presentation during the curtain call, and the cast and crew will celebrate with a private party. Since its debut on Broadway on Jan. 26, 1988, the show has been seen by 11 million people in New York and grossed nearly $645 million, according to a press representative. The worldwide box-office take was put at $3.2 billion. Nelly Furtado's Weekend The pop singer Nelly Furtado was the big winner (and the host) when the Junos, Canada's equivalent of the Grammys, were awarded in Toronto on Sunday, Reuters reported. Ms. Furtado, 28, above, took the prizes for best single, best album and fans' choice, after winning for artist and pop album the night before. Bob Rock, the Canadian rocker-turned-producer, was inducted into the Canadian Music Hall of Fame for his work with bands including Metallica, Aerosmith and Mötley Crüe. Up and Coming in Germany With 150 works by Cézanne, Monet, Gauguin and Rodin, among others, a major exhibition of 19th-century French art from the Metropolitan Museum of Art is to open in Berlin on June 1 at the Neue Nationalgalerie, the Berlin tourism board announced yesterday, The Associated Press reported. Organizers of the show, to run through Oct. 7, hope to achieve the success attained at the same museum in 2004, when 1.2 million visitors turned out for an exhibition drawn from the collection of the Museum of Modern Art. The 18th-century Staatsoper opera house, top, in Berlin is expected to undergo three years of major renovation beginning in 2010, The Associated Press reported. ''Everything must be taken out,'' said Peter Mussbach, the general manager. ''This is a gigantic task.'' Gutted at the end of World War II and reopened by East German authorities in 1955, the house was last renovated in 1986. In 2002 a hydraulic stage elevator collapsed during a performance of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni.'' Mr. Mussbach said that during renovations, expected to cost $174 million, operas would be staged at an alternative site, but he declined to specify where. In Hamburg, Germany, the foundation stone was laid yesterday for the new Elbe Philharmonic concert hall, bottom left, a $322 million structure designed by the Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron and scheduled for completion in 2010, The Associated Press reported. The 360-foot-tall futuristic complex is atop an old coffee warehouse on a spit of land jutting into the Elbe at one end of Hamburg's busy harbor. It will feature two concert halls, one with 2,150 seats; the other, 550, as well as a luxury hotel, bars and restaurants, apartments and a viewing platform.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a high-definition video projection system that can put an actor's image on stage next to him omitted the opening date for the play ''Losing Something,'' which will mark the first use of the system by an American theater company. Previews begin tonight at the 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, and the official opening is Friday.

SHERMAN--Judge Ralph, passed away April 1, 2007, 90, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Queens. A New York State Supreme Court Justice, Queens County. Loving husband of Lillian for 67 years; adored father of Jeffrey (Melissa), Richard (Karen) and Robyn (John) Holzer; cherished grandfather of Gennifer, Lindsay, Chad, Courtney and Skylar; beloved brother of Sydney. Services Thursday April 5, 2007 10am at ''Guttermans'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury.

A Clinton Township police officer was arrested yesterday on a gun charge after he took a shotgun from a relative's house and headed for Somerset County in his truck, the county prosecutor's office said. Around 10:30 a.m., a countywide alert was issued for the officer, Jason Peltack, after a friend called the police and told them that the officer had taken a 12-gauge shotgun from a home in Bridgewater. As a precaution, the prosecutor's office ordered Immaculata High School in Somerville to be locked down for about an hour, said Wayne J. Forrest, the Somerset County prosecutor. Mr. Forrest would not say why the school was thought to be in danger or how the officer had planned to use the gun. Officer Peltack, 27, was arrested around 11:20 a.m. in Raritan and charged with a fourth-degree firearms offense. He was placed on paid medical leave and ordered to undergo a psychological evaluation, the authorities said. JOHN HOLL

The rape convictions of a Buffalo man incarcerated for more than 21 years were vacated yesterday, five days after prosecutors announced that newly discovered evidence had linked another man to the attacks. The man, Anthony Capozzi, 50, was not in court for the hearing, during which Judge Shirley Troutman of Erie County Court ordered his release. Mr. Capozzi, who is schizophrenic and is being treated at a state prison hospital in Marcy, was convicted of two rapes in the early 1980s. He was released after prosecutors said that another man's DNA matched the DNA samples from the rapes. That man, Altemio Sanchez, cannot be charged with the rapes because of the statute of limitations, which was five years at the time, prosecutors said. Mr. Sanchez has been charged with three murders in the Buffalo area since 1990. He has pleaded not guilty. DAVID STABA

An article yesterday about First Data, the credit-card processing company that is near a deal to be acquired by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, misidentified in some copies the payment network controlled by First Data. It is the STAR network, not the NYCE.

E.P.A. AUTHORITY IS UPHELD -- In a rebuke of Bush administration policy, the Supreme Court has ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases in automobile emissions. [Page A1.] THE TRIBUNE COMPANY IS SOLD The Tribune Company, the owner of 23 television stations and newspapers like The Chicago Tribune and The Los Angeles Times, has agreed to a sale to Samuel Zell, the Chicago real estate mogul, for $8.2 billion. [A1.] BUT WHAT ABOUT LOS ANGELES? -- What happens now to The Los Angeles Times, which has been a huge thorn in the side of Tribune? [C1.] ANALYZING THE SALE -- Taking Tribune private will ease quarterly earnings pressures, but operational challenges remain. The Media Equation: David Carr. [C1.] FINANCING THE SALE -- Employee stock ownership plans of the sort being used to buy Tribune have not always worked out as hoped. [C4.] FOR SALE: CHICAGO CUBS -- As part of the Tribune deal, the Chicago Cubs will be sold. One of the potential buyers could be Mark Cuban, owner of the N.B.A.'s Dallas Mavericks. [D1.] GOOGLE TO SELL TV ADS -- Google plans to begin selling television ads on all national satellite channels on EchoStar's Dish Network, bringing its online advertising technology to new markets. Google's chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, above, said the company thought it could ''add value to this important medium by delivering more relevant ads to viewers.'' [C3.] LENDER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY -- The New Century Financial Corporation, a prominent player in the subprime mortgage business, filed for Chapter 11 protection in the federal bankruptcy court in Delaware. [C1.] FREMONT GENERAL AUDITOR RESIGNS -- The auditor for Fremont General, another seller of subprime mortgages, has resigned. [C9.] A SWITCH BY EMI -- EMI Group, the British music giant, has decided to sell songs online through Apple's music service without copy protection, a significant shift in how copyrighted music will be sold in the iPod era. [C1.] A GREAT YEAR FOR AIRLINES? -- An airline trade group says industry profit will be $4 billion this year. But some analysts think the industry could top the record of about $5.4 billion in profit, set in 1999. [C3.] BIG TRADE DEAL WITH SOUTH KOREA -- If ratified by Congress, a new trade deal reached between the United States and South Korea would end tariffs on more than 90 percent of the product categories traded between the countries. [C1.] XEROX BUYS A RIVAL -- Xerox will purchase Global Imaging Systems, which sells printers and copiers, for $1.5 billion as it seeks to expand its reach in the small and midsize business markets. The deal is Xerox's third and largest in the last 12 months as it tries to increase growth in equipment revenue. [C11.] VERDICT IS OVERTURNED -- A jury verdict in favor of a whistle-blower who charged that the Kerr-McGee Corporation cheated the government out of millions of dollars in royalties for oil and gas pumped from publicly owned coastal waters has been overturned. [C3.] STARWOOD CHIEF RESIGNS -- Steven J. Heyer has resigned as chief executive of Starwood Hotels and Resorts after he and the board clashed over his management style. [C2.] AEROFLOT BIDS FOR ALITALIA -- Aeroflot, the Russian national airline, has made an unexpected offer for all or part of Italy's national airline, Alitalia. [C8.] STEM CELLS PATENTS IMPERILED -- Three basic patents on stems cells have been revoked in a preliminary decision by United States Patent and Trademark Office, an action that could ease limits on research in the field. [C2.] MANUFACTURING GROWTH DECLINES -- Manufacturing growth slowed more than expected last month and the cost of raw materials rose adding to concern that inflation is not declining as the economy slows. [C11.] BID FOR CELLPHONE COMPANY -- AT&T and a Mexican affiliate have bid more than $6 billion for control of Italy's largest cellphone company. [C11.] EUROPEAN ENERGY DEAL COMPLETED -- The German energy giant E.On has withdrawn its offer for the Spanish utility Endesa in favor of a deal where rival bidders would sell E.On part of Endesa's assets. [C3.] LOSING A PERSONAL DEVICE -- Business travelers tired from being on the road can and do lose their personal electronic devices, which can be a unpleasant experience. Not to mention that once lost, the gadgets are rarely recovered. [C6.] ONLINE BIOMET OFFICIAL RESIGNS -- Another Biomet executive resigns after an inquiry into the backdating of stock options. That report and more are in a special section on executive pay at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. TENET HEALTHCARE, one of the largest United States health care companies, agreed Monday to pay a $10 million civil penalty to settle charges that it failed to disclose that its earnings growth from 1999 to 2002 was driven by its exploitation of a loophole in the Medicare reimbursement system. (DOW JONES/AP)

To the Editor: Re ''A Rail System (and Patience) Stretched Thin in Chicago'' (news article, March 26): The cataclysmic struggles of Chicago's El system are a mere glimpse into the enormous infrastructure challenges facing cities all over the country.

Citibank, one of the largest providers of student loans, as well as five universities have agreed to pay $5.2 million to students and the New York State attorney general to resolve an investigation into student loan practices, Andrew M. Cuomo, the attorney general, announced yesterday. Citibank, which at year's end had $33.7 billion in student loans outstanding, agreed to pay $2 million into a fund to educate students and parents about student loans.

To the Editor: Re ''A Tale of Power and Intrigue in the Lab, Based on Real Life'' (March 27): While certainly not condoning the murder of faculty mentors by their graduate students, I can appreciate the frustration that a student must feel, particularly after a long time in graduate school, when his hopes for an advanced degree are dashed. When I was a graduate in the late '40s, the path was clear. First, candidacy exams were taken, and then qualifying exams to see whether the student could proceed to the Ph.D. or be satisfied with an M.S.
The most powerful Shiite cleric in Iraq has rejected a proposal to allow former Baath Party members to return to government. Page A12.

A snapshot of a segment of opera's next generation, with elements of randomness in the composition: that's the most the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions Grand Finals concert can actually hope to offer. The 11 finalists who sang onstage at the Metropolitan Opera on Sunday afternoon had been culled from some 1,500 singers in four rounds of national competition. The six winners took home $15,000 each; the five others, runner-up prizes of $5,000. All got the same boost of singing with the Met orchestra, on the Met stage, for an enthusiastic audience; for most of them, this will lead to new professional opportunities, though there are no instant tickets to a big career. Were they the best young singers in America? Probably not. Some were excellent. Some were all right. No competition is definitive: rather than achievement, the judges can only evaluate a given singer's performance on a given day.

Hiram Williams spoke yesterday to his brother, Bernie, who played so gracefully with the Yankees for the past 16 seasons. Hiram could hear the disappointment in Bernie's voice and could understand why it was a draining day for a baseball player who no longer has a team. It was opening day at Yankee Stadium, a time for the fans to rekindle their love affair with Derek Jeter and the rest. But Bernie Williams, who had been part of that relationship for almost two decades, was absent. The man who does not want to play for anyone except the Yankees watched the game on television.

Khalid Latif, 24, an imam who has served as a chaplain and adviser at Princeton University and New York University, was appointed yesterday as chaplain for Muslim members of the Police Department. Mr. Latif, who holds a master's degree from Hartford Seminary, is the second Muslim to join the Christian and Jewish clergy members in the department's chaplains' unit. He succeeds Izak-El M. Pasha, a spiritual leader to thousands of black Muslims, who retired a year ago. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the number of Muslims in the department was ''in the thousands.'' THOMAS J. LUECK

To the Editor: ''From Ashes of Yukos, New Russian Oil Giant Emerges'' (news article, March 27), about the politically motivated expropriation of Yukos and the current rigged ''sale'' of its assets, did not mention that the renationalization of the company sanctioned by President Vladimir V. Putin did not simply affect the company's now-imprisoned billionaire chief executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky. It is surely of equal importance that Yukos was a publicly traded company listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with thousands of individual shareholders around the world.

DORAN--Frances Elizabeth, on April 1, 2007 of Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of the late John A. Dear mother of Mary Jane Milton, Kathleen Kelly, John A. Doran Jr., Dennis Doran, Patricia Chlupsa, Suzanne Lynch, Eileen Brower, William Doran and Timothy Doran. Also survived by 30 grandchildren and 14 greatgrandchildren. Calling hours at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Tuesday 3-5 and 79pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday 11:30am, St. Mary's R.C. Church Manhasset, with interment to follow in St. Charles Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to The Little Village House 150 Pt. Washington Blvd., Manhasset, NY 11030.

Anne van der Molen lives on the edge of the River Maas, by definition an insecure spot in a country constantly trying to keep water at bay. But she is ready for the next flood. Excited, even. ''We haven't floated,'' she said of her house, ''but we're looking forward to floating.''

To the Editor: Re ''In Defense of Day Laborers'' (editorial, March 28): Last July, after a yearlong study, the League of Women Voters of the Hamptons adopted a position in support of the establishment of a hiring center for day laborers in the Hamptons. We did so based upon the belief that such a center is a humane response to day-laborer hiring practices and that such a center will reduce traffic congestion and provide a safe and clean environment where an orderly hiring process can take place.

For a governor with a penchant for numbers, the calculus seemed apt: two backbenchers, one presidential candidate, and an endorsement. When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Gov. Jon S. Corzine began their careers as elected officials in the United States Senate ranked 97th and 98th in seniority, they sat near each other in the back with all the other freshmen.
By JENNY ANDERSON

The predominant topic this week has been fund-raising: candidates have reported their totals for the first quarter of 2007, from Senator John McCain's $12 million to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's $26 million. Posts below explore who raised what where, and who didn't. Now, which issue do you think the candidates need to address?

Chris Webb, trends and exterior color designer for General Motors, has the daunting task of developing colors for all G.M. vehicles. Hopping from car to car throughout G.M.'s auto show displays, the energetic Mr. Webb gave a fascinating and rapid-fire explanation of paint trends and technology. For example, did you know that many show cars - including a bright orange Camaro concept car here in New York - use special dyes to create a deeper tone? Problem is, he said, those dyes are "U.V. unstable" and fade in as little as six months.
URBANDALE -- Mitt Romney, conducting a telephone conference call with potential Iowa caucus-goers tonight, told them he considered Jesus Christ to be his "personal savior."
The Times's Jeremy Peters takes a look at the new Mercedes-Benz C-Class.

On Monday afternoon, I walked to lunch wearing flip-flops, a T-shirt and jeans. This morning, as I played tourist during an excursion to the Gateway Arch with some colleagues (and where I ran into Tom Glavine in the gift shop) I needed a sweater, my North Face fleece and gloves - and was still cold. The weather in St. Louis has been odd, to say the least, and during Willie Randolph's pregame session with reporters, he said the cold here reminds him of his Double-A season in 1974, when he played for the Pirates' affiliate in Thetford Mines, Quebec, a small town in the south-central part of the province.
Call it Matsuzaka Mania or the Dissection of Daisuke. Whatever the moniker, it is percolating here in Kansas City, Missouri.

As our friends at The Daily Politics are reporting, Gov. Eliot Spitzer spent a half million dollars of his own money on television commercials rebutting the omnipresent ones that 1199 and the Greater New York Hospital Association aired to scale back the proposed Medicaid reductions.
New York Times contributing reporter Jerry Garrett reviews the Ford Flex.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. - Maybe it was Yankee stadium that brought out the combative New Yorker in former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, but when he was asked about the treatment of his wife, Judith, by the press on Monday, he bluntly told reporters that they should back off and "show some decency."
It's getting warmer, time to argue in court about mass bike rides. [Runnin' Scared]
Money, head scarves, fundraising and abortion today gave political bloggers a large feast on which to feed.

We asked Cassi Feldman, a freelance contributor to The Times, to visit a couple of Starbucks shops in Manhattan and talk to workers and customers, in light of our recent posts (here and here) arising from a federal labor complaint against the company. The Industrial Workers of the World, an ardently leftist union, began to organize Starbucks workers in 2004.

Circuit City's move to fire its better-paid workers, the subject of David Leonhardt's column in Wednesday's Times, is a logical extension of the flexibile employment market that is more often praised than practiced in this country. Americans regularly criticize Western Europe for job protection policies that, by making it hard to fire people, also discourage hiring them in the first place.
Mark Fields has taken plenty of razzing the past year over his collar-length hair style, which has been universally described as a mullet.
Creighton University pitcher Pat Venditte, believed to be the only ambidextrous pitcher in N.C.A.A. Division I baseball, performs in a game.
On a snowy night in Ithaca, my four housemates and I sprawled on the mismatched couches of our quirky college abode. Since the start of our senior year, we've perfected "couching" (our word) to a T.
Lawrence Ulrich, a contributing reporter to The New York Times, reviews three concept cars from General Motors.

Left to their own devices, and couches, humans instinctively resist change. Kings and C.E.O.s like it at the top. Workers don't volunteer to give up their jobs in the name of progress. Profits and productivity may create wealth, but how it gets into the right hands is another matter. Money doesn't flow - that sounds so planned. It sloshes. There's a difference. As scary as it sounds, it's the chaos of markets that keeps us well fed and out of trouble.

First Toyota had to offer incentives to help move its new Tundra. Then on Wednesday, with the world's press gathered, about five protesters from FreedomFromOil put up a banner over the front entrance of the Javits center criticizing the truck and the company for how they affect the environment. The police arrested most of the protesters quickly, but needed a cherry picker to get the last two. The banner came down with them.

Nearly every executive at the auto show has been asked how their company could be affected by this week's Supreme Court ruling directing the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate carbon dioxide as a pollutant.
The cars on display at the auto show look perfect and the exhibitors hire an army of people to keep them that way. This is a showcase, after all.

Dice Holdings, which runs career Web sites for technology and finance professionals, filed Wednesday to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering. Dice was acquired in 2005 by private equity firms General Atlantic and Quadrangle Group, which plan to sell an unspecified number of shares in the offering, according to the preliminary prospectus.

The performance guru Carroll Shelby introduced, or rather reintroduced, the King of the Road Mustang at the 2007 New York auto show. Shelby introduced the original King of the Road model in 1967 -- at New York show.
