For all the money Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has amassed, he sometimes seems a bit embarrassed to talk about it. Asked at a news conference if he had any quarrel with the accuracy of a new Fortune magazine article putting his fortune at more than $13 billion, the mayor was rendered speechless for a minute.
Another round of the campaign for Jerry Orbach Way is scheduled for tonight at Roosevelt Hospital in Midtown.

Amid the rampant speculation about who might buy Chrysler -- private equity firms? Canadians? -- and what they might do with the beleaguered automaker, one analyst is putting forward an unusual argument. Mark B. Warnsman of Prudential Equity Group is asserting that DaimlerChrysler should stick with its Chrysler unit rather than dump it (though he said he suspects it will end up getting sold anyway).
The metro editor, Joe Sexton, is still answering reader questions for the "Talk to the Newsroom" feature. Please send your questions to asktheeditors@nytimes.com.

Talk about dedication. Nearly an hour after the AMG Black Series introduction, Volker Mornhinweg, who has been the chairman of AMG for a year-and-a-half, was still around the Mercedes-Benz booth and gracious enough to chat and even spill a few beans.
One thing I love about New England (where I live part time) is that people are proud of how frugal they can be.

So the white spots on the side of the soft tires of the F1 cars - that failed to be visible to spectators at the first race - will be replaced by a white-painted groove on the surface of the tire that touches the track.... While this news is now a few days old, what is more interesting at the moment is that the weather forecast at the moment is for rain on Friday, Saturday AND Sunday.... and so wet tires will be the story of the day, not the soft tires.
City health officials said today they gave away five million of the new subway-themed condoms in the first month following the product launch on Valentine's Day.

The campaign for Senator John McCain just released a schedule of events for later this month -- as forecast by The Times's Adam Nagourney today -- that includes forums for major policy speeches and, at the end of April, an official announcement tour of his presidential candidacy through the early primary/caucus states.

How's this for a coincidence? On the same morning that Barack Obama's presidential campaign released some of its fund-raising numbers for the first quarter of 2007, one of his chief rivals, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, is huddling at her Chappaqua home with her senior staff to talk about campaign strategy and the weeks ahead.

Atop a cliff on the sea in an area of Corfu called St. Spiridon, almost at the northernmost tip of the Greek island, there's a gorgeous beach house for sale that offers complete privacy. Situated on its own peninsula with 150 meters of sea frontage, there's a pathway that winds its way down through an olive grove onto a virtually secluded beach. The property was completed last year and includes five bedrooms and a large living room with a fireplace and access to various terraces and a pool area.

Companies may be technically complying with new federal rules for disclosure of executive compensation, but Christopher Cox, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is suggesting that regulatory filings are often so long and incomprehensible that they aren't really disclosure at all.

We were a bit surprised by the overwhelming response (more than 170 comments) to our Starbucks post yesterday, so the metro desk has assigned some stringers to make the rounds at a few Starbucks shops talking to customers and employees about unions, piercings, coffee and what have you. Meanwhile, we've solved a mystery from that post -- the location of the Starbucks store in the picture. It wasn't in the original caption information that we had, so we asked blog readers to guess.

It may have been spurned once, but Kohlberg Kravis Roberts hasn't given up on Australia's Coles yet. Though the supermarket giant said it has received an A$19.7 billion ($16 billion) buyout offer from Wesfarmers and others, K.K.R. said its consortium was still in pursuit. "The consortium continues to look at the Coles business," a spokesman for the private equity firm told Reuters on Wednesday.
Andy Pettitte's return to the mound at Yankee Stadium will have to wait at least one more day.
The Ford Flex full-size crossover.
Last night at dinner, I had the privilege of sitting with the new director of Ford's SVT division, Hermann Salenbauch.

Senator Barack Obama's presidential campaign announced today that it had raised at least $25 million in the first quarter of the year, a tally that is tantalizingly close to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's fundraising in the same period.

If Google and Microsoft are circling DoubleClick -- a bidding feud that has been reported but never acknowledged by any of the parties -- it may be based partly on a new initiative that the online advertising firm announced Wednesday.

Let the sniping begin. Samuel Zell, the billionaire real estate mogul who emerged as the likely new owner of Tribune on Monday, said that one of his rivals sought him out as a partner last month -- only to go behind his back with another offer for the media empire. So Mr. Zell told the Chicago Tribune, according to a transcript obtained by The Los Angeles Times.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is set to investigate suspicious trading activity in the days before Kohlberg Kravis Roberts offered to buy First Data, the credit card processor, for $29 billion, the Times of London reported Wednesday. At issue is a surge in the trading of call options in First Data shares days before Monday's announcement: About 80,000 of those options were sold last week, more than double the volume for all of February.

Senator John McCain's sluggish first-quarter fundraising prompted a shakeup of his campaign team and a revamping of its strategy for garnering big donors. The Times's Adam Nagourney writes that Mr. McCain's aides will adopt the big-donor bundler approach introduced by President Bush's first campaign in 2000 and that they have delayed an official announcement until after a major Iraq speech by the Arizona senator.

What role the spouses of John Edwards and Rudy Giuliani would play during their theoretical presidencies has been discussed recently by the nation's political prognosticators. The New Republic's Michael Crowley wants to know: What about Bill? Crowley writes at The Plank:

During this early stage of the invisible primary, John McCain's presidential campaign is foundering. So decrees the punditocracy, in its accumulated wisdom. Joe Klein pronounces himself "boggled" by McCain's recent Baghdad stroll. "I mean, you might disagree with him on an issue, but he's usually been honorable and intellectually honest about his position. No longer," Klein writes at Swampland, the Time political blog. "This is the sort of flagrant, Bushian baloney-slicing that he ran against in 2000. Is it his faltering campaign? Is it age? It's sad to see a good man embarrass himself in this way."

CKE Restaurants, which owns, runs and franchises restaurant brands including Carl's Jr. and Hardee's, said Tuesday it had agreed to buy back 4.1 million shares of its stock for $77.3 million, or $18.97 a share. The company is purchasing the shares from Pirate Capital, an activist hedge fund, through an already-announced stock repurchasing plan. The shares amount to 6.1 percent of its total outstanding shares as of April 3.
Bert Teunissen casts an eye on ways of life that are fading away.
New York is known as a city that never sleeps, and some Toyota executives apparently do not, either.

The Bank of America said Tuesday that Peter Scaturro, the chief executive of U.S. Trust, will not join the bank as originally planned when the two companies combine later this year. Mr. Scaturro, 47, will step down from U.S. Trust before the transaction is completed, a Bank of America spokeswoman said, declining to comment on the reason for his departure. Mr. Scaturro had been expected to become head of Bank of America's private-banking business after it purchased U.S. Trust from Charles Schwab.

DaimlerChrysler's chairman, Dieter Zetsche, said Wednesday that the German-American automaker has been in talks with potential buyers of its struggling Chrysler unit, confirming weeks of conjecture and rumor. Mr. Zetsche did not identify any of the interested parties, however, and said the company was still considering "all options" for the Chrysler business.

Goldman Sachs's flagship hedge fund, Global Alpha, lost 5.7 percent in February, hurt by positions in stocks, global bonds and currencies including the Japanese yen. The decline left the $10 billion fund down 2 percent for the year through Feb. 28, according to a monthly update sent to investors. That compared with an average gain of 1.9 percent for hedge funds worldwide, according to data compiled by Hedge Fund Research in Chicago.

Global Crossing may be attractive to private equity firms as it wins more customers for the fiber-optic network that forced the company into bankruptcy five years ago, the chief executive, John Legere, said in an interview with Bloomberg News. But he added that Temasek Holdings, which is Global Crossing's majority owner, has no immediate reason to sell its stake, and an analysts said Temasek is likely to wait a year and a half or so before considering it.

The Blackstone Group is in talks to buy into China's Guofeng Group, the country's biggest plastics products manufacturer, Reuters reported on Wednesday citing sources it did not identify. Blackstone has been in talks with Guofeng Group, based in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui for several months, though no deal has been signed yet, the sources said.

The Carlyle Group's bid to buy part of Chongqing City Commercial Bank is expected to be rejected, according to Bloomberg News. The nay comes as China is cracking down on buyout firms based on concerns that they are not adding enough value and are only seeking short-term profits that do not improve the companies they buy.
A nap in a colorful wildflower meadow, without the pollen and bees.

In an auction Wednesday in Moscow, Eni, Italy's state-run oil company, won the bid for a stake in Gazprom's oil unit, a step that will help the Russian government reclaim the assets of the jailed billionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky.

The chiefs of the merged New York Stock Exchange and Euronext said Tuesday, on the eve of the opening day of trading of its shares, that they were determined to create a truly global market that would include operations in China.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is set to meet Wednesday to consider whether it should ease a part of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which imposed new duties on corporate executives and accountants after a series of fraud-ridden business collapses in 2002.

With the financial sector already among the busiest for mergers, private equity firms and other buyers are looking deeper at behind-the-scenes payment processors and business-services providers as takeover targets, analysts said on Tuesday.

In an initial public offering expected to raise about $99 million, Veraz Networks of San Jose, Calif., becomes the latest in a series of tech firms to catch Wall Street's eye this week despite the red ink at their bottom lines. MarketWatch reported that Veraz, a maker of voice over Internet protocol equipment, will offer 9 million shares at $10 to $12 each with underwriters Credit Suisse and Lehman Brothers.
Take a peek at the homes of the rich, mercury glass and sarrine-inspired tweed and more.

The investment fund Lone Star confirmed widespread rumors on Wednesday that it would sell two of its South Korean holdings. Following a legal battle that forced it to abort a planned $7.3 billion sale of the Korea Exchange Bank last November, the fund is selling Kukdong Engineering and Construction and STARLease. ABN Amro is serving as Lone Star's adviser.

Citigroup hired an executive from UBS to head its metals and mining operations in Asia, Finance Asia reported Wednesday. The executive, Alexander Molyneux, will become managing director of the division in mid-April after leaving UBS in Australia where he was most recently an executive director in the investment banking team.

Closing a $52 million Series D round of financing, Boston's Surface Logix has raised $20 million to help fund clinical development of its small molecule drug candidates. The round was fed by existing investors such as Venrock Associates, Arch Venture Partners, CW Group, HBM BioVentures, and Unilever Technology Partners.

Alcatel-Lucent said it would buy Tropic Networks, a Canadian network equipment company created by Nortel Networks and other Canadian tech giants. Terms for the transaction were not disclosed. The deal is the result of a three-year relationship between Tropic and Alcatel, which led a $33-million round of financing for Tropic in 2004.

For more than a year, Michael Brick, the Brooklyn courts reporter for The Times, has been chronicling the brief law enforcement career of Fred the Undercover Cat. Fred is gone, but his biggest case -- well, his only case -- endures. The latest installment is in The Times today.

MicroChips has secured $13.4 million in a round of funding led by the Novartis Venture Fund, the venture capital arm of Swiss drug giant Novartis. Other investors include CSK Venture Capital of Japan, Polaris Venture Partners, IDG Ventures, Medtronic, Boston Scientific, and the Boston University Community Technology Fund.

After forcing its way into the bidding, the Inland American Real Estate Trust has won the fight for Winston Hotels for about $458 million. In February, Winston Hotels of Raleigh, N.C., agreed to be acquired by private-equity interests in New York, but last month Inland American pushed its way into the picture by making an unsolicited $15-a-share proposal.

The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group agreed to buy the British wireless network division of National Grid for 2.5 billion pounds ($4.93 billion) and combine the unit with its Arqiva broadcast business.

The prospect that Cadbury might merge with Hershey, though still merely speculation, would put Wm. Wrigley in an awkward spot, Breakingviews writes. Wrigley might like to bid for Hershey itself, but Wrigley's shares have have lost much of their flavor in recent years as the company failed to prove its prowess at deal-making.

Comcast, the nation's largest cable operator, said Tuesday that it was buying a small New Jersey cable operator for $483 million. Analysts said the price was high in light of the number of subscribers but understandable given the customers' affluence. The operator being acquired, Patriot Media and Communications, serves 81,000 video subscribers in central New Jersey, many of them in upscale neighborhoods that fit in with Comcast's service area.

Shareholders of the brokerage firm Nikko Cordial have started a campaign to force Citigroup to raise its takeover offer of $13.4 billion for the firm, placing sell orders in the market at a higher price. Investors had placed sell orders for 122 million Nikko shares at 1,900 yen (about $15) on the Tokyo exchange Wednesday morning, up from 71 million at the close of trading on Tuesday, according to Instinet Japan.

Australia's biggest gaming company, Publishing & Broadcasting, which is owned by James D. Packer, agreed Wednesday to buy casinos in Canada for 1.37 billion Canadian dollars ($1.2 billion). Mr. Packer joined with the Macquarie Bank to buy Gateway Casinos Income Fund, a casino operator in western Canada, for 886 million Canadian dollars, Publishing & Broadcasting said. The venture also offered to buy two closely held casino management companies.

Shareholders of the News Corporation have approved an $11 billion asset swap that increases Rupert Murdoch's control over the company and transfers the DirecTV Group to Liberty Media, controlled by John C. Malone.

The news that Samuel Zell is becoming the new chairman of Tribune and has no plans to sell any of its individual newspapers has not discouraged potential buyers - and even his rival bidders - from planning their next move.
Gray, the new navy blue. Not as traditional or boring as light blue or khaki, but not as racy or impractical as white.
Images from Lynn Davis's show at the Rubin Museum.
Both hydrogen- and battery-powered cars, if they’re to solve the pollution problem, depend on the development of clean, renewable electricity production.
Mercedes-Benz introduced the 2007 CLK63 AMG Black Series Wednesday at the New York Auto Show.
A soldier’s heart-rending arc from hardscrabble childhood to decorated Iraq war hero back to hardscrabble adulthood.
Steve Smucker test hydration packs.
With stunning swiftness, China’s surging ranks of classical musicians have found a home in Western concert halls, jolting a musical tradition born in the courts and churches of Europe.
Thom Filicia’s new show, “Dress My Nest,” correctly identifies one of the prevailing issues of our time — the problem of translating a person’s essence into footstools and swatches.
Care to watch a novel or two? The “American Masters” series on PBS will present seven of them on Wednesday, by writers from Theodore Dreiser to Saul Bellow.
Salonika's cafes and markets provide ample room for creative-types and visitors to ramble and explore.
General Motors showed off three products of its South Korean design studio at the New York Auto Show on Wednesday.
Faded but stately, crumbling but proud, the walled city of Fez might well be the largest and most enduring medieval Islamic settlement in the world.
Britain’s relief at the sailors’ and marines’ safe return was tarnished by questions about how they behaved during their detention.
Stop the presses! Leon Black's Apollo Management is planning to go public!
Jeep Liberty midsize sport utility vehicle.
It's a new era for DealBook.
By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN
By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN
By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

From a policy perspective, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken on more food issues, and provoked more controversy, than any New York mayor before him. As a result, he has the potential to change the way more New Yorkers eat - whether in the haughtiest dining rooms or the poorest home kitchens - than all the city's food activists and restaurant critics combined.
By PETER EDMONSTON
By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED
By PETER EDMONSTON
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa - The first standing ovation went to Elizabeth Edwards.
By ERIC DASH
By MATT RICHTEL
By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED
Some of the best dosas around can be found at the Temple Canteen in the basement of the Hindu Temple Society of North America in Queens.
In “Firehouse Dog” a pampered Hollywood pooch trades his movie-star lifestyle for a run-down firehouse sadly in need of a mascot.
The rapper Ice Cube returns to the multiplex with “Are We Done Yet?,” a feeble fable of better parenting through home improvement.
Paul Verhoeven’s “Black Book” encompasses the best and very worst of its director’s signature pulp brutalism, which means it’s pretty much a hoot.
Today, Condrieu is a fashionable wine, but only 35 years ago this northern Rhone Valley appellation was barely alive, with only about 30 acres of grapes to its name.
President Bush appointed three officials who have already drawn heavy criticism on Capitol Hill.
The U.N. report finds that global warming caused by humans has contributed to recent shifts in ecosystems.
Tarik Shah pleaded guilty today to a charge of “conspiring to provide material support or resources” to Al Qaeda.
Thailand’s government has blocked access to YouTube and several other Web sites because of content that it says is offensive, officials said today.
The incident was the second violent clash in the last week in the northern Gaza Strip despite a tenuous cease-fire.
Iran wants an envoy to visit five Iranians imprisoned following an American raid in northern Iraq in January.
In 55 seasons at Grambling State University, Eddie Robinson won more than 400 football games.
Three Yale University students were arrested early Tuesday morning for burning an American flag on a pole attached to a house in New Haven, the Yale Daily News reported today.
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said today that Iran had “pardoned” and would release the 15 British sailors and marines.
The House speaker was the most senior American politician to visit Syria since 2003.
The company confirmed for the first time today that it is in negotiations with a number of parties.
In the eighth inning Tuesday night, Mets reliever Aaron Heilman found an answer to an unanswerable question: How do you get Albert Pujols off balance?
Publishing & Broadcasting, which is owned by James D. Packer, agreed to buy casinos in Canada for $1.2 billion.
Orlando Hernández allowed one run and five hits in seven splendid innings and also added two hits, including a two-run double that supplied the bullpen with some additional comfort.
The Lady Vols defeated Rutgers Tuesday night with a hounding defense, giving Coach Pat Summitt her seventh national title and first since 1998.
Three former South American military officers suspected of war crimes have been arrested by United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, the agency said.
In one move, the Islanders saved their dwindling playoff hopes, crimped the Rangers’ march to a postseason berth and earned a victory against their bitter rivals Tuesday night.
Elizabeth Edwards said she was determined not to let public curiosity and concern over her illness overshadow her husband’s presidential campaign.
Faculty members in the California State University system postponed strike plans after tentatively settling a two-year contract dispute.
The government proposed relaxing its rules on labeling irradiated foods and suggested it might allow some products zapped with radiation to be called “pasteurized.”
The 2007 Atlantic hurricane season should be “very active,” with nine hurricanes and a good chance that at least one major hurricane will hit the United States, a top researcher said.

Two young brothers whose bodies were recovered from lake ice accidentally drowned, according to an autopsy report released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The boys, Tristan White, 4, and Avery Stately, 2, died of “probable fresh water drowning,” according to the autopsies performed by the Ramsey County coroner. A search team on Sunday found the bodies of the boys encased in ice in a small lake near their home on the Red Lake Indian Reservation. They disappeared on Nov. 22, prompting a large-scale search.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 3 (AP) — Rashanda McCants will have to wait to follow her older brother into pro basketball.

Martin Brodeur tied Bernie Parent’s single-season record for victories by a goalie and Lou Lamoriello got a win in his return to coaching last night as the Devils defeated the visiting Ottawa Senators, 2-1.
The tax credit culminates a nine-month effort to bring some measure of relief to property owners in New Jersey.
Tayshaun Prince scored 24 points and the Detroit Pistons beat the host Indiana Pacers, 100-85, last night to guarantee the Pacers their first losing season in a decade.
This year, the New Jersey Senate is facing its biggest turnover in two decades.
The authorities said that the shootings did not appear to be related.

An article in The Arts on March 20 about Paul Jacobs, chairman of the organ department at the Juilliard School, and his efforts to stimulate interest in organs, misidentified a type of organ he plays. While he prefers pipe organs, he also plays electronic — not electric — ones.

An article yesterday about the deepening crisis in Ukraine misidentified the political leader affiliated with the Our Ukraine Party. He is President Viktor A. Yushchenko, not Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich.
Corrections: For the Record
pro football.

An obituary on Sunday about Baron Bernd Freytag von Loringhoven, one of the last survivors of Hitler’s bunker, rendered his surname incorrectly in several references. He was Baron Freytag von Loringhoven, not Baron von Loringhoven.

Australia’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a six-year high, giving policy makers time to study an inflation report later this month that may prompt an increase. The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia left the overnight cash rate target at 6.25 percent for a fourth consecutive meeting after raising it a quarter percentage point in November.

The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group agreed to buy the British wireless network division of National Grid for £2.5 billion ($4.93 billion) and combine the unit with its Arqiva broadcast business. National Grid, owner of the power and gas networks in Britain, said National Grid’s wireless unit had access to more than 14,500 communication sites in England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales. The unit, based in Warwick, England, owns more than 2,500 sites and has contracts with its parent for access to electricity transmission towers, National Grid said. Arqiva, based in Hampshire, England, offers networking services to broadcasters and mobile phone companies including the Vodafone Group, Telefónica, O2 and Orange of France Télécom. Macquarie is based in Sydney, Australia.

The Anheuser-Busch Companies said it would build a brewery in Foshan, China, to help reach its goal of doubling the distribution of its Budweiser beer in China over the next five years. Busch said it would make Budweiser available to an additional 150 million potential beer drinkers by bringing it to 100 new cities, each with a population of at least a million people. The company also said it would introduce the domestic brew Harbin to 33 new markets in 2007. The Foshan brewery, in Guangdong Province, is scheduled for completion in late 2008 at a cost of $63 million.

TNT, the Dutch postal company, said it would cut up to 7,000 jobs by 2010 as part of a revamping intended to save 300 million euros ($400 million) in costs annually. The company said it would freeze employee wages until the revamping was finished and adopt other unspecified measures to avoid further losses. The company said it would enter talks with its unions and employee advisory boards to work out further details.

The Hershey Company said it was forming a joint venture in India with Godrej Beverages and Foods to manufacture and sell confections, snacks and beverages. Hershey said it would invest $60 million and take a 51 percent stake in the venture, which will be called Godrej Hershey. The rest of the venture will be held by Godrej Industries, a privately held conglomerate that is the parent company of Godrej Beverages. Through the venture, Hershey, based in Hershey, Pa., will obtain access to Godrej’s two factories and 1.6 million retail outlets. Godrej Beverages, which makes juices, soy milk and cooking oils, has annual sales of $70 million. Richard H. Lenny, Hershey’s chief executive, above, called the deal a significant step in Hershey’s global growth strategy. Production is expected to start in 2008.

CSL, an Australian drug maker, asked for quick approval of a seasonal flu vaccine in the United States, where health officials have been battling shortages by encouraging new suppliers. CSL is seeking priority review, which could gain clearance for the shots for people 18 and older by Sept. 30, said Paul Perreault, an executive vice president at the company’s CSL Biotherapies unit.. The application is the first attempt by CSL, which has made the flu vaccine since 1962, to sell shots in the United States, Mr. Perreault said.
The campaign would force Citigroup to raise its takeover offer of $13.4 billion for the firm, placing sell orders in the market at a higher price.

The North Haven town finance director was charged yesterday with hindering prosecution and tampering with evidence, the chief state’s attorney’s office said. The director, Vincent Palmieri, 65, of North Haven, was released on a promise to appear on April 16 in State Superior Court in Meriden. His lawyer, Frederick Leaf, said, “We believe my client is absolutely innocent of these charges.” Joseph Ierardi, the town’s director of community services and recreation, and his wife, Patricia, who works for the same department, were expected to be arrested today, their lawyer, Hugh Keefe, said yesterday. The authorities declined to discuss the investigation, but Mr. Keefe said it involved allegations of misuse of a relatively small amount of money. “People should believe in the presumption of innocence,” he said.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell has nominated an insurance executive to serve as the state’s next insurance commissioner, officials announced yesterday. The executive, Thomas R. Sullivan, 45, most recently served as senior vice president at Specialty Risk Services, a subsidiary of the Hartford Financial Services Group. Mr. Sullivan, whose appointment requires confirmation by the state legislature, replaces Susan F. Cogswell, who was reassigned to a deputy commissioner’s position.

The blood alcohol content of a Rider University freshman who died last week after drinking at a fraternity house was more than five times the legal limit for driving, the Mercer County prosecutor said yesterday. The student, Gary DeVercelly, 18, above, of Long Beach, Calif., had a blood alcohol content of 0.426 percent, according to autopsy results released by the prosecutor. Mr. DeVercelly died on Friday at Capital Health System’s Fuld hospital in nearby Trenton. His death is being treated as accidental, but that could be amended after further investigation, Casey DeBlasio, a spokeswoman for the prosecutor, told The Times of Trenton.

A man charged with slicing a postal worker’s chest with a power saw inside a subway station last summer pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree assault. The man, Tareyton Williams, 34, had been charged with attempted murder for grabbing the saw from a worker’s cart and attacking the postal employee, Michael Steinberg. He pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in exchange for a sentence of 18 years in prison. In court, Mr. Williams admitted that he tried to cut Mr. Steinberg with the saw inside the station at 110th Street and Broadway in Manhattan about 3:30 a.m. on July 7. Mr. Steinberg, then 64, suffered cuts, broken ribs and a punctured lung.

A man who posed as an investigator to lure two women to Queens motels and forced them to have sex with him was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 15 years in prison, prosecutors said. The man, Eric McCoy, 37, of Beach 26th Street in Far Rockaway, pleaded guilty on Feb. 26 to first-degree rape, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. McCoy, posing as an investigator on both occasions, told the women that they were under investigation and ordered them to accompany him to a motel for questioning. He said Mr. McCoy beat one of the women and threatened each with arrest if they did not have sex with him.

The beaten body of a man was found on Monday night in a house in Putnam County, the New York State Police said last night. Although the police had not positively confirmed the victim’s identity, investigators believed it was Richard McKeon, 86, of 22 Fordal Place in Lake Peekskill. Neighbors became concerned when they had not seen Mr. McKeon for several days, the police said. They notified the police after entering the house and found him dead in the kitchen with bruises on his body. The police said they were on the lookout for someone Mr. McKeon knew. Lt. James H. Murphy, a state police spokesman, said last night that investigators did not have a motive for the killing, though he added that it did not appear to be a robbery.

The body of a missing Newark woman was found inside a metal garbage can in a vacant lot near a construction site on Brookdale Avenue on Monday night, the Essex County prosecutor’s office said yesterday. Relatives reported the woman, Kasie DeJarnette, 38, missing last month, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the prosecutor. She appeared to have died from asphyxiation, he said, but the case would not be ruled a homicide until after a medical examiner’s evaluation.

A man has been arrested in connection with eight burglaries in Suffolk County over the past three months, the police said yesterday. The man, Wayne Toney, 23, of Wyandanch, was arrested on Monday shortly after a robbery in which someone kicked in a house door and stole jewelry, the Suffolk County police said. After a further investigation, the police said, Mr. Toney was also arrested in connection with robberies in which copper pipes were stolen from houses’ heating systems. He was charged yesterday with eight counts of second-degree burglary in Suffolk County District Court, the police said.

A Jackson Heights man was charged yesterday with four break-ins in northern Queens in the past year, prosecutors said. The man, Antonio Diaz, 36, of 34th Road, is accused of stealing thousands of dollars in cash, laptop computers and electronic equipment from homes, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Diaz drilled through door locks or climbed through windows after residents had left for work. Mr. Diaz pleaded not guilty to burglary in Criminal Court, prosecutors said.

Local and state police investigators used machines, shovels and dirt sifters yesterday to search for the remains of a 2-year-old boy, who they believe was murdered 17 years ago by his father. The dig took place at an intersection underneath an elevated portion of the New Jersey Turnpike, officials told The Jersey Journal. The boy, Curtis McCoy, has been missing since November 1989. The boy’s father, Curtis Williams, was charged in January 2006 with killing the boy. In 1989, Mr. Williams picked up Curtis from his mother, La Shawn McCoy, in South Carolina, so he could spend Thanksgiving with his father in Union City, the police said. Not long after, Mr. Williams told the Newark police that his son had disappeared while they were out shopping.

China plans to issue revised rules to curb speculation and the lucrative trade in grave plots, the state-run newspaper China Daily reported. Traditional preferences for graves, instead of smaller areas for urns carrying ashes, has resulted in soaring prices, it said. It said in Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan Province, the average price of a grave in a public cemetery was about $1,000 per square yard, while the average house price was about $500 per square yard. The revised rules will say that public cemeteries can sell grave sites only to customers who produce a death certificate, or face a fine of up to $64,000. The traditional view that a person can have a peaceful afterlife only if buried in a grave is still widely accepted in China.

Most Zimbabweans headed to work in the capital, Harare, appearing to ignore a call by labor unions for a two-day nationwide strike to protest deteriorating economic conditions. “The response has been mixed,” said Lovemore Madhuku, chairman of the National Constitutional Alliance, a coalition of rights groups, churches and labor unions that is demanding a new constitution. “Most shops and banks seem to be open, but there’s very little traffic and very little sign of business taking place.”.
There were conflicting rulings over whether the name of the opposition leader would appear on the ballot in 17 days.

Archbishop Angelo Bagnasco of Genoa, the head of Italy’s bishops’ conference, was under police guard after “Shame on you Bagnasco” was spray-painted on the doors of his Cathedral of San Lorenzo over his comparison of gay rights to incest and pedophilia. He made the comments at a meeting of church workers over the weekend, according to a newspaper report. A police spokeswoman said the archbishop, who has been vocal in the Vatican’s campaign against a bill in the Italian Parliament that would grant rights to unmarried couples, including homosexuals, was being accompanied by a police escort. Last week, the bishops’ conference issued a directive ordering Catholic lawmakers to vote against the bill.

About two thousand lawyers and opposition supporters chanting “Go, Musharraf!” and other slogans against President Pervez Musharraf protested outside the Supreme Court in Islamabad as the country’s suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, left, appeared before a panel of judges to defend himself on charges of misuse of power. Similar protests were held in other cities. The panel adjourned the private proceedings until April 13. Mr. Chaudhry’s lawyers urged an open hearing. Demonstrations and lawyers’ strikes have erupted around the country since General Musharraf’s decision on March 9 to suspend the independent-minded Mr. Chaudhry. Opponents say General Musharraf suspended him to weaken the judiciary. At the protest in Islamabad, flags of an alliance of religious parties and flags of the political parties of the exiled prime ministers Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif fluttered in abundance.
Investigators have been questioning a Salem County man in connection with the killings of four prostitutes whose bodies were found on the outskirts of Atlantic City in November.
States are already using the Supreme Court’s decision to speed their own efforts to regulate gas emissions.
Some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned, the biggest expansion in the West’s quest for water in decades.
The Mets’ José Reyes is one of a record 246 players on opening day rosters who were born outside the 50 states. The total surpasses the previous record of 242.
Despite leading his rivals in fund-raising, Mitt Romney has trailed Senator John McCain of Arizona and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in most polls.
The exchange will bring Web publishers and ad buyers together on a Web site where they can participate in auctions for ad space.
After three years in Houston — and another trip to the World Series — Andy Pettitte resumes his Yankees career Thursday against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.
The news that Samuel Zell is becoming the new chairman of Tribune has not discouraged potential buyers — and even his rival bidders — from planning their next move.
A former Qwest president testified that he could not recall comments he made in 2000 and 2001 about the company’s financial performance.
Returning from a Passover Seder, she was struck  with her husband as they crossed a street.
The $500 million public health initiative by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation is one of the largest ever tried by a private philanthropy.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit is seen as part of an attempt to sway Bush administration policy on Iraq and the rest of the Middle East.
The maneuvers come at a time when the senator is lagging in fund-raising and under fire for his support of the Iraq war.
For 15 years, the state has been using money from its pension fund for state and local workers for other government purposes.
The Cardinals have not announced plans to retire Mark McGwire’s No. 25, leaving the fate of a McGwire statue at Busch Stadium unclear.
April 3, 2007.

9 P.M. (2) NOVEL REFLECTIONS ON THE AMERICAN DREAM There was a time when the country’s collective ambitions — and subsequent despairs — were fodder for great literature. Take John Steinbeck’s “Grapes of Wrath,” which confronted an inconvenient truth: it sometimes takes more than hard work and clean living to get ahead. When it was published in 1939, the novel was criticized as being full of lies, corruption and Communistic themes. It sold out in a flash. This special looks at seven stories that dared to challenge the fiction of the American dream: works from Theodore Dreiser’s “Sister Carrie” and Edith Wharton’s “House of Mirth” to F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “Great Gatsby” (above, a scene from a re-enactment) and Saul Bellow’s “Seize the Day.” Passages from each book are dramatized through still photography, animation and archival film; Patricia Clarkson narrates.

The $25 and Under column last Wednesday, about the Colombian restaurant Las Americas in Queens, referred incorrectly to a region of Colombia that is home to a dish called bandejas Paisa. YOU cannot say enough about falafel. These seasoned fritters are among the best things you can make with chickpeas, they're easy and rewarding to fry (perfect for novice deep-fryers) and they are vegetarian. Unlike other bean fritters, falafel is made from uncooked beans. The cooking goes best when the beans are soaked for a full day in plenty of water.

After more than 100 years, Lodge, a maker of cast-iron cookware, has added a new line, the Signature Series, with stainless steel handles. That may not sound like much, but it means that the handles stay cooler for stovetop cooking and that the look is more 21st-century. The performance of the pans is everything you expect from cast iron and they are every bit as heavy as the regular Lodge pans. The line includes Dutch ovens (4.5- and 7-quart $129.95 and $149.95), a 2.5-quart covered casserole ($129.95), straight-sided skillets that are more like sauté pans (10 and 12 inches, $89.95 and $99.95), and a 12-inch grill pan ($109.95).

Tennessee cornerback Pacman Jones and Cincinnati receiver Chris Henry met separately yesterday with Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, as part of the process that could lead to lengthy suspensions for both players because of repeated off-the-field incidents. Goodell is expected to rule on discipline for Jones and Henry within 10 days. Since he was drafted in 2005, Jones has been arrested five times and questioned by the police in 10 episodes. He could face a felony charge for his role in a melee that led to a triple shooting in a Las Vegas strip club. Henry was arrested four times between December 2005 and June 2006 and has already served a two-game suspension that Goodell issued last season. Goodell is expected to announce a tougher personal-conduct policy before the draft on April 28-29.

A man has been arrested in connection with eight burglaries in Suffolk County over the past three months, the police said yesterday. The man, Wayne Toney, 23, of Wyandanch, was arrested on Monday shortly after a robbery in which someone kicked in a house door and stole jewelry, the Suffolk County police said. After a further investigation, the police said, Mr. Toney was also arrested in connection with robberies in which copper pipes were stolen from houses' heating systems. He was charged yesterday with eight counts of second-degree burglary in Suffolk County District Court, the police said.

The widow and associates of Alexander V. Litvinenko, who was poisoned in London in November, said Tuesday that they had established a foundation to demand justice and expressed worries that Britain and Russia might allow his killers to avoid trial. Mr. Litvinenko, 43, a former K.G.B. agent, died Nov. 23 after ingesting polonium 210, a rare radioactive isotope.

The Hershey Company said it was forming a joint venture in India with Godrej Beverages and Foods to manufacture and sell confections, snacks and beverages. Hershey said it would invest $60 million and take a 51 percent stake in the venture, which will be called Godrej Hershey. The rest of the venture will be held by Godrej Industries, a privately held conglomerate that is the parent company of Godrej Beverages. Through the venture, Hershey, based in Hershey, Pa., will obtain access to Godrej's two factories and 1.6 million retail outlets. Godrej Beverages, which makes juices, soy milk and cooking oils, has annual sales of $70 million. Richard H. Lenny, Hershey's chief executive, above, called the deal a significant step in Hershey's global growth strategy. Production is expected to start in 2008.

Members of a Republican Congressional delegation to Iraq who were criticized by Iraqis for portraying the security situation in Baghdad as much improved said Tuesday that they were realistic about the dangers that remain there. Representative Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, said a brief weekend tour of the Shorja market had given him some hope that the recent increase in American forces in Baghdad and some new military tactics were having a measurable impact on security in the city.

John Adams, the second president of the United States and the son of a Puritan, would undoubtedly blush at the makeover planned for his former London residence. While the developer is maintaining the historical features of Adams's three-story house, including a broad ballroom with high ceilings and an ornate fireplace, he is also adding the latest in high-tech gadgetry. Improvements will include Lutron-brand controlled lighting, electrically operated curtains, underfloor heating and an audio-video system throughout the structure.

FEW FIRMS exemplified the previous deal-making boom better than Drexel Burnham Lambert, whose rise and fall in the 1980s was described by James B. Stewart in ''Den of Thieves.'' While that era was marked by criminal prosecutions, notably of Michael R. Milken and Ivan F. Boesky, not all of the players were ''thieves.'' Many know that Mr. Milken has become a philanthropist supporting cancer research, and that Rudolph W. Giuliani, who prosecuted him, is running for president. Here are others from Mr. Stewart's book, with updates: Martin A. Siegel PRISON, AND A STALLED RETURN As an investment banker, he was a star at Kidder Peabody, then Drexel, before pleading guilty to conspiracy and tax evasion. He received a two-month prison sentence, thanks to his cooperation with the government. He resurfaced in the mid-1990s as an adviser to the Ideon Group. But when the board found out about the hire, it insisted that his contract not be renewed. Herald L. Ritch NEVER LEFT THE GAME Then a rising star, he is now a veteran in mergers and acquisitions. In 1988, he joined Freeman Spogli and then served as a top executive at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He left D.L.J. in 2000, shortly after Credit Suisse acquired it, leading a contingent of defectors to Salomon Smith Barney. He is now president and co-chief executive of Sagent Advisors, a boutique bank. Ivan F. Boesky A LIFE OF SECLUSION His $100 million fine for insider trading has never been surpassed. He served two years in a federal prison after cooperating with prosecutors. In 1993, Mr. Boesky and his wife divorced, and he lost his Westchester County mansion and Park Avenue apartment. Reclusive, he has been seen in New York, France and Switzerland. James Dahl AN ACTIVIST INVESTOR He made a plea agreement with prosecutors. Leaving Drexel in 1990, he moved back to Jacksonville, Fla., his hometown, and set up an investment firm. He was back in the spotlight in the late 1990s through his activism at Gehl, a construction company, after he was refused a board seat. Gehl finally bought his 10 percent stake for $14.9 million. Gary Winnick GLOBAL CROSSING AND AN IMPERIAL LIFESTYLE After leaving Drexel in 1985, he founded the Pacific Capital Group, an investment firm. He then founded Global Crossing, a telecommunications darling of the late 1990s. But the company's fortunes crumbled, culminating in a bankruptcy filing in 2002. Mr. Winnick's imperial lifestyle -- and the lengths he went to preserve it -- angered employees and investors alike. An investigation by the S.E.C. was concluded without any charges against him. Dennis B. Levine AFTER PRISON, CONSULTING He made a deal with prosecutors that resulted in a two-year prison term on perjury, securities fraud and tax evasion charges. When he left prison in 1988, he was barred from associating with broker-dealers. Later, he founded the Adasar Group, a consulting firm named after his two children. Peter J. Solomon WALL STREET WISE MAN Mr. Levine's mentor at Shearson Lehman Brothers, Mr. Solomon left the firm in 1989 to hang his own shingle, the Peter J. Solomon Company. He has since become one of Wall Street's gray eminences. His firm has recently advised on deals that include Kate Spade, Lands' End and Barneys New York. Lawrence B. Pedowitz REPRESENTED MARTHA STEWART Still a partner at the law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. But his post-Milken highlight may be his role on Martha Stewart's defense team. With a partner, John Savarese, he helped negotiate a deal with federal prosecutors: Ms. Stewart would plead guilty to one felony count of making a false statement to federal agents, according to a 2004 New Yorker article. Ms. Stewart did not take the deal, went to trial and ended up being convicted. Harvey Pitt SERVED AS S.E.C. CHAIRMAN In 2001, he was appointed chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, leading it during Sept. 11, the collapse of Enron and the wave of scandals that led to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act in 2002. But he resigned in 2003 amid controversy over one of his appointments. He is now runs Kalorama Partners, a consulting firm. Linda Gosden Robinson STILL IN PUBLIC RELATIONS She was Mr. Milken's spokeswoman in the 1980s. As chairwoman of Robinson Lerer & Montgomery, she has represented clients like Pfizer and Morgan Stanley. Her firm was acquired by Young & Rubicam, which itself was then bought by the WPP Group of Britain. She also serves as a director of Revlon and BlackRock. Kenneth Lerer INTERNET EXECUTIVE He quickly moved from representing business moguls to becoming one himself. While still president of Robinson Lerer & Montgomery, he became senior vice president of America Online, and then an executive vice president of Time Warner. He has since moved to newer media: in 2005, he co-founded the Huffington Post Web site with Arianna Huffington. (Pages are from ''Den of Thieves,'' by James B. Stewart. Copyright c1991 by James. B. Stewart. Reprinted by permission of Simon & Schuster, Inc.)

An article in The Arts on March 20 about Paul Jacobs, chairman of the organ department at the Juilliard School, and his efforts to stimulate interest in organs, misidentified a type of organ he plays. While he prefers pipe organs, he also plays electronic -- not electric -- ones.

Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today because of the second day of Passover, tomorrow for Holy Thursday and Friday for Good Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

ABC drew the most viewers on Monday with its combination of ''Dancing With the Stars'' and the premiere of the latest edition of ''The Bachelor,'' but CBS led the night among adults 18 to 49 with its coverage of the N.C.A.A. basketball championship. Because CBS's broadcast was live, Nielsen's preliminary estimates for the game's audience are unreliable, but Florida's victory over Ohio State appeared to dominate the television competition from 9:15 to 11:30 p.m., faring significantly better in the ratings than the year-ago championship game. ABC was most dominant earlier in the night as a 105-minute episode of ''Dancing With the Stars'' earned approximately 17.1 million viewers from 8 to 9:45. Following it on ABC, the debut of ''The Bachelor: Officer and a Gentleman,'' the 10th iteration of the series, garnered more than 10 million viewers from 9:45 to 11. Fox ranked third for the night as ''Prison Break'' at 8 (8 million) and ''24'' at 9 (10.9 million) posted relatively typical ratings. NBC finished fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF

The body of a missing Newark woman was found inside a metal garbage can in a vacant lot near a construction site on Brookdale Avenue on Monday night, the Essex County prosecutor's office said yesterday. Relatives reported the woman, Kasie DeJarnette, 38, missing last month, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the prosecutor. She appeared to have died from asphyxiation, he said, but the case would not be ruled a homicide until after a medical examiner's evaluation. JOHN HOLL

A Jackson Heights man was charged yesterday with four break-ins in northern Queens in the past year, prosecutors said. The man, Antonio Diaz, 36, of 34th Road, is accused of stealing thousands of dollars in cash, laptop computers and electronic equipment from homes, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Diaz drilled through door locks or climbed through windows after residents had left for work. Mr. Diaz pleaded not guilty to burglary in Criminal Court, prosecutors said.

THE merger boom has created a subplot perfect for a spy thriller: a proliferation of code names that executives and investment bankers use to disguise the parties in a potential deal. Often inspired by Greek gods, sports figures or city names, the code names turn up in early presentations in place of actual company names, which, at least in theory, are supposed to stay secret until an agreement is announced. A common approach is to substitute a word with the same first letter of each company, although deal makers sometimes get more fanciful.

A man who posed as an investigator to lure two women to Queens motels and forced them to have sex with him was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 15 years in prison, prosecutors said. The man, Eric McCoy, 37, of Beach 26th Street in Far Rockaway, pleaded guilty on Feb. 26 to first-degree rape, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. McCoy, posing as an investigator on both occasions, told the women that they were under investigation and ordered them to accompany him to a motel for questioning. He said Mr. McCoy beat one of the women and threatened each with arrest if they did not have sex with him.

Isiah Thomas will soon send the National Basketball Association a check for $50,000 -- the apparent price for restoring a franchise's dignity. The Knicks last season were a punchline, a bog of bruised egos and joyless faces. When Thomas, the team president, also became the coach, he spoke of instilling confidence and regaining respect. That mission has pushed him to extremes.

BLATTNER--Alvin Robert ''Bob'', died peacefully on March 30, 2007, at age 84. Bob was born in Cairo, Egypt, son of Robert and Marguerite Blattner (nee Bialobos). His dry humor, sharp observational powers, and unique sense of satire and wit made him a self appointed commentator on the human condition. Surviving are his children, Dr. Stephen Blattner of Cape Elizabeth, ME and Marguerite Blattner of San Diego, CA, his grandchildren Zachary Blattner and Arielle Blattner, and his daughter-in-law Dr. Francine Blattner. Burial at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Saw Mill River Road, Hastings, at 3 PM, April 6. Donations may be made to: Maine Veterans Home, 290 US Route 1, Scarborough, ME 04074.

Fizzy, fragrant, pink and refreshingly tart, rhubarb cider is springtime in a glass. The lightly sparkling Nectar de Rhubarbe from northern France needs no alcohol to deliver its light allure; the label says it has less than 1 percent. The cider is sold in 750-milliliter bottles smartly secured with Champagne corks. It deserves a Champagne flute for sipping, but at only $6.99 a bottle at Fairway, you might freely pour it over a bowl of ripe strawberries.

A new analysis of combined data from two parts of a large federal study of hormone therapy has found that women in their 50s do not appear to have an increased heart attack risk if they take the drugs. But it also found that women in their 60s and 70s who still had hot flashes and night sweats were at increased risk for heart attacks, even if they were not taking hormones. And if these women took hormone therapy, their risk was higher still. ''The main indication now for hormone therapy is hot flashes and night sweats,'' said Dr. Jacques Rossouw, a researcher for the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute who directed the federal study, the Women's Health Initiative. ''This says that if you are older than 60, you should not take it.''

FREUND--Shelley, adoring wife of Leonard, devoted mother of Jay and Bud, and loving grandmother of Jesse, Daniel, Hannah and Charlotte. Passed away peacefully in her sleep, surrounded by family, good friends and wonderful memories. We love and miss you Ma. You had style.

The $25 and Under column last Wednesday, about the Colombian restaurant Las Americas in Queens, referred incorrectly to a region of Colombia that is home to a dish called bandejas Paisa. People who live in Antioquia and other northwestern provinces are colloquially known as Paisas, and the area is known as the Paisa region, but the area is not called Paisa.

Mike Conley Sr., the father of Ohio State's Mike Conley Jr. and the probable agent for his son's teammates Greg Oden and Daequan Cook, said that the three freshmen would probably decide in the next two weeks whether they would leave early to enter the N.B.A. draft. Conley Sr. said that he had not talked to the three players or to Ohio State Coach Thad Matta since the Buckeyes lost to Florida, 84-75, in the N.C.A.A. title game Monday night.

THROUGHOUT rural Italy, the first thing many families eat on Easter morning is a giant frittata made from uova benedetta, eggs blessed on the day before Easter, when the village priest goes around giving each farmhouse a benediction. One Easter, on a farm outside the old Samnite town of Venafro in Molise, I shared a 40-egg frittata made by the farmer's wife. It wasn't the best frittata I ever had, but it surely was the holiest. As the dull winter landscape of the Mediterranean breaks into fresh green life, the exuberance of holiday feasting neatly matches the exuberance of nature. The magic and mystery of Easter and Passover are firmly grounded in the realities of a Mediterranean springtime. The artichokes, asparagus, young fava beans and fresh green peas on the Easter table reflect that, as do the eggs that have piled up, uneaten throughout Lent, in the family larder.

I STILL remember my first taste of Condrieu. It was at Lutèce umpteen years ago, and it accompanied a warm lobster salad. Ever since then, to me, Condrieu and lobster were like pearls and a black dress. So naturally, luxuriating in the honeysuckle, melon, candied lemon and floral flavors in our wonderful array of Condrieus, I assumed lobster would star in my pairing.

IN college, I worked at a restaurant where the owner had a low opinion of the ordering habits of his female clientele. Each time he spied a hostess seating a table of women, he curled his thin lips and hissed derisively: ''Here come the rabbits.'' What he meant was that women nibbled salads, and that was to be pitied. And in the case of this particular restaurant -- an Upper West Side sports-bar-cum-steakhouse with a choice of soggy mesclun or sliced pinkish tomatoes and red onions -- it certainly was.

A couple of restaurants have embellished their takeout capacity. At Good, 89 Greenwich Avenue (Bank Street), Steven Picker, left, turns his bar into a retail counter at lunchtime, with well-composed sandwiches (tuna, turkey club, mozzarella with roasted pepper and arugula, all $7), salads (roasted pear and cheddar with greens, grilled chicken breast with grilled onions, all $7), drinks, soups, sweets and fruit, all ready to take away: (212) 691-8080.

Detroit's automakers stumbled in March while their Asian competitors took a sizable leap forward. Figures released yesterday showed that dealership sales declined at General Motors, Ford Motor and the Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler, even though all three said they would cut back on deliveries to rental car companies to focus on more profitable sales to individual consumers and were offering some of the largest discounts in months.

Two representatives from Spalding were at the Nets' practice facility yesterday as players tested the company's synthetic basketballs. The N.B.A. started this season with a new synthetic ball that players complained was too slippery and gave them cuts on their hands. The league switched back to the traditional leather ball in January.

Andy Roddick practiced on the indoor hard court at Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Winston-Salem, N.C., yesterday and declared himself fit to compete in the Davis Cup quarterfinal match with Spain that begins tomorrow. Roddick, who strained his left hamstring March 28 in a match against Andy Murray at the Sony Ericsson Open in Key Biscayne, Fla., all but guaranteed he would play.

8 P.M. (13) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE -- Starting in 1978 with a recital by the pianist Vladimir Horowitz, and continuing with performers ranging from the United States Marine Band to the singer Natalie Cole, this series has celebrated the breadth of American music. Tonight it honors the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz, a nonprofit education organization founded in 1986 by the Monk family and Maria Fisher, an opera singer, to offer young musicians college-level training from jazz masters and to bring jazz into public schools. Musicians including Clark Terry, above, perform for President and Mrs. Bush; Barbara Walters is host. 8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL -- Exactly how skinny was she? Twiggy regales the contestants with the story behind her nickname before instructing each woman to come up with a moniker for herself and then use it at a celebrity-heavy party. But when one model gets a little too comfy with the rapper 50 Cent, the festivities turn all wet. 9 P.M. (13), 10 P.M. (49) NOVEL REFLECTIONS ON THE AMERICAN DREAM -- There was a time when the country's collective ambitions -- and subsequent despairs -- were fodder for great literature. Take John Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath,'' which confronted an inconvenient truth: it sometimes takes more than hard work and clean living to get ahead. When it was published in 1939, the novel was criticized as being full of lies, corruption and Communistic themes. It sold out in a flash. This special looks at seven stories that dared to challenge the fiction of the American dream: works from Theodore Dreiser's ''Sister Carrie'' and Edith Wharton's ''House of Mirth'' to F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby'' (above, a scene from a re-enactment) and Saul Bellow's ''Seize the Day.'' Passages from each book are dramatized through still photography, animation and archival film; Patricia Clarkson narrates. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- Sanjaya Malakar may need more than Howard Stern's help to survive this round. But then, he may just have the vote of every hairstylist in the country. Tonight, one more contestant goes home, leaving eight. A performance by Tony Bennett softens the blow. 10 P.M. (ABC) LOST -- Kate must fend for herself after a betrayal. Meanwhile, Sawyer faces disciplinary action for bad behavior. 10 P.M. (Sundance) EMIR KUSTURICA, A TENDER BARBARIAN -- For a quarter of a century, the lovably gruff, Sarajevo-born Mr. Kusturica has been a mainstay of world cinema with films like ''When Father Was Away on Business,'' ''Time of the Gypsies,'' ''Underground'' and ''Black Cat, White Cat,'' which won kudos for their melding of unrestrained desire, rambunctious ethnic music and magical realism. In this documentary, Marie-Christine Malbert creates a profile of her sometime collaborator as he directs his romantic comedy ''Life Is a Miracle,'' presides over the jury at the Cannes Film Festival and performs with No Smoking, his Gypsy rock band. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

The beaten body of a man was found on Monday night in a house in Putnam County, the New York State Police said last night. Although the police had not positively confirmed the victim's identity, investigators believed it was Richard McKeon, 86, of 22 Fordal Place in Lake Peekskill. Neighbors became concerned when they had not seen Mr. McKeon for several days, the police said. They notified the police after entering the house and found him dead in the kitchen with bruises on his body. The police said they were on the lookout for someone Mr. McKeon knew. Lt. James H. Murphy, a state police spokesman, said last night that investigators did not have a motive for the killing, though he added that it did not appear to be a robbery. JENNIFER 8. LEE

Eighteen young women joined together in Manhattan on Sunday to burst into the spotlight as contestants in the Miss New York City pageant, a steppingstone in the Miss America competition. The winner was Erica Lynn Harris of New York University. She and Cherelle Gaines, who was named Miss Manhattan, move on to the Miss New York contest in July.

An obituary on Sunday about Baron Bernd Freytag von Loringhoven, one of the last survivors of Hitler's bunker, rendered his surname incorrectly in several references. He was Baron Freytag von Loringhoven, not Baron von Loringhoven.

To the Editor: As the articles in ''Humans vs. Cancer: Who's Winning Now?'' illustrate (Op-Ed, April 1), there is no shortage of ideas for how to deal with cancer. What appears to be missing, however, is a sense of urgency -- an appreciation of cancer as the grave and growing crisis it is -- and the national will to confront it.

A NEW SIDE TO VERMONT -- Vermont, which offers American companies lucrative tax breaks through unusual insurance arrangements, now rivals the Cayman Islands and Bermuda as the insurance destination of choice for many companies. [Page C1.] GETTING IN ON GLOBAL POSITIONING -- The United States monopoly on satellite navigation is about to be challenged. Russia plans to launch eight navigation satellites by the end of the year, seeking to take on a role as navigation technology becomes ubiquitous in the economy. [C1.] A BROADER SENSE OF OUTSOURCING -- The outsourcing of jobs to countries like India has increasingly included the jobs of Western white-collar elites, in fields as diverse as investment banking, aircraft engineering and pharmaceutical research. [C1.] ANOTHER TRY FOR TRIBUNE? -- Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle, the two Los Angeles billionaires who lost the auction for the Tribune Company to Samuel Zell, reconvened with advisers to consider making a new bid for the company, according to a person close to them. [C1.] TAX PREPARER FRAUD -- The Justice Department took steps to shut down franchises of the Jackson Hewitt tax preparation chain, charging that more than 165 stores had enabled thousands of customers to fraudulently obtain $70 million by falsifying tax returns. The I.R.S. commissioner, Mark Everson, above, said that the government's action was limited to certain franchises, not the Jackson Hewitt headquarters. [C3.] U.S. SUES ANTITAX ADVOCATE -- The leader of a nationwide movement that contends most Americans are not required to pay income tax was sued by the Justice Department, which said that his followers had used his scheme to avoid paying $21 million in income taxes. [C3.] AUTO SALES IN MARCH -- General Motors, Ford Motor and the Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler all reported declines in dealership sales in March. Toyota, meanwhile, reported an increase of 7.7 percent, and sales of its Prius doubled. [C3.] RECORD SPEED ON RAILS -- A French high-speed train broke the world speed record on rail, reaching 357 miles an hour in a test. [C4.] BUYOUT FOR AUSTRALIAN RETAILER -- A consortium has offered to buy the troubled retailer Coles, the second-largest retailer in Australia, on terms that would make it the largest takeover attempt in Australia. [C3.] STATES EMBOLDENED ON CLIMATE -- President Bush said that he did not intend to use his authority to regulate the gases that cause climate change. But the Supreme Court's Monday decision is creating political momentum in a growing number of states to bypass the Bush administration and make their own rules. [A1.] NEWS CORP. ASSET SWAP APPROVED -- Shareholders of the News Corporation have approved an $11 billion asset swap that increases Rupert Murdoch's control over the company and transfers the DirecTV Group to Liberty Media, controlled by John C. Malone. Under the agreement, signed in December, the News Corporation will buy back Liberty's 16.3 percent stake in the company, raising the Murdoch family's stake in the News Corporation to 38 percent, from 31 percent. [C6.] DOUBLECLICK'S NEW VENTURE -- DoubleClick, which delivers marketing messages to Web sites and monitors how many clicks they get, plans to announce that it is setting up a Nasdaq-like exchange for the buying and selling of digital advertisements. Advertising. [C6.] HOUSING DATA HELP STOCKS SOAR -- Shares surged, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to a five-week high, as the housing market and consumers showed signs of resilience and falling oil prices gave investors an extra reason to rally. [C11.] OFFICES RESURGENT IN MANHATTAN -- The strength of Manhattan's commercial property market is causing developers to rethink plans to convert aging office buildings into residential condominiums. [C8.] JPMORGAN MAY BUILD SKYSCRAPER -- JPMorgan Chase is in negotiations to build a 1.3-million-square-foot skyscraper in Manhattan near ground zero and bring thousands of employees downtown from Midtown, according to government officials involved in the negotiations. [B1.] JAILED VIDEOGRAPHER IS RELEASED -- A freelance videographer and blogger was released from jail, eight months after he was incarcerated for refusing to turn over a tape of a violent protest, ending what has been called the longest incarceration ever of an American journalist. [A9.] ONLINE THE EXECUTIVE PAY PACKAGE -- The latest on the compensation packages of corporate executives, gleaned from proxy statements and other documents, and interactive features on executive pay are at nytimes.com/business. TIGHTENING MORTGAGE REINS -- A growing number of New Yorkers, often with six-figure salaries and reasonably good credit, have begun to find that mortgages are harder to get as lenders try to stem losses from loans to the weakest, or subprime, borrowers. A report and slide show are at nytimes.com/realestate. MANHATTAN MULTITASKERS -- On bicycle, on foot and often behind the wheel, users of digital devices present potentially dangerous situations every day. A report and slide show are at nytimes.com/multimedia.
