About two thousand lawyers and opposition supporters chanting ''Go, Musharraf!'' and other slogans against President Pervez Musharraf protested outside the Supreme Court in Islamabad as the country's suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, left, appeared before a panel of judges to defend himself on charges of misuse of power. Similar protests were held in other cities. The panel adjourned the private proceedings until April 13. Mr. Chaudhry's lawyers urged an open hearing. Demonstrations and lawyers' strikes have erupted around the country since General Musharraf's decision on March 9 to suspend the independent-minded Mr. Chaudhry. Opponents say General Musharraf suspended him to weaken the judiciary. At the protest in Islamabad, flags of an alliance of religious parties and flags of the political parties of the exiled prime ministers Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif fluttered in abundance. SALMAN MASOOD

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Bush Says Democrats 'Undercut' Troops in Iraq The political brinksmanship over Iraq war spending intensified, as President Bush said Democrats had ''undercut the troops'' by passing legislation that ties continued war financing to timelines for the withdrawal of American units. A6 Members of a Republican Congressional delegation to Iraq who were criticized by Iraqis for portraying the security situation in Baghdad as much improved said they were realistic about the dangers that remain there. A6 Pelosi Arrives in Syria Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, arrived in Syria for a visit that is seen as part of an attempt to sway Bush administration policy on Iraq and the Middle East. A6 Blair Hopeful in Iran Dispute Prime Minister Tony Blair said that he was still hoping to secure through diplomatic means the release of the 15 British sailors and marines captured by Iran and that the next 48 hours would be ''fairly critical'' in resolving the dispute. A5 Behind the crisis of Iran's detention of the Britons lies an internal Iranian struggle pitting radicals, aligned with the president, against more pragmatic officials concerned about the country's growing isolation. A5 An Iranian diplomat kidnapped by men wearing uniforms of the Iraqi Security Forces was freed in Baghdad, Iraq's foreign minister said, adding he continued to work to free five other Iranians held by American military forces. A7 Civil Conflict Linked to Youth A study conducted by Population Action International suggests that young populations can contribute to strife. While it is not clear why, the study shows that 80 percent of the civil conflicts that broke out in the 1970s, '80s and '90s occurred in countries where at least 60 percent of the population was under 30. A8 A Political Stand-Off in Ukraine Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, above, and his cabinet resisted an order by Ukraine's president, Viktor A. Yushchenko, below, to disband Parliament, while thousands gathered near the Parliament building in support of the prime minister. The cabinet, which is loyal to Mr. Yanukovich, responded to the decree by ordering government agencies to disregard it. A8 France Wary of a Paperless Vote While France will be using paperless computer voting for the first time in the coming presidential election, opposition to electronic voting has grown, in part because some are made by the American company whose machines were involved in a disputed Congressional election in Florida last November. A3 NATIONAL A9-12 West Seeks Water As Drought Resumes A Western drought that began in 1999 has resumed after a couple of wetter years. And some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned, the biggest expansion in the West's quest for water in decades. A1 McCain Delays Announcement Lagging in fund-raising and under fire for supporting the Iraq war, Senator John McCain is overhauling his presidential campaign finance operation and delaying the official announcement of his candidacy, his aides said. A1 Debate on Greenhouse Gases A day after the Supreme Court ruled that the federal government had the authority to regulate greenhouse gases, President Bush said he thought the measures he had taken so far were sufficient. But the court's ruling was being welcomed by Congress and the states. A1 Efforts to Reduce Child Obesity The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation plans to spend more than $500 million over the next five years to reverse the increase in childhood obesity, one of the largest public health initiatives ever attempted by a private philanthropy. A9 Romney on the Trail The Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney dashed across southern New Hampshire, enjoying the attention that has come with his fund-raising haul while trying to raise his profile among voters. A11 New King Documents for Sale A new cache of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers has surfaced for sale to the highest bidder. A9 Plans to House Veterans The Department of Veterans Affairs and two nonprofit groups in Los Angeles have plans to sign a long-term lease this month that will allow damaged V.A. buildings used as sets for movies and television programs to be transformed into housing with social services and counseling for disabled homeless veterans. A9 Democrats Seek Interview House Democrats requested a private interview with an aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who has asserted her constitutional right not to testify at a public hearing about the dismissals of United States attorneys. A11 SCIENCE/HEALTH New Risks in Hormone Therapy A new analysis of a large federal study of hormone therapy has found that women in their 50s do not appear to have an increased heart attack risk if they take the drugs. But women in their 60s and 70s who still had hot flashes and night sweats were at increased risk for heart attacks, even if they were not taking hormones. And if these women took hormone therapy, their risk was higher still. A10 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 New Jersey Is Diverting Billions From Pension Fund New Jersey has been diverting billions of dollars from its pension fund for state and local workers into other government purposes over the last 15 years, using a variety of unorthodox transactions authorized by the Legislature and governors from both major political parties, according to an analysis by The Times. A1 New Tower Near Ground Zero? JPMorgan Chase is in negotiations with state and New York City officials to build a 1.3 million-square-foot skyscraper near ground zero and bring thousands of employees downtown, according to officials. B1 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-8 Tennessee Wins Championship Tennessee defeated Rutgers, 59-46, to become N.C.A.A. women's champions, and Coach Pat Summitt won her seventh national title and first since 1998. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-11 Vermont, a Tax Haven At conferences of the offshore insurance industry, there is often someone promoting Vermont. The state offers companies lucrative tax breaks through unusual insurance arrangements. C1 Pursuing the Tribune Company The news that Sam Zell is becoming the new chairman of the Tribune Company and has no plans to sell any of its individual newspapers hasn't discouraged potential buyers -- and even his rival bidders -- from planning their next move. C1 Russia on Global Positioning Russia and the United States are in the midst of a technological fight over America's monopoly on satellite navigation. The Russian space agency plans to launch eight satellites that would nearly complete the country's own system. C1 Business Digest C2 ARTS E1-12 Biography on Iowa Library Cat In a hotly contested deal, the life story of Dewey, a rescued cat who lived for 19 years in a library in a small town in Iowa, has sold for about $1.25 million to Grand Central Publishing. E3 OBITUARIES A13 Tom Moore A president of ABC Television Network in the 1960s who helped it narrow the ratings gap with NBC and CBS, and who later won five Emmys as head of his own production company, he was 88. A13 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: More than a feeling; it didn't end well last time; shackles on the AIDS program; stay on track. Column: Thomas L. Friedman. Crossword E10 TV Listings E11 Weather C12

ANFANG--Edward, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away at home on March 31, 2007. Born in NYC on March 13, 1919, Mr. Anfang supported his widowed mother, Ruth, and late sisters, Sylvia and Esther, by apprenticing in the printing trade. He was graduated from Morris High School in the Bronx, and attended night school at City College of New York where he was graduated Phi Beta Kappa in History. He was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Coast Guard, a Mason and Worshipful Master of Girard Lodge in New York. Mr. Anfang was President of Copley Press and Lithography, Inc., in lower Manhattan until his retirement in the 1980s. The success of Copley was the result of Mr. Anfang's creativity and high standards, and the genuine mutual respect, care and love he shared with his employees. Mr. Anfang loved to read, study, garden and travel, and was dedicated to furthering Judaism and Jewish causes, including the arts. He was a longtime resident of Teaneck, New Jersey, served the Jewish Center of Teaneck as a Board member and as President, and was a congregant of B'nai Torah in Boca Raton. Mr. Anfang was also a member of the Board of Yeshiva University's Wurzweiler School of Social Work. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gloria; his four daughters, Linda of Cincinnati, Roxanne (Edward) of Miami, Sandra of Half Moon Bay, CA, and Pamela of S. FL, and, six adoring grandchildren: Matthew (Marina) of Edgewater, NJ; Rebecca of Chicago; Michael, Justin, Marissa of S. FL; and, Clay of Half Moon Bay, CA. Services will be held on April 5, 2007, at 12:00 noon at the Jewish Center of Teaneck, followed by interment at Cedar Park Cemetery in Bergen County, NJ. Services were by Gutterman and Musicant in Hackensack. A memorial service in S. FL will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to your favorite charity. $(6$)ANFANG--Edward, age 88 passed away March 31, 2007 after a short illness. He was a Phi Beta Kappa Graduate of City College of NY, past President of the Jewish Center of Teaneck, and past Grand Master of the Girard Masonic Lodge in NYC. Mr. Anfang is survived by his wife Gloria (nee Murovchick), his daughters, Linda Chernus, Roxanne Joffe, Sandra Anfang and Pamela Rivlin. He is also survived by grandchildren, Matthew Joffe, Rebecca George, Michael Rivlin, Justin Joffe, Marissa Rivlin and Clay Huddle. Services will be held at The Jewish Center of Teaneck, 70 Sterling Place, Teaneck, NJ on Thursday April 5, 2007 at Noon. Interment will take place in Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Contributions may be made to a favorite charity. For further information call Gutterman and Musicant, 800-522-0588 or GuttermanMusicantWien .com

ZIEMAN--Isaac Zelig. Beloved husband of Ingeborg, father of Mimi and Josh, grandfather of Ari, Noa, Jake, Maya and Emma. Yitz, was a very special contributor to human kind, who passed away peacefully surrounded by his family. A true survivor, he handled his illness with the same determination and dignity that he showed throughout his life. We were blessed by him and his spirit and we will miss him. Service is tomorrow, 9:30am, at Plaza, 91 and Amsterdam.
Tomorrow is the deadline for "Win A Trip." The applications are rolling in and we're looking forward to picking a winner later on this month.

Our earlier post on the role circumcision might play in reducing the risk of contracting H.I.V. drew strong opinions from scores of readers. Tonight, Geoffrey Cowley, a spokesman for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, sent us a statement saying that the city had not developed a campaign to promote circumcision, but had begun a discussion on the possible benefits of the procedure.

Trailing by two runs with one out in the bottom of the seventh inning, Derek Jeter hit a hard ground ball in the hole between the shortstop and the third baseman. Ben Zobrist, the Devil Rays shortstop, got to the ball but did not have enough time to turn and throw and Jeter was given an infield hit.

The good news for a handful of New York sports writers (including me) is that Yankee principal owner George M. Steinbrenner has returned to his home in Tampa, Fla. Steinbrenner was on hand for the Yankees opener against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays on Monday.
Food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a the Minimalist, watches Pep Crespo make paella at a restaurant called L'Alter outside the city.

CHARLESTON, S.C. - On the last day of his four-day campaign outing through several of the early states, Rudolph Giuliani said that he would be leaving the consulting firm he founded so he could focus on winning the Republican nomination.

In an interview with the Rev. Jesse Jackson this afternoon, he told us that while he had "concerns" about Fox News, he had decided to "give deference" to the Congressional Black Caucus institute which cut a deal with Fox to do two presidential debates.
Infiniti's new EX concept car offers drivers features that make parallel parking easier.
I still remember the day when I was in my mid-20s that Cate, my best friend from college, told me her cousin had gotten into Harvard.
Contributing writer Richard Chang reports on the unveiling of the redesigned Subaru WRX at the New York International Auto Show.
Maserati's new GranTurismo, one of many exotic cars on display at the New York International Auto Show, features a 405-horsepower V-8 engine.

There are no automaker design studios in New York City. I find this extremely puzzling. New York is the center for fashion, all sorts of design, music and art - all of which must feed into each other somehow and breed a sort of design energy that would be beneficial to automakers. Right?
My literary hero and role model is a fictional serial killer.
A. O. Scott, chief movie critic of The Times, reviews "The TV Set," about the filming of a fictional sitcom.
A. O. Scott, chief movie critic of The Times, reviews "The Hoax," starring Richard Gere and Hope Davis.
Is it just me, or has the time come to get out the fool's cap, dust it off and place it smartly on the head of John McCain?
While snow flurries sprinkle the field, Johnny Damon is warm and toasty in the Yankees' clubhouse right now. There's no need for him to take batting practice, because he's not playable tonight.
Heart disease kills more Americans than any other disease, partially because treatments known to make a difference are often ignored.

Shares in Puma Rudolf Dassler Sport surged nearly 10 percent on Thursday as speculation mounted that PPR, the French luxury goods conglomerate, would launch a bid for the German sportswear maker. "There are rumors in the market that Pinault Printemps could make an offer for Puma next week," an unnamed trader told Reuters. Puma shares rose 9.5 percent by mid-afternoon trading in Germany Tuesday, far outpacing that country's mid-cap stock index, up 0.2 percent. The trading volume of Puma shares exceeded the three-month average by more than six times.
Sometimes you don't know what you are missing.

Critics of The New York Times Company's corporate governance have gained a powerful ally. Institutional Shareholder Services, a proxy advisory firm, on Thursday advised the media company's shareholders to withhold their votes for directors seeking re-election in order to send a "strong message" that changes are needed. The firm's recommendation came less than three weeks before the Times's annual shareholder meeting, which is likely to be a contentious affair. A fund managed by Morgan Stanley has been pressuring the Times Company to dissolve the two-tiered stock structure that gives voting control to the Sulzberger family, something the Times has said it will not do.

On Rush Limbaugh's show today, Vice President Dick Cheney talked about the trip taken by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to visit with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, and the message she delivered from her meetings in Israel about peace talks. (Which the office of Ehud Olmert, the prime minister of Israel, moved quickly to clarify.)

The New York City health commissioner's decision to encourage men at high risk of contracting HIV to get circumcised has drawn an array of reactions today, including a note of caution from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
As review sites have become more popular, the individual traveler's word is weightier than ever. When booking a trip, do you find hotel review sites helpful? Why or why not?

Washingtonians, in the years that I lived in their city, always professed to care little about fashion, and I saw no reason not to take them at their word. However, Washington loves inside dope - of every kind - and so I learned a valuable lesson in that early part of my career: Tell the readers what's going on in the fashion world, fill up their heads with information to drop at their next dinner party, but, for god's sake, don't show them. It's the showing bits that kill copy, that bore down on the reader like an ancient aunt. " and Mr. Ungaro's collection of ruffled dresses "
Kirk Kerkorian is not so much offering to buy Chrysler as he is volunteering to be paid to take it on.

The Democratic National Committee announced today that it would "sanction" six presidential debates, beginning later this year. It said dates, logistics and such have not been decided yet. They would start in July, and be held once a month.
Following is the draft script of the weekly "Only in New York" audio podcast. Listen at left or download it to a portable player.
Senate Democrats were caught off guard by the Bush administration's recess appointments this week. And part of the reason was that lawmakers are just not accustomed to being on recess this year.

There were about 40 members of the news media parked to the right of the third base dugout at Kauffman Stadium, about 20 stationed in the stands behind the dugout and about 30 more poised to the left of the dugout. This scene was a tribute to Daisuke Matsuzaka, who, eventually, would walk out of the dugout onto the field.

Tracinda, the investment arm of the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, offered today to pay $4.5 billion in cash to buy the Chrysler Group, 12 years to the month after an earlier attempt by Mr. Kerkorian to buy the company, which was instead acquired later by Daimler-Benz of Germany.

In addition to the controversy involving the legality of the Super Aguri and Toro Rosso cars, there's that other story about the moving floors, particularly on the Ferrari and the the BMW Sauber. That little device that is supposed to hold the floor in place legally during inspection of the car, yet allow it to move - which is illegal and helps the aerodynamics - when the car is on the track, has, not surprisingly turned out to be considered no problem at all by the drivers of the Ferrari and the BMW.

An expensive bidding war for a blood test maker, Biosite, may grow even pricier. On Thursday, Inverness Medical Innovations made a $1.6 billion tender offer, topping an earlier $1.55 billion offer from Beckman Coulter. The bid by Inverness, which already owns 4.9 percent of Biosite, values Biosite at about $90 a share. Beckman Coulter's offer was valued at about $85 a share.
The new trade link between Brazil and China marks a profound shift in world agricultural trade.
The mix of commerce and culture — plus sublime modern architecture, great food, nonstop nightlife and amazing views — makes Hong Kong a great weekend destination.
An ad for American Express.
Tiger Woods is going for his fifth green jacket and 13th major victory over all at this year's Masters.

The management-led consortium seeking to take Four Seasons Hotels private eked out a victory Thursday as shareholders voted in favor of the group's $3.4 billion offer. About 70 percent of limited voting shareholders who cast votes and 51.9 percent of non-insider shareholders approved the deal, the luxury hotelier said.

The desire to get behind the velvet rope can be a powerful thing. But when regular investors are finally given the chance to own a piece of Blackstone Group, the hugely profitable private equity giant, they should resist, Jim Jubak, markets editor for MSN Money, declared on TheStreet.com. He actually suggests they should run screaming from the I.P.O. -- even as he predicts that they probably won't.

The judging committee, after reviewing your more than 200 nominations, has finally settled on a name and a myth for the mysterious hexagon on Saturn. But first, let's take a look at a hexagon in Denmark pointed out to me by several readers.
The Volvo XC70.

At 1 p.m. today, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is scheduled to announce that the Police Department's training academy, shooting range and driver training facility will be consolidated and moved to a campus to be built in College Point, Queens.

Technorati is known for its software that searches and indexes thousands of blogs. So the company is presumably quite aware of the buzz making the rounds on the Net, in which bloggers are speculating that Technorati is positioning itself for a sale. Technorati has denied those rumors, but the denials may only be fanning the flames. After Michael Arrington of TechCrunch (the blog that broke the news that Google might buy YouTube) wrote about the situation, he appended his post with this update quoting Technorati's chief executive:
Predictably, my account last week of a presentation and test drive of BMW's liquid hydrogen-powered cars generated all kinds of angry nay-saying.
The stunning “Los Muertos” plunges the viewer directly into its protagonist’s world.
So much for peer pressure.
“Ping Pong” is probably the most extravagant celebration of a childhood game ever committed to film.

With the Democratic presidential field outraising the G.O.P.'s, $78 million to $51 million, The Times's Adam Nagourney, writing from Des Moines, writes that "the figures quantified a trend apparent here and in New Hampshire."

The board of Ion Media Networks is pushing the media giant NBC Universal and the hedge fund Citadel Investment Group to raise their already-sweetened takeover offer before a deadline next month that could plunge the troubled TV network into bankruptcy, the New York Post reported, citing sources it did not identify.
“G. I. Jesús” may be a mixed bag, but it is so impressive in so many ways that it demands to be taken seriously.

Deutsche Bank has lured an 18-year veteran investment banker from Goldman Sachs to join its mergers and acquisitions group. The banker, Bruce Evans, who was a managing director in Goldman's consumer retail investment group, will report to Jean Manas, Deutsche's head of mergers and acquisitions in the Americas -- and a former Goldman banker, the New York Post reported.

We wouldn't want to engage in the practice of "spinning the money before it is spent, ordaining mega-fund-raising as the sine qua non of a credible candidacy," condemned by editorial page of The New York Times today. But let's link to Philadelphia Inquirer columnist Dick Polman's assessment of the state of the 2008 Democratic presidential race anyway. "The plain truth is that the Clinton campaign has failed its first big test," Polman writes on his personal blog. He adds, "We don't yet know officially that Obama has outraised Clinton in primary season money, but ABC News, citing inside sources, reported last night that he collected $23 million, and Clinton $20 million. Her campaign has declined to confirm or deny."

British actress Helen Mirren, who has won a heap of awards for playing Queen Elizabeth, has bought herself a rundown castle in Puglia, Italy for £680,000 -- or about $1.3 million. From the looks of it, she'll have to spend a lot more to make it habitable.

Usually it's impossible to escape the hordes of hovering public relations people during the press days of an auto show. That was definitely not the case on Wednesday at the Saturn display here in New York. Three visits to Saturn's information booth revealed nothing: no press kits, no cigar-chomping executives, not a single marketing wunderkind.

The founder of Colony Capital, Thomas Barrack, says he wants Carrefour, the European retailer, to raise as much as 30 billion euros ($40 billion) from property sales, more than what Carrefour says its real-estate assets are worth, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Barrack, who bought 9.1 percent of Carrefour with the French billionaire Bernard Arnault, said the company should consider selling and leasing back stores to finance expansion.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has dropped out of the group considering a bid for J Sainsbury, the British supermarket chain, because of its involvement in a takeover approach of Alliance Boots, Bloomberg News reported. The Times of London said the remaining members of the CVC Capital-led consortium could submit a Sainsbury bid by Thursday.

William Neuman, who covers transportation for The Times, reports today that officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority are looking at using glass doors -- which open and shut at the edge of the platform and prevent passengers from falling or jumping onto the tracks -- when they build the much-anticipated Second Avenue subway.

Defense lawyers at the criminal fraud trial of the media baron Conrad M. Black sought to show on Wednesday that millions of dollars of payments received by Mr. Black and his co-defendants were approved by the board of his former company. Prosecutors contend that Mr. Black and three former executives diverted some $60 million from the media conglomerate, Hollinger International, by sending the payments to entities closely controlled by Mr. Black.

Rexel, the world's biggest distributor of electrical equipment, raised 1.02 billion euros ($1.36 billion) in an initial public offering intended to cut debt Wednesday. Selling 61.5 million shares at 16.5 euros per landed the offer was at the low end of the spectrum for Rexel, with the business now valued at 4.18 billion euros.

Along with its purchase of ActaVascular Systems this week, CardioVasc, a medical device company, said it had raised $20.3 million in venture funding. The companies will combine to be called Nfocus Neuromedical.
David Pogue referees a face-off between TiVo and the generic cable company box.
An exhibit at the 2007 New York International Auto Show featured concept taxicab designs.

A group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may borrow $11 billion to pay for their third attempt to buy the Coles Group, Australia's second-biggest retailer. Citing unnamed sources, Bloomberg News reported that the group is in talks with Barclays, Citigroup, Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs, the Royal Bank of Scotland and UBS regarding the loan.

AT&T's Rick Moore said the company is open to Italian partners in its bid for Telecom Italia Mr. Moore, AT&T's development head, told an Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera, "We are absolutely ready to take into consideration the interests of Italian industrial and financial partners."

In a letter to the Indian finance ministry obtained by the Financial Times, Vodafone has acknowledged that it would be in breach of limitations on foreign direct investment if it attempts to take direct ownership of India's Hutchison Essar. The proposed deal for the mobile operator is valued at $11.1 billion.

A threat to the proposed 479 million pound ($944 million) sale of Ford Motor's Aston Martin to a consortium led by the British entrepreneur David Richards loomed Wednesday as a pay dispute intensified. The Transport and General Workers Union said its members at some of the company's factories planned to stage a one-hour walkout on April 13 followed by a ban on overtime.

The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously Wednesday to ease rules under the Sarbanes-Oxley anti-fraud law that would give more leeway in requirements for companies and their auditors. Sarbanes-Oxley was enacted in 2002 following several corporate and accounting scandals and requires companies to assess the strength of their internal checks and balances to guard against fraud.

The Carlyle Group, the Washington-based private equity giant, plans to start a $1 billion hedge fund called Blue Wave, according to two reports Thursday that cited undisclosed sources. The Wall Street Journal said the fund would open next month, but a source told Reuters that was "inaccurate."

Lehman Brothers has been granted a license to operate in Qatar, the bank said Thursday. After having moved into Dubai last year, Lehman will continue to expand its Middle East business via a strategic relationship with the Qatar Investment Authority to seek ways to invest globally.

A British private equity firm, Charterhouse, is considering an initial public offering of Saga, a company that sells holiday travel packages and insurance to elderly consumers. Charterhouse provided financial alssistance for a management buyout of the company three years ago. Saga has appointed Close Brothers to work with the board in "exploring future ownership options" for the business, according to reports. An initial public offering would take place in the latter half of 2007 while analysts believe a float would value Saga at more than £2.5 billion.

The unitholders of the Movie Distribution Income Fund are going to court in a bid to halt CanWest's purchase of Alliance Atlantis Communications until they are given a say in who their Canadian partner will be, The Globe and Mail reported.

Under pressure from stock market investors, Britain's Financial Services Authority will review the rules that apply to foreign companies listing in London, according to a report in The Guardian. Investors are concerned that a two-tier system of corporate governance is developing as companies domiciled in Britain have to comply with one set of rules while those outside face less stringent regulations.
As Barclays and ABN Amro continue to thrash out a deal, speculation mounted Wednesday that the Royal Bank of Scotland could foil the British bank's proposed takeover of the Dutch giant.

Looking to expand the Chicago area's gambling market, Ameristar Casinos of Las Vegas has agreed to pay $675 million to acquire the Resorts East Chicago casino in East Chicago, Ind. Resorts International Holdings is an affiliate of an investment group, Colony Capital. Ameristar said it expects to close the deal sometime in the fourth quarter.

Canada's Quebecor might consider an initial public offering for its media division if conditions become right, a move that would help facilitate stock-based acquisitions, Quebecor's chief executive, Pierre Karl Péladeau told The Globe and Mail.

Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

In a fourth round of funding, Xoft said Wednesday it had raised $33.2 million to continue making its miniature X-ray device used to treat breast cancer. New investors in the round included Easton Capital, New Science Ventures and Hambrecht & Quist Capital Management.

Atlanta-based CompuCredit has made its first international portfolio buy in a deal with Barclaycard, a division of Barclays Bank. The maker of credit cards for high-risk individuals bought $970 million in Monument sub-prime credit card receivables from Barclaycard for $770 million.

Unarco Material Handling has purchased Kingway-Inca-Clymer Material Handling from American Capital Strategies. Though deal terms were undisclosed, Unarco becomes the second-largest pallet rack maker in the United States with the acquisition.

Software AG of Germany said Thursday it would acquire webMethods, a Nasdaq-traded maker of application integration software, for $546 million. At $9.15 per share, the offer is nearly 26 percent more than webMethods' closing share price on Wednesday. WebMethods, based in Fairfax, Va., held its initial public offering in February 2000, with its shares jumping more than 500 percent in their first day of trading to close at $212.63, after adjusting for stock splits.

The health care company Roche Holding agreed to buy BioVeris for $600 million to expand its medical testing business. The move strengthens Roche's position in diagnostics, where it is already a global leader. BioVeris said it had agreed to be acquired for $21.50 a share, a 58 percent premium to Tuesday's closing price of $13.60. The purchase will allow Roche to expand its immunochemistry business from human diagnostics into segments like life science research, patient self-testing, veterinary testing, drug discovery, drug development and clinical trials.

Cemex, the third-largest cement producer in the world, received clearance from United States antitrust regulators for its $11.7 billion hostile offer for the Rinker Group of Australia. The Justice Department said Cemex, based in Monterrey, Mexico, had agreed to sell 39 operations in Florida and Arizona to preserve price competition for large transportation projects in the two states. Rinker, based in Sydney, a building materials maker, gets about 80 percent of its sales in the United States.

Lundin Mining, a Canadian mining company operating in Europe, said it had agreed to acquire Rio Narcea Gold Mines for 993 million Canadian dollars ($858 million) to take advantage of record nickel prices. Lundin offered 5 Canadian dollars for each share of Rio Narcea, 3.7 percent higher than its closing price on Tuesday, and 1.03 Canadian dollars per warrant, Colin Benner, the vice chairman of Lundin, said in a conference call. The company plans to increase Rio Narcea's nickel and copper operation in southern Spain and might sell its gold mine in Mauritania, it said. Rio Narcea is based in Toronto, and Lundin is based in Vancouver, British Columbia.

Prosecutors rested their case Wednesday against Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, after more than a dozen company managers, industry analysts and others testified that they had been worried about looming financial challenges at the time Mr. Nacchio was selling $101 million in stock.

A lawsuit filed in federal court in Manhattan last week contends that a retirement plan offered by the New York State United Teachers breached its fiduciary duty when it accepted millions of dollars in payments from an investment firm in exchange for endorsing the firm's products to plan members.

At least one suitor is exploring an investment in the American Stock Exchange, the New York Post said Thursday. It reported that Morgan Stanley, which was hired recently by the exchange to explore strategic options, has enticed Susquehanna Investment Group to begin "highly preliminary" talks.
The tactics of the task force emphasize efforts to improve living conditions and self-governance.
Salman Rushdie, Cormac McCarthy,  Jonathan Safran Foer and J. M. Coetzee made it to the shortlist of eight contenders for the $135,500 prize.

The Infiniti EX Concept design study.
The Bentley Brooklands.
The only remotely notable thing about this particular jumble of boos, bangs and door creaks is that it tries to wed the horror trend with the heated-up God market.
Matching a plant’s  color, shape and texture comes into play when choosing a container.
The owner of an Ohio nuclear plant has asked its insurance company to pay for two years of lost production after a corrosion problem that it called “unexpected and unforeseeable.”
European diplomats are investigating whether Ethiopian and Somali government forces committed war crimes last week during heavy fighting in Somalia’s capital.
The change is a major step for Florida, which bans more people from the polls than any other state.
The charges against three Muslim men today were the first to be brought in connection with the attack.
At least 18 American service members have been killed so far this month, a especially high toll.
Genetically, the yapper arguing with your ankle is almost identical to the drooling behemoth bred to hunt bears.
The subject was the fate of a kidnapped BBC correspondent, Alan Johnston.
Hundreds of conservative Muslims staged a protest outside the courtroom during the verdict.
A judge said today that he would seal any psychological evaluations of Lisa Nowak, the former astronaut accused of trying to kidnap a romantic rival.
Britain’s relief at the sailors and marines safe return was tarnished by questions about how they behaved during their detention.
Carlos Beltrán went 4-for-12 (.333) with a team-best 6 runs batted in against the Cardinals in the Mets' opening series.

A man was fatally shot yesterday morning in South Ozone Park after transferring money to Caribbean relatives at a check-cashing store, the police and his companion said. The man, Courtney Atkinson, 51, who worked as a skycap at the Delta Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport, left his home on 126th Street around 11 a.m. to cash his paycheck and forward the money to relatives in Jamaica, according to his companion, Novette Facey. He was returning to the store, on Rockaway Boulevard, after realizing that he had made an error in the transfer, Ms. Facey said. The police said he was shot once in the chest on his way to or from the store. Ms. Facey, 38, who is the mother of three of his children, said she became concerned when he did not return home, and went outside to look for him. She discovered his body, covered by a sheet, lying on their street. The police said that they did not know if robbery had been the motive, and that there were no arrests as of last night. Ms. Facey described Mr. Atkinson as a hardworking man and kind father who liked nothing better than to set a pot of chicken-foot soup on the stove and kick back to reggae and calypso music. She cried as she said: “I loved him. I don’t know how I’m going to live without him.”.

A 35-year-old man fatally stabbed his 67-year-old father last night in a parked S.U.V. as his mother watched from the back seat, the police and witnesses said. The victim, Ying Du of Flushing, Queens, was taken to St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan, where he was declared dead on arrival, the police said. The son was taken into custody for questioning and a knife was recovered at the scene. The S.U.V., a Nissan Pathfinder, was parked in front of 64 West 37th Street, where the family business, Phoenix Jewelry, is situated, according to neighbors. Mr. Du was sitting in the passenger seat and his son was in the driver’s seat when they began arguing shortly after 6 p.m., witnesses said. The son took out a pocket knife and stabbed his father in the torso, the police said. A store owner who witnessed the arrest said the suspect “was pretty catatonic, comatose” and “was obviously in shock.”.
Pitcher John Maine took a perfect game into the fifth inning before departing after allowing one hit and two walks in seven innings Wednesday night.
Stephon Marbury led the Knicks with 30 points — 28 in the second half — but could not deliver the victory despite some uncanny scoring.

Cable subscribers will once again be able to watch out-of-market baseball games, ending their fears that the Extra Innings package would become the exclusive domain of DirecTV for the next seven years.
The Nets soundly defeated the Atlanta Hawks to move a game and a half ahead of the Orlando Magic for seventh place in the Eastern Conference.
The planned sale would contradict earlier reports that Apollo Management was planning an initial public offering.

The lawyer and parents of John Walker Lindh, the American-born Taliban soldier serving 20 years in prison after his capture in Afghanistan, called on President Bush to commute his sentence and set him free.

Lawyers who filed a class-action lawsuit against Menu Foods, which recalled more than 90 brands of pet food last month, are alleging that the company knew the food was tainted but waited to recall it. The lawsuit, filed in Chicago on March 20 by a woman whose cat died after eating the food, is also seeking an injunction to keep Menu Foods from destroying contaminated food because it is evidence. Numerous other lawsuits have been filed against the company. The Food and Drug Administration said that it had received more than 10,000 complaints, and that tests of the food had found a chemical used to make plastic cutlery. A Menu Foods spokesman would not comment.

A former intern for the National Archives pleaded guilty to stealing 164 Civil War documents, including the War Department’s announcement of Lincoln’s death, and selling most of them on eBay. Denning McTague, 40, who worked for the National Archives and Records Administration in Philadelphia last summer as an unpaid intern, pleaded guilty to one federal count of stealing government property. The stolen documents were worth $30,000, and all but three were recovered, prosecutors said.
The Department of Education wants to relax testing rules so children with disabilities like dyslexia can take easier exams than required under the No Child Left Behind Act.
Italia Federici, the head of a Republican environmental advocacy group, has been told by federal investigators that she is a target for criminal prosecution.
A senior Justice Department aide refused to submit to a private interview with the House Judiciary Committee, which is investigating the dismissal of eight United States attorneys.
Community Board 4 proved to be slightly more accommodating to Jerry Orbach’s widow, who is trying to have a Midtown street corner renamed for her husband.

Pictures with an article in Science Times on Tuesday about how animals experience time were published in error. The photographs were of the Florida scrub jay — not the western scrub jay, which was used in the research described in the article.

A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with the Advertising Column, about a digital exchange set up by DoubleClick, reversed the placement of two of its executives. Scott Spencer was at left, and Michael Rubenstein was at right. (David Rosenblatt was in the middle.).

A headline on Friday about a planned vote in Congress over the widespread killing of Armenians by the Ottoman Turkish government early in the 20th century incorrectly described the killings, in which 1.5 million Armenians died. It was genocide, not a “massacre.”.

The Lundin Mining Corporation, a Canadian mining company operating in Europe, said it had agreed to acquire Rio Narcea Gold Mines for 993 million Canadian dollars ($858 million) to take advantage of record nickel prices. Lundin offered 5 Canadian dollars for each share of Rio Narcea, 3.7 percent higher than its closing price on Tuesday, and 1.03 Canadian dollars per warrant, Colin Benner, the vice chairman of Lundin, said in a conference call. The company plans to increase Rio Narcea’s nickel and copper operation in southern Spain and might sell its gold mine in Mauritania, it said. Rio Narcea is based in Toronto, and Lundin is based in Vancouver, British Columbia.

A front-page picture caption on Monday about casualties suffered by an American combat brigade in Diyala Province in Iraq misidentified an officer standing at right while a hospitalized soldier received a Purple Heart. He is Command Sgt. Maj. Ray Edgar — not Maj. Charlie Fenton, the brigade’s chaplain, who was not pictured.

A picture caption in the Dining section yesterday with an article about a dinner of wild animals prepared by Steven Rinella, a writer, referred incorrectly to a bird Mr. Rinella was holding. It was a song sparrow, a protected species, which was later released; it was not one of the English sparrows that were cooked, and are not protected.

Because of an editing error, schedule information yesterday with a music review of a concert in the Wordless Music Series misstated the date of the next concert in the series. It is April 30, not April 20, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on West 64th Street in Manhattan.
An obituary yesterday about a former editor and publisher of The Detroit Free Press misspelled his given name. He was Neal Shine, not Neil.

The health care company Roche Holding agreed to buy the BioVeris Corporation of the United States for $600 million to expand its medical testing business. The move strengthens Roche’s position in diagnostics, where it is already a global leader. BioVeris said it had agreed to be acquired for $21.50 a share, a 58 percent premium to Tuesday’s closing price of $13.60. The purchase will allow Roche to expand its immunochemistry business from human diagnostics into segments like life science research, patient self-testing, veterinary testing, drug discovery, drug development and clinical trials.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about problems facing the Smithsonian Institution misidentified the museum criticized by experts as having as its chief weakness its later-20th-century and contemporary collection. It is the Smithsonian American Art Museum — not the National Gallery of Art, which is not part of the Smithsonian.

A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about auto sales in March gave incorrect rankings in the “How Automakers Fared” section. A corrected chart is on Page C2 today. The chart also misidentified the make and model of a car shown as the “Biggest Gainer.” It was a Toyota Prius, not a Chevrolet Impala.
Corrections

Cemex, the third-largest cement producer in the world, received clearance from United States antitrust regulators for its $11.7 billion hostile offer for the Rinker Group of Australia. The Justice Department said Cemex, based in Monterrey, Mexico, had agreed to sell 39 operations in Florida and Arizona to preserve price competition for large transportation projects in the two states. Rinker, based in Sydney, a building materials maker, gets about 80 percent of its sales in the United States.

Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the Juno awards, Canada’s equivalent of the Grammys, misidentified the site of the awards ceremony. It was Saskatoon, Saskatchewan — not Toronto.

A unit of Siemens, the biggest engineering company in Europe, sued Saint-Gobain Ceramics and Plastics, contending infringement of a patent for a radiation detector that is used in medical diagnostic scanners. Siemens Medical Solutions USA said the United States unit of Saint-Gobain, a European building materials supplier, was wrongly using the technology in marketing PreLude 420 crystals for scanners that produce images from radioactive materials injected into the body to detect diseases like cancer. The suit was filed in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del. Siemens is based in Germany and Saint-Gobain is based in France.

Google agreed to make it easier to remove offensive content posted on its Orkut social-networking site, heeding requests from prosecutors in Brazil. Google will set up a page on Orkut where prosecutors will send requests to remove content, the Rio de Janeiro state prosecutor’s office said. In Brazil, where Orkut is the most-used social networking site, prosecutors complained last year that the company was taking too long to comply with their demands to eliminate some material on the site. Google, based in Mountain View, Calif., said it had added workers to review reports of offensive or illegal content, along with special tools for law enforcement to expedite reviews.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the origins of the Etruscans referred incorrectly to the location of Lydia, an ancient region from which the Etruscans might have migrated to Italy. Lydia was in what is now western Turkey; there is no “east coast” of Turkey.

An article on Sunday about a shortage of playing fields for organized sports leagues in New York City referred incorrectly to an agreement between the city and some elite private schools regarding 63 playing fields on Randalls Island. The schools — not the city — would also get a virtual monopoly on two-thirds of the fields during after-school hours for 20 years.

An article on Tuesday about an accusation by the National Labor Relations Board of unfair labor practices at four Starbucks coffee shops in Manhattan misstated part of the name of the union seeking to organize Starbucks employees in New York, and misidentified the organization that reached a settlement with Starbucks last year. The union is the Industrial — not International — Workers of the World, and the settlement was with the labor relations board, not with the union.
Down went Gilbert Arenas. And with him, in all likelihood, went the Washington Wizards’ hopes of making a run in the playoffs.
As preliminary work proceeds on the Atlantic Yards project, new questions are being raised by opponents and new lawsuits are being filed in courts across the city.
A police officer has been indicted on charges of evidence tampering and official misconduct in connection with the shooting of a fellow officer, according to court documents unsealed yesterday.
In Newark, where many children are hit by cars, a school program teaches young pedestrians to look both ways.
pro basketball.
Officials at three universities profited from the sale of shares held in a student loan company that each of the universities recommends to student borrowers.

Air Force fighter jets pounded the headquarters of the Tamil Tiger rebels’ naval wing, destroying fuel reserves, military officials said. But the rebels denied that the base, near the northern town of Mullaitivu, was bombed, and said the government warplanes struck civilian areas, killing two people and wounding four more amid a sharp escalation in violence in recent days. There was no way to independently confirm what had happened. The area, part of the island that is under the control of the Tigers, is off limits to outsiders. But if government claims turn out to be true, it would be a major blow to the guerrillas, who rely on the sea to transport arms, medicine and fuel supplies.

The international war crimes tribunal sentenced a former Bosnian Serb paramilitary commander, Dragan Zelenovic, left, to 15 years in prison for raping Muslim women during the Serbian seizure of the town of Foca in 1992. One was just 15 when she was illegally imprisoned and repeatedly raped. Another was gang raped by 10 men, the court heard. Mr. Zelenovic, who was named in a landmark indictment that for the first time charged rape and sexual enslavement as a crime against humanity, was deported from Russia last June after being discovered in Siberia under a false name. He pleaded guilty in January. The judges convicted him of personally committing nine rapes in apartments and an abandoned house in Foca and involvement in three others. “The scars left by the sexual assaults were deep and might never heal,” the presiding judge, Alphons Orie, said as the sentence was handed down. “This perhaps more than anything speaks about the gravity of the crimes in this case.”.

Fresh clashes erupted in the South Waziristan tribal region after a local force opened a renewed offensive to expel foreign militants from their land, officials said. Up to 60 foreigners, mostly Uzbeks, were believed to have been killed, and about 40 surrendered, said Hussainzada Khan, the region’s top administrator. Thousands of foreign militants fled to the tribal lands from Afghanistan after the defeat of the Taliban in 2001. Relations between the foreigners and at least some of the tribesmen broke down last month, and government officials say more than 200 people, mostly Uzbeks, have since been killed. Tribesmen beating traditional war drums for the first time in three years raised an army of 1,500 fighters in Wana on Tuesday.

Three people were killed yesterday morning when a small plane that had taken off from White Plains crashed in a field near Maryland’s Eastern Shore, the authorities said. Severe thunderstorms were in the area at the time of the crash, the state police said.

The Vatican announced the release of Benedict XVI’s first book as pope, “Jesus of Nazareth,” to be issued in Italian, German and Polish on his 80th birthday, April 16. The book is the first of two volumes on the life of Jesus Christ, which he has said he began working on in 2003, while still a cardinal. In an excerpt printed in the Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera, Benedict drew modern-day lessons from the Parable of the Good Samaritan, saying that rich nations that had “plundered and sacked” Africa had an obligation to help the world’s poor.

Australia’s attorney general, Philip Ruddock, said David Hicks, left, who has been held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for five years, may be free to speak to the news media once he returns home to Australia. Mr. Hicks, left, who was captured in Afghanistan in late 2001 and pleaded guilty last month to providing support to a terrorist organization, is expected to be sent soon to Australia to serve a nine-month sentence. Conditions of his plea bargain before an American military tribunal include that he not speak to reporters for a year. But Mr. Ruddock says such a gag order may not hold up in Australia. Mr. Hicks has claimed he was mentally and physically abused at Guantánamo, but his plea bargain included a signed statement that he was never mistreated.
Wal-Mart has quietly introduced an ambitious self-help project to make its workers more productive.

Two French aid workers are missing in southwestern Afghanistan, along with three Afghan workers, officials said. The aid workers set off on a journey with a driver, a guard and a cook on Tuesday morning and have not been heard from since, said Muhammad Daoud Askaryar, the police chief of Nimruz Province, which borders Iran. The French Foreign Ministry said the two worked for the nongovernment organization Terre d’Enfance, which focuses on programs for children.
Sam Ross’s story, with its heart-rending arc from hardscrabble childhood to hardscrabble adulthood.
April 4, 2007.

A homeless man who did odd jobs for an 86-year-old man was charged yesterday with beating the man to death in his home, the state police said. The victim, Richard McKeon, a World War II veteran, was found in the kitchen of his two-story house on Monday night after the police received a call from a concerned neighbor. The suspect, Robert Gallo, 52, became angry after Mr. McKeon would not let him move in, the state police said. Mr. Gallo was arrested at a local motel on Tuesday night and charged with second-degree murder.

The city is reviving a long dormant program to help postal workers alert the authorities when they suspect that a homebound or elderly person needs assistance, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Under the program, the city would provide the elderly and those with disabilities with special stickers, or magnets, to place in their mailboxes. If mail piled up in those boxes, mail deliverers could alert supervisors, who would report through 311 that a resident might be in distress. Workers at the Department for the Aging would then try to get in touch with the person’s emergency contact or visit the home. Residents can register for the program through 311.

The death of a man who survived nearly 30 years after being paralyzed by a sniper was ruled a homicide yesterday after the city medical examiner found that he had died as a result of his wound. The man, Gilberto Medina, 70, died at home of an infection on March 21. On Oct. 25, 1977, he was shot on a Bronx street in what the police called a random act. He was hit in the spine, a wound that left him paralyzed from the waist down. No one was arrested in the case. The reclassification of Mr. Medina’s death comes after several similar cases in which people died years after they were shot, stabbed or otherwise assaulted. There were 35 such reclassifications last year, the police said, roughly three times the historical average.

A former Navy sailor pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he supported terrorism by disclosing secret information about the location of Navy ships and the best ways to attack them. The sailor, Hassan Abujihaad, 31, of Phoenix, was arraigned in United States District Court in New Haven. He has been held in bail since his arrest last month in Phoenix. His lawyer, Dan LaBelle, filed a motion on Tuesday asking that Mr. Abujihaad be released based on conditions determined at a hearing. Mr. LaBelle has said his client has a job and two small children. A hearing on the request is scheduled for April 11. Mr. Abujihaad, who was employed at a U.P.S. warehouse in Phoenix, is accused in a case that began in Connecticut and followed a suspected terrorist network across the country and into Europe and the Middle East. Compiled by John Harney.
Democrats raised a total of $78 million, compared with just over $51 million by their rivals, figures show.

Federal prosecutors are seeking the death penalty against a man accused of plotting the murder of an informant against him in a drug trafficking case. It is only the second time that the federal death penalty has been sought in New Jersey since the modern federal death penalty law was enacted in 1988. The penalty is to be sought against William Baskerville, whose trial began yesterday in United States District Court in Newark. According to the charges against him, Mr. Baskerville, 37, of Newark, learned the identity of an informant after being arrested on drug charges in November 2003. Prosecutors say that while behind bars he ordered the execution of Kemo Deshawn McCray, who was killed on March 2, 2004. Mr. Baskerville has denied any role in the killing.

DNA tests have confirmed that a leg found on the North Shore of Long Island matches a female torso that washed ashore in Westchester County last month, the police said yesterday. Tests on a second leg were also expected to show a match, said Detective Sgt. Robert Holland of the Mamaroneck police. He said investigators still did not know the woman’s identity. The torso was found on March 3 in a suitcase at Harbor Island Park. Deputy Mayor William Paonessa said the village had no active missing-person cases. The legs were found about three weeks later off Cold Spring Harbor in Suffolk County and off Cove Neck in Nassau County. The police said the torso had a stab wound and belonged to a large woman with a tattoo of two red cherries on a green stem above the right breast.

The City Department of Investigation has arrested a supervisor at the Human Resources Administration on charges of diverting nearly $10,000 in public assistance to pay rent on her Bronx apartment, Investigation Department officials said yesterday. The employee, Cherie Heyward, 44, whose job included supervising a unit that processed authorizations for payments at the Rider Job Center, was involved in issuing 12 checks for $720 to $920 between October 2003 and March 2004, for a total of $9,786.91, the officials said. Those checks, they said, were ostensibly for Ms. Heyward’s companion, a client of the job center, but went instead to Ms. Heyward’s landlord. Ms. Heyward, who has been charged with third-degree grand larceny, faces up to seven years in prison.

An unemployed mother of five has been arrested after turning her five children into beggars, the Yonkers police said yesterday. The woman, Antoinette Jones, 37, pleaded not guilty to endangering the welfare of a child — a misdemeanor — when she was arraigned on Tuesday in Yonkers City Court. She was released without bail after Judge Charles Wood issued an order of protection that bars her from seeing her children. The police said they discovered the panhandling when Ms. Jones’s 11-year-old son was reported missing at a Pathmark supermarket about 8 p.m. on Monday. When officers arrived, Ms. Jones’s 18-year-old daughter told them that Ms. Jones had made them walk several miles from their home to the supermarket, where they were told to stand outside and beg. The boy returned to the store several hours later.

A report released yesterday by the Environmental Protection Agency found no evidence of discrimination against the people who live near a site where several proposed cleanups under the Superfund program had failed. Senators Robert Menendez and Frank R. Lautenberg and Representative Frank Pallone Jr. had asked the agency’s inspector general to investigate allegations that the agency had neglected the residential area near the Ringwood Mines — where the Ford Motor Company dumped paint sludge from its plant in Mahwah for many years — because the area was populated by Ramapough Indians. The report said that “problems with communications” hurt cooperation between the agency and residents and recommended improving relations. The lawmakers criticized the report and asked the agency to study the treatment of residents more fully. Compiled by John Harney.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi insisted Syria’s government block militants seeking to cross into Iraq to join insurgents there.
The Yankees called off Wednesday’s game against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays and manager Joe Torre said Andy Pettitte’s start would be pushed back to Thursday night.
President Bush used the Congressional recess to push through three appointees who will serve without Senate confirmation through 2008.
A bomb was thrown into a mosque in Thailand’s rebellious south, wounding at least 14 worshipers, an official said.
Police said that three Yale students did not explain what drove them to burn a flag that was hanging from a front porch.
What is it about Mickey Mantle that makes him fascinating enough to have become something of a literary muse?
An arms-sale package that the U.S. is planning to offer Persian Gulf allies has been delayed because of objections from Israel.
Canada’s Conservative government said local markets would be eligible for deregulation after April 18.
Scott Thorman’s solo homer in the 11th inning gave visiting Atlanta a 3-2 victory against the Philadelphia Phillies last night, the Braves’ second consecutive comeback win.
Liberty point guard Becky Hammon, who had been the face of the franchise for several years, was traded to the San Antonio Silver Stars for the draft rights to center Jessica Davenport.
Schools in the predominantly white and wealthy town have been in danger of violating state laws on racial balance since 2000.
British sailors and marines will arrive in London today on a commercial flight from Tehran, resolving a diplomatic impasse that began on March 23.
Discovery plans to start a 24-hour channel focused on eco-friendly living, as part of a push into the rising environmental movement.
A subsidiary of Barnes & Noble will take a $10 million charge related to an investigation of stock option granting practices.

In 55 seasons at Grambling State University, Eddie Robinson won more than 400 football games.
The three Argentine and Peruvian former military officers had fled their home countries to avoid prosecution there.
The man, Tarik Shah, pleaded guilty to plotting to teach would-be Qaeda operatives how to wage jihad with hand-to-hand combat.

Planners are considering one innovation that would make the Second Avenue subway radically different from every other line in the city.
The Devils players were not the only ones stunned Monday when General Manager Lou Lamoriello fired Coach Claude Julien and then took the team over.
The 71st Masters began today, and Tiger Woods remains the benchmark at Augusta.
The company confirmed for the first time that it is in negotiations about a deal for the troubled American unit.
The new subway-themed condom exceeded all expectations, with five million sent out by mid-March.

Carson Kainer learned he needed a kidney transplant two weeks after the Reds chose him in the 14th round of last June’s draft.

The world’s largest seed company said a strong market for corn-based ethanol fueled its corn seed sales and raised quarterly profit by 23 percent.
The top United States intelligence official said that his position lacked the authority needed to run the country’s 16 intelligence agencies.
The effort by the housewives to coax tuberculosis patients into treatment has been an effective way to tackle the epidemic.
In Ukraine, a dispute between the westward-leaning Viktor Yushchenko and the Russia-leaning Viktor Yanukovich needs to be settled in the courts, not the streets.
A widely used system for examining mammograms is leading to less accuracy, a new study finds.
Much as we like the idea of ethanol production, it would be a tragic mistake to jettison two decades of farm-based conservation for short-term profit.
The Mets manager will wear Jackie Robinson's retired number when Major League Baseball reactivates it for the 60th anniversary of the breaking of the color barrier.
The audit would examine state financial records to determine how severely the pension fund for state and local workers has been jeopardized by underfunding.
The Obama campaign announced it had raised $25 million only days after Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said her campaign had raised $26 million.
The deal between the European Union and the United States to modernize and rationalize the governance of the trans-Atlantic aviation market is a welcome one for consumers.
Shell expects to resume oil production in Nigeria within five to six months after shutting down operations because of militant violence.
The operation was the latest in a string of raids on companies accused of employing illegal immigrants.
Fidel Castro said the Bush administration’s support of ethanol production for automobiles would leave the world’s poor hungry.

Bob Clark specialized in horror movies and thrillers early in his career, directing such 1970s flicks as “Children Shouldn’t Play With Dead Things,” “Murder by Decree,” “Breaking Point” and “Black Christmas.”

ALBANY, April 4 — New York State is getting its first fish pathologist. A million dollars is going to jump-start the effort to provide cellphone service along a major highway in the Adirondacks where a Brooklyn man died, unable to get a signal. And the state’s dairy farmers will get $30 million to help them recover from a bad year.

As expected, Candace Parker did not enter the W.N.B.A. draft Wednesday, which was great news for Tennessee and potentially bad news for every other college team.

The Commission on Judicial Conduct will receive an increase of $2 million under the budget the Legislature passed, bringing its annual spending to $4.8 million.

The Rangers’ win-or-else blinders notwithstanding, the Rangers and the Islanders have become ludicrously entangled in the Eastern Conference playoff race.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 4 (AP) — It was the equivalent of reaching under the couch cushions and finding a dollar or so in loose change.
Researchers said a rib bone found at the site where Joan of Arc was burned at the stake is actually that of an Egyptian mummy.

The job market also showed only modest improvement, reinforcing views of a weakening economy.
Lone Star Funds said it would divest itself of two of its South Korean holdings, fueling speculation it was planning to exit the country.

Beginning with next week, the winners of PGA Tour tournaments on the FedEx Cup schedule will gain automatic entry into the Masters.

TAG sales can be found through local papers, community bulletin boards and signs along the road, but there are more comprehensive resources, including estatesales.net, a national online listing service, and Antiques and the Arts Weekly (antiquesandthearts.com), a newspaper serving antiques dealers and collectors. Tag sale regulars —those who buy and those who sell — tend to develop their own philosophies about the best ways to shop. These are a few pointers.

A mountain village in Umbria is caught up in a tug of war with the Metropolitan Museum of Art over the Etruscan chariot that is a highlight of the museum’s new Greek and Roman galleries.
Natural swimming pools are self-cleaning pools that combine swimming areas and water gardens.

CNN is replacing the anchor team of Soledad O’Brien and Miles O’Brien and installing the newly hired Kiran Chetry and the former CBS News correspondent John Roberts.

11:30 P.M. (My Network TV) HAPPY BIRTHDAY, ELTON! Never mind the cake and candles: a celebration like this calls for a fireworks extravaganza. In honor of his 60th birthday and his record-breaking 60th concert at Madison Square Garden, Elton John, above, hams it up amid an explosion of confetti. Celebrities like Sharon Stone, Simon Cowell, Sharon Osbourne, Robin Williams, Whoopi Goldberg, Paul McCartney, the Beckhams and Mr. John’s longtime collaborator, Bernie Taupin, salute the rocket man.
“The queen of swing,” as Ms. Smith is now nicknamed, dispenses just enough nuggets of insider dish to whet your appetite for a marathon.
An article last week comparing stretching classes misspelled the given name of an instructor who teaches active isolated stretching. She is Susana Picheny, not Susan.
Elegance and temerity were on display in a program of New York premieres at this company’s Joyce Theater debut.

The nature and pervasiveness of child-to-parent advice has reached new proportions as many parents are treating their offspring as worldly equals.

TiVo has been quietly adding features that take the machine well beyond its original function as a video recorder.

A 35-year-old man fatally stabbed his 67-year-old father last night in a parked S.U.V. as his mother watched from the back seat, the police and witnesses said. The victim, Ying Du of Flushing, Queens, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, where he was declared dead on arrival, the police said. The son was taken into custody for questioning and a knife was recovered at the scene. The S.U.V., a Nissan Pathfinder, was parked in front of 64 West 37th Street, where the family business, Phoenix Jewelry, is situated, according to neighbors. Mr. Du was sitting in the passenger seat and his son was in the driver's seat when they began arguing shortly after 6 p.m., witnesses said. The son took out a pocket knife and stabbed his father in the torso, the police said. A store owner who witnessed the arrest said the suspect ''was pretty catatonic, comatose'' and ''was obviously in shock.'' JENNIFER 8. LEE
Introduced on Wednesday: BMW 5 Series Is it real? Yes, indeed.
WEITZMAN--Yaffa. Her soft, intense glow warmed and uplifted everyone she touched. All our love. Jerrold and C. Jeremy

To the Editor: In your enumeration of many of the current Washington scandals, and the concomitant presence of Karl Rove's ''tracks'' everywhere (''The Rovian Era,'' editorial, April 1), the most significant scandal was unmentioned: the Iraq war.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the origins of the Etruscans referred incorrectly to the location of Lydia, an ancient region from which the Etruscans might have migrated to Italy. Lydia was in what is now western Turkey; there is no ''east coast'' of Turkey.

The death of a man who survived nearly 30 years after being paralyzed by a sniper was ruled a homicide yesterday after the city medical examiner found that he had died as a result of his wound. The man, Gilberto Medina, 70, died at home of an infection on March 21. On Oct. 25, 1977, he was shot on a Bronx street in what the police called a random act. He was hit in the spine, a wound that left him paralyzed from the waist down. No one was arrested in the case. The reclassification of Mr. Medina's death comes after several similar cases in which people died years after they were shot, stabbed or otherwise assaulted. There were 35 such reclassifications last year, the police said, roughly three times the historical average. THOMAS J. LUECK

If you are the kind of person who forgets to water the plants, Rain Bird's Time-Release Water offers an effortless, if somewhat unattractive, solution. A gel made of 98 percent water and 2 percent cellulose, it was developed 10 years ago for parkland use and was recently introduced to the consumer market. It comes in a tube that sits near the plant's roots. Over time -- 30 days in the case of the 9-ounce package ($1.18), above, or 90 days if you buy the 32-ounce container ($2.06) -- the bacteria and enzymes in the soil break down the cellulose, releasing the water, said Randy Hall, a product manager for the company. After the gel has dissolved, the tube can be replaced. Or you could pick up a watering can. Information is at rainbird.com/landscape/products/accessories/RBIS.htm. ELAINE LOUIE

The Yankees called off yesterday's 1 p.m. game against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays because of rain, postponing Andy Pettitte's return to Yankee Stadium. No makeup date was announced. ''I heard it's going to be maybe 20- or 30-mile-an-hour winds,'' Pettitte said in the clubhouse yesterday, after his start was pushed back a day. ''You never want to deal with wind, because that's usually the thing that'll give you trouble with your command. That's the important thing that I'm thinking about -- hopefully it's not too, too windy out there.''

A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with the Advertising Column, about a digital exchange set up by DoubleClick, reversed the placement of two of its executives. Scott Spencer was at left, and Michael Rubenstein was at right. (David Rosenblatt was in the middle.)

SIMON--David O. Epstein Becker & Green, P.C. mourns the passing of our esteemed partner David O. Simon. David was an outstanding lawyer, noted for his honesty, integrity, good humor, creativity and commitment to the practice of law. He will be greatly missed as a friend and colleague. David was a member of the New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council and was active in numerous other professional and civil organizations, including the New York State Bar Association's Health Law Section and the American Health Lawyers Association. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Committee for Modern Courts, and was past chair of the Corporate Counsel Section of the New York County Lawyers Association. David also served as Deputy Assistant Attorney General and Counselor to the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights in the United States Department of Justice in Washington, D.C. In that position, he directed all employment discrimination suits brought by the Department of Justice and was extensively involved in negotiating the Civil Rights Act of 1991, which significantly amended Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and with promulgation of the Justice Department's regulations implementing the Americans with Disabilities Act. Our thoughts and prayers are with Judy, Molly, Henry and the rest of Davids family.

With 12 minutes remaining Wednesday night, Continental Arena was already nearly empty, quiet and hollow. The life had been sucked out of the building, but for good reason. The Nets soundly defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 101-86, to move a game and a half ahead of the Orlando Magic for seventh place in the Eastern Conference.

The city is reviving a long dormant program to help postal workers alert the authorities when they suspect that a homebound or elderly person needs assistance, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Under the program, the city would provide the elderly and those with disabilities with special stickers, or magnets, to place in their mailboxes. If mail piled up in those boxes, mail deliverers could alert supervisors, who would report through 311 that a resident might be in distress. Workers at the Department for the Aging would then try to get in touch with the person's emergency contact or visit the home. Residents can register for the program through 311. DIANE CARDWELL

An article on Sunday about a shortage of playing fields for organized sports leagues in New York City referred incorrectly to an agreement between the city and some elite private schools regarding 63 playing fields on Randalls Island. The schools -- not the city -- would also get a virtual monopoly on two-thirds of the fields during after-school hours for 20 years.

A corner of Astoria, Queens, that already has a pair of funky clothing stores (Loveday 31 and Candy Plum) has just gained the home-design equivalent. Mackenzi Farquer, above, a 28-year-old Chicagoan who graduated from the New York School of Interior Design, took over a former garage across the street from Kaufman Astoria Studios, tore out a dropped ceiling to discover a skylight and filled the space with inexpensive furnishings like a vintage yellow table lamp ($68), top, and old dining chairs that she and her mother repainted ($140 each), above left. Ms. Farquer's feet are resting on a Saarinen-inspired tweed covered stool ($160). The old mercury glass lamp, above right, is $145, and the mirrored bird coat hooks, above left, just $15. ''I think they're most adorable if you hang a flock,'' Ms. Farquer said. Site Design, 35-11 34th Ave., Astoria, sitedesignnyc.com. FRED A. BERNSTEIN

The Vatican announced the release of Benedict XVI's first book as pope, ''Jesus of Nazareth,'' to be issued in Italian, German and Polish on his 80th birthday, April 16. The book is the first of two volumes on the life of Jesus Christ, which he has said he began working on in 2003, while still a cardinal. In an excerpt printed in the Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera, Benedict drew modern-day lessons from the Parable of the Good Samaritan, saying that rich nations that had ''plundered and sacked'' Africa had an obligation to help the world's poor. IAN FISHER
DALEY--Joseph C., April 5th, 1997. A one of a kind gentleman. We truly miss you. Terry and Rickey Rackow

Because of an editing error, a report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Tuesday about the Juno awards, Canada's equivalent of the Grammys, misidentified the site of the awards ceremony. It was Saskatoon, Saskatchewan -- not Toronto.
