A new collection of leaf-patterned rugs by Paul Mathieu, a French artist, for the company Odegard, includes four designs: two variations on oak leaves and two on acanthus (including Acanthe Dehors, below). Although Mr. Mathieu's designs are modern, he was inspired by the ''grand tradition'' of the knotted-pile ''Savonnerie style'' carpets popular with the aristocracy in late-17th-century France, he said. The rugs are made of hand-spun Himalayan wool and come in five standard sizes (from 4 by 6 feet to 10 by 14 feet), starting at $115 a square foot; they can be ordered in custom sizes as well. For information and showroom locations: (800) 670-8836 or odegardinc.com. STEPHEN MILIOTI

An article on Tuesday about an accusation by the National Labor Relations Board of unfair labor practices at four Starbucks coffee shops in Manhattan misstated part of the name of the union seeking to organize Starbucks employees in New York, and misidentified the organization that reached a settlement with Starbucks last year. The union is the Industrial -- not International -- Workers of the World, and the settlement was with the labor relations board, not with the union.

To the Editor: For the last 36 years I have been one of ''the ones who can't see anymore,'' as the actor Gary Sinise describes wounded veterans in Bob Herbert's April 2 column (''Our National Debt''). With virtually no help from elected officials and most national veterans groups, it took me until 1998 to receive benefits for Vietnam war-related legal blindness.
Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today because of Holy Thursday and tomorrow because of Good Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

VARDY--Michael Moshe, Ph.D., 79, died peacefully April 1st. Devoted husband of the late Edith, beloved father of Joel, Iris and Michael, proud grandfather of Noah, Alex, Sophia, Andrew, David. Zionist who opposed Nazi occupation in Budapest to join struggle for Israeli independence. Associate Clinical Professor, Department of Psychiatry, Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Accomplished Psychoanalyst, teacher, mentor, writer, researcher, intellectual. We will miss you Aba.
LASCHEVER--Frances. Died April 4th, 2007, age 96. Devoted mother of Sandra. Beloved grandmother of Joan and Laura.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about problems facing the Smithsonian Institution misidentified the museum criticized by experts as having as its chief weakness its later-20th-century and contemporary collection. It is the Smithsonian American Art Museum -- not the National Gallery of Art, which is not part of the Smithsonian.

Two French aid workers are missing in southwestern Afghanistan, along with three Afghan workers, officials said. The aid workers set off on a journey with a driver, a guard and a cook on Tuesday morning and have not been heard from since, said Muhammad Daoud Askaryar, the police chief of Nimruz Province, which borders Iran. The French Foreign Ministry said the two worked for the nongovernment organization Terre d'Enfance, which focuses on programs for children. CARLOTTA GALL

For anyone looking for a sign of the health of the Democratic Party going into the 2008 presidential campaign, it came Wednesday with the last of the fund-raising figures reported by the major presidential candidates. With the $25 million reported by Senator Barack Obama's campaign, closing in on Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's $26 million, the Democratic presidential candidates collectively outperformed the Republicans, and by a substantial amount: Democrats raised a total of about $78 million, compared with just over $51 million by their rivals, according to preliminary first-quarter figures provided by the campaigns.
An article last week comparing stretching classes misspelled the given name of an instructor who teaches active isolated stretching. She is Susana Picheny, not Susan.

Boost is an amusing new seat for the younger set, who need a little extra help reaching the dinner table. A departure from the traditional booster seat -- and the old-fashioned (and outmoded) stack of phone books -- Boost is a block of dense foam printed with an image of the Yellow Pages. Slightly form-fitted to accommodate a child, this new take on the booster seat fits most chairs; $22 at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street), (800) 243-9810 or mxyplyzyk.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

The announcement, at the company's annual meeting in Berlin, seemed to be aimed at placating restive shareholders. Mulally, insisting that he saw no need for deeper cuts beyond those called for by its recovery plan, dismissed speculation by some analysts that Ford would require a third round of cuts on top of the two already announced. ''I don't see anything standing in our way of restarting our production.'' Cuomo, New York attorney general. [A1.] YOUTUBE BLOCKED IN THAILAND Thailand's government blocked access to YouTube because of a video clip that denigrated the country's monarch. Its rival, Circuit City Stores, swung to a loss of $12.2 million, as it continued to struggle with charges related in part to store closings. Nikolaj Hübbe to Lead Danish Ballet Nikolaj Hübbe, a longtime principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has been appointed artistic director of the Royal Danish Ballet from July 1, 2008, to June 30, 2012, and has been named the company's principal stage director from Aug. 1, 2007, to June 30, 2008. Mr. Hübbe, who was born in Copenhagen, began his training in 1978 at the Royal Danish Theater Ballet School, was appointed a principal dancer at the Royal Danish Ballet in 1988 and joined the City Ballet in 1992. Mad Ovlisen, chairman of the board of the Royal Danish Ballet, said, ''Nikolaj Hübbe is an obvious choice as artistic director.'' He succeeds Frank Andersen, who had announced he was leaving. Peabody Award Winners A ''60 Minutes'' report by Ed Bradley that led to reconsideration of the rape charges against members of the Duke University lacrosse team was among 35 winners of the 66th Annual Peabody Awards announced yesterday by the University of Georgia's Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication. Other winners include ''ABC News Brian Ross Investigates'' broadcasts and Web postings about sexually explicit e-mail messages from Representative Mark Foley, a Florida Republican, to young Congressional pages; the HBO documentary ''Baghdad E.R.'' about a military combat hospital in Iraq; the PBS ''American Masters'' presentation of ''Andy Warhol: A Documentary Film''; and the BBC-National Geographic nature film ''Galapagos: Born of Fire.'' Entertainment series chosen for prizes included NBC's ''Friday Night Lights,'' about football in a small Texas town, and ABC's ''Ugly Betty.'' Presentations will be on June 4 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan, where the sportscaster Bob Costas will be master of ceremonies. The awards recognize distinguished achievement and meritorious public service by stations, networks, producing organizations and individuals. Keith Richards Kidding, Spokeswoman Says No dad, poor dad, was ingested along with cocaine by the rocker Keith Richards, below, a spokeswoman said yesterday, Reuters reported. The denial came after Mr. Richards, 63, a member of the Rolling Stones, told the British magazine NME in an interview that he had snorted the cremated ashes of his father mixed with some cocaine. His father, Bert, died at 84 in 2002. The spokeswoman had no further comment on why Mr. Richards had made the statement. A spokeswoman for the magazine said late Tuesday, after his remarks were first reported, that they had been genuine and not a joke. Impac Award Finalists Salman Rushdie of Britain, Cormac McCarthy and Jonathan Safran Foer of the United States and J. M. Coetzee of South Africa made it to the shortlist of eight contenders yesterday for the $135,500 International Impac Dublin Literary Award, billed as the world's richest prize for a single work of fiction, Reuters reported. Other finalists are Per Petterson of Norway, Peter Hobbs and Julian Barnes of Britain and Sebastian Barry of Ireland. The winner will be announced in Dublin on June 14. Country Singer Surrenders The country singer Billy Joe Shaver surrendered on Tuesday in connection with a weekend shooting in a Texas bar and was released after posting $50,000 bail, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Shaver, 67, was charged with assault and a weapons violation. His lawyer, Joseph A. Turner, said Mr. Shaver had acted in self-defense when he shot a drunken, aggressive stranger who had a knife after being followed from a bar in Lorena, Tex., about 80 miles north of Austin. The victim was said to have been shot in the cheek. Footnote NBC announced yesterday that it would renew the comedy series ''30 Rock,'' starring Alec Baldwin and Jane Krakowski, for the 2007-8 season . ''Spider-Man 3,'' directed by Sam Raimi and starring Tobey Maguire and Kirsten Dunst, will have its United States premiere as part of the Tribeca Film Festival, where it will be shown on April 30 at the UA Kaufman Astoria in Queens, the home borough of Peter Parker, whose alter ego is the superhero.

To the Editor: Re ''Bush Splits on Greenhouse Gases With Congress and State Officials'' (front page, April 4):

A headline on Friday about a planned vote in Congress over the widespread killing of Armenians by the Ottoman Turkish government early in the 20th century incorrectly described the killings, in which 1.5 million Armenians died. It was genocide, not a ''massacre.''

Because of an editing error, schedule information yesterday with a music review of a concert in the Wordless Music Series misstated the date of the next concert in the series. It is April 30, not April 20, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on West 64th Street in Manhattan.

Pictures with an article in Science Times on Tuesday about how animals experience time were published in error. The photographs were of the Florida scrub jay -- not the western scrub jay, which was used in the research described in the article.

THE surest signs that spring has arrived are daffodils and forsythia in the park and a fresh crop of warm-weather bedding. This season's beds are dressed in intense colors and bold patterns, sometimes mixed or overscale. 1. The Bulb pattern from Area comes in two color combinations: lavender and blue, above, and green and blue. A full-queen duvet cover is $165, a queen-size sheet is $85 and a pair of pillowcases is $60; (212) 924-7084 or arealinenshop.com. 2. Peony is another duvet cover and sham set by Isaac Mizrahi for Target, with coordinating sheets (prices and sizes, same as above). 4. The Gypsy Velvet quilt in queen size is $370. For locations: (800) 442-8157 or www.pineconehill.com. 5. Bandana Paisley percale sheets are $28 to $60, standard cases are $30 a pair and comforter covers are $75 to $125; (800) 870-3513 or garnethill.com. 6. Tatami, a boldly patterned duvet cover from Designers Guild, comes in all sizes (queen size is $270). INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Iran Sets Free 15 Captured Britons Iran released 15 British sailors and marines it seized at sea nearly two weeks ago, resolving a diplomatic impasse with what Iran's president called a ''gift'' to the British people. A1 American officials are reviewing a request from the Iranian government for an envoy to visit five Iranians imprisoned since an American raid in Iraq in January, a military spokesman said. A8 Israel Objects to U.S. Arms Deal A major arms-sale package that the Bush administration is planning to offer Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf allies to deter Iran has been delayed because of objections from Israel. Israel says that the weaponry would erode its military advantage in the region, according to senior United States officials. A1 U.N. Issuing Climate Report The latest United Nations assessment of the role of humans in global warming has found with ''high confidence'' that greenhouse gas emissions are at least partly responsible for a host of changes already under way. A6 Pelosi Meets With Syria Leader Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, said she had frank words with President Bashar al-Assad and other Syrian officials in Damascus, pressing the president over Syria's support for militant groups and insisting that his government block militants seeking to cross into Iraq. A3 Clashes Continue in Gaza Israeli soldiers shot dead a Palestinian who was trying to plant explosives in the Gaza Strip, Palestinian and Israeli officials said. A3 NATIONAL A12-17 Inquiry on Loan Companies Reveals New Information Officials at three universities profited from the sale of shares held in a student loan company, an expanding investigation into the relationships between student loan companies and universities has found. A1 Obama Raises $25 Million Senator Barack Obama's presidential campaign announced raising $25 million in the first three months of the year, settling the matter of whether he could stand toe to toe with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, at least in raising money. A15 Bush's Picks Anger Democrats President Bush used the Congressional recess to push through his choice to be ambassador to Belgium and to fill two domestic policy positions -- provoking Democratic ire with all three appointments. A15 Arrests in Immigration Raid Immigration agents arrested two managers and 60 other employees of an industrial cleaning company on immigration violations and charges of identity theft in a raid at a central Illinois meatpacking plant. A12 Metro Areas Regain Population Several metropolitan areas that lost population or saw growth fall off when the high-tech bubble burst appear to have recovered in the year that ended July 1, new census figures show, but many coastal areas continued to hemorrhage people. A14 Study Finds Flaws in Screening A highly promoted and widely used computerized system for examining mammograms known as computer-aided detection, or CAD, is leading to less accuracy, not more, researchers are reporting. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 City Plans to Fight AIDS By Promoting Circumcision New York City's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene is planning a campaign to encourage men at high risk of AIDS to get circumcised in light of the World Health Organization's endorsement of the procedure as an effective way to prevent the disease. B1 New Jersey Pension Audit Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey said he would ask independent auditors to examine state financial records to determine how severely the pension fund for state and local workers has been jeopardized by underfunding. B3 Racial Imbalance in Schools The overwhelmingly white and wealthy town of Greenwich, Conn., is beginning to confront the racial imbalance in its well-groomed neighborhood schools head-on for the first time, more than 50 years after the landmark desegregation ruling in Brown v. Board of Education. B1 OBITUARIES B7 Eddie Robinson The football coach at Grambling State University who helped bring racial awareness to a segregated Southern society, he was 88. ''Home Design in New York City,'' a conference at the Museum of the City of New York on April 14, promises a glimpse inside some of the city's most famous residences -- among them, John D. Rockefeller's apartment (Michael Gross, center at bottom right, the author of ''740 Park: The Story of the World's Richest Apartment Building,'' will discuss its ''oil money look'') and Sister Parish's numerous interiors (the designer Mario Buatta, bottom left, will explain how they convey what he calls an ''automatically civilized'' look, as if the owners had been in residence for years). Other participants include the curators Donald Albrecht and Thomas Mellins and, right from top, the designers Cristina Grajales and Jamie Drake and the architect Richard Sammons. Images like the 1936 photo of a Park Avenue apartment, top left, from the Samuel Gottscho Collection, will be on display. The Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue (103rd Street), (212) 534-1672 or mcny.org. ELAINE LOUIE

A picture caption in the Dining section yesterday with an article about a dinner of wild animals prepared by Steven Rinella, a writer, referred incorrectly to a bird Mr. Rinella was holding. It was a song sparrow, a protected species, which was later released; it was not one of the English sparrows that were cooked, and are not protected.

Melinda Doolittle drew another round of praise on Fox's ''American Idol'' as the network dominated Tuesday with more than twice the viewers of its closest competitor. According to Nielsen's estimates, 25.7 million viewers tuned in to ''American Idol'' at 8 p.m. Following it, ''House'' at 9 attracted 21 million viewers of its own. CBS ranked second for the night ahead of ABC, whose ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show garnered 14.6 million viewers at 9. Among adults 18 to 49, ABC shared third with NBC, which led the 10 p.m. hour with ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (11.2 million). In the cable news race, the three leading channels all posted improvements in the first quarter of 2007 compared with the same period a year ago. MSNBC, in third place, showed the largest percentage increases, particularly in prime time, where it saw a 37 percent jump in total viewers (from 353,000 to 485,000). Fox News remained far ahead in first, averaging 1.5 million viewers in prime time, and CNN finished a solid second (759,000). Comedy Central also earned its best first quarter in the network's history, averaging of 1.1 million total viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

ZIEMAN--Isaac. The Dialogue Project will deeply miss the presence of Isaac. His experience, wisdom and spirit touched all of us. His concern and compassion for the rights and needs of all people, and his passionate commitment to social justice, made his a voice that Jews, Palestinians, Muslims, Christians and others, heard with the greatest respect. He helped us to understand more deeply. We send our condolences to his wife, Ingeborg, and his entire family. The Board of the Dialogue Project

SCHAEFFER--Irene. Our wonderful, special and dear friend. She was a shining light in the lives of all who had the privilege of knowing her. We will all miss her very much. Our sincere condolences to Mannie and the family. Dee and Arthur

ALLEY--Fred. We express our deepest sympathy to the family of Fred Alley, our hunting friend. Our prayers our with you. Ten Mile River Preserve $(6$)ALLEY--Fred. The Officers, Committees, and the staff of the Pawling Mountain Club mourn the loss of Fred Alley, an avid sportsman, former president, and dear friend. Sympathies to his wife Sharon, and their children. He will truly be missed.

After a dismal first quarter, music sales showed signs of life last week, with seven new albums in the Top 10. The country star Tim McGraw, above, with ''Let It Go'' (Curb), is No. 1 with 325,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That qualifies as one of the biggest openings of the year, though ''Let It Go'' moved less than half what Mr. McGraw's last studio album, ''Live Like You Were Dying,'' did in its debut week three years ago. Volume 24 of the pop compilation series ''Now That's What I Call Music!'' reached No. 2 with 230,000 purchases; the rapper Young Buck bowed at No. 3 with 140,000 sales of ''Buck the World'' (Interscope); and another rapper, Mims, moved 78,000 copies of ''Music Is My Savior'' (Universal) to open at No. 4. Good Charlotte's new ''Good Morning Revival'' (Epic) reached No. 7, Elton John's compilation ''Rocket Man: Number Ones'' (Island) is No. 9, and Jennifer Lopez's new Spanish-language album, ''Como Ama una Mujer'' (Epic), is No. 10. Last week's chart-topper, Modest Mouse's ''We Were Dead Before the Ship Even Sank'' (Epic), fell to No. 11 with 48,000 sales, a 64 percent decline. BEN SISARIO

An obituary yesterday about a former editor and publisher of The Detroit Free Press misspelled his given name. He was Neal Shine, not Neil.

The City Department of Investigation has arrested a supervisor at the Human Resources Administration on charges of diverting nearly $10,000 in public assistance to pay rent on her Bronx apartment, Investigation Department officials said yesterday. The employee, Cherie Heyward, 44, whose job included supervising a unit that processed authorizations for payments at the Rider Job Center, was involved in issuing 12 checks for $720 to $920 between October 2003 and March 2004, for a total of $9,786.91, the officials said. Those checks, they said, were ostensibly for Ms. Heyward's companion, a client of the job center, but went instead to Ms. Heyward's landlord. Ms. Heyward, who has been charged with third-degree grand larceny, faces up to seven years in prison. DIANE CARDWELL

Will the real buyer please stand up? Yesterday, the Cleveland Museum of Art did, announcing that it was the winning bidder for a rare 10th-century granite statue that sold late last month for $4.07 million at Sotheby's, setting an auction record for a work of traditional Indian art. The statue, above, depicting the Hindu god Shiva as Brahma, was sold by the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo, which is getting rid of many older works to increase its endowment for buying contemporary art. John Eskenazi, a London dealer, bid on behalf of the Cleveland museum, which has a world-class collection of Indian art. RANDY KENNEDY

A man was fatally shot yesterday morning in South Ozone Park after transferring money to Caribbean relatives at a check-cashing store, the police and his companion said. The man, Courtney Atkinson, 51, who worked as a skycap at the Delta Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport, left his home on 126th Street around 11 a.m. to cash his paycheck and forward the money to relatives in Jamaica, according to his companion, Novette Facey. He was returning to the store, on Rockaway Boulevard, after realizing that he had made an error in the transfer, Ms. Facey said. The police said he was shot once in the chest on his way to or from the store. Ms. Facey, 38, who is the mother of three of his children, said she became concerned when he did not return home, and went outside to look for him. She discovered his body, covered by a sheet, lying on their street. The police said that they did not know if robbery had been the motive, and that there were no arrests as of last night. Ms. Facey described Mr. Atkinson as a hardworking man and kind father who liked nothing better than to set a pot of chicken-foot soup on the stove and kick back to reggae and calypso music. She cried as she said: ''I loved him. I don't know how I'm going to live without him.'' ANN FARMER

To the Editor: Re ''New Generation of Qaeda Chiefs Is Seen on Rise'' (front page, April 2):

Lawyers who filed a class-action lawsuit against Menu Foods, which recalled more than 90 brands of pet food last month, are alleging that the company knew the food was tainted but waited to recall it. The lawsuit, filed in Chicago on March 20 by a woman whose cat died after eating the food, is also seeking an injunction to keep Menu Foods from destroying contaminated food because it is evidence. Numerous other lawsuits have been filed against the company. The Food and Drug Administration said that it had received more than 10,000 complaints, and that tests of the food had found a chemical used to make plastic cutlery. A Menu Foods spokesman would not comment. KATIE ZEZIMA

From today's mailbag:

As much as I love going out West (San Francisco, especially) or back home (Philadelphia), no city on the Mets' schedule is as special to me as Atlanta. I went to college here, where I met my wife and figured out for sure that I wanted to be a sportswriter. Most of my friends don't live here anymore, but I love coming back for no other reason than to eat here and here and here.
Another press conference? Or a cruise through Manhattan in an electric sportscar? Which would you choose?

Unusual trading activity before last week's buyout of First Data has reignited concerns about insider trading. The abnormal pre-deal trades are part of a larger trend: In August, an analysis conducted for The New York Times by research firm Measuredmarkets found that securities of 41 percent of the largest companies receiving buyout bids in the prior 12 months showed suspicious trading before those deals became public. Now, the First Data trades, and allegations of insider trading before this year's $45 billion TXU buyout, are giving the issue new attention.
The controversy over the firings of eight United States attorneys has just claimed its second career (well, outside of the fired prosecutors).

Senator John McCain got a little more than he bargained for when he visited Baghdad's central market last weekend. Shortly after his visit to the market - the scene of numerous deadly bombings in the past year - Mr. McCain said that the security situation in Baghdad was much improved in recent weeks as a result of a new infusion of American troops.

My son Michael is a huge fan of the N.B.A. He's 4 years old. When I told him about the concept of the All-Star Game, he almost couldn't believe it. All the best players... in the same game? To him, the very premise sounded too good to be true.

The Baltimore Orioles are still seeking their first victory of the season as they crawl into Yankee Stadium to begin a three-game series tonight. Jim Duquette, their general manager, said in late March that he had noticed an important difference between this team and the 2006 club.

In December I wrote about a school in Washington State, Overlake School, that had raised the money to sponsor a school in rural Cambodia, which then was also named Overlake School. The American students had visited their Cambodian counterparts, and both sides had been beneficiaries. That kind of program is also one of the best ways to reduce the scourge of sex trafficking in rural Cambodia, because when girls get educated they are much less vulnerable to traffickers.

Reporter Jerry Garrett selects a double handful of cars that stand out at the New York show.

For some Americans approaching their golden years, choosing the right place to grow old is less about golf and weather than about finding neighbors who share their attitudes and interests. Developments that cater to gays and lesbians have popped up from California to Florida. Retired Jews - or Catholics and other Christians - looking to continue a life of service and fellowship can buy homes and condos in religion-centered communities in Washington and New Jersey. Neighborhoods that attract retired pilots have taxiways and hangars. Looking for fellow neopagan anarchist pansexuals? Try Pumpkin Hollow, an all-ages collective in Liberty, Tenn.

At some companies, changes in chief executives’ pay roughly corresponded with changes in their shareholders’ total return last year. Several exceptions were in favor of shareholders, while other outliers favored C.E.O.’s.

Greenpeace's latest ranking of mobile phone and computer manufacturers came out this week and the results were quite surprising. Companies were scored based on their take back and recycling policies for their products, and on whether they have moved to manufacturing with less toxic materials. Greenpeace says that as much as 4,000 tons of e-waste are discarded an hour, things like keyboards and computer circuitry.
“Whole New Thing,” a minutely observed family drama, is the rare film in which the actors playing parents and child feel biologically connected.
The literary and journalistic frauds of the present era are small potatoes compared to the work of Clifford Irving, the subject of “The Hoax.”
“Grindhouse” is soaked in bloody nostalgia for the cheesy, disreputable pleasures of an older form of movie entertainment.
Gently and quietly told, “Daratt” (“Dry Season”) is an unassumingly political work that unfolds with the simplicity of a parable and the gravity of a Bible story.
Monica M. Goodling, a top aide to the attorney general, had said she would assert her Fifth Amendment rights and not testify about the firing of U.S. Attorneys.
The federal Education Department said that it had placed a senior official on leave, following disclosures on Thursday that he held stock in a student loan company.
Jean-Marie Le Pen, who is running in his fifth presidential race, this time has tried to shed his image as an anti-immigrant, anti-Europe racist.
There was no release of radiation, but it was the second shut-down this week of the Indian Point 3 reactor, in Buchanan, N.Y.
Greek Navy divers searched the wreck of a cruise ship today for two missing French passengers after authorities rescued nearly 1,600 tourists and crew members from the ship.
The former captives said today that they were threatened before making statements appearing to apologize for trespassing in Iranian waters.
The three Yale students arrested early Tuesday for burning an American flag were not trying to making a political statement, but were just pulling a prank, according to their lawyer.
Billy Gillispie, who took Texas A&M to the Round of 16, was introduced as the Wildcats’ new coach today.
State police captured a third bank robbery suspect today connected to the deadly shooting of an agent.
A suicide bomber detonated a truck with explosives and chlorine gas near a residential complex in Ramadi today.
The main international group studying climate change also predicted damaging and costly effects in the future.

An article on Saturday about a delay in a deposition for lawsuits against New York City over arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention misstated the context of a response by Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman. Mr. Browne was responding to a general question about a pre-convention surveillance program when he said, “No comment on anything that may have a bearing on pending litigation.” He says he was not in fact addressing a question about an apparent discrepancy between statements by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and himself about whether that surveillance had uncovered a plot to bomb a subway station.

An unemployed Brooklyn man was arrested and charged Wednesday with illegally transferring more than $3.6 million from the city comptroller’s office. He used the money to pay for jewelry, cellphone bills and insurance premiums, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said yesterday.
It was a forgettable return for Andy Pettitte, who was lifted in the fifth, and the Devil Rays capitalized on the Yankees' mistakes.
The Pentagon provided “inappropriate” analysis for its reports of a strong link between Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda, a report states.
The Islanders remained eligible to make the playoffs because they won their second consecutive game and the Rangers defeated Montreal, 3-1.
The victory capped a determined late-season run by the Rangers and turned a once-moribund season into a berth in the playoffs.

An electronics components maker, MMI Holdings of Singapore, said that the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company had agreed to buy the company for $664 million. A unit of Kohlberg Kravis agreed to pay 1.65 Singapore dollars a share for MMI, a 16 percent premium to the closing price on Feb. 8, when the firm first approached the company. MMI, which has factories in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and China, makes components for computer hard drives.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company dropped out of the group that is considering a bid for J Sainsbury, the supermarket chain, leaving its three partners to pursue the takeover plan. CVC Capital Partners, the Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group make up the rest of the group, which must decide on a bid by next Friday.

The Bank of England held its benchmark interest rate steady at 5.25 percent for a third consecutive month. The bank has raised rates three times in the last year, and the pause was largely expected, but most analysts expect the bank to raise the rate one more time next month to help control inflation, which has been exceeding the bank’s target range.

China told banks to increase their reserves for the third time this year, cutting the amount of money available for lending in a new effort to cool an investment boom that Beijing worries could lead to a financial crisis. The order comes on top of repeated interest rate increases and investment curbs imposed in the last year on real estate, auto manufacturing and other industries. The effort has had limited success in slowing the growth of investment. The amount of reserves that lenders must keep with the central bank was raised 0.5 percentage point, to 10.5 percent of their deposits, the central bank said. The increase takes effect April 16.

Software, a software maker, agreed to buy webMethods of the United States for $546 million in cash to add networking software to its product line and more than double its customer numbers in North America. Software, based in Darmstadt, will pay $9.15 for each webMethods share, the companies said. The price is 26 percent higher than the closing price of webMethods on Wednesday. WebMethods, based in Fairfax, Va., sells software systems that allow companies to link ordering and customer service systems and monitor the data, said David Mitchell, the chief executive.

Nintendo raised its group sales forecast 7.3 percent for the year that ended in March, to 966 billion yen ($8.14 billion), as a result of strong sales of its Nintendo DS hand-held game console. The company, which previously projected group sales of 900 billion yen, said it also expected profit to exceed its previous forecast, but did not say by how much. Robust sales of Nintendo DS hardware and software were the driving forces behind the revision, the company said. Nintendo, based in Kyoto, said it would release full results on April 26.
It is becoming increasingly apparent that José Reyes is evolving into the rare leadoff hitter who can claim both power and speed as elements of his game.
Mr. Bloomberg supports seeking new ways to combat the disease, but suggested that he was unconvinced that government should be involved.

Martin Brodeur surpassed Bernie Parent, Philadelphia’s stalwart Stanley Cup-winning goalie, for wins in a season with 48 and the Devils clinched the Atlantic Division title with a 3-2 victory against the Flyers last night.
Part of a wall collapsed yesterday in a popular Greenwich Village restaurant and onetime speakeasy where literary giants like John Steinbeck and F. Scott Fitzgerald once gathered.
Offshore oil and natural gas platforms in the Gulf of Mexico need to be built as much as 10 feet higher than had been thought, an engineer told the National Hurricane Conference.

A Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist is lending his talents to a crime-fighting television show in an effort to track down the killer of a young musician who was slain nearly three decades ago. The cartoonist, Berkeley Breathed, left, best known for the 1980s political cartoon “Bloom County” and the quirky “Opus” comic strip, has more than a passing interest in the 1979 case. The authorities believe the killer may have burglarized Mr. Breathed’s home when he was a student at the University of Texas at Austin. The cartoonist’s drawing of the burglary scene will be broadcast Saturday night on “America’s Most Wanted” on Fox. The victim, Michael Cahill, 28, was shot to death April 13, 1979, when he confronted a burglar leaving his apartment with his guitar.

Geraldine Blue Bird, who became a symbol of the extreme poverty that plagued the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation when President Bill Clinton visited it in July 1999, was sentenced in Rapid City on Wednesday to 34 years in federal prison. Ms. Blue Bird was convicted last fall of conspiracy to distribute cocaine, possession with intent to distribute cocaine, possession of a firearm in relation to drug trafficking and conspiracy to distribute marijuana. She was “pretty much the ringleader” of a conspiracy based out of her home that trafficked an estimated $2 million worth of cocaine from Denver to Nebraska and South Dakota over three years, beginning in 2002, the local United States attorney, Marty Jackley, said. Twenty-eight people, including family members, have been indicted in the investigation.
The State Senate expressed regret for the practice of slavery and apologized for official actions that promoted legalized discrimination over four centuries.

A law strengthening protections for social workers was signed into law by Gov. Ernie Fletcher, a Republican, six months after a worker was slain while taking an infant boy to visit his mother. The legislation, named in honor of the social worker, Boni Frederick, includes $6 million to hire 60 to 80 more social workers and to improve safety procedures. One safeguard calls for visits between birth parents and abused or neglected children to take place in secure locations. Ms. Frederick died in October after being stabbed and beaten when she took a 10-month-old boy for a visit at his mother’s house. The boy was found safe and returned to foster care after a three-day manhunt. His mother and her boyfriend have pleaded not guilty to charges of murder, kidnapping, robbery and theft.

A nuclear reactor at the Indian Point power station was shut down for nearly a day because of a mechanical problem, but the malfunction posed no danger to the public or workers, plant officials and federal regulators said yesterday. Workers shut Indian Point 3, one of the station’s two active reactors, shortly after 4 a.m. Tuesday. Officials said a water pump that feeds the plant’s steam generators had malfunctioned. No radiation was released, they said. The 31-year-old plant resumed service about 1 a.m. Wednesday, after an employee analysis determined that it was safe to restart, said Neil Sheehan, a spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

The State Department of Labor said yesterday that the unemployment insurance services provided at 250 Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn and at 138-60 Barclay Avenue in Flushing, Queens, have been phased out. It said claimants were sent three notification letters before the phaseout. The department said those people who relied on either of the offices are encouraged to use its telephone or Internet claims systems. The department also said that it has expanded outreach to Chinese speakers, including making more interpreters available. The toll-free phone number for claims questions is (888) 209-8124.

An article on March 30 about France’s debate over national identity and its role in the presidential election misstated a provision of a law that regulates the wearing of head scarves by Muslim girls and women, one of the cultural issues with which the nation has struggled. The 2004 law bans head scarves in French primary and secondary schools; it does not apply to higher education.

New Jersey Transit service on the Montclair-Boonton Line was suspended for more than seven hours during the morning rush yesterday after a hydrant broke, flooding the tracks, the agency said. Service was suspended on the line around 5:45 a.m., said Penny Bassett-Hackett, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit, after more than a foot of water rose over the tracks near the Watsessing station, near Montclair State University. A delivery truck crashed into the hydrant in the parking lot of a nearby Home Depot store. Pumps were brought in to remove the water and commuters were diverted to bus and Newark PATH lines. Service was restored about 1 p.m., Ms. Bassett-Hackett said.

An article on Wednesday about an analysis of studies on the effects of hormone therapy for menopause misstated the results of a study on the risks of taking estrogen alone as hormone therapy. Estrogen alone increased the risk of stroke; it did not also increase the risk of breast cancer. The article also omitted the name of the journal that published the analysis. It was The Journal of the American Medical Association.

A coalition of advocacy and neighborhood groups filed a lawsuit yesterday in State Supreme Court seeking to overturn the state’s approval of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, charging that the review process was flawed. The suit, filed by 26 groups, stated that the Empire State Development Corporation intentionally understated or played down the potential costs and traffic and pollution effects of the project in its zeal to approve it in December. The $4 billion project, proposed by the developer Forest City Ratner, calls for eight million square feet of housing and office space and a basketball arena near Downtown Brooklyn.

The owner of a Putnam County bar has been charged with allowing an off-duty bartender to drink and drive, resulting in a head-on crash that killed her and another woman, the authorities said. The bartender, Sandra Longchamps, 43, of Southeast, had finished her shift at the Paddock Restaurant and Tavern in Patterson on the day of the Super Bowl and stayed to have drinks, the Putnam County Sheriff’s Department said on Wednesday. She then drove about a mile and plowed into a minivan, the department said. A coroner’s report said that Ms. Longchamps’s blood alcohol level was more than four times the legal limit. The department said that Ray Knox Jr., 41, who owns the Paddock and lives in New Milford, Conn., was charged on Wednesday with violating New York’s alcoholic beverage law, which can hold a bartender or server liable for injuries caused by an alcohol-impaired patron.

A father and two sons have been charged with growing marijuana in the attic of their home, prosecutors said yesterday. The father, Fred Massaro, 46, and his sons Michael Barbis, 19, and Thomas Barbis, 18, were arrested on Wednesday after officers discovered 20 marijuana plants in their attic during a raid, the Suffolk County police said. Detectives seized the plants, an additional pound of marijuana and $330 in cash from the house, which had been under surveillance, the police said. All three were charged with criminal possession of marijuana, of a controlled substance and of a hypodermic needle, prosecutors said. Mr. Massaro was charged with endangering the welfare of his two younger children, ages 12 and 13. The arrested men were arraigned yesterday in Suffolk County District Court and ordered held in bail, prosecutors said.

An article on Tuesday about the disappearance of Jewish landmarks in Miami Beach included an outdated reference to Congregation B’Nai Jeshurun in Manhattan, from which Rabbi Kliel Rose, who is trying to attract new members to Temple Emanu-El in South Beach, was recruited. It is unaffiliated and no longer a Conservative synagogue.

Three Yale University students arrested after an American flag was set ablaze on the porch of a New Haven home were not trying to make a political statement, their lawyer said yesterday. The students, Nikolaos Angelopoulos, 19, Farhad Anklesaria, 19, and Hyder Akbar, 23, were charged with arson, reckless endangerment and other crimes after, the authorities said, they set the flag on fire Tuesday morning while returning to campus. “There was absolutely no political motivation,” said the lawyer, William Dow. He called the burning “a foolish college prank” and said that Mr. Akbar regretted the vandalism and intended to apologize. The other two students maintained their innocence and said they were in the wrong place at the wrong time, Mr. Dow said. Compiled by Anthony Ramirez.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the turnaround effort at the Ford Motor Company misstated the number and timing of plant closings under its restructuring plan. Ford will close 16 plants, not 14. And nine of those plants, not all 16, will close by 2008. The rest will close by 2012.
Corrections
A senior official at the Education Department sold more than $100,000 in shares in a student loan company even as he was helping oversee lenders.
The agent was shot from behind at close range during a confrontation with gunmen outside a bank in New Jersey.
April 5, 2007.

Four warships and two military helicopters joined a fleet of commercial vessels that rushed to evacuate 1,200 passengers, mostly Americans, and 300 crew members from a cruise ship that ran aground off the Aegean island of Santorini while trying to dock. The authorities said the cruise ship, the Sea Diamond, operated by Louis Hellenic Cruise Lines, began listing after striking a bed of rocks about a mile from the coast. The ship was later towed from the rocks. It had left Greece’s main port of Pireaus on Monday for a weeklong island-hopping cruise in the Aegean.

Prosecutors in Ankara decided not to open a case against Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan after looking into claims that he praised Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader, by using the honorific “sayin,” or esteemed, the Anatolian News Agency reported. Praising a criminal or criminal organization is a crime. The news agency said prosecutors found “no element of criminal offence” in a 2000 Australian radio interview in which Mr. Erdogan was said to have used the honorific. Turkey’s main opposition party had insisted that the claim should disqualify him from running for president this year.

Bangladesh’s national elections will not be held in the next year and a half, the election commission said. “We need at least 18 months to prepare a flawless voter list, along with photographs of voters,” the chief election commissioner, A. T. M. Shamsul Huda, told reporters at his office in Dhaka. National elections that had been scheduled for Jan. 22 were postponed after weeks of violent street protests demanding electoral reforms. On Jan. 11, President Iajuddin Ahmed imposed a state of emergency. The emergency powers have banned political activity and suspended fundamental rights.

A medical tribunal in West Yorkshire found a dentist guilty of urinating in his surgery sink and of using dental tools meant for patients to clean his fingernails and ears. The tribunal said it was satisfied that the evidence showed that the 51-year-old dentist, Alan Hutchinson, who “routinely” did not wear gloves or wash his hands, had risked the health of “himself, staff and patients” for more than 28 years. A nurse who worked for Dr. Hutchinson for 16 years said she had caught him urinating in the sink more than once. A later hearing will decide if the dentist’s unhygienic habits impaired his ability to treat patients, and if so, whether he should be banned from practicing.

The federal government lifted a three-month freeze on the acquisition of land by state governments to set up special economic zones intended to attract overseas investors with generous tax breaks. The freeze was imposed in January after violent protests by farmers in West Bengal State who said they were being displaced without proper compensation for their land. Commerce and Industry Minister Kamal Nath said developers would now be required to buy the land directly from the farmers, rather than from state governments. The federal government will also limit the size of the economic zones.

The widely feared strongman Ramzan A. Kadyrov was inaugurated as the new president of Chechnya with a blessing from the Kremlin, which has relied on him to stabilize the region after more than a decade of separatist fighting. Human rights groups say that security forces under Mr. Kadyrov’s control abduct and torture civilians suspected of ties to Chechnya’s separatist rebels. Some suggest that he was tied to the murder last year of the journalist Anna Politkovskaya. But Mr. Kadyrov, 30, is credited with a reconstruction boom that he administered as the region’s prime minister, under which the capital, Grozny, is being transformed from a moonscape of rubble and shattered buildings. “My main goal is to make Chechnya prosperous and peaceful,” he said at the inauguration ceremony in Gudermes, east of Grozny.
Mitt Romney wanted to avoid the fate of others whose self-financed campaigns went down as quixotic indulgences.
After failing in one takeover in the 1990s, the billionaire has returned with a $4.5 billion bid for the automaker.
Although Samuel Zell will control a minority of the Tribune Company board, he will have the right to veto any major transactions.
The tactics of the task force emphasize efforts to improve living conditions and self-governance.
The Bush administration said that the release of the 15 Britons created no new openings in dealing with Tehran.
Pat Venditte is believed to be the only ambidextrous pitcher in N.C.A.A. Division I college baseball.
The chief of counterterrorism at Scotland Yard said that the police now had a better picture of the preparations for the suicide mission.
At least 18 American service members have been killed this month, according to Iraq Coalition Casualty Count, an independent Web site.
Presidential hopeful Mitt Romney addresses conflicting reports of his hunting record in an effort to reassure Republican conservatives that he is one of them.
After two championships, the Florida coach is staying put.  But the controversial Bob Huggins will leave Kansas State for West Virginia after one season.
Augusta National battered almost everyone and nearly toppled defending Masters champion Phil Mickelson on the first day of play.
Britain’s relief at the sailors’ and marines’ safe return was tarnished by questions about how they behaved during their detention.
European diplomats are investigating whether Ethiopian and Somali government forces committed war crimes last week during heavy fighting in Somalia’s capital.
The 911 system has not kept pace with the nation’s rapidly changing communication habits.
James Blake is preparing to play No. 6-ranked Tommy Robredo of Spain on Friday in the opening match of a Davis Cup quarterfinal.
An independent corporate advisory group is urging shareholders to pressure the company over dissatisfaction with its performance and ownership structure.
A golfing buddy recalls the men who died in Wednesday's crash of a small plane that took off from Westchester County Airport and crashed in Maryland.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,252 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:.
Michigan State became the first Central Collegiate Hockey Association team to reach the Frozen Four since 2003, and the first in the championship game since Michigan won in 1998.

FAIRPORT, N.Y., April 5 (AP) — Constellation Brands, the world’s biggest winemaker, said Thursday that its quarterly profit grew 26 percent as strong wine sales in the United States helped offset heightened competition in Britain and a drop in sales of imported beer.
A British official indicated that the government intended to take some steps to regulate and try to influence the affairs of Muslim religious institutions and mosques.
“I think abortion is wrong,” Rudolph W. Giuliani said. “But ultimately, I think it is a woman’s right, a woman’s choice.”
The long-beleaguered Police Academy will move to a 30-acre, high-tech campus in Queens.

DENVER, April 4 (AP) — Defense lawyers in the insider trading trial of Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications, told a federal judge on Thursday that they thought they could wrap up their case in a day and a half, and might not present evidence about secret government contracts, as they have indicated they would since December 2005.
A Ugandan court scrapped the nation’s adultery law on Thursday, saying it was unconstitutional and favored men.
Is risk decreased by assuming more of it and spreading it out? Investors seem to think so.
The biscuits, made by Sunshine Mills Inc., contain wheat gluten imported from China that contained melamine, the F.D.A. said.
Citigroup reorganized senior management at its private bank yesterday, replacing the chief executive, Damian M. Kozlowski, with two executives.
The potential buyer, David Bistricer, is back with a new plan, powerful lobbyists and potential backing from two politically influential black ministers.

Remington Arms, the gun maker that has equipped American soldiers for 150 years, has agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm, Cerberus Capital Management, for $118 million, a statement by Remington said yesterday. The company, based in Madison, N.C., reported its first profit in three years in 2006.

Each development in the show trials of Guantánamo Bay inmates brings fresh evidence of how urgent it is for the courts to strike down the Military Commissions Act of 2006 and for Congress to rewrite it.
An exhibit at the New York International Auto Show  celebrates the 100th anniversary of the modern-day taxi by presenting forward-looking concepts.
Jimmy Rollins said the Philadelphia Phillies were the team to beat in the National League East. So far, they have merely been beaten up.
The owner of an Ohio nuclear plant has asked its insurer to pay for two years of lost production because of corrosion that it called “unexpected and unforeseeable.”
An unusual law that shapes the oversight of German companies is again being re-examined after corruption scandals at Siemens and Volkswagen.
The special agent shot dead Thursday in suburban New Jersey was the 51st to die in the line of duty in the agency’s 99-year history.

The media lord’s lawyers produce evidence that some noncompete payments were reported to the S.E.C.

.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy requested “a full and complete account of the development of the plan to replace United States attorneys” from the attorney general.

A tiny maker of diagnostic tests attracts an offer of $90 a share.

.

The wireless chip developer hopes to resolve a dispute over a technology license agreement that expires Monday.

.
At their best this season, the Knicks were merely a .500 team. The late-season injuries, and the resulting swoon, highlight their failure to capitalize when the roster was whole.
The New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway would do well to look at nearby ports for a glimpse at how public agencies have learned to work with private firms.
Many executives of large companies are starting to call for a national approach to fixing health care, warning that an employer-subsidized health system is unsustainable.
Aggressive border collies will be used in Central Park to keep geese away from the park's Kentucky bluegrass.
Three more reminders of how President Bush’s claims of wanting to work with Congress’s Democratic leadership are just empty words.
Diane Rothschild was an advertising executive and copywriter who headed her own firm and created pithy and amusing ad campaigns, including some for the Range Rover off-road vehicle and J&B Scotch.

Jon S. Corzine, the governor of New Jersey, has agreed to let two outside ethics advisers review whether his former romantic relationship with the head of a leading state workers’ union local influenced recent contract negotiations with the union, the governor’s spokesman said yesterday.
Officials are tempted to fiddle with state pension laws rather than honestly explain to voters that tax cuts must be paid for.
Scientists have just discovered which gene fragment controls the size of dogs, the mammal with the greatest range in size.
California is a prime spot for catching people who kill, smuggle or do other untoward things with rare species and exotic plants.
The Tennessee attorney general decided to scuttle a settlement over Fisk University’s plan to sell a Georgia O’Keeffe painting after purchase offers dwarfed earlier estimates of its worth.
Johnny Damon, who has played 1,705 games in the major leagues and has never been on the disabled list, had an M.R.I. Thursday that revealed a mild strain of the calf.
James J. Culleton is the former prosecutor hired to defend the New York City police officer who fired 31 shots in the confrontation that killed Sean Bell.
Gov. Charlie Crist said it was time for Florida to leave the “offensive minority” of states that uniformly deny ex-offenders voting rights.

Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn called yesterday for increased library hours and money for new education initiatives and health clinics for underserved areas. Those changes are included in a proposal that would add $61 million to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s $57.1 billion preliminary budget for next year.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters) — Enron investors appealed Thursday to the Supreme Court, seeking review of their class-action lawsuit against investment banks that had put together financing transactions for the company, which collapsed in 2001.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters) — New jobless claims rose by 11,000 last week, more than was forecast, but analysts said the labor market remained on solid ground.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi  said she raised the issue of the lack of women in Saudi politics with officials, but refrained from criticizing the kingdom over it.
